WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The State Department has made public the following text of an edict delivered to-day by Minister Wu to Secretary Hay. This is the edict referred to by United States Consul Fowler at Che-Foo, in his message received here yesterday:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y.; July 23. -- Seymour Hyde's keel yawl Albicore, New York Yacht Club, and Alfred Peat's thirty-footer Enpronzl, have both been hauled out on the marine railway at the Woods yard, to be overhauled preparatory to to-morrow's regatta off Larchmont. Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard's keel schooner Corona, New York Yacht Club, has been hauled out on the marine railway at the Hawkins yard to have her underbody prepared for fast work.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The State Department to-day made public the following:

HONOLULU, July 16. -- Hawaii is now feeling the reaction from feverish activity in starting new sugar plantations during the past year and a half. The plantations that have been started within that time have required so much capital for their development that it is straining the resources of this community to meet the demand.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 23. -- The National Committee of the Gold Democrats will meet here on Wednesday. It is said all of the committeemen will be present. The Gold Democrats will meet a committee of the Anti-Imperialist League. Mr. Frenzel, Secretary and Treasurer of the Gold Democratic Committee, says he has had no communication with the Anti-Imperialistic Committee in New York, so he knows nothing about what their programme will be.

The Chinese Minister in London has received a dispatch from the Taotai Sheng saying an official of the Tsung-li-Yamen found the foreign Ministers at Peking safe. The message from Peking announcing this was dated July 18, the same day as Mr. Conger's alleged dispatch.

LIMA, Ohio, July 23. -- E.L. Smith, an attorney of Tippecanoe City, is conducting an agitation among the members of the Knights of the Maccabees, directed against the policy of the present supreme tent officers located at Port Huron, Mich., the headquarters of the order. Mr. Smith said to-day:

ALBANY, N.Y., July 23. -- A license granted by the State Racing Commission to the Saratoga Racing Association for the present season was filed to-day. The track is authorized to conduct races at Saratoga from Aug. 1 to Aug. 31.

DETROIT, July 23. -- Baron Paul Merling, German Consul General at Peking, spent to-day with Mr. Ledyard, the father-in-law of Baron von Ketteler, the German Minister to China, murdered by the Chinese in Peking. Baron Merling has been absent from his post since the latter part of May.

At the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions a cable signed "Towler" was received from Che-Foo yesterday. As the board knows of no one of that name at Che-Foo, Dr. Brown believes the message to be from Consul Fowler. The cable reads:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23. -- From Shanghai and Yokohama newspapers received by China steamer to-day many interesting sidelights are gained on the dangerous situation of the foreign legations in Peking. Of the position of the foreign colony in the British Legation the Japan Mail of Yokohama-says: "This is a time when to live in Peking at all is to suffer terribly from heat.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23. -- From Shanghai and Yokohama newspapers received by China steamer to-day many interesting sidelights are gained on the dangerous situation of the foreign legations in Peking. Of the position of the foreign colony in the British Legation the Japan Mail of Yokohama-says: "This is a time when to live in Peking at all is to suffer terribly from heat.

A more tragic ending to a day's sport than that of the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta yesterday afternoon, yachtsmen along the Sound hope never to see. Just thirty seconds after the last racing boat had crossed the finish line, off Larchmont Harbor, a terrific explosion two miles or so further down the Sound rent the air and shook the fleet of pleasure craft that had drifted into anchor off the clubhouse.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Bureau of Navigation this morning received the following cablegram from Admiral Remey:

MINNEAPOLIS, July 23. -- Chinch bugs came into the city in large numbers yesterday, much to the surprise of entomologists and in direct violation of their theories. Just why they should leave the fields, where they are always confined, in books, has not yet been explained. Scientists approached on the subject this morning were unable to give any satisfactory explanation.

There was a very lively meeting of colored Republicans last night at the headquarters of the Young Men's Republican Club, 222 West Forty-seventh Street. What the gathering lacked in numbers it made up in noise. There was crimination and recrimination, and much bitterness was manifested.

After working nine days and nights preparing to raise the wrecked Bremen from her mud bed, off Weehawken, the wreckers yesterday made a futile attempt to float the vessel. The Bremen still lies as she fell, over a week ago, when, after being almost floated, she snapped two huge derrick chains and turned over.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y.; July 23. -- Seymour Hyde's keel yawl Albicore, New York Yacht Club, and Alfred Peat's thirty-footer Enpronzl, have both been hauled out on the marine railway at the Woods yard, to be overhauled preparatory to to-morrow's regatta off Larchmont. Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard's keel schooner Corona, New York Yacht Club, has been hauled out on the marine railway at the Hawkins yard to have her underbody prepared for fast work.

A surprisingly large crowd witnessed what was nominally an "off day's" racing at the Brighton Beach track yesterday. The sport, like the attendance, was vastly better than it promised, and though the fields were small, only three horses running in each of two races, the contests were spirited and fast time was made in most of the races.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23. -- Mineola was the winner to-day in the race in the Newport Racing Association series for seventyfooters, Capt. Wringe landing A. Belmont's boat in the lead by two minutes, the widest margin in any race yet sailed in the series. Yankee was second, but not far ahead of Virginia, and Rainbow came in last.

BOSTON, July 23. -- The American Board has received a letter, from the Rev. George D. Wilder, dated Tien-Tsin, June 12, which gives details concerning the outbreak of the Boxer movement and makes known the readiness and determination with which Capt. McCalla of the United States Navy responded to the call for aid.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 23. -- A license granted by the State Racing Commission to the Saratoga Racing Association for the present season was filed to-day. The track is authorized to conduct races at Saratoga from Aug. 1 to Aug. 31.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 23. -- An audience of fully 5,000 people listened to-day to an address on "Americanism" by Gov. Theodore Roosevelt of New York. The address was delivered under the auspices of the Jewish Chautauqua Society now holding its Summer assembly here, and the big marine hall room of the steel pier was crowded to the doors with the immense gathering.

BOSTON, Mass., July 23. -- Perfect tennis weather here to-day favored the opening matches in the Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament, which began on the courts of the Longwood Cricket Club. The sun shone brightly and there was little wind. The California visitors found it too hot for them, and both of the Hardy brothers were beaten.

As there is no official body in New Jersey charged with the duty of examining into the causes of fires, the North German Lloyd Steamship Company determined to request ex-Fire Chief Hugh Bonner, formerly of the New York Fire Department, and James Mitchel, formerly Fire Marshal in New York, to investigate the fire on its piers in Hoboken, N.J., and its cause fully, and to report their findings.

PARIS, July 23. -- Mr. Ferdinand W. Peck, United States Commissioner General to the Paris Exposition, entertained at dinner this evening the American athletes who contested in the world amateur championship contests in connection with the exposition. The table, which was in the form of a horseshoe and tastefully decorated, occupied the entire first floor of the United States National Pavilion.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The President has listened to the appeal of the Chinese Government as transmitted by Minister Wu, and has signified his willingness to mediate between the Imperial Government and the powers, but only upon conditions which first must be met by the Chinese Government.

LONDON, July 24. -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Parliamentary Secretary of the Foreign Office, William St. John Brodrick, communicated certain statements of the Chinese authorities with regard to the safety of the legations at Peking, and said the Chinese Minister declared that the envoys were unharmed. Mr. Brodrick read the text of the imperial edict of July 18.

LONDON, July 24. -- The Chinese Minister, Sir Chih-Chen-Lo-Feng-Luh, has communicated to the press the following dispatch from Sheng, Director General of Chinese Railways and Telegraphs and Taotai of Shanghai, dated Shanghai, July 23:

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Topics of the Times" to-day says: "When a kindly and well-disposed reader writes a letter of commendation founded upon a misapprehension of what was here said, we must, for his sake if for no other person's, repeat ourselves."

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Topics of the Times" to-day says: "When a kindly and well-disposed reader writes a letter of commendation founded upon a misapprehension of what was here said, we must, for his sake if for no other person's, repeat ourselves."

There was not much wind at Larchmont yesterday, but what there was lasted from noon until sunset, and the dozen yachts starting in the second day's regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week furnished better sport than did the fifty-odd contestants in the opening races on Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The Executive Committee of the Anti-Imperialist League issued a call to-day for "The National Liberty Congress," to be held in Indianapolis Aug. 15. The call, which is signed by George S. Boutwell of Massachusetts, President of the Executive Committee, and W. J. Mize, the Secretary, is as follows:

-- In presenting anew the often-discussed objections to "the United States of America" as the official designation of this Republic, Prof. MOSES COIT TYLER of Cornell makes the sweeping assertion that "never before has there been a nation of any consequence in the world without its own appropriate, distinctive name."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am much pleased to read in to-day's (Sunday) edition your article headed "The Wall of Central Park."

Provoked, we suspect, by certain newspapers of the Pacific Slope, the more important journals of Japan have, for the last few months, been considerably exercised over the movement in this country for the exclusion of Japanese laborers. They regard some sort of legislative action to that effect as almost inevitable.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., July 23. -- Several new features were developed to-day in the trial of Caleb Powers, charged with complicity in the assassination of Gov. William Goebel. In addition to the testimony the session was enlivened by a sharp passage between the Court and ex-Gov. John Young Brown, senior counsel for the defense.

Tammany Hall, through its General Committee, formally ratified the action of the Kansas City Convention at a meeting held last night at the Fourteenth Street headquarters. Ex-Judge George M. Van Hoesen presided, and in a front seat was Richard Croker, who had come up from Brighton Beach to be present.

The moral leadership of the effort of the powers to bring order out of chaos and confusion in China has been practically established at Washington. The attitude of our Government has been unimpeachably correct from the beginning not only in the sense of international law, but in the sense of right and wisdom.

Fred Puffer, who was one of the most prominent members of the old New Jersey Athletic and Manhattan Athletic Club teams a few years ago, died at his home in this city late on Sunday evening. He had never been in good health since, his return from Cuba, where he went, with Eugene Goff, the all-around athlete, as a member of the Seventy-first Regiment.

If the Democrats of this State, in the organization or "in the woods," have had any doubt about what is to be the outcome of the next election in this State, it seems to us that they have not properly interpreted the meaning of recent talk at the Fifth Avenue Hotel conferences.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In marked contrast to most European powers, the United States Government finds it necessary to go begging for its army -- at least the great bulk of the enlisted strength is maintained in this manner.

The friends of ex-Alderman Patrick H. Keahon of the Seventh District were very jubilant last night. They claimed that the Edward F. Brennan Association had Joined them in their fight to make Mr. Keahon the Tammany leader there in place of Oysterman James W. Boyle, one of the Commissioners of the new East River Bridge.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department to-day made public the text of the appeal by the Emperor of China to President McKinley asking the United States to mediate between the powers and China, and the President's reply. The statement issued by the department is as follows:

NEWPORT, July 24 -- The annual meeting of the Newport Golf Club is set for Saturday next, when the ticket selected by the Nomination Committee will be elected as follows: President -- Edgerton L. Winthrop; Vice President -- George L. Rives; Governors (for two years) -- H. Mortimer Brooks, A.M. Coates, John Clinton Gray, Oliver H.P. Belmont, and Royal Phelps Carroll.

The friends of ex-Alderman Patrick H. Keahon of the Seventh District were very jubilant last night. They claimed that the Edward F. Brennan Association had Joined them in their fight to make Mr. Keahon the Tammany leader there in place of Oysterman James W. Boyle, one of the Commissioners of the new East River Bridge.

Selbach and Van Haltren between them were the immediate cause of the New Yorks winning a close game from the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For six innings neither side scored, and runs were exceedingly valuable. The Pittsburgs made one in their half of the seventh inning and the New Yorks at once evened up matters.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 24 -- The united Sunday schools of this village and neighboring ones started on an excursion up the Hudson this morning. They went down the river instead of up, as was intended, and spent the day 300 feet off shore and reached the dock on schedule time this evening.

Twenty men, two tugs, and a wrecking barge were added yesterday to the small army of men and the wrecking fleet at work on the Bremen. All day and all night three pumps were kept going on the heavily listed wreck to offset leakage, and to prevent the incoming tide from filling her and weighting her deeper into the mud.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 24 -- Percy Chubb's sloop yacht Vigilant, New York Yacht Club, was hauled out on the marine railway at the Hawkins yard to-day to have her underbody smoothed and prepared for fast work Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard's keel schooner Corona, New York Yacht Club, after having her underbody overhauled, was launched from the same yard.

These were several narrow escapes and plenty of excitement early yesterday morning at a fire, which almost destroyed the four-story tenement at 41 Vandewater Street. The fire was discovered by Adam F. Kline, who lived on the top floor, who, awaking from sleep, found fire and smoke in the hallway.

Selbach and Van Haltren between them were the immediate cause of the New Yorks winning a close game from the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For six innings neither side scored, and runs were exceedingly valuable. The Pittsburgs made one in their half of the seventh inning and the New Yorks at once evened up matters.

BOSTON, Mass., July 24 -- Officials of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association to-day made the first positive announcement of the success of the negotiations for the international matches this season. The American committee has been negotiating with the British authorities for many weeks, but the matter hung fire until last week, when a formal challenge was received, and it was authoritatively stated that an English team will sail from abroad on Saturday's steamer.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department to-day made public the text of the appeal by the Emperor of China to President McKinley asking the United States to mediate between the powers and China, and the President's reply. The statement issued by the department is as follows:

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 24 -- Senator Elkins spent nearly all of last night and a part of to-day in conference with the party leaders, hearing their reports of the situation throughout the State, and smoothing over the differences caused by yesterday's action of the State Committee.

SANTA FE, July 24 -- Dr. George L. Cote and Fay C. Cote of Los Angeles, Cal.; Prof. R.W. Bullock of Greeley, Col., and the Rev. G.S. Madden of Bland, who arrived here to-day, reported that in the excavating of a number of large stone ruins situated in Pajarsto canon, between Bland and Espanola, they made startling discoveries.

NEWPORT, July 24 -- The annual meeting of the Newport Golf Club is set for Saturday next, when the ticket selected by the Nomination Committee will be elected as follows: President -- Edgerton L. Winthrop; Vice President -- George L. Rives; Governors (for two years) -- H. Mortimer Brooks, A.M. Coates, John Clinton Gray, Oliver H.P. Belmont, and Royal Phelps Carroll.

UTICA, N.Y., July 24 -- The first session of the Prohibition State Convention was held at Summit Park, near this city, today. There were about 200 delegates present at the morning session. H.W. Wilbur was made temporary Chairman and Charles E. Lattimer of New York temporary Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The following telegram has been received from the Japanese Minister for Foreign Affairs under date of July 22. It is the report of the Japanese Consul at Tien-Tsin, who wired it on July 21:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Minister Wu today took to the State Department a copy of the identical telegram sent out by Sheng to the powers, repeating the Chinese assurance of the safety of the envoys up to July 18. The telegram was made public at the State Department in the following statement:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Navy Department is preparing for possible eventualities arising out of the situation in China. One of the great difficulties which would confront the United States in the event of naval warfare in Chinese waters is the lack of a naval base close to the scene of operations. Manila is 2,000 miles from Taku, while some of the Other powers have bases within striking distance.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- W.W. Rockhill, who has been selected as special Commissioner by the President to go to China, returned to Washington this morning from Block Island, and began immediately to prepare for his long journey. He has decided to take Mrs. Rockhill with him and to sail from San Francisco on the America Maru of the Japanese line.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 24 -- Through the explosion of a boiler tube in the steam yacht Trilby, owned and captained by Fred L. Spink of Seriba, Oswego County, three children lost their lives, one more was frightfully scalded, and three older persons were more or less burned here at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

It was a day of military departures to face the Boxers and Chinese troops; It was a day of sad partings for some, while other soldiers, tired of the monotony and inactivity of garrison life in Cuba, went forward eagerly to rush into the exciting arena of genuine war.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 24 -- Police Captain John T. Day and Policeman Peter J. Lamb are dead and Policeman August Mora is severely wounded as the result of an encounter with two desperate negroes -- Leonard Pierce and Robert Charles.

It was a day of military departures to face the Boxers and Chinese troops; It was a day of sad partings for some, while other soldiers, tired of the monotony and inactivity of garrison life in Cuba, went forward eagerly to rush into the exciting arena of genuine war.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 24 -- John Jay Chapman, Thomas M. Osborn, Everett B. Abbott, William H. Riley, Isaac H. Klein, and Alfred B. Robinson, members of the Anti-Imperialist Committee appointed to confer with the National Committee of the Gold Democrats, arrived here to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- An investigation by the police of the death last night of Mrs. Charles Marchand and her six-year-old daughter proved conclusively that the woman gave the child carbolic acid and then committed suicide. The husband, who was taken into custody after the double death, was released to-day.

Through the bravery and presence of mind of an eighteen-year-old boy, Richard Jansen, a painter, thirty-five years old, living with his family at 172 St. Ann's Avenue, was rescued from drowning in the Harlem River yesterday. The rescue was made by Thaddeus Neggesmith, a son of Policeman Neggesmith of East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, in the presence of several hundred pedestrians who happened to be crossing Harlem Bridge at the time.

Gen. Li, a pro-foreign Chinese commander stationed near Taku, says a runner who left Peking on July 14 reported that the Maxim ammunition of the legation guards was then exhausted; that Peking was in a state of anarchy, and that the Boxers were fighting the regular troops and gaining the better of the struggle.

"Men at ports all safe" was the message received from Bishop Frederick R. Graves, at Shanghai by the Protestant Episcopal Board of Foreign Missions yesterday.

BERLIN, July 24 -- This evening's papers devote considerable attention to President McKinley's consent to mediate, and the comment is all unfavorable. Surprise is generally expressed that Washington takes Chinese official news seriously. The Berliner Tageblatt complains that the United States Government is "so convinced of the wisdom of its Chinophile policy that it is preparing in advance to lay the blame for its non-success upon Governments less credulous than President McKinley and Secretary Hay."

UTICA, N.Y., July 24 -- The first session of the Prohibition State Convention was held at Summit Park, near this city, today. There were about 200 delegates present at the morning session. H.W. Wilbur was made temporary Chairman and Charles E. Lattimer of New York temporary Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department is again in a waiting attitude regarding China. It has frankly, promptly, and fully answered the Chinese Emperor's appeal for mediation, and the correspondence made public to-day makes it appear that the next move is for the Chinese Government.

SANTA FE, July 24 -- Dr. George L. Cote and Fay C. Cote of Los Angeles, Cal.; Prof. R.W. Bullock of Greeley, Col., and the Rev. G.S. Madden of Bland, who arrived here to-day, reported that in the excavating of a number of large stone ruins situated in Pajarsto canon, between Bland and Espanola, they made startling discoveries.
"Men at ports all safe" was the message received from Bishop Frederick R. Graves, at Shanghai by the Protestant Episcopal Board of Foreign Missions yesterday.

TIEN-TSIN, July 14, via Che-Foo, July 16, and Shanghai, July 24 -- The Ninth Regiment, United States Infantry, entered the fight at Tien-Tsin with 430 men. An incomplete list of casualties shows 18 killed, 75 wounded, and 2 missing. The marines had 4 killed and 18 wounded.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 24 -- Through the explosion of a boiler tube in the steam yacht Trilby, owned and captained by Fred L. Spink of Seriba, Oswego County, three children lost their lives, one more was frightfully scalded, and three older persons were more or less burned here at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

The meeting of two of the smartest twoyear-old fillies of the season of 1900, Charles Littlefield, Jr.'s, fleet Sweet Lavender, and J.R. F.P. Keene's quickfooted daughter of Domino, Cap and Bells, in the one stake run at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, stood out conspicuously as the feature of the afternoon's sport.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 24 -- Another world's record was made to-day at the Glenville track, when the black gelding Coney, by McKinney, paced the second heat of a race in 2:02 3/4. This is the fastest mile ever paced by a horse in hopples. Frank Bogash has held the record for three years at 2:04 1/4. It was also the fastest mile ever paced on the Glenville track.

PORT SCOTT, Kan., July 24 -- The feature of the proceedings in the Populist, Democratic, and Silver Republican State Conventions, which met here to-day in separate halls to nominate State tickets or effect a fusion in the interests of a single ticket, was the turning down of the Senatorial aspirations of Jerry Simpson by the Populist Convention.

Keene's quickfooted daughter of Domino, Cap and Bells, in the one stake run at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, stood out conspicuously as the feature of the afternoon's sport.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- W.W. Rockhill, who has been selected as special Commissioner by the President to go to China, returned to Washington this morning from Block Island, and began immediately to prepare for his long journey. He has decided to take Mrs. Rockhill with him and to sail from San Francisco on the America Maru of the Japanese line.

Selbach and Van Haltren between them were the immediate cause of the New Yorks winning a close game from the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For six innings neither side scored, and runs were exceedingly valuable. The Pittsburgs made one in their half of the seventh inning and the New Yorks at once evened up matters.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Gov. Roosevelt will, it is hoped, speak to the workingmen in Chicago on Labor Day. When Edward Carroll, E.A. Davis, and John Long invited New York's Governor to speak here Sept. 3, he returned no definite answer. Now Graeme Stewart, representing the National Committee; Walter Fieldhouse, representing the State Committee, and Congressman Lorimer, representing the County Committee, have wired Gov. Roosevelt asking him to come to Chicago and speak.

PORT SCOTT, Kan., July 24 -- The feature of the proceedings in the Populist, Democratic, and Silver Republican State Conventions, which met here to-day in separate halls to nominate State tickets or effect a fusion in the interests of a single ticket, was the turning down of the Senatorial aspirations of Jerry Simpson by the Populist Convention.

BOSTON, Mass., July 24 -- The Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament was continued again here to-day at the Longwood Cricket Club grounds. Play began early in the morning, and was continued all day long, the last match between Ware and Wrenn not being finished until the shadows had begun to lengthen.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- An investigation by the police of the death last night of Mrs. Charles Marchand and her six-year-old daughter proved conclusively that the woman gave the child carbolic acid and then committed suicide. The husband, who was taken into custody after the double death, was released to-day.

LONDON, July 25 -- Consultations are in progress between Cabinet Ministers and officials as to the course to be pursued should the Ministers prove to be alive. The contingency of China holding them as hostages is uppermost in the minds of all, although it is officially stated the Chinese diplomats have not yet hinted at such action.

Gen. Li, a pro-foreign Chinese commander stationed near Taku, says a runner who left Peking on July 14 reported that the Maxim ammunition of the legation guards was then exhausted; that Peking was in a state of anarchy, and that the Boxers were fighting the regular troops and gaining the better of the struggle.

LONDON, July 25 -- Consultations are in progress between Cabinet Ministers and officials as to the course to be pursued should the Ministers prove to be alive. The contingency of China holding them as hostages is uppermost in the minds of all, although it is officially stated the Chinese diplomats have not yet hinted at such action.

TIEN-TSIN, July 14, via Che-Foo, July 16, and Shanghai, July 24 -- The Ninth Regiment, United States Infantry, entered the fight at Tien-Tsin with 430 men. An incomplete list of casualties shows 18 killed, 75 wounded, and 2 missing. The marines had 4 killed and 18 wounded.

Selbach and Van Haltren between them were the immediate cause of the New Yorks winning a close game from the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For six innings neither side scored, and runs were exceedingly valuable. The Pittsburgs made one in their half of the seventh inning and the New Yorks at once evened up matters.

BERLIN, July 24 -- This evening's papers devote considerable attention to President McKinley's consent to mediate, and the comment is all unfavorable. Surprise is generally expressed that Washington takes Chinese official news seriously. The Berliner Tageblatt complains that the United States Government is "so convinced of the wisdom of its Chinophile policy that it is preparing in advance to lay the blame for its non-success upon Governments less credulous than President McKinley and Secretary Hay."

Through the bravery and presence of mind of an eighteen-year-old boy, Richard Jansen, a painter, thirty-five years old, living with his family at 172 St. Ann's Avenue, was rescued from drowning in the Harlem River yesterday. The rescue was made by Thaddeus Neggesmith, a son of Policeman Neggesmith of East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, in the presence of several hundred pedestrians who happened to be crossing Harlem Bridge at the time.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 24 -- John Jay Chapman, Thomas M. Osborn, Everett B. Abbott, William H. Riley, Isaac H. Klein, and Alfred B. Robinson, members of the Anti-Imperialist Committee appointed to confer with the National Committee of the Gold Democrats, arrived here to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In marked contrast to most European powers, the United States Government finds it necessary to go begging for its army -- at least the great bulk of the enlisted strength is maintained in this manner.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 25. -- A furious storm broke over the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club's links at an early hour this morning, but, instead of interfering with the sport of the day, the rain left the previously hard-baked course in a condition to be more fully enjoyed later in the day. A delightful breeze blew over the hills all day, and a host of spectators drove out to see the play in the afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, July 25. -- An armed mob, several thousand strong, has paraded the streets of New Orleans since 8 o'clock. Scores of negroes have been beaten and maltreated. Hundreds of shots have been fired and a number of casualties are reported.

There is an air of business about Republican National Headquarters at 1 Madison Avenue. Senator N.B. Scott was at his desk early yesterday, and when a TIMES reporter called he was endeavoring to wade through a bushel or so of mail. National Committeeman Fred S. Gibbs looked on good-naturedly and offered his assistance.

Many persons who were anxious about the future of the Congressional Library when the President made the mistake of committing it to the care of a gentleman of literary taste and wide general information but without executive judgment or force, shared with us the satisfaction we expressed upon the appointment of Mr. HERBERT PUTNAM to take charge of a very important work.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The State Department has received a dispatch from Consul Gudges at Panama saying the revolution there had taken a serious turn. The attacking force -- he did not make it plain which party to the trouble, but probably the insurgents -- was considering the proposition of bombarding the City of Panama.

We had hoped he would give the facts, the only facts that are pertinent to the point at issue between THE TIMES and himself, but he disappoints us.

The downpour yesterday afternoon made the Speedway muddy, and not at all what horsemen desire for fast driving, and there was only one contest of the light-harness contingent. But that one furnished a lot of fun, and the mud and the rain did not prevent a goodly gathering of amateur reinsmen from making the most of the disagreeable conditions and going up to see it regardless of weather.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 25. -- In the return hole contest on the local links this afternoon between the Atlantic City Country Club and Cape May the local team won, 7 up. The professionals of the two clubs, Dougherty of Cape May and John Reed of Atlantic City, also had a match of twenty-seven holes, which the Cape May man won, 2 up.

Wind and weather have steadily disfavored the Larchmont yachtsmen this season, but better racing conditions than those of yesterday, the fourth day of the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week, could not be desired. A clipping southwest breeze, strong enough to embarrass the more lightly sparred craft, blew steadily all day, and the fifty-eight starters in the open regatta furnished excellent sport.

Now it appears that still other powers were addressed in a similar strain.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The Chinese Minister saw the Conger message soon after it reached Washington. He read the communication with interest, and seemed well satisfied with the information it conveyed. He called attention to the fact that this, at least, was unquestionably a genuine communication, and proved that the legations, though in danger on July 4, were not in absolute extremity.

LAWRENCE, L.I., July 25. -- The tennis tournament of the Lawrence Tennis Club, of which a large number of the members of the Rockaway Hunt Club are leading spirits, is in session here to-day, and has attracted quite an enthusiastic crowd of tennis lovers to their execeedingly well laidout grounds.

LOUISVILLE, July 25. -- In the Louisville Circuit Court to-day Judge Field handed down a decision in the case of Judge John H. Wilson against Judge William L. Brown, in which the plaintiff sought by quo-war-ranto proceedings to establish his claim to the Judgeship of the Twenty-seventh District.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 25. -- Edward Wise, the young man now in the condemned house at the State prison in Sing Sing, and who was to go to the electric chair on Aug. 6, has had his sentence changed from death to imprisonment for life by Gov. Roosevelt. Wise was involved in the killing of Charles F. Beasley, a cab driver, in West Twenty-ninth Street, Manhattan, on the morning of Nov. 9, 1898.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The Navy Department to-day made public the mall reports of Rear Admiral Kempff, explaining his reasons for refusing to join with the Admirals of the other powers in the attack on the Taku forts and giving an account of the attack, which includes many details not heretofore published.

LONDON, July 26. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Daily Mail asserts that a Chinaman who was employed at the British Legation as a writer and interpreter has escaped from Peking to Liu-Chwang, and that he declares that at the time he left Peking most of the members of the legations were dead and the condition of the others was hopeless.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 25. -- When the father of Bessie Noble objected to her marrying James G. German, the two determined to elope. They decided to use their wheels to flee the parental wrath. After dinner yesterday Miss Noble stated to her father that she was going to ride her bicycle to the home of her aunt, Mrs. Robert A. Mathis, who lives about two miles north of Seneca Falls.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 25. -- What promises to be quite a closely contested polo match will tie seen on the field of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club to-morrow afternoon, when a team of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club will play a match with the team from Great Neck for a handsome silver cup.

A reader of THE TIMES in a letter which we published yesterday, in commenting upon the position of this journal in the Presidential contest, said: "You are opposed to a third ticket, and advocate voting for what you call the lesser of two evils."

At Normandie-by-the-Sea yesterday ex-Senator David B. Hill held a long and secret conference with two of his stanchest allies, Frank Campbell of Bath, N.Y., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, and Elliot Danforth, ex-Chairman. The conference excited comment, and explanation of it was that it was the first step in an effort to adopt a conciliatory policy for Senator Hill and Richard Croker.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are informed by dispatches in this morning's papers that Consul Gudger at Panama has been asked to protest against the bombardment of Panama by the so-called rebels against the Colombian Government. This protest is supposed to be based upon the provisions of the treaty between New Granada (now Colombia) and the United States of Dec. 12, 1846.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Dr. J.H. Breasted, Professor of Egyptology in the University of Chicago, has just been appointed by the Emperor of Germany to superintend the publication of his new Egyptian dictionary. This lexicon, which will enable students of Egyptology to study the hieroglyphics in the various museums throughout the world, is an idea original with the Emperor.

Harmony was the watchword at Republican State Headquarters yesterday. Chairman B.B. Odell, Jr., was the individual expected to do the harmonizing. He had plenty to do, and his expression was that of a very tired man when he hastened away to catch a train for Newburg

DETROIT, Mich., July 26 -- Sidney Lucas won the Turf Congress Stakes at Highland Park to-day. The race was the opening feature of the Highland Park Club's fifteen days' Summer meeting. The largest crowd that ever visited the course was in attendance. Five horses started in the stake event, and the American Derby winner was always the favorite, opening at 4 to 5, and dropping a point lower before post time.
GEORGETOWN, Ky., July 26 -- In the trial to-day of Caleb Powers, charged with complicity in the shooting of Gov. Goebel, several interesting features were developed.

Many dreary racing days have fallen to the lot of yachtsmen this year, but none more hopeless than yesterday, the fifth of the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week. Rain fell during the greater part of the time, but except for an interval of two hours in the afternoon there was no wind mixed up with it.

NEW ORLEANS, July 26 -- Disorderly scenes following the rioting of last night prevailed throughout the city to-day and resulted in the swearing in by the Mayor of 500 special policemen and the ordering out of 1,500 of the State militia, Gov. Heard responding promptly to the appeal of Mayor Capdeville for assistance in suppressing the existing lawlessness and in preventing to-night a recurrence of the violence of last night.

This protest is supposed to be based upon the provisions of the treaty between New Granada (now Colombia) and the United States of Dec. 12, 1846.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 26 -- Golf as it should not be played would be a very appropriate motto with which to characterize the tournament competitions at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club to-day. Everything except the best wishes of the club committee and the warmth of an open wood fire in the men's locker room seemed to be against the golfers.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- "Unless the railways entering Indianapolis make better rates," so Sergeant at Arms John I. Martin telephoned from there to Secretary Walsh to-day, "the notification meeting may as well be called off, so far as this town is concerned."

DETROIT, Mich., July 26 -- A crowd of 300 members of the Country Club and elite of Detroit society watched Harry Vardon, the former champion golf player of England, trim W.H. Way of Detroit. Vardon played a faultless game and defeated Way in all points of the game. The Englishman's stroke was clean, precise, and effective.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 26 -- At a business meeting of the National Committee of the National Democrats to-day Charles Tracy of New York was elected Chairman to succeed George F. Peabody of New York, who resigned because of illness. It was decided to establish headquarters in Indianapolis.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., July 26 -- Chief of Police Merritt of this place yesterday effected the arrest at Ilion of "Capt. Inglis, United States Army." The arrest was made on a trivial charge, and the prisoner was supposed to be R. Dey Held, but he proved to be none other than the clever swindler who operated in Poughkeepsie during the recent regatta under the alias of "Capt. Inglis, United States Army."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- There were no developments to-day, to warrant the assumption that there has been the slightest improvement in the Chinese situation. Indeed, the general tendency of such news as found ight was to add to the steadily growing doubt as to the good faith of the Chinese Government as manifested in its acts.

Vardon played a faultless game and defeated Way in all points of the game. The Englishman's stroke was clean, precise, and effective.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 -- According to a number of employes of the North Jersey Street Railroad and some residents of Irvington and Maplewood, lightning last night performed a queer prank upon the westbound wire of the New York and Irvington line on the street between Irvington and Maplewood.

-- It grieves The Richmond (Va.) EASTON, Penn., July 26 -- A tour of inspection of the Bangor and Portland Railroad by officials of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, the recent purchaser, resulted most disastrously this afternoon to three members of the party.

At a joint meeting of the Executive and Regatta Committees of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen and the Regatta Committee of the Harlem Regratta Association, held at the New York Athletic Club house last night, it was announced that the money necessary to send the American crews to Paris had finally been raised, and that the oarsmen will sail on the Westernland of the Red Star Line next Wednesday.

August Ruisenger of 162 Sands Street, Brooklyn, was before Magistrate Kramer in the Adams Street Court yesterday morning charged by Charles C. Gailbraith, the Eastern manager of the Armour Beef Company, with having converted to his own use $210.90 which he had collected as an employe of the company.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26 -- James W. Thorne, 1900, of Chicago, known among his Princeton classmates as the "Globe Trotter," in company with George L. Denny, 1900, of Indianapolis, and Edward B. Meigs, 1900, of Philadelphia, left Princeton June 1 on a driving tour to the Yellowstone Park.
Thursday, Aug. 16, will be "Wheelmen's Day" at Bergen Beach, and elaborate preparations have been made for the entertainment of the throng of cyclists who are expected to be present.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 26 -- The managers of the Monmouth County Horse Show waited in vain all the morning for the rain to cease, and at noon announced that the opening of the seventh annual Summer exhibition of the association, which was to have taken place this afternoon, was postponed until '2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon and night, and will be continued on Saturday, commencing at 11 A.M.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- A conference of leading steel and Bessemer iron Interests in this country was held to-day in the offices of the Federal Steel Company, in this city, in compliance With a call issued by President E.H. Gary of the Federal Steel Company, President Schwab of the Carnegie Steel Company, and Joseph G. Butler, Jr., representing the Bessemer Furnace Association.
Thursday, Aug. 16, will be "Wheelmen's Day" at Bergen Beach, and elaborate preparations have been made for the entertainment of the throng of cyclists who are expected to be present.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26 -- All the seventy-foot yachts are at Bristol to-night except the Rainbow, which went to Providence. They are all badly in need of repairs after the hard usage received in yesterday's race in a gale of wind. It is said by those in a position to know that their condition is serious.

The observant William Brady, who returned from abroad on Wednesday, found time to pay attention to other things than theatricals while in Europe. He saw the American athletes score their sweeping victories over the Englishmen in London, and again in Paris "run rings around the foreigners," he said.

At a joint meeting of the Executive and Regatta Committees of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen and the Regatta Committee of the Harlem Regratta Association, held at the New York Athletic Club house last night, it was announced that the money necessary to send the American crews to Paris had finally been raised, and that the oarsmen will sail on the Westernland of the Red Star Line next Wednesday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 26 -- At a business meeting of the National Committee of the National Democrats to-day Charles Tracy of New York was elected Chairman to succeed George F. Peabody of New York, who resigned because of illness. It was decided to establish headquarters in Indianapolis.
Senator M.A. Hanna will be at Republican National headquarters this morning.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Dr. J.H. Breasted, Professor of Egyptology in the University of Chicago, has just been appointed by the Emperor of Germany to superintend the publication of his new Egyptian dictionary. This lexicon, which will enable students of Egyptology to study the hieroglyphics in the various museums throughout the world, is an idea original with the Emperor.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 26 -- There was more fine sport at the Grand Circuit races to-day, the track being very fast after its thorough soaking on Wednesday. The programme was a big one, including the two races postponed from Tuesday. Summary:

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 -- According to a number of employes of the North Jersey Street Railroad and some residents of Irvington and Maplewood, lightning last night performed a queer prank upon the westbound wire of the New York and Irvington line on the street between Irvington and Maplewood.
LONDON, July 27 -- The Canton correspondent of The Daily Telegraph, in a dispatch dated Wednesday, says:

At Normandie-by-the-Sea yesterday ex-Senator David B. Hill held a long and secret conference with two of his stanchest allies, Frank Campbell of Bath, N.Y., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, and Elliot Danforth, ex-Chairman. The conference excited comment, and explanation of it was that it was the first step in an effort to adopt a conciliatory policy for Senator Hill and Richard Croker.
Senator M.A. Hanna will be at Republican National headquarters this morning.

No independent Democrat needed to be assured, before the meeting at Indianap- oils of the National Committee of the National Democrats, that the committee would decide against the proposition to nominate a third Presidential ticket. The decision by a unanimous vote not to nominate is not surprising; it is altogether wise, reasonable, and gratifying.

A reader of THE TIMES in a letter which we published yesterday, in commenting upon the position of this journal in the Presidential contest, said: "You are opposed to a third ticket, and advocate voting for what you call the lesser of two evils."
LONDON, July 27 -- The Hongkong correspondent of The Daily Express wires as follows under yesterday's date:

The objections to the nomination of Mr. ODELL as the Republican candidate for Governor do not lie against the character of the man. He is of good standing and reputation. He is said to be very popular with Republicans throughout the State. Some men of sound independent notions about the duty of the Executive to use the boss instead of letting the boss use him are advocating the nomination of Mr. ODELL.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- It is said to-night that the cablegram received by the Navy Department to-day from Admiral Remey contained no statement as to when the forward movement of the allied armies on Peking was to be made.

The denial of the publishers that they had formed a combination for the purpose of reducing the royalties paid to authors may have been necessary to allay the alarm which their meeting seems to have aroused in the West, but it was not essential to the peace of mind of those acquainted with the business of publishing books.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- A conference of leading steel and Bessemer iron Interests in this country was held to-day in the offices of the Federal Steel Company, in this city, in compliance With a call issued by President E.H. Gary of the Federal Steel Company, President Schwab of the Carnegie Steel Company, and Joseph G. Butler, Jr., representing the Bessemer Furnace Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The music lovers of New York will rejoice on reading F.K. Wineburgh's letter of protest in your excellent paper of this morning. Let us hope that in it we find the first spark of indignation which will spread into a conflagration and sweep away or utterly destroy the present mediocre, vulgar, and idiotic musical regime.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 26 -- Passengers on the steamer Cottage City, which arrived here from Alaskan ports this afternoon, report a great calamity as having taken place at Lake Labarge. The news, however, lacks confirmation, and is given as passengers heard it in Juneau. The stern-wheeler Florence S., operated and partly owned by Capt. Barrington, they were told, had been caught in a storm on the lake and was capsized.

No independent Democrat needed to be assured, before the meeting at Indianap- oils of the National Committee of the National Democrats, that the committee would decide against the proposition to nominate a third Presidential ticket. The decision by a unanimous vote not to nominate is not surprising; it is altogether wise, reasonable, and gratifying.

EASTON, Penn., July 26 -- A tour of inspection of the Bangor and Portland Railroad by officials of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, the recent purchaser, resulted most disastrously this afternoon to three members of the party.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Navy Department has made public the following additional report of Admiral Kempff:

CHICAGO, July 26 -- "Unless the railways entering Indianapolis make better rates," so Sergeant at Arms John I. Martin telephoned from there to Secretary Walsh to-day, "the notification meeting may as well be called off, so far as this town is concerned."
GEORGETOWN, Ky., July 26 -- In the trial to-day of Caleb Powers, charged with complicity in the shooting of Gov. Goebel, several interesting features were developed.

Let us hope that in it we find the first spark of indignation which will spread into a conflagration and sweep away or utterly destroy the present mediocre, vulgar, and idiotic musical regime.
LONDON, July 27 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Daily Express, wiring yesterday, says:

August Ruisenger of 162 Sands Street, Brooklyn, was before Magistrate Kramer in the Adams Street Court yesterday morning charged by Charles C. Gailbraith, the Eastern manager of the Armour Beef Company, with having converted to his own use $210.90 which he had collected as an employe of the company.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26 -- James W. Thorne, 1900, of Chicago, known among his Princeton classmates as the "Globe Trotter," in company with George L. Denny, 1900, of Indianapolis, and Edward B. Meigs, 1900, of Philadelphia, left Princeton June 1 on a driving tour to the Yellowstone Park.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., July 26 -- Chief of Police Merritt of this place yesterday effected the arrest at Ilion of "Capt. Inglis, United States Army." The arrest was made on a trivial charge, and the prisoner was supposed to be R. Dey Held, but he proved to be none other than the clever swindler who operated in Poughkeepsie during the recent regatta under the alias of "Capt. Inglis, United States Army."

The observant William Brady, who returned from abroad on Wednesday, found time to pay attention to other things than theatricals while in Europe. He saw the American athletes score their sweeping victories over the Englishmen in London, and again in Paris "run rings around the foreigners," he said.
LONDON, July 27 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Roberts:

In the mere nature of their policies, aside from the differences in substance, there have always existed in the mind of the student of international affairs certain points similarity between the Liberal Party of Great Britain and the Democratic Party of the United States. Both are close constructionists, as opposed to the broad Constructionism of respectively the Liberal-Union Party, as the dominant factor in the old Conservative Party evidently is, and the Republican Party.

The old three-story frame house at 348 East Eighty-fifth Street, which for the last thirty years was the home of Mrs. Thomas Bennett, whose husband was formerly one of the wealthiest men in Harlem, and a Tammany leader, was empty and deserted yesterday afternoon for the first time since Mrs. Bennett entered it after her marriage in 1870.

It appears that some of these large and able-bodied vessels were caught out in a breeze of wind the other day in company with several Newport catboats, a few naphtha launches, and some knockabouts.

LONDON, July 27 -- Beneath the gabled roof of Middle Temple Hall, with Van Dyck's noble portrait of Charles I. hanging over them, and surrounded by coats of mail of ancient Knights Templars, faced end relieved with coats of arms, some fifty leaders of the American bench and bar were this evening ertertained by the Judges and lawyers of England.

George Green, Jr., twenty-nine years old, of 95 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, was arrested at West Orange, N.J., yesterday on the charge of having attempted to bribe James J. Fogarty of 176 Broadway, the foreman of the jury which tried Alfred R. Goslin and the other Brooklyn Rapid Transit raiders last month.

Fogarty of 176 Broadway, the foreman of the jury which tried Alfred R. Goslin and the other Brooklyn Rapid Transit raiders last month.
LONDON, July 28 -- A Shanghai dispatch to The Daily Mail says:

BALMORAL, South African Republic, July 25 -- The Boers state that their plan of campaign is to keep up guerrilla warfare until November next. At that time, they say, the Democrats in the United States, if successful in the elections there, have promised intervention in South Africa.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., July 27 -- Sergt. F. Wharton Golden, the prosecution's star witness, was placed in the witness box to-day in the trial of Caleb Powers, charged with complicity in the assassination of Gov. Goebel. Unless present plans are changed, the State will rest its case to-morrow at the conclusion of Golden's testimony.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 -- Arrangements have been practically completed for bringing the Olympic games, emblematic of the world's championship, to Franklin Field, the University of Pennsylvania's athletic ground, in the Summer of 1904.

Lieut. Flaherty and six men of Engine No. 21 had a narrow escape from being burned to death in a fire which destroyed the offices and workshops at 232 and 234 East Fortieth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, of the Colonial Company, formerly Rees Rees, refinishers and lace curtain cleaners, shortly after 8 o'clock last night.

When the preparatory signal for the Larchmont Yacht Club's races was set a half hour before noon yesterday, a merry north-northeasterly breeze blew across the Sound. Only a few light clouds broke the blue of the sky overhead, and there was every promise that the fifth day of Larchmont race week was going to give the twenty-one yachts then jockeying behind the starting line some excellent sport.

Many elements of mystery attach to the suicide by acid of a young woman caller on William H. Dodd, assistant manager of the American Express Company, at the Presbyterian Hospital yesterday afternoon, where the young man is lying seriously ill with typhoid fever.

BOSTON, Mass., July 27 -- After a whole day's delay on account of yesterday's hard rain, the Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament was continued at the Longwood Cricket Club here to-day under the most favorable conditions.

Many comments are appearing just now on the projects of steamship companies in building enormous vessels. That these leviathans do promise increased safety and comfort at sea cannot be denied, and all travelers must rejoice that in a quarter of a century 8 knots an hour have been added to the speed of ocean steamers and more than 260 feet to their length.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 27 -- Walter J. Travis, Harry B. Hollins, Jr., and Daniel Chauncey were the respective prize winners in the three silver cup competitions that have occupied the chief attention ou the golfers on the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club links since Tuesday morning.

Senator M.A. Hanna of Ohio, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, came to the city yesterday. While somewhat disturbed by the pangs of rheumatism, the Senator was not in ill-humor. When he entered the headquarters at 1 Madison Avenue, he was leaning on a cane and on the arm of Cornelius N. Bliss.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with pleasure the letter of Henry Craigin, which was no doubt suggested by that of Frederick K. Wineburgh. The latter's unfortunate reference to the Fatherland's dominance in Central Park's musical arena will, I am afraid, arouse some of our sensitive German friends.

BERLIN, July 27 -- Part of the German expeditionary force for China sailed to-day from Bremerhaven on board three transports. Emperor William, who was accompanied by two of his sons and the Imperial Chancellor, Prince Hohenlohe, witnessed the embarkation of the expedition and delivered a farewell address to the troops.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 27 -- Four Milk Inspectors are creating consternation among farmers and creamery men in sections of Orange County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you, Mr. Editor, allow me to make a few remarks to Mr. P.W. Roche, as he solicits expressions from Eastern Democrats? Nothing that I have seen in print regarding the political questions of the day echoes my sentiments so fully as does this letter.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary Hay signalized his return from Canton to Washington this morning by the announcement that under no circumstances will the United States Government accept the Chinese offer to turn over the foreign Ministers to the allies at Tien-Tsin in consideration of a suspension of the campaign against Peking.

It would be unfortunate in many respects if the President should yield to the renewed clamor against Pension Commissioner EVANS, remove him from the head of the Pension Bureau, and appoint him to be First Assistant Postmaster General in place of PERRY S. HEATH, resigned.

OMAHA, Neb., July 27 -- The special referees appointed to hear the testimony in the suit of the State against the Standard Oil Company held an animated session in Omaha to-day. The hearing was cut short by developments showing that most of the books were to be found in Chicago, and the referees will hold their next session there.

LONDON, July 27 -- In the House of Lords to-day Earl Wemyss asked whether the Premier, Lord Salisbury, had received information "confirming the view of one of our Military Attaches, to the effect that it was all-important that England should be entirely unassailable by November next, and whether he had satisfied himself that our means of defense were such as to render all attempts at invasion futile?"

COLON, July 27 -- The Liberal rebellion in this department has ended after the sacrifice of more than 600 lives, while the grounded numbered many hundreds, the Liberals having been the greatest sufferers. Dr. Mendoza, representing the Liberals, and Gen. Alban arranged at a conference held yesterday for a cessation of hostilities, the Colombian Liberals being pledged to surrender their arms and being guaranteed freedom from prosecution and the retention of all political rights.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States Government has not been notified of the selection of a commander for the allied forces in China, and it is thought the selection has not yet been made. Gen. Chaffee has orders to do everything in his power to facilitate the choice of a head for the expedition.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27 -- This was the big day at the Grand Circuit races, and there was a large crowd present. The feature of the day's racing was the defeat of Dare Devil, the black stallion from the Village farm. In the 2:10 trot. Summary: 2:23 class, pacing; purse $2,500, (threee in five.)

BAR HARBOR, July 27 -- At last the Bar Harbor season is on, announced by a daily increasing number of dinners and luncheons and confirmed by the eagerness with which society has accepted the kebo Valley dinner dances and engaged seats for the dinners far in advance. For to-morrow not a seat has been open since Wednesday.

The hearing was cut short by developments showing that most of the books were to be found in Chicago, and the referees will hold their next session there.

Peter Reinhart, a carpenter, thirty-eight years old, was locked up in the Fourth Avenue Station, Brooklyn, last night, charged with having shot two men. One of them is badly wounded and may die. The shooting took place in Reinhart's apartment on the first floor of the house 44 Forty-tirst Street at 6 o'clock last night.

The Brotherhood of Tailors will hold a mass meeting, in the Hebrew Institute, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, on Wednesday evening to consider whether the members should strike for better conditions. These men sew coats, and the brotherhood is supposed to have 12,000 members.

TUXEDO, N.Y., July 28 -- Tuxedo and the North Jersey Country Club had their annual team golf competition to-day on the Tuxedo links. The game was played over the new eighteen-hole course, and the home team won by 18 points to 5, the contest being counted on the Tuxedo system of 1 point for each victory.

The following unsigned cable message, dated Shanghai, July 19th, which is supposed to be from the Rev. George D. Fitch, confirming the news of Friday, to the effect that the missionaries at Pao-Ting-Foo had been massacred, was received at the headquarters of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions in this city, yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., July 28 -- The Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club here this afternoon furnished one of the most brilliant matches of the season, and with an endins quite as much of a surprise as any played this year. Beals Wright met W. A. Larned in the semi-finals and beat him in three straight sets, to the surprise of everybody.

A crowd of about 1,500 people witnessed the annual games of the St. George's Men's Club of New Yorlc City at Celtic Park yesterday. The number of competitors was large, some of the runs having over forty entries, and several trial heats were necessary in most of the events. .

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 28 -- The Monmouth County horse show was brought to a successful close to-night in the presence of a fashionable attendance. The programme was a long one and the Judges were at work in the ring long before noon.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- The Committee on Organization of the National Civic Federation announces the Executive Council or governing body for that organization. This council will act until the first annual meeting, and is as follows:

LONDON, July 28 -- All the week we have hung between hope and despair, tormented by the conflicting news from China, but the hope has prevailed and at the week's end the impression is decided and strong that perhaps a majority of the white men in the beleaguered City of Peking may remain to-day alive.

LONDON, July 28 -- Lady Randolph Churchill (nee Jerome) was to-day married to Lieut. George Cornwallis West at St. Paul's Church, Knight's Bridge. The church was thronged with handsomely dressed women. There was no restriction upon the number admitted to the church to witness the ceremony, but only relatives and intimate friends were bidden to the subsequent wedding breakfast, and no reception was held.

NEWPORT, July 28 -- At a meeting of the Newport Golf Club to-day the following were elected officers for the ensuing year; Egerton L. Winthrop, President; George L. Rives, Vice President; Governors, for two years, H. Mortimer Brooks, A.M. Coates, John Clinton Gray, and Royal Phelps Carroll.
LAKE PARK, Minn., July 28 -- A hailstorm passed over the western part of Becker County last night and destroyed from 4,000 to 8,000 acres of growing crops.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Mr. Wu, the Chinese Minister, went to the State Department early to-day expressly to deliver an edict received by him to Secretary Hay. It is similar in form to the edict published yesterday in London. The Minister says that the only differences are those involved in separate translations.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 28 -- Dr. William R. Brooks, director of the Smith Observatory, to-day gave out a statement concerning subsequent observations made of the new comet which he discovered last Tuesday morning.

PATERSON, N.J., July 28 -- Three boys are detained at Police Headquarters, suspected of being incendiaries. They are Christopher Devogel, aged nine; Nicholas Hallett, aged eleven, and Christopher Doremus, aged twelve.

There is a possibility of a strike at the American Sugar Refineries Company's plants in Brooklyn, which employ 5,000 men, over rumors of reduction of wages. These rumors have been freely circulated since Thursday, and last night there was a gathering of the laboring men in the vicinity of the plants to discuss them.

TRENTON, N.J., July 28 -- Miss May Worthington, a typewriter, of 230 Passaic Street, this city, had a thrilling experience last evening. Standing on the narrow steps of a vestibuled car that was traveling at the rate of sixty miles on hour, she rode for over twenty miles before she could attract the attention of any one on the train and be released from her perilous position.
Army. Major Thomas Cruse, Quartermaster, is relieved from duty in the Department of Porto Rico, and will proceed to New York City and report for further instructions.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 28 -- The Monmouth County horse show was brought to a successful close to-night in the presence of a fashionable attendance. The programme was a long one and the Judges were at work in the ring long before noon.

The Brotherhood of Tailors will hold a mass meeting, in the Hebrew Institute, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, on Wednesday evening to consider whether the members should strike for better conditions. These men sew coats, and the brotherhood is supposed to have 12,000 members.

LONDON, July 28 -- Lady Randolph Churchill (nee Jerome) was to-day married to Lieut. George Cornwallis West at St. Paul's Church, Knight's Bridge. The church was thronged with handsomely dressed women. There was no restriction upon the number admitted to the church to witness the ceremony, but only relatives and intimate friends were bidden to the subsequent wedding breakfast, and no reception was held.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- At the Newport Golf Club this afternoon the golf handicap contests for the subscription cups brought out the largest gathering of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The dispatches from Consul Fowler, conveying assurances from Yuan Shi-Kai, Governor of ShanTung, that the foreign Ministers were well and had been provisioned, in connection with constantly reiterated assurances from other Chinese sources of the envoys' safety, have raised a new theory at the State Department.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- The Committee on Organization of the National Civic Federation announces the Executive Council or governing body for that organization. This council will act until the first annual meeting, and is as follows:
HAVANA, July 28 -- Mr. Estes G. Rathbone, recently Director General of Posts in Cuba, was arrested at 11 o'clock to-day on four charges.

The Crescent Athletic Club baseball team continues its winning career. At Bay Ridge yesterday afternoon the leaders in the Amateur League race vanquished the Montclair Athletic Club team. But the vanquishing was not easy. It was the hardest kind of a struggle, in which the Crescents did not send the winning runs over the plate until their last turn at the bat.

Gen. James H. Wilson, who arrived from Cuba Friday night on the Ward liner Yucatan, was released from Quarantine yesterday afternoon, and will proceed for China to-day. Gen. Wilson spent almost a year and a half in Cuba as Governor of the Provinces of Matanzas and Santa Clara. When seen last night at the Manhattan Hotel he said:

LONDON, July 28 -- Quietly but steadily Japan's three war vessels building at Elswick are being pushed toward completion. The Idzumo, a powerful armored cruiser, is nearly ready, and 600 Japanese sailors are aboard of her, patiently waiting the word to sail. The average opinion is that they will be needed for a deadlier conflict than the suppression of the Boxers.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 28 -- Charles Hitcheeck, Jr., gave unmistakable proof today that he comes worthily lay his honors as the golf champion of Yale, for he won the Trustees' Plate handily for the beat 18-hole score, in the 36-hole handicap that closed the invitation tournament of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

There is a possibility of a strike at the American Sugar Refineries Company's plants in Brooklyn, which employ 5,000 men, over rumors of reduction of wages. These rumors have been freely circulated since Thursday, and last night there was a gathering of the laboring men in the vicinity of the plants to discuss them.

TRENTON, N.J., July 28 -- Miss May Worthington, a typewriter, of 230 Passaic Street, this city, had a thrilling experience last evening. Standing on the narrow steps of a vestibuled car that was traveling at the rate of sixty miles on hour, she rode for over twenty miles before she could attract the attention of any one on the train and be released from her perilous position.
Chairman James K. Jones of the Democratio National Committee was yesterday asked to define Mr. Bryan's position regarding what the Democrats term imperialism. He said:

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 28 -- The fifth weekly handicap at the Kebo Valley Club was won by Amos R.E. Pinchot of New York. The best players did not show their usual condition. In the afternoon the ladies' putting contest proved a great social attraction. First prize was won by Miss Frances Hinkle of Cincinnati.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 28 -- The last day of the Grand Circuit meeting was marked by another sensational performance. The world's record for pacers in hopples, which was broken on Tuesday by Coney, when he went a mile in 2:02 3/4, was again lowered by Prince Alert today, when he covered the track in 2:02.

PARIS, July 28 -- The situation which will succeed the entry of the international troops into Peking is a matter affording subject for the greatest anxiety. Already things do not appear to be going altogether smoothly at Tien-Tsin, and jealousies are beginning to peep out that may develop into a very serious disagreement before long.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 28 -- Dr. William R. Brooks, director of the Smith Observatory, to-day gave out a statement concerning subsequent observations made of the new comet which he discovered last Tuesday morning.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 28 -- On Friday afternoon W.T. Hilton and James S. Taylor of the Powelton Club played a bestball golf match with Frank Croker, son of Richard Croker, and S. Morgan Allen of the Deal Beach Club, on the Powelton links. The Poweltons won by 1 up.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The dispatches from Consul Fowler, conveying assurances from Yuan Shi-Kai, Governor of ShanTung, that the foreign Ministers were well and had been provisioned, in connection with constantly reiterated assurances from other Chinese sources of the envoys' safety, have raised a new theory at the State Department.

Gilbert R. Manley. Gilbert R. Manley, prominent in St. Lawrence County and Canton, N.Y., died at the Long Island College Hospital, where he had been for three weeks. He came to visit his son, Dr. Mark Manley of 261 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, and was taken ill while there.

The following unsigned cable message, dated Shanghai, July 19th, which is supposed to be from the Rev. George D. Fitch, confirming the news of Friday, to the effect that the missionaries at Pao-Ting-Foo had been massacred, was received at the headquarters of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions in this city, yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 28 -- More than 1,000 society folk of Westchester County attended the open-air horse show which was held in Rochelle Park to-day for the purpose of raising funds for the benefit of the New Rochelle Hospital. The managers of the affair say that they cleared more than $500 for the deserving charity.

TUXEDO, N.Y., July 28 -- Tuxedo and the North Jersey Country Club had their annual team golf competition to-day on the Tuxedo links. The game was played over the new eighteen-hole course, and the home team won by 18 points to 5, the contest being counted on the Tuxedo system of 1 point for each victory.

Some evils have come in the train of the building boom which began in the Borough of the Bronx over a year ago, and which has been stimulated by speculation and by the desire of builders to take advantage of the extension of the time within which frame buildings can be erected in the new fire limits.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Mr. Wu, the Chinese Minister, went to the State Department early to-day expressly to deliver an edict received by him to Secretary Hay. It is similar in form to the edict published yesterday in London. The Minister says that the only differences are those involved in separate translations.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 28 -- The fifth weekly handicap at the Kebo Valley Club was won by Amos R.E. Pinchot of New York. The best players did not show their usual condition. In the afternoon the ladies' putting contest proved a great social attraction. First prize was won by Miss Frances Hinkle of Cincinnati.

COLON, July 28 -- The Canal Company has placed its hospitals and its medical staff at the disposal of the one hundred and eighty, persons who were wounded during the recent insurrection. The surgeon from the French cruller Suchet is also assisting in the work of caring for the injured. The Government Is still busy burying the dead.

NEWPORT, July 28 -- At a meeting of the Newport Golf Club to-day the following were elected officers for the ensuing year; Egerton L. Winthrop, President; George L. Rives, Vice President; Governors, for two years, H. Mortimer Brooks, A.M. Coates, John Clinton Gray, and Royal Phelps Carroll.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- United States Consul General Dubois, at St. Gaul, has sent to the State Department an Interesting account of the trial of a great airship, wimessea by him, which took place on the afternoon of July 2, at Manzell, on Lake Constance, Switzerland.

The average opinion is that they will be needed for a deadlier conflict than the suppression of the Boxers.

MUNICH, July 28 -- The fifth round of the international chess tournament, now in progress in this city, brought about the following results to-day: Gottschall and Berger drew, Maroczy beat Halprin, Jakob vanquished Bardeleben, Marco disposed of Wolf, Janowski beat Showalter, Pillsbury downed Cohn, Burn defeated Popiel, and Billecard lost to Schlechter.

LONDON, July 29 -- A dispatch from Shanghai to The Daily Mail, dated July 28, says:

Peter Reinhart, a carpenter, thirty-eight years old, was locked up in the Fourth Avenue Station, Brooklyn, last night, charged with having shot two men. One of them is badly wounded and may die. The shooting took place in Reinhart's apartment on the first floor of the house 44 Forty-tirst Street at 6 o'clock last night.

Already things do not appear to be going altogether smoothly at Tien-Tsin, and jealousies are beginning to peep out that may develop into a very serious disagreement before long.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- At the Newport Golf Club this afternoon the golf handicap contests for the subscription cups brought out the largest gathering of the season.

Not even the closing regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week escaped the weather Jonah, that on five out of the seven days did its utmost to spoil the long-anticipated sport. At the start, shortly before noon, a faint southeasterly breeze gave the fifty-eight yachts participating barely steerage way over the line, and even this air faded away before all had crossed.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 28 -- Charles Hitcheeck, Jr., gave unmistakable proof today that he comes worthily lay his honors as the golf champion of Yale, for he won the Trustees' Plate handily for the beat 18-hole score, in the 36-hole handicap that closed the invitation tournament of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

BANGOR, July 28 -- The Maine men who sold out their ice properties last Winter to the trust, or the American Ice Company, realize now that they made a great mistake, for, instead of having any difficulty in disposing of the crop, as they seemed to fear, they would have found the demand far greater than the supply.

A Chinaman who has arrived at NiuChwang from Peking confirms the reports of the massacre of foreigners. He was tortured, but did not change his story. He says the Ministers killed their faniilies when the Chinese swarmed into the legations.

BOSTON, Mass., July 28 -- The Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club here this afternoon furnished one of the most brilliant matches of the season, and with an endins quite as much of a surprise as any played this year. Beals Wright met W. A. Larned in the semi-finals and beat him in three straight sets, to the surprise of everybody.

A crowd of about 1,500 people witnessed the annual games of the St. George's Men's Club of New Yorlc City at Celtic Park yesterday. The number of competitors was large, some of the runs having over forty entries, and several trial heats were necessary in most of the events. .

PATERSON, N.J., July 28 -- Three boys are detained at Police Headquarters, suspected of being incendiaries. They are Christopher Devogel, aged nine; Nicholas Hallett, aged eleven, and Christopher Doremus, aged twelve.
LAKE PARK, Minn., July 28 -- A hailstorm passed over the western part of Becker County last night and destroyed from 4,000 to 8,000 acres of growing crops.

Chief Engineer Bensel of the Dock Department, who has been studying the question raised by the Hoboken fire of replacing wooden, piers with steel and stone structures, said yesterday that no iron piers had yet been successfully constructed to meet the requirements demanded by the great steamship lines.

LONDON, July 28 -- All the week we have hung between hope and despair, tormented by the conflicting news from China, but the hope has prevailed and at the week's end the impression is decided and strong that perhaps a majority of the white men in the beleaguered City of Peking may remain to-day alive.
