LONDON, July 28 -- An attack has been made in The Express against the treatment of emigrants arriving at New York. That paper sent a representative in the steerage of the steamer La Champagne, who, in the course of a series of articles entitled "The Closed Door," has been giving English readers alleged vivid pictures of the horrors of a steerage passage.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- To-day brought forth the usual crop of edicts and reports from various quarters and the usual visit from Minister Wu to the State Department, all bearing directly upon the welfare of the foreign Ministers in Peking. This constantly growing mass of assertion is beginning to have a cumulative effect upon the skeptics, and there was a noticeably more hopeful view taken of the state of affairs to-day.

Chief Engineer Bensel of the Dock Department, who has been studying the question raised by the Hoboken fire of replacing wooden, piers with steel and stone structures, said yesterday that no iron piers had yet been successfully constructed to meet the requirements demanded by the great steamship lines.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 28 -- At the bicycle meeting on the Eclipse trotting track at this place to-day, under the direction of the Glen Cove Bicycle Club, W.A. La Due of Cold Spring, N.Y., smashed the Long Island record in a half-mile ride against time, covering the distance in 1:03. The summaries:

KANSAS CITY, July 20 -- A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Edward L. Swazey, charging him with intent to defraud, by selling to the Third National Bank of Springfield, Mass., a mortgage of $7,250 on 261 head of cattle owned by J.H. Kenney of Hemphill County, Texas. It is alleged that Swazey represented that the mortgage was a first lien, whereas it was it second lien.

HAVANA, July 29 -- The Court before whom Estes G. Rathbone, formerly Director of Posts of Cuba, was arraigned yesterday, after his arrest on a charge of fraud, issued an order directing that the prisoner be removed this morning to the Carcel, but Lieut. Col. Scott, Acting Governor General, advised that he be allowed to remain in the Vivac until it was known whether bail would be secured.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 29 -- "Jimmy" Michael, the bicycle rider, was declared defeated, by the referee, in his match with Bon Monroe of Memphis, at Crescent Park this afternoon. The trouble grew out of the terms of the contest for the race, by which Michael's manager, J.C. Kennedy, controlled everything.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 29 -- Mr. Bryan is so well along with his notification speech and his plans are so well developed that he hopes to-morrow to be able to announce his itinerary for the trip to Indianapolis and return. He has no knowledge of the time and place for his notification by the Populists and Free Silver Republicans, and it is not believed his present itinerary takes into consideration that function.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 29 -- Two pickpockets were arrested at Interlaken today, the station at which on Sundays all trains stop for Asbury Park. The Sunday afternoon Pennsylvania train is run in two or three sections as the demand requires.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The daily acknowledgments in the public press of money received for the aid of the famine sufferers of India should cause us to pause and consider. Let the money continue to come in, but let the donor of even a penny question himself regarding the "reasons why" which account for the necessity of his open-hearted act.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- A fierce dispute has broken out between Ho-Yow, the Chinese Consul General, and Tong-KaiChong, editor of The Chinese World and of The Oriental and Occidental Press, the latter one of the leaders of the Reform Association, which seeks to raise an army and overthrow the Empress Dowager and restore Emperor Kwang-Su to the throne.

A series of swimming races at the Yorkville swimming baths, foot of East Eighty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon attracted a number of well-known local swimmers and a large crowd of spectators. The events were all well contested, and some of the finishes were very close. John Mumford, the veteran swimmer of the New West Side Athletic Club, won the club championship over John McAleer by less than 6 inches in a race of 75 yards.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- There is a growing expectation at the State Department that news of the utmost importance may be forthcoming at any moment from Peking. It was even thought that something might be received to-day, but this hope was doomed to disappointment. The few cablegrams that were received referred to minor matters, and did not touch at all upon conditions in the Chinese capital.

HAVANA, July 29 -- The decree calling the Constitutional Convention and providing for the election of delegates meets with almost universal approval at the hands of the Cuban press. The element which has always clamored for independence sees in the convention the probable consummation of the plans of a lifetime.

Stanley of Philadelphia, sixty-five years old. The wedding was attended by all the fashionable people of Vineland, and the couple received a great send-off.

COLUMBUS, July 29 -- The Grand Circuit meeting opens to-morrow. A.H. Merrill of Danvers, Mass., will start the horses. There are over 200 entries. The big race will be the free-for-all trot for stallions for a purse of $5,000 Thursday. Six horses will probably start -- Charles Herr. Croesus, Gayton, Tommy Britton, Dare Devil, and Gratton Boy.

LONDON, July 29 -- Tod Sloan, who was injured last Friday at the Liverpool July meeting, while riding Maluma, is progressing favorably, and it is expected that he will return to London early this week. It is doubtful, however, that he will be able to ride for some weeks.

Richard Croker refuses to bury the hatchet. He does not like ex-Senator David Bennett Hill, and it is said he so told Chairman J.K. Jones of the National Democratic Committee yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- South Chicago steel workers are again preparing for a campaign for McKinley. A Republican marching club was formed with 200 members at the first meeting, and the leaders predict a club of 2,500 to 3,000 members by the time the campaign is in full swing. In 1896 the workers in the mills organized the largest Republican marching club in the State, and it was active throughout the entire campaign.

Throngs of pleasure seekers in Central Park West were treated to the spectacle of a confiagration on wheels yesterday afternoon, when the forward motor of north-bound open car No. 1,041 burned out. The car raced with destruction along the "Motorman's Speedway" for three-quarters of a mile.
An imperial edict of July 29 declares that the Ministers in Peking are held as hostages.

DETROIT, July 20 -- Section 1 of the Buffalo Bill Wild West Show train collided with a freight train near Milwaukee Junction shortly before daybreak to-day, and a show employes' sleeping car, containing some forty sleeping inmates, was smashed. One man is dead, and nine others are in Detroit hospitals suffering from more or less serious injuries.

It was announced at the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, at Broadway and De Sales Place, Brooklyn, yesterday, that the 200 American pilgrims, led by the Very Rev. Eugene Porcile, pastor of the church and Director General of the Fathers of Mercy in the United States, were received by Pope Leo on Thursday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 29 -- Two pickpockets were arrested at Interlaken today, the station at which on Sundays all trains stop for Asbury Park. The Sunday afternoon Pennsylvania train is run in two or three sections as the demand requires.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 29 -- The Brooklyn Naval Militia, who are in camp near Moses Point, spent most of to-day in shaking down their camp and exploring the surrounding country and waters with a view of getting an idea of what kind of land and water they are to work over during the coming week.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- A remarkable address on China was delivered before the Moody Bible Institute congregation this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Marshall, Field Secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, and a Chinese missionary of wide experience.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 29 -- Within sight of twenty-two of his companions, James Morris, a boy staying at the camp of the Children's Seashore Home, in Chelsea, was drowned to-day.

John Mumford, the veteran swimmer of the New West Side Athletic Club, won the club championship over John McAleer by less than 6 inches in a race of 75 yards.

Between brushes on the Speedway yesterday morning there was an exciting episode decidedly out of the ordinary on the course where the light harness horsemen congregate. It was a runaway, or rather a couple of them, and a serious accident of some kind was threatened until prompt and efficient action by the mounted police brought the two frightened horses to a standstill.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club announces the following stakes for the Autumn meeting of 1900, to be run at Gravesend. They close Wednesday, Aug. 15 next:
LONDON, July 31 -- Li-Hung-Chang is understood to be preparing a proclamation for distribution as he travels toward Pechi-Li, assuring the Boxers of pardon if they disband and return to their homes.

BERLIN, July 30 -- King Humbert's assassination has awakened universal expressions of horror for the deed and sympathy for Italy throughout Germany. Upon the arrival of the news this morning the flags at all the Ministries were half-masted. Count von Buelow's representative, other officials, and many private persons called upon the Italian Ambassador, Count Lanza di Busca, who arrived this afternoon from Schwerin.
LONDON, July 31 -- Li-Hung-Chang is understood to be preparing a proclamation for distribution as he travels toward Pechi-Li, assuring the Boxers of pardon if they disband and return to their homes.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The report from London that the British and American troops at Tien-Tsin are preparing for an advance within forty-eight hours aroused much interest here. The announcement seems to have been made just before the arrival of Gen. Chaffee at Taku, and gives rise to some interesting theories concerning the effect of that commander's presence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Answering a question of your correspondent, who writes about the relic of St. Anne, which is reverently kept in one of our Catholic churches in this city, I will say that for a Catholic the matter of any reported miracle is one of evidence, to be disbelieved or believed, as the evidence is weak or strong.

PARIS, July 31 -- One must go back to the time of the Lyons tragedy, when President Carnot was assassinated under similar conditions, and at almost the same hour, at the conclusion of a speeech, to obtain a correct notion of the effect of the news of the crime at Monza upon Parisians.
There was marked activity yesterday at Republican National Headquarters, at 1 Madison Avenue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 30 -- At the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, owing to a heavy rain in the night, the track was slow, but the weather was clear. Ths most exciting race of the day was the 2:16 pace, which was postponed after four heats, two of which had been taken by the favorite, Annie Thornton.
MONZA, July 30 -- The body of King Humbert, Italy's murdered sovereign, was embalmed to-day and prepared for removal to Rome, where it will be laid to rest in the Pantheon.

The identity of the assassin who killed King Humbert was established yesterday beyond a doubt. He is Gaetano Bresci, who left Paterson, N.J., in May, and went directly from New York to Europe, having been delegated by an Anarchist group, it is believed, to assassinate the King:
Sir Claude MacDonald, British Minister to China, in a cipher dispatch received at Tien-Tsin, reported that from June 20 to July 16 the British Legation had been repeatedly attacked.

The worst racing weather of the season failed to check the attendance of the hardened racegoers at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, and a crowd of nearly 2,000 huddled in the grand stand to witness the running of about the worst programme of the meeting. The track was soft and deep with mud, and withdrawals caused considerable reduction in the fields in most of the events.

PARIS, July 30 -- It was rumored this afternoon that an attempt had been made against the life of the Shah of Persia. Investigation proved that while the Shah was visiting the exposition this morning a member of his suite noticed near by a rough-looking Persian carrying, as customary, poniards in his belt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Answering a question of your correspondent, who writes about the relic of St. Anne, which is reverently kept in one of our Catholic churches in this city, I will say that for a Catholic the matter of any reported miracle is one of evidence, to be disbelieved or believed, as the evidence is weak or strong.

The anti-imperialists will go crazy with joy over the news that the President's proclamation of amnesty to all Filipinos who would give up their arms and declare their intention to respect the flag and obey the authority of the United States has had no effect. A Manila dispatch says that Senor PATER- NO'S two fest day ceremonies in celebration of the amnesty were a fiasco.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- On Thursday afternoon Miss Leary will be at home to her Newport friends. She will have a musicale for the entertainment of her guests. Throughout August Miss Leary will continue these "at homes" with music.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article on the "Balance of Trade" and the letters of your correspondents on the same subject have omitted a very important part of the subject, i.e., the inability of any nation having a currency based on gold to pay in gold for its excess of imports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that a municipality should be held culpable in the eyes of justice in the same degree that an individual would for the overt commitment of a wrong act. The consolidation of the Cities of New York and Brooklyn leads to a discovery that it was not legal, just, or right, to charge a taxpayer for what he did not enjoy or use.

Senator James K. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was an early arrival at the Hoffman House yesterday. He received many telegrams and a heavy mail, and in the bundle were said to be a telegram and a letter from William J. Bryan. What these contained Senator Jones did not say, evading a direct answer by declaring he had not read them.

MUNICH, July 30 -- This morning the placers met in the sixth round of the international chess tournament, and at the close of play the following results were announced: Burn worsted Jakob, Janowski beat Cohn, Marco vanquished Gottschall, Bardeleben beat Billecard, Pillsbury worsted Popiel, Showalter downed Halprin, Schlecter defeated Wolf, while the game between Berger and Maroczy was adjourned, the position being in favor of Berber.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 30 -- At the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, owing to a heavy rain in the night, the track was slow, but the weather was clear. Ths most exciting race of the day was the 2:16 pace, which was postponed after four heats, two of which had been taken by the favorite, Annie Thornton.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The letter referred to by Consul Fowler as coming from the German Legation at Peking is supposed here to have been an autograph letter, and, as such, absolutely removed from the possibility of fraud. The Japanese report also is understood to have gone to the coast without having passed through Chinese hands.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- The steamer Alameda, from Australia, is a veritable treasure ship, for she brought on her last voyage from Sydney $2,700,000 in English sovereigns, which were taken to-day to the branch mint here to be coined into $5 pieces. This is the largest cargo of coin ever brought from the antipodes.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- The steamer Alameda, from Australia, is a veritable treasure ship, for she brought on her last voyage from Sydney $2,700,000 in English sovereigns, which were taken to-day to the branch mint here to be coined into $5 pieces. This is the largest cargo of coin ever brought from the antipodes.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- In addition to the charges that the Bureau of Statistics and the Bureau of Education were being used as Republican machines, the Democrats have now made similar charges against the Census Office.
There was marked activity yesterday at Republican National Headquarters, at 1 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, July 31 -- The Morning Leader asserts that Lord Kitchener has been dispatched from Pretoria to Krugersdorf to organize a column to relieve Gen. Baden-Powell, now besieged by Gen. Delarey at Rustenberg, in Western Transvaal.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 30 -- Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador to the United States, is staying at the Octagon Hotel here. The first detailed news of the assassination of King Humbert came with the New York morning papers. One of his suite was the first to see the headlines. He seemed stunned.

PARIS, July 31 -- One must go back to the time of the Lyons tragedy, when President Carnot was assassinated under similar conditions, and at almost the same hour, at the conclusion of a speeech, to obtain a correct notion of the effect of the news of the crime at Monza upon Parisians.
ROME, July 31 -- A proclamation from the Queen Regent has arrived announcing the ascension of the new King, and stating that Parliament will be convoked after the funeral.
Sir Claude MacDonald, British Minister to China, in a cipher dispatch received at Tien-Tsin, reported that from June 20 to July 16 the British Legation had been repeatedly attacked.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- It looks now as if there is a question whether the four seventy-footers turned out this Spring by the Herreshoffs will be able to join in the cruise of the New York Yacht Club beginning next Monday. There is apparently little doubt that they can be put into con- dition for racing, but the time is short to make changes and improvements necessary to strengthen the boats sufficiently.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., July 30 -- In the trial of Caleb Powers, ex-Secretary of State, charged with being an accessory before the fact to the murder of William Goebel, which was resumed to-day, the defense opened its side of the case with a motion for peremptory instructions for a verdict of acquittal.

LAWRENCE, L.I., July 30 -- The tennis tournaments that have been in progress here during the past few days on the grounds of the Lawrence Club, closed to-day when the last of the five competitions were played off. The members of the Rockaway Hunt Club are among the leading spirits of the tennis club, and many have been in daily attendance.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Chinese Minister, Mr. Wu, received news of the Fowler dispatch with great satisfaction. He has been under a severe strain for several weeks past, and aside from his natural anxiety as to the trend of affairs in China, has taken as almost a personal matter the incredulity of the European Chancelieries and the unfavorable comments of certain sections of the press.

The Rev. Dr. Rainsford is spending his Summer as usual at Murray Bay, on the St. Lawrence, and is one of the most enthusiastic players on the popular golf links there. Miss Amy Bonner, Henry Taft, William Byrd, Miss Byrd, Miss Alice Miller, and Mr. and Mrs. John Suydam are among the golf enthusiasts who keep the course lively with handicaps and mixed foursome events.

CUMBERLAND, Md., July 30 -- George L. Wellington, the senior Republican United States Senator from Maryland, has definitely announced his determination to oppose the re-election of President McKinley, but has not yet made up his mind in what manner he will do it. Senator Wellington has not been in full accord with his party, either in local or National affairs, for nearly two years.

A Manila dispatch says that Senor PATER- NO'S two fest day ceremonies in celebration of the amnesty were a fiasco.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 30 -- The tie for the handicap played on Saturday over the Shinnecock Hills links was played off to-day between Mr. Cheney of Maidstone and C. Hitchcock, Jr., of Yale. Going out Mr. Cheney had the advantage of two strokes, finishing in 43, while Mr. Hitchcock took 45.

British naval experts are just now in a somewhat fierce controversy that in some of its features is curiously like the one which has so long and indecisively raged between the advocates of education on the old classical lines and those who would more or less closely confine the attention of students to specialized studies of directly practical value.

It is well nigh as profitless to seek out the cause of the murder of King HUMBERT of Italy as it is to inquire into the cause of any other accident due to the breaking down of some trusted safeguard. There is a railroad accident with loss of life and much wreckage. We seek out the cause and find a broken rail.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Nearly 500 engineers on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad are soon to be made happy by a distribution of service medals. The medals are divided into ten classes, one being given for each five years of continuous employment.

KANSAS CITY, July 30 -- As a result of the war on the bucket shops inaugurated by the Chicago Board of Trade, bucket shop men and grain brokers all over the country have entered into an agreement to base their trades hereafter on New York grain quotations, instead of on those of the Chicago Board.

BOSTON, Mass., July 30 -- The local enthusiasts on lawn tennis to-day were treated at the Longwood Cricket Club grounds to one of the most remarkable matches that have ever been played. It was the final of doubles in the Eastern championship tournament, and the winners are entitled to the right to represent the Eastern section of the country at Newport next month in the final series of matches for the National championship.

WHEELING, West Va., July 30 -- Union workmen believe that when an ironworks builds a fence around its works it is preparing for labor troubles. That was the first intimation of trouble at Homestead in 1892, and has been the initial step in numerous big strikes since.

HAVANA, July 30 -- On the eve of the departure of Col. C.F. Humphrey for China, where he will serve as Assistant Quartermaster General on the staff of Major Gen. Chaffee, his American and Cuban friends here have presented him with a sword and Mrs. Humphrey with a watch, the presentation taking place at a reception given at the Palace.

The members of the Rockaway Hunt Club are among the leading spirits of the tennis club, and many have been in daily attendance.

PARIS, July 30 -- It can be stated on the best authority that the French police are in possession of important facts concerning the antecedents and associates of Bresci, the murderer of King Humbert, and that they are in communication with the Italian police on the subject.

The expansion of trade provides a safeguard against dullness of trade. If our foreign trade is confined to Europe a period of depression in England or on the Continent deprives us of our only market; wages are reduced; factories are shut down; men are thrown out of employment.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Within the last few days violent attacks have been made upon the Administration in some Democratic newspapers, and particularly in one Republican paper which has hitherto supported the Administration, because of an alleged discovery that the State Department had secretly arranged with England to transfer certain Alaskan territory to Canada.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 31 -- Miss Teresa Huntington Blake, the daughter of Samuel Parkman Blake, a retired banker of Boston, Mass., while making a hurdle with a high-jumping horse on the stock farm of J.O. Holloway, near this city, lost her life this afternoon. The horse in going over the hurdle accidentally stumbled on the top rail and fell.

The most recent advices to the Committee of 100 on India Famine Relief Show that the distress in the famine district is actually on the increase. Under date of July 23, the Viceroy announced that on that day the Government provided for 6,281,000 persons. In no event can the situation essentially improve until the harvests of October and November are gathered, and it is inevitable that these harvests will be less than usual.

BOSTON, Mass., July 31 -- The final match in the Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament was played at the Longwood Cricket Club here this afternoon between Dwight F. Davis and Beals C. Wright, both of Harvard. Davis finally won, after nearly three hours of brilliant play, by three sets to one.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- The precincts of the Borough Court of this town were littered to-day with a varied assortment of stable and carriage furniture, including a carriage lamp, broom, bridle, blankets, pads, sleigh bells, carriage seats, cushions, shears, , all of which bore evidence of having in the long ago seen better days.
Army. Assignments to regiments of officers recently promoted:

With two stake events on the programme and a fair card of overnight events, the racing at Brighton Beach yesterday promised so well that the attendance was increased to holiday proportions. The weather was bright and fine, and the track had dried out, and was little short of fast, but the sport nevertheless fell somewhat short of expectations, withdrawals in the races that promised best robbing the contests of a part of their interest.

LONDON, July 31 -- At the first day's racing at the Goodwood Meeting to-day the Stewards' Cup, for three-year-olds and upward, three-quarters of a mile, was won, by J.A. Drake's aged chestnut horse Royal Flush, by Favo, out of Flush, guided by "Johnny" Reiff. Richard Croker's Americus, ridden by Ribgy, was second, and The Grafter was third.

Mr. BROCKWAY has chosen the part of wisdom in voluntarily resigning his post as Superintendent of the Elmira Reformatory, and it is an evidence of the tact and good judgment of the managers that they were able to reach a friendly understanding with him.

BERLIN, July 31 -- The German press again discusses the undesirability of allowing a German sovereign State to become an English heirloom, passing from hand to hand. The National Zeitung concludes its article on the subject by telling the young Duke that it will depend on him to dissipate all objections made inside and outside of the Duchy to the succession going to a Prince of foreign birth and education.

The market for outside securities yesterday showed a greater degree of activity than for some days, but there was a continuance of the recent absence of stocks with the result that prices were firm and strong in most instances. Copper and transportation issues were not active.

A copy of The City Record appeared yesterday, giving in 381 closely printed pages the entire salary list of the city employes, including the increases and decreases since Jan. 1. This copy is the first fruit of the Mazet investigation law requiring this information from the city department heads twice each year.

At the meeting of the International Law Association, now being held in Rouen, France, the following report which was prepared at a meeting held here last month was submitted by Charles Henry Butler, Harrington Putnam, and Julien T. Davies, American members of a committee appointed at the Buffalo conference of 1899.

Around the Horn to 'Frisco in fifty-five days is the programme mapped out for a New York Harbor tug. She is the L. Luckenback, and will, if nothing happens, begin her long voyage to-day. Capt. McKay, her commander, arrived a few days ago from California, and is reputed to be an expert navigator of Southern seas.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 31 -- Official reports have been received here that the Chinese again bombarded Blagovestchensk, capital of the Amur Government, on July 26 and July 28. The Russian guns replied and reinforcements were then approaching.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The War Department to-day promulgated the following order fixing the time of holding the Cuban elections for the selection of delegates to the Constitutional Convention:

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 31 -- Four young women were drowned in the surf here to-day. They were carried beyond their depth, and although promptly brought to the shore by the life saver on duty and the bathers who could swim, it was too late 10 save their lives.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Vice Consul Monoghan, at Chemnitz, Germany, has transmitted to the State Department an interesting statement concerning the steel production of the world. German authorities, he says, estimate the production last year at 26,841,755 tons, as against 23,866,308 tons in 1898.

BOSTON, July 31 -- In the first half of today barely 500 shares of mining stocks changed hands all told, and the only change worth noting was a loss of 1, to 62, in Butte, which later sold at 62 1/2. Central Oil gained 3/4, to 15 6/4, on odd lots -- 25 shares in all. Santa Ysabel sold at 85. Amalgamated was firm at 87.

Changes, said to be the most sweeping since the organization of the present Fire Department in 1865, were made yesterday in the personnel of the force, and will take effect at 8 o'clock this morning. New officers just promoted will assume command of companies in the down-town districts, while the old commanders have been transferred to companies where the duty is lighter.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31 -- To-morrow afternoon the first of the series of the ladies' golf matches will be played on the links of the Newport Golf Club for a subscription cup. The match will be a handicap limited to 20 strokes and 18 holes.

There is a firm belief among the 5,000 odd Italians in Paterson that the Italian Consul in New York has instituted a search on his own account in order to discover whether or not the assassin of King Humbert had accomplices in that town. The police of the town and the Prosecutor at Pleas pay that they have heard nothing of any such investigation, but several Italians asserted yesterday that it was being made.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Nearly 400 persons, many of whom had never seen the inside of a police station before, were captured today in a wholesale raid on alleged bucket-shops situated in the down-town district and carted off to the police stations. A dozen firms, some of them connected with the Board of Trade, were visited by the police.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The War Department this evening received two cablegrams from China. The first read:
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The War Department has received the following cable dispatch from Gen. Chaffee:

There has been a strike on for some little time in the hat and cap manufacturing house of Max Greenberg, at 222 Wooster Street. The strikers have been frequenting the neighborhood of the shop since they went out, and they have sent their demands to the firm every day, but have received no satisfaction.
BOSTON, July 31 -- John Nelson defeated "Jimmy" Michael on the Charles River Park track to-night in a twenty-mile motorpaced race. Nelson won by fully five yards, in 33:03 1-5.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The Board of Trade has answered the petition of the Central Stock and Grain Exchange for the enforced continuance of the dally market report with the charge that the Stock and Grain Exchange is conducting a bucket shopping business, and is, therefore, not entitled to the market quotations.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The United States Ambassador here, Joseph H. Choate, saw the Prime Minister, Lord Salisbury, yesterday and ascertained his views with regard to the changes in the Chinese situation brought about by the direct dispatches from Peking. Lord Salisbury assured Mr. Choate that Great Britain had no intention of delaying the advance on Peking, nor, so far as he knew, had any other power.
Richard Croker has again humiliated ex-Senator Hill, and the fact was the main topic in Democratic circles yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 31 -- In the sweepstakes sailing race for twenty-footers at Chippewa Bay under the auspices of the Chippewa Bay Yacht Club over a twelve-mile triangular course, the Challenger, owned by J. Ingalls, won, with Navijo, owned by L.H. Hayden, second, and Akalo, owned by W.B. Hayden, third.

BOSTON, July 31 -- A slight change in the dates for the first competition for the International Challenge Bowl presented to the United States National Lawn Tennis Association by Dwight F. Davis is announced, the opening being on Aug. 7 and continuing through the next two days at the Longwood courts.

The Empire of China admitted at least one impulse to follow the Western world when it took upon itself the obligations of international law. In the estimation of WHEATON, "There is no circumstance which marks more distinctly the progress of modern civilization than the institution of permanent diplomatic missions between different States."
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin to-day received a dispatch from Lieut. Col. Coolidge, commanding the Ninth Infantry at Tien-Tsin. It came by way of Che-Foo and is as follows:

John W. Scheer, formerly a retail ice dealer, but lately employed as a driver by the American Ice Company, to which he had sold his business, applied to Justice Giegerich, in the Supreme Court, yesterday for the continuation of the preliminary injunction granted by Justice Dugro preventing the American Ice Company from using Scheer's name on its wagons and from soliciting business in his name.

Arbuckle Brothers yesterday issued the following notice, which was regarded, in connection with its reception by the trust, the National, and the sugar trade generally, as an indication that the sugar war may be renewed:

The Chicagos did not have a chance to win yesterday's baseball game with New York after the fifth inning. The New Yorks hit almost when they pleased, and this, coupled with the Chicagos' errors and poor fielding, gave the New Yorks an easy victory.
NEWPORT, July 31 -- Entertaining at luncheon this afternoon at the clubhouse were A. Cass Canfield and Richard Peters.

Since the 18th of June 2,000 little girls from the Industrial Schools of the Children's Aid Society have been sent to Bath Beach, each company remaining for a week. Two thousand boys from the same schools have spent a day at the same place, all having had an opportunity to bathe in the salt water, while the remainder of the time was passed in the enjoyment of the pastimes abundantly provided for their entertainment.

The policy of Senator Hanna and the other men in charge of Republican National headquarters in this city is to make as good a showing as possible at the September elections in Maine and Vermont for the moral effect that decisive Republican victories there will have on the elections in November.

Dr. John Clark Ridpath, the historian, died in the Presbyterian Hospital last evening at 5:30 o'clock of a complication of diseases. He had been a patient in the hospital since April 26. His wife and son were at his bedside when he passed away.

Notwithstanding that the favorable news developments of the day on the whole overshadowed the unfavorable, the movement of stocks on the stock market yesterday was decidedly irregular. In the early part of the trading, which continued as on previous days largely professional, quotations held well, some fairly substantial advances appearing.
LONDON, July 31 -- A member of the Chinese Legation gave an extended interview to an American correspondent to-day, in the course of which he said:

J. Alva Jenkins, who filed plans on Monday for a five-story settlement house, to be erected at Tenth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, is John D. Rockefeller's private secretary. The new building will cost $100,000, and it has been intimated that it may be intended as a gift by Mr. Rockefeller to some church or institution.
LONDON, July 31 -- A dispatch from Tien-Tsin to-day says:
BOSTON, July 31 -- One of the cleverest of confidence schemes was recently worked successfully on all the large railways in the United States.

WHITESTONE, L.I., July 31 -- There was an interesting meeting of the Inter-State Naval Reserves Regatta Association aboard the New Hampshire, off this place, tonight. Delegates representing the First Naval Battalion of New York, Second Naval Battalion of Brooklyn, the Fourth Naval Battalion of New Jersey, and the reserves of Pennsylvania and Rhode Island were on hand.

The battle of San Juan Hill was fought over again yesterday in Special Term, Part I., of the Supreme Court, where Clinton H. Smith, ex-Major of the Seventy-first Regiment, removed from the National Guard lay Gov. Roosevelt after the Cuban campaign, renewed his legal warfare for rehabilitation.
Prizes fell thick and fast among the Pastime's athletes in the games given yesterday by the United Retail Butchers of Greater New York at Ridgewood Park.

NEWPORT, Aug. 1 -- The thirty-foot yachts raced over the Jamestown-Bishop's Rock Buoy course this afternoon for the cup offered by the Newport Yacht Racing Association with the wind light from the northeast. So many fouls occurred that, although the Hera finished first, there was no decision rendered as to who had won the cup, the judges deciding to consider the matter.

Is it Polyphemus or a pigmy that confronts the Christian powers at Peking? Have we aroused a veritable monstrum horrendum, or is it only the familiar and not formidable little Chinese devil with whom the allies are to try conclusions? Has that decrepit old Flowery Kingdom vital force enough to prepare for us an Armageddon, or will it meet the allied troops with absurd armies and only a show of resistance?

Once upon a time three goddesses had a beauty contest. The prize was a golden apple, and the referee was an amiable young man named Paris. He awarded the prize to Aphrodite, otherwise known as Venus. This justly celebrated lady was, therefore, the first and till very recently the only member of her sex who had a record as being officially declared uncommonly beautiful.

READING, Penn., Aug. 1 -- The iron workers of Pennsylvania are greatly agitated over the very evident purpose of iron manufacturers generally to reduce wages. The American Iron and Steel Manufacturing Company, having immense plants at Reading and Lebanon, announced a reduction in wages of twenty-five per cent., to take effect to-day.

With the sailing of the Majestic and the arrival of the Oceanic, town was very lively yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Witherbee, Mrs. Henri Cutting, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Schuyler, and John L. Cadwalader were among the well-known people who sailed on the Majestic. Mrs. James P. Kernochan and her daughter, Mrs. H.C. Pell, and Miss Ruth Lawrence and Mrs. Samuel Thomas returned on the Oceanic.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- Business was quiet on the Boerse to-day owing to the decline in foundry shares and rumors of cheap American offers of iron. The prices of Upper Silesia Works eased off, especially for cail shares. Italian and Chinese securities were firm.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Gold and stock tickers gave no Chicago Board of Trade quotations on grain and provisions to-day, and many exchanges in other cities and bucket-shops had to depend on other means to secure the quotations. Instead of Chicago grain quotations, the tickers handled the fluctuations of the New York, Minneapolis, Duluth, St. Louis, and other markets.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 1 -- Ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld's promised speech in reply to Gov. Roosevelt's St. Paul address was the feature of the second day's session of the Association of Ohio Democratic Clubs. The attendance was very small, although there were numerous speakers of local reputation.
That nothing except the mint can make money without advertising is an axiom among successful men of affairs.

-- Protest is entered by The Washington Post against describing the New Orleans riots as a race war, or as in any sense the result of racial hatreds or prejudices. The Southern whites, it declares, have no disposition to persecute the blacks, and the troubles were in reality what are commonly called "labor troubles."

The senior eight-oared shell crew of the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia, which will represent the United States in the international rowing regatta to be held at Paris on Aug. 25 and 26, sailed yesterday morning on the Westernland of the Red Star Line.

Some evidently unwarranted concern was recently provoked by the publication, apparently for campaign purposes, of a story attributing to Secretary of State HAY and the Administration a willingness to throw away valuable mining property in Alaska, heretofore claimed by the United States and owned by citizens of the States, in order to carry out an alleged secret bargain by which Mr. HAY was to yield American territory to Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The seizure of the property of the Maritime Canal Company has long been expected, although the United States Government has done all hat it properly could do to conserve the rights of the concessionaires. Under the terms of the concession the Nicaragua Canal Company was allowed a period of ten years after the completion of the preliminary surveys in which to complete the construction of the canal.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 1. -- J.D. Parker, editor of The Smithfield Courier, was in Raleigh to-day. After the Red-Shirt mob at Smithfield yesterday had dragged Mr. Teague, the Populist speaker, from the stand and destroyed the structure, and after a number of persons had been injured in a general riot, the mob made an attempt to destroy the office of The Smithfield Courier and to assault the editor.
The necessity of choosing between the saving of his wife or child was the trying experience which faced Capt. Walter J. King of the canalboat J.L. Kiers early yesterday morning in Newtown Creek.

Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan yesterday mortgaged to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the property in One Hundred and Fourth Street, south side, 125 feet west of First Avenue, for $40,000, due in one year. A new church and parish house is being erected on the premises.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Chinese Imperial Government is putting forth the most powerful efforts to secure through negotiation the abandonment of the international movement upon Peking. The cablegrams received at the State Department to-day from Li-Hung-Chang all tend to demonstrate his desire to secure the succor of the Ministers at Peking and their delivery at Tien-Tsin, if this can be safely effected, trusting that in return the international column can be halted.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 1 -- Many new details of the siege of Tien-Tsin were received here per the steamer Grenogle today. Charles F. Gammon, Superintendent of the American Bible Society in China, arrived at Nagasaki shortly before the steamer left for Victoria. He said as soon as the Chinese troops received word that the bombardment had begun they immediately opened fire on the city.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Sir Claude MacDonald's latest letter, while a strong indictment of the Chinese Government, is not nearly so much so as Dr. Morrison's dispatch. That correspondent, with the Imperial edicts as authority, declares that as late as July 2 the Imperial Government urged the Boxers to continue their "loyal and patriotic services in exterminating the Christians."

The removal of the portico and inclosed balcony in front of the Pabst Hotel, in West Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, because they are encroachments on the domain of the public, will be done either by the proprietor of the hotel, James B. Regan, or by Florence Sullivan, Superintendent of the Bureau of Incumbrances in the Department of Highways, under the order of Commissioner James P. Keating.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Secretary of the Navy to-day issued to shipbuilders a circular calling for bids for the construction of six armored cruisers, three authorized by the Act of March 3, 1899, and three by the Act of June 7, 1900. Those authorized by the former Act are to be sheathed and coppered.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Aug. 1 -- Owing to the condition of currency exchange, rents and the prices of food, labor, and the necessaries of life, with scarcely any exception, have advanced here 66 2-3 per cent. Apparently there is a concerted effort on the part of merchants and shopkeepers to hold prices to the gold basis.

The market for outside securities yesterday was fairly quiet, and the movements of prices were somewhat irregular. Several issues developed some strength. Copper and transportation stocks were conspicuously strong.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Sugar led a more active market to-day, and there was fair buying of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and Union Pacific. Mining stocks were ignored almost completely, but the rise of the last two days in the London price of the metal attracted favorable comment here. Dominion Coal rights sold at 5 @ 7c.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 1 -- The preliminary and first rounds of the mixed foursomes match at the Kebo Valley Golf Club for the cups offered by J.L. Ketterlinus were played to-day. Sixteen couples entered, several golfers coming from Northeast Harbor for the tournament. Franklin Ellis and Mrs. T.G. Condon showed excellent form and played surprisingly well.

The rest that Trainer Charles Brossman promised his great old mare Imp after her disgraceful defeat by Ethelbert and Skyscraper lasted just six days. Imp was dragged out again yesterday at Brighton Beach and raced to the best of her present ability, only to be beaten again, this time by Belle of Troy, a selling class mare, to whom Imp when herself could concede almost any weight.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 1 -- The energetic period of serial entertainment begun last week was continued to-day with fresh additions to the society calendar. The weekly Malvern hop produced a crowd of society leaders and proved the most successful of the season. An unusually large number of young men were present.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The Summer meeting of the Saratoga Racing Association began this afternoon, and the fine, clear weather, cool and pleasant, brought out a great attendance.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 1 -- Her Majesty's steamship Phaeton, which arrived here today from South America, had a narrow escape from collision with the United States warship Iowa last night. She was coming up the straits in a dense fog, when suddenly the officer on watch discovered a large white man of war, which proved to be the Iowa, not two hundred yards away.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 1 -- When the Northern Pacific steamship Glenogle left the Orient, a feeling of unrest permeated the cities of the entire Chinese coast. This was best demonstrated so far as the officers of the Glenogle saw, at Shanghai, where 10,000 Chinese were on the wharves with baggage and all personal effects on hand, ready to take their departure on the first steamer which would take them out of the country.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- "The allies began the advance from Tien-Tsin this morning," announced an agency bulletin dated at Shanghai at 11:10 A.M. yesterday. It is assumed that the Americans, British, and Japanese are taking part in this forward movement, whether other nationalities are or not.

Advancing quotations were the rule on the stock market yesterday. This was due not to any favorable news developments, but almost entirely to a renewal of operations by bull cliques. Professionalism, in fact, was the dominant feature of the market, and it was this primarily that advanced quotations.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 1 -- The Government of Nicaragua has taken possession of the property of the Maritime Canal Company, and removed the company's cars, rails, and property to the interior from Greytown, under Article 54 of the concession.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Ten Eyck did not sail for Europe to-day, and will not so because of a misunderstanding between him and the officials of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen. When the champion and his clubmate, who is his cousin, won the double-scull race at the National regattta is was understoood that both were to be sent to Paris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at he close of business July 31, 1900, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,109,346,710, an increase for the month of $1,635,452. This increase is accounted for by the increased disbursements of cash inident to the beginning of the new fiscal year.
Army. Transfers in the Forty-third Infantry, Unites States Volunteers: Second Lieut. John N. Truden from Company L to Company D, Second Lieut. William H. Burt from Company D to Company L.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Surgeon Gen. Sternberg says that the large sick list of the Ninth Infantry, reported by Col. Daggett, is probably due to severe service and exposure together with the change of climate and possibly bad water. The Surgeon General says that such illness would not be unusual under the circumstances.

NEW LONDON, Mo., Aug. 1 -- Alexander Jester, the octogenarian who has been on trial here for the past four weeks on the charge of killing Gilbert Gates, brother of John W. Gates, in 1871, was acquitted tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Secretary of the Treasury has designated the following architects to act as a board to pass upon the plans to be submitted by a number of competing architects for the United States Government building at Indianapolis: D.H. Burnham of Chicago, Henry Van Brunt of Kansas City, H. Langford Warren of Boston, E.B. Green of Buffalo, and James Knox Taylor, the Supervising Architect of the Treasury.

From The Chicago Times-Herald. Among the Democratic newspapers which have come out boldly in support of the Republican ticket none has been more liberal in opening its columns to the protests and criticisms of its Democratic readers than THE NEW YORK TIMES. These have run the gamut from mild deprecation to bitter reproach, while there has been a chorus of commendation showing how general has been the approval of its course among its readers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Dr. Robert Coltman Jr., the staff correspondent of The Chicago Record in Peking, who had not been heard from since June 12, sends the following dispatch:
NEWPORT, Aug. 1 -- To-morrow evening a brilliant dinner will be given at White Lodge, the Summer home of Lispenard Stewart, who is entertaining in honor of Lord and Lady Pauncefote.

Upward of 3,000 persons who had gone to attend the Retail Butchers' Mutual Protective Association's barbecue at Ridgewood Park yesterday were treated to the spectacle of a double steer killing. Two 1,000-pound steers had their throats cut within full view of the gathering which surrounded a raised platform and howled with delight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The possible connection between Bresci, the Italian murderer of King Humbert, and the New Jersey group of Anarchists has moved this Government to take measures to investigate the Anarchist situation in and around New York.

At the regular meeting of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday there was a disagreement between President Grout of the Borough of Brooklyn and the Commissioner of Water Supply. A resolution was offered granting permission to the Jamaica Water Supply Company to open certain streets in the Borough of Brooklyn to lay water mains.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- At the second day's racing of the Goodwood meeting to-day the Good wood Plate, handicap, two miles, was won by Lord Beresford's Jiffy II., ridden by J. Reiff.

Senator Hanna was an early arrival at Republican National Headquarters yesterday, and he was soon joined by Senator Scott of West Virginia, Joseph H. Manley of Maine, and Committeeman Fred S. Gibbs of this State.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Joe Patchen, out to lower the world's record of 2:04 1/4, made by him on this half-mile track, was the big card at the Elks' Carnival at Combination Park. Medford, this afternoon. The black champion was unable to do better than 2:06 1/2 in his second trial, although he was in fine fettle, and in his two working-out miles went so easily that the record really looked in danger.

DES MOINES, Ia., Aug. 1 -- The Republican State Convention to-day had one of the most interesting sessions in the history of the party in Iowa. The new auditorium was packed almost to suffocation with delegates and visitors, but the proceedings were orderly and the work of the convention went off smoothly and without a hitch, notwithstanding the warm contests for the various offices.

The following letter from the Republican State Committee's headquarters at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and signed by Gen. E. A. McAlpin as Treasurer, was received Monday by an employe of the Post Office in this city, it being one of several thousand sent from the same source to all the Federal employes in the city:

Ex-Senator David B. Hill was at Democratic State Headquarters for nearly four hours yesterday. Indeed, he reached there before any of the employes, the colored doorman excepted, had put in an appearance. The ex-Senator was accompanied by Gen. Earle.
The Fall century run of the Century Wheelmen will he held on Oct. 7. Regular club runs will be resumed on Sept. 2.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 1 -- It is reported from Kerrville, in Southwestern Texas, that a large section of country has been flooded. Scores of families are said to be destitute and homeless.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Special Master J. Kearney Rice has filed a report in the Court of Chancery in the suit of Charles C. Weber for divorce from his wife, Amelia Weber, recommending to the Chancellor that the South Dakota divorce obtained by Mrs. Weber be set aside and that a divorce be granted to Mr. Weber for desertion.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- The will of Mrs. Natalie Mayer, who accidentally shot and killed herself at her home on the Havemeyer estate at Mahwah, N.J., on July 14, was admitted to probate to-day by Surrogate Pell. The will was filed last week. The delay in admitting it to probate was caused by a desire to have the four executors qualify, but only two or them did so.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Henry K. Davis, a correspondent in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES, in commenting upon our country's position in assuming the government of the Philippine Islands whether the Filipinos wish to receive our sovereignty or not, in part, says: "If they do, then it is a question for Congress to consider as to whether or not we want them.

NEWCASTLE, N.H., Aug. 1 -- The Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament ended here this afternoon on the courts of the Longwood Cricket Club, with a brilliant match for the challenge cup. Champion M.D. Whitman successfully defended his claim to the trophy, beating his challenger, Dwight F. Davis, by three sets to one.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 1 -- For several weeks a strange man has been annoying the women of Great Plain district, this city, by following those who chanced to be out alone and unprotected of nights. Of late his actions have become more bold and insulting, and the women have become so terrified that not one could be induced to venture out of doors after nightfall.

The State Board of Railroad Commissioners met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The applications of the New York and Brooklyn Tunnel Transportation Company and of the New York, Brooklyn and Jersey City Railroad for permits were examined.
St. Matthew's Lutheran Church has sold to Gordon, Levy Co. the block front on the north side of Canal Street between Forsyth and Eldridge Streets, 200.3 by 50, now occupied by old buildings.

The Board of Education met last night and voted the janitress, Mrs. Catherine Higgins, an increase of salary of $600 per annum, from $4,600 to $5,200, and also passed a resolution giving her for the month of August the sum of $498.33. The reason for voting her these sums of money were stated in the resolution, "in order that she may be enabled to properly care for the premises."

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 1. -- The Democrats held a rally at Caesar, in Cleveland County, to-day. After the speaking, Bob Brackett, Republican, became engaged in a fight, and was cut badly. He is reported to be dying. Orange Latimore was also cut. During the fight, Frank Queen, another Republican, opened fire on the crowd.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 1 -- The knockabout yachts raced this morning, and the event proved uninteresting, the finish being exactly the same for the first two as in Saturday's race. The Rip, owned by Edgar T. Scott of Philadelphia, crossed the finish line in the harbor first, with the Papoose, owned by E.V. Massey, a close second.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 1 -- An address on bankruptcy by Referee Eastman of Chicago was the feature of to-day's session of the Commercial Law League of America. A special Committee on Bankruptcy was appointed to report on Friday. A number of amendments will be recommended.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 3 -- A dispatch received here says that there was a large gathering of Anarchists to-night at the mouth of the abandoned mine near Shaner Station, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, to exult over the killing of King Humbert. The meeting was in charge of G. Ciancabilla, editor of L'Aurora, the Anarchist newspaper formerly of Hoboken, N.J., who spoke for an hour, rousing his hearers to a high pitch of rejoicing.

As the result of an investigation made among the Italians in West Hoboken yesterday, it was learned that Gaetano Bresci's companion, when he left for Italy, was Nicola Quintavelli, an Italian barber, who was formerly the manager of a shop at Savoy and Spring Streets, and who lived at 500 Paterson Avenue, West Hoboken.

I have thought an article on Chinese walls may not be uninteresting to my young readers of both sexes. It seems to be in the very nature of a Chinaman to have a wall. He takes to it like a young duck to the water. He seems to have an instinctive propensity that way, like a hen to sit on eggs.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 1 -- Late China advices were brought by the steamer Grenogle to this port. Lieut. von Kron of the German Army arrived at Yokohama in company with 300 wounded and incapacitated Germans and others on the steamer Korn, chartered by the German Government, just before the Glenogle sailed.

Ex-Gov. ALTGELD, in his speech last night before the Ohio Association of Democratic Clubs at Toledo, told his hearers to "bear in mind that every trust in America is fighting the Democratic platform." He did not except the Democratic stockholders in our own Ice Trust.

Few of the most liberally equipped libraries in this country seem likely to be comparable, in a very short time, with the Library of Congress at Washington in completeness of newspaper and periodical supply. If the recently manifested disposition of the Congress to deal very liberally and broadly with the Librarian shall continue, the advantages in this respect of the Washington library will soon become notable.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- A gang of fifteen convicts left here this morning for the new State prison at Mapanoch, in Ulster County. The men all belong to Class A -- that is, they are all short-term men, each having less than one year to serve, and are ali either carpenters or masons.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Henry Fredericks, fifteen years old, was drowned to-day in Mirror Lake, near Pelham, the scene of so many fatalities. The boy was a son of Andrew Fredericks, a lumberman of this place.

Over 1,000 of the Italian Anarchists of Paterson were present at the mass meeting held there last night. The assembly room at the back of the Bartholdi Hotel, on Straight Street, which holds about 500 people, was packed to the doors, while the saloon in front of it was filled with a crowd of Italians which extended outside all the way across the street.

DANBURY, Aug. 2 -- Oliver Taylor, Jr., the seventeen-year-old son of a wealthy farmer of Ball's Pond, killed a monster blue heron this morning after a struggle in which the bird came near besting its captor. He was walking about a fish pond on his father's premises when the bird swooped down from above and caught a fish which was sunning itself near the surface of the water.
A Christian town near Peking has it is reported, been wiped out by Imperial Chinese troops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Chinese Minister had just read the dispatch of Dr. Morrison from Peking to The Times when he was seen this morning. Mr. Wu, who all along has maintained an optimistic tone as to the trend of events in China, seemed more distressed by the latest developments than at any time since the trouble began. He said:

The State Board of Railroad Commissioners held two sessions yesterday, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, at which a number of matters were disposed of, among them the application of the Fifth Avenue Stage Coach Company for an extension of its lines. The extensions, which will give the company an east and a west side line to Harlem, were granted.

None of the Republican leaders supposed to be most closely connected with the action of the State Committee in sending out to Federal employes an appeal for campaign funds managed to throw any light yesterday as to where the list of names and house addresses used by the committee came from.

The following cablegram was received yesterday by the New York Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief from William H. Fee, United States Consul at Bombay, and Chairman of the Americo-Indian Relief Committee:

Richard Croker talked freely yesterday on the political situation. It was at the Cafe Savarin, and his listeners were exSenator Arthur Pue Gorman and Col. L Victor Baughman of Maryland. The latter is Mr. German's personal friend and representative.
The Chicagos and New Yorks had a long session at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, the visitors winning by good batting in the seventh inning.

The stock market yesterday, such little as there was, was dull and heavy, with professionalism again the dominant factor. Barely 170,000 shares were traded in, with five stocks -- Sugar Trust, Baltimore and Ohio, Brooklyn Rapid Transit, Continental Tobacco preferred, and Union Pacific -- furnishing more than one-half of the entire transactions.

We published yesterday morning a circular addressed to the employes of the Federal Government in this city by the Republican State Committee through their Treasurer, E.A. McALPIN, begging for "voluntary contributions" to the committee's campaign fund.
The Democratic State Committee is to receive no material financial aid from Tammany Hall, it was reported yesterday.

Blazing horse feed in the stable attached to Jacob Doll's piano factory and lumber yard in the Southern Boulevard, near One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, caused a brief but exciting fire at 7:25 o'clock yesterday morning, and proved the heroism of Mrs. John Gounoud, who was alone with her four small children on the upper floor of the two-story brick structure where the family resides.

We think that Mr. T.B. REED, former Speaker of the House of Representatives, should be left alone to decide his course in the present canvass in accordance with the dictates of his own judgment and conscience, and all right-minded men will sympathize with his annoyance in seeming to be pressed prematurely to announce that decision.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 2 -- The second of the twenty-mile matched pacing races between "Jimmy" Michael and John A. Nelson, scheduled to take place in this city this afternoon, did not occur, on account of Michael's failure to put in an appearance. The manager of the Bridgeport track received a telegram from J.C. Kennedy, manager for Michael, that the latter was sick.

Only two of the 231 persons captured in the Tivoli raid Wednesday night were held for examination. Three others were fined and all the rest were permitted to go free by Magistrate Pool, in the Jefferson Mar- ket Police Court, yesterday, after the Magistrate had said to them: "Go and sin no more."

To the Editor of The New York Times: You can howl "dishonest money," "prosperity," "repudiation," , until the polls close in November, and you will not deceive a single reader or blind him in the impending struggle. The danger to the Republic is imperialism. Call it expansion, raising the flag, standing by the President, duty, destiny, or what you may.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Boston had a better market to-day. Demand appeared for some of the mining stocks, and prices in several cases made good gains.
Gutwillig Brothers have bought from Joseph Guinet the two four-story dwellings on the east side of West End Avenue, 20 feet north of One Hundred and Second Street, each 20 by 100.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, who reports Emperor William's extraordinary sermon on board the Hohenzollern, says that some of the most striking sentences attributed to the Kaiser are the following:

Mrs. Jennie Quintavalli, the wife of Nicola Quintavalli, who was arrested Wednesday at the Rio Marina, on the Island of Elba, on suspicion of being an accomplice of the assassin Bresci, and on whose person were found letters and photographs of well-known Anarchists, lives it 242 East One Hundred and Ninth Street, this city.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 2 -- W.P. Schreiner, ex-Premier of Cape Colony, speaking in the House of Assembly to-day, announced his intention to support an amendment to the Government's Treason Bill, which, without disapproving martial law, declares its continuance in certain districts contrary to the rights of British subjects.
Capt. John Mclntosh, senior commander of the Ward Line's fleet, died early yesterday morning at his home, 288 Monmouth Street, Jersey City. He was in his sixty-third year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- High officials of the Administration are convinced that there is not and never has been anything in the stories that the allies are halting at Tien-Tsin because of inability to agree upon a Commander in Chief. They believe, that the only reason for the delay has been the slowness with which supplies are landed.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 2 -- It is announced that the Algoma Central Railway, which has a charter from the Canadian Government for a road between the Soo and Missanabi and the connecting branch from Michipicoten to Dalton, has secured the local stock in the old Hudson Bay and Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company, thereby acquiring its charter and privileges.

Margaret Ott, a six-year-old girl, fell under a northbound Lexington Avenue car last night near One Hundred and Eleventh Street, and was instantly killed. For fully fifteen minutes the child's body remained under the wheels, but the car was finally lifted by a wrecking machine. A crowd of several hundred persons had collected in the meantime, and traffic on the avenue was completely blocked.

-- According to an almost incredible report, the waiters of Paris are organizing for a general crusade against the tip system, and the substitution for it of wages paid in the regular way. The waiters say, or at least are said to say, that they are tired of being beggars, of getting alms instead of pay, and that they aspire to rise to the plane of respected and self-respecting workingmen.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 2 -- Returns up to 11 o'clock to-night show that the State is safely Democratic by at least 40,000 majority, possibly 50,000. The vote polled is one of the heaviest ever known in the history of the State. Out of ninety-six counties in the State, it is estimated that seventy will give safe Democratic majorities.

LONDON. Aug. 3 -- In the House of Commons yesterday, replying to a query by Sir Ellis Ashmead Bartlett, as to whether the forces of Great Britain and Japan were prepared to advance in strength on Peking, and as to who is commanding the allies, Mr. St. John Brodrick said he had no fresh information to communicate.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The National Zeitung, in a leading article on "America in China," says:

Policeman Thomas J. Monday had a hard chase after a pickpocket yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. He was at the corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, where the transfers from car to car are given. A crowded car came along from the east and stopped. Among the passengers who got off was Louis H. Peavy, a retired merchant of 1,182 Madison Avenue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 2 -- The free-for-all trot for stallions was the principal event on the card to-day, and it attracted a crowd of fully 8,000 people. The weather was fair and the track fast. There were four starters in the big trot -- Cresceus, Grattan Boy, Charley Herr, and Dare Devil.

A climax was reached last night in the struggle for supremacy between James W. Boyle, the present Tammany leader of the Seventh Assembly District, and Patrick H. Keahon, whom the dissatisfied members of the organization have chosen as leader, and after whom they have named their association.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @ 62 1/2. There were no sales.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Negotiations between the United States and China have been closed unless the terms laid down by the State Department are accepted in full. The department has made public the following correspondence between Li-Hung-Chang and Secretary Hay regarding the abandonment of the advance to Peking asked for by Li:

Justice Smith has banded down a decision finding for the plaintiff in the long-pending suit of May Thorne Brantingham against Eunice E. Huff, over the will of Joseph Thorne, an inventor of improvements in typesetting and sewing machines. Mr. Thorne died on May 4, 1897. His wife had died only eleven days before, May Thorne was an adopted daughter.

Two Brooklyn papers, the Eagle and Standard-Union, refused yesterday to accept the regular election notices showing what offices are to be filled this Fall and sent out by the Secretary of State under the provisions of the election law, on the ground that last year's bills have not been paid.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- This was the last day of the horse racing at New Paltz. In each of the two races the favorites won, although in the second race Elmer D.'s claim to first money was sharply contested. Summaries:

The recent cool weather has revived interest in all outdoor sports at the different resorts, and beginning with to-day there are golf and tennis matches, impromptu yacht racing, and entertainments of various kinds at many of the seaside and mountain places. James J. Van Alen gives a garden party at Newport, and tennis and golf matches will be among the attractions there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see in THE NEW YORK TIMES letters from intelligent correspondents who cite particular forms of attack against Bryan and compare them with what was said against Jefferson. Nothing can be so ridiculous as the comparison of Bryan to Jefferson, or the pretense that because Jefferson was abused violently the attacks upon Bryan should now be disregarded.

The market for outside securities continued quiet and steady yesterday. The general absence of stocks kept prices strong, Copper and transportation issues were traded. in and either remained steady or scored advances.

Forty-seven entries for the annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, which will be sailed to-morrow off Greenwich, Conn., have already been received by Chairman Frank Bowne Jones. The list includes many of the best-known racing yachts, and also a number which have not appeared in previous regattas this year.

NEWPORT. Aug. 2 -- Miss Leary gave her first at-home in several seasons at her cottage this afternoon. It was a brilliant gathering, and during the afternoon Miss Leary had a number of artists for her musicale, which is always included in her at-homes during August. Among the performers were the Misses Kieckhoefer, Heath Gregory, and Mile. De Rohan.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 2. -- Judge Lewis Schenck of the Somerset County Court to-day began the taking of testimony in the efforts of Mrs. Louisa Perrine Miller of this city to show that Winfield Scott Allen, a former wealthy resident of Williamsport, Penn., was Stephen Pangborn, Jr., her father.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Increased attendance and spirited racing marked the second day's sport of the Saratoga Racing Association. The weather was perfect. Matt Byrnes resigned as starter early in the afternoon. The veteran starter, James F. Caldwell, was immediately appointed in his place, and prompt and good starts resulted, the delays at the post being very slight and the jockeys under perfect control.

The report was current in political circles yesterday that the Republican managers have become alarmed because of the feeling against the establishment of the Porto Rico tariff and the growing anti-trust and anti-imperialistic sentiment in the New England States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A telegram has been received at the Treasury Department from Lieut. Jarvis at Cape Nome, Alaska, which indicates that the situation there is improving. The telegram left Nome on July 20, and it was said there had been only three new cases of smallpox since the last report.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners has learned that several large corporations whose franchises are taxable have sent to local Assesors circulars stating that they should deduct from the assessment on real property of corporations the amount of the assessment placed on their franchises by the State Tax Board.

JAMESTOWN, N,D., Aug. 2 -- Bowden, a border town in Wells County, has been the scene of much excitement during the past few weeks. Everything is on a wideopen plan there, and a few citizens who object do not as a rule have their objections sustained. Trouble began upon the arrival of the Rev. Mr. Pettinger, who decided that the town should be reformed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Such steps as the National Government is taking -- toward the detection and arrest of any persons in the United States who may have been connected with the assassination of the late King Humbert were not instituted at the formal request of the Italian Government.
BAR HARBOR, Aug. 2 -- The semi-final round in the mixed foursomes golf tournament to-day at Kebo Valley resulted as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Adolph Lichstern Co., the brokerage firm which has been bitterly fighting the efforts of the Board of Trade to shut out its quotations from their offices, has dismissed its injunction proceedings against the board cutting off quotations, and the board dismissed the cross bill, wherein Lichstern Co. were charged with bucketshopplng operations.

An iron beam 14 feet long, 10 inches square, and weighing 2,000 pounds, which had been placed in position on the eleventh floor of the building now in course of construction at Broadway and Walker Street, was torn from its fastenings by accident at 2:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon, falling a distance of 70 feet.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- At the third day's racing of the Goodwood meeting to-day the Goodwood Cup, for three-year-olds and upward, two miles and a half, was won by Douglas Baird's bay colt Mazagan, by Martagon, out of Maize; J.W. Larnach's bay colt Strong Bow, by Merion, out of La Fleche, was second, and Lord Beresford's bay gelding, Jolly Tar, by The Sailor Prince, out of Joy, ran third, ridden by J. Reiff.

The Post Office Department has opened negotiations with the North Jersey Street Railway Company and the Jersey Ctty, Hoboken and Paterson Street Railway Company for the use of trolley lines for mailcarrying purposes. The mall-wagon service will expire July 1 next.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Gov. Voorhees to-day refused to confirm the report that, in accordance with Ambassador Fava's request, Secretary of State Hay had asked him to set in motion the State's legal powers to investigate the hatching of the plot to kill King Humbert in this State.

QUEENS, L.I., Aug. 2 -- The handsome cup offered as a trophy for the championship wing shot of Long Island and Brooklyn, and which was put up for competition by the Medicus Rod and Gun Club, was won after a hard, battle to-day by "Tom" Morfey. The cup has been shot for at three competitions, Morfey killing twenty-four out of twenty-five birds at each event.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 3 -- The Grand Circuit meeting, which closed to-day, was the most successful ever held under the auspices of the Columbus Driving Association. The track was fast to-day. The Admiral prohibitive favorite, on account of his showing in the 2:10 pace, won the 2:19 pace to-day in straight heats. He was never pushed, and the only contest was between Braden and Daisy J. for place.

The present volume is a collection at personal gossip about all sorts and conditions of men. written in a pleasing manner by one who seems to have had a varied and intimate acquaintance with the celebrities of his age: his recollections possessing a feature common to such class of books -- that is, the touching upon of many little points of interest a more serious biography might have missed.
MONZA, Aug. 3 -- King Victor Emmanuel III has addressed the following proclamation to the Italian people:

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Democrats have realized that their plan to get the German vote for Bryan with the "imperialism" cry is futile, and they are devoting their energies to Alschuler, the Democratic candidate, in the hope that they can split the ticket and elect him, if the State goes Republican.

J.P. Morgan Co. and Baring, Magoun Co. of this city, Kidder, Peabody Co. of Boston, and Drexel Co. of Philadelphia have been authorized to receive subscriptions for the 3 3/4 per cent, three-year exchequer bonds of the British Government to be issued for the new u10,000,000 war loan.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 3 -- In the final polo game of the series for the Rhode Island cups, played this afternoon on the field of the Point Judith Country Club, the Westchester team defeated the Dedham second team by a score of 15 3/4 goals to 10 1/4. The Dedhams had a handicap of 1 goal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The President to-day appointed forty-eight enlisted men in the regular army as Second Lieutenants in that organization, and assigned them to various arms of the service. All the men have excellent service records, and were promoted strictly on merit. They made high averages in their examinations.

The third-rail system on the lines of the Manhattan Railway Company will be in actual operation before Oct. 1. General Superintendent W.E. Baker, who has had charge of the electrical construction and equipment since the change in motive power was decided on, said yesterday that at least one trial train operated by electricity would be run over a section of the Second Avenue line by that date.

A recent writer has claimed that fully 1,000 volumes or pamphlets descriptive of the Waterloo campaign or some phase of it have already appeared in print. At first glance this would appear an exaggerated statement, but a little investigation tends to substantiate the claim. In view of this condition of Waterloo literature the question naturally presents itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The thirty-fifth annual report of the Secret Service Division submitted to Secretary Gage by Chief Wilkie to-day, showing 654 arrests during the year, with 218 convictions, 253 cases awaiting action of the courts, and four fugitives from Justice. Missouri had the largest number of cases, 78, Pennsylvania was second with 63, New York third with 52, Indiana had 51, and Texas 40.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 3 -- A letter received by a local Chinaman by the steamer Glenogle, says Cho-Ta, a reformer who escaped from Peking, gave to the writer the following information from the capital up to June 26:

Cincinnati, like Washington, is disappointed. The census enumerators report that they found but 325,902 population in Cincinnati.
