Cincinnati confidently expected to be told that there were 375,000 people within the municipal limits. The police, school, and health officers' estimates sustained that hope, and the increase of more than 16 per cent in population between 1880 and 1890 led the statisticians of the press to predict an increase of at least 15 per cent.

This is the title of an article in the current number of The Independent by the President of Lafayette College, situated at Easton, Penn. The article is ably and carefully written: it is marked by much good sense and candor; it is in some regards sound, and there is in it a touch of unconscious pathos.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 -- The first day's international race for the Seawanhaka Cup between the American challenger Minnesota or the White Bear Club, St. Paul, Minn., and the Canadian defender Red Coat came off on Lake St. Louis to-day, and resulted in an easy win for the Canadian boat by 6 minutes and 20 seconds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of "T.H.H." about cranks being allowed to come to this country without restriction, and which you publish in today's TIMES, exhibits a feeling prevalent among many in this country and one which must be deprecated by a believer in a democratic Government.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Charles T. Vail, Postmaster at Valley Station, who is confined to the home of M.B. Smalley at Dunellen as a result of being thrown from a trolley car at Dunellen last week, received word this morning that his mill and store at Valley Station had been destroyed by fire.

CHE-FOO, July 29, via Shanghai, Aug. 2 -- Public opinion and the foreign press at the treaty ports are alarmed at the possibility that the Chinese will prevail upon the powers to consent to the establishment of peace without inflicting punishment befitting the Chinese Government's crime.

"Things Chinese " is the most opportune of books. The volume is written by an Englishman in the civil service, who has lived almost a lifetime in China. The author gives a cool and dispassionate view of China and Chinamen. Having been so long in close contact with the Far Kast, he has made a complete study of his surroundings.

Assistant Sanitary Inspector R.A. Block of the Brooklyn Health Department yesterday visited Coney Island, and after inspecting the buildings on Tilyou's Walk, made a report concurring in Inspector William H. Tighe's report, filed some days ago, in which he stated that the condition of certain building's on the walk was dangerous to health.

During the auction season of 1899-1900 that has just ended in London, (the last sale here was on June 22,) sixty-four books realized $500 or more each. The following is a list of these books, the items being placed in order of money value:

In accordance with his oft-repeated wish, and after having told of a premonition of death. J.H. Gittings died some time early yesterday, between 1 in the morning and daylight. The police believe that he committed suicide, but physicians, after a cursory examination of the body, think he died from disease of the heart, caused by intense grief at the loss of his wile.

Yesterday's stock market differed litle from the market of lately preceding Says, except that in a few instances the professional operators became somewhat more aggressive, and for that reason were more successful in forcing prices higher. The market, however, was one of specialties, only five stocks in the list crossing the 10,000 mark and contributing together more than one-half of the entire market transactions.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- August Belmont's seventy-footer Mineola and Cord Meyer's sloop Altair were launched to-day from the marine railway at the Hawkins yards, after having their underbodies smoothed and repainted and otherwise prepared for the New York Yacht Club cruise.

VIENNA, July 5 -- As we walk through the long galleries of sculptures in foreign museums, sooner or later we become haunted, not so much with the completed and the perfect beauty in them as by the broken masterpieces, tho torsi. In so striking a number of instances the highest thought, the ripest energy of the sculptor seem to have been condensed on precisely what is left half done or else shattered.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- At the meeting of the Cabinet this morning, it was announced that the would be assassin of Mouzaffered-dine, Shah, of Persia, had given his name as Salson. A man of this name who had been regarded and watched as an Anarchist disappeared from Paris in 1895 and had not since been located.

Detective Sergeant Carey of the Central Office yesterday morning arraigned in Jefferson Market Court, before Magistrate Pool, John L. Dunlap, who is doing business at 73 West Eleventh Street, under the firm name of the Local Credit Company. He also has an office in the Syndicate Building on Park Row.

The Countess de Chavanne dedicates her story to "The Young Women of America," and the subtitle of the romance being "American Gold Regilding the Coronets of Europe," "Ouirda" is to be considered in the light of a caution. There are your Counts and the Marquises all in a line.

A new Roman Catholic Church, situated in a quite new parish, will be used for the first time to-morrow. A year and a half ago Archbishop Corrigan decided upon the planting of a new parish church on the west side half way between the Blessed Sacrament, at Broadway and Seventy-first Street, and the Holy Name, at Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street.

Gen. E.A. McAlpin, Treasurer of the Republican State Committee, which has recently sent out begging letters to the Federal employes in this city, was asked yesterday if he knew where the committee secured the house addresses of the men. Gen. McAlpin, the day before, was asked the same question at his factory in Avenue D. but refused to give an answer, saying that he never talked politics at his place of business during business hours.

TIEN-TSIN, July 25. via Shanghai, Aug. 2 -- The events at Peking, which might be expected to cast a shadow over the allied forces, are seemingly but slightly regarded here. High officers are entertaining nightly at elaborate dinners, with military bands playing operatic airs.

In publishing the separate volumes of his series on "Comparative Aesthetics," Prof. Raymond has deliberately put the cart before the horse to the extent of reserving the second volume of the series (in the order of ultimate arrangement) until the end. This is the volume just now published, and the reason for withholding it five or six years is explained in the preface with more than usual candor.

In the Tenderloin saloon known to Italians and negroes as "The Black Dago," 142 West Twenty-seventh Street, William Simmons, a negro waiter on a Bridgeport boat, was mortally wounded by Arazia Arlotea, a bartender in the place, yesterday. Simmons's wife had left him some time ago, taking their baby to live with her in rooms over the saloon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The North Atlantic Squadron is at Portland Me.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Police Capt. Hermann Schuettier, who helped to suppress the Anarchists in this city in 1886, is traveling in Germany, and, according to advices received here to-day, he has been requested by officials of foreign Governments to assist in breaking down the activity of European Anarchist organizations and to hunt down the conspirators against monarchs.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 3 -- Charles J. Cannon, a prominent citizen and local politician, who was also State Oyster Inspector for this district, was shot and killed on the street by Assistant Chief of Police M.H. Prince shortly before noon to-day. No cause for the deed is assigned by Capt. Prince or his friends, and the killing is a mystery.

The Fleming H. Revell Company will shortly issue an elaborately decorated edition of "The Psalms of David," with illustrations and text decorations, by Louis Rhead, who, with his brother, so well caught the meaning of Bunyan'a texts. The introduction will be by Newell Dwight Hillis.

James P. Keating, Commissioner of the Department of Highways, acting on the decision that he had Jurisdiction in the matter of the encroachment on the sidewalk by the portico and inclosed balcony in front of the Pabst Hotel, caused the following peremptory notice to be served on its proprietor:

LONDON, July 26 -- As I predicted, the avalanche of Chinese books is upon us. Every publisher who has a book relating, even remotely, to China upon his shelves has dusted it and is now busily advertising it. The list is already a long one and it includes all sorts and conditions of books, from the valuable if not always readable works written by missionaries, to the latest novel in which a Chinaman appears.

The author of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden" and "A Solitary Summer" some time ago wrote to her London publishers that she had been so encouraged by the reception of the former book that she would cheerfully comply with their request to add several new pages, in fact a quarter more than appeared in the first edition.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 3 -- Of the eight witnesses introduced by the defense in the Powers case to-day, all but one were called for the purpose of attacking the credibility of witnesses placed on the stand by the prosecution. One of these, ex-State Auditor Stone, stated that Witness W.H. Culton, an alleged co-conspirator of Powers, was removed from a place of trust in his office because he defaulted in the sum of 81,000.

A runaway horse created temporary excitement yesterday afternoon on Madison Avenue and had the right of way for several blocks. The animal, which is owned by George Hogan of 426 West Fourteenth Street, was standing hitched to a light wagon, which had no occupant, near the corner of Forty-fifth Street.
It was a quiet day at Republican National Headquarters yesterday. Senator Hanna was one of the earliest arrivals. He received two visits from State Chairman Odell.

Men with guns have been sleeping on a number of the yachts of the Greenville Yacht Club since last Wednesday night, when thieves went through the fleet of yachts anchored in the bay off the foot of Linden Avenue, Jersey City. The boat to suffer most was the flagship of the fleet, the yacht Louisa L., owned by Commodore Charles J. Leach.

NEWPORT, Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Ladenburg entertained at dinner last night, and later many of the cottagers dropped in to attend her impromptu musicale, at which Edward Isham, the baritone, and George Devol, the tenor, sang.
Capt. Frederick Wohlfarth of the College Point Precinct rescued two men at the risk ot his own life on Thursday night. When he hauled the men into his boat they were almost unconscious.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 3 -- The Circuit Court has issued a writ of attachment against Lewis G. Tewksbury and Alexander M. Loury, on the application of W. Browning Johnson of 29 West Forty-ninth Street, New York City, who claims the defendants owe him $12,472. He wants to seize in payment for his claim the pacer Lewis G., that belonged to Tewksbury, which is now at the Fairburn farm near Westfield.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: From the several communications sent you as to the authorship or even evidence of such a person as "Ned Myers," the writer was not far wrong when he sent to The Bookman published in the number for July, 1898 an article entitled, "A Bit of Forgotten Naval History by Fenlmore Cooper."
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your controversy with Mr. Schurz regarding the "infamy" of the Philippine situation, it seems to me that you unjustly depreciate Mr. Schurz's argument.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of July 28 W. H. Farrington asks why "Ned Myers" was not included in the Darley edition of Cooper's works. The reason for this omission seems plain -- "Ned Myers" is a biography, and would therefore be out of place in a set of novels.

Mr. Paul Nathan of the Lotus press has just completed a book which treats the practical side of printing in so thorough a manner thai it presents a strong claim to the attention of the master printers, as does Mr. Theodore De Vinne's recent book on the artistic aspects of typography. Taken together these two books should prove simply invaluable to printers throughout the country.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 3 -- James E. Boyd, the only Democratic Governor Nebraska, ever had, is radically opposed to several of the Bryanites' doctrines. To-day ex-Gov. Boyd, who has been a member of the Democratic National Committee from Nebraska and always stood high in the party councils, in an interview said:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "Woods and Waters," a volume of verse by Mr. Rufus J. Childress of Louisville, Ky., is interesting not only for the quality of the verse, but for the personality of the author and on account of the obstacles he has been compelled to overcome in following his natural bent.
SAMUEL WILL JOHN, Birmingham, Ala., writes: "In your issue of July 21st you condemn in strong terms The London Academy for allowing John Paul Jones to be called a pirate in its columns, and say:

The personality of Robert Browning presents so many varying aspects that it could be truthfully said that to know the man Robert Browning would be to know philosopher, poet, philanthropist, scholar, and musician.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- George E. Roberts, the Director of the Mint, in speaking to-day of the probable modification of the present estimate of the stock of gold in the country said:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The State Department to-day issued the following:

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., Aug. 3 -- A forest fire at Sopp's Arm, White Bay, has destroyed a large sawmill, several million feet of lumber, and a settlement of 120 houses. The whole place was wiped out. A schooner that happened to be landing coal for the use of mail steamers took the residents to a place of safety.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- In response to questions, the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, said to-day, in the House of Commons, that the Boer Governments, in fleeing from Bloemfontein and Pretoria, left masses of private correspondence among the archives, which the authorities on the spot were examining.
According to United States Consul General Goodnow at Shanghai, Li-Hung-Chang told the French Consul that because the foreigners were advancing on Peking no messages would be delivered to the envoys.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- There was a let-up to-day in Linseed, little appearing in the market. The common brought 11 1/2 and the preferred 55 5/8. Metropolitan Elevated common sold at 31 and the preferred at 79. The bonds fetched 97. Northwestern Elevated preferred sold at 64 1/4. There was some demand for Biscuit common at 30 3/4@31 1/4.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 3 -- A novel attraction for Bar Harbor was an entertainment given in the Louisburg parlors this evening by society women staying there. A little French comedy was acted by the younger people. Mrs. Hoffman-Chapman sang several songs, and Mrs. Charles Whelen played a selection.

Thomas W. Lawson, among the half dozen of the richest men in America, known in the world of finance as the Copper King, gave to The Journal the history of the copper development in this country, and for the first time, as he said, he gave the true version of his purchase of a flower for $30,000 that became known as the "Mrs. Lawson pink."

The following congratulatory messages from President McKinley and the King of Portugal were flashed direct, to-day, between the United States and Portugal, over the new line of the Commercial Cable Company, which has just been put in operation between the Azores and this country:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 3 -- Mark Lynch of Halifax defeated Erastus Rogers of Worcester, Mass., on Bedford Basin this afternoon in a three-mile sculling race for $300 a side. The match was rowed in fairly smooth water, and was witnessed by a great crowd. Betting on the result before the race was even.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Boston had a good market what there was of it. The firmer tone in mining stocks, noted yesterday, continued, and several specialties gained well. Montana advanced 6, to 306; Isle Royale, 1, to 28; Osceola, 1 1/8, to 67 3/8; Arcadian, 1 1/2, to 21 1/2; Baltic, 1/2, to 20 3/4. Butte sold at 65 for an odd lot.

The social diversions to-day and this evening are quite numerous. Southampton, in its way, has had more than the usual number allotted to it. Mrs. Jules Reynal's large dinner last evening, the dance at the Meadow Club, and the pony races there to-day have attracted many of the men from town.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Walter D. Tyler, a prominent citizen of this city, lies unconscious, in the City Hospital, as a result of a blow on the neck struck by Loveland Miller, Jr., this afternoon. Tyler's condition is critical and doctors fear he cannot recover.

-- Considering the very large amount of grief that has been inflicted upon the antiimperialists by recent happenings in the Philippines, one can hardly begrudge them the intense and long-continued satisfaction they are getting out of the now widely advertised incident at Oroquieta, a little town in Mindanao.

There is a chance that hate will reveal much to the authorities relative to the alleged plotting of the Anarchists at Paterson to kill the crowned heads of Europe. Last night in a saloon in Straight Street, Paterson, an Italian whose name does not appear to be known to the proprietor of the place said he knew of a meeting held in that city early in May, of which he intended to inform the authorities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Nathaniel J. Brown, one of the oldest business men of Chicago and a pioneer lumberman, canal builder, quarryman, and land speculator of the Middle Western States, is dead, at the age of eighty-eight years, at the old Brown homestead, in Lemont. He was born in Windsor, Vt., in 1812.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Representative James D. Richardson, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, arrived at headquarters to-day and took chargre. The Democrats are already receiving many reports from the Middle West and are fairly busy. Some optimistic reports are received from local leaders in Illinois, mostly to the effect that the bolters of 1896 are back in the fold.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Elizabeth, of blessed English memory, was probably one of the most picturesque monarchs that ever wielded sceptre. To describe her character would exhaust the description of all female, and most male, characters. A storage battery of lively inconsistencies, she was true only to her real character of a lightning change artist in all other characters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The laws governing the use of the streets and sidewalks of this city absolutely prohibit their occupation for any purposes whatever excepting for the sale (within prescribed limits, the so-called area or stoop-line.) of fruit, soda water, newspapers and periodicals, and the occupation of onethird of the street from the curb outward by building material in front of a house or houses undergoing repairs.

CHE-FOO, July 29 -- A cable is being laid between Che-Foo and Taku. The land line between Che-Foo and Shanghai is managed and operated by Chinamen, and is inefficient. The line is overcrowded with work, and business is in hopeless confusion. Messages over the line are public property. There should be a cable between Che-Foo and Shanghai, managed by foreigners, so as to give satisfactory service.

Let them put Mr. COLER on a pedestal and place a halo around his head as soon as they want to. Mr. COLER is the only man who sought to have a Republican Legislature stamp him as the only honest man in this State. It was not done, however, because the Republican legislators wanted purer gold before stamping it. --

While there is something to criticise in the arrangement and appearance of this catalogue, it will prove, as the first complete list of members, of unique interest. Familiar though one may be with the history of Phi Beta Kappa, one cannot but be struck with the frequency with which he meets the names of men who have achieved success, fame, and even greatness.

What a fine chance Mr. R. Caton Woodville has now for his special work! The three pictures he has to-day on exhibition are "My Brave Irish," at Pieter's Hill; "The Dawn of Majuba Day, 1900." Pardeberg, and "A Chip of the Old Block," Elandslaagte. When an artist of the present paints a purely military picture, it is by no means so free and easy-going a work as some would suppose.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- The form players had a rough time of it to-day at the Saratoga track, not a single favorite passing the winning ost. The feature of the day was the Worden Stakes, a selling affair for two-year-old fillies. Six competed, with the Missouri filly in Shot, owned and bred by Barney Schreiber, equal favorite with John F. Schorr's Lady Schorr, at 8 to 5.

The growing scarcity of the original edition of "Warren's Guide" insures the enthusiastic reception of the present reprint, for there is no one interested in the subject of book plates to whom Lord de Tabley's volume does not appeal. There is always a kind of veneration for a pioneer, and especially when the pioneer turns out to be a master, as is the case with Warren.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Ex-Representative William D. Bynum of Indiana, who was Chairman of the Gold Democratic National Committee in 1896, said to-day: | "While the Republican Party has the better chance to carry Indiana, the vote will be very close, in fact so close that the result may be determined by the smallest circumstance.

The annual meeting of the Ex Libris Society, which has on its rolls so many American members, was held at the Westminster Palace Hotel, in London, June 27, a dinner and social evening finishing the day. There were several changes in, the Council, but the Secretary, Mr. W.H. K. Wright of Plymouth, and the Treasurer, Mr. J.T. Armstrong of London, were re-elected.

According to a statement made last night by Capt. Thomas of the Tenderloin Precinct, the fight upon Ackron's Tivoli has resulted in the surrender of Ackron. There was a rumor about the Tenderloin that O'Connor, the manager of the dive, had surrendered his license last evening on the telephoned orders of Ackron.

The Right Hon. Sir George Goldie reached Liverpool by the steamship Majestic, on his return from China, where he has traveled for several months in the interior. Replying to an inquiry whether his visit had enabled him to form any definite idea as to the best way of dealing with the Chinese question generally, he said:

The nomination of Bird S. Coler for Governor is much more than a possibility. Many visitors at Democratic State headquarters yesterday discussed the matter with Executive Chairman McGuire, but none of them would speak for publication.

These must be discouraging days for Prof. Brander Matthews. He it was who once wrote a fascinating essay on the nature and purpose of the short story. He declared that there was a special brand of the article, which in order to differentiate it from the story simply short, he called the "short-story."

The voters of North Carolina have ratified the amendment to the State Constitution limiting the right of suffrage, apparently by a large majority. It is stated that the negroes in the State took but little interest in the election, and even that some of them voted in favor of the amendment, which was openly declared to be intended to abridge and largely destroy their right to vote.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 3 -- Considerable encouragement has been given to the social season here by the energy and gayety of a large contingent of New Yorkers at the Louisburg. Society seems more lively there this season than ever. This morning Charles Williams, a well-known reader, gave an entertainment in the parlors which attracted a crowd at society people.

Two very interesting articles appear in the current issue of The Open Court, Dr. Paul Carus, editor, (Chicago.) One is a valuable historical paper, well illustrated, also prepared by Dr. Ernst Krause of Berlin, (who has written much for this periodical over the pen name of "Carus Sternel.''

One of the worst features of the habit of early rising is that those addicted to the habit are peculiarly liable to the sin of self-righteousness. They assume that they are the superiors in virtue to those who sleep longer. We have observed the same tendency in those who for one reason or another do not take a vacation.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 4 -- A hearty welcome was given A.E. Stevenson on his arrival here at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon. A big crowd gathered at the Union Station. Carriages carried the party of the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, who has returned from Minnesota to prepare for the campaign, to Franklin Square, where, just across the street from the Stevenson home, was the speakers' stand.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 4 -- News of the lynching of a negro by a mob of his own color near Bayou Vidal, La., has reached this place. Thursday night a well-to-do negro farmer was murdered and his body sunk in the bayou. Suspicion pointed to a strange negro who was seen hanging around the neighborhood.

The bank statement issued yesterday shortly before the close of business made a favorable showing, but not so favorable as had generally been expected. Instead of a predicted increase in surplus, reserve of $5,000,000 the gain was $1,608,900. Specie increased $2,188,900, and legal tenders $1,080,200, while loans increased $2,596,200, and deposits $6,640,800.

Gen. Jacob Dolson Cox, who served one term as Governor of Ohio and was Secretary of the Interior under Gen. Grant, died yesterday at Magnolia, Mass. Gen. Cox was born in Canada, in 1828, although his parents were natives of the United States who were in Canada at the time of his birth.
"And did you finally become accustomed to the oil and garlic of Porto Rican cooking?" asked a New Yorker of the newly arrived young teacher from one of the Government schools on the island.

The number of international marriages -- that is, marriages between rich American girls and titled Europeans -- is annually increasing. Some oppose these marriages because, they say, Americans make better husbands than foreigners. They contend that American girls who marry foreign husbands thereby cast a slight upon American men.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The programme finished by the race meet of the Schenectady Racing Association at the Driving Park to-day was the best that has ever been presented in this section. Some of the best-known riders in the upper portion of the State participated, and the events were well contested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A statement prepared by Mr. Chamberlain, the Commissioner of Navigation, shows that the tonnage tax collections during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1900, amounted to $890,482, compared with $834,087 for the previous fiscal year. The collections are the largest for any year since 1884, when these taxes were reduced to rates below those charged by the principal European nations.

The annual outing and field day of the Berkshire Historical and Scientific Society was held in Lenox on the north shore of Stockbridge Bowl on Thursday, Aug. 2. The gathering was on the land of Charles Bullard of Boston in a fine grove of maples, beneath the high slope on which stood, until 1890, the "Little Red House," where Nathaniel Hawthorne lived and wrote from 1850 to 1852.
Louis Zeltenstein of 123 Debevoise Street is lying in a critical condition at his home as a result of a blow on the head, said to have been inflicted by an unknown young man.
RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The Spring Lake and Red Bank golf teams played a game here this afternoon, the former winning. The players and their scores were:

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Londoners have been reveling this week in their first experience with modern rapid transit as furnished by the new Central London Electric Underground System --" the twopenny tube," as some of the papers call it. Eighty thousand persons have daily learned for the first time that it is no longer necessary to waste two hours on an omnibus in order to reside five or six miles from their places of business.

HAVANA. Aug. 4 -- Troops are being ordered from the Provinces of Pinar del Rio and Havana to concentrate in the suburbs of this city. Four hundred men of the Seventh Cavalry are now en route to the rendezvous. In the future no militia will occupy either province.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 31st ult., under the heading of "Bressi's Deed," you speak of the assassination of King Humbert and incidentally create a very wrong impression. After speaking of the criminal instinct in man, you give voice to the following, "The grerms of suggestion are abundantly supplied by the preachings and teachings of Anarchy and its Siamese twin sister, Socialism."

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Aug. 4 -- A tornado, accompanied by a terrific hail and rain storm, started near Thompson, N.D., at 7 o'clock this morning, and swept to the northwest through a rich farming country and many thriving settlements, across into Minnesota, where it spent its fury in the Red Lake Indian Reservation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There seems to be a good deal of mist encircling the important political questions now under discussion -- the paramount question with the large body of people who are opposed to the actions and platforms of the two great parties claiming their support, being the choice between two evils.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Three weeks' yacht racing began in the Solent to-day. Despite the season of mourning in Court circles, the Prince of Wales has promised to appear at Cowes next week.

BERLIN, July 18 -- The Militaer Wochenblatt, the leading military journal, publishes a review of the military strength of the Chinese Empire, and comes to the conclusion that the field troops, without the Bannermen and Green Flags, number about 250,000 men, of whom about one-third have been stationed at garrisons in the provinces of Chi-li and Shan-Tung.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- It has been quite a dull week, but Lenox is never very gay in midsummer. There is the usual amount of driving and golf and house parties, and dinners and luncheons are also among the fashionable events. The picnic given by John E. Parsons to the Prince and Princess Brancaccio was the one leading affair of the week.

LORENZO MARQUES, June 18 -- Just prior to the entry of Lord Roberts into Pretoria the city was in a state of turmoil unprecedented even in the several crises through which it has passed, and its falling so easy a prey to Lord Roberts and his host was no doubt mainly due to the utter confusion that prevailed in the town for the week or two previous.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Those who have always hoped have triumphed about China, and it is wonderful now to find what numbers of people have all along been confident that the Chinese would not slay their European guests. Evidently, however, the rebels and such of the regular troops as sympathize with them came very near murdering the whole colony.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter to THE TIMES this morning, Mr. Anderson Price sets out to compare our Philippine policy with that of England in the Transvaal, and reaches an imaginary parallel between our relations to Aguinaldo and those of France to Washington during our Revolution.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- James Lawrence, son of Mrs. J.G.K. Lawrence, and George Dixon, son of Dr. George A. Dixon, were badly injured yesterday during the pony and gymkhana races given by the Southampton (L.I.) Horse Association. The accident was caused by several horses bolting in the saddling races, and they went roughshod over the crowd before being checked.

The market for outside securities was quiet and generally strong in the absence of stocks. Copper issues were conspicuous again, the general belief that the demand for copper will increase being held to closely. The trading was mostly professional in character.

A monument to Catawba Indians who served in the Confederate Army was dedicated at Fort Mill, S.C., on Tuesday, July 31. The monument was erected by Col. Samuel E. White and Mr. John M. Spratt. In the park in which the monument stands is another to Confederate soldiers, erected by Col. White and others of Fort Mill.

The Covent Garden Syndicate will spend $75,000 next Winter in remodeling the stage of the house. A similar enterprise might be undertaken at the Metropolitan at a smaller expense, but with desirable results.

One of the first and most noticeable problems confronting the powers when they set about the work of reconstruction in China will be the missionary difficulty. Some of the most attractive ornaments of the Newport villa of a well-known young New York matron are old pieces of Russian brass, iron, and copper, of which she purchased a number in a Russian shop in New York. Among these is a quaint pair of andirons, three feet in height, hammered out by hand, as all Russian metal work is.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is none of our National business what becomes of the Philippines. We should immediately announce to the world our intention hereafter to mind our own business exclusively by recognizing the folly of continuing the war in these Asiatic islands. We should then quit them at once by withdrawing our troops as fast as our transports can take them away, retaining, at most, a coaling station.

HONOLULU, July 10 -- Forecast of a school plan for the Philippines is made possible from this distance by the presence here of F.W. Atkinson, on his way to Manila to assume the duties of Superintendent of Instruction. From the time that the appointment was suggested to him from Washington, early in the Spring, Mr. Atkinson's thought has naturally dwelt on his work, and he has devoted himself to a study of it.

One might roam the country over in search of the melancholy for days and weeks and yet it is doubtful if he would find a life tragedy fuller of pathos, more deeply sad, than that of the brilliant wit, good fellow, and funmaker Charles H. Hoyt.

MONTREAL, Canada, Aug. 4 -- The second day's international race between the White Bear Yacht Club's challenger and the Canadian defender Red Coat for the Seawanhaka Cup on Lake St. Louis to-day was declared off at 6 o'clock, when it was seen that it would be impossible to finish within the time limit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Albion W. Tourgee, United States Consul at Bordeaux, France, in a report to the State Department, records two very significant statemen's regarding economic conditions in France attributed to the Minister of Agriculture and the Minister of Public Works of the republic.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The result of the recent international sports in France has been a suggestion that a permanent international society of athletics be formed. It is argued that cycling is the only sport that has an organization of this character, and that such a society, as proposed, would do much in spreading interest in athletic games.
A big list of cricket matches was brought off yesterday at Prospect Park, and a large crowd of spectators was attracted to the Parade Ground to witness the sport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The news of the death of one of the foremost Filipinos has just been received. He belonged to a class which those who call themselves anti-imperialists fail to take into account. Mr. Ramon Aenlle was the owner of one of the large cigar fabricos in Manila, employing thousands of workpeople.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 4 -- With the first days of August comes the floodtide of gayety at Narragansett. The Casino has been the centre of attraction. There is not a day that there are not at least a dozen or more parties from Newport, who come over to luncheon or to dinner, and mingled with these are the many sojourners at the various hotels and cottages.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Mid-summer week, the first in August, always witnesses a curious change at Long Branch. Many of the cottagers and hotel guests who have been here during the first part of the season go to the mountains, and each boat and train is filled with departing travelers.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 4 -- Social events centred about the Kebo Club to-day. The handicaps in the morning drew a large crowd of the fair sex, who watched the playing from the piazzas. The ladles' putting match in the afternoon recalled the palmy days of the old club in the size of the crowd of society people and the gayety and delightfulness of the event.

Their rebellion has been a failure, and now therefore they do for all essential purposes 'consent.'"

England's military power looms up before the world in vaster proportions than ever before. Her basis of military strength is not only the forty millions of population of the British Isles, but the large and rapidly increasing population of Canada, Australia, and New Zealand; and India affords a recruiting ground among its warlike tribes for millions of men, if necessary, to be mustered into the British service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Some features of the dispatch received from Gen. Chaffee yesterday, which the War Department refused to make public, became known today. The first dispatch received by the War Department from Gen. Chaffee contained very little information, but closed with the statement that he was going forward to Tien-Tsin and would give his views.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $1,608,900. The banks now hold a surplus of $29,144,878 above the legal requirements.

MALOJA, in the Engadine, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -- G.P. Way and his son and thirteen other Americans, accompanied by Mr. De la Rue, an Englishman, climbed the Cimadirosso without a guide yesterday.

The traveling sidewalk at the Paris Exposition, while by no means new in conception, is here carried out on a far larger scale than ever before attempted. Extending for a length of 3.4 kilometers around, the quadrilateral formed by the Rue Fabert, the Quai d'Orsay, the Avenue de la Bourdonnais.

COBURG, Aug. 4 -- Emperor William arrived here at 11:30 A.M. to attend the funeral of the Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha. He was given an ovation by dense crowds awaiting him at all points along the route.
Chicago's Postmaster is very proud of the "tremendous" business done by his office. The total for July was $476,940.80, an increase of $100,748.78 over 1898, and of $55,338.46 over last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The Republicans of the Twenty-second Senatorial District, which comprises the whole of Waestchester County, held their convention to-day in the Orawaupum House.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 4 -- Reuben Miller, chief clerk of Caleb Powers while he acted as Secretary of State, was the chief witness in the Powers trial to-day. He expressed the belief that the shot which killed Goebel was fired, as were those which followed it, outside the Executive Building.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 7 -- New Zealand was the first country in the World to introduce a system of State pensions for its old and needy people -- that is to say, every man and woman who has attained the age of sixty-five years and has resided for twenty-five years in the colony is entitled to a pension of 6s. 11d. per week.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4 -- The first dinner dance of the season was given this evening by Mrs. Isaac Bell, Jr., in honor of her daughters, the Misses Bell. A number of original and delightful features were introduced, and about one hundred of the cottagers were present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Which one of the many unwise and un-Democratic planks of the Kansas City platform is the most objectionable depends somewhat upon the point of view of each observer.

The Crescent Athletic Club baseball, team completed its Amateur League schedule yesterday afternoon at Travers Island, where it beat the New York Athletic Club green-diamond warriors by a score of 7 to 4. The Crescent victory made it impossible for any Amateur League rivals to wrest the championship from the Bay Ridge players.

An erstwhile New York girl who is now in the city says this is the most peculiar Summer of her existence. She may be said to be enjoying the pleasures of domestic life though a bachelor. The young woman is a bachelor girl who has trials of her own, largely due to her being a most attractive bachelor maiden.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4. -- In the weekly handicap tournament played on the links of the Newport Golf Club this afternoon, two new players came to the front and won handsome cups subscribed for by the members of the club.

The 500 shirtwaist makers who struck on Friday in the factory of Floersheimer, Romal Co., in Wooster Street, met yesterday morning in a hall in Spring Street and organized as the Shirtwaist Makers' Union. Most of the strikers were women and girls. They elected Fanny Bergman as Secretary, and also appointed twenty girls to picket the factory.

SORRENTO, Me., Aug. 4 -- "The most successful season Sorrento ever enjoyed " is the universal tribute those who have been here longest say of the present Summer. The hotel is filled with guests, not a cottage is to be had, and a daily round of amusements testifies to the activity of the Summer residents and the vitality of the resort.
BRISTOL, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The work of repairing and strengthening the hulls of the seventy-footers preparatory to the annual cruise of the New York Yacht Club has been going on here all week.

In the recently issued report for 1899 of the American Iron and Steel Association, Mr. James M. Swank, the Secretary, explains that undoubtedly the great increase in the last few years in the world's supply of gold and its conversion into a circulating medium must be credited with a stimulating effect upon business generally in all progressive countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- B. F. Keith has purchased a portion of the Baldwin property, on the south side of Chestnut Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, for the purpose of erecting a million-dollar theatre. The owners of the estate were John M. Stafford and Anthony M. Zane.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since I want a thoroughgoing McKinley newspaper, I have decided to renew my subscription to your valuable sheet. You make the ablest apologies for and, the most plausible defense of the Administration of any paper that comes under my notice. The advantages of knowing the best that can be said for a bad cause are manifest.

The bronze drinking fountain given to Topeka by the Rev. Charles Sheldon is now in place at a populous city corner, where the thirsty passer-by can quench a desire for water at all hours of the day or night. This charitable donation of the respected pastor certainly contributes much comfort to the shoppers, passers-by, and those compelled to wait for street cars at the transfer station.

PARIS, July 24 -- The exposition would not be complete without a wizard. As a matter of fact, it has two, both of whom are quite amazing. This should be a matter of satisfaction to that very large contingent of American ladies to whom all that concerns the mysterious "Beyond" and the practice of the black arts is of fascinating importance.

"When a guest of mine says 'It's raining,' it's raining," declared a well-known New Orleans caterer, talking about the hotel and restaurant business. "If he says 'It's snowing,' it's snowing. I never allow any of my employes to contradict a customer upon any subject whatsoever.

The largest crowd that ever gathered on the Brighton Beach race track witnessed and cheered the victory of Perry Belmont's great colt Ethelbert in the Brighton Cup race yesterday, and cheered again the performance when the time was hung out, establishing a new world's record for a cup course -- two miles and a quarter.

In a small town not far from New York, recently, one of the natives was in a store, shopping. As she waited for her change there entered a finely dressed woman, with a general appearance of wealth and patrician origin. Many of the residents of the town are people of wealth, and Summer visitors are usually persons of money and position.

There were two horse shows in the neighborhood of New York last week, both very pretty. The suburban shows held during the Summer months are necessarily small and chiefly local. Several attempts have indeed been made to have in the neighborhood of New York an open-air show that should correspond in importance with the Autumn show in Madison Square Garden.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The embarkation day reunion of the Knights of Columbus, commemorating the embarkation of Christopher Columbus from the Port of Palos, Spain, Aug. 3, 1492, was continued to-day. Solemn high mass was celebrated in the Church of Our Lady of the Sea, the Rev. T.P. Carroll of Newark, N.J., State Chaplain of the Knights of Columbus, being the celebrant.

According to a men who is in close touch with college sports, the discovery has been made that rowing is not good for football players, that the two sports do not fraternize so to speak, and that it is coming to be recognized that the football player can play better football if he lets rowing alone. This is not a rule that works both ways.

City Magistrate Connorton last night said that unless his colleague Healy of Far Rockaway surrendered the sitting at Far Rockaway and all the papers belonging to the court to him on Monday morning he would prefer charges against the Far Rockaway officer and ask that he be removed from the bench.

MUNICH, Aug. 4 -- Play in the International chess tournament was resumed in this city this morning, when the tenth round was begun. The results were as follows: Pillsbury worsted Bardeleben, Berger beat Jakob, Maroczy beat Showalter, Marco and Popiel drew, Schlechter defeated Janowskl, Gottschall vanquished Cohn, while the games between Halprin and Billecard and Wolf and Burn were drawn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Taken in connection with what has preceded them, to-day's cablegrams from China place the Chinese Government in the unique position of denying liability for what the Chinese troops have done at Peking while assuming responsibility for what they are now doing in the neighborhood of Tien-Tsin.

The State Historian, Mr. HUGH HASTINGS, has written to our esteemed contemporary The Sun a letter full of good sense on the subject of sea bathing. As Mr. HASTINGS was for thirty years a Summer resident of the New Jersey coast and a skillful ocean swimmer, his remarks ought to carry weight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The Grand Jury today voted six true bills against Lloyd J. Smith, former manager of the Chicago Elevator Company and member of the Chicago Board of Trade, charging him with fraudulent methods in the management of the elevators. The specific charge was that Smith permitted about 800,000 bushels of grain to be shipped from the elevators without the proper cancellation of the warehouse receipts, which were hypothecated.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The tune of the local Anarchists has greatly changed during the last few days. They are keeping very quiet, and are even inclined to recall what they said earlier in the week. They are getting hazy in their recollections of Malatesta and the others. They know now that the Secret Service agents are at work, and some who were talkative early in the week are almost in a panic now.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your reprint in this morning's issue of an article from The New York Herald with reference to the need of reform in legal advertising suggests to us another branch of the same subject sadly in need of reformation, and which can be improved greatly to the gain of high-class metropolitan newspapers, and still more so to that of the advertisers.

The recent actions of the political conventions of the Republicans and Democrats in Philadelphia and Kansas City appear to make It opportune and appropriate for some notice of a few points of history, and to observe the prospects of the future.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The first sign of the opening of Princeton's football campaign season has been noticed here upon the appearance in town of James Robinson, "Nassau's" football trainer. When interviewed to-day on the prospects of the team, he was rather reticent, but spoke as follows:

"Probably no sport is more unjustly decried as dangerous than small boat sailing," said an expert. "Bicycling, lacrosse, hockey, skating, and football are all recognized as involving more or less risk to heads and limbs, but, in popular opinion, they are tame as compared to the dangers of sailing.

"Aunt Louisa" Eldridge has established a record. Among the flat dwellers of Manhattan she is Grand Prioress, and some day when the dwellers have a reunion she is in line for further honors. Her record consists of having lived for thirty-three years and four months in the same apartment, and in all that long time, while thoughts of moving have come to her now and then, she has dismissed them.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- Newport is at last awake, and the season has begun in earnest. This was perhaps due in a measure to the arrival of Mrs. Astor and the inauguration of her series of weekly dinners. Then followed quickly the visit of Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, and the various entertainments given for them.

A pleasant way of spending Saturday and Sunday is a trip up the Hudson in a small rowboat or canoe, which may be either rowed or paddled, or, if fitted with sails, advantage may be taken of favoring winds which, generally, at this time of the year, blow from the south. With a fifteen to a twenty-foot rowboat accommodations may be had for three men, and a sufficiently large camp outfit to make them comfortable.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 4 -- Late comers at the Asbury Park and Ocean Grove hotels this evening, especially those who had not booked their rooms in advance, were forced to accept makeshift sleeping accommodations -- the makeshift entitling them to slumber on a cot put up in the parlor or corridor.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I hope you will be kind enough to print, in the interest of the truth, which has a terrible enemy in the yellow press of this city, these few remarks:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Sun recently published a letter signed "A Mechanic," and commented upon it editorially. In that letter the writer stated he was a Democrat: that he intended to vote for McKinley, and further stated that fifteen fellow-workingmen who were Democrats would do likewise.
"P-r-r-r-ump," went the car, as, slipping foot by foot, it came to a grudging stop.

NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., Aug. 4 -- To-day Northeast Harbor is probably the most popular resort on Mount Desert. It is now quite a rival of Bar Harbor, and as it is less of a cottagers' resort, it attracts much of the transient travel. There is at Northeast Harbor that absence from the conventions of society which made Bar Harbor so popular some years ago.

ROME, July 21 -- The heat is the one local topic of conversation, but bad as it is -- 91 and 92 in the shade -- the evenings are bearable and the nights really cool. The King and Queen fled yesterday to Monza, and after that are going to the mountains, while there is a general exodus from the city, with one notable exception -- Leo XIII.

An elderly man, somewhat below the medium height, thin, and wearing a gray mustache, who said he was Major William Edsal, aged sixty-eight, of 55 Sylvan Place and formerly an officer in the army, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Zeller in the Harlem Police Court on a charge of passing a worthless check for $17.50.

At Antietam came an incident which, in my opinion, is one of the most thrilling of that awful war. Lee had pushed his victorious legions into Maryland. Stonewall Jackson was by his side. Longstreet was in the front of the fight -- all on the Southern side. On the Northern side were McClellan and Sheridan, grimly contesting every foot of the advance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your treatment of the Philippine question you seem to think that it is only important that we gave no express "pledges, promises, or assurances to the Filipinos that we would recognize their independence or the hope of it."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bryan insisted upon a special plank in the platform for 16 to 1, and with some difficulty he carried it by a bare majority of two votes, and they were from the Territories of Hawaii and Oklahoma, which have no Electoral votes to give.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- A dispatch from Pretoria, dated Aug. 4, to a news agency here, says:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Petitions in bankruptcy filed in this city to-day included the firm of Zieman Siegal, dealers in building materials. They have liabilities amounting to $100,096; assets not scheduled.

Clearly there is no reason as yet for the alarm which has often been excited by the accounts of successful experiments with regard to war machines. There is, to begin with, no grand secret in the matter, nothing which an evil-minded capitalist or ambitious Government could use while right-minded capitalists or Governments remained, ignorant how to manufacture the new weapon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The manner in which certain sharpers recently took advantage of the poolroom keepers of this city by use of the long-distance telephone from St. Louis, Mo., to beat their telegraphic connections, calls to mind the manner in which the policy players of New York, sixty years ago, by a clever scheme, managed to cheat the then policy dealers.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 21 -- The announcement that Siberian territory has been invaded by Chinese troops has caused the greatest indignation here. Russians now realize that the present rising in China is much more than a mere insurrection of fanatics and rebels. According to popular opinion here, a well-organized plot exists to expel all foreigners not only from Chinese territory but from Eastern Asia.
UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- At the Herkimer Republican Convention this afternoon Samuel M. Allison was nominated for member of the Assembly.

One man's requirements often happily combining with another's alibity work great advantage to both. Such a circumstance effected the beginning of the success of Fred Wellhouse, the most extensive commercial orchardist in the United States. He is widely known as the "Apple King" of Kansas, and the story of his successful career in orcharding is related by F.D. Coburn, Secretary of the Kansas Board of Agriculture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to be the general opinion that the Anarchists are only engaged in killing off a few Kings, and that therefore they should be left to themselves by police and other beneficiaries of voters. Just before the murder of President Carnot I happened to have a little business with an Italian who openly declared himself an Anarchist and follower of Kropotkin.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 4 -- For the past ten days organizers of the United Mine Workers of America have been hard at work throughout the entire anthracite coal region, and they have enough meetings arranged to keep them very busy for some days. During this time the "locals" are holding sessions and electing delegates.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The last afternoon of the Elks' Carnival at Combination Park was devoted chiefly to cycle racing, the fifteen-mile motor-paced race, professional, with Nelson, McBachern, Starbuck, and Stinson as participants being the star events. This fell an easy prey to Nelson in 28:10 3-5, no records being broken, although the champion's riding won him round after round of applause.

The funeral of Robert Dunlap, the hatter, who died suddenly at Monmouth Beach Friday, will take place to-morrow from St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, at 12 o'clock noon. The interment will be in Woodlawn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to be the general opinion that the Anarchists are only engaged in killing off a few Kings, and that therefore they should be left to themselves by police and other beneficiaries of voters. Just before the murder of President Carnot I happened to have a little business with an Italian who openly declared himself an Anarchist and follower of Kropotkin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A young married couple were arrested in this city last night at the request of the Maryland authorities, and were sent to Baltimore to be tried. The charge against them is that on July 19 they were married, and that they are people of different races. The husband, Robert W. Burnside, is a light-colored negro.

Mrs. Lena Schneider, twenty-four years old, of 420 East Sixth Street, and her daughter Rose, four years old, accidentally fell from a window on the tird floor of St. Zita's Home for Friendless Women at 125 East Fifty-second Street, yesterday afternoon, and were taken to the Flower Hospital.

In Hempstead Harbor, off the straggling Long Island village of Glen Cove, there will be gathered this morning one of the largest fleets of pleasure craft that ever shared the adventures of a New York Yacht Club cruise. When darkness fell over the anchorage of the club off Station No. 10, at Glen Cove Landing, last night, signal lights twinkled from thirty or more yachts already at the rendezvous.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Wharton, who was arrested here yesterday afternoon on his arrival from Louisville, Ky., on a warrant charging him with receiving property under false pretenses from Miss Clara Somers of Ocean Grove, entered bonds for $1,000 for his appearance at the next term of the Monmouth County Court, Dr. Gilbert E. Palen of Philadelphia, Penn., becoming his bondsman.
SCHNECTADY, Aug. 5. -- Severe forest fires are raging along the line of the West Shore westward of this city and the farmers of the vicinity have been lighting the flames all the afternoon.

The rumor that was started the latter part of last week that the Governor was about to remove Col. GARDINER from the office of District Attorney is without any tangible or plausible foundation. We have little doubt that it will turn out to be the opposite of the truth.

Two young men and two young women were thrown into the lake in Central Park yesterday forenoon through the capsizing of their boat, and one of the young women -- Miss Mary Isenhoff, twenty-one years old, of 270 Broome Street -- was going down for the third time when she was pulled out of the water. She fainted when she got ashore.
A weak and semi-demented old woman who had been cruelly abandoned the day before was yesterday morning arraigned before Magistrate Zeller in the Morrisania Police Court.

John L. Reagan, a member of the Harlem Rowing Association, will be the substitute for the Vesper Boat Club eight, which is to compete in the international regatta at Paris. Mr. Reagan will sail for Europe on the Deutschland on Wednesday. He will go at his own expense. Before the Vespers sailed last week Reasan had a talk with the Secretary of the National Association.

Not one of the leaders of the French Revolution attained the age of fifty. It is true that, with the exception of Mirabeau and Marat and a few minor figrures, their lives were cut short by the guillotine. Gensone, the eldest, was forty-one when he went to the scaffold: Lebon was twenty-five.

Policeman Weiner of the Speedway mounted squad had a long stern chase after a runaway yesterday, and owing to a broken bit had a difficult task to bring the horse to a stop after he had caught it. But he did it, and did it so cleverly that the spectators of the exciting performance broke out into spontaneous applause for the policeman's gallant feat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The State Department has taken the ground that the dispatch from the Tsung-li-Yamen delivered at the State Department yesterday by Minister Wu is not an answer to the dispatch of Secretary Hay sent on Aug. 1. In that dispatch Secretary Hay finally and decisively insisted that free communication with the Ministers must be established before any steps would be taken by this Government toward a peaceful solution of the present trouble.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- When Senator Morgan of Alabama was asked to-night if he concurred in the declaration made by the National Democratic Convention that imperialism was the paramount issue, he replied: "There is no paramount issue. There is no paramount issue in any campaign.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5. -- The train reached Kansas City this evening over two hours late. Among those who came through were Mr. and Mrs. C.F, Buck of Denver, Said Mr. Buck:
"Poll -- Poll -- Pretty -- Pret-t-t-y Poll. Polly want a cracker?"

According to the eighty-fourth annual report of the American Bible Society, just issued, and covering the work of that organization for the last portion of 1899 and the first part of 1900, the total issues for the year at home and abroad amounted to 1,406,801 copies; of these, 832,497 were distributed outside of the United States.

HAVRE, Aug. 6. -- La Bretagne, the French liner, scheduled to sail for New York Saturday, is still delayed owing to a serious strike among her stokers and bunkermen. At first the cabinmen joined the strikers, but these are now on board.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 5. -- The Right Rev. James Augustine Healy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Maine, died at his episcopal residence, on Congress Street, this afternoon. He returned from Canada Friday night, where he had been on episcopal business, and seemed to be in his usual health, though for many years he had been subject to frequent attacks of acute indigestion.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- Robert W. Sinclair, aged fifty-one years, a fruit commission merchant in this city, and his wife, Annie E., aged thirty-two years, were both found dead last night in the grarden in front of their Summer home, at Green Tree Station, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, near this city.
NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- Arthur H. Lewis of Philadelphia is visiting here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Errors were responsible for all the runs in to-day's baseball game between Chicago and Brooklyn. Brooklyn won in the sixth, after two outs, Taylor being mainly responsible by giving a base and muffing a throw, two hits following. The third base play on both sides was the feature, everything hit in that direction going like rifle shots. The score:

A great deal of our most popular weather lore is wholly superstitious, ascribing prophetic virtues to the weather of particular days or the week, saints' days, and even to the movable feast days. Although it is interesting enough in its way, that kind of weather lore can hardly be taken as a reliable guide.
Senator Platt had very few callers at Manhattan Beach. He received a group of reporters, and one of them remarked:
MALONE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A gold brick swindler who has been operating under the names of Smith, Ogden, Pratt, and Flower, is under arrest in the Franklin County Jail at this place.
MANILA, Aug. 5. -- Lieut. Bocton Hulesberg (?) was ambushed and killed near Santa Cruz, Province of Laguna.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The Hotel Albion, a well-known house and one of the largest here, has been seized by the Sheriff under foreclosure of a chattel mortgage, and 100 patrons must seek other quarters.

An unidentified man, a longshoreman or bargeman, after stealing a Battery rowboat Saturday night rowed out into the bay, where he was caught by the tide and drifted for hours, constantly menaced by passing tugs and returning excursion craft. The details of his midnight experiences will never be known.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 5. -- Judge Hook of the United States District Court has ruled against the claimant to 160 acres of land comprising the principal business portion, with 200 home sites and valuable railway yards, in the City of Argentine, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City.
"If the name of Bird S. Coler is presented for Governor at the State Convention he will receive the support of the Kings County delegation."
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Aug. 4, total transactions included 1,118,685 shares of stock, $4,701,500 bonds, including $12,500 Government and $83,000 State bonds.

The letter carriers, at their meeting yesterday at Brevoort Hall, in East Fiftyfourth Street, drew up a pension and retirement bill for letter carriers which it is intended to introduce in Congress. The bill provides that letter carriers for the first ten years of service are to pay 2 per cent. of their wages into the pension fund.

NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 5. -- At All Saints Memorial Chapel this morning, and again this afternoon, the Rev. Braddin Hamilton of New York occupied the pulpit. At the morning service he delivered an unusual sermon, admonishing his fashionable audience that they were under an especial obligation to lead upright lives, because what they did served in a measure as an example to the rest of the country.

Golfers who are spending a portion of the Summer in those popular resorts where the old Scotch sport has come to be one of the most attractive features, all report an unusually lively season, with links thronged, and every one eager to enter the weekly competitions. The recent big tournament at Shinnecock furnished a clear illustration of how popular similar open or invitation events out of town are likely to be this season.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Our money market is getting into an interesting condition. The Chancellor of the Exchequer's demand for another u13,000,000 to be added to his already excessive borrowings -- u10,000,000 of it now in three years, 3 per cent. bonds offered at 98 -- has caused it to become nervous and anxious.

The century run of veteran riders, for which expert long-distance cyclists had been pluming themselves for some days, took place on Long Island yesterday and was successful. The number of contestants was estimated to be about 800. There were eight divisions, and some of the divisions had less than 100 riders, while one had as many as 140.

The contest for the cricket championship of New York is nearing its conclusion, and in a few weeks the final resting place of the pennant will have been decided. The race is now in a most interesting condition, for the Knickerbocker Athletic Club and the Livingston Field Club are tied for first place, and every game played will now have an important bearing on the result.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H., Aug. 5. -- Col. John Hay, Secretary of State in President McKiniey's Cabinet, is a very sick man to-night. He is at his beautiful country house, The Fells. With him are Mrs. Hay. the Misses Helen and Alice Hay, and Master Clarence Hay.

The market for outside securities last week was generally firm and slightly more active than during the previous week. Midsummer dullness prevailed during the first few days, while the most conspicuous feature toward the close of the week was the increased strength and activity of copper stocks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At a recent meeting of the Democratic district leaders Mr. Croker is reported to have strongly urged on them the necessity of looking after the young men who will cast their first vote this year, and Chairman McGuire of the Campaign Committee has spoken of the advisability of getting the young voters to join Democratic Clubs.

Since the beginning of May a joint departmental committee of the British Cabinet has been attempting to formulate plans not merely for the government of the conquered territories in South Africa, but for the establishment of an essentially British body politic in those districts within the shortest possible time.

The convention that is to assemble in the City of Havana on the first Monday of November next "to frame and adopt" a Constitution for the people of Cuba is called and appointed to meet, not by the people of Cuba or by their authorized representatives, but by an order issued by the War Department of the United States.

From The Richmond (Va.) Times. In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of THE NEW YORK TIMES appears a very interesting review of a New York State Library Bulletin by the Hon. A. Judd Northrup. The title of Judge Northrup's paper is "Slavery in New York," and his treatment of the subject is straightforward and fearless.

After three days more of racing at the Brighton Beach race track, the Summer rest will come, and for seventeen days there will be no local racing. The Saratoga meeting will fill in the time for horse owners and the habitual race-goers who find horse racing and the attendant speculation necessary to existence, but the general public will have the time off before the regular season opens at Sheepshead Bay on Aug. 25.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- A general strike has been ordered, to begin to-morrow, of the union workmen employed on two extensive business buildings in this city.

In the remarkable collection of articles on the situation in China in the current number of The North American Review, one of the most suggestive is by "A Japanese Diplomat." It is an earnest and forcible argument for the maintenance of the integrity of the Chinese Empire, with every possible aid from the powers in promoting reform, and with the establishment of free commerce throughout the empire.

A small boy ran up to Patrolman Young of the Eldridge Street Station at the Bowery and Canal Street last night and told him that a man who had just killed another man had escaped, having boarded Car 171 of the Third Avenue line.

There was plenty of excitement at the Guttenberg track yesterday afternoon during the progress of the twenty-five mile amateur interstate championship race. Over forty riders competed, and with the exception of several who fell, all the others made a strong bid for the honors. Special prizes offered for the riders leading at the end of each mile proved a cure for loafing and thereby kept up the interest in the race throughout.
This morning's news from China is of a contradictory description, both with regard to the allies' advance and the intentions of the Chinese Government as to the envoys.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A belated message from Minister Conger was received to-day at the State Department. It came through Consul General Goodnow at Shanghai, who transmitted messages received by Mr. Ragsdale, United States Consul at Tien-Tsin, from Mr. Conger and Mr. Squiers, Secretary of the United States Legation at Peking.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- An Anarchist riot occurred this afternoon at the corner of Twelfth and Halstead Streets, in which twenty-five persons were bruised in a struggle with forty-five policemen, summoned to quell the disturbance. Five persons were arrested, among them being Mrs. Lucy Parsons, widow of Albert R. Parsons, who was executed Nov. 11, 1887, in Chicago for aiding and abetting the bomb throwing in the Haymarket riot.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The action of the village authorities in seizing the property of the Ossining Electric Railway for non-payment of taxes had a serious effect on the Methodist camp meeting, a mile from the village, cutting down the attendance fully two-thirds, few of those coming to attend the services being able or willing to pay the $1 demanded by the hackmen to drive them to the camp meeting grounds.

THE RECENT ACHIEVEMENTS OF HER MAJESTY'S SHIP VIPER. -- The wonderful speed attained recently by a turbine vessel belonging to the British Navy has excited the apprehension of certain circles of retired naval officers in Paris. The Viper a fortnight ago sped over the sea at the rate of 43 miles an hour in a trip from the Tyne to Portsmouth.

A war of words took place at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union between Delegates Eugene Johnson of the Manhattan musicians, and who has a city contract to supply music at some of the city parks, and William J. O'Brien of the granite cutters.

BRISTOL, R.R. Aug. 5. -- The steam yacht Ballymena, recently purchased by Samuel T. Shaw of New York, has been cleaned and painted on the dry dock. The boat has returned from the dry dock at East Providence, where she was cleaned and painted. She is now bound to Oyster Bay, her new headquarters.

SALINA, Kan., Aug. 5. -- Union Pacific east-bound passenger train No. 4, which left Denver last night, was stopped by several men west of Hugo, Col., ninety miles this side of Denver. The passengers in the Pullman sleeping cars were robbed of their money and valuables.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The American and British forces began the advance on Peking last Thursday, according to a dispatch dated Aug. 2 from Tien-Tsin to The Daily Express.

A correspondent, quoting our recent remarks as to the failure of the act of March 14 to establish beyond all doubt the gold standard, asks: "And yet THE TIMES gravely argues to its readers that the Republican Party, having been put in power by Democratic votes in order to pass a sufficient bill, should be put back because it failed' to do what it should have done.

When the steamship Deutschland was reported off Fire Island Sunday night people had been wondering what was the matter with her for nearly twenty-four hours. To have made good her previous records she should have reached the bar before Saturday midnight.

Had the good little sailing breeze that rippled over Long Island Sound late yesterday afternoon not been so tardy in rising, the races for the Commodore's Cups, from Glen Cove to Huntington Bay, which opened the fifty-fifth annual cruise of the New York Yacht Club, might have furnished some of the rarest sport of the season.

The news that comes to us from China of trouble in the upper valley of the Yang-tse-Kiang is disquieting. It may be said to be the worst news we are now getting from the empire. Newspaper readers must have inferred from the contradictory and unintelligible nature of the dispatches about the advance of the allies from Tien-Tsin that the censor is at his post.

HELENA, Mont., Aug. 6. -- Fire is sweeping through the vast timbered area between Tupper Geyser Basin and Yellowstone Lake in the National Park. It started Friday and was soon beyond the control of the soldiers and road crews who were hurried to the scene.

The guileless Brooklyn police have again been imposed upon by a practical joker. They learned yesterday that they had been hunting for three days for a missing woman who was not missing. While the perspiring bluecoats were sending out general alarms, searching in this place and that, and making inquiry among the woman's friends, she was at home quietly performing her usual household duties and unaware that she had "mysteriously disappeared."

LONDON, July 21. -- It is a curious Summer in England, July has brought after its first week, which was abnormally cold, a hot wave of unprecedented duration and severity, and the English, who cling to traditions in a way that surprises even Americans who know them and their ways, are sweltering in the cities under the rays of a sun that would be torrid even in New York.

CLAREMONT, N.H., Aug. 6. -- The appointment of James O. Lyford of Concord, as guardian of Charles H. Hoyt of Charleston, N.H., the playwright, was made by Judge Tenney in the Sullivan County frobate Court to-day. The appointment was as anticipated, and was made at the request of Mr. Hoyt, and was acquiesced in By Frank McKee, business partner of the playwright.

James Kerrigan, a well-known cattle dealer living in Harway Avenue, Coney Island, died last night in the Kings County Hospital, from the result of injuries inflicted by footpads. Kerrigan was found unconscious at 6:30 o'clock in the morning by Elliott Amsbroe. He was lying alongside the West End trolley road, in a section known as the West Meadows, about 400 feet north of the bridge spanning Coney Island Creek.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Floyd C. Clarke, fifty-two years old, the manager of the Stevenson Malt House in this city, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the heart. Mr. Clarke had suffered from deafness for several years, and a carbuncle on his face had caused him terrible pain for many weeks.

Coffey's Pavilion, at Far Rockaway, was crowded to overflowing yesterday afternoon during the second annual water carnival arranged by the Volunteer Life Savers' Association. A. Reuse and J. Rellly of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club traveled through the water in quick style and won most of the prizes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Messrs. Hedges, Edens, and McCoy, Assistant Superintendents of the free-delivery system, appointed by the Postmaster General to investigate the free-delivery service at New York, have submitted their formal report.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6. -- Blue jackets, marines, ex-soldiers of the Ninth Infantry, and refugees crowded the decks of the transport Logan, from Taku via Japan, which reached her dock here to-day. There were men, women, and children on the vessel, direct from Tien-Tsin, who had escaped from the mobs of Boxers and the imperial Chinese troops.
NEWPORT, Aug. 6. -- Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and Mrs. R.I. Gammell entertained at dinner this evening, and during the afternoon Hugh K. Norman entertained at the Clam Bake Club.
James Shevlin carried to Richard Croker at Saratoga yesterday the views of Hugh McLaughlin on the boom started by the friends of Controller Coler to make him a candidate for Governor.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 6. -- Determined to die, an unknown man threw him-self into the sea from a yacht this evening, and then, finding rescue imminent, sent a bullet through his brain. The body was not recovered. The deed was committed in the presence of thirty fellow-passengers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Pei-Tsang, where Sunday's battle between the allies and Chinese is reported to have been fought, is a walled town. The same is true of practically all the towns along the river, and means that the allies will have the same kind of trouble at every step of the way where they find troops.

The outdoor life has again come into prominence, and this week will tie one of yachting, of golfing and tennis, and of various sports in the open. No very large entertainments are to be given at any of the resorts. There, will be many formal dinners at Newport, and large luncheons and dinners also at Bar Harbor and Southampton, and other places, and the weekly hops and dances.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Brooklyn batted Cunningham, hard in the first five innings of to-day's baseball game with Chicago, and evened up the score, out made only two singles after that Chance scored in the ninth on his three-bagger and Green's single. Clingman was given-ills release to-day. The score:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The State Department has received a cable dispatch from the United States Charge d'Affaires at Rome saying that he has been informed by the Foreign Office that the, funeral of the late King Humbert will take place in Rome on Thursday next.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 6. -- A most remarkable family resides at Monroe Falls, a few miles from this place. To-day Mr. and Mrs. Moore gave to the public an outline as to how they had raised a family of twenty children on the small salary which Mr. Moore has commanded, $1.20 to $1.30 per day.
