NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 6. -- The first game in the polo match for the Narragansett Cups was played this afternoon on the field of the Point Judith Country Club between the Myopias of Hamilton, Mass., and the Philadelphia Freebooters. The Freebooters were allowed a handicap of 5, and played a very strong game throughout, winning by a score of 12 8/4 to 10.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- At the racing to-day of the Hurst Park Bank Holiday meeting the Vyner Handicap, for three-year-olds and upward, seven furlongs, was won by Orris Root, ridden by L. Reiff.
ROME, Aug. 6. -- The Chamber or Deputies to-day reopened, with an immense throng present. The tribunes were draped in black.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Two convicts escaped from Auburn prison at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The men are Albert Dean and Edgar Pratt. Dean is serving a fifteen-year sentence for kidnapping. He was convicted in Columbia County and was received here in February, 1898. He had Previously served a term here for jail breaking.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6. -- Capt. Frederick Jerome, an old-time sailor, who had the credit of saving over 1,000 lives during his career, is dead in this city. He was born in the south of England in 1823. The freedom of the City of New York and an elegant snuffbox for saving hundreds of lives in the wrecks of the Henry Clay and Ocean Monarch in the years 1846 and 1848 were presented to him.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 6. -- The social season so auspiciously begun received unexpected encouragement to-night with an announcement of the plans of the MondayEvening Club for the next six weeks. This club is a recent organization, in which Mrs. Burton Harrison is the chief mover. The announcement of the club's programme has dissipated all the dull August, for it promises such a series of entertainments as Bar Harbor has not seen for seasons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The phrase in the Declaration of Independence which asserts that "Governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed," and which has been incorporated into the Bryanese platform, has never in a single instance been practically accepted by the Government of the United States.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- A prominent citizen of Peeksklll received last week from his nephew, Irving Hart of the Third Cavalry, Troop L, now at Vigan, Luzon, in the Philippines, a letter which gave some idea of what the feeling was and prospects were in that section at the time the letter was written, June 1.

Senator MORGAN of Alabama, takes a philosophic view of the campaign. He declares that he has given it little attention yet, and he plainly does not think that the people are highly excited on the subject. When they turn to the matter he believes that they will act for themselves and without regard to what the politicians tell them is the "paramount issue."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson, in an interview to-day, gave the results of his observations on his recent trip through the West as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The Democratic campaign opened in Monroe County this evening. A Bryan and Stevenson banner was swung to the breeze in front of the State Armory, and there was an oration by Isaac M. Brickner. A large crowd witnessed the ceremony. A parade was then formed and all marched to the New Osburn House, where a banquet was served in the assembly hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it that the newspapers have made no comment on the arresting of all the women at the Tivoli and letting the men go scot free? Civilization is little further advanced in the one essential improvement for the elevation of mankind than it was thousands of years past.

The foreclosure sale of the property of the Staten Island Cricket Club at New Brighton, Staten Island, will take place on Aug. 16. The sale will be conducted at the clubhouse on the premises by Auctioneer Philip A. Smyth. The property consists of the block front on the south side of First Avenue, between Davis and Bard Avenues, a nearly regular plot 556.10 by 411.5, together with the clubhouse, grand stand, and other buildings.
Andrew D. White, American Ambassador to Germany, arrived in New York yesterday on the Deutschland. He was in excellent health and spirits.

Suspiciously weak riding and races that strongly suggested fraud have been of such frequent occurrence at the present Brighton Beach meeting, and so regularly overlooked by the Jockey Club's Stewards of the meeting, that it caused genuine surprise when the track, officials suddenly awoke yesterday and with a promptitude that was startling took steps toward examination into a suspected fraud.
TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 6. -- State Health Officeer Porter's official statement of the health situation here, issued to-night at 10 o'cclock, is as follows:

BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Lever's of golf who followed Harry Vardon in his exhibition match against the best ball of Stuart Gillispie of Fairfield Country Golf Club and Harry Roy Sweeney of Albany Country Club were treated to one of the best exhibitions yet given by him in this country.

George R. Purvis has sold for William J. Tales to Mrs. Jessie Hussey the, five-story flat 308 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 18.9 by 100.11, taking in part payment the three-story dwelling 76 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 16.8 by 99.11.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 6. -- The preliminaries in the Southeastern States tennis tournament were played at the opening of the tournament this afternoon on the courts of the Atlanta Athletic Club, Summaries:

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The Ossining trolley road is still lying idle, and people have to walk up the long and steep hill leading from the railroad station to the village or hire hacks, paying 25 cents for each ride. Business men are complaining, too, that their trade is suffering.

An unknown man, about forty years old, fell into the North River from the pier at Canal Street last night. He was fished up from the river shortly afterward, but though his would-be rescuers and Dr. Page from the Hudson Street Hospital worked over him for quite a while they failed to resuscitate him.

Elizabeth Fitzgerald, the fortune teller of many aliases, whose title in occult science was Mme. Zingara, seeress and prophetess, is in the Tombs Prison. She was in June, 1898, indicted for extorting money from Mollie E. Burns, a teacher and typewriter, of 110 West Seventeenth Street. Before this she had been arrested on Miss Burns's complaint and bail was furnished by Henry Straus of 1,997 Lexington Avenue.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Arthur Featherstone's Iroquois Belle won the Hendric Stakes this afternoon with ease, with only three starters. Motley and Killasbandra being the others. Iriquois Belle lay back of the leaders until the stretch was reached, when she went to the front and won cleverly by two lengths from Killashandra, who was a like distance before Motley.

NEWPORT, Aug. 6. -- A full-grown Maltese cat was literally pecked to death by a flock of sparrows on Pelham Street this morning. The ivy which climbs the north wall of the United Congregational Church long furnished a snug retreat for countless sparrows that build their nests there, and the thickness of the leaves hides the places where the birds build their nests.

Edward Forshay, an actor, was taken to Bellevue Hospital at 3 o'clock yesterday morning suffering from chloroform poisoning. Forshay and his wife, Edna, are vaudeville actors, and came from Detroit yesterday. They arranged with R.W. Jackson, proprietor of the Trafalgar Hotel, 115 East Fourteenth Street, to stay two weeks.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- Boston had a gooat market to-day, the copper shares having their fourth consecutive day of fair demand and rising values. Some of the lowerpriced stocks came out of retirement and gained well, while the middle-priced stocks hardened further.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- One of the severest wind, rain, and thunderstorms ever known in this section broke over this village to-night about 7 o'clock. The Lake Champlain Yacht Club held its annual face meet here to-day and this evening the fleet anchored in the bay near Hotel Champlain at Bluff Point, about three miles north of this village.
The Republican National Committee fears the election of a silver Senate in the four years following March 4, 1901. The members admit the possibility.

Senator Hanna was an early arrival at National Republican Headquarters, and about the first matter to attract his attention was the fact that there was a pretty general desire that he should take the stump, visiting some of the largest cities.

Justice Giegerich, in the Supreme Court, yesterday morning, continued, pending the trial of the action, the temporary injunction granted by Justice Dugro, restraining the American Ice Company from doing business in the name of John W. Scheer, who had sold his ice wagon and trade to the defendant corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the whole world has forgotten for the moment the recent mode of Chinese warfare above epitomized, and how fundamentally Chinese it is, it should now be recalled in explanation of the last two months' news" from Peking, , and of the present attitude of the Chinese Government toward the powers and their envoys.
LONDON, Aug. 7. -- In a cablegram which was read in the House of Commons yesterday the Consul at Tien-Tsin says:
There was a great muster or cool dresses and hot faces in Queen's Hall. On the platform students of the Royal Academy of Music bad mustered, bent on giving pleasure and receiving prizes.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Two favorites scored in the three races presented at the opening card for the Buffalo Grand Circuit meeting held at the Fort Erie, Ont., track this afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- A special dispatch from Pretoria, dated Aug. 5, says Gen. Lord Kitchener has narrowed the circle around De Wet and Steyn by driving out the enemy from one of the flank positions which he held.

The meeting of fire underwriters to be held at Long Branch on Thursday to act upon the amended report of the General Fire Insurance Committee of Twenty-five is being discussed in local insurance circles, and a large attendance is anticipated. Opinion as to the outcome of the meeting continues to be divided.

-- One might easily imagine that "F.," the correspondent whose letter on the Oroquteta incident we published yesterday, had a large amount of special and private Information in regard to happenings in the Philippines. There was nothing in the press dispatches about the killing of those eighty-nine natives to warrant him calling it a "murder," or to justify his doubt if a "more dastardly outrage " is recorded in the whole history of Spanish rule.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6. -- A movement started some time ago to transport negro plantation hands from Louisiana to the Hawaiian Islands is rapidly taking shape, and the promoters of the scheme express full confidence in their ability to carry it out successfully. To-day J.B. Collins, a Hawaiian sugar planter, after stopping over at Monroe, arrived here and joined John Hind, one of the promoters.

The deadly electric "third rail," which is crowding the trolley for the man-killing record in Brooklyn, added another victim to its list yesterday afternoon. Charles Bruswitz, seven years old, of 810 Park Avenue, stepped upon the heavily charged rail in the cut of the Brighton Beach line of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, at Franklin Avenue, between Sterling Place and Douglass Street, and was almost instantly killed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 6. -- Final arrangements have been completed for the meeting to notify William J. Bryan and Adlai E. Stevenson of their nomination as President and Vice President by the Democratic Party. Military Park, where the notification will take place, has been elaborately decorated.
The British Consul at Tien-Tsin officially announces that the advance of the allies began last Saturday.
DOVER, Del., Aug. 6. -- The Union Republicans (Addicks faction) held their State convention here this afternoon and nominated the following ticket:

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 6. -- There was a meeting this evening at 84 Market Street of Italian residents of this city, who deplore the killing of King Humbert. Resolutions were adopted expressing sorrow over the death of the King, and these will be forwarded to the Italian royal family. M. Antonio presided.

Gen. JOHN M. PALMER is a Democrat of the old school, a conscientious citizen of sound and statesmanlike mind who sees his duty clearly and performs it faithfully. He is loyal to the declaration of Democratic principles made at Indianapolis four years ago to serve as the platform upon which he was nominated for the Presidency as the candidate of the Gold Democrats, but he will this year vote for McKINLEY.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The following cablegrams were received at the Navy Department to-day:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 6. -- A general State election for Stare and county officials and for members of the General Assembly was held in Alabama to-day, and a large majority was returned for the Democratic ticket, headed by William J. Samford of Lee County, who will be inaugurated as Governor on Dec. 1.

Members of the Gloucester's crew at the battle or Santiago have risen in protest against the reception of Lieut. Col. Clinton H. Smith into the command of Spanish War Veterans which bears the name of their gallant ship, and ten of them met last night at the home of Peter Keller, on the top floor of 2,386 First Avenue, to discuss the situation.

Domenico Pace, an Italian, foreman of a gang of roustabouts, saved his own life yesterday by shooting Giovanni Corillo a the bulkhead of Pier 13, at Grand Street Jersey City. Corillo is at the City Hospital. Dr. Varick, who has his case in charge says that his left lung was traversed by a pistol bullet, and that the wound is a fatal one.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7 -- William J. Bryan of Nebraska and Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois reached this city at 7:20 o'clock this evening. They came on a special train of twelve coaches, all filled with enthusiastic Democrats. To-morrow, in Military Park, shortly after 2 o'clock, Messrs. Bryan and Stevenson will be notified of their nomination by the Democratic Convention at Kansas City.

It is now estimated that at least $40,000,000 has been offered to the Government of Great Britain on the loan that it has placed on our market. The event is entirely without precedent, the only transaction resembling it being the subscription of a modest amount to a Russian loan earlier in the year, mainly by insurance interests able to make use of the securities in their business in Russia.

A committee of Jersey Central Railroad conductors had a conference with Division Superintendent Wentz in Jersey City yesterday. Superintendent Wentz declined to say what occurred beyond a statement to the effect that the conductors asked for a readjustment of the rules under which they were working, many of which are now tacitly ignored, having been adopted fifteen years ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- A tornado struck this city this afternoon, doing great damage in the city and beyond it. The storm centre was about forty feet wide, and swept along the earth for a distance of about four miles.

Edward L. McWilllams, ex-Chief of the Jersey City Police force and for more than twenty years employed as a detective at the Astor House, was found dead in Room 108, at the Cosmopolitan Hotel, West Broadway and Chambers Street, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon with a pistol wound in his left temple.

Clamor against a Commissioner of Pensions upon the ground that he earns a reputation for ability and honesty in complying strictly with the law, and the demand for his unsolicited promotion because he will not consent to or approve designs upon the Treasury in the name of unrequited patriotism, provoke indignation, disgust, and surprise when considered in the light of the array of pension statistics printed in THE TIMES yesterday morning.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 7 -- In a letter to P.M. Ringdal, Chairman, and the members of the Committee of Notification of Candidate for Vice President of the People's Party, Charles A. Towne has declined the nomination tendered him by the Populist National Convention at Sioux Falls. The letter is of considerable length, and sets forth fully Mr. Towne's views in regard to the nomination.

The thousands of sweltering New Yorkers who audibly and forcibly remarked yesterday that it was one of the hottest days they ever experienced were right. The thousands more who sprung the old story about it being the "hottest day this year" were officially correct, according to the Weather Bureau records.

A woman with snow-white hair and a face furrowed by many wrinkles fell into the East River off Twenty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital to die. Her clothes were of plain black, but scrupulously neat, and in them she carried a bundle of papers that told a tale of ceaseless wandering, of travels over almost every land of the Western Hemisphere, of wealth and want and adventure.
Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles knows what it feels like to be an immigrant, unless he has forgotten his five minutes' experience in front of the New York Barge Office yesterday afternoon.

Frederick Gross, thirty-five years old, an employe at the Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street power house of the Third Avenue electric road, was terribly shocked by electricity yesterday. It is thought the man sustained at least 1,000 volts. He fell against a "channel" rail.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Griffith showed great form in to-day's baseball game with Brooklyn, holding the latter down to one hit an inning, excepting in the third, when two singles and a passed ball grave them one run. Weyhing gave two bases, hit a batter, and was touched up for six hits in the fifth. Cross again played a wonderful game at third.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The allotment of such a large portion of the war loan to America has not been well received in many quarters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The War Department has received the following cablegram from Gen. Chaffee:

One of the arguments most constantly in use a few years ago by the advocates of the free and unlimited coinage of all silver offered at the mints at the ratio of 16 to 1 was that a gold standard could not be maintained because of the insufficiency of the gold production to meet redemption demands, and that silver must therefore be used to provide money.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- Young Karl Ragsdale, son of Consul Ragsdale at Tien-Tsin, was one of those who came home on the Logan. Although the merest lad, he was in the thickest of the fighting. He was with Capt. McCalla as an aid, and has for the American naval man an admiration that nothing will ever dim.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Gov. Roosevelt was visited to-day by Andrew D. White, Ambassador to Germany, and Frederick T. Holls. They took luncheon and dinner with the Governor, and spent the afternoon in his company. They started back to New York on the 8:02 train.

The Broadway corridor on the third floor of the Post Office Building was crowded from early yesterday morning to late in the afternoon with men in most all walks of life. Many nationalities were represented, but Russian and Polish Hebrews, Germans, and Swedes predominated.

The excellence of the sons and daughters of James R. Keene's great horse Domino has been an interesting theme to turfmen since the first of them raced. Never before were colts of one blood so universally good and fast. Hanover's first crop of two-year-olds were a sensational lot and more numerous than the Dominos, but the Dominos stand out above all others for speed and courage.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 7 -- In the last grolf team match between the Seabright and Montclair teams the results were as follows:

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 7 -- The second event of the polo tournament for the Narragansett cups was played on the field of the Point Judith Country Club this afternoon, between the Point Judiths and the Westchester Country Club. Point Judith had a handicap of two, but Westcheater won by the score of 12 1/2 to 8 1/2.

CHARLOTTENBURG, Aug. 7 -- Dr. Lieb-knecht, the well-known member of the Reichstag and one of the leaders of Socialism in Germany, died last night. He was born at Giessen in 1826 and was editor of the Vorwaerts, the Socialist organ.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club Labor Day sports, like the meets of previous years, promises to be the most popular set of games of the year. The programme is an exhaustive one, and includes every event popular to local athletes. All the international champions will appear at Bayonne on Labor Day.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Thomas Jerold, forty-eight years old, was killed by a bolt of lightning shortly before 6 o'clock this evening. Jerold was a peddler, and was coming through Furnace Woods, about four miles from this place, when a heavy thunderstorm came up. He stopped under a tree to protect himself from the rain.

If out of the 135,000 shares traded in yesterday 10 per cent, represented transactions for the account of outsiders -- and 10 per cent. is probably a liberal estimate -- the full regular commissions earned by brokers of the Stock Exchange aggregated about $1,600. There are 1,100 members of the New York Stock Exchange, and the division of commissions would average about one dollar and a half per member.
"The busiest day I have had since I came to New York," remarked Senator Hanna to a TIMES reporter yesterday on the eve of his departure for Long Branch.

David Stewart has sold for the Faye estate to Max Marx the plot on the east side of Eighth Avenue, 49.11 feet north of One Hundred and Fifty-second Street, 50 by 100. Mr. Marx has resold the lots, through W.A. Darling, to Alexander Cameron.

The inhabitants of a row of houses situated on Newark Avenue, near the Hackensack River, Jersey City, are afraid to go out at night on account of a gang of roughs who loiter about the corner of West Side and Newark Avenues and hold up people who pass there after dark. In the last few weeks the thieves have grown more daring, and have attempted to break into the houses.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- The Foreign Office admits that serious differences have broken out between the powers with reference to the advance on Peking and as to the measures that are being taken in the Yangtse Valley.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- In the House of Commons to-day, Benjamin Louis Cohen, Conservative, member for the East Division of Islington, asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, the reason for the early closing of subscriptions for exchequer bonds. In substances, the Chancellor of the Exchequer replied:

NEWPORT, Aug. 7 -- Rehearsals for the peasants' dance in costume, which will be a feature of Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's ball at Crossways during the month, are in progress. The first was given at Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs's villa and the second at Mrs. Elisha Dyer's. There will be two quadrilles, with sixteen women and men in each set.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 -- A cablegram was received to-day from Biuefields, Nicaragua, giving details ou the most destructice fire that ever occurred in that port. The flames started last night and cut a swath through the heart of the town, creating a loss estimated at $175,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- It was rumored to-day that the dispatch given out as having been sent by Gen. Chaffee on Aug. 3 was in reality a part of his suppressed dispatch giving the plan of campaign in China. This was emphatically denied by all the officials of the War Department who were questioned about it, and it was asserted that the dispatch was entirely new and was received here at 4 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador, announces that a memorial funeral service will be held at Washington on Aug. 19 at 11 o'clock in honor of King Humbert. President McKinley has already signified his purpose to come on from Canton and be present at the official ceremony, and members of the Cabinet la the city also will be present.

Scarcely any increase in activity showed in the market for outside securities yesterday, though for a few issues there was fairly good demand. The most active issues were found among those not as a rule openly traded in, and on the curb itself the day was as dull as any day of late. Liquidation is seemingly over and prices are under no pressure, but there is no buying in sufficient volume to materially advance prices.

The Rev. Ezra B. Lake, one of the founders of Ocean City, N.J., and Superintendent of the Ocean City Association, died yesterday morning at Ocean City, after a few days' illness of billous dysentery, supposed to have been brought on by drinking the water at Seaville camp. He was President of the Seaville Came Meeting Association, and labored arduously for its success.

Mr. ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT speaks to stone-deaf ears when he asks the anti-imperialists if it is wise for a nation to show cowardice. They cannot understand him because they have no conception of the idea present in his mind. Cowardice in the individual they readily comprehend, but it is perfectly evident that the words nation and country have no such meaning for them as they have for the majority of Americans.

HAR HARBOR, Aug. 7 -- The social season is now on in earnest. Dinner parties and luncheons no longer have the significance they had a week ago, for Mrs. Burton Harrison's theatricals, the Kebo Club's activities, and announcements of grand balls and entertainments in preparation have caused them to fall into insignificance by comparison.

A dividend of $8 a share on the stock of the Standard Oil Company was announced yesterday, and will be payable on Sept. 15. The books will close Aug. 15. The company is capitalized at $100,000,000, almost all of which is outstanding. The payment of this dividend will consequently require the expenditure of about $8,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Another cablegram came to the State Department late this afternoon from Minister Conger at Peking -- the second that has been received from him since June 12. It is the first which has come direct from the Minister since that date, the other having been received through the Chinese Minister here, Mr. Wu.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 -- As a result of the behavior of the police during the recent riots here, it is probable that the entire police system of New Orleans will soon be reorganized. To-day Peter F. Pescud of the Board of Police Commissioners handed Mayor Capdevielle his resignation as a member of that body.

-- Doubtless there are good and sufficient reasons for the more than leisurely manner in which the work of changing the street car tracks on Forty-second Street is progressing -- good and sufficient reasons, that is, from the viewpoint of the contractor who has the job in hand and of the corporation by which he is employed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- A story of Russian brutality in China is told by Mrs. E.B. Drew, wife of the British Commissioner of Customs at Tien-Tsin, who arrived from the Orient on the transport Losan. She says:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @ 62 1/2. There were no sales.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- William J., Bryan was in Chicago for four hours to-day, on his way to the notification meeting at Indianapolis. He arrived on the Burlington Railroad at 9:30 A.M., accompanied by Mrs. Bryan, their son, Gov. and Mrs. Thomas of Colorado, and Col. John I. Martin, Sergeant at Arms of the Kansas City Convention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a martyr to the "no coat" cause. Encouraged by THE TIMES, which in most matters to me seems admirably authoritative, I laid aside my coat; and I have been looked upon with disdain by the Head Waiter of one of our most highly decorated and expensive hotels, not to mention my having suffered the necessity of going elsewhere for my luncheon.

The Bath Beach police are trying to clear up the mystery surrounding the disappearance of Charles Murphy, an undertaker of 47 Madison Street, Manhattan, who is believed to have been drowned Monday afternoon. Murphy went in bathing about 5 o'clock from the bathing pavilion of Willlam Shields, and the last seen of him was when he dived into the water.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration." This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Announcement was made yesterday of the classes and purses for Grand Circuit sulky races to be held at the Empire City tiack on Sept. 10 to 15, Inclusive. In all there will be eleven events for trotters and nine for pacers. Among these will be a trotting and a pacing race for amateurs to road wagons, each to be for a prize of a thousand bushels of oats.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- "In case the troops advance, the Chinese must fight. The suggestion that the allies should be allowed to enter Peking in order to escort the Ministers to Tien-Tsin is absolutely impossible."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read with much amusement Mr. Breck's communication in this morning's TIMES on "The Consent of the Governed." He says this "means, in a republic, the consent of a majority of the people."

The exports of merchandise from the Port of New York for the week were valued at $12,763,719, against $9,305,395 in the preceding week and $6,136,474 in the corresponding week last year. Since Jan. 1 the exports of merchandise from this port have aggregated $360,863,873 against $275,876,730 in the same period last year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Better sailing weather than that which favored, the New York Yacht Club's fleet to-day on the run from Huntington Bay to Morris Cove could not have been desired. From noon until sunset a fresh east to southeasterly breeze curled the Sound into bunches of whitecaps, and gave the yachts competing in the race twenty-eight miles of rapid windward work.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- Although no plan has yet been adopted for international protection against Anarchists, the German Foreign Office is authority for the statement that it is quite likely a scheme will be devised, and that the preliminary steps have already been taken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- "The Dead Sea, which for thousands of years has been a forsaken solitude in the midst of a desert, on whose waves no rudder has been seen for centuries," says United States Consul Winter at Annaberg, in a letter to the State Department, " is to have a line of motor boats in the future.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Miss Margaret Astor Chanler of New York has forwarded from Manila to the Secretary of War a severe criticism of the army's medical system in the Philippines, alleging that there is a lack of surgeons, lack of nurses, lack of medical supplies, including such articles as sheets, and asking that she be allowed 500 sheets for emergency distribution.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- The fa- mous Long Island lawn tennis championsnip tournament was started here this morning before a larger crowd of spectators than usual. The weather and the condition of the courts were perfect, while the players provided excellent sport. Four matches were played in the preliminary round and two in the first round.
Controller Coler arrived in New York yesterday afternoon from Liberty, N.Y., where he has been spending a short vacation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would be interesting to learn just what reasons Justice Porter of Pennsylvania assigns as justification for his decision against the business of "ticket scalping," and, also, why legislation against this business is needed or desired, by whom it is desired, and for whom it is desired.

In a double sense MARTIN ENGEL, the leader of the Tammany organization in the Eighth District, made a touching exhibition of personal devotion on Tuesday. ENGEL, like CHOKER, is a "leader" who leads his followers to admit first that the "Boss" is great, and next that his greatness cannot be questioned, or admission of it avoided, without penalty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Chinese situation is considered very grave by the authorities in Washington. The receipt of the message from Minister Conger last night, which indicated a continuation of the firing upon the members of legations and the Chinese Government's insistence that the Ministers should leave Peking, which Mr. Conger considered would mean certain death, have brought matters to an acute stage.

HAVANA, Aug. 8 -- The press unanimously criticises and condemns what it terms the corrupt condition of the Cuban judiciary system. Bold charges have been made by the newspapers that Judges and other members of the courts have been receiving fees for cases coming to trial in the courts and which they themselves have to decide.

It is now generally believed that a pool has been effected on east-bound freight business out of Chicago, although none of the railroad officials of the lines interested will admit it. Among the reasons which are given for the belief that a pool exists is the result of an examination of a compilation of the east-bound shipments for the last few weeks.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -- William J. Bryan and Adlai E. Stevenson were to-day in this city officially and formally notified of their nomination by the Democrats at their recent Kansas City Convention to the offices respectively of President and Vice President of the United States. The ceremony was made the occasion of a demonstration with which the Democrats may be fairly said to have begun their National campaign.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 8 -- The subcommittee of the National Committee having in charge the contests between delegates to the late National Convention at Kansas City from the District of Columbia, Oklahoma, and the Indian Territory, Senator J.K. Jones presiding, took up the subject at the Grand Hotel this morning and settled the disputes.

Joseph Rabiner of 40 East Third Street, this city, shot and killed his brother-in-law, Isaac Stein of 330 East Seventy-seventh Street, on the piazza, of the Holland House, Rockaway Beach, last evening. He also shot his father, Jacob Rabiner of 317 East Seventy-ninth Street. Then he turned the weapon on himself.

The extensive use of cipher codes by this Government in the war with Spain, and since that event by other Governments on account of the South African and Chinese complications, has led to a largely increased demand for code books from the general public, and now the International Cable Directory Company issues a pocket edition for the use of travelers.

The steamship Teutonic, which reached her pier late yesterday afternoon, brought a number of prominent Japanese. One of the first to come ashore after the big liner came up to her pier was his Excellency Prince Iwakura of Japan, who has been traveling in England and on the Continent in the suite of Prince Asigurawa.

The bosom of WILLIAM J. BRYAN must be stirred by an angry resentment against Senator HOAR and Mr. CARL SCHURZ for their impudence in having said and much better said long before him all the things to which he now gives belated utterance in his long and dreary speech of acceptance.

The relatives and friends of Patrick Charles Murphy, the undertaker at 49 Madison Street, who has been missing since Sunday afternoon, when he went to take a swim at Bath Beach, feel sure that he was drowned. The waters along the beach were carefully searched yesterday, and a diver who was employed to search for the body did not cease working until darkness set in.

When we saw, the other day, that our neighbor The Tribune had ventured to deny several assertions made by Mr. GAMALIEL BRADFORD of Boston, and to charge him with unfair attempts to make party capital out of a war appropriation for which both parties voted unanimously, we could not help feeling that our neighbor had committed a serious mistake.

Some of the stockholders of the Republic Savings and Loan Association are not yet satisfied with the appointment of receivers for that institution. These stockholders met on Tuesday and held what they termed an annual meeting. At this meeting an entire new set of officers was elected and certain amendments' to the by-laws were adopted.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 8 -- Among the passengers on the Empress of Japan, which arrived from the Orient to-day, were twenty-nine missionaries' who were fugitives from North China. Many of them had narrow escapes. One of the number, a Miss Hawes, was in the compound at WeinShan when it was rushed by the Boxers.

Senator Platt and ex-Senator Jacob Worth of Brooklyn are said to have buried the hatchet, which was first flourished between them when Worth broke from the State leader to support Seth Low in the last Mayoralty campaign.

Occupants of flat houses and other residences in the Bronx, who have long complained of the scarcity of water and who of late have been subjected to considerable hardship by the scant supply, are not promised even temporary relief for nearly another year and perhaps longer.

A crowd of about 4,000 at the Brighton Beach race course yesterday witnessed the close of the seaside track's Summer meeting and the last racing about New York until the Sheepshead Bay Autumn meeting opens. The weather was pleasant, the track fast, and the sport interesting throughout, with the additional pleasing feature that the public continued to pick the winners, three favorites and three heavily-backed second choices being successful.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The largest crowd of the meeting witnessed the running off the programme of five over-night events this afternoon. The day was overcast, and rain fell at frequent intervals on a heavy track.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 8 -- The following ticket was nominated by acclamation at the Republican State Convention to-day:

The Board of Stewards of The Jockey Club held a meeting yesterday morning in the rooms of the club with August Bel mont, James Galway, F.R. Hitchcock, and Andrew Miller, present, Mr. Belmont presiding. James Galway was appointed The Jockey Club's steward for the Autumn meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, which opens on Aug. 25.
NEWPORT, Aug. 8 -- To-morrow afternoon Miss Leary will hold her second reception of the month at her cottage.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -- At night a mass meeting was held at Tomlinson Hall, which was presided over by Mayor Carter H. Harrison of Chicago and addressed by Mr. Bryan and Webster Davis. The meeting was not called to order until 8:30 o'clock, but the hall which is a large one, was filled an hour before that time.
BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- The Post says Field Marshal Count von Waldersee starts for China in a fortnight.

Commissioner Keating of the Department of Highways called on Acting Mayor Guggenheimer yesterday afternoon, and reported on the condition of Forty-second Street, about which the Acting Mayor sent him a letter recently. Mr. Keating admitted that the condition of the street was deplorable.

Detectives from the Brooklyn Central Office have arrested six men and locked them up in the Coney Island Station on suspicion of having been implicated in the murder of the man who was found unconscious and dying Monday morning along the West End trolley road near the bridge over Coney Island Creek.

In yesterday's market for outside securities the trading, with the exception of a single stock, was as dull as on any day since extreme dullness became the daily condition. The one stock actively traded in was Rubber Goods, which supplied probably more than half of the whole day's business.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies will jointly appeal to the Federal Court for a dissolution of the permanent injunction granted yesterday by Judge Henry of Kansas City to the Christie Street Commission Company and the Grain Brokerage Company of Kansas City, which restrains the telegraph companies from refusing to furnish them with market quotations of the Chicago Board of Trade.
The United States Government regards the situation in China as extremely grave.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The report of the appointment of Field Marshal Count von Waldersee as Commander-in-chief of the international forces meets with general approval.

Charles F.W. Neely, charged with embezzling funds intrusted to him as Chief of the Bureau of Finance of the Cuban Postal Department, will be extradited to Cuba to stand trial in Havana. It is probable that the order in extradition for Neely will be signed on Aug. 13. The decision was rendered yesterday by Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court.
SCHENECTADY, Aug. 8 -- Robert Gibbs, aged nineteen years, residing at Rotterdam Junction, this county, while riding a bicycle along the canal bank last evening, struck a chicken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- After a brief respite from work at the seashore the Chinese Minister was again busy to-day at the legation. He made an early visit to the State Department, delivering the edict of Aug. 2, which had been delayed en route. This was turned over to Acting Secretary Adee and the text of the edict made public.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 8 -- When he fleet of the New York Yacht Club left Morris Cove early yesterday morning for the thirty-nine-mile run to this port, there was every prospect that the yachts were going to have a brisk windward work in he clipping easterly breeze that curled down the Sound.

Joseph Lutz, the owner of a sweatshop at North Second and North Seventh Streets, Brooklyn, had a narrow escape from being killed last night by a crowd of angry Italians. His life was saved by the appearance of several policemen, who were compelled to draw their revolvers and threaten the Italians to prevent an assault.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- Suit was brought to-day in the United States Circuit Court by the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities against Penrose A. McClain, Collector of Internal Revenue of this district, to recover $200,000 inheritance tax collected under the War Revenue Act.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value or the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Gold begins to go abroad in volume larger than generally has been anticipated even by bankers who have been advised of the certainty that a large proportion of the new British loan was to be taken here and paid for in shipments of American metal. There is as yet, however, no appreciable effect upon money market conditions.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- Trading was quiet to-day, but interest was distributed fairly well, and, as prices generally held, the market could not be called a bad market, apart from the all-pervading dullness. There was hardly a price change worth chronicling. Copper Range was bought fairly well at 20 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Two dispatches received to-day from Gen. Chaffee about the battle of Pei-Tsang serve to explain why the casualties were almost entirely Russian and Japanese, as reported in Commander Taussig's dispatch giving the first news of the battle.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 8 -- The Democratic convention of the Seventh Congressional District to-day renominated John L. Burnett of Gadsden for Congress. Mr. Burnett will be opposed by ex-Congressman M.W. Howard, whom he defeated in 1898.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- William Wegener, who was for a number of years the tenor soloist at Sinai Temple, will be heard this Pall and Winter in grand opera. He has signed with the Savage-Grau Opera Company, and will leave soon to join them in New York. Mr. Wegener has a repertoire which comprises all of the standard operas and many lighter works.
Speculation with regard to the probable Republican nominee for Governor was very active yesterday in political circles.

From The Kansas City (Mo.) Journal. Lieut. Burton J. Mitchell, aide to Gen. Funston, writes to The Iola (Kan.) Register, giving some account of the work of pacifying the Insurgents. He thinks that the defeat of Mr. Bryan will finally settle the Philippine trouble, for the insurgent bands are borne up with the belief that Bryan would remove the soldiers and allow the local chiefs to rule the land.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Chinese Minister visited the State Department today and transmitted to this Government the following edict:

The citizens of New York were yesterday somewhat relieved by a lower temperature than prevailed on Tuesday, and at the same time they suffered from a larger percentage of humidity in the atmosphere. A citizen who is an optimist remarked: "It is lucky the heat of yesterday did not wait for the increasing humidity of we would have been all half killed."

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- America has a lead of two matches in the first contest for the Davis International tennis trophy, Whitman and Davis both winning over the English team this afternoon at Longwood. The courts were wet from the heavy rain and afforded the players none too sure a footing.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -- W.J. Bryan's speech, in response to the address of Chairman Richardson notifying him of his nomination for President by the Democratic Convention at Kansas City, was devoted entirely to imperialism and its effects. No mention was made of silver. The full text of the speech is as follows:

BUTTE, Mont., Aug. 8 -- The shaft-house of the Parrot mine was destroyed by fire to-day, entailing a loss of $100,000, with insurance of about $30,000. The fire started in the carpenter shop of the mine, and the flames were soon communicated to the shaft-house adjoining.

TRENTON, Mo., Aug. 8 -- Edward Spencer, a prominent farmer, was found guilty in a justice court of beating his wife, and was sentenced to jail and to pay a fine. The prosecution was forced by Spencer's neighbors, who declared if the law did not interfere they would.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- The thirtieth annual convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America began here to-day, and will continue until Friday. About 300 delegates are in attendance from nearly every State in the Union.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, in reply to the speech of Gov. Thomas notifying him of his nomination at Kansas City, spoke as follows:
James W. Boyle, Tammany leader of the Seventh District, threatened last evening to bring a suit against his opponent for the leadership, Patrick Keahon.

In appointing an Advisory Committee Chairman JONES has made the not discreditable admission that the National Democratic Committee and its Chairman expect to need nudging from time to time, to be told of things that ought not to have been done as well as of those that should have been done and have been overlooked.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding Mr. Rosenberg's assertion in yesterday's TIMES that Englishmen could not stand our "crowded and pestilential" street cars, I beg humbly to say that for dampness, muddiness, foulness, sourness, murkiness, darkness, and pestilentialness generally the London underground is no plus ultra.

ROME, Aug. 8 -- The funeral train bearing the body of King Humbert left Monza at 4:28 P.M., accompanied by the Duke of Aosta, the Count of Turin, and the Duke of Oporto. A large crowd witnessed its departure in silence.

Yesterday was very much richer in social events than Tuesday. The tennis tournament is one of the coups of the Southampton season. There are numerous house parties and dinners there in consequence. The Malvern hop and the dinners preceding it at Bar Harbor are mentioned elsewhere.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When I read the remarks on the civil war contained in the two answers to my late short communication to THE TIMES I feel like gathering these fellow-beings round my knee, soothing their perturbed spirits, and, after stilling their thirst for mere controversy, giving them to drink from the pure waters of fact.

Controller Coler has held up the bills of the experts for work done on the Molineux murder trial. He says that they are exorbitant. If the experts want pay promptly for their services the bills will have to be scaled down, according to Controller Coler, or suits will have to be brought against New York County for the money.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 8 -- A mist straggled down from Green Mountain this morning, and by 10 o'clock the town was enveloped in an impenetrable fog. Despite the gloom and the cold, society continued the active pace set last week. Neither at the Malvern hop nor at numerous dinner parties and receptions was any diminution of enthusiasm over the prospects of the season apparent.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y .,Aug. 8 -- The second day's play in the Long Island lawn tennis championship tournament was started this morning on the courts of the Meadow Club. Two of the matches were for places in the semi-final round, and were productive of sport of more than usual brilliancy.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 8 -- In the trial of ex-Secretary of State Powers on the charge of complicity in the Goebel shooting the defense to-day produced one of its principal witnesses in Surveyor Coolman, who has a chart of the Capitol grounds at Frankfort.

Louis Berger, the switchman on the New York Central Railroad, who was found unconscious with a fractured skull early Tuesday morning, near his post of duty at Seventy-third Street and Twelfth Avenue, died at 11 o'clock yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital without having recovered consciousness.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 9 -- Mrs. W.P. Walley held a reception and musicale at Bournemouth, her Eden Street cottage, this afternoon. The guests were many, and the event a pleasureable one. Among those who contributed to the musical features was Myron Whitney.

Apparently the situation in South Africa has resolved itself into a series of military enigmas of indefinite duration -- but only apparently. The news that the British line of communication has been ruptured at some point or other is quickly followed by other advices noting the re-establishment of the cordon and the defeat of the Boers engaged.

The announcement that the long-expected retirement of Col. Robert F. Simmons as presiding judge on The Jockey Club race tracks had been decided upon by The Jockey Club was made yesterday, when news came from Detroit that Charles H. Pettingill, formerly starter on The Jockey Club tracks, had been engaged to succeed Col. Simmons in the judges' stand, and would begin his duties at The Coney Island Jockey Club's Autumn meeting, beginning Aug. 25.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve, decreased u321,000; circulation, decreased u284,000; bullion, decreased u604,545; other securities, decreased, u1,545,000; other deposits, decreased, u2,052,000; public deposits, increased, u185,000; notes reserve, decreased u139,000; government securities, decreased u4,000.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 9 -- In an interview to-night on Mr. Bryan's speech of acceptance, Senator Hoar said: "Mr. Bryan has put his case with great power and with great dexterity. Many good men the first time they read it, will be much impressed by it, but they will like it less after more careful consideration.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Malatesta, the Anarchist, who is considered by The Tribuna of Rome the leader of the regicide conspiracy, was interviewed in London yesterday. He is represented as having said:

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Fannie McPherson, a young woman who has been engaged in confidence work in various Eastern cities, was arrested to-night in the South Station. The matron saw her hovering about the cash drawer in the restaurant, and, recognizing her likeness to published portraits, called a policeman.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Senator Hanna of Ohio, manager of the Republican campaign, when asked his opinion to-day of Mr. Bryan's speech, remarked:
CAPE HENRY, Va., Aug. 9 -- The following wreck report is received from Weather Bureau Observer Dosher at Hatteras, N.C.:

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Senator Henry J. Coggeshall, who has represented the Oneida district in the State Senate for eighteen years continuously, was turned down in the Republican County Convention at Rome to-day, after one of the most interesting political contests ever witnessed.

John C. Hanley of St. Paul. Minn., President of the National Cotton Growers' Association, Secretary of the National Grain Growers' Association, and presiding officer at the recent International Congress of Agricultural Associations at Paris, is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- An important dispatch has been received in diplomatic quarters in Washington, forwarded from the Foreign Office of one of the powers taking part in the International movement, and giving with much detail a conversation by Li-Hung-Chang, in which he expresses his despair over the condition of the Chinese Government and his fears that the anti-foreign element has gained complete ascendency at Peking.

Trading in the market for outside securities was again yesterday very limited, and, apart from the transactions in two or three issues, the day's business showed little of any interest. A good deal of attention was drawn to the new British war loan bonds, which were actively traded in. In other sections of the market only a few sales were recorded, and changes in price were generally insignificant.

LONDON, Aug 9 -- At the third day's racing of the Brighton August meeting today the Brighton Highweight Handicap, for three-year-olds and upward, one mile, was won by A. Stedall's chestnut filly La Lune, by Despair, out of Moonflower, guided by Rigby.
The German-American McKinley and Roosevelt League held a very largely attended meeting at 102 East Fourteenth Street last night. Standing room only was the rule.

No relief was experienced yesterday from the torrid heat to which New Yorkers have been subjected for the past few days. Forecaster Emery's prediction that the heat would remain has been fully verified, and residents of this city will willingly, if not cheerfully, testify that the man who has charge of the weather predictions has in this instance, if in no other, been absolutely correct.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- Albert H. Cunha, the big centre of Yale's football eleven last year and catcher on the 'Varsity baseball team, will enter Stanford University this Fall, graduating with the class of 1901. Cunha's father, who is a wealthy merchant of Honolulu, has written for him to come home, and after a stay of a month in the islands he will return and enter Stanford.

SAUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Two sensational matches were played here this morning on the courts of the Meadow Club in the semi-final round of the Long Island lawn tennis championship tournament. Richard Stevens of the Hoboken Cricket Club won a decisive victory over the former holder of the National championship title, "Bob" Wrenn, in three hotly-contested sets.

The second report of the Executive Committee of the New York Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief has just been made public by its Chairman, L.T. Chamberlain. The report begins by saying that the receipts of the relief treasury are over $200,000, and that the daily receipts during the two and a half months of really organized effort have averaged $2,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- Field Marshal Count von Waldersee, recently appointed to the supreme command of the German forces in China and looked upon in some quarters as likely to be chosen as commander in chief of the international troops, was interviewed this evening by a correspondent shortly after his arrival in Berlin.
Col. R.G. Lowe, Vice President of the Galveston and Dallas (Texas) News Publishing Company, is at the Hotel Imperial.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A.T. Huntington, Chief of the Division of Loans and Currency in the Treasury Department, has prepared an eighty-seven page circular of information concerning United States bonds, paper currency, coin, the production of precious metals, Among the subjects upon which information is given are the following:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 9 -- The priests of the Newark Diocese played a game of baseball with those of the New York Diocese on the Seton Hall College grounds this afternoon. The general public was not admitted, so only a few witnessed the contest. Most of the clergymen were young, and had played ball during their college days.

Ex-Mayor Gleason of Long Island City is the latest convert to the man's shirt waist. He came over to Manhattan a few nights ago and saw several young men sporting the cool garment, and being pleased and taken by them, the ex-Mayor hied himself back to the centre of the city the next morning and ordered a dozen.
PHILLIPSBURG, N.J, Aug. 9 -- Father Diana, the priest in charge of the Catholic church at Alpha, has been arrested on a charge of forgery, preferred by six members of the parish.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Representatives of many of the leading fire insurance companies of the United States held an important conference at the West End Hotel this afternoon. Five sections of the agreement of 1900 affecting fire insurance companies in operation in the country were adopted.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Dwight F. Davis and Holcombe Ward, American tennis champions in doubles, defeated the English pair, E.D. Black and H.R. Barrett, this evening in the International Tennis Tournament at Longwood in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4. This was the third consecutive victory of the American team.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Oswald Sanderson's fin keel sloop Anoatol, N.Y. Y.C., and E.M. Wiley's keel sloop Cygnet have been overhauled and repainted and launched from the Jacob yard, and the keel sloop Metahka has been hauled out at the same yard to have her rudder adjusted and other minor difficulties remedied.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Harry Caldwell of New Hampshire defeated Burns Pierce in a twenty-mile motor paced race on the Coliseum track this evening in 34:30 3-5, winning by 240 yards. Watson Coleman of this city lowered the track record to 1:34 in a motor paced exhibition mile.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Marlanus De Waal, seventeen years old, a son of A.E. De Waal of Chestnut Street, Nutley, was drowned at Green Pond, Morris County, yesterday afternoon, by the swamping of a rowboat, and three Nutley people were endangered. Dr. George S. Philhower, De Waal, Mrs. Phlihower, and Edmund J. Guthrie went overboard.

It was not very brisk yesterday at the different resorts. There was a little entertaining, but nothing of a kind out of the ordinary. Newport always has its round of luncheons and dinners, and just now it is interested in golf, which until the advent of Mrs. John Jacob Astor has been sadly neglected.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 -- New Yorks played excellent all-around baseball to-day in the game against Cincinnati, and their batting at opportune times enabled them to win. The home team played a faultless game in the field, but Scott was the stumbling block to victory. On the other hand, Mercer was steady and had the ball under control at all times.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- An address to the Democrats of the United States, signed by Mr. Bryan and others, was issued to-night. It urges the formation of Democratic clubs and is as follows:

OAKLAND, Cal., Aug. 9 -- Don Carlos Ezeta, ex-President of San Salvador, appeared before Justice of the Peace John Stetson, in response to a citation on an order of examination, requiring him to answer questions as to his property possessions, a judgment for $63 having been found against him.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug 9 -- George Welsh and "Doc" Roberts, young colored waiters employed at the Hotel Imperial, Maryland Avenue, near the beach, were found asphyxiated by gas this morning.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- There has been a fire on the surface at the Parrot mine, and hoisting will be suspended for a few weeks in consequence. The stock opened this morning 2 1/2 off at 40, touched 39 1/2, and then rallied to 40 3/4, with over 3,000 shares traded in during the first half of the day. Copper Range, advanced 3/4 to 20 3/4, and Butte 1, to 63.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Thirty men returned cards in the preliminary medal play round of the Otsego Golf Club tournament this morning, and the sixteen who qualified for the Otsego Cup played their first round at match play this afternoon. The gold medal offered for the best score in the qualifying round was handily won by Devereaux Emmett of Garden City, who finished eight strokes better than any of the other competitors.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Charles Glenolin of 73 Jefferson Street, while crazed by the heat this evening, made four attempts to end his life. He was first seen wading out into the water near the Glenwood Station.

John Burns, sixteen years old, a son of ex-Alderman James Burns of Jersey City, and Henry Burns, John's brother, were arrested at the Salvation Army lodging house, 161 Pavonia Avenue, shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning. John was charged with stealing $945 from Oscar Kreig, his employer, and Henry was said to be his accomplice.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- After an imposing ceremonial that was withal as simple as was possible under the circumstances, the body of King Humbert of Italy was to-day deposited in the Pantheon here, after having been borne through miles of lanes formed by his sorrowing countrymen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9 -- After quite an absence from Newport, W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse returned to his villa, East Bourne Lodge, to-day, from his home in England, accompanied by his son, W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse, Jr., and Sheldon Whitehouse. Mr. Whitehouse, Jr., recently returned from an Abyssinian expedition.

NEWPORT, Aug. 9 -- When the last belated members of the New York Yacht Club's fleet, now on its fifty-fifth annual cruise, reached this port to-night after a tedious run from New London, there was gathered in Newport Harbor the largest and most magnificent fleet of pleasure craft ever assembled in American or any other waters.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @ 62 1/2. There were no sales.
Max Cohn has purchased the plot 242 and 244 Clinton Street, 40 by 72, and will erect thereon a seven-story store and loft building.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 -- The Hon. H.A. Taylor, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Department, Washington; T.V. Powderly, United States Immigration Commissioner, and C.S. Hamlin of Boston are in the city for the purpose of conferring with the local steamship and railway companies on the matter of providing for a more searching examination of immigrants destined for the United States, but landing at Canadian ports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The State Department at 10 o'clock this morning made public the text of the note addressed to the Chinese Government, which was last night delivered by Acting Secretary Adee to Minister Wu for immediate transmission to the authorities at Peking.

Mr. COLER describes his article in the current number of The Independent as "academic." It is so in a sense that perhaps he did not intend to imply, as the shall presently point out. But that it is without very decided significance with regard to certain personalities in New York poli-. tics is an absurd suggestion.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 9 -- According to news received by the Empress of Japan, one European who was serving the Chinese was killed in the recent fighting at TienTsin, and two men, supposed to be Frenchmen, have been taken prisoners by the allied forces.

Our Government is guided by the clear sense and prudence that have marked its conduct from the beginning of the trouble in China, when it postpones any action on the proposition to appoint the German General, Count WALDERSEE, Commander in Chief of the forces co-operating in China.

Joseph H. Manley of Maine was yesterday in control at Republican National headquarters. Mr. Manley is a hard worker, and while he is sanguine of the success of the McKinley and Roosevelt ticket, he frequently manifests a little uneasiness about the result in November.

David B. Hill spent a few hours in New Work yesterday en route for Albany. He came to the city from Normandle-by-the-Sea, and the politicians were not aware of his presence until he had lunched at the Hoffman House and started on his way home.

Joseph Rabiner, the young man who, in attempting to kill his father, shot and killed his brother-in-law, Isaac Stein, has a very slight chance of recovery from the wounds he inflicted on himself after the homocide at the Holland House, Rockaway Beach, late Wednesday afternoon. The father, Jacob Rabiner, received two superficial wounds, and within a few days he will be discharged from the hospital.
MUNICH, Aug. 9 -- The players met in the fourteenth round of the international chess tournament to-day, when the following results were announced:
Controller Coler made public yesterday the bills of the handwriting and chemical experts for work on the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "Consent of the Governed" controversy now going on in your columns prompts me to remind some of your numerous correspondents who have undertaken to apply that doctrine to the Philippine question that the American government of the islands is built upon the Treaty of Paris and doesn't need anybody's consent.

JAMESPORT, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Ex-Register Hugh McLaughlin of Brooklyn spends most of his time fishing here and the rest of it sitting on the porch of the Great Peconic Hotel. He was in the latter place this afternoon when approached upon the subject of Controller Coler's article on Commercialism in Politics.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9 -- The Cuban teachers as a body, who have been trying to devise some suitable means of expressing their thanks to Harvard, and to all people who have helped them, have adopted plans. A loving cup, to be presented to the university, and the National concert which will be given next Thursday evening, will partly serve the purpose.

Quotations generally advanced upon the Stock Exchange yesterday. But there was no attending increase in activity. The Stock Exchange tape stood almost still during most of the day. Such business as was transacted was easily traceable to the operations of room traders, who still have the market to themselves.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The wedding of Miss Lavinia Payne, daughter of James P. Payne, a New York business man, and Howard J. Barnett of Reading, Penn., was celebrated here yesterday at the residence off the bride's parents. The Rev. S.T. Graham of Trinity Episcopal Church officiated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I offer a protest through your paper at the treatment now being accorded to the patrons of the Brooklyn elevated roads? I was corning down on a train of the Kings County road this morning, when there began a general discussion at the way the passengers are being abused.

The entire property of Harper Brothers, including realty, plant, and right to use the firm name, was sold under foreclosure yesterday for $1,100,000. This, the only bid made for the property, came from Adrian H. Joline, who acted as the representative of Alexander E. Orr, Chairman of the Committee on Reorganization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When I read Mr. Bryan's speech at Indianapolis I could not but think of the words of Scripture, Matthew xxiii., 29: "Woe unto you scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites: because ye build the tombs of the prophets and garnish the sepulchres of the righteous."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The statement from Berlin that all the powers have agreed to the appointment of Count von Waldersee as the Commander in Chief of the allied forces does not aply to the present operations. It is well understood among the powers that there is to be no Commander in Chief for the advance on Peking.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. F.E. Elwell is to be congratulated for his letter on the Tivoli arrests, published in THE TIMES of the 7th inst.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 9 -- A stranger, thought to be Frank Ronick, from Virginia, jumped from the State House dome this afternoon and was killed.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 -- The unique spectacle of houses being given away has been witnessed in the upper districts of New Orleans for some days past, and has caused a boom in the house movers' trade never before known here. The streets for squares have been blocked with houses for days, and the real estate men have reaped increased profits from the sale of vacant lots to put them on.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I was pleased with the article "Kipling Again," signed "May Harris," in your issue of Saturday, Aug. 4. Not often does one find such insight into Kipling by men and one never looks for it in women. In my time I have known but three women who knew or cared much for Kipling.
BAY CITY, Mich., Aug. 10 -- To-night George D. Jackson declined to accept the Congressional nomination unanimously given him yesterday by the Democrats of the Tenth District.
Senator Platt was interviewed at Manhattan Beach last night and while he would not express a preference for the Governorship, he said:

The scene of this unpretentious tale is laid partly in Missouri and partly in Kansas in the days when the friends of freedom and the advocates of slavery were in hot contest over the new territory. The Jay-Hawkers, from whom the book gets its name, were bands of "free-soil" men who raided Missouri homes for the purpose of carrying slaves into Kansas and freedom.

The first volume of Andrew Lang's "History of Scotland" covers the period between the Roman occupation and the death of Cardinal Beaton, in 1546, and includes not only a record of events of historical importance, but also sketches of social life and manners from a very early period. The author long ago gained a reputation for thoroughness, and this has been greatly enhanced by the exhaustive study which we now have before us for notice.

The hearing in the proceedings to secure the removal of John F., W.T., and E.H. Gaynor and Benjamin D. Greene, accused of conspiracy to defraud the Government, to the jurisdiction of the Georgia courts was continued before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Department of State made public this morning the following telegram from Minister Conger, which was received by Minister Wu late last night, (Aug. 9,) being contained in a telegram sent to him by the Taotal of Shanghai: ...

In a recent magazine article Mr. Josephson of the John Crerar Library of Chicago puts in a strong plea for a specially founded and endowed Bibliographical Institute, the income from such endowment to be ample enough for the employment of a competent staff of bibliographers and scientific men, his principal aim being the preparation of a complete and accurate bibliography covering the entire field of American literature.

Mrs. Mark, the mother of sixteen-year-old Florence Margaret Mark, who eloped with Charlie Chong Glow, a Chinaman, devoted the entire day yesterday in the search for her daughter. The eloping couple failed to appear at the law office of Mark Alter at 115 West Tenth Street, as they had arranged to do.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Baron Russell of Killowen, Lord Chief Justice of England, died this morning as the result of an operation performed yesterday by Dr. Treves.

Mr. McLaugblin has done a signal service to historical literature in his volume, "Matthew Lyon, the Hampden of Congress." His is the kind of patient, scholarly research that never receives remuneration in monetary value. Its lofty motive and abiding service must be its own exceeding great reward. The author tells us of years of work, and then of more years of searching for a publisher, and finding none.

-- Some irritation seems to have been created in England by the amount of attention attracted and of discussion created in manufacturing circles here by the aircushioned "spinning ring," a recent product of American ingenuity which is confidently expected to work marked changes in our textile industries.

Over 5,500 people, men, women, and children, attended the fifth annual family excursion of the Republican organization of the Twenty-first Assembly District yesterday. The excursion was to Oscawanna Island, up the Hudson. Abraham Gruber, the leader of the district, was the central figure of the big party, and received many ovations.

"A.L.L.," New York, writes: "Elizabeth Akers seems to be right in doubting the account given of 'the amiable child' by Kathryn Jarboe. The story of the drowning of little St. Claire and the statement that 'Lord Claire' owned property in 1797 on the Hudson cannot be substantiated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Bids for the armor for the battleships -- six armored cruisers and three protected cruisers -- authorized by the last two sessions of Congress, were opened at the Navy Department to-day. The armor advertised for aggregates 35,950 tons, and constitutes the largest item of its character ever opened to competition by the Navy Department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest the articles published in your paper at different periods on the question of vertical penmanship in our public schools and beg to add a few remarks on the subject.

Gen. Cox, who died the other day, left his war memoirs in such shape that his son announces through Charles Scribner's Sons that there is nothing to hinder their early publication in two volumes, with maps and illustrations, as had originally been arranged between author and publisher. The work will be entitled "Military Reminiscences of the Civil War."

In the great Madison Square Garden, consecrated as the home of prize fighting in the city by virtue of a lease to the Twentieth Century Athletic Club, about 9,000 coatless, hatless, and perspiring men and boys saw Robert Fitzsimmons knock out "Gus" Ruhlin in the sixth round of what was to have been a twenty-five round fight last night.

NEWPORT, Aug. 10 -- The torpedo finder, the invention of Thomas J. Moriarty, was given another trial by the examining board of the torpedo station this afternoon in the harbor. The contrivance was fixed into the head of a torpedo, and the latter fired from a torpedo tube as in actual practice. The torpedo was regulated to sink at the end of its run, which it did.

At a meeting of the Board of Direction of the recently organized American Publishers' Association, an organization representing the largest houses in this city and Boston, the Secretary was authorized to make to booksellers and bookbuyers the declaration which follows of the purposes of the association:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Since writing my former letter, I have obtained a little more light on the subject of the little grave of St. Claire Pollock, in Riverside Park. As the matter will probably continue to excite interest and inquiry from time to time, as it always has done, perhaps it is best to put on record all that is positively known about it.

The work of changing the Forty-second Street surface railroad into an electric line, which has been in hand for a year and is not yet finished, has occasioned great public inconvenience and annoyed to a serious degree those living or doing business along the route of this destructive improvement.

In some ways the week closes with encouraging indications as to the immediate future in China. It is now known that the edict permitting the Ministers to communicate with their Governments in cipher is being carried out. Though the communications are not yet prompt or full, our own Government has heard from Mr. CONGER, and he reports the condition of things no worse than when last heard from.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Not yet need literary Alexanders sigh in vain for more worlds to conquer -- least of all need, the multitudinous army of story tellers despair. Literature, it seems no less than civilization, does sometimes "git forrid on a powder-cart," surely in the last few years Pegasus has followed fast in the wake of war's juggernaut car.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The Executive Committee of the Populist Party-to-day decided to call a meeting of the National Committee of that party, to be held in this city on Aug. 27. At that meeting the question of filling the vacancy, on the Presidential ticket occasioned by Mr. Towne's declination of the nomination for the Vice Presidency will be disposed of.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days of combination of capital or trusts on the one side and the combination of labor on the other we hear a great deal said about rights and very little said about duties. Now wherever there are rights there must of necessity be duties. If there was no capital there could be no recompense for labor.

The death of Baron RUSSELL will be mourned most sincerely in this country, where his fame was only less established than in England, and where he had many warm friends and admirers. He was only sixty-seven, and that, for a hard-worked English lawyer and statesman, is an age at which death seems sadly premature.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Mayor James K. McGuire, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, declared to-day that he is not a candidate for the nomination for Governor, and that he favors the nomination of Controller Bird S. Coler. Heretofore the Mayor has said that he favored the nomination of "a man of the type of Coler," and not making a specific declaration in favor of New York's Controller.

Many men are indebted to the suggestions of all-pervading trade for their reading, which at once creates and forestalls their needs. Like a certain other provision for human necessity, it is on hand with mental pabulum for every event in life and in every season of the rolling year.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: While our friend F.C. Hunt is "in out of the storm," I would suggest, that he send to the Howard Publishing Company, Campau Building, Detroit, Mich., and get a copy of "Francis Bacon's Cipher Story" with which to while away the time.

The Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief received the following cablegram yesterday from William T. Fee, United States Consul at Bombay, and Chairman of the American-Indian Famine Relief Committee:

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Were any evidence needed that Americans have but lately begun to be interested in their own history, to know that their country has a history, it might be found in the dates and contents of the papers gathered in Volume VIII. of Dr. Edward Everett Hale's works, as "Addresses and Essays on Subjects of History, Education, and Government."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: While cherishing the deepest reverence for the superb genius of the immortal bard of Avon, all Baconian heresies to the contrary notwithstanding, it is still allowable to note anachronisms in his works where they involve popular ideas of history.

Now that we are studying China, some short allusions to Chinese art as much as anything else might explain what is the mental status of the Chinaman. M. Paleologue is certainly, of all Europeans, the one who has most carefully studied Chinese art. The Chinese are by no means to be disdained as landscape painters.
