GOODLAND, Kan., Aug. 10 -- Two men, who on Sunday last robbed a Union Pacific train in Colorado and killed a passenger, were surrounded in a ranch house near here to-day. During the fight which followed, one of the robbers was killed, and the other was burned to death. Two possemen -- J.B. Riggs, owner of the Commercial Hotel of Goodland, and George Cullins -- were severely wounded.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 3,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Our esteemed contemporary The Evening Post quotes from a correspondent of The (London) Academy the following anecdote of the inimitable Beaumarchais, in support of the opinion that "there are many roads to style; no royal one":

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- In the first half of the day Boston traded in 700 shares of mining stocks, one-half of the total in Parrot, 800 railroad, 400 miscellaneous, and 2,300 unlisted shares (2,000 of them Sugar.) Grand total, 4,200 shares. There was not a variation in prices calling for mention apart from Sugar, the market for which closely followed New York.

CANTON, Aug. 10 -- President McKinley's stay at his home in this city assumed even less of a vacation air when telephone connection was permanently established between the White House and the President's library. Secretary Cortelyou has been provided with an additional stenographer from Washington, and his work, which begins early, extends late into the night.

LONDON, July 30 -- Possibly because of the extreme heat, the Omar Khayyam discussion continues in a languid sort of way. Some one has just demonstrated to his own satisfaction that the Rubaiyat was not written until 400 years after Omar's death, and that, although it is in substance a Persian poem, it is not entitled to be called the work of Omar Khayyam.

The purpose of this article is to protest most earnestly against the cruel and monstrous alterations and mutilations of this great poem, as they occur in a volume issued from the press a little over a year ago, and edited by Mr. George W. Rauch of Lexington, Ky.

To-day's bank statement will be awaited with more than ordinary interest, though it is uncertain to what extent the week's gold exports may be included. From this time forward, however, the showing must become more manifest and doubtless more influential.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 10 -- The private office of John N. Baldwin, assistant general attorney of the Union Pacific Railroad, was to-day turned into a tribunal wherein referees representing the Supreme Court will, for some weeks to come, listen, to the evidence and arguments in the case of the State of Nebraska against the Union Pacific Railroad Company.

ROBERT J. McWILLIAMS, New York, writes: "Four or five years ago Scribner's Magazine for Christmas contained a poem by Robert Louis Stevenson entitled, 'Ticonderoga; or, the Naming of the Name.' It occurred to me at the time I read the poem that I had previously read or heard a similar story, or legend.

Although yesterday's temperature did not break any records it kept the official thermometer above 90 all afternoon. The breeze that was blowing for the greater part of the afternoon did not make the heat endurable. At times it blew as hard as twelve miles an hour, but it came from the southwest and was hot and stifling.

MILFORD, Penn., Aug. 10 -- The nomination for Representative on the Democratic ticket in Pike County is being hotly contested by Michael J. Lynn of Tafton and Joseph B. Westbrook of Dingman's. A. nomination on the Democratic ticket in Pike County is equivalent to an election, and each aspirant is struggling hard for success at the primaries to-morrow evening.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The note signed by Acting Secretary of State Adee and given to Minister Wu for transmission to his Government has been submitted by the United States to the other powers.

Beginnings, as we all know, are usually small things, but continuations are not always strikingly great ones, and the place occupied in the world by the prolonged prose fable has become, in our time, among the incidents of literature, the most surprising example to be named of swift and extravagant growth, a development beyond the measure of very early appearance.

Fritz Miller, who was a prisoner in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning declared that he had been brutally assaulted by Policeman Perkins. His testimony was corroborated by six witnesses, one of them a policeman.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- All fashionable Rye turned out to-day to attend a fete given for the Village Improvement Association on the grounds of the American Yacht Club at Milton Point. This innovation on the part of the club was granted at the request of the women, who managed the affair, and nearly a thousand persons from Rye and the neighboring villages of Mamaroneck, Port Chester, and Greenwich attended.

John Hogan, a former Battalion Chief of the Jersey City Fire Department, yesterday attempted to kill his wife by cutting her throat, and then cut His own throat. The scene of the crime was 95 Danforth Street, where Hogan, his wife, and his wife's mother, Mrs. Simonson, boarded with Mrs. John McNeil.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 10 -- A woman's body was found in the ocean at the foot of Chelsea Avenue at 6 o'clock this morn- ing. She was identified as a Slav servant girl employed in the Chelsea boarding house. Her first name was Mary, but her second name was not known. She was hired at an intelligence office at 315 East Seventy-third Street, New York.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 10 -- Senator Tillman to-day gave his views on the China question. He is unalterably opposed, he says, to missionaries going to China. He favors convening Congress at this crisis, and will support an alliance with Great Britain and Japan to prevent partition. He said:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- The local market acted at the opening as though "something was going to happen," but it did not. Marsden and Union Traction stirred a little very early in the day, but nothing came of it. Asphalt 5s, which relieved the monotony yesterday afternoon by reaching 76 1/2, were reasonably steady to-day near 75 3/4.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- A jury in the London Sheriff's Court to-day gave Louie Freear, the actress, L800 damages against George Lederer, the English manager of Sire Brothers and the Greater New York Amusement Company for breach of contract. She was discharged, it appeared, before the termination of her agreement because she refused to sing on the Maguolia Grove (New York theatre) Roof Garden.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Apropos of the interesting article about Shakespeare printed in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of July 21 last, permit me to point out a master faculty of Shakespeare, which deserves notice. Besides being a genial delineator of character and great literary painter of nature, Shakespeare was also an orator.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 10 -- One of the unique features of the season will be an entertainment for the benefit of the Town Hospital in Music Hall, Aug. 29. The entertainment is under the general charge of Mrs. A.C. Barney, whose talents for arranging such affairs is as well known here as in Washington, her Winter home.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a letter on "A. Lang and Music," in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 4, by Mr. Cunninghame Moffet, he tries to prove that "most poets and literary men hate music."

Proceedings have been begun to set aside the will of Robert Courtright, the eccentric Fordham hackman who died on June 23 at his residence, 2,726 Marion Avenue, at the age of seventy-six. Courtright's career was a checkered one. It was said before his death that he was worth millions, and that his favorite pastime was to count his gold, which he kept in bags hid away in his home, at night.

G.P. Putnam's Sons have in preparation a new issue, in two editions, of Gov. Roosevelt's works, one edition being in cloth and the other in paper. The set, which contains fifteen volumes, will be called American Idesls Edition. It will not only include those works by Mr. Roosevelt published by the Putnams, but also those of his books which have been presented, through other houses.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- W.A. Larned defeated Richard Stevens here this morning in three straight sets in the final match of the championship singles in the Long Island lawn tennis championship tournament. The former champion of Yale, John A. Allen, also won over Samuel Hardy, the Pacific Coast star, in the final contest of the consolation singles.

Conditions in the market for outside securities, yesterday counterparted those on the Stock Exchange, and the day was one of the dullest the curb market has had this year. It was only here and there in the market that any disposition to trade was shown, and transactions in particular stocks seldom exceeded 100 or 200 shares.
Senator GRADY is said to have remarked of the possible candidacy of Mr. COLER for the Governorship:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- A sensational incident of the last day of the trotting meeting here was the punishment meted out to Driver Charles J. O'Brien for his alleged pulling of Klmer D. in the 2:18 Class pacing race, four heats of which were finished yesterday, and which was completed to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The monthly report of the statistician of the Department of Agriculture shows the average condition of cotton on Aug. 1 to have been 76, as compared with 75.8 On July 1, 1900; 84 on Aug. 1, 1899; 91.2 on Aug. 1, 1898, and 85.3, the mean of August averages of the last ten years.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Andrew Carnegie has given out the following statement regarding the situation in the Far East and the relation of the United States to future developments there:

Considerable discussion is going on at present among the clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this diocese concerning the election of an assistant, or Bishop Coadjutor, for Bishop Potter. Bishop Potter has been in orders for forty-three years, and despite his sixty-odd years is yet remarkably active, but it is pointed out that the labors of this diocese are far too heavy for one man to direct.

James Blackwell, who has four aliases -- Stanley, Saunders, Cameron, and Fisher -- was yesterday taken to the Centre Street Police Court as a member of a notorious and successful gold brick gang. He is wanted in Springfield, Mass., and Police Inspector Boyle of that city asked that he be held pending the arrival of requisition papers.

Schedules of Hugh W. Adams, doing business as Hugh W. Adams Co., commission pig iron merchants at 15 Beekman Street, were filed yesterday by William G. McAdoo, the assignee. They show total liabilities of $385,534, of which there are direct $154,498, and contingent $231,036; nominal assets, $280,838, and actual assets, $70,762.

A rumor was started yesterday by some politicians gathered at Democratic State Headquarters in the St. James Building, that William L. Strong, ex-Mayor of New York, had declared to a friend that he would support Controller Coler for Governor if nominated against a Platt machine candidate.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- The official Reichsanzeiger this evening publishes a proclamation forbidding the export of arms or war material to China or to ports adjacent to Chinese territory.

Dr. John Alexander Dowie, "Overseer on Earth of the Christian Catholic Church in Zion," arrived in this city yesterday from Chicago. The earthly Zion of which Dr. Dowie is overseer is situated on the shores of Lake Michigan, forty-two miles from Chicago, but the overseer does not live there yet, because the city is not completed.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Showery weather prevailed this afternoon, but the rainfall was so slight that the track was not affected. The racing, was excellent, and the starting prompt and good, the Clark gate feeing used in the first three races. The Pepper Stakes, with a guaranteed value of $5,000, was the feature of the day.

The announcement in THE TIMES yesterday that Col. Robert F. Simmons, presiding judge on The Jockey Club race tracks, had resigned, and that Charles H. Pettingill had been appointed to fill the vacancy in the judges' stand, has been confirmed by an official statement from F.O. Hanlon, Assistant Secretary of The Jockey Club.

The examination of John L. Dunlap on a charge of usury was resumed yesterday before Magistrate Pool in the Jefferson Market Police Court. Charles Winten, the complaining witness, who is a clerk, testified that since February, 1898, until recently he had renewed monthly a loan of $30, getting only $25.04, the rest going for fees.

Ernest Tribelhorn has sold for Spencer C. Judson, to an estate, the seven-story apartment house 2,790 and 2,792 Broadway, between One Hundred and Seventh and One Hundred and Eighth Streets, 51.6 by 105.4 by 50.4 by 93.9.

Fannie Frazier, the sixteen-year-old adopted daughter of Mrs. James McWilliams, who was brought here by her mother on Tuesday night, and, who, it is alleged, has been abducted and ill-treated, was brought before Magistrate Mayo in the Centre Street Court again yesterday afternoon.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 10 -- On the grounds of the Point Judith Country Club this afternoon beneath a clear blue sky, with a natural stage on the green lawn and with tall pine trees for a background, Shakespeare's "As You Like It" was produced before a large and fashionable assembly, practically all of the cottage colony being in attendance.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The Times-Herald to-morrow will say:

About $3,250,000 in gold will go to London by the Campania to-day, making a total shipment of about $8,552,000 worth of American gold to Great Britain and France this week. Of this amount, $2,700,000 was sent on account of the British war bonds and $1,602,000 was shipped to France. Further gold payments for the American allotment of the British war bonds are anticipated as likely next week.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: As my calling is that of actor, I did not think it strange, some four or five years ago, that I was asked by Dr. Orville Owen of Detroit and a shrewd middle-aged gentleman, who was presented as the business representative of the publishers of Dr. Owen's books, to read a play called "The Earl of Essex," with a view to playing a part therein.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Capt. F.W. Sanger of the Monmouth Beach Golf Club to-day presented a cup to be played for over the Monmouth links. Eight players who qualify will play off the first round, match play, before Aug. 25. The semi-finals and finals will be played on the latter date.
The following letter, hitherto unpublished, from Gen. W.T. Sherman to United States Senator J.R. Doolittle of Wisconsin, is printed in the current issue of The North American Review:
WATERLOO, Iowa, Aug. 10 -- The Republican State Committee has announced that Gov. Roosevelt will open the campaign in the West on Sept. 20 in this city. This will be his only speech in Iowa.

We have it on the authority of Prof. Charles Eliot Norton, the American literary executor of John Ruskin, that there will be no "authorized biography" of Ruskin. Prof. Norton remarked, on leaving this country for England a few weeks ago, that he doubted "the existence of any distinctive literary remains."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The August report of the statistician of the Department of Agriculture shows the following averages of condition upon Aug. 1:

The lives of s.everal persons were imperiled yesterday by a fire which destroyed the three-story apartment house at 158 Bayard Street, Brooklyn. The fire started in the apartment of Mrs. Conrad Weir, on the ground floor of the building.

NEWPORT, Aug. 10 -- This evening Mrs. Ogden Mills gave another large, brilliant dinner in honor of Lord and Lady Pauncefote, to thirty guests. During the dinner Bussell's Hungarian Band played on the veranda, and after the dinner there was dancing.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have recently read a letter In THE SATURDAY REVIEW, signed by Mr. Arthur T. Vance, in which the writer very confidently asserts that the late David Hannum of Homer, N.Y., is the "original" of David Harum. I had thought this point settled long ago by the explicit denial of a similar statement, written by Mr. Westcott's sister.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 10 -- A heavy thunder shower put an end to the international tennis at Longwood this afternoon. When play began it seemed an almost ideal day for tennis. Notwithstanding that the climax came yesterday when the Americans won the decisive point, the "gallery" was larger than on any previous day.

Now the green tea goes round, brewed in a metal pot, with stalks of mint and cubes of beetroot sugar - a sickly concoction, in truth, yet preferable to the spiced coffee that is the only alternative in a land where the sons of men appreciate neither alcohol nor cold drinks of any sort, and the daughters of men lend not the grace of their presence to the festive board.
First Lieut. Lawrence B. Simonds, Eighth Infantry, will proceed to Fort Snelling, Minnesota, and join his company.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- Evidence is fast accumulating that a dissolution of the Dominion Parliament will take place at no distant date. October has been fixed upon by certain newspapers as the proper month in which to hold a general election, and there is much to be said in its favor. But the date, or even the month, when Sir Wilfrid Laurier will appeal to the people has not yet been decided upon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his latest communication Mr. Breck makes several slight mistakes in referring to those who have the temerity to differ from him on the Philippine question. Speaking for myself, I have no time or "thirst for mere controversy," or to make "ranting and unsubstantiated assertions do duty for proved facts."

Nicholas II. is a man of much more than average intelligence, quick of apprehension, keen in investigating, fertile in distinctions, but somewhat slow in reaching definite conclusions, and slower still in drawing practical consequences from them. The two qualities which have heretofore stood him in best stead are his power of observation and his splendid memory.

VIENNA, July 28 -- The youthful King of Servia's love affair, to all appearance, will be attended by serious consequences for Servia and the Obrenovitch dynasty. Servia belongs to Austria's sphere of interest; a great party in the former always hold to Austria, but the majority of the people sympathize with Russia.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The revival of the famous Long Island lawn tennis championship tournament was brought to a close this afternoon on the courts of the Meadow Club with the series of English-American matches. There was a larger gathering of spectators than on any previous day of the meeting and the event was made a gala occasion.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 11 -- The big day of the League of American Wheelmen divisional meet, when racing occurred at Buttonwood Park, was fully as successful, from a sporting point of view, as any the L.A.W. ever held in New England. The races brought together the largest number of professional amateur wheelmen that has ever been seen in New England since the National Cycling Association came on top to control the sport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having perused Mr. Rosenberg's letter in your issue of the 7th, and the answer of "A.C." in to-day's issue, I cannot help expressing my pleasure that the "explosion" which your first-named correspondent awaits has been of such a mild "firecracker" nature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My newsdealer can vouch for the assertion that I am a daily reader of your paper. I scan its pages carefully, yet somehow I missed reading in the issue of July 6 the letter of W.H. Lewiston. It was handed to me to-day, citing the difference between Mr. J.T. Oakley, the Tammany leader, and Mr. J.F. Pegnam, the Republican leader, both of the Fourth District, Manhattan.

Freda Benjamin, eighteen years of age, and her sister Clara, twelve, daughters of Herman Benjamin of 690 Union Avenue, the Bronx, were drowned at the Oak Point bath at the foot of East One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, at 6:30 o'clock last evening. Their mother, Mrs. Ida Benjamin, and Dr. Cohen, who lives at the same address, narrowly escaped the same fate while they were trying to rescue the girls.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11 -- While a great many are anxiously waiting for the military tournament, there are many who want to see a second Horse Show. The second annual exhibition of the Norwood Park Horse Show, which will be held on Sept. 8, is coming only three weeks off. While Miss Norma L. Munro, who will manage the exhibition, is in Europe, still the details were arranged by her before sailing.

The occupation of the Porto Rican women, so the girl found, is in passing the time as comfortably as possible in doing absolutely nothing, if gossip can be called nothing, for her leisure gives her ample time for that. And the girl herself formed the subject of some of the gossip she found.
NEWPORT, Aug. 11 -- To-day Newport passed through its third warmest day of the season with the thermometer registering 91 degrees.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Before a slim crowd this afternoon at the Washington Park race track Cresceus demonstrated his claim to the title of the fastest trotting stallion in the country by beating Tommy Britton in straight heats. A slight rain made the track lightning fast, and in the first heat a local record was broken, Cresceus reeling off the mile in 2:06 1/2.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- One of the chief topics of interest in Princeton at the present time is football, and attention has been turned in this direction, preparations having been made for welcoming back Old Nassau's gridiron yeterans. The university field has been put in fine condition for the early season practice, and everything is now ready for the preliminary work to begin.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- While people in the United States are enduring severe heat waves the weather in this country has been extraordinarily cold, the thermometer registering 60 degrees and lower. The cold, prolonged rains and gales have nearly spoiled country life and sport. London is
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. F. Washbourne, in to-day's letter headed "Even-Handed Justice," advocates gross injustice.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 -- Hughey, the St. Louis pitcher had Brooklyn completely at his mercy in to-day's baseball game. St. Louis hit the ball hard. The score:

William Hagey, a construction boss employed by Naughton Co. on their contract job in West Forty-second Street, died early yesterday morning on the sidewalk in front of 1,731 Second Avenue. Coroner's Physician O'Hanlon found last evening that death was due to a fracture of the neck and cerebral hemorrhage due to a fall or a blow.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 7 -- We are now in midsummer, and, although we are told that the worst month is yet to come, that September is a time of heat and storms, we do not look forward to it with dread, for, so far, no one has suffered with heat. We are assured by Cubans that this is the warmest Summer Cuba has had "in the memory of the oldest inhabitant."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- "The most woeful and reckless waste of wealth in these modern days is that of the costly machinery, enormous dredges, steamboats, locomotives, railroad tracks, and cars on the Isthmus of Panama," said ex-State Senator Leonard E. Perkins the other day.

Mrs. Caroline W. Astor has filed with the County Clerk exceptions to the report of Referee William M. Hoes, in the suit brought against her by James R. Roosevelt, H.B. Ely, and Douglas Robinson, as trustees of the will of William Astor, and of the trust in respect to the residuary estate of William Astor created for the benefit of John Jacob Astor and the remainder men.

In 1882 the storage capacity from Croton Dam, (Croton Lake and Reservoir,) the natural ponds of the system, and the old reservoirs was 9,500,000,000 gallons, Croton Lake holding in reserve but half a billion of this. Now four new reservoirs, Sodom and Bog Brook, Titicus, Carmel, and Amawalk, hold for future needs at any hour 32,000,000,000 gallons more.

The people of New York are, it would seem, constitutionally optimistic. No fact is better attested than that, with our present available water supply, we cannot continue our present daily rate of use and waste without finding ourselves confronted by a very formidable water famine in 1905.

All of the scoring in the baseball game between the New York Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club teams yesterday afternoon was done in the first three innings. After that, owing to good pitching and sharp fielding there was a string of zeros. The game was played at Travers Island, and practically was a contest for second place in the Amateur League race.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 11 -- The season is at last here. Not the season those of gloomy forecast would have had us believe, but the active, say season which society has been working for and hoping for against belief and against criticism. The present week has contained an extraordinary amount of social doings, but promises to be surpassed in gayety and unconscious activity by those which follow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- W.J. Bryan's visit to Chicago has practically resulted in an understanding that he will travel almost as much during the present campaign as he did in 1896. The first inclination on his part was to avoid the making of many speeches this year, but there has been such general pressure that it is understood he is now inclined to yield and to visit many parts of the country.

The only arms the British public knows are the Royal Arms, appearing as they do on official paper, in many churches, on writs, summonses, , and over the shop fronts of certain tradesmen -- in fact, so misused and vulgarized is the royal escutcheon that it must be regarded by the bulk of the populace as a trade mark.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 11 -- In the shipyard of H.M. Bean, at Camden, on Penobscot Bay, next Tuesday, a great event in the history of shipbuilding will take place. It will be the launching of a six-masted schooner, the first vessel of her kind ever built. This remarkable vessel has been named the George W. Wells, and she is the largest schooner that has yet been built.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Navy Department this afternoon decided to reject all bids for armor plate presented to the department yesterday. It is stated at the department that this does not mean that the alternative plan of erecting a Government armor-plate factory will be adopted, although the Secretary of the Navy has at his disposal $4,000,000 with which to start such a plant in case satisfactory terms cannot be made with the private manufacturers.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- King Victor Emmanuel III. took the formal Constitutional oath to-day before Parliament. The Senate Chamber was hung with mourning draperies, the benches and tribunes being covered with black furnishings, bordered with silver. The chamber was filled with Senators and Deputies, Royal Missions, high officials of the State, and the Diplomatic Corps.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Next Saturday the official announcement of the awards of the Exposition juries will be made. The occasion will be an imposing one. The ceremonies will take place in the Salle des Fetes, and the President of the Republic, his Cabinet, and other functionaries will be present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago THE TIMES, in an editorial, emphatically denied that it had been, bought over by Republican interests, a charge made by a Southern paper. An admission of the truth of this charge would probably have been the last action to be expected.

The 1st of September, 1832, Col. Lee was appointed Superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point. My memory as to our move from Baltimore is very dim. The family went to Arlington, and remained until our new home at West Point was gotten ready -- some time that Winter.

When Appollo gave Orpheus his lyre, he gave him his gift "to soothe the savage breast." In the splendid Pompeian fresco showing a nature-peace, the bay-crowned, central figure is said to be Orpheus, though its godlike proportions suggest the divinity himself. At any rate, nothing can be finer as the conception of an inspired musician; the whole body sings, not only the mouth.

Woman in Morocco is no more than a domesticated animal, but then students of social evolution assure us that she was once on that footing, purchased and fed, that she might do the work of the house and bear the race, in what are now civilized communities. It is the utter misconception of the romance of marriage that has raised her to a throne that she often shows herself wholly unable to grace.

SIMLA, July 12 -- The famine returns at last show some signs of decrease. The grand total of people on relief is still in excess of 5,500,000, but there has been a distinct drop during the last few weeks. This is directly due to the fact that the monsoon rains have at last put in an appearance.
Controller Coler is out in the open and says he intends to fight for the nomination for Governor.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 11 -- Herschel V. Jones, a reliable crop authority, in his annual report in The Journal, says of the Spring wheat crop of the Northwest:

PARIS, July 31 -- As a demonstration of the national force and of the most characteristic products of France that vast section of the old Machinery Hall devoted to the foods exhibits has a unique and grandiose interest. The heart of France is in her agriculture. She is par excellence -- in Europe -- the land flowing with milk and honey.

There was blood everywhere -- on men, oars, thwarts, guns. Still, those of us who survived, and who were able to handle a rifle, managed to return the enemy's fire. The worst was we could not see the smoke from the insurgents' rifles, so warily did they cling to their ambush in the thick undergrowth.

The hot wave under which the city has been groaning ever since last Tuesday reached its climax in the hottest day of the year yesterday. Forecaster Emery says that the hot wave has spent itself and that it was only the sting in its tail that struck the city yesterday.

Within a hundred-years the methods of church administration and work have changed materially. It has not been a change involving catastrophe, but one of growth. Consider the single item of church music. Well-nigh the distance of a diameter lies between the church music of the beginning and the end of the century.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 11 -- "Big Salt Water Day" was celebrated to-day at Wreck Pond by the farmers of Monmouth and Ocean Counties. The pond, called "Wrack Pond" by the Grangers, is situated between Sea Girt and Spring Lake, and on the second Saturday in August of every year, as far back as the oldest farmer can remember, they have made that romantic spot their Mecca.

An unknown woman, well-dressed and of refined appearance, was found unconscious from the heat near the road at Two Hundred and First Street and Decatur Avenue last night. She died in the Fordham Hospital at 12:30 o'clock.

John L. Farwell, for many years a banker in Claremont, N.H., who now resides with his son-in-law, Dr. H.B. Pettingill, at 74 West Forty-sixth Street, in this city, yesterday filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States District Court. The schedules showed liabilities of $466,734.15 and other amounts unknown, and assets, $2,387 in real estate and unliquidated claims.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 11 -- Two deaths and eight prostrations from heat is the record of to-day. The Government thermometer registered 98 at 4 o'clock P.M., the highest reached this year.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Ex-Police Commissioner James Martin and Richard Croker have evidently forgotten all past differences, as they attended the races together this afternoon and appeared to relish each other's society to the highest degree. In view of his inevitable struggle with David Bennett Hill in the Democratic State Convention, Croker appears to be busily engaged harmonizing all possible elements, and is credited with making considerable progress in that direction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Gen. Joseph Wheeler made a strong plea for a standing army in his convocation address at the University of Chicago. He declared that the most certain way to avoid the desolation and the horrors of war was to be constantly ready with men and arms for every emergency: that the only security for peace was to be always prepared and ready to engage in war.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While sensible of THE TIMES'S courtesy in publishing and commenting on my communication in defense of ticket scalping, I would like to add that it was far from my intention to give the impression that railroads should redeem unused tickets or portions of tickets.

A Chinese company has built a temple in San Francisco, and it will be soon dedicated with much pomp and ceremony. The new temple is of brick, cost $20,000, and is one of the handsomest in the city. The god of war is the principal image within it. This god, which stands about three feet high, is made of wood, and elaborately garnished with gold.

Stanton and Rutgers Streets were the scene of a free fight yesterday afternoon between Italian and Irish laborers. As the result of the fight, one Irishman and two Italians, all three suffering from various wounds, are locked up in the Madison Street Police Station, and about twenty other Italians and Irishmen are nursing cuts and bruises.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The arrest and commitment to an insane asylum of William A. Oridge, manager of the Western Union Telegraph Company here, caused a sensation this morning. Mr. Oridge is very well known here, having been in the service of the telegraph company for thirty-five years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No one questions the beauty of the theory of Rousseau and Jefferson that just government rests upon the consent of the governed. It is a most beautiful and high-sounding phrase which cannot be taken literally, or as descriptive of actual conditions.

In the lower end of the Borough of the Bronx are two triangular public places the condition of which is anything but creditable to the city authorities. One of these is at College and Morris Avenues and One Hundred and Forty-second Street, and the other is at Morris Avenue, One Hundred and Forty-third and One Hundred and Forty-fourth Streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Popocratic nominee for President places his speech of acceptance unmistakably in the "high school commencement oration" class, by the declaration that his solution of the Philippine question is an easy one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have observed with regret your tergivisation while on political questions. I have, on the other hand, seen with pleasure that you threw open your columns to correspondents who differed with you. May I, therefore, request that you will give me an opportunity in a short space to combat some of the false premises and incorrect reasoning in your article of to-day on "The Race Problem."

An ambulance of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals containing thirty dogs was struck by a trolley car of the Middle Village Line yesterday afternoon at Middle Village, Queens County, and the dogs were liberated. Some of the animals were so badly injured by the accident that they had to be shot.

Henry Young, an eighteen-year-old colored boy, employed as a night watchman by Mendel Son, scrap-iron dealers at 608 and 610 West Twenty-fifth Street, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday mornings by Policeman Cussick of the West Twentieth Street Station, charged with the murder of Frank Davis, a colored bootblack, eighteen years old.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- The ticker had many protracted intervals of silence to-day in Boston. Quotations were few and far between, fluctuations were confined to half a dozen stocks, and trades were in small, odd lots for the greater part. Sugar led in activity, if it can be called that. In all, 2,886 shares and $2,000 bonds made up the two hours business, one-half of the stock transactions being in sugar.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- The yachts are here and the men have returned. In the beginning of the week every one who could went to the meeting of the fleet; consequently, the week has not been very gay, and the entertainments, except in one notable instance, have been dinners and luncheons and bridge whist parties.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Chicago has now been baked on both sides and in the middle for eight days. Yesterday there were 9 deaths and 16 prostrations. To-day the record is 11 deaths and 21 prostrations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- The local market was dull and devoid of interest to-day. Asphalt 5s went back to 75 1/2, and Philadelphia Electric 4s were off a quarter from yesterday's good figure, at 68. Bethiehem Steel was a slight relief to the monotony, reaching 15, an improvement of half a point; 9 1/8 was bid for Marsden, Pullman reached 186 1/2, Asphalt Company of America, 10 1/4 to 10 1/2.

A large part of the success of Chinese armies in times past has been due to their ability to strike terror to the hearts of their enemies, so every corps has its regiment of "Terror Strikers," dressed in the most preposterous of costumes and drilled in outlandish poses, acrobatic feats, and facial grimaces.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The United Kingdom is overflowing with prominent Americans, who dominated Cowes and are in evidence at every important race meeting, and many of whom are members of house parties at historic English or Scotch places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The fighting in China is practically at an end. China has made preliminary overtures to this country for a cessation of hostilities. The question now under discussion between the two countries is the sending forward of a comparatively small force of soldiers from the army at Yang-Tsun.

The nuisance and menace arising from the running of from 200,000 to 450,000 gallon daily of liquid sewage after inadequate chemical treatment at the White Plains Sewage Disposal Works into the Bronx River just above Hartsdale and below the Leggo Dam are greater now than in any Summer since the present system of disposing of White Plains sewage went into operation.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 11 -- A large number of witnesses in rebuttal for the prosecution were heard to-day in the trial of ex-Secretary of State Caleb Powers, on trial for alleged complicity in the Goebel shooting. Some of them were strong in their contradictions of witnesses for the defense.

A warrant for a man who is dead was issued by Magistrate Meade in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday, and instead of a trial on a charge of embezzlement there will be a funeral. The man for whom the warrant was asked was Frederick Grimm, fifty-five years old, janitor of five flathouses, beginning at 514 East One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street.

One of the most sensational features of the recent Brighton Beach race meeting was the time recorded in races day after day. The making of new track records was a matter of common occurrence, and beyond that some new world's records were established, the most notable of these being Voter's mile in 1:38, the best time ever made on a circular track, and Ethelbert's two miles and a quarter in 3:49 1-5.

Detectives Leeson and Moody yesterday arrested and locked up at Police Headquarters a man who gave the name of John Wall and who, the detectives assert, has been bunkoing passengers sailing on ocean liners. A number of complaints have been received from passengers who have lost money through different games and who were unable to remain here pending prosecution of the charges.

Assistant Superintendent John W. Rogers of Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, Post Office Inspector Joseph E. Jacobs, and Detectives Flay and Becker of Capt. McClusky's staff yesterday arrested in Brooklyn John Butler, alias "Frisco Slim," alias Emerson Palm, a notorious tramp burglar.

Silk underwear, or that with a large proportion of silk, can be obtained at reasonable prices, and many women prefer it to any other. There is nothing which fits more closely and makes less bulk. But silk underwear to last must be washed with care. Only tepid water should be used and castile or some other good white soap.

THE SITUATION IN SERVIA. -- According to advices from Vienna the resignation of ex-King Milan as Commander in Chief of the Servian Army, and his departure from Belgrade in a huff, was not occasioned by his son's marriage to Mme. Draga Maschin, but was owing to the fact that the Czar of Russia had congratulated King Alexander on the nuptial event.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug 11 -- Mid-August always means the height of the season at the Pier, and this year is no exception to the rule. Polo is, of course, the most alluring of the many attractions, and the relative merits of the respective teams and the individual players are subjects for discussion in the evening between dances.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- On Sept. 1 a number of new laws will go into effect, having passed the recent Legislature and secured the approval of the Governor, prominent among which is the law repealing the Horton law, which permits prize- fighting in the State.

A glamour of romance has always surrounded the Slavic Princess who is so early destined to share a throne made vacant by an assassin. Elena, third surviving daugh- ter of the reigning Montenegrin Prince, was born in 1873, and as Danilo, the heir apparent, had arrived two years before, the advent of a daughter was not so depressing a circumstance, and Elena was welcomed more cordially than her elder sisters, who preceded the heir.

The season has reached its zenith. At all the watering places it is quite gay and at many of them from this week there will be a diminuendo instead of a crescendo. Narragansett has only a fortnight or more, and the year is pretty well over at Bar Harbor in September. Newport prolongs its season.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- "Johnny" Nelson of Chicago to-day defeated "Archie" McEachern of Canada in a thirty-mile motor-paced bicycle race at the Woodside Park track. Nelson broke every record from one to thirty miles with the exception of those for one, two, and twenty-five miles.

CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The first railroad train to run regularly on Sunday in this country followed the establishment of the pioneer milk store in New York City. That store was at 193 Reade Street, and was opened in the Spring of 1842, as is recorded in an Orange County newspaper of Feb. 13, 1843, as follows:

PARIS, July 27 -- In one way Paris is the worst city in the world in which to hold a World's Fair. And that is because, of all cities in the world, Paris is the most strictly a permanent exposition in itself. There is no other community so ostensible, so to speak, none other in which the corporate desire to put one's self in evidence, to expose one's self, is so strong.
"Remember one thing," says a veteran cyclist, "and that is, if you have any regard for your clothing, that there is no such thing as an unleakable oilcan. Don't carry an oilcan in your pocket."

On one occasion a man intimated his desire to "change his religion," and was duly confronted with the Colonel. "Now," said the Colonel, "I hear you want to change your religion. What are your reasons? Have you conscientious convictions in regard to the matter?" The man intimated that he had.

Yesterday's market for outside securities was the smallest yet recorded. Only a few issues were dealt in at all, and none to a greater extent than 200 or 300 shares. The new English bonds showed larger transactions than any other issue, but even in these there were only two transactions, aggregating L20,000.

A fire of mysterious origin started at 7:40 o'clock last night in the one-story stable, storage house, and carpenter shop, 100 by 135 feet, of Robert Gair, lithographer and paper box manufacturer, on the northeast corner of Plymouth and Washington Streets, Brooklyn. The flames destroyed from $20,000 to $30,000 worth of property before they were extinguished.

Wall Street is having a holiday, though hardly one which is much enjoyed. Many of the traders of the Stock Exchange have struggled to make this Summer season a business time, but have failed utterly. Two elements necessary to activity are absent -- those financiers who are strongest and the public, which is seldom ready to follow other leadership.

Elsa Marny, a new contralto engaged by Henry W. Savage for his season of English opera at the Metropolitan, has been a singer since her eighth year. At sixteen she was a member of a concert troupe touring Germany, Russia, and Finland, singing French, German, and Russian compositions.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 11 -- The weather makers have been unusually kind to the Monmouth coast resorts this week. The scorching hot wave, which has prevailed since Wednesday, hurried thousands upon thousands of melting tourists to the seashore, and, as usual, 90 per cent. of the refugees from the city's heat headed for Asbury Park and Ocean Grove.

From the latest report on the destruction of wild animals and snakes in India it appears that during the last ten years an average of 21,000 human beings have been killed annually by venomous snakes; or, in other words, no less than sixty people die on an average every twenty-four hours from snake bite in British India.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 11 -- Secretary Edgerton of the Populist National Committee returned from Chicago to-day. He said, in reference to a statement that Chairman Butler will bolt the ticket:

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 -- Congressman Overstreet of this district, Secretary of the National Congressional Bureau of the Republicans at Chicago, left to-night for Chicago. In speaking of the probable complexion of the next House, he said:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Question -- How is it that August, being an even month, has thirty-one clays in it?

The weekly statement of the associated banks yesterday showed an increase in loans of $4,348,300 and an increase in deposits of $2,926,900. The legal reserve decreased $1,018,925, reducing the surplus to $28,125,950. There was an increase in circulation of $765,600.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let peace prevail. This motto should be adopted by the Democratic Party in New York, and the quarrel between Messrs. Hill and Groker for the State leadership should be at once adjusted, as nothing tends to demoralize an army, whether engaged on the battlefield or at the ballot box, so much as disputes between its leaders.

No sketch of the Boer character could be complete without some reference to the religious side of it -- the side most difficult of comprehension to an ordinary English mind. The psalm-singing Boer, with a text on his lips while he aims a treacherous blow in the dark, is to us the very embodiment of cant and hypocrisy.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 11 -- This evening the Kebo Club was again the centre of activity. Those who entertained at dinner were Herman G. Dennison, T.M. Gunther. Mrs. Edgar T. Scott, Miss Willing, Mrs. Henry Lane Eno, Mrs. Thomas Gerald Condon, Mrs. J.J. Emory, Mrs. Van Nest, and S.F. Sharpless.

John J. Gunther, who stabbed Adam Zimmerman, a German tailor, in the left breast on Friday night on the stoop of his home, 234 Troutman Street, Williamsburg, which caused his death two hours later in St. Catharine's Hospital, was arraigned yesterday in the Ewen Street Police Court and remanded without bail for examination on a charge of murder.

The budget is the mirror which reflects not only the financial, but also the social and political conditions of a country. Therefore, for a clear appreciation of the existing evils we must cast a glance at this important register of the public weal. After a series of unpardonable errors, (to use Signor Villari's words,) the deficit in 1888-9 was computed at 470,000,000 lire.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Mme. Wu, wife of Wu Ting Pang, the Chinese Minister to this country, attracted even more attention than usual to-day. She was out sailing in a small yacht with her son, her two nephews, and several guests. The yacht sprung a leak and the whole party barely escaped drowning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The influential Southern Viceroys of China, including Li-Hung-Chang, have united in a communication to Washington, asking that the United States use its good offices with the powers toward seeing that foreign forces are not landed at Shanghai.

Suspensions ranging from five years down to six months were imposed upon the fighting men from the warship Gloucester who violently interrupted the mustering in of Lieut. Col. Clinton H. Smith as a member of Gloucester Command No. 17, Spanish War Veterans, a week ago, at a courtmartial held at the residence of Dr. Adrian D. Williams, 614 Macon Street, Brooklyn, last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The following cablegram was received to-day at the Navy Department:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Ten years ago the harbor of Newport contained a worn-out fort known as Fort Adams, a scanty place known as the training station and the torpedo station, with an old-time building used for manufacturing guncotton on a small scale and an experimental factory for smakeless powder.

Sarah Floyd-Jones. Miss Sarah Floyd-Jones died on Friday night in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. She was born eighty-one years ago in this city and was the daughter of the late Gen. Henry Floyd-Jones. Her mother was formerly Miss Watts of Charleston.

Most of the old port of Billingsgate has now been filled up, and a convenient quay stands in its place. A new market has also been erected in place of the old sheds. With these improvements, it is said to be now the finest fish market in the world. Without going around the whole world to prove the superiority of Billingsgate, one would submit that it is really a very fine market indeed.

We have our idea -- the Anglo-Saxon idea. Russia has hers -- the Pan-Slavonic idea. One Russia, one faith, one law, one tongue, one army. Shall a miserable Finland and her paper Constitution stand between Russia and her unity? "Are we not to be allowed" -- cries the Procurator of the Holy Synod -- "by suspending the privileges of Finland to unify the 'Russian Army'?"

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11 -- A daring murder and robbery was committed on the Pennsylvania passenger train No. 8, which arrived here from St. Louis at 11:40 o'clock last night. Charles Lane, Adams Express messenger, formerly of St. Louis, but recently a resident of Columbus, was shot and killed shortly before the train reached the Union Station in this city and the "local" safe was robbed of all the money and valuables which it contained.

Senator Platt's remarks on the Gubernatorial situation started anew yesterday the boom for Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., for Governor. It was conceded by the politicians that Mr. Odell was still in the running and that his friends among the machine politicians would make him the candidate, whether he wanted the nomination or not.
Margaret Fleming, thirteen years old, of 533 West Fifty-seventh Street, was killed by a fall from the fire escape at the rear of the fourth floor of her home at 3 o'clock yesterday morning.

"I see they talk of celebrating the bi-centenary of the sweet pea in England this Summer," said a florist, "and that considerable talk is being made in London about its being actually the national flower. I believe the sweet pea first appeared in England in the Summer of 1700, but no one is actually sure of the exact day or month.

Recent public statements by Gov. ROOSEVELT indicate pretty plainly that he is not likely to remove District Attorney GARDINER on the facts brought out in the hearings before Commissioner WILCOX. We have already expressed the opinion, judging by the testimony as published in the daily press from time to time, that such action on the part of the Governor would not disappoint the public mind.

The sum of twenty thousand dollars is awaiting in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia a determination as to whether it shall go to one person or be divided between two persons. The two persons are man and wife. Fourteen years ago the wife was injured in a railway accident in Kentucky.

LENOX, Aug. 11 -- It has been the liveliest week in August that Lenox has had in some years. Very few of the cottagers are away at the seashore and a comparatively small number will go away this season. The Anson Stokes family will soon return to Lenox from their shooting box in the Adirondacks near Paul Smith's.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 12 -- The meeting of the United Mine Workers at Hazleton to-morrow, when delegates representing all the miners in the anthracite region will meet to decide if the union should light the operators in their effort to obtain recognition, will have another subject to discuss.

SLATINGTON, Penn., Aug. 12 -- Fifteen persons were killed and seven seriously injured to-night in a grade-crossing accident three miles east of this city, when a passenger train on the Lehigh and New England Railroad crashed into an omnibus containing twenty-five persons. All the dead and injured were in the omnibus, and only three escaped uninjured.

Golf during the coming week, as has been the case since the middle of July, will find its chief attractions in Summer resorts. Two big events are on the calendar, the women's annual club tournament at Shinnecock, and an open tournament for men at Richfield Springs. Both will begin to-day, the former continuing through Friday and the latter through Wednesday.

When the Congress last adjourned, the Senate, consisting then of 86 members -- vacancies existing in the representation of Delaware, Montana, Pennsylvania, and Utah -- held a clear majority of 15 Republicans. That lead will be retained, substantially, until March 4, 1901. Then there will be some changes.

The roof and front wall of a two-story brick building at the corner of Shinbone Alley and Elm Street caved in at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and two men who were sitting on a truck just in front of the building were badly injured by falling bricks and timbers. The building was occupied as a stable by S. Seligman, a truckman, at the corner of Barrow and Hudson Streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Where from has the American laborer gotten his prosperous state, his independence, but from strikes? What has made the American laborer a man, a citizen to be relied on in an emergency, but strikes? It is well enough to say to another man if you are not satisfied go somewhere else, but "just put yourself in the other man's place" and see where you will land.

Very few oarsmen were on the Harlem River yesterday morning. The terrible heat of the past few days had enervated them, and they thought it best to take things easy. After the shower in the afternoon, however, the cool atmosphere acted like a tonic, and the boys started in to make up for lost time.

SARATOGA, Aug. 12 -- Judge Augustus Van Wyck is credited with favoring John B. Stanchfield of Elmira for Governor on the Democratic State ticket. They stumped the State together in a former campaign. Stanchfield was formerly a law partner of ex-Gov. Hill, and the mention of his name at present is thought by many to be for the purpose of winning Stanchfield over to the Tammany Hall faction.
George Dennis, a well-to-do baker of 371 Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg, died late on Saturday in the Eastern District Hospital from apoplexy.

Three thousand or more men and women completely filled Cooper Union last night, drawn thither by the exercises of the Zionist festival held under the auspices of the Lovers of Zion," the oldest Zion organization in the United States, in honor of the Fourth Zion Congress, which opens in London to-day under the leadership of Dr. Herzel, and at which will also officiate Dr. Max Nordau and Prof. Richard Gotthell of Columbia University.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A destructive fire occurred early this morning and resulted in a loss of $140,000, partly covered by insurance. The fire originated in the workroom of Heffron Linehan, shirt manufacturers, and spread from there to the building occupied by the Glens Falls Electric and Gas Company and D. Robertson Company.

The storm of yesterday afternoon seemed to centre over the northeastern section of Queens Borough and much damage was done. Several lives were lost as a direct result of the storm. Some were struck by lighting, while others were killed by electric wires being blown down.

A break came yesterday in the record-breaking heat wave that had been smothering New York with its blighting breath for six days and nights. The break came with a suddenness almost unprecedented in the records and recollections of men who spend their lives in studying the mysterious workngs of the elements.

As will be seen by our Wilkesbarre dispatch this morning, the labor situation in the anthracite region is by no means a simple one. One of the most interesting and important features of it is that the miners of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western mines are not in harmony with the United Mine Workers, a general organization which includes the soft-coal miners and is made up for the most part of them.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Our market has, on the whole, taken the sale of British Exchequer bonds in New York with equanimity. At first a howl of wrath arose from the Stock Exchange, whose hungry, desperately hungry members had meditated in their brief holiday over the prospect of making a little by the issue to help recoup them for their losses in "Khakis."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- The Sunday tranquillity of this Summer resort was broken to-day by the announcement that Cardinal Gibbons would preach a sermon in the Church of the Sacred Heart, of which the Rev. Dr. Kerby, an old friend of Cardinal Gibbons, is the pastor. The hour set for the commencement of the mass was 10:30 A.M.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12 -- Aboard the many craft of the New York Yacht Club's fleet, which lies at anchor in Newport Harbor, and wherever yachtsmen have gathered to-day, the races for the Astor Cups, which will be sailed to-morrow, have furnished the principal topic of conversation.

The first and most natural interpretation of the appointment of LI-HUNG-CHANG as Envoy Plenipotentiary to negotiate with the foreign powers in China for a "suspension of hostilities" is that the Chinese Government is beginning to realize the extent and nature of the resentment it has aroused by its violation of treaty obligations as to the safety of the foreign representatives in its capital, and wishes to ward off the just consequences of its conduct.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Clarence de Hart, son of Dr. Henry G.V. de Hart of this village, was shot in the right leg this morning at Beck's Rye Beach on the Sound. The shooting was done by a watchman at Beck's Hotel.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- The Italians of this city held a parade this morning in honor of the deceased King Humbert. There were about 500 men in line, led by the Rev. Thomas Merzon, pastor of the Italian Catholic Church of Orange. A hearse was improvised from a coach that was drawn by four white horses draped in black.

While returning home from a crabbing expedition at Fort Schuyler yesterday Herman Meyer, a machinist, of 438 East Eighty-fifth Street, and his daughter Agatha, aged twenty-two, were drowned by the overturning of Mr. Meyer's sloop, which was caught in a squall while passing through Hell Gate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The volume of appropriatlons, new offices, , required by law to be prepared and published at the end of each session of Congress under the direction of the Committees on Appropriations of the Senate and House has aeen completed for the first session of the Fifty-sixth Congress by Thomas P. Cleaves and James C. Courts, chief clerks, respectively, of the committees.

Many Brooklyn people and excursionists at the beaches were thrown into a panic by the storm yesterday. When it broke there were thousands of pleasure-seekers at Coney Island, Bergen Beach, Bath Beach, and other resorts along the shore, and there were wild scrambles on the part of the crowds to get under cover.

While yesterday afternoon's brief windstorm was chasing clouds of dust through the streets there was a great scurrying of boats on the rivers and in the harbor. Small and large craft made haste to find berths in shore, and hundreds of excursionists who were not used to the water thought the black sky above and the still blacker sea beneath augured their quick destruction.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A serious accident took place on Main Street this afternoon during the severe thunderstorm that broke about 2 o'clock. Trolley Car No. 319 of the North Jersey Street Railway Company had just passed Park Street, when there was a blinding flash, accompanied by an explosion, and the car was enveloped in flames.

CEBU, P.I., June 20 -- A recent visit along the northern coast of the Island of Mindanao, and an overnight's run to the southward, developed some interesting facts connected with the American army of occupation and the disposition of the people in that section of the Philippines.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 12 -- President Loubet, accompanied by M. Delcasse, Minister of Foreign Affairs; Gen. Andre, Minister of War, and M. de Lanessan, Minister of Marine, arrived here this morning at 9 o'clock, and proceeded immediately to the reviewing ground, where he inspected the expeditionary corps for China.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 12 -- Charles R. H. Ferrell, a former employe of the Adams Express Company, was arrested this afternoon in this city, and has confessed to the killing of Messenger Charles Lane and the robbery of the "local" safe of the Adams Express Company on the Pennsylvania east-bound train, which arrived in this city at midnight Friday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Gov. Roosevelt leaves here in the morning at 8:10 o'clock for New York. It is undetermined at what hour he will return. He has no special plans for his visit to New York beyond a visit to his physician. The Governor has received no word from Attorney General Davies relative to the date when he will come here for a consultation relative to the Gardiner case.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- A.G. Hales, representative in South Africa of The Daily News, is the latest war correspondent to attack the methods and red tape of the British War Office. He says:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- There were two drowning accidents here between last night and this morning, both victims being boys. One lost his life while bathing in the Passaic River, and the other fell from a stringpiece into the deep lock of the Morris Canal. Both were dead when taken from the water.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Italian residents of this city gathered in great force at the Carnegie Music Hall yesterday afternoon to do honor to the memory of King Humbert at a meeting held under the auspices of the Italian United Societies.

CHATHAM, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Schooner yacht Ivanhoe, from Boston for Newport, in attempting to go around Monomoy Point through Light House Channel, went ashore on Monomoy Beach. Assistance was given by the Monomoy life-saving crew and the craft was floated at high water. She proceeded to Newport, although leaking some.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The Boerse last week had a very bad experience, industrials falling heavily until Thursday, when the lowest quotations of the year were reached. Friday and yesterday showed a partial recovery, but the week closed with many standard iron and coal shares more than ten points down.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 12 -- Unusual efforts were employed yesterday to avoid mob violence and to protect the life of Jesse Durham, a half-witted boy who murdered his aunt, Mrs. Bruntin, in Meade County.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Aug. 12 -- Miss Alma Osborne and Melville M. Wood, a school teacher, were drowned last night. Mr. Wood attempted to rescue Miss Osborne, who had fallen in a sinkhole while wading in White River. The bodies have not been recovered.

Conrad Mulier of 160 Second Street was arraigned in Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of keeping a gambling place. With him were arraigned nine men who were arrested at the same time. The evidence given by the police was of such a nature that Magistrate Brann became angry and refused to entertain the charges against the prisoners.
Frank Campbell, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who arrived in town late last night, places a very roseate hue on the Democratic outlook in the State.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- The ticker had many protracted intervals of silence to-day in Boston. Quotations were few and far between, fluctuations were confined to half a dozen stocks, and trades were in small, odd lots for the greater part. Sugar led in activity, if it can be called that. In all, 2,886 shares and $2,000 bonds made up the two hours' business, one-half of the stock transactions being in sugar.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several days ago there appeared in your columns a letter signed, if remembrance serves, "Jack Thorne," presumably relating to the recent race riot in New Orleans. That letter was intemperate, and after the fashion of all intemperance removed itself from the plane of serious consideration.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- During the manoeuvres of the French fleet off Cape St. Vincent last night a collision occurred between the first-class battleship Brennus, flying the flag of Vice Admiral Fournier, commander of the fleet, and the torpedo boat destroyer Framee.

The Republican National Committee purposes to appeal to pensioners for their support, and is about to flood the country with literature telling how much the party has, done for the old soldier and sailor compared with what was done for them under the two Cleveland Administrations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Orimar, owned by J.T. Stewart, and ranked as the fastest horse on Western tracks, has broken down and will be retired for the season. He won fame at the close of the Washington Park meeting here by equaling the world's record of 1:38 for a mile on a circular track, made this season by Voter at Brighton Beach.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 12 -- According to advices brought by the steamer Danube, Canadians are doing the chief trade of the lower Yukon. It is reported that they are shipping goods freely from Dawson, and as there are no United States officers on the boundary they do not have to pay duty. It has been decided by the people of Skagway to tax foreign ships landing there.
Still an open field for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination. That was the opinion expressed by Senator Thomas C. Platt at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- One of the most severe fires ever experienced here started this morning, and before it was out had destroyed the Park Opera House and five cottages. The loss, it is estimated, will amount to about $30,000 to residents of this place. Besides this the fire destroyed all the scenery and other properties of William A. Brady's "A Stranger in a Strange Land" Company.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 12 -- One woman was killed and three others were so severely injured by a single bolt in the storm to-day, that they will probably die. When the storm came up Mrs. Nouth and her two daughters, Lizzie and Nellie, and a woman friend, were sitting under a grape arbor back of the house.

NEWPORT, Aug. 12 -- A merry party of Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's guests took a midnight bath at Bailey's Beach last night after having left Mrs. Fish's hospitable board at Crossways. The party was led by Mr. and Mrs. Whitney Warren and Miss Emily Hoffman.

PARIS, July 30 -- The national buildings ought to be one of the chief attractions of a universal exposition, and commonly they are. Unfortunately, the current architecture of every Continental capital is modeled upon that of Paris, and one no more looks for nationality in architecture than in costume.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 12 -- It is not thought probable, from the conditions suggested by an early preliminary survey of the Ohio political situation, that the President's State will register a result materially different from that of four years ago, when it went Republican by 51,109 over Mr. Bryan as the Democratic candidate, and 48,494 over Mr. Bryan as the candidate on both the Democratic and Populistic tickets.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- John McGuire, a conductor on the Erie Railroad, will, he says, appear before the Grand Jury next month and ask for the indictment of Dr. Vroom of Ridgewood in connection with the death of Mrs. McGuire a short time ago. Mrs. McGuire sustained injuries in a collision between a horse drawing a wagon driven by her and Dr. Vroom's motor carriage.

There was war in Chinatown last night. The contestants were members of the Hep Sing Tung on the one side, and of the Mongolian Masonic Order on the other. As a result of their first pitched battle, Loang Kin lies dead in the Hudson Street Hospital, while, his murderer, Goo Wing Chung, is a prisoner in the Elizabeth Street Police Station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Department of State to-night made public the correspondence with the German Government and the Emperor relative to the selection of Field Marshal Count von Waldersee as chief commander of the co-operating foreign forces in China.
Net changes for the week of 1 point or more in the more active securities were:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The State Department has no information whatever about the dispatch from Managua to the effect that the concession of the EyreCragin syndicate has been forfeited. Its officials are unable either to affirm or deny the report.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The deadlock in the Harrison Common Council, which began last May over the election of a President, was broken to-night. The Council met and took its nine hundred and forty-seventh ballot for President.

William Steinitz, who for years was the champion chess player of the world, died Sunday afternoon in the Manhattan State Hospital, on Ward's Island. For months he had been insane. The last few years of his life were especially tragic. After being recognized as the most expert chess player of the world for over twenty years, he met his defeat at the hands of Lasker, a comparatively young man.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 13 -- One of the most important conventions that the United Mine Workers have ever held in this section began in the Grand Opera House here to-day. About 300 delegates, representing the Lackawanna, Luzerne, and Susquehanna anthracite coal districts, are in attendance.

Since Mr. BRYAN'S elaborate speech at Indianapolis has spread through the country there has been a good deal of criticism of the effect it is likely to have in encouraging the Filipinos in holding out against the United States troops in the hope that the election may place at the head of the Government in this country a man ready to promise them the terms that he offers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me through THE TIMES to say to the Massachusetts anti-imperialists that their recent Faneuil Hall meeting has received most grateful recognition from men of the same mind here in the West?

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 13. -- The first utterance from a high source among colored educators in North Carolina on the question of the recently passed constitutional amendment come from S.G. Atkins, President of the Slater Industrial College, located in Winston. The letter, which has been given wide publication, is a direct appeal to the negro population to accept the inevitable and go to work to educate themselves and make themselves worthy citizens.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13 -- Thomas F. Cushing met with a serious accident near the Casino to-day when he was knocked down and trampled on by a horse driven by Miss Pearson's coachman. Several spectators grabbed the horse after the coachman had failed to restrain it and saved Mr. Cushing anything more serious than a broken collar bone.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 -- The body bearing marks of murder found in a sewer in Mount Auburn last Saturday by two boys is believed to be that of William Schamadam, who lived in Cleveland. Late in July he went to Hamilton, Ohio, and about a week ago he came here in company with another mill worker.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @ 62 1/2. There were no sales.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 13 -- Phillips was invincible to-day, and the champions were shut out. A double, a passed ball, a hit, and Beckley's home run gave the Cincinnatis 4 runs in the fifth. Score:

The telegraph wires bring all the news from Newport of the yachting and the many entertainments which took place there yesterday. Southampton is enjoying the preliminary women's golf tournament at Shinnecock. Mrs. Henry G. Trevor is entertaining a large house party, as is also Mrs. Charles T. Barney.

The first annual reunion and encampment of the National Association of Spanish War Veterans will, on the command of Willis J. Hulings, Commander in Chief, be held at Chattanooga, Tenn., Oct. 8 to 12 inclusive. It will be a "fourfold," meeting in conjunction with the Grand Army of the Republic, United Confederate Veterans, and the Society of the Army of the Cumberland.

Gov. Roosevelt had a busy time of it in the city yesterday. Looking the picture of health, he arrived at 9:15 o'clock, and after having his throat treated by his physician he hurried to Republican National headquarters, where he had an engagement with Attorney General John C. Davies to discuss the report on the charges against District Attorney Gardiner and the amended complaint against Mayor Van Wyck in connection with the Ice Trust.
An application for the position of official hypnotizer for the police force was made to Chief Murphy, at Jersey City Police Headquarters, yesterday, by Samuel Applebaum of 133 York Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- The twentieth annual lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the United States will open here to-morrow morning at the Casino. The entry list is so much stronger than any for many previous seasons that there is certain to be some record-breaking tennis matches before the week is out.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- In an interview Prof. John Fryer, head of the Department of Oriental Languages in the University of California, who has arrived here from China, says:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- August Belmont's Mineola, in the fairest kind of a test, added another victory to her already long list to-day by winning the Astor Cup, for sloops, against a field of nine competitors, which included three sister seventies, the British built cutters Hester, Isolde, and Astrild, and the two fifty-one footers Shark and Altair.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The War Department this afternoon received the following casualty list from Gen. Chaffee:

According to his statements in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday, Abraham Frank, a decorator, of 211 East Fourteenth Street, is such a firm believer in astrology that he deserted his wife as soon as he learned that she had been born under Venus in order to make room for the second husband, which an astrologer assured him always came to the women who were born under that planet.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Attorney General Davies to-day advised State Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks to dismiss the charges preferred against the Bankers' Life Insurance Company of New York City by John P. Beal of Pennsylvania, who alleged that the company was violating the anti-discrimination section of the insurance law.

Three hundred "jackies" of the First Battalion, Naval Militia, took train early yesterday morning for Whitestone, L.I., where they will remain for a week to practice for war. Headquarters will be aboard the training ship New Hampshire, anchored almost within the shadow of Fort Schuyler and within sight of the Willets Point Torpedo Station.

This is the story of an erratic burglar alarm which always goes off at the wrong time. It started in last night, and Third Avenue was in a turmoil. The alarm is located over the front door of the pawnbroker's establishment of Alex Schlang, at 1,856 Third Avenue, between One Hundred and Second and One Hundred and Third Streets.

Though total transactions on the Stock Exchange fell short of 200,000 shares yesterday, the market was firm and in some parts there was pronounced strength. In a few quarters where short interests accumulated last week smart rallies took place. National Lead preferred shares illustrated this feature by jumping up 7 points on transactions of only 500 shares.

Special Policeman John Horan of 213 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, detailed at Sulzer's Harlem River Park, was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court before Magistrate Zeller charged with intoxication by his wife, Jennie. He was held in $300 bonds for three months.

Philip Rudnitsky, a grocer of 75 West Ninety-seventh Street," left his horse and wagon at Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue yesterday afternoon while he went into a flat with some goods. When he came out, horse and wagon were gone.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A statement has been going round the papers to the effect that at the next diocesan convention, to be held in New York on Sept. 26, Bishop Potter will ask for an assistant, and the name of the rector of the Church of the Ascension has been mentioned as a possible candidate.

EDWARD SCHULTZ died at his home, at 140 Danforth Avenue, Jersey City, on Sunday, from intermittent fever. He was born in New York in 1862. He was Treasurer of the Republican County Committee. He was not married.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13 -- James Shevlin, Hugh McLaughlin's first lieutenant, returned to Saratoga last evening after a flying trip to New York. The Tammany and up-State leaders all agreed that the situation as to the Gubernatorial nomination was in the hands of Hugh McLaughlin, the veteran leader of Kings County.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The settlement now going on is easy and absorbs attention. The tone of most departments on the Stock Exchange to-day was cheerful, the changes generally being toward higher prices, notably in the case of consols. The promised break in coal prices induced a few purchases.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 -- Delegates to the convention of the National or third party ticket are beginning to arrive. This party originated at the time of the meeting of the Gold Democratic Committee in this city. At that time there was a committee of eleven sent here to confer with the Gold Committee and urge it to recommend the nomination of a third ticket.
