RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Notwithstanding the fact that it rained almost incessantly throughout the day, there was no postponement of the open tournament of the Waiontha Club, and the majority of those who entered were on hand. A number of women who are to contest were also present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States Government could have sent to China 20,000 soldiers from the Philippines in aid of our Minister in China but for the encouragement the rebels received from the Democrats in making them believe that by the election of Bryan they would be given their independence.

Leave of absence for twenty days, to take effect Aug. 17, is granted First Lieut. Albert E. Truby, Assistant Surgeon, who upon the expiration thereof will proceed from New York City to San Francisco and report to the commanding General, Department of California, for assignment to duty with troops detailed for foreign service.

PARIS, July 30 -- Nothing could be more marked and emphatic than the differentiation between the two serious and permanent palaces of the exposition and the fifteen or twenty others, equally palatial and often even more extensive, which in design as well as in construction are obviously temporary and provisional, to disappear as soon as they have served their turn, and to leave the ground they stand on to its legitimate uses.

The bursting of a fifteen-inch steam pipe yesterday morning in the plant of the New York Steam Company, on Greenwich Street, between Cortlandt and Dey Streets, resulted in the death of three men and the injuring of four others.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13 -- Mrs. George Scott gave a delightful musicale at the Scott villa, Belmead, this evening, which was one of the largest functions of the season. Distinguished artists were engaged, and the invitations being general, Belmead was filled with many of the cottagers.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 13 -- To-night's entertainment by the Monday Evening Club will probably be the most important society event of the week. In the Kebo Valley Clubhouse, Miss Pendleton, one of the originators of the Monday Evening Club theatricals, presented a pretty little Japanese play, the characters of which were taken by prominent young people of this resort.

The portal to the Paris Exposition on the Place Concorde has so many peculiarities that among French and foreign critics objurgation alternates with the supreme contempt of silence. It belongs to no accepted style of architecture, though it suggests Cambodia and Siam. It serves no purpose, since the public might enter better elsewhere, and it cannot protect a crowd from sun or wind or rain, being open on all sides.

PERRY, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- At the Republican County Convention held at Warsaw this afternoon Charles J. Gardner was renominated for member of the Assembly by acclamation, Elmer E. Charles of Warsaw for District Attorney, E.M. Jennings of Warsaw for County Clerk, J.W. Ives of Java for Superintendent of Poor, Dr. L.C. Broughton of Castile and Dr. Henry P. Sharpe of Arcade for Coroners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The occupation of Ho-Si-Wu without opposition on the part of the Chinese, confirmed the Government officers in their belief that the fighting on the road to Peking is practicably over. The usual gloomy dispatch from London excited amusement. In every stage of the campaign the Londoners have refused to credit good news until the last moment, and have then attempted to find a dark side to it.

John Butler, alias "Frisco Slim," a tramp burglar who was arrested on Saturday afternoon at his home, 62 Middagh Street, Brooklyn, on a charge of being one of a party of three who on April 27 last blew open the safe of the Massanutten Bank, Strasburg, Va., was again arraigned in Centre Street Court yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Times yesterday printed a long editorial dealing with the economic position of the United States, as evinced by the allotment of the war loan. It traces the progress during the last four years of the reduction of the American debt, but maintains that the United States has not yet ceased to be a debtor Nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Department of State to-day made public the reply of the United States Government to Minister Wu's communication, delivered on Sun- day morning, notifying the department of the appointment of Li-Hung-Chang as envoy plenipotentiary to negotiate with the powers.

ROME, Aug. 13 -- The railroad accident not far from this city, last night, turns out to have been more serious than anticipated. It now appears that fifteen persons were killed and forty were wounded, of whom fifteen are seriously injured. Among the latter was Gen. Buffin, head of the Belgian Mission to the late King's funeral, who had his leg broken.

Pease Elliman have sold for Charles Buek the new five-story American basement dwelling 57 East Forty-ninth Street, 18 by 100.5, one of a row erected by Mr. Buek on part of the old Columbia College property.

Under bright skies and in a cool, refreshing breeze, the steamer Cymric of the White Star Line was bowling along at her average speed about noon Sunday, Aug. 5, on her way to this port, with 125 cabin and 848 steerage passengers, when fire was discovered in the hold, and for thirty-six hours the officers and crew fought to save the vessel.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 -- The dismembered body of a farmer named Joseph Schaeffer, who lived near the line between Baltimore and Howard Counties, has been found in the Patapsco River, near Woodstock, Md., and the police are confident that murder has been done.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nearing the close of the Administration of President McKinley, and about to wage a new campaign to determine who shall represent the people for the next four years, would it not be meet to ask why our present incumbent should not be returned to the position he so ably fills?

The Rev. Emil A. Meury, pastor of the Second Reformed Church, Jersey City, yesterday conducted the funeral of Agnes Kastenschmidt, who on Friday last committed suicide at her home, 455 Palisade Avenue, by inhaling illuminating gas. There was no appparent cause for the deed, and it was not known that the girl had left any explanation.
Robert Kingston Scott, twice civil Governor of South Carolina, died at his home in Napoleon, Ohio, Monday night. He was stricken with apoplexy a year ago, but had apparently recovered.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Last Thursday the allies were at Ho-Si-Wu, only thirty-three miles from Peking and eighteen miles beyond Yang-Tsen, at which point they had been last heard from.

The Census Bureau has scarcely issued a sufficient number of bulletins showing the growth of cities in the last ten years upon which to base safe generalization or conclusion, but some indications are given in the announcements for Buffalo, Cincinnati, Louisville, Milwaukee, Providence, and Washington that seem to justify the expectation that the cities of the East will give a relatively good account of themselves as compared with those of the West.

A newspaper correspondent who is traveling in the West to watch and report upon the drift of things political recently came across a Republican of the State of Indiana to whom he mentioned that the general complaint by both Republicans and Democrats in that State was that there was great apathy in both parties.

With a good deal of strength as well as with more activity than appeared on any day last week the market for outside Securities opened yesterday under favorable conditions. Transactions were not confined to as few stocks as was the case last week, and the day's total was relatively a large one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The War Department has received the following from Gen. Barry:

The cable dispatch published yesterday to the effect that President Paul Kruger of the Transvaal intended to contribute more than $2,500,000 to the Bryan campaign fund was not taken seriously by politicians. The following opinions were expressed:

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 13 -- The Manitoba and Lake Superior Railway has just been incorporated here, with a capital of $100,000 and a limit of indebtedness of $10,000,000, to build a line of road between Winnipeg and Duluth. Though the plans of the company are held strictly secret, it is known that the line is the United States branch of a large Canadian enterprise, said to be nothing less than a second transcontinental road.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Boston trading did not increase in volume or in interest to-day, but was as flat as ever. Moderate dealings in Sugar, Atchison, and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, with some interest here and there in the mining stocks, made up the day's total. Massachusetts Mining weakened 1/2, to 6, on an expected assessment of $1 next month.

Louis Windmuller returned from an ex- tended tour of Europe on the steamship Augusta Victoria, which reached this port Saturday. During the course of his travels he spent considerable time at the Paris Exposition.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 -- The congress of the Anti-Imperialist League will be called to order on Wednesday morning in Tomlinson Hall by Senator Henderson of Missouri, and he will introduce ex-Gov. Boutwell of Massachusetts, who will preside over the meeting.

Major Frederick E. Prime, an engineer officer of the Union Army during the civil war and Chief Engineer in Grant's Mississippi campaign, died at his home, at Litchfield, Conn., Sunday. He was not so well known to the younger officers of the army, having been retired nearly a generation ago on account of disability contracted during his years of arduous service.

District Attorney Marion Erwin of Georgia closed the case for the Government yesterday afternoon in the proceedings looking to the removal of John F.,W.T., and E.R. Gaynor, and Benjamin D. Greene, accused of conspiring with ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter to defraud the Government in connection with harbor improvements at Savannah.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 13 -- The strike of the 2,000 union stevedores who went out last week is assuming an ugly aspect, and minor disturbances are of daily occurrence. A big crowd last night attacked a street car at Locust Point, in which were a number of non-union colored men who had taken the strikers' places, and bombarded it with bricks and other missiles until dispersed by the police.
Gloria Quayle in the cast that is to tour the Western States with "The Christian" is to be portrayed by Julia Stewart.

The greater part of Jersey City was set in an uproar last night by a stampede of twenty-five horses of the Fifth United States Cavalry. The horses, after kicking out the sides of the pen in which they were confined, ran through a large part of the city, clearing everything out before them and finally dashed across the Hackensack meadows.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The improvement on the Stock Exchange previously noted was maintained to-day, chiefly owing to easier money and the absence of unfavorable Chinese or South African news. The business done, however, was small, there being no incentive for fresh engagements. Home railroads were irregular, and foreigners were featureless.

If the keepers of gambling houses in the Tenderloin could have been present at the annual outing of the Martin Engel Association at Colleg Point yesterday, they would have opened their eyes in wonder. Without doubt the very god of chance would have turned green in the face at the variegated assortment of shrines that had been established in his honor on the picnic grounds.

H.B. Sire, principal lessee of the New York and Casino Theatres, said last night that he intended to oust George W. Lederer from the management of the latter house. Mr. Lederer's representative, when told of this plan, declared that the Sires were unable to do any such thing.

Chief Engineer Robert Van Buren of the Brooklyn Water Department yesterday gave out a statement regarding the water supply of the borough. He asserts that certain newspapers have incorrectly estimated the supply of water, and reasserts that Brooklyn is short of water on storage. The great need, Mr. Van Buren declares, is increased, conduit facilities from the watershed to the reservoirs at Hempstead, Ridgewood, and Mount Prospect.

The friends of Mayor VAN WYCK seem desirous of presenting him to the public in the role of martyr -- a role for which in several important ways he is singularly unfitted. The martyrdom that they appear to have in view for his Honor lies in his removal from office in the middle of a political campaign and under circumstances indicating a spirit of persecution on the part of the Governor.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The United Hatters of North America, stimulated by their victory over Fred Berg Co., but manufacturers of Orange Valley, have instituted a similar strike against the firm of Eugene V. Connett Co., one of the largest soft hat manufacturing concerns in this country.

SOUND BEACH, Conn., Aug. 14 -- A special school meeting was held in the school-house here to-night to decide whether the School Committee, consisting of G. Hopkins Ferris, William J. Worrell, and Charles Palmer should reappoint Miss F. Ida Lockwood as teacher of the primary department of the school.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@62 2 1/2. There were no sales.
"Because he is ashamed of us, he told her father that all the members of his family were dead."

Strength in the Stock Exchange market was well reflected in the market for outside securities yesterday. No appreciable increase in activity occurred, but there appeared to be better inquiry for stocks, and several advances were recorded on very light transactions. Several stocks that were not affected by Monday's movement were the centre of some interest yesterday and showed substantial improvement at the end of the day.

An apparently trustworthy report finds its way from Chicago to New York that WEBSTER DAVIS, a spellbinder who for years had devoted himself to the task of converting every Democrat within the range of his magnificent oratory to be a Republican, and out of sheer desperation and exhaustion of raw material for conversion has undertaken to turn his converts back again, has within three weeks declined 623 invitations to speak.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Though the evangelistic opposition meeting was resumed to-day under the porch of All Souls* Church, near Queen's Hall, at which latter place the Zionist Congress is in session, the presence of an increased police reserve force prevented anything more serious than constant "booing" and hooting.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- The rain had the advantage over the women players at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club yesterday, and prevented the scheduled opening in the club tournament, but the links are in better condition than they have been for a long while. Play started at 2:30, and a large gallery was present each to follow their own choice.

What may prove to be the culmination of a double tragedy having its beginning in a romantic attachment took place yesterday, when Annie H. Zeman, a pretty Bohemian girl of eighteen living at 766 East One Hundred and Sixty-fourth Street, attempted to commit suicide.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Light fields, due to the heavy sticky rain, ruled this afternoon. There were no stake features. The attendance was large.

HAVANA, Aug. 14 -- The following new law is the cause of considerable complaint among the American and British banks, corporations, , it being claimed that some of its provisions are tantamount to paying taxes twice:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Throughout today word was anxiously awaited from Gen. Chaffee as to developments in the military situation near Peking, but not a word came, nor did Admiral Remey send anything on the situation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- At the close of the official day at the State Department the following announcement was bulletined:

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 14 -- President Hill of the Great Northern system is planning several big moves in the transcontinental railway field. It is said that he will soon announce his intention of competing more strongly for freight and passenger business between the East and China, via his lake lines, his railroad from St. Paul to the coast, and his vessels that ply between Seattle and China and Japan.

Dining and dancing at Newport; dancing and dining at Southampton; bathing at Narragansett, and listening to music and lectures at Bar Harbor were the chief dtversions of the members of New York's gay world, now scattered at these and other resorts yesterday, and will be also their diversions to-day.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- In addition to the second round and semifinals in the gold tournament for the Richfield Springs Cup and the general handicap for the Handicap Cup, the qualifying round and first round for the Women's Cup were played to-day at the links of the Waiontha Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Judge Wallace's order in the Neely case will stay the execution of any order issued by the State Department in regard to the extradition of the alleged defaulter.

The rival Democratic factions in the Ninth Assembly District are both hard at work preparing for the primaries. The followers of John C. Sheehan say that they are certain to carry the district and retain Mr. Sheehan in his present place as leader of the district, notwithstanding Tammany Hall's recognition of his opponent.

A veteran of the civil war who was known as George E. Rau and also as Harry J. Martin was found dead in a room at the Hotel George, at 2,400 Eighth Avenue, yesterday morning. Dr. Ogilvie of the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital said that he died of heart disease, but those who knew the man say that they think he committel suicide.

Harry Botts of 74 Marion Street, Brooklyn, was locked up in the Canarsie Police Station late yesterday afternoon, charged with assaulting and seriously injuring his brother, William Botts, of 74 Hull Street, while out in a rowboat on Jamaica Bay. The brothers were fishing when they quarreled.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 14 -- The first day's session of the National (or Third) Party Convention was devoted entirely to addresses, no formal action being taken beyond the appointment of a committee of three to confer with the anti-imperialists, whose convention opens to-morrow morning.

According to the report made by Messrs. CLEAVES and COURTS, the Clerks of the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations, after a careful digesting of the bills as signed by the President before the adjournment of the last Congress, the total amount authorized to be expended in the fiscal year 1900-1901 is $710,150,862.88, or about $421,000 more than was reported by Senator ALLISON on June 6 as the total of the appropriations for the year.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The war cry has been sounded by Richard Croker and David B. Hill. At last the two Democratic leaders have thrown off all restraint and are now at open warfare. The Tammany leader has selected Saratoga as the place to do battle with his old enemy, the bachelor of Woolfert's Roost.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Indian Agent Getchel wires as follows from the Devil's Lake Reservation, North Dakota:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A high Government official said to-day that the indemnity which the United States would demand for every American citizen killed or maimed by the Chinese in the course of the present trouble would be sufficient to support the victim's family for the remainder of their lives.
The retirement from active service, Aug. 12, of Col. James G.C. Lee, Assistant Quartermaster General, by operation of law is announced.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for John T. Higgins to a client, for occupancy, the fourstory dwelling 148 West Seventieth Street, 17.6 by 100.5.

Justice Fitzgerald, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, signed an order for Thomas Bennett, now a prisoner on Blackwell's Island, to show cause why he should not pay to his wife, Mary J. Bennett, $150 counsel fee and alimony, pending her suit against him for a separation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- News of Collis P. Huntington's death created a sensation in this city, where his movements, both in railroad and private life, have been watched and studied with keen interest.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- President Kruger at one time made a formal application to the United States to grant him a sanctuary in case the necessity for it arose. This occurred, according to Secretary of State Reitz of the Transvaal Republic, the day Lord Roberts entered Pretoria.

A "close personal and political friend of RICHARD CROKER" threw a revealing light upon the motives that actuate the Kings County Democracy in their opposition to the nomination of Mr. COLER in this brief statement made to a reporter of THE TIMES:

John D. Lindsay of the law firm of Nicoll, Anable Lindsay, said yesterday of his efforts in behalf of his client. C.W.F. Neely, and the proceedings before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court on Monday:
RAQUETTE LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Collis P. Huntington died at his camp, Pine Knot, in the Adirondacks, at about midnight.

HUYSSEN HOLM -- Deputy Sheriff Radley received an attachment from Rochester yesterday for $1,765 against William A. Huyssen and Nils Holm, Huyssen Holm, shoe dealers, at Sedalia, Mo., in favor of John Kelly, (incorporated,) shoe manufacturer, of Rochester. The Sheriff served the attachment on a fire insurance company, to attach a policy of insurance of $2,000 on their stock at Sedalia.

Two dead heats in one day is unusual on the Speedway, or any other place. There were two on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, however. Anyway, that's the way they looked to spectators stationed at the finish post, and that's what the official verdict doubtless would have been had there been judges there for the sole purpose of deciding finishes.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 14 -- Despite the fog and rain, society continued to amuse itself to-day with unabated energy. One of the most novel entertainments of the season was given to-night at Ban-Y-Bryn, the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Barney. Two hundred of the most prominent society people here were present.

MANILA, Aug. 12 -- Reports from the Visayas Islands show that there has been increased activity among the insurgents there during the last six weeks. The American losses in the Island of Panay last month were greater than in any month since January last.

About two hundred men and women, principally Italians, and all avowedly Anarchists, met last night in Clarendon Hall and applauded a number of speeches denouncing the late King Humbert of Italy and the aristocracy and press of the world and lauding the act of Gaetano Bresci, the assassin.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 -- The championship lawn tennis tournament began at the Casino here to-day with clear weather and a fair attendance. The opening matches in the singles were somewhat slack, there being only one or two of interest, although the East vs. West match in the final series of championship doubles matches furnished enough excitement for one day.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 14 -- The New York baseball team made but one run in the two games played here to-day. In fact, they were at bat for sixteen innings before a single run was tallied, and that was their only score during the day. No special features marked the playing. The scores:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount at the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14 -- Tammany gold is not going to flow into the pockets of the gambling house men this week. Richard Croker has told some of the leaders that it would be better for the New York politicians not to buck the faro bank or spend money to see the little ivory roulette ball fly around.

Covered with rags, and gaunt from starvation and exposure, August Keins, fiftyfive, years old, and his two children -- Martha, four years old, and Emma, three years -- were found living in an abandoned wagon at Bay Ridge and Third Avenue early yesterday morning. The children were almost starved.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Father Diana, the Hungarian priest, at Alpha, who was arrested last week, charged with forgery, has been held under $1,000 bonds for the Grand Jury. Much of the priest's history was brought out at the hearing. It was asserted that he studied for the priesthood in Hungary, but for some reason he did not take orders.

Senator Hanna was an early arrival yesterday at Republican National Headquarters, and during the forenoon he was driven to Senator Platt's office, at 49 Broadway, where the two Senators had an extended conference. What they talked about neither would say. Senator Platt accompanied Senator Hanna up town, and soon after their arrival at headquarters the appointment of the following Advisory Committee was announced:

Lemuel E. Quigg, who stands so close to Senator Platt that what he says is generally accepted as official, asserted yesterday that Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff of Kings County will be nominated for Governor by the Republican Convention at Saratoga next month.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The first day's meet of the Hudson and Mohawk Valley Circuit under the auspices of the Newburg Driving Park Association was held on the half-mile track here this afternoon. Three races were run off, and favorites won in each. The day was fine, the attendance was about 2,000, and the sport was excellent. The summaries:

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Congressman James B. Sherman of the Oneida district, passing through here to-night, said that the mention of his name as a candidate for Governor was without authorization. He said that Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff would probably be the choice, and is entitled to the nomination.

Starin's men all said that the fourth annual free excursion for the women and children of the Twenty-first Ward, given by Capt. F. Norton Goddard, and conducted under the auspices of the Civic Club yesterday, was the biggest that ever left this city, although some of those given by Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City to the little folk in his bailiwick may have equaled it.

Policeman Patrick J. Darcy of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station and living at 315 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, yesterday, at the corner of One Hundredth Street and Broadway, saw a runaway horse, attached to a light delivery wagon, racing down the street without a driver.

An event of some interest will be the meeting between Dennis Horgan, the Irish champion, and "Dick" Sheldon of the New York Athletic Club in the sixteen-pound shot-putting event at the carnival of sport of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club at Bergen Point on Labor Day. Horgan holds the world's record of 48 feet 2 inches for this event.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 -- At noon today Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard's pennant was hauled down from the schooner yacht Corona, the flagship of the New York Yacht Club, and the fifty-fifth annual cruise of the club was formally declared at an end. The ceremony came at the close of a meeting of the fleet Captains called by Commodore Ledyard, according to a timehonored custom, to vote upon a motion to disband the fleet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The tension as to the Chinese situation has been intense throughout the day, for it is felt by officials that the crisis has reached an acute stage, which cannot be continued many hours without bringing word of momentous import, determining, either for good or evil, the entire course of events.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A strike was inaugurated to-day in the hat factory of Brennan Carr, on Wallace Street. Orange, Sixty men employed in the making department went out.
NEWPORT, Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Ogden Mills grave a small dinner and an Informal dance this evening at her cottage, Ocean View, in honor of her daughters, the Misses Beatrice and Gladys Mills.

A general alarm has been sent out by the police for Margaret Haas, the eighteen-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Haas of 18 Rogers Place. Haas is a piano manufacturer. His daughter was employed by Leicester Allen, an inventor, living at 1,002 East One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street, as a companion for his wife.

Collis P. Huntington's body arrived at the Grand Central Station from Pine Knot Camp, in the Adirondacks, at 4:32 P.M. yesterday, and it was at once removed to the Huntington mansion, at Fifty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. Funeral services will be held there at 11 A.M. to-morrow, and the burial will be in the mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery.

The late SAMUEL J. TILDEN, "a Democrat but not a revolutionist," a power in this State and in this country while he lasted as a political leader, was a reticent man to those who had not fully established with him the right to be treated with the fullest of confidence. Even with his intimate acquaintances he was given to whispering.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 15. -- The final event in the polo contest for the Point Judith Cup this afternoon on the field of the Point Judith Country Club was between the Myopias and the Dedhams. There was no handicap and Myopia won by a score of 16 to 8 1/4. The Myopias outplayed their opponents in every period.

Information comes from Washington that the Democratic Congressional Committee has prepared for distribution a list of persons who were formerly Republicans and who have been constrained by opposition to "absolutism" to abandon MCKINLEY and the Republican Party and devote themselves to the task of electing BRYAN.

JOHN DUNN died in Oswego yesterday, aged seventy-one years. He was once a prominent vessel owner and had acquired considerable wealth. He was widely known In commercial circles. He was father-in-law of Judge C.N. Bulger, Democratic State Committeeman.
Dispatches to London and Paris from Shanghai say the allies are reported to have reached Peking on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The official statistics of the wheat crop of the world for 1899-1900 have just been compiled by the Department of Agriculture. They show that in the countries of the southern hemisphere whose wheat crops are commonly included in statements of the world's wheat crops the production will hardly fall less than 160,543,000 bushels.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 15. -- The Republican State Convention met to-day, adopted a platform, and nominated a full State ticket. The managers of J.M. Frink, the King County candidate for Governor, controlled the convention by a large majority, and their slate, chosen last night, was nominated without a hitch, as follows:

"'Tain't no laughing matter so far as I kin see, an' so I repeats, as I sed, I kin pick out a Canarsie clam from a Coney Island clam in a pitch-dark room any time, an' if any o' you Judges doubts my' word, an' wants to gamble onto it, why, I'm your man.

BOSTON, Aug. 15. -- Boston had a good market in stocks at last, buying in the mining group becoming buoyant and prices rising substantially. The leaders in the new outburst of activity in the mining shares were Utah, Centennial, and Parrot, but Montana was prominent; also Wolverine and Osceola.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The French have a proverb, "Put yourself in my place," which one hears at every turn in Paris. If we apply it in the matter of the Chinese war it will make some things comprehensible that are now mysterious. Of course, no argument can be heard in explanation or palliation of the atrocious conduct of the Chinese toward their victims.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Montague R. Leverson is in no danger of prosecution by the Government for his letter, made public to-day. Even in the early days of the Filipino war the Administration adopted the policy of prosecuting no one for treason. The precedent was set in the case of Edward Atkinson, when he sent seditious literature to soldiers in the field and took the position that they should not obey their officers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- Mr. Bryan. Mr. Stevenson, and others made speeches to-day at Sunny Side Park on the occasion of the annual meeting of the United Irish Societies of Cook County. The meeting was presided over by the Rev. F.L. Reynolds, and the attendance was large, notwithstanding the stormy weather.

The man who is self-deceived is a hopeless case. You cannot set him right, for he shuts his eyes to light and his mind to reason and goes his stumbling way through the quagmire of error, convinced that he alone has found the high road to truth.

Thomas F. Ryan, who has occupied a large part of the Summer in a trip through Canada and the Western States, has returned to New York, convinced that the election of McKinley and Roosevelt is assured. Having traveled through the Canadian Northwest Territory and British Columbia, Mr. Ryan journeyed through the Pacific States, and came back to New York by such easy stages as enabled him to talk with his friends in many cities.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Bangror and Portland Railroad Company, which was recently bought by the Lackawanna, held at Easton, Penn., on Aug. 14, the old Directors resigned and the following were elected in their place: W.H. Truesdale, President of the Lackawanna; B.D. Caldwell, General Traffic Manager, and F.F. Chambers, Secretary and Treasurer of that road; Edward Warren, B.E. Loomls; Conrad Miller, ex-President of the road, and G.W. Mackey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- It is generally belived that the recent dispatches sent by Ministers Conger, MacDonald. de Cologan, and Pichon were identical. Secretary Root refused either to confirm or deny this report, and no verification of it could be obtained. The rumor seemed to find its chief support in M. Pichon's warning that the troops must not pause to enter into negotiations with Li-Hung-Chang.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- The following dispatch has been received from the French Consul at Canton: "All is quiet here. In the district of Swatow the agitation against the Christians and missionaries is alarming. Many missions in that region have been pillaged and burned. The Viceroy and my-self have decided each to send a delegate to make an investigation and re-establish order.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Larchmont was aglow to-night with illuminations and fireworks in honor of the annual parade of the Volunteer Firemen. The Larchmont Department is made up of bankers, brokers, merchants, and yachtsmen, who, under Chief Mayhew W. Bronson, marched and conducted themselves like paid firemen.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 15. -- The yacht race to-day between the 25-foot knockabouts proved a victory for the Rip, owned by Edgar T. Scott, which crossed the line in 2 hours 48 minutes with the Bobs, Antonio Stewart, owner, a minute and a half behind. The course was the regular eighteen-mile run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The War Department has made public the Filipino correspondence captured some months ago by Gen. Funston's command in Luzon. It was translated from Spanish under the direction of Capt. John R.M. Taylor of the Fourteenth Infantry, who is in charge of insurgent records.

The American capitalists who have subscribed for British consols to the amount of u5,000,000 evidently prefer an investment yielding a fraction less than 4 per cent. Interest but secured by the resources of the United Kingdom to the bonds and shares of American industrial corporations, on which from 5 to 12 per cent, is promised and in many instances paid, secured by the expectation of good management and good fortune.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@62 1/2. There were no sales.

Business in the market for outside securities yesterday, though not much more active than on the earlier days of the week, was somewhat broader. A number of stocks appeared in the day's list of active issues, but in most cases transactions were not large. A good deal of strength appeared in some of the copper stocks which recently have given some evidence of a revival of interest in this class of stocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Navy Department this morning made public a dispatch from Admiral Remey announcing the arrival of Gen. Chaffee at Matow, the next town of importance after Ho-Si-Wu, which the Americans occupied with slight opposition on Aug. 9. The text of the dispatch is as follows:

In the following list "rate" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The racing today was uninteresting. The track, although it had dried out somewhat, was still heavy.
"What have you to say, Senator, of Abraham Gruber's attack on you?" Senator Platt was asked yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- The second day's play in the championship lawn tennis tournament at the Casino here furnished more excitement and better tennis than yesterday's play. The challenge match for the National championship in doubles held an enthusiastic crowd for two hours and a half, and after the play had ceased on the championship court the spectators thronged around the other courts to watch the struggling players in the singles matches.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 15. -- Mrs. W.P. Draper of New York entertained this afternoon at a reception and musicale at her cottage, the Boulder, on Kebo Street. Myron Whitney, Jr., gave several vocal selections. Among those present were Mr. and Mrs. J. Pierpont Edwards, Mrs. Alexander Van Nest, Mr. and Mrs. W.P. Walley, Miss Sharswood, the Mises Tarn, Miss Dimock, Charles T. How, and Count and Countess Laugier-Villars.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The most successful open golf tournament of the Waiontha Golf Club of Richfield Springs was brought to a close here to-day with the playing of the semi-finals and final for the Ladies' Cup, and the final for the Richfield Springs Cup.
"Jake" Dahmer was released from the Elmira Reformatory the other day and came to live with his parents at 111 West Thirtieth Street, almost within the shadow of the Tenderloin Station House.

Albert Friedlander has sold, through Folsom Brothers, for about $45,000, the plot 403 to 407 East Twenty-third Street, 75 by 98.9. The seller bought the property under foreclosure in April, 1899, for $37,050.

The members of the Buyers' Association of America, who are in convention at the Hotel Albert, University Place and Eleventh Street, are absorbed by the question as to whether the Constitution should not be amended so that membership will be open to buyers for wholesale firms. There seems to be a feeling in favor of admitting the wholesale buyers to the organization, although the opposition constitutes a large majority.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- A committee appointed last night to solicit subscriptions for funds to keep the Rome baseball team in the race the rest of the season has commenced work and is meeting with good success.

Edward M. Shepard, who was a leader among the Gold Democrats in 1896, and who is now mentioned as a possible Democratic candidate for Governor of this State, came out flat-footed for William Jennings Bryan for President yesterday. Although repeatedly asked for his views since the Kansas City Convention, Mr. Shepard has refused them until yesterday, when he gave out the following statement:

In the most favorable conditions the infant children of the poor have an unequal struggle for existence in their crowded tenement homes, and in such heat as we have just passed through it is not strange that they should succumb in unusually large numbers to the combined influences of high temperature, foul air, and improper feeding.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter from "F. Washbourne" published in your issue of Aug. 10, under the heading "Even-Handed Justice," justly called forth the admiration of all right-minded people -- laying aside the political question touched upon therein.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 15. -- Cincinnati outbatted Brooklyn in both games to-day, but lost the only game that was completed. Errors lost the first game. The second was called at the end of the sixth by agreement. The score:
SARATOGA, Aug. 15. -- David B. Hill arrived here to-day with a gripsack loaded with political bombs which he expects to explode under the camp of Richard Croker and his Tammany followers.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Transports with British troops arrived in Shanghai roadstead on Tuesday. The Viceroy protested to Admiral Seymour against the landing of the troops, and Admiral Seymour wired to his Government for instructions as to how he should act.

"I look for the most successful meeting we have ever had," remarked Dr. Kane, President of the Road Drivers' Association, yesterday after a meeting of the association to discuss details for the meet matinee at the Empire City track on Sept. S. "The entries are coming nicely and it looks as if we would have about the right number in each race. Four or five starters to each event are plenty in wagon races.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 15. -- The first day's sessions of the Liberty Congress of the National Anti-imperialistic League were somewhat disappointing so far as the attendance of delegates was concerned. About 300 accredited delegates were present, and more are promised for to-morrow.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly Committee on Revision to "consider the whole matter of a restatement of the doctrines most surely believed among us, and which are substantially embodied in the Confession," held three executive sessions here.
John Drew is scheduled to appear in "Richard Carvel" at the Empire Theatre on Sept. 11.
Charles Emory Smith of Philadelphia, Postmaster General in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet, was in the city yesterday. Asked for his opinion of the prospects of President McKinley's election, he said:

Business on the Stock Exchange surpassed in its aggregate yesterday any recent record. The market, moreover, was very strong. Many stocks rose substantially. And it is a matter of fairness to record that general sentiment in the Street showed material improvement -- and some commission houses even reported that they could discern indications of a developing disposition upon the part of the outside public to make preliminary ventures.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15. -- The dispatch to the effect that the War Department had just made public correspondence of the Filipino Junta, captured by Gen. Funston in Luzon, including a letter from Dr. Montague R. Leverson of Brooklyn, N.Y., to Apacible, head of the Junta at Hongkong, occasioned considerable comment among the Eastern delegates to the anti-imperialist convention.

From The New York Sun, Aug. 15. The death of Collis P. Huntington makes it proper to say now that he was the "Responsibility" who offered through The Sun a year ago the prizes of $700 in what was widely known at the time as "The Man Without the Hoe" competition.

First Vice President H.E. Huntington of the Southern Pacific Company, who is regarded as the successor of his uncle, Collis P. Huntington, to the Presidency of the system, arrived at the Pennsylvania Railroad station in Jersey City at 12:35 P.M. yesterday. He was accompanied by William Hood, Chief Engineer of the Southern Pacific.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- David B. Hill threw two of his political bombs into the Tammany camp yesterday, when he made a bold move to capture the State Committee from the control of Richard Croker.
William M. Ryan and P.H.J. Daly have sold for Annie M. Ivory to Max Gold and Max Lippman, for about $20,000, the old building 197 Henry Street, 25 by 87.6. The buyers will improve the property.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 16 -- The Liberty Congress of the American League of Anti-Imperialists to-day emphatically indorsed the candidacy of William J. Bryan for President. The resolutions to that effect were read to the convention by Col. Charles R. Codman of Massachusetts, who moved their adoption, after stating that the entire committtee of twenty-five had indorsed them.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- There was an easier feeling in the Boston market, with further taking of profits in mining shares, and a partial return to the familiar conditions of dullness and neglect. Parrot was off 7/8, at 42 1/8; Utah 5/8, at 31 7/8; Centennial 3/4, at 18. British Columbia hardened 3/8, to 12. United States held at 9.

Extracts from an article by Signor CRISPI which appears in the current number of La Rivista Marittima are given this morning. It will probably be considered by many Italians as most untimely and ill-advised. In brief, it advocates an increase of the navy at a time when Italian political economists realize that the fiction of the financial equilibrium can no longer be kept up.

In the sustained strength of the market for outside securities, observers see some indications of a revival of public interest in that market. The feeling that present prices are likely to be maintained and even improved seems to be growing, and views of the immediate future of the market are more optimistic than those held a few weeks ago.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 16. -- Wild throws by Williams and O'Brien in the first inning, letting in two runs, seemed to take the heart out of Pittsburg in to-day's baseball game with Brooklyn, but McGinnity's underhand pitching would have beaten them anyhow. Hustings made his debut in the seventh inning, and, barring nervousness, made a good impression.

From Tuesday morning until late last night, John Dalton, his wife, and their five children were forced to make their home on the sidewalk in front of the house in which they formerly lived at 69 Montgomery Street. On Tuesday their landlord, John Crowley, disposessed them from the two rooms that they had been occupying for the past three weeks, because they were unable to pay the $2 rent which they owed him.

The Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief received the following cablegram yesterday from William T. Fee, United States Consul at Bombay, and Chairman of the Americo-Indian Famine Relief Committee:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 16. -- There was a gathering to-day in the North Russell Street African Methodist Episcopal Church at the first session of the "Non-Partisan Conference," called to bring together leading colored men of New England" to take such steps as will arouse the country to a just sense of duty, and to emphasize the race's eternal hostility to being deprived of its inherent political rights."

James Carroll of 381 Middleburg Avenue, Astoria, Queens Borough, was held under $500 bail yesterday by Magistrate Healy to answer a charge of assault. The allegation is made by his wife, who asserts that on Aug. 13 Carroll knocked their twelve-year-old girl down with his clenched fist and then held the child upon the ground and set two mastiff dogs upon her and tried to induce them to bite the child.

NEWPORT, Aug. 16 -- To-morrow evening Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., will give a dinner and dance at Wayside. The dinner will be for the younger set, which will be followed by a dance in the handsome red and gold ballroom.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 16 -- Lincoln gave a warm welcome to Mr. Bryan to-day upon his return to his home here. He reached the city at 3:20 P.M. and was met at the station by a large crowd, which escorted him to his residence and which, after listening to a speech, only dispersed to meet in the evening with many others at a reception given in the State Capitol grounds.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 16 -- The Democratic State Convention met here today and named the following ticket:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Arthur Harris, who is wanted in New York for the killing of Policeman Thorpe was arrested in this city this morning at the home of his mother. Harris arrived here yesterday morning about 3 o'clock, unaware of the serious charge against him, and sought the house where his mother lived seven years ago, but found she had moved.

This Nation has come to a higher place and to more distinguished honor among the civilized powers of the world and the Administration has established new titles to the confidence of the American people by the wise and statesmanlike policy of the President and Secretary HAY in dealing with the exceedingly difficult situation created by the troubles now approaching a fortunate adjustment in China.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Republicans of Kings County, proud of the record of the Hon. T.L. Woodruff as Lieutenant Governor of this State for four years, have suggested Mr. Woodruff (without his consent) as a candidate for Governor. I know of no one who is better fitted for the office than Lieut. Gov. Woodruff.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 16 -- At the Narragansett Casino to-night the Hope-Robson Company played a successful return engagement, presenting "Roseberry Shrub Sec" and "A Pantomime Rehearsal." Additional interest was lent to the performance by the debut here of Miss Elizabeth Welmore Hunter, the society amateur of Newport.

The tennis tournament at Newport and the weekly dances at Southampton and other suburbs will take away from the city, to-day and to the week's end, all the male members of the social world who can leave. The next few days will be an utter blank socially, as far as New York is concerned.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- F.P. Garrettson, one of the original promoters of the boat racing in this harbor, has offered a purse of $100 for a twelve-oared cutter race between the racing crews of the Old Colony Boat Club and that of the Training Station on Labor Day and over the Belmont-Garrettson course.
A big policeman with a warrant rudely interrupted the lovemaking of John Cross, a young clerk, and his fiancee, at whose horne in Williamsburg Cross was spending the evening on Wednesday last.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A well-dressed man went to the residence of Charles H. Young, a New York business man living at 1,048 North Broadway, this afternoon, and represented himself as being in the employ of the Telephone Company. He said he had been sent to repair the telephone, and was admitted to the room where the instrument was set up, and left alone there.

Henry E. Janes and Herbert Janes, composing the firm of Janes Kirtland, manufacturers of ranges at 725 and 727 Sixth Avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Herbert B. Shoemaker. The business is a very old one, having been established more than fifty years ago by Janes, Beebe Co., in which their father, E.R. Janes, was the senior partner.

The Census Bureau at Washington yesterday morning announced that the completed count of the returns for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx showed a population of 2,050,600. The population of Manhattan is 1,850,093, and that of the Bronx 200,507, and the count by Assembly districts is as follows:

There is nothing imposing about the team batting or fielding averages of the baseball nine of the Crescent Athletic Club, which won this year's championship of the Amateur Baseball League, yet that team had a very successful season. The Crescents played ten league games, and won nine. As the league is made up of six strong amateur teams, the record of the Crescents is all the more praiseworthy.

The second annual regatta of the Hoboken Amateur Rowing Association will be held to-morrow afternoon over the Guttenberg course, on the North River, beginning at 3 o'clock. While the entry is hardly up to the expectations of the association there is plenty of good sport in prospect, particularly in the senior single gigs.

-- As a corrective or antidote for the dolorous eloquence that has been set flowing at Indianapolis for the apparent purpose of proving that American patriotism and courage are on the wane, we can cordially commend the sentiments expressed in a "soldier letter" published this week by The Columbia (S.C.) State.

Senator Hanna was an early arrival at Republican National Headquarters yesterday. A big mail awaited him and with the assistance of Private Secretary Dover and two stenographers he waded through it and dictated answers.
LAS VEGAS, New Mexico, Aug. 16 -- ExUnited States Senator John J. Ingalls died at 2:25 A.M. to-day. He was surrounded by his family. The funeral will be held in Atchison, Kan.

Carlo Karno, a Japanese steamship steward, who lives at 107 Cherry Street, gave his neighbors on Cherry Street an exhibition of his pugilistic powers last night, which resulted in his being locked up in the Oak Street Station, after a narrow escape from being roughly handled by a crowd of east side toughs.

The funeral of Mrs. Kate Reilly of King's Bridge did not take place yesterday afternoon, although all arrangements had been made. Instead the woman's body was taken to the Morgue, where an autopsy will be made to determine if she died by violence.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- Viscount Wolseley, Field Marshal and Commander in Chief of the British Army, according to The Daily Mail, delivered the most scathing condemnations ever heard at Aldershot after witnessing yesterday's manoeuvres. He declared that the 30,000 men who participated were utterly unfit to send abroad, badly led and badly taught.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday announced a decision in a case involving the construction of the tariff law as to reciprocity treaties. Wine, imported from France by way of Liverpool, by Hermann Brothers of Louisville, was assessed by the Surveyor of Customs at Louisville the full regular duty.

JAMBS W. BANKSON, leading member of the Baldwin-Mellville Stock Company, died at Montreal on Wednesday night of typhoid fever He was born in 1878, at Baltimore, Md. His wife, Lotta Linthicum, is the leading woman in the company.
LONDON, Aug. 17. -- A cablegram to Vienna from Hongkong announces the capture or Peking, but the Austrian Government, like other European powers, is still without confirmation of this report.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 16 -- Among those who entertained to-night were Dr. and Mrs. W.W. Seely, at Hillhurst, their cottage on Cleftson Road. Their guests were: Charles T. How, Mrs. Carpenter, Mr. and Mrs. T.G. Conton, Mrs. Frederick Joy, Mr. and Mrs. David Jayne, Johnston Livingston, Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Barney, Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin, E.J. Curley, Miss Matthews, and Miss de Peyster.

The United States Sub-Treasury yesterday received the first order of the season for silver dollars by telegraph for the movement of the new cotton crop. The order was for $14,000, including $12,000 for Texas and $2,000 for Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- United States Consul Kennedy at Para writes that there is a movement on foot which is backed by foreign capitalists, mostly French, to erect a flour mill of gigantic size in that city. A syndicate has also been organized, composed chiefly of Europeans, for the purpose of erecting a flourmill, a sawmill, and sugarmill combined, and to be known as the Para and Amazon Valley Milling Company.

The race trouble which was first encountered by the New York police force Wednesday night is now practically at an end. The burial of Policeman Thorpe and the arrest of the negro Harris, who, it is alleged, killed him, both had much to do with quieting the feeling in the neighborhood of Ninth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, where the rioting started.

Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD seems to have arrived at a state of mind in which he is prepared to aid in bringing on his country very grave, substantial, and long-lasting evils in order to avoid danger inherent in a practically imaginary difference of policy between the two Presidential candidates.

From The Boston Herald. An interesting collection of data bearing upon household expenses has been made by the Women's Educational and Industrial Union, and tabulated by the Bureau of Statistics of Labor. This is the third series of statistics which the union has made through its employment office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the ostrich seeks to elude its pursuers by hiding his head in the sand, so Mr. Bryan and his followers endeavor to cover the 16 to 1 fallacy with the mantle of antiimperialism; but the veil is too thin to conceal what Mr. Bourke Cockran calls the "vicious principle" of repudiation, the advocacy of which brought Mr. Bryan into such prominence in 1896.

The record of the police in the riotous attacks on the negroes in their quarter on Wednesday night may briefly be summed up. They stood idly by for the most part while the negroes were being beaten except when they joined savagely in the sport, until the rioting threatened to extend dangerously; then they gradually dispersed the crowds, arresting almost no whites and many blacks, most of the latter being clubbed most unmercifully.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Aug. 16. -- That favorites do not always win was again clearly demonstrated this evening on the picturesque polo field of the Rockaway Hunt Club, when the much-talked-of polo match between the four of the recently organized polo team of the Great Neck Polo Club and one of the teams of the Rockaway Hunt Club lined up for competition for a handsome trophy, which was the bone of contention.

Battalion Chief Charles W. Lane of the City Fire Department was killed last night at Jamaica. A buggy in which he was driving was hit by a Brooklyn Rapid Transit trolley car. The Chief and his companion, a young woman friend, were thrown out. The young woman escaped injury beyond a few bruises, but Chief Lane received injuries which caused his death within a short time.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Gov. Roosevelt spent a quiet day, without any political visitors and with no affairs of political importance to bother him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Occupied as the President has been with affairs in China, he has been able to give very little thought to his letter of acceptance. Up to this time he has hardly made a beginning, but from now on he hopes to have more time to himself, which he will devote to the letter.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The only important feature of this morning's session of the National Convention of the Irish Catholic Benevolent Union was an address by Bishop McPaul. The Bishop dwelt upon conditions which, he said, existed in New Jersey. He spoke of the Reform School at Jamesburg, where, he said, the Catholic inmates were not surrounded by those influences which would result in the boys growing up Catholics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- In all probability the Ministers are now in the hands, of the allies. If they have not left Peking by this time it is due to necessary delay in preparing for the moving of so large a body of people, including the 3,000 native Christians whom Minister Conger has declared he will not abandon.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- This morning Count von Waldersee, accompanied by the Countess and by Vice Admiral von Waldersee, his brother, visited the United States Embassy and asked John B. Jackson, Secretary of the embassy, to present his best compliments to President McKinley. He spoke in the highest terms of the American troops, saying: "I know what they can do, and will consider it a great honor to have such gallant soldiers under my command."

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- It was estimated to-night that fully 15,000 attended the grangers' annual picnic at Swinefield Bridge on the Morris County side of the Passaic River, to-day. The crowds drove, rode wheels, or walked to the big grove from all parts of Essex, Morris, and Union counties, and spent the day listening to speeches, talking crops and politics, and patronizing the fakirs of every description, who found the picnic exceedingly profitable.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A heavy track spoiled what promised to be a good day's racing. The Mumm Handicap had most of its interest destroyed by the withdrawal of Blues, Sharpshooter. The Puritan, Rockstorm, and other colts. The Schorr entry, Alard Scheck and Lady Schorr, being 7 to 10 favorites, coupled, in the betting.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The third day's play in the National championship tennis tournament at the Casino here this morning furnished excitement and brilliant play enough for a whole tournament. The weather was very bad early in the day, and not only soaked the courts, but kept away a large part of the customary spectators who gather at the Casino each day to watch the tennis matches.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Department of State makes public to-night the communications exchanged to-day between the Chinese Minister, Wu Ting Fang, and the Acting Secretary of State.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The list of the works of James Fenimore Cooper, published at the request of a correspondent in THE REVIEW of Aug. 11, was far from complete. In addition to his romances, the names of which were given with approximate accuracy, Cooper published several works, historical, biographical, sociologic, controversial, and descriptive.

Henry Hinckler of 5 West One Hundred and Eighth Street, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, before Magistrate Zeller explained away a charge of attempted burglary, with a story that sounded like the plot for a French farce. On the third floor of 310 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, said Hinckler, lives a woman who has quarreled with her husband.

Mr. Hugh Hastings, the State Historian, has just issued the second volume of the "Public Papers at George Clinton, First Governor of New York." Mr. Hastings writes that, as this work has made progress, it has been deemed necessary "to enlarge the scope, and in a measure to depart from the original plan."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The Navy Department to-day made public the reports of Col. Robert L. Meade and Major L.W. T Waller of the United States Marine Corps, on the fighting at Tien-Tsin. They give not only a graphic account of the initial engagements in the Chinese campaign, but furnish the information with official exactness.
There was little doing in Democratic circles yesterday, the great majority of the so-called leaders still being in Saratoga.

The discourse now brought before us evidently grew immediately out of the discussion awakened by the healing of the "man which was blind from his birth." It opens with the parable of "The Sheepfold," and the report of it occupies nearly the whole of the tenth chapter of St. John's Gospel.

W.P. Hazen, Chief of the Secret Service in this district, and United States Marshal Bernhardt took two Italians from the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II., which arrived in port yesterday. They are detained near Liberty Island as undesirable immigrants.

MOREHEAD, Ky., Aug. 17 -- The Adkinses and Howards have had a bloody battle in Elliott County, in which one of the Howards was killed and another fatally wounded. One of the Howards and one of Lindsay Adkins's boys quarreled over a young woman, after which both went home and brought back other members of their families for reinforcements.

The earliest library in this State of which we have any record belonged to Jonas Bronck, for whom the Borough of the Bronx was named, though the spelling has been corrupted. He was one of those worthy but unfortunate Mennonites who were driven from their homes in Holland to Denmark by religious persecution.

Justice Fitzgerald, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted a temporary injunction restraining the members of the new East River Bridge Commission from awarding the contract for the building of both the Manhattan and Brooklyn approaches of the bridge.

-- Not all the disappointments of life are unpleasant, and perhaps as good a way as any to increase the percentage of agreeable disappointments is to treat with courtesy and a well-devised assumption of confidence people from whom, for one reason or another, little is expected and that little unsatisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A Cabinet official said to-day that unquestionably the native Christians in China, said to number several thousand, will be included in any arrangement made between this Government and China incident to the cessation of hostilities.

Old violins nearly always have histories. Few of these records have more of romance in them than that of a Stradivarius recovered yesterday. It is worth $5,000. One man came to his death, one was sentenced to a year in the penitentiary, and a woman has grieved for five years on account of this rare instrument.
PARIS, Aug. 17. -- The list of the awards to American exhibitors at the Paris Exposition was made public to-day.

BAR HARBOR. Aug. 17. -- The fancy dress ball at the Louisburg to-night marked the height of the season's indoor festivities. The event included a subscription ball, preceded by tableaux representing characters and scenes from Diclcens and "Mother Goose." Miss Furniss, Mrs. Lindley Hoffman Chapin, Mrs. George Forsyth, F. de Peyster, and De Witt Clinton managed the production of the tableaux.

DETROIT, Aug. 17. -- Col. James M. Wood of this city is preparing plans for a new vaudeville theatre to cost $300,000 to be begun this Autumn in Sixth Street, Pittsburg. The theatre is to be built by Eirick La Marche, proprietors of the Empire Theatre, Cleveland. Col. Wood said that Wiggins Moore, proprietors of Wonderland, the vaudeville theatre in this city, would probably also be interested.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 17. -- Gov. Candler to-day, upon advices received from the Deputy Sheriff of Liberty County, this State, ordered out the Liberty troop, a cavalry company of the Georgia militia, to assist Sheriff Brewer of that county in quelling a riot now said to be assuming serious proportions at Johnston Station, fifty miles from Savannah, between the whites and the blacks.

James Madison's Writings. The publication of the first volume of "The Writings of James Madison." which will take place early in September, will be an t vent of no little Importance in the light of the coming Presidential election, when interpretations of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States are so varied and promote so much controversy.

The siege of the foreigners in the Chinese capital lasted fifty-six days. The bombardment of the legations, in which, with the exception of some of the Roman Catholic missionaries, all the aliens in Peking had assembled for safety, was begun on June 20. Previous to this, however, the Europeans, Americans, and Japanese had been virtually prisoners for three weeks.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Up in this State there dwells a good man and true, who, in his own original way, is cutting a nicho high up on the pinnacle of fame that shall endure to remind posterity of him and his good works mmeasurably beyond the time when the voices of some of his decriers have been stilled forever.

PENDLETON DUDLEY, Saranac Inn, N.Y. writes concerning James Newton Basketfs "As the Light Led": "I must join several of your readers who have expressed their disapproval of your review of James Newton Baskett's 'As the Light Led.' To me, who was raised in Missouri, there is little in Mr. Baskett's story that does not ring absolutely true.

With the exception of Newport, the watering places seem to be suffering this week from a reaction. The dance last night at the Meadow Club, Southampton, however, was more largely attended than usual, owing to the large number of people assembled there in consequence of the women's invitation golf tournament, which closed yesterday.

How much of himself a reader fuses with his Impressions received from any author It Is of course impossible to say; but in the discussion as to the gloom and pessimism of "The Rubaiyat" it is at least admissible to claim that the nineteenth century man Is foisting upon the Persian poet an undue measure of his own moroseness.

Richard Harding Davis slipped through New York unobserved last week, and is now at his Summer home in Marion, Mass., hard at work revising his South African sketches, which are in the course of publication in Scribner's Magazine for presentation in book form in time for Christmas.

Collis Potter Huntington's body found its last resting place In the family mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery yesterday. Before the journey the tomb funeral services were held at the Huntington mansion. They were attended by many social, financial, and railroad notables, as well as by nearly all of the employes in the dead man's service and in that of his corporations.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 17. -- Pittsburg gained a big advantage over Brooklyn in to-day's baseball game, and in the first inning made four runs, which were sufficient to win, as Brooklyn totaled but three during the entire game.

The policy of the American Government in the Philippines, which its opponents call "imperialism," is to establish order under the sovereignty of the United States, and to develop self-government among the natives as fast and as far as practicable.

The death on Thursday of ex-Senator John J. Ingalls will give new interest to the poem entitled "Opportunity" which he wrote many years ago. It has been widely printed and much admired. In the number of THE SATURDAY REVIEW of exactly two years ago a correct version of this poem, secured from the Senate himself for the purpose, was printed in these columns as follows:

While thousands of people watched a street duel on the east side last night the shots of one of the contestants went wild, and struck two little boys, one of whom lies dead in the Hudson Street Hospital with a bullet in his brain. The other is dangerously wounded, having a big hole in his right side and a pistol ball somewhere in his body.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: A version of the poem "Bivouac of the Dead," by Theodore O'Hara of Kentucky, and perhaps as correct in its entirety as any one extant, may be found in the "Library of American Literature," Volume VII., compiled and edited by Stedman and Hutchinson, and published by William Evarts Benjamin of New York.

The senate of the New York University several days ago submitted to the judges of the Hall of Fame a list of 234 nominations. From these the final selection of 100 names is to be made. It is explained that the list has been divided into three groups, based on the manner in which the names have been obtained.

The Morristown Field Club's horse show is fixed for Oct. 11, 12, and 13. The indications are that the show will be the event of the season in New Jersey, and excel the last equine exhibition there. The arrangements are on a grand scale, and include several innovations. Many improvements have been made to the show grounds.

It was once said of a prominent author, who never turned off a slovenly paragraph, and whose charm of style was unfailing, that he would rather write a perfect sentence than sit down to a perfect dinner. It was the joy of putting thought in imperishable forms that inspired him. No superior art, indeed, can be exercised without joy; and, in literary art, there are multiplied and exalted satisfactions.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Aug. 17. -- A passenger train on the Perkiomen Railroad struck a team of horses and wagon at Palm, Montgomery County, at 11 o'clock to-day and instantly killed the three occupants of the vehicle. The dead are:
PARIS, Aug. 17. -- The stranding of large numbers of Americans in Europe for want of funds is much more serious than at first supposed. The facts seem to be these:
