The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" bas been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Following is the weekly road report issued by the New York State Division, League of American Wheelmen, of roads in the near neighborhood of New York, New Jersey, and the whole of Long Island. These conditions, when issued, were dependent to a large extent on the weather, as a heavy shower might in some instances greatly improve certain roads, and on others have just the opposite effect.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In the issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW of July 21 you published an article by Mr. Vance, wherein a very sweeping attack is made upon what he terms the "big word mania among scientists." Mr. Vance apparently looks upon the philosophers as a sort of big-word trust, who endeavor to hoodwink the public with an unpronounceable and distracting philosophical jargon.

People who are lovers of books have a fondness for reading about books. Next to the pleasure received from one's favorite authors is that derived from the man who writes interestingly concerning them. Indeed, in some cases the latter by no means holds second place to the former in our affections.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Miss Angela Ralston and Alfred T. Reagan, both of San Francisco, were married here at the City Hall last night by Mayor Fiske. They had, through a friend, arranged the matter ahead of time, and last night, unknown, it is said, to the parents of the bride, Miss Ralston left New York and in company with her fiance hastened to this city.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: As several articles have recently appeared in your SATURDAY REVIEW concerning the work of the Roycroft Press, I take the liberty of writing to you upon the subject. Like Mr. George Bicknell, who defends Mr. Hubbard in your issue of July 28 against your recent notice of one of the book, I own several of the Roycroft publications, and hope to own several more.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 17. -- A desperate attempt at train-wrecking was made on the meadows back of this city late tonight which, if successful, would undoubtedly have resulted in a terrible loss of life. The tracks were obstructed with railroad iron and ties, and the 10:30 P.M. express on the Pennsylvania road from this city, carrying more than 200 passengers, was almost derailed.

If history is "philosophy teaching by experience," a history of education -- the growths, and strivings, and vicissitudes of the human mind -- should be a most interesting book. The records for such a book have been gathered by Dr. Davidson from the time of dawn in human intelligence, and traced through schools of thought, ancient and modern, in a clear, concise, and well-proportioned narrative, with ability and charm.

A new volume has recently come before the public from the pen of Bernard Capes, who has already won the hearts of readers by his many interesting and unique stories. The present work follows in the footsteps of "At a Winter's Fire," which appeared about a year ago, and is a combination of seventeen short stories, romances, fantasies, whimsicalities, and levities.

HENRY S. HASKINS, New York, writes: "Does the modern tendency to epitomize a situation, paragraph, or sentence in an idiomatic or slang phrase weaken our use of the language? Are we becoming verbal slatterns, preferring gaudy rags of epigrammatic speech to the sober garb of conservative expression?

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was glad to read your editorial, "A Disgrace to the Police," in to-day's issue, but it wasn't half severe enough. Imagine innocent men and women not only assaulted by toughs in the presence of policemen, but actually clubbed by the latter when appealed to for protection!

G. Choate, who was appointed referee to hear testimony in the suit brought by William J. Logan against James G. Moore, Henry H. Rogers, William Rockefeller, and others, growing out of the famous Brooklyn gras war, has filed his report in the Supreme Court. In the report, which is a most voluminous one, Mr. Choate recommends that Mr. Logan's suits against each and all of the defendants be dismissed.

Army. Leave of absence for twenty days, to take effect Aug. 17, is granted First Lieut. Albert E. Truby, Assistant Surgeon, who, upon the expiration thereof, will proceed from New York City to Havana and report to the commanding General, Division of Cuba, for assignment to duty.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 17. -- Mr. Bryan will devote the greater part of next week to speechmaking in Nebraska and Kansas. He will make the first of a series of addresses at Wahoo, twenty miles north of Lincoln, Tuesday afternoon, and will follow this with four speeches on Wednesday at Auburn, Tecumseh, and Pawnee, respectively.

The population of that part of Greater New York included in Manhattan and Bronx Boroughs found on June 1 by the enumerators of the Federal census is reported to be 2,050,600. This is an increase of population in the boroughs in ten years of 535,299, or 35.33 per cent. For substantially the same territory the increase between 1880 and 1890, as reported by Census Commissioner PORTER, was 309,002, or 25.62 per cent.

No more I weep. They do not sleep * * * a grizzly band, * * *, they linger yet. -- The Bard. Alas! Fulton Street is no more. Its glory has departed; it is dull, listless, and forsaken. A bright spot has been sponged off the dull old New York slate and a Sunday quiet reigns o'er the scene.

All earnest minds are interested in the work of education and sympathize with those engaged in it. They would, by word or deed, encourage their hearts and strengthen their hands. Those have not thought much about it who do not recognize the arduous character of the work; who do not regard it as of prime importance among natural human obligations, and most potent among those things that conduce to human completeness.

Bertha M. Herbert, a student nurse at the City Hospital on Elackwell's Island, mysteriously disappeared from that Institution Thursday night under circumstances which have caused the gravest apprehension. At 9:30 in the evening she told one of her acquaintances that she was going down to the dock to get a pall of salt water, and since then nothing has been heard from her.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the disgraceful conduct of the policemen in the race riots yesterday, I would suggest that you remind the 70,000 straight Republicans who voted for the Republican stool pigeon in the last Mayoralty election that they are responsible for the present condition of affairs in this municipality.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Some time ago I was present at a small literary gathering when a successful author was asked, "What style of stories does the average woman generally care for? "Well," he replied, thoughtfully, "If I were to write a novel to be read by the gentler sex only, judging from experience, I would plainly disclose the outcome of the plot in the first few chapters.

In this excellent and stimulating little book Glanvill assumes a very different aspect from the inconsistent Glanvill of the biographical notices and the "grave Glanville" of the "Scholar Gypsey." His belief in witchcraft and ghost stories, apparently so irreconcilable with his "careful skepticism" and his scientific sympathies.

The long-expected report of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company was issued late yesterday afternoon. The figures were given out by the officers of the company in the form of a preliminary comparative statement of Brooklyn Rapid Transit and constituent companies for the years ending June 30, 1900, and 1899, to be followed later by a detailed report in pamphlet form.
LONDON, Aug. 17. -- Though the demand for money was fair to-day, a large amount was seeking employment. Further arrivals are expected at the Bank of England forthwith.

There is no doubt that Prof. Flournoy's took will be eagerly devoured toy spiritualists and believers in reincarnation and that their future publications will contain long extracts pointing to a confirmation, of their spiritual conceptions. There are many passages in "From India to the Planet Mars," which, robbed of their context, would go far toward establishing the actuality of spiritualism.

Although a writ of habeas corpus was issued in the Supreme Court on Thursday for Fannie Frazier, seventeen years old, she did not appear before Justice Fitzgerald in Special Term, Part II., yesterday, A representative of the Gerry society, which had been commanded to produce the girl, was on hand, however, and told the Court that the society knew nothing of the whereabouts of the girl.

In the market for outside securities yesterday active trading was confined to three or four stocks, while the majority of issues showed very small transactions. Prices were fairly well maintained and some further advances were recorded, but all told the day's changes were not important. Stock is not being very freely supplied and advances are easily brought about.

There was no more rioting between the whites and the negroes on the west side yesterday. This was chiefly because of the severity of the police, in compliance with Chief Devery's orders not to take prisoners, but to club the rioters into submission wherever they proved obstinate.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- I wonder if the letters written from New York to The Daily Express by Mr. R.H. Sherard have been copied by the New York press. Mr. Sherard made the passage in the steerage of one of the French transatlantic steamers, and passed through the ordinary experience of an immigrant at Ellis Island.

One hundred and forty-nine entries have been received for the first swimming tournament of the Atlantic Yacht Club, to be held at Sea Gate, beginning at 3 o'clock this afternoon. This is easily the biggest entry for such a tournament ever received in this country. The list includes many National and local champions, and practically all the amateur experts in the metropolitan district.

"Who could once see Mme. Lerestelle and ever forget her?" remarked that fine yellow rascal his Excellency Ling Wen, Secretary of the Chinese legation in Paris. Ling Wen is a precious scoundrel, for he has not only murdered the Chinese Minister residing in Paris, but has also stolen the official seal.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 17. -- The argument in the case of Caleb Powers, charged with being an accessory to the murder of William Goebel, was not concluded today, the Court refusing to hold a night session. Commonwealth Attorney Robert B. Franklin will make the closing speech for the prosecution to-morrow morning.

Discord and insincerity is said to prevail among the members of the Central Passenger Railroad Association, and the constant quarreling of the roads of that territory is beginning to disgust their Eastern connections. The temper of these is shown by the following letter, which was sent by an official of one of the Eastern lines to the Chairman of the association.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- James J. Van Alen gave a stag dinner this evening at Wakehurst. Among the guests were Lispenard Stewart, Elisha Dyer, Jr., Royal Phelps Carroll, W. Fitzhugh Carroll, Henry Clews, Jr., James T. Woodward, George B. De Forest, Winthrop Rutherfurd, Arthur T. Kemp, John R. Livermore, Fernando Yznaga, De Lancey A. Kane, William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., Hermann Oelrichs, and James Lawrence Van Alen.

A recent privately printed bibliography of books, pamphlets, newspapers, and broadsides, published in the town of Worcester, Mass., from 1775 to 1848, should excite interest as containing a full account of the work of the most prominent printer in the United States a hundred years ago. The compiler of this book, which was published in Worcester in 1899.

From Biblia. About the mound is a wall some twenty feet in height, pierced by three openings, the remains of gateways. Nearly the entire inclosure is filled with a brick platform, equal in height with the surrounding wall. The southern part of the mound contains a few unimposing ruins, but on the northern edge stands the temple, a pyramidal shaped building, reaching seventy feet above the platfrom.

HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- A new departure in electric railroading, and one destined to have an important bearing on the future motor power, is about to go into operation between Albany and Hudson, over the line of the Albany and Hudson Railway and Power Company's tracks. The latter company purchased the Kinderhook and Hudson Railway, which has heretofore been operated by steam power.
WINDERMERE, Ontario, Aug. 17. -- The twenty-first annual meet of the American Canoe Association, which began on Aug. 3 at Big Island, Lake Rousseau, closed today. Summaries of final races follow:

It is impossible to settle the question of spelling such a word as "licence" with any hope of finality. The only rule is to conform with the prevailing fashion. Just now the fashion seems to be to spell the substantive with a "ce" and the verb with an "se," to create an artificial distinction. There is no sense in this idiotic notion, which contradicts etymology and history.

George R. Read and R. Pehlemann Son have sold for W.J. Casey, for $240,000, the five five-story flats, 205 to 211 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, on a plot 150 by 100.11. Mr. Casey takes out-of-town property in part payment.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 5. -- Haarlem has been the scene of some excitement and much interest to art lovers from any part of the world, for it has unveiled a fine statue to the great master, Frans Hals, and Haarlem counts now one more work of genius to her already rich store.

BOSTON, Aug. 17. -- Trading continued quiet to-day. In the mining group Utah was about the only feature, losing 1 1/8, to 30 1/8, while Parrot and Isle Royale, the other active specialties, were steady. Otherwise there was not much interest in this group. Sugar was less active than usual, but Chicago, Burlington and Quincy was bought quite well, also Atchison.

James Young, a laborer, living at 444 Cherry Street, deliberately threw his two-year-old child into the East River yesterday. Four men saw the deed; Young admits it. He was not intoxicated, nor can he explain his action, except by attributing it to temporary insanity.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Application was made to-day to the Court of Chance by for the dissolution of the Distilleries Company of America, which is incorporated under the laws of New Jersey with a capitalization of $125,000,000. The application is made on behalf of Henry I. Dittman and Kalinam Hass of New York, who are stockholders of the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- There was little of interest in the racing this afternoon. The weather was clear and warm, the track in that condition known as "dead," slow time being made in each contest. Four favorites -- McAddie. Duoro, Bannockburn, and Trillo -- won, Elsie Barnes, at 5 to 1 in the betting, defeating Dolly Weithoff in the remaining race.

The London Daily News has just had what it calls "a Plebiscite." The attempt was made to ascertain by means of an English verdict what were the most popular pictures in this year's Royal Academy Exhibition. If the "most popular" are not invariably the best pictures, it is quite likely that according to the judgment of the people they are pretty near it.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- The German press, while expressing joy at the happy discharge of one part of the China programme in the relief of the envoys, points out that there is much left to be done. The Berliner Post says:

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The semi-finals in the women's invitation golf tournament were played to-day for the Boardman Cup at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. A large number was present to see the players start. The first pair to start were Miss Julia Clark and Miss J. Russell.

In my view, a person who published things in a mere newspaper could not properly claim recognition as a literary person; he must rise away above that; he must appear in a magazine. He would then be a literary person; also he would be famous -- right away. These two ambitions were strong upon me.

There was not much doing at Republican National Headquarters yesterday. Senator Hanna was an early arrival, and among his callers were Ethan Alien Hitchcock, Secretary of the Interior; Gov. Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, Supt. John McCullagh, Senator Elsberg, Collector of Customs George R. Bidwell, Victor Dolliver of Iowa, Simon Wolfe of Washington, and the Senator's son, D.R. Hanna.

Under the title of "Paris, as Seen and Described by Famous Writers," Esther Singleton has collected over fifty interesting descriptions of the famous capital by such authors as Victor Hugo, Grant Allen, Hamerton, Balzac, George Band, Prosper Merimee, Ernest Renan, Emile Zola, A.J. C. Hare, Theodore de Banville, Thackeray, Theophile Gautier, Arsene Houssaye, and Edouard Fournier.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@62 1/2. There were no sales.
Chief Devory was asked last night if he wanted to say anything in reply to the attack upon him by Coroner's Physician Hamilton Williams at the Pequod Club on Thursday night.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your recent review of the biography of Matthew Lyon, in which is mentioned his frequent exclamation, "By the bulls that redeemed me," brings to my mind a fact, little known and yet perhaps of interest to your readers, that connects the Kipling of to-day with the wild and patriotic Irishman of a century ago.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Very rarely, outside of Japan, do sorrowing friends mourn over two such victims to "hari-kiri" as the self-immolated Cockran and Shepard.

When Commodore Ledyard's flag was hauled down from the topmast of the schooner yacht Corona in Newport Harbor Tuesday noon, and the cruise of the New York Yacht Club thereby declared at an end, there passed into the domain of reminiscence one of the most enjoyable and successful of the fifty-five of these annual events recorded in the archives of the club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The President and his Cabinet are now busy preparing for the next move in China. None of them yet knows what it is to be. There have been frequent conferences, and as far as possible the officers of the Administration are trying to prepare for any question which may arise.

The outcry against oleomargarine as a food product has resulted in an official report by the Secretary of the Treasury to the House of Representatives of the ingredients used in its manufacture. During the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, over 91,000,000 pounds of oleomargarine were manufactured in the United States.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have recently returned from a visit to Canada, where I passed most of the time among the French-Canadians. As possibly some of the readers of THE TIMES may be interested in the present status -- moral, mental, and physical -- of that race, I venture to send to you a very brief summary of the observations of an entirely unprejudiced American upon the subject.

The third supplementary practice day of the season was held at Creedmoor yesterday for the marksmen and sharpshooters classes. The attendance was large, and the weather favorable. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Col. N.B. Thurston, Ordnance Officer, N.G.N.Y., of Major Gen. Roe's staff.

LORENZO MARQUES, June 21 -- Commercially as well as politically the near future will bring some important changes in the administration of the various colonies of South Africa. There will be a reconstruction of boundaries throughout the whole of South Africa, and a rearrangement of customs dues, railway tariffs, and landing charges, so as to bring each port as much into line as possible.

The full tide of the Summer season has now set in Sailing, dancing, and fishing parties, yacht races, golf and tennis tournaments, polo, and numerous luncheons, dinners, and dinner dances are the tale that is told of each and every watering place on and from the New Jersey coast to Maine's most remote resort, and of the lesser inland summering places.

Dr. Franklin Booth, aged sixty-three years, was run over by a trolley car in Elmhurst late last night and badly injured. His legs were mangled and he directed several passengers who alighted to rescue and assist him, and how to stop the flow of blood. He was conscious all the time and displayed great courage.

Among other things you say "from the present outlook it will die [our association] a quiet and unnoticed death," and also "the members will not stand by their pledges."

NEWPORT, Aug. 18 -- A children's party was given to-day at the residence of Miss Pierson, on Ochre Point. The young people arrived and departed in prettily decorated pony carts and automobiles. After luncheon outdoor sports were enjoyed on the spacious lawn overlooking the sea.

CASSEL, Prussia, Aug. 18 -- In the Throne Room of the paiace here at noon to-day Emperor William presented to Field Marshal Count von Waldersee a Field Marshal's baton. The members of Count von Waldersee's staff were present.

In each compartment, two wooden seats, unfurnished with cushions, faced each other. SYDNEY, July 18 -- Although the work of Australian federation has become practically accomplished by the appointment of a Governor General, there have been no manifestations of enthusiasm in any of the federating colonies, resulting in some degree from the mutual jealousies displayed by New South Wales and Victoria, and which are likely to become increased.
"Faith cure and exercise will do more than medicine or surges sometimes." remarked a Bellevue Hospital doctor the other night.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 13 -- When Americans came to Havana almost two years ago they were surprised to find that, in this metropolis of Cuba, in this enlightened age, there was neither cable nor electric car. Indeed, there were very few street cars of any kind, three lines of horse and one of steam being the sum total of facilities in this direction.

Representative Charles H. Grosvenor of Ohio, who is regarded as the official spokesman of President McKinley in the House of Representatives, returned home yesterday from a trip to Europe. When seen, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, he said that the impression prevailed abroad that the election of Mr. Bryan to the Presidency would have no effect on the currency laws.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- That racing has taken a firm hold on the Summer visitors to this resort was proved by the large crowd that witnessed the five events scheduled this afternoon.

Mayor James K. McGuire of Syracuse, who is the Democratic State campaign manager, came to New York yesterday with the intention of going to Jamesport to see Hugh McLaughlin. He was to visit the veteran Brooklyn leader as an emissary of David B. Hill.

Oarsmen from the boat clubs along the Harlem and Hudson Rivers vied with each other yesterday afternoon on the occasion of the open regatta given by the Hoboken Amateur Rowing Association over the Guttenberg course, which is a mile straightaway, on the Hudson River, off Guttenberg.

BRANFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- How far negotiations have gone for the purchase of a station at Stony Creek, a village just outside this town, is not known here. But it is known that a committee representing the New York Yacht Club has made an offer for the purchase of the tract known as Indian Point.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The ceremony of officially announcing the awards made to the exhibitors at the Paris Exposition took place this afternoon. It was not less magnificent in its pomp than the ceremony attending the formal opening of the exposition. The announcement of the awards occurred in the Salles des Fetes, the hall which itself is one of the most beautiful exhibits.

SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 18 -- The regular weekly handicap was played on the links of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club to-day. The day was a perfect one for golf, and some good cards were handed in. The best gross score was made by C.D. Barnes, making the round in 82. His card was:

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 18 -- The huckleberry crop is a godsend to the families of coal miners at and in the vicinity of Hazleton, returning to them as it does between $40,000 and $50,000 every year during the months that the season lasts, and what is true of the mining centre is true of others, for the mountain regions of the entire anthracite field are prolific in their yield of this popular fruit.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- The Newport polo season was opened this afternoon with a match between the Point Judith Country Club and Monmouth County Club teams for the Newport Cup. The play was on the Westchester Polo Club's new grounds near the golf club, and was witnessed by a large number of the society people of Newport.

William H. Sayne, the State of Pennsylvania Commissioner to the Paris Exposition, arrived here yesterday on the Lucania. A party of Philadelphia friends, headed by Hampton Moore, the secretary of the Mayor of that city, met the Lucania down the bay on a tug and took Mr. Sayne aboard.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 18 -- Old residents declare that the crowd here is larger than ever before. The shore-front hostelries refused applications for rooms early in the week, and late-comers, who persisted in stopping at their favorite hotels, gladly accepted the offer of cots in the corridors for the night.

PORT JERVIS, Aug. 18 -- The Department of Public Works of New York State will proceed with the work of draining the Bashas Kill Swamp, situated in the Mamakating Valley of Sullivan and a small portion of Orange Counties.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 18. -- After being out less than an hour the jury in the case of the Commonwealth against ex-Secretary of State Caleb Powers, charged with being an accessory before the fact to the murder of William Goebel, brought in a verdict of guilty this afternoon, and fixed the punishment of Powers at imprisonment for life.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Many of the bestknown amateur athletes in New England competed in the games at Charles River Park under the auspices of St. Augustine's Parish this afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-foot yacht Rainbow finished first again to-day in the second of the series of races for the Newport Yacht Racing Association prizes, but this time she won by one minute and thirty-three seconds, W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.'s, Virginia being second, and August Belmont's Mineola third.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- This has been the gayest and busiest week thus far this season. The social movement began on Monday with a number of pleasant and informal events, and in the evening a minstrel entertainment at the Opera House. The tennis tournament opened on Tuesday and has continued through the week with the usual large attendance and picturesque scenes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Two Congressional Committees in this city are watching each other narrowly. Chairman Richardson and his associates on the Democratic committee do not take much stock in the interviews which Chairman Babcock and his Republican associates give out to the effect that there is danger of the Republicans losing the House.

The Department of Agriculture has recently, through Mr. B.T. GALLOWAY, its Chief of the Division of Physiology and Pathology, made an investigation that possesses interest not only for the class specially concerned in a great and increasing business, but for all persons who buy flowers, fruits, and vegetables grown under glass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- "The heat wave in London," says Consul Marshall Halstead, at Birmingham, in a report to the State Department, "has created an opening for electric fans. The Daily Mail says that London is the most backward of all great capitals in provisions for meeting heat.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- There have been enough American electric railroad promoters at the Carlton this week to carry through any scheme for rapid transit in London which can be devised. Tom L. Johnson of Brooklyn came from Paris Thursday, and under the same roof were W.L. Elkins and P.A.B. Widener of Philadelphia, who have since gone to the Continent, and Edwin Johnson, representing the Edison Company.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 18 -- Next Tuesday bids will be opened in Washington for the construction of the buildings and piers of the United States naval coaling station at East Lamoine, on Frenchman's Bay. The date for the opening of the bids was first set for Aug. 14, but owing to changes in plans it was deferred one week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To-day's reading in THE TIMES must give food for thought to all thinking, loyal, and patriotic citizens. The daily perusal of your news and editorial columns impresses me with the idea that you at least try to give an honest and impartial picture of political events.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Justice Frederick Smyth of the Supreme Court of New York, First Department, died at the Hotel Dennis, this city, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The immediate cause of his death was pneumonia, contracted a few days ago, but he had never entirely recovered from the attack of vertigo which he sustained on July 20, which had caused almost total collapse, and he had been in ill health since January.

Trading in the market yesterday for outside securities was very light Only three or four stocks showed any activity, while most of the issues that attracted attention during the week were not the objects of much interest. There seemed to be very few outside orders in the market, the half holiday having its usual effect of lessening the amount of trading.

A good many of those who now throng the dramatic agencies do not, however, come from the resorts.

On the steamship Trave, which arrived here from Bremen yesterday, were the first Christian Endeavor Society delegates to return from their European travels under the guidance of the Crawford Floyd tourists' agency. In the party were about 200 persons, more than half of them being women.

The Hon. JOHN I. PLATT of Poughkeepsie, in a communication elsewhere published in this issue of THE TIMES, denounces the canal improvement proposed by the Greene committee as "the greatest act of folly and the greatest outrage upon the taxpayers ever proposed in the State of New York."

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18 -- With the dinner dance at the Kebo Club to-night, the Hinkle Cup tournament on its links for three days of the week, the handicaps there this morning, and the second reception and entertainment by the Monday Evening Club in the clubhouse the first of the week, Kebo was the centre of social doings during the past seven days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although a Republican, and proud of the history and triumphs of the Republican Party, I do not intend to support the present Administration in the coming election. I have read and carefully weighed the editorials of our lending and substantial newspapers, and the point that has impressed me is that there seems to be a desire to befog and misrepresent the issue involved in the present campaign.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Another party of destitute Christian Endeavorers arrived in Paris to-night from Switzerland. Some few of them are receiving remittances from home, which enables them to help their less fortunate companions.

There was some fine cricket played in the vicinity of this city yesterday, and the day was marked by the first defeat of the Paterson Club in the championship series of the New York Cricket Association.

Yet the British troops, after all, occupy the nerve centre of the richest region in China, which sustains 150,000,000 people, and were landed with the consent and approval of the powers.

What testimentary disposition Collis P. Huntington made of his vast estate will not be known until the family shall instruct its lawyers to petition for the probate of the will. This la not likely to be done earlier than Tuesday, nor later than Thursday. A member of the family said yesterday that these proceedings would not be delayed for the arrival of the Princess von Hatzfeldt.

Stock market conditions show small change. Activity does not appear. Professional trading remains about the only thing tangible upon the Stock Exchange. Commission houses stay idle, outsiders still holding aloof, and there is no appearance anywhere of interest whatsoever upon the part of those leaders who are strong enough to give the market quality.

Baseball playing, such as the Montclair Athletic Club team did yesterday would have landed that team higher up in the Amateur League race had it been done earlier in the season. The Jerseymen met the New York Athletic Club nine on the Montclair field and had the visitors "on the hip" from the outset.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 18 -- The ladies' putting match was the social event of the afternoon, and the Kebo dinner dance the main attraction of the evening here. The former was held on the putting greens of the Lodge hole, and drew society like a magnet. The crowds of society people, the gay dresses, laughter, and the hum of conversation were reminiscent of the palmy days of the Kebo Club.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $7,568,900. The banks now hold a surplus of $20,557,050 above the legal requirements.

Lieut. Col. Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Volunteers did not appear at the regular meeting of Gloucester Command, No. 17, Spanish War Veterans, at its headquarters, at 371 Amsterdam Avenue, last night. His friends, however, were there in force, and completely turned the tables on his opponents, who interrupted his mustering in two weeks ago by driving him from the hall with shouts of "Coward! "

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Thousands of Methodists from all quarters have been pouring into Ocean Grove the week through in order to be present at the opening of the annual camp meeting, scheduled for to-morrow, when the opening sermon will be preached in the auditorium by the Rev. Dr. J.W. Hamilton of Boston, one of the newly elected Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 18 -- That struggling minority in Vermont, the State Democracy, will undertake this year to reduce the inevitable Republican majority to its lowest terms. The State election is only three weeks distant, Tuesday Sept. 4, being the date when a complete set of State officers will be elected, and both branches of the Legislature, the Assembly and Senate, will be filled.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Living in Middlesex County are two persons whose combined ages aggregate 232 years. When they were reported to Charles S. Tunis, Supervisor of the Census of the Fourth District, he thought a blunder had been made. He made a personal investigation of each case, and was convinced of the correctness of the reports of the enumerators.

The police of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station are looking for two well-dressed young men who were seen leaving the basement of the four-story brownstone house 68 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, owned and occupied as a Winter residence by the family of Mr. Betz, who was formerly connected with the Betz Brewing Company.

One of the best amateur swimming tournaments ever held in this country took place yesterday afternoon at Sea Gate, under the auspices of the Atlantic Yacht Club. The entry list included most every amateur of note in the metropolitan district. A fashionable crowd of more than 1,500 people witnessed the sport, and they voted the carnival one of the best entertainments ever given by the club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of Mr. Huntington brings out the information that he was the gentleman who offered the money prizes for the best answers to "The Man with the Hoe," being moved thereto, according to The Sun, by a desire to combat the "false and meretricious philosophy" of Mr. Markham's poem.

Young boys pounded each other in a boxing match last night at the home of the Duane Social A.C., in Pearl Street. There, under the shadow of the great bridge and adjoining the Oak Street Police Station, the east side devotees of the prizering gather two or three times a week to applaud the spirited, if not scientific, boxing bouts between boys, youths, and men which the club offers to its patrons.

ZAMBOANGA, P.I., July 6 -- Throughout the length and breadth of the Philippines it would be very difficult to find a more loyal community than that which exists in and about this town and province. Capt. Very in reality sowed far better than he knew during those tiresome, vexatious days when the gunboat Castine was cruising off this portion of the coast and keeping up a vigilant blockade.

Three facts are regarded as proved: 1. The bactericidal property of the chemical rays of light. 2. The power of these rays to produce an inflammation of the skin. 3. The power of the chemical rays to penetrate the skin. The method consists in treating local superficial skin disease of bacterial origin by the concentrated chemical rays, the ultra-violet being the most valuable.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 18 -- The question of a successor to Senator Marion Butler is giving the Democrats some trouble. The State Convention of last April directed that a primary election should be held on the day of the Presidential election, in order to instruct the members of the General Assembly whom they shall vote for for Senator.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 28 -- Russia is again threatened with the Asiatic plague, or "tehouma," as it is called here. This fact seems to have been overlooked by the Western European press. After having ravaged British India, where it is still raging, the "tehouma" has spread, on one side to China, and on the other to Arabia.

The remarkable growth of the trade of the United States, and the manner in which its expansion is cutting into the business of the British manufacturers, was the dominant note at the Congress of Chambers of Commerce of the British Empire, which has just concluded its labors in London.

Policeman Felix McNally, for many years attached to the Grand Central Sub-Station, died at his home, 742 Columbus Avenue, Friday, after a lingering illness of nearly six months. Policeman McNally was one of the oldest men on the force, having been born in St. John, N.B., July 5, 1833. He was appointed to the force Feb. 9, 1882.

Her intended independent action created not a little criticism: but, now that it has been checked, official circles silently grin at what is regarded as a rebuff.

The weekly sttement of the associated banks yesterday showed a decrease in the surplus of $7,568,900. Deposits decreased, $3,091,600 and loans increased $6,837,400. Specie decreased $8,106,900 and legal tenders decreased $234,000. There was an increase of $672,300 in circulation, and the legal reserve declined $8,341,800.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article on "Economy and Patience" will be read and thoughtfully considered by thousands of your subscribers, and it is my hope that some will give expression to their views thereon. May I by your courtesy submit mine?

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- About 5,000 shares and $2,000 bonds made up the Boston dealings. No listed bonds changed hands, the $2,000 being New England Gas and Coke. Boston and Albany rose 3/4 on small lots, to 250 3/4, and Elevated was firm at 144 1/4. Utah Mining hardened 1/2, to 31 1/2, closing at 31 1/4, a 1 3/4 net rise for the week.

A royal welcome was accorded to Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan by several hundred of the clergy and laity of the diocese yesterday morning, when the Archbishop returned from a four months' tour in Europe.

Ebenezer Parker, sailmaker's mate, died in the United States Naval Home in Philadelphia three weeks ago at the age of sixty-three years, and thus was reduced by one the little squad of the real oldfashioned American men-o'-warsmen in whom are embodied the traditions of the wooden ships and iron men that in bygone days made the fleets that flew the Stars and Stripes the terrors of the seas.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 -- Murder was the result of an argument between two men this afternoon over donations to a church. Joseph Richter shot and killed George Uchtman after a heated controversy, in which there were criminations and recriminations.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The young people here have devised a new idea this week, and now moonlight picnics on Monument Mountain have become a fad. This mountain, which has become famous through the poem of Bryant, is a delightful spot, and the young people drive there about sunset, climb the mountain, have tea, and watch the moon rise.

David Mitchell, who was Chief Assistant District Attorney during the time William M.K. Olcott was District Attorney, died at his residence, 200 West One Hundred and Second Street, yesterday morning, of liver complaint. He was born in Dumbarton, Scotland, fifty-four years ago. At the age of three and a half years he was brought to America by his parents, and went to live in Manchester, N.H.

"Tom" McManus, known in every art studio in New York as one of the best of models, is to-day a complete wreck. Homeless, with no friends, it is only a question of a short time until death will claim him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the managers of the Kings County Elevated Railroad had deliberately set about arresting the growth of population and depreciating real estate values in certian districts of the Borough of Brooklyn they could not have adopted a system of transit more likely to make their purposes succeed than the one they have recently introduced.

Mrs. Julian Lawrence Meyers of this City, her daughter Sylvia, and Lieut. Percy Stanislaus Hicks of the Fourth Lancers and the Hyderabad contingent of the Indian Staff Corps, who arrived in this city on the Lucania yesterday, are the principals in an international romance.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 18 -- Ex-President Palacio is dead.

The punishment of F.D. Beard by fine, at Saratoga, for sending to the post a steeplechaser, Ingomar, who had not been properly schooled over the steeplechase field, was an unusual proceeding, but, at that, it establishes a precedent that horsemen generally agree should be productive of good results.

When I asked one long in Government employ if his thirty years in their midst had led him to believe that the Chinese could be regenerated, awakened, or galvanized to some semblance of modern life, he exclaimed: "No, never! It is not possible to regenerate China as China. It cannot be effected from within by the Chinese.

The report of the premium receipts of the fire insurance companies in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx for the first half of 1900, as prepared by the Committee on Fire Patrol of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters, amounted to about $5,100,000, as against $3,800,000 for the corresponding period of 1898, and $4,500,000 for the first half of 1898.

Plum Island on Labor Day will see an outpouring of boys and young men from New York at the Summer camp of the Boys' Club, who will go there to take part in the first field day of the organization, preparations for which have been laid out on quite an elaborate scale. The boys in their clubhouse in St. Mark's Place have long been preparing for the event.

From The London News. Queen Victoria's long life and reign, her large family circle, and her prominent position, have all tended, of course, to give the impression that she has been quite exceptionally exposed in her person and surroundings to the shafts of the grim archer. Perhaps it is not really so.

From The Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal. For more than a month visitors at Fountain Ferry Park have been attracted by the erection of a dwelling about one mile west of the park on the Indiana shore. The building of a house does not usually attract much attention, but this is an exception, for its constructor is a woman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- From Gen. Chaffee to-day the War Department received official confirmation of the fall of Peking and the rescue of the besieged foreigners.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- One fact is immediately proved by the military display at the exposition. That chivalrous invitation, "Messieurs les Anglais, tirez les premiers," which preceded the British defeat at Fontenoy, will never be repeated upon any battlefield again, though the editor of the Matin recently used it as the cri de ralliement of the present situation in China.
NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- It is understood that Hermann Oelrich is to purchase land in the neighborhood of Portsmouth and to establish on it a model farm second to none in the country.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Just in the nick of time your gold became available and saved our market from a nasty jar. London stock brokers and others still grumble at the smart stroke played by the Chancellor of the Exchequer; but had he left the money market to its own devices, last week must have seen the Bank of England forced to put the rate up to 5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- In the last day's contests of the world's fly-casting tourament at Garfield Park Lagoon, A.E. Lovett of San Francisco won the long-distance contest with 105 feet. F.N. Peet of Chicago was second with 102 feet.

Some interests that hope for a better market and find it hard to wait are beginning to calculate upon the early return to town of those leaders whose absence accounts largely for this Summer's lethargy. Yet really there are no signs of any such early homecoming; and market dullness is not likely on that account to find nearby relief.

The Cuban teachers arrived to this city last evening, reaching Jersey City over the Pennsylvania at 6 o'clock last night, afterward being ferried to the transport, which, after their visit to New York is concluded, will convey them back to Cuba.

Sunday is supposed to be a pretty quiet day for traveling, and so it is on most of the avenues taken up by the travel of the week day. But any one who stood at the curve by which the Brooklyn trolley lines come in and go out on the bridge any time after sundown yesterday would have seen a crowd larger and rather more unmanageable than that of the rush hours on ordinary days.

We are constantly invited to admire the virtues of WILLIAM J. BRYAN. He has, they tell us, a most engaging personality. His wonderful tenacity of mind and purpose in keeping up the fight for free-silver coinage against the advice and entreaty of some of the greatest men in his party proves him to be a man of strength, courage, and consistency.

From The Chicago Chronicle. The servant-girl question is a burning issue in Milwaukee. Housekeepers are in despair. Many of them cannot get servants of any kind and others get such poor ones that they wish they had none at all. A new movement has been started there within a short time by the management of certain charitable employment agencies who make a specialty of trying to find work for all sorts and conditions of people.

The trial of those burghers and others implicated in the plot to carry off Lord ROBERTS and murder his subordinate officers will be followed with considerable interest everywhere. It is natural that the discovery of the plot should have been followed with the utmost indignation throughout the British Army.

Golf during the coming week will, to a great extent, be preparatory to the women's National championship, which will occupy the greater portion of next week at the Shinnecock Hills Club, near Southampton, L.I. The entries for this event will close to-morrow, and the committee of the United States Golf Association will make the drawings for the preliminary medal play round later in the week.
President Eliot of Harvard University accepted with the following remarks the loving cup presented to the university by the Cuban teachers who have passed six weeks at the Summer school there:

With the Middle States regatta but two weeks off, the Harlem River oarsmen thought it necessary to work like Trojans yesterday, and they did. The weather was just perfect for hard work with the sweeps and sculls, which fact made the oarsmen more than thankful, for the hot spell had put many of them behind in their training.

From The Philadelphia Medical Journal. An aged colored individual is making the rounds of the physicians' offices and hospitals, exhibiting himself as a man with two hearts. He also claims to be able to displace his hearts into the abdominal cavity. He has traveled widely in this country and has been in Europe.

Her mind unbalanced, as is believed, by anxiety over a charge which she was to have faced next Wednesday in court, Mrs. Lizzie Frazer, a midwife, committed suicide yesterday morning at her home, 331 Furman Street, Brooklyn, by inhaling illuminating gas.

Disappointment and surprise prevailed among the members of the Sixty-ninth Regiment Saturday afternoon when it became known that Col. Duffy had put an emphatic veto on the proposition to send a company of the regiment to take part in the military tournament at Long Branch next Friday and Saturday.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Special services in the immaculate Conception Church in memory of King Humbert of Italy were held this afternoon at the request of the Italian societies of this city, which had arranged to be present. The Rev. Father Ludwig, pastor of the church. Informed the societies that he did not want them to come to the church in uniform.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day gave out for publication a letter which he had written on Aug. 9 to Gen. John M. Palmer of Springfield, Ill., relative to the St. Paul speech made by the Governor, in which he had been quoted as making derogatory remarks concerning Democrats.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- The Casino lawn tennis courts were deserted to-day, and the expert players who are still left to struggle for the championship of the United States are taking a much-needed rest. To-morrow morning Larned will meet George Wrenn in the final round of the all-comers tournament, and the winner will challenge the National champion, M. D. Whitman, the next day for his title.
CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 19. -- The Rev. Dr. John Henry Barrows, President of Oberlin College, to-day preached the last sermon of the season before the Chautauqua Assembly. Among other things he said:

Fanciers and owners of light harness horses flocked to the Speedway yesterday in copious quantities. They found the course in good condition after its recent wettings-springy and smooth -- and the air of that snappy, exhilarating tone that adds to the zest of brushing. The wind was inclined to be boisterous but was not troublesome, blowing down the course so that it was at the backs of the drivers engaged in brushes.

A murder was committed some time on Saturday night on the second floor of 674 Second Avenue. The victim was a young woman, Catharine Scharn, twenty-three years old, whose body was found early yesterday morning by her eighteen-year-old brother, Frederick, who made his home with her.

The Republican National Committee has issued a long statement in which it says that there are four primary facts which, in its opinion, seem to justify the party in asking the voters of the United States to continue it in control of the affairs of the Government. The statement gives these facts as follows:

R.E. Durand of the United States Industrial Commission had a chance to sea the representatives of organized labor on their native heath yesterday at the meeting of the Central Federated Union. Mr. Durand came to get information from the delegates regarding the labor unions, and submitted a list of questions in reference to wages, hours of labor, strikes, and other matters which he wished to have answered.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Seven of the series of ten races scheduled for the seventy-footers have been sailed and the remaining three races are set for Monday, Wednesday, and Friday of the coming week. The weather indications to-night are favorable and the owners of the four yachts are looking forward to some good sport in to-morrow's race.

From The London Globe. The practice of plagiarizing from the works of others is universally condemned; yet at one time it boasted a professor of its own, who taught not to imitate the best authors, but to steal from them. Richescurce, the professor in question, was deservedly held up to public contempt by Isaac D'lsraeli in his "Curiotities of Literature."

The term of imprisonment of ex-Coroner Edward B. Coombs of Brooklyn in the King's County Penitentiary expires to-day. Coombs was convicted of presenting a false and fraudulent bill and claim containing false and fraudulent items for audit, allowance, and payment while a Coroner under the old Brooklyn City Government.

From The Westminster Gazette. There have been few more remarkable expeditions in recent years that the combined bicycling and climbing tour which has Just been accomplished by Dr. and Mrs. Workman, an enterprising American couple. They have spent two years in India, and in the course of that time have bicycled from south to north of the whole peninsula, traversed the Islands of Java and Ceylon, and thrice penetrated on foot far into the Himalayas.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- A story in connection with the assault on the Shah that is worth relating, if only by reason of the ingenuity, is published in so grave a journal as the Republique Franchise, controlled by ex-Minister Meline, who is not given to sensationalism.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- The tendency of the Boerse last week was somewhat stronger.

The Merchants' Association has just issued a bound volume containing the report of the investigation of the water supply of New York City made by its Special Committee on Water Supply. The Chairman of the committee is M.E. Bannin and D. Le Roy Dresser Is Vice Chairman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- The mystery of a twenty-five-thousand-dollar express robbery is perplexing officials of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company, the Commercial National Bank of Chicago, and the Adams Express Company.

A crowd estimated as much in excess of the 100,000 mark and which is thought to have been the largest that has visited Coney Island this season, saw the sights at that resort yesterday. The police had their hands full in keeping the crowd in order, an unusual number of arrests being made, including several pickpockets.
GEORGETOWN, Ky., Aug. 19. -- Caleb Powers issued a statement this evening, as follows: To the Public:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Cuban delegation which called upon the President at the White House yesterday to plead for Cuban independence is not as hopeful or as well satisfied as its members stated in an interview after the close of the visit. Senor Cisneros, who headed the delegation, said in an interview to-day:

A number of our correspondents, indignant at the fact, which we have felt forced to demonstrate, that the Gold Standard act of March 14 does not prevent Mr. BRYAN from paying the interest and principal of the bonds in silver, ask us whether the Republican Party shall be rewarded for failing to keep its pledges by a renewed lease of power.
The primaries will be held one week from to-morrow, and hot fights are promised on both sides in several districts.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 19. -- It is feared that a general strike of the United Mine Workers of the anthracite coal region will probably be declared toward the end of September.

THE ANTI-SEMITIC RIOTS IN ODESSA. -- It is reported in St. Petersburg that a serious anti-Jewish outbreak occurred in Odessa a fortnight ago, followed by similar troubles in other districts, especially in the Government of Kovno. The police were powerless to restore order, even with the assistance of Cossacks and infantry.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $7,568,900. The banks now hold a surplus of $20,557,050 above the legal requirement. The changes in averages show an increase in loans of $6,837,400, a decrease in specie of $8,106,900, a decrease in legal tenders of $234,900, a decrease in deposits of $3,091,600, and an increase in circulation of $672,300.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Foreign missions originated under the old theology which taught the fall of man, and that the heathen must know of Christ and be converted in order to "get saved." In other words, unless they received our Gospel and experienced a change of heart they were doomed to suffer eternal punishment.

Severe thunderstorms seriously hampered telegraphic communication in various parts of the country last evening, and for hours cable service to Europe was all but abandoned. A big storm raged from 10 o'clock until midnight over an area of country extending from Pittsburg to Columbus, Ohio, and to Indianapolis, Ind. This greatly delayed all business with Chicago and the Far West, for many of the Western Union through wires pass through the affected district.

From The Torrington (Conn.) Register. Among all the arguments against expansion the wildest and wooliest is furnished by a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES. That newspaper, by the way, prints without distinction innumerable letters from those who disagree with its policies, as well as the usual encomiums of a paper's political tendencies which the less independent journals are so ready to print.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.-- Amid scenes of impressive solemnity, and in the presence of the President of the United States, members of the Cabinet, officers of the army and navy, the Ambassadors and Ministers of foreign countries, and a great concourse of people from civil life, the memorial service for King Humbert of Italy was held at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church at 11 o'clock to-day.

From The London Express. Something quite new in "ye ancient and royal game of golf " was witnessed in the warehouse of Anderson, Anderson Anderson recently, where Braid played Taylor, the champion, and beat him by 6 holes up and 5 to play.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Remarkably fast time was made in the one-mile amateur tandem handicap at the Vailsburg board track yesterday. The winners, W.J. Keefe and Charles Widman, both of Newark, covered the distance in 1:57 1-5, having started from the 150-yard mark.

New York City's population, according to the announcement from Washington, was on June 1 pretty nearly three and one-half millions of people -- 3,437,202, to give the precise figures reported. As nearly as the census officers can make out, the increase in population in ten years in the territory that is now New York City was 944,611, or nearly a million.

The police of this borough were condemned in unmeasured terms by the Rev. Dr. Dean Richmond Babbitt, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, McDonough Street and Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, in a sermon last evening on the race troubles on the west side last week.

All Hoboken ferryboats were crowded yesterday afternoon with hundreds of happy German families going to attend the opening day of the twenty-sixth annual festival of the Plattdutsche Volksfest Verein, which continues throughout the greater part of the week, at Schutzen Park, Union Hill.
Net changes for the week of 1 point or more in the more active securities were:

All the white people who live in that part of Sixtieth Street, near West End Avenue, called "Battle Row," and all the negroes who live on the other side of the street in "Cuckoo Row," talked for hours last night about the latest exploit of "Mike the Bite," a character of the neighborhood, whose fame is in both rows and beyond.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 20 -- Dr. Sturley Harrington, a physician of Farley, across the river in Missouri, drunk and imagining he had been wronged, killed James Wallace, his uncle, a wealthy farmer; Mrs. William Wallace, his mother-inlaw, and J.P. Dillingham, Sheriff of Platte County, who tried to arrest him.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 20 -- After receiving into their bodies yesterday the force of an electric current which rendered them unconscious, Michael J. Bevlin of 60 Centre Street, Orange, and George Medien of West Orange were at work to-day somewhat sore, but otherwise not the worse for their experience.

The protest of CALER POWERS against his conviction as an accessory to the murder of GOEBEL will receive an assenting response from many men of candid minds who are accustomed to weigh evidence and are familiar with the forms of procedure in properly conducted trials by jury.

In the State Convention of the New York Democracy, held at Syracuse, on Sept. 12, 1879, WILLIAM DORSHEIMER made a speech of menace in which he plainly told the convention that, if the majority nominated LUCIUS ROBINSON, the seventy-two Tammany delegates would walk out of the hall and organize another convention.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
The probabilities now are that Charles A. Hess will make a contest to be continued as leader in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District.

The market for outside securities yesterday was fairly quiet and prices ruled generally strong. Active trading was confined to comparatively few issues and the general market was characterized by the absence of stocks, which has obtained for several weeks. With few exceptions, the trading of the day appeared to be strictly professional.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20 -- Terrific electrical, wind, and rain storms have raged in the northern, eastern, and southern sections of Maryland during the past forty-eight hours. Several lives have been lost, five or six injured, and the estimated aggregate loss to property is about $75,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- The will of Sally M. Waln of this city, who died recently, leaving an estate valued at $200,000, was probated to-day. Among the public bequests contained in the document are the following:

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Corp. Fred J. Dunford, late of Company C, Ninth United States Infantry, who was reported in press dispatches as missing after landing at Tien-Tsin, China, July 10, has arrived safely here. There is a touch of romance in the circumstances of the young soldier's homecoming.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing your letters from readers published in THE SUNDAY TIMES. I am impressed with the profound wisdom, of your contributor, Joseph Culbertson Clayton. No doubt he is a direct descendant of the renowned house of Clayton.

Barnett Co. have sold for William Stonebridge, to Edwin H. Smith, for $2,200, the two lots, 25 by 200, on the north side of One Hundred and Eighty-second Street, 350 feet west of the Southern Boulevard.

JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 20 -- Golfers at Jefferson began their gala week this morning with perfect mountain weather, and the Waumbek Golf Club links in perfect condition for tournament play. In addition to the men's tournament, in which thirty-four golfers started in the first two preliminary rounds, the special attraction was the Vardon exhibition which attracted all to the links.

Richard Croker changed his political programme and returned from Saratoga yesterday to take personal charge of Tammany Hall affairs. All business will have to be transacted direct with Mr. Croker now, as he announced yesterday that he would be at the Wigwam every day until after election, with an occasional day or two of rest.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- It is probable that the intercollegiate tennis tournament will be held in October, and hereafter at the grounds of the Merion Cricket Club, Philadelphia. This is the unanimous request of the members of the Intercollegiate Association, which requires only the formal approval of the National body to go into effect.

Senator William M. Stewart of Nevada, long one of the strongest pillars of the freesilver party, has pronounced for McKinley and Roosevelt. He called at Republican Headquarters and gave his reasons for renouncing Bryanism. Senator Stewart was one of the founders of the Republican Party, but silver took him out of the organization.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Executive Committee of the State Fair Commission this morning arranged for a race by Cresceus, 2:07 1/4, at the fair races, against the stallion record, 2:05 1/4, made by Directum at Nashville in 1893. The fair Association offers $1,000 for the race with $500 additional if Cresceus breaks the record.
Andrew Mack appeared at the Academy of Music last night in his new play, "The Rebel," the scenes of which are based upon the Irish rebellion of 1798.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The twenty-second annual congress of the Federation of Trades and Labor Unions of New Jersey began its sessions here this morning. H.C. Curtis of the Garment Workers' Union of Newark, the First Vice President, presided. Fifty-four delegates were present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Senator William M. Johnson of Hackensack, N.J., the President of the New Jersey, State Senate, has accepted the office of First Assistant Postmaster General, made vacant by the resignation of Perry S. Heath. He will take charge in a few days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 20 -- Gen. John B. Gordon, Commander in Chief of the United Confederate Veterans, has prepared a reply to a resolution recently adopted by a camp of Confederate veterans at New Orleans, condemning the blue and gray reunion in Atlanta, recommending that no more similar reunions be held, and protesting against Gen. Gordon accepting an invitation to the Grand Army of the Republic reunion at Chicago.

Gov. Roosevelt was an early arrival in the city yesterday, and after visiting his physician he went to Republican National Headquarters. There he was in conference for some time with Chairman Hanna, Treasurer Bliss, and Senator N.B. Scott with reference to his itinerary, which will have been definitely decided upon before the Governor comes to town on Friday.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 20 -- One of the largest and most notable events of the season was the ball and reception tendered to Gov. William Gregory of Rhode Island and staff by Messrs. J.G. Burns Son, at the Rockingham Hotel, this evening. Over one thousand invitations had been issued, and the ballroom was thronged with guests from Narragansett, Newport, Jamestown, and Watch Hill.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Far Rockaway won the second part of the Grand Union Hotel Stakes this afternoon by a head from Lady Schorr, with Longshoreman only half a length away. For the first time in over a week the track was in good condition and the time made in several events was fast.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, telegraphs that the heavy, general rainfall has continued in most of the affected tracts. The crops promise well in the central provinces and Berar, sowing is active elsewhere, and the necessity for free kitchens will shortly disappear.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Julian Ralph, in The Daily Mail this morning, quotes from a "diplomat of high standing," whose name is not given, who declares that Russia is vigorously endeavoring to secure American support and to break the harmony existing between the United States and Great Britain.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- The Grand Circuit meeting on the Readeville track opened this afternoon. The chief event of the programme, the Blue Hill Stakes, of $5,000, was won by Annie Burns, owned in Rushville, Ind., in five heats. The summaries:

HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The first trip over the new third-rail system of the Albany and Hudson Railway, operated by power from the new water-power station at Stuyvesant Falls, was made to-day, and the working of the new electrical plant proved satisfactory in every particular. At points along the route the train ran at the rate of sixty miles an hour.

MANCHESTER, Aug. 20 -- The market last week was more active. Indian offers increased, and a fair number were accepted on a basis of Winter deliveries of cotton, though as many firms decline to assume such risks, the market was very irregular and business was unevenly distributed. Bombay took for early shipment shirtings and nainsooks and Madras wide goods.

Ex-Coroner Edward B. Coombs was released from the Kings County Penitentiary yesterday afternoon, his term of imprisonment having expired. Coombs was not required to pay the fine of $1,000 which was imposed upon him when he was sentenced because of a legal flaw in the commitment.

Controller Coler was at his office yesterday, after spending a short vacation at Liberty, N.Y. One of his first callers was Elliot Danforth, the friend of David B. Hill. For over an hour a conference was held in the Controller's private office.

James L. Wells, President of the North Side Board of Trade, has prepared a table showing that in the last decade the population of the Borough of the Bronx has increased by a larger percentage than that of any other borough of the city. His statement is as follows:

NEWPORT, Aug. 20 -- The grand stand and the side lines, at the Casino to-day during the tennis playing were crowded with the members of the smart set of Newport, Narragansett Pier, and Jamestown. There were many fine gowns, some of the most striking being:
Senator Hanna was in extremely good humor when he reached Republican National Headquarters yesterday, although the weather was not at all favorable to rheumatic patients.

Up to a late hour last night the police were unable to grain a single trustworthy clue that might lead to the solving of the mystery surrounding the death of Kathryn Scharn, the young woman who was found murdered in her apartment on the third floor of 674 Second Avenue early Sunday morning.

The ado over the Scharn murder case indicates pretty clearly that the sensational newspapers in this city are hard put to it for "sensations" of that particular kind. This case, indeed, seems likely to be classed for a short time with the Guldensuppe and Kate Adams cases, as the most notable New York murder case of its year; but nothing has thus far transpired concerning it to lead one to consider it really memorable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Chinese Government to-day made formal application through Li-Hung-Chang, as its Envoy, for the appointment of an American Commissioner to bring about the cessation of hostilities in China and the restoration of general peace.

Another chapter was added yesterday to the history of the Stradivarius violin stolen from Prof. Jean J. Bolts in March, 1895. Victor Flechter, who is now under suspended sentence on a charge of taking it, visited Police Headquarters, accompanied by two violin experts, who positively identified it as the missing instrument.

From The Philadelphia Ledger. WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Cabinet has given considerable time of late to the discussion of Philippine affairs; notwithstanding the stress of the Chinese situation. Since the Taft Commission began its work at Manila in May progress has been made in preparing the way for a permanent form of government under which, there may be peace.

A strike of the iron workers took place yesterday at both the New York and Brooklyn towers of the New East River Bridge because the wages of the men, which were 30 cents per day higher than the union wages, were cut down to the union rate of $3.20 per day. All the iron workers belong to the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union.

Italians from all parts of the city filled St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday at a solemn high mass of requiem and pontifical absolution for King Humbert. Consul General Branchi of Italy, who represented the Italian Government, and many of the Consuls of other countries in this city were present, besides Secretary Youngs, representing Gov. Roosevelt and Acting Mayor Guggenheimer and other city officials.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to you, published yesterday, Mr. Clayton says:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt's Rainbow crossed the finish line a winner in to-day's race, the eighth for the seventy-footers of the series for the thousand-dollar cup. She had beaten the second boat, Yankee, by 14 seconds, and Mineola by 1 minute 9 seconds. It was a fluky day, and Virginia got all the worst of the light airs.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- For several weeks people near Hunt's Point, in the Borough of the Bronx, have noticed an eleven-year-old boy lurking in the woods and along the highways. At times he was entirely nude, and he sometimes appeared wearing a sheet about him and visited the houses in the neighborhood to beg for food.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The State Department to-day issued the following statement:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- The final round of the all-comers' championship lawn tennis tournament drew a large crowd or spectators to the Casino here this morning, and they saw Larned beat Wrenn in the easiest possible manner, the score being 6-3, 6-2, 6-2. Wrenn was outclassed from the start, and there was never a time when he had a chance to win.

Yesterday at the resorts began the very gayest week of the season. Newport, Bar Harbor, Southampton, and the other Summer cities seemed to vie with each other in the number and variety of their entertainments. From the telegraphic reports one will find a full description of the debut ball given for Miss Gladys Brooks, the second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Brooks, and which was the great event of last evening at Newport.

The Sire brothers, lessees of the New York Theatre, opened war against the ticket speculators on schedule time last night, and within less than two hours after the doors of the theatre were opened two arrests had been made, one in the ranks of the Sires and the other in the ranks of the ticket vendors.

We publish in another column a dispatch from the well-known correspondent at Washington of The Philadelphia Ledger giving a summary of the advices received by the Secretary of War from Judge TAFT, the Chairman of the commission sent out to the Philippines to organize civil government in the Islands.

The Triennial Congress of the General Society of Mayflower Descendants will be held at Plymouth, Mass., on Saturday, Sept. 15, 1900. The headquarters of the New York Society will be at the Samoset House. September will be the two hundred and eightieth, anniversay of the sailing of the Mayflower from Plymouth, England.

The projected Cape Breton Railway has become an assured fact through the granting of the necessary concessions by the Canadian Government. When completed this railroad will run from Hawkesbury across the Strait of Canso to Louisburg, Nova Scotia, a distance of 100 miles, with a branch to Sydney, N.S.

The stock market does not broaden, yesterday's total transactions falling short of 200,000 shares. Of net changes, few were important or interesting even. About half a dozen issues changed as much as a whole point for the day, and in this list were only two railway stocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The diplomats connected with the Russian Embassy have been annoyed by constant reports attributing atrocities to the Russian troops in China. One of the most notable instances was an alleged interview with Mrs. Anna Drew, wife of E.B. Drew, the chief secretary of Sir Robert Hart.

The financial operations of Alfred R. Goslin received another airing in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday when Richard Grey, fifty-eight years old, of 788 Amsterdam Avenue, and Charles T. Whedon, fifty-five years old, of Sea Cliff, L.I., were arraigned before Magistrate Crane on a charge of conspiring to defraud the public.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Aug. 20 -- A terrific windstorm struck this city to-day, coming suddenly from the north. No one was killed, but eight large buildings were completely wrecked and 200 small houses were blown down, causing a loss of $300,000.

The provisions of the will of Collis P. Huntington may be made public to-day. Charles H. Tweed, Second Vice President of and General Counsel for the Southern Pacific Company, said yesterday that it was quite likely that the will would be filed, with the petition for its probate, today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Gov. Theodore Roosevelt is in Washington and the guest of President McKinley at the White House.

Commissioner Fitchie of the Bureau of Immigration announced yesterday that he had received a letter on Saturday from United States Consul Byington at Naples. This letter, he says, goes a long way toward explaining the action of the Government in detaining Moresca and Guida, the two Italians suspected of being Anarchists, who arrived here on the Kaiser Wilhelm II. from Naples.

To the Editor of The New York Times; An editor myself, albeit a mere Britisher, I know you will be pleased to learn that I appreciate your endeavors to educate the people of this country. I heartily congratulate you on having obtained my approval, for I can assure you that it is difficult to satisfy the journalistic aspirations of one who has been trained in the serene circles of British newspaperdom.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20 -- Society here has never before been so busy as to-day. Showers postponed the finals of the mixed doubles tennis tournament at the Kebo Club till to-morrow, and the annual meeting of the Canoe Club, with its interesting events, to Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Marshal Halsted, United States Consul at Birmingham, England, has made an official report on the sale of American goods in England. He says in part:

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The Pall Mall Gazette publishes a dispatch from Rome which declares that an important medical discovery, namely, the cause of Bright's disease, has been made by Dr. Ovid Brown, formerly of New York, and now of Rome.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- In Boston the issue of new stock by the United Fruit Company caused a decline of 1 1/2, to 124 1/2, in the stock, the new rights being quoted at 1 3/4 bid and 2 asked. They figure out just a bit over 2, with the price of the stocks 124 1/2. The right is for one new share at par to ten old shares.

According to some of the dispatches received from China, the Emperor and Empress Dowager are on their way to the Province of Shen-Si. If this be so their destination would almost certainly be the famous old town of Singan, also known as Segan and Sian.

The visiting Cuban teachers were strikingly impressed yesterday, really for the first time since they have been in this country, by the manners and customs of los nervosos Americanos, wherein they relate to sight-seeing by the rapid transit method. It was an object lesson in celerity of movement which the easy-going Southerners are not accustomed to in their island home.

We trust that Democrats in this city and the State generally understand precisely what it is that RICHARD CROKER is trying to do. Tammany has no candidate of its own. Any unscrupulous, characterless old hack would suit the organization, anybody who would help the jobs through and let the chiefs fill their pockets all the time.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Delehanty's two-base hit in the tenth inning of to-days' baseball game with New York sent the winning run across the plate for the home team.
