The funeral of Justice Frederick Smyth of the Supreme Court was held at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church. A solemn requiem mass was celebrated by Bishop Parley, Coadjutor Bishop of the diocese. The deacon was Father Hayes; sub-deacon, Father Thornton, and masters of ceremonies, Fathers McCue and Early.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- For the first time since life sentence was imposed on her, eleven years ago, Mrs. Florence Maybrick had a private interview with her counsel. Dr. Clark Bell of New York, at Aylesbury Prison, to-day. Mrs. Maybrick, like her many friends, is indignant at the attacks made by The Liverpool Post on the late Chief Justice of England, Lord Russell of Killowen, her former counsel.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 21 -- The Prohibition State Convention to-day nominated for Governor John D. White of Manchester, Clay County, formerly a Republican Congressman from the Eleventh District. Candidates for Presidential Electors were also nominated. There were fifty delegates in the convention, including' several women.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- George E. Green, ex-Mayor of Binghamton, was unanimously nominated for Senator by the Republican Convention for the Thirty-eighth Senatorial District, held in this city to-day.

PEKING, Aug. 14, via Che-Foo, Aug. 21 -- The American and Russian flags were planted on the east wall of Peking at 11 o'clock this morning. The Indian troops entered the British Legation at 1 o'clock and the Americans at 3. There was a joyful reception from the wall.

Why should not the New York Stock Exchange have an auditor -- a corps of auditors -- an accounting department whose privilege and duty would be to scrutinize and analyze the reports of corporations whose securities are offered to the public through the use of Stock Exchange facilities?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The State Department to-day received an appeal from the Viceroys of Nanking and Hu-nan asking that no personal indignities be shown to the Emperor and Empress Dowager, and renewing assurances of friendship and of maintaining quiet in the South of China if this condition is met.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 21 -- The Fifth Annual Convention of the National Association of Local Fire Insurance Agents will be held here Aug. 30 to Sept. 1. It is estimated that between one thousand and fifteen hundred delegates will take part in the sessions. Legislation affecting the interests of agents and companies as well as the general public is anticipated.

The market for outside securities yesterday was extremely dull, the trading being much more restricted and intermittent than on Monday. The few issues dealt in on Monday were almost inactive, and the general absence of orders to buy and sell being more marked than for some time. Copper and transportation stocks showed some strength on a slight demand.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 21 -- The "Regular," or Dupont, faction of the Republican Party held its State Convention in this, city to-day. Ex-Congressman Jonathan S. Willis was elected Chairman, and the following ticket was nominated:

Grand Street from Attorney Street to the river was a surging sea of humanity beneath a blaze of pyrotechnics last evening when the Columbian Club and Tammany Hall General Committee of the Twelfth Assembly District returned from their fifteenth annual outing, held under the direction of District Leader P. J. Scully.
NEWPORT, Aug. 21 -- This evening Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs invited the persons who are to dance in the peasant quadrille at Mrs. Fish's ball to-morrow night, to hold the final rehearsal at her cottage.

Porter Co. have sold for B.G. Coles the three-story brownstone-front dwelling 32 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, 21 by 100; also, for the estate of Matthew Byrnes, the three-story brick dwelling 29 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 16.8 by 100.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21 -- The biggest day of Bar Harbor's social season dawned this morning and brought the opening of the long awaited horse fair. Society thronged Robinhood Park from an early morning hour to nearly sunset, examining the entries, watching the races, and congratulating itself upon the success of the occasion.

Yesterday was international Day at the big festival of the Plattdeutsches Volksfest Verein at Union Hill Schuetzen Park. The attendance was large. To-day will be Coronation Day, when the best shots among the five hundred testing their aim and nerve on the king, honor, and bull's-eye targets will be crowned with wreaths of olive and bay.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- At a meeting of the Democratic County Committee held here to-day a resolution was unanimously adopted favoring the nomination of Bird S. Coler for Governor.

Louis Noot, a Baltimore importer, who arrived on the steamship Friesland of the Red Star Line from Antwerp yesterday, was arrested by Special Agent Theobald of the Treasury Department and taken before United States Commissioner Alexander, who held him on $1,000 bail to await the action of the Grand Jury.
Sheriff William F. Grell has picked out a large calf on William J. Bryan's farm and marked it for slaughter in the event of Democratic National success.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 21 -- Ten million dollars' damage is estimated to be the result of the forest fires in Colorado and Wyoming. This estimate was made to-day by C.E. Wantland, General Land Agent of the Union Pacific Railway, who said:

BUCYRUS, Ohio, Aug. 21 -- The news of the safety of Dr. Roberts has just reached here in a cablegram from Shanghai. The message states that Dr. Roberts and several missionaries who had been stationed on a farm at Koo-Fan have been located in the legation at Peking and are now with the allied forces, having been liberated on Aug. 16.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 21 -- The passengers and crew of the "owl" car on the Westfield and Elizabeth Street Railway had a bad fright early this morning while passing through Garwood. A shot was fired, apparently from the yard of the Hall Signal Company's works, and the bullet flew into the car and hit a clay pipe which Frederick Winters of this place was smoking.

Frederick Scharn, the brother of Kathryn Scharn, the young woman who was found murdered in her apartments at 674 Second Avenue early Sunday morning, was committed to the Tombs yesterday by Coroner Fitzpatrick, who held him without bail pending the result of an inquest. No charge was brought against the prisoner in the proceedings in the Coroners' office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Cabinet session to-day practically opened consideration of the momentous questions growing out of the capture of Peking and the war in China. Until to-day's session the absorbing question has been the safety of Minister Conger and the legationers at Peking.

The ordinary gloom of the Centre Street Police Court was somewhat relieved yesterday morning, when in the usual motley assemblage of those to be arraigned appeared one man clad in the raiment that is ordinarily dedicated to festal occasions. The man in swallow-tail coat, white vest, and patent leather shoes was Henry Hearsey, 22 years old, of 160 East Eighty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The State Department has made public the following extracts from a cablegram received last night from Minister Conger.

Charles Seaton, a young Englishman, living at 106 West Seventy-third Street, was arrested at 5 P.M. yesterday at his office, 71 Wall Street, on a warrant issued by Magistrate Leroy B. Crane, charging him with forgery under Section 514 of the Penal Code.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Capt. John E. Henderson and three men, whose names could not be learned, had a thrilling adventure and narrowly escaped losing their lives on the sloop yacht Speedway, which capsized in a squall four miles out to sea this morning.
Ex-Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy will open Croker Democratic campaign headquarters at the Hoffman House on Thursday. This announcement was made officially from the Democratic Club last evening.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 21 -- Mr. Bryan addressed a large audience of Saunders County people at Wahoo, the county seat, today. The speech was an appeal to Republicans to vote the Democratic ticket. Giving his reasons for this appeal, Mr. Bryan said: ...

August G. Roeder, once a prosperous wine merchant in this city, and in later years a real estate broker in a small way and finally a negotiator in petty trading with an office wherever he might be, killed himself with a pistol yesterday after twice wounding his wife and trying to kill the son Otto at 332 East Fourteenth Street.

Acting Mayor Guggenheimer heard yesterday a protest from a committee of the United Colored Democracy against the action of the police in the recent race riots in the Tenderloin. The delegation was headed by Edward E. Lee. The members of the delegation quoted many instances of police prejudice, which they claimed came under their personal observation.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- There was a narow market to-day, but it was strong. Some of the mining shares were decidedly firm. Montana advancing to 322 1/2. Some 300 shares changed hands in the forenoon, and the price held within a point of the highest in the afternoon. Utah rose 1 1/2, to 31 3/4: Parrot 3/8, to 42 3/8, and Tamarack 5, to 210.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 21. -- Senator Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, formally opened the Republican campaign at this place to-night, presiding at an immense and enthusiastic mass meeting held in the Auditorium, and thousands of men and women from the resorts in this neighborhood struggled to gain admission to the building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Census Bureau to-day announced the population of Minneapolis, Minn., as 202,718, and St. Paul, Minn., as 163,632. The following are the official bulletins:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Minister Storer, at Madrid, informs the State Department that a treaty of amity, commerce, and navigation and general intercourse has been signed provisionally by the Minister of State and himself.

Had Herr Teufelsdrockh issued his celebrated clothes philosophy this year he would have had more than the masculine shirtwaist to chronicle. Here is a German savant who seems to have pointed out a method by which white people can stand the dangers of the sun in tropical heat almost as well as the natives of the tropics themselves.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 21 -- It was given out this afternoon at the offices of the Anti-Imperialist League that Andrew Carnegie, the millionaire ironmaster of Pittsburgh would shortly return to the United States from Scotland to assist in the campaign against McKinley.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions;

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The Western three-year-old John Yerkes to-day, at the Saratoga races, defeated King Bramble by the shortest of heads in the Fairview Stud Stakes, a selling affair at a mile. The pair raced in close company, and it was due more to the superior finishing powers of Turner over itchell than ability on the part of John Yerkes that caused him to gain the decision.

Senator Hanna did not remain long at National headquarters yesterday, but while there he was about the busiest man in New York. Among his callers were ex-Mayor W.L. Strong, Gen. O.O. Howard, Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency; United States Marshal Austin of Knoxville, Congressman Brownlow of Tennessee, Congressman W.C. Lovering of Massachusetts, S.D. McCormick of Kentucky, Chairman Odell, Col. H. Lovell Jerome, and a number of others.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- George W. Kaltenbach, eighteen years old, has disappeared from home. He lived with his parents at 221 Van Houten Street. He was employed in the Rogers Locomotive Works, and was paid well. He worked on Wednesday last, and in the evening left home to pay a visit.

HONGKONG, Aug. 21 -- A prominent reformer has obtained from the Yamen runners a letter from Gen. Yung-Lu, Commander in Chief of the northern armies, to Gen. Tung-Fu-Siang, commanding the Kan-Soo troops. It begins: "It is not convenient to accomplish my secret orders," and proceeds:

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Miss Marie Tempest made her debut in comedy to-night at the Prince of Wales's Theatre in Anthony Hope and Edward Rose's dramatization of "Simon Dale," produced under the title of "English Nell." The audience gave every manifestation of approval, and, though the play may lack strength, Miss Tempest's interpretation of the title role was conceded to be excellent.
DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The next time Jacob Krebs of Beaver Brook decides to enter the state of matrimony he will avoid the pitfalls of newspaper personals.

The managers of the Bridgemen's Union threaten that unless the demands of the striking bridgemen on the new East River Bridge are complied with they will extend the strike to all the work now under construction in this country by the New Jersey Steel and Iron Company, and by the contracting firm of Terry Tench.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 21 -- R.G.F. Candage of Brookline, Mass., Acting President, to-day called to order in the high school auditorium the twentieth annual session of the National Farmers' Congress. There was a large attendance. Gov. Charles S. Thomas, Mayor Robinson, and others delivered addresses of welcome.

If the conspiracy to force New York into a contract with the Ramapo Water Company is successful, it will not be because our people are cleverly deceived, but because the forces of corruption are stronger and better organized than those which have volunteered for the defense of the city against a gigantic public swindle.

The daily brushing supply on the Speedway yesterday was of meagre quantity, owing to the comparative scarcity of fast steppers. It was not without quality, however, although nothing very exciting took place. Several drivers were on hand who have not been seen much on the course this Summer, and they did their share in providing the afternoon's sport.

A special regatta for Labor Day is announced by the Atlantic Yacht Club. It will be open to all yachts or duly organized yacht clubs. Suitable prizes are offered to the winners in each class in which two or more yachts compete. Sail-over, second, and third prizes will be awarded in accordance with Rule 28.

The dinner that Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs will give to-night at her Newport villa will be an unusually large and handsome affair. One hundred and fifty guests have been invited, many of whom will be in fancy peasant, and other costumes. The dinner is to be served on the large, deep veranda overlooking the ocean and under a canopy of vines.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The challenge match for the National Lawn Tennis Championship between champion Malcom D. Whitman and William A. Larned, who Won the all-comers' tournament yesterday, drew a large crowd of enthusiasts to the Casino here this morning.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- In reporting to the State Board of Health, the Tuberculosis Committee of the board states that Dr. Gray, its Inspector, reported the examination of a herd of five cows, recently tested in Broome County, where all were found diseased, one cow having recently died from tuberculosis.

Henry J. Down, a colored man, lodged charges yesterday with Inspector Thompson, at Police Headquarters, against Sergt. Morgan of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, who he said had treated him unjustly and had been guilty of conduct unbecoming a gentleman. Down lives at 342 West Fifty-first Street, and is a member of the committee of colored residents of that neighborhood who are trying to prosecute certain of the white rioters during the recent race troubles.

FALLS CITY, Neb., Aug. 22. -- This was a busy day for Mr. Bryan. It was after 1 o'clock this morning when he reached Auburn, his first stopping place after leaving Lincoln. At 8 o'clock he made an hour's address there. At Tecumseh, the next stopping place, he spoke briefly, and after a hasty dinner started upon a twenty-one mile drive across country to Pawnee.

Eugene Wood of Albany has, through a personal friend, made public his dealings with Tammany Hall and Richard Croker during the past three years. After Mr. Wood declared against Richard Croker at the meeting of the State Committee and sided with David B. Hill in the factional fight, the leader of Tammany Hall has been bitter in his statements against Mr. Wood.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., Aug. 22. -- That dilatory stork which has caused so much annoyance to the newspapers and occasioned some solicitude among the members of the Vanderbilt family arrived at George W. Vanderbilt's home to-night at 8 o'clock. It brought a girl, who is to be named Cornelia Stuyvesant Vanderbilt.

There were busy times at Republican National Headquarters yesterday. Senator Hanna was an early arrival, and so numerous were his visitors that he had to delay his intended return to Elberon at 3:30 o'clock to enable him to sign letters and dictate replies to many letters and telegrams.

The Commissioner of Public Charities has discovered that waifs and foundlings comics under the care of his department have been named fantastically, without regard for their feelings and the accidents of their future. Young men accustomed to see much misery and to deal with the miserable are too apt, as they become hardened, to view life too flippantly.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- There was a freight wreck that blocked the east-bound freight and passenger tracks of the Pennsylvania Road for several hours, between this city and Stelton, last night.

If the commander of the allied forces in China does not hurry up he is going to be left out of the procession. His title is most imposing, and it is said that he has even started for the scene of action. But he is still a long way from the front. Like the war horse of Scripture, he scenteth the battle afar off.

The brushing on the Speedway yesterday afternoon was not in proportion to the number of road drivers on hand. There were many of the latter, but only a few brushes. But what contests there were were full of life and action. The brushes that attracted the most attention were a couple in which a trotter and a pacer had a chance to show their paces in competition against each other.
There were many who thought they knew Lord Russell well who, at the date of his appointment to the Chief Justiceship, prophesied some loss of reputation for him.
Louis Wirth has sold to an investor the two five-story double flats, with stores, 3,855 and 3,857 Third Avenue, 37 feet north of Wendover Avenue, on a plot 50.4 by 100.
Officials of the Western Trunk Line territory to meet the Inter-State Commerce Commission on Sept, 18 for the regular quarterly consideration of rate questions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By printing "All the news that's fit to print," you succeeded in accumulating an intelligent class of readers. It probably took you a long time and hard work to achieve this result. Are you mindful of the fact that it requires just as much skill and labor to keep a good thing as to acquire it?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The most important dispatch received from China today was not made public by the War Department, but was the subject of an extended conference at the White House this morning between the President, Secretary Root, and Acting Secretary of State Adee.
Army. Major Georga Andrews, Assistant Adjutant General, will report in person not later than Sept. 4, to the Adjutant General for duty in his office.

The Protective Association of Harlem Property Holders, recently organized by the representatives of large up-town interests in real estate, has elected the following officers; William H. Barnes, President; J.M. Horton, Vice President; Paul Mayer, Secretary and Treasurer, and exCivil Justice James P. Davenport, counsel.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Thomas Faed, the artist, is dead.

-- Having noticed the publication by THE TIMES of a letter in which statements of our own were referred to as "twaddle," The Mobile (Ala.) Register is moved to ask, "Isn't that allowing too much liberty with the press?" The question is a reasonable one, and, fortunately, not difficult to answer.

We believe that Mr. BRYAN'S announcement of what he will do in the Philippines if he is elected President will prove to be the most serious blunder of his campaign. It was the definite statement of a formulated policy. He told the people of the country exactly what he would do as soon as power came into his hands."

The numerous wing shots who rendezvous at Dexter Park, Jamaica, L.I., held a team shoot yesterday. They named themselves after four principal cities. The Philadelphias won by a wide margrin, and received a silver loving cup. Emil Steffens, who promoted the event, offered a prize for the highest individual score.
J. VAN AMBERG of Pultney, N.Y., died suddenly of heart disease yesterday.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 22. -- In the matter of the partition of Great South Bay, Commissioners Young, Ketcham, and Terry, under an interlocutory judgment of the Supreme Court in the suit brought by the heirs of William Smith against the Town of Brookhaven, have filed a report with the court in which the eastern portion of the bay is awarded to the town and the western portion to the Smith heirs.

Sergt. William R. Taylor of the United States Army, attached to the recruiting office at 25 and 27 Third Avenue, was last night reported to be dying at his home, 150 Second Avenue, from erysipelas. According to the story told by Taylor and his friends, his condition is due to an assault made upon him by three men on the night of July 20.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@62 1/2. There were no sales.

Much is heard here of the scarcity of coal in Europe, and Wall Street is familiar with a variety of causes that have led to the development of unprecedented exportation from this country. One of the bases of considerable stock market enthusiasm is that such coal shipments to foreign markets are likely from this time forward to develop rapidly and largely.

Deputy Commissioner of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies Kirwin and the elevated railroad officials of Brooklyn are working on plans for doing away with the danger to life in the "third-rail" system in use on the elevated railroads. The recent fatal accidents attributable to the third rail have impelled Commissioner Kirwin to take steps to compel the company to make the system less dangerous to life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Under the instructions of the Secretary of War, the Adjutant General of the Army has cabled instructions to Major John B. Kerr, Tenth United States Cavalry, to repair to Berlin and report to duty to the Ambassador.

Ex-Senator Edward Murphy and Richard Croker opened political headquarters in the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon. Senator Murphy arrived at 11 o'clock. He was shown to Room 309, which had been engaged from now until after election.

The approach of the Boer forces from the west and east toward Pretoria might have been construed as a strategic move in the early days of the British occupation of the capital of the Transvaal, when that place was insufficiently defended and Lord ROBERTS'S lines of communication with the south were, constantly interrupted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- After a long conference at the White House to-day, the reply of the United States to the application of Li-Hung-Chang for the appointment of a Peace Commissioner was completed and a copy of the reply sent to the Chinese Minister, Mr. Wu, to be forwarded to Earl Li.
A Japanese official dispatch says it is reported that the Emperor refused to leave Peking.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22. -- George H. Hosmer passed away this afternoon at the Carney Hospital, South Boston, where his last days were made as comfortable as possible. He had not enjoyed good health for the past couple of years, and two months ago went to the hospital with consumption, from which he died. He leaves two children.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your admirable article in Monday's issue on "The Crush at the Bridge" you omit to point out any remedy for the trouble, so I thought you might kindly allow me to suggest one.
LONDON, Aug. 23. -- "To-day, 1,500 Americans attacked the Imperial Palace," says a dispatch to The Morning Post from Peking, dated Aug. 15, "and captured four of the courts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Representative C.K. Wheeler of Kentucky, who came to Washington yesterday to report the political outlook to the Democratic Congressional Commtttee, said in an interview:
The National Union Fire Insurance Company of Washington, D.C., has been licensed by the Ohio Insurance Department to transact a reinsurance business in that State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The most important development of to-day as to the actual conditions in Peking was a dispatch to the State Department from Minister Conger, dated at Peking only three days ago. It was given out with the following statement:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22 -- The feature of the Grand Circuit meet at the Readville track this afternoon was the big Massachusetts stake, $10,000, the fifth renewal for 2:12 trotters, and Thomas W. Lawson's Boralma won in straight heats. Despite the fact that the gelding was noticeably lame in his off hind leg, he made a new mark for himself, as well as for the event, 2:09 1/2.

KENSICO, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The tracks of the Harlem Division of the New York Central Railroad, which were torn up in the wreck of two freight trains here at 8 o'clock last night, were repaired by 9 o'clock this morning so that trains could be moved as usual, and by afternoon they were running again on time.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- There was active trading in United Fruit rights to-day at 1 5/8 @ 7/8; Montana also was active, losing from 324 to 319, later 320, while Utah lost 1/2, to 31, and Dominion Coal hardened 1/2, to 42. Boston Elevated rose 5, to 150.

The securities of the firm of Price, McCormick Co. were sold at auction yesterday by R.V. Harnett Co. at the New York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, by order of Assignee W.J. Curtis. The trustees of the insolvent firm were among the buyers. Assignee Curtis expressed himself as satisfied with the prices obtained.

The city and suburbs are, of course, still socially dead, and with propitious weather at Newport, Bar Harbor, and Southampton those and other leading resorts are enjoying the height of their season. To-morrow the two days' Horse Show at Southampton will begin. The Bar Harbor Horse Show, which began Tuesday, will end to-day.

JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 22. -- The second preliminary round in the men's golf tournament to-day developed a slump in golfing all through the list, and fully half the field turned in cards comparing unfavorably with Monday's round. The gross scores for the two days follows:

The Sub-Committee on Franchises and Taxation of the Committee on City Affairs of the Reform Club has addressed a memorial to the Charter Revision Committee, recommending certain repeals of and amendments to sections of the charter.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- C.J. Joss, a former clerk of Parr's Bank, accused of stealing about $300,000 from the bank in January, 1809, has been committed for trial. He was caught passing a five-pound note.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- There was a meagre attendance on the Stock Exchange to-day, and operators were generally idle. It is not anticipated that much business will be done until the approaching settlement has been completed. Government securities were dull. Home railroads were irregular. Great Westerns were flat on the possibility of a strike, and Great Easterns closed above the worst figures of the day.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 22. -- Four addresses were crowded into this afternoon at the Republican mass meeting. The speakers were Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, Lee Fairchild of California, Gen. Adam E. King of Maryland, and Congressman Samuel McCall of Massachusetts.

A meeting was held in Brooklyn yesterday by some of the striking bridgemen, who were ordered out Monday. They protested against the action of the union in declaring a strike when the men were perfectly satisfied with their lot.

Mr. EDWARD MURPHY, a Democrat of Troy, in this State, who has just come down here to open what are described as anti-Coler headquarters, says that Controller COLER would be the weakest candidate in all the list of those Democrats who have been considered in connection with the nomination for Governor.
BAR HARBOR, Aug. 22. -- Mrs. W.P. Draper entertained a score of friends at luncheon in the Boulder Cottage, Kebo Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The production of iron ore in the United States for the year 1899, according to the annual report of the United States Geological Survey, which has just been compiled by John Birkinbine, amounted to 24,683,173 long tons, an increase of 5,249,997 tons or 27 per cent, over 1898.

HAVANA, Aug. 22. -- Enrique Varona, Secretary of Education, was recently asked by the Republican Party in Puerto Principe to be a candidate during the forthcoming elections of delegates to the Constitutional Convention. In his reply, published to-day, he says:

CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Five thousand people attended the second day's races of the Greene County Fair at Cairo this afternoon. In one of the races Phil Proper of Hudson, the driver of Decker Boy. was cut down by John Vantassell, also of Hudson, the driver of Leo S. One of Proper's legs was broken. Vantassell was suspended from all National Association tracks for one year for foul driving.

Senator Hanna was the guest of honor at a banquet given by the Republicans of Asbury Park at Hathaway Inn, Deal Beach, after the rally at Asbury Park on Tuesday night. The speaking did not begin until after midnight, and the National Chairman himself made some remarks which convinced his hearers that there was plenty of hard work to be done between now and election day. In part, he said:

The first cablegrams which have come to the mission boards in this city from Peking since communication was cut off over two months ago, arrived yesterday. One of them was received by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions. It came from the Rev. Dr. John Wherry of Peking, and was dated from Che-Foo, where it is supposed to have been sent via Tien-Tsin.

Trading was dull in the market for outside securities yesterday, and was confined to a few issues. The general midsummer absence of stocks was the only feature of consequence, as has been the case for some weeks past. Copper stocks were strong and inactive in most cases. Transportation issues changed fractionally.

After working four days on the murder of Kathryn Scharn, the police yesterday seemed to be no nearer solving the mystery than they were at 1 o'clock Sunday morning, the hour when the body of the young woman was discovered in her room, at 674 Second Avenue. A number of clues were followed yesterday without result.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- A great mob attacked the city prison and jail to-night in an effort to get hold of Louis Peck, a negro, forty years old, who confessed to Prisonkeeper Washer that he had attempted to assault Christina, the six-year-old daughter of Theodore Maas.

It was announced yesterday that the State Banking Department had formally approved an agreement for the merger of the Assured Building-Loan Association with the Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings. The agreement of merger, as passed by the Board of Directors of each institution, is to be submitted to the stockholders on each concern on Sept. 5, and it is expected that the merger will be unanimously approved.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 22. -- Nearly 1,000 delegates were in attendance at to-day's ression of the Farmers' National Congress. Addresses were delivered on "Natural Resources of the South" by J.B. Killebrew of Tennessee, and on Dairying" by G.M. Whittaker, Dairy Commissioner of Massachusetts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- There has just arrived here on board the steamer Hongkong Maru Dr. P.C. Leslie, a missionary of the Canadian Presbyterian Mission in the Honan Province of China.

The annual outing of the Horatio Seymour Club of the Ninth Assembly District was held yesterday at Witzel's Grove. Councilman Frank J. Goodwin, who is fighting John C. Sheehan for the leadership of the district, and his lieutenant, Thomas F. Smith, private secretary to Richard Croker, headed their followers, and upon their return last night they pronounced the affair a huge success.

The third attempt to burn the five-story flathouse, 169 West Ninety-ninth Street, within the past forty-eight hours, was discovered shortly after 1 o'clock this morning by one of the tenants. The other attempts to burn the place were made at 1 and 3 o'clock Wednesday morning. The house is occupied by fifteen families, and the janitor, Patrick Donovan, lives in the basement with his family.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The following official bulletin was posted at the War Department this evening: ...

The uprising in Akron, Ohio, of armed citizens intent upon quickly and cruelly putting to death a negro accused of criminally assaulting a white girl, which promised Wednesday night to develop into a veritable race war, mas happily quelled soon after daylight yesterday morning.

The amateur drivers who are wont to congregate on the Speedway congregated there yesterday in force. The brushing period of the afternoon was choch full of interesting speed bouts which on the whole were characterized by the maintenance of a fast, even clip on the part of the various contestors.
The Consuls at Shanghai have not received any messages from Peking since Aug. 20, and fear that the Chinese may have cut the allies' communications.

The will of Collis P. Huntington will be offered for probate to-day if the decision of the family, arrived at yesterday, is adhered to. Copies and an abstract of the document will be issued at noon for publication by Charles H. Tweed, Second Vice President and General Counsel of the Southern Pacific Company.

The reply of the United States to the dispatches of LI-HUNG-CHANG is, as its entire conduct of the Chinese matter has been, based on a clear and just conception of the rights and duties of all parties.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The Democratic Convention for the First Chautauqua Assembly District was held here this afternoon. Arthur W. Kettle of Jamestown was nominated for Member of Assembly. The convention then broke into two factions. The Hill faction elected Joseph Powers, Frank E. Sherman, and M.E. Herrick delegates to the State Convention, with James Hughes, R.D. Mahan, and W.T. Reed alternates.
TOULON, Aug. 23 -- Gustave Paul Cluseret, famous as soldier and revolutionist and one of the Deputies from Toulon, died here to-day of pneumonia.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 23 -- John Gibbs died last night from lockjaw, resulting from a slight wound received some time ago. No attention was paid to the wound until it developed symptoms which proved to be the forerunners of lockjaw, and then it was too late to save the life of the young man.

Because ten-year-old Rebecca Adelstein insisted upon climbing up instead of down a fire escape when the tenement at 8 Avenue B, in which she lives, took fire yesterday morning, she, her father, mother, her brother, and two sisters are all at present suffering from more or less severe burns.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The sloop yacht Lodona, owned by a New York yachtsman, and H.W. Johnson's keel sloop Newasi have both been hauled out at the Jacob yard to have their bottoms smoothed and adorned with a new coat of paint.
Nelson D. Stilwell has sold to a builder the plot, 66.8 by 100, on the south side of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 266 feet east of Eighth Avenue.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday displayed a fair degree of activity as compared with the prevailing dullness for some days. The increase in the volume of business was due in part to profit taking, but there were inquiries from outside buyers for several issues which have recently been inactive.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- Every yachtsman in Newport is talking of the collision in Wednesday's race between the seventy-footers, Yankee and Mineola Each yacht has its supporters, and all admit that the Regatta Committee has a difficult task to render a decision, especially as the members were not close enough to the boats to witness the manoeuvring preceding the collision, and the collision itself.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- O.L. Richards's bay horse Charentus won the Citizens and Merchants' Stake of $5,000 this afternoon, leading from start to finish. The race was a fast one, the mile and a sixteenth, being run in 1:45 1/2 the first mile being negotiated in 1:39. Advance Guard was second, and the Brooklyn and Suburban Handicap winner, Kinley Mack, third.

If the anti-imperialists are right, this Republic is doomed. If the dangers they see are not ghosts, but real; if the charges they make against President McKINLEY are true, then there is indeed something the matter with us, a disease far worse than imperialism.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Coach Patrick Dempsey of the Vesper Boat Club crew of Philadelphia in an interview to-day with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES stated that, contrary to the original intention, he will not enter a crew in the four-oared shell race and that the crews rowing would be strictly confined to the eight-oared race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The correspondence between the State Department and Li-Hung-Chang regarding the request that the United States appoint a Commissioner to arrange for the cessation of hostilities was made public by the department to-day as follows:

The troubles of which this story tells were all caused by a dog, a fine St. Bernard, which had always enjoyed a reputation of gentleness and fondness for children in the neighborhood of King Street, where he lived and died.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- During the first half of the day the total transactions in Boston were 2,279 shares and $4,000 bonds, a wonderful record of stagnation. During that period there were sales of 360 shares of Sugar, 70 Union Pacific, 100 Atchison common and 54 preferred, and 10 Chicago, Burlington and Quincy.

Frederick Scharn, who is locked up in the Tombs on suspicion of having murdered his sister, Kathryn Scharn, was indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury on a charge of burglary in the third degree. The indictment was found on the testimony of Mrs. Kehoe, who occupies rooms in the same house with Scharn and whose watch, she says, the latter stole on the night of July 31.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 23 -- William J. Bryan to-day received the second official notification of his nomination for the Presidency. This notification came from the Populist Party, and Thomas M. Patterson of Colorado acted as mouthpiece of the party in making it. Mr. Bryan was at the same time informed of the indorsement of his candidacy by the United States Monetary League, this notification being given by A.W. Rucker.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Maurice J. Sullivan, a real estate agent: Deputy Sheriff Charles Moore, and Lawyer Stephen Stillwell were arraigned before Judge Irving M. Taylor to-day. Yesterday they went to the home of John Wendel and tried to get an interview with Miss Georgianna Wendel, a sister of Mr. Wendel.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day money was easy, the distribution of two millions of railroad dividends having no appreciable effect on the short-loan market. Operators complain loudly of the absence of orders. The depression is attributed to the wet weather, talk of political troubles, dear money, and anything of a gloomy character that can be thought of.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Gen. Gaselee, the commander of the British forces at Peking, has telegraphed to the War Office as follows:
The Democratic political pot was kept boiling yesterday. Here is what happened.

PATERSON, N.J. Aug. 23 -- It is believed here that Louis Peck was formerly a resident of this city. He left town one day in haste after an assault, and for three days posses searched for him. He came here from Port Jervis and fled from that place because he was wanted for another assault upon a child.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- By a unanimous vote of the stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad, at a meeting here to-day, the purchase of 30,000 shares of preferred stock of the Central Massachusetts Railroad at $65 per share was ratified. The total number of votes cast was 139,642.
JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 23 -- The three divisions in the men's golf tournament played their first round at match play yesterday, opponents meeting as drawn on the previous afternoon. Results follow:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States has taken the lead in replying to China that there will be no temporizing negotiations, and there is every reason to believe that the other powers will be united in the same policy.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Philip Ipp, a barber, of 187 River Street, lost his life to-day at noon in the Passaic River while engaged in saving the lives of others. He leaves a bride to whom he was married a month ago.

The last vestige of the identity of the Board of Walking Delegates, which for fifteen years has ruled matters in the building trades, was swept away yesterday at a meeting in Central Hall, 147 West Thirty-second Street. The meeting consisted of delegates from twenty-three building trades unions, representing the principal trades unions of the old Board of Walking Delegates and Building Trades Council.
George W. Lederer's new Casino production, for which no name has yet been selected, has satisfactorily passed through its first rehearsal.

The "pink tea" given by Abraham Gruber and his followers in the Republican organization of the Twenty-first Assembly District in Colonial Hall, Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and First Street, last night gave them their last chance for impressing upon the voters of the district that Mr. Gruber should be retained as the leader of the district.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- When day dawned Thursday morning. it revealed a Scene of desolation and the evidences of violence and lawlessness unparalleled in the history of this city.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23 -- The last day of the horse fair proved the principal social attraction, not for Bar Harbor alone, but for neighboring resorts. Crowds of excursionists began to pour into town early this morning, and by noon the attendance at Robin Hood Park exceeded yesterday's figures.

Among the improvements to be undertaken by the Long Island Railroad under the management of the Pennsylvania Railroad will be the placing in service of a first-class express train on the Wading River Branch instead of the way train which now leaves Long Island City at 5:40 P.M.

Alter the Fish ball there has been a reaction in social matters at Newport, and the modish world has hardly recovered from the unwonted excitement of Wednesday evening. At Bar Harbor to-day, provided the weather be fine and the water smooth, will take place the annual regatta and fete of the Canoe Club.

Italians numbering over 5,000, and representing thirty or more societies, marched yesterday in parade in honor of the memory of King Humbert, and solemn high mass for the repose of the King's soul was celebrated in the presence of an immense congregation in old St. Patrick's Church, in Mott Street.

Yesterday's baseball game at the Polo Grounds between the New Yorks and Philadelphias was won by the home players after things looked squally for them in the last two innings. The score was 5 to 4, and the visitors made three of their four tallies in the eighth and ninth innings. However, the New Yorks deserved to win, as they played a better all-around game than the Quakers.

Justice Freedman was asked in the Supreme Court yesterday by counsel for the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company to direct the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments to file a further return to the writ of certiorari obtained by the company for a reviewal of the assessment placed on its property for the year 1899, which amounts to about $17,000,000.

Yesterday's baseball game at the Polo Grounds between the New Yorks and Philadelphias was won by the home players after things looked squally for them in the last two innings. The score was 5 to 4, and the visitors made three of their four tallies in the eighth and ninth innings. However, the New Yorks deserved to win, as they played a better all-around game than the Quakers.

Secretary Kerr of the United States Golf Association announced the pairings for the qualifying round on Tuesday in the women's National championship at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. The first pair will start at 9:30 o'clock in the morning. The first sixteen will keep on at match play for the championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Dennis Flynn, the Republican delegate from Arizona, has just returned from a tour of the West, and called at the White House. Mr. Flynn's observations have convinced him that the Republicans will sweep the West by an overwhelming majority.

Security market dullness is not confined to Wall Street. All the exchanges of the world seem to be in much the same condition, in so far as activity is concerned. One difference is that elsewhere weakness is more pronounced, yesterday's cables noting declines at London, with recessions at Paris and some notably sharp breaks at Berlin -- a record which appears to be made now pretty much every day.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- The National Negro Business League, made up of delegates from about twenty-five States, assembled in Parker Memorial Hall, here this forenoon. Sessions will continue until to-morow night. The leading spirit in the movement, which has for its object the improvement of conditions among the colored people, is Booker T. Washington of Alabama.

The Democratic factional fight in the Seventh Assembly District, Brooklyn, where Assistant Corporation Counsel Luke D. Stapleton, an adherent of Senator Michael J. Coffey, is seeking to overthrow Councilman William J. Doyle, the organization leader in the District, in the coming primaries, has been productive of charges of fraud in the enrollment of voters.

Short and sharp was the fight between the aspirants for the pugilistic championship, Robert Fitzsimmons and Thomas Sharkey, in the arena of the Seaside Athletic Club, at Coney Island, last night. In five minutes and six seconds of actual fighting Sharkey was stretched on the canvas-covered floor, unconscious and counted out, and Fitzsimmons stood over him, the fighter with the first right to challenge J. J. Jeffries for the world's championship.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- The Monmouth County military tournament and athletic games began this afternoon on the grounds opposite the railroad station, and will be concluded to-morrow.

Richard Croker made his first political speech of the campaign yesterday. The paramount issues of Tammany's campaign were outlined. Mr. Croker struck out into new fields of argument. He also told his political friends what caused the downfall of Rome, and what has really destroyed the power of the Spanish kingdom.

The writer had dropped off at Washington Square South to look at a group of windows by Bancel La Farge -- strong and original work, by the way, simple and dignified in design, simple also in color, and of singular harmony and splendor. In Washington Square and its neighborhood is one of the homes of our French citizens.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Rollin Lynde Hartt has been writing for The Atlantic a series of articles, the titles of which extend in geographical distribution from "A New England Hill Town" to "The Mormons" and "The Montanians." The latest one appears in the August number under the name "The Iowans."

Robert Burns Wilson, Kentucky's poetpainter, is happiest with the pen, as he is with the brush, when he deals with nature. Landscapes in water color are perhaps his best work, although some of his figure painting, notably the religious subjects, is strong both in conception and execution.

"Master Christian," Marie Corelli's eagerly awaited novel, will be published Aug. 29, through Dodd, Mead Co. The advance orders for the book, it is said, have been very heavy, while news comes from England that, as far as this author is concerned, the advance orders there have been unprecedented.
Sales on the Stock Exchange of 10 shares of Corn Exchange Bank stock at 345, and 20 shares of National City, in two lots of 10 shares each, at 339 and 338.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- The residents of the town of Reading, eight miles north of here, have never tolerated me presence of a negro, and when one appeared there last night he narrowly escaped rough treatment. The negro is a boy of sixteen and he went to Reading to go to work for an Italian fruit dealer.

The frontispiece of the life of John Paul Jones, which Charles Scribner's Sons have in preparation, will be a reproduction in color of a miniature painted on ivory by a Dutch artist in 1780. The original is in the Hermitage Gallery in St. Petersburg. It represents the American Commodore in full Court dress.

Almost every trace of evidence which the police thus far have been able to find against Frederick Scharn, who is locked up in the Tombs on suspicion of having murdered his sister, was knocked in the head yesterday -- that is, unless the police are withholding something from the newspapers.

It is safe to say that the average American traveler in Europe finds Venice the most unique and interesting city he visits. The city is built on numerous islets in a lagoon, formed by the waters of the Adriatic, its buildings resting on piles or stone foundations, access to which is had by 146 canals connected by 367 bridges, navigated by gondolas, which serve as the cabs of other cities.

The last few years have witnessed a revival of interest in the life and times of Oliver Cromwell Scribner's Magazine has recently completed the publication of Theodore Roosevelt's sketch of the life of the Lord Protector, and The Century has about reached the middle point of its serial publication of the life of Cromwell by that gifted English scholar and statesman, John Morley.

An amusing little volume has been published by Karslake Co. of London, which will doubtless be viewed with varied emotions by Omarians. It is called "The Soliloquy of a Shadow-Shape on a Holiday from Hades," by Arthur H. Scaife. In this poem, written in his own quatrains, Omar Khayyam appears as the critic and denouncer of latter-day mortals, not by any means as their corrupter.

Harry Robinson, a coal-black Southern negro, who lives in Astoria, was passing Santo Deletto's saloon, at 211 East Ninetyseventh Street, early Thursday morning when he saw a man of his own race force the door leading to the private apartments up stairs. Watching for a time he saw the stranger emerge with a big bundle, and run along the street.

The story of "The Seventy" is marked by many peculiarities, and they are all full of interest and instruction. It is told only by St. Luke. But he gives us no clue whatever as to when they fulfilled their mission. Equally learned and painstaking students have therefore differed very widely concerning it.
The Federal Life Insurance Company of Chicago has been licensed to do business in Michigan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the letters under the heading "Letters to Editor" in your paper with great interest, as I am desirous of hearing both sides of any question when candidly expressed.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 -- Mrs. James P. Kernochan will give a large dinner dance at her cottage. Sea View, on Sept. 8.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- A very ordinary card was run off here this afternoon. The best race of the day was in the six-furlong handicap, for which Meehanus was a strong odds-on favorite. Prejudice, the second choice, won by a length, with Gibraltar, who met with some interference, second, a like distance before Ralston.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 24 -- W.M. Hindman, pastor of W.J. Bryan's church, has been asked to resign by the Fusionist members of that church, because it is believed he is not in entire sympathy with the political beliefs of one of its distinguished members. The pastor is also accused of worldliness.

The buying of books is to some men a pastime; to others it is a passion; but to the librarian and the intelligent book collector it is both a business and a pleasure. The man who is endowed with a zeal for knowledge is eager to be continually adding to the stores which will enable him to acquire and to dispense that knowledge.

-- Chicago papers present as convincing proof of their city's maltreatment by the Federal Census takers the fact that though in 1896 Chicago cast 350,000 votes and New York only 308,000, yet the same part of the present New York is credited with 2,050,600 inhabitants, and Chicago with only 1,698,575, or 352,025 less.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- When President McKinley answered the charge that he designed an unconstitutional war of conquest in China by ordering that the troops bound for the Orient should go to Manila instead of Taku, he and his advisers believed that all serious danger in China was over.

Messrs Croker, Van Wyck, Devery, and Carroll were sharply assailed last night by Dr. Hamilton Williams, Coroner's physician, at a meeting of the Pequod Club, the Sheehan organization in the Ninth District.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- The negro Peck, Whose crime, the assault on a child, resulted in the serious rioting last Wednesday, was brought here secretly to-day, hastily put on trial, sentenced to life imprisonment in the State penitentiary, and hurriedly taken from the city again.

Gov. Roosevelt had a very busy day in town yesterday. After visiting his physician he proceeded to 1 Madison Avenue, where he saw Chairman Hanna, National Committeeman F. S. Gibbs, Gen. F. V. Greene, and others.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 24 -- The publication of pictures by New York papers of the Democratic candidate in the cornfields on his "farm" provokes a smile among Bryan's friends in Lincoln. The impression has gone abroad that Mr. Bryan is a farmer, while in Lincoln it is known that Mr. Bryan is not an agriculturist.

The Philadelphias turned the tables on the New Yorks in the baseball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, winning out by timely batting in the eighth inning. Jack Dunn, who was released by the Brooklyn team, pitched for the Philadelphias and held the local team down to four hits. The score:

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Thousands of immense dragon flies, night hawks, and insects, large and small, classified and unclassified, caused a total eclipse of the sun at Austin shortly before 5 o'clock this afternoon, and frightened women and children. The darkness lasted for more than half an hour, and then, almost as suddenly as they came, the clouds of insects, following the course of a stiff wind that sprang up, disappeared in the distance.

Americans have again made an interesting discovery in Babylonia. As announced by cable several days ago, the expedition under the auspices of the University of Pennsylvania, and under the direction of Prof. Hilprecht, has found at Nippur, one of the four cities mentioned in the Book of Genesis, the library of the great temple, the age of which is upward of 4,000 years.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- The Boston market had a larger volume of business than yesterday, no less than 1,975 shares of Atchison common and preferred changing hands in the morning, which, with 203 shares of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and 110 shares of Union Pacific, exceeded the total of yesterday forenoon's dealings.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @ 62 1/2. There were no sales.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 -- Randolph Feal, a negro, was arrested to-day at Mill Park, West Va., by Detective Balmer of this city, who will bring him here. He is believed to be the murderer of William Schamadan, the iron molder whose body was found in a manhole at Mount Auburn on Aug. 11.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Thomas Winthrop Hall died at Hannibal. Mo., from sunstroke on Tuesday. His body was brought to Chicago and interred here to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your issue of to-day contains a bit of news which must have a depressing effect upon every Republican in this State outside the little coterie whose centre is Senator Platt. I refer, of course, to the announcement of Mr. Odell's consent to accept the nomination for Governor and the tacit understanding that that consent implies the withdrawal of all other candidates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Department of Agriculture is about to issue a bulletin prepared by Entomologist L.O. Howard on the mosquitoes of the United States. It discusses their structure and biology and indicates the difference in all stages of existence between the kinds of mosquitoes that transmit malaria and those that do not, and also discusses the subject of remedies.

KANKAKEE, Ill., Aug. 24 -- Dr. Emil Enos, chief of the medical staff at Kankakee Insane Asylum, has prepared for the coming meeting of the American Association of Hospital Physicians at Indianapolis skiagraphs and data of a strange case under his care.

But by a kind of irony Edward FitzGerald has lately been flung into the deepest pit of notoriety. Not only has he found an absurd biographer he has become the victim of an absurd cult. The man who spent his whole life far from coteries, whose best companion was the Captain of his lugger, whom not even warm-hearted friendship could drag to town, has been forced to lend his name to a dining club.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- The session of the Negro National Business League was resumed at Parker Memorial Hall at 10 o'clock to-day. Among the speakers was W.O. Emery of Macon, Ga. He advised the colored people of Boston to remove to the South, and to go into business. He said there were many more business opportunities for them there, and that the South was the land for the negro.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Gen. Chaffee has cabled to the War Department the following reports of casualties which have occurred in his command since his last report:
The Croker-Murphy faction spent yesterday devising plans to defeat Controller Coler for the nomination of Governor.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- Gen. William Ludlow of the United States Army has nearly finished his investigations here. He has investigated the General Staff, the Ministry of War, the War Academy, the Infantry Sharpshooting School, a school for non-commissioned officers, a cadet school, and also several barracks.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 -- August Belmont's yacht Mineola won the race of the seventy-footers to-day, beating the Yankee one minute and fifteen seconds and the Rainbow one minute and forty seconds, leaving the question of which yacht wins the $1,000 cup, offered by the Newport Yacht Racing Association for a series of races between the crack boats, still an open one until three protests have been decided by the committee.

Army. The orders of Lieut. James A. Moss. Twenty-third Infantry, to proceed to Fort Slocum, New York, for duty with recruits to be sent from that post to the Philippine Islands, and to join his regiment upon his arrival in Manila, are amended so as to direct him to proceed to Fort D.A. Russell, Wyoming, for duty with Company M of his regiment, to which company he is assigned.

Two additions to the list of five-hundred-dollar books lately published in THE SATURDAY REVIEW are to be made because of recent sales held in London by Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge. On July 21 they sold a copy of Turberville's "Epitaphs, Epigrams, Songs, and Sonnets," 1570, for L105, and on July 28 an imperfect, small, and much repaired copy of the first folio edition of Shakespeare's plays, 1623, for L252.

This number of the Knackfuss Monographs is written by Heir Knackfuss himself, and has for its subject an extraordinarily interesting person. Albrecht Durer was one of the giants of the flay of early art. He was a painter, an engraver, and a designer of woodcuts. He imagined for the Christ a type of head entirely new, and so noble that it has been surpassed in no age or country.

It would be interesting to know how many plans for reading courses have proved futile in the Summer now ending. Nothing is easier in the balmy. Spring than to write out a course at reading for the Summer months. There is something alluring in the thought of basking in sunlight and in the illumination of great minds at the same time.

Janpole Werner have sold, through G. Tuoti Co., for about $60,000, the two six-story double tenements 325 and 327 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, each 27 by 100. The same brokers have also sold for Weil Mayer, for about $21,000, the five-story double tenement 313 East Forty-eighth Street, 25 by 90 by 100, the buyer giving in part payment a residence at Port Chester, N.Y.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel McL. Quackenbush, since 1861 pastor of the Prospect Hill Reformed Church, died at his home, 3 East Ninety-fourth Street, yesterday. He had been in ill-health for several years, but his death was due to complications which set in a week ago. Dr. Quackenbush is said to have been longer in active service than any other minister in the city.

The will of Collis P. Huntington was filed yesterday in the Surrogates' office by a clerk from the office of Maxwell Evarts of the legal staff of the Southern Pacific Company. It is a document of more than 8,000 words, and was executed March 13. 1897, the witnesses being Mr. Evarts, A.K. Van Deventer, and George E. Downs.

DEAL BEACH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Despite the frequent showers and the threatening condition of the weather, there was an immense gathering of golf enthusiasts at the Deal Beach Golf Club to-day to witness the professional golf match at thirty-six holes, in which J.H. Taylor, open champion of Great Britain, played against the best ball of two noted professionals, R.B. Wilson of the Deal Beach Golf Club and Willie Norton, Seabrigrht Golf Club.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: While interested in the discussion starting with the question, "Is Omar's philosophy wholesome?" I have waited till now when I can add a word to the optimistic standpoint taken by our editor. In connection with a religious work of mine to be issued shortly I have had occasion to make use of one of Omar's quatrains, which I first discovered in Lubbock's "Pleasures of Life."

ROCHESTER, Aug. 24 -- Assemblyman A.J. Rodenbeck of this city has finished his preliminary report to the Joint Committee on Statutory Revisions of the Legislature on the revision of the statutes, including the general laws and codes.
The market for outside securities was extremely dull throughout the day yesterday, the trading being restricted to a few stocks. Some of the copper stocks were figured at times.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- A dispatch from Seattle, Washington, says that a terrific storm raged at Nome Aug. 7, resulting in heavy loss of life. The water front is lined with wreckage and stranded vessels of all descriptions. Out of sixty-eight steam launches, it is reported that only five remained afloat, and of seventy-two barges all but seven drifted ashore.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The letter signed "John Marshall," published in your issue of Aug. 18, contains internal evidence that its author is one who says the thing which is not. Mr. Marshall is evidently one of a small group of envious snarlers at Elbert Hubbard, who try to take revenge for their own failures by decrying Mr. Hubbard's success.

BOSTON, Aug 23 -- In the publishers' calendar, August is the moon of announcements, and, as usual, Messrs. Lee Shepard are ready first, always excepting Messrs. L.C. Page Co., whose Autumn announcements are made in the Spring, and appeared some months ago in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW.

Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken of New York University announced yesterday the establishment of the School of Commerce Accounts, and Finance. The purpose of this new school is to train men for practical business.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 24 -- A. social slump, foreshadowed by the unusual activity attendant upon the horse fair, reached Bar Harbor to-day. Golfers were few and far between, but one dinner was given, and everywhere society seemed to be recovering strength for future activities. Opportunities for such exertions are not far away.
John Crosby Brown, Treasurer of the Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief, reports the following contributions received yesterday:
The road officers of the Linwood Wheelmen have arranged the following club runs for next month: Sept. 2, Rockaway; 9, Tottenville; 16, Hudson County Boulevard; 23, City Island; 30, Belleville, N.J.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- When the Transvaal war broke out there was a memorable "slump" in "Kafirs." Which by interpretation means that South African mining securities fell very low. There has lately been a terrible "slump" in South African books. Only a month or less ago South African books of all sorts flooded the market, and unless a South African book happened to be positively unreadable it was sure of a good sale.

Newport had a slight reaction yesterday, as the dispatches printed elsewhere will show, but Bar Harbor and Southampton were very gay. The first day of the Horse Show at the former place had a fitting climax in the dance at the Meadow Club in the evening. At Bar Harbor the weather was unfortunately against the canoe race, which does not take place until to-day.
The presence of so large a body of Cuban teachers in the North has aroused a new interest in Cuban matters, and some enlightenment regarding the literature of the island may be welcome.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: Noting the arguments for and against the worth of the Roycroft productions, may I offer this?

No finer figure for the sculptor could there be than that of King Alfred. Alfred would bear idealization. The King was as brave as he was sweet-tempered. He was the patron of learning. His name is endeared to humanity in a barbarous age. Mr. Hamo Thornycraft has been commissioned to erect a colossal statue of King Alfred the Great, which is to be reared at Winchester, England.

There came a time in the career of "Bill" Spinks when he felt that an old-time friend had played a mean trick on him. This was yesterday morning in the Yorkville Police Court, when Magistrate Meade held him in $1,000 ball for trial on a charge of burglary. Bill Spinks's supposedly correct name is Martin Dooling, but with him any old name will do.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Aug. 24 -- W.J. Bryan began the day with a speech here at 10:30 A.M. The community is regarded as strongly Republican, but there was a large audience.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In reading your SATURDAY REVIEW notices of new books I am more and more struck by the contrast between the older and more conservative earnestness which has, thank heaven! not yet quite vanished from critical fashion, and the newer style of flippancy which belongs to the positivist and damnatory school, and which often forms an inky cloud for cuttlefish misconception.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your paper with satisfaction and find your editorial page quite a delight, not the least being the views of those who are "against the Government." I lay a little claim to intelligence, but I cannot agree with Mr. Franklin in his characterization of your editorial utterances.

Mr. BRYAN has formally been notified of his nomination by the Populist Convention, and has accepted the nomination in an elaborate speech, in which he used all the arguments he dared to use to show why the Populists ought to give him unreserved and loyal support.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The Labor Day parade refuses to pass the Grand Army of the Republic grand stand that Contractor Behel has built. It has been estimated that the union-men will walk 12,500 miles Sept. 3 to avoid seeing the non-union structure.

Lord Russell's definition of true eloquence as the power of evoking the sympathy and stirring the feelings of the audience is faulty in that it describes the effect of eloquence, not the thing itself. But we gather from what his colleague, Mr. Charles W. Mathews, has written about the manner in which the great lawyer thought, worked, and talked, that he set little store by the formal art of oratory and seldom practiced it.

William Barclay Parsons, chief engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission, returned yesterday from a two weeks' vacation and resumed the active supervision of the subway. It was reported that some members of the West Side Association had expressed considerable indignation when they heard that William Bradley, the contractor in charge of the subway work at Eighty-sixth Street, had cut down fifteen trees, notwithstanding the fact that the appropriation to save them was now pending.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In replying to "Hornet's" criticism, I realize that I shall be one of many to speak, which is doubtless what he wished when he framed his remarks in such ill-mannered language.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- The annual report of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway, known as the "Big Four," shows a mileage of 3,260. The gross earnings were $19,276,308, an increase of $2,551,815; net earnings, $5,858,976, an increase of $1,315,309, compared with last year. The freight increased 9.3 per cent.; the revenue from freight increased 17.08 per cent.

The deaths of John J. Ingalls, ex-Senator, and Noble L. Prentiss of the editorial staff of The Kansas City Star, make a notable gap in the list of men and women who, as working writers, have connected the name of Kansas with current American and historical literature. Inman, Ingalls, and Prentiss have done really good work in the presentation of regional life, color, and action.

Col. O.C. Sabin of Illinois was a visitor at the Republican National Headquarters yesterday. The Colonel has followed the example of Senator Stewart of Nevada and returned to the Republican ranks. Col. Sabin was the organizer of the Silver Knights of America and was conspicuous in the Patriarchs of America, of which "Coin" Harvey was President.

SAN LUIS, Province of Santiago de Cuba, Aug. 24 -- The object of Governor General Wood in making his present tour of the island was not only political, but to enable him to inspect the public works and make a personal investigation of the accounts of the hospitals, troops, and the works undertaken for the improvement of the island.
Our correspondent is quite right. The article in which these criticisms were made was a notice of "The City of Tagaste." printed on July 14, and the suggestions made were these:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S." for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 60 cents for each $500 or consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Messages from Tien-Tsin report serious mortality among the American horses, owing to the heat.

The greatest prize of the American turf, the Futurity Stakes, worth about $40,000 gross, will be run for this afternoon at the Sheepshead Bay track. Fifteen horses are named to start for the big event. These include all the best two-year-olds of the season of 1900, and in the class of the contestants the promise is made that the race will be one of the most sensational of the season.

On a trip down town by the Eighth Avenue trolley that "formal garden" for the public of the west side which is called Hudson Park comes on the view as a pleasant surprise. This little green spot has had a year's test of popularity with the denizens of the somewhat dingy quarter it consoles.
The Peking correspondent of The London Times says looting is proceeding systematically in the city.

United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew, who returned home yesterday from his annual trip to Europe, spoke in glowing terms of the Paris Exposition Edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, while the American liner New York was coming up the bay.

United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew returned home yesterday from his annual vacation trip to Europe. He was a passenger on the American liner New York, and was accompanied by his son, Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., and his niece, Miss Paulding. Mr. Depew was in excellent health and spirits, and said he had thoroughly enjoyed himself and was now ready to take off his coat and enter into the work of the campaign.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- The efforts which foreign nations make to compete with France in the culinary domain are worthy of a good deal of attention. In Paris there are not a few establishments where meals of various kinds are prepared in exotic ways to suit foreign palates, but it is at the exposition that international cooking may be best examined and compared with the home industry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Chicago has always had the greatest confidence in Lake Michigan. It has been there ever since the city was built, and there is evidence which would lead even the most incredulous to believe that it was there some time previous to the arrival of M. Beaubien and the other interesting pioneer Frenchmen.

The announcement that, by the will of Collis P. Huntington, all his pictures will eventually go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art is being discussed with much interest by art lovers of this city. It is said that no accurate estimate of the value of the bequest can be formed until an inventory of the pictures has been taken.

A General Eastern Freight Agent of one of the transcontinental railroads thought that this Summer he would like some variety in the matter of his vacation. For him there was no attraction in an extended railroad trip, nor did a tour through Europe appeal to him, as he had exhausted those fields.

Two badly scared youngsters, with tearstained, swollen faces, were arraigned before Magistrate Zeller in the Harlem Police Court yesterday charged with stealing $1,200 worth of railroad tickets from the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station of the New York Central and Hudson River Failroad.

A General Eastern Freight Agent of one of the transcontinental railroads thought that this Summer he would like some variety in the matter of his vacation. For him there was no attraction in an extended railroad trip, nor did a tour through Europe appeal to him, as he had exhausted those fields.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Internal party dissentions in the Oneida-Herkimer Congressional District may result in the defeat of Congressman James S. Sherman. A storm which had been brewing for some time broke after the County Convention, held in Rome last week, and its fury has centred about the Congressman.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 25 -- The Ekwanok Country Club of Manchester, Vt., will hold the first of its annual tournaments in competition for the President's Cup, presented by the Hon. Edward S. Latham, on Sept. 3, 4, and 5. The terms of competition are as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Willia was in fine fettle in to-day's baseball game with Brooklyn, allowing the latter but four hits and striking out four men. Boston batted McGinnity hard in the first part of the game, but after the fourth inning made only two hits off his pitching. Difficult catches by Long and Duffy were features. The score:

The volunteer fireman, out of date as he is in cities, still plays a most important part in suburban life about New York. Even in parts of New York the volunteer is relied on for protection against fire, but the paid Fire Department is beginning to crowd him out, and he flourishes best in the villages that surround the big city.

AVERILL PARK, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Between Scowackett, on the rush-grown banks of the tortous Wyantskill, and Panola, whose lone white spire shows above the pines at the foot of Mount Webster, there yawns a deep, wide gulf of bitterness. Panola has dragged the pride of Scowackett in the dust, and Scowackett lies awake nights plotting revenge.

Copyright, 1900. LONDON, Aug. 25 -- It is not necessary for me to comment upon the universal gratification felt at the relief of the foreign Ministers in Peking. We have all rejoiced. Their sufferings were terrible, as well as fearfully prolonged, and it gives one something of a sheek to know that the relief expedition was only just in time to save the foreigners.

Although the Knickerbocker Athletic Club baseball team outbatted the Montclair Athletic Club team two to one yesterday and also outfielded them, they won the game by a margin of only one run. The game was played at Montclair and was one of the Amateur League championship series.
Frederic W. Adee. Frederic W. Adee, for many years a well-known lawyer of this city, died yesterday at his home in Westchester. He was in his forty-eighth year and was unmarried.

United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew returned home yesterday from his annual vacation trip to Europe. He was a passenger on the American liner New York, and was accompanied by his son, Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., and his niece, Miss Paulding. Mr. Depew was in excellent health and spirits, and said he had thoroughly enjoyed himself and was now ready to take off his coat and enter into the work of the campaign.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- It requires a very large assembly of any description to attract much attention in London -- the International Zionist Congress, which has been in session during the last week, has startled no one -- but those who have watched it with any degree of interest have been surprised at the scope and importance of the Zionistic programme.

McGuire of the Democratic State Campaign Committee yesterday denied the right of the Croker-Murphy faction to send letters broadcast throughout the State summoning politicians to the Hoffman House headquarters of Messrs. Croker and Murphy under the pretense that they were being called to visit the regular Democratic State Headquarters.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 -- What promises to be one of the most attractive and well attended sporting functions held in this vicinity for some time will be the Rockaway Hunt Club's horse show at Cedarhurst on Labor Day. Many prominent society people have entered their favorite equine pets in the various classes.
