BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 25 -- The luncheons, receptions, dinners, and musicales of last week were obliged to yield this week to the superior attractions of the Horse Show, the regatta, tennis tournaments at the Kebo Valley Club, the Canoe Club's annual meeting, with its interesting events, and the Lewisburg hop and Kebo dinner dance.

From The London Pall Mall Gazette. ROME, Aug. 11 -- As time passes it only serves to show what a difficult position will be that of the new Queen of Italy -- a young woman without experience, brought up in an out-of-the-way Court, almost bourgeoise in its plainness, without yet fluently speaking the language of her adopted country, and with habits and ideals totally different from those of her subjects.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Prince and Princess Brancaccio have just returned here and will remain here for some weeks as the guests of Mrs. David W. Bishop. September will be the gayest month that Lenox has ever had. John Sloane will have a number of distinguished guests during the month.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- National Chairman Hanna came here from New York to-day and held a conference lasting two hours, with about two dozen prominent manufacturers and business men of this city.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, Aug. 25 -- The Niagara International tennis tournament was continued here this afternoon. The final rounds of men's and ladies' scratch singles were played this morning, and this afternoon the finals of men's and ladies' doubles were disposed of. The men's and ladies' handicap singles and doubles will be played on Monday, as also will be the championship single match between R. D. Little, holder, and H.H. Hackett, challenger.

Clara Hubbs, bookkeeper of the clothing house of Finegold Spero, committed suicide by inhaling gas on Friday night in the office of the firm, at 147 East Forty-second Street. After investigating the case all day yesterday, the police were unable to discover any cause for the act.

After a week of untiring etfort, the police seem to be as much in the dark as ever as to who murdered Kathryn Scharn. As a mystery, they concede that the murder has already made a record for itself.

John Brennan, twenty years old, a messenger, living at 312 West Forty-seventh Street, was shot three times early this morning at Sixty-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue by a colored man, who is known to the police as "Lamplighter," living somewhere in West Sixty-first Street. "Lamplighter" escaped.

NEWPORT, Aug. 25 -- The future of the seventy-foot yachts which have done considerable racing hereabout lately has not been fully decided upon, but it is known that after the races in New York they will return here and be taken to the Herreshoff works in Bristol, there to be practically rebuilt before next Spring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- One of the most significant results of the race trouble in North Carolina is the announcement by Representative George Henry White of that State that he is compelled to leave the State and make his home in New York because the subjugation of the negro has been carried to such a point that an educated colored man can no longer remain there.

The sixth annual regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club of New Rochelle, sailed on the Sound yesterday afternoon, was one of the largest and best of the season. There were no accidents or mishaps of any kind, and of the thirty-eight boats which started only three failed to complete the course. Thirteen of the eighteen classes filled, and were productive of good races, leaving only five sail-overs.

At the dinner given to Senator Hanna at Deal Beach on Tuesday night there was one incident which gave the guests plenty of fun and made "Tony," the head waiter at Hathaway Inn, the proudest and happiest negro along the Jersey shore.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 25 -- Mr. Bryan made two speeches here to-day -- one or them in the afternoon and the other in the evening.

A large number of competitors and some very close finishes made the annual regatta of the Lone Star Boat Club, which was held on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, a very interesting affair. The races were rowed over a half-mile course, with the finish in front of the clubhouse at the foot of One Hundred and Fifty-third Street.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 25 -- During the sham battle at the military tournament at West End to-day between companies of the Eighth New York and the Second New Jersey Regiments, with Gatling guns, a shell burst and wounded Sergt. E. Kennedy of the Second Battery in the arm. The injury, however, was not serious.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic was opened to-night by the dedication of the new coliseum, in which all the joint campfires, the reunions, the war song concerts of the veterans, and the religious and other exercises for the public incidental to the encampment will be held.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 25 -- Glorious weather, several interesting social events and the usual out-door sports have marked the week here. On Monday at the Point Judith Country Club, the annual golf tournament was begun, and the clubhouse was gay with visitors. The playing began at 10 o'clock each morning and lasted until daylight failed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 -- It has been the gayest week of the season here with the closing days of the tennis tournament, the Fish ball, and the Oelrichs dinner on Wednesday night, and numerous other dinners and entertainments. The coming week will also bring a number of events, but the height of the season has been passed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The War Department has not yet received from Gen. Chaffee the report requested of him a few days ago upon conditions in Peking. In fact, several recent cablegrams of inquiry addressed to Gen. Chaffee have not been answered. In this situation it has been found necessary to call upon Gen. Chaffee again for a full report for the guidance of the officials of the United States Government.

WEIMAR, Aug. 25 -- Prof. Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the philosopher, died here to-day of apoplexy.

That department, and also the United States legation at The Hague, have been so flooded with inquiries from the victims of the craze that it is impossible to answer them individually, and the State Department has, therefore, issued the following general notice:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Silence on all subjects relating to China was the order of the day in all the executive departments. It was declared by high officials that the trouble was all over, and that there was no reason why the newspapers should be excited. Nevertheless, the same policy was observed as was the case yesterday that of treating all reports which came in as of too gave a nature to be divulged.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 25 -- The closing days of August find the Twin Cities crowded with guests, and the indications are that the present condition will prevail well along into September, to the gratification of the bonifaces. Not since 1892 have the hotel men and boarding house keepers enjoyed such a prosperous season.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 21 -- One of the greatest boons to soldiers serving in Cuba, and the same is doubtless true of American soldiers in other foreign parts, has been, and is, the canteen. It is a blessing not only to the enlisted men who patronize it and for whose benefit it is established, but also to the officers who look after the welfare of these men.

That department, and also the United States legation at The Hague, have been so flooded with inquiries from the victims of the craze that it is impossible to answer them individually, and the State Department has, therefore, issued the following general notice:

INTER-STATE PARK, Aug. 25 -- A goodsized crowd of wing shots journeyed out to Inter-State Park, to-day in spite of the very oppressive heat, and enjoyed an afternoon's sport at the traps. The principal event of the day was the team race between Dr. Webber and G.W. Hagerdorn and "Tom" Morphy and Dr. Wynn.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The only news tonight from Peking comes by way of Berlin, where official dispatches have been received dated Taku, Aug 25, reporting that an undated Russian Peking telegram received on Wednesday last says that large masses of Boxers are still in the southern part of the capital, and that a force of troops under Prince Ching is in the Imperial City.

Two badly scared youngsters, with tearstained, swollen faces, were arraigned before Magistrate Zeller in the Harlem Police Court yesterday charged with stealing $1,200 worth of railroad tickets from the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station of the New York Central and Hudson River Failroad.
BRISTOL, Aug. 25 -- Repairs were made on the Mineola and Yankee in quick time last Thursday at Bristol, the racers being sent to Newport on the afternoon of that day.

The Democratic National Executive Committee has decided to try to straighten out the factional struggle in New York State and to get the followers of David B. Hill and Messrs. Croker and Murphy to settle their troubles and work in harmony for the success of the National ticket.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- A disease has broken out among the cattle of the farmers of Monroe and Wayne Counties, Penn., that is causing the death of a large number of young stock. The symptoms of the disease seem to be those of murrain, a fatal contagious epidemic. The symptoms also are nervous prostration, spots of blood on the visible mucous membranes, abdominal pains, and the passage of blood elements.

JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 25 -- Finals in the men's golf tournament of the Waumbek Golf Club to-day gave the Jefferson Cup to Judge S.O. Prentice, Hartford Golf Club, who beat Henry A. Blair of the Onwentsia, 2 up.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- Much dissatisfaction is finding expression in political circles and in the press regarding the Government's silent refusal to call the Reichstag together in view of the financial situation arising out of the Chinese imbroglio. Since it has been confirmed that 7,000 additional troops are to embark for the Celestial Empire between Aug. 31 and Sept. 7 the agitation for an immediate assembly of the Reichstag has become general.

The Sisters in charge of the Summer home of the St. Vincent de Paul Society in Pelham Bay Park, on the Sound, sent word to the Westchester police last night that six of the children, three boys and three girls, who were having a two weeks' outing at the home, had disappeared, and it was feared they were lost in the woods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Silence on all subjects relating to China was the order of the day in all the executive departments. It was declared by high officials that the trouble was all over, and that there was no reason why the newspapers should be excited. Nevertheless, the same policy was observed as was the case yesterday that of treating all reports which came in as of too gave a nature to be divulged.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The Vesper Boat Club eight-oared shell crew of Philadelphia to-day had a practical walkover in their trial heat against the well-known Nautical Club crew of Paris. The warm weather about noon was very trying on the oarsmen, but the Americans were in the pink of condition and stood it well.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 -- It has been the gayest week of the season here with the closing days of the tennis tournament, the Fish ball, and the Oelrichs dinner on Wednesday night, and numerous other dinners and entertainments. The coming week will also bring a number of events, but the height of the season has been passed.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- It was "getaway day" at the Spa, and several good things were put through. The Spencer Handicap, With a value of $5,000, was the star attraction. Charentus appeared to be the only one worth considering, but Martimas showed a startling reversal of form. Charentus and Martimas raced together far ahead of the bunch to the finish.
Frederic W. Adee. Frederic W. Adee, for many years a well-known lawyer of this city, died yesterday at his home in Westchester. He was in his forty-eighth year and was unmarried.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The Democratic campaign was opened for Tompkins County in Ithaca to-night, the leading speaker being Congressman William Sulzer of New York. Mr. Sulzer spoke on the leading issues of the campaign. He was frequently interrupted by applause, and every mention of Mr. Bryan's name was cheered.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The only news tonight from Peking comes by way of Berlin, where official dispatches have been received dated Taku, Aug 25, reporting that an undated Russian Peking telegram received on Wednesday last says that large masses of Boxers are still in the southern part of the capital, and that a force of troops under Prince Ching is in the Imperial City.

Charentus appeared to be the only one worth considering, but Martimas showed a startling reversal of form. Charentus and Martimas raced together far ahead of the bunch to the finish.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 21 -- One of the greatest boons to soldiers serving in Cuba, and the same is doubtless true of American soldiers in other foreign parts, has been, and is, the canteen. It is a blessing not only to the enlisted men who patronize it and for whose benefit it is established, but also to the officers who look after the welfare of these men.

Ridden by a jockey brought from England for the one race, his owner a thousand miles away at sea. and none present of those immediately connected with the management of the colt, save his trainer and former owner, to exult over the victory. William C. Whitney's Ballyhoo Bey yesterday, at the Sheepshead Bay course, won the richest stake of the American turf, the Futurity, worth $42,080 gross.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Secretary Gage has given the following interview on the question of what Mr. Bryan could do for silver if he were elected President:

"I wonder what they'll do to poor McGinnis," moaned John McGinnis, a hod carrier, of 769 Columbus Avenue, yesterday morning as he was arraigned before the Magistrate in the Harlem Police Court by Policeman McLaughlin of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station, on a charge of intoxication and disorderly conduct.

The announcement that, by the will of Collis P. Huntington, all his pictures will eventually go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art is being discussed with much interest by art lovers of this city. It is said that no accurate estimate of the value of the bequest can be formed until an inventory of the pictures has been taken.

Army. Second Lieut. John Sherman Chambers, recently appointed, with rank from Aug. 22, is assigned to the Twelfth Infantry, and upon the receipt and acceptance by him of his commission will join his regiment.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- The efforts which foreign nations make to compete with France in the culinary domain are worthy of a good deal of attention. In Paris there are not a few establishments where meals of various kinds are prepared in exotic ways to suit foreign palates, but it is at the exposition that international cooking may be best examined and compared with the home industry.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 26 -- There was not a large crowd at Hlllsgrove to witness the bicycle races this evening, and while there was some excellent racing, the principal event turned out unsatisfactorily. In the twenty-mile motor-paced race between Bolting of Providence and Munroe of Memphis, Bolting dropped out after the eleventh mile and Munroe finished alone, making the distance in 37:28 1-5.

H. Coulter Brinker. thirty-five years old, of 31 Nelson Street, Newark, N.J., a guest of the Grand Hotel, Broadway and Thirty-first Street, was found dead early yesterday morning at the bottom of the airshaft in the hotel. It is supposed that he fell out of the window of his room which he occupied on the sixth floor of the hotel some time during teh night.

It was like a lime kiln on the asphalt walk along the Speedway yesterday morning, but that did not prevent a good-sized gathering of spectators from seeing the Sunday brushing bouts of the fast steppers. Nor did the earnest endeavors of Old Sol to melt up everything in sight stand in the way of some excellent sport on the part of the light-harness horses and their drivers.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 20 -- Lincoln people have begun to believe that W.J. Bryan's recently constructed platform porch is not destined to be used very much during the campaign as a speaking rostrum, and that the throngs of admirers who were expected to come to Lincoln because of his "increased popularity" will not materialize.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 20 -- Lincoln people have begun to believe that W.J. Bryan's recently constructed platform porch is not destined to be used very much during the campaign as a speaking rostrum, and that the throngs of admirers who were expected to come to Lincoln because of his "increased popularity" will not materialize.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26 -- H. Coulter Brinker, whose death in New York caused a sensation here to-day, was the leading man of the Brinker-Abell Stock Company, which is to open for the season at the Neu Century Theatre on Labor Day. Brinker came here from the Imperial Theatre, St. Louis, two years ago, as leading man at the Columbia Theatre.

As a means of encouraging and developing polo players among the boys living in the immediate neighborhood of the clubs that are members of the Polo Association, William A. Hazard has offered trophies for a junior polo tournament, and with the aid of the leading hunting clubs and polo teams has arranged for the tournament to be held on the grrounds of the Rockaway Hunt Club from Sept. 3 to Sept. 8.
The final game for the cricket championship of New York was played on Saturday, and the team of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club may now be officially declared the pennant winner of 1900.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The Poughkeepsie Zither Club, one of the leading social organizations of this city, held a clambake a few days ago, and out of the fun and frolic of the occasion arose an incident which some people insist has a serious side to it.

Secretary GAGE has done well to give out a statement of the consequences of Mr. BRYAN'S election so far as concerns the Treasury and the public credit. Ordinarily the Secretary of the Treasury is the one Cabinet officer who can with the greatest propriety abstain from taking any part in a political campaign.

The entries for the Middle States rowing regatta, to be held on the Harlem River on Labor Day, will close to-day with Secretary Brown of the Atalanta Boat Club. The entries will be made public to-morrow evening at a meeting of the association, which will be held at the Hotel Marlborough.

The Rev. Len G. Broughton of Atlanta, Ga., preached in the Hanson Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and last evening. Mr. Broughton preached on a wide range of subjects, from Coney Island to cigarette smoking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Late to-day a dispatch was received at the Japanese Legation from the Japanese Foreign Office conveying the latest and most authentic information of the situation in and around Peking. The advices were of a disquieting nature, as they indicated that the Chinese had rallied their forces, and were preparing for an attack upon the allies in Peking.

NEWPORT, Aug. 26 -- The entries for the automobile races at Aquidneck Park on the afternoon of Sept. 6 are arriving from out of the city, while most of the cottagers here are entering their machines. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., has entered his racing locomobile and John R. Livermore his locomobile.

Two boys were killed and four others were stunned by lightning which hit an electric wire in the Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, N.J., yesterday afternoon at 1:30. Hill, N.J., yesterday afternoon at 1:30 o' clock.

SOMERSET, Ky., Aug. 26 -- Near Flat Rock, Pulaski County, on Thursday last Mrs. Serepta Sellers was shot dead after having been beaten with a club, by Mrs. Nancy Hunley and her daughter, Phoebe King.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Unless the unexpected happens, Adlai E. Stevenson to-morrow 'Will be substituted for Charles A. Towne as the Vice Presidential nominee on the Populist ticket. A poll of the National Committee of that party was taken tonight and the Illinois man was seemingly assured a comfortable majority.

Whitney, which was one of the dominating features in the race for the Futurity Stakes on Saturday, and which was responsible for much of the public interest in the event, did not end with the victory of Ballyhoo Bey.

Richard Croker has disappeared again. He was at the Democratic Club early yesterday, but had not returned at a late hour last night. No one at the clubhouse could give any information regarding his whereabouts. He was not at Brighton Beach. One of his closest friends asserted that he did not accompany ex-Senator Murphy to Elberon.

J., Aug. 26. -- Thomas Connolly, nineteen years old, residing at 212 Van Houten Street, is in the General Hospital, and the house physician says there is but a slight possibility of his recovery. About 200 cyclists took part in the century run of the Jefferson Wheelmen of this city, which was held over the Rockaway and Valley Stream course on Long Island yesterday, and although drenched by the storm of the afternoon and seriously hampered by the mud, a majority of them managed to finish within the time limit of fourteen hours.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 26 -- The Rev. Dr. H.H. Lowry. President of the Methodist University of Peking has just arrived here irom China. Dr. Lowry has been a resident of China for 35 years. He speaks the language like a native and has been in close touch with the Chinese. He places the blame for the anti-foreign feeling partially on the missionaries themselves.

John Davis, alias "Lamplighter," the negro who shot John Brennan, twenty years old, a white messenger boy, in the abdomen in front of 203 West Sixty-second Street at 11:30 o'clock Saturday night, has not yet been captured. Brennan was taken to Roosevelt Hospital, and Dr. Brewer, the visiting physician, yesterday performed the operation of removing the bullet from the young man's stomach.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The apathy of the citizens of New York to the usurpation of their rights upon the streets and sidewalks by the illegal obstruction thereof is astonishing, and seems to be only explainable by the generally held sentiment that no matter how just the complaint may be, to prefer it suggests the crank, or that other despised one -- the kicker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Gen. Louis T. Michener, the well-known Republican of Indiana and former political adviser of ex-President Harrison, ridicules the story that the Republicans have made a poll of Indiana and find that it is Democratic by 18,000.

Mr. PLATT talked with much frankness and blithe confidence to the reporters on Sunday evening in regard to State politics. It is evident that his intention to nominate Mr. ODELL as Governor is based on the assurance he has that Mr. COLER will not be the Democratic candidate. "Neither CROKER nor MURPHY will have him," he said emphatically.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Aug. 27 -- The Philadelphia Cricket Team commenced its annual tour to-day, playing its first match -- a one-day event -- with the Hamilton eleven. It rained nearly all the morning, but after luncheon the clouds passed away and the sun shone brightly during the afternoon.

The London Times has recently spoken out in criticism of English railways, making comparisons unfavorable to them with American railways in respect to speed and punctuality. Our London namesake points out that we have trains that run at higher speed than any English train.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Third Baseman Tamsett and Right Fielder Jones of the Rome baseball team have been sold to Cleveland. They have gone to that city. They will play the same positions with Cleveland that they have played with Rome.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Third Baseman Tamsett and Right Fielder Jones of the Rome baseball team have been sold to Cleveland. They have gone to that city. They will play the same positions with Cleveland that they have played with Rome.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 27 -- The largest gathering to listen to a political speech that ever assembled in Duluth was at the armory to-night when Charles A. Towne opened the campaign in a lengthy address, in which he replied to the recent speech of Gov. Roosevelt, delivered at St. Paul on the occasion of the National Convention of the League of Republican Clubs.

HAVANA, Aug. 27 -- Senor Lanuza, former Secretary of Justice, who was recently asked to represent the Republican Party of Cienfuegos in the forthcoming Constitutional Convention, published to-day a private letter, written last April, in which he gives his reason for not joining the Republicans. He takes this step in order to explain his exact position.
PARIS, Aug. 27 -- I hear from a thoroughly well informed source that a serious insurrection has broken out in Persia which may in all probability cause the Shah's visit to Europe to be curtailed.

The baseball game yesterday at Washington Park between New York and Brooklyn was one postponed from a previous series. It was a one-sided affair, the Brooklyns batting out eight runs off Mercer before he was taken out at the end of the fourth Inning. Taylor, the deaf-and-dumb pitcher from Albany, finished the game and displayed not a little ability.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Department of State made public to-day the following dispatch from Minister Conger, received this morning:

The primary polling booths will be opened to-day from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M., according to the new Primary Election law. Delegates will be elected to Congressional, Senatorial, and Assembly district conventions, and also Assembly district conventions to be held for the purpose of electing delegates to the State conventions.

The season of public amusements, the atrical and musical, being at hand, the attention of those whose business it is to comment on the art or lack of art on the stage and concert platform is once again called to a curious belief which dwells in the minds of friends of singers, musical performers, and actors.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Aug. 27 -- The Philadelphia Cricket Team commenced its annual tour to-day, playing its first match -- a one-day event -- with the Hamilton eleven. It rained nearly all the morning, but after luncheon the clouds passed away and the sun shone brightly during the afternoon.

The baseball game yesterday at Washington Park between New York and Brooklyn was one postponed from a previous series. It was a one-sided affair, the Brooklyns batting out eight runs off Mercer before he was taken out at the end of the fourth Inning. Taylor, the deaf-and-dumb pitcher from Albany, finished the game and displayed not a little ability.

The men seemed to be waiting for somebody. The street was unusually quiet. Aside from a few reporters across the way, an occasional policeman coming and going, or a man passing by, everything was quiet.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Despite the hot weather, an air of bustling activity was apparent all day long on the links of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, and, with barely a dozen exceptions, all of the Sixty-five competitors entered for the women's golf championship of the United States were on hand to do their best practicing before the great event to-morrow morning.

Horton Bryant, Janitor of the block of handsome apartment houses at the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Sixth Street, was shot and probably fatally wounded on the premises at noon yesterday by Andrew Gogger, his trusted assistant, whom he had Just discovered to be a burglar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The report that Andrew Carnegie is going on the stump for Bryan has led to a controversy in this city.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 27 -- The largest gathering to listen to a political speech that ever assembled in Duluth was at the armory to-night when Charles A. Towne opened the campaign in a lengthy address, in which he replied to the recent speech of Gov. Roosevelt, delivered at St. Paul on the occasion of the National Convention of the League of Republican Clubs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Some of the European powers are disposed to balk at the present attitude of the United States unless they can find out what it means.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27 -- Gov. Pingree has written Chairman Diekema of the Republican State Committee declining the latter's invitation to accompany Gov. Roosevelt and Col. A.T. Bliss, Republican candidate for Governor, on Roosevelt's brief campaigning trip in Michigan. Gov. Fingree gives poor health, previous engagements, and his intention to take a brief rest as the reasons for non-acceptance.

After suffering untold agony for three days Edward Peterson, thirteen years old, died of hydrophobia in Harlem Hospital yesterday afternoon. The case is deemed by physicians to be one of the most remarkable on record, and is the seventeenth case of genuine hydrophobia that has proved fatal in this city during the past five years.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 27 -- The Grand Circuit meeting began at Narragansett Park to-day, and, in spite of the excessive heat, the times were fast, strong evidence that the track was in the best condition known in years.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 27 -- The Grand Circuit meeting began at Narragansett Park to-day, and, in spite of the excessive heat, the times were fast, strong evidence that the track was in the best condition known in years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Chief James A. Sample of the Issue Division of the Treasury Department, who has been in Porto Rico aiding in the establishment of the American coinage system, returned to-day, and visited Secretary Gage to report on the work.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- "Men," said Inspector McDermott of the Central Office, "here are two buttons, which you will notice are of peculiar make. I want the men to whom they belong." These words, addressed to Detectives Muldoon and McGuire, accompanied by a button given each man, were the means of arresting one of the most desperate burglars ever captured in this city Saturday night.

The Bedford Democratic Club, which includes among its members a number of the most influential men in Democratic politics in Brooklyn, placed itself on record last night as favoring the nomination of Controller Bird S. Coler for Governor.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 27 -- The Yale Review, a quarterly publication devoted to the study of economic, social, and political topics, and edited by Professors E.G. Bourne, T.C. Schwab, Irving Fisher, Henry W. Farnam, and W.F. Blackman, is out in its August issue with an attack on the candidates of both the Republican and the Democratic Party, and a call for a new party and an independent Presidential candidate.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Aug. 27 -- R.D. Little of Princeton retained his title as champion in the international tennis tournament here to-day. His opponent was H.H. Hackett of Princeton, who was beaten in a four set match.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 27 -- The mystery surrounding the North-western train robbery of last weak and the dangerous wounding of B. Balch, the banker, of Omaha, was partly cleared to-day when the injured man regained consciousness for the first time.

Harold H. Stridiron, a lumber salesman of 119 Seeley Avenue, Chicago, Ill., was shot in the head twice, and probably fatally wounded, by John Essing, a railroad contractor and bridge builder of Chicago, in a room in the Hotel Vendome yesterday morning. Immediately after shooting Stridiron Essing placed the muzzle of the revolver in his own mouth and sent a bullet upward into his brain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The first direct word from Gen. Chaffee since Aug. 18 came to-day in the form of a cablegram dated to-day at Taku, reporting the action of the Sixth Cavalry with the enemy near Tien-Tsin on Aug. 19. The message is as follows.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- A heavy wind and rainstorm this afternoon put a damper on the opening day of the State Fair. It was Syracuse Day, and the attendance was good. Owing to wet track only one heat of the 2:18 trot was run off, other events being put over. Emma Winter, b.m., by Director, won the heat in 2:203/4: Lady Noretta, b.m., second; Tip T., third.

A dispatch from St. Petersburg says it is persistently rumored there that the Russian Government has received a message asserting that after a fierce battle inside Peking the allies retreated, losing 1,800 men, mostly Russians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Gen. Louis T. Michener, the well-known Republican of Indiana and former political adviser of ex-President Harrison, ridicules the story that the Republicans have made a poll of Indiana and find that it is Democratic by 18,000.

HAVANA, Aug. 27 -- Senor Lanuza, former Secretary of Justice, who was recently asked to represent the Republican Party of Cienfuegos in the forthcoming Constitutional Convention, published to-day a private letter, written last April, in which he gives his reason for not joining the Republicans. He takes this step in order to explain his exact position.

Horton Bryant, Janitor of the block of handsome apartment houses at the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Sixth Street, was shot and probably fatally wounded on the premises at noon yesterday by Andrew Gogger, his trusted assistant, whom he had Just discovered to be a burglar.

Mr. PLATT talked with much frankness and blithe confidence to the reporters on Sunday evening in regard to State politics. It is evident that his intention to nominate Mr. ODELL as Governor is based on the assurance he has that Mr. COLER will not be the Democratic candidate. "Neither CROKER nor MURPHY will have him," he said emphatically.

Hugh Riley, with his reliable old trotter, Commodore Porter, (2:13;) Charles Weiland, with his green trotter Jack Hart; Walter Kilpatrick, behind his black gelding Royal Rene, (2:20,) and B.T. Kearns, piloting his black pacer Drex, (2:16 1/4,) were a quartet of amateur drivers that helped make things lively on the Speedway yesterday afternoon.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- Business was quiet on the Boerse to-day. Americans and Canadian Pacifies were dull in sympathy with the New York market. Transvaals improved in expectation of a dividend being declared by the Netherlands Railroad. Mine shares recovered on bear purchases. Exchange on London, 20 marks 48 1/2 pfennigs for checks.

Testimony was taken yesterday in Room 1,709 of the Commercial Cable Building, before a notary, by Attorney General C.J. Smyth of Nebraska, in the proceedings instituted by the State of Nebraska under its anti-trust law against the Standard Oil Company of the State of Indiana.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- For four hours and a half to-day the thinning ranks of the Grand Army of the Republic passed in review before their leaders and before many thousands of spectators, packed in almost solid masses along the four miles of the line of parade. Probably 30,000 members of the army of veterans took part in the parade.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Elegant weather and a grand field of highclass feminine golfing talent heralded the women's National golf championship, which began this morning on the Shinnecock Hills golf links. It marks the fifth competition for the Cox Silver Trophy held under the auspices of the United State Golf Association.
The Democratic primaries were held yesterday in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx and in Brooklyn.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 28. -- The Pot and Kettle Club house at Hull's Cove was opened to-day, Bar Harbor's best society being present at the function. A novel and distinguishing feature of the entertainment was that the seven charter members of the club received, attired as French chefs.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- Mrs. Ogden Goelet gave this evening at her villa, Ochre Court, on Ochre Point, a ball in honor of her daughter, Miss May Goelet. In appointments, decoration, and display it was not only the most notable entertainment this season, but of several seasons.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- The first of the series of hunts to be given by the Monmouth County hounds occurred this afternoon, and was a success. The start was from the one-mile corner, at Middletown, and ending at Honeyman Hill, on the estate of Congressman Melville Bull.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Abbie Lawrence, ten years old, while standing on the station platform here today, was drawn in between the engine and foremost car of a passing train. It is supposed that she was unable to resist the suction created by the train's motion. She did not fall under the wheels, but was struck by the steps.

The market for outside securities yesterday was dull and almost featureless. The scarcity of orders and the slight disposition on the part of brokers to trade in the small supply of stocks on hand combined to produce a stagnant condition, which many brokers say exceeds the record of several years for midsummer dullness.

Assistant Corporation Counsel Terence Farley was asked yesterday if James P. Keating, Commissioner of Highways, was prevented by any law from carrying out his announcement, over his own signature, that if the incumbrance on the sidewalk in West Forty-second Street created by the portico and inclosed balcony of the Pabst Hotel was not removed by Aug. 25 he would proceed to take it down and remove it to the corporation yard.

From The Cincinnati Commercial Tribune. Bread pills have ever been regarded as potent factors in the practice of medicine, but it remained for the modern school of physicians to discover the true value of psychic influence in the treatment of mental and bodily disorders.

A fire broke out in the cabinet works of Louis Spatz Son, on the top floor of the four-story brick factory building, 85 and 87 Quay Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, and before the flames could be extinguished $30,000 damage was done. Part of the floor was occupied as a varnish shop by the James Clark Plumbers' Supplies Manufacturing Company, which also occupied the entire second floor.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Miss Blanche and Nellie Babcock, cousins, who reside in New York, and who are stopping here for the season, had a narrow escape from drowning this afternoon. Nellie is a good swimmer. Her cousin cannot swim at all. This afternoon while bathing Nellie swam out into deep water and her cousin not realizing her danger waded out until she was up to her neck.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- A double play by Hickman, unassisted; Long's brilliant stop, and Van Haltren's base running were the features of the baseball game to-day between New York and Boston. Umpire Swartwood's decisions occasioned considerable objecting from both sides. The score:

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Paul K. Ames, receiver of the Long Beach Association, has arranged with the Town Board of Hempstead to take title to the Lions Beach property by Sept. 10. The consideration is $25,000. The part of the beach acquired runs from the westerly end to a point east of Point Lookout Life Saving Station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin to-day received a dispatch from Gen. Chaffee, sating that he (Chaffee) had received no dispatches from Gen. Corbin since Aug. 14. This was the date on which the allied army attacked and entered Peking.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Trading flattened out to-day almost completely, and careful search failed to reveal any development of prices worth chronicling. Generally speaking, the undertone is a little softer, hut there is no disposition to "short" the market, and certainly no one is selling long stocks.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 28. -- The Kentucky Legislature convened in extra session to-day. There were seven members absent in the House and two in the Senate. In the Senate, Dyer succeeded Hill, deceased; Watkins succeeded Bell, deceased; Tolin succeeded Furnish, resigned, and Harbeson succeeded William Goebel, who was killed last January.

An attempt is being made by the "Western railroads to complete the organization of the different sub-committees which were to take charge of rate questions in the various divisions of the territory of these railroads, under the Presidents' agreement adopted at the June meeting. It is understood that George W. Ristine, President of the Colorado Midland, has been asked to take charge of the Omaha, the St. Louis, and the Kansas City committees.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 28. -- Mr. Bryan to-day expressed himself as highly gratified over the action of the Populist National Committee at Chicago in indorsing the nomination of Mr. Stevenson for the Vice Presidency. He said: "I am very glad that Mr. Stevenson has been indorsed by the Populists.

Runaway victories were in order at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, and in four of the six events the horses that made the running were returned the winners. These included Demurrer and Lady Massey, who captured the two stake fixtures of the afternoon's programme, and Belle of Troy and King Bramble, purse winners.

L. Laflin Kellogg of Kellogg, Rose Smith, counsel for Julius Meyers, the taxpayer who is opposing the issuance of the contracts advertised by the East River Bridge Commissioners for the approaches to the bridge, characterized the prevailing rate of wages law as a "monstrous, vicious, unconstitutional, and illegal enactment," before Justice Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The diplomatic situation in regard to China entirely over-shadows the military situation for the moment. The War Department deprecates the talks of serious military movements, and pays no attention to stories of attacks on Peking. The Secretary of War is very busy, but not in his capacity as such. His activity is as adviser to the President, as actual Secretary of State.
Charles Galewski has bought from the estate of D.H. Behrend the three-story building 199 Prince Street, 25 by 100.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- Albany witnessed one of the most exciting primaries in some time to-day, the vote polled by the Democrats being one-third larger than at the primary for the last general election. The strife was between State Committeeman Patrick E. McCabe, supported by David B. Hill and District Attorney Zeb A. Dyer, backed by Messrs. Croker and Murphy.

The last week of August has opened, fortunately, with somewhat cooler weather, but, although by the calendar the time of preparation for the annual flitting from seashore to mountains and from mountains to seashore has arrived, the continued high thermometer will defer these until the Autumn winds begin to really blow.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Joseph J. Murphy, second son of ex-Senator Murphy, will be married to Miss Elizabeth Farrell, daughter of John J. Farrell, of this city, to-morrow.

Richard Croker has decided to become a campaign orator. His friends in Tammany Hall, since the meeting of the Executive Committee, at which Mr. Croker is said to have made one of the speeches of his life, have been urging him to take the stump.

Richard T. Wallace, a real estate agent, who has an office on Olin Avenue, William's Bridge, found an old tin box several days ago buried in the foundation of his office. Olin Avenue is being raised and widened, and it was found necessary to move the office back some twenty feet. When the old foundation was torn out Mr. Wallace found the tin box, which was pretty well battered.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28. -- Four months ago there arrived in this city Dr. C.A. Von Ahlfeldt of Berlin, Germany. He became acquainted with the Rev. Frederick J. Stanley, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, to whom he told a hard-luck story, stating that his brother was an officer on a German man-of-war then making a voyage around the world and due in a few weeks, when he would be in funds.
LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The Viceroy of India, Lord Curson of Kedleston, telegraphs that abundant rain continues to fall, but that cholera still prevails in many districts of that country.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 28. -- If the anthracite coal operators refuse to grant the demands or the United Mine Workers as embodied in the reports of the scale and the Resolutions Committee as presented and adopted at to-day's convention, within ten days of date or by Sept. 8, a strike involving 140,000 miners, of whom 40,000 are members of the Mine Workers' organization, will be declared.

We are asked by a correspondent what answer we have to make to the following statement of Mr. BRYAN, at Pawnee, Neb., on the 22d: "They say they do not believe in the ratio of 16 to 1. When they make that assertion, you ask them why Mr. McKINLEY'S Administration is coining silver dollars to-day at the ratio of 16 to 1.

So far as the Republican primaries were concerned the organization won all along the line except in the Twenty-first Assembly District. There Abraham Gruber, who had been placed outside the breastworks, not only repeated his victory of March last, but won by a largely increased majority.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- This evening Mrs. Ogden Mills gave a dinner to twenty-six guests, who were afterward driven to Mrs. Goelet's ball.

The stock market yesterday was featureless, quotations moving listlessly and without any appreciable change. What activity there was resulted, as on recent previous days, almost entirely from the operations of professional traders, the public continuing to hold aloof from the market.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- About three months ago articles of incorporation were filed in the office of the Secretary of State at Trenton by the Capital Investment and Supply Company of New Jersey. The seven incorporators are colored men.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The Rogers Locomotive Works, which has built locomotives for every country in the world, will busy itself during the next three months in finishing up what work is on hand, and on or about Dec. 1 its doors will be permanently closed as a locomotive works and also probably as an iron works of any kind.

As Mr. BRYAN goes about the country exhorting his fellow-citizens to save the freedom of the land by electing him President, he fails, so far as we have followed him, to tell them what he proposes to do in certain matters with which he would certainly have to deal if his appeals were successful.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 28. -- The Northern Pacific Steamship Company's Cape Nome steamship Tacoma ran ashore to-day in a dense fog, about half a mile south and east of Alki Point, on a very dangerous piece of beach.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The body of Alfred Bingen, a broker, who had an office at 35 Broadway, New York, was found this morning in a vacant lot in Second Avenue, this city. There was a bullet hole in the right temple and a revolver was found lying beside the body. Papers in the pockets led to the identification of the man.

The entries for the annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association, to be held on the Harlem River on Labor Day, were opened at a meeting of the association, held last night at the Hotel Marlborough, and were found to number fifty-eight, exactly the number received for the Harlem regatta last June.

The owners of the show now running at the Herald Square Theatre are at war. They stood in opposite corners of the lobby last night and eyed each other viciously, each surrounded by small groups of men, to whom he declared in confidential whispers that his rival was "morally cross-eyed."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- Colonel and Mrs. John Jacob Astor have returned from New York on the Nourmahal.

Shortly before midnight last night the police of the Old Slip Station arrested Christian Walters, a German who says he is thirty-four years old and lives at 120 Second Street, on the charge of highway robbery.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- Colonel and Mrs. John Jacob Astor have returned from New York on the Nourmahal.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 17 -- The topic of the hour here is the appointment of Field Marshal Count von Waldersee as Generalissimo of the allied forces in China, and many are the adverse criticisms which the appointment has evoked throughout Russia.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Through proceedings instituted by State Commissioner of Excise Lyman, the liquor tax certificate of the Tivoli, the resort on West Thirty-fifth Street which has come into much notoriety, has been revoked and canceled because the place was of a disorderly character and sold liquors during prohibited hours in violation of the liquor tax law.

The dispatch from Lord ROBERTS published this morning puts an end to the hope entertained by the British public that BOTHA and his Generals would fight out the last formal battle of the war at Machadodorp, on the Delagoa Bay Railway, a few miles east of Belfast, where, less than a week ago, "Bobs" established his headquarters.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- W.J. Bryan will lead the fight of the Democrats himself in the Central and Eastern States. He win take command next week in Chicago, and then will begin an invasion of Republican territory, for he has decided to stump Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, New Jersey, Maryland, and West Virginia.

The business of the allies in China has reached a critical stage. The rescue of the Ministers was successfully accomplished because there was perfect unity of purpose and action. It would be a very dull Foreign Office indeed that did not perceive that a continuance of that unity and agreement is the surest guarantee of success in the difficult work that remains to be done. On that all depends.

The police of the Tenderloin precinct yesterday learned of what they at first thought was an incendiary fire, at 353 Fifth Avenue, opposite the Waldorf-Astoria. The building had been scorched on the 1st of July. On Monday evening last Theron J. Blakeslee, who occupies the upper part of the four-story building, was himself in the country.

Our contemporary The Herald is not quite fair to Mr. BRYAN. It sends a correspondent to obtain an expression of his views about silver free coinage, in answer to a set of prepared questions, and on receiving to each and every one of its questions the unvarying answer, "I will discuss public questions in my own way and in my own time," announces that "BRYAN will not talk on silver."
The longest Cabinet meeting held since the present Administration came into office was devoted yesterday to discussing the diplomatic situation in regard to China.

MILAN, Aug. 29 -- The trial of Bresci, the Anarchist who, on July 29, shot and killed King Humbert of Italy, at Monza, while his Majesty was returning from a gymnastic exhibition, opened here to-day. At the close of the trial, Bresci was pronounced guilty and sentenced to imprisonment for life.

MILAN, Aug. 29 -- The trial of Bresci, the Anarchist who, on July 29, shot and killed King Humbert of Italy, at Monza, while his Majesty was returning from a gymnastic exhibition, opened here to-day. At the close of the trial, Bresci was pronounced guilty and sentenced to imprisonment for life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- W.J. Bryan will lead the fight of the Democrats himself in the Central and Eastern States. He win take command next week in Chicago, and then will begin an invasion of Republican territory, for he has decided to stump Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, New Jersey, Maryland, and West Virginia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The State Department announces that W. Irwin Shaw, United States Consul at Barranquilla, Colombia, who was reported to have died of yellow fever, is alive and well.

While one of the soldiers stationed at Fort Wadsworth was walking along the shore yesterday morning he discovered the body of a man lying on the rocks near old Fort Tompkins. The body was that of James Rankine, an expert machinist, who had been employed in Brooklyn, where he was recognized by men from Bay City, Mich., whom he had refused to join in a strike at that place.

Kinley Mack, winner of the Brooklyn and Suburban Handicaps in the Spring, yesterday added one more triumph to his list of victories by winning the Autumn Cup at the Sheepshead Bay course, and at the same time establishing a new track record by finishing two miles in 3:27 4-5, as against the best performance for the same race by Ben Hollacay, Kinley Mack's former stable companion.

Kinley Mack, winner of the Brooklyn and Suburban Handicaps in the Spring, yesterday added one more triumph to his list of victories by winning the Autumn Cup at the Sheepshead Bay course, and at the same time establishing a new track record by finishing two miles in 3:27 4-5, as against the best performance for the same race by Ben Hollacay, Kinley Mack's former stable companion.

The rival factions in the Ninth Assembly District were at rest yesterday after the spirited primary of Tuesday. John C. Sheehan left the city on an early train for Long Branch, where he has a Summer home. Councilman Frank J. Goodwin and Thomas F. Smith, private secretary to Richard Croker, spent the day resting, and it was not until evening that the contestants appeared at their headquarters.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Prominent men from all parts of the country gathered around the tables in the banquet hall of the Auditorium Hotel to-night to attend the feast given by the Hamilton Club of this city in their honor. The Hamilton Club is a Republican organization and its banquet was, after the menu, a banquet with politics the chief thing under discussion.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The saloon keepers of this city have decided to contest in the courts the city ordinance under which several of the saloon keepers were convicted of violating the law in selling liquor after 1 A.M.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- One of the best posted men of the Diplomatic Corps, who is actively engaged in present negotiations, to-day described the international complication substantially as follows:

A design for the Lipton Cup, given by Sir Thomas Lipton to the New York Yacht Club, has been received by the club from the London designers of the trophy, and is now on exhibition in the model room of the Madison Avenue clubhouse.
Arthur T.J. Rice, a retired banker, who was for forty-five years connected with the Broadway National Bank, lost his life in a peculiar accident while bathing at Brighton Beach yesterday afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The saloon keepers of this city have decided to contest in the courts the city ordinance under which several of the saloon keepers were convicted of violating the law in selling liquor after 1 A.M.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Prominent men from all parts of the country gathered around the tables in the banquet hall of the Auditorium Hotel to-night to attend the feast given by the Hamilton Club of this city in their honor. The Hamilton Club is a Republican organization and its banquet was, after the menu, a banquet with politics the chief thing under discussion.

PEAPACK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The Peapack Smiths, to the number of about 2,500, gathered to-day around the site of the cabin which their founder and common ancestor erected 150 years ago in this valley, one of New Jersey's most beautiful spots. He was John Smith, and came from Holland, where he was John Schmidt, but when he married he and his wife took the English form of spelling the name.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Through proceedings instituted by State Commissioner of Excise Lyman, the liquor tax certificate of the Tivoli, the resort on West Thirty-fifth Street which has come into much notoriety, has been revoked and canceled because the place was of a disorderly character and sold liquors during prohibited hours in violation of the liquor tax law.

Gen. Francis V. Greene, President of the Republican County Committee, called a meeting of the Executive Committee for 3 o'clock yesterday. All the members except ex-Senator Fred S. Gibbs were in attendance.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 29 -- "The Dream of Alice in Wonderland." a burlesque, arranged by Mrs. Albert Clifford Barney from Lewis Carroll's well-known book, was presented to-night by society amateurs before a large audience. The players included Mrs. Walter Damrosch, the Misses Barney, Fox, Walley, Draper, Tarn, Berry, Vanest, Alexander, Baird, Taylor, Potter, MacMichael, Wiltse, and Hollins; Messrs. Charles Whelan, Younman, Franzen, Belgel, Stanton, Merryweather, A.J. Vankaathoven, Taylor, Ralph Pulitzer, and Franklin Ellis.

Richard Croker was elated over the results of the primaries. His followers declared that David B. Hill would be routed as the State Convention and that the combination of New York, Kings, and Erie Counties would dominate affairs and put Mr. Hill under the shadow of holding a small minority of the delegates.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 29 -- The Philadelphia cricketers went up against the strongest aggregation they will meet on their tour, to-day, when they played the Upper Canada College, Past and Present. They defeated them by two runs in one of the most exciting finishes ever seen on a cricket field.

The business of the allies in China has reached a critical stage. The rescue of the Ministers was successfully accomplished because there was perfect unity of purpose and action. It would be a very dull Foreign Office indeed that did not perceive that a continuance of that unity and agreement is the surest guarantee of success in the difficult work that remains to be done. On that all depends.

As September's advent draws near plans are being made for certain out-door sports which an exceptionally hot Summer has precluded. The first meet and run with the hounds at Newport on Tuesday will be followed a series of paper chases at Jamestown. A number of coaching parties are also being planned at Newport.

There is every reason for rejoicing over the speed attained by the new battleship Alabama on her trial off the New England coast on Tuesday. The addition of another seventeen-knot battleship to the navy is something to give a thrill of delight to every person who takes a pride in the floating defenses of the country, and to every one who regards fighting strength as the surest means of preserving peace.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 29 -- The Philadelphia cricketers went up against the strongest aggregation they will meet on their tour, to-day, when they played the Upper Canada College, Past and Present. They defeated them by two runs in one of the most exciting finishes ever seen on a cricket field.

BANGOR, Aug. 29 -- The condition of Charles Addison Boutelle, member of Congress for the Fourth Maine District and candidate for re-election, is a matter of great interest in political circles generally as well as to the people of his district and of all Maine.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- An all-day session of the Cabinet was held to-day to consider the serious diplomatic situation in regard to China.

The police of the Tenderloin precinct yesterday learned of what they at first thought was an incendiary fire, at 353 Fifth Avenue, opposite the Waldorf-Astoria. The building had been scorched on the 1st of July. On Monday evening last Theron J. Blakeslee, who occupies the upper part of the four-story building, was himself in the country.

BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The women's and men's eighteen-hole golf handicap was the order of the day at the Eagle Nest Country Club to-day, and quite a number turned in cards. In the men's event Dr. Wells of Englewood again played from scratch, while in the women's handicap Mrs. Wells was the back starter.

There is every reason for rejoicing over the speed attained by the new battleship Alabama on her trial off the New England coast on Tuesday. The addition of another seventeen-knot battleship to the navy is something to give a thrill of delight to every person who takes a pride in the floating defenses of the country, and to every one who regards fighting strength as the surest means of preserving peace.
Controller Coler was boomed as an independent candidate for the Governorship last night at a meeting of the Franchise Tax and Municipal Ownership League, held in the Sturtevant House.

PEAPACK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The Peapack Smiths, to the number of about 2,500, gathered to-day around the site of the cabin which their founder and common ancestor erected 150 years ago in this valley, one of New Jersey's most beautiful spots. He was John Smith, and came from Holland, where he was John Schmidt, but when he married he and his wife took the English form of spelling the name.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 17 -- The topic of the hour here is the appointment of Field Marshal Count von Waldersee as Generalissimo of the allied forces in China, and many are the adverse criticisms which the appointment has evoked throughout Russia.

While one of the soldiers stationed at Fort Wadsworth was walking along the shore yesterday morning he discovered the body of a man lying on the rocks near old Fort Tompkins. The body was that of James Rankine, an expert machinist, who had been employed in Brooklyn, where he was recognized by men from Bay City, Mich., whom he had refused to join in a strike at that place.

The rival factions in the Ninth Assembly District were at rest yesterday after the spirited primary of Tuesday. John C. Sheehan left the city on an early train for Long Branch, where he has a Summer home. Councilman Frank J. Goodwin and Thomas F. Smith, private secretary to Richard Croker, spent the day resting, and it was not until evening that the contestants appeared at their headquarters.

The dispatch from Lord ROBERTS published this morning puts an end to the hope entertained by the British public that BOTHA and his Generals would fight out the last formal battle of the war at Machadodorp, on the Delagoa Bay Railway, a few miles east of Belfast, where, less than a week ago, "Bobs" established his headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- An all-day session of the Cabinet was held to-day to consider the serious diplomatic situation in regard to China.

Our contemporary The Herald is not quite fair to Mr. BRYAN. It sends a correspondent to obtain an expression of his views about silver free coinage, in answer to a set of prepared questions, and on receiving to each and every one of its questions the unvarying answer, "I will discuss public questions in my own way and in my own time," announces that "BRYAN will not talk on silver."

The politicians who will manage William J. Bryan's Eastern campaign came to New York yesterday to open headquarters. The first conference was held in the Hoffman House last evening. There were present ex-Gov. William J. Stone of Missouri, Daniel J. Campau of Michigan, and James D. Richardson of Tennessee.

Daniel Sully, an Irish-American comedian, not without metropolitan fame, began an engagement at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night in a new play written by Daniel L. Hart, a Wilkesbarre journalist, entitled "The Parish Priest." The scene of this domestic drama is laid in the beautiful vale of Wyoming, in Pennsylvania, and the story involved is well within the modesty of nature.
At the all-day Cabinet meeting on Wednesday it was decided that the United States should side with Russia in regard to the policy to be pursued in China.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 30 -- The fifth annual convention of the National Association of Local Fire Insurance Agents met here to-day.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 30 -- On the returns from about 76,000 votes and with about 5,000 to hear from, Gov. MeSweeney leads in the race for Governor by about 3,000 votes over Col. James A. Hoyt, the Prohibitionist candidate. Senator Tillman, with no opposition, returns to the United States Senate.

The hearty, whole-souled way in which the Democracy of New York has turned its back upon W.J. BRYAN in order to give its undivided attention to its own Kilkenny amusements is likely to fill the minds of the managers of the National campaign with concern and apprehension.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The State Department to-day made public the following cablegram from Minister Conger, received this morning through the United States Consul at Chee-Foo:

A report that the Swedish Government is seeking to place a loan of $10,000,000 in this country was confirmed yesterday by Vice President Albert H. Wiggin of the National Park Bank. He would, however, make no more definite statement concerning the matter than this: "We have had inquiry from Europe as to the chances of placing a Swedish loan in this country."

The first results of the work of the committee which held sessions in this city in February last to hear charges brought against employes of the Immigration Bureau, became apparent yesterday when charges against eleven of the employes, were forwarded to the defendants from the Treasury Department in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The combination between Russia and the United States is now accomplished. The two nations are united for the present, and occupy together the position which America formerly occupied alone of planning policies on the Chinese question for the rest of the world. There is no alliance; there is no permanent combination; but there is a temporary combination for the accomplishment of immediate purposses in China.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Pugilism in New York and the Horton law came to an end, to all purposes, last night in Madison Square Garden, when James J. Corbett, in the fifth round of what was to have been a twenty-five-round fight, pounded into unconsciousness Norman Selby, better known to the patrons of the prize ring as "Kid McCoy."

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The "Russo-American surprise," as it is called, is the chief feature of the morning papers. While Russia's part in the proposal is regarded with considerable suspicion, it is generally recognized that the flight of the Empress Dowager and the Emperor renders the situation extremely difficult, and, therefore, that it might be wise to adopt the Russo-American programme as the best solution of the problem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The first authentic and detailed account of the terrible conditions at Peking during the siege reached here to-day. It came through official German channels, and during a call by the German Charge d' Affaires, Baron Speck von Sternburg, on Secretary Root the contents of this interesting document were made known.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- With the selection of officers and the choice of Denver for the National encampment of 1901, the thirty-fourth National encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic practically came to a close to-day. The programme as mapped out by the Reception Committee includes two days more before the veterans are supposed to return to their homes.

Sir THOMAS LIPTON may or may not be something of a wag. If he is, he may easily be suspected of preparing a practical joke on the yachtsmen of this country. Sir THOMAS has offered a handsome cup to be sailed for by the seventy-footers off Sandy Hook. The date selected for this contest is Sept 13.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 30 -- John R. Rogers was nominated to-day for Governor by the Fusionists in union convention. The eighth ballot, which gave him the nomination, stood: Rogers, 704 1/2; Fawcett, 241 1/2; Voorhes, 11; Neil Cheetham, 43; Thurston Daniels, 53. The full ticket nominated is as follows:

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Highland Beach was the scene of an exciting episode to-day. Mrs. Thomas H. Watson, wife of Thomas H. Watson of 462 Broadway, armed with a revolver, attempted to recover possession of her two children, a boy and girl, nine and twelve years old respectively.

Louis Kramer, a fireman attached to Truck 9, and a patient in the convalescent ward at Bellevue Hospital, was married yesterday to Miss Bertha Nussbaum in the Lusk Room, adjoining the convalescent ward.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Ex-Senator John B. Henderson has sent a letter to The Evening Star of this city with regard to the Chinese question. It is in part as follows:

SARATOGA, Aug. 30 -- At to-day's session of the twenty-third annual meeting of the American Bar Association, the annual address was delivered by George R. Peck of Chicago, Ill., who spoke on "The March of the Constitution." He sketched its development and commented at length on the more important decisions.

Unusual activity on the part of the street cleaners was noted in the early morning hours yesterday. It was the day set apart for the fifth annual festival and games of the employes of the Department of Street Cleaning at Sulzer's Harlem River Park, and drivers, sweepers, and hostlers, with the promise of a half holiday if their work was done by noon, were moved to exceptional effort.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Money was much wanted to-day, but the belief that there would be further large arrivals of gold eased discount rates, except for the conclusion of settlement accounts. Business was scarce on the Stock Exchange, but the tone was generally favorable. In home railroads there was renewed inquiry, for most descriptions of stocks, a more hopeful view prevailing in regard to the settlement of the Taff Vale Railroad difficulty.

The whereabouts of the Rev. Dr. David Loynd, who was reported as missing by the officials of the Christian Alliance, is still a mystery. A man of the same name sailed for Europe on Tuesday, Aug. 21, aboard the Cunard liner Servia, but the Rev. Dr. Eben Creighton of Newburg, through whose influence Dr. Loynd came from England to America, says that he was not the same man.

The artificial nature of the advance in quotations on Wednesday and the purely professional tone of the trading were strikingly borne out by the course of the market yesterday. Those stocks which on the previous day had developed most strength were among the weakest of all the securities on the list, declines quite generally appearing in the stead of much-predicted continuing and substantial advances.
PEKING, Aug. 14, by Post, via TIEN-TSIN -- A medal will be struck commemorating the siege of Peking. It will bear the legend, "Men, not walls, make a city."

Henry W. Luckenbach, a well-known piano manufacturer of Williamsburg, who had been in business for many years at 386 Broadway, died early yesterday morning in the German Hospital of injuries he received the day before by falling from a third-story window. He lived at 323 Division Avenue.

Chief Rodenbough of the Bureau of Elections has been accused by the officers of the Bureau of Elections of unfair treatment regarding the selection of polling places for the coming elections. The complainants allege that policemen employed in the work of examining proposed polling places are demanding fees from $5 up, falling the payment of which an adverse report is made.

TABLE ROCK, Wyoming, Aug. 30 -- As a result of the robbery of the New York and Pacific Coast Limited of the Union Pacific last night, four bandits secured $100,000 in currency belonging to the troops of Manila, and since to-day at noon the robbers have been fighting their way fiercely against heavy odds in order to escape with their booty.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 30 -- The Malvern hop, several dinners and luncheons, a barn dance at the Edwards Cottage, and a swimming party at the Pulitzers are among to-day's social doings. The squadrons come next week, society must depart for home the following week, and it seems as if an effort were being made to crowd a season's events into the last few days.
First Lieut. Sidney S. Jordan, Second Artillery, is detailed as a member of the Board of Survey appointed April 29, 1899, vice First Lieut. Arthur S. Conklin, Seventh Artillery, who is relieved.

Ashforth Duryee, in conjunction with D. Phoenix Ingraham Co., have sold for a client a plot of eighteen lots running through from Jerome to Walton Avenue, 75 feet south of One Hundred and Eighty-third Street, having frontages of 250 feet on Jerome Avenue and 200 feet on Walton Avenue.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 30 -- There was racing from 2 o'clock until darkness to-day in connection with the Grand Circuit meeting, and the 2:20 class was carried over until to-morrow because of darkness. The racing was the best of the week, and the attendance broke all records for a Grand Circuit meeting at the track.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- The will of Edward E. Poor has been admitted to probate by Surrogate Pell. It is dated Jan. 19, 1899, and names Mrs. Mary E. Poor, his wife; Peter Reid of Passaic, and William M. Johnson, now Assistant Postmaster General, as executors, without bonds.

Frank L. Perley, manager of Alice Nielsen, has entered into a business partnership with W.G. Smyth, formerly of the theatrical firm of Smyth Rice. The new firm will probably give a number of dramatic productions during the coming season.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 -- This afternoon Miss Leary gave the regular weekly musicale at her cottage, the attendance being larger than usual. The Misses Kieckhoefer, Miss Harriette R. Woods, and Heathe Gregory contributed to an interesting programme.

The work of Acting Captain Joseph Burns and Precinct Detective Harold Lockwood of the Tenderloin, yesterday, developed a new feature in the attempted killing of Harold H. Stridiron by John Essing Monday last in the Hotel Vendome. As a result of work done yesterday the police have found the jewelry of Lillian Hayes, and are looking for a young man well known along Broadway, whose atempt to secure the jewelry gave the voice their clue.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- Willis went to pieces in the tenth inning of to-day's baseball game and allowed the visiting team to make four hits, besides making two errors. This gave New York three runs and the game. Van Haltren played a magnificent game in centre field. The score:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The next visit of Minister Wu-Ting-Fang to the State Department is awaited with considerable interest, and it is believed that when it takes place, on his return to Washington, he will have several questions to ask of Assistant Secretary Alvey A. Adee.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- Thomas J. Powers, Commissioner of Banking for Pennsylvania, was killed by falling from a train in the outskirts of the city last night. His body, badly mangled, was found under the Pennsylvania Railroad bridge spanning the Delaware River at the northern end of this city this morning by three men gunning in the marshes.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- With the exception of Miss Genevieve Hecker, the young Wee Burn golfer who threw such a bombshell into the women's metropolitan ranks two months ago at Morristown, when she won the New York local championship, all of the favorites won today in the second match play round for the highest golf honors in the United States open to feminine players on the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club links.
Chief of Detectives McClusky has taken action in regard to the mysterious assault which David Wertheimer of 182 Avenue A claims to have suffered at the hands of a Central Office detective.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The session of the State Convention of the New York State Retail Liquor Dealers' Association this morning was largely taken up with a discussion of a proposition to make an agreement with the Federation of Labor, whereby the members shall bind themselves to handle only union-made cigars and other goods.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 -- The Rogers brothers produced John J. McNally's new variety farce, called "The Rogers Brothers in Central Park," in this city to-night, under the management of Messrs. Klaw Erlanger, with every sign of success. As a production, scenically speaking, it is as elaborate and handsome as either of its predecessors, while the music, composed and arranged by Maurice Levl, includes a number of taking pieces.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 30 -- Ogden H. Fethers of Janesville, Wis., was to-day elected Supreme Chancellor of the Knights of Pythias. Mr. Fethers had previously served as Supreme Vice Chancellor, and his promotion was in accordance with previous custom as regards the highest office in the order.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Aug. 30 -- The Democratic County Committee to-night announces that United States Senator Wellington will follow Mr. Bryan on Tuesday night at this place in a speech in which he will definitely declare his position in the Presidential fight.

The following statement by Richard Croker has been sent to The New York Journal, and in compliance with Mr. Croker's request, and through the courtesy of The Journal, a proof has been furnished to THE NEW YORK TIMES:...
The Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief received the following cable- gram yesterday from William T. Fee, United States Consul at Bombay:

United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew attended a reception given in his honor by the Republican Club, of which he is the President, last evening, and after receiving hearty congratulations on his return from Europe from the large company of his fellow-members, spoke at considerable length on the campaign.

Trading was intermittent and insignificant in the market for outside securities yesterday. The prospect of three consecutive holidays removed what disposition might otherwise have existed to do business, aud only a few transactions were recorded during the day.

It seems that Prof. Jebb of England has found some good words to say for Macaulay. This will be refreshing to those innocent persons who have persisted in enjoying such things as the impeachment of Warren Hastings and the essay on history in spite of the combined attacks of the allied critics on the once-worshipped writer of sparkling reviews.

THE WAUMBEK, JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 31 -- Twenty-six cards were turned in to-day in the Waumbek Golf Club's men's handicap for the Fisk Cup, and the contest was made very close by the finest kind of handicapping, the limit being twenty-five strokes. Three were tied for first prize, and these will play off to-morrow.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Not belonging to "that weak-minded class of readers" referred to by "Hornet," and yet acknowledging to the frequent sin of "seeing how a book turns out" before I read it properly through, I wish to vindicate my practice.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "Hornet" has stung. May one of the "weak-minded class of readers who begin at the ending and end at the beginning" apply a little salve to the wound and defend rather than deny the crime with which women are charged?

The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
