To the Editor of The New York Times: The Boston Watchman's assumption that two out of three persons finding a pocketbook containing $50 and the owner's name and address would return the money to the owner, together with your albeit somewhat halting indorsement of that position, had filled me with new and higher ideals regarding the honesty of mankind, and American mankind particularly, when I started out upon a cold and material world yesterday afternoon.

Edward Reich, sixty years old, florist, of 103 Hill Street, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, was arrested last night and locked up in the Liberty Avenue Police Station, charged with committing what is expected to prove a fatal assault upon his wife, Margaret, sixty-one years old. Mrs. Reich is in St. Mary's Hospital suffering from a compound fracture of the skull, and is expected to die at any moment.

"The International Brotherhood," which was founded in England in 1807, through the efforts of Miss Skeat, daughter of Prof. Skeat of Oxford, the Chaucer authority, is slowly winning its way, and especially in Manchester, which is now regarded as one of the brotherhood's most influential centres.

The fast freight line of the Lackawanna Railroad yesterday received the first bale of the new cotton crop shipped from Memphis, Tenn., and consigned to B.B. Harvey Co. of Boston, thus winning the honor of carrying the first bale of the new crop, for which there is considerable rivalry every year among the railroads.

Possessor of a direct yet poetic style, that some critics have called Elizabethan, and being an enthusiastic student of the literature of the Elizabethans, Mr. Hamilton W. Mabie may be sure of a large, sympathetic, yet critical audience when his volume "William Shakespeare: Poet, Dramatist, and Man" appears.

The report originated by a London dispatch to the effect that the dominating financial interests of the Southern Pacific, as represented by the Speyer syndicate, had decided to offer the Presidency of that system to the President of one of the large Eastern systems was not received with much credulity by railroad men in this city.
ALICE ENTWISTLE, New York, writes: As an old Californian, I want to correct come of the errors that crept into a note upon our Western literati in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 4.
William J. Bryan's Eastern campaign managers spent a busy and anxious day yesterday trying to decide what is best in the interest of their candidate.

A few additional letters have reached us in the controversy that has been goins on recently among correspondents writing to THE SATURDAY REVIEW concerning the Roycroft books. We are pleased to see that the discussion has extended from our columns to the editorial columns of some of our influential contemporaries in various parts of the country.

Whether this "certain lawyer" was present when "the seventy" returned and heard the words which Jesus then uttered is by no means improbable, but it is not certain. The question which he asked was a question very often discussed by learned rabbis of every school, and he had probably often heard it answered by them with more or less satisfaction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Senator Mason arrived from the West to-day and set at rest all doubt as to his realty to Republicanism. He said: "I am with President McKinley and the Republican Party in this campaign and will take the stump for the ticket. That was settled weeks ago in my talk with President McKinley.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In these days of the commonplace, when the love element in man has been crushed out by the greedy paw of the ultra materialist, it is no huge joke to visit East Aurora and the Roycrofters at their work of making things as well as they can with joy in their hearts and sunshine in their faces.

When the allied forces finally attain Peking and unopposedly enter the capital I venture to prophesy that their astonishment will be great at discovering that the chaos and conflict which have marked the last few weeks has had so little effect on the subordinate machinery of Chinese administration.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- The first large yachting excursion of the cottagers this season took place here this afternoon and this evening.
George Osborne has been engaged to play the part of Prince Engelbert, a blase old diplomat. In "Her Majesty," which is to introduce Grace George in the title role.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- At 12:30 o'clock to-morrow afternoon the wedding of Miss Elsie Clews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clews, to Herbert Parsons of New York, will take place at the Summer home of the bride's parents, known as The Rocks, close to Bailey's Beach. The Rev. Henry Van Dyke of Princeton will officiate, assisted by a local clergyman.

Richard Croker was filled with wrath yesterday and the man servant of the Tammany leader, as well as the attaches of the Democratic Club, wore long faces. A story was published that there was a plan forming to depose Mr. Croker from the leadership of Tammany Hall, backed by John F. Carroll and Mayor Van Wyck.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department to-day mude public the text of the Russian proposal and its own response, as follows:

Louis Weiss of 116 East Tenth Street, was found dead in bed yesterday in his room in the boarding house kept by Adolph Krauslich. He had committed suicide by taking acid. Little was known of Weiss at the house, he having been there only two days. He left a sealed letter that was taken charge of by the Coroner, and an unsealed letter addressed to "My Dear Frances."

Within the past two days official information has been made public on two points in the situation in China of great importance, one the agreement between Russia and our Government in opposition to the treatment of LI-HUNG-CHANG by the Admirals at Taku, the other the policy of the same two Governments as to the withdrawal from Peking and the common objects to be sought there or elsewhere.
Why is it that so many writers neglect to become "authors" and thus deny themselves the honors that always bedeck the brow of the latter class of literary endeavorers?

Singing is a form of music, is it not? and poets, if one does not mistake are called singers. William Morris called himself the "idle singer of an empty day." It would follow, having predicated with logical premises, that the third and irrefutable term of the syllogism would be that poets are musicians and vice versa.

PEKING, Aug. 14, by post, via Tien-Tsin. -- One disadvantage that the Americana bad during the hard march to the relief of Peking was that their transportation wagons were late in arriving The Ninth Infantry possessed the only outfit which reached Tien-Tsin up to the time of starting. The supplies were divided among the soldiers of the Ninth and the Fourteenth Infantry Regiments and the battery.

In recent conflicts between the various factions of the Democratic Party, probably no subject has been more often cited, misconstrued, or misapplied than what is known as Jeffersonian doctrine. One point upon which the contestants have failed to agree is the discrimination that Jefferson made between principle and opinion, between judgment and impression.

"Ha: ha!" will exclaim certain readers of "The Pious Pilgrimage," by the author of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden," which appears in The National Review for August. "I told you so! The fair Elizabeth is not an Englishwoman after all, but a German." But can one be sure that "Elizabeth" is actually giving the public a few delightful pages of autobiography?

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I see that an individual masking as "Hornet" questions whether women are rational creatures. He seems to regard them as monkeylike things, and, I presume, would like to shut them up where they could do no harm.

-- There was more than met the careless eye in a brief dispatch from New Orleans that was printed on the first page of THE TIMES this week. To tell the story again, in the little hamlet of Bateyville, somewhere in Southern Louisiana, one A. GAUTREAUX conducts a store, dealing, doubtless, in the widely diversified merchandise with which such places are usually stocked.

From to-day the house party flourishes. Monday being a holiday, many men will take advantage of it to stop over in the country until Tuesday morning. At nearly all of the resorts there will be many attractions, notably tennis and golf matches, dinners and dances. It is the last day of the woman's championship golf tournament at Shinnecock, and Boston and Philadelphia, represented by Miss Curtis and Miss Griscom, will contend for the championship.
Here are the populations of different cities as disclosed by the census:

An exciting chase occurred between a motor vehicle and a policeman on a bicycle in Fifth Avenue last night. The policeman, George Storer, about 7:35 o'clock was at Thirty-seventh Street when a motor vehicle passed him at great speed.

A brave man and true is John Talman, managing editor of The Pioneer Press of St. Paul. Few managing editors in this work-a-day world of journalism have the time to spend weary nights in defending Poets Laureate, but Mr. Talman can do this to the extent of more than a column -- and his paper keeps coming out just the same.
The note sent to the powers by the United States on Wednesday night was made public yesterday.

As the finale of a thoroughly interesting afternoon's racing on the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. Jockey Tod Sloan, breaking though his determination to do no more riding while in the United States on his present trip, accepted the mount on J.E. Madden's filly Lady Massey, and finished first on her in clever style.
Political leaders in the Borough of Queens were before the Police Board, as the Board of Electlons, yesterday afternoon, vainly endeavoring to solve some knotty problems.

An American in Paris engaged in literary research wrote recently to a friend in New York: "All my days are spent in the Bibliotheque Nationale. I am progressing in my work, it is true, but so slowly. The officials are as polite as possible, but it is the enormous length of time requisite to get a book which is exasperating.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 -- Henry H. putnam of Boston, in an address to-day before the National Association of Local Fire Insurance Agents, discussed the, present condition of the fire insurance business. In the course of his address he said:

For records of book auction sales in Philadelphia, before the Revolution one must rely on Pennsylvania's early papers. The American Weekly Mercury, Keimer's Universal Instructor. Franklin's Pennsylvania Gazette, and The Pennsylvania Journal. The date of the first auction in the Quaker town is still lost in obscurity, though one of the earliest libraries disposed of was probably that of Charles Read, whose books were advertised for in 1737 in the fashion peculiar to those days.

The architect who has been selected to draw the plans for the new Lady Chapel which is to be built at the rear of St. Patrick's Cathedral, has just returned from Europe, and is now working out the details of the structure. The architect was selected by a competition, and plans were received from architects in England, France, Canada, and all parts of the United States.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: None of those who reply to "Hornet's" criticism of those who "skim through" or "scan" a book seem to me to have struck the keynote to the fallacy of the statement that it is a pernicious feminine habit born of the irresistible curiosity inherent in woman.
Senator Platt and other Republicans prominent in party affairs will leave for Saratoga early this afternoon. Chairman Odell will Joint them at the United States Hotel to-night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Chicago has a gas war. The new Municipal Gas Company threw down the gauntlet to-day to the Ogden Company and the Ogden Company responded by saying it would fight to the last ditch. General Manager W.P. Martin of the Municipal Gas Company made the announcement that the company had already started selling gas throughout the North Side territory at 60 cents a thousand feet net.

VINELAND, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Jealousy over the appointment of Joseph Spencer as Borough Marshal led to a fight between him and Capt. Samuel Creech, a former Marshal and Mr. Spencer's rival for the recent appointment. The affair came off last night, and might have come under the heading of a prizefight.

The phrase "world literature" was an invention of Goethe. His own hope that he might produce some work of literary art fit to be so classified was unquestionably realized. Goethe is ranked with Homer and Dante, and one feels inclined to place Shakespeare in that company, if not at the head of it.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- There was a fair demand to-day for copper shares and good gains, but the movement was confined to a few stocks -- Osceola, Isle Royale, and Utah leading. Osceola was up 1 1/4, at 69 1/4; Royale rose 1 1/8, to 30 7/8; Utah gained 3/4, to 31 3/4. All of these gains were sustained. Wolverine rose 1/2, to 41 1/2.

Both Kennedy and Bernhardt were retired in the second inning yesterday for giving too many free passes in the Brooklyn-Philadelphia game at Washington Park, Brooklyn. Kennedy gave six of them in one inning, forcing two runners across the plate. An error by Dahlen let in two more. Howell was hit hard in the third, but settled down after that.

WOODBURY, N.J., Aug. 31 -- A feud between farmers over a country road has resulted in Herbert Clement having been shot and his left cheek torn and jaw broken. The wound will in all probability end his life, and Daniel Bettle, the would-be murderer, is dead in the Woodbury Jail, a suicide.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- The thirty-footers raced in pairs this afternoon for a handsome cup offered by Mrs. Herman B. Duryea for the championship of the fleet. The Wa-Wa and Hera were started from Brenton's Reef Lightship and sailed around the southerly mark used in the races of seventy-footers.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The following dispatch has been received at the War Office from Lord Roberts:

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Money was much wanted to-day, but the expectation of more abundant money next week eased the discount rates. The anxiety lelt in regard to the future course of the money market has been considerably relieved by the large arrivals of gold, raising the bank's reserve by nearly five millions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin has written a letter to Senator Sewell of New Jersey, a member of the Military Committee of the Senate, setting forth in definite terms the attitude of the War Department on the question of the army canteen. The letter, which was written Aug. 28, and was made public to-day, is as follows:

The entries for the Grand Circuit trotting and pacing races to be held at the Empire City track Sept. 10 to 15, inclusive, are all in. The fields as a rule are of high class, with quality as well as quantity represented. The entries follow:

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 31 -- The committee of seven appointed by the general passenger agents of twenty-one roads, now assembled here, are not yet ready to report. The party met twice to-day, and at each meeting the committee asked for further time in which to draft an outline for the now trans-continental organization and to present an outline of the details under which the association should be conducted.

We print in another column some interesting extracts from an unpublished work by James Fenimore Cooper. The title is given by our correspondent, Mr. Keese, as "The Men of Manhattan," though in the painstaking biography of Prof. Lounsbury it is given as "The Towns of Manhattan."
"The Life and Time of Cardinal Wiseman." by Wilfrid Ward, will shortly be published in a new and cheaper edition of two volumes by Longmans, Green Co. The work will contain three portraits.

A new book by William Loring Andrews always finds its audience as soon as published. The present small volume of about forty pages may be regarded as a supplementary chapter to an earlier book, "The Bradford Map," which was published in 1893. As is always the case in the Andrews books, we find in this volume an almost complete perfection of mechanical detail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Only two replies have as yet been received to the Russo-American proposition for the restoration of peace in China. One was from the British Foreign Office, through the American Embassy in London, stating that Lord Salisbury was absent from London, and merely promising consideration for the note.

Pease Elliman have sold for Charles Buek to Frederick O. Beach, for about $54,000, the new five-story American basement dwelling 51 East Forty-ninth Street, 21 by 60 by 100. Mr. Buek has also sold the five-story American basement dwelling 316 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, 20 by 58 by 100.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- John Hammond, known as "John the Barefoot Burglar," who committed suicide at White Plains last Wednesday, was arrested by Detective Sergeant Christie in this city three years ago for stealing $1,300 worth of jewelry from Lillian Blauvelt, an actress.

Judge Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, yesterday confirmed the report of Augustus Brown, as referee, in the action brought by Mary J. Westervelt and Flora E. Rogers against Thomas E. Rogers and William Cauldwell, as trustees of the estate of Jason Rogers, manufacturer of locomotives.

The St. Paul of the American Line was warped into her dock last night at 11 o'clock, after the fastest and one of the most pleasant voyages in her history. Those aboard of her were treated to the rare spectacle of a race between ocean liners, and the interest was so great that none slept on the St. Paul Thursday night or Friday morning until dawn.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 31 -- The wars of the past few years have made the live stock market of New Orleans a lively one, and small fortunes have been made by those who "got in on the ground floor." This city is the natural distributing point for Cuba and Porto Rico and the Transvaal, and besides, the American animal has field qualities found in the horse and mule of no other country.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- The second annual meeting of the Revision Committee of the League of American Wheelmen was held here to-day, when various by-laws of the league were brought up to be revised, after which they will be submitted to the National Assembly, when the revised laws shall be acted on.

John M. Letsche of 122 Danforth Avenue showed the Jersey City health authorities an interesting little experiment in hypnotism yesterday. Mr. Letsche also has a theory in regard to the use of hypnotic suggestion in the training of children, which he seems to have applied to his own four hopefuls with good results.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I find in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 4 a very interesting article (taking up again the topic first discussed in a SATURDAY REVIEW editorial of July 21) on the question raised by Mr. Andrew Lang, whether writers, as a rule, care for music, as to which I should like, with your permission, to say a few words.

F. Marion Crawford, who has divided his time during the Summer between the baths of Lucca and Amalfi, will probably return to this country before the middle of the month. He is very anxious to be present at the opening night of his play, "In the Palace of the King," which will be presented in Washington, Sept. 24.

From The Indianapolis Press. In three parallel columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, three correspondents give three very different estimates of the work of Mr. Albert Hubbard and the Roycrofters. Mr. Hubbard has some very attractive qualities of literary style. He writes with a stub pen, and draws marks under his words.

Edward Brandon, a broker, and one of the oldest members of the New York Stock Exchange, who lives in Soho, N.J., and whose office is at 34 New Street, filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States District Court yesterday. The schedules show liabilities of $58,331.51, and assets, $35,065.

New interest was added to Democratic politics in Brooklyn last night by the return of ex-Rcgister Hugb McLaughlin, the Kings County leader, from South Jamesporl. I.I., where he spent the Summer. Mr. McLuughlin reached Brooklyn at 6:30 o'clock. He was accompanied by Mrs. McLaughlin.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- In the absence of further news from China the papers are again filled with discussions of the Russo-American proposals, which, so far as may be gathered from the representations of opinions in various European capitals, are calculated to subject the unity of the allies to an exceedingly severe and dangerous test.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The supporters of the Administration of President McKinley have treated the opposition of the so-called anti-imperialists as a matter of policy only, and have held up to them the evils likely to result from the election of Bryan as a reason why they should discontinue such opposition and aid in the re-election of the President.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 31 -- Capt. Grendahl telegraphs the following message here from Skjervoe, Norway:-
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- William V. Graham of 71 East Eighty-sixth Street, Manhattan, was found dying at midnight last night in front of the New York Infant Asylum here.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Never in a championship golf tournament in this country have two such spirited and nerve-racking finishes been seen in a semi-final day as was the case to-day at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, when the National competition for women was brought to the final round.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In his delightful "retrospect" of Lowell in the September Scribner Mr. Howells writes of "The Cathedral" that Lowell's friends objected to "some humorous lines, which seemed to them too great a drop from the higher moods of the piece," but that "he could not change his lines, and they stand as he first wrote them."

When the thought of "better books," in an intellectual sense, has been presented to the mind of general readers, by an association of influential men, formed to promote the buying and selling of such, the term suggests also a betterness in books in a material sense, in which there is scarcely less need for some slight agitation.

We were pointing out the other day that what continues to call itself the manly art of self-defense has become neither manly nor an art, but has been reduced to the elemental brutality of "slugging." It must be admitted that the last conspicuous contest to occur before the expiration of the permission to prizefighting extended by the Horton law did more to redeem the reputation of the prize ring than almost any previous contest.

More or less well-meaning persons in various parts of the State are making plans to nominate Controller COLER as an independent candidate for Governor if Tammany succeeds in preventing his nomination by the regular party convention at Saratoga.

To any one not domestically related to either Philadelphia or Boston it matters little which of the fair contestants in the final round of the women's golf championship wins to-day. Lovers of the gentle sport of the green have found much to delight them in the features of the contest, and in the issue the chief cause for satisfaction is that the honor goes to one who has not held it before.

A new political economy from a strong and authoritative hand would be welcome at the end of this century in which so many books on that subject have been published. It is time that it were written. It is two generations since J.S. Mill began to write on the production and distribution of wealth.

All in all, the developments in trade circles during the week have been such as to warrant the belief that the turn of the tide toward continuing improvement has actually begun. It is true that the demand for money for commercial purposes continues small, suggesting nothing so much as stagnant business.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly let me know through the columns of your paper why you invariably refer to Mr. Bird S. Coler as "Controller" Coler?

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to two articles that have appeared in THE TIMES on the missionaries, and especially with reference to what "J. F.M." has to say, permit me a few words:

There is on exhibition at the Paris Exposition a recording telephone known as the telegraphone, which is based on an entirely new principle, and which, although it is not yet perfected, promises to eventually prove a valuable addition to the present methods of long-distance communication.

Another burglary has been added to the number of those which alarmed the neighborhood of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street during the last few weeks. It was discovered yesterday that the four-story brownstone residence of Mrs. Elizabeth Campbell, at 2,152 Fifth Avenue had been completely ransacked by burglars, presumably on Friday night.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- The German press is full of articles commenting on the latest turn of the China question, which is generally construed as marking the beginning of serious discord between the powers, whose interests are colliding at too many points to enable them to maintain a united front for long.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 4 -- The colonies, in vulgar parlance, have "got their backs up" over the new line of steamers between San Francisco and Australia because they are owned and manned by citizens of the United States, and the colonial shipping companies are complaining of the American shipping laws, which prevent them from competing in the trade between Honolulu and San Francisco.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in THE TIMES signed "F.M. W." recalls a story told me by Dr. Brewster, the predecessor of Dr. Evans. Brewster came to Paris from Connecticut in the thirties, and soon became very distinguished in his profession. He was not only a dentist in the usual acceptation, but combined mechanical ability in his profession then little known.

"Who is the strongest man in town?" asked a correspondent at Belfast of some workmen at noontime. "No one knows," was the reply. A farmer, a stableman, and a milkman came along and the conversation became general.

The Knickerbocker Telephone and Telegraph Company, recently incorporated under the laws of the State of New York, filed yesterday a mortgage for $5,000,000 on all of its property, franchises, and telegraph and telephone lines in this city and elsewhere that have been constructed or are to be completed.

Fine linen is as great a delight to the housewife now as it was in the days when she spun and wove it herself. Women who have plenty of money to spend have days when they treat themselves to a feast of fine linen, and they go then to the shops and invest in a goodly quantity, $100, $200, and sometimes $300 worth of it at a time.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 1 -- A new steam yacht, about 150 feet in length, and with a speed of 28 knots, it is said, will be constructed here for August Belmont next Winter. If Mr. Belmont is elected Commodore of the New York Yacht Club next season, and the boat referred to is constructed, it will be the fastest flagship afloat, Mr. Belmont has been in Bristol several times recently to consult about the boat.

A Parliamentary paper has been issued containing a correspondence relating to preventive inoculation against cholera and typhoid in India. Dealing first with the correspondence on the anti-cholera inoculations, we observe that it consists of extracts from the Sanitary Commissioner's reports for 1896, 1897, and 1898.

The next time that Mrs. Mary McCluge of Eighteenth Street, near Eighth Avenue, goes to Rockaway Beach for an outing she will probably avoid the Canarsie route. There are hospitable folk at Canarsie, and it is usually a long time between boats to Rockaway from there.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Gen. Elwell S. Otis said to-day that affairs are progressing favorably in the Philippines.

NEWPORT, Sept. 1 -- Miss Elsie Worthington Clews, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clews, was united in marriage to Herbert Parsons of New York, at 12:30 to-day. The ceremony was performed in the Clews Summer home, The Rocks.

Better racing weather than that which yesterday favored the Autumn regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club has not been welcomed this season by yachtsmen along the Sound. A brisk easterly breeze blew steadily from the start to an early finish, and sent the racers spanking over long ground swells.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The presence of 200,000 additional persons in Chicago might not be particularly noticed if these persons had come to work or stay at home. But 200,000 sightseers -- all desirous of seeing the same things -- have congested Chicago greatly this past week. Perhaps the streets have never been so full.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Perry M. de Leon, Consul General in Ecuador, has sent in a report giving some interesting particulars regarding the manufacture of the Manavi, or Panama, hat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Gov. Brady of Alaska, in a letter to Secretary Hitchcock, dated St. Michael, Alaska, Aug. 3, describes the distress in Alaska, which the Government is now taking steps to alleviate. Gov. Brady says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have every reason to feel that the saddening and discouraging effect of the recent race riots in New York City upon colored citizens throughout the South is inexpressible, while it stimulates the Southern whites to renewed boastfulness and triumph.

The first Sunday of September, with its following holiday of Labor Day, has come to be reminiscent of all Sundays that bring a Monday holiday in their train. Then do men abandon their city clubs for those of the country, and New York and its fashionable districts is "a banquet hall deserted."
The Russian note to the powers of Aug. 25 was made public in St. Petersburg yesterday.

The English turfman's contempt for time is a measure of merit in judging the performances of race horses has been modified somewhat since the American horseman John Huggins, training "by the watch" on English race courses, has taken a place among the foremost of the trainers in Engand.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 1 -- The Horse Show that will be held on Monday by the Rockaway Hunt Club at its spacious grounds at Cedarhurst, has attracted much attention from the club members and their friends. The entries in all the ten classes, which are large, will be announced on Monday morning.

President John K. Cilley of the Ninth National Bank has sold about 3,600 shares of his holdings in the stock of that bank to Vice President Charles H. Imhoff, in accordance with a plan by which it is likely that Alvah Trowbridge, now President of the North American Trust Company, will be chosen this Fall to succeed Mr. Cilley as President of the Ninth National.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial this morning entitled "Mr. Bryan on Coinage" you discuss at some length one of the numerous shifty and glittering queries of the Democratic candidate. It is his propensity for indulging in such remarks that stamps him the demagogue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The profound thought of M. Franklin in your estimable issue of the 23d inst. deserves consideration. I refer to his statement: "Imperialism is a system. *** The system or the theory of a system necessarily precedes the individual who performs it."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why would it not be good taste and good sense to reserve the names of our sovereign States for first-class battleships like the Oregon and Alabama? There is fitness in all things, and since first-class battleships take precedence over all other ships, they alone should be permitted the honor of bearing the great names of the States and Territories.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- We always expect something unusual in the way of crime from Paris, and are seldom disappointed from one week's end to another.

LENOX, Sept. 1 -- The cottagers are returning from the various seaside resorts and from the Adirondacks. William D. Sloane and family came down from the Thousand Islands and the Adirondacks this week, and are now at Elm Court. Both their married daughters, Mrs. Burden and Mrs. Hammond, are with them.

Another record has been made by the Hamburg-American Line flagship Deutschland. She arrived here early yesterday morning, having made the voyage from Cherbourg, a distance of 3,050 knots, in 5 days 12 hours and 29 minutes. This beats the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse's best westward record, made on Nov. 15 of last year, by 4 hours and 58 minutes.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 1 -- The ninth annual meeting of the New Jersey State Rifle Association was continued to-day. The principal event was the contest for the Wimbledon Cup, valued at $500. This prize was presented by the National Rifle Association of Great Britain to the National Rifle Association of America, and is competed for every Fall.

The statement of the effect of the canteen, as part of the post exchange in the army, made public by the Adjutant General is of the highest interest. It is also of the highest importance. The curse of intemperance is even more formidable in military than in civil life. Nothing could be more desirable than the discovery and application of the most efficient means for reducing it to a minimum.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter of the 27th inst., published in your journal, Mr. M.T. Richardson says:

In our English service the system adopted for replenishing the ammunition of the troops engaged has consisted in selecting a certain number of men to carry cartridges from the rear up to the firing line, it having been apparently supposed that it would be possible for these men to move along the line and to distribute ammunition to those whose pouches were empty.

Mr. CHADWICK must be aware that we have no "warrant," Republican or other, for the expression of opinions as to the purposes of the United States Government or of the gentlemen now in control of it, to which he is not entitled as much as we. We try to base our opinions on careful and candid consideration of facts as accurately ascertained as is practicable, as we doubt not he does.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Col. Asa Bird Gardiner collapsed in Montreal last night while on his way to this city to attend the hearing scheduled to take place to-day before Gov. Roosevelt in the matter of the charges preferred against him by the City Club of New York City. Col. Gardiner had been at Lake Rideau, Canada, to recuperate.

New rules have been adopted by the New Amsterdam and Consolidated Gas Companies since the ending of the gas rate war, and the raising of the price of gas from 65 cents per 1,000 cubic feet to $1.05. Some of these rules have aroused indignation in Harlem.

NEWPORT, Sept. 1 -- All is ready for the fourth exhibition of the Newport Horse Show, which begins at the Casino Monday afternoon. The stands and general appointments have been improved since last Summer, and the place presents a pretty picture. A number of new features will be introduced.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 1 -- Vice Chairman Edmisten and Secretary Edgerton of the Populist National Committee have issued an address appealing for support for William J. Bryan. The address in part says:

-- Every once in a while somebody attempts with varying success to create a sensation by declaring that strayed electrical currents are working day and night on the Brooklyn Bridge and its anchors, and that in time they will bring that impressive structure and the load of passengers it happens to be carrying at the fatal moment down with an eminently unpleasant combination of splash and crash.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest what you have published concerning Christian missions in non-Christian countries, especially in China. Of course, a daily newspaper cannot be much concerned about Christian missions or religion of any kind, except as the State may be affected thereby.

Here, on the west side of Mboga, I staid for three weeks hunting elephants, my best tusks being 98 pounds and 86 pounds; these, curiously enough, were obtained the same day from two single-tusked elephants, one being a right tusk and the other a left, and each measured 7 feet 10 inches.

MACON, Ga., Sept. 1 -- Bishop Warren A. Chandler passed through this city yesterday. He was asked: "What will be the attitude of the church toward the Chinese missions in view of the present troubles in China?"

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 1 -- For more than twelve hours the representatives of the railroads who are here to form a transcontinental association have been discussing one question which threatens to undo all the work accomplished by the special committee.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 1 -- The Official Messenger to-day publishes the text of the circular addressed to the Russian representatives abroad, dated Aug. 25, the gist of which, as shown by the correspondence issued yesterday at Washington, the Russian Charge d'Affaires communicated to Acting Secretary Adee on Monday.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Sept. 1 -- The season is rapidly drawing to a close here, though for this period of the Summer it is holding out remarkably well. The Rockingham will remain open until Sept. 15, while the Imperial will keep open until Oct. 1.

There is a young man of Gotham who has a white elephant on his hands. An obliging friend lent him a small sailboat with a fin keel, which causes her to draw about six feet of water. He was so overjoyed at having the use of this craft, which is a pretty fast one, that the matter of draught did not trouble him at first.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 1 -- A late season is now a certainty. The American squadron is expected to arrive to-morrow and the British fleet, under Admiral Bedford, on Tuesday. They will remain for a week or longer, so that people who in other years are leaving at this date have been tempted to remain to enjoy the visit of the squadrons.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Not until the principles of the Democratic Party were recast by the Chicago Convention was it ever heard that paternalism and democracy are compatible doctrines.

That very essential element in the revivifying of the real estate market, namely, getting the market back in town, will undoubtedly begin to make its influence felt within the next week or two. To-morrow's holiday has come to be regarded as the dividing line between Summer and Fall, and as marking the end of the period during which larger investors and operators in real estate practically abandon their business.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1. -- John A. Moffett, President of the United Hatters of North America, announced to-day that on and after Tuesday next the big hat factory conducted by Fred Berg Co. would be operated exclusively by union men. The fight against the Bergs continued for ten months.

One or the special correspondents in Peking told the world a few days ago what to us at least, was new, that the Emperors of China are relieved of some of their burdon of representation by doubles trained to perform the part. Servants of the palace, carefully picked, and possibly, it may be, related in an illegitimate way to the dynasty, are carefully told what to do, and on ceremonial occasions represent the Emperor.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 1 -- It is understood from various sources that the new seventy-footers will be taken to Bristol late in the Fall and hauled out one at a time on the marine railway to have a greater amount of stiffening and otherwise put in shape. In order that the boats may not be strained from stem to stern and from keel to rail when racing in sharp seas.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- Nine singles, a double, and one error in the third and fourth innings of to-day's baseball game netted the Boston's ten runs. Umpire Swartwood had a lame shoulder and retired at the end of the fifth inning. Freeman and Carrick finished the game. The score:

LONDON, Sept 2 -- The Foreign Office here is apparently not yet ready to publicly declare Great Britain's position in the present Chinese situation, but it is believed that Lord Salisbury favors the principle contained in the American-Russian proposals, though possibly he may have some modifications to suggest.

HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- Not long ago I saw an oil painting of a man in such a grotesque costume that my attention was attracted to it. It hung in the "den" of a wealthy man, and, although surrounded by other paintings very much more noticeable as works of art, this was the picture that caught and held the eye, and which the owner valued most as a curiosity.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Gov. Roosevelt has appointed James A. Blanchard of New York City a Justice of the Supreme Court in place of Justice Smyth, deceased. In announcing the appointment, Gov. Roosevelt stated that he had first offered the Judgeship to Charles C. Beaman, and then to Henry Taft, both of whom were unable to accept because of their obligations to their clients'and law partners.

The awards of the Grand Juries are being distributed by the President of the French Republic and M. Millerand, Minister of Commerce, in the Salle des Fetes of the Champ de Mars, as this issue goes to press. The hall has been beautifully and tastefully decorated for the ceremonial.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your leading editorial of the 21st inst. you state that imperialism implies an Emperor, and strive to quell the fears of antiimperialists by calling attention to the undeniable fact that William McKinley is not of the stuff of which Emperors are made.

Ex-Gov. Horace Boies of Iowa says he will vote for Bryan if no sound-money, anti-imperialist Presidential ticket is put in the field. "Mr. Bryan," he says, "will have my vote, not because of his financial views, but in spite of them."

SIMLA, Aug. 2 -- There is as yet no abatement of the famine in India. Indeed, until the last day or two, things looked gloomier in a large portion of Western India than at any period since the failure of the monsoon a year ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By way of introduction, I would say I have been a reader of THE TIMES for thirty years, not always agreeing with its politics, but knowing its value as a clean paper, fit to be read by every one. Therefore I venture to present my views on the present political situation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Gen. Chaffee was instructed to hold himself in readiness to withdraw from Peking before the Russian proposition was made to the United States. Action of the kind taken by Russia was anticipated. It is believed that the United States Government was aware of Russia's intentions before the formal notification was made by M. de Wollant.

SARATOGA, Sept. 1 -- The Republican clans are gathering and politicians are very much in evidence at the big hotels. Senator Platt, Chairman Odell, Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, Executive Chairman William Barnes, National Committeeman Frederick S. Gibbs, Secretary Reuben L. Fox, Dwight Lawrence, Archie Baxter, Clerk of the Assembly; Col. M.J. Dady, Lemuel E. Quigg, William Berri, Senator Horace White, James Whipple, and others are at the United States.

The State rifle team to represent New York at the Sea Girt rifle meeting the present week will take up its headquarters at Sea Girt to-day at the Beach House. It is one of the most promising teams ever selected from the Guard, and its organization by Col. N.B. Thurston could not have been better planned.

FIGHTING HAILSTORMS. -- J.C. Covert, United States Consul at Lyons, writes that a concerted effort is being made by the surrounding vineyard owners to prevent the ruinous hailstorms which frequently destroy whole crops in a few minutes. Fifty-two cannon have been distributed over an area of 2,500 acres.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 4 -- Intense excitement has been caused throughout New Zealand by an all-night debate in Parliament upon an article contributed by G.J. Grattan Grey to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published in its issue of Nov. 26 last In that article, which was written on Oct, 27, Mr. Grey condemned the South African war and the sending of troops from the Australasian colonies to fight against then Boers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "I shall convene Congress in extraordinary session as soon as I am inaugurated, and recommend an immediate declaration of the Nation's purpose:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1 -- Several parties of "chicken" and quail hunters who go to the stubble fields in private cars, with all of the comforts of home, have passed through St. Paul during the week, impatient to be on the ground at the opening of the season, and, perchance, get in a few shots before the season actually opens.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan had a conference with exSenator Hill to-day. No announcements were made relative to what passed between them.

Base hits that were so swift and clean that they lacerated the air and errors that were ludicrously bad were scattered throughout yesterday's Amateur League baseball game, at Bergen Point, in wholesale profusion. The contending teams were those of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club and Montclair Athletic Club.

A cobra when thoroughly roused to anger is by no means a gentle creature. * * * He was now a most formidable beast to approach, striking out desperately at every movable thing within and even out of his reach. But even in this condition Kullan had no difficulty in seizing the largest of cobras.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 1 -- Features of to-day's session of the National Association of Local Fire Insurance Agents were the reports of the resolutions and Nominating Committees.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1 -- This afternoon four of the thirty-footers raced in pairs for a cup offered by Mrs. Herman B. Duryea. The wind at the start was a good sailing breeze, but before the race concluded the wind was very light from the southwest. Summaries:

It is only with the arrival of Turkish Governors in the middle of the ninth century that architecture can be said to have begun, in Muslim Egypt, with the Mosque of Ibn-Tulun. This remarkable man's father was a slave from Bokhara in the body-guard of the Caliph of Bagdad. It was the way most Governors began.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- According to reports from Shanghai, Great Britain has furnished to Liu-Kun-Yih, the Viceroy of Nanking, and Chang-Chih-Tung, Viceroy of HanKow, strong guarantees against the reported intention of the Dowager Empress to supersede them on account of their alleged pro-foreign tendencies.

The stock market developed few new features last week, a fact that is in no sense surprising in view of the limited trading and the professional tone dominating. Transactions for the week were little in excess of a full day's trading at an ordinarily active period, and, as in lately preceding weeks, a few manipulated specialties engaged the lion's share of attention, furnishing from day to day the little life that the market displayed.

Two games for one price of admission is the inducement offered by the New York Baseball Club to attract a large crowd to the Polo Grounds to-morrow. The first game will be called at 1:45 P.M. and the second at 4 o'clock. On Tuesday afternoon the two-game programme will be repeated, and on Wednesday the postponed game with Cincinnati will be called at 4 o'clock.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1 -- The law for the prevention and suppression of forest and prairie fires has been in operation five years, and the fifth annual report of the Chief Fire Warden, Gen. C.C. Andrews, being for the year 1899, has just been published. The number of forest fires reported for 1899 is only 10; acres burned over, 3,635; damage, $1,541; number of prairie fires, 34; acres burned over, 24,616; damagre, $4,856.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 17 -- Count Lamsdorff will certainly not find his new position as Foreign Minister a sinecure. The questions which he will be called upon to solve are by far the most intricate of any which a Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs has handled during the past twenty years.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1 -- Everything points to a late season here. The season of entertaining and entertainment began later than usual, the late arrival from abroad of many Newporters being responsible for this. Cards are out for many functions during September.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Complete official returns for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1900, show that 1,446 vessels, of 393,168 gross tons, were built and documented in the United States. Since 1856 this record has been exceeded only twice -- in 1864, when 415,740 gross tons were built, and in 1874, when 432,725 gross tons were built.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 1 -- The estimate of the Minister of Agriculture, Dr. Ignatius de Daranyi, of the world's crops shows that the Hungarian crops have improved since the statement of July 31. The quality of wheat has improved owing to the favorable weather while the grain was ripening and during its harvest.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Much money changed hands in the market to-day. New issues of capital, aggregating nearly two millions, had to be met, besides two and a half millions of interest and dividends distributed.
Mr. Bryan's campaign managers have lad the Gubernatorial situation in New York partly unloaded on their shoulders.

This week, which may fairly be accounted the first of the theatrical term of 1900-1, will be one of the busiest and probably one of the most prosperous of the season. The crowds of visitors from out of town make September theatricals profitable, whether the temperature is high or low. The promise of the new plays thus far is good.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- One of the biggest deals in assessment life insurance ever consummated was closed to-day by the consolidation of the Northwestern Life Assurance Company of Chicago with the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- In the four years that have passed since the last Presidential campaign there has been an enormous increase in the number of men employed by the railroads of the country, likewise a great increase in the wages paid. Two representative roads present the following:
Mrs. J. Priestley Gobbin ruffled herself with all the dignity of indignant silk and defiant diamonds into the private office of Silk, Ruffles Lace Brothers' big department store.

A poorly dressed woman who described herself as Mrs. Margaret Moore, twenty-two years old, of 20 Cottage Place, and who carried a two-year-old child in her arms, called at Police Headquarters last night, and wanted to tell Sergt. Carey of the Detective Bureau all about the Scharn murder mystery.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- A case involving a charge of abduction was before County Judge Smith Lent here to-day. Frederick Oberfell applied for a writ of habeas corpus, alleging that Rosa Oberfell, sixteen years old, and Anna Oberfell, fifteen years, are now imprisoned and restrained of their liberty by the Mother Superior, or some other person, in charge of the Nazareth Industrial School, a Lutheran institution, in the village of Bronxville, Westchester County.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Preparations are being made at Norwood Park for the second annual Horse Show. Since the return home of Miss Norma L. Munro from Europe she has full charge of the affair, which will take place Sept. 8. The programme has just been given out and is as follows: Class 1 -- Judging ponies in harness.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City Banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $3,189,550. The banks now hold a surplus of $27,078,475 above the legal requirements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- If Mr. Bryan of 1900 will not answer the direct question put to him by the representative of a New York newspaper as to whether he would, if elected, direct his Secretary of the Treasury to meet Government coin obligations by silver payments, Mr. Bryan of 1895, by The Record, will do unequivocally," said Representative Loudenslager, who is in charge of the Eastern Headquarters of the Republican Congressional Committee.

QUEBEC, Sept. 1 -- The annual international golf match between the United States and Canada was decided here today on the Quebec links, resulting in a victory for the players from over the border by five holes up. The match throughout was most interesting, and was followed by a very large number of spectators, including a number of American visitors who had several opportunities of applauding the fine shots made by their countrymen.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A tangible result of the recent visit to Mrs. Florence Maybrick at Aylesbury Prison of Dr. Clark Bell, of New York, the prisoner's counsel, was the discovery of a hitherto unknown letter from the late Baron Russell of Killowen, Lord Chief Justice of England, to Mrs. Maybrick, reaffirming his belief in his client's innocence and vigorously declaring his conviction that she had been unfairly condemned.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 1 -- Bar Harbor continued its exciting whirl of social events to-day. With the arrival of the North Atlantic Squadron to-morrow and the arrival of the British Squadron on Tuesday, everything will give way to entertaining the officers.

VIENNA, Aug. 24 -- The number of technical schools in this country is considerable, and it is at least equaled by their excellence: the training they afford is very good. Naturally, not all of them are of the same grade, but some can boast of a very comprehensive curriculum, as is the case with the Lehranstalt fur Textilindustrie at Bruenn, which, like almost all the good educational establishments in Austria, is a State institution.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- American "coal kings" and their agents are apparently swarming to England, and rumors of many important deals filled the air during the past week. W.P. Rend of Chicago is here on his way to Paris. He is hopeful of supplying both the French and Russian Navies with steam coal from West Virginia.

Hugh McLaughlin and Controller Coler held an important conference yesterday. Politics was talked of for an hour. The place of meeting was Hugh McLaughlin's residence on Remsen Street, Brooklyn, after the veteran leader had completed his morning talks with politicians.

A young man wearing a seersucker coat and with big beads of perspiration on his face, came into the smoking car of an Erie Railway train as it was getting along toward the meadows of Orange County the other day. He was the express messenger.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- "Jimmy" Michael to-day regained the middle-distance cycling championship by defeating "Johnny" Nelson in a twenty-five-mile motor-paced race on the Woodside Park track. Michael finished about a quarter of a lap ahead of Nelson in 39:16, breaking the world's record of 39:45, made by Nelson on the same track about two weeks ago.

The Milky Way now passes at 9 P.M., directly overhead. In or along it are the constellations Scorpio, Sagittarius, Ophiuchus, the Eagle, the Dolphin, the Swan, Cepheus, Cassiopeia, and Perseus. The Scorpion can be located by means of its bright, ruddy star Antares, now nearing the horizon in the southwest.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- A delegation from the Saengerbund, consisting of Messrs. S.K. Saenger, A. Claassen, and Otto Wissner, as guests of the Emperor, were present at the military tattoo this evening. After the parade the delegation was presented to his Majesty, Mr. Saenger making a brief formal address, in which he thanked the Emperor for the prize he gave at the National Saengerfest held in July.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 1 -- David Rumsey, a well-known and prosperous farmer of Hempstead, after many unsuccessful ventures in the matrimonial line, has at last begun to realize that the course of true love never runs smooth. Some weeks ago Mr. Rumsey proposed marriage to an attractive widow, Mrs. Sturm, of New York, whom he had engaged as a housekeeper.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning your clever writer of "Topics of the Times" makes reference to a dispatch from New York to The London Telegraph, wherein it is asserted that "tipping has become a fixed custom in this city." This correspondent of the London paper further says: "Tip the waiter or lose his respect.

ASBURY PARK, Sept. 1 -- The twin cities are crowded to-night with pleasure seekers. Thousands arrived during the week, and while the departures have been many, tonight's crowd on the board walk and at the amusement resorts outnumbers by far the usual mid-July throng. A number of the hotelkeepers announce that their houses will be kept open until Oct. 1.

CHILDWOLD PARK, Sept. 1 -- The gayety here continues with unabated zest. Mrs. Jesse Rosenberg and Mrs. D. Hecht of New York gave a musical tea and dance in the Casino on Saturday afternoon, at which a number of young girls from New York and Philadelphia were dressed in white frocks and aprons as waitresses.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Monday, Aug. 27, you publish a communication by M.T. Richardson, which states that the doctrine that "all men are created equal" is a "stupendous fallacy." Your correspondent then goes on to show that men differ both in mental capacity and physical strength, and are therefore not equal.

The American Theatre, renovated and partly redecorated, was opened for the new season last evening under the management of Henry Greenwall, who has been very successful in the direction of popular theatricals "on the road." A stock company, organized somewhat on the old "lines," wiil be maintained there, and after the run of the present play, "The Great Ruby," it is the manager's intention to change the bill every week.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Miss Frances C. Griscom of Philadelphia won her title to-day to be known during the coming year as the woman golf champion of the United States. She defeated in the grand final struggle on the Shinnecock Hills Club links her younger opponent. Miss Margaret Curtis of Boston by 6 up and 4 to play.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 1 -- Last Winter there were built at the consolidated shipyards of the great lakes, between this city and Cleveland, twenty-three large freight ships of steel of a carrying capacity of 143,000 gross tons, and costing $6,800,000. With the exception of five these ships were built to the order of the great steel and iron consolidations of the lakes, who were anxious to carry their own freight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have the Yellow Peril in far-off China and the Black Peril in some of our own Southern States, and now we are confronted with what, for want of a more distinctive designation, I will call the new political peril, right here in the State of New York.

The annual gymnastic tournament of the public playgrounds attached to the city schools, which was concluded last week at the Crotona Park open-air gymnasium, served to call attention to an important but little-known feature of the city's educational system. There are twenty-nine of these playgrounds, in addition to three open-air gymnasia, seven evening play centres, six recreation piers, and eleven swimming baths, at all of which instruction in gymnastics, games, or swimming is given.
To remove spots from tan shoes or saddles rub lightly with a rag dipped in alcohol, then wash with soap and water, and finish with ordinary russet leather polish.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- The presence in Paris of the International Medical Congress has brought to light an unusual pathological case at the Salpetriere Hospital. It is that of a woman, about forty years of age, suffering from religious mania, who believes that she was recently crucified and walks upon the points of her toes to protect the soles of her feet, the muscles of which have contracted by reason of this practice.

It must be evident to every visitor to a World's Fair that it is extremely well worth while for a nation to be well represented at such a competition. It would be hard to say, for example, how much British prestige has suffered at a time when Britons must admit that it is very much in need of support, by the failure of Great Britain to be adequately represented at the Paris fair.

Controller Coler, in a letter to Acting Mayor Guggenheimer, urged the Municipal Assembly to pass bond issues and save the city an unnecessary expenditure of $934.57 a day, or $341,118.95 per annum, for interest charges.

The publication in THE TIMES a week ago of certain facts connected with a poker game on one of the big ocean liners, and the publicity that a similar episode on another steamship has gained in New York, mark a departure from custom that promises bad results for the sharpers who have made their business the fleecing of ocean travelers.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 1. -- William J. Bryan to-day made his second brief visit of the campaign to Indiana. He arrived at a few minutes past 4 this afternoon, speaking briefly at La Porte en route, and here more at length to-night. He was enthusiastically received at both places, and both at La Porte and South Bend the audiences were large.

Let us take a place like Portsmouth, where garrison duty in a great fortress and the practice of active defense against descents from the Solent or by manoeuvres beyond the inland forts give a sense of reality to any training, and where at least three regiments of infantry are quartered. For the daily work of each regiment two officers are actually "on duty" all the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Outraged Citizen" should run the gantlet of the commuter from the Erie Railroad, and he would feel doubly outraged. From West Street to Washington and Warren we are obliged to travel in single file, and it is often difficult to get through at that.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -- On the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club this afternoon the qualifying round of the annual competition for the President's Cup, offered by John D. Crimmins, was played. The gross handicap and net scores follow:

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- I have not observed the general excitement and indignation which is said to exist in this country in regard to Russia's unexpected proposals to withdraw troops from Peking and to open peace negotiations as soon as possible. The suggestion, in the main, is accepted by the United States Government.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 1 -- As the result of a runaway while the Rev. Matthew Patten was taking a number of girls to a Sunday school picnic and his endeavor not to collide with a carriage in front of him containing his wife and her mother. Miss Agnes Howard and Miss Alice Mathews are nursing serious wounds, and several of their companions are congratulating themselves on their narrow escape.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The criminal pervert who comes most prominently before the French public this week committed his crime in Tours, though he came to Paris to spend the money of the man he had murdered. Paris may be depended upon for at least one grotesque sensation each week, though the sensation may have had its beginnings elsewhere.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -- The Republican State Convention will be called to order at New Haven next Tuesday evening, and after various preliminaries are attended to an adjournment will be taken until the following day, when the nomination for Governor and other State officers will be made.
The sixth annual report of the Southern Railway Company for the year ending June 30, made public yesterday, makes a very gratifying showing. The income account shows as follows:

A new law went into force yesterday, requiring firms and individuals who conduct business under an assumed name to file certificates showing the persons who are interested in the business. A number of notaries and young lawyers found business yesterday getting authority from storekeepers in various parts of the city to file these certificates and collecting therefor a fee varying from $2 to $5.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Upon further examination one discovers that Germany is not so pervading here as she was at Chicago in 1893, or as she appeared at first sight to be here. To be sure, she is very much in evidence and her exhibits doubtless are more numerous and upon the whole bulk larger than those of any other nation, except the hostess.

If England tries to hold her own, if she wants even to extend her influence and her commercial ramifications, don't let that be called intrigue. England, when looking at the returns of exports and imports, and of other commercial statistics, is not yet frightened. Even her far from successful military operations at the Cape need not perturb her.

Why should there hot be less antagonism and more unity of effort between Boston and New York in taking care of the North Atlantic freight traffic? Why should it not be New York and Boston as against other competing ports north and south of them, rather than the one against the other?

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 2 -- After two days' firing on the ranges of the New Jersey State Rifle Association, the military and lay marksmen enjoyed a rest to-day. The shooting will be resumed at the different ranges to-morrow morning, and it is expected that during the week there will be some high-class shooting done in the several contests which are to be decided.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 -- William Peck of this city, a prominent leader in the Glass Workers' Union, to-day gave the reason why the thousands of glass workers in the United States intended to vote for Mr. McKinley.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Thirteen persons killed and over thirty others injured is the appalling record of a rear-end collision between an excursion train and a milk train on the Bethlehem Branch of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway this morning at Hatfield, Penn., twenty-seven miles north of this city.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2. -- The excursion train from Bethlehem was to have arrived in this city at 10:30 A.M. to-day. There was a great crowd of people present at the Reading Station to greet their friends as they came in. An hour passed and no train arrived. Noon came, and still no train.
The following was issued yesterday from Republican National Headquarters:

SHANGHAI, Sept. 2 -- William Woodville Rockhill, Special Commissioner of the United States Government to investigate and report on conditions in China, in an interview to-day emphasized the importance of the harmonious action of the powers as a measure of self-defense. He said:

Thousands of people journeyed to Van Cortlandt Park, in the Borough of the Bronx, yesterday to witness the manoeuvres of the Second Battery, N.G.N.Y., which is in camp there under the command of Capt. David Wilson.

Although the interest of local light harness drivers centres chiefly in the coming matinee and Grand Circuit meets at the Empire City track the less formal contests on the Speedway are none the less attractive to them. The outpouring on the course yesterday morning was large, even if some of the best horses are in training or are still awaiting cooler weather before seeking the sport that the Speedway grants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I cannot refrain from raising one note, at least, of indignation and protest over the barbarous treatment of the murderer Bresci. It is not conceived in sentimental disgust over a proper desire to punish this unfortunate man. He deserves, however, a reasonable, adequate, and human punishment.

Mrs. Julia Mollenhauer, whose husband is a member of the family of sugar refiners of that name, was lured to a stable in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning, after attending a cake walk with Mrs. Isaac Halliday, her maid. There both women were attacked and Mrs. Mollenhauer was robbed of a considerable sum of money and diamonds valued at about $1,500.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The New Jersey State Board of Pardons is being subjected to a great deal of pressure in the case of Barney O'Nell, a young man now in the State Prison here. Powerful influence has been brought to bear to bring about his release, but great pressure has also been used to keep him a prisoner.

NEWPORT, Sept -- In the history of the Casino there never were so many persons in attendance upon a Sunday evening concert as were present to-night. On the grillroom piazza were over 150 at the dinner, while below many who were entertaining at their cottages came for the concert, arid over 1,000 of the people of Newport were also present.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- In response to a request for a sentiment on Labor Day Mr. Bryan to-night wrote the following: "'The laborer is worthy of his hire.' On this day, set apart for the consideration of the wage workers' interests, let each one inquire whether the man who toils enjoys a fair share of the proceeds of his labor, and if not, let him apply a remedy."

Labor Day will be characterized, as it has been for the past three years or more, by a grand outpouring of golfers upon all local links, and scarcely a club of any pretensions in the metropolitan district has failed to arrange some competitive feature for its members. This day will really mark the return of golfing activity to the New York territory.

While several thousand persons were bathing in the surf at the Parkway Baths near Brighton Beach yesterday, H. Basch of 41 Harrison Avenue, Brooklyn, who was swimming at some distance out, was attacked by cramps. He sank, but managed to cry for help as he went down for the second time.

More than 10,000 persons gathered yesterday in Ridgewood Park, Brooklyn, where the twenty-fourth annual cannstatter, or Schwaebischen Volksfest, and Industrial, horticultural, and agricultural exhibition was opened. The exhibition will last five days. To the organization there is attached more than seventy German societies, and the festival each year is attended by thousands of persons from a wide territory.

Forty-nine racers, have been entered for the Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which will be sailed to-day on Long Island Sound, from a starting line off Larchmont Harbor. Events, have been provided for all classes of yachts, but the schooner entries have been very light, and none of the Herreshoff seventies will appear.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The presentation of awards at the exhibition was an imposing affair, and with the addition of a few special detail, very much a repetition of the inaugural ceremony. The same speeches, the same speakers, the same Festival Hall, with its gigantic Russian organ and massed bands; the same variegated Diplomatic Corps, with its gold lace and feathers.

Last week was easily the dullest week of the Summer in the market for outside securities. Few issues were traded in, and only seven of the more active securities recorded a net change for the week of 1 point or more, the greatest net change being a net advance of 4 1/2 points for American Chicle, as the result of a demand and an absence of the stock.

Richard Croker's edict in reference to the nominations for Congress, State Senators, and Assemblymen has gone forth. Tammany Hall will this year attempt to elect a solid delegation of Congressmen, as was done two years ago.
Regarding the political situation Appraiser Wilbur F. Wakeman last evening said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Where the divine right of Kings is recognized, the monarch can grant different degrees of liberty to different subjects. The people of England can be ruled in one way, the people of Canada in another, the people of Ireland in another, while the people of India may be governed according to still different forms.

From The Indianapolis Press. Resting by the side of Gen. William Henry Harrison's sabre in the "Old Curiosity Shop" collection of antiques in the old State Bank Building at Terre Haute, Ind., is a target rifle of ancient design that is declared to be the weapon that gave Logansport her name. The old rifle might well come under the classification of heavy ordnance, for it is over seven feet in length.

Wall Street is not unlikely from this time on to give more consideration than lately it has done to the market movements of the steel and iron stocks. The return of John W. Gates to the city is, rightly or wrongly, taken in many quarters to signify that very shortly pronounced activity in the Steel group will develop, but whether on the side of advancing or declining values does not appear.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

"When Adam delved and Eve span, Who was then the gentleman?" The poetic interrosation, frequently propounded, has never, we believe, been found capable of satisfactory solution. At the fag end of the nineteenth century, however, a question of far greater and more immediate importance has been raised by that of late muchabused but invaluable institution, the Post Office.

John Bedell was loudly cheered at the Guttenberg track yesterday when he dismounted from his wheel after having been beaten, by George Scofield of the Kings County Wheelmen in a match race that was decided under extraordinary circumstances.

Edwin H. Smith of Fergus Falls, Minn., has returned from a flying trip to London and Paris. Mr. Smith has had a series of thrilling experiences since he left this part of the country. He came within measurable distance of being burned alive on the White Star Line steamer Cymric, which reached New York Aug. 14.

Mrs. Hugh F. Madden of 5 West Eighty-second Street has succeeded in finding her brother, Wilfred Oakes, of whom she had heard nothing for about ten years, by means of a letter of inquiry addressed by her to Postmaster Gordon in Chicago.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- There is nothing in the whole round of this huge show more interesting than a visit to the Swiss village. One is inclined to say that there is nothing so sweet and wholesome. It is a little tour in Switzerland for one who does not know Switzerland, and it is found equally interesting by those who do know.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I see in your paper of yesterday a note or letter from Dr. Eugene Hoyt condemning a former writer of an article favoring the Prohibition Party.

Nearly all the great railroad systems of the country have published their statements of earnings for July and as the majority of them begin their fiscal year with that month it is interesting to note the showing made in net earnings as compared with the same month last year. The following roads reported increases:
"Senator HILL, is as strong for COLER as ever," says State Chairman CAMPBELL.

Dr. Hamilton Williams, the Coroners Physician, who was assaulted on Saturday night at Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street while in the company of H.J. Tepper of 248 West Fourteenth Street, said last night that he had received no information regarding the assault further than that which he had furnished to the police on Saturday night.

The holiday potpourri of sports arranged for to-day is fully up to the Labor Day standard, and Labor Day is one of the most prolific days of the year in sports. If anything this year's Labor Day medley of competition and pastime exceeds any previous one. A glance at the long list of fixtures shows scarcely anything missing in the line of healthful and entertaining outdoor contests.

WILLIAMSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The Williamstown accommodation train on the Reading Railroad, which left Camden at 9:40, was wrecked this morning by some person opening a switch near Radix Station, south of this place.

Detectives Hollahan and Dixon of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station were walking along Third Avenue at 11 o'clock last night, when at the corner of One Hundred and Seventh Street two men hurried by them on a run. As they passed the detectives saw blood on the hands of one of the men and gave chase.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The statue of the late Alphonse Daudet which the sculptor St. Marceaux is now finishing will be erected next Spring either in the Square Ste. Clotilde or in the Luxembourg Gardens. It will be paid for by public subscription, and the 11,000f, already collected have almost entirely been subscribed by the friends of the famous artist.

SARATOGA, Sept 2 -- There is more excitement around Congress Hall, where the tuneful singers of the New York Maennerchor are holding their annual festival, than there is around the United States Hotel, where the Republican leaders of the State are gathering around Senator Platt for the purpose of nominating a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and other State officers.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- From the appearance of the market at the beginning of last week the Bank of England's efforts to pull the outside discount rates up to its own minimum had apparently been successful. Slowly but steadily the quotations hardened until 3 7/8 became the actual working rate.
A dispatch from Taku declares that the allied troops between Tien-Tsin and Peking have made the whole country desolate, murdering inoffensive natives, maltreating women, burning, and pillaging.

Nearly 700 Tammany braves steamed away from the police pier at the Battery yesterday on the Starin steamer Valley Girl for the eleventh annual outing and games of the Daniel B. Finn Association, at Witzel's Point View Island, off College Point, L.I., while heavy clouds overhead threatened to give them a drenching before the day was done.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- So far as can be ascertained there were no important developments in the Chinese situation here to-day. The officials maintain unusual reticence. They say they have no information to make public regarding the replies to the American-Russia propositions regarding the withdrawal of the military forces of the powers from Peking.

Policeman Robert Leahy of the East One One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station, was patrolling his post in Second Avenue at 12:40 o'clock this morning and was just south of Ninety-eighth Street when he heard cries of "Murder!" "Police!" Looking in the direction of the sound he saw a man running toward him from the corner with a crowd following him.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- August Belmont's seventy-footer Mineola arrived from the eastward and was hauled out at the Hawkins yard to be smoothed and otherwise prepared for the coming events on the 13th.

TAKU, Aug. 30, via Shanghai, Sept. 3 -- The Chinese in the Pei-ho Valley are paying dearly for the folly of their Government. The retribution they are suffering exceeds the ordinary penalties of war. Along the river and the roads traveled by the foreign troops between Tien-Tsin and Peking an orgie of looting and destruction continues, with much useless slaughter of unoffending inhabitants.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The publication of the text of the Russian proposals has intensified rather than diminished the suspicions entertained by Great Britain of Russia's proceedings. The rupture of the European concert is considered an accomplished fact.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Last week the Boerse showed a decided improvement. Interest was concentrated chiefly upon industrials, and particularly upon coal shares, of which the standard lines showed gains of from 8 to 12 points. Iron shares also advanced, upon the reports of a continued improvement in the American iron trade.
