The Tammany element at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union was in high glee at a report made by Edward Kelly, delegate of Electrical Workers' Union No. 3, of a visit which he paid to Richard Croker last week. According to Kelly, Mr. Croker is the hard and fast friend of the labor unions, and his fealty toward them is unchangeable.

The British steamship Masconomo, which has been engaged in the British transport service since the middle of March last, arrived at this port yesterday from South Africa. Capt. Mann says that the Masconomo stopped at St. Helena on July 30 and 31 for repairs and that he visited the imprisoned Boers while on the island.
The Albany Law Journal has this to say of Justice EDWARD PATTERSON of the Supreme Court in this county and of the Appellate Division in the First Judicial District:

Far from settling the question of superiority between the two most noted two-year-old colts of the season, William C. Whitney's Balleyhoo Bey, winner of the Futurity, and J.R. and F.P. Keene's Tommy Atkins, the race for the Flatbush Stakes on Saturday leaves that matter still open, and the subject of dispute that has more bitterness in it than any similar problem that the year has produced.

LILLE, Aug. 8 -- You can leave Brussels just after 1 and reach Lille before 5 o'clock, travel down through the storied and picturesquely rural country of Flanders, where rolling lands are crowned here and there by castles more or less in ruin, but are still held by their lordly owners, though rarely lived in.

SARATOGA, Sept. 2 -- It Is likely that all mention of the canals will be left out of the platform. It is a very delicate subject for the party to deal with. This was demonstrated when the leaders got together this afternoon to discuss the matter. There were some who wanted a ringing canal plank, promising wholesale improvements and honest administration.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 2 -- On Tuesday Vermont elects two Congressmen, a full State ticket, and a Legislature, which will elect a United States Senator to complete the unexpired portion of the term of Justin S. Morrill.

Bishop MCFAUL, of Trenton, N.J., has in the current number of The North American Review an able and serious article on "Catholics and American Citizenship." It contains an eloquent tribute to the principle of civil and religious liberty, to the fidelity of Catholics to this principle in the past, and an asseveration of the zeal with which they are now attached to it.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 2 -- The flagship New York and the Scorpion arrived in the harbor this morning. They are the advance guard of the North Atlantic Squadron. The Kentucky and Texas were last heard of from Boston. The Kearsarge is at North East Harbor. All are expected here to-morrow.

The eleventh annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association, which will practically close the season for the local oarsmen, will be rowed on the Harlem River to-day, beginning at 9:20 A.M. The races will all be one-mile straightaway, over the old Harlem course between Gates's lumber yard and the Central Bridge.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Seth Taber, of the Peekskill Board of Trustees went before Justice James E. Lynch, a few days ago and asked for warrants for the arrest of John S. Boyd, Democrat, and Nathan Posey, Fred E. Roe, and Isaac H. Smith, Republicans, also Trustees of the village.
On tie Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Sept. 1, total transactions included 735,734 shares of stock, $4,319,500 bonds, including $52,500 Government and $8,500 State bonds.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The authorities are investigating the death of Jonathan Harris of Belle Plain, whose body was taken from the Tuckahoe River yesterday. They have not as yet been able to obtain any light in the affair. Harris left his home early Friday morning to snoot mud hens.

The National Civil Service Reform League has sent letters through a special committee to Senators Hanna and Jones, Chairmen, respectively, of the Republican and Democratic National Committees, with respect to the solicitation of political assessments or contributions from public employes during the pending campaign.

The full text of the Russian communique, of which an abstract was given in the dispatch of Acting Secretary ADEE, confirms the impression that the United States did wisely in adopting the policy explained in that dispatch. The preference for a complete joint occupation of Peking until the objects common to all the powers had been further advanced is justified.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would seem as if Mr. Odell, an estimable gentleman, but, judging from the evidence, a Platt machine man of the most flexible type, able and willing to say "Yes, Sir," and "No, Sir," according to the whims and wishes of his political chief, is fated -- and slated -- for the Gubernatorial nomination.

The lowest and meanest view of the character of WILLIAM J. BRYAN that has been taken by any one during either of the Nebraskan's campaigns has just been put forth by Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN in a letter to an inquiring friend who wanted to know how he could honestly support the candidate he opposed four years ago because of his destructive financial doctrines, which he has not in the least changed.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- "The ornament of a house is the guests who frequent it." There is a sense in which the most important exhibit a nation can make at a World's Fair is the visitors it sends to it. There is certainly no lack of American visitors, although one hears that there are far fewer than were expected, and thereupon wonders upon what the great expectations can possibly have been founded.

The census gives very impressively one aspect of the consolidation which has resulted in Greater New York. The resultant city is more than twice the size of the next following, and for a long time to come seems secure from competition in point of numbers. Proba- bly very few of us expected that so vast a population would be shown.

Visitors to Midland Beach, on the ocean side of Staten Island, yesterday received more than their money's worth, as they had an opportunity of witnessing a fight which lasted for some hours between the proprietors of Midland and those of Woodland Beach, a resort which adjoins to the south.
Carl Schurz has addressed the following open letter to Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury:

Golfers turned out yesterday on the Richmond County Country Club links, near Dongan Hills, Staten Island, in numbers sufficiently large to suggest that the Summer season of golf inactivity at local clubs was practically over. Two competitions were played. Ralph Lane won first honors in the men's handicap, and in the mixed foursome event he still has a chance for the prize.

SARATOGA, Sept. 3 -- One of the central figures here is Cornelius Vanderbilt. He is a delegate from the Twenty-fourth New York District, and there is a rumor current here that he is to receive a Congressional nomination in New York.

Although American competitors in the international games were conspicuous by their absence yesterday afternoon at Bayonne, N.J., the Knickerbocker Athletic Club's annual Fall carnival of Labor Day sports afforded abundant attractions for the lovers of amateur athletics. A well arranged programme with plenty of well-known competitors was evident, coupled with several interesting finishes.

Nature and humanity supplied a lane through which 148 enthusiastic wheelmen started on a swift journey of twenty-five miles yesterday morning for prizes and a small degree of fame. The elms that shade the Coney Island cycle path were nature's part of the lane, while spectators to the number of perhaps 30,000 gathered five and six deep on the outer edges of the path, and these were the human setting for the parading cyclers.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Society turned out in force to-day at the first annual horse show held under the auspices of the Rockaway Hunt Club. The exhibition was in the open. Many well-known society people were present. The prizes were blue, red, and yellow ribbons, together with a number of very handsome silver cups.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- This evening Miss Leary gave one of the largest dinner parties of the season at her cottage on Mill Street for Miss Van Alen and her sister, Miss Sarah Van Alen, daughters of James J. Van Alen. Fifty invitations were sent out.
GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 3 -- The Transcontinental Passenger Association is now an assured fact.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The Velodrome races to-night were well attended. In the five-mile motor race Dyer, and Kraemer's motor gave out on the second mile, and Miller and Judge won. W.S. Fenn of Hartford won the second heat of the third of a mile handicap in 0:38 4-5, beating the world's amateur record.

SARATOGA, Sept. 3 -- It is not a Republican State Convention that is to meet here to-morrow. It is simply a meeting to ratify the selections made by Senator Thomas C. Platt and other party leaders. The ticket will be the same as in 1898, excepting that Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., of Newburg, Chairman of the State Committee, will take the place of Gov. Theodore Roosevelt, the nominee for Vice President.

A large crowd was present at the Guttenberg track yesterday to witness the trotting races arranged by several prominent horsemen of this city. The main attraction was an attempt by Mrs. H.D. Gill to create a new record for women drivers. She was behind the noted speedway pacer Jack. She came near accomplishing the feat, the first mile being covered in 2:23, and the second in 2:20 1/2, while the record is but 2:19.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- It cannot be learned that there has been any marked advancement of the negotiations between the powers touching the withdrawal of the international forces from Peking. The plain indication is that the powers are acting upon the hint conveyed in the last note of the State Department and are bringing all their influence to bear upon Rusia to induce her to change her mind as to withdrawing her troops.
EDEN MUSEE. -- New moving pictures were shown last evening, and they proved of unusual interest. Several new wax groups were also on exhibition.

Nothing of consequence developed last week to affect the rates for money in this market. Continuing ease was the order, with much more money offered than was needed or taken. The weekly bank statement -- though the figures do not necessarily signify anything consequential, and certainly more frequently than not fall to represent actual conditions -- showed a further increase in the cash holdings of the banks, and on the whole was decidedly favorable.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 3 -- The Kearsarge arrived in the harbor this morning and anchored near the New York and Scorpion behind Rodick's Island. The Massachusetts, the Kentucky, and the Texas arrived later in the day and joined the squadron, completing the number expected, although two or three converted gunboats are to come later.

A party of Wall Street men who had been out sailing on the yacht Patrol entered the Sheepshead Bay Police Station yesterday afternoon and told of a thrilling rescue at sea. They said that three miles off Norton's Point they had picked up four men who had been clinging for half an hour to an overturned yawl.

The tone of the British press in respect to the proposition of Russia, partly adopted by the United States, for a withdrawal of the allied troops from Peking is one of distinct antagonism. It is made the more marked by the deliberation which has been shown by The London Times in forming and pronouncing its opinion.

William F. King, President of the Merchants' Association of New York, in an interview yesterday said that, speaking as an individual, he viewed the present campaign not as a partisan struggle at all. Instancing the prosperity which has developed since 1896, he said:

NEWPORT, Sept. 3 -- An interesting race was rowed in Newport Harbor this morning over the Belmont-Garretson course, from off the torpedo station to and around the buoys in front of the training station wharf, a distance of about three and a quarter miles. The prize was $900, offered by F.P. Garretson, and the competing crews were the Training Station and Old Colony crews.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 -- It was a sorrowful message which conveyed to Mrs. Jennie D. Bell of Avenue, Ohio, a village near Columbus, the intelligence of the death of her son Walter, which occurred at the Bethesda Hospital at 1 o'clock to-day from injuries received in the morning while attempting to board a freight train.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 -- The Montcalm, bound for South Africa with 1,400 mules, cleared from this port on Saturday night and dropped down the river a few miles, intending to start for the Gulf early Sunday morning. On Sunday morning, however, the British stokers refused to go to work because four Danish stokers had been given places in the ship's crew.
SARATOGA, Sept. 3 -- Senator Thomas F. Grady is here, and is quite confident that Controller Bird S. Coler will not be nominated for Governor by the Democratic State Convention next week.

NEW YORK, Sept. 3 -- The two baseball games between the New Yorks and Cincinnati at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon resulted in an even break. The visitors won the first and the home team the second after five innings had been played. The first game the New Yorks had practically won, but became careless and played carelessly.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The eleventh annual reunion of the Sixth Heavy Artillery was held at Verplanck's Point, about four miles from this city, to-day. At the roll call 98 veterans answered to their names.

Labor Day was celebrated in New York and its vicinity yesterday chiefly by picnics and reunions of local unions and by district and local assemblies of the Knights of Labor. In Manhattan Borough the principal event was the parade of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, which proved so picturesque as to draw crowds of sight-seers.

SARATOGA, Sept. 3 -- "Just think of it," said Gen. John Palmer, ex-Secretary of State, "here am I at the head of the Albany delegation, the first county on the roll, and I won't have a chance to open my mouth. Everything has been fixed."

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- New plans to teach boys a trade through the co-operation of a labor organization and a technical school have just been propected by the Lewis Institute and the Industrial Trades Union, known as the "Non-Union Union." The purpose of the innovation is to give to all apprentices vouched for by the union a technical education and fit them for their respective callings.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- Sunday evenins a man supposed to be a second-story thief entered the cottage of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Bryce, on Bellevue Avenue, climbing up the lattice work into the room of Miss Iselin, who is visiting there. Miss Iselin heard the man in her room, and, making a sudden spring from her bed, opened the door of her bedroom and ran through the hall and gave the alarm.
MANILA, Sept. 4 -- The United States transport Californian arrived here safely to-day. She was delayed sixteen days at Guam with a broken propeller.

Richard Croker is opposed to the nomination of Controller Coler for Governor. He said so yesterday, after keeping silent a month on the matter. Friends of the Tammany Hall leader have been circulating stories of Mr. Croker's antagonism to Controller Coler for several weeks, but whenever the former was asked about the subject, he always said:
CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 -- Senator Foraker on his return from French Lick Springs to-day gave out the following:

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- To-day Chicago's organized labor marched in review before William J. Bryan and Col. Theodore Roosevelt. The Democratic candidate for President and the Republican Vice Presidential candidate stood on the loggia of the Auditorium Hotel, together with Charles A. Towne and Senator W.E. Mason, and several other political leaders.

On the face of it it would seem unnecssary, if not impertinent, for the National Civil Service Reform League to call the attention of Senator HANNA and Senator JONES to the terms of the law governing the collection of funds for the use of the National Committees of which they are respectively Chairmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A dispatch from Minister Conger was received by the State Department to-day. It was chiefly interesting as being the first word from him since his dispatch received Aug. 27, referring to the proposed parade of troops through the imperial palace in Peking. Like that dispatch, this is dateless.

With the customary hot weather, which, as usual, seemed to have no deterrent effect upon the playgoers, the new theatrical season was begun last evening. All the playhouses that were open were well filled. Otis Skinner, who presented his own dramatization of "Prince Otto" at Wallack's, was cordially received by a big audience, and his play was treated kindly.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The difficulty of communicating with the British Minister at Peking, Sir Claude M. MacDonald, delays the promulgation of the views of the British Government in regard to its future steps in China, the Government being unwilling to commit itself publicly to a definite decision until Sir Claude has fully reported on the situation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- By a trite little joke sprung with cool, but effective declamation, W.J. Bryan to-day arrested a stampede of frantic men and women in the speakers' stand at Electric Park, preventing a panic.

THEODORE ROOSEVELT and WILLIAM J. BRYAN took part as guests and speakers in the Labor Day celebration in Chicago yesterday. They sat down together to a luncheon given by the representatives of organized labor. Then they addressed a large audience of working-men and their families assembled in Electric Park.

A row that was started yesterday afternoon on the fifth floor of the flathouse at 221 West Sixty-third Street terminated in a shooting affray, and as a result one man is in Bellevue Hospital with a bullet wound just below the heart and a number of others are under arrest at the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station.

The annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association, held over the old rowing course on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, was in many respects the most successful regatta held on local waters this Summer, and a fitting climax to a rowing season of unusual activity and interest.
BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- A leading Berlin journal asserts that Emperor William, while conversing with a group of officers last Saturday evening, said:

Among the passengers arriving on the steamer La Touraine yesterday were Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Ockerson of St. Louis, who have spent several months abroad. Mr. Ockerson represented this Government at the International Congress of Navigation, and the Congress of Merchant Marine, which met in Paris.

An apple core tossed by a small colored boy precipitated another race disturbance near Eighth Avenue yesterday afternoon and for a time Forty-seventh Street west of Longacre Square was filled with a fu- rious crowd of white men who attacked every colored man within their reach. Bricks were thrown and revolvers were flourished, while the negro denizens of the block for the most part fled in terror to their homes.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 3 -- At the Orange Oval this morning a crowd of over 2,000 people saw one of the prettiest baseball games of the season. Once before this season the Orange Athletic Club had played the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York and won from them. To-day the Knickerbockers evened the record by making a score of 7 to 5.

Such was the rhythmic toast with which Police Captain Titus regaled the ears of Patrick Divver and his Fourth Ward followers at Witzell's Grove, College Point, yesterday afternoon. Then a score of Tammany braves tossed a score of glasses of champagne out of sight, and "Paddy" smiled broadly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Department of Agriculture has issued a report on investigations of the big trees of California that brings out some interesting and new conclusions. It shows that the dimensions of the big trees are unequaled and that their age makes them the oldest living things.

Nobody in whose mental make-up there is even a trace of Sir Lucius O'Trigger's love of a quarrel between other people -- and whose mental make-up, alas, is without such a trace? -- could have failed to experience a thrill of pleasurable anticipation as he read the explanation given by the Captain of the Campania for his arrival in port several hours after the St. Paul reached here.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The Republican State Convention meets under rather unusual circumstances. Heretofore when political conventions have been held here it has been at the close of the Saratoga season, and politicians have been in possession of the place.

Larchmont yachtsmen have had just grievance against the weather that has been doled out to many of their racing events this year, but the crisp southeasterly breeze that blew for their Fall regatta yesterday sent the competing craft over Long Island Sound at a pace that left no room for complaint.

NEWPORT, Sept. 4. -- This morning women were in charges of the fleet of thirty-foot yachts for a seven-mile race, and the day was perfect for such sport. The ladies had entire charge of the handling of the boats, and Miss Alice Blight won in the Hera, owned by Ralph N. Ellis.
Copyright, 1900, The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Sept 4. -- Details regarding the killing of several American women missionaries have been learned from official sources.

As "labor day," it is evident that Labor Day is a failure. Laborers of good sense yearly abstain, with more and more profusion and enthusiasm, from the express celebrations of it. But as a public holiday, the first Monday in September meets a long-felt want, and from year to year if is more extensively taken advantage of for an outing.

Traffic officials of railroads interested in the transportation of iron and steel to the seaboard and for export will hold an important meeting to-day at the rooms of the Trunk Line Association in this city. They will attempt to relieve the rate situation, which is now in a very unsatisfactory state.

Many New York families who have spent the Summer out of town will be back at their homes during the present week, and expressmen plying their vocations about the railroad stations and steamboat piers expect to do the heaviest business of the year during the three days following Labor Day.
Richard Croker denounced David B. Hill yesterday as an "untruthful sneak," a "liar," a "coward," a "trickster," a "peanut politician," and also used other epithets.

SARATOGA, Sept. 4. -- The Republican State Convention, which assembled here to-day to carry out the programme formulated by Senator Platt, was devoid of interest, even to the delegates. At no time during the two sessions was the convention hall filled. Every action of the convention having been anticipated, it was impossible to awaken any interest in the proceeding's.
Mr. SHEPARD thought panic and great financial disasters not too high a price to pay for the defeat of McKINLEY and imperialism.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Without excitement the Republicans of Connecticut assembled in State convention in this city to-night to prepare by temporary organization for the session of to-morrow, when candidates for State officers will be nominated and Presidential Electors named. There was not a whisper of the bitter factional contest which has made the canvass of candidates one of the most striking in the history of the party.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Inter-State regimental team match, the first stage of which was completed yesterday, was decided this afternoon after the second stage, which consisted of skirmish runs, was finished. The honor went to the team representing the Second Battalion of the District of Columbia, with a total score of 830.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 4. -- The vote for Governor in 160 cities and towns out of 246 in the State gives Stickney, (Rep.,) 36,671; Senter, (Dem.,) 13,667; others, 1,127. The same cities and towns in 1896 gave Grout, (Rep.,) 40,664; Jackson, (Dem.,) 11,917; all others, 1,264. The Republican plurality is 23,000; majority over all, 21,877.

William H. Riker of 122 West Seventy-fourth Street, the druggist who formerly was in business at the corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, but who has no place of business now, has filed a petition in bankruptcy with liabilities $192,841 and assets $8,790, in debts due him.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Sept. 4. -- As William J. Bryan went to bed to-night he remarked that he had done a pretty good day's work, campaigning in West Virginia, Maryland, and Ohio. He had been speaking ever since early morning. His first speech was at Zanesville, Ohio; he spoke again briefly at Cambridge, Ohio; then he passed into West Virginia.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 4. -- Flying the flag of Vice Admiral Bedford at the fore and the ensign of Great Britain at the stern, her Majesty's ship Crescent, the flagship of the British North American. Squadron, steamed at half speed into the inner harbor, at 9:20 o'clock this morning, closely followed by the Psyche, Tribune, and Indefatigable.

Samuel Green was arrested yesterday by Deputy Sheriff Strauss on an order signed by Justice McAdam of the Supreme Court in an action brought against him by Mrs. Wilhelmine Walther to recover $2,500, paid by her to Green in a real estate transaction in this city. Green gave security in $3,000, and was released.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Sept 4. -- In a Speech delivered here to-night, in the presence of William J. Bryan, who afterward spoke from the same platform. United States Senator George L. Wellington of this State announced his opposition to the present Republican Administration, and his determination to support Mr. Bryan.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 4. -- The following is a proclamation calling a special election for Governor filed with the Secretary of State this afternoon by Chief Justice Hazelrigg:

Copyright, 1900, The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Sept. 4. -- Reports received here from the treaty ports show that the opposition to the allied forces evacuating Peking before a final settlement with the Chinese is arrived at is universal and intense among the foreigners. The commercial and missionary bodies are cabling protests to their Governments.

JEFFERSON, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Preliminary play in the Waumbek Golf Club's tournament for women ended to-day and match play in the two divisions for the Manager's and Assistant Manager's Cups will begin to-morrow. In comparison with the women's August tournament the play is much improved, and the second round to-day was headed by Miss Dallett of St. David's Golf Club, with a record-breaking card of 38 for the ten-hole course.

The question of an adequate water supply for the ever growing City of New York is receiving earnest study from President Joseph S. Wood of the Mount Vernon Board of Education, who has compiled figures showing that the Croton water shed will, in the course of a very few years, be unable to furnish a sufficient supply.

"I don't think that any child eligible under the law will be refused admittance when the schools open on Sept. 10, and for the first time all of the schools will be ready for occupancy on the opening day." This remark was made yesterday by John Jasper, Superintendent of Schools in Manhattan and the Bronx.

The advent of young Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT in politics may or may not prove to be an important event. There is frequent and well-grounded complaint that young men of education, refinement, and social position avoid participating in practical politics, but content themselves with voting and lamenting that political methods are not more seemly.
Li-Hung-Chang, Prince Ching, Hsu-Tung, and Gen. Yung-Lu have been appointed Commissioners to negotiate peace terms by an imperial edict issued at Tai-Yuen-Foo.

NEWPORT, Sept. 4. -- The second day of the Horse Show was very successful. The morning and afternoon sessions were very well attended, Jwarragransett Pier, Jamestown, and Providence being well represented. Robert L. Gerry was again one of the principal exhibitors, and drove and rode handsome animals and won many ribbons for his exhibits.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 4. -- The Grand Circuit races to-day at Charter Oak Park were attended by 3,000 persons, and twenty heats were finished before the sport was over. Summaries:

CITY ISLAND, Sept. 4. -- Charles A. Appleton's sloop Tigress put into this harbor this morning in a disabled condition. Her topmast was carried away at the masthead, caused by Henry S. Baird's centreboard sloop Hussar II. fouling her off Larchmont, Labor Day, while participating in the regatta.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- The American Steel and Wire Company of New Jersey has under consideration plans for the construction of an immense Bessemer plant at Waukegan, Ill., with a capacity of 1,000 tons a day and to cost $3,000,000. If the plans are carried out the company will become a factor in the structural steel business.
WASHINGTON, Sept 4. -- The following dispatch was received to-day by the War Department from Gen. Chaffee:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- The market was not benefited by its holiday, to-day's sales aggregating less than 7,000 shares, coming close to the lowest total of the year. Prices were quite firm, but the changes, as a rule, were too unimportant to be noted, ranging from 1/8 to 8/8. Many of the most prominent stocks were not even dealt in, Asphalt, Choctaw, the Northern Pacifies and the American Railways being included in the list.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:
NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Sept. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. William E. SAhepherd gave a dinner to Admiral and Mrs. George Dewey at their cottage on Central Street last evening.
NASHUA, N.H., Sept. 4. -- Mrs. Ellen Dunlap, wife of Irving H. Dunlap, chief clerk of the Fish Commission in Washington, committed suicide by drowning in Pennichuck Pond this afternoon.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Another bright day greeted the lawn tennis players here to-day, and the courts of the Sleepy Hollow Club were kept busy constantly all day until twilight -- in fact, when darkness finally did stop the play for the day C.D. Millard and G.P. Snow were in the middle of their match, the end of which had to be postponed until-to-morrow.

Ex-Senator HILL on Monday delivered an address to several thousand workingmen assembled at Troy at a demonstration in observance of Labor's holiday. He spoke at considerable length and at times with intense earnestness and force. He did not make use of his opportunity, as Mr. BRYAN did at Chicago, to deliver a partisan harangue.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Money was abundant to-day, but the demand slackened and the market was inclined to be easier. On the Stock Exchange there was an all-around hardening, in view of the hopeful anticipations in regard to affairs in China and South Africa and the railroad troubles, but business remained small.

Business in the market for outside securities was resumed yesterday after the holiday without any material increase in activity, though in some cases prices showed improvement. Only a few stocks were traded in to any extent, while in most issues transactions did not exceed a single hundred shares.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Officials of the Chicago and Kansas City railroads admit there is an overflow of grain at Kansas City, but they deny that the situation there is as serious as reported. A good deal of wheat is standing in the yards awaiting shipment East, but there is no serious block and little shortage of cars.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- Boston had its shares of the Sugar episode, nearly 6,000 shares changing hands in the first half of the day. Otherwise the market was as dull as ever, and price changes were few. The mining stocks Had a somewhat softer tone in some oases. Isle Royale eased 5/8 to 31, and Utah 1/2 to 31 1/2 Montana held at 319.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The reported edict of the Chinese Government, said to have been issued from Tai-Yuen-Foo, appointing Li-Hung-Chang, Yung-Lu, Hsu-Tung, and Prince Chins as Commissioners to negotiate peace, has not been communicated to the State Department thus far, nor, so far as can be learned, have the Chinese authorities here received such an edict.

More than one-half of the dealing's in the stock market yesterday represented trading in Sugar Trust and People's Gas stocks, the former contributing 81,000 and the latter 33,000 of a total of 207,000 shares. The large dealings in these stocks, however, are not surprising in view of the day's developments.

SARATOGA, Sept. 4. -- If Lieut. Gov. Woodruff had had his own way he would not be renominated for Lieutenant Governor to-morrow, but would have succeeded B.B. Odell, Jr., as Chairman of the Republican State Committee. That was his ambition, next to the nomination for Governor which he knew he could not secure.

SARATOGA, Sept. 4. -- Senator E.O. Wolcott of Colorado is said to be responsible for the advent of young Cornelius Vanderbilt into politics. Senator Wolcott met Mr. Vanderbilt abroad and found him desirous of entering the political field. He notified Senator Platt of the discovery and suggested that Mr. Vanderbilt was of the calibre calculated to do useful political work.

The only event in society here yesterday was the wedding of Miss Lalla Baldwin Morton to Daniel E. Seybel, which is described elsewhere. At Bar Harbor the advent of the North Atlantic Squadron and the visiting British warships, and the receptions and entertainments in honor or this occasion, are affairs of moment.

The New Yorks won two baseball games from the Cincinnatis at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and good pitching was of material assistance in the double victory. Hawley was steady in the first game, and the fielding back of him was fairly good. The first game was close, and the result doubtful until the end.

MALONE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- At the Franklin County Democratic Convention here to-day R.M. Moore, P.H. Kissaine, and Frank J. Kendall were elected delegates to the State Convention. Although uninstructed, it is stated that they will support Bird S. Coler for Governor. S.E. Jennison of Moira was nominated for member of the Assembly.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- This evening Mrs. Lewis Quentm Jones gave a delightful dinner dance in honor of her daughter, Miss Frances Coster Jones, one of the season's debutantes.

John W. Keller, Commissioner of Charities, attached trusts and imperialism at a meeting of the Tenth Assembly District organization of Tammany Hall at 96 Second Avenue last night. In the beginning of his talk he said:

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- A report was current to-day that two cases of the plague had been discovered in the vicinity of the London Docks. But the medical officer, when questioned on the subject, said he knew nothing about the matter.

The storm centre in the fight for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination was the Willoughby Street auction rooms, in Brooklyn, which Hugh McLaughlin uses as a political headquarters. Controller Coler had another talk with the Brooklyn leader in the morning. He came to his office in Manhattan and was happier than at any time since the fight for his nomination was started.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Politicians here are discussing the visit of Corporation Counsel Jonn Whalen, who came to Elmira last evening to attend the State convention of the Catholic Mutual Beneficial Association. Mr. Whalen has been in conference with John B. Stanchfield during the day. When asked to-night regarding Mr. Stanchfield's candidacy Mr. Whalen said:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 5. -- When cotton-mill officials went to their offices this morning they were informed that a remarkable and altogether unexpected transaction had been executed in the print cloth market here late yesterday, M.C.D. Borden of New York, owner of the Fall River Iron Works, the largest cotton manufacturing plant in the city, and of the American Print Cloth Works, having purchased 500,000 pieces of cotton goods at 2 7/8 cents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Weather Bureau has issued the following special storm bulletin:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- To-day was the last of the Newport Horse Show. The gathering was the greatest of the exhibition, and the most prominent cottagers were present in large numbers, as were large delegations from Jamestown and Narragansett Pier. The weather was perfect. During the afternoon Miss Stillman, daughter of James Stillman, offered $7,500 for the high-steppers Kitchner and Kopelia, owned by W.H. Barnard of New York, and the offer was refused.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- This evening Mrs. Ogden Mills gave a large dinner, the table being decorated with American Beauty roses.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Money is plentiful temporarily. The principal movements in the near future will be the payment of an installment of u2,500,000 of the war loan Friday and a similar amount of Exchequer bonds next week, to meet which shipments of American gold are considered probable.

The advocates of a third ticket who met at Indianapolis on Aug. 16 concluded their labors yesterday by organizing a new party, placing candidates in nomination for President and Vice President, adopting a platform and party emblem, and making arrangements to carry on a campaign against both the Republican and Democratic Parties.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- It was expected that Miss Georgiana Wendel, the Irvington heiress, would be present in court to-day before County Judge Smith Lent to be examined as to her mental condition, but she was not.
NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- James J. Van Alen gave a large dinner dance this evening in honor of his second daughter, Miss Sarah Van Alen, who was formally introduced to society.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 5. -- The Republicans of Vermont elected their State and Congressional ticket yesterday by a plurality of at least 32,250, and a majority over all of 31,000. If the towns yet to hear from give a vote corresponding relatively to the vote of the towns reporting to-day, the figures mentioned will be about right.

The proclamation of Lord ROBERTS announcing the annexation of the last of the Boer republics in South Africa to her Majesty's dominions provides for the re-establishment of the name of the territory which even its status as "the South African Republic" had failed to repudiate -- the Transvaal.

The size of Governors Island is to be doubled. This, at least, is the recommendation of a board of survey, of which Col. Kimball is Chairman, which met on the island about ten days ago. The board was appointed to consider the present condition of the island and suggest plans for its improvement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A blood-stained bill given by a man to a woman has turned out, in a peculiar manner, to furnish evidence of crime against the man. A woman named Dolly Belmont was arrested yesterday by Detective Parham on a warrant sworn out by George Gamble. He charged the woman with having stolen $125 from him in the place where he lodges.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Secretary Gage has made the following reply to the open letter of Carl Schurz of New York, in which Mr. Schurz denies that Mr. Bryan's candidacy menaces sound money:

It seems a pity that such a to-do was made about the solitary Boer at Bar Harbor. He really did not deserve it. In the first place, very few people are acquainted by sight with the Boer flag. Therefore, if Mr. EDWARD VAN NESS chose to have one made and to hoist it on a tall pole on his grounds, the theatrical display might have been overlooked.

SEA GIRT. Sept. 5. -- The Hilton Trophy, which was won last year by the New Jersey State team, will remain with them for another twelve months, as they won it again to-day, defeating teams from New York and the District of Columbia, and another representing the Department of the East.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your paper every day carefully and attentively. The editorials are especially good reading. The communications are interesting. The absence of "pictures" is very agreeable. It does not follow that I indorse all you write, but in the main your advice and argument on the leading topics are eminently sound.

Refrigeration for hay fever is the latest discovery for that disease, and the discoverer is George A. Traver, the artist, whose studios are in the Alpine, at Thirty-third Street and Broadway. Although his first experience with the cure has riot been wholly successful, Mr. Traver, despite the fact that his face was badly frost bitten, is persisting in his treatment, and his hay fever is under control for the first time in five years.

With an ideal day for fast driving and a large gathering of amateur reinsmen there was promised unusually brisk sport and plenty of it on the Speedway yesterday afternoon. Things looked better than they really were. Spirited brushes were so few that one regular Speedway spectator was led to remark:

Army. Second Lieut. W. Frank Mohr, Thirty-ninth Infantry, United States Volunteers, having tendered his resignation on account of physical disability, is honorably discharged from the service, to take effect Sept. 15.

Albert G. Titus yesterday secured from Justice McAdain in the Supreme Court an order directing that the summons and complaint in a suit for separation brought by the petitioner against his wife, Marian, be served on her by publication. The order also directed that a copy of the summons and complaint be sent to Mrs. Titus at Varese, Italy, where she is now supposed to be.

After a conference, which lasted for five hours, at the headquarters of the Trunk Line Association yesterday the freight traffic officials of the railroads east of Chicago interested in the transportation of finished steel decided to maintain the present rate of 18 cents per hundred pounds from Pittsburg to the coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 5. -- Replies to the Russo-American proposals have at last been received from some of the powers. Their tenor is very gratifying to the Administration, for each of them expresses above everything else a desire for harmony and indicates a perfect willingness to act in accord with the other powers.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- This afternoon the fleet of thirties sailed for a cup offered by Winthrop Rutherfurd, which was won by Reginald Brooks in the Wa Wa. The wind was light from the east. The course was a run to Jamestown Shore, a reach to Dyer's Island, and a beat home. The start was at 3:25. The summary:

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- About one thousand citizens attended a meeting in the City Hall to-night, called by Mayor Hinchliffe, to arrange for cencerted action in regard to the purchase of the Rogers Locomotive Works or the adoption of some plan for keeping it in operation. George H. Blakely presided.
HAMILTON, Ontario, Sept. 5. -- Henry Ledyard, Jr., son of the President of the Michigan Central Railroad, was married to-day to Miss Mary A.M. Hendrie, daughter of William Hendrie of this city.
Some of the powers have replied to the Russo-American proposal that the troops be withdrawn from Peking.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The Chinese Minister here. Sir Chih-Chen-Lo-Feng-Lu, admits the correctness, in a general sense, of the cable message sent to him, according to Shanghai advices, by Li-Hung-Chang, in which the latter is quoted as saying:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the advertisement of his infidelity some days ago Mr. Clinton Stevens does not seem to realize that he takes a stand of a low order in the moral world. In this enlightened age the man who is ready and loud to proclaim his disbelief in the Christian religion is not accounted a very wise or a very safe man.

QUINCY, Ill., Sept. 5. -- A wild engine, rushing over the rails at a terrific speed and endangering scores of lives in a heavily laden passenger train, created a panic in the yard of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road early this morning.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Newburg to-night witnessed the greatest demonstration ever accorded an individual. It was in honor of the return home of Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., after his nomination by the Republican State Convention at Saratoga. The Orange County delegation, about 100 strong, accompanied him home in a special train over the West Shore Road, the train consisting of two Pullman coaches.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 5. -- Bar Harbor's celebration in honor of the visiting squadrons was continued to-day with renewed enthusiasm. The chief events comprised a reception on board the United States flagship New York in the afternoon and a grand ball at the Kebo Valley Club in the evening.

The Cincinnatis lost the final game with the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The game was too one-sided to be interesting, and every one was satisfied when Umpire Snyder called the game in the seventh inning on account of darkness. There was, however light enough to continue. The New Yorks have released Sheehan.The score:

While Newport and Bar Harbor and Southampton yesterday were all alive to gayety, town was naturally very dull. But with the exception of Bar Harbor, gayety was a bit forced. There are already signs of the waning season everywhere, and the news current is the detail of various Autumn plans of the fashionables who are to leave the scene of their Summer pleasures, just as soon as possible.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The Admiralty has issued Vice Admiral Seymour's detailed report of the experiences of the first Peking relief expedition. It is good reading, but embraces nothing not previously known. Referring to the harmonious action of the forces of the eight nationalities engaged, the Admiral especially mentions Capt. von Usedom of the German Navy and Capt. McCalla of the United States Navy.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 5. -- The event of the racing in the Grand Circuit to-day was the trial of Cresceus to beat the world's stallion record, Directum's, 2:05 1/4. Cresceus did not make a skip in the mile, and the time by quarters was 0:31 1/4, 1:02 3/4, 1:33 1/2, 2:04 3/4, beating the record with apparent ease. Summaries:

We have no knowledge whether the dispatch published yesterday about the American tourists held in pawn at Venice refers to the same company of which the failure left some hundreds of Christion Endeavorers to cross the Atlantic like so many new St. Peters, "on their uppers."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- The Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association met at the Newport Reading Room this morning and with a stenographer and all the owners of the seventy-footers, and the Captains of each boat in attendance, took testimony in the race of the seventy-footers, which was protested by the owners of the Mineola and the Yankee, for the cup offered by the association.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The papers comment this evening upon Russia's latest communique and upon the utterances of the Journal de St. Petersburg regarding it. The Vossische Zeitung says that it will not make Russia's surprising step any more intelligible. The National Zeitung observes:

Work on the tax budget for 1901 was begun yesterday. The heads of the city departments have until Sept. 10 to make requisitions on the Board of Estimate for money to run the City and County Government next year.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- There was some increase in volume of trading, but not much. There was more interest in Chicago, Burlington and Quincy than had been the case of late, and a little more was done in the Atchison shares. Sugar continued the leader, while interest in mining stocks was narrowed to Utah, Wolverine, and Osceola, with dealings small in these.

William E.D. Stokes appeared in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station early this morning as complainant against Herbert Haughton, dealers in real estate and ownceny of $6, although he said he believes the prisoner had taken money and articles to the value of between $5,000 and $6,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The War Department to-day made public the following letter of instructions, purporting to be signed by Aguinaldo, with the explanation that it was among the records captured by the American forces. The instructions refer to the attack which it was contemplated to make on Manila early in January, 1899:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5. -- The Western Turf Association, which owns Tanforan Park, has reelected all of its old officers and decided to begin the racing season for 1900-1901 on Nov. 19. It is understood that Prince Poniatowski, who, with Charles Fair and W.H. Crocker, now controls the association, and is planning to secure the Ingleside track, will go East on Friday and endeavor to interest Messrs, Keene and Whitney in the enterprise.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against Solomon Feldstein, dealer in leather and findings at 66 Canal Street and 90 Pitt Street, by Stern, Singer Barr, for the following creditors: United States Leather Company, $10,440 Albert R. Bogert, $707, and the New York Counter Company, $71.

The dining room of the residence of Archbishop Corrigan, at Fiftieth Street and Madison Avenue, was the scene of a lively struggle last evening. During the disturbance glassware and furniture worth about $500 were destroyed by a man who was temporarily insane.
The managers of Mr. Bryan's Eastern campaign have become indirectly involved in the political struggle between David B. Hill and the Croker-Murphy faction.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Another bright day favored the lawn tennis players here to-day, and the open tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Lawn Tennis Club was continued all day long on the club courts in Upper Broadway. The feature of the day was the struggle for places in the semi-final round of the championship singles, and the four fortunate players to earn brackets were Paret, Brannan, Tallant, and Millard.
BATH, Me., Sept. 5. -- Arthur Sewall died at 8:30 A.M. to-day at his Summer home at Small Point, about twelve miles from this city. He was stricken with apoplexy last Sunday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5. -- The greatest political battle in the history of the Republican Party of Connecticut was fought to a bitter end to-day when in the long-awaited State Convention the candidates for the various State offices were nominated and the party Presidential Electors were chosen, the victory went to the State organization and against ex-National Committeeman Samuel Fessenden of Stamford.

The stock market yesterday at the opening developed a generally stronger tone, reflecting the favorable view taken of the Vermont election returns and the higher quotations sent over by London -- the advance in those quotations being due in large measure to early buying from this side following the news from Vermont.
BATH, Me., Sept. 5. -- Arthur Sewall died at 8:30 A.M. to-day at his Summer home at Small Point, about twelve miles from this city. He was stricken with apoplexy last Sunday.

Secretary Lyman J. Gage of the Treasury was in New York last night for a few minutes. The Secretary, accompanied by Mrs. Gage, came from Washington, reaching the city at 6:30 o'clock. He drove immediately to the Barge Office, where he was joined by Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, and Mrs. Hillls, who will be his guests on board the lighthouse tender Iris on a short cruise along the New England coast.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- There was no response here to the improvement in the New York market. Trading was slightly more active, but the activity was due to an increase in the sales of Marsden, under which the price receded half a point. The selling was believed to be by large holders.

DEER PARK, Md., Sept. 5. -- Mr. Bryan doubled on his tracks to-day, and to-night finds him again enjoying the refreshing breezes of the summit or the Alleghanies. He made only two speeches during the day, the first at Morgan's Grove, near Shepherdstown, and the second at Keyser. At both places the crowds greeted him with enthusiasm and both speeches were vigorously applauded.

Janpole Werner have resold the two five-story double flats 137 and 139 West One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 50 by 100.11, recently taken by them in trade for five lots on the south side of One Hundred and First Street, just west of First Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Forty-cent gas, a cut of 10 cents per 1,000 cubic feet, was announced by the Municipal Gas Company this afternoon as a reply to the action of the Ogden Gas Company in meeting its cut to 50 cents on Tuesday. Dwellers on the North Side expressed confidence that before the end of the week they would be enjoying house illumination without cost.

Laborers employed by the Edison Electric Light Company were prevented by two women in Monitor Street, Greenpoint, yesterday from putting up a big pole in front of their homes. The women were Mrs. Frederick Trautwein, the wife of an upholsterer, who lives in and owns a neat three-story apartment house opposite Winthrop Park, at 166 Monitor Street, and Mrs. W.J. Cosby, the wife of a machinist, who owns a similar house at 165 Monitor Street.

The encroachment on the public sidewalk in West Forty-second Street, between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, by the Pabst Hotel portico and inclosed balcony came before Justice Joseph H. Stiner in the Tenth Municipal District Court yesterday.

There seems to be every prospect that the interruption to traffic in Broadway through the change of motive power of the Metropolitan Railway Company will be over about the middle of the month. President Vreeland, after going over the line yesterday and consulting with his subordinates, announced that the surface of the street from the Battery to Central Park and to Columbus Avenue will have been restored in twelve days.

NEWPORT, Sept. 6. -- The event of this evening was the dinner which Mrs. Frederick Neilson gave at the Casino. The horseshoe piazza and theatre were inclosed by improvised hedge fences, while from the eaves of the piazza, root heavy rows of garlands were suspended so as to form a flower room over the heads of the guests who sat upon the lawn.

There is something highly respectable in the attachment of a man for his old associations, whether they be personal, social, or political. Therefore we have no hesitation in saying that there is something highly respectable in the coming out of RICHARD OLNEY in favor of W.J. BRYAN.

Mishaps before the start spoiled the plans for pair matches in the opening race of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's raceabout tournament at Oyster Bay yesterday, and possibly brought the three days' series of contests for the J. Rogers Maxwell Cup to an untimely end.

The first public test of the Langston mooring device, an invention which has aroused the interest of the Navy Department, was made yesterday in Gravesend Bay and was observed by a party which included several high officers of the navy. The inspection party went aboard the Albert H. Ellis at Pier 3, on the East River, at 11 o'clock A.M.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- For the first time this season the thirty-foot boats were compelled to sail this afternoon under double reefs. The thirties started out to battle for a cup offered by W. Butler Duncan. They started at 3:23 P.M. The summaries:

Judge Brown of the United States District Court yesterday appointed Theodore M. Taft receiver of the assets of Solomon Feldstein, dealer in leather and findings at 66 Canal and 90 Pitt Streets, against whom creditors filed a petition in bankruptey on Wednesday, on the application of Stern, Singer Barr, representing Chapman Burt, creditors, for $4,393.
Hugh McLaughlin has deserted Controller Coler in the fight for the Gubernatorial nomination. The surrender of the Brooklyn leader to Richard Croker was most abject yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- New York County pays 49.6 per cent, of the State tax for 1900; Greater New York pays about 64 per cent. of the entire tax which must be raised this year for the support of Government. In connection with the adoption of the equalization table of 1900 it may be interesting to note just how the counties which have representatives on the board fared.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- The first automobile race ever held in this section drew about 10,000 people to Aquidneck Trotting Park this afternoon. The races were made up of all kinds of motor vehicles, from the gasoline tricycle to William K. Vanderbilt, Jr.'s, French gasoline machine. Some of the events were most exciting, but the majority were tame.

SAN FRANCISCO, Call, Sept. 6. -- The Overland Monthly, founded by Bret Harte thirty-two years ago, and made famous by himself, Mark Twain, Joaquin Miller, Charles Warren Stoddard, and other California writers, has been sold to Frederick Marriott, proprietor of The San Francisco News Letter, a weekly literary and commercial paper.

An "inspired" report has found its way into the newspapers that the controller of the important actions of Tammany Hall has decided that Representative DANIEL J. RIORDAN of the Eighth Congressional District and Representative THOMAS J. BRADLEY of the Ninth District are to be renominated for Congress, and that Representative WILLIAM ASTOR CHANLER of the Fourteenth District is to be refused the compliment of a return.
LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The money market was a shade harder to-day owing to renewed operations by the Bank of England to establish an improvement in rates.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Alexander Maybaum, ex-Mayor of Vailsburg, caused a sensation at a meeting of the Common Council of that borough last night, when he charged indirectly that money was illegally used for the purpose of getting the Council to purchase the water plant owned by two local land companies.
ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- Controller Morgan died at 10 o'clock last night at his home, 1 Main Avenue, in this city. Heart disease was the immediate cause. He had been ill for two weeks, but was recovering.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The State Department made the following announcement to-day:

Militarism couchant and rampant, imperialism, Anglomania, and numerous other diseases, which, according to Mr. BRYAN, EDWARD ATKINSON, AGUINALDO, and other patriots, are threatening the health, if not the life, of our body politic, will certainly be discovered in the report of Vice Admiral SEYMOUR on the operations in China under his direction.

Papers were served yesterday on Lee Phillips, Secretary of the Now York Civil Service Commission, to prevent the sanitary squad of Greater New York from being paid pending a decision as to whether the men were legally appointed. The complainant named in the action is Israel Stone.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Delegates from the eight Congressional districts had already conferred and decided upon the district electors before the Republican State Convention was called to order by State Chairman Franklin Murphy in the Taylor Opera House, shortly after noon to-day. It was apparent from the first that there would be no opposition to the selection of John F. Dryden and David Baird as Electors at Large.

NEWPORT, Sept. 6. -- The result of the women's golf match on the links of the Newport Golf Club was reached to-day for the handsome cup offered by Mrs. Royal Phelps Carroll. Miss Anna Sands won in the finals from Miss Madeline Goddard by a score of 1 up.
WHEELING, W. Va., Sept, 6. -- W.J. Bryan's speech here to-night was the longest speech he has delivered during his West Virginia campaign. It was in part as follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The population of Trenton, N.J., is: 1900, 73,307; 1890, 57,458.

After a wait of over two months, during which time Withers Dickson, the architects, whose plans for the new City Prison were accepted by Commissioner Wright under the Strong administration, hava vainly endeavored to get a satisfactory reply from Commissioner of Corrections Lantry, they yesterday made public the following letter which they sent to the Commissioner on July 27:

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 6. -- The Prohibitionists' State Convention in Worcester to-day was attended by 176 delegates from 73 cities and towns. They had a parade from Union Station to the hall, with a drum corps and wore badges showing canteens turned upside down. The speakers denounced President McKinley as a "backslidden Methodist, traitor, and anarchist."

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- Inquiry at the office of the Election Commissioners shows that Richard Olney, who, in his letter announcing himself for Bryan, pointed out the duty of every citizen to exercise his right of suffrage, is not himself a registered voter and has not been for at least five years.
A special meeting of the Board of Directors of the Southern Pacific Company was held at noon yesterday in this city, which was productive of some important results.
A likely array of light-harness horses will face the starter at the Road Drivers' matinee at the Empire City track to-morrow, as the following entry list shows:

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve, increased u436,000; circulation, increased u270,000; bullion, increased u696,531; other securities, decreased u665,000; other deposits, decreased u314,000; public deposits, decreased u2,336,000; notes reserve, increased u472,000; Government securities, decreased u2,098,000.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 6. -- The celebration in honor of the two fleets continued to-day with a luncheon for the Admirals at the cottage of Johnston Livingstone, a garden party in the afternoon at Kenarden Lodge, the home of John Stewart Kennedy of New York, and a large dinner at the Malvern, followed by a dance, both given by Mr. and Mrs. De Grasse Fox.

(From The New York Tribune.) Acting Mayor Guggenheimer is thoroughly sick of his job, and will not be a candidate for any city office next Fall. Some of Mr. Guggenheimer's admirers, noticing the businesslike way in which he has been discharging the duties of the office of Mayor in the absence of Mayor Van Wyck, have suggested that no fitter candidate could be found for the Mayoralty than Mr. Guggenheimer.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Several dispatches have arrived from Washington during the last five days, which have met with various interpretations here. One of these is that the United States Government intended to withdraw its troops from Peking if Russia did the same. Official circles were slow to believe this, however, although a short Washington dispatch to-day seems to confirm it.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6. -- After three days' deliberation the conference of distillers and distributors has accomplished what seems to be the closest association, if not the strongest combine, of spirit distilling, interests since the days when the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company controlled 95 per cent. of the output of such goods.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6. -- No action was taken to-day by the National Board of the United Mine Workers of America, which is in session here, regarding the proposed strike in the Pennsylvania anthracite coal region. It is understood, however, that the members of the board were placing themselves in possession of information that will be used in the final consideration of the matter.

For a third time Miss Georgiana Wendel of Irvington-on-Hudson, who is alleged to be insane by her family, failed to appear before County Judge Smith Lent of West-Chester County, at White Plains, yesterday, although he had ordered her and her custodians to present themselves without fail at 2 o'clock.

Senator WELLINGTON of Maryland has made a speech in his home town of Cumberland in which he has declared that he will support BRYAN for President. This announcement was anticipated. For several years he has been gradually disagreeing with his own party at home, with the Senators of his own party at Washington, and with the Administration.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
Charles Buek has sold, through Oscar L. Foley, for about $63,000, the new five-story American basement dwelling, 49 East Forty-ninth Street, 21 by 60 by 100.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 6. -- The Grand Circuit racing to-day was sensational in one feature. Prince Alert, one of the three starters in the free-for-all pace, after making half in 1:00 3/4, came in at the wire either held by Walker, who was up, or in distress, taking second place. The bets were declared off by the judges on the supposition that Walker held the horse.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 6. -- It is understood here that the Pittsburg and associated interests have taken costly and determined steps to insure the development of an expert business in iron and steel. A hurried order has been placed for the construction of a fleet of ten great freighters that will ply from Lake Erie ports via the Welland Canal and Gulf of St. Lawrence across the Atlantic.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 6. -- Gov. Theodore Roosevelt arrived in this city to-day, accompanied by John Proctor Clark of New York. A committee of about 150 Detroiters met the Governor's train at Essex, Ont., and escorted him here. A public reception was held in the hotel this afternoon.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 6. -- A foursomes golf match between officers of the British and American squadrons was one of the features of the naval celebration here to-day. The match was eighteen holes, handicap medal play, for two handsome silver cups offered by Mrs. George R. Sheldon' of New York.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 6. -- The refusal of the coal companies at their conference in New York to confer with the miners only makes the belief among the people of the Wyoming Valley the stronger that there will surely be a strike. The miners will be compelled to go out now or back down ignominiously.

The latest claimant for feminine swimming honors is a schoolgirl, Miss Priscilla Higgins, the fourteen-year-old daughter of George A. Higgins, a well-known resident of Fort Hamilton, where he lives at the Shore Road and Ninety-seventh Street. Miss Higgins yesterday swam across the bay from Fort Hamilton to St. George.

The Republican Club started a new political plan on the Bowery last night by formally opening headquarters in the heart of Senator Timothy D. Sullivan's district. The headquarters are at 132 Bowery, where the club has rented the entire building for the remainder of the campaign.

Yesterday's market for outside securities was in most respects a counterpart of the earlier days of the week, but at the close several issues which had been neglected for many days attracted some attention. Distilling of America and one or two other stocks showed some strength after a long period of dullness and helped a little to relieve the monotony of the market.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- At the Democratic Town Convention here yesterday a resolution that caused some excitement was introduced by Vincent Ford. The resolution pledged the delegates to the County Convention to work to elect to the State Convention delegates favorable to Bird S. Coler for Governor. The resolution was defeated by a vote of 17 to 21.

Claims under the prevailing rate of wages law to the number of twenty and aggregating $50,000 were filed yesterday with the Controller. All the claimants were employes of the Charities Department, who were paid $1 a day for their services, and now declare that they were entitled to the prevailing rate with double price for Sundays and holidays.

CHRISTIANIA, Sept. 6. -- A telegram from Tromsoe, Norway, reports the return of the Stelia Polare with the Duke of Abruzzi's arctic expedition on board. It says the Stella Polare reached a point in latitude $6.33 north, thus penetrating further north than Dr. Nansen.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- Bingham Mining was prominent in to-day's trading, the price rising 3/4, to 12 3/4, continuing yesterday's advance of 1/2. Fitchburg preferred was strong, hardening 3/8, to 138 3/8. Massachusetts Electric wag fairly active at 24 3/4@ 24 1/2%, the preferred selling at 76 1/2. Sugar quieted, only 800 shares selling in the first half of the day, against 3,500 shares in the same time yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- The State Equalization Board met in annual session to-day and adopted the equalization table for 1900 fixing the percentage of State tax for 1900 to be paid by the respective counties. The table as compiled shows an increase in the assessed value of real estate over last year amounting to $397,744,563, and a decrease in the personal property subject to local taxation over last year of $12,838,635.

Mounted Policeman James D. Cotter, attached to the Tremont Station, turned out with the squad at noon yesterday, and was riding his horse on Tremont Avenue, at the corner of Washington Avenue. At that point the tracks of the Union Trolley Company run, and a car had just passed. The horse stepped on the rail, and immediately leaped several feet into the air, having received a severe shock.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Sept. 6. -- W. J. Bryan addressed a large meeting on imperialism in the city park to-day. The Democratic candidate also discussed more fully than before the charge that he had secured the ratification of the peace treaty with Spain.

Aside from a sensational mixup in the opening race, in which three horses fell with their riders, all escaping severe hurt, the racing at Sheepshead Bay yesterday Was uneventful, though the sport was excellent. The weather was fine, the attendance close to holiday proportions, and the track phenomenally fast.

Sorrow has been brought to many a household in the residence section of Washington Heights, between Broadway and St. Nicholas Avenue, from One Hundred and Forty-fifth to One Hundred and Fiftieth Streets, by a dog poisoner who has been busy there for about a week. The police of the West One Hundred and Fifty-first Street Station have worked on the case without result.

The New York and the St. Louis baseball team gave about the worst exhibition at the Polo Grounds yesterday that has been seen there in some time. St. Louis took a lead at the start and was never headed. Sudhoff, their little pitcher, was a tough proposition for the New Yorks. The score:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- A new note to Russia is being prepared, copies of which will be sent to the other powers. Acting Secretary of State David J. Hill was in conference with the President about it this afternoon, and after the close of business at the departments there was another conference at the White House, in which not only Dr. Hill but Secretary Root participated.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6. -- The Democratic State Central Committee held its postponed organization meeting here this afternoon. The important duty of sending out a call to the party for the primaries was finished. The call is an open one, referring in no way to free silver, as the Bryan wing at the earlier meeting attempted to have it.

Brooklyn Democrats named the sixty-three delegates to the State Convention at their Assembly district conventions last night. In all but one district the delegates were elected without instructions. In this one district, Mr. Coler's home district, the Seventeenth, the delegates were pledged to support Controller Coler as the candidate for Governor, "first, last, and all the time." Bridge Commissioner Shea is the leader of this district.

-- Trouble of a kind which, though it is far from uncommon in these latter, days, is carefully ignored in the current denunciations of trusts, is reported from a city that would be regarded as a big one if it were not so near New York. The manager of a theatre there recently found himself in need of a chief for his corps of stage carpenters.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Ten thousand people greeted Controller Coler at the Chatham Fair to-day, and accorded him an ovation. He was introduced to the people by the President of the Agricultural Association, and addressed them. He again attacked commercialism in politics, speaking in part as follows:

The National Civil Service Reform League, of which Carl Schurz is President, recently sent through a sub-committee a letter to the Chairmen of the Republican and Democratic National Committees with respect to the solicitation of political assessments from public employes during the campaign.
WILLIAMS, Cal., Sept. 7. -- The Rev. Lorenzo Waugh, the oldest Methodist minister in the world, died suddenly in the railroad station here just after alighting from a train.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- It was a decidedly dull market to-day. Barely 1,000 shares of mining stocks changed hands in the first half of the day, with considerably less Sugar and very little railroad stock, save that 1,000 shares of Atchison common came out. General Electric was taken well, 325 shares selling in the morning at 141@142, mostly 141.

We have received another communication from the correspondent who was probably the first to lift the veil covering the identity of the author of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden," in which the writer presents additional information concerning the Countess von Arnim, called forth by the publication in last week's TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of extracts from a magazine article entitled "A Pious Pilgrimage."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: May I use your columns to make a point with reference to books in their external form? It has been for a good while the fashion to reduce the punctuation of the title page to the lowest possible terms. Sometimes this goes so far as to make the title page bear about the same relation to ordinary print that a skeleton has to a man.

Now that Fall is at hand and Winter not far off, when men and women are most vulnerable on their reading side, some heads are no doubt thinking of what educational processes may be adaptable to the furtherance of the intellectual life of the masses. Their natural opportunities are necessarily slender, their taste is crude, their aspirations do not soar.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- A curious injunction suit was brought to-day in the District Supreme Court. The plaintiffs are Augustus Davis, Jr., William E. Ryan, and Matthew H. Ramage, and the defendant is the M.A. Winter Company. The plaintiffs charge that the defendant has in its possession the voices of Bryan, Stevenson, Sulzer, and other statesmen and refuses to surrender them, although the plaintiffs are the legal owners thereof.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The new note which was under consideration yesterday has been held up until replies to the Russo-American proposal are received from Great Britain and Japan. These replies may modify it.

From The Brooklyn Eagle. Some think that Richard Olney reflects or represents the present political views of Grover Cleveland. They argue that as Mr. Olney was Attorney General and then Secretary of State under President Cleveland, the accord of the two on politics now is plain.

A Word or Two With Robert Grant ANXIOUS INQUIRER inquires as follows: "I have just read Judge Grant's 'Unleavened Bread,' and want to say that the title is appropriate -- the book is heavy. But that is aside from the object of these remarks. What I wanted to ask was, why does he use the word 'appreciate' so often for 'realize'?

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Iowa Central Railway Company was held here to-day. The old Board of Directors was re-elected with the exception of G.E. Taintor of New York, who is succeeded by Horace J. Morse of New York. The financial statement shows net earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30 of $623,569.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In your "Art and Artists" column of Aug. 11 you are good enough to quote at some length from an interview drawn from me by The Strand Magazine lately. There are a few mistakes in your article -- one of the original interviewer's and two of your own reviewer's -- that, for the sake of "accurate drawing," it may be as well to correct, with your kind permission.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 7. -- Under the constitution of the United Mine Workers of America the Executive Board must decide before 6 o'clock to-morrow night upon the application of the districts embraced in the anthracite region for permission to strike.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 7. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived in this city at 6 o'clock this evening, and was accorded a grand street demonstration. To-night he spoke in the Auditorium, which was crowded to its utmost capacity, and later made a brief speech in Power's Theatre. During his trip through Michigan to-day. Col. Roosevelt made eight speeches, beginning at Bay City at 8:30 in the morning and ending at Hastings at 5 o'clock.

From the Cranbrook Press of Detroit, Mich., comes this, their first book, a charming reprint of what is thought to be the first published life of Lincoln, and was written early in 1860 by Mr. John Locke Scripps of The Chicago Tribune for campaign purposes. The reprint has been prepared by Mr. Scripps's daughter as a memorial to her father.

On a January day sixty years ago a famous man, and one who was to become famous, presented himself at Collector Bancroft's desk in the Boston Custom House and took the oath of office as a measurer in the United States Revenue Service, to which position he had just been appointed.

Another exodus takes place to-day. There are house parties everywhere. It has been the end of a very gay week and the close of the Newport season. The last days there have not been as lively as was expected, and the automobile race was rather tame. A dance this evening will be one of the last functions of the waning Summer.

Elizabeth Porter Gould has written a charming little sketch of Anne Gilchrist, and especially of her in her relations to Walt Whitman, in which the rise and gradual development of a perfect friendship is traced, the book containing as an appendix Mrs. Gilchrist's "A Confession of Faith," which forms a portion of Herbert Gilchrist's biography of his mother, published in 1886, the whole making a very interesting contribution to Whitman literature.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I could not help admiring the article of Mr. S.N. Tuckman, printed in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 11, in which the writer skillfully tries to demonstrate that Shakespeare was an orator. He, however, loses sight of a very important distinction. It is one thing to be an orator, and another to know the requisites of an orator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Minister Wu arrived in Washington from Cape May this afternoon, and, although it was near the close of the official day, he proceeded directly to the State Department. It is understood that he had received an intimation that the department officials were desirous of conferring with him, hence his return to Washington.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 7. -- William Bullock, the negro slayer of Chief of Police Walsh of Red Bank, escaped from jail through a tunnel under the floor of his cell some time last night.
