He was last seen at 10 o'clock, when the door of his cell was securely fastened, but when Jailer Brannin opened the door this morning the only trace of the prisoner was the tunnel's mouth.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 7. -- The features of to-day's programme in honor of the visiting squadrons were a luncheon party at the cottage of Mrs. Frederic Joy, a garden party at the Kebo Valley Club given by Mrs. James W. Pinchot and Mrs. Henry Dimock of New York, and a dinner party at Liangollen, with Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Jackson of New York as host and hostess.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: May I ask for the hospitality of your columns in an appeal from the criticisms of our compatriots which I have just read in Mr. Eliot Gregory's witty but unjust volume, "The Ways of Man," which, by the by, should have been called "The Ways of Man and Woman," for the author falls foul of both sexes alike?
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- This afternoon the thirty-foot yachts raced for a cup offered by Victor Sorchan. Start was at 3:25. Summary:

The last of a series of freight traffic conferences between officials of the Trunk Line and Central Freight Associations, which have been going on for the last week at the rooms of the Trunk Line Association, was held yesterday.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I am moved to send you the following extract and prophecy from one of Fenimore Cooper's little known books, "The Chronicles of Cooperstown," written in 1838, by reading the communication from Mr. Keese of Cooperstown and your remarks thereon, "Fenimore Cooper and Manhattan," in last Saturday's issue.

Copyright, 1900, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- The Rich Fool. Luke, xii., 13-23. GOLDEN TEXT -- What shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? -- Mark viii., 36.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- New Zealand will be conspicuous in The October Atlantic. The hero of Mrs. Mary Hallock Foote's story, "The Prodigal," begun in the September number, is an Aucklander, and intensely proud of his nativity, and Mr. John Christie, a New Zealand journalist, will contribute a paper on the development of the country which is little known to Americans not connected with its trade.

In polite speech there are no such things as superfluous women. There may be more women than men in some places, but no one would think of calling them superfluous. But in the science of social economics there may be such women, for superfluous means more than are needed.

George L. Merritt, cashier and confidential clerk of Hough Rowland, stock brokers, at 51 Exchange Place, is missing, and detectives are seeking him with a warrant issued on complaint of his employers, charging him with the theft of $12,563. Merritt has not been seen by any member or employe of the firm since Friday a week ago.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- P.F. Collier introduced the most original entertainment of the season this evening in the shape of a jungle party. The affair was to have been given at Bailey's Beach, but the threatening weather altered the plans, and all the properties for the party were taken instead to Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs's stables.

When a cable dispatch from Shanghai, telling of the killing of missionaries at Quirious, Fen-chow-Foo, and Taiku, all in Shan-Si, was shown to Dr. Creegan, Secretary of the American Board of Foreign Missions, yesterday, he said that he had no means of either affirming or denying its truth.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The editorial, "A Book Wanted," in today's issue of your paper, refers to the late Henry George as deriving in large part his economic views from Carlyle and Ruskin.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. John White Chadwick calls attention in the last SATURDAY REVIEW to a statement of Mr. Howells that Lowell "could not change his lines" in "The Cathedral," which some of his friends objected to because "they seemed to them too great a drop from the higher moods of the piece."

The local cotton market yesterday opened at from 22 to 30 points lower than the closing prices on Thursday, and the bulls experienced some of the panic which had prevailed among the short interests on the previous day. Holders of cotton in Europe, the South, the West, and in Wall Street gave orders to unload, on account of the high prices on Thursday.

HERKIMER, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Ex-Senator Hill appeared here this evening and occasioned something of a sensation in political circles. He came ostensibly to visit his old friend, ex-Judge Earl. He arrived from Albany at 5 o'clock, and was met by Judge Earl at the Central Station, and went with him to the Palmer House, where they had dinner together.

Bradstreet's reports 154 failures in the United States during the week, against 165 for the previous week, and 123, 142, 173, and 308 for the corresponding weeks of 1899 to 1896. The Middle States had 53; New England, 24; Southern, 11; Western, 44; Northwestern, 11; Pacific, 5, and Territories, 6.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 7. -- High officials of two leading corporations to-day stated that the Southern furnaces had been driven south of the Ohio River for a market, and are at present restricted to the small Southern domestic trade and the export business. They state further that the cost of production of pig iron has increased in the South in the last eighteen months $3 per ton.

Professionalism was the dominant feature of the stock market yesterday, with a resultant irregular movement of prices. At the opening the tone was heavy, partly because of the continued uncertainty growing out of the political situation, but in larger measure because of the rather free selling for London account.

The General Committee of the German-American McKinley and Roosevelt League met last night in the Assembly Rooms of the United Charities Building, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. Plans for carrying on campaign work among the German voters were discussed by the members of the league.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: My attention has been attracted to the article in THE REVIEW of Aug. 11 headed "Mr. Malone and Dr. Owen." It well illustrates how differently things look from different standpoints and what different meanings the same words will convey to different people.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Noting a few lines of dissent from my statements as to the paying qualities of books from a publisher's (a retired publisher's) standpoint, in some of your late issues, may I add:

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday extended to a larger number of stocks than recently has been the rule, but with three or four exceptions transactions were not in large amount. The general strength of the market has each day become more noticeable, and, though some few issues show declines, the tendency of the market for some days past has been upward.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Sept. 7. -- It is stated that Pennsylvania and New Jersey capitalists have in view the purchase of the Massapequa Hotel and adjoining cottages and unimproved real estate, owned by Snedeker Co. Thomas D. Snedeker to-day said it was true that his firm had given an upset price on the property to a real estate promoter associated with the Long Beach syndicate.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In the issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW for Sept. 1. I find Mr. George J. Manson of Brooklyn takes exception to a passage in Tolstol's "Ressurectlon" regarding Thoreau's attitude toward injustice and slavery. In the life of Henry David. Thoreau by H.E. Salt (Richard Bentley Son. London; 1890,) may be found, on Page 100, the passage alluded to, quoted almost exactly by Tolstol.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- I have always believed -- that is to say, of late years -- that when Bryant wrote of the saddest days of the year he really referred to August. Being an author, he knew that in August nobody reads anything, no editor buys anything, and no publisher in his right mind publishes anything.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 7. -- John P. Frenzol, National Secretary of the Gold Democrats, gave out to-day the following statement of campaign plans and reasons for entering the campaign against Mr. Bryan:

It was a day for the commoners among the horses at the Coney Island Jockey Club track yesterday. So, too, it was as far as attendants were concerned. Clubhouse, members' stand, boxes, and reserved chairs were pretty thoroughly deserted, and the grand stand, lawn, and field had but a corporal's guard as compared with the attendance on worst days of this phenomenally successful Fall meeting.

The five-story brick factory building 458 and 460 East One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, owned by T.B. Clark, who uses the two lower floors as a paper-box factory, was totally destroyed by a fire which started at 1:40 o'clock this morning. The police have no doubt that the fire was started by an incendiary.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, whose new pier at Jackson Street wharf has just been completed, is reported to have closed contracts with the North German Lloyd Steamship Company and with an English steamship line for regular service between Philadelphia and Bremen and between Philadelphia and London, respectively.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 7. -- In order to commemorate the baseball season of 1900 with special reference to the fine work of the Pittsburg club, The Chronicle Telegraph makes an offer which in substance is as follows:

The recent little revolt against Omar and Omarism (the coined word standing for some of the silly but harmless things done in the name of the Persian, who Mr. Andrew Lang thinks may never have existed) is easily explainable. It does not represent anything so serious and lamentable as a final reaction of taste against the FitzGerald quatrains which represent all there is of Omar that any but the crazy Omarites care for.
We publish in another column the "bitter cry" of a librarian in Massachusetts who has been collating the statistics of reading in libraries and deduced therefrom pessimistical conclusions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Manila newspapers just received at the War Department give details of a desperate mutiny among the native prisoners in Bilibia Prison, which resulted in the death of four and the wounding of fifteen of them. The report states that the outbreak came without the slightest warning.
PARIS, Sept. 8. -- At Maisons-Laffitte yesterday "Cash" Sloan, on the Due de Gramont's Barnevelt, won the Prix de Chamant, 5,000f., over a course of 2,100 meters.

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 7. -- At a meeting of the cotton spinners here to-day it was decided, practically unanimously, not to purchase American spot cotton during the month of September. Four-fifths of the employers in the trade were represented.
NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 7. -- Shirtwaist men may now attend court here. Judge Strong believes the new Summer garb to be a sensible one, and means to encourage it.

Not without pleasure and the complacency which arises from having done a good deed have we read the numerous comments on Andrew Lang's remarks and our own more recent ones about the distaste of typical literary men for music. That defenders of the professional purveyors of words should arise was to have been expected.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- Business on the Boerse to-day opened dull, owing to the absence of stimulus. Americans were quiet. Local shares were weak on an unsatisfactory report about the American iron market; later they had a better tone on London advices. Chinese securities were in special demand; toward the close they were duller.

Three annual railway reports, showing the results of operations in each case for the fiscal year ended June 30, were issued in Wall Street yesterday. The roads issuing the reports were New York Central, St. Paul, and Norfolk and Western, and in each case the figures made a very gratifying showing.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I notice "Agnostic's" tempting articles toward Dr. Owen's cipher stories, I feel friendly toward the correspondent who doesn't profess to know, and now that the threatened storm seems to have blown over, I feel encouraged to poke my head out again.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The riflemen's tournament on the ranges of the New Jersey State Rifle Association is nearing an end.

We do not accept at once stories of pictures bought for a song and sold for a million. Such yarns deserve careful sifting. The following in regard to the purchase and sale of an Italian work of art, since it has been repeated in several leading English journals, may he credited. A great many years ago Lady Arundel saw a small painting of a Madonna in Rome.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 7. -- The statement that Miss Ellen Jewett of Boston, the anti-lynching agitator, may make one of her famous speeches here has created some stir among the colored people. It has been said that Miss Jewett may be in Richmond next week, when the big colored Baptist convention opens, when there will be thousands of negro visitors in the city.

Developments in the trade situation during the week have been so conflicting that it is hard to determine whether the good or the bad predominates. On the one hand all reports indicate a general betterment of Fall merchant trade, particularly in the South and the East, while the settlement of the tin-plate wage scale has certainly averted a strike in that line.
NEWPORT, Sept. 7. -- Mrs. Edward S. Willing gave a dinner this evening in honor of Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor. Mrs. Astor was among the guests.

Better conditions are generally reported in the Dominion, says Dun's Review, and shipments to the North have not decreased as yet, although the season has advanced. St. John reports activity in dry goods, millinery, and shoes on Fall shipments, but orders for present delivery are small. The business outlook is encouraging at Halifax, with collections fair, and crop conditions promising well.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 7. -- The statement that Miss Ellen Jewett of Boston, the anti-lynching agitator, may make one of her famous speeches here has created some stir among the colored people. It has been said that Miss Jewett may be in Richmond next week, when the big colored Baptist convention opens, when there will be thousands of negro visitors in the city.

Developments in the trade situation during the week have been so conflicting that it is hard to determine whether the good or the bad predominates. On the one hand all reports indicate a general betterment of Fall merchant trade, particularly in the South and the East, while the settlement of the tin-plate wage scale has certainly averted a strike in that line.
NEWPORT, Sept. 7. -- Mrs. Edward S. Willing gave a dinner this evening in honor of Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor. Mrs. Astor was among the guests.

Better conditions are generally reported in the Dominion, says Dun's Review, and shipments to the North have not decreased as yet, although the season has advanced. St. John reports activity in dry goods, millinery, and shoes on Fall shipments, but orders for present delivery are small. The business outlook is encouraging at Halifax, with collections fair, and crop conditions promising well.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In your issue of Aug. 11, Page 532, Column 4, is a letter headed "Some Discrepancies in Henry IV." The fourth paragraph begins: "Now the battle of Holmedon or Holmedon Hill, occurred Sept. 14, 1402, and there were no guns or gunpowder in use in England at that date."
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept, 7. -- The Grand Circuit meeting closed at Charter Oak Park this afternoon.

Recently the representative of the Philippines Company in this city accused Col. Amos S. Kimball, Assistant Quartermaster General, United States Army, and in charge of the New York Depot, of having in his contracts discriminated in favor of the International Express Company. As soon as these charges appeared, Col. Kimball communicated with the War Department and asked for an investigation of them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Republicans are going to make an effort to carry North Carolina, according to Senator Pritchard of that State, who said to-day:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 7. -- The broad policy of administration which has characterized the regime of President Hadley of Yale was further demonstrated to-day by the opening of a new department in the university where energetic students of limited means can secure an education by their own labor.

A volume which will have a certain attraction for the lovers of novels in general, but particularly for those who are interested in books which have New York for their scene of action, will be "New York in Fiction," the publication of which is announced for October by Dodd, Mead Co. The author is Arthur Bartlett Maurice, editor of The Bookman; his work is fully illustrated from photographs of well-known houses and places.

Richard Croker and ex-Senator Murphy spent yesterday looking for a Gubernatorial candidate. The Tammany leader was anxious to conciliate the lieutenants of David B. Hill in New York, and also Hugh McLaughlin in Brooklyn. The hunt for a representative man to become the head of the Democratic State ticket was not successful yesterday.

The New Yorks defeated St. Louis in yesterday's baseball game through misplays by Jones and McCann. In the eighth inning, after two were out, McCann failed to hold a throw by Jones and two runs were scored before the ball was recovered, and Smith, who had hit the ball, was resting at third. Hawley's pitching was a notable feature. The score:

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Action in the investigation to determine the mental condition of Miss Georgiana Wendel was transferred from White Plains to this place to-day, when County Judge Smith Lent visited the woman at the family homestead.

J.C. Dana of the City Library of Springfield (Mass.) writes as follows to The Republican of that city: "The Critic of New York has lately been publishing each month lists of books reported as most popular by the libraries of the leading cities of the country. A compilation of these lists from Jan. 9 through June gives the results shown in the following table; twenty-six libraries, which are in twenty-two cities, are here represented.

Tom Ronan, who was introduced as the "Chauncey Depew of the Bowery," was the feature last night at the meeting of the new Republican East Side Club at 132 Bowery. Ronan proved himself a political speaker of such rare excellence that the crowd would have enjoyed a continuous performance by him.

The contract for erecting the Soldiers end Sailors' Memorial Monument in Riverside Park, at Eighty-ninth Street, for which $250,000 was appropriated by the Legislature in 1893, may be awarded next Monday at a meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Soldiers and Sailors' Memorial Arch.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 7. -- An unparalleled case has been recorded in the Mexican Custom House in Juarez. Two fine compartment cars, the property of the Mexican Government, built for the use of President Diaz and his Cabinet, were held by the customs officials for the payment of duty on the steel used in the manufacture of the cars.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The Chinese crisis presents no new feature this morning. Nothing appears to be certain. Regarding Russian action, various statements are made in Vienna and Berlin, with an assumed air of authority; but the balance of opinion leans to the belief that Russia is still inclined to adhere to her decision to evacuate Peking, whatever the other powers may do.
The salient points, of Mr. Olney's letter announcing his support of Mr. Bryan are herewith reproduced from The Boston Herald:

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 8. -- Squadron week at Bar Harbor was brought to a close to-day by a reception at the Poland Kettle Club, Hull's Cove, in the afternoon, and a dance there in the evening, both attended by a large number of British and American officers. The officers were driven out from the Mount Desert Reading Room in buckboards and cut-unders, returning to their ships in time for dinner.

GLASGOW, Sept. 8. -- An official bulletin issued to-day says two additional bubonic plague cases have been admitted to the hospital, and that nine additional persons have been placed under observation.

A GREAT FRENCH SURGEON'S CLINIC. -- One of the most interesting places which the hospitality of the Parisian physicians threw open to their visiting brethren at the recent International Medical Congress was the private surgical clinic' of Dr. Doyen, one of the leading surgeons of the world.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 8. -- Charges were filed to-day with the Governor against Sheriff Emmor J. Caldwell of Saratoga by John Burke Hennessy of New York City, the editor of a weekly publication, who alleges that Caldwell is neglectful of his duty in that he has failed to suppress gambling in Saratoga.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 8 -- Squadron week at Bar Harbor has been the gayest, most nerve-destroying, most picturesque week of the season. From the moment the flagship New York dropped anchor behind Rodick's Island the townspeople and cottagers have been in a mild state of excitement, endeavoring to carry out a crowded programme of events arranged by Admiral Upshur.

William Melbourne MacDowell, the actor and formerly the,, husband of Fanny Davenport, was arrested yesterday and locked up in the Ludlow Street Jail on an order of arrest issued by Justice McAdam of the Supreme Court, as a result of a suit for separation brought by his wife, Mrs. Wilhelmina MacDowell.

As was to be expected, the New York Athletic Club carried off the honors at the annual championship meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union at the Columbia Field yesterday afternoon. The winged-foot athletes won twelve of the fifteen events, leaving only three to be divided among the other clubs.

SARATOGA, Sept. 8. -- David B. Hill is facing, a desperate political situation. He is being goaded on by his friends and his enemies to make a fight against the Croker-Murphy faction in the State Convention. He is being urged to stand by his colors and sank or swim with the boom started several months ago for Bird S. Coler for Governor.

NEWARK, Sept. 8. -- Many devotees of tiapshooting assembled on the grounds of the South Side Gun Club yesterday to witness the match between F. E. Sinnock of Newark and W. B. Widmann of Trenton for the E. C. Cup, emblematic of the clay bird shooting championship of New Jersey.
Republicans regard it as a good sign that there is strife for the Republican Congressional nominations in some of the districts in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx.

A telegraphic dispatch from Raleigh, N.C., a few days ago, stated that a railroad ticket agent at that place had sold 300 tickets to negroes leaving the State during the month of August, and the information was added that a large proportion of those leaving North Carolina were going to Massachusetts.

It seems now to be assured that the name of Controller COLER will be presented to the Democratic Convention, and that those who favor his nomination and those who oppose it must alike stand up and be counted. This will of itself be a significant and useful spectacle. We all ought to be thankful for the events which seem to have made it certain.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Russia's proposition to withdraw from Peking has resolved itself into a problem for France which French statesmen are now tackling very gingerly. The complete withdrawal from Peking, after careful consideration, is now deemed not to be altogether in line with France's interests and her views as to the best and most effective method of dealing with the Empress Dowager and her clique of advisers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the present crisis in China was callable of a complete settlement, as far as the so-called Powers are concerned, without prolonged and serious diplomatic negotiations, is more than the most optimistic could have anticipated. Just now these negotiations are in progress, and a most interesting period it is.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The election of Mr. Odoll would complete the subjugation of the people of this State to the despotic power of the boss and invest him, virtually, with the executive and legislative powers of the State. If he could then seize the judicial authority, he would have the whole Commonwealth and could say, with the French King, "I am the State."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8 -- The fourth exhibition of the Newport Horse Show at the Casino is now a thing of the past, and with its memories will pass into history as having been one of the greatest social successes of many seasons, and it is hoped by every one in Newport that the Executive Committee has done handsomely in a financial way, and it is believed this end was accomplished.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 21. -- Notwithstanding all statements to the contrary in he official Russian press, there is a growing movement in Finland against the Russification of the Grand Duchy. The Finns will certainly not submit passively to a regime which threatens to deprive them of the hereditary rights guaranteed them by their Constitution.

Miss Anne Brown of Brooklyn adopted a cat this Summer. Miss Anne is an advanced woman in many ways. She believes that her sex has not had all the advantages which make for noble womanhood. She believes that woman should be uplifted in every way possible, mentally, morally, and physically.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived in Chicago at 9 o'clock to-night and proceeded at once to the Auditorium Annex, where he will remain over Sunday. He will start for La Crosse, Wis., to-morrow night, where he delivers a speech on Monday. He is accompanied by his secretary and John Proctor Clarke of New York.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 8. -- The picturesque grounds of the Rookaway Hunt Club presented an animated appearance this afternoon, when the first of the series of polo games for the Juvenile Cups, offered by William A. Hazard, were played. The day was perfect, and many well-known society people of Brooklyn and Manhattan, who are stopping at Cedarhurst, Lawrence, Far Rockaway, Hempstead, and Meadow Brook, were in attendance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 8. -- Francis G. Langdon, a wealthy resident of Hyde Park who is a Captain in the Seventh Regiment, New York, was nominated for the Assembly to-day by the Republicans of the Second Dutchess District.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Gas at 40 cents for all Chicago or municipal ownership is the cry of the mass meetings now being held to protest against the discrimination of the gas companies in making a cut rate for one territory and mulcting the remainder of their patrons for the full amount. Two big meetings were held last night, another to-night, and several are scheduled for next week.

But for one thing the artist would consider it an altogether satisfactory vacation. She went away gladly, but she came back still more gladly, but this one important discovery that she made will mean something to her for the rest of her life if it amounts to as much as she thinks it may.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 8. -- The nomination of George P. McLean of Simsbury to the Governorship by the Republican Party this week caps the climax of the bitterest and most abusive campaign known in the annals of the party of this State. The ordinary voter has been at sea in the conflict between "Boss" Fyler, who holds the reins, and "Sam" Fessenden, who would control them.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 8. -- The official police census gathered by seventy-seven patrolmen was announced by Mayor Fleischmann this morning. According to the police count the Government enumerators missed 14,556 people. The police census gives Cincinnati a population of 340,458, against the Government figures of 325,902.

BOSTON, Sept. 8. -- There was no market to speak of in Boston to-day. Transactions were few and far between, and scarcely a variation in prices was recorded. Mexican Central 4s were back at 79, and Bingham Mining held at 12 3/4. Quincy was strong at 149; Montana sold at 319; Calumet, 733; Tamarack, 222; Isle Royale, 30 1/2.; Eureka, 23 3/4, and Utah, 31.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nobody doubts that Russia is for herself first, last, and all the time. Her designs on Chinese territory are too deep-rooted to be lightly cast aside, and we may be perfectly sure that her present attitude on the Chinese question is only one of a series of well-planned and carefully executed moves.

From The Forum. After Great Britain had commenced her legislation for the protection of child labor, nearly thirty years elapsed before France followed with the law of 1841. The necessity therefor was indeed urgent, if the industrial population was to be saved from utter degeneration. Of this no better proof was needed than the experiences of recruiting officers for the army in 1840.

From The Atlantic. Yesterday Nature bore herself proudly; now she appears overwhelmed and tearful. The plumed bamboos which held themselves so haughtily are now spread and bent under the incessant beat of the rain, and cataracts run through their battered leaves. The fields have turned to lakes, the streams are rivers, the rivers are floods; and these roofs of bamboo and nipa are irrigating pipes guiding numberless Jets inside the houses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The spirited but injudicious letter of ex-Senator Henderson about our troops in China, which is reprinted in THE TIMES, appears inopportune at this crisis. Every candid citizen must admit that the position of the Administration was a difficult one when confronted by the Chinese imbroglio that so unexpectedly burst on the world.

On a former occasion we gave a number of details concerning the strength of Russian arms in Manchuria, showing what has been accomplished by them, and we drew attention to the fact that a war of conquest was being carried on there while the attention of the world was centred upon the Peking legations.

The play is over. The lights are out and the curtain has fallen. This is what one must believe of the season at Newport and Bar Harbor, both of which finished, technically this week. Newport had a horse show, an automobile show, and a number of dances and dinners and one large ball. Bar Harbor had its reception to the North Atlantic and British Squadrons, with attendant festivities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prof. Laughlin some time ago, Secretary Gage later, and this morning in your paper Gen. Schurz, show in a most clear light that the Republican Party is simply playing the sound money Democrats and independent voters for "blooming suckers," to use a phrase some of your readers may not understand, but which the man in the street will.

BANGOR, Sept. 8. -- The campaign in Maine, which closed to-night, has been fought on both sides with the greatest vigor known in the past ten years, the Democrats being encouraged in various localities to make a fight on local issues, while the Republicans have put forth the utmost exertions to keep the majority up to the average of former years.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- This town is becoming famous for its suicides. It averages one a day the year around, and during the hot weather there is a shocking increase of these melancholy occurrences.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

CHILDWOLD PARK, Sept. 6 -- The hunting season is now on here, and every one who shoots is in camp in the Racquette River region, or following a guide through the wood in the grass river country. A few ambitious hunters have brought in their two deer, which is the legal limit in this State, but they have not confined themselves to hunting high-antlered bucks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The last decade has witnessed a new departure in "emperorism." ("Imperialism" is a dangerous term to use these days; besides, the word which I use conveys a better idea of what I wish to say.) It is the "yellow emperorism" of Kaiser "Wilhelm, who has copied the ways of the yellow journals to advertise himself.

ALTON, Ill., Sept. 8. -- Two bloodhounds and a posse of fifty men, under the Rev. Owen W. Rose of Sabula, Iowa, are scouring the country in the neighborhood of Godfrey, Ill., just north of this city, in search of two negroes, for the purpose of lynching them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Admiral Watson reported to the Navy Department this morning his arrival on his flagship Baltimore at Tompkinsville. The Admiral will be detached from duty and placed on waiting orders for a time, while the Baltimore will be put out of commission and undergo extensive repairs at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

The journeymen barbers' unions of this State, especially of New York City, have united in declaring war against cheap shaves and hair cuts, unclean shops, " half-baked barbers," as practitioners are called who have served too brief an apprenticeship, and many other evils of the trade.

The statement has been made of late that, following the letters from members of exPresident Cleveland's Cabinet giving their views on the present campaign, the exPresident himself would come out with a letter expressing in a way the same ideas as did his former advisers and associates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8. -- The United States monitor Wyoming was successfully launched at high tide this morning from the shipyard of the Union Iron Works in the presence of thousands of people, lined along the shore or crowded on excursion steamers. The event had been made a feature of the semi-centennial celebration of California's admission into the Union.

In a well-sheltered cove at Bay Ridge the series of races comprising the sixteenth annual regatta of the Nautilus Boat Club were rowed yesterday over a course of five-eighths of a mile, with a turn. The start and finish were on a line parallel with the clubhouse, which was prettily decorated for the occasion, while the balconies were filled with handsomely gowned women, who cheered the contesting scullers and crews.

Charged with swindling east side women out of hundreds of dollars by promising them marriage, Joseph Topkin, twenty-three years old, a Russian cigarmaker, of 334 East Eighth Street, was locked up last night in the Eldridge Street Station.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your attention, editorially and otherwise, to the comfort and convenience of the patrons of the New York Central is most commendable, and has interested me, although not a regular patron of that road. The general question, however, is one of personal interest to all those unfortunate beings who are obliged to travel on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was natural that the partisan press should make merry over the smallness of the numbers attending the convention, but we cannot forget that the whole Christian Church once numbered only a dozen members, whose leader, we are told, had not where to lay His head.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been a constant reader of THE TIMES for the last two years. I must confess that I had never dreamed to what extent a man could talk through his "chapeau" till I came to read the letter published under the above title in your issue of the 19th of August last.

A secret society known as the Gee Kon Tong is the "poolroom syndicate" of Chinatown. Under its rule fan-tan tables flourish along Mott and Pell Streets, and depots for lottery tickets, flanked by opium dens, do a thriving business. But Police Capt Titus of the Elizabeth Street Station, nevertheless, asserts that the Mongolians of his district are no gamblers, and that Chinatown is the most orderly part of the city.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Belle Haven-on-the-Sound marked the close of its Summer season this afternoon by holding its tenth annual horse show in front of the Casino. A parade of four-in-hands was one of its principal features. Thirteen of these showy vehicles assembled at the brow of the historic "Puts Hill," coming from Stamford, Rye, New Rochelle, and Greenwich, and paraded to the Casino, two miles distant.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 8. -- No trace has yet been discovered of William Bullock, the negro murderer of former Chief of Police Walsh of Red Bank, who escaped from the county jail Thursday night. It is believed that Bullock, after gaining his liberty, took a course toward the shore, where he has or will attempt to board a boat.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 8 -- The cottagers have all returned to Lenox except Mr. and Mrs. Morris K. Jesup. The last to arrive were the Stokes family, who came down from their shooting box in the Adirondacks the last of this week. Nearly all have large house parties, or will next week, when the golf tournament takes place.

William F. King. President of the Merchants' Association, has prepared a statement concerning the subject of coal exports and their bearing upon the business of this country and its future commercial and manufacturing possibilities. Mr. King says in part:

BARNEGAT PIER, N.J., Sept. 8. -- One of the best races ever seen on Barnegat Bay was sailed to-day between the sloop yachts Arthur R. Fling, owned by William P. Richardson of New York City, and the Andarena, sailed by Capt. Eugene Long-street.

Sir Matthew White Ridley, the British Home Secretary, speaking at a public meeting last evening, said that no arrangement would be satisfactory that would provide the Chinese Government with a "plausible appearance of triumph."

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 8. -- The Republican campaign was opened here tonight by Senator Julius C. Burrows of Michigan, whose speech created a profound impression and is said to be the strongest exposition of the Republican position yet heard on the stump. Senator Burrows said in opening:

Copyright, 1900, The Associated Press. LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The Trades Unionists concluded their annual congress at Huddersfield to-day. A million and a quarter of skilled workers were represented in the deliberations, which have attracted wider interest than usual because of the sensitive state of public feeling caused by the recent strikes and rumors of strikes.

The report has reached here that the British War Office has decided not to put up any more disappearing guns on fortifications anywhere in the British Empire. Confirmatory information on this report was obtained yesterday from a high officer of the navy, who has had an opportunity of observing the new fortifications which England is putting up at Gibraltar.

NEW ROCHELLE, Sept. 8. -- The twentieth annual regratta and aquatic sports of the New Rochelle Rowing Club were held on the Sound to-day under very favorable circumstances. There was considerable delay i starting the last two contests, so that the eight-oared race was finished in the dark.

Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, Military Governor of the Province of Havana, Cuba, who arrived at Quarantine Friday on the transport Rawlins, came to the city yesterday afternoon. The General, accompanied by his aide, Leut. Dee, was met at Pier 22, Brooklyn, by Gen. John K. Brooke, commander of the Department of the East, and Capt. Willard of Fairfax, Va., who was senior aide on his staff during the Spanish-American war.

The Manhattans are an ideal family, their friends say. They credit this fact largely to little Mrs. Manhattan, who is a model housekeeper, has her house always in order to receive quests, sets a table which would do credit to a French chef, and doesn't spend a fortune in doing it. She also wears pretty gowns and has an amiable disposition.

Morris Lassar and Patrick Mulvaney, newsboy pugilists of tender years, had a prizefight last night considerably outside of the usual order of procedure in such events. The boys are devoted followers of the art to which Corbett, Jeffries, Fitzsimmons, and such others known to fame, devote their lives, and they and their followers had long discussed their, respective merits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You say to-day in an editorial: Mr. Sohurz makes it plain that the destruction of the country's business and the ruin of its credit is the price he is willing to pay to prove that the Republican Party was guilty of hypocrisy and false pretenses when it enacted the gold standard law.

Sir Walter Besant in The Century. The name of Ratcliffe, or Redcliff, marks a spot where the low cliff which formerly rose up from the marsh curved southward for a space and then receded. It is a hamlet which at first offers little to interest or to attract. It consists of mean and dingy streets; there is not a single street which is not mean and dingy.

The one pronounced feature of the stock market last week was its continued professionalism. What little life the market developed from day to day was due almost solely to the operations of the room traders, working for profits through systematic scalping, the record therein differing in no essential respect from that of recent weeks.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday presented no new features, and the total of the day's transactions was as small as has recently been the rule. Prices continued to show a good deal of strength, and advances were not wanting, but the market was not broad enough nor sufficiently active to attract much attention.

A man, poorly clad, with sunken jaws, was found, at 9:30 o'clock Thursday morning, lying at Forty-fourth Street and First Avenue by a policeman of the East Fifty-first Street Station. He was taken to the station house, and an ambulance from Flower Hospital was called. The man said he was Dennis Kenny, thirty-one years old, and homeless.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Japanese Legation received to-day a telegram from the Foreign Office, at Tokio. It said:

The management of the American Theatre on Monday, Sept. 17, will begin the system of a weekly change of bill with a spectacular production of a new version of "Three Musketeers," which will be presented with entirely new scenery and costumes and with every principal member of the stock company in the cast.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 8. -- The Republicans of Ohio opened the Presidential campaign here to-day with a parade, followed by a meeting which for enthusiasm and attendance has hardly been equaled in the Buckeye State.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 8. -- A hurricane, accompanied by a heavy rain, prevailed along the Texas coast and for a hundred miles inland to-day. Telegraph and telephone wires are down along the coast, and no accurate news is obtainable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At Morgan's Grove, W. J. Bryan, speaking to an audience no doubt composed largely of farmers, made the statement that he could not see why or how any farmer could vote for the Republican ticket, asking if the Republican Party is responsible for good crops or the famine in India.

From The Nineteenth Century. The Irish peasant is still, thank Heaven, what Sir Walter Scott called him, after the visit of the great novelist to Ireland in the early thirties-he is still "The gayest fellow in the world under difficulties and afflictions." He has a cheerful way of regarding circumstances which to others would be most unpleasant and disheartening.

Another effort may be made by Mrs. H. D. Gill to beat the record for woman drivers at the Empire City track this week. Mrs, Gill drove the crack Speedway pacer, Jack, (2:12 1/2) a mile close to the record at Guttenburg last Monday, and on the superior Empire track she stands a good chance of lowering the record.

The cricket season of 1900 is last drawing to a close. Still, considerable interest is evinced in the game, and quite a large crowd gathered at Prospect Park yesterday to witness the match between the Manhattans and a picked team of native West Indians, resident of New York. The West Indians had a strong batting side, and succeeded in putting on 132 before they were disposed of.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 8. -- Ordinarily there is requisition for from 70 to 150 kegs of powder every morning at each colliery of average size. Only four kegs were taken into the Pine Brook shaft of the Scranton Coal Company to-day. At the Diamond Colliery of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company, where eighty kegs are daily taken in, only two kegs were taken in to-day.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- Mareorama, stereorama, cineorama diorama, panorama! A list which suggests those conversations in "Le Pere 'Goriot " when Vautrin's wild chaff fascinated the shabby boarders at Mme. Vauquer's pension in the old Saint Marceau quarter. " In those days," says Balzac, " the recent invention of the diorama had introduced into certain painters' studios the joke of speaking in ' rama.' "

From The Engineering Magazine. One of the German locomotives shown at Paris is so singular in the salient feature of its design that, had not the idea been indignantly repudiated by its designer, one would have felt impelled to regard it as a huge scientific practical joke. It is a four-coupled compound express engine built by Krauss of Munich for the Bavarian State Railways.

Herman Duryea sailed the Yankee to another victory in the special races of the Larchmont Yacht Club yesterday, winning the silver cup set up by Commodore Clarence A. Postley. An amazing blunder on the part of Capt. "Bob" Wringe of the Mineola and Capt. George Parker of the Rainbow really won the fight for Yankee.

From The London Daily News. Entering the great palm house, after noticing that an impudent sparrow was perched on the head of the god Pan, and another on the bosom of the goddess Flora, was found a deeply interested procession winding round the palms and tree ferns. A young lady whose sweetheart was calling attention to the leases was naturally reminded of toilet and dress.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Just one week from to-day Capt. Pell of the football team will lead out his sturdy warriors on the university field and begin the preliminary work of the football campaign. He has sent out letters to all the candidates, instructing them to be ready to don their field regalia on Sept. 15 and start in on the nine weeks' work that must be spent on the gridiron.

The bank statement issued yesterday shortly before the close of business, and covering a period of five days -- allowing for the Labor Day holiday -- was a distinct surprise and disappointment to the Street. Instead of a predicted increase in surplus reserves, a decrease of $1,022,225 was reported. Legal tenders decreased $2,711,100, specie increased $2,387,500, loans increased $1,939,000, and deposits gained $2,794,500.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Railroads operating south of the Ohio and east of the Mississippi have departed from the time-honored campaign-year custom of gratuitously wheeling Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates and their retinues about their territory on electioneering expeditions.

LONG BRANCH, N.J. Sept. 8 -- Owing to the hot weather of the past few days, certain of the hotels here have kept open longer than usual, and those that have kept open have had a fair proportion of guests, and the week has been profitable.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Still another accident with its attendant panic and score of people seriously injured, though fortunately none fatally, is laid at the door of the Paris police, whose failure to keep a crowd under control on Sunday brought about the disaster.

From Ainslee's. The trouble between the cattle and sheep Industries mainly proceeds from the natural differences between the two classes of live stock. Cattle are home-keeping in their habits. They are as hard to lose as a house cat, unless, perchance, the cheerful and unreckoning rustler happens along.

No one questions or doubts " Bobs" in the British Army. His place is unique there -- and in all the world besides. In all the world besides no other man has the confidence, affection, and pride of so many men. It is not merely the private soldier who is wholly satisfied simply to be led by him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to take issue with your article in "Topics of the Times," in which you seem to pity our Brooklyn residents, saying that on account of electrolytic action (electrolysis) on the Brooklyn Bridge we are constantly depressed by the possibility of being some day compelled to leave our quarters on nothing faster than ferryboats, and you pity the anxious expression on our poor, pathetic faces.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Perhaps not at any Salon can the tendencies of modern art be judged so well as at a World's Fair. Here every nation is apt to put its best foot foremost, no matter how apathetic it may show itself in other departments, and to exhibit what its experts regard as the best of its current work.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- The lawn tennis tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club was continued here to-day, and furnished plenty of excitement and two disputes. The final of the championship singles was scheduled for this morning, but just before the match started Tallant's racket was broken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Orders have been cabled to Gen. Chaffee to prepare his forces for withdrawal from Peking. Further than that, the War Department has taken steps to have at Taku a sufficient number of United States transports to remove these troops to the Philippines as soon as they reach the port.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- With the Stock Exchange closed to-day, there was less doing in the money market than usual on Saturday. The advances for the day were easier and discounts were firm. The joint-stock banks were not disposed to work freely, and were disinclined to make concessions. The upwardness is expected to continue in view of the Bank of England's withdrawing money from the market.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 8. -- The Columbia Oval Cricket Club of New York played the Bridgeport Cricket Club here to-day, and administered rather a bad defeat to the local eleven by 40 runs and 3 wickets. E. Murphy, the New Yorkers' chief bowler, did some great execution with the ball, and captured 5 wickets for 15 runs, and S. Fox, who played well for 12, was the only Bridgeport man to score double figures.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The Kendals, who have been rehearsing a new play by Mrs. W. K. Clifford, entitled "Unwisely but Too Well," have been chagrined by the discovery that Sydney Grundy's play, "A Debt of Honor," produced by George Alexander on Thursday at the St. James's Theatre, is almost a replica of the work they had in hand.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 8. -- The weekly golf handicap at the Kebo Club to-day ended in a tie for first place between Henry Lane Eno of New York City and J. Montgomery Sears, Jr., of Boston, at 82 net. Many British and American officers entered the event, several bringing in good scores. The following among others handed in cards:

A Polish woman went into the Delancey Street Police Station last week and demanded that her husband be locked up because he had given her a fever blister. He had been in the habit of having these blisters, she said, but not until the night previous to her complaint had he dared to Kiss her, and then only because he was drunk.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 8. -- Hermosillo, capital of the State of Sonora, Mexico, is excited over the disaster which has overtaken the Wells expedition. This expedition was fitted out by Mr. Wells of Hermosillo to explore the Island of Tortugas, in the Gulf of California. The expedition left Guaymas in a sloop last June and the first account of its progress reached Hermosillo three days ago.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 8. -- W. J. Bryan made a record-breaking railway run from Chicago to Milwaukee to-day to open the Democratic National campaign in Wisconsin. Ninety-six minutes after the candidate's special train left Chicago, Col. Bryan was bowing to an enthusiastic crowd which met him at the station here.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 1. -- An eccentric woman has livened up things among the Summer hoarders at the various farm-houses near here. Her antics made more than one visitor from New York feel "crawly." She made the rounds of several of the most reputable boarding houses, and it was at the last she visited that the secret of her peculiar actions was discovered.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Sept. 8 -- The first week in September has proved the pleasantest of the entire season at Narragansett, and while the large hotels are beginning to close, the smaller houses, including the larger Imperial, will remain open through the month, while most of the cottage colony will remain well into October.

When the regular Saturday customers of John B. Dellagorio, a barber at 99 Park Row, arrived there yesterday they were astonished at seeing a large sign which covered the greater part of one wall. It read:

The story of the week-long wandering about New York of Julie Poiroux, with her two-year-old daughter Germaine in her arms, was told last night to the police, through the interpretation of a French waiter. Unable to speak or understand a word of English, she traversed the town over, looking for her husband and anybody with a moment's spare time who could speak French.

-- Mr. W.W. ROCKHILL, the President's Special Commissioner to China, having been interrogated by The Associated Press representative at Shanghai in regard to the situation and prospects of the unhappy empire as he saw them, proceeded to talk with great volubility, telling just what he thought the allies ought to do and prophesying terrible things if they adopted any other course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been a reader of THE TIMES ever since I can remember, but I find your partisan editorials favoring McKinley very hard to swallow, though your absolute fairness in printing letters opposing your views make a sort of jelly to mitigate the dose.

It is to be hoped that the recent legislation prohibiting camping parties from entering the Yellowstone Park, unless provided with camp stoves, will be adopted by the Forestry Boards of all of the States. The open camp fire, while undoubtedly a picturesque affair, is responsible for the loss of more good timber, game, and, sometimes, human lives than most people are aware.

Not infrequently men who have not had the advantages of college education declare that such education has no advantages. It is not often that the man who has had a college education declares that it was without advantage to him. The self-made man is altogether too prone to look down on college education.

HAVANA, Sept. 4. -- On the Gulf coast, well within the city limits, within a stone's throw of two of Havana's largest charities, La Beneficencia, the orphan asylum, and San Lazaro, the leper hospital, is a little inclosure within high walls. Loopholes everywhere along the wall and sentry boxes tell that its original use was not one of peace, whatever it may be now.

A season of unusual automobile activity is predicted for New York and Its immediate vicinity during the coming Fall. Several of the various committees of the Automobile Club of America have been holding meetings to arrange for different events, and by Oct. 1, when most of the prominent absentees return to town, the buzz of automobile interest will be heard unceasingly.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 8. -- After an all-day secret session the National Executive Board of United Mine Workers of America adjourned to-night at 7 o'clock until to-morrow. The board issued a statement postponing the ordering of a strike pending the result of negotiations. Officials say influences are at work to adjust the trouble, but decline to saw what they are.

The following incident in local campaigning shows a tendency on the part of the campaign managers to utilize the advertising columns of the daily newspapers for campaigning purposes. The following advertisement appeared in one of last Sunday's newspapers:
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $1,022,225. The banks now hold a surplus of $26,056,230 above the legal requirements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The crocodile tears which the Democratic Party and the so-called anti-imperialists lavish so plentifully when we speak of the Philippine Islanders ought to make sensible people laugh, when the source of those tears is considered.

SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 8. -- The ninth annual meeting of the New Jersey Rifle Association, which ended to-day, was one of the most successful ever held here. The last big contest to be decided was the President's Match, which was started yesterday. Capt. Walter F. Wittemore of the Fourth New Jersey easily held his position to-day and won handily with a total score of 262 on the six ranges.

For upward of a year, as men in the open reckon time, the semi-official slumbers of those for whom fate had no kinder allotment than a park bench, have been undisturbed by the blue-coated genii of the place. From sundown to sunrise every park in the city, with the natural exception of Central Park, has been given over to a carnival of beggary.

MANILA, July 20. -- A proclamation, of which the following is a translation, was issued March 14 last by the chief of the insurgent forces in Cebu: General Headquarters of the Revolutionary Army, Cebu.

"Arizona," the drama of modern American life at an army post, by Augustus Thomas, which will be acted for the first time in New York at the Herald Square Theatre to-morrow night, is somewhat more than a year old. It has been performed with great success in Chicago and some other cities, and has been published in book form.

David Garrick's victory over Ethelbert in the first running of the Annual Champion Stakes of $5,000, was easily the feature of the closing day's races at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday. The Lorillard colt has been an uncertain sort of a quantity since John Madden sold him to Mr. Lorillard.

Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor ou New York, looks what he is -- the successful man. His success is not due to chance, but comes from business sagacity and the application to politics of the business principles that brought him success in the financial world.

From St. Nicholas. At an entertainment given Queen Elizabeth by the Earl of Leicester the most astonishing prodigality was displayed. Among other sumptuous details it was reported that 365 hogsheads of beer were consumed. The Cardinal of the realm had in his household over 500 persons.

READING, Penn., Sept. 8. -- Warrants were sworn out this afternoon for the arrest of Irvin G. Becker, A. F. Zuber, and Henry Moyer, election officers, who conducted the Republican primary election in Perry Township, Berks County, last Saturday. The accused are charged with making a false return and stuffing the ballot box whereby Elias Zuber, Joseph Heckman, and Howard Seiger were returned as delegates to to-day's Republican County Convention.

After more than a year of service in the East, Rear Admiral John C. Watson arrived here yesterday on the United States cruiser Baltimore -- the fourth vessel to return home of Dewey's Manila Bay fleet. The big warship as she lies at anchor off Tompkinsville still bears the scars that a few stray Spanish shells imprinted on her sides and decks during the memorable battle.

"It's the season for dressmakers," said United States Treasury Agent W. H. Theobald yesterday, in telling of the seizure of feminine garb belonging to Mrs. Elizabeth Shanahan of 11 East Forty-sixth Street and Miss Anna E. Conlin of 8 West Thirty-eighth Street. In each case the woman will have an opportunity to explain her possession of the Parisian " creations " to Government officers to-morrow.

Clambakes have come to be one of the annual features of the New York Athletic Club, so much so that a large percentage of the members look forward to the yearly open-air feast of clams and other delicacies with as much eagerness as others await the big athletic games in Summer or the amateur minstrel show in Winter.

The matinee race meet of the Road Drivers' Association at the Empire City track yesterday afternoon was a well-managed light-harness function which proved entertaining to about 7,000 spectators. While of sufficient importance find dignity to be a distinct affair of its own, the meeting acted as a good prelude to the weeK ou Grand Circuit trotting which begins at the same track to-morrow.
Daniel W. Hopper has been elected President of the Maryland Fire Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The War Department has made public a report of Major Gen. Otis, giving details of the operations of the United States Army in the Philippines from Sept. 1, 1899, to May 5, 1900. The period covers the active operations that were begun after the arrival of the additional troops, including the new volunteer regiments.

Not a few homecoming residents of East Orange, N.J., in many respects one of the most attractive, convenient, and safe of our many suburban towns, have returned to discover that their houses, which had been locked and left without other protection than the general care of the police authorities, had in the absence of the owners been entered and plundered of such articles as tempted the taste or necessities of the robbers.

The rooms of the Detective Bureau and the adjoining hallways at Police Headquarters were crowded yesterday morning with hundreds of detectives from all the boroughs of the city. William Barrett, alias Thompson, alias Taylor, velvet smooth bank sneak thief, was the attraction. The police of Milwaukee, Cleveland, and especially of Paris are anxious to secure him.

Army officers are much concerned about the prospects of the military establishment. Under existing law the army must be reduced before July 1, 19O1, to the normal strength before the war with Spain, pro-one regiment of artillery, which was made a permanent addition owing to the necessity of having more men to man the new fortifications.

What are our objects in China? They were clearly stated in the memorandum published Sept. 1, to which Mr. ADEE'S name was subscribed, in the absence of his immediate chief. This paper was remarkable, among other things, for the first appearance in diplomatic language of the familiar phrase, "the open door."
Memorable in the history of ocean voyages will be the runs of the great German liners Deutschland and Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse from this port to the Lizard, where both were reported last night.

Continuing ease rules in the money market, though the indications point that this may not be for long. The movement of money to the interior has begun and the demand promises to grow greater from this time on. Naturally, this cannot fail to affect the situation, but bankers are in no way alarmed over it.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 9 -- For the first time in its history Pike's Peak was yesterday ascended by an automobile, and John Brisben Walker of New York performed the feat. Although he did not go quite to the top, yet he made an ascent of 11,000 feet, the highest, it is said, that an automobile has traveled anywhere in the world.

"Billy McGlory," (McGrory,) who lately opened a resort in West Fifty-ninth Street, between the Grand Circle and Columbus Avenue, has finally closed his concert garden, and has definitely, retired, worsted from the fight he had been waging for months against the friends of law and order in that section of the town.

SARATOGA, Sept. 9. -- The Croker-Murphy-McLaughlin forces, after a day of dealing with the up-State political leaders, announce late to-night that it is their intention to nominate John B. Stanchfield of Elmira for Governor, and State Senator William F. Mackey of Buffalo for Lieutenant Governor.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 -- A trip over the storm-stricken section along the Mississippi River, starting some thirty miles below the city and reaching to the Gulf, shows a damage of about $100,000 to the rice crop. Truck farms, poultry, cattle, and other damage will double the amount. The river rose six feet during the storm and flooded the sec- tion.

Hundreds of persons, most of whom were women, visited the United States cruiser Baltimore at her anchorage at Tompkinsville yesterday afternoon. The officers and men showed every attention to their callers, and were busy all the afternoon showing the location and telling the nature of the few injuries the Baltimore received while attached to Admiral Dewey's squadron at Manila.

Transactions in the market for outside securities last week assumed somewhat larger proportions than did those of the previous week, and at the same time a stronger tone prevailed. Daily totals were still small, but some signs of new life appeared, and here and there in the market was found an indication that in the near future trading may become more active.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept 9 -- The National Executive Board of the United Mine Workers of America adjourned sine die to-day without promulgating a formal indorsement of the application of the miners of the anthracite districts for permission to strike. At the close of the session President John Mitchell said:

The police of the West Thirtieth Street Station believe, from an autopsy made by Coroners' Physician Weston, that Charles T. Merry, the waiter found dead seated in a chair early yesterday morning outside a saloon at Seventh Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, where he was employed, was murdered.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 9 -- The West Indian storm which reached the Gulf coast yesterday morning wrought awful havoc in Texas. Reports are conflicting, but it is known that an appalling disaster has befallen the City of Galveston, where, it is reported, two thousand or more lives have been blotted out and a tremendous property damage incurred.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 -- Senator Wellington's flop to Bryan will not admit him to the councils of the Democratic managers in Maryland. Arthur P. Gorman, as the head of the organization, has neither welcomed Wellington into the Democratic ranks nor said one word of indorsement of his course.

Contracts have been awarded for the construction of 400 miles of the Kansas City, Mexico and Orient Railway, the total length of which will be about 1,400 miles, 100 of which have been built and are now under operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think your correspondent on the subject of "Profit on Silver Coinage" had a correct idea, but did not carry it out clearly. A very good little lecture on 16 to 1 could be worked up from this germ if put into simple language, which, by the way, is not done in most of the articles I have read on the subject.

Capt. McNamara of the Prospect Park police had a rather lively experience while in charge at Brooklyn Headquarters last night. He was enjoying the breezes from an electric fan upstairs in the telephone room of the Smith Street building about 10 o'clock when there came an urgent call for help over the wire.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 9 -- Later repairs and improvements on the four seventy-footers Yankee, Mineola, Rainbow, and Virginia have apparently been successful in remedying their more obvious defects in construction. It is now reported that none of the four leaks badly, and that Virginia, at least, is perfectly water-tight.

An operation similar in many ways to that performed about a year ago at Roosevelt Hospital on Walter Duryea for a broken neck was performed yesterday afternoon at the Harlem Hospital on Mrs. Annie Smith of 2,499 Third Avenue. The operation occupied nearly two hours time, and is expected to be successful.
The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, preached there last night on "The Golden Rule in Business, Politics, and Religion." He said in part:

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- W.C. Nixon, General, Superintendent of the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway, of which Galveston is a terminal, who has been visiting in Chicago, left to-night for Texas to assist in restoring traffic on his road, cut short by the destructive storm which swept the Gulf city.

It would seem that at Lydenburg the curious strategy of the Boers, which has characterized the Pretoria campaign from the first, has again been employed with the result that a practically impregnable position has been presented to the British while the enemy has moved on to some new place of refuge.

MARSEILLES, Sept. 9 -- Major Marchand of Fashoda fame embarked here to-day on a steamer bound for China, where he is going to represent France on the international commission composed of officers intrusted with the settlement of diplomatic questions and any difficulties arising between the different portions of the foreign corps.
"Well, Senator," said a NEW YORK TIMES reporter to Senator Thomas C. Platt at the Oriental Hotel, at Manhattan Beach, yesterday evening," what about the political outlook?"

The Brooklyn police were called upon Saturday to solve what appeared to be a mystery, but which yesterday proved to be no mystery at all. It involved the apparently strange disappearance of an aged woman, just arrived in this country from Denmark.

The Taff Vale strike is at an end. Nearly at midnight on Thursday, Aug. 30, telegraphs The Daily Mail Cardiff correspondent, the men's executive decided to close with the final offer of the company, and yesterday their constituents, assembled in mass meeting at Cardiff, accepted what was really the inevitable, five only voting against the decision to return to work.

The liveliest brushing in several months was seen on the Speedway yesterday morning. There have been days recently when there were more stepping matches, but not with the same quality of horses competing or the nip-and-tuck drives down the course. It was hot and no breeze was lurking around, but the horses were many, and so were the spectators.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9 -- The yacht Dart, Capt. Samuel Monroe, of the Absecon Inlet fleet, came near going to pieces with fifteen souls on board on the sandbar at the inlet this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The letter of President McKinley accepting the nomination of the Republican National Convention for the office of President of the United States, was made public to-night. It is as follows:

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The sensational crime of this week in Paris was committed last evening by a band of young ruffians whose methods are exactly like those of the "gangs" that made the lives of respectable people miserable in certain of the poorer districts of New York ten or fifteen years ago.

MANILA, Sept. 9 -- The Philippine Commission, at its first public session, to be held next Wednesday, will discuss the appropriation of one-third of the Treasury's $6,000,000 for the construction and repair of roads and bridges throughout the archipelago. The people profess to be much gratified at the prospect of this work of development.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- Much the most striking feature of the money market last week was a rise of three-eighths in private discount upon a more unfavorable statement by the Reichsbank for the end of August than the market had expected. The bank's heavier loss in deposits than usual shows the effect of the China expedition, causing a withdrawal of Government funds.
The last of the Sunday cycle meets for this season at the Guttenberg trade given by the American Cycling Racing Association was attended by 2,000 persons yesterday.

Diving through, nine feet of water in Coney Island Creek yesterday afternoon William L. Meyer went head first into the mud of the bottom, and was held fast by it until he died, in spite of all the efforts of his brother, Henry Meyer, and Andrew Sullivan, a companion, to extricate him.

The police of the East Twenty-second Street station found a girl, deaf and dumb, wandering about Third Avenue in a dazed and bewildered condition and apparently lost, early yesterday morning. She was taken to the station house and later transferred to the East Thirty-fifth Street station, where she could be placed under the care of a matron.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 7 -- Mails from the North bring a bunch of belated messages, with a notice from the cable office at Taku, dated Aug. 20, saying that the office, being five days behind on Government messages, is not able to undertake other work. The wires to Peking were being cut daily by Boxers, and communications were interrupted half the time, although restored as rapidly as possible by the British and Americans.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

HOUSTON, Sept. 9 -- It is reported from Beaumont, Texas, that the City of Sabine Pass was completely destroyed by the storm. The hurricane was the worst ever known. The last previous news from Sabine Pass was received from there yesterday morning, and at that time the water was surrounding the old town at the pass and the wind was rising and the waves coming high.

Several boxing matches, a potato race, arid an exhibition half-mile walk toy Samuel and Louis Liebgold, in addition to the regular track and field events, engaged the spectators at the games of the Pastime Athletic Club, held at the club grounds in East Sixty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon.

We should be at a loss to say, even after this lapse of time during which the eyes of courts and journals have been fixed upon them, just why it is that HORGAN SLATTERY were chosen as the official Tammany architects, and have been stuck to as such, ever since the present gang of Tammany bandits has been in possession, of the City Government, and, but for Mr. COLER, of the City Treasury.

Workmen have been engaged for nearly two months in refurbishing the pillar on Notre Dame Street, at the intersection of Jacques Cartier Square, which was erected in the early part of the century in memory of Lord Nelson, the greatest hero in modern naval history. Before the task was begun the monument, surmounted by a figure of Nelson, was rapidly crumbling from the effects of over ninety years of exposure to the elements.

A busy week is in store for the golfing fraternity. The Tuxedo invitation tournament is the big feature in the metropolitan district, and it practically marks the beginning of the local Fall season in large events. Westbrook, Essex County, Orange, St. Andrew's, Baltusrol, and others will months of undiminished activity are now months of undiminished activity is now assured.

So much has been said, since the issues of the coming election began to take definite shape, about the importance of choosing men of the highest character and the greatest force for membership in the next Congress that an inspection of the list of candidates thus far chosen must be made with peculiar interest.
The Republican County Convention will be held at Murray Hill Lyceum on Wednesday, the 19th inst. Candidates to succeed Justices Edward Patterson and P. Henry Dugro will be placed in nomination.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- There are many things in the exposition that are better calculated than the exhibition of the City of Paris "to take the eye of a vulgar crowd," in Rufus Choate's famous phrase about the second-hand harness. But there is not one that is more instructive to those who are interested in the problems of which the Parisian solution is here shown.

A north-bound car of the Eighth Avenue line crashed into a Roosevelt Hospital ambulance shortly before midnight last night at Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue. The car was running at a rapid rate of speed, and the ambulance was overturned, splintering its side and wrecking two of the wheels.

-- Keeping up its work -- possibly more profitable than patriotic -- as the official Filipino organ in America, The Springfield Republican prints a long letter which it says was sent by one SIXTO LOPEZ, formerly of Manila and now of London, to Gov. ROOSEVELT. The Republican sadly remarks that the Governor has not chosen to make the letter public, so it has been forced to do what little it can in that direction itself.

From The Portland Oregonian. He was that king of all kingly fishes -- a Royal Chinook. Fresh from the limitless freedom of unfathomed seas, from untracked journeys to mysterious feeding grounds, whose location no man has yet been able to guess, he was beautiful beyond compare; in form, fraceful, symmetrical; in color, a silvered harmony.

There was an election in Arkansas one flay earlier than that recently held in Vermont. It was assumed at once, without figures in either case, that Vermont had elected its Republican ticket and that the Democratic candidates in Arkansas had been successful. Since the first brief announcements concerning both States Vermont has reported very definitely, and the statement that the Republicans had won with a plurality of about 32,000 is not questioned.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- There has been no further word of the Russian gold about which so much was made a week ago, and now the market is disposed to look upon it as a myth, invented for the purpose of easing discount rates. Whether this was the intention or not, rates have sagged persistently, and have dropped as low as 3 1/2 per cent. for three months' paper.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 10 -- Starting as soon as the water began to recede, the work of rescuing the wounded and dying from the ruins of their homes began.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 5O cents for each $500 of consideration. This ''consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
WASHINGTON, Sept 10 -- The following telegrams passed between the White House and Texas to-day:

SOMERSET, Penn., Sept. 10 -- The President and party arrived here over the Baltimore and Ohio Road at 5:30 this afternoon, to be present at the wedding of Miss Mabel McKinley, the President's niece, and Dr. Hermanus L. Baer. In the party were President and Mrs. McKinley, Mrs. Katherine Matthews of Washington, sister of Mrs. Abner McKinley; Secretary to the President G.B. Cortelyou, Dr. P.M. Rixey.

"Help, quick! I've located the murderer of Katie Scharn!" shouted a wild-eyed man who rushed into the Coney Island Police Station yesterday morning. Capt. Driscoll, in his private office, heard the outcry and ran out. The stranger had hair that hung almost to his shoulders and a long beard.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 10 -- Admiral Farquhar took a hand to-day in the entertainment of the officers of the visiting squadrons. At 10 o'clock the Scorpion, a concerted gunboat, started from the harbor with a merry party of nearly 200 aboard, on a trip around the island to Somes Sound.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 10 -- W.S. Wall of this city, who has a Summer home at Morgan's Point, relates the escape of Mrs. Wall and others, who would have all perished but for the heroism of James Black, a well-known merchant at Morgan's Point. Mrs. Wall returned to the city on the first rescue train that went down to the Point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A formal order was issued to-day by the War Department announcing the retirement of BrigGen. Joseph Wheeler, who to-day reached the age limit of sixty-four years. Gen.
