Wade, commanding the Department of Dakota, was telegraphed to take charge of the affairs of the Department of the Lakes until the Department Commander arrived.

A number of New York and Long Branch horsemen met at Long Branch on Sunday night to plan the organization of the Gentlemen's Driving Association. It is the intention to secure Elkwood Park, near Long Branch, where there is a fine mile track and other equipments of a good plant for a term of five years, to promote harness racing.

The Brooklyn baseball team on its home grounds lost yesterday's game to Pittsburg through Leach, for the visitors, getting in a home-run drive in the eighth inning, with Clarke and Ritchey on bases. Leach had been substituted for Donahue, who had gone to right field as an understudy for Wagner, the latter having been called home by the death of his mother.

Only a jaundiced opponent and critic of the President can derive satisfaction from perusal of a condemnation of the letter of Mr. McKINLEY as a defensive document, forced from him by the assertion at Kansas City that the issue of imperialism was to be paramount in the Presidential campaign.

The effect of a further advance of 16 to 29 points in the Liverpool cotton market, greatly accentuated by the news of the Galveston storm, produced an activity of speculation and an intensity of excitement on the floor of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, which many old time traders declared to be without parallel in the history of the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The monthly report of the statistician of the Department of Agriculture shows the average condition of cotton on Sept. 1 to have been 60.2, as compared with 76 on Aug. 1, 1900; 68.5 on Sept. 1, 1899; 79.8 at the corresponding date in 1898, and 76.6, the mean of September averages of the last ten years.

From time to time small lots of "apathy" appear to be offered to the managers of the leading parties in the campaign, and purveyors of this political commodity are meeting with occasional encouragement from the really anxious. It is much more usual to hear of the business at this stage of political work than later, and for reasons that seem to be particularly strong in this campaign.

SARATOGA., Sept. 10 -- The meeting of the State Committee, which was called for 8 o'clock, sent the delegates trooping toward the ballroom of the Grand Union Hotel. The general impression seemed to prevail that there was going to be a merry war there between Mr. Croker and Mr. Hill.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 10 -- Among the refugees which the Galveston, Houston and Henderson train picked up at Lamarque, which is about 4 1/2 miles south of Virginia Point, was Patrick Joyce, who resided in the west end of Galveston. Joyce told a harrowing tale of hardships he had suffered to reach the mainland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is the "Democratic" Convention at Saratoga intending to imitate the Kansas City one -- also called "Democratic" -- by bidding good-bye to its senses and nullifying the people's wish? It looks so -- and what a curious commentary the situation makes on mere mechanism in politics.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 10 -- Wire communication was opened with Beaumont and Orange this afternoon. It is reported that several lives were lost in the localities of Sabine Pass and Port Arthur, but the towns are reported to have suffered only slightly from the effects of the storm.

SHANGHAI, Sept 8 -- John Goodnow, the United States Consul General here, after inquiries in every possible direction, learns that the number of British and American missionaries and relatives of missionaries probably murdered during the uprising in China has been ninety-three. One hundred and seventy others stationed in Pe-chi-Li and Shan-Si Provinces are unaccounted for, and there is reason for the belief that they have met the same fate.
HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 10 -- Richard Spillane, a well-known Galveston newspaper man, who reached Houston to-day after a terrible experience, gives the following account of the disaster at Galveston:
NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, Sept. 10. -- The tie for second place in Saturday's handicap in the Niagara international golf tournament was played this morning, and E.P. Fischer was the winner.

LENOX, Mass., Sept 10 -- W.W. Hoffman of the Atlantic Golf Club, the nineteen-year-old son of Francis Burrill Hoff man of New York, won the handsome Alexandre Cup at the opening of the invitation tournament of the Lenox Golf Club today. It was thirty-six holes handicap. He had a handicap of twelve, but made the best gross score of the day, and did his first nine holes in thirty-seven, three better than bogy.

EAGLE LAKE, Tex., Sept. 10 -- Three churches, together with many dwellings and business houses, were completely blown to pieces in Saturday night's storm. Crops of all kinds are almost ruined. The loss to this community is estimated at about $250,000. No lives were lost here, but the town of East Bernard was blown away and three persons were killed there.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Money was much wanted to-day, some heavy inovements being expected this week. Discount rates were firm.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- The liveliest and most exciting chase of the season was held this afternoon by the Monmouth County Hounds. There were fully 200 followers, who rode in every sort of vehicle and followed the hunt as best they could from the start, which was at Coddington Point. The riding of the Master of the Hounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Chinese Minister, Wu Ting Fang, to-day delivered to the State Department an imperial edict conferring on Li-Hung-Chang absolute and unconditional authority to negotiate with the powers for peace, and for the settlement of questions growing out of the war.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 10 -- The first train from Houston arrived in Dallas last night over the Houston and Texas Central. It left Houston yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, instead of that hour the night be- fore, the usual time of departure, getting here practically ten hours late.

As Galveaton, Tex., stood on Saturday morning its prospects were of the brightest. Its prosperity and rapid growth as a commercial, financial, and business centre seemed to be assured and those interested in its welfare were confident that great as had been its strides toward equal importance with New Orleans in the last few years, its advance would be still more remarkable in the near future.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let those who so readily yield to the demagogic persuasions of the Populists, and, like them, are ever ready to raise a howl of indignation against the policy of the Administration in the Philippines, peruse carefully the proclamation of Aguinaldo to his soldiers submitted by the press to-day.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62 1/2 @63 1/2. There were no sales.

Twenty sturdy-looking young men, candidates for the Columbia University football team, boarded a train at the Grand Central at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon for Branford, Conn., where the squad is to go through two weeks of preliminary practice before the opening of college.

From The Herald. There is much to be said in condemnation of the reprehensible manner in which some newspaper correspondents misinterpret their functions and neglect their obligations. The sole duty of a correspondent is to report what actually occurs. The public neither wants nor values his "views" or "ideas" or "opinions" about the events that he is describing.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Sept. 10 -- Gov. Roosevelt opened the Republican campaign in Wisconsin to-day, addressing two meetings here, one in the afternoon, and the other in the evening. Both meetings were held in the Empire Rink, an immense building, which was crowded to its fullest capacity.

-- Of course the alarm of the passengers on the steamer San Marcos because two heavy projectiles from the fortifications on Sandy Hook passed close to that vessel as she was entering port on Saturday will be treated by the military authorities as merely an amusing display of civilian timidity, and the usual statements as to the great care with which artillery practice is invariably conducted will be made.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 10 -- The Republican voters elected their State ticket today by a plurality over the Democratic candidates of more than 33,000.

How do the real Democrats of the State of New York, men who are not members of "the organization" nor otherwise "Democrats for revenue only," like the spectacle which RICHARD CROKER is presenting at Saratoga? It must be perfectly plain to them that, even while he is aspiring to extend over the State the bossism which, to our injury and disgrace, he is allowed to exercise over this city, he is a thoroughly disloyal Democrat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Senator Hanna arrived in Chicago to-day to take charge of the Republican National campaign. He was busy all day with Vice Chairman Payne of the National Executive Committee at National Headquarters, preparing the programme for the next three weeks. To Congressman Landis of Indiana, who urged the Senator to make several speeches in Indiana, Senator Hanna said:

NEWPORT, E.I., Sept. 10 -- The Esperanza and Dorothy raced in the finals this morning for Mrs. Herman B. Duryea's cup and to settle the championship of the fleet of thirty-footers. The Esperanza was sailed by W. Butler Duncan and the Dorothy by H. Yale Dolan, these two yachts having previously sailed in pairs with other yachts of the fleet and beaten them.

SARATOGA, Sept. 10 -- David B. Hill came to town in the dark of the night. His arrival at 1 A.M. was unexpected, and no political lieutenants met him at the hotel or station. Mr. Hill was assigned a suite of rooms in the Grand Union and far away from the cottage headquarters of Richard Croker.

The stock market yesterday was generally quite indifferent to the news of the day and developed no new feature. Trading continued professional and within narrow lines, barely 118,000 shares of stock being dealt in. Of this number London contributed perhaps 10,000 shares, the dealings mostly representing sales.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- William J. Bryan was the guest this morning of the Nebraska Bryan Club of Chicago at a reception held at the Sherman House. Col. Bryan having shaken hands with 200 or more people, was introduced by H.V. Gannon, President of the club, and said in part:

The new Board of Trustees, under the Elsberg law, of the College of the City of New York held its second meeting last night at the Hall of the Board of Education. All the members were present except Edward M. Snepard and James W. McKeen. Those present were Miles M. O'Brien, Joseph F. Mulqueen, Edward Lauterbach, Edward B. Amend, Theodore F. Miller, Fordham Morris, Henry P. O'Neil, Alexander S. Webb, and Charles Putzel.
NEWPORT, Sept. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kingsland of Scarborough-on-the-Hudson have rented Pinard Cottage No. 3, which they have occupied for the past two seasons.
Measures for the relief of the sufferers in Galveston are preparing in this city and are expected to take definite shape to-day.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 10 -- Gov. Sayers is in receipt of the following telegram from a prominent Galveston man, who made his way by boat from Galveston to Houston over the submerged country:
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The following statement of the situation was received to-night from Houston, Texas:

The annual outing of the Timothy D. Sullivan Association, held yesterday at Donnelly's Grove, College Point, L.I., was in the nature of a wake for the now dead Horton law. It was probably the largest wake ever held. At least 6,000 constituents and friends of Senator Sullivan took part in the affair.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Felix S.S. Johnson, the United States Commercial Agent at Stanbridge, Canada, has sent the following report to the Department of State:

SARATOGA, Sept 10 -- At midnight, with the first session of the Democratic State Convention but ten hours off, the Croker-Murphy-McLaughlin combine has positively agreed on only two of the candidates of the ticket which will be named by the Croker-Murphy-McLaughlin combine. Senator Hill and his friends are in a hopeless minority.

"Arizona," a drama of Western life, by Augustus Thomas, of which most New Yorkers who keep in touch with theatrical matters have heard much, and some have seen in other cities, was acted here for the first time at the Herald Square Theatre last evening. In the performance it quite satisfied, the expectations of persons who had read it.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Reading first preferred, Philadelphia Electric, and Electric of America common were the only stocks to show any life here to-day, one-half of the day's sales being of these three issues. Elsewhere the usual dullness prevailed. Prices were generally firm, especially the coalers, on a more hopeful outlook in the anthracite region.

In the Republican Conventions for the naming of candidates for Congress in the five districts of Kings County last night, all of the men who had been picked as winners were nominated, several of them without a struggle. The nominees are as follows:

BUZZARD'S BAY, Sept. 8 -- It has been intimated that ex-Secretary of State Olney's denunciation of President McKinley and imperialism and his declaration for Bryan for the Presidency would be followed by a similar utterance from ex-President Grover Cleveland, but it can be safely said that no such action will be taken by the former President during this campaign.

B.B. Odell, Jr., Republican nominee for Governor, referred to the Ramapo question, denying that he was interested in that or any other water company in a speech which he made last night at the Republican Club at 450 Fifth Avenue, where a reception was given to the nominees of the Saratoga Convention.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- It is quite within the bounds of possibility that the exposition may be kept open for another month after Nov. 5, the day originally set for closing, even though formal notification was sent out last week that the time would not be extended.

Vacation ended for public school pupils yesterday morning and every schoolhouse was a centre of great activity and more or less confusion as the boys and girls filed in with their parents to be registered on the opening day of the term, while the corridors leading to Superintendent Jasper's office in the Board of Education Building were crowded with men and women teachers reporting for duty and waiting to be assigned.

Bartolomo Veccio of 141 Mott Street was held for examination in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning upon the charge of having rooted several of his countrymen of large sums of money. Detective Sergeant Petrosino made the arrest and tells an interesting story of Veccio's work. The latter, it is alleged, worked with Giuseppe Napoli, whose picture is No. 4,060 in the Rogues' Gallery.

Otto Seyd, importer of dress goods at 60 Mercer Street, corner of Broome, made an assignment yesterday without preference to James Peterkin. Mr. Seyd was brought up in this line of business, started for himself in 1892, and was supposed to have a capital of $50,000. On Jan. 1, 1898, he admitted Franz List, who had been in his employ, as a partner.

Charges of extortion were made against the police of the Oak Street Station in the Centre Street Court yesterday by a Greek peddler, Karalabos Kololouros. He was brought before Magistrate Cornell during the morning session. His face was badly cut, his clothing torn nearly to pieces, and one of his eyes was entirely closed.

SUCRE, Bolivia, Sept. 10 -- On the petition of the Argandona Bank the Court of First Instance has issued an order directing that an embargo lie against the Bank of Potosi and its branches. This is likely to produce a serious conflict of authority, especially as the liquidation of the institution has been badly conducted by the Government since 1893.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- William J. Bryan addressed an audience of about a thousand persons this afternoon at the University of Chicago. More than half the students were women, and scattered among the auditors were Japanese and Indians, who applauded no less enthusiastically than did the American students.

Within a few days the Roosevelt Hospital will have for its ambulance service two electric ambulances. They are able to travel sixteen miles an hour, weigh 4,80O pounds each, and cost about $3,000 each. They are gifts to the hospital, a prominent physician of this city giving one of the ambulances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Withdrawal from Peking is now only a question of days, according to the opinion of army officers here, although the State Department officials still declare that no decision has been arrived at Gen. Chaffee's dispatch, made public to-day, settled the question in the military mind.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Starting with a bunch of time-stained and crumbling bones and a handful of ragged clothes, found in an old well in Fishkill, the secret of a murder committed fourteen years ago was to-day finally exposed by District Attorney Wood, with the help of Sheriff Smith and his officers, and a full confession obtained from the murderer, Peter Austin.

Hamilton Odell, as referee in the certiorari proceedings brought by the National Academy of Design, has filed in the Supreme Court a report in which he holds that the property of the academy is exempt from taxation, and was so on the second Monday of January, 1899, when the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments levied an assessment on the property of $112,000.

New York's week of Grand Circuit harness racing started off well. The strife of the high-class steppers for purses was spirited; fast time was made on the Empire City track, which itself was fast; there were not too many heats to become tiresome and yet enough to satisfy; the programme was carried through with commendable promptness, and the starting was uniformly good. The attendance was fair.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 10 -- At a meeting of the Town Board of the town of Hempstead to-day. Long Beach was sold for $25,000 to the Long Beach Land Company. The beach is about four and a half miles long and from a quarter to half a mile wide.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 10 -- Bishop H. M. Turner of the African Methodist Church denies the report that he will take the stump in favor of the election of Mr. Bryan. In an interview to-day he says:

Allan Hay. Allan Hay, one of the organizers and first Presidents of the West Shore Railroad, died at his residence in this city, 28 Mount Morris Park West, on Sunday afternoon last, from complications resultant from advanced age. Mr. Hay was eighty-seven years of age.

If Germany's man of blood and iron were still alive he would read the accounts of the passages of the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse and the Deutschland, rub his hands, and remark in good German, "I told you so." It was in 1881 that he introduced that policy of governmental aid to the German merchant marine which has shown some striking results.

More than 10,000 Sicilians and Italians turned out last night on Elizabeth Street and shouted themselves hoarse in honor of the Virgin Santa Fortuna, the Sicilian patron saint and the interceder for all the luck that befalls the inhabitants of that historic isle. For weeks the colony in Elizabeth Street had made preparations.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- This afternoon the thirty-footers raced in a southwest breeze that was of sufficient strength to furnish the amateur skippers all the sport they desired. The course was from Brenton's Cove to a mark off Jamestown, thence around Dyer's Island to the finish line in Brenton's Cove, making a reach to Jamestown, a run to Dyer's Island, and a beat to the finish.

News was received in Brooklyn yesterday that ex-Superintendent of Police William J. McKelvey of that borough had died yesterday morning at Sharon Springs, N. Y., where he was staying for his health. Mr. McKelvey had been suffering for some time from stomach trouble, and went to Sharon Springs a week ago.

SARATOGA, Sept. 11. -- The Committee on Contested Seats met early in the afternoon and was in session until quite late. It heard contests in nine counties, as follows: Albany First District; Allegany, Cayuga, two districts; Fulton and Hamilton; Oneida, Second District; Orange, Second District, and Queens.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 11 -- From reports reaching the Governor this morning it will be necessary to co-operate with the Federal troops to place all the mainland opposite Galveston, as well as the island, under martial law.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 11 -- The first vessel to leave Galveston after the storm contained a party delegated to inform the outside world of the catastrophe and to ask for help. It consisted of Lieut. J.J. Delaney, Southern Pacific Company; E.G. Cox of the firm of Thomas Taylor Co., E.L. Porch of Welch Porch, South Galveston; the correspondent of The Houston Post, and Richard Spillane of The Galveston Journal.

The disaster at Galveston exceeds not only in the number of the dead and injured and the loss of property, but also in the horror of the conditions following the destruction, any other disaster to an American city. The memories of all will revert at once to the flood at Johnstown, Penn., and the Charleston earthquake.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Representative Loudenslager, in charge of the Eastern headquarters of the Republican Congressional Committee, has received during the last ten days a large number of letters in reply to questions asked of persons in various Congressional districts.

SARATOGA, Sept. 11. -- When the Committee on Resolutions convened after the convention adjourned to-day, Frederick Schraub, a Hill adherent, proposed the name of Prof. James Milne of Cortland as Chairman of the committee. Senator Thomas F. Grady, who offered the resolution for the appointment of the committees, according to all precedent should have been Chairman.
NEWPORT, Sept. 11 -- Last evening Miss Leary gave a dinner followed by a musicale, in honor of her guest, Miss Paulding, a niece of Chauncey M. Depew.
The Republicans nominated candidates for Congress in several districts of Greater New York last night. In others adjournments were ordered.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- The civil marriage of Miss Harriet Ives Gammell of Providence to Thomas Shaw Safe of London took place to-day at the residence of Miss Gammell, Ocean Lawn, on the Cliffs, in this city. The ceremony was performed by John F. Blodgett, Associate Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, the witnesses being the bride's brothers, Robert Hale Ives Gammell and William Gammell of Providence.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 10 -- The Taku steamer, which has arrived here, brings reports of the latest events in Peking.

President McKINLEY's letter of acceptance, undoubtedly the most remarkable and potent in influence of all the letters written by Presidential candidates since the custom of a formal acceptance came into vogue, marks the turning point in the campaign. From now until the day of the election MCKINLEY and ROOSEVELT will gain votes surely and rapidly, just as McKINLEY and HOBART grained daily after the August fright of 1896 had passed.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 11 -- National Organizer Fred Dilcher of the United Mine Workers arrived here to-day direct from the session of the National Executive Board in Indianapolis, and after learning from District President Nichols and Secretary Dempsey of mutterings of discontent regarding the delay of the strike, order, gave out the following statement:

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 11 -- A heavy rainstorm this morning caused a postponement of Admiral Bedford's reception on board the flagship Crescent. Both the American and British fleets had planned to sail to-morrow morning, but now arrangements have been made to hold the reception to-morrow afternoon, and neither squadron will weigh anchor before Thursday morning.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 11 -- The Santa Fe Railroad ran its first relief train to Hitchcock this morning, finding conditions along its line about as prevailed along the Galveston, Houston and Henderson. In many places homeless inhabitants of the section traversed were found housed in empty box cars, while others were sitting on the wreck of their household effects piled together in promiscuous heaps.

The members of the Congressional Medal of Honor Legion who assembled in Brooklyn yesterday to attend the tenth annual reunion of the legion were tendered last evening a public reception by the citizens of Brooklyn at the Academy of Music, on Montague Street. The large building was crowded, the attendance numbering about 2,500.

-- There seems to be a disposition in some quarters to emphasize the fact that more than once in the past people familiar with the character of the land on which Galveston was built and of the waters around it have prophesied that a disaster, like that which has now overwhelmed the city was sure to come in time.

Kings County Republicans extended greetigs and applause to the nominees of the Republican State ticket at a reception given in their honor at the Union League Club of Brooklyn last evening. Previous to the speaking the candidates, Senator Chauncey M. Depew, and about twenty-five members of the club sat down to an informal dinner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Consul General Bray, at Melbourne, under date of July 27, 1900, sends a report regarding the Shell Trading and Transport Company of London, England. Mr. Bray says he is reliably informed that this company has secured sites in Melbourne and Sydney on which it will erect large refining works, the product of which will, it is anticipated, compete keenly with American oil in those markets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been curious to know what is the true theory of government by injunction. I understand perfectly that these injunctions must be issued because juries would not convict if the cases were submitted to them.

September's second week, with continued warm weather, finds Newport, Bar Harbor, and Southampton still filled with their Summer residents and guests, and even Narragansett with more visitors than usual at this time of the year. The Adirondack hotels are not only well filled but some of them are crowded.

SARATOGA, Sept. 11 -- The battle which will occur in the convention to-morrow will be the most bitter ever waged in a party gathering in this State. The whole interest of the convention centres around this fight, and everybody is talking about it rather than about the candidates to be nominated or the platform to be adopted.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Doncaster race meeting opened to-day with a phenomenal run of successes for American horse owners and jockeys.

Charles G. Barber, who died at Windermere, England, last Saturday, was the senior partner in a firm of wholesale coal dealers, Barber Ziegler, at 1 Broadway. He was born in New York, fifty-three years ago. At the time of his death he was abroad with Mrs. Barber on a business trip.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The caving in of one side of a sewer trench here today buried three men. One was taken out Without being seriously hurt. Another was longer under the heap of earth and is suffering, while the third man was dead when taken out.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62 1/2 @ 63 1/2. There were no sales.

The course of the stock market yesterday was disappointing. Wall Street had been treated to so many stories of what bull leaders purposed to do did the Maine election show 30,000 or more plurality that in unsophisticated quarters the idea quite generally prevailed yesterday -- the Maine figures having come up to estimates -- that higher, permanently higher, stock market quotations were assured.

Important meetings of the Trunk Line Association Passenger and Freight Committees Kept the traffic managers and General Freight as well as General Passenger Agents of the various lines composing this association busy until late yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Secretary of the Treasury has received the following joint telegram, dated yesterday, from Postmaster Griffin and Special Deputy Collector Rosenthal at Galveston:

John M. Thompson Co. and M. Lindheim Co. have sold for Dr. Eliot Gorton to Mrs. Myra Plummer the new sevenstory apartment house at the southeast corner of Irving Place and Nineteenth Street, on a lot 27 by 88.7. The buyer is an investor, and the price, it is said, is little below the figure at which the property has been held -- $165,000.

Over fifty entries have been received for the Tuxedo Club's invitation golf tournament, which will begin this morning and continue through Saturday. The metropolitan district will be represented by its best golfers, including the National champion, Walter J. Travis, Percy R. Pyne, second, the intercollegiate champion; R. C. Watson, Jr., who made a new record for the Myopia course, near Boston, a few days ago.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 11 -- The Republican State Convention for the nomination of a candidate for Governor and candidates for Presidential Electors, held here to-day, was one of the most largely attended delegate gatherings ever held by the party in the State, and the enthusiasm ran high.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Not much attention is paid here to Dr. Morrison's assertions from Peking that the march of the troops was delayed by "bogus edicts" presented to the American Government by Wu Ting Fang. There is nothing to show that Dr. Morrison has any facilities for ascertaining that the edicts submitted by the Minister were bogus.

YANKTON, S.D., Sept. 11 -- The demonstration here this evening in honor of Gov. Roosevelt's arrival was almost unequaled in the history of the small city. The city was crowded with an immense throng. A torchlight procession and a parade were the features of the evening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator Cullom of Illinois, speaking to-day of the political outlook in the Middle West, said:

CHICAGO, III., Sept. 11 -- A remarkable windstorm has blown over Chicago to-day. For the greater part of the time the velocity was about sixty miles an hour, but to-night this increased to eighty-four miles.
NEWPORT, Sept. 11 -- On the links of the Newport Golf Club to-day there was a mixed golf foursome for the trophy offered by A.H. Crossfield.

Chief Devery said yesterday afternoon that he was going to ask Capt. Wohlfarth of the Flushing Police Station to make a report upon the conduct of his men during the picnic of the Timothy D. Sullivan Association at College Point Monday, at which there were gambling and prizefighting.

The marvelous effect of Mr. McKINLEY'S essay in producing a letter which everybody finds readable and nobody finds dull, is due doubtless to a good many things besides literary skill. We find a large part of it to consist in the manner in which the President takes the people of the United States into his confidence and shares his responsibilities with them.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11 -- Judge Charles D. Burns, known as the "marrying Judge," of this American Gretna Green is making great and, so far, successful efforts to conceal the names of the contracting parties In a marriage at which he officiated this morning.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The French Government has decided to send to the Government of the United States a message expressing sympathy with the people of the United States on account of the Galveston disaster.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Trading to-day was distributed somewhat better than yesterday, but was featureless, price changes being few and slight. Bingham, British Columbia, and Cochiti, alone among the mining stocks, showed anything like animation, and British Columbia in gaining 1/2, to 11 1/4, made the only noteworthy change in price.

New York sweltered and stewed yesterday in a humid atmosphere that made men cross-grained, destroyed tempers and collars, and called down maledictions upon the heads of those who would prove to you by figures that you ought to be cool and tell you how lucky you are that you are not now in such and such a year, when the temperature was a great deal higher.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- The Whitehall and Granville Railroad Company of Washington County, a street surface railroad, to be operated by electricity or other power, except locomotives, capital $750,000, was incorporated to-day. The road will run from Whitehall to Granville, a distance of about fourteen and a half miles.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The Times publishes this morning additional advices from its Peking correspondent, Dr. Morrlson, under date of Aug. 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Census Bureau announces the populations of the following places:

A card that promised spirited stepping and fast time was provided for the patrons of Grand Circuit racing at the Empire City tract yesterday afternoon, and the promise was fulfilled. The fastest time of the day, which was made in the 2:05 pace, was the second best mile ever paced on the track.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 11 -- The railroads have suffered the loss of millions of dollars in actual damage by the storm, to say nothing of the loss from stoppage of business. At Galveston their wharves, warehouses, depots, and tracks are ruined. The costly bridges which connect the island with the mainland must be entirely rebuilt.
Magistrate Olmsted rendered a decision in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon which affects the owners and operators of automobiles and other motor vehicles.
Mayor Van Wyck issued the following appeal yesterday for help for the Galveston, sufferrers:

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 11 -- Belated election returns from all over the State came sifting in to-day, but with the exception of knox County, very few showed any decided change from those received last night. The estimates sent out last night held good all day, and to-night, with 375 cities, towns, and plantations heard from, out of a total of 512, the estimated Republican plurality for the State ticket remains somewhere between 32,0OO and 33,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The State Department has received a report from John Fowler, United States Consul at Che-Foo, showing the steps taken by him to secure a vessel to go to the rescue of the missionaries and their families, who were escaping from the interior of China.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 11 -- There was a split to-day in the Twelfth District Democratic Congressional Convention, and two nominations were made -- Stanley W. Davenport, the present Representative, and Asa Dewitt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your deductions, in "Topics of the Times," as to the motives that inspired the delegates to the International Typographical Union Convention to submit to a referendum vote of the membership a resolution prohibiting speed contests on typesetting machines will undoubtedly be accepted by laymen as logical.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The State Department this afternoon issued the following:

The New York baseball team won a game and played a draw with the Chtcagos yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The first game was practically a walk-over for the local nine. In the second, however, Griffith had them guessing until the ninth inning, when a double by Van Haltren and singles by Bowerman and Seymour, an out, and a wild pitch enabled the New Yorks to tie the score.

Postmaster Van Cott said yesterday that more mail was being handled in this city than ever before in the history of the local Post Office. The receipts of August showed an increase of 7 per cent, over those of the same month in 1899, and it is probable that this month's figures will be proportionately high.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration " has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1.000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Two of the seventy-footers, Mineola and Rainbow, are at this place. The Rainbow has been hauled out on the marine railway at the Hawkins yard to be overhauled and prepared for the race over the America's Cup course for the Lipton Cup, and the Mineola left this harbor in tow for the lower bay late this afternoon in readiness.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 11 -- Some order is being brought out of chaos, and something like a systematic attempt is being made to clear the debris and remove the dead.

TIEN-TSIN, Sept. 3, via Nagasaki, Sept. 10 -- A Christian refugee from Pao-TingFoo, where Peking officials were enlisting troops when he left, asserts that he saw a large force of Boxers between Peking and Pao-Ting-Foo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Do me the justice to present a correct statement regarding the marriage that took place in the Tombs a few days ago. The young couple had been engaged for a year beforehand and had fixed on that day to be married. They were of age and knew what they were doing, and had the consent of their relatives.

WASHINGTON, Sept 11 -- Gen. Wilson, Chief of Engineers, has not yet received any advices as to losses upon fortifications and river and harbor works in Texas, though dispatches to the Quartermaster's Department indicate that the fortifications have been damaged. The following telegrams have been received:
BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The hard-coal syndicates in Silesia and the Rhine provinces have raised the prices of hard coal 25 per cent. and soft coal in Berlin is 50 per cent. higher.

Mr. Samuel Untermyer, who is a prominent lawyer and Democrat of New York, is stopping with his family at the Hotel Ritz. He will return to New York by the Fuerst Bismarck on Sept. 7.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 12 -- At 5:15 o'clock this afternoon President Mitchell and Secretary Wilson of the United Mine Workfers of America affixed their signatures to the document which will call the miners of the Pennsylvania anthracite region from their work Monday morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept 12 -- The religious ceremony uniting in marriage Miss Harriet Ives Gammell of this city and Thomas Shaw Safe of England took place in Emmanuel Church at noon to-day, following the civil marriage performed at the bride's residence yesterday.

We see no reason why Mr. STANCHFIELD should not poll the entire Democratic vote of the State of New York. We do not see why he should not poll the entire independent, anti-boss vote. The party vote and the independent vote would elect him, and THE TIMES believes he ought to be elected.

BROOKINGS, S.D., Sept. 12 -- Gov. Roosevelt's special train arrived here this evening. During the day many receptions took place and numerous speeches were made from the platform of the car, and from specially arranged street stands, around which the inhabitants of the towns crowded An outdoor meeting was held in a tent near the Court House grounds at this place.

It must now seem, to the officials temporarily in charge of the State Department, and so of our policy in the Far East, extremely fortunate that they committed themselves no further than they did to an approval of the Russian proposal. The concert of the civilized world is indeed necessary to bring about a tolerable condition of things in China.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 12 -- Relief for those stricken in the awful calamity of last Saturday is now beginning to pour in from all over the country. Relief committees are being organized, and food, clothing, and money raised to be sent here as rapidly as special trains can carry the supplies to the people so sorely in need of them.
SARATOGA, Sept. 12 -- Richard Croker, who does not seem to be particularly exultant over the victory he has scored and the ticket he has nominated says to-night:

SARATOGA, Sept. 12 -- The Democracy of New York State, in convention assembled, after a thrilling, bitter factional struggle, nominated to-day the State ticket. Every stage of the proceedings was marked by great excitement. Richard Croker was pilloried. The trained orators of David B. Hill. with whips of logic and merciless sarcasm, pulled aside the curtain of State politics and exposed to public view the secrets of the bosses.

May Irwin, the actress, acquired title yesterday to the 21x100.5 parcel, on the north side of Forty-fourth Street, east of Seventh Avenue, from Annie R. Neeler. Miss Irwin paid $10,000 in cash and assumes the payment of a mortgage for $23,000, which is a lien against the property.

Three hundred or more guests sat down at a banquet given last night to the Medal of Honor Legion at the Union League Club, Brooklyn. Col. H.H. Masters, President of the club, was toastmaster, and the principal speakers were ex-Congressman John S. Wise of Virginia, Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, and the Rev. Dr. M.W. Stryker, President of Hamilton College.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Additional reports telling of the damage by the drought in Connecticut continue to pour in from every part of the State. At Mystic the city water supply has been cut off. By this action four large factories closed Monday, throwing hundreds of men and women out of employment.

New York got its share yesterday of the storm that wrecked Galveston. Luckily for the inhabitants of Manhattan Island, the character of the storm changed entirely after it had left a trail of death and destruction in Southern Texas, and as it swept through the northern part of that State, and through portions of the Middle West, it was as a zephyr in comparison with the hurricane of a few days before.

Nearly suffocated by smoke, Policeman John P. Murtha of the East Eighty-sixth Street Station last night, after two attempts carried Mary Hansen and her nine-months-old son, William, from the third floor of 305 East Ninety-second Street to the street.
HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 12 -- The loss of life at Galveston is now conservatively placed at 5,000, while many believe that from 8,000 to 10,000 people have perished.

DENVER, Sept. 12 -- Burlington Train No. 1, known as the Overland Flier, was held up by a lone highwayman at 2 o'clock this morning five miles from Haigler, Neb., near the Colorado line. The robber secured about $500 in cash and probably twice that much in diamonds and watches, and made his escape by bringing the train to a stop.

A meeting of the School Board for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx was held at the Hall of the Board of Education, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, last night. Miles M. O'Brien, the President, was in the chair.

The sons of ZERUIAH have been too strong for the children of Israel, as the Boers are so fond of representing themselves to be.

Little over 100,000 shares of stock were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with the movement of prices, except in a few issues affected by special developments, marking no material change. Brokers on the floor gave themselves over more to skylarking than to business, though they were not slow to take what few orders were offered to them.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 12 -- The Democratic State Convention, which met here to-day, selected the following candidates for the National Electoral College:

Harry Bingham. Harry Bingham, twenty years ago the most prominent member of the Democratic Party of New Hampshire, died yesterday at his home in Littleton, N.H., aged seventy-nine years. He was graduated from Dartmouth College in 1843, and three years later was admitted to the bar.

MANILA, Sept. 12 -- At the first public legislative session of the Philippine Commission held to-day bills appropriating $1,000,000 gold from the funds of the island for highways and bridges and $2,500 in part payment of surveying expenses were passed.

Mr. GAGE would be happier and Mr. SCHURZ less jubilant if that interview of July 15 had been altogether suppressed. It is exceedingly awkward to be publicly exhibited as saying on Aug. 25 that direful things would happen which on July 15 you had said could not happen at all.

WASHINGTON, Sept 12 -- The question of withdrawing the American troops at once from Peking is now before the President, and a speedy decision is expected. The action of the French Government in joining Russia in orders for the withdrawal of troops has brought about the contingency touched upon in the reply to Russia in the following language:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 -- Senor Godoy, Chilean Minister at La Paz, Bolivia, has transmitted to the Bolivian Government an energetic note rejecting the pretensions of Bolivia to a concession by Chile of a port on the Pacific, which Chile is not now prepared to make.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 12 -- A heavy gale blew over the Lenox golf links, and troubled the golfers playing in the first and second rounds for the Lenox Cup. It was a hard test of endurance and skill, but excellent scores were made. The surprise of the day was the defeat of Johnstone, the long-distance driver of Chicago, who lost to Jaques of Lenox.

GALVESTON, Sept. 12 -- The official records of the United States Weather Bureau, which have been made up and forwarded to Washington, give some valuable additional information about the storm. Unfortunately, the recording instruments were destroyed or crippled beyond operation at about 5:10 o'clock on Sunday evening.

Abraham Gruber presided last night at a joint debate at the rooms of the People's Club, 9 Seventh Street, and listened, together with about fifty other persons, to a discussion on the subject, "Resolved, That we favor the re-election of President McKinley." Those who spoke on the affirmative side represented the Republican State Committee and were W.S. Bennett, C.S. Dana, and Montague Seering.

Carnegie Hall was crowded last night with the representative colored people of New York, who assembled in response to a call of the Citizens' Protective League for a mass meeting to express indignation over the recent race disturbances and to protest against the failure of the proper officials to fix the responsibility and punish the guilty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Monday's issue of THE TIMES the City of Lincoln is called upon to explain its decline in population. Having lived in that town for the better part of the decade, I may, perhaps, be permitted to offer an explanation for it.

Tuxedo reopened its golf links yesterday to visiting players by an invitation tournament, after omitting these larger golf features for three years. In that interval the course has been extended from nine to eighteen holes, and the popularity that the links in the famous Ramapo Valley always enjoyed in past years among the golfing fraternity led to a large gathering of competitors for the improved and sportier course.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- University of Pennsylvania supporters had great cause to feel encouraged at tiie football outlook for the present season when thirty-nine candidates for the team lined up for practice on Franklin Field to-day. John Gardiner, the stroke of the intercollegiate champion crew, and Woodley of last year's regular team were on hand and did a lot of earnest work.

ELMIRA, Sept. 12 -- The Elmira Democracy celebrated with red fire, rockets, martial music, heavy guns, and speechmaking to-night the nomination of John B. Stanchfield for Governor. The impromptu ratification began with the formation of a line in front of the Democratic, headquarters.

According to Pittsburgh dispatches the Pressed Steel Car Company has received a contract for a number of ore cars of 80,000 pounds' carrying capacity, to be used on the Great Southern Railroad of Spain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The charge brought by a Greek peddler against Policeman McGrath of the Oak Street Station of demanding tribute money, and the statement made by the peddler that tribute money, or "monthly taxes," are regularly paid by street peddlers to the police, ought to be of interest to all good citizens.
The storm which devastated Galveston and was felt in this city yesterday pursued a remarkable course.

Powell Spiebler, an artist, who had been married at the City Hall on Monday, committed suicide last evening by shooting himself in the mouth in the flat where he was living with his wife, at 30 West One Hundred and Fourth Street. His bride of two days, on seeing him dead, wrote two notes and lay down beside her husband's body and swallowed a morphine powder.
Republican conventions for the nomination of candidates for the State Senate were held in the seven Senatorial districts of Kings County last night. The following candidates were named:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62 1/2@63 1/2. There were no sales.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 12 -- The news of the declaration of the big coal strike was received in Hazleton to-night. It traveled quickly, and crowds of people soon gathered on the streets. Business men, when they heard that the order to strike was at last out, greatly deplored the action taken, and fear that they will suffer heavily if the strike continues for a long time.
ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- According to an act of the last Legislature, the State Controller's Department to-day completed the purchase of twenty-five acres of land at Lake George.

Even the most popular of toys must have its day and pass. Not even golf, that now absorbs the interest of old and young as few outdoor sports have done, can be assured of a permanent hold upon its present devotees or an equal number of followers. It will never be as "popular" as the bicycle still is.

A meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club was held yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Jockey Club course. August Belmont, James Galway, F.R. Hitchcock, and Andrew Miller were present. The report of the Stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club meeting in the Mitchel case was presented.

Freight agents of the trunk lines are much interested in the prospective results of the conference of Tuesday last, at which means were considered for the prevention of a demoralization in freight rates in trunk line territory. It appears now that the matter was rather more serious than outsiders were led to believe.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- It was ascertained here to-night that Gov. Roosevelt had forwarded to Attorney General Davies his memoranda relative to the charges preferred against Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, by the City Club, predicated upon the report of Ansley Wilcox of Buffalo, who was appointed by the Governor to take the testimony.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- The tail-end of the West Indian nurricane which swept over Lake Erie last night was the most disastrous storm that has visited this section in several years.

SOMERSET, Penn., Sept. 12 -- Miss Mabel McKinley, the only child of Mr. and Mrs. Abner McKinley, and niece of the President, and Dr. Herihanus L. Baer, were married here to-night. The wedding was one of the most notable ever held in this State. The presence of President and Mrs. William McKinley, together with other prominent persons from various parts of the United States gave dignity to the affair.
The Democratic Party of New York, in convention assembled, declares as follows:

Queer things always happen at the Fall meeting on the Gravesend track, but in all the years of racing there, no queerer upset than that in the fourth race yesterday ever occurred. The race, a mile and a sixteenth, for all ages, had only four runners, and a virtual gift for Vulcain, who started favorite at 4 to 1 on.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- The order of President Mitchell calling out the miners in the anthracite coal region of Pennsylvania recalls the last great strike in the same district three years ago, which was practically ended by the tragedy at Lattimer, in which twenty-one miners were killed and over fifty wounded by Deputy Sheriffs.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Sept. 12 -- Harry Vardon, the former British golf champion, just managed to uphold his reputation in to-day's play on the new links of the Essex Country Club by a margin of 1 up in defeating Joseph Lloyd, the professional, and John Dingwell in a thirty-six hole best-ball match.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 12 -- Mayor Jones to-day estimated the loss of life in and around Galveston at 5,000.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Sept. 12 -- The Summer season here came to a sudden and disastrous end this afternoon through the complete destruction by fire of the great Rockingham Hotel, Sherry's beautiful and famous Casino, the Hazard block, the Knights of Pythias Hall, and a score of smaller building's.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 12 -- Mayor Jones to-day estimated the loss of life in and around Galveston at 5,000.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Sept. 12 -- The Summer season here came to a sudden and disastrous end this afternoon through the complete destruction by fire of the great Rockingham Hotel, Sherry's beautiful and famous Casino, the Hazard block, the Knights of Pythias Hall, and a score of smaller building's.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- All the correspondents in China are sending terrible stories of the wholesale massacres of missionaries and native Christians. It is asserted that during July between 15,000 and 20,000 converts were massacred in the northern provinces. Large numbers of missionaries are still unaccounted for and small hope is entertained of their escape.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The charity which your readers have already, through your own kindness, so generously helped -- the Free Home for Incurabla Cancer, at 426 Cherry Street, New York -- is in precisely the condition which I have always desired for it -- paying its way humbly, without large surplus, but near the danger point of no ready money.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 12 -- Returns from 1,600 precincts in Michigan to the Republican Stte Central Committee indicate that a large number of Democrats who voted for Bryan in 1896 have changed and will work for the re-election of President McKinley.

In the opinion of many in the dry goods district, a very fair gauge of the general business situation and of business prospects was furnished by an important auction sale of silks on Tuesday and by an equally important sale of dress goods and suitings yesterday. In each case the auctioneers were Townsend Montant of 87 and 89 Leonard Street, where the sales were held.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Fourteen mining stocks were traded in in the first half of the day and Utah, with 1,100 shares, furnished more sales to the total than the other thirteen together. About 800 shares of Sugar changed hands in the same time. 100 Atchison, 19 C., B. Q., and 34 Union Pacific, common and preferred.
GALVESTON, Texax, Sept. 12 -- The following statements were issued here tonight for transmission to the newspapers of the country:
Mayor Van Wyck sent the following telegram yesterday afternoon to Mayor Jones of Galveston:

-- Even before Galveston had sufficiently recovered from the stunning blow inflicted upon her by the storm to appeal for aid, preparations for the work of rescue and relief were begun all over the country, and now that her people have made definite statement of their needs the universal sympathy is taking the form of prompt and generous assistance.

LORENZO MARQUES, July 31 -- To judge by the reports that have been made on the state of the Johannesburg mines that were worked for the benefit of the Boer Government, the damage caused by the eight months' unskillful working and by the neglect of the proper means of maintenance, is simply enormous, and must retard for some time the resumption of the normal output all along the reef.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The right of a conductor to eject a man from a railroad car if his ticket is overdue was established in court here to-day in the suit of Barney V. Wolfson of Trenton against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.

Transactions in the market for outside securities yesterday were on a very small scale, and, with two or three exceptions, the interest taken in the trading was of the smallest. Prices showed perhaps less strength than on the earlier days of the week, but in some cases at least the declines recorded were due to manipulative efforts.
BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- The news bureau sent to China by the German Fleet Society cables from Shanghai that it has received the following telegram from the Russian Government:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is never a very comfortable feeling with me to disagree with your editorial writings, but a perusal of your remarks in this morning's issue, under the caption "The Democratic Nomination," has created an impression in my mind that at least one of your points therein contained is not, in my opinion, altogether well taken.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 13 -- National Committeeman James, who is directing the preparations for the strike, called on Sheriff Harvey of Luzerne County to-day and offered in the event of the swearing in of Deputy Sheriffs, to furnish any number of men up to 5,000 who would guard public property against injury and the law-abiding element of the county against any lawlessness.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 13 -- There is about a six-weeks' coal supply in this city. The people are laying in coal for the Winter, and the supply is being sold rapidly. The announcement of the strike has caused much worry among the dealers and in the factories, which will nave to close down if no coal comes.

A day of rare golf excitement and enthusiasm was given yesterday on the Tuxedo Club links, so picturesquely situated in the Ramapo Valley, when the first and second match play rounds for the Tuxedo, Ramapo, and Wee Wah Cups were played. The day was perfect for the game, and there was just enough suggestion of Autumn coolness in the atmosphere to force the players to do their best.

The Grand Circuit harness racing at the Empire City track yesterday afternoon was full of interest from start to finish. The biggest crowd so far of the meeting was on hand, miles were reeled off in swift time, the track was fast and the weather fine, and the peerless stepper, The Abbott, driven by Geers, broke the world's gelding record for trotters.

The Rev. Joseph Frewen. The Rev. Joseph Frewen died at St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, yesterday, from dropsy. He was formerly rector of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Hoboken, but was transferred to Terre Haute, Ind., several years ago. Owing to his illness he was advised to take a vacation, and in July he returned to Hoboken as the guest of the Rev. James McEvoy, the present rector of St. Joseph's Church.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The War Department has received the following telegram, dated Sept. 12, from Gen. McKibben, who was sent to Galveston to report on conditions there:

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 13. -- Houston now is the haven of unfortunate people of Galveston. Trains have already brought in between 500 and 1,000 of the survivors, and a motley crowd they are. Men bareheaded, barefooted, hatless and coatless, with swelled feet and bruised and blackened bodies and heads, were numerous.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Last Winter, during the excitement over the Boer war, a Patent Office employe named Gustave Thielkuhl was found to be engaged in recruiting men for service in the Boer Army. He was warned to stop, and nothing more was heard of the matter until later, when it was discovered that Thielkuhl was still actively at work.

BRANFORD, Sept. 13. -- To-day's practice of the Columbia squad was the sharpest thus far of the week, Coach Sanford putting the boys through two hours of hard, sharp work. The men were divided into three squads, at centre, quarter back, and rush line, and each squad went through the form of putting the ball in play, with Sanford closely following each man.

Our neighbor The World addresses to us seven questions concerning the political status of the Filipinos and asks that answer be made to each of them "in all sincerity," as a contribution to the elucidation of the "paramount issue." Questions and answers follow:

The people of this city have been prompt to answer the call for help from storm-swept Galveston. As far as the official figures could be obtained last night from the various places where public contributions are being made, the result is as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of to-day encourages me to invoke your aid in calling public attention to another and far more important effect of gas main leakage.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 13 -- Nearly all the local assemblies of United Mine Workers held meetings to-night to take action on President Mitchell's strike order. The statement issued by Mr. Mitchell was read by the Secretaries. In some of the assemblies the reading was received with much enthusiasm, while in others there was dead silence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In 1898 I was a delighted reader of THE TIMES. Nominally a "Democratic" paper, it nevertheless seemed to me such an unbiased exponent of sound political doctrine as was adapted to the taste of an independent. In that year came the nomination of Roosevelt on the one hand and of Augustus Van Wyck on the other.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- General Superintendent Kimball of the Life-Saving Service has received telegrams from the Superintendent of the Gulf district, in which he says that the keeper and five of the crew of the Galveston Life-Saving Station had landed at Texas City. One surfman and the keeper's wife were missing and are supposed to have been lost.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- A dispatch from Peking to The Times says:

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 13 -- While going at a record-breaking clip in a preliminary test of her machinery, the torpedo boat destroyer Goldsborough met with an accident similar to one which occurred on Feb. 25 last, breaking the rocker shaft on the port engine.

ELKHART, Ind., Sept. 13 -- While strolling along the banks of the St. Joseph River, accompanied by his bulldog, this afternoon, Lyman Alcorn heard loud cries for help. Hurrying round a bend in the stream, he discovered several boys in the water, one of whom, a boy named Wilson, aged eight years, had ventured while bathing beyond his depth and was drowning.

The arrest of a negro who was engaged in a fight on Seventh Avenue, betweetn Thirtieth and Thirty-first Streets, last night, led to a commotion that for a while threatened results similar to the recent race disturbances in that vicinity. The trouble was caused by John Chamberlain, a negro, who lives at 144 West Twenty-sixth Street.

Last season Mr. Francis Wilson tried the experiment of performing a travesty on the most poetic drama of recent years, namely, "Cyrano de Bergerac." The task did not prove congenial, for it was not easy to make Cyrano funny without utterly destroying all semblance to the original. The public found it quite as difficult to accept Mr. Wilson in the part as to believe in his travesty of the work.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- "A Wanderer's Psalm," the new oratorio by Prof. Horatio W. Parker, head of the Department of Music at Yale, was performed yesterday at the Hereford Festival with considerable success. It is favorably criticised in the London papers this morning.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 13 -- The excitement in the cotton market here continues. The situation has been intensified by Neill Brothers' unexpectedly bullish report, but the biggest settling day on record passed successfully. The only failure announced was that of S. Hillis, a small firm, which had no effect on business.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- There is considerable comment here upon the New York cable dispatches announcing that Mr. Charles T. Yerkes of Chicago and New York has purchased the franchise of the Charing Cross, Euston, and Hampstead Railroad, and that it is proposed forthwith, to construct another electric underground road.

It was asserted at Republican National Headquarters yesterday that a canvass just completed demonstrates that 95 per cent. of the business men of the country are strong supporters of the McKinley Administration, and that they regard the possible success of Mr. Bryan as a catastrophe.

Abraham Gruber was the principal attraction at a mass meeting held last night at the Republican headquarters which have been open for the past week at 132 Bowery. Gen. Francis Vinton Greened who was Chairman of the meeting, spoke, as did Edgar J. Dwyer, a locomotive engineer from Jersey City; Montagu Lessler, a lawyer, and Adelbert H. Steele.

A fumble by Doyle in the first inning of yesterday's baseball game between Chicago and New York proved fatal to the latter team. It was responsible for at least two runs. Matthewson pitched a splendid game and deserved to win. A base hit on several occasions would have won the game for New York, but it was not forthcoming.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13. -- The States to-day received a telegram from John H. Poe, a member of the State Board of Education, who lives at Lake Charles, stating that eighty-five lives were lost on the Gulf and Inter-State train which left Beaumont early Saturday morning from Bolivar Point, after having made connections with the Southern Pacific train which left this city Friday night.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- A Times correspondent writing from Tien-Tsin July 21 gives some interesting details of the fighting about Tien-Tsin, where "an army of 10,000 highly trained modern troops was held in check by an army of Chinese not in any overwhelming degree more numerous.

Louis Straus, residing at 298 Manhattan Avenue, has filed a petition in bankruptcy with liabilities $87,513 and nominal assets $20,138, consisting of a judgment against James D. Kinsley of Newton, Mass., obtained on June 30, 1892, for $20,128, and cash on hand $10.

-- Among the incidental consequences of a strike in the anthracite coal region, as has often been stated in the past few weeks, will be the substitution, for a time inevitably, and for all time probably, of bituminous coal for anthracite in a very considerable number of the places and uses in which the more expensive fuel has hitherto been able to maintain its position.

There appears to be a dead-lock among the powers regarding Russia's proposal to withdraw from Peking. It is believed in London, however, that the Czar will agree to allow his troops to remain in Peking until he sees the results of the present negotiations, which are said to contain the suggestion of a compromise calculated to maintain the unity of the powers while satisfying both the advocates and opponents of the withdrawal.

A reorganization of the operating department of the Long Island Railroad has just gone into effect pursuant to by-laws recently adopted by the Board of Directors. The plan under which the officers of this road will hereafter make their reports and transact other official business resembles to a large extent that which the Pennsylvania Railroad has been using for many years.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 13 -- Gov. Sayres urges that the people of Texas and the whole country give encouragement to the sentiment that Galveston must and should be rebuilt. He said to-day:

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 13 -- In order to place before the public the Conditions existing in the anthracite fields of Pennsylvania, President John Mitchell and Secretary-Treasurer W.B. Wilson of the United Mine Workers of America issued to-day to the public a statement giving in detail the causes that have led up to the strike.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62 1/2 @63 1/2. There were no sales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The crisis that was near yesterday over the evacuation proposal of the Russian Government has been averted for a time, and the diplomatic side of the matter has become again the object of attention.

SANDY HILL, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff made a political speech this afternoon at Washington County Fair, held between Fort Edward and Sandy Hill. Fully 25,000 people were in attendance and the Lieutenant Governor received hearty applause.
ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- In the absence from the State of Gov. Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, as Governor, issued to-night the following proclamation relating to the Galveston disaster:

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 13. -- Capt. Charles S. Riche, United States Army, Corps of Engineers, when seen after he had completed a tour of inspection of the Government works around here, made the following statement to a News reporter:

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 13. -- B.F. Cameron, a lumber dealer of Stowell, Chambers County, says that the relief party which went from Stowell to Bolivar reported to him that there were over 1,000 dead bodies on the beach at Bolivar, in East Bay, and to sight of the salt marshes which line the bay.

The racing at Gravesend yesterday was interesting and spirited, but above all else sensational. Visitors to the track were in a whirl of excitement and bewilderment from the time they arrived until they departed. Those who put their faith in form, as developed at Sheepshead Bay, finished the day with enough material for reflection to keep them thinking until the racing is resumed to-morrow afternoon.

The Amateur Athletic Union annual championship meeting at Columbia Field to-morrow afternoon should furnish excellent sport. The weight and hammer throwing contents will be remarkable for the reappearance of J.S. Mitchel, who has not competed since 1897, and It will be interesting to note whether or not be has deteriorated.

Cornelius Vanderbilt's Rainbow, throughout the season the most unfortunate of the four new Herreshoff seventy-footers, turned the tables on her sister yachts yesterday and won in the race held off Sandy Hook Lightship by the New York Yacht Club the $1,000 cup set up by Sir Thomas Lipton.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Elizabeth A. Beckett to a Mr. Phinney, for $25,000, the four-story brick and stone-front dwelling 274 West Eighty-ninth Street, 18 by 100.8

To the Editor of The New York Times: You say to-day, in speaking of Mr. McKinley's letter of acceptance: "For all his positions the President has the support of established fact and original authority. It is not often that a contender in the field of politics is so extraordinarily well furnished forth with vital, essential, telling facts of which the enemy was quite ignorant."

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 13. -- The people of this city to-day dedicated to the memory of Gen. Henry W. Lawton a monument crowned by a cannon captured by him, and christened the principal city park in honor of the dead hero. The ceremony occurred under the auspices of the Union Veteran Legion, and William J. Bryan was the principal orator of the occasion.

It is now believed that Robert H. Noble, former Tax Collector of Weehawken, who was killed by a train in this city several weeks ago, deliberately threw himself in front of the locomotive. He was a defaulter, and the death on the same day of his political sponsor, Simon Kelly, removed all hope that his peculations would not be exposed.
James H. Eckels of Chicago, ex-Controller of the Currency, talked on politics with a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Holland House last night. He said:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 13 -- Advices to Gov. Sayers to-day indicate that several trains loaded with supplies for the destitute are en route to Galveston. The arrival of these supplies will relieve the situation very materially, as the Governor is informed that quite a lot of clothing is included in the list.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 13 -- The departure of the British and American squadrons this morning afforded Bar Harbor a memorable spectacle. Long before 9 o'clock the cliff walk swarmed with townspeople and Summer residents. Smoke was pouring furiously from the funnels of the Crescent and Psyche.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Gov. Roosevelt, through Attorney General Davies, this afternoon made public his decision in the matter of the charges against Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, by the City Club. The charges, eighty in number and containing some 2,000 specifications, are dismissed by the Governor on the ground that the evidence was insufficient to sustain them.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Great Britain's reply to the Russian proposition for the evacuation of Peking was sent two days ago, and, as published yesterday, Great Britain declines to evacuate Peking prior to receiving satisfactory guarantees from the Chinese Government for the fulfillment of certain conditions.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Discount rates were steady to-day, although there was much uncertainty regarding the immediate future. Money was fairly plentiful, the settlement on the Stock Exchange passing off satisfactorily. Home railroads were inactive and weak in sympathy with the decline in Great Eastern caused by the report that the men employed on that line were dissatisfied with the Directors' reply to their demands and that they would go on strike Saturday.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- The raid against New England Gas and Coke continued to-day, and the price fell 2 points more-from 12 to 10 -- with the fives off 1/4, to 61 3/4. Dominion Coal came down 1 1/2, to 40 in sympathy, and it looked like a concerted movement against the Whitney shares.

LONDON, Sept 13. -- At the third day's racing of the Doncaster September meeting to-day the Corporation Selling Handicap Plate was won by Remember Me, ridden by Rigby, who also, on Tin Soldier, tied for first place in the race for the Rous Plate, the tying horse being Quest.

Richard Croker walked into the Hoffman House yesterday soon after his return from Saratoga. He talked with a number of party leaders, but there was no exultation in his talk over the defeat of David B. Hill and Controller Coler in the State Convention. Mr. Croker did not want to talk much about the State ticket.

The air of Jersey City yesterday was charged with Republican enthusiasm and split with Republican cheers. The occasion of the unusual display of Republican fervor was the annual convention of the State Republican League Clubs of New Jersey, and a great Republican mass meeting at night under the league's auspices.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 13 -- Galveston is beginning to slowly recover from the stunning blow of last week, and though the city appears to-night to be pitilessly desolated, the authorities and the commercial and industrial interests are setting their forces to work, and a start has at least been made toward the resumption of business on a moderate scale.

It was semi-officially stated yesterday that several subscriptions have already been received in this city to the impending lean which the German Government is seeking to place in this country through a syndicate.
ABERDEEN, S.D., Sept. 13 -- Gov. Roosevelt and party arrived here this evening. Alter a paratle and torchlight procession speeches were made in the open air. Gov. Roosevelt said, in part:
SYRACUSE, Sept. 13 -- The will of Thomas Kingsford, the starch manufacturer, was probated to-day at Oswego.

As Georgiana E. Simonson, a dressmaker of 403 Park Avenue, was about to be dispossessed several days ago, she was informed that she had inherited $25,000. When the news came her poverty was such that she had only a few pieces of furniture in her rooms, and her landlord had ordered her to move out.

NEWPORT, Sept. 13 -- Miss Leary grave her seventh and last musicale this afternoon, which was one of the largest attended functions of the season. Mr. Terhune, who is visiting her, sang several tenor solos.

Charles E. Ackron, one time proprietor of the Tivoll, appeared in two courts yesterday. His first appearance was before Magistrate Olmstead and the other before Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, Part I.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: So many letters have lately appeared to your columns regarding Mr. Cooper as a man that it may be interesting to posterity to know how he was regarded by his immediate neighbors and contemporaries. In this letter, moreover, I have nothing to say concerning Cooper's literary style, which, by the way, was severely criticised by both the American and English press when his books appeared.

Mr. R. Nisbet Bain, in his life of Elizabeth of Russia, takes up a period in the history of that country which is comparatively unknown to us -- that is, the interlude after the days of Peter the Great, whose work she was able to consolidate and modify, thus making the finest of all preparations for the schemes of her successor, Catherine.

SHAMOKIN, Perm., Sept. 14. -- A telegram was received this afternoon by John Fahey, President of the Ninth District, United Mine Workers of America, from Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, announcing that he will be here oh Sunday to address a mass meeting Which the strike leaders expect will be attended by at least 10,000 mine workers.

Mr. E.N. Gosse, in the current number of the Anglo-Saxon Review, begins an interesting discussion in an article entitled "Culture and the Small Nations." His thesis is that the citizens of the small countries which are kept national by the mutual jealousies of their bigger neighbors, have a compensation for their smallness.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 14. -- The Ohio Democrats opened their campaign here today with a meeting in the afternoon at Groodale Park and in the evening at the Goodale Auditorium. W.J. Bryan made speeches at both meetings.

"Linnet" is primarily a tale of the Alps, for from its characters radiates the fresh air of the mountains, which still clings to them even after they have been transplanted to the foggy, grimy streets of London. The thread of the story winds along conventional lines, yet it is written with strength and rugged vigor.

Regular Sunday services will be quite generally resumed in the New York churches to-morrow. In consequence of the appalling calamity at Galveston, large numbers of collections will be taken up for the relief of the sufferers.

Berkie Chumko, seventeen years old, a Hungarian servant girl employed by Mr. Lewis Etkin of 512 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, was arrested this morning at 1 o'clock, charged with having tried to poison her employer's three children.

Last year we were saying something about the need for a Professor of Books. Emerson saw with his clear eye the need end importance of a knowledge of the natural history of books, of acquaintance with their outward form and structure, as well as of their inward spirit and texture.

GALVESTON, Sept. 14.--Of the foreign steamers which were grounded by the storm on Pelican Flats, north of the city, the Norwegian steamer Gyller and the British steamer Norma are off and berthed alongside the wharf. The British steamer Benedict will, it is expected, be refloated without difficulty.

Every succeeding year New York society returns to the city a little later, and, although many of the men are to be seen in town during the week, with an occasional party for the play, or a shopping expedition, when Sunday arrives the city is almost deserted by its modish residents. In fact, at this time of the year New York society is scattered to the four winds.

An "experience meeting," so called by ex-Gov. Stone of Missouri, was held in the headquarters of Mr. Bryan's Eastern campaign managers yesterday. This gathering marked the opening of the Democratic fight in the East.

Much good does it do the young woman who receives among her bridal gifts fine cook books. A presentation copy of how "To Live on Five Dollars a Week" is as Greek to her.
