"Dear Mabel" may be a college graduate, with a smaller of French and not know veal from mutton. Her book tells her to select "a good rib roast." What does she know about a rib roast?
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 14. -- The first real attempt to clear away the great mass of debris piled along the beach front for a distance of several miles was begun today.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Rear Admiral Montgomery Sicard died of apoplexy at 9 o'clock this morning at his Summer home at Westernville, a mansion erected by William Floyd, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, whose granddaughter the Admiral married.

"Man, man, has it never crossed you that it's a queer thing the like o' you and me having no ancestors?" "Ay, we had them in a manner o' speaking, no doubt, but they're as completely lost sicht o' as a flagon lid that's fallen ahint the dresser."

Some college professors have suddenly discovered that many, if, indeed, not most, of the young men who go up for examinations cannot write down the answers to the questions in simple English. These young men, say the professors, appear to be unacquainted with a sufficient number of English words to enable them to write what they desire to say.

Wall Street on Thursday builded much on the reports that a settlement of the Chicago Gas war was being arranged by interested parties and that negotiations had progressed so far that the attorneys of the warring companies had met and drafted the terms of settlement. And at the time the hope that a peaceful solution of the difficulty might be arrived at was not ill-founded.

Public swimming baths about the city are responsible for an epidemic of "pink-eye," according to Dr. Cary, chief of the staff of physicians of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, who, with his assistants, are fairly worn out in treating the sufferers who in the last few days have flocked to their dispensary.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- Cablegrams announcing the intention of the United States to withdraw from the international entente are not credited here. The German Foreign Office asserts that nothing in verification of such a rumor has been received.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The Rev. J. F. McCarthy of St. Patrick's Cathedral received a dispatch from Galveston this morning announcing that the twenty-four Newark nuns at the Catholic Convent of the Sacred Heart at that place are safe.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: As your corrospondent, Mr. Ackerly, asks in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 8 how far the Cooperstown of to-day has fulfilled Mr. Cooper's predictions and demands of sixty years ago, I will, answer the queries as briefly as possible, assuming that others of your readers may also be interested.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: May I venture to ask you to give me a list, or can you tell me where to obtain a list, of books suitable to be read to an intelligent boy of four years of age? He is beyond the "Mother Goose" age, and something other than the purely instructive is desired.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In "A Discourse Commemorative of Daniel Webster," delivered before the Faculty, students, and alumni of Dartmouth College in 1853 by Rufus Choate, nine months after Webster's death, there is one sentence which contains 710 words, and another, the longest ever spoken by man, which contains 1,219 words, in the same discourse.

Brooklyn's water scarcity had yesterday become of such gravity as to prompt drastic official action to restrict consumption. At a conference between George W. Birdsall, Chief Engineer of the Department of Water Supply of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx; James Moffett, Deputy Commissioner; Robert Van Buren, engineer in charge, and Ignacio M. De Varona, Engineer of Water Supply of the Borough of Brooklyn Department, it was decided that further economies were necessary.

What a striking contrast there is between this lesson and that of last week! Then we looked upon men completely absorbed in raking together straws, and sticks, and dust of the ground. From long habit they either could not, or would not, look up to see "the celestial crown" held over their heads.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Money tends to be harder, as much is wanted for payments on the Stock Exchange, and also for the installment of exchequer bonds and London County stock. Discounts were firm today. The Bank of England appears to be taking steps to maintain the firmness, perhaps in view of the foreign loans afloat.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 14. -- The destitution and suffering in the smaller towns and in the country districts on the mainland that were swept by the storm is greater than indicated in the earlier reports. Many applications for aid were received from these points to-day by Gov. Sayers.

LENOX, Sept. 14. -- The Lenox Cup, the golf trophy formerly held by Chester Griswold, Jr., will remain in the custody of the Lenox Club this year. S. Frothingham beat H.W. Allen of the Pittsfield Country Club, in a well-played match of thirty-six holes to-day, which decided the ownership of the prize.

It may be of interest to add here a few facts as to the settlement of the region we may call Fenimore Cooper's land many years previous to the arrival of Cooper's father at Cooperstown. On the site of this village a set clement had been planted by George Croghan nearly ten years before the border wars began in that region.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., have decided to remain here until late in the Fall.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I read with a great deal of interest your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 1 entitled "Macaulay and His Style." You declare that it is regardod as "an evidence of Philistinism to admire Macaulay." If that be so, then I am a Philistine of the first magnitude.

Overshadowing all else in the trade developments of the week is the strike ordered in the anthracite coal districts, effective on Monday. What the results of it will be, how far-reaching, it is impossible at the present writing to say, but all indications point that the order to strike will be very generally followed.

M.L. C. Ernst have sold, through Clarence M. Fowler, to Charles F. Davis, the five-story apartment house, 444 Manhattan Avenue, 34.4 by 95. The same firm has also sold, through Edward Polak, to Mary F. O'Donnell, three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, 100 feet west of St. Ann's Avenue, and the plot at the southeast corner of German Place and One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, 75.9 by 100.
LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The following dispatch has been received at the War Office from Lord Roberts:
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Capt. H. W. Pell of the football team arrived in town this afternoon, and about a score of candidates are also here, ready to begin the season's work.
FARGO, N.D., Sept. 14.--Gov. Roosevelt made several speeches to-day en route to Fargo. At Wilmot he spoke from the rear platform of his private car.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The protest of "An Indignant Benedict" against Mr. Eliot Gregory's satire upon American husbands in the volume entitled "The Ways of Man," published in your issue of Sept. 8, recalls to me a forgotten reminiscence of the long ago. In 1875 Mr. Bronson Howard, the dramatist, and I were living at Waybridge on the Thames, he writing plays and I contributing illustrations and sketches to the London press.

There are on every hand signs of the approaching opening of the art season. Studies are being cleaned and painted, and put in order for their occupants. The art schools are soon to open, and with the return of the dealers from their annual trips abroad numbers of important canvases will soon be placed on exhibition.

The confused and contradictory dispatches from the various capitals concerning the Chinese situation must strongly remind the experienced reader of the like dispatches that have appeared when some particularly atrocious act of the Turkish Government has aroused the concert of Europe and shamed the powers into a pretense of doing something.

LYONS, N.Y., Sept 14. -- To-day was politicians' day at the Wayne County Fair, and the State political campaign was opened here in the presence of 10,000 persons from the territory between Syracuse and Rochester by Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, and C.H. Corrigan, the Socialist-Labor Gubernatorial candidate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The American Anti-Trust League, with headquarters in Chicago, has issued a public address officially indorsing William J. Bryan for President and Adlai E. Stevenson for Vice President, and pledging to them the active support of the league.

Dr. Charles Sutherland of Wigmore Street, London, had a remarkable dream. It was a regular nightmare. But, what was worse, the doctor kept on dreaming the same horrors. A woman was drowning and crying for help. That dream affected the health of the doctor, and so he made up his mind to take a holiday.

The Police Board's investigation into the change of police outrages committed on negroes during the recent west side race disturbances was continued yesterday afternoon at Police Headquarters before President York. As during the preceding session, the investigation was specifically into the clubbing of the negro, Elliott.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Justice Scott granted an order upon the application of Ernest Martin, permitting the service by publication of the summons and complaint in an action brought by Martin against Francis D. Carley. a well-known broker. Mr. Martin is suing to establish a $5,000 trust in his favor, and for an accounting and receiver.

Henry Grosvenor Barbour of 65 East Eighty-ninth Street, a son of the Rev. Dr. Henry M. Barbour, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Beloved Disciple at Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, shot himself to death on Thursday night or yesterday morning in the St. Charles Hotel, Myrtle Avenue and Jay Street, Brooklyn.

In the first comment made in these columns on the terrible disaster at Galveston it was confidently predicted that the outpouring from the public purse in aid of the people of the stricken city would be immediate and generous. How bravely that prediction has been fulfilled the readers of our news columns well know.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- At a special meeting of the Board of Trade to-day a resolution authorizing the President and Secretary to execute contracts with the Exchange Telegraph Company was adopted.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Frank P. Johnson, a well-known capitalist of Worcester, Mass., is whitewashing walls and sweeping out corridors in the county jail to-night, as a consequence of his desire to argue a point of law with Judge Zacher of the Branford Court.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- It was learned to-day that Charles W. Compton, who was yesterday made defendant in a suit for $30,000 damages for breach of promise, brought by Miss Ida E. Smith, transferred his real estate to his three maiden sisters, who, it is claimed, were instrumental in breaking the match.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- At a meeting of the stockholders of the Fitchburg Railroad here to-day the lease of that road to the Boston and Maine Railroad was ratified by a vote of 95,623 shares to 227 shares.

Copyright, 1900. The Associated Press. PEKING, Sept. 5, via Shanghai, Sept. 14. -- Prince Ching arrived here yesterday, accompanied by an escort of British and Japanese cavalry. He spent the night in his own palace.

According to reports received by Dun's Review, better conditions prevail in most sections of the Dominion, St. John reporting an influx of Summer visitors which has improved retail trade, and Halifax finds business stimulated by the Provincial Exhibition and fine weather. Toronto finds trade a little quiet after two weeks of unusual activity, but prospects are encouraging.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- The heaviness in the Boston market, which characterized the close yesterday, continued to-day, with the same features prominent. Dominion Coal, which yesterday fell 1 1/2, lost 2 1/2 more today, to 37 1/2, with preferred off 3/4, to 110. New England Gas and Coke lost 3/8 more, to 9 5/8, 910 shares selling in the morning; the 5s were off 4 1/4 more, to 57 1/2.
HAVANA, Sept. 14. -- This evening Gen. Maximo Gomez, Senor Tamayo, Senor Sener, and Mayor Rodriguez, the last three representing the National Party, held a conference at the palace with Gen. Wood.
Four Republican mass meetings were held in this city last night at which men of prominence spoke, arousing much enthusiasm among the large audiences that listened to them.

LONDON, Sept 2. -- The Londoner is dead. It died quietly and without any apparent agony. One day, when it should have been on the newsstands, the people who inquired for it found that it was not. It was by no means a had paper, but the attempt of the proprietor to induce the public to buy for twopence what it has been accustomed to buy for sixpence was a failure.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 14. -- The operators of the Wyoming Valley report tonight that the usual quota of coal was mined to-day and that they expect no decrease in the output to-morrow. All collieries were in operation to-day with the exception of the Exeter mine of the Lehigh Valley Company at Exeter Borough.
Copyright, 1900. The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Sept. 14. -- Li-Hung-Chang starts for Peking to-day.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The Grand Race of the Nations, one of the leading events of the cycling carnival at Vincennes, was to-day won by America. Great Britain, Germany, Italy, Austria, Belgium, France, and Holland also competed, each country being represented by three men. Tom Cooper, Floyd McFarland, and George Banker constituted the American team.

Business in the market for outside securities yesterday was as small as on the previous day, and in no way did the trading show much life. Very little interest in the curb market is being manifested by the public, and the narrowness of the market has become daily more evident. Notwith-standing this, prices continue to show strength, and in not a few cases the orders that are forthcoming are sufficient to bring about substantial advances.

Walter J. Travis, the National amateur golf champion, carried off the chief honors of the day yesterday in the tournament of the Tuxedo Golf Club by winning the Tuxedo Cup, and in the final round he made the surprisingly low record of 71 strokes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- Calvin Pardee, who has been a coal operator for thirty-eight years, and is at the head of the Lattimer Harwood Collieries, in the Lehigh region of Luzerne County, expresses the opinion in an interview that the demands made by the United Mine Workers are absurd, and that a sufficient number of collieries can be kept running to break the force of the strike, no matter how long it lasts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The publication of Gustave Thielkuhl's charges that Webster Davis had recruited troops for the Transvaal while holding a Federal office was followed to-day by the announcement that Postmaster General Smith had dismissed Mr. Davis's brother from the Government service.

Mr. E.C. Stedman's long looked for American anthology will soon make its appearance. The present anthology will include the entire range of American poetry from 1787 to 1899, and opens with a full and carefully written introduction, which contains, a survey of the entire course of American poetry, from its beginnings.

Mr. Hugh Hastings, the State Historian, continues in this, the third volume, the public papers of George Clinton, first Governor of New York. The period treated is of singular interest. It was in 1778 that the exposed condition of the frontiers "was a constant source of anxiety to the backwoodsman and to the State authorities."

Elisha Turner. Elisha Turner, a prominent manufacturer of Torrington and well known throughout Connecticut, died yesterday at his home in Torrington. He was President of the Turner Seymour Manufacturing Company, President of the Torrington Savings Bank, and a Director of the Brooks National Bank of that place.

BOSTON, Sept. 13.m -- When the teacher of Bostonia Beighnse asked her, during the first week of the school term, to name the Presidents of the United States, her mother, Mrs. Wardbosse Beighnse, instantly wrote a complaint to the member of the School Committee owned by her husband. "For," said she, "it is unreasonable to expect a child to remember such things over vacation."

"Anima Vilis" is a romance of singular interest, for, as fur as we remember, it is essentially a story of the steppe. Human nature may be about the same in all parts of the globe, with such modifications as arise from surroundings. The Siberian may be an exile, sent out of Russia for political causes or for social crimes.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Prof. Jebb of England has made two discoveries with respect to Macaulay. One is that the illustrious historian's style was oratorical rather than literary. The other is that Macaulay said clearly and directly what he wanted to say.

Unusual attractive sport is offered by the Atlantic Yacht Club in its Fall regatta, which will be sailed to-day from a start off the Craven's Shoal Buoy in the lower bay. The four Herreshoff seventies will meet again -- this time for a cup given by ex-Commodore Frederick T. Adams, and the two British-built cutters Astrild and Isolde are to have another of their hard-fought races.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit a few words in regard to the present politico-financial situation?

NEWPORT, Sept. 15 -- The Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, R.N. Ellis, Woodbury Kane, and A. Cass Canfield to-day decided the protest of the yachts Yankee and Mineola in favor of the former.

From The Spectator. The real danger of sovereigns is out of doors and must be reduced to a minimum by bullet-proof carriages, speed in traveling, and incessant watchfulness. The best carriage for the purpose is the motor car which William II has just purchased, for as weight matters comparatively little it can have steel sides.

The English did not seem to make use of scouts or patrols, while our patrols were so numerous that we occasionally fired on each other by mistake. Why was Buller waiting? He should have followed us up without a halt from the relief of Ladysmith, and now weeks had gone by. We were exasperated at his dilatoriness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has received a report from Assistant Surgeon Thomas, in charge of the plague inspection work at Glasgow, Surgeon Thomas says that all the cases now under surveillance are to be traced to a wake held over a woman, the wife of a dock laborer, who died about Aug. 21.

The men at the various political headquarters to whom is assigned the task of getting out campaign material, such as songs and various odd devices, are hard at work these days, for the selections that have not already been made must be comleted and the material ready for use by next week.

It is interesting to note that the partaking of mince pie at evening may induce bad dreams, but it is hardly profitable to speculate deeply why my dream took the form of a leering demon with the impolite habit of squatting on my chest. The stuff that dreams are made of is not susceptible of that type of analysis.

The special board of inquiry at the Barge Office yesterday afternoon decided to allow, the twenty-two Roumanian actors and actresses to land, despite the contention of the Hebrew Actors' Union that they were liable to become public charges.
HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- The storm of last week destroyed the lighthouses and lightships along the south coast of Cuba. They are to be rebuilt forthwith.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

Copyright. 1900. LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Are we to have the general election next month? That is the conundrum. I can only reply that Chamberlain and "Bobs" are doing their best to bring it about, the former by working his newspapers and publishing documents like that report upon the Boer hospitals calculated to inflame popular passions once more in his favor, and the latter by proclamations of annexation and general threats of vengeance.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Although much money has changed hands, the demand is less pronounced than yesterday, and the supply is larger, owing to borrowing from bank discounts, strengthened by the new issue of two millions in Treasury bills, for which tenders will be received at the Bank of England Sept. 21, and which will probably take off much money from the market unless the bank takes a large portion.

The committee appointed to revise the constitution of the League of American Wheelmen has completed its work, and its report will appear in the League of American Wheelmen Magazine for October. There will no special session of the Assembly called to act upon the recommendations of the committee, as it is thought better to give time for the careful consideration of the proposed changes.

The September Grand Jury is investigating charges of attempted extortion made by a prisoner in the Tombs -- Belle or Mrs. E.D. Fitzgerald is one of her many pseudonyms -- against Policeman William A. Spolasco, a member of the Criminal Court squad. The subject will be taken up again to-morrow by the Grand Jury, which on Friday heard Spolasco's accuser.

Free distribution of Pasteurized modified milk, prepared especially with a view to preventing disorders in the bowels of very young children, which has been carried on since July 17 by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities in co-operation with the Borough Health Department, will be discontinued for the season to-morrow, and it is hoped that another Summer will see the work conducted on a larger scale.

Advance copies of the prospectus of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences for the coming educational year have just been issued. The season of active work begins on Thursday, Sept. 27, 1900, and closes on Saturday, June 1, 1901. The number of anniversary addresses, lectures, exhibitions, and department meetings, open to every member, is 550, or about fifteen for each of the thirty-six weeks of the season.
OTTAWA, Sept. 15. -- The appearance once again of Hugh John Macdonald into the arena of Dominion polities has given an increased interest to the campaign which is beginning all over the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Next week marks the opening of the two hundredth year of Yale University. The bare fact that Yale is to be two centuries old is not half so interesting to the students as the changes the anniversary will bring about in studies and professorships.

The Irish peasant is passionately fond of music. Even the untutored playing of the town fife and drum band will send him into ecstacies. But, unhappily, there is little or no developed musical capacity, vocal or instrumental, in rural Ireland. The harper was extinct as far back as the days of our grandfathers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept 15. -- With a very large attendance of spectators the golf match for the Count of Turin Cup. at 36 holes, was played this afternoon on the Newport links. Reginald Brooks won the trophy by the score of 164 gross, 6 handicap, 158 net. Some of the other best net scores were: Fred P. Sands, 160; Nathaniel Thayer, 166; J. J. Mason, 166.

Paul Kester's "Sweet Nell of Old Drury" seems to have made an unquestioned triumph at the Haymarket Theatre in London. Julia Neilson's acting in the title role seems to be unusually graceful and vivacious. Her singing in a pretty scene in which Nell cozens the King is also cordially praised.

Imp, fast and game as she is erratic, gave racegoers one of her surprises at the Gravesend track yesterday. In the "Second Special," a race at a mile and a half, she made the double-crowned Kinley Mack and the oft-heralded "champion" Ethelbert look like the proverbial "thirty cents" very badly battered.
Col. W.J. BRYAN, in his own book on "The First Battle," quotes with assumed approval his remarks made at Baltimore on Sept. 19, 1896, when he said:

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15. -- Constitutional reform is to be the keynote of the campaign in this State this Fail. An organization, non-partisan in character, and made up of leading men of both parties in this State, has revived the movement toward this end, and the State Democratic Convention will place the question before the voters as the paramount issue of the State campaign.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to ask a little space in your estimable paper to correct some statements by "S.P." of Rhinebeck, N.Y., in your issue of Sept. 6, not wishing, however, to go into personalities or to slander him for his honest convictions.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 15. -- The exodus from Galveston grows as the facilities for getting away from the city are increased. Boats left here to-day more frequently than on any day since the storm, some proceeding direct to Houston via Buffalo Bayou, and others making connection at Texas City with the Great Northern Railroad train.

The mystery surrounding the suicide of Henry Grosvenor Barbour of 65 East Eighty-ninth Street, son of the Rev. Henry M. Barbour, was cleared yesterday morning by the discovery of the woman who was with him in the St. Charles Hotel, Myrtle Avenue and Jay Street, Brooklyn, at the time of the shooting.

It has become obvious that for the determination of many questions of date, of relation, of culture, objects of no intrinsic value may be of more than trifling importance. And not merely the object, but the exact position in which it is found -- under what layers of soil, in connection with, what other memorials, or if altogether solitary -- is of equal concern.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Rear Admiral William T. Sampson is here. The Admiral, who is accompanied by his wife, is the guest of Mrs. Robert M. Thompson, who recently returned from Europe and is at her Summer residence here. Mr. and Mrs. Thompson gave a large dinner tonight at the Meadow Club in honor of their guests.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 15. -- The situation in the Lackawanna district to-night as regards the strike is remarkable. Out of thirty-five mines more than half of them are shut down. In some cases this is due to the refusal of the mine boys to go to work, it being impossible to run the mines without them.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 15. -- Many collieries were shut down at noon to-day. Hundreds of men removed their tools and are ready for the strike. Orders were issued at the coal company offices to-night to the effect that all collieries would be operated on full time next week. If not enough men report, then work will be shut down altogether until the strike is settled.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 15. -- The miners' strike is now on in earnest, and when Monday morning comes there will not be a single colliery in the Wyoming Valley in operation.

CEDARHURST, L.L, Sept. 15. -- What is probably the largest tennis tournament that has been held on Long Island this season is now in progress on the grounds of the Rockaway Hunt Club. Prizes are being competed for in men's singles and doubles, ladies' singles and doubles, and mixed doubles.

HONOLULU, Sept. 8, (via San Francisco, Sept. 15.) -- The bark Ceylon to-day brought to Honolulu all the participants in a fight Aug. 11 on the guano island of Laysan, 600 miles northeast of Honolulu, in which two Japanese laborers were killed by Capt. Spencer, the "King" of the island. Forty Japanese laborers had been taken there to help load vessels from Honolulu with guano.

From The World of Yesterday. THE TIMES answers with candor and courtesy the questions concerning Mr. McKinley and the Philippines put to it by The World in "A Short Catechism on Freedom." Such a discussion ought to do good. It is at least a great improvement on the usual method of the defenders of the President's policy, which is to call those who do not side with them "traitors."

THURSDAY, SEPT. 20. -- By William M. Ryan, foreclosure sale, William A. Boyd, referee, 422 West One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, south side, 276 feet west of St. Nicholas Avenue, 19 by 99.11, three-story stone-front dwelling. Due on judgment, $17,118.

From The Spectator. Fond as the butterflies are of the light and sun, they dearly love their beds. Like most fashionable people who do nothing, they stay there very late. But their unwillingness to get up in the morning is equaled by their eager desire to leave the world, and its pleasures early and be asleep in good time.

LORENZO MARQUES, Aug. 1. -- Already is being discussed the question of removing the capital, or, to speak accurately, the seat of Government of the Transvaal, since Pretoria is not, and never has been, the capital of the Transvaal. The small town of Potchefstroom has always held that position, for which it certainly enjoys exceptional natural advantages.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15 -- On Monday the Yale football team will assemble in this city for the preliminary practice of the season. Capt. F. Gordon Brown arrived today and made final preparations for the advent of the Yale kickers. There will be twenty-odd men here for the first week's work, about half of whom will be new men.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 15. -- The details of the financial statement for the year ended June 30 last, given out by the Finance Department, show that the revenue was $51,000,783, and the expenditure $42,976,051, leaving a surplus on ordinary revenue of $8,024,731.
HAVANA, Sept. 15. -- At this moment, when the definite result of the most important election ever held in Cuba is in the balance, the demeanor of the public is unexpectedly placid.

The continuance of almost Summer heat is having a marked effect upon the social as well as the business world. Many families in the nearer suburbs, and even at Newport, Southampton, Bar Harbor, and further resorts, who have spent the early weeks of September there, arid who had planned to come nearer home at this time, have postponed their departure on account of the continued warm weather.

WASHINGTON, Sept 15. -- M. de Wollant. the Russian Charge d'Affaires, was in Washington to-day for the first time since he delivered to the State Department the Russian proposition for the evacuation of Peking. He did not call at the State Department, however, and his return was not regarded as significant, as he is moving his family from the seashore to the mountains.

M. Henri de Regnier, the French poet, who last Winter under the auspices of the Cercle Francais of Harvard University gave a series of lectures at the universities and principal colleges of the United States, was not very favorably impressed by his visit, as is shown by an article giving his "impressions" published in the Gaulois of Paris.

During yesterday's short session of the curb market, trading was so light that very little interest was shown even by traders, and the day's changes were in few cases important. Prices were less firm than earlier in the week, and in some parts of the list the declines were sufficient to bring prices below the previous Saturday's figures.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 1 -- The conflict which has arisen between Bulgaria and Roumania, and which may result in a general conflagration in the Balkans, is a subject of paramount interest here. The apparent cause of the trouble was the murder of Prof. Mihaileano, but the real cause is a more deeply rooted one.

Gen. Louis P. Di Cesnola, Director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, returned fron a European trip yesterday on the French liner La Lorraine. During his trip abroad Gen. Di Cesnola had an extended interview with the late King Humbert of Italy, and was the last foreigner who was so favored by the monarch, who a month afterward fell a victim to the assassin Bresci.

From The Fortnightly Review. The growing costliness of fashionable London tends to exclude from its most modish circles a class that could perhaps ill be spared. That phenomenon, however, is not peculiar to the capital. It is to be found in all parts of the provinces: it is but one of the many indications of the changes inseparable from the substitution of commerce for land as a foundation of national prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- If Lieut. Gen. Miles is right, the much-vaunted disappearing gun carriage, now in use all along the seacoast, is a lamentable failure, and every cent invested in it is money thrown away. If he can prove his proposition the highly expensive machines will be taken down everywhere and replaced by the oldfashionied carriage, and the United States will have nothing to show for the immense sums invested in them but experience.

The conference between officials of the American Tin Plate Company and a committee from the Tin Plate Workers' International Protective Association of America for the purpose of arranging a scale of wages for 1900-1901 ended last night in a disagreement, the Tin Plate Company failing to concede some of the demands put forth by its employes.

HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 15. -- In a thirty-six-hole match play on the Myopia links today, J. H. Taylor was defeated by the best ball of " Jack" Jones of Myopia and "Joe" Lloyd of the Essex County Club by a score of 3 up and 2 to play. Taylor was sick all day and his play was not up to the usual standard.

Howard Gould's large steam yacht Niagara, with Mr. and Mrs. Gould and a small party aboard, arrived in port late yesterday afternoon after a four months' cruise in European waters. The Niagara left Southampton twelve days ago. Her homeward passage was made under agreeable weather conditions, and all aboard were reported well.

From The Philadelphia Press. Las Vegas, New Mexico, which cast 750 votes four years ago, had a Republican club with 150 members; now they have a Hammer and Tongs Republican Club of 400 members, enthusiastic in the cause, all of whom have made personal application for membership, showing considerably more than 100 per cent. increase.

Security market values have to stand few severer tests than long-continuing dullness. Wall Street has been at a standstill for months; there has been neither buying nor selling on any substantial scale since early last Spring; not only have investors been holding aloof, but there has been no show of liquidation.

C.M. Hamilton, the young golf champion of the Baltusrol Club, and winner of several valuable trophies in past competitions, led the field yesterday from scratch in the handicap with which the Tuxedo golf tournament was closed. He made the score of 157 strokes for the 36 holes, turning in the low figure of 76 for the last 18 holes.

The bank statement, issued yesterday shortly before the close of business, did not make an encouraging showing. Surplus reserves decreased $5,220,075, while specie showed a loss of $2,691,100, and legal tenders a loss of $2,263,100. Loans, on the other hand, increased $7,022,600, and deposits increased $1,063,500.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- It is learned from a person who saw Dr. Miquel, the Minister of Finance, this afternoon that he is highly delighted with the success of the loan and the New York Life Insurance Company's subscription.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- Trading was more active to-day; there was brisk selling of Sugar and some of the copper stocks were fairly active. Amalgamated Copper lost 7/8, to 87 1/8, on an odd lot, closing at 87 1/2 bid; Montana lost 2, to 312; Centennial Eureka lost 1/2, to 18, rallying to 19; Isle Royale lost 1, to 29.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Wesleyan College has begun her football practice on Andrus Field under the direction of ex-Capt. "Bert" Wilson, '97. There is a large squad for so early in the Reason. The training table includes C.R. Dodds and Yarrow, '01; Inglis, '02; Cornwall, Lacey, and Calder, '03, of last year's Varsity.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The Times publishes a second article to-day on American competition in small metal goods. Commenting editorially upon the article The Times arrives at the conclusion that "a protective tariff leaves trade to adapt itself to the special needs of the home market and to only compete in the foreign markets with the surplus not specially adapted for foreign needs."

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 15.--About forty persons were injured to-night in a collision which occurred on the Yonkers trolley system at 9 o'clock. Two cars, traveling in opposite directions on a single track at the rate of ten miles an hour, came together with terrific force. One of the victims will probably die.

READING, Penn., Sept. 15.--There was no a colliery owned by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company that did not work to-day, and more than 2,800 cars of coal were brought down from the lines.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- On the Boerse to-day 3 per cent, home funds were firmer on American advices. Americans and Canadians were dull. Mine shares declined, owing to the unsatisfactory outlook in the iron industry. Bank shares were weak.

The committee having in charge, the erection of a monument to the late Adjt, Gen. Josiah Porter has decided upon a site just south of the old mansion at Van Cortlandt Park Parade Ground. The monument will be of granite and bronze, the pedestal 10 feet in height, surmounted by a portrait statue of the General, in the first quality of bronze, 9 feet in height.

Peter Cooper hoped during the closing years of his life that the great building he raised "To Science and Art," and which is his monument, would some day be devoted entirely to the uses for which it ,was erected, and in the trust deed by which he conveyed the property to the public he expressed the wish that the space used at night might also be employed during the day for education.

Several letters were received yesterday by the Secretaries of the American Bible Society inquiring as to the truth of the report published Friday regarding the condition of the society. The report stated that the society is anxious to sell the Bible House, and it was intimated that the affairs are in bad shape.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 15. -- The Howard trial was resumed to-day and Engineer Woodson concluded his testimony. Lieut. John Rlcketts testified that, after the shooting, he saw a man jump the rear fence near the Executive Building. The man, he thought, had a gray mustache, and he did not believe Howard was the man.

Mr. E.H. Sothern will act Hamlet tomorrow night at the Garden Theatre for the first time in his life. Preparations for a handsome production of Shakespeare's tragedy have been going on at the Garden Theatre for a long while. Eight new scenic pictures have been painted by E.G. Unitt.

The skins of various kinds of sea animals will be popular in all kinds of leather goods the coming season. There will be sealskin and walrus. Anything which comes out of the sea and is adaptable will be finely dressed and appear in all sorts of fashionable shapes. Not that other animals will be neglected.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 15. -- The following statement to the public was issued from the United Mine Workers' headquarters here to-day. It was signed by John Mitchell, President, and W.B. Wilson, Secretary-Treasurer :

PRINCETON, Sept. 15. -- On Wednesday of next week the formal opening of the university will take place. President Patton has arrived from his Summer home in the Bermuda Islands; and Dean Winans came in on Thursday from his trip to his former home in Nova Scotia.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 15. -- The eighteenth annual reunion of the Old Time Telegraphers' Association and the Society of the United States Military Corps will be held in St. Paul and Minneapolis next Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. Extensive preparations have been made for the gathering, and old-time operators, many of whom have not handled a telegraph key for twenty years or more, will be present.

TUESDAY, Sept. 18. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Louis C. Raegener, referee, 73 West Eighty-ninth Street, north side, 58 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 42 by 75, two five-story brick flats. Due on judgment, $40,725.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- An ingenious little swindle has just come to light in Paris, whereby Leon Gervais, a well-know merchant of Toulouse, was done out of 6,000 francs and his son spent several days in prison.

Brig. Gen. M.I. LUDINGTON, Quarter-master General of the United States Army, has made a very interesting report concerning the branch of the public service under his control. This report was not required in the ordinary course of business, but was made necessary by accusations brought against the Quarter-master Department of gross carelessness, prodigious and shameful extravagance in the expenditure of money, and the failure to require vouchers for purchases aggregating millions of dollars.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $5,220,075. The banks now hold a surplus of $20,836,175 above the legal requirements.

The contributions to the local Galveston relief funds so far as reported to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday aggregate $208,081.40, a sum $20,589.02 in excess of the amount reported collected up to Friday night, which was $178,492.38.

"She's gone with a younger man." James Ficke, until recently a private in the United States Army, thus answered an inquiry as to his young wife's whereabouts. He is forty-seven years old and has retired from military service, after doing duty continuously since his youth. His home is at Gelston Place and Ninety-fourth Street, Brooklyn, and it was from there that Mrs. Ficke eloped week before last.

The close of New York's Grand Circuit meeting, at the Empire City track yesterday, was attended by the second largest crowd of the week, heats with driving finishes, and several swiftly stepped miles. Under gray skies and in the cool air the harness horses furnished struggles that, owing to closeness at various points of the track, were uncertain as to outcome and contested with much vigor.

From The Cornhill. "Four great loves of bread and a white flag were stuck up on all the church steeples, but that was only a trumped-up peace, that Amiens one, for the wars went on worse than ever, until the victory of Trafalgar," he continued, proud of this opportunity of airing his knowledge. "And there never was such a thing as that heard of afore, they tell me; but then we heard Nelson was dead.

Some of the public-spirited citizens of the Bronx have started a project to erect a soldiers and sailors' monument to the memory of the men from the Bronx who lost their lives in the Spanish war. These include a number of the sailors on the Maine, Rough Riders, members of the Seventy-first Regiment, and other volunteer and regular organizations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To say that certain of your readers were utterly disgusted by your editorial of the 13th inst. advocating the election of Mr. Stanchfield would be expressing it mildly. You speak of Mr. Odell as "a very respectable man," yet in your very next sentence you practically assert that he has no will of his own and is simply the tool of others.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 13 -- The vexatious delays and accidents disappointed 2,000 spectators at Buttonwood Cycle Track this afternoon. Following the amateur events came the announced twenty-mile matched motor-paced race between Eddie McDuffie and Arthur Ross. It was Ross's first appearance since his recent trip abroad, where he won many prizes.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15.--The much-talked-of strike of the anthracite mine workers in the coal regions of Pennsylvania, under the auspices of the Union Mine Workers of America,...
NEWPORT, Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish and James J. Van Alen entertained at dinner this evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The representatives at the Central Church, the Hamilton Club, and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra have united to build a twelve-story structure in Washington Street. It will be a church, a clubhouse, and music hall combined, and will, in a general way, be patterned after St. James's Hall, London.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- The topic of the hour to-night among the Yale men who have returned to this city is the report that Charles Wylie McKelvey of Bridgeport, who was graduated last June with the class of 1900, tried to smuggle from Europe a diamond necklace. McKelvey arrived in New York Thursday on the Hamburg Line steamship Fuerst Bismarck, it is said.

RIGHT AND LEFT HANDEDNESS. -- In a recent volume by Dr. Fritz Lueddeckens, "Rechts und Links Handigkeit," a new theory is put forward to explain the fact that most of us are right-handed. The author believes that it is due to the higher degree of blood pressure which usually exists on the left side of the brain, which governs the right side of the body.
The work of the United Hebrew Charities for August, according to the reports of the various committees and from the books of the society, shows the following results:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Aug. 17 you state that "by law every bond of the United States and the interest thereon, except the refunding 2 per cents, is payable in standard silver dollars, at the discretion of the Government, which in practice means the Secretary of the Treasury under the direction of the President."

The flight of ex-President KRUEGER to Lorenzo Marques, preparatory to his embarkation for some European port, has offered the long-awaited opportunity to Lord ROBERTS to apply simultaneously both parts of RICHELIEU'S favorite dual axiom: All means to conciliate, and, failing these, all means to crush.

BRANFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Capt. "Tom" Simons of the Columbia team left here to-day for his home in New York for a few days. Simons will drum up recruits for the team among promising football material in the "prep." school circles in New York. There is a great scarcity of high-class players among the new men on hand, as, with the exception of three or four, the new men are not brilliant.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The grand manoeuvres of the French Army, which have been proceeding for the past week in sectional form, entered their final and general stage today. The scene of the operations, La Beauce, is the great wheat plain of France. Four army corps are taking part in the mimic warfare.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15. -- Plans for the opening of the Yale School of Forestry this Pall are now completed, and when the term begins one of the most unique departments in any university in the country will be in full running order.

Edgar French, forty-one years old, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital on May 1 to be treated for chronic heart trouble. He was sent to the Metropolitan Hospital on Blackwell's Island and discharged on May 27. He was readmitted at Bellevue and sent to the island on June 17.

Everybody who cherishes a sincere regard for dramatic art hopes that the present craze among theatrical purveyors for stage versions of popular novels will not last long. A dramatized novel is not often an artistic play. If the novel is a masterwork which one cherishes, the dramatization is likely to have a disturbing not to say a depressing influence on his mind.

The Princess Angela of the royal family of Arcacia is an uncommonly charming young woman. She is so attractive that Miss Annie Russell, to whom people are crediting a very large share of her consummate charm, says that it is an absolute delight to play the part, that it would be possible simply to live on indefinitely in it while it played itself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are doubtless a number of men who, like myself, are in a quandary regarding the manner in which to cast their votes at the coming election. An easy solution of the problem would be not to vote at all, but that I consider a shirking of a sacred duty.

SIMLA, Aug. 16 -- At last it is possible to report some improvement in the famine districts. The general-outlook throughout India, in fact, is more favorable to-day than has been the case for two years back.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 14. -- Provisions are selling at famine prices here, sugar bringing 2s. 6d. a pound and pork the same price, while matches are sold at 1s. a box. Other staple articles are proportionately dear, while many necessities are not obtainable at any price.

Notwithstanding the fact that the programme of the annual championship games of the Amateur Athletic Union offered the best that can be had in this country in amateur athletics, there was a comparatively small crowd of spectators at Columbia Field yesterday to see the sport.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- Archbishop Ryan of this diocese, which includes many of the coal districts, who yesterday consented to serve as an arbiter in connection with the mine workers' strike should his offices be desired in that connection, said to-day that he believed arbitration was yet possible.

Sales of high-class residential property in increased numbers, negotiations for several valuable business properties, and reports of additional inquiries among brokers have combined to give a more favorable aspect to the business of the last few days and to strengthen the hope for a Fall market of at least moderate activity.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The French Government, which had intended to celebrate the exposition year by giving a banquet to all the Mayors of France, has decided to limit the function to a small affair and ask only 15,000 guests. There are 36,123 representatives of the municipalities of France, and it was feared that if they should all accept the invitation, the banquet hall might be uncomfortably crowded.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- James R. Keene, who sailed for the United States to-day, said to a press representative:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was Cicero who said, "No sensible men ever changed one with inconsistency who had merely changed his opinion." The world exists by change, and but for that all matter-would go back to chaos to form a pillow for a sleeping god. "The thinking minds of all nations call for change.

It has been generally accepted as certain that the season following a contest for the famous America's Cup would be devoid of interest in yacht racing. The stimulus then given to designing and building is usually succeeded by apathy, and lovers of nautical sport find matters dull and flat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been a constant reader of your paper for nearly thirty years, and I have always placed confidence in its fairness and good judgment. I would like to ask its opinion and the reasons for the opinion on the following supposition:
JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 15.--Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, addressed a Republican gathering in this city to-night. He said in part:...

HONOLULU, July 11. -- Since by its admission as a Territory of the United States Hawaii is likely to get more attention at home than heretofore, some interest may attach to the conditions of living, the kind of people who have become, citizens, the business outlook, the chances for labor or investment, and in general to the sort of acquisition which the country has made in this Pacific outpost.

Senator KEAN of New Jersey has begun a work which promises results of vast economic and industrial importance to that State. That his example will be followed by others, under syndicate management, is extremely probable.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The annual regatta of the New York Athletic Club was held on the club's private course in front of the clubhouse on Travers Island to-day. The boathouse piazza was crowded with members and their guests.

A New York dressmaker has had an experience this past Summer. It was that she wanted, a great deal of it, but the conditions under which it was obtained were a surprise to her. She had seen in the shops silk waists and blouses well made and sold for altogether less than she could make one, and she was anxious to know how it could be done.

With mainsail soaked to the reef points and deck slippery with the salt spray, Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-footer Rainbow heeled across the finish line at the Fall regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club yesterday afternoon, winner over August Belmont's Mineola, in one of the most spirited and closely fought races of the season.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 15. -- W.J. Bryan spoke here to-night at the Coliseum Hall under the auspices of the National Democratic Committee of Commercial Travelers. The hall is said to seat 14,000 people. Not only was every seat occupied, but every available foot of standing room was also covered.

There is a prospect of the Laborers' Union Protective Society, which has a membership of 11,000 in New York and has ten divisions, being arrayed against the Bricklayers' Unions. The society is composed of masons' laborers and they received 33 cents an hour, but their agreement with the Mason Builders' Association was not renewed this year.

In an official manner the officers of the "Woman's Christian Temperance Union at Indianapolis on Friday announced that the Indiana branch of the organization had not originated the "chain" of prayer intended to secure the defeat of WILLIAM MCKINLEY for President, had not indorsed it, and did not believe that it had been indorsed by any local union of the State.
PORT JERVIS, Sept. 15. -- The Erie Railroad Company since last Spring has been storing coal at this place, until at the present time it has over 30,000 tons piled upon grounds of its own.

HAVANA, Sept 11. -- A very large proportion of the population of Cuba belongs to the colored race. In this respect Havana itself reminds one of a Southern city in our own country, but with a difference. There the race knows its place and keeps it; there is no attempt at familiarity with white persons.

Richard Croker will take personal charge of the Democratic campaign in this State. Mr. Croker announced that he would visit the Democratic State Headquarters, which are now controlled by the friends of David B. Hill, every day, and would give advice on matters of importance.

Copyright, 1900. The Associated Press. BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The Chinese situation here is deemad to be highly unsatisfactory and most complicated, though no sensational events are immediately expected and isolated action upon the part of any one power is not anticipated. According to the opinion here, all the interested powers are too firmly convinced of the importance of continued harmony and solidarity to jeopardize them when no necessity calls for it.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The Democrats of the Second Assembly District, Orange County, this afternoon nominated Philip A. Rorty for member of the Assembly.

DELPHI, Ind., Sept 15. -- Senator Marcus A. Hanna addressed the Republicans of the Ninth Congressional District of Indiana here to-day. A large crowd had assembled at the train, and a procession escorted the Senator to the Court House Square, where he addressed an audience of about 5,000.

The Vailsburg board track on the out-skirts of Newark was yesterday the scene of some lively work among the cycle racers. Frank Kramer was on his mettle, and headed a group of fast professionals in the final heat of the quarter mile open. Fisher, the speedy rider from Chicago, who finished second, made things very interesting for the winner all the way.
"Half the time the ship stood on its head, and we did the same."

GALVESTON, Sept. 16. -- The Ursuline Convent and Academy, in charge of the Sisters of St. Angelo, proved during the storm a haven of refuge for nearly 1,000 unfortunates. No one was refused admittance to the sheltering institution. Negroes and whites were taken in without question, and the asylum has thrown open to all who sought its protuction.

Few golf clubs can offer to their devotees so much that is at once sporty and beautiful to the eye as can be found at the Tuxedo Golf Club. Nature has been lavish of her charms in and around Tuxedo Park, and the golfers have one of the most rugged and picturesque portions of the entire preserve for their special domain.

M.H. De Young of The San Francisco Chronicle, who visited Paris as President of the Board of United States Commissioners of the Exposition, was a passenger on the American liner New York, which arrived yesterday. Seen at the Waldorf-Astoria last night he said:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 16. -- To-day at Rockhill, S.C., the Coroner's jury found that Harry A. Brown had been shot to death by Paul R. Bratton, and that the latter's brother, John S. Bratton, was an accessory. The evidence showed that the Brattons drove to Rockhill from Yorkville; fifteen miles, Friday night, and made diligent search for Brown.

Carnegie Hall was well filled, though not crowded, at the memorial services for Galveston's dead yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Salvation Army, and at which the Young Men's Christian Association and the various churches and synagogues of New York were represented. Justice Charles F. MacLean of the Supreme Court presided, being introduced by Commander Booth-Tucker as they stood beneath a great American flag hung across the proscenium.

John B. Randolph, long connected with the American Art Association of 6 East Twenty-third Street, died in the J. Hood Wright Hospital yesterday from injuries received by falling down a flight of stairs at his home, 312 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 16. -- A last desperate attempt is being made to-night to bring about peace between the coal operators and their men. Father Phillips, who has worked hard for a settlement of the differences between the employers and the mine workers, has again entered the field, with the proposition that Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia be accepted as arbitrator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Frank H. Hitchcock, Chief of the Section of Foreign Markets of the Agricultural Department, has prepared a bulletin showing the value and character of American agricultural Imports from each foreign country for the five fiscal years 1895-9. It shows that the agricultural imports had an average annual value of $366,964,708, of which more than one-half came from tropical countries.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 16. -- With the exception of President Mitchell's arrival, there was little evidence shown here to-day that Hazleton was the storm centre of the present coal war between labor and capital. Nothing occurred to disturb the serenity of the Sabbath. Quite a large number of miners came to town, but soon left when they found that there was no news.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- Succi, the Italian fasting champion who is about to renew here what he has already accomplished a score of times -- remaining without food for forty days -- will be on exhibition inside the exposition grounds, and the appropriate place he has chosen wherein to sit out his forty days and forty nights of fasting is the playhouse called the "Theatre of the Gay Authors," in the merry Rue de Paris.

Sylvester R. Koehler, curator of printing in the Museum of Fine Arts of Boston, died Saturday of heart disease in Littleton, N.H. He was born in Leipsic, Germany, in 1837. He removed to the United States in 1849, and located at Roxbury, Mass. He rapidly acquired a reputation as a writer of articles on art, and became editor of The American Art Review.

Jimmie Smith, Messenger 1,534 of the American District Telegraph Company, who went to South Africa to deliver to President Kruger the message from the school children of Philadelphia and the scrapbook of clippings on Boer sentiment in this country, prepared by a bureau, was a passenger on the New York, which arrived yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Frederick B. McKee, who says he is a traveling salesman of 103 Merrimac Street, Boston, Mass., was held for the Grand Jury to-day. Martin Albright of 210 Broome Street charged McKee with having taken his poeketbook containing $78 from his pocket.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 16. -- That the strike of the mine workers in the anthracite coal regions of Pennsylvania, which President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America has officially ordered to begin to-morrow morning, will be one of considerable magnitude seems certain to-night from reports received from the regions affected.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- Prices generally declined last week, although the Boerse was somewhat mote active than usual. A pessimistic tone characterized the market, due to the German loan, the rising discount rates, and the disappointing reports from industrial centres. The Boerse is not pleased with the loan.

From The Rochester Union. Are the States of New York and New Jersey powerless to save the Palisades? This query is suggested by a communication to THE NEW YORK TIMES in which the correspondent says: "The destruction of the Palisades goes on at a fourfold rate; instead of using ordinary blasting powder, as formerly, the quarrymen are employing dynamite.

BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 16. -- Gov. Roosevelt spent last night at Bismarck, and began the Sunday trip westward at 6 o'clock this morning. There was no speechmaking during the day, but there was some handshaking and conversation between the New York Governor and the people along the route.

Now, to-day there has sprung up a new and a third class of newspapers. The members of this class belong to neither party. They call themselves independent, and yet they are as bigoted in many cases as the old party papers. They feel that they must remain independent at all cost, and they pick out for general assault the leaders or the bosses of both parties.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16. -- Mr. Bryan attended service at the Centenary Methodist Church to-day and spent the remainder of the day with relatives in this city. He left to-night for Southeastern Kansas, where he will spend the next two days. He speaks at Galena, Kan., to-morrow, and will make several short speeches en route to that place.

A great deal more attention is being directed to the question of the exportation of American coal than the facts warrant. Considering the people behind the movement, it is fair to assume that a gigantic, speculation is organizing, the object of which is to give a fictitious value to certain tracts of undeveloped coal lands and to "boom" the stocks of the coal roads having seaboard terminal facilities.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 16. -- The United Mine Workers spent the Sabbath in strengthening their lines where they were weak. Organizer James came up from Hazleton and addressed a large mass meeting at Hudson, a mining town five miles north of this city. In the course of his address Mr. James was loudly applauded.

The refusal of the Workingmen's State Federation at its convention Utica last week to contribute $500 to the striking cigarmakers here started a passage at arms yesterday between two delegates at the meeting of the Central Federated Union. John J. Pallas, who attended the convention, was making a report of its proceedings when Morris Brown of the Cigarmakers began an attack on the Federation.

S.K. Saenger, President of the United Singers of Brooklyn, was welcomed by the delegates at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at Arlon Hall, on Wall Street, Brooklyn, on his return from Europe, where he presented to Emperor William of Germany a souvenir in recognition of the Kaiser Prize, which the Emperor sent to this country to be competed for at the National Saengerfest, held in July last in the Thirteenth Regiment Armory.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Sept. 16. -- At 7:30 o'clock this evening the United Mine Workers' leaders said that from reports at hand from Dauphin, Columbia, Schuylkill, and Northumberland Counties, indications pointed to at least 50 per cent, of the men, principally between here and Centralia, going on strike to-morrow, in which event the collieries cannot be operated.

HAVANA, Sept. 16. -- In yesterday's elections of delegates to the forthcoming Constitutional Convention the National Party again triumphed in the Province of Havana. Not only did it elect the five delegates of the majority representation, but it also captured one of the minority representatives, the Republican Party electing the other two, namely, Manuel Sanguily and Berriel.

From The Indianapolis Journal. In his speech at La Cross Gov. Roosevelt said: "The regular army is the servant of the people, and is no more a menace to your liberties than is the police force in this city."

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $5,220,075. The banks now hold a surplus of $20,836,175 above the legal requirement. The changes in averages show an increase in loans of $7,022,600, a decrease in specie of $2,691,100, a decrease in legal tenders of $2,2263,100, an increase in deposits of $1,063,500, and an increase in circulation of $372,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Peter Hartman, a resident of Burkett, Ind., was attacked by three highwaymen while walking in Van Buren Street, near State, at 12:40 o'clock this afternoon, dragged into a hallway, and murdered for his money. The assault was witnessed by several persons, and when Hartman fell to the pavement with a crushed skull, the result of a blow with a pop bottle, there were shouts for the police.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 16. -- The excitement in cotton last week practically blocked all attempts to complete important transactions in cloth. Prices were very irregular, although the sales effected were usually at substantial advances. Satisfactory demands from India were scarce, the manufacturers frequently declining to quote or asking figures quite unobtainable.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- The extension of time granted to Mayor Van Wyck of New York City in which to file his answer relative to the charges made against him of holding stock in the so-called Ice Trust expired on Saturday at the noon hour. Nothing was filed by the Mayor, however.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 16. -- To-day was devoid of any excitement in connection with the strike. At the Mine Workers' headquarters Organizer Dilcher sat during the greater part of the day chatting with the other officers. As far as could be learned the mine officials were absolutely idle.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 16. -- B.B. Odell, Jr., has sold out Ills Interest in the Consumers' Gas Company and the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light, Heat and Power Company of Newburg to a syndicate of which F.R. Bain of this city is a member. The transaction involved several hundred thousand dollars.

It is truly a remarkable spectacle that this Union of States now offers to the contemplation of the nations. For blind reactionary stupidity the world has seen nothing like it on so grand a scale since the Holy Alliance was dashed to pieces on the rocks of English enlightenment and the Monroe doctrine eighty years ago.
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- There is as yet no definite news as to whether Li-Hung-Chang will go to Peking.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The first week's practice of the University of Pennsylvania football candidates was productive of good results, and the coachers are well pleased with the work of the squad. They speak to-night in a highly complimentary manner of the earnest work of these who are trying for positions on the eleven.

-- Most of the humor of politics is entirely unintentional, the average politician taking himself with the utmost seriousness and constantly endeavoring to create the useful impression that upon his success or failure in "carrying" some larger or smaller part of the country depends the fate of at least one nation.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 16. -- Gov. Sayers gave out the following to-day:

Little two-year-old Doretta Kitt, while watching a passing funeral procession from the second-story window of 711 Second Avenue on Saturday, reached in vain for a flower growing on the fire escape. Her dress, by which her mother held her, parted, and she fell to the pavement below, striking on her head.

Copyright, 1900, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Sept. 16. -- All last week our credit merchants were endeavoring to press the rates down, but they did not succeed. The banks refused to work for brokers under 3 1/2 per cent, in any instance, and some of the leading buyers of bills among them would not go below 3 9-16 per cent.

From The Rochester Union and Advertiser. But it is in the nomination for Governor that the bosses and their machine -- the "combine" -- suffered the most signal defeat, and ex-Gov. Hill, the leader of the honest Democracy of the State, achieved the greatest victory. Controller Coler of New York was the issue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A workingman would again raise his humble voice about prosperity and that philosophis address of Gov. Roosevelt's in Chicago on Labor Day, in which he told the laboring men how to bear the burden. Well, I think that was the slickest political speech this fine politician ever delivered. Gov. Roosevelt is out for votes, and all he said there was intended to gather votes.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Charles Brown, a patient in St. Barnabas's Hospital, eluded his attendant early this morning and jumped through a closed window on the first floor. He fell on the flagstones in the areaway, and the attendants rushed out, expecting to find torn badly injured. Instead, they saw him run along High Street toward Clinton Avenue, with the speed of a sprinter.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16. -- August Koch, who tried last year to purchase the Detroit League club, and Joseph O'Brien, who was a candidate for the Secretaryship of the American Association of Baseball Clubs, are on their way to Philadelphia for the purpose of making another effort to organize the association for next season.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The first step in the litigation involving the title to the estate of Freeholder James Carroll, which is estimated at $25,000, was taken yesterday when Sheriff Hopper served upon Mrs. Annie Carroll an injunction restraining the transfer or sale of certain tracts of land and buildings on Ramapo Avenue pending the determination of an action instituted in the Court of Chancery.

Mrs. Annie Bennett, colored, of 125 West Third Street, was found dead on the sidewalk in East Fourth Street last night with a severe cut over the right eye. Mrs. Susie Collins, a white woman, of 84 Cornelia Street, was locked up in the Mercer Street Station on suspicion of having caused the death of the woman.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Every-thing is ready for the football candidates to begin practice to-morrow and about thirty candidates are now here. It was learned to-night that Langdon Lea, head coach of last year's eleven, will be here this week to assist Capt. Pell in coaching the candidates before going on to the University of Michigan to direct the coaching there.

William Russell of 428 East Eighty-third Street, a driver for the Horton Ice Cream Company, was on his way up Lexington Avenue to his work at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning when he saw flames suddenly shoot out of the trolley slot on the avenue between One Hundred and Twenty-second and One Hundred and Twenty-third Streets.
VICTORIA, B.O., Sept 16. -- It is reported here that Japanese collieries have made a contract to supply the United States fleet at Manila with 60,000 tons of coal within a period of two months.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Cordang of Holland was the victor in the twenty-four hour international contest for the Gold Cup, which began at 6 P.M. yesterday at Vincennes. He covered 956 kilometers and 775 meters.
BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- Harvard's football prospects at the opening of the season tomorrow are by no means as bright as has been reported. Capt. C.D. Daly said to-night:

HAZLETON, Sept. 16. -- Officials of the United Mine Workers' Union to-night brought all their resources to bear upon the Markle men at Jeddo, Highland, Oakdale, and Elbervale to obey the strike order The union leaders want them to strike to-morrow, and a big meeting was held at Jeddo for the purpose of inducing them to do so.

HONOLULU, July 12. -- American globetrotters who return by way of the Pacific always remark favorably on the accommodations at Honolulu for ships. Docks and piers are generaly unknown at ports in this part of the world. Even Hongkong and Nagasaki do their large shipping business in midstream.

The steam yacht Niagara, belonging to Howard Gould, which reached New York on Saturday, lay all day yesterday, off Thirty-fourth Street, the owner and his wife remaining on board and receiving a few friends. The yacht will go to-day to Sand's Point, where the new home of Howard Gould is situated.

THE BULGARO-ROUMANIAN "INCIDENT" CLOSED.--It is believed in diplomatic circles in St. Petersburg that the trouble between Bulgaria and Roumania is practically over, although it is admitted that Roumania feels particularly sore over Russia's veiled intervention.

From The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier. The worst effects of the storm, naturally, are manifested in Galveston, because of the peculiarly exposed position of the city. Situated on a low island, "no part of which is more than six feet above sea level," with its houses built to the water's edge, "no city," as is truly noted, "could be in greater danger with such a storm as has just visited it."
From The Philadelphia North American. We are to have a strike in the anthracite coal region, not because the miners want it, but because the mine owners will do nothing to prevent it.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 16.--The strike situation remains very quiet in Schuylkill County. Only the Lehigh Company's colleries at Mahanoy City and Lost Creek will be affected by the strike order in the Schuylkill district.

The Trenton True American does not approve of our recent suggestion that Senator WELLINGTON, having repudiated the candidates of the party that elected him to the Senate, should resign and give the Democrats of Maryland a chance to have a Senator of their own party. It particularly objects to our remark that none but "a scurvy politician" would hold on to the place for the five-thousand-dollar annual compensation given to a Senator.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- John W. Warner, a lineman of the New York and New Jersey Telephone Company, had a narrow escape from death on the top of a high pole in Belleville yesterday afternoon, and is in a serious, condition at his home in this city.

From widely separates quarters of the world come two announcements that possess a melancholy interest for all who had cherished the hope that the effort to maintain republican government in South Africa would eventually amount to something more than nominal republicanism, and that the Dutch of those remote States would so direct all their efforts as to command the widest and warmest sympathy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You speak of several countries of South America, Asia, and Australasia in which there is coal for the mining, but you make no mention of India, the coal trade of which is constantly becoming more Important.
Senator Thomas G. Platt, who is confident of Republican success in the coming election, returned to his old quarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

The movement of prices in the stock market yesterday ran contrary to what most professional speculators expected. After the declines on Friday and Saturday, unmistakable signs of liquidation having appeared on those days, the weight of opinion inclined strongly to the belief that yesterday this liquidation would continue and a generally lower range of prices follow.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The order to strike was obeyed to the letter by the miners in the Lackawanna district to-day. Every colliery from Nanticoke to Forest City was suspended. Even the washeries were deserted by the regular employes, and while they were run for a few hours with hands picked up outside, work was suspended later.

-- From Copenhagen by way of St. Thomas there comes a rumor that negotiations between Denmark and the United States for the sale by the former to the latter of the Danish West Indies have not ceased, as had generally been supposed, but have instead entered upon a new and interesting phase.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The desire of China to begin negotiations for peace was shown to-day in a dispatch from Prince Ching, delivered by Minister Wu to the State Department. The dispatch was dated at Peking, Sept. 8, and in it Prince Ching states that he has been clothed with full authority, together with Li-Hung-Chang, to negotiate for peace.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Cyrus Field Adams, publisher of The Appeal, Chicago, and President of the National Afro-American Press Association, has received a letter from Galveston from W.H. Noble, Jr., publisher of The Times of that city, in which he appeals for help. The letter states that about 1,500 Afro-Americans lost their lives in the recent storm, and that fully 10.000 are homeless.
HAVANA, Sept. 17. -- The long-expected change in the personnel of the Associate Justices of the Audiencia came suddenly to-day.

Conventions to nominate candidates for the State Senate were held by the Republicans last night in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx. In the Tenth, Eleventh, Thirteenth, Sixteenth, Seventeenth, and Twentieth Districts adjournments were taken, and the probabilities are that no nominations will be made.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 17. -- The first really sensational testimony in the trial of James Howard, charged with having fired the shot that killed William Goebel, was given to-day by James Stubblefield, a former Deputy Sheriff of Clay County.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Sept. 17. -- President Samuel Gompers of the National Federation of Labor said before leaving here for Hazleton to-day that there is no doubt as to the final outcome of the strike being victory for the men, as the conditions were so extremely bad that any movement on their part would be advantageous.

"The rainfall of Saturday night and Sunday morning," said George W. Birdsall, Chief Engineer of the Department of Water Supply, yesterday, "added nothing to the resources of the Borough of the Bronx, and only slightly relieved the situation in Brooklyn. In the Bronx district, only .73 of an inch of rain fell.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17. -- The National Association of Baseball Clubs is being organized here to-day at the Hotel Rennert by A.H. Koch and F.C. Richter, representing Philadelphia; C.S. Havener and Joseph D. O'Brien, representing Chicago; Phil Peterson and Harry Goldman, representing Baltimore, and H.D. Quinn, representing Milwaukee.
"LOST OR STOLEN -- A picture of David B. Hill in frame 32 inches by 40 inches from Democratic State Headquarters. Finder please return to the St. James Building."

In legend and fable the approved way of laying a ghost has always been to right the wrong that made it walk. As soon as the injury done to the departed was redressed his ghost would gather his sheet about him and vanish. It is not in this way that the Republican hierarchy is proceeding with the twin ghosts of imperialism and militarism.
