Essex Market Court was thrown into a ferment this morning when City Marshal Max Cross of 153 Clinton Street, followed by several score of his friends, was draggred thither by a policeman and charged with inciting to riot. Alter the court officers secured quiet an explanation of the case was obtained by Magistrate Mayo.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 17. -- At a mass convention of Missouri Populists held here to-day resolutions were adopted indorsing the entire Democratic State ticket. The Populists estimate that their voting strength in Missouri is about 10,000.
The September meeting of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters will be held tomorrow.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Four Orange women -- Mrs. Halpren, Mrs. Goldstein, Mrs. Silverstein, and Mrs. Rosenfeldt -- appeared before Justice Bray in the police court this morning to ventilate a family dispute and to have him pass upon questions of Mosaic law. The first two women were the chief participants in the dispute and the other two were witnesses.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 17. -- One of the most delightful affairs of the season was the musicale and ball given this evening at the Kebo Valley Golf Club by Mrs. Alexander T. Van Nest of New York. The event marked the culmination of one of the most notable social seasons Bar Harbor has ever known.

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 17. -- A startling political coup is promised for Wednesday with the assembling of the Democratic, Populist, and Labor Party conventions in this city. It is nothing less than a bolt of the Democratic convention by the Daly faction, and the organization of a separate party.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Cornell football candidates reported to-day at Percy Field for the first practice of the season. About twenty-five men were on hand. All of last year's team who will be back this year reported except Alexander, who will arrive later. Capt. Starbuck, in falling on the bail, dislocated his shoulder, and it is doubtful if he will be able to play again for two or three weeks.
MONTREAL, Sept. 17. -- A large proportion of the shipping business which has heretofore gone by way of Montreal will in future be transferred to Boston.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Following are the instructions issued by President McKinley to the Philippine Commissioners last April:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- Wounds of various kinds about their favorite hunters sustained in Saturday's very stiff chase prevented several of Newport's most skillful and daring cross-country riders from taking part in to-day's hunt. Miss Greta Pomeroy's and Alfred G. Vanderbilt's horses are among these which are in the hands of veterinary surgeons, and consequently neither Miss Pomeroy nor Mr. Vanderbilt was among the hunters to-day, though they were out to see the chase.

GALVESTON, Sept. 17. -- The ninth day after the storm, and still the gruesome work goes on of recovering the dead from the gigantic mass of debris that lines the south side of what remains of the city.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- The great strike of mine workers in the anthracite coal fields of Pennsylvania, which represent practically the hard coal output of the world, began to-day.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 17. -- The Republican State Convention to-day gave Senator Wolcott, an opportunity to reply to the attacks of Gov. Thomas, which he did in the following language:

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- The Boston market was generally steady. Utah weakened 1/2, to 29 3/4, and Montana 2, to 309, later 310, but most of the mining stocks held well. Centennial Eureka rose from 18 1/2 to 19 1/2 and Isle Royale from 28 1/2 to 29. Gas and Coke sold up from 9 to 11, 5s rose 3 1/2 to 60 1/2, and Dominion Coal sold up 1 to 39 1/2.

The Seabreeze Selling Stakes, cheap and common in its promise, was the feature of the programme at the Gravesend racetrack yesterday. The card, at its best, was not particularly attractive, but the crowd in attendance was fully up to the average, and, as if put on its metal to prove that it was not a crowd of "regulars," the enthusiasm over each of the several head finishes of the day was far above the ordinary.
SAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 17. -- It was announced here to-day that Admiral George Dewey, Mrs. Dewey, and Miss McLean will arrive in Oakdale Wednesday. They will visit Rear Admiral Nicoll Ludlow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Coroner Birch to-night rendered a verdict in the Kensico railroad disaster, which occurred a few weeks ago. The verdict holds Frank Draper, the conductor, and George Donovan, the brakeman, of Train No. 90, which had halted in front of the station at Kensico, criminally responsible for the disaster.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17. -- An old four-story tenement building at 403 East Front Street, used as a branch nursery of the Salvation Army, was burned this evening. James Harkins, forty years old, and two of his children, whom he was trying to rescue, were burned, to death, as wall as two other children.

From The New Orleans Times-Democrat. "How in the world the gunners on our big battleships ever manage to land a shell within a mile of the thing they are shooting at has been a mystery to me ever since I saw a piece of heavy ordnance actually turned loose," said a man from California.

It is perfectly evident that the reading of Attorney General DAVIES'S letter to Prof. DUNCAN CAMPBELL LEE about the Ice Trust resolution proposed by the latter to the Democratic State Convention excited unpleasant reflections in the mind of RICHARD CROKER. There does not appear to have been any other incident to account for Mr. CROKER'S amazing volubility to the reporters on the Ice Trust question.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial tribute to the useful yet modest life of that valuable public servant, William Saunders, of the United States Department of Agriculture, will gratify those who knew and appreciated his strong character, his skill and patience in the cultivation of plants and flowers, and the beauty he gave to the streets and parks of Washington.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 17. -- Every mine in the Wyoming Valley, with the exception of one, was closed to-day by the miners' strike. The exception was the colliery operated by the West End Coal Company at Mocanaqua. The men there refused to go out, saying they were satisfied with the present condition of things.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Census Bureau announces that the population of Augusta, Ga., is 39,441, as against 33,300 in 1890, an increase of 6,141, or 18.44 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The following telegram was received at the State Department to-day from Senator Morgan:
CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- William J. Bryan's letter accepting the Democratic nomination for President was given out to-day and is as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Harvard's first football practice of the season began this afternoon at 3:30, when Capt. Charles O. Daly headed a procession of forty-two sturdy athletes from the Locker Building to the temporary gridiron on Soldiers' Field. Of last year's eleven, there were present Hallowell and Campbell, ends; Gierasch and Sawin, half backs; Ellis, full back, and Daly, quarter.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--General Manager C.E. Henderson of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company stated this afternoon that thirty-eight of the thirty-nine collieries operated by that company were working to-day.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 17. -- Father Duecy of New York arrived here on the late train to-night rather unexpectedly. Upon his arrival he called at strike head-quarters, but after a few minutes returned to his hotel.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration:

An examination into the record of Policeman William A. Spolasco, charged by "Belle Fitzgerald" "With offering to secure her release for $2,000, showed that once before he had been tried on a similar charge. This was on July 2, 1888, when he was tried by Commissioner McClave for offering to suppress for $5 a complaint made against a citizen.

Two weeks ago it was announced that the box office of the Metropolitan Opera House would be opened Sept. 17 for the sale of seats for the English opera season, which begins Oct. 1. The numerous requests to reserve seats and various other questions which were asked the managers led them to believe that a greater interest was being taken in the approaching season than the interest manifested last year.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 17. -- Charles Akey, beed twenty-three, is locked up at the police station charged with being a deserter from the United States Army in Manila. He does not deny his guilt, but blames his downfall to native bengo.

From The London Express. Well known in England as New Zealand's energetic Agent General, the Hon. W.P. Reeves is better known in his own country as the man by whose agency New Zealand has become "a country without strikes." From 1891 to 1896 Mr. Reeves, while Minister of Education and of Labor, bent his energies to the passing of industrial arbitration legislation.
MADRID, Sept. 17. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 80.00. Gold was quoted at 29.00.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Not caring for an elaborate wedding ceremony. Miss Jeannette Cecil of Summit and John Randolph Giles of East Orange were quietly married here a few days ago. Their marriage was a surprise to their families and friends. Mrs. Giles is a daughter of Mrs. George W. Cecil, and is a favorite in society.
Richard Croker and David B. Hill got under the same roof -- that of the Hoffman House -- yesterday, and that was as near as they came to getting together on politics.

When the news of the disaster at Galveston was made known we commented that the community was in need of aid beyond the provision of supplies and money. The tremendous shock to the energies and spirit of the people was not to be overcome by the simple process of giving money to provide for the suffering and the homeless.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The grear struggle between the anthracite coal miners of Pennsylvania and their employers was begun to-day. Each side is confident of winning, and neither of the contending forces shows any disposition to yield.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Not caring for an elaborate wedding ceremony. Miss Jeannette Cecil of Summit and John Randolph Giles of East Orange were quietly married here a few days ago. Their marriage was a surprise to their families and friends. Mrs. Giles is a daughter of Mrs. George W. Cecil, and is a favorite in society.
Richard Croker and David B. Hill got under the same roof -- that of the Hoffman House -- yesterday, and that was as near as they came to getting together on politics.

"New York should give at least $2,000,000 to the suffering people of Galveston and the other towns of Texas which were swept by the storm of a little over a week ago," said one of the members of the Relief Committee of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Eighteen of the best women golfers in Lenox this morning started off in the tournament for a handsome sliver cup presented by George Winthrop Folsom. The following eight qualified in a round of eighteen hotel, medal play:

As the Sixty-ninth Regiment Band played his favorite air, "Then You'll Remember Me," from "The Bohemian Girl," on the recreation pier at East Twenty-fourth Street last night, Ferdinand Hoch, thirty-eight years old, a homeless man, jumped off the pier into the water, thirty feet below, in an attempt to drown himself.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Twenty-four men out of twenty-five who had been ordered to appear here to-day, were on hand this afternoon, when Capt. Gordon Brown took his team for the first day's practice of the season at the Yale Field. Mike Murphy, Yale's old trainer, was on hand for the first day of the new year.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 17. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived here at 8 o'clock this evening and addressed two meetings, one at the Auditorium and the other at the Opera House. In his speech at the Auditorium Gov. Roosewelt talked on militarism, ridiculing the attitude of Mr. Bryan. He spoke in part as follows:

With "imperialism" and "militarism" expressly omitted from Mr. BRYAN'S letter of acceptance, because they were included in his speech of acceptance, it should seem that there was nothing left for him to talk about but sixteen to one. He does talk about that, partly because he cannot help it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- A mixed double tennis tournament which began at the Newport Casino this morning has created considerable interest among the tennis players and cottagers generally. Through the generosity of Col. John Jacob Astor two handsome prizes are offered, a silver cup for the lady winner and a gold match safe for the gentleman making the best score.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 18 -- Trouble is brewing to-night in the Lykens Valley region between the union and non-union anthracite miners over the refusal of the men at Williamstown to join the strike. The mine employes in the neighboring towns of Lykens and Wiconisco are on strike, and threaten to compel the Williamstown men to quit work.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 -- A number of sporting events were on the card for decision at the Suffolk County Fair grounds to-day. Besides the usual fair attractions athletic contests and harness races were on the programme for decision. The summaries:

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Sept. 18 -- Mr. Bryan made two speeches here to-day. The first assembly was held in the public square, the crowd being so great that it was impossible to conduct the meeting in the hall where it was intended to hold it. The attendance at the second meeting, which was held in the park, was even greater.

After a hard fight a resolution was passed by the Board of Aldermen yesterday authorizing the Controller to issue bonds to the amount of $267,800 to pay for the laying of a forty-eight-inch water main from the Croton Aqueduct, near Gun Hill Road, through Mosholu Parkway and Bronx Park to the Southern Boulevard, and in the Southern Boulevard to One Hundred and Seventy-third Street, Borough of the Bronx.
Vice President Thorne of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, who left New York late yesterday for the scene of the strike, made this statement:

WAVERLY, Iowa, Sept. 18 -- David B. Henderson, Speaker of the National House of Representatives, delivered a political address to a large and enthusiastic audience here to-night. Speaker Henderson said in part:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The leader of the strike says at the end of the second day that 118,000 of the 141,000 mine workers in the anthracite coal fields are idle. No representative of the mine operators makes a statement for their side, but individual mine owners dispute the strikers' figures, saying there are more men at work than the union leaders will admit.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Senator Hanna entertained twenty-five leading business men of Chicago at luncheon at the Union League Club yesterday, after which he made a short speech.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The Yale team went through an hour and a half of practice this afternoon. George B. Cutten, the well-known Yale centre, coached the men, and with Capt. Brown put them through some sharp work. Hyde and Sharpe punted to the field the first part of the afternoon, and later Coach Cutten lined an eleven up for practicing starts and centre quarter back passings.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The Duke of Manchester has concluded that it is useless to attempt to compound with his creditors and has signed his consent to be adjudicated a bankrupt. In his statement to the court the Duke says the family estates, of which he is a life tenant, are so heavily incumbered that the receipts only suffice to pay the interest.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Commodore Joseph W. Hancox died at the Coleman House last night at the age of eighty-eight years.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 18 -- There was a hitch in the Republican harmony plans to-day. The Union Republican (Addicks) State Committee, at a meeting called to ratify the compromise State ticket selected by the Republican State Committee on Friday last, refused to accept Dr. L. Heisler Ball as candidate for Congress.

The Charter Revision Commission will hold its first meeting since the Summer vacation on the first Monday in October. At that meeting it is hoped that the sub-committees which have been at work during the Summer will be ready to report to the full commission, although it was said last night that one or two, if not more, of these committees will not be prepared at that time to submit their reports.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Senator M.A. Hanna at noon to-day made an address to several thousand down-town business men and their employes at the rooms of the Commercial McKinley Club. He said in part:

"It wasn't entirely surprising that Cornelius Vanderbilt refused to be drawn into accepting a political nomination this year," remarked the veteran politician, after he had removed his cigar from his mouth and began rummaging among Luther Little's pile of country exchanges at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.
CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 18 -- The Pennsylvania State League of Republican Clubs has telegraphed greetings to the President, which were acknowledged by telegraph. The messages follow:

Mr. ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT'S fellow-citizens will not, we suppose, take too seriously his eulogy upon the government of this municipality published in these columns the other day. For they have long been aware that his general excellence as a citizen was only equaled, if it was not somewhat impaired, by his fondness for paradox.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--Following is the weekly summary of crop conditions issued by the Weather Bureau:...

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 18 -- Conditions in the Lackawanna district to-day were practically the same as yesterday. Not a pound of coal is being mined, and the number of culm washeries at work remains unchanged.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- An attempt to execute a selling order in Fitchburg preferred in lack of bids was given as the cause of a decline in the price from 138 to 135 1/2. The next transaction, at the same price, was marked "ex dividend" on the tape. The dividend is 1 1/4 per cent., reducing the decline to 1 1/4.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 18 -- The work of clearing the streets of debris is progressing rapidly under the perfect organization instituted by military rule under Adjt. Scorry. Over 2,000 men are engaged on the work. Ninety-eight bodies are reported as having been found in the wreckage and removed to-day, making a total of 1,861 victims so far recovered.

-- A writer possessed, apparently, of some little astronomical knowledge, but the reverse of adroit in giving his knowledge expression, contributes to The St. Louis Republic an article in which he criticises the Weather Bureau with great severity because it failed to add to its announcements of the approach of the Galveston storm a special warning, based on the position of the moon in its orbit.

Conditions to the market for outside securities yesterday indicated no improvement over the previous day. Trading was on an even smaller scale than on Monday, and, barring General Carriage and two or three other stocks, transactions were limited to a few hundred shares. Very few orders from the public reach the market, and traders show very little disposition to commit themselves to either side of the account.

The statements of the two parties to the coal strike are Quite irreconcilable. If 100,000 miners are "out," as Mr. MITCHELL declares, then it is statistically impossible that 60 per cent, of the miners can be at work, as the representatives of the operators assert. Whereabouts, between these two extremes, the truth may lie, is a question which nobody can answer who is willing to answer it.

A serious problem as to the tax rate for 1900 is now facing the city officials. The question is whether the tax rate went into effect on Aug 25 at 11:10 o'clock A.M., When Mayor Van Wyck signed the tax rolls, or will go into effect to-day, when President Guggenheimer of the Municipal Council affixes his signature to a document at noon.

Detective Shafer of the Harbor Police and six patrolmen and Chief Detective O'Brien of the Lehigh Valley police and four of his men had an exciting time with river pirates at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the Kills, opposite Fishkill Creek. After a battle which extended over a dozen coal barges, and a running fusillade of pistol shots, they succeeded in capturing four of the pirates.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- The question of revision of the Westminster Confession was discussed at length by the Presbytery of New Brunswick at its quarterly meeting, held at Dayton, ten miles from this city, to-day. The attendance at the session was unusually large, it being expected that definite action would be taken upon the matter.

Pittsburg won yesterday's baseball game from New York at the Polo Grounds by hitting the ball at the proper time, while the New Yorks were unable to bat at critical stages. Hawley was hit safely sixteen times. Waddeli pitched excellent ball. The score:

The quarterly conference of Presidents of Western railroads was held yesterday in the Board Room of the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway. Although none of the important questions which were considered by the conference were definitely disposed of, steps were taken which it is believed will insure a speedy settlement.

The Rev. Henry J. Guller. The Rev. Henry J. Guller, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Flatbush, Brooklyn, died yesterday morning at his home, 227 Lenox Road. Death was due to pneumonia. Mr. Guller was called to the pastorate in August, 1893, upon his graduation from the Theological Department of Colgate University at Hamilton, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Formal manifestations of sympathy with the people of Galveston in their great affliction continue to come from all parts of the world. In addition to those already received, such expressions have come from the President of Chile, the Spanish Minister, the Belgian Minister, the Mexican Minister, the Peruvian Minister, and the Haitian Minister.

Richard Croker's ire was aroused last evening. The object of his wrath was Thomas C. Platt. The Tammany leader talked as if Senator Platt was his bitterest enemy. He denounced Mr. Platt as "an old liar," and he branded the Republican State leader as a man who levied blackmail or corporations to raise campaign funds for the Republican Party.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 18 -- The Republican County Convention was called to order shortly after noon to-day in Apollo Hall, in this city, and is still in session at midnigrht. The convention is dead-locked over the nomination for Sheriff. The convention was called to order by John L. Conklin, the Chairman of the County Committee.
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold to a Mrs. Pardo for investment, at $24,500, the five-story tenement 55 West Fortyeighth Street, 25 by 85 by 100.

"It is either a beach of gold two hundred miles long, the greatest placer gold field in the world, or the greatest disappointment of modern times." This was the statement of an officer of the Government who returned from Cape Nome about a year ago with tidings of what was then believed to be a discovery even more important than that of the finding of gold in California.

The United States transport McPherson, which is being loaded by the Citizens' Relief Committee of the Merchants' Association with miscellaneous supplies aggregating over $120,000 in value for the sufferers in Galveston and Eastern Texas, is scheduled to sail at daylight to-day. The Army Department was advised yesterday morning that the loading could not be finished before night.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 -- The Wheeler Transportation Line, embracing the three steamers Easton, Minnie Wheeler, and Chesapeake, with all the real estate and leasehold property of the company, has been sold to a syndicate of New York and Philadelphia men. The sum involved in the deal is $140,000.

The alleged meddling of spirits from another world in financial affairs of this is made the basis of an answer in a lawsuit now pending in the Supreme Court, involving $20,000, brought against Mrs. Alicia V. La Bau of 144 Riverside Drive, by Arthur P. Dodge, inventor of the Dodge motor, and President of the Kinetic Power Company of Wilmington, Del.

Wall Street quotations fail to reflect any phase of the big coal strike. Many speculators sold stocks short in free and easy fashion preliminary to the strike's declaration, making no concealment of their expectation that market values must fall to pieces the moment the strike started.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Census Bureau announces that the population of Montgomery, Ala., is 30,346, as against 21,883 in 1890, an increase of 8,463. or 38.67 per cent.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Money was in good demand to-day, and there, was a fair supply. It is feared it will be needful to send gold to Germany in connection with the new German loan now being placed in the United States. Discounts were firm. The financial and banking houses are acting cautiously, especially in view of the approaching general election.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The Foreign Office has sent a circular note to all the powers announcing that the German Government considers that an indispensable preliminary to the beginning of peace negotiations with China is the delivering up of those who were responsible for the outrages.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Sept. 18 -- At the forty-sixth annual conference of the West Wisconsin District of the Methodist Church, which closed to-day at Viroqua, Wis., the ministers and delegates from the entire district adopted a resolution denouncing in severe terms the existence of trusts in this country.

A resolution was introduced in the Board of Aldermen yesterday which the politicians claim is the first of a series of attacks by Richard Croker and Tammany Hall against the so-called Whitney-Brady traction interests.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 18.--The second day of the anthracite coal strike has failed to bring forth anything that would lead to the coming together of the coal operators and the striking mine workers. Neither side has approached the other, and as far as could be learned to-night, there is no such move contemplated by either operators or their employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Col. William S. Patten of the Quartermaster's Department has completed arrangements for the free transportation to the United States of the bodies of the soldiers and sailors and civilians who lost their lives and were buried in the Philippines and in China. According to the present plans, a burial corps will take passage on the transport Hancock, scheduled to leave San Francisco on the 1st prox. for the Philippines.

Stephen Hayt, a Brooklyn merchant, is confined in jail at Waterloo, N.Y., awaiting examination on a charge of bigamy. He was arrested in his apartments at 733 Be Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, on Saturday on a warrant issued by a Magistrate at Seneca Falls. N.Y.
BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- Seventy-two new coal mines have been opened in Prussia this year, increasing the output for 1900 by 2,500,000 tons.
Our neighbor The Sun declares that it would rather see "the Philippines abandoned and expansion lost than see free silver triumph."

HAVANA, Sept. 18 -- The results of the elections of delegates to the forthcoming Constitutional Convention are being freely discussed by the Havana delegates and other prominent Cubans. The conclusion reached is that the convention will be controlled by the revolutionary element. Alfredo Zayas, Nationalist delegate, said to-day:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Although it is officially stated that Mr. McKinley's sudden visit to Washington, where he will arrive to-morrow, is not caused by any startling developments in the China situation, it is understood that his return is due to the present unsatisfactory state of affairs. In short, the President is coming to Washington to see if he can straighten out the Chinese muddle.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 18. -- The initial day's celebration of the presentation of commemorative tablets to the Kearsarge and Alabama, although ushered in by gloom and storm, nevertheless proved a great success through the fortunate clearing of the weather, and to-night the two bronze tablets are in the custody of the commanding officers of the great battleships.

David B. Hill left town last evening. He was invited to attend the meeting of the State Executive Committee to be held this evening, and there meet Richard Croker. who is a member of the same body. Mr. Croker also offered to talk with and shake hands with Mr. Hill if the latter was willing to do so.
Albert C. Bostwick won two races yesterday in the automobile speed tests on the old racetrack at Guttenberg, N.J., establishing at the same time new five and ten mile records.

The free and unlimited coinage of silver at the ratio of 10 to 1 independent of all other nations is now advocated by W.J. BRYAN in his letter of acceptance, as it was advocated by him in 1896. He does not dodge the issue or call free silver coinage by any other name. He stands on his Kansas City and the Chicago platform.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 -- Mayor Hayes and the reorganized Board of School Commissioners of Baltimore under the new city charter have placed themselves and James H. Van Sickle, the new Superintendent of Education, in a peculiar predicament. Judge Stockbridge to-day sustained the contention raised that Van Sickle is disqualified for appointment under the provision of the new charter that municipal officials must be legal residents and qualified voters of this city.
PITTSBURG, Kan., Sept. 18 -- While Mr. Bryan was speaking here last night about trusts, some one in the crowd shouted an inquiry about the New York Ice Trust.

More than 175 women of Weehawken Township, N.J., enjoyed themselves hugely yesterday playing politics and casting votes. The voting had nothing to do with the Presidential campaign, the question was simply one of a $70,000 appropriation for a new school house, but they did not mind the difference, it was voting.

The Stock Exchange banking and brokerage firm of Hatch Foote, at 3 Nassau Street, which was formed in 1867, failed yesterday with liabilities of about $2,000,000. After an announcement from the rostrum of the New York Stock Exchange of the firm's suspension, a general assignment was made to E. Ellery Anderson, the firm's counsel.

New York City consumes about 50,000 tons a coal a day under normal conditions at this season of the year. The amount landed in New York daily since the strike commenced will average about 10,000 tons. These figures were furnished by J. Samuel Smoot, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Retail Coal Dealers' Exchange, and are his explanation of the scarcity and increase in price.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 18 -- In response to requests on the part of many newspapers for his views regarding the strike situation, the Rev. Father Phillips of St. Gabriel's Church, who has been a prominent factor in the strike, to-night gave out the following authorized statement:
The amount raised in this city for the Galveston sufferers is not up to the expectations of the business men who are actively engaged in looking after the relief of the people of the Southern city.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- According to The Dally Mail's St. Petersburg correspondent Russia will claim an indemnity of L100,000,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--Senator Hanna, encouraged by the reception given to his speech yesterday at the Commercial McKinley Club, has about decided to go upon the stump during the last two weeks of the campaign.

Sandwiched in between boxing exhibitions, trapeze performances, slack-wire walking, capers by "educated" dogs, a balloon ascension, and other happenings incidental to such an occasion were a series of harness races at the Guttenberg track yesterday afternoon. Of the 6,000 persons present on the second day of the Tri-State Fair, most seemed to regard the harness horses the chief attraction.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 19 -- While Mr. Bryan was speaking here to-day his attention was called to the speech made at Delphi, Ind., by Senator Hanna, the Chairman of the Republican National Committee, in which the Senator was quoted as saying he was ready to debate "imperialism" with Mr. Bryan or any other Democrat.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 19 -- The meeting this afternoon at Jeddo of the employes of G.B. Markle Co. who operate the Jeddo, Ebervale, Highland, and Oakdale collieries, proved to be probably the most remarkable gathering of its kind ever held in the anthracite regions. It was expected to be a talk between John Markle, managing partner of the firm, and his employes, who number 2,500, but it developed into a joint debate.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Some of the copper stocks were strong to-day under the lead of Tamarack, which was bid up from 220 to 239 by a house heretofore prominent in "combine" activities. One per cent, was bid to call 1,000 shares at 300 for sixty days. Tamarack closed at 236, a recession of 3 from the highest, but a net rise of 16 for the day.

WINNEMUCCA, Nev., Sept. 19 -- The First National Bank was robbed of about $13,000 at noon to-day by three men, who entered the front door of the building, and with revolvers made all present throw up their hands.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 19 -- The sixth annual convention of the National Municipal League opened here to-day with about 100 delegates present. In the absence of President James C. Carter of New York First Vice President Charles Richardson of Philadelphia presided. This convention is the starting point of active work in the adoption of the so-called municipal programme adopted at the Columbus convention last year.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 19 -- Of the 27,000 men employed at the Reading Company's colleries, it is stated here to-night most positively that not more than 8,000 have struck. By working the miners who have not struck as many hours as possible the output of anthracite has been kept up to the average under normal conditions: About 1,400 cars of hard coal passed down the Reading Road to-day, and much more will be moved to-night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Some interest attached to the market this morning by reason of the action of Union Traction. The preferred stock opened at 50 1/2, and, after selling to 50 3/4, broke to 49 at the close. The common opened at 12 and closed at 11 1/2, the lowest point. Metropolitan Elevated preferred closed at 82, half a point under the opening. Other securities stood at I he usual figures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Germany's proposal to the powers that the punishment of those responsible for the recent outrages in China be made a preliminary condition of peace negotiations will not, it is understood, be accepted by the United States.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Holbrook Mann, son of the Rev. Charles H. Mann of Orange, who was severely Injured on Tuesday, Aug. 7, by diving off a float into shallow water at the Summer residence of the Manns, at Balley's Island, Me., is now at his father's home. The young man made the journey comfortably, and is resting easily.

An attractive programme and the promise of good class sport drew a large attendance to the Gravesend race track yesterday. The weather was a trifle chilly, but the track remained fast, and that, with well-balanced fields, made the racing quite as interesting as the card promised, though the results were somewhat topsy-turvy.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- At the Vaudeville Theatre this evening Charles Frohman and A. S. Gatti produced a new farcical comedy by Pierre Decourcelles, entitled "Self and Lady," which proved a great success.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- After receiving the contents of a shotgun in his chest, Thomas Doyle boarded a trolley car, rode some distance, and then walked from Irvington to this city, six miles. He was found in a semi-conscious condition yesterday morning on the steps of the Fireman's Insurance Company's building, and is now in the City Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Minister WuTing-Fang was greatly interested to-day in the German note to the powers. When seen at the Chinese Legation he said:

For a long time "The Three Musketeers" have exercised all the functions of sovereignty over the little principality on Thirty-third Street bounded by Sixth and Seventh Avenues. Whenever rations were short at the sign of the three a sudden sally upon innocent wanderers into the principality filled up the larder.

After a terrific fight with the Galveston hurricane, the steamship Hyades, badly battered, and with several of her crew injured, reached Dow's Stores, Brooklyn, yesterday. She is the first ship which went through the territle Gulf storm to reach this port. Much of the ship's cargo of 389,000 bushels of wheat, which is consigned to the Tweedie Trading Company, was damaged by water, which found its way through the hatches.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 19 -- Atlanta Camp No. 159, United Confederate Veterans, at its last meeing adopted a resolution couched in strong language, taking exceptions to a resolution passed at the recent encampment at Chicago of the Grand Army of the Republic relative to Southern school histories.

-- Havana had forty-nine deaths from yellow fever in the month of August, and efforts have been made to deduce from this fact the conclusion that the sanitary effects of American rule do not amount to much after all.

The phrase that will properly describe a thoroughly up-to-date retail store has not yet appeared. The department store pitches its stuffs into a common hopper for general distribution. In contrast to this, a complete book store, china store, shoe store, and all the rest, each entire in its technique and unique in its merchandise treatment, are united in a federation of stores.

The Democratic State leaders gathered in force at State Headquarters in the St. James Building last evening. A conference lasting over three hours was held. The Croker-Murphy factionists and the followers of David B. Hill fraternized and talked about carrying New York for the State and Natipnal ticket as if no difference had arisen between the leaders for years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- On Aug. 17 Secretary Root cabled the Philippine Commission for a report of its operations to date. Portions of the reply, cabled on Aug. 21, were incorporated by President McKinley in his letter of acceptance of the renomination for President. Following is the text of Secretary Root's dispatch and the commission's reply:
BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The United States Embassy in Berlin has sent $500 to the Salveston relief fund, Prof. Earth being the only German who contributed.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 19 -- The third day of the strike passed off as quietly as the two preceding days. Beyond the occasional stoning of a mine worker going to or from his work, there has been no disorder.

The season of county fairs, always events in the suburbs, are beginning. Horse shows are taking the place of the simonpure old county lair in many places, but in the more retired districts the old fair, with its exhibition of fruits and vegetables, of domestic knitting, quilting, decoration, and painting, its side shows, and its trotting matches, still holds its place.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 19 -- The tie-up of the mines has caused the laying off of almost every coal train crew in this region, and whatever coal is being moved is going out in the freight trains. Only three Delaware and Hudson coal trains went north yesterday and three crews were marked out for to-day, but one of these was employed in dumping ashes for the road bed.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 19 -- The expected clash between the union and nonunion miners in the Lykens Valley region was averted by the strikers at Lykens abandoning their proposed march to Williamstown to-night to attempt to force the miners there to quit work.

NEWPORT, Sept. 19 -- The cottagers' lawn tennis tournament was continued at the Casino this morning, though only one match was played. This was between Mrs. John Jacob Astor and Cyril Hatch and Miss Emily Hoffman and Stuyvesant Leroy. The summary:

In a letter to Christian Work, which will appear in its issue of Sept. 27, the Rev. Dr. J. Milton Greene calls attention to what he terms the mockery of justice in Porto Rico. His letter shows a remarkable state of affairs, and is, in part, as follows:

Members of the Charter Revision Commission who have been requested to make public the result of their labors declined to talk about the matter yesterday, on the ground that they are bound by law to make a report to Gov. Roosevelt, and that they would be lacking in courtesy if they discussed the probable shape of the report before it had been sent to the Chief Executive.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Sept. 19 -- Capt. William Wilds and William Russell, a negro, were run over by a train here this morning and instantly killed. Capt. Wilds was a prominent Confederate veteran, for many years Tax Collector of this county, and at one time Postmaster.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, Sept. 19 -- The plant of El Diario, organ of the Federal Party, was completely destroyed by a mob last night. The type and presses were smashed. The supposed causes of the disturbance were articles attacking Mayor Egozcuo, who is a Republican. No arrests were made.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 19 -- Mr. Bryan concluded his present tour with a speech here, departing to-night for his home in Lincoln, from which he has been absent since Aug. 29. Before leaving he was tendered a public dinner at the Donovan house and introduced to many of the residents of the city.

We raise this question in order to answer it unreservedly and emphatically in the negative, and to give our reasons for that conclusion. The charge that Mr. STANCHFIELD is "CHOKER'S candidate" has been made by several correspondents of THE TIMES. It is made again in the following letter from an esteemed reader and friend of this newspaper:

From The Utica Observer. The public record of Jonn B. Stanchfield on labor questions is one which organized labor examines with satisfaction. But in the Democratic State Convention at Saratoga, in the heat of debate, there was a vague accusation, not distinct enough to invite answer, and there are whisperings growing out of it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- To-day for the first time in recent years morning practice was instituted by the Yale team. Capt. Brown took his men out for an hour's hard work and drilled them two hours again this afternoon. Slocovitch of Columbia was here this afternoon, but was an onlooker simply.

The publication yesterday of the legal notice of the partition sale of the property in this city belonging to the estate of Bradish Johnson disclosed the fact that the referee is ex-Surrogate James M. Varnum, while the auctioneer named to conduct the sale is William M. Ryan. This sale will include thirty-seven parcels of Manhattan and Bronx realty, which have been appraised at over $4,000,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 19 -- The largest number of players Harvard has had on the third day of football practice for years greeted Capt. Daly yesterday and were introduced to Trainer McMaster's tackling dummy. At the south side of the field, near the bleachers, Head Coach Dibblee and Trainer "Jack" McMasters initiated squads of twenty men into the mysteries of tackling hard and low.

NEWARK, N.J. Sept. 19 -- A meeting participated in by about 150 members of St. Peter's German Catholic Church was held last night to devise means for obtaining an accounting of the receipts and expenditures of the church. St. Peter's Church was organized about forty-seven years ago.

The investigation conducted by President York of the Police Board into the charges of brutality made against the police during the late race riots on the west side was continued yesterday afternoon in the courtroom at Police Headquarters. When the session began Lawyer Israel Ludlow, representing the various negro complainants who have begun damage suits against the city, protested because his clients had been subpoenaed, saying that the first witness of the day.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 19 -- Today was uneventful in the Wyoming Valley. The strikers kept away from the works, and there was no disorder of any kind.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 19. -- Normal conditions are fast being restored in Galveston. The work of clearing the streets of debris continues unabated, and all relief work is now thoroughly systematized. Several human bodies were found to-day. No attempt was made to identify them, and they were immediately cremated.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- General Manager Williams of the Susquehanna Coal Company and the Lykens Valley Coal Company, controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad, was summoned to this city to-day to confer with President Isaac J. Wistar of the coal, companies regarding the situation at the nine collieries operated by the two companies.

The St. Louis Baseball Club's share of the gate receipts at Washington Park, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, were attached by Deputy Sheriff O'Donnell, upon an order issued by Justice D. Cady Herrick of the Supreme Court, to Gus Weyhing, one of the pitchers of the Brooklyn team. Weyhing was released by the St. Louis club on July 26.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Swept by a northeast wind, blowing at the rate of thirty miles an hour, a fire which started early yesterday morning in Spring Lake, destroyed three hotels, including the lion-mouth House, eight cottages, and eight stores. The property loss, estimated at $350,000, will be swelled considerably when the value of personal effects destroyed is computed by the owners.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- It is understood that the immediate cause for issuing Germany's circular note to the powers regarding the Chinese settlement was the fact that Li-Hung-Chang, during his recent interview with Dr. Mumm von Schwartzenstein, the German Minister to China, mentioned a number of names of alleged high mandarins, hitherto wholly unknown, as those responsible for the Peking outrages and said that China was willing to punish them.

Although it was decided by the local coal dealers of Brooklyn at a meeting on Saturday night to fix the price of coal at $5.75 per ton delivered, inquiry yesterday afternoon developed the fact that many of the dealers are already charging as high as $6.50 and $7 a ton. Several of the dealers said that there was a prospect of the price going still higher.

Manager Heinrich Conried of the Irving Place Theatre has decided to open his season at the above house on Saturday evening, Sept. 20, and for the opening attractions a double bill will be given, consisting of a one-act comedy entitled "Die Sittliche Forderung," and a comedy by Skowronnek called "Der Tugenhof," which was among the few pieces which proved successful throughout Germany and Austria last season.

It was announced yesterday that Maurice L. Muhleman, Deputy Assistant Treasurer of the United States in this city, will shortly become President of the Federal National Bank, whose organization was approved by the Controller of the Currency several weeks ago.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Cornell football candidates have begun to get down to hard work. Coach Houghton gave them extended practice at tackling the dummy to-day. In addition, they were lined up for break-through practice, and considerable time was devoted to catching punts. Longer runs are taken than at this time last year.
MANILA, Sept. 19.--During the last seven days there has been a distinct increase of insurgent aggression, particularly near Manila,...
PORT SAID, Sept. 19.--The British steamer Lorle, Capt. Graham, from Philadelphia Aug. 22, via Algiers Sept. 11, has arrived here with the first importation ou American coal.

John B. Stanchfield, Democratic nominee for Governor, arrived in New York yesterday from Elmira to make arrangements for the State campaign. He was at the Hoffman House early yesterday morning with Senator William F. Mackey of Buffalo, nominee for Lieutenant Governor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19 -- The formal opening of Princeton University was held in Marquand Chapel this afternoon at 3 o'clock. President Patton, in greeting the students, congratulated the freshman class upon its being the largest that ever entered the university. He spoke of the recent massacres in China, with particular reference to the report of the massacre of the Rev. Cortlandt Van Rensselaer Hodge and wife.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 19 -- The operators in this section do not take kindly to the arbitration idea. Superintendent Lathrop of the Lehigh Valley Company says:
Dr. Hunter Holmes McGuire. Dr. Hunter Holmes McGuire died at his country home near Richmond, Va., yesterday from the effects of a stroke of paralysis suffered several months ago.

The examination by Assignee E. Ellery Anderson of the books of the banking and brokerage house of Hatch Foote, which, failed on Tuesday, with approximate liabilities of $2,000,000, has progressed sufficiently to show that part of the speculations of Charles B. Foote, which ruined the firm, were charged by him on the firm's books against his brother-in-law, Thomas Hastings.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- The camera in politics is the latest protective move of the Republicans here. Dr. R.X. Giering has organized a kodak force during registration days for the benefit of his party, and already there are loud protests from Democratic workers.

Harry Allen Ely, until recently First Lieutenant of Company G, of the Forty-sixth Regiment United States Volunteers, who returned on the transport Sherman several weeks ago, gave it as his opinion in an interview yesterday that the continuance of the insurrection in the Philippines was due almost wholly to the support that the Filipinos have been receiving from prominent persons in the United States.

Wall Street is hearing much "bad news." Strike developments and possibilities, disquieting political bulletins, reports of enforced liquidation -- such is the daily record just now. Some effect finally shows in the stock market. That, of course, is precisely what is aimed at -- precisely the reason why much of the stuff is invented.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 20 -- Lieut. C.G. Calkins, formerly navigation officer of the cruiser Olympia, Admiral Dewey's flagship, and now hydrographic officer at this port, speaking of the Hobson interview, said:

Those members of the gay world who have come into town during the past few days find the city, and especially the uptown streets and avenues in the fashionable districts, full of almost new interest. The crowded shops, restaurants, streets, and hotels have an almost novel attraction for people who have spent the long, hot Summer at the further resorts, and even in the suburbs.

CLINTON, Iowa, Sept 20 -- The Republican State and National campaign in Iowa was opened to-night at Davis Opera House by Senator William B. Allison, who was introduced by ex-Congressman George M. Curtis, and addressed nearly 2,000 persons. His speech in part was as follows:

Congressman J.W. Babcock of Wisconsin, Chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, who is in the city, while confident of the re-election of President McKinley, is not altogether sanguine that the political complexion of the next House of Representatives will satisfy the Republicans.

The racegoers who make a business of being in attendance every day, rain or shine, had yesterday's sport on the Gravesend track practically to themselves, the occasional patron of horse racing being but mildly in evidence. The crowd was about the average, however, in spite of gloomy weather.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage "plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Well knowing that the independents of New York State would be compelled by a sense of duty to support McKinley, there can be little doubt that "Boss" Platt, in naming his State ticket, did, with malice aforethought, intend to give them an incidental enforced repast of boiled crow, such as none can enjoy, and which revolts not a few, including the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
No increase was made yesterday in the Galveston relief funds being raised by the Stock, Produce, Cotton, and Mercantile Exchanges.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 20 -- There was little activity to-day around the United Mine Workers' headquarters from where the coal miners' strike is being directed. Most of the union officials spent the day in the outlying towns meeting the striking men and giving them instructions. No overtures have been advanced by either side, and there is at present no indication that any will be put forth soon.

CHARTRES, France, Sept. 20 -- The grand manoeuvres of the French Army were concluded this morning with the Presidential review. The whole body of troops, numbered 97,000 men, with 20,000 horses. The review took place on a plain five miles from here. An immense concourse of spectators was present.

William E. Cashman, a policeman attached to the Eldridge Street Station, was knocked down for an alleged insult to a woman yesterday at the corner of Willoughby and Fulton Streets. He afterward arrested the man who asaulted him, but the desk Sergeant at the Adams Street Station refused to entertain the charge.

BRYN MAWR, Sept. 20 -- Bryn Mawr College opens for its sixteenth academic year at work Oct. 2. The number of students admitted to the college at the June examinations was 94, by far the largest in the college history. If the usual proportion of one-half more is admitted in September the entering class will number nearly 40, showing a very large increase.

The Democratic State leaders are not in harmony as to what should be made the paramount issue in the New York campaign. The differences of opinion which have arisen between John B. Stanchfield, Senator Mackey, Norman E. Mack, and some other leaders have charged the atmosphere, around the Hoftman House and the St. James Building with suppressed excitement.

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners met yesterday afternoon for the first time since July 12. and besides listening to a report from Chief Engineer Parsons of progress to the present time, adopted the change in the Post Office loop as already outlined in THE NEW YORK TIMES, and discussed the proposed Broadway extension to the Battery and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept 20 -- The United States has prepared definitive memoranda on the several Chinese questions, and these will probably be delivered to China, Germany, Russia, and France some time to-morrow. The President has made preparations to return to Canton Friday evening, and at present there is nothing to indicate that any change in his plans will be necessary.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Resolutions were adopted this afternoon at the annual meeting of the New Jersey State Liquor Dealers' Protective League, held in the German-English school hall, by which that organization is to be converted into a secret society with ritual,
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Polonius, sire of many noted track and road horses, and son of Rysdick's Hambletonian, is dead at Walden. He was foaled in 1872.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 20 -- Scranton is the first city to experience hardship as a result of a scarcity of coal. The men at the Columbus wathery, out of sympathy for the strike movement, refuse to prepare any culm except for the electric light riant of which the washery is a part, and this compels the trolley company to use unwashed culm just as it comes from the refuse heaps.

Martin Van Buren Burroughs, a wellknown Brooklyn politician, was found dead in a room of a boarding house at 453 Pacific Street yesterday afternoon. There was a bullet wound in the right side of his head, and a pistol, which he had used, was beside him on the bed. Dr. J.J. Markey was called in, but he said that Mr. Burroughs had been dead about ten hours.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 20. -- After a protracted and animated joint session of the Conference Committee of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers and of the conference committee of the manufacturers, an adjournment was taken to-night until to-morrow morning without any definite result being reached.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 20 -- The mine operators give out the following statement to-night:

Liquidation forced a number of declines in the market for outside securities yesterday. In nearly every stock traded in some loss appeared, and in a few stocks the declines were serious. After seven days of irregularity the market showed decided downward tendency, resulting from larger selling orders then have appeared in the market for some time.

From The Brooklyn Eagle of Yesterday. SAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 20 -- A correspondent of The Eagle saw Admiral Dewey this morning at the home of his brother-in-law. Admiral Nicoll Ludlow, in Oakdale, where he is now a guest. The distinguished naval officers had read the interview with Lieut. Richmond P. Hobson, published in this morning's papers, but Admiral Dewey did not appear to be especially disturbed about it, and remarked:

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 20 -- Official reports of conditions at interior towns have begun to conic in from the agents sent out for the relief of the section visited by the storm outside of Galveston and Harris County. Following are summaries of reports so far received showing the conditions at half a dozen towns on the Santa Fe.

The National Civil Service Reform League has a cause of quarrel with the Civil Service Commission. The commission has denied the league access to its records, and a special committee of the league, consisting of Charles J. Bonaparte, Edward Cary, and Frederick L. Siddons has addressed a letter to the commission complaining of the commission's prohibition, and renewing the demand for certain information.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 -- The official schedule of the Brown University football team for this season has been completed. The schedule in the completed form is as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your able and interesting editorial on "Europe and American Coal" in Monday's issue, you discuss the "coal panic" and the possibility of a continuance of the demand from Great Britain for our coal. You do not call attention to one fact, that is probably not generally understood, that we ourselves are importers of coal.

OGDEN, Utah, Sept. 20 -- Gov. Roosevelt spent to-day campaigning in Utah. Leaving Pocatello, Idaho, at 6 o'clock this morning, his first stop was at Logan, Utah, where a meeting was held in the Cache Mormon Tabernacle. Addresses were made by Mrs. J. Ellen Foster, Gov. Roosevelt, and others.
Various legal difficulties have befallen the principal legatees under the will of Edgar E. Duryea, the wealthy starch manufacturer and reputed millionaire.

Not in a long time has there been such a representation of fast trotters and pacers on the Speedway as there was yesterday afternoon. One of the speediest steppers on the course was the horse that holds the World's pacing record to wagon, the bay gelding Free Bond, who went in 2:04 1/4 at the Empire City track last week just after he was bought by C.K.G. Billings of Chicago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the sermon delivered by Dr. MacArthur on Sunday, Sept. 9, and noted especially his comments upon the "prayer chain" originated by a member of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union organization. I am in full accord with his designation of it as "silly," "blasphemous."

GALVESTON, Sept. 20 -- This evening Mayor Jones proclaimed that martial law would cease at noon to-morrow and the civil authorities would assume direction of municipal affairs. This was done at the suggestion of Gen. Scurry, who expressed the belief that conditions had reached such a stage that the civil authorities were able to cope with the situation.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- For the first time in the history of this city a Democratic Mayor has declared against the levying of assessments against City Hall office holders for campaign purposes.

Many curious and interesting complications growing out of the Hoboken water front conflagration are coming up for adjustment. For example, a barge load of grain was purchased by a Produce Exchange operator for shipment to Europe by one of the steamers of the North German Lloyd.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 20 -- A conservative estimate made to-night from reports received from all the Reading Company's collieries places the amount of coal mined to-day at those collieries at 44,200 tons, or 1,700 carloads. This is 300 more cars, or 7,800 more tons, of coal than were carried from the Reading regions yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- The report that the United States had refused to accede to the proposal of Germany to postpone peace negotiations until those responsible for the outrages at Peking had been punished is received with incredulity in German official circles.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 20 -- Mr. Bryan spent the greater part of to-day in going through his accumulated correspondence. He also received a large number of callers. A committee of twenty-five members of the Bryan Veteran Bimetallic Club of this (Lancaster County) called to assure him of their support.

Harry Dell of Michigan, who is known to have pocketed more than $7,000 within four years by operating in spurious drafts, has come to grief. The man, who last night was at Police Headquarters, has operated under many names, and was heretofore in peril but once, when in August, 1898, he was arrested for cheating the proprietor of the Park Hotel, at Lake Park, Minn. He escaped punishment.
The committees appointed by the 'Western Presidents' conference of Tuesday last have completed their preliminary work and have adjourned to meet again in Chicago on Wednesday next.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 20 -- This town has become in all respects the most important of the places affected by the strike of the anthracite coal miners. It is the headquarters of the mine workers, and John Mitchell, the head of that organization, from this point directs the efforts to make the strike effective.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society has sold, through M. Kamak, to Morris H. Hayman the eight five-story brick flats occupying the block front on the east side of Eighth Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-sixth and One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Streets, 199.10 by 88.

Engineer Archi Philip Louis Santi has a scheme. He wants the city to build a "dyke-bridge " between the Borough of Manhattan and Staten Island, to cost $24,000,000. A description of the bridge was published in The City Record yesterday. In a letter transmitting the plan Engineer Santi says:
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The Times-Herald to-day says: "The Iroquois Club has asked Grover Cleveland and Richard Olney to speak hore soon under its auspices against McKinley and for Bryan.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Coal scarcity is more keenly felt to-day, and although the Reading Company is mining and shipping its usual quota of anthracite, dealers are finding it hard to get as much as they need. The tonnage of the other great coalcarrying companies is gradually diminshing, however, and in the natural order of things, unless the strike is settled, will soon cease altogether from some districts.

OCEANIC. N.J., Sept. 20 -- Charles B. Foote, the banker and member of the firm of Hatch Foote, died at 3 o'clock this afternoon. At 9 o'clock this morning all his family were called into the room, in the belief that the end had come. He lingered, however, until this afternoon, though he did not regain consciousness.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 20 -- At the meeting of the National Municipal League this afternoon, the feature was a paper on "The Influence of Public Service Companies on City Governments," by the Rev. Dr. Washington Gladden, who is a member of the Columbus City Council. Dr. Gladden said, in part:

That old fox LI-HUNG-CHANG never made a more vulpine remark in his life than that which he most advertently made the other day about the "personal responsibility" of the Empress Dowaser, who, according to her astute agent, was "ill-advised" in recommending and commanding the massacre of missionaries and Ministers.

John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor of New York, opened his campaign in this city amid scenes of as great enthusiasm as a contracted hall would allow at the meeting of the Commercial Travelers' and Hotel Men's Anti-Trust League, in the old Revere House, Broadway and Houston Street, yesterday at noon.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Sept. 20 -- While Gov. Wells and Secretary of State Hammond were in Idaho last night to meet Gov. Roosevelt and escort him to this city, Judge O.W. Powers of Salt Lake, a Democrat, was appointed United States Senator. The appointment was made by Aquila Nebeker, President of the Senate, who is Acting Governor, according to the Constitution.

--"There should be some way," declares Mr. RICHARD CROKER in reference to the charge just made for the thousandth time that the organization of which he is the head raises funds by the taxation of vice, "there should be some way of preventing a man from making statements of that kind."

Lord Revelstoke of Baring Brothers, London, who arrived on the Majestic yesterday, said that the floating of the recent British loan here could not fall to cement further the friendship between the two countries.

The warehouses of the Terminal Warehouse Company, in West Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets, from Eleventh to Thirteenth Avenue, were yesterday morning, for the first time since their construction in 1890, visited by fire. Two floors of Sections 1 and 2, forming the Eleventh Avenue front, were ravaged, but the other twenty-two sections escaped damage owing to the solid construction of the building and the intrepidity of the firemen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Revenue officers have brought down from the Mare Island Navy Yard on a Government tug 154 cases of rare Oriental goods, which had been brought into this country on the hospital! ship Solace. The articles seized would net a small fortune. The duty is nearly 60 per cent.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Trading was fairly active to-day, especially in Sugar, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Atchison. Tamarack receded 5, to 231; Montana rose 3, to 313, but fell back to 310; Parrot lost 3/4, to 39 1/2, later 39 3/4; Wolverine lost 1/2, to 39; Utah 1 1/8, to 28 1/2; Arcadian 1, to 17; Isle Royale 1, to 28, and Osceola 1, to 64.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- It was explained today at the British Foreign Office that "it was found inexpedient for the powers to accept the Russian withdrawal proposal," as they had reliable information that "the Boxers were ready to reoccupy Peking as soon as the allies retired."

QUEENS, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Nine very interesting shoots were held to-day at Inter-State Park, in which a number of the crack shots of the club competed. Upon the conclusion of the scheduled events several miss and outs were also shot off. Three of the regular events were at fifteen blue rocks, three at twenty blue rocks, one at fifty blue rocks, and two events at live birds, of seven and ten birds each.

The chaotic condition of the retail coal trade as the result of the strike of the anthracite miners was illustrated last night at a meeting of the Retail Dealers' Coal Exchange, held at 131 East Fifty-eighth Street. It developed at the meeting that there is at present practically no established retail price for the anthracite product.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- The tragedy that has been looked for since the coal workers' strike was inaugurated came suddenly and unexpectedly at Shenandoah this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to say a few words on Mr. Roosevelt's letter of acceptance? It seems to me, Mr. Editor, that he has either intentionally or unintentionally misstated the facts in connection with the acquisition of Louisiana, or that the men who wrote the histories of the United States differ widely from one another.

The letters of Thomas Edward Brown, which are attracting considerable enthusiasm in England, will be published in this country early in October by E.P. Dutton Co. The English critics say that these letters do not resemble any others to be found in literature. Their variety seems to be a perpetual surprise; in fact, as one of Brown's friends once said, "You never come to the end of Brown."

PONCHATOULA, La., Sept. 21. -- Last night four negroes were hanged here after the jail had been broken open and the prisoners, accused of robbing the family of Henry Hotfelder, had been taken from their cells. Mrs. Louise Hotfelder, who resisted the colored men, was choked and beaten so unmercifully that she lost her mind.

When the Hamburg-American liner Kaiser Friedrich arrived here yesterday, her commander, Capt. Bauer. reported that the voyage had been so rough that he had never seen anything like it in nearly forty years of service on the sea.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have been deeply interested in what Kathryn Jarboe, Elizabeth Akers, and Francis J. Ward had recently to say in your paper about "An Amiable Child." Elizabeth Akers expresses a wish "to know something about his mother," and Kathryn Jarboe says that his mother was a lineal descendant of the St. Clairs of Scotland and Ireland.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 21. -- The storm of last night over Northern and Northwestern Texas was one of the fiercest rain and electrical affairs of which there is any record. The fall of rain at Dallas during the night approximated three inches, at Fort Worth, thirty miles west, eight inches. The property loss within a radius of a hundred miles of Dallas is estimated at $2,000,000, confined largely to cotton and railway interests.

It is a very good sign that the abuses of advertising should be beginning to attract attention in more than one country. It is the Anglo-Saxon countries in which the protests against these abuses are most frequent. We might take some credit to ourselves for that but for the too evident fact that the opposition to too shameful or disgusting advertising is there more needed than in other lands.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 21. -- The National Municipal League held its final meeting of the annual convention to-day. Charles J. Bonaparte of Baltimore was the principal speaker of the forenoon session. His paper was entitled "The Essential Element in Good City Government." He said, in part:

LONDON, Sept 22. -- A flood of election manifestos appears in the morning papers. The Conservative candidates, following the lead of Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain, give the successful war the first place in their campaign. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, Liberal leader in the House of Commons, and Sir William Vernon-Harcourt, in their addresses, denounce the "unprecedented precipitancy of a dissolution in order to snatch a hasty judgment on an incomplete register of voters."

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 21. -- In less than two hours, and with an enthusiasm and harmony that will render memorable its proceedings, the Democratic State Convention to-day nominated a full State ticket, chose the six State Electors, elected a new State Central Committee, and adopted a platform.

A meeting of representatives of all Protestant foreign mission boards in North America having missions in China was held yesterday in the assembly room of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, at 156 Fifth Avenue. The purpose of the meeting was to outline a policy for mission work in China.
AN ADMIRER sends us the following poem by Mrs. George Archibald Palmer of Elmira, which was written a decade ago, and now exists only in a garbled form. The original verses are as follows:

Andrew Bertram Hart, a member of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, and a son-in-law of the late Altamont De Cordova, who had been prominent in Wall street for many years, was found dead yesterday morning in a ramshackle old Summer house, consisting of four posts supporting a roof, at the end of Noye's Dock, at Woodmere, L.I.
"We will come down to the Harlem River with not less than 150,000 plurality for the McKinley and Roosevelt Electors."

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 21. -- At noon to-day martial law was abolished and the Civil Government resumed control of affairs. The contract for clearing the streets has been awarded to a local firm. They will establish boarding camps on the beach and commence work Monday morning with an army of laborers at $2 per day.

The 154 delegates to the Democratic State Convention who voted for the nomination of Controller Coler for Governor propose to commemorate the fight made at Saratoga against "commercialism in politics" and the "domination of the bosses."

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Tonight at the Lyceum Theatre William Collier produced a new three-act play by Augustus Thomas, entitled "On the Quiet." The piece is a comedy. Mr. Collier portrays a lively young college student who marries a girl but is obliged for financial reasons to keep the marriage secret.
The fund for the relief of the people of Galveston was increased by $11,415.97 yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- William J. Bryan has canceled his dates in Illinois, and will make speeches in the East instead.
E.R Hunt has resigned as Philadelphia agent of the Maryland Casualty Company.

Wonderful seems to have been the aptitude of Henry Knox. The artillery officer of the past as of the present, it is supposed would have to go through a certain training before he could understand his special duties. But here is the man who leaves his bookstore in Boston, joins the patriots, and in a short time becomes the commanding officer of artillery under Gen. Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The whole tenor of your article, "The Chicago Example," tends to create the impression that the decline in the price of Brooklyn Rapid Transit yesterday was due to the underground wire agitation. There is no agitation to impose underground wires on the Metropolitan or Manhattan Companies or the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company, and yet their stock declined more than that of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit.

The extraordinary stability of west-bound freight rates in Trunk Line territory for the last year or more has been a matter of congratulation among all those interested in the prosperity of these lines, and a great deal of speculation has been indulged in as to the methods which made this maintenance of rates possible in this territory.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 21. -- There were 3,000 people at the Lenox Horse Show today, including Mrs. Grover Cleveland, Chauncey M. Depew, Dr. W. Seward Webb, Oliver Gould Jennings, who drove up from Fairfield with his four-in-hand; Prince and Princess Brancaccio, William D. Sloane, De Lancey Kane, William C. Schermerhorn, and all the Lenox cottagers with their numerous guests.

Dramatic critics are with no little reason decrying the prevalent craze of the theatregoing public for dramatized, novels. Plays made from novels nearly always show the traces of the saw and the hammer, and in most cases they fail to rise above the level of theatrical carpenter work.

In the withdrawal of the former Chairman of the Irish Parliamentary Party from active political life is a touch of irony that will doubtless be appreciated by the Irish mind, although the British Liberal organs may sincerely indulge in ante-mortem eulogies over a Parliamentary career impetuously ended.

The Work Together Club has been organized, with headquarters at 225 West Ninety-ninth Street, and came out with a statement, yesterday defining its aims. The President of the club is the Rev. John P. Peters and its Secretary is Lewis W. Davidson. In its statement the organization says:

A certain amount of imagination is required of the writer who would make statistics interesting, and Mr. Adams possesses this imagination in a high degree. His previous studies in history and National tendencies gave him a good foundation for such a task as he has undertaken in his latest book, and his judicious arrangement of facts shows careful work among official publications and compilations of returns, which are so repellent to the general reader.

There is a goodly amount of interest just now in the playing of professional golfers, and there is excellent reason for it. Our own amateurs have advanced a long way in the science of this admirable game, and there is needed the superior work of the men who make a business of golf to show how far from the possible standard of excellence we yet are.

AN ONLOOKER, Brooklyn, N.Y., citing an example of a friendship formed through the medium of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, writes: "Two contributors, who have written especially worthy articles at various times, were mutually attracted by seeing expressed by one another common interests. This led one to write to the other a letter so charming, so characteristic, and so whole-souled that a friendship was immediately formed and a personal correspondence is a further bond of friendship.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 21. -- Mayor Samuel M. Jones has refused the unanimous nomination of the Democratic Congressional Convention, and Negly D. Cochran, editor of The Bee. was nominated.

The last word about Prince Bismarck has not been written, nor will this personage be taken off the stage of history for many a year. The latest contribution to Bismarckian literature has for title. "Conversations with Prince Bismarck." The author, Heinrich von Poschinger, takes his material from many sources.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21. -- This afternoon Rear Admiral Farquhar and Capt. Charles H. Stockton, President of the United States Naval War College, had an extended conference over the naval manoeuvres which will take place off Newport next week in connection with the War College course.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- 4 A.M. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Daily News cites the opinion of a high foreign official that the Emperor and Empress Dowager will, under the pressure exerted by the Viceroys, surrender Prince Tuan and the other anti-foreign leaders to the powers.

With an ease that almost spoiled the interest in the race Cornelius Vanderbilt's Rainbow yesterday again defeated August Belmont's Mineola and won the special cup that had been offered by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club. In the lead from start to finish Rainbow was never endangered by her opponent after the first hour of the race, and at the end of the twenty-three and one-half miles here margin over Mineola was 5 minutes 21 seconds.

Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor of this State, yesterday declared himself as unqualifiedly in favor of New York City owning its own water supply, and he has explicitly pledged himself to support the repeal of the Ramapo or any other grant that may be an obstacle to such full ownership.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The United States Government has made full answers to the various inquiries addressed to it by the powers relative to the Chinese trouble. Moreover, it has made a disclosure of all of its purposes. This action was taken after the Cabinet meeting to-day.
