This interesting memoir is more strictly personal in all its details than any story, of the French Revolution we can remember reading. That is it deals with the experiences of Mlle. des Echerolles and her immediate family during the sad days of the Terror, all public events referred to being those which she knew from personal experience.

The opening of the New York art season is in sight. So many people have come to town in consequence of the cool weather of the past week that there have been many visitors at the art shops, and engravings and etchings in particular have been readily sold to Southern and Western house owners who are tarrying in New York for a few days on their way home from the Northern Summer resorts.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The communication from your correspondent, Karl M. Sherman, in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of last week leads me to believe that some of your readers who pursue the elusive flrst edition may be interested in the list of titles appended here.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Clifford V. Brokaw's British-built cutter Queen Mab has been hauled out at the Jacob yard preparatory to going out of commission for the season.
William Wood, sometimes called "The Grandfather of Athletics in the United States," died on Thursday night at his home, 293 Lenox Avenue. He was eighty-six years old.

Dr. John W. Duke, a dentist of 269 West Forty-fifth Street, was a prisoner in the West Side Court yesterday morning, charged with having belabored on the head with a glass water pitcher Patrick J. Farley, who had been visiting Annie Curran, the doctor's servant.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- James J. Corbett, the pugilist, will return to New York by the first available steamer, to effect a reconciliation with his wife. He said to-day: "I received some American papers on "Wednesday containing alleged reasons for my sailing for Europe and interviews with my wife as to my reasons for leaving.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- President McKinley, accompanied by Secretary, Cortel-you, left Washington at 7:45 o'clock this evening for Canton, Ohio. The train is due at Canton to-morrow morning. The President looked in excellent health.
MADRID, Sept. 21. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 80.20. Gold was quoted at 32.54.

Assignee E. Ellery Anderson of the insolvent banking house of Hatch Foote said yesterday that 160 shares of Standard Oil stock were charged against the Thomas Hastings account by Mr. Foote. Mr. Hastings, he said, had several months ago deposited something like $80,000 worth of stocks with the firm to strengthen it, but that he has no reason to disbelieve Mr. Hastings's statement that the speculative account was unauthorized.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The "Indignant Benedict" who used your delightful SATURDAY REVIEW to air his grievances against Mr. Gregory's new volume, "The Ways of Men," should have read the title of the article which excites his wrath, more carefully before plunging into criticism.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: From a general interest in books, and in sympathy with recent articles touching the making and selling of them, and especially with your plea in THE SATURDAY REVIEW for the better class of literature, I wish, if I may, to offer, through you, a suggestion to the publishers.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I cannot allow Mr. Stone's vituperative attack upon Mr. J. Fenimore Cooper, in your last issue, to remain unanswered, containing, as it does, statements so entirely wide of the truth.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The first installments of the diary of Marie Bashkirtseff, which have appeared in The Gentlewoman, are precisely what we might have expected. The story that they have been lately discovered is an error. They were submitted to the editor of the original edition of the diary soon after Mlle.

Again English and American shipowners may open their eyes with wonder, for news has come across the water that still another giant transatlantic liner is being built for one of the rival German steamship companies. The new vessel has been ordered from the Belfast yards of Harland Wolff by the Hamburg-American Line.

A full-fledged West India island came under the auctioneer's hammer in the real estate salesrooms of Peter P. Meyer Co. at 111 Broadway yesterday afternoon, and within the space of a minute had been knocked down to the only bidder at $25,000.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 21. -- Notwithstanding the large number of miners obeying the order of the Mine Workers' Union, all hope of success of the strike is found among the directors of the strike. The strikers would be glad to believe that they will win, but all of them are aware that the corporations and coal owners will absolutely refuse to consider any demand or proposal from John Mitchell or the officers of the union.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 21. -- During the Summer, frequent complaints have been made to the police of the various cities along the line of the Consolidated Railroad from New York to Boston of the work of what appeared to be an organized gang of pickpockets, who preyed on the passengers of the express trains between New York and Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- It was officially announced to-day that I.A. Sweigard, General Superintendent of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway, and E.C. Tomlinson, Superintendent of the New York Division, had tendered their resignations. W.G. Bessler succeeds Mr. Sweigard and W.A. Garrett will ocupy the place vacated by Mr. Tomlinson.

Would you talk pure Maghribin? Are you fond of powder-play? Would you swallow cous-cousoo? Rabelais, the wonderful man, has a word to say about this North African food preparation. Do you wish to bestride an Arab barb? Do you incline to don the burnoose and be a true believer of the Prophet?

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- The sixty-seventh annual report of the Boston and Maine Directors shows that the company earned for the year a surplus of $172,016 in excess of all charges and dividends. The year covered by the report, as President Tuttle puts it, was one of unusual business prosperity throughout the country.
HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 21. -- President Mitchell to-night issued the following:

DE SOTO, Mo., Sept. 21. -- By a vote of 32 to 1 the St. Louis Presbytery, composed of Presbyterian churches of Eastern Missouri, decided, at the Fall meeting just ended, against any revision of the Creed.

During the book auction season that will open in this city on Sept. 24 at Bangs Co.'s and on Oct. 2 at Anderson's, it will be interesting to see whether the beautifully printed publications of William Loring Andrews will bring at public sale the prices they brought during the late season of 1899-1900.
SALT LAKE, Sept. 21. -- The following signed statement has been given out by Judge O.W. Powers, who was appointed United States Senator from Utah, yesterday, by Acting Governor Aquila Nebeker:

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 21. -- As stated in a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was expected last night that the strikers would to-day make a powerful effort to close some of the individual collieries in the Schuylkill districts, and that operations would be opened at Shenandoah, where there are five individual collieries.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- To-day and to-night were lively times for the sophomores and freshmen. At 12:30 to-day the freshmen held their first meeting for the election of officers. While they were gathering at the gymnasium the naughty sophs, togged in all their show regalia of orange and black sweaters and fantastic hats, intimidated the freshies and chased them into the auditorium at a trot.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21. -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt, who has been entertaining a good deal lately, both at his farm, Oakland, and at his cottage in Bellevue Avenue, known as Rocky Hall, gave a luncheon and dinner to-day.

The enthusiastic women Republicans of the city began their campaign work yesterday afternoon with a woman's mass meeting, given under the auspices of the National Commercial and Industrial League, at the Republican Rooms, 737 Broadway. As a woman's meeting the affair might not be considered altogether a success, but as the audience, composed largely of men, seemed to enjoy the affair greatly there is no knowing what good seed may have been sown.

The order, issued by Chief Croker, a few days ago, to the effect that firemen must not belong to political organizations, was followed yesterday by a statement from Commissioner Scannell that hereafter any men connected with the department who belong to such organizations would have charges preferred against them under Section 738 of the Charter, which provides that any member of any uniformed force of the city shall not belong to a political organization.

There was a conference in the Hoffman House yesterday for the purpose of raising campaign funds. Among those present were ex-Senator Murphy, William McAdoo, State Chairman Frank Campbell, ex-Gov. Stone of Missouri, Norman E. Mack, and Col. William C. Wetmore, the St. Louis tobacco manufacturer, and Richard Croker.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 21. -- Three regiments of infantry, a battery, and a troop of cavalry were ordered out at midnight by Gov. Stone to assist Sheriff Toole in maintaining order in the Schuylkill mining region.

The horse show at Lenox yesterday was the event of the season in the Berkshires. The Executive Committee, following the plan of the Southampton show, ruled out all professional horse dealers, so that the affair was throughout an amateur one. The display of horseflesh surprised the judges, and some admirable driving was also seen, particularly on the part of Miss Kate Gary.

During three weeks Canadian failures, Dun's notes, were $2,098,168 in amount of liabilities, mainly owing to three large defaults at Montreal for $1,419,675. General conditions continue satisfactory throughout the Dominion, with active trade at most points, and no serious effects from the recent disasters at Montreal.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21. -- May Irwin appeared in her new play, "The Belle of Bridgeport," for the first time this evening and scored a distinct success in her new songs, in her impersonations, and in her comic scenes, which are unusually good in this play. A mad scene in the last act is turned into an excruciatingly funny performance.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21. -- The dispute between the Board of Supervisors of Nassau County and the City of New York relative to the apportionment of the county debt of the old Queens County territory and the apportionment of the personal property, including the arrears of taxes as between the county and the city, is to be amicably settled without further recourse to the courts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Further consolidation of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy system is to be effected at the annual meeting of the stockholders in this city Nov. 7. Next month the several auxiliary lines leased and operated by the parent corporation in Iowa and Missouri will be merged with the greater system.
BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- The German Foreign Office has received replies from Italy, Austria, and France agreeing, without reserve, to Germany's China proposal.

Everybody seems to agree that Mr. MITCHELL, the leader of the coal strike, has made a great and probably irretrievable blunder, in his treatment of the Markle mines. At these collieries, in fact, all the conditions prevailed that MITCHELL had announced his purpose to make prevail all over the anthracite region.

Charles Hitchcock, Jr., the young Yale golf champion, and Louis Livingston, Jr., a former champion of his home club at Westbrook, will meet to-day in the final struggle for the chief trophy in the Westbrook Golf Club tournament, on the links between Islip and Oakdale, L.I.
Dr. Lewis Albert Sayre, one of the most noted physicians and surgeons of this country, died early yesterday morning at his residence, 285 Fifth Avenue, this city. He was eighty years old.

The prospectus of this institution containing the preliminary announcements for the coming season has just been issued. The season begins on Thursday, Sept. 27, 1900, and closes on Saturday, June 1, 1900. The number of valuable courses of evening lectures and addresses that are of very wide and general interest will be greater than in any previous year, and the number of afternoon lectures has also been increased.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Sept. 21. -- Gov. Roosevelt's visit to Salt Lake City was decidedly interesting, both from a political and a social point of view. The Governor reached here at 10:30 A.M. The train was met by a great number of people and a brigade of Rough Riders, who escorted the Governor through the principal streets, where flattering demonstrations took place.

The annual season of intercollegiate football matches is at hand, and the various teams are already hard at work preparing for the battles of the gridiron. Football talk is coming forward and there is a plentiful discussion of the prospects of the different colleges in the impending struggle.

Another exhibition of rowdyism was witnessed by the small crowd of spectators at Washington Park yesterday toward the close of the baseball game between New York and Brooklyn. Brooklyn had one run to get to tie, one man out, and two on bases, when McGinnity hit to Da vis, and a double play resulted.

Quotations in the market for outside securities were under less pressure yesterday than-on Thursday, and the course of the market became less irregular. Prices showed a little strength, and here and there advances were recorded, but the return movement was much less marked than the declines of the previous day.

Leslie Stephen's critical articles are always of great interest, and his paper on Waiter Bagehot, lately published in the pages of The National Review, will be found to present a clearly formulated and expressed criticism upon that writer, to whom new attention may well be directed. While Walter Bagehot's literary rank needs no countersign, Mr. Stephen wonders whether he has yet received his due meed of lame.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- Nothing could more strikingly illustrate Dr. James Martineau's character than his words, "Be sure that you do not spare me," addressed to his biographer, the Rev. Dr. A.W. Jackson. Always he was willing to abide by his convictions of right, no matter at what cost of suffering, and no question of general opinion could disturb such a man.

The racing at the Gravesend track yesterday, an extra afternoon's programme, was for the benefit of the Galveston Aid Fund, and the net result was a handsome addition to the sum raised in New York for the sufferers from the recent Texas disaster. The free list was suspended, and all who entered the gates paid for admission.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Sept. 21. -- Superintendent Adam Boyd, Inside Foreman Foley, and Breaker Bosses James and William Mitchell of Indian Ridge Colliery were returning from work at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon when they were met at the Lehigh Valley station by a mob with sticks and stones.

The first instance of actual violence in the course of the coal strike was due, so to speak, when it occurred. Whatever may have been the specific merits or demerits of the parties to the actual collision, it could not long have been postponed. It is not necessary to impute insincerity to the leaders of the strike in their professions of an intention to abide by the law.

As the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II. was about to sail for Italy yesterday morning Detective Moody saw four men scuffling on the pier near the steerage gangway. He separated the combatants, who gave their names as Giuseppe Greco, Francisco Greco, Antonio Martinse, and Natal Demowa, all Italians.

Just about now the thoughts of the peole of the theatre are turning toward their seasons on the road. With faces averted from the Rialto, grips in hand, and regret in heart, they are thinking of days in boarding houses or cheap hotels, nights in stuffy cars, and weeks and months of wandering far away from the glare and glamour of "the alley."
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Incoming Boston and New York vessels report encountering severe weather on the Atlantic, and in several cases sustaining deck damage.

CHICAGO, Sept. -- 22 -- Important recommendations for improving the army service are made in the annual report of the Department of the Lakes, made public here to-day. The report was compiled by Gen. Joseph Wheeler before his retirement.
Mrs. B.R. Jacobs of the Glen Ridge Golf Club, N.J., has won the Governors' Cup, which has been in competition all Summer. She beat in the final round Miss Van Nest by 2 up and 1 to play.

The man who has taken up his residence in his wife's tomb in the Evergreens Cemetery, in Brooklyn, is heard from occasionally through interested people who visit and write about him. He is an exceptional individual, something of a philisopher, a modern Diogenes, who is completing his days in a way he considers tends most to his happiness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Prof. J.W. Jenks of the Industrial Commission, who has been in Europe for some months studying the trust problem there, has submitted a preliminary report to the commission on the subject, and will have a report in greater detail ready by the time Congress assembles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to your editorial indorsing the nominees of the Democratic State Convention, I would beg leave to submit the opinion of one of Brooklyn's young independent, or Cleveland, Democrats. In your indorsement you see no reason why Mr. Stanchfield should not receive the full Democratic, as well as the independent and antiboss, vote.

The coal strike begins to tell. Up to within the last day or two Wall Street has chosen to ignore the Issues and possible influences there involved; but the course of the market on Friday and Saturday reflected in rather a pronounced way awakened interest, and even apprehension.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Some interesting facts regarding the new trans-Siberian railroad are given in a report from W.R. Holloway, United States Consul General at St. Petersburg.
Boston is now contributing about $1,000 a day to the Galveston relief fund. The total amount thus far is more than $50,000.

When the circuit of the National League and American Association of Professional Baseball Clubs -- to give it uts complete, high-sounding title -- was reduced to eight cities last Winter, it was believed that a much more interesting race would result, and that interest in the National game would take a depided brace.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- Business to-day was light in volume, just exceeding 10,000 shares in the two hours. Utah, at 28 3/4, shows 1 3/8 net loss for the week; Wolverine, at 39 1/2, rallied 1/2 to-day. Dominion Coal is unchanged at 38 1/2, while Gas and Coke shares and bonds were not traded in today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thanks for your editorials bearing upon the candidacy of Mr. Stanchfield. Your presentation of the merits of the case has furnished abundant satisfaction to one who had been beset with difficulties from which, apparently, there was no means of extricating himself.

Copyright, 1900, The Associated Press. LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Lord Salisbury has not yet answered the German proposal nor has he even discussed its terms with his advisers, and it is likely that several days will elapse before Great Britain puts herself on record regarding the suggestion of Emperor William.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Fritz Wittig, a member of the freshman class of Rutgers College, was injured in a cane rush here last night, and it is not thought that he will recover. The rush was one of the old-fashioned kind, a cane being given to about forty members of the freshman class, who placed it on the ground and formed a ring around it, guarding it with their bodies.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Sept. 22 -- With the arrival of the militia here to-day this borough assumed its normal condition, and the anticipated resumption of violence on the part of the miners did not occur. It might have been the presence of the soldiers that restrained the turbulent element, but many of the residents believe the lack of riotous scenes was due to the fact that all the collieries here were closed.
The funeral of Mrs. James E. March, wife of Port Warden March, the Republican leader of the Sixth Assembly District, took place yesterday morning at her home, 30 Marion Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The notes which have recently passed between the United States and China, Russia, and Germany were made public to-day. The text shows the inaccuracy of the published report that the notes contained an announcement of the purpose of the United States to withdraw from China.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Internationals and Americans were quiet on the Boerse to-day. Industrials were steady. Banks relapsed sharply on liquidations, apparently for provincial bankers and speculators, on their objecting to their names being registered for time bargains. There were also numerous local and speculative sales.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- If the Council Redistricting Committee has its way, the whole of Chicago will be reapportioned into wards quite different geographically from what now exist.

The President in his letter accepting a renominatlon has referred briefly to events and quoted liberally from records and instructions, to justify the course of the Administration in dealing with the Philippines, and to show that there never was any "alliance" between the American and Filipino forces against Spain, or any promise of independence to the Filipinos after the defeat of the "common enemy."
"No," said the Barclay Street man, with a smile, "it never wears out."

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- A state of open warfare exists between the Municipal Council and the Government. This was made apparent to-day by the publication of a letter from the Premier, Waldeck-Rousseau, declining all direct communication with the Council.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, opening the Birmingham campaign this evening, delievered an address to a great open-air meeting. His speech was an impassioned arraignment of the opponents of the war in South Africa, in the course of which he said: "I was going to call them traitors, but I will instead say misguided individuals."

If there are people who think that there are nowadays no cakes elaborately decorated for weddings, with charming little brides and bridegrooms standing under marriage bells, horseshoes, and other appropriate canopies upon them, they should visit the establishment where such thing's are made.
SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 22 -- A parade of 2,000 slate pickers, runners, drivers, door tenders, and helpers from the mines of Scranton and vicinity was held to-day.

The regular supplementary practice for marksmen and sharpshooters was held here to-day with a very large attendance. The weather was fair, a stiff 9 o'clock wind blowing throughout the day. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Col. W.B. Thurston, Ordnance Officer, N.G.N.Y. Col. Nelson Henry, Surgeon General State of New York, visited the range to-day.

Mr. CHARLES A. GARDINER of the New York bar fired a broadside or two at the riddled hulk of anti-imperialism last night for practice. His argument was legal, Constitutional, and sufficient. It may be said that Mr. GARDINER wastes his good ammunition on an enemy already destroyed.

A picturesque fire which destroyed about $100,000 worth of property occurred yesterday morning in the big warehouse and grain elevator of Nash, Whitten Co., at Bowne Street, on Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn. The flames spread to two adjoining warehouses, one of which, owned by the Lyman Grain Drying Company, was recently rebuilt after having been destroyed by fire three months ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You open your columns to all kinds of letters, all sorts of discussions. May I call the attention of your readers to a topic that may cause a great deal of letter writing on the part of some of them -- "Taxpayer," "X.Y.Z.," "Pro Bono Publico," and others?

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Thomas Whitehead, forty years old, of 30 Central Avenue, Harrison, jumped from a second-story window to escape from fire in his house this morning. His feet were badly sprained and he suffere other injuries. He was removed to St. Michael's Hospital in the Kearny police ambulance.

MANILA, July 19 -- Civil government In the Philippines will become operative on Sept. 1, when the commision of which exJudge William H. Taft is President will assume charge of affairs and Gen. MacArthur will become Chief Executive instead of Military Governor. Whether the official change will be other than nominal at first may be doubted.
DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 22 -- Senator C. K. Davis opened the Republican campaign in Duluth last night, and spoke to an audience of about 3,500 persons, the armory being filled to the doors.

Declining quotations were the order of the day on the stock market yesterday. The serious turn in the coal strike situation and the growing impression that higher money rates in a short time are inevitable created early, in the day an uneasy feeling, aggravated later by the publication of the weekly bank statement distinctly unfavorable.

I heard the angry shouting of many voices, not in the plazza before the hotel, but at some little distance; it was impossible to distinguish any meaning in the tumultuous cries.

In a rollicking northwest breeze that snapped off the mainmast of E.C. Henderson's big sloop Cymbra and forced the smaller boats to sail under reefed mainsails, the Riverside Yacht Club's Fall regatta yesterday afternoon brought the yacht-racing season on Long Island Sound to a stirring close.

Manifestoes are being showered out upon the constituencies and the press in quite a bewlldering manner. Varied as is their phraseology, they may be summed up by the classification of Khaki and anti-Khaki.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 22 -- William J. Bryan to-day continued his canvass of the First Congressional District in this State. He started out early in a motor vehicle, intending to make three speeches before returning to Lincoln late to-night.

The Mallory Line steamship Alamo, which came so near being destroyed by the West Indian hurricane that destroyed Galveston on Sept. 8, arrived in port yesterday. Every one on board, from the Captain down to the cabin boy, had a story to tell concerning what he experienced, what he saw, and how he felt during the great storm.

Several features have combined to make the yachting season of 1900 memorable, and not the least of these is the unusual number of participants in the sport. Such additions to the racing fleet as the "seventies," the imported cutters Hester, Astrild, and Isolde, and the new fifty-ones have all along been prominent in the eyes of yachtsmen, but they have by no means been the only new-comers this season.

The announcements we published yesterday of the intentions of the two great German steamship lines are calculated to make British shipowners still more anxious. The one consoling feature of them is that the colossal new boat to be built for the Hamburg-American Line is to be built in a British dock yard.

In "The Belle of Bohemia," at the Casino to-morrow night, Sam Bernard will appear as a wandering photographer named Klotz, while his brother, Dick, will be a brewer named Dinkelhauser. Virginia Earl, returning to skirts, will be Katie, wife of the photographer, who sings on the stage under the name of Clarisse, and is the belle of all Bohemia.
What Lieut. HOBSON said and what Lieut. HOBSON was reported as saying about the condition of the sunken Spanish ships in Manila Bay are, of course, two very different things.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept 22. -- Sixty four bodies were recovered to-day, fourteen being taken from one building at Twenty-second and Beach Streets. With the exception of the abolishment of the temporary hospital which was established in the United States Custom House directly after the storm, there were no developments in the health situation to-day.

Now comes at Newport that season of the year which older residents and visitors there who know it vastly prefer to the more lively weeks of the social season proper. With the departure of the gayer birds of fashion, the more conservative set comes to the front and proceeds to enjoy itself.

Edward Fitz Gerald, one of the wisest and kindliest of men, who had been a lover of the stage and a student of the drama, accounted the Hamlet of Henry Irving a valueless and tiresome performance. But Horace Walpole, whose counterfeit presentment appears briefly in the new romantic piece at the Empire Theatre, thought the great Garrick a poor actor, a mere mimic, and "nothing wonderful."

CAMBRIDGE, Sept. 22 -- Harvard's first week of football practice has been characterized by two encouraging features. In the first place an unusually large number of candidates have appeared on Soldiers' Field, so that on Thursday, the fourth day of practice, Capt. Daly could count seventy vigorous players jogging in his wake.

SPOKANE, Washington, Sept. 22 -- Single-handed, a masked man robbed the westbound passenger train on the Northern Pacific at 1 o'clock this morning and succeeded in setting away with about $500 in cash, several watches, and a quantity of jewelry. The robbery occurred after the train left Athol, Idaho, and the lone robber left the train at Rathdrum.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your workingman correspondent, A.M. Baugh, has a grievance against Gov. Roosevelt. It is a double-barreled grievance. In the first place, he thinks the Governor has too much money; in the second place, he objects to the praise of workingmen by this "pampered son of wealth," who is "rather too patronizing."

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the time passes by and the Presidential arguments are discussed pro and contra in essays, speeches, and articles, I am surprised to find such a lack of logic on the part of thoughtful people, even of prominent men of National reputation, that sometimes I am tempted to doubt my own judgment, which, if you will allow me the space, I wish to submit to your readers.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 22 -- The Republican Registers, acting under instructions from the State Committee and the advice of counsel, refuse to recognize Dr. Del Valle and his son of Porto Rico as citizens of the United States, notwithstanding the decision of the Board of Election Supervisors that they are citizens and entitled to vote.

The regular monthly meeting of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was held yesterday at the Grand Central Station. F.W. Cheney of South Manchester, Conn., was elected a Director to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Henry C. Robinson of Hartford, Conn., which occurred on Feb. 14 last.

A NEW INTERLOCKING SWITCH. -- Up to the present there have been two general methods for operating railroad switches from a central tower. The most common and oldest of these is by means of manual levers in the tower, mechanically connected to the track switch by a system of rods, chains, or wires.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The theory of our institutions is that the rule of action, public and private, is found in the reason and conscience of the individual and the community. This applies in civil, social, financial, religious, political, and all other affairs of men. How does submission to a "boss" or the actions of a Croker, or a Platt, or Bryan's actions and proposals answer to this test?

Col. Joseph H. Wood, Grand Marshal of the Grand Army parade during the recent National Encampment in Chicago, died of angina pectoris Friday night at his residence, 721 West Adams Street, that city. Col. Wood retired an hour before death apparently in perfect health. At 11:30 o'clock his wife noticed that he was breathing heavily.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The controversy on the relative merits of the British and American baggage systems has been revived by the complaints of transatlantic visitors who have lost trunks in England. These, in turn, have called forth protests against the adoption of the check system.

John Farreli, five years old, who lived on Prospect Place, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, was run over and fatally injured y a motor car of the Brighton Beach line early last evening in the railroad "cut at Prospect Place, several hundred feet west of Franklin Avenue. The boy died soon after he had been taken to the Memorial Hospital.

The Republican campaign in Kings County was formally opened last night, when a mass meeting was held in each of the twenty-one Assembly districts in the county. All of the meetings were well attended and much enthusiasm was shown.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- The astronomical observatory of Harvard College is about to establish a station in the Island of Jamaica, W. I. Members of the staff of the observatory are now engaged in packing the instruments and preparing for speedy departure.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 22. -- As the result of collections held in the various Catholic churches in the State last Sunday Bishop Michael Tierney of the Hartford Diocese has sent a check of $5,000 to Bishop Gallagher of Galveston, to be added to the Galveston relief fund.

About $1,500 was realized for the Galveston Relief Fund from the New York Road Drivers' Association matinee at the Empire City track yesterday afternoon. Such was the announcement of Secretary Reeves. By dint pf much energetic canvassing among local reinsmen, in a short space of time an attractive programme was prepared for the charity races.

A series of special matches between B. B. Crowninshield's raceahout Jolly Roger, the swiftest boat of her class in Massachusetts waters, and Johnston De Forest's Scamp, winner this year of the Long Island Sound championship, will be sailed this week under the direction of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club for a special cup offered by Rear Commodore Alfred Peats.

WALLA WALLA, Washington, Sept. 22 -- At a meeting of Trustees and stockholders of the Washington and Columbia River Railroad the following new officers were elected: President -- Charles S. Mellen; Vice President -- Joseph McCabe; Secretary -- George N. Earle; Chief Engineer -- J.G. Cutler; Assistant Secretary -- R.H. Relf; Treasurer -- J.G. Cutler; Assistant Auditor -- Rowland Smith.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. One of the national delicacies of Northern Russia is "tresca," an appalling dish, consisting of codfish caught the previous Summer, and eaten in an advanced stage of decomposition; its odor alone is beyond words, its taste the writer fortunately does not know.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22--The first official announcement that Gen. Chaffee will soon withdraw from China came not from the War or State Department, but from the Navy Department. It was in the shape of an order largely increasing Admiral Remey's squadron, in view of the "possible withdrawal" of the American troops.

Trading on the curb yesterday was so limited in amount that very little interest was taken in the day's business. Only a few issues showed transactions amounting to as much as three or four hundred shares, and most stocks, even among those which during the week had shown some activity, gave evidence of the extreme dullness of the market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In deciding to support Mr. Stanchfield for the office of Governor, have you not overlooked one view of the situation? Mr. Stanchfield stands on the Kansas City platform, and in his speeches Advocates the election of Bryan. In doing this he is either sincere and horest or he is not.

There was another outbreak between the White men and the negroes last night near Thirty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, and for a couple of hours things were lively in that section. It became necessary to order out the police reserves of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station. Several arrests were made.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 22 -- At the end of the first week of the miners' strike the directors of the movement are gratified to know that nearly 80 per cent. of the miners of the Lehigh district and a large percentage of the miners in other districts are idle and determined not to work until the operators signify their willingness to consider the bill of grievances presented to them as the ground for the strike.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22 -- It can be stated on the authority of a close friend of Richard Sheldon, the noted shot putter, that Sheldon will enter Yale in the class of 1902 this Fall, and will try for the Yale football team. Capt. Brown and all of the Yale officials say that they know nothing about the matter, but all of Sheldon's friends here are certain of the truth of the rumor.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Not merely has the biggest banquet known to history passed off to-day in Paris without a serious hitch; but a political fact of the greatest importance has been demonstrated thereby.

Copyright, 1900, The Associated Press. LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The political campaign has begun in earnest. Only another week remains before the polling begins. Hardly any one doubts that the Conservatives will win.

The chorus girls in popular productions in New York have learned a new way of adding to their incomes this past year, and incidentally it may be noticed that a big New York millinery publication has been showing its illustrations of hats with the heads of pretty and attractive girls inside them.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- George W. Williams, the negro who shot his wife on Aug. 23 at their home in Summit Place, this city, attempted suicide by hanging himself in Police Headquarters to-day. He was discovered and was cut down in time to save his life.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 18. -- Yellow fever is more prevalent this year than it was last year or the year before; in fact, it may almost be said to be epidemic. The death rate, however, is small, comparatively, 30 per cent, or less, against 50 per cent, in other years. During the month of August there were only 40 deaths from this fever out of 254 patients.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 22 -- Gov. Russell has before him an application for pardon that is not only of great interest throughout this State, but is also Nationaly in character because of the man for whom pardon is asked, his relatives, and friends. The name of the applicant is Waightstill Avery Anderson.

BRANFORD, Conn., Sept. 22 -- Capt. "Tom" Simons, the brilliant full back of last year's Columbia team, and the best man Sanford has had with him the past two weeks, left the team this morning for good. He has resigned his position as Captain of the team, has withdrawn from college, and will go into business this Fall.
A new advantage of the coaster brake has been discovered -- that it makes easier the cleaning and lubricating of the chain.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept, 22. -- The annual championship games of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Association held on the M.A.A.A. grounds here this afternoon again saw the New York contingent carry oft the bulk of the honors. Out of the twelve events in the programme they carried off eight championships, Long won the sprints handily, and the longer distances were just as easy for Grant.

Caves, especially deep and extended ones, and those affording opportunities for adventure, are interesting to everybody; many a person considers it prominent events in his life to have visited the famous Mammoth and Luray Caves.

Yerkes's London railroad deal, the purchase of the franchise of the Charing Cross, Euston and Hampstead Underground Railroad, creates considerable interest. He is said to be paying u100,000 for the rights, which gives the promoters a handsome profit.

Not less than 2,000 people crowded into the great tent at Camp McKinley, the Republican stronghold, at Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, last evening to hear Judge Charles A. Gardiner speak on "Constitutional Problems Involved in the Republican Policy of Expansion."

Mrs. Sadie Morrison, nineteen years old, of 652 East One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street, was admitted to the Harlem Hospital last night to be treated for dementia. It was the last act in a little domestic drama which had many tragic elements.

The steamship Deutschland of the Hamburg-American Line fleet, which was abreast of Cherbourg at 6:40 P.M. on Sept. 15, arrived at Sandy Hook yesterday at 2:13 P.M. She was behind her records, as her passage occupied 6 days and 33 minutes, against 5 days, 12 hours, 20 minutes, her best western trip, and 5 days, 7 hours, 38 minutes, her best eastern trip.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Money was in fair demand during the week, but borrowings from the bank were not fully repaid. Discounts hardened on the withdrawals of gold for Germany and expectations of additional withdrawals for the same destination. There was an indisposition to do business on any terms early in the week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Harry Elkes won the second of his series of three races with "Johnny" Nelson at Charles River Park to-night, breaking all records up to fifty miles. Elkes rode 36 miles 826 yards in one hour, and finished eight and one-half laps in the lead. He covered the fifty miles in 1:22:22 2-5.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. When service commences in our mediaeval church we should notice a to us curious fact. The parish churches of the Middle Ages had, as doubtless our own observation has taught us, no vestry, and the chasuble was laid on the north side of the altar and put on in sight of the people.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept 22 -- This afternoon's football practice was decidedly the dost interesting of the week to the players and to the big crowd of spectators. Instead of spending the whole practice hour to the usual work of running, punting, and falling on the ball, Capt. Pell chose two elevens from the large number of candidates, and the two squads were drilled separately in formations and signals.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Sept. 22 -- The Republican campaign was opened here to-night with an address by George D. Meiklejohn, Assistant Secretary of "War. Mr. Meiklejohn was accompanied on the stage by E.D. Dietrich, candidate for Governor, and other candidates on the State ticket.

It was very good tea and she had paid a good price for it. She is a connoisseur in teas and will drink none but the best. But there was a flavor to this which did not exactly please her and she decided to give it to some other tea lover less fastidious. So starting out one day on a charitable errand she took with her the package of tea.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 22 -- Except the strikers themselves, everybody in the Shenandoah region seems pleased that Gov. Stone respected the wishes of the business men and ordered the troops to go there. The deputies and local police could not cope with 1,500 strikers.

Delightful weather, well-balanced fields, and a fast track made the conditions for the racing at Gravesend yesterday that drew a large half-holiday attendance. The sport was spirited from beginning to end, but the results were just a little bewildering and opposed to old-fashioned ideas of public form.

Great clouds of black smoke rolled from the towering twin chimneys of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company's plant, at Duane and Elm Streets, all day yesterday, and, drifting off to the east, gradually settled down in the streets of the crowded tenement district and grave the residents a foretaste of what they may expect should the great anthracite strige compel manufacturers generally to use bituminous coal in the region in which they live.

The Pequot and Fort Griswold Hotels, at New London, Conn., were placed in the hands or a receiver yesterday, upon application made by Well, Wolf Kramer of New York to Chancellor Magie, in the Chancery Court, in Jersey City. The application was made in New Jersey because Blanchard, Hager Co., who operate the hotels and thirty-five adjoining cottages, are a New Jersey corporation.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Although seven weeks have elapsed since young Holbrook Mann, the son of the Rev. Charles H. Mann of this city, was taken from the water at Bailey's Beach, Me., senseless and helpless, and the surgeons said his neck was broken, the young man continues to live, and, to the astonishment of surgeons, is apparently not failing in the least.

Ticket speculators will not be tolerated at the New York Theatre if the management can find any way of circumventing them, and the struggle begun at the roof garden late in the Summer and which resulted in the arrest of one of the speculators will be resumed on the opening of the Winter season to-morrow night with redoubled vigor.

A good deal of thinking must nave been done in Washington last week to enable the State Department to clear up so many vexatious matters in the Chinese situation in a series of notes so brief and yet so comprehensive and, on the whole, so satisfactory.

That gas in places where it does not belong is a danger to be reckoned with by dwellers in cities, and perhaps to a greater extent in New York than elsewhere, the public learns slowly. This is due, no doubt, to the fact that the discipline of the gas companies is absolute, and that all connected with the business are extremely discreet.

Two men at outs with life shot themselves in Central Park about the same hour yesterday morning, both on the east side, near Fifth Avenue, although the spots they chose were separated by over a mile. One man is dead in the Presbyterian Hospital, and the other is in Bellevue, and will be made by the doctors to cheat death for the time being.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- To-morrow for the first time this season Yale's football players will enter a scrimmage if Capt. Brown and Trainer Murphy adhere to their announcement. The policy in force has been to work the men very gradually up to the work cut out for them.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 23. -- The Secretary of Yale University has authorized several important announcements of new professorships to be occupied by their incumbents at the opening of the university term this week. The announcement is made that David J. Brewer, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, has accepted the lectureship on the "Responsibilities of Citizenship" on the Dodge foundation.

Francis Gouldy, an old-time New York merchant, died at Newburg on Saturday night, aged eighty-eight years. He was born in England on April 19, 1812, his father being a warm friend and associate minister of John Wesley. When the boy was seven years of age the family removed to New York, where the father died soon after.
MANILA, Sept. 23. -- Documents captured in Manila show that the insurgent activity in this vicinity was ordered by rebels here, following instructions from the Hongkong Junta.

Detectives Byrnes and Buckeridge of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station last night arrested Frank Farrell, alias Hogan, Ryan, Murphy, McGuire, McCarthy, and Tobin, of Jersey City. They say he is one of the cleverest of boarding house thieves, and that the police of this and other cities have been looking for him for ten months.
William A. Clark of Montana says that many of the far Western States will give their Electoral votes to McKinley and Roosevelt. Talking with a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday, he said:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 23. -- An entire family, consisting of man, wife, and daughter, living in Beaufort County, in the heart of the "Black District," has been exterminated by Joseph Small, a negro. The tragedy occurred in an out-of-the-way county, and the meagre information received is contained in a report made to the Governor to-day by white citizens.

Foreign Correspondence NEW YORK TIMES. PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Paris is still hoping that the Czar of Russia may, after all, be induced to visit the exposition, and diplomatic negotiations have also, it is said, been made to the, German Emperor and the Prince of Wales, the visit of any one of whom would be a boon to hotel keepers and tradesmen.

RAWLINS, Wyoming, Sept. 23. -- Gov. Roosevelt had a good rest to-day. At the conclusion of the meeting at Rock Springs last night his train pulled out on what is called "O'Neill's Spur," where it remained during the night and to-day, remote from town and city. The train rested near Daly's Ranch, and the party, numbering thirty or more, was entertained at the ranch with a game dinner.

The Reading Company's representatives in the Schuylkill region asserted positively yesterday that they would attempt to reopen twenty-five mines to-day. They expressed confidence that a large number of men would return to work.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23. -- The conference committees of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers and of the manufacturers at 6:30 o'clock this morning signed the wage scale that will be effective until July, 1901.

Over 100 cyclists took part in the individual record century run of the New York State Division of the Century Road Club, which was held over the Merrick Road yesterday. There were no pacemakers, but the riders were all handicapped, the handicap limit being two and a half hours, and their times were taken both at the start and the finish.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Sept 22, total transactions included 1,577,871 shares of stock, $5,457,000 bends, including $24,000 Government and $23,500 State bonds.
BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The Boerse last week experienced exceedingly bad conditions. Heavy falls were reported along the entire list of industrials. Yesterday's prices were the lowest of the year.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 23. -- The strike of the mine workers may be much more complete to-morrow. If it is not it will not be because the strikers and the officers of their organization have not made the most active use of the opportunity that Sunday and a cessation of labor grave to them.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- George W. Williams, the negro who shot his wife at their home, 58 Summit Street, on Aug. 23, and who was traced to Mahwah, in the northern section of New Jersey, where he was arrested last evening, has become a raving maniac or else he is a good fakir.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Gen. Andre, Minister of War, has reported to President Loubet in favor of authorizing Paris and Bazeilles to place the cross of the Legion of Honor in the municipal arms, in recognition of their splendid defense in 1870 against the Germans. Several other French towns enjoy this privilege on account of courageous resistance, and the decision of Gen. Andre is certain to be very popular with Parisians and the army.
SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 23. -- The Rev. Luther Hess Warring, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, and one of the leading divines of this city, preached a strong anti-strike sermon to-night.

There was more in the assault of three colored women on a detective the other night than a casual spectator would imagine. The incident viewed superficially had a distinctly humorous cast. But as out of the mouths of babes and sucklings cometh forth wisdom, so the utterance of the colored woman in the police station contained some pretty substantial philosophy and a deal of suggestion.
"Charles R. Johnson, Bangor, Me.," registered at Jaeger's Hotel, 561 Seventh Avenue, early in September.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 23. -- W.J. Bryan left here for Chicago to-night over the Burlington Railroad. The trip was decided upon suddenly, and will be hurriedly made. The train on which the Presidential candidate travels is due in Chicago to-morrow morning, and it is Mr. Bryan's intention to leave Chicago to-morrow evening on his return trip, reaching Lincoln early Tuesday morning.

The Tammany members of the Central Federated Union who say they have discovered a friend to organized labor in Richard Croker tried at yesterday's meeting to turn nearly everything that was done into political channels. Even Miss S. McConnell, a member of the Red Cross Society, who was granted the privilege of the floor, was the innocent cause of starting the Tammany men on their favorite topic of anti-imperialism.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The growing strength of the time-money market, with increasing demand and a hardening of rates, is in no sense of the word surprising, and but bears put the correctness of the views expressed from time to time in these columns by representative bankers. Higher money rates are more than inevitable; they are at hand.

The residents of the old town of West-field, Richmond Borough, have been alarmed by burglaries during the past three weeks to such an extent that a Vigilance Committee has been organized by the cltizens for the protection of their property.

At St. Leo's Church yesterday morning Father Ducey, after a sermon in which he compared the mistakes of the heart with those of the intellect, greatly to the advantage of the former, said that he supposed that a great many of his hearers were waiting for him to speak of the conditions as he found them in the mining districts of Pennsylvania.

After a voyage notable for the rough seas and high winds that impeded her progress across the Atlantic, the American Line steamship St. Paul, with 1,285 passengers aboard, arrived at her pier yesterday morning.

A barrel of alcohol, which exploded last night in the saloon of Baunsee Weiner, not only destroyed the place and a small restaurant adjoining, but badly damaged two flats over the store in the six-story brick building at Rivington and Clinton Streets, terrified the tenants, and drew a crowd of over 5,000 people, which necessitated calling out the reserves of the Fourteenth Precinct, who had a hard time keeping the crowd within bounds.
LONDON, Sept. 28. -- One of the weekly commentators on financial matters dwells upon America's new role as a money lender, saying:

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Sept. 23. -- Tomorrow will probably witness developments that may constitute a crisis in the strike situation in the Schuylkill region. Last night the operators of the Reading Company's mines declared positively that they would make the attempt to start at least twenty-five of the company's collieries on Monday morning.
Net changes for the week of 1 point or more in the more active securities were:

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Newark will to-morrow obtain possession and control or the large Pequannock water plant built for the city by the East Jersey Water Company, in which the late Vice President Garret A. Hobart was largely interested. The threatened litigation has been practically averted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- A baseball game yesterday afternoon between a team from the Pond Tool Works and another from St. Mary's School wound up with a fight, in which one man was seriously injured. There has been great rivalry between the two teams all Summer, and this was the third game for the championship of the city.

HAZELTON, Penn., Sept. 23. -- Three of the deputies who were sworn in by Sheriff Harvey of Luzerne County, and who are sons of prominent Wilkesbarre people, were arrested fete last night at Freeland on a charce of highway robbery. They are Hamilton Farnham, Van Buren B. Howard, and A.R. Shoemaker, Jr.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23. -- George D'Vys, the last surviving member of the Government relief expedition which rescued Dr. Kane, the American Arctic explorer, in 1855, died here at noon to-day from pneumonia after an illness of four days.
MADRID, Sept. 23. -- Marshal Arsenic Martinez de Campos died this morning, shortly after 10 o'clock, at Zarauz, near San Sebastian.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 23. -- A terrific fight occurred this morning between the police and a crazy negro whom they were attempting to arrest. A negro of gigantic build named Edward Gurley, laboring under the hallucination that he had been called to heaven, cut the throat of his nephew, Oscar Montgomery, in order that he might take him along with him.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- A critical period is approaching in our money market once more. All last week, although short credits were abundant at 3 to 3 1/4 per cent., often less, discount rates kept close to the 4 per cent. bank rate.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 23. -- About midnight last night Miss Gertrude Coddington, aged eighteen years, daughter of Moore Coddington, a miller, of Somerset Street, attempted to commit suicide while walking on that street by swallowing carbolic acid. She then ran to a saloon and called out Archie B. Ellis and Walter Higgins, with whom she was acquainted, and they conveyed her home.

During a fit of insanity, Frederick Schmidt, a cripple, attempted to murder his fourteen-year-old daughter with a hatchet as she lay asleep in her bed early yesterday morning. He struck her one blow with the sharp edge of the weapon which fractured her skull and destroyed her right eye.

A few days ago an electrically propelled street car in the upper part of New York ran over a boy and killed him. The car was running on schedule time down a fairly steep grade, on rails the bearing surfaces of which were polished like silver. The motorman was attending strictly to business.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Boston and New York played a tia same to-day, the game being called at the end of the seventh inning on account of darkness. Heavy batting and poor fielding marked the work of both teams. Attendance, 1,500. The score:

ONEONTA, N.T., Sept. 24. -- The Republican campaign was opened here to-night, when 2,000 persons listened to speeches by Lieut. Gov. "Woodruff and Col. Archie Baxter. Mr. Woodruff made a forcible address. Referring to Mr. Stanohfield's speech on trusts, he said:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- F.C. Henderson's sloop yacht Cymbria put into this harbor dismasted and otherwise a wreck, the result of the wind which prevailed last Saturday while she was participating in the Riverside Yacht Club regatta near the Long Island shore. The yacht will not be put into shape again this season, but will be hauled out at the Robertson yard and laid up for the Winter.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The refusal of the United States to accede to Germany's proposition regarding the Chinese settlement is prominently commented upon by the entire German press. In spite of the previous intimations through Washington cablegrams, the refusal has come as a great surprise.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- William J. Bryan came to Chicago this morning from his home in Lincoln, Neb., held a conference with various members of the Democratic National Committee, and returned to Lincoln this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Navy Department is doing everything in its power to expedite the dispatch of the ships which the Government has decided to send to the Asiatic station to reinforce the American fleet there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a Bryan man this time, although not one in 1896, and I attribute my conversion to the Republicans themselves. I attended the Republican meeting at Fifty-ninth Street last Friday evening, and have attended every meeting held by the Dry Goods Republicans at Leonard Street and Broadway to date, and I have not heard a single whole-hearted argument at any of them.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 25. -- A telephone message received here last night by the Chief of Police from Liano says that San Saba, forty miles north of that place, containing about 1,000 people, was partially swept away by the flood in the San Saba River, which was still rising. All bridges had been carried off.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

"Don't hear so much talk about the horseless age as you did a year or two ago, do you?" asked the proprietor of one of our fashionable hoot stores on upper Broadway yesterday. "Seems as if it was only yesterday that I heard people say that the day of the horse was ended, and, that he would pass into oblivion.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Presbytery of New Brunswick, in session here to-day, by a vote of 16 to 43, defeated the proposition in favor of a revision of the Confession of Faith.

BOONTON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- In St. Mary's Cemetery here there is a monument which tells of the sorrow of his relatives over the death of Edward Boylan. The monument has stood there thirty-two years. It tells that Boylan was twenty-two years of age when he died. On Saturday a gray-haired man stood in front of the monument and read the inscription.

Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell declined last night to speak of a published report alleging the existence of a shortage of $2,000 in the relief fund of the uniformed force, of which Mr. Scannell is Trustee. It is from this found that the beneficiaries of members of the force receive $1,000 insurance on the death of a fireman.

The Executive Committee of the Council of the New York University held its first regular monthly meeting of the coming term at the office of William F. Havemeyer, the Treasurer, at 32 Nassau Street, yesterday and completed arrangements for the opening of the various schools.

Prof. Alfred Stille. Dr. Alfred Stilie, for many years professor of the theory and practice of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, died at his home in Philadelphia yesterday. Dr. Stille was one of the leading physicians in this country, and was also well Known in Europe.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- President Pattern to-day, referring to the reports that a Philadelphia brewer had secured the patent right to use the university seal on casks and whisky barrels, with a view to furnishing university brands of liquors, said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- It has been decided by the Democratic National Committee that Mr. Bryan will make a determined effort to capture the vote of New York State. The matter was settled to-day at the conference at Democratic headquarters in which Mr Bryan participated.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 24. -- Gen. J. Watts De Peyster of Tivoli, whose feud with his son, Col. Johnston L. De Peyster, has been the source of much gossip for several years, to-day had an emissary put a padlock on the village engine house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Surgeon General's office of the War Department has no information regarding the epidemic of yellow fever in Havana, although it is known to exist there to a considerable extent. Private advices from Havana indicate that the yellow fever outbreak is serious.

Could the spirits of Edwin Forrest and The other great actors who trod the stage of the "Old Bowery" Theatre in olden times have visited the once fashionable playhouse last night they would have wondered if their auditorium had been transplanted bodily to the land of the Russian, the Austrian, and the Pole.

Mr. MOORFIELD STOREY of Massachusetts contributes to the "editorial page of The New York Journal" an article opposing Mr. McKINLEY'S election and advocating that of Mr. BRYAN -- a despotic conscience sometimes makes strange bedfellows. Mr. STOREY is a man of ability and of the highest personal and professional character.

SHENANDOAH, Penn. Sept. 24. -- To-day's developments in the Schuylkill coal regions demonstrated that in all probability the strike of the anthracite coal miners will be a long one, and the fight between mine owner and miner a hard one. This is the opinion of conservative men who have not only studied the situation as it is to-day, but who have watched the progress of former strikes in the anthracite regions.

Chief Engineer George W. Birdsall of the Department of Water Supply declared yesterday that the condition of the Water supply in the Boroughs of "Brooklyn and the Bronx was dally becoming more serious, and that he did not know what might happen unless there is a heavy rainfall. He added:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- The great glass tank used in the fourth act of "Lost River," the new play by Joseph Arthur which was to have been put on for the first time to-night, burst this afternoon at rehearsal, and the members of the company who were on the stage escaped instant death only by the most remarkably good fortune.

LONDON, Sept 24. -- The American missionaries J.H. Roberts, Mark Williams, William Sprague, Mrs. Sprague, and Miss Virginia Murdock, who escaped from Kalgan. Province of Chi-Li, China, in June, were chased across the Gobi Desert. Thence they traveled by way of Siberia, and have just reached London in good health.

"The Belle of Bohemia," the new burletta produced in fine style by Mr. Lederer at the Casino last night, is not quite so "spicy" and "Tenderloiny" as some of its predecessors, but it is full of easily appreciated fun and simple melody, and ought to be very profitable. Harry B. Smith wrote it and Ludwig Englander composed the music.

Policeman Herman Ohm of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station and Policeman John J. Cleary of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station appeared before Magistrate Brann in the West Side Court yesterday afternoon to, answer the charge that they had, without cause, brutally beaten negroes In the race riots of last month.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The Paris press has been unduly excited this week by two criminal cases in which members of "the His Lif" figure as criminals -- one a Duchess and the other a Marquis. The nobleman is the Marquis Adolphe de Nantcuilly, of an ancient and honorable family, but the Duchess has thus far managed to keep her name off the police records.

The City Magistrates are about to adopt a plan which they say will be followed in the police courts in the matter of the giving of bonds by irresponsible persons. Professional or straw bondsmen are to be subjected to closer scrutiny than heretofore, and to this end a list of "suspicious'' persons is now being prepared for distribution to all the Magistrates.
HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 24. -- President Mitchell, in discussing the situation in the entire strike region, to-night said:

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 24. -- Threatening Weather cut down the attendance for the first day of the Terre Haute races, but every event was finished, the last heat of the 2:30 pace being raced in semi-darkness. Summaries:

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- A party of twenty persons, comprising the first trolley excursion from Boston to New York, started from Post Office Square at 8:45 o'clock this morning. Robert H. Derrah, the originator of the trip, was in charge. A porter and a matron also accompanied the party.

Imperialism was vigorously assailed last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum, Thirtyfourth Street and Third Avenue, before an audience that filled the house to the doors. Approval of the denunciation of the present attitude of the Republican Administration toward the Philippines was shown by frequent applause.

The law, which went into effect on Sept. 1, requiring all persons doing business in the city to register their full name and address with the County Clerk, has begun to permeate Chinatown, and its effects on the international laundry business and other Celestial enterprises became apparent yesterday.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Because she wanted "to get out of the brush," and was tired of constantly watching "only trees, brooks, rocks, and other natural things," an Ulster County woman has left her husband, a prominent resident of that place, and will hereafter reside with her sons in Brooklyn.

The thirty inhabitants of Whitepot, L.I., were shocked lately to learn that one of their number had been arrested upon his arrival in Germany on suspicion of being an Anarchist detailed to shoot the Kaiser. Whitepot is a settlement adjoining Middle Village. The residents are all Germans who plant potatoes and celery and see that they are kept free from weeds.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Hazleton Boiler Works of East Rutherford, with orders booked ahead for six months and with plenty of work on hand, are idle to-day for lack of coal. Six carloads ordered some time ago have not yet been delivered, and the proprietors can get no assurance of the early delivery of the fuel.

The heavy losses in the market for outside securities last week were followed by further declines yesterday, and, with two or three exceptions, the day's net change were on the side of losses. Only a few Blocks supplied as much trading as a single hundred shares, and there were only three or four issues that were active to the extent or more than 500 shares.

Lenox and Tuxedo are foremost this week in the social interest of out-of-town resorts. The Westchester Horse Show, which begins at White Plains to-morrow, will attract a large Autumn colony, whose members are now occupying their country houses all through Westchester County. The show promises this year to be unusually successful.

The movement of prices on the stock market yesterday was decidedly irregular, with extreme weakness showing in a number of specialties. In the early trading a fair degree of strength developed on short covering and London buying; but when this ceased the quotations generally were inclined to sag.

In response to the request of the Charter Revision Commission for the views of citizens as to the actual working of the present city charter and its need of amendment, the Manufacturers' Association of New York, meeting at 198 Montague Street, Brooklyn, last night adopted the following suggestions, which will be sent to the commission:

NEWBURG, Sept. 24. -- A Republican demonstration was held to-night tn Newburg, the home of B.B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor. After two banners had been raised, the Republican clubs marched to the Academy of Music, where they were addressed by Mr. Odell, Senator Chauncey M. Depew, and John S. Wise.

NEWPORT, Sept. 24. -- The long-talked-of naval manoeuvres off Newport were begun to-night with an attempt of a fleet of warships and torpedo boats to make an entrance to the bay. It is probable this force was unsuccessful, but it will not be known for two or three days, when the Committee of Arbitrament has heard the decisions of the umpire and the protests.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Alexander Raymond, nineteen years old, announced in court to-day that he had two wives. He was arraigned on a charge of embezzlement. Raymond pleaded guilty and was sentenced to thirty days' imprisonment. He said he took the money because his expenses were so heavy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The pressure for currency for moving the crops is beginning to be felt. The issues of gold certificates by the Treasury at various points in the South and West, In exchange for deposits of gold In the New York SubTreasury by banks on behalf of their country correspondents, are already $1,000,000 more than at the same time last year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- The remnant of the Columbia team will go back to New York to-morrow afternoon, so that the little practice done to-day was practically the last of the season. Only a dozen men were here to-day, and all of them were first-year men, except Rogers, who came back from New York this morning.
BROOKINGS, S.D., Sept 24. -- The "Prohibition special" reached here this evening in time for the National candidates to address a rally, after which the train left for Watertown.

A north-bound Third Avenue closed car and a trailer crashed into a wagon of the Henry Elias Brewing Company, filled with empty kegs, at Nineteenth Street and Third Avenue at 5:30 o'clock last evening, when the cars were filled with people. The forward car was demolished, the wagon nearly cut in two, one man was killed, and a dozen men and women were injured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a lifelong Democrat, I have been very much surprised at the statements published in some of the newspapers during the last week to the effect that it is the intention of the Democratic organization in this city to refuse a renomination to those Representatives in the present Congress who supported the "Gold bill" (so called) at the recent session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Viola Alien was well received to-night at the National Theatre as Dona Maria Dolores de Mendoza in "In the Palace of the King." This was practically the opening of Miss Allen's season in Lorimer Stoddard's dramatization of Marion Crawford's novel, and she was greeted by a large and distinguished audience.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The detectives who have been on duty at the Chinese Legation for about two months to-day returned to Headquarters, there being no further necessity, in the judgment of Major Sylvester, Chief of Police, and Mr. Wu, for the presence of detectives at the Minister's residence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Lawyer Daniel Caslim of Yonkers had a narrow escape to-day, in the Westchester County Court, from being sent to the Elmira Reformatory, because District Attorney George C. Andrews did not happen to know him from the prisoner, his client.

There was a lull on the Speedway yesterday after the activity of Sunday. There were a good many fast steppers on the course, but only a few of the amateur drivers were eager to engage In brushes. The liveliest sport took place just before dusk. Dr. John Moore, with his fine big trotter, McMillan, (2:17 1/2,) was among the late arrivals.

Five crates fell from an express wagon in Chambers Street near Broadway yesterday afternoon and exploded. The shock was felt by everybody in and about City Hall Park, and the report drew a crowd which blocked traffic on Broadway for nearly an hour.
Senator M.A. Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, returned to the city yesterday, and in the early evening talked of the political situation.

In the Supreme Court, Special Term, Brooklyn, before Justice D. Cady Herrick, yesterday Lawyer Lehman, of Leventhal Lehman, as counsel for Mrs. Julia M. Mollenhauer, defendant in an action for an absolute divorce brought by her husband, John W. Mollenhauer, applied for alimony for his client for $300 and counsel fee.

Mr. PLATT is doubtless the luckiest politician that ever lived. He has been the boss of a great party in the greatest State of the Union for something like fifteen years. He has never won a victory -- they have all been won for him by forces that he had not the remotest influence in bringing into being and making effective.

JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 24. -- The discovery that State Penitentiary inmates have been included in Joliet's census has caused consternation here. The Government recently announced that Joliet had a population of 30,720.
"If the strike lasts until Saturday the price of anthracite coal will rise from 75 cents to $1 per ton."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- There has been no word from any of the Governments concerning their view of the American position in regard to China, and it is expected that some days will elapse before any new move is made.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The first line-up and scrimmage of the season on University Field took place this afternoon. Most of the candidates who have been out on previous days were on the field in football toggery, but only the twenty-two chosen ones and their substitutes got more than the usual round of general practice.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24. -- The football practice at Harvard was brightened to-day by the unexpected return to college of E.H. Kendall, half back last year. He is in fine physical condition. Another man who came out to-day is Roberts, from Salem High School. He weighs 275 pounds, and will be drilled for centre rush.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 24. -- The strike of the coal miners is not yet complete in the Lehigh region, which President Mitchell of the Mine Workers' Union is most anxious to announce as no longer a source of the anthracite coal supply. But it has extended to-day slightly here at Hazleton, and it may include to-morrow a greater number of men than on any day since the strike began, a week ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Dullness was the feature of the market. Biscuit and Linseed were sold at recent figures. Metropolitan Elevated preferred opened at 82, sold up 1/8, and closed at 81 7/8.

Mrs. Madeline Miller, the young woman who about a year ago brought suit against Dr. Barnes of the Barnes Sanitarium, Stamford, for $50,000, claiming she had been imprisoned in the place and had escaped by jumping from a second-story window, tried to kill herself last night at her home, 113 West Fifteenth Street, by drinking carbolic acid.
The subscription funds for the relief of the sufferers in Galveston showed an increase yesterday of $1,589.50, making a grand total raised here of $290,690.13.

The officers of "the Hungarian Holy Crown" are more candid than the advocates of our own system of "protection." We have received from the Austro-Hungarian Consul General's office in this city an interesting pamphlet the title of which is: XLIX. Act of 1899 and Instruction About Favors Granted to Native Industrial Undertakings in the Countries of the Hungarian Holy Crown."

The following letter on the political situation, written by Abram S. Hewitt to Marcus Schnitzer, editor and publisher of the Oesterreichisch-Ungarische Zeitung (Austro-Hungarian Gazette) of this city, appears in to-day's issue of that paper:

James F.D. Lanier's place at Westbury, L.I., a residence and a tract of about sixty-five acres, has been sold to Hamilton W. Cary, for about $100,000, through Brokers Smith Stewart. This property is in the Meadow Brook colony, and was at one time occupied by William C. Whitney for a year, and subsequently by Clarence W. Mackay for two years.
CAPE TOWN, Sept. 25. -- A large number of guns, mostly damaged, have been found along the Crocodile River, especially near Hectorspruit.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The first touch-down of the year was made on University Field this afternoon by Humbird, the youngster who used to win prizes for Lawrenceville Preparatory School as a sprinter. Humbird, despite his small stature, was the most conspicuous person on the field to-day.

The use of electricity in the cure of consumption was one of the principal topics discussed before the American Electro-Therapeutic Association, which held the opening session of its tenth annual conference yesterday at the Academy of Medicine. Dr. Walter H. White of Boston, President of the association, was in the chair.

The full pamphlet report of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, which was made public yesterday, the figures of the income account having been given out a few days ago, contains information of the company's operations during the year ending June 30, 1900, the fourth year since the reorganization of the company.
LONDON, Sept 26. -- The news from China this morning indicates that events are rapidly drifting in the direction of war between China and Germany.

The subscription funds for the relief of the sufferers in Galveston showed an increase yesterday of $7,681.18, making a grand total of $298,371.31. This includes $6,444.72 added to the Chamber of Commerce Fund through Oelrichs Co. by the committee formed in Bremen at the instance of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, and with the co-operation of the Bremen Chamber of Commerce and the Bremen Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Census Bureau announces that the population of Rockford, Ill., is 31,051, as against 23,584 in 1890, an increase of 7,467, or 31.66 per cent.
