Mrs. Angelina Vergella, who lives on the top floor of a tenement house at 80 Chrystie Street, rescued from possible suffocation yesterday morning three little children who had been abandoned in the tenement. The children, the eldest of whom is six years, had been shut in a little room in the rear of the top floor with an open gas jet.

READVILLE, Mass., Sept. 25, -- With some fine trotting events on the track and a lot of finely-bred horseflesh shown in the tanbark ring, the second day of the New England Trotting Horse Breeders Association meet at Readville was full of interest. The entries to-day in the prize exhibits were larger and the contests for blue ribbons were much keener than yesterday.

The bay gelding Tiverton, (2:21 1/4,) who made his record at the Empire City track a short while ago, was one of the most successful performers on the Speedway yesterday afternoon. Among the horses that Tiverton defeated yesterday was the pacer James C., driven by James N. Campbell.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Administration is taking steps to counteract the effect of the flood of stories about, looting, robbery, and massacres of Filipinos by American soldiers, which have been coming in from soldiers and sailors in private letters. Ever since the Philippine war began newspapers have printed soldiers' letters describing cases of loot and pillage, which have been made use of by opponents of the Administration.

Lieut. Richmond Pearson Hobson, who arrived in this city from Yokohama, via Vancouver, Monday night, reported for duty to Rear Admiral Albert S. Barker, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, yesterday shortly before noon. He then reported to Capt. Bowles and left the yard for Washington.

NEWPORT, Sept. 25. -- The second and last stage of the naval manoeuvres conducted this evening apparently resulted in a great victory for the torpedo boats. With the perfect weather that prevailed the small boats were brilliantly handled about the harbor, bay, and at sea. The handling of the searchlights was a feature of the mimic battle.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 25. -- For six years Alix has held the world's trotting record against time at 2:03 3/4.

Sheriff Harvey of Luzerne County, Penn., has asked Gov. Stone to send troops to Hazleton and its vicinity. The Sheriff says he is no longer able to control the situation, and is backed up in his request by private citizens.

Senator Hanna spoke on the edge of the Bowery last night -- in Cooper Union -- to an audience that packed every available inch of sitting and standing room in the large ball. Senator Hanna was the magnet that drew this immense crowd, although the announcement that he was to speak was made late in the afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Charles A. Gardiner, in his address delivered at Camp McKinley last Saturday night, should at least be given credit for expressing the sentiments of the Republican Party openly and fearlessly. In fact, if a few more were to follow his example, I think McKinley's chances of re-election would be greatly decreased and Bryan would occupy the White House for the coming four years.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Bright, pleasant weather greeted the first day of the annual Fall exhibition of the Agricultural Society. Many residents of the Wheatly Hills section of Long Island came over to the fair in automobiles, only to find that the horseless vehicles were barred from the grounds.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Sugar monopolized interest in the market to-day, save for some attention bestowed on Federal Steel. In home specialties business thinned out to a very small total. In the first half of the day only about 1,250 shares of mining stocks changed hands. There was a fair business in Atchison bonds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Yesterday (Sunday, Sept. 23) there were over 4,000 pushcarts besides hundreds of horse wagons doing business on our streets and sidewalks during the entire day. The noise, confusion, and disorder were indescribable. The whole thing was contrary to law, and the police had been asked to enforce the law, which they promised to do, but failed to do.

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 25. -- A memorial window has been placed in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church here by James H. Hyde and Caleb Hyde to the memory of their father, Henry Baldwin Hyde, who was President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The window has been placed over the door on the north side of the church, near the chancel. The inscription reads:

WASHINGTON, Sept 25. -- The United States Government to-day took the first step toward the redemption of its pledge made to the Russian Government Aug. 28 last by cabling orders to Gen. Chaffee to reduce the American forces in China to the proportions of a legation guard. The text of the order to Gen. Chaffee is as follows:

DENVER, Col., Sept. 25. -- The heavy special train of Gov. Roosevelt's party, to which was added to-day the private car of Senator Wolcott, accompanied by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge and Mrs. Lodge of Massachusetts, arrived in Denver at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

When the Ice Trust raised the price of ice last spring to 60 cents a hundred, they explained to the people that the reason for it was the scarcity of the ice crop in Maine. Maine dealers said there was no such thing as a scarcity, so far as they had heard, and the trust went to a great deal of trouble to deny those statements.

BOSTON, Sept 25. -- Mercer and Carrick had a bad inning in each game of baseball of the two-game series here to-day, enabling Boston to take both handily. Nichols and Lewis were very effective. Tenney played a fine game on first, accepting twenty-eight chances without a misplay. The scores:

Unexpected happenings gave to the racing at the Gravesend track yesterday a not altogether agreeable spice. One event in particular, the coming to life of Lieber Karl, who, backed by his stable, showed sudden and startling improvement, and won the only stake on the card, and in doing it made a new track record, caused much unpleasant comment.

A piece of stone weighing about ten pounds, sent up by a blast near the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street on Monday afternoon, was hurled through the drawing room window of the residence of George Vanderbilt, across Fifth Avenue on the northwest corner. The missile, in crashing through the heavy plate glass, broke into two sections and strewed the floor of the room with rare bric-a-brac and valuable statuary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Isthmian Canal Commission stated to-day that it would be able to submit a report to Congress sufficiently comprehensive to serve as a basis for the action of that body at the approaching session if it should be desirable to act.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- The police are completely at sea concerning the mysterious death of Mrs. Eva Boss. She was found dying in the flat of Dr. Thomas A. Wallace, who, Himself was brought back to life with difficulty. Mrs. Boss, who was only eighteen years old, died at 1 o'clock this morning.

The Municipal Assembly was spurred to action yesterday by mandamus proceeding's brought in the courts to compel the Councilmen and Aldermen to approve the issue of bonds for municipal improvements. The result was that the sessions yesterday were the liveliest held in a year and bond issues amounting to over $5,000,000 were passed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Gen. MacArthur announces in a cable message from Manila that First Lieut. Francis K. Meade, Twenty-first Infantry, died Sept. 22 of typhoid fever. Lieut. Meade entered the West Point Academy June 20, 1894, having been appointed from Virginia, his native State.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- Superintendent of Insurance Hendrieks to-day made public the following statement concerning the Traders' Fire Insurance Company of New York:

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Cash, or checks as good as cash, is what over 100 business men acting as members of committees are after in the various lines of trade in Chicago this week; they want the cash for the National Republican Committee. The committees in the different mercantile branches were appointed by National Committeeman Stewart soon after the mysterious Union League Club luncheon given by Senator Hanna ten days ago.

There appears to be a general disposition to overrate the importance of the war game now playing at Newport. To describe the operations as "naval manoeuvres" may be sufficiently correct, but it conveys to the average mind the idea of attack and defense carried out on the scale of the naval manoeuvres of the British fleet in and around the home ports.
JEDDO, Penn., Sept. 25. -- G.B. Markle Co. to-day replied to the bill of grievances presented by their employes. The reply is in part as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The all-aged selling race at the opening of the Newmarket first October meeting yesterday, was won by "Danny" Maher, on London. Tod Sloan was second, on Joe Ullman, and Lester Reiff third, on Chonkina. In this race the first five horses were ridden by American jockeys.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania's gridiron warriors for the first time this season lined up against one another in actual combat to-day on Franklin Field without a score by either side. The first scrimmage was not scheduled to occur until to-morrow, but Coach Woodruff decided that it was time to begin, and from now the struggle of 'Varsity against scrub is on.

The report of Superintendent Snyder of the Jersey City public schools for the year which ended in June shows that the enrollment of 1899 was 33,978; 1898, 33,860, and 1897, 30,561. The average attendance in 1899 was 21,895 and in 1898, 21,511. The burning of School No. 20 made a large increase in the attendance impossible.

The excavations for the rapid transit subway on Elm Street, between Bleecker and Crosby Streets, which have been practically deserted by workmen for the past three weeks, were a scene of activity yesterday. Large gangs of workmen were hard at work all day in the excavations, and from now on the work there will be pushed with all possible speed.

The many rumors that charges were to be preferred against Capt. James D. Clifford of Hook and Ladder Company No. 18 in Attorney Street, were confirmed yesterday when Chief Croker announced that orders had been given to prepare the charges against him. In a general way the charges will be insubordination and violation of the rules of the department in belonging to a political organization.

BERLIN, Sept 25. -- The firm of Hohner Co., in Trossingen, Wurtemberg, has sent 6,000 French harps to the German troops in China. The instruments bear Prince Bismarck's motto, "We Germans fear God and nothing else in the world."
E.R. Reynolds, manager and financial backer, and Bandmaster John Philip Sousa have decided to part company, after being associated for the past four years.

Advancing quotations were quite generally the rule in the stock market yesterday. The improvement, however, was not substantial enough to warrant the belief that it was to be permanent, for the purchases that brought about the higher prices did not represent any new interests in the market or investment buying, but solely a short covering movement.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 25. -- As far as the Schuylkill coal regions are concerned the attention of the strike leaders is now directed principally to the colleries in the part of the county south of Broad Mountain. Many of the mines of that district are close to this city, and it is these collieries that produced yesterday and today most of the coal mined in the Schulykill regions.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 25. -- For some days there has been a persistent rumor that the coal operators are preparing to make some concessions to the miners, including a readjustment of the powder question. But the concessions, it was stated, would not be made until the men have returned to work, and for that reason it was exceedingly difficult to secure any authentic information upon the question.

Sam Bernard is "featured," to use the technical phrase, on the house bill at the Casino, in company with his brother, Richard, now newly risen to prominence, and Virginia Earl, who is as comely and graceful as she used to be in the musical comedies at Daly's and sings in the same old way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Senator Albert J. Beveridge of Indiana was the chief speaker at a Republican mass meeting to-night in the Auditorium under the auspices of the Marquette Club. There was a great desire to hear the Senator, and early in the day all the admission tickets that had been prepared had been given away.

With the coming to New York of Columbia's football squad real football practice will begin to-day on the old field across from the college. The squad left Branford Point, where preliminary work started on Sept. 10, yesterday early in the afternoon, and arrived at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street shortly after 4 o'clock.

William Marsh Rice, a retired capitalist eighty-four years old, died at his home, 500 Madison Avenue, on Sunday night. His body was to have been cremated yesterday morning, but instead after funeral services had been held at the house by one of the Rev. Dr. Morgan's assistants from the Church of the Heavenly Rest it was taken to the Morgue and an autopsy was performed by Coroner's Physician Donlin at the direction of Coroner Hart.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Sept 25. -- A movement is on foot to hold a meeting of Senandoah citizens to ask Gov. Stone to withdraw the troops. They will pledge themselves to preserve order with the departure of the soldiers. Then, they believe, some of the men will go back to work.

The Republican women held the second of their mass meetings for women at 737 Broadway last night at 6:15. Their idea in holding the evening meetings at this hour is that they may attract the business women on their way home. They were not entirely successful last night, because the women did not understand or were not prepared to stop, but there was an enthusiastic meeting.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- It transpired to-day that little Marguerite Upton, eight years old, who was shot in the arm last Wednesday and is now a patient at the general hospital, kept a secret six days in order to shield her cousin.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Supporters of McKinley, Roosevelt, and sound money gathered at this place to the number of at least 1,500 to-night to take part in an open-air ratification and banner raising held on Bernardsville Mountain under the auspices of the Bernardsville Township Republican Club.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 25. -- J. H. Taylor played the best ball of August Schultz of the Brooklawn Country Club and A. Gourlie of the Hillensdale Club at the links of the Brooklawn Country Club to-day, and won by 9 up. He broke the record of the course for nine holes going out, making it in 34.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill opened his campaign work with a speech in the Lyceum Theatre here to-night. He and John B. Stanchfield. Democratic candidate for Governor, were escorted to the theatre by the John B. Stanchfield Club, led by a band of musicians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your paper of this date contains a cable dispatch, of a column's length, from the Philippine Commission to the Secretary of War. This appears, from your preliminary statement, to have been sent in this expensive way for political campaign purposes; and I would be glad to know the probable cost of such a cablegram, and if you approve of spending public money for such purposes.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 25. -- If the request of Sheriff Harvey of Luzerne County to the Governor of Pennsylvania is granted, Gen. Gobin may to-morrow move troops into this place and neighborhood to command the situation that Mr. Harvey has declared he is no longer able to control.

The Democratic campaign managers have decided upon the details of Mr. Bryan's stumping tour through New York State. The Democratic Presidential candidate will arrive from the West on the morning of Oct. 16. He will be received by the Tammany Hall Reception Committee. A handshaking reception will probably be held during the afternoon at the Hoffman House or at the Democratic Club.
LONDON, Sept 25. -- Lord Salisbury has replied to the German note in terms identical with those of the United States reply.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 25. -- Gen. John M. Palmer died at his residence here at 8 A.M. to-day.
BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- Alarming news from China has reached the German Government, but it will not be published now, as Germany intends to use it during the conferences in Peking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In money matters, as in religion, faith is a leading essential. The impairment of confidence by the agitation of the money question, the destruction of faith in the future business prosperity of the land through the demands of Mr. Bryan for free silver, constitute the most serious feature of the situation which confronts the country.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- A high official of the German Foreign Office denies that Lord Salisbury has informed Count von Hatzfeldt-Wildenburg, the German Ambassador to Great Britain, that the reply of the British Government to the German note would agree with that of the United States. The official said:
FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The Presbytery of Monmouth has declared against revision.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 26. -- James B. Howard, charged with being a principal in the assassination of William Goebel, was found guilty to-day, the jury fixing his punishment as death.

The first trolley ride between Boston and this city which has ever been enjoyed by any large party was completed yesterday by a number of Boston people. The party started from the Post Office Square in Boston at 8:45 o'clock on Monday morning, arriving at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, Manhattan, at 5 o'clock yesterday evening.

This is an up-to-date story, a companion to the old one of the excellently well painted fly on the painting which, as the critics criticised, quietly flew away. This is not a painting, but one of the fly pins which vendors have been selling on the streets since the middle of the Summer for five cents each.

"Newspaper scribblers do not fully comprehend the trouble they sometimes make for staid and reputable citizens," remarked the man from Harlem with a grievance. "One of the city papers a short time ago published an item to the effect that certain sorts of nervous headaches were due to the fact that women did not properly attend to respiration.
WASHINGTON, Sept 26. -- War between Germany and China is believed late tonight in Washington to toe inevitable, and it may come at any time.

Charles W. Dabb, who for several years has been proprietor of the Leland Hotel in Chicago, has purchased a one-half interest in the lease and furniture of the new Hotel Navarre, at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, from Richard H. Stearns.

The eleventh annual report of the Great Northern Railway Company, which was issued, yesterday, calls attention to the large amount of work done in the way of permanent improvements to the property. The general plan is to give the Great Northern the easiest grades of any transcontinental line. The necessary work will probably require two more years.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Cornell opened the season in football on Percy Field this afternoon, and defeated Colgate by 16 points to nothing. The game was easily won. Although Cornell's team was made up largely of new men, they showed the effects of a week's coaching under Houghton, and rarely had difficulty in graining through the visitors' line or stopping the rushes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit a reader and admirer to express approval of the growth of sweet reasonableness in THE TIMES's treatment of the Chinese difficulty? But where do you find expressed "our intention to hold to strict account every person, of whatever rank or station, who may be proved to have been concerned in the outrages upon foreigners in China"?

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 26. -- News was received in Helena to-day that one of the biggest strikes of fabulously rich ore ever reported in this State was made on Monday in the East Pacific Mine, fifteen miles east of here. The ore runs from $30,000 to $40,000 a ton in gold. Pieces are shown that are at least one-half solid gold.

Senator P.H. McCarren charged last evening that a "corruption fund" of between $20,000,000 and $30,000,000 was being raised by Senator Hanna to buy votes in New York State above the Harlem River and in Indiana and Illinois.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Boston won to-day's baseball game, making it three straight from New York. Thinking the game was clinched. Capt. Davis substituted Matthewson for Seymour in the fifth inning. His wildness, combined with Boston's batting, drove him from the box in the eighth inning.

LONDON, Sept 26. -- At the second day's racing of the Newmarket First October Meeting, to-day, the Great Eastern Railway Handicap was won by Spark H. Water Hen ran second, and Wild Irishman, ridden by Tod Sloan, was third. J.A. Drake's Sir Hercules, on which Lester Reiff had the mount, was confidently backed at 2 to 1 to win.

SOUTH PITTSBURG, Tenn., Sept. 26. -- Two negroes passed through here last night with another colored man, whom they said they were going to hang for an assault on a woman. Officers heard of the affair and followed. To-day they found portions of the negro's clothing in the woods on the bank of the creek.

NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., Sept. 26. -- W. J. Bryan spoke to a large crowd here tonight. The speech had been looked forward to with, much interest, because Mr. Bryan had announced that he would deal with the trust question, as affected by the suit instituted by Attorney General Smyth to annul the sale of the Argo Starch Works of this city to the National Starch Company, popularly known as the Starch Trust.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 26. -- With the close of to-day the strikers in the Schuylkill coal region felt well satisfied with the progress they had made during the past twenty-four hours toward accomplishing a complete tie up of the collieries. More miners had joined their ranks, and the prospects for still more doing so were good.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The State Department has received a note from the legation of Sweden and Norway, dated Washington, Sept. 11, inclosing a copy of the laws and regulations relating to the Nobel bequest. The first award will take place Dec. 10, 1901. The Nobel endowment is based on the will of Dr. Alfred Bernnard Nobel, engineer, drawn up Nov. 27, 1895.

Columbia's football stock took a decided rise yesterday, when thirty stalwart youths, some of whom were veteran players, others novices eager to learn and of the right sort, gathered in the old lot opposite Columbia to enter upon a campaign, of arduous training preparatory to the gridiron battles of the next two months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is highly significant that so few business men have come out in favor of Bryan, and if within your wider range of vision there are more, still there can hardly be too many exceptions to prove the rule of unanimity for McKinley. So far as I know nearly everybody who has changed from McKinley to Bryan belongs to the professional rather than to the business world.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26. -- George F. Drew, the first Democratic Governor of Florida after the war, died at his home this afternoon, aged seventy-three years. Two hours before his demise his wife passed away from the effects of a stroke of apoplexy.

Among the passengers on the steamship Spaarndam, which arrived from Rotterdam yesterday, were two naturalized American citizens, William Phelps and John Andersen of California, who returned to the United States from South Africa, from which country they say they were unjustly expelled by the British military authorities.

Some time ago we had occasion to call attention to the fact that the espousal of the British cause in South Africa by La Tribuna di Roma and other members of the non-Clerical press of Italy tended toward a broadening of the point of view of these papers and a more sympathetic treatment generally of matters not essentially Italian.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Sept. 26. -- As a result of the strike in the anthracite coal region all locomotives on the Shamokih division of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad are burning bituminous coal. They have used hard coal almost exclusively heretofore.
Hocking Valley's gross earnings for the third week in September the largest in the history of the road.
PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Archbishop Ireland leaves here for London to-morrow, whence he will sail Oct. 10.

Johnston Da Forest's raceabout Scamp, winner this year of the Long Island Sound championship, met with a double defeat yesterday in her series match with B.B. Crowninshield's Jolly Roger, the Boston boat, that after having beaten everything in her class in Massachusetts waters, came down the Sound in search of new honors.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Once more England is in the midst of a political campaign. And the last election of the century promises to be the least interesting of all. On the confession of Herbert Gladstone, the chief Liberal whip, it is impossible for his party to win over the 160 seats necessary for a victory.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 26. -- From one end of the middle coal field of Pennsylvania to the other, over practically the entire anthracite region, the production of hard coal has ceased, the small number of cars produced each day by the few miners who have resisted the entreaties or the inarches of the strikers scarcely contributing anything appreciable to the market stock, which is being rapidly exhausted.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Harvard University opens to-morrow for its two hundred and sixty-fourth year of educational activity, with largely increased endowment, an entering class greater in numbers than any preceding class, and seven new buildingrs in process of construction. The vigor and prosperity of the institution are unparalleled.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "The Motorman and His Victims" is an editorial published in THE TIMES of the 24th inst. Its contents give me cause to write the following:

Although Capt. George McClusky of the Detective Bureau declared yesterday that there was no suspicion of foul play in the death of William Marsh Rice, the aged millionaire who died suddenly on Sunday night at his apartments, 500 Madison Avenue, he admitted that his men were working on certain things connected with Mr. Rice's life and affairs.

The Democratic Honest Money League of America issued an address yesterday to the Gold Democrats of the United States. After reciting the causes which led sound money Democrats to support Mr. McKinley in 1896, the address says:

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- With keener competition among the exhibitors in the Horse Show the third day of the breeders' meet at the Readville track was far ahead of the preceding ones. Fifteen classes of exhibitors were given awards, among them being six for the championships. To-day Thomas W. Lawson led in winning two blue and one red ribbon, with $150 in cash.
MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- At the opening of the Republican campaign in Mount Morris to-night Lieutenant Governor Woodruff addressed the meeting, and said, among other things:
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. F.B. Swayne and Mrs. Edwin Parsons will close their Newport season to-morrow, and return to New York for the Winter.

A brother and sister, who had believed each other dead, have been reunited through the tragic death of their father, Peter Vogel, who died from the effects of a blow struck by his son-in-law, Harry Calback, last week. The Calbacks live in scantily furnished rooms in the rear of 143 Newell Street, Greenpoint.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 26. -- The request made yesterday by Sheriff Harvey for troops, although not refused, was not granted by Gov. Stone. The Sheriff and the State officials at Harrisburg, however, have an understanding between them, and if the necessity arises soldiers will be thrown into this region in short order.

Owing to active trading in German Treasury bonds and one or two other issues, which recently have been very dull, yesterday's market for outside securities gave more appearance of life than has shown in some weeks. But this activity did not extend to the general list, and beyond the securities referred to the day was about as dull as the earlier days of the week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Westchester Fair and Horse Show which began to-day attracted about 10,000 spectators, and they were favored with fine, though very warm, weather. Summary of awards:

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Interest in the production at the Duke of York's Theatre last evening, under management of Charles Frohman, of "The Lackeys' Carnival," by Henry Arthur Jones, was increased by the action of Miss Evelyn Millard in withdrawing from the cast because her husband had objected to certain lines in her role.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- Archbishop Ryan was reticent to-day in regard to his visit to President Truesdale of the Delaware and Lackawanna and Western Railroad and to President Olyphant of the Delaware and Hudson Coal and Railroad Company in New York.

As to the tendencies of railway financiering -- what do statistics show? An incentive to inquiry appears in a current Wall Street bulletin pointing out that in the list of railroads (beyond three-score) reorganized during recent years fixed charges -- interest obligations -- have actually decreased over $24,000,000 per year.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Since the county fair opened there have been a number of daylight burglaries in the county. The thieves take advantage of the occupants of houses visiting the fair.

We were remarking the other day that the recency of the entrance of Prussia, as the German Empire, into the arena of world politics, might possibly be responsible for the startling innovations of the German Foreign Office upon diplomatic usages, and seemed clearly to be responsible for the manner in which those innovations were treated by the German press.

PARIS, Sept. 26: -- In view of the disaccord among the powers regarding China, there were a reaction and realizations on the Bourse to-day, especially considering the approach of the settlement. Shortly before the close it was rumored that the Emperor of China had decided to hand over Prince Tuan to the powers and the market slightly improved.

Major Hamilton S, Wallace, Paymaster, will proceed to San Francisco and report to the commanding General, Department of California, for transportation to Manila on the transport to leave that port Oct. 16, and upon his arrival in Manila will report to the commanding General, Division of the Philippines, for assignment to duty.

ALBANY, Sept 26. -- Apropos of the political speech delivered by ex-United States Senator David B. Hill at Elmira last evening. In which the speaker quoted figures showing the expenditures of certain State departments, both State Controller Gilman and Attorney General Davies have prepared statements in regard to their respective departments, in which they assert that the figures were inaccurate.
Senator Hanna made another visit to the offices of J.P. Morgan Co. in Wall Street yesterday, which was much more protracted than his call on Mr. Morgan the day before.

The second day of the Westchester Horse Show, which is unusually good this year, is the chief suburban social attraction to-day. The Autumn colony in Westchester County will be largely represented at the fair grounds at White Plains. The attendance yesterday was a large and fashionable one. To-morrow there will be a movement of the horse-loving element in society toward Tuxedo, whose first annual horse show will be held on Saturday.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- August Belmont's seventy-footer Mineola left this place yesterday for Bristol, to be laid up at the Herreshoff yards. The Mineola will undergo a number of alterations, the principal one being the cutting away of the bow.

The report of Chief Examiner Vanderpoel of the State Insurance Department in regard to the insolvent Traders' Fire Insurance Company, New York, was sent to District Attorney Gardiner yesterday morning.

More than 300 college men, graduates from nearly every college and university in the United States, formed last night in the Savoy Hotel the Democratic Club of College Men, pledged its support to the nominees of the Democratic Party in State and country, and indorsed the party platform.

The Board of Education last night adopted the budget preliminary to asking the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to grant the sum of $19,258,378.80, as called for by the Finance Committee, for the maintenance of the city schools for 3001. This sum is an increase over the amount allowed for 1900 of $4,664,267.71.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In your editorial, "The Motorman and His Victims," in last Monday's TIMES, you state the case in a very just manner and point out the trying position occupied by the motorman. The remarks made by the unfortunate man after having run over the boy are cries from the soul.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- The preparations for the wedding of Miss Elsie French to Alfred G. Vanderbilt early next January are progressing slowly.

NEWPORT, Sept. 26. -- The last engagement in the "Battle of Narragansett Bay," as the naval manoeuvres this week are now familiarly called, took place this afternoon aboard the cruiser New York, the contending forces being the umpires who have figured as judges in the various attacks.

The convention of the Catholic Young Men's National Union, at its second day's session in the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, yesterday approved of Bishop McFaul's idea of a federation of all the Catholic societies in the country, to be formed by delegates at a meeting to be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Manhattan, on Thanksgiving Day.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 26. -- President Hill of the Great Northern has received from Chief Engineer Stevens a telegram stating that the east and west crews in the immense bore under the Cascade Mountains have met. The two forces, working from opposite ends in the big tunnel, brought the two ends together with hardly the variation of an inch.

There is at present no indication of surrender by either the operators or miners of the anthracite coal region. Various propositions looking to a settlement by arbitration have been made, but, so far as can be learned, these have been put forward by persons not directly connected with the dispute.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Port Chester had a parade to-day, in which two thousand veterans of the civil and Spanish-American wars, firemen and civic societies took part. It was a general holiday and all business was suspended. The occasion was the dedication of a granite monument surmounted by a bronze figure of an officer, which was built three years ago by George R. Read and George W. Quintard and presented to the village.

A reorganization of the free circulating libraries of New York, with one central head, has just been recommended by the Executive Committee of the New York Public Library, as a result of an investigation carried on by the committee in response to a request of Controller Bird S. Coler.

Daniel D. Mangam died at Sing Sing yesterday. He was seventy-two years of age. Mr. Mangam was for several terms Trustee and Treasurer of the town of Sing Sing, and Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, in which he took a great, interest. He was connected with the National Bank of Sing Sing as Director, and was one of the Trustees of the savings bank.

The racing at the Gravesend track yesterday was commonplace, and a crowd considerably below the average was in attendance. Only one stake, and that a cheap selling sprint for three-year-olds, the Standard, over the short six-furlongs course, was run, six moderate performers starting.

Howard A. Colby, the crack golfer of the Essex County Country Club, Orange, led the field yesterday in the opening round for the golf championship of the State of New Jersey, played on the Essex County links. The contest is the first meeting held under the auspices of the recently organized New Jersey State Golf Association.

A hot sun and a muggy atmosphere aid much to render the Columbia football players uncomfortable at their practice yesterday afternoon, but Coach Sanford had no mercy* and sent the men through the hardest work they have had this season.

READING, Penn., Sept. 27. -- Frank S. Stevens of Reading was appointed to-day Superintendent of the Reading Division of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, succeeding W.G. Besler, who recently was promoted to the position of General Superintendent in place of I.A. Sweigart, resigned.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The practical deadlock in the efforts to commence peace negotiations with China has given an impetus to the suggestion that the Ministers at Peking be instructed to hold meetings for the purpose of drawing up the terms of a treaty of peace.

PAPILLON, Neb., Sept. 27. -- W.J. Bryan started on his last tour of the country today, and made his first speech at this place. His departure from Lincoln was simple and unostentatious. He was accompanied by his private secretary and three or four representatives of the press.

A proposal to divide the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was brought before the Diocesan Convention yesterday at its session in the Church of the Incarnation. The plan bid fair to receive a majority of votes until Bishop Potter expressed himself as opposed to it. After he had addressed the convention and made a counter proposition, the resolution was defeated by an overwhelming vote.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 27. -- Cresceus, the king of stallions, added a jewel to his crown to-day by winning in five hard-driven heats the twenty-thousand-dollar race at the New England Trotting Horse Breeders' Association meet on the Readville track.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 27. -- At 10 o'clock to-night President Mitchell admitted that he believes that the mine operators have agreed to make the striking mine workers an offer of a 10 per cent. increase in wages.

SOUTHAMPTON, Sept. 28 -- 1 A.M. -- The American Line steamer New York, Capt. W.J. Roberts, from New York City, Sept. 19, for Southampton, arrived here last evening at 10 o'clock, about seventeen and a half hours late.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 27. -- C.A. Collier was injured this morning shortly after 4 o'clock by the accidental discharge of a pistol. His condition is serious. Mr. Collier is now under the influence of opiates and has been since a few minutes after the accident. For this reason he has not been able to give an account of the affair.

Though the total transactions in yesterday's market for outside securities were not much larger than those of the previous day, the trading was broader, and included a number of stocks not active earlier in the week. In sympathy with the better market on the Stock Exchange, prices were stronger, and some considerable advances showed in the closing quotations.

Wall Street theorists agree generally in attributing the current strength of the market to the covering of shorts by speculators who have been freely selling stocks they didn't own. The value of a rally on such account is doubtful. When the short interest is eliminated a forceful supporting element is removed from the market.

The most notable theatrical incident last night was the opening of Oscar Hammerstein's new playhouse, the Theatre Republic, on West Forty-second Street, adjoining the Victoria Music Hall. There was a great assemblage, including, as it seemed, nearly all the habitual first-nighters, and the unique, beautiful, and comfortable auditorium was greatly admired.

A new laboratory, to be used in connection with the Willard Parker Hospital, will be built by the city at the foot of East Sixteenth Street. The structure will be two stories in height, and will stand on a plot 50 by 25. Architects Horgan Slattery; by whom the plans were filed yesterday at the Building Department, have estimated the cost of the building at $20,000.

A thorough investigation into the affairs of the late William Marsh Rice, the aged millionaire who on last Sunday night was found dead in his bed by Charles F. Jones, his secretary and attendant, was begun yesterday by Capt. James A. Baker of Houston, Texas, who was the Southern representative of the dead man.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 27. -- United States Marshal Burns succeeded after the play here this evening of "Becky Sharp" or "Vanity Fair," in serving an injunction on Miss Gertrude Coghlan, restraining that actress from presenting "Becky Sharp" until Oct. 5, when she must appear at Syracuse and show cause why the injunction shall not be made permanent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Save for the strenuous and successful efforts of Mr. Bryan in persuading Democratic Senators to vote for the treaty with Spain ceding the Philippines, the treaty would have failed of ratification. Mr. Bryan, more than any one man, is responsible for the acquirement of the Philippines.

Not many persons will be astonished by the decision of the arbitrators on the results of the sham fight at Newport, to wit, that the torpedo boats were entirely vanquished. The facts are plain. The small craft were successfully stopped in their apparently mysterious careers by both forts and battleships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Thomas Fitchie, Commissioner of Immigration at New York, has submitted his annual report of the work done at the New York station for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1900. That year marks the close of the first ten years of Federal control of immigration.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept 27. -- W. Gould Brokaw's fast schooner yacht Amorita is being dismantled in this harbor preparatory to going out of commission and hauling out at the Jacob yard for the Winter. It is not expected the Amorita will undergo any changes during the Winter.

Charles S. Peck, seventy-one years old, one of the oldest real estate dealers in this city, living at 13 West Eighty-fourth Street, and having an office at 30 West Thirtieth Street, was picked up dead with a fractured skull at 5 o'clock yesterday morning in front of 403 West Seventeenth Street. There was evidence that he had met with foul play.
The Republican district conventions to nominate candidates for the Assembly in New York County were held last night. But one fight developed, and that was in the Twenty-ninth District.

Tunnel transit to Brooklyn Is at last assured. The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, and, acting upon a resolution presented by Controller Coler, authorized the construction it an underground railroad from the terminus of the Manhattan tunnel at City Hall Park to Fiatbush and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, the latter terminus being it the Long Island Railroad station.

Gossips about the hotels have a story about the good nature of United States Senator Fairbanks, who has been about town for the past few days. Some years ago, so goes the tale, the Senator was be-friended by D.J. Mackey of Indiana, who was in his day very much of a railroad magnate in that State.

Herbert -- Alien. Henry Lloyd Herbert and Mrs. Suzanne C. Alien were married at All Souls' Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, by the Rev. R. Heber Newton, at noon yesterday. Only relatives and a few friends were present. Ralph N. Ellis was Mr. Herbert's best man.
TO the Editor of The New York Times: May I suggest a way of ending the coal strike?

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- At the third day's racing of the Newmarket first October meeting to-day the Jockey Club Stakes, of 10,000 sovereigns, was won by J.R. Keene's bay colt Disguise II., by Domino, out of Bonnie Gal, ridden by Cannon. Lord William Beresford's bay gelding Jolly Tar, with J. Reiff in the saddle, came in second, and R.A. Brice's colt Forfarshire, by Royal Hampton, out of St. Elizabeth, was third.

Ex-Gov. William J. Stone, who is in charge of Mr. Bryan's Eastern campaign, gave to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter last evening an interview as to the alleged corruption fund of $20,000,000 or more which Senator P.H. McCarren stated was being raised by Senator Hanna. The utterance of ex-Gov. Stone is the first which has been made by him during this campaign out of the ordinary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Minister Conger has been advised by the State Department of the substance of the replies made by this Government last Friday to the Governments of Germany, Russia, and China respecting China, which clearly indicated to him the general nature of the instructions he is to receive.

DAKOTA CITY, Neb., Sept. 27. -- William J. Bryan arrived here to-night and addressed a meeting in the Court House yard. From Papillon, where he spoke early in the day, Mr. Bryan drove to Blair, a distance of thirty miles, making two brief speeches on the way, one at Millard and the other at Bennington.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -- It has been a day of developments at Yale. "Dick" Sheldon donned his football togs to-day and appeared on the field for the first time since 1896, and Olcott, the guard of last year's team, arrived. Sheldon will enter the game for the first time to-morrow. Olcott was put in at centre in place of Holt, and went through his first day's work at the new position.

The Republican campaign managers heard yesterday of several suits started in cities where the ballot machines were to be used at this election to have the voting declared illegal. The contention of the Democratic politicians is that the voting machines do not allow the voter to cast his ballot for the Presidential Electors individually, but for the Democratic or Republican Electors together.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27. -- Mrs. F.O. French is having her cottage, Harbour View, renovated and put in condition for occupancy this Winter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Boss grain trimmers began before daylight to-day trying to find men enough to stow away the grain in the ships, which were to take on ear-goes at the elevators along the river. Despite all their efforts, they could not find a man, and several ships will be delayed in port on that account.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 27. -- Gov. Sayers has returned from Galveston and reported conditions in that city as greatly improved. The Relief Committee is doing excellent work, and the people generally talk hopefully. There were about 1,700 men at work clearing away the debris on Wednesday.

-- Such a scene as that which enlivened the visit of Gov. ROOSEVELT to the town, or mining camp, of Victor, Col., is a commonplace of the election season in England, and would there pass almost unnoticed, but, happening as it did in the midst of our gentler and more advanced civilization, it will naturally create no little talk and indignation.

In his very adroit speech at Elmira the other day ex-Senator HILL succeeded admirably in showing that the course of the Republican Party on the currency has been such that the party ought to be replaced by one more trustworthy, if such a one there were, but that the only other party by which the Republican Party can at all be replaced is, on this issue, unspeakably worse.

The annual report of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad was made public yesterday. The report shows an increase in net earnings of $859,119 and a surplus after payment of all fixed charges and dividends of $2,099,083. The table below contains a detailed statement of earnings, operating expenses, , for the years ending June 30, 1899, and 1900, respectively:

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- President H.H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway last night entertained about 125 guests at a masquerade barn dance, which was given at his country home. "Rest-a-While," at Brewster. Invitations were sent to Mr. Vreeland's neighbors for miles about, and they were generally accepted.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The German press and Foreign Office continue to deny that Great Britain has rejected Germany's proposal. They also continue to blame the United States for the recently revived Chinese obduracy and the resume evidences that the Chinese intend to resume hostilities on a large scale.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The Unionists are still confident of a victory at the forthcoming Parliamentary general election, but there is an undercurrent of apprehension, that the party will be returned to power with a smaller majority than has been expected. The St. James's Gazette says:

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Prices for local stocks showed a little improvement, but otherwise the situation was unchanged. There were few orders either way in anything. Biscuit common opened at 32, went off 1/4, advanced to 33, and closed at 32 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The War Department has received a dispatch from Gen. MacArthur recording the death of Second Lieut. James D. Banner of the Twenty-eighth United States Volunteer Infantry, by the accidental discharge of his pistol, Sept. 27. He was a native of Pennsylvania, and had prior service as private in the Eighth Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry during the Spanish-American war.

There were several lively tilts between Robert F. Westcott, Capt. Oberlin M. Carter's father-in-law, and Lawyer Kellogg at he hearing before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday upon the application for the removal from the jurisdiction of the Georgia Federal Courts of Benjamin D. Greene, John F. Gaynor, E.H. Gaynor, and W.G. Gaynor.

The Greek corvette Nauarchos Miaulis, Commander Paul Coundouriotis, the first vessel of the Hellenic Navy that ever touched in New York Harbor, arrived yesterday at noon from Philadelphia, and the Greek colony of this city, numbering about 3,000 souls, took a holiday in honor of the event.

I. Randolph Jacobs Co. have sold for a Mrs. Ettinger the live-story three-family flat 55 East Ninety-ninth Street, 25 by 100; also, for a Mrs. Silverman, the three-story dwelling 1.525 Madison Avenue, 16.8 by 70.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27. - Cardinal Gibbons has been asked to act as arbitrator between the striking miners and the operators of the anthracite coal regions of Pennsylvania. While admitting that he has been approached on the subject, his Eminence said to-night that he had heard from only one side of the parties in controversy, and must decline to discuss the question of arbitration until all had been heard from.

Speyer Co. of this city yesterday forwarded to James Stillman, Treasurer of the Galveston Relief Fund of the Chamber of Commerce, a check for $30,000, being the first installment of a collection made in London by the banking houses there of Speyer Brothers, Baring Brothers Co., Limited, Brown, Shipley Co., and N.M. Rothschild Sons.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Practice on University Field, this afternoon was hard and fast. General practice introduced the programme, followed by special coaching of men in the plays of their various positions. Then came the line-up between the 'Varsity team and the second eleven, which was of a kind better suited to Thanksgiving weather than to the hot sultriness of to-day.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 27. -- In a letter received to-day at the Populist Party National Headquarters Adlai E. Stevenson accepts the nomination, for the Vice Presidency tendered him by that party early this month. The letter nominating Mr. Stevenson follows:

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27. -- The question whether or no a man can leave a bequest to propagate a campaign against the doctrine of immortality will be presented to the Connecticut Supreme Court for decision this Fall. S.L. Hall of Hartford, who died about five weeks ago, left $14,000 for such a purpose, and his heirs are now contesting his will.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The first practice this season on the 'Varsity gridiron, the appearance of Boal and Campbell, and the presence of a large number of coaches, made the work of the Harvard football squad to-day notable. The appearance of Boal and Campbell made the outlook for the team brighter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- There were fully 15,000 spectators at the Westchester County Fair and Horse Show today. The thunderstorm early this morning laid the dust nicely, and freshened the atmosphere. There was a large number of handsome equipages on the ground, and most of the society folk of the country were present while the awards were being made.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve decreased L671,000, circulation increased L117,000, bullion decreased L554,083, other securities increased L1,115,000, other deposits decreased L453,000, public deposits decreased L790,000, notes reserve decreased L830,000, Government securities decreased L1,650,000.

PUEBLO, Col., Sept. 27. -- Gov. Roosevelt's tour from Cripple Creek to Pueblo was not marked by any serious disturbance. His train left Cripple Creek last night for Leadville. There was not the slightest demonstration when the train passed through Victor, the scene of the attack on the Governor by a mob yesterday afternoon.

SAVANNAH, Sept. 27. -- Some time ago the Plant system of railroads made its return for taxation. The State Controller declined to accept the valuation returned by the company, and made a new assessment, fixing the taxable value at $757,148 above the amount fixed by the company. The corporation objected, and a board of arbitration was appointed, one member by the Plant system and one by the State, the third being chosen by the two.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew was the attraction at a big Republican rally in Brooklyn last night in the Academy of Music, where he addressed a full house of Republican men and women and a few Democrats. It was a characteristic Academy of Music Republican audience, about the same kind of audience that always turns out at that kind of meeting, well-dressed as to the boxes, auditorium, and first gallery, and of plainer quality aloft.

A statement concerning the population of cities was published in the "Washington press dispatches appearing in the newspapers of yesterday morning that calls for some explanation. We here reprint the dispatch:

POTTSVILLE, Sept. 27. -- Excepting the Potts Colliery in the Ashland District and the North Franklin Colliery at Treverton, to the Shamokin District, all the coal mines north of Broad Mountain in the Schuylkill region were completely tied up to-day. At the two collieries mentioned tout small forces worked to-day, and the amount of coal mined was insignificant.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 27. -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers today sent a telegram to the Central Pennsylvania bituminous coal field, which possibly may have the effect of bringing the soft coal mine workers into the contest which the anthracite workers are now waging against the mine owners.
Maj. Gen. Elwell S. Otis was the guest last night at a dinner tendered to him by Lafayette Post, at which some 400 persons, anxious to do honor to the late commander in the Philippines, assembled.

One Customs Inspector is under suspension and a Deputy Surveyor of the Port has been accused of collusion with smugglers in passing dutiable goods into this country. The accusation is based on an autograph confession made by Mrs. M. Shanahan, a dressmaker, of 11 East Forty-sixth Street, whose trunk, containing many Paris costumes, was seized at her house after it had been passed by the Inspector.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 27. -- At an informal conference of the local operators tonight the report of the negotiations for settling the strike was discussed, and the consensus of opinion was that influences reported to be at work toward effecting a settlement are of a political hue, and that these interests cannot advance any argument that will cause the operators to turn from the course they have mapped out.

We have already dealt with the question who is responsible for such a break as there has undoubtedly been in the concert of the powers. That is not now the practical question. The practical question for every one of the powers is, what shall be done now that the concert has been impaired, and that there has appeared "the little rift within the lute, which by and by may make the music mute"?

Controller Color's expert accountants yesterday discovered a clerical error amounting to $10,000 in a requisition for funds made by the Board of Education. They considered the matter a very good joke on the members of the Board of Education who signed the requisition. Here is a transcript of the account:

Philadelphia beat New York in the baseball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon by heavy batting. Taylor, the deaf and dumb pitcher, was batted out of the box in the third inning and Carrick took his place, but he could not hold the Philadelphias in check. Pitcher Seymour has been suspended by the New York Club.

Arrangements have been practically completed for the annual convention of the New York State Christian Endeavor Societies, to be held at Binghamton Oct. 15, 16, and 17, and a very large attendance is expected, as these gatherings have grown steadily in popularity year by year. The convention text is "Thou therefore endure hardness as a good soldier."

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the last weeks the medical and lay papers of this country, and particularly of the City of New York, told us of the magnificent gift from Mrs. Caroline Hoagland to the St. Bartholomew's Church, Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. David H. Creer is rector.

The attack upon GOV. ROOSEVELT at Victor, Col., is likely to have important and unexpected consequences for the people of that Commonwealth. The first reports of the outrage almost irresistibly suggested that there was something and somebody behind it, and that it was by no means the mere spontaneous ebullition of human nature at its dirtiest and meanest which the Bryanites of Colorado are interested to make it appear.
John H. Berry has sold for De Witt C. Judson, to a client for investment, at about $80,000, the three five-story apartment houses 202, 204, and 206 St. Nicholas Avenue, on a plot 95 by 119.

MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, was received at Mount Morris to-night with great enthusiasm. He spoke in the Opera House to fully 800 persons and also at the village hall to about 300. Mr. Stanchfield touched upon the issue of imperialism for the first time in his State campaign.

The author of "The Cruise of the Cachalot," Frank Bullen, is now hard at work on what promises to be a rather remarkable book. It will bear the title of "With Christ at Sea," and will be a story of the religious life of the inhabitants of the forecastle, based upon Mr. Bullen's long experience.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- Firmness prevailed on the Boerse to-day in American and Canadian securities as a result of New York advices in connection with the reported settlement of the coal strike. Local stocks were firmer. They eased later, but at the close there was a sharp recovery. Home funds were weak.

One interesting feature of the twelfth revised edition of Baedeker's "London and Its Environs" is the quantity of detail that is given about all things likely to interest the tourist, and not to interest him merely, but to attract him. Many of these details, too, may be passed over by the tourist for the time, but they will be important to refer to later as giving significance to his sightseeing.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- At the last day's racing of the Newmarket First October Meeting to-day, the Rous Memorial Stakes was won by Mr. Theobald's brown colt Volodyovski, ridden by Lester Reiff.

Americans should honor the centenary ofof George Bancroft not only because of his brilliant career as a patriot and diplomatist, of his work as historian, and man, of letters, but because of his life of integrity, earnest purpose, and tireless industry.

The probable coal strike settlement aside, the developments in the trade world during the week have been neither significant nor important. Those that have appeared are, on the whole, favorable; though here and there unfavorable manifestations show. The large failure reported in the wool trade and the continued dullness in the cotton manufacturing line are chief of the unfavorable features.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- There were about 10,000 visitors at the Westchester County Fair and Horse Show to-day, and another fair day favored the management. The summaries:

ABERDEEN, S.D., Sept. 28 -- Mr. Bryan has been campaigning to-day in South Dakota. Leaving Sioux City at 7:30 o'clock this morning, he proceeded to Yankton, speaking briefly at small towns along the way.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 28. -- An important meeting of the coal operators of the Wyoming and Lackawanna Valleys was held at the office of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company in this city to-day. All the representatives of the big coal companies with collieries in this section were present. The only individual firm of coal producers represented was Coxe Brothers Co.

The racing at Gravesend yesterday was vastly better in promise than it was in fact, for withdrawals cut the card to pieces. The best contest of the day was for the Bayview Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth, fifth on the card, which brought out a field of five, with Mr. Brown and Intrusive nearly equal favorites, and Favonius the next choice.

ST. ALBANS. Vt., Sept. 28 -- E.H. Lemay of Montreal was arrested here on a writ charging him with alienating the affections of Mrs. J.W. Ketchum of Vergennes. The amount of the damage was alleged to be $50,000. Mr. Lemay is a wealthy banker and lumber dealer in Montreal and a man of prominence.

Richard Croker's circular asking for contributions was sent out yesterday to all city officials who owe their places to Tammany Hall. The notices were sent in ordinary envelopes and were delivered through the mails to all city and county officials.

COLUMBUS, Neb., Sept. 28 -- Senator Beveridge addressed a large gathering at the State rally in this city this afternoon. Many drove in from the surrounding country and swelled the crowd of townspeople. The Senator confined himself to discussion of trusts, saying in part:

It is well that the Episcopal Convention has asked Bishop POTTER to investigate the allegations that clergymen of his diocese have been insulted by officers of the police force when the clergymen went to the officers to report evidence of vile crimes practiced in the neighborhood of their churches.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 28 -- The house of Charles Gruss, a man of seventy years, who was known as a miser, was burned this afternoon, and a search of the ruins revealed the fact that a double crime had been committed. The body of the old man was found in the ruins, and there were wounds on the head that had been made by a hammer or some other blunt instrument or weapon.

It is painful to have to do with a Government whose word you cannot take for anything. The contrast between the commercial morality of China, which is very high, and the political morality, which is very low, is approached in other lands, and notably in our own, but is not elsewhere equaled, at least not out of the East.

Henry M. Hills, a well-known lumber broker, died yesterday at his home, in the Hotel Lincoln, Fifty-second Street and Broadway, of hemorrhage of the stomach, alter an illness lasting but little more than a day. Mr. Hills, who was a man of splendid physique, weighing more than 200 pounds, was seemingly in perfect health on Thursday morning when he left his hotel.

The German-American McKinley and Roosevelt League, Twenty-first Assembly District Branch, held a mass meeting last night in Colonial Hall, One Hundred and First Street and Columbus Avenue. Arthur Von Briesen read a letter from Andrew D. White, United States Ambassador to Germany, which was in part as follows:

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28 -- The music festival came to an end to-day with some brilliant miscellany. At the afternoon concert Miss Jean Foss sang a couple of Wagner's songs, the orchestra gave "The Flying Dutchman" overtime and Liszt's "Prelude," and Miss Augusta Cottlow essayed the first pianoforte concerto of Tschaikowski.

Whatever else it may be, the new monthly magazine to be begun in November by Doubleday, Page Co. will be thoroughly and consistently American. It will appeal to that healthful, rebust, and active Americanism, which is the just pride of the people of the United States and the curious wonder of the rest of the world.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 -- Miss Frances A. Caspari, formerly instructress in German at the Western Female High School in this city and for twenty-two years connected with the public schools of Baltimore, was arrested to-day on the charge of having obtained $300 by false representation from Mrs. Bertha A. Greer.

After a fortnight of voluntary idleness by something like 135,000 miners in the anthracite coal field of Pennsylvania, with a practically total suspension of hard coal production, increase of coal prices, and loss of earnings to the miners and their families, there is a prospect of settlement of this clumsy and needless strike with concessions to the miners of an advance in wages.

The investigation into the affairs of William Marsh Rice, the aged millionaire who was found dead in bed at his apartments, 500 Madison Avenue, last Sunday evening, was continued yesterday by Capt. James A. Baker of Houston, Texas, who was the Southern representative of Mr. Rice, and who is now looking after the interests of the relatives of the dead man.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- A letter from Mrs. E.H. Conger, wife of the United States Minister in Peking, was received yesterday by Mrs. J.S. McConnell, a sister of Mrs. Conger, who lives in this city. It was the first mail communication to come from Peking since the siege, and recounts briefly the horrors endured by those who were imprisoned.

About two months ago there was sold at Sotheby's a valuable and unique collection of horn books and children's books of the seventeenth and eighteenth and the early portion of the present century, this collection probably being unparalleled in its particular direction.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28 -- The state- ment referred to by Herr von Brandt in the Deutsche Revue was made by Bishop H.C. Morrison of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the laying of the cornerstone of the Fourth Avenue Methodist Church, in Louisville, on Aug. 15. Bishop Morrison said:

Judging from the contradictory nature of reviews, nothing would, seem more difficult than to determine the ethical quality of a book. One magazine of repute asserts that in the interests of good morals Count Tolstoi's "Resurrection" should not be reviewed at all; another avers that it is a very evangel of purity.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- William Browne Sons, wool dealers, who also own and operate the Phoenix Mills Company, manufacturers of top and worsted yarns, have asked for an extension of time from their creditors. Members of the firm to-day admitted this statement, and added that they believed the extension would be granted.

The political situation here and conditions generally throughout the world were freely commented on yesterday by Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, who comes home after his trip abroad with a conviction that profound distrust of each other prevails among the nations.

Advance figures from the report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for the year ended June 30, 1900, which, were received in this city yesterday, show heavy increases in expenditures for maintenance of equipment, way, and structures. In spite of this, however, the percentage of operating expenses to gross earnings decreased from 68.57 for the previous year to 67.14 for last year.

At some unknown time, in some unknown city, an unknown Pharisee courteously invited Jesus of Nazareth to "eat bread" with him. The story is told us by St. Luke, and by him alone. The invitation was for "the Sabbath day," and it appears to have been accepted without the least hesitation or questioning.

Bishop Henry C. Potter purposes to take issue with the Police Department for the insults said to have been heaped upon his personal representative at the Pro-Cathedral in Stanton Street by Capt. Herlihy of the Eldridge Street Station and inspector Cross, who is in charge of the east side district in which the station is situated.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.
Shipment of 355,000 ounces of silver to Europe by to-day's steamer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- If the protest regarding the appointment of Prince Tuan forwarded by Minister Wu-Ting-Fang remains without effect and Tuan is kept in the Privy Council, the United States will refuse to negotiate with China unless assurances are given that the action of the envoys shall not be subject to review by the Chinese Emperor.

It is nearly a half century now since Thackeray came to this country for the first time, having made some money at home by his lectures, and venturing with many misgivings and sinkings of the heart on a voyage from which be hoped to bear back a fair sum toward provision for "my women," as he called his wife and little girls.

Mr. Herne, in his long speech between the acts of "Sag Harbor" in the new Theatre Republic night before last, spoke of the big place of amusement on Longacre Square as the "finest building in New York," (a somewhat exaggerated phrase, by the way, for a blunt realist,) and declared that Mr. Hammerstein's ability to recover from the effect of losing such a structure was the best proof of his wonderful vitality.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Before the Court of Appeals on Wednesday next the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company will make a vigorous and determined effort through distinguished counsel to set aside the victory of the city authorities of New York over the corporation, which would mean the enrichment of the city treasury by $2,000,000 in back taxes.

Charles E. Bedell, the engineer in charge of the steel work on the new East River Bridge, in course of construction, was killed yesterday morning by falling from the Brooklyn span to the ground, a distance of eighty-five feet.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Sept. 28 -- The first day in Kansas of the Roosevelt campaign has been successful as far as audiences and interest are concerned. The meetings have been larger and the interest greater than at any otner time during the trip west of the Mississippi River. Big meetings were held at Abilene, Salina, and Lindsborg.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly offer the following short catechism to the Bryanites:
HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 28 -- Notwithstanding the rumors of settlement and of concession upon the part of the operators, there was no change in the coal strike situation here to-day.

Undergraduate enthusiasm, a most telling force in the development of college athletic teams, has apparently arrived at Columbia. Nearly 500 students rimmed the gridiron on South Field, opposite the university library, yesterday afternoon, and remained interested spectators throughout the sharp practice given the football candidates by Coach Sanford and Capt. Simons.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- John Penn, Conservative, had the distinction of being the first member returned for the new Parliament, having been re-elected for Lowisham, which he has represented since August, 1891, without opposition, this morning.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 28 -- A dispatch from Coldwater, Mich, says that William E. Nivison, a wealthy farmer, living four and a half miles from Coldwater, was bunkoed, assaulted, and robbed of $5,000 this afternoon on one of the most public roads leading to Coldwater.
Archibald Graham and James A. Tyng will meet to-day on the links of the Essex County Country Club at Orange to determine the amateur golf championship of New Jersey.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The principal papers comment upon a dispatch from Washington which asserts that Secretary Hay will return to the active discharge of his official duties next week, having made it a condition that President McKinley should give him an absolutely free hand in foreign affairs.

Much less business was transacted on the curb yesterday than was done on Thursday, and the course of prices was less irregular. Since the declines of a week ago the market has become much firmer, and there now appear to be coming into the market orders induced by the relatively low prices at which many stocks are now selling.

The announcement, some years ago, that Mark Twain was secretly at work on a book, or a tome, in which he would faithfully record his exact and full impressions of such of his contemporaries as have interested him, or may enjoy that he in the begining years of his tranquil and useful life, was received with astonishment and some expressions of incredulity.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- All Tuxedo society turned out to-day to attend the first annual horse show, which was held on the polo grounds. The day was ideal; just right for horses.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Fort Mott, N. J., has been designated by the Acting Secretary of War as a station for saluting foreign vessels of war.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Charles E. Bedell was a young and promising bridge builder and architect. He has put up a number of bridges in different parts of the United States. He was a graduate of Yale University. His father, Edward F. Bedell, who also lives here, is connected with the firm of Cooper, Hewitt Co. of Burling Slip, New York, the iron manufacturers and bridge builders.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 28 -- Except by discussing the matter, the miners of the Schuylkill region paid no attention today to the announcement that the mine operators would grant a 10 per cent. advance in wages. There was no relaxation of the efforts of the union organizers to extend the United Mine Workers organization, and to add recruits to the ranks of the men on strike.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 28 -- President J.K. Cowen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad while here to-day talked freely of the proposed improvements on the system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The War Department has received a dispatch from Gen. MacArthur reporting that over fifty men of the Twenty-ninth Volunteer Infantry and the gunboat Villalobos were captured by the Filipinos. Capt. Shields, in charge of the party, was said to be wounded.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I think that all of your readers will vote aye with me in deciding that Mr. W.L. Alden, your London correspondent, is at once the ablest and the most impartial critic of the literature of the day. I have never yet been deceived in his estimate of books or in his recommendations or denunciations.
VALLEY CITY, N.D., Sept. 28 -- Judge J.M. Dennett has just returned from the Cascade Mountain district of Washington, bringing samples and news of the location of vast fields of pure anthracite coal.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 -- Cardinal Gibbons, who for many years has openly been in favor of organized labor, but has at the same time deprecated strikes and advocated arbitration, this evening expressed his willingness to act as arbitrator in the settlement of the anthracite miners' strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Lieut. Col. James Allen, chief signal officer in the Philippines, in submitting his report of the operations of the Signal Corps, tells of a number of interesting experiences of his men. He has under him 350 men available for duty and 3,000 miles of telegraphic lines and cable.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- The 'Varsity Tigers showed the scrubs how to play football in this afternoon's practice game. The playing was hard and full of snap and dash from start to finish. It took only five minutes for the first team to earn a touchdown, the first they have made this year. Mattis was the man who carried the ball across the line.

There were no developments yesterday to throw light on the strange death of Charles S. Peck, the real estate dealer, who was found dead on the sidewalk in front of 403 West Seventeenth Street early Thursday morning. A dozen detectives from the Central Office and from the West Twentieth Street Station worked on the case last night and the night before, but without success.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Apparently Germany's retreat from an untenable position has been virtually accomplished. The Paris correspondent of The Morning Post says:

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Few readers tolerate coincidences in a story; their impulse is to demand adherence to probability, and they decline to admit that events ever dovetail in the world as they may in a novel. Still, here is Mr. William Ewing Love's little book, "Graven on the Tables," "just in time to be taken as comment on the miners' strike.
NEWPORT, Sept. 28 -- August Belmont is registered at the La Farge cottage.

Robert F. Westcott, father-in-law of Capt. Oberlin M. Carter, the army officer who is now serving a term of imprisonment for defrauding the Government, was called to the witness chair yesterday by counsel for the defense in the hearing before Commissioner Shields on an application for the removal of John F., E.H., and William T. Gaynor and Benjamin E. Greene to the jurisdiction of the Georgia courts.

LAKE PLACID CLUB, Morningside, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The New York Library Association, which has been in existence ten years, closes to-morrow at this place its annual meeting. The attendance has been the largest ever brought together. The topics presented and the discussions participated in are generally agreed to have been the most instructive and the widest in interest that have ever come up at these regular gatherings.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Miss Corelli's new book, "The Master Christian," is undoubt- edly amusing. Indeed, regarded simply as a work of humor, it is perhaps the most successful effort of the kind that has been made since Mr. Jerome wrote his "Three Men in a Boat." Now and then there is a joke the good taste of which may be questionable, but there is not room to question its humor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- The steamer Samoa arrived to-day from Siberia, via Cape Nome. The Samoa left this port last June, having on board a number of British and American mining engineers and Russian miners, employes of the East Siberia syndicate, which had an imperial concession to mine for gold along the coast of Siberia.

The scene at the second day of the Westchester County Horse Show, at White Plains, yesterday was a repetition in a smaller way of that of Thursday, which was the so-called society day of the affair. There was a fine array of traps, and some handsome costumes. Mrs. J. Borden Harriman wore a box coat and skirt of checked tweed and a sailor hat.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Sept. 28 -- When the train entered Junction City a great surprise awaited the Governor. Drawn up in line on their horses were "Buffalo Bill's" soldiers and Indians, in costume, and a large crowd.

Mr. CARL SCHURZ grows more truculent as he perceives the waning of the people's interest in his anti-imperialist alarms. In his Cooper Union speech last night he dared and defied a good deal. He challenged the world to show that his way was not the only way to defend liberty, right, and justice and preserve the Republic.

To the editor of The New York Times: Mr. David B.
