Hill, in his speech delivered at Elmira on the 23th inst. attempts to fortify his so-called anti-imperialist argument by citing an opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr. Hill questes but a single seatence, isolating it from its context, and thereby willfully perverting its meaxing.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. William T. Bull gave a luncheon to-day at Dudley Place.

Two world's records were made yesterday at the New York Athletic Club games on Travers Island. Maxwell W. Long, a member of the club, signalized his retirement from the track, on which he has won so many notable victories, by lowering the figures for the 440-yard run almost a full second, and in the hammer throwing event John Flanagan lengthened his own previous record by over a foot.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 29 -- As the climax to a war of more than a year's duration, between opposing factions in the congregation of the Belmont colored Baptist Church, situated in the backwoods of Newberry County, the pastor of the church, the Rev. Young Reeder, and a visiting preacher and supporter of Reeder, the Rev. Henry Williams, were shot in the pupit by assassins last night, Reeder receiving a death wound.

On behalf of some minority stockholders of the St. Louis Southwestern Railroad Company an order was obtained yesterday in the Supreme Court directing Edwin Gould and others, shareholders and Directors in the same company, to show cause to-morrow why an injunction should not be issued restraining them from conducting the annual election of Directors of that company, which is to take place on Tuesday next at St. Louis, Mo.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- "There is much reason to believe," says this week's Field, "that never in the whole history of British sport has anything occurred of such a revolutionary nature and so shattering to the accepted standards of belief as the triumphant descent on the British turf of the American jockeys and trainers."

The action of the Rapid Transit Commission with regard to a tunnel road connecting the City Hall and the Manhattan rapid transit system with the borough hall in Brooklyn and with the terminus of the Lond Island Railroad is the most important step toward a really useful extension of the transportation facilities of the city since the completion of the original rapid transit plans.

MANILA, July 20 -- In its legislative capacity, the Civil Commission, which will assume control in the Philippines Sept. 1, will have work in hand likely to present to the native mind striking diversities of government. To the extent that theories of law are rooted in common soil, the effort will be to strip the old system of the foreign growths that overlay it and thereby make its application simple, direct, and intelligible.

The Staten Island Historical Society held a meeting yesterday afternoon at Stony Brook, New Dorp. S.I. on the site of the first Waldensian church in North Amrica and of the first church on Staten Island. It was built in 1600. In 1653 the first Court House of Richmond County was erected near the church, and the public whipping post was in the rear.

Great excitement was caused among the crowds of Saturday evening strollers in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street at about 10 o'clock last nignt by two pistol shots coming in rapid succession from in front of a saloon at Park Avenue much frequented by sporting characters. A man with a revolver in his hand dashed through the crowd before the door and ran down the avenue, with several hundred persons in pursuit.

We find everywhere that blood is blended into complex ritual customs, and thus associated with complex emotional states. Among the ancient Arabians blood was smeared on the body on various occasions, and in modern Arabia blood is still so used. Everywhere, even in the folk-lore of modern Europe, we find that blood is a medicine, as it is also among the primitive aborigines of Australia, so carefully investigated by Baldwin Spencer and Gillen.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The second day of the Tuxedo Horse Show was more largely attended by the society colony than yesterday. The threatening weather did not stop the crowds gathering, and the boxes were all filled.

Some improvement shows in Wall Street sentiment. Market values are not advancing, but there are evidences of a material modification of that uneasiness which for months past has been ruling. Especial reasons for this do not clearly appear, though what can be counted effective appears in the non-fulfillment of depressing predictions on account of which the market at various times has been put under pressure.
"In a corner o' one face of the pedestal, way down low where it's hid by the bloomin' grass, I cut deep into the stone the name 'Nyanza.'"

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29 -- A pretty wedding occurred at Jamestown this afternoon, when Dr. Benjamin Franklin Van Meter of Loxington, Ky., married Miss May Hubbard Wetherill, daughter of the late Col. Alexander M. Wetherill, Sixth United States Infantry, who was killed during the charge of San Juan Hill, Cuba, and in whose memory the new fortifications in Jamestown were named Fort Wetherill.

John Contee Fairfax, eleventh Lord Fairfax, and Baron of Cameron, in the peerage of Scotland, died on Friday at his country tome in Northampton, Maryland. He was in his seventieth year and was believed to be the only British peer with American citizenship.
William A. Halsey, President of the insolvent Traders' Fire Insurance Company, yesterday issued the following statement:

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Robert Hensler, Jr., teller of the Dime Savings Institution, who was arrested last night on warrants charging him with falsifying in the bank's ledger the accounts of Fannie Reiff and of the Knights of Pythias, furnished $5,000 bail to-day for his appearance in the Upper Court.

In his recent address before the Royal Geographical Society of England, reports of which have just reached this country, Ewart S. Grogan entertainingly describes some of his experiences in the practically unexplored regions of Africa. These extracts from the address will have an interest to the scientist, the hunter of big game, and the general reader alike.

It is natural that the more extreme of the Bryanite papers should scold shrewishly at the policy of the Administration in China at the moment when that policy makes absurd the criticism that the anti-imperialists passed on the inevitable lust of conquest which the Chinese situation must breed in the heart of the tyrant McKINLEY, and in the souls of the land-grabbing syndicate by whom he is supposed to be ruled.

One of the most interesting and important of the special Consular reports which have been issued by the Government is that upon "School Gardens in Europe." Instructions were sent to the different Consuls in Europe to look into the matter of school gardens in the particular country in which they were located, and to report any information they might obtain with photographs and sketches.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Islands of New Zealand were discovered in 1642. Capt. Cook visited them in 1772, but not till 1839 did Wakefield of England take formal possession.

The Autumn meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club ended yesterday at the Gravesend track with a fairly interesting afternoon's sport and results that brought much sorrow and wonderment to the students of public form. The right horses persistently failed to win, and the large crowd in attendance departed from the track very much dissatisfied.

Now that Uncle Sam's navy needs men and the regular methods of recruiting them through receiving ships are insufficient, the tug Fortune has been detailed to visit small towns for the purpose of collecting sailors. From her first trip, which included a fortnight's stay at Albany, she returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard week before last, having sent ahead of her fifty-three recruits.
With tears in his eyes a son appeared before Magistrate Brenner, in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday and asked for a warrant for the arrest of his mother as a disorderly person.
SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 29 -- The following was issued to-night from the headquarters of District No. 1 of the United Mine Workers:

"At support we are ready for anything that may happen. The call, 'Clear ship for battle,' has sounded and systematic confection has been followed by the quiet of perfect readiness. As darkness comes on all nights not quite necessary are extinguished, and all other carefully screened. The ship is in send-darkness inside, and not a night is to be seen from the outside.

Another conference was held yesterday between First Vice President W.T. Graham, Vice Presidents W.M. Leeds and Warner Arms, and District Managers George Greet and Berthold Goldsmith of the American Tin Plate Company, and a dozen members of the Tin Workers' Association of America, who make up a committee of that body.

Among the papers read at the twelfth annual conference of the Institute of Journalists, held in London beginning Sept. 10, was one by the President, Sir J. Henderson, on the evolution of journalism, and another on the law of copyright, with special reference to the recent case of The London Times against John Lane, by Mr. J. Andrew Strahan, counsel to the institute.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- W. Bourke Cockran of New York, in opening his Western campaign itinerary here to-night, spoke to an audience that crowded the Coliseum, built to seat 12,000 persons. The speech was made under the auspices of the Anti-Imperialistic League, and attracted thousands who were unable to enter the auditorium.

revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

So far as developing new business or showing new tendencies in the market is concerned, the dealings of the last week have been wholly featureless. Business has been of a desultory character, involving small properties, with the monotony broken only occasionally by a trade in which the total of considerations reaches six figures.

More than 3,500 people pushed and jammed and wriggled into the headquarters of the Commercial Travelers' McKinley and Roosevelt Club, at 737 Broadway, yesterday at noon to hear Senator Hanna, who addressed a meeting of business men. Outside the sidewalk was packed with men trying vainly to get within the hall.

A number of labor organizations in New York and throughout the country, it was stated yesterday, are preparing to start an agitation for the establishment of a system of arbitration in this country similar to that which exists in New Zealand. Heads of labor organizations here have been in correspondence with labor leaders in New Zealand regarding the workings of the law there, under which arbitration of labor disputes is to a certain extent compulsory.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- A rather dull game with Tufts opened the football season here to-day. West Point winning by the score of 5 to 0. There was no lack of enthusiasm on the part of the spectators, however, as nearly 5,000 yelled themselves hoarse whenever the home team made a gain.
Major Gen. Charles F. Roe and Brig. Gens. McCoskry Butt and George Moore Smith have all returned from Europe and resumed their military duties.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- There was considerable demand for money in connection with the usual quarterly requirements, but, thanks to the Bank's release of funds yesterday, the expected pressure did not occur.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 29 -- In their efforts to effect a complete tie-up of the anthracite mines the strike leaders are greatly concerned, and are ready to admit that they are disappointed with today's developments in three districts. The districts in question are Minersville, Tower City, and Panther Valley.

The system of relief distribution now in operation in Galveston is described in a telegram from Clara Barton, President of the American National Red Cross, received yesterday at the rooms of the Red Cross Texas Relief Fund, 156 Fifth Avenue. She says in part:

A mild impeachment of sport is sometimes founded on the ailments induced by athletic exercise. Here again it is excess that is invariably to blame. Thus, rowing trill soon find out a tendency to weak heart, but will not, I fancy, weaken a Bound one. Dr. Morgan shows, in his University Oars, that Oxford and Cambridge rowing men survive the boat race by forty years or more.
Prof. C.C. Langdell, it is now said, will not resign his chair in the Harvard Law School, but he will no longer do any teaching, wishing to spend all his time in writing law books.

CROOKSTON, Minn., Sept. 29 -- Mr. Bryan to-day visited the valley of the Red River of the North, traversing this rich agricultural section from Wahpeton to Grafton, and, turning from Grafton to Grand Forks, then started eastward and reached this place to-night. He made nine speeches again to-day.

Archibald Graham of the North Jersey Country Club of Paterson won the championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association yesterday in the final round of the first tournament held by that organization. He defeated James A. Tyng by 5 up and 3 to play in a thirty-six-hole round.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Yale took Trinity into camp this afternoon in the first football game of the season by the score of 22 to 0. The score might have been larger in Yale's favor, but Capt. Brown was careful not to overwork his men, and put practically a new team into the field in the second half.

POTTSVILLE, Sept. 29 -- The Eastern shipments of bituminous coal are enormous, and to-day the Reading Company sent to Harrisburg a large number of locomotives employed in the coal trade. The Western Maryland Railroad Company has been pouring soft coal into the Reading yard at Shippensburg during the past few days so rapidly that the yard at that point became congested.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Richard Croker's horse Electric Wilkes won again to-day, taking the purse in the three-minute class, while Smitz, driven by his owner, A.C. Fish of New York, gathered in the gentlemen's road wagon contest, owners to drive, after a lively race. The summaries:

There will be a rush of important new plays this week. To-morrow night at the Garrick Theatre, for instance, William H. Crane will appear in the title role of the dramatization of "David Harum," and this must be accounted an important incident because of the popularity of the actor and the enormous circulation of Westcott's novel.
I can save a vote for McKINLEY and ROOSEVELT, provided my statement is correct.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Martin Van Buren Williamson, alias "Pie Crust," was defendant to-day in a suit brought by C.E. Robinson for two months' rent. Mr. Williamson, however, says it is not the trifling sum that was wanted, but his recipe for succulent pastry covering. Williamson has a secret process for making pie crust and other pastries, and for the last four years has interested several capitalists in its production.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 29 -- A statement made by Mrs. Ellen Spencer Mussey of Washington, member of the Red Cross organisation, who accompanied Mrs. Clara Barton to Galveston, in an interview that "of all of the money that has been contributed throughout the country for the relief of the sufferers of Galveston, that city has only received $50,000," has caused much surprise among those who are conducting the relief work.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Cornell found no easy problem in Syracuse University to-day, having to fight hard to win by a score of 6 to 0. The visitors were strong in line, but Cornell forced her opponent's left wing for good gains. Morrison scored Cornell's touch-down by plunging through Syracuse's right tackle and clearing himself of the bunch.

The regular supplementary practice of the season for the expert class of the military marksmen was held at Creedmoor yesterdy at 700 and 800 yards, open only to those who qualified as sharpshooters previously. The attendance was only fair on account of the threatening weather; wind light from 5 o'clock.

BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- Owing to Emperor William's special wishes, the theatre censorship throughout Prussia is now much more stringent. All the new plays submitted for censorship in Berlin for the coming season have been either forbidden outright or greatly modified. The objections were largely of a political or social nature.

QUEENS, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Three live bird events and a number of interesting miss and outs, which were replete with some excellent marksmanship, were successfully run off this afternoon at Inter-State Park, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Gun Club. There was no wind, the birds were very fast, and many drivers and difficult twisters were among those encountered in the second and third live bird event.

On the subject of people's ignorance of canine breeds I would like to tell one more story, vouched for by a professional dog-breeding friend of mine. One afternoon a lady called at his kennels, and one of his men approached her. The following dialogue ensued between the lady and the yardman: "I live in the suburbs of X., and want a good house dog -- one that you can guarantee."

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 29 -- One may well draw a long breath of relief and cry "At last!" as he looks back upon the week of music that accompanied the forty-third festival of the Worcester County Musical Association into history. This, not because of thankfulness that the nerve-wrecking strain is over, but for the reason that the enterprise seems to have emerged wholly from the restraints of localism.

We have some difficulty in making out, from the reports of the proceeding yesterday before Magistrate FLAMMER, what the grounds of the Magistrate's decision were. He apparently had no difficulty in coming to the conclusion that four or five park policemen had been perjuring themselves before him.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- D. O. Thomas, Coal Dock Inspector of the City of Perth Amboy, has just returned from the scene of the Pennsylvania coal strike. He thinks the strike will soon end. He said to-day:

The Republicans of the Twenty-third Assembly District will formally open the campaign in the upper west side to-morrow night at the Liberal Republican Club, One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The club will raise a McKinley and Roosevelt banner, and there will be a parade through the district of the McKinley Guards of Camp McKinley, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue.

NEWPORT, Sept. 29 -- The last hunt of the season by the Monmouth County hounds occurred this afternoon, P.F. Collier was the master of the hounds, and the finish was in the following order: Mrs. Ladenberg, Mrs. T.W. Pierce, J. Clinch Smith, and Alfred G. Vanderbilt.
This is likely to be the banner year for 2:10 pacers. No less than fifty-three already have entered the select circle.
Invitations have been Issued for the wedding of Frederick D. Stein and Miss Lizzie Samson on Oct. 10 at the Waldorf.

The "appeal to the people" in England, although theoretically an obviously enlightened and liberal system for gaining the opinion of the electors, has been often criticised from the fact that the time of appeal is entirely at the pleasure of the Ministry, which is thus enabled to employ certain methods to turn the popular vote to its favor.

Lamartine had enormous powers of assimilation, as the following curious fact will show. The discussion of a grand project for a canal was down in the agenda of the Chamber. The Deputy intrusted with the principal speech in its favor fell ill on the very morning of the debate. The parties interested were advised to intrust Lamartine with the task of defending the scheme.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Nine of the strongest players of the Apawamis Golf Club of Rye were badly beaten on the Fairfleld Country Golf Club links at Greenwich to-day. The summary:

PRINCETON, Sept. 29 -- Practice on Princeton University Field this afternoon was real football playing, and more exciting than many regular games. The 'Varsity men were in better fighting trim than in yesterday's game, and were too big a problem for the scrubs, who were plainly outclassed.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Sept. 29 -- William Waller, the veteran Onwentsia golfer, won the Western amateur golf championship this afternoon from William Hollabird, Jr., the seventeen-year-old Glenview player, by the narrow margin of 1 up.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 29 -- The motion for a new trial In the case of James Howard was overruled by Judge Cantrill to-day, and Howard was sentenced to be hanged Dec. 7. It was agreed that the attorneys should be allowed to file their bill of exceptions in the appeal to the Court of Appeals any time between now and the third week in October.

A series of complications involving the legitimacy of three children and the marriage status of two men arises out of a suit for the annulment of his marriage brought in the Supreme Court by Julius Henky, formerly steward of the Hotel Grenoble, against Lydia A. Henky, through his attorney, William C. Wolf.

THE NEW BRITISH RULE IN ASHANTI. -- According to recent advices received at the British Colonial Office from West Africa, the British Resident Agent to Ashanti, Capt. Donald Stewart, has returned to his post in Kumassi and will shortly inaugurate reforms in the administration of the protectorate which, it is said, will give the natives no cause for further revolt.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Prince Inkanthor of Cambodia came here ostensibly to see the exposition, but really to expose the grievances which both he and King Norodom have against the French Resident in Cambodia, whom they accuse of many misdemeanors, notably bribery, embezzlement, and systematic insolence.

The police yesterday decided that Charles S. Peck, the real estate dealer who was found dead near the corner of Seventeenth Street and Ninth Avenue early Thursday morning, had not been sandbagged, as was at first supposed, but had met his death by a fall. The autopsy showed that Peck's skull had been fractured.

The trusts have been brought forward as a new issue. They have, it is said, oppressed the people, and will oppress them the more if the Republicans continue in office. It is impossible to show just where the shoe pinches, however, and this issue cannot be said to be wholly a success. Imperialism has also been tried.

Joseph Everard, fifty-seven years old, brother of James Everard, the brewer and manager of the Everard Brewery, at One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue, was locked up in the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station yesterday, charged with the abduction of two young girls.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 29. -- Immediately upon his arrival here this evening Gov. Roosevelt was escorted to Shawnee Park, in Armourdale, Kansas City, Kan., where an immense open-air meeting was held.

The wines known as Constantia are obtained by stopping the natural fermentation of the "must" or juice, either by the addition of alcohol or sugar or by allowing the grapes to be so ripe when gathered as to contain a percentage of sugar sufficient to arrest fermentation. Red and white Muscatel, Frontignac, and Pontac grapes are chiefly used in the making of Constantia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The feature of the county fair to-day was the baby show, which was held early in the afternoon, and in which sixty-two babies contested for the prizes. The judges were Mrs. J.L. McArthur, Mrs. J.E. Campbell, Mrs. Clara Parker, and W.C. Pells. The prizes were diamond and pearl pins for the girls and diamond studs for the boys.

Senator M.A. Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, left New York yesterday for Cleveland to spend a day or two with his family. He will go to Chicago early in the week and direct the campaign from the headquarters in that city. The Senator said he would try and return to New York for a few days before the campaign closed, but was not certain.

"The attitude of different races and different classes of people toward snakes is a most interesting subject of study," said an expert in ophiology, recently, in discussing serpents and their ways. "Without going outside of this country we can find nearly all the variations," he continued, "from abject terror and violent hatred up to the highest love and respect.

E.H. Parker in The Contemporary Review. In cases of great national crises, the Chinese unfortunately have no guiding star of principle; besides, there is no loyalty in the public service. From the Emperor downward nearly everybody is ready to sacrifice any one else, including his family and ancestors, to save his own skin.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 29 -- All negrotiations between G.B. Markle Co. and their employes are off, and arbitration has received its first serious blow in the present struggle between the miners and mine owners. To-night the committee of employes which presented grievances to the firm sent the following communication to John Markle, the managing partner:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29 -- The Old Guard of New York, 125 strong, invaded New Haven to-day as the guests of the Governor's Foot Guard, and held the town until midnight.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The flag of the United States ship Patapseo, which was sunk by a torpedo in Charleston (S.C.) Harbor in 1865, is to be presented, according to a dispatch from New York, to Admiral William T. Sampson, who is now the commandant of the Charlestown Navy Yard. The Admiral says he has heard nothing of the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with much interest and a little amusement that I read J.C. Schroeder's letter of the 18th inst. In THE TIMES of the 25th inst., stating that he is a Bryan man in 1900, although not in 1896. While he doesn't state that he voted for McKinley in 1896, still it is intimated that he did.

Mrs. Abia Swift Gilman, born Lippincott in 1817, widow of the famous abolitionist and New York banker, Winthrop Sargent Gilman, narrowly escaped burning to death from a gasolene torch yesterday morning in front of the Charles Scribner mansion, 12 East Thirty-eighth Street. The venerable lady's hair was singed and some of her garments were destroyed.

BUFFALO, Sept. 29 -- At the City Convention Hall to-night, which was filled by an audience of 3,000. John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor; Bird S. Coler of New York, and H.L. Chapman of Columbus, Ohio, addressed the most important meeting that has yet taken place in the Democratic campaign of Erie County.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 29 -- E.E. Loomis of the Lackawanna Coal Company and Edward A. Rose of the Delaware and Hudson Company came to this city tonight from Scranton and were closeted with some of the General Superintendents of the companies operating collieries in this section.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- We are right in the general election and are thankful that the struggle if sharp will be short. Already sundry unopposed returns have begun to constitute the new Parliament, and most of the borough pollings will be over by the end of next week.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- One hundred and sixty-seven constituencies, returning one-fourth of the membership of the House of Commons, made their nominations to-day. In all, sixty-six candidates were returned unopposed. The Ministerialists aggregate 59, Liberals 5, and Nationalists 2.

The installation of the pneumatic switching system in the yards at the Grand Central Station will be completed about the same time as the new passenger waiting room, which will be ready about Oct. 15. The pneumatic system, among other advantages, will add considerable space to the capacity of the yards.

A Bryan and Stevenson banner was raised yesterday at noon at the intersection of Reade and Washington Streets by the produce merchants of that vicinity. The flag raising was accompanied by music and oratory. When Joseph F. Rinn, who acted as Chairman, called the meeting to order, there were probably 250 people gathered around the speakers' wagon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer is a native of the anthracite coal regions of Pennsylvania. I take this way of protesting against the shameless exaggeration of some of the papers of this city. The letters of those so-called women reporters are gross departures from truth, the pictures accompanying them are a disgrace to the mind that conceives them and the hand that limns them.

According to Senor Emiliano Isaza, a special Commissioner in this country for Jose Marraquin, the latest President of the Republic of Colombia, the steam yacht Atalanta, which was purchased from George Gould by the Colombian Government about six months ago, will never become a Colombian gunboat, as was intended.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 29 -- "We are closing the mines and awaiting developments," was all that President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers would say to-night when asked whether he had received any information from New York or elsewhere as to what the operators are doing in their efforts to settle the coal strike.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Ulric G. Peters, stock broker, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with assets of $3,000 and liabilities of $7,000. He is a well-known member of the Chicago Stock Exchange, of which he has been a member several years. Most of the liabilities are marginal deposits for the purchase of stock which have been made by his customers.

SIMLA, Aug. 20 -- It would be very premature to say that the great famine which for the last twelve months has held India in its grip is now over. With a great many more than 5,000,000 people still in receipt of relief from Government, let alone vast numbers of others relieved by private charities, it will be readily understood that the situation is still one of considerable gravity.

Until 1820 the fate of Mexico and its inhabitants was the same as Spain has dealt out to all her colonies; they were oppressed, robbed, murdered, and trodden under foot by a long succession of infamous and heartless rulers, whose only creed was their own enrichment, who feared neither God nor man, and whose systematic course of torture and death seems to have been as necessary to them as their daily food.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- A unique test of how far the right of the authorities of a city extend in the investigation of illegal use of municipal utilities is to be brought in court in connection with the stock-yards water scandal. Messrs. Swift Co. deny the right of city officials to take any Kodak pictures in their plant, although the firm has permitted Inspectors to go through all the departments unchallenged.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., July 20 -- The cruel murders recently committed by a couple of black natives in New South Wales have naturally directed increased attention to the present condition of the remnant of the strange, mysterious race which formerly peopled the Australian island continent.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Sept. 29 -- As Major Halberstadt of Pottsville, the Brigade Surgeon, and Thomas Glenn of Philadelphia of Gen. Gobin's staff, were to-day on their way on horseback from here to the Twelfth Regiment camp on the hill back of Turkey Run, they were fired upon from ambush.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept 29 -- Harvard defeated Wesleyan on Soldiers' Field this afternoon 24 to 0 in the first football game of Harvard's season, bettering last year's score over Wesleyan by 4 points.

CRANSTON'S, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The venerable statesman and editor, John Bigelow, one of the founders of the Republican Party, who has held high offices under both Federal and State Governments, to-day declared both Presidential candidates unworthy of the support of their countrymen, and advised all whom his words might reach to follow the course he intends and vote for neither one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Department of State was to-day informed by Consul General Goodnow at Shanghai, that Sheng, Chinese Director of Railways and Telegraphs, had handed to him a decree of the Emperor and Empress, dated Sept. 25, blaming their Ministers for encouraging the Boxers.
Thomas G. Shearman, the well-known lawyer, political economist, and single tax advocate, died at 9:20 o'clock last night it his home, 176 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

As a musical affair the concert of the Aschenbroedel Verein, with its orchestra of 400 pieces and its chorus of 2,000 voices, and its well-known metropolitan conductors, was a success, but not as a practical expe- dient toward the relief of the Galveston sufferers, as the benches of Madison Square Garden were poorly filled yesterday afternoon.

MAMARONECK, Sept. 30 -- Because of complaints about his motor vehicles by residents of Mamaroneck, who say that the machines frighten their horses, Albert C. Bostwick has sent a letter to a local paper in which he defends them. He has also issued a public notice to the effect that he will have any animal that is brought to his estate on Orient Point trained to become accustomed to motor vehicles.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- It was announced officially last night that Lord Roberts has been appointed Commander in Chief of the British Army. Yesterday was his birthday.

Senor Sixto Lopez, who was Secretary, of the so-called Philippine Peace Commission that visited the United States in the Winter of 1899, and who since that time has been one of Agulnaldo's trusted emissaries in Europe, returned to the United States yesterday on board the Cunard liner Campania.

Lack of wind spoiled the Fall regatta of the Hudson River Yacht Club yesterday afternoon, only one of the nine yachts that started being able to finish within the time limit of seven hours. The fortunate craft was the 20-foot catboat Pilot, formerly the Adele Ray. It took her over five hours to cover the 15-mile course.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 30 -- Warner M. Newbold, Superintendent of the North and South Alabama and Birmingham Mineral Divisions of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad shot himself in the head at his residence in this city to-day and died at 4 o'clock this afternoon. He never spoke, and the cause of his act remains unknown.

Mormon Elder Brigham H. Roberts, one of the Seven Presidents of the Seventy in charge of the propaganda of the faith of the Latter-Day Saints, spoke at the Amphion Academy, Bedford Avenue and South Tenth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. This was his first speech in this part of the country since he ws barred from Congress.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- A fatal affray with revolvers, bricks, and clubs took place last night on Wood Street, near Hamilton Street, in the "Tenderloin" section of the city. It was between union and non-union molders. Detective Sergeant W. L. Foulks was killed, two men have died since from bullet wounds, and others known to have been wounded were carried away by friends.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, with the Roosevelt children, Theodore, Jr., Alice, Kermit, Archie, and Quintin, left Sagamore Hill yesterday for a two weeks' stay in Connecticut. The Governor himself is not expected to return until the latter part of October.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Another sheaf of imperial edicts throws into still worse confusion the complicated Chinese situation. All the news with regard to the edicts emanates from Shanghai.

Falling bank reserves continue to show. For the fourth consecutive week the bank statement has presented a smaller surplus reserve account and a steady loss of cash, chiefly by reason of shipments to the West and South for crop-moving purpose, and of an excess of Government receipts over expenditures.

The last of the great stakes for two-year-olds, the Matron, second in value only to the Futurity, to be run for to-morrow at the opening of the Westchester Racing Association's Autumn meeting at Morris Park, offers the final chance of the present season for a contest between the best colts and fillies of the year, but the prospects are that the field will be a limited one.

Four years ago, when Mr. BRYAN was practicing oratory and prediction, preaching ruin and wretchedness as the inevitable results of adherence to the gold standard, in the attempt to convince the voters that he was a fit man to guide the affairs, of the Nation, he made many prognostications that he regarded of such permanent value that he put them in his book, "The First Battle."

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- We have had a very hard money market all the week, and I estimate that between L3,000,000 and L4,000,000 has been borrowed from the Bank to enable us to get over the end of the quarter. The borrowing would have been heavier only the Bank itself took money from the market early in the month to force it then to harden its quotations, and this money is now being repaid.

United States Senator William E. Chandler of New Hampshire, who has been in the city for a few days, has written a pa- per on "The Issues of the Canvass of 1900." It is in the nature of a dialogue be- tween an ardent Republican and a voter about to exercise the right of franchise for the first time.

Magistrate Mott in Centre Street Court yesterday morning, having disposed of the regular watch, as it is termed in police parlance, gave orders that those having no business in court retire, and that the doors be closed.
BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- The most striking feature of the Boerse last week was the smoothness of the monthly settlement. Not for years had Berlin seen such an easy September settlement.

The Central Labor Union was dissolved in tears, figuratively speaking, for half an hour yesterday over the proposed so-called Onion Trust. The Municipal Council has under consideration an ordinance to tax dealers in all kinds of farm produce $300 a year, but has not given the matter a final hearing.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 30 -- The following open letter has been issued by Erving Winslow, Secretary of the Anti-Imperialist League:

During the first part of last week the selling movement of the previous week was continued, and prices suffered further material declines. The amount of stock offered for sale became less as the week progressed, and on the latter days quotations became much firmer than they had been at any time within the past two weeks.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 30 -- Col. Bryan arrived here early this morning and spent the day as a guest of State Senator Baldwin, an old classmate at college. He attended service at the Pilgrims' Congregational Church.

"The School Outrage" was in part the subject of the discourse of Dr. Cortland Myers last evening at the Baptist Temple. Five hundred members of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics attended the service in a body. Dr. Myers's text was "God Save the King." He said, in part:

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Levy of 156 West Ninety-seventh Street yesterday invited a number of their friends to spend the evening with them. Among them were Julius Silverman, a lawyer, of 26 West Nintey seventh Street; William S. Bennett of 15 Manhattan Avenue, Mr. Dinkelspiel of 160 West One Hundred and Nineteenth Street.

In his "Foot Note to History" ROBERT Louis STEVENSON makes a pregnant and impressive remark upon the difference between the German-speaking and the English-speaking residents of Samoa when the troubles there began. To the Briton or the American, he says, criticism in a newspaper of the conduct of a public official seems to be far better justified than criticism upon a private person.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 30 -- Regarding the contributions for the Galveston flood sufferers, Gov. Sayers to-day made the following statement:
Secretary HAY, on his way to washington from his long and enforced stay at his New Hampshire home, must have found the news sent by Consul General GOODXOW almost incredibly good.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 30 -- The posting by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Irou Company of a notice granting an increase of 10 per cent, to all the employes of its thirty-nine collieries in the Schuylkill Valley did not cause any appearent commotion at the headquarters of the United Mine Workers here to-day.

Richard Croker received a half dozen reporters at the Democratic Club yesterday. He was in good humor and willing to talk. Asked for his opinion of the attack by Gov. Roosevelt at Kansas City on the Ice Trust, Mr. Croker said:

The present football season gives promise of bringing out its share of new gridiron stars, and, judging from the reports from the various seats of learning -- which are a shade more hopeful than usual at this time -- more than its share. Promising line men are attracting attention in the early practice, and also promising candidates for back of the line positions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept 30 -- Yale men are not altogether enthusiastic over Saturday's game with Trinity. The most important lesson learned by the Yale team was the necessity for better training of the ends and tackles in getting their man on a kick-off. This week there will be some hard work put in on this point, and Gould, Kunzig, and Coy will be given some training.

News of the wreck of the British ship Nonpareil, owned by the Standard Oil Company, and one of the finest vessels of her kind in the world, was brought into port yesterday by the tramp steamship Glengoil. On the tramp was the crew of the lost ship, consisting of twenty-nine men.

-- As was to be expected, The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier refuses to commend the display of good feeling in which representatives of the North and South recently took part at Portsmouth, N.H., when the tablets on the cruisers Kearsarge and Alabama were unveiled. Such evidences of the disappearance of sectional bitterness weary.

After another hard day's work trying to solve the mystery which surrounds the death of Charles S. Peck, the real estate dealer, who on last Thursday morning was found dead on the sidewalk on West Seventeenth Street, near Ninth Avenue, the police last night admitted that they were still in the dark, although they maintained that the man's death was due to a fall and was not the result of foul play.

The Democrats will hold many of their local conventions this week. Candidates for Congress will be named on Wednesday, for State Senators on Thursday, and for members of Assembly on Saturday. The Congressional slate is reported to be as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Senator W.A. Clark of Montana yesterday consummated plans for the building of the Los Angeles and Salt Lake City Railroad, after consultation with Salt Lake City and Los Angeles capitalists, who are in Chicago. Another chief promoter is R.C. Kerens of St. Louis, Republican National Committeeman from Missouri, who is also here.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 30 -- It was learned here this evening that the New York Central Railroad has refused to handle any Philadelphia and Reading or Jersey Central coal cars for the mines in the Clearfleld region. In consequence they have been sidetracked at Newberry Junction.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30 -- The New Haven and Derby Road will be equipped with electricity within the coming year, and a start made to build an extensive electric railway system connecting New Haven, Derby, and Bridgeport. There is now in process of construction on Long Wharf in this city an electric plant, which will be capable of producing 3,000 horse power.

Second Lieut. Harry A. Woodruff, Seventeenth Infantry, will proceed, upon the expiration of his sick leave of absence, to Governors Island and report to the commanding General, Department of the East, who will cause him to be examined to ascertain his physical condition, with a view to assigning him to light duty at a post in New York Harbor for a period of four months.

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for the estates of Edward Tracy and James Russell to Jacob F. and Joseph F. Cullman the lot on Fifth Avenue, 52.2 feet south of Eighty-fifth Street. This lot adjoins the apartment house known as The Fifth Avenue, which was recently bought by the Messrs, Cullman through Broker Goldsticker.

NEWPORT, Oct. 1 -- The British three-masted schooner Leonard Parker of St. John, N.B., came in sight of Block Island this afternoon, with a jury mast rig. The Harbor Master was unable to board the vessel, owing to the heavy sea which was running.
LONDON, Oct 2 -- The general election results up to midnight show that 132 members have been returned. They are divided as follows:

State Chairman Frank Campbell has twice during the present campaign placed on Richard Croker's shoulders the responsibility for the outcome of the election in New York State. Yesterday, in an interview, Chairman Campbell said that if Tammany Hail and the Brooklyn organization rolled up a majority of 80,000 Mr. Bryan had a chance of carrying New York State.

The civil and criminal courts opened yeserday. There are indications that there will be a great deal of work for Judges and lawyers, but many important civil ac- tions may not be taken up until after the election.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew to-night addressed fully 10,000 people at two of the largest political mass meetings ever held along the Hudson River valley. The Academy of Music, capable of holding 5,000 people, was taxed to its fullest capacity, as was the Y.M.C.A. hall, while dozens of overflow meetings were held in the streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Betterment in the housing of the masses of the people is desired by reformers and philanthropic people generally. Even the selfish are concerned, for a knowledge of filth diseases makes it clear that a city is only as healthy as its most unhealthy part.

Cornelius Vanderbilt did not make his maiden speech at 126 Second Avenue last night. Officials of the Austro-Hungarian Republican League, which has its headquarters at that address, had announced his coming, and until nearly 11 o'clock an expectant crowd waited impatiently while local orators killed time.

Altogether conflicting are the reports considered in Wall Street as to international exchange conditions and tendencies. The popular view is that gold being due to the United States from Europe is about to come this way in large volume. Some theories providing optimistic bases for speculators have it that England and Germany and France must all ship gold this way within the next month.
At National Republican Headquarters the Democratic assertion that the German-American vote will be with Bryan this year is ridiculed.
Leslie Bingham, who formerly belonged to Julia Arthur's company, has lately made a popular hit as Lucy, the waif, in the rustic drama called "The Dairy Farm."

READING, Penn., Oct. 1 -- Operations will commence next Wednesday on the construction of the Reading, Lancaster and Baltimore Railroad from here to the Ches- apeake Bay. The new line will be about seventy miles in length.

McCOOK, Neb., Oct. 1.-- Gov. Roosevelt's first day in Nebraska may be regarded as successful, though the morning started out wet and chilly, and the audiences of a necessity were small. Thirteen speeeches were made during the journey to-day and at night. Probably 30,000 or 40,000 people were addressed during the day.
BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The principal street-car lines in Berlin to-day introduced a uniform fare of 10 pfennigs.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 1 -- Scranton's independent operators came back from the Wilkesbarre conference angry and defiant. They declare they will not join in the proffer of a 10 per cent, increase unless the coal-carrying companies agree to reduce their tolls, or, to be exact, allow them 65 per cent, instead of 60 per cent, of the tidewater selling prices for their product.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 1 -- Ex-United States Senator Quay to-night made the first of what is to be a series of speeches throughout the State of Pennsylvania in favor of the election of McKinley and Roosevelt and those candidates for the State Legislature favorable to that faction of the Republican Party recognizing Mr. Quay as its leader.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the great army of "perplexed voters" to whose plaints you have so often given space in the columns of THE TIMES, I desire to thank you for having republished the letter of Abram S. Hewitt, written by him on the present political situation, in your issue of the 26th inst.

The deed transferring the title to the publishing plant of Harper Brothers, together with the property 325 to 337 Pearl Street and 79 to 83 and 84 to 90 Cliff Street, was recorded yesterday. The transfer is made by Hamilton Odell, as referee, and the Morton Trust Company to Alexander E. Orr, Chairman of the Reorganization Committee of Creditors, for a stated consideration of $1,100,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Her Majesty," with Grace George in the title role, was presented to-night at the Columbia Theatre. In spite of some dry spots in the dialogue and an unusual number of first-night hitches, the play scored a success, and after each act Miss George and Frank Worthing were called before the curtain three times, together with Fernanda Eliscu and Morton Selton, who shared the applause with them.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 1 -- The Cipher Code," Charles Klein's three-act play of Washington official life, was acted in the Detroit Opera House to-night, with John E. Kellerd in the leading role. Kellerd was called before the curtain for a speech after the second act.

Nearly 300 firms which had failed to comply with the requirements of the new law requiring the registration of unincorporated firms doing business under assumed names filed their certificates in the County Clerk's office yesterday. The time limit expired Saturday, and all firms that filed the certificates yesterday are subject to the penalty of $100 for violating the law.

Much speculation has been caused in certain golf circles regarding the attitude of the United States Golf Association toward the special prize of $150 and a gold medal made by a sporting goods firm, to go to the professional other than Vardon or Taylor who makes the lowest score in the coming open championship tournament in Chicago.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 1 -- Prepations are about completed for a big demonstration of strikers to be held in this city to-morrow. President Mitchell and other leading officers of the United Mine Workers will be prsent. After the parade a big mass meeting will be held.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Messrs. Stanchfield and Coler opened the Democratic campaign in Niagara County with a mass meeting at the Hodge Opera House to-night. Former County Judge Millar, who presided, was in 1896 District Committeeman for Palmer and Buckner.
NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 1 -- In a match on the Ross Hall links to-day the team representing the New Brunswick Golf Club scored a very decisive victory over the Morristown. The score follows:

Mr. CROKER'S defense of the share he and his fellow-Democrats have had in the Ice Trust and his attempt to throw all responsibility for the iniquity of that most revolting speculation on the officers, who, he says, are Republicans, is in accordance with a plan adopted after much study and discussion by himself and his friends.

There was a gathering of Democratic officials connected with the Municipal Assembly at the Democratic Club last evening, Richard Croker was sought out by Alderman John McCall, the Tammany leader in the Board of Aldermen, and by Councilman Oakley, the Tammany leader in the upper branch of the Municipal Legislature.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 1 -- Senator Beveridge of Indiana spoke here to-night to a large audience in a tent in Shelly Park on the necessity of opening new markets for the American producer. The Senator said in part:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Proposals for constructing by contracts six armored cruisers will be received at the Navy Department until 12 o'clock noon on Friday, Dec. 7, 1900, when they will be publicly opened. A circular defining the chief characteristics of said vessels is now ready for distribution among bidders.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct 1 -- Mary Mannering presented the long-expected stage version of "Janice Meredith" at the Star Theatre to-night. An unusually sympathetic first-night audience greeted her and proclaimed the play to be a success. Miss Mannering met the popular idea of the heroine.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- To-day was "town meeting" day in Connecticut, 162 of the 168 towns in the State holding "the little town" elections for the purpose of choosing officials of the town governments and settling for the coming year the liquor license question.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 63 1/2 @ 65. There were no sales.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 1 -- After six weeks in extraordinary session, the lower branch of the Kentucky General Assembly has by a vote of 5S to 39 -- every Democrat voting in the affirmative and every Republican in the negative -- passed a new Election bill. Under the old law the Legislature elected the State Election Board, and this board named the County Boards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Sept. 29 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,106,156,671, a decrease for the month of $6,122,435. This decrease is accounted for by the increase in the cash on hand, and the redemption of 2 per cent, bonds.

The Autumn sports in the suburbs have begun with a rush. The Meadow Brook Hounds are in good shape, and the tri-weekly meets and runs have started with good fields. The Saturday meet and run, which takes place later in the day than on Monday and Wednesday, is preceded by a breakfast, either at the clubhouse or some of the many hospitable homes in the neighborhood of Meadow Brook.

The first work on the provisional budget of expenses of the City Government for 1901 was done yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Mayor Van Wyck presided, and made running comments on the items as read. No formal action was taken on any appropriation.

Coroner Anthony J. Burger yesterday conducted an inquest into the death of Henry Grosvenor Barbour, the son of the rector of the Church of the Beloved Disciple, Manhattan, who on the night of Sept. 13 shot and killed himself in a room in the St. Charles Hotel, Brooklyn, after, as alleged, he had fired a bullet into the breast of Miss Helen Parker Forbes, or Southgate, his companion.

It is evident that we are to meet, in the course of the negotiations with China, with many discouraging and vexatious hindrances. We need not belittle them in order to say that, upon the whole, they threaten much less awkwardness and disappointment than would be involved in the effort to take charge of China, and to govern it ourselves, or in conjunction with our allies.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1 -- Blanche Walsh this evening at the Academy of Music produced for the first time on any stage Eugene Presbrey's romantic drama "Marcelle." The house was packed to the doors and Miss Walsh received an ovation. Her part is a strong one.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- The under-graduates at Princeton are growing angry over the efforts of the football management to have the Yale-Princeton game played in New York instead of on Princeton University Field. The belief has almost become a conviction that the game will be played on Columbia Field instead of as scheduled, and the students are indignant.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 1 -- The coal operators of the Wyoming, Lackawanna, and Lehigh Valley regions held a meeting in this city this afternoon, and decided to offer the miners an increase of 10 per cent, in wages and also to reduce the cost of powder to the miners from $2.75 to $1.50 a keg.

Columbia University entered upon her one hundred and forty-seventh academic year yesterday. The opening exercises were held in the temporary chapel in Schermerhorn Hall, and were conducted by the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water, rector of St. Andrew's Church, and Chaplain of the university.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -- The annual rush between the freshmen and sophomore classes of Harvard took place this evening, and was the fiercest that has been seen here for many years, and finally resulted in the sophomores being driven off the field.

An expected debate on the question of the revision of the Confession of Faith drew a large number of clergymen and Elders to the meeting of the Presbytery held yesterday in the First Church. The question of revision was brought up at the General Assembly last May, and the 232 Presbyteries were asked to give expression to their views severally on the advisability of revision.

The two men who were arrested Sunday on suspicion of knowing something about the death of Charles S. Peck, were discharged yesterday. Chief of Detectives McClusky said he was convinced neither of them could shed any light on the case. The names of the men were James Layburn of 123 Ninth Avenue and John Syron of 32 West Seventeenth Street.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The statement published in Paris that France, Russia, and Germany have arrived at a complete understanding in regard to the retention of troops at Peking and that Germany abandons her demand for the punishment of the instigators of the outrages before the peace negotiations begin is denied here officially.

The second entertainment and ball in aid of the locked-out building trades of Chicago, held in the Lexington Opera House last night, presented the appearance during the greater part of the evening of a very turbulent political meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The news from China continues to be highly encouraging for the success of America's policy, or that part of which shows confidence in the willingness of the Chinese Empire to punish its own criminals.

Light on some phases of the situation in the Philippines and confirmation of several stories of the interest taken by the Fillpinos in American politics and the Presidential campaign are given in translations of documents sent to a friend in the United States by an American Army officer doing duty at the scene of hostilities.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1 -- To say that the Republicans are confident of carrying Connecticut next November is to give but feeble expression to the feeling that prevails not only in the committee room of the State Central Committee but wherever Republicans meet. Four years ago McKinley's plurality was almost as great as Bryan's total vote.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 1 -- The Baron and Baroness Hengel-Muller of Washington are at the Leclercq cottage on Dresser Street for a month's stay.

Most of the net changes resulting from yesterday's trading in the market for outside securities were on the side of advances, but in only a few cases were the changes more than fractional. Transactions were on a small scale, and only one or two stocks were sufficiently active to attract any attention.

MEADOW BROOK, L.I., Oct. 1 -- The Meadow Brook Hunt Club's regular schedule of cross-country runs was begun today, and the opening event of the season furnished some very creditable sport. The course was laid over eight miles of excellent hunting country. There were no ladies in the saddle.

A true account of Stephen Crane's first inspiration to write poetry is of singular interest. This young writer had an aversion to reading. He feared the influence on his style lest it quench his originality and put him in the way of unconscious imitation. One evening he was calling on William Dean Howells.

The first game of yesterday's double-, header on the Brooklyn grounds lasted eleven innings, Boston winning through a fumble by McGimnity. It was a pitchers' battle, Nichols winning out because of faultless support. The score:

Ex-Senator David B. Hill spoke last night to the Kings County Democracy in favor of the National and Stale tickets of the Democratic Party, and faced the men, many of whom were on the platform with him, who only a few weeks ago defeated his aspirations to be again the leader of the party in New York State and prevented the nomination of Controller Coler for Governor.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Oct. 1 -- A pretty wedding took place to-day in St. Saviour's Church, when Miss Maria Griswold Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Winthrop Gray, became the wife of William Bay Coster of New York City. St. Saviour's beautiful church was profusely decorated with white Autumn flowers, clematis, and red Virginia creeper.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 1 -- Mr. Bryan made the first speech of the day at West Superior, Wis., beginning before 8 o'clock in the morning. He immediately crossed the St. Louis River to Duluth, and, starting with an hour speech there, he made speeches at eight other places on the way, which, together with the speech at Duluth and Superior and those made to-night in this city, made an even dozen speeches for the day.

Columbia football managers and candidates received a surprise that left behind it something near consternation yesterday afternoon when to each aspirant for honors on the gridiron was delivered a circular from the Faculty Committee on Athletics setting forth the rules that had been adopted regarding the eligibility of a student to represent the university on any of its athletic teams.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- There was increased activity in the market to-day, Sugar, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Atchison, and Union Pacific leading. More interest was shown in the mining group. Prices gener- ally were firm. Gas and Coke was up 3/4, at 11 3/4, and the 5s 5, at 65. American Telephone fell 2, to 135, on the announcement of the death of President Hudson, but rallied to 138.

There was never a doubt at the Garrick Theatre last night, from the moment of the spirited entrance of David Harum in his own dooryard, after a drive behind that famous bay horse that would stand without a halter, (and did.) that Mr. Crane's portrayal of the horse-trading financier and homely philosopher and humorist was a lifelike and satisfying embodiment of the idea of Harum one gets from Westcott's prodigiously successful book.

When a general election approaches it has been the experience of business men to look in all directions for arrest of business, the interruption being caused, in some years, by both unduly excited public interest and properly aroused concern, or by one of these diverting reasons.

MANILA, Sept. 28, via Hongkong, Oct. 1 -- Persistent native reports, which are generally believed, have been current in Ma- nila for several days to the effect that Capt. Devereaux Shields and Company F of the Twenty-ninth Regiment of infantry, consisting of fifty-four men, stationed, at Boag, Marinduque Island, embarked Sept. 13 on the gunboat Villalobos and landed on the Marinduque coast Sept. 14.

LITTLE NECK, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Mrs. Willlam Kirkman, twice a widow, whose last husband was Capt. Kirkman of Saddle Rock oyster fame, answered an advertisement of a man who wanted a wife. The advertisement was answered in a few days by the appearance of a portly, well-dressed man of about titty, who said he was a wealthy fruit grower of California.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Mercer of the New York baseball team pitched a great same here to-day, and the home team's hits were few and scattered, During the game Lajoie was his by a pitched ball, and Delehanty hurt his arm in throwing. Both were forced to retire from the game. The score:

Robert F. Westcott, father-in-law of Capt. Oberlin M Carter, again took the stand when the hearing in the matter of the Southern harbor improvements frauds was resumed, before United States Commissioner Shields, yesterday at noon.

ROME, Oct. 2. -- A dispatch from Milan announces the arrest of five suspected Anarchists from the United States. One was found in possession of a revolver and a poniard. They were supplied with American and English money.

James R. Torrance has been appointed referee to sell the property 9 to 13 Maiden Lane, known as the Gill Building. The appointment was made by Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court upon entering judgment in a suit brought by Frederick Ayer against Frank N. Gill and others to foreclose a second mortgage of $233,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- There are some curious doings just now with regard to armor plate. The opponents of a Government plant at the last session of Congress made a compromise with the advocates of that scheme by which the power of establishing such a plant, was vested in the Secretary of the Navy, provided the armor plate corporations would not do the work cheaply enough.

The Speedway hadn't thoroughly recuperated yesterday from the rain, but going good enough for speed trials was found on the sides, and here the fast harness horses engaged in brushes at a lively rate for an hour or more. The closest brush of the afternoon was between the big pacer Jack, (2:12 1/2,) driven by Mrs. H. D. Gill, and the bay pacer Miss Meander, (2:16 1/2,) over whom George Main Held the reins.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Owing to the fact that Stevens plays Princeton's football team to-morrow, the latter were not lined up to-day against the scrubs, as has been their custom, but light signal practice end passing the ball consumed the allotted time for drill. The practice was as unsatisfactory as was the pitiable performance on Monday.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 2. -- About 700 members of the American Bankers' Association were in attendance at the opening, session of the annual meeting here this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Play in the Intercollegiate Lawn Tennis Association's twentieth annual tournament started this morning on the courts of the Merion Cricket Club, at Haverford, under somewhat disappointing conditions. An entry list in every way representative of the association's true strength had been confidently anticipated, but when the time of starting arrived it was found that only six of the members of the organization had representatives present.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- Gen. Osman Pasha, a near relative of the deceased Osman Pasha, the "Hero of Plevna," arrived to-day at Marseilles from Constantinople, whence he fled owing to the Sultan's suspicions that he was engaged in a conspiracy. He embarked surreptitiously on the steamer Bagdad in order to rejoin his relative, Mahmoud Pasha, in Paris.

This is the story of a little boy who did not run away to fight Indians. His purpose in leaving home, secretly and alone, was more worthy, but he forgot to tell his father, and hence was responsible for a lot of unnecessary worry.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- John Gleason, a man who is supposed to be demented, shot and seriously wounded the Rev. Lawrence P. McCarthy, rector of the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, of East Boston, at the parochial residence this afternoon.

-- After reading Archbishop IRELAND'S definite, and of course unquestionably correct, account of what the Pope and Cardinal RAMPOLLA told Him about their complete contentment with the policies and acts of the American authorities in Cuba, Porto Rico, and the Philippines, we are really sorry for papers belonging to the class of The New York Freeman's Journal.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 2. -- President Walters and other officials of the Atlantic Coast Line Company left Baltimore to-day for Bridgeport, Conn., where the annual meeting of stockholders will be held to-morrow. A plan to distribute part of the assets of the company among the stockholders has been approved by the Board of Directors, and will be submitted to the stockholders for ratification.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 2. -- Sixty thousand majority is the vote the Democratic Party of Georgia expects to obtain at the general State election to-morrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was thinking the other day, Mr. Editor, what a difficult task it was for the City of New York, under the cumbrous, complicated machinery of our new charter, to accomplish any public improvement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Favorable news has reached Washington from the European Chancelleries indicating that a complete agreement as to China is within sight.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- At the second day's racing of the Nottingham Autumn Meeting to-day the race for the Bentinck Plate resolved itself into a match between Richard Croker's The Scotchman II., ridden by tester Reiff. and E. Corrigan's Chimura, on which J. H. ("Skeets") Martin had the mount.
The annual report of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company for the year ending June 30, 1900, was made public yesterday.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 2. -- When William J. Bryan concluded his last speech here tonight he had made eighteen addresses and had consumed about fifteen hours of time during the day. Beginning at 8 o'clock in the morning, he talked at intervals until 11 o'clock to-night, putting in fully six hours of speechmaking.

LEXINGTON, Neb., Oct. 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt spoke to a large crowd in the public square here. He answered a question put to him by Mr. Bryan in a recent speech concerning the Ice Trust of New York, and took occasion to ask Mr. Bryan a question. He said:
ROME, Oct. 2. -- Thieves have entered the Vatican, forced a safe, and carried off sesurities worth 357,000 lire and 3,000 lire in silver.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The first game in the annual interclass baseball series was played on University Field this afternoon between 1902 and 1904. The game was watched with interest by all baseball enthusiasts in college, as it was the first appearance of the freshman team, and on this class will devolve the necessity of developing men for several vacant positions on the Varsity next Spring. 1902 won easily.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 2. -- Customers of the East Jersey Water Company from now on will have to drink Passale water taken from the river at Little Falls unless the company agrees to pay the city the price it asks for Pequannock water. At noon today the supply the company had been receiving was cut off by Engineer Sherrerd of the Water Department.

The Water Department in Brooklyn announced yesterday that there was something of an improvement in the water supply situation in that borough. The Gravesend and New Utrecht water systems had been tapped, it was said, and by this means 6,000,000 gallons were being added daily to the-borough's regular supply.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Senator Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, to-day made his first address in Chicago since his return from New York. He addressed a noon meeting of commercial men and retail salesmen. The large hall in which he spoke was filled, not a few women being in the audience.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 2. -- Perry Belmont, who represented this district in Congress for eight consecutive years, beginning in 1881, was again nominated to-day by acclamation, Townsend Scudder, the sitting member, presided over the Democratic Convention which would listen to no other name except that of Mr. Belmont.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The Democrats of Massachusetts met in Faneuil Hall here to-day, and with stirring speeches by the leaders of the party, nominated a full State ticket and adopted a platform. The ticket follows:

ST. LOUIS, Oct 2. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the St. Louis, South-western or Cotton Belt Route was held today at headquarters in the Equitable Building. President Edwin Gould called it to order, the principal business being the election of three Directors. A fight was expected on the part of minority stockholders who protested against a new by-law passed at the meeting last year.

Frequent readers of this paper do not need to be told that we have at all times endeavored to refer to Mr. CARL SCHURZ as a man whose long public service, earnest and able advocacy of many good causes, scholarly discussion of great issues, and unquestioned sincerity entitle him to the fullest respect.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Yesterday's pollings in the Parliamentary general election leave the state of parties at present as follows:

Perhaps the main merit of the French proposal with respect to the Chinese difficulty is the evidence it furnishes that there is not the " Asiatic Dreibund " the existence of which some German journals seem to affirm, although the German Government seems to deny. The last Asiatic Dreibund of which we have any authentic knowledge was that formed in 1895, in order to rob Japan of the fruits of her victory over China.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 2. -- The Brockton Pair opened to-day with one of the largest first day crowds that ever collected on the grounds. Over 10,000 people were present. The 2:50 trottins race was won easily by Gene D. in straight heats. In the second heat of the 2:35 pace, two drivers were thrown and one horse jumped the fence and was seriously injured.

A plumber's gasoline blower exploded at noon yesterday In the residence of Charles D. Blatchford, the property clerk of the Police Department in Brooklyn, at 240 Grand Avenue, near De Kalb Avenue, that borough, seriously injuring Mrs. Leonie Blatchford, wife of the property clerk; Anthony Bristman of 249 Kingsland Avenue, and Charles Murdoch of 137 Steuben Street.

WETUMPKA, Ala., Oct. 2. -- Winfield Townsend, alias Floyd, a negro, was burned at the stake in the little town of Eclectic, fifteen miles from this place, a half hour after midnight, this morning. The crime with which he was charged was an assault upon Mrs. Lonnie Harrington, whose husband set fire to the brands which reduced Townsend's body to ashes.

George F. Baker, President of the First National and Astor National Banks, was elected President of the New York Clearing House Association at the annual meeting of that body yesterday, to succeed James T. Woodward. Henry P. Davison, Vice President of the Liberty National Bank, was chosen Secretary of the association, succeeding Francis L. Hine.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2. -- The twenty-eighth Fall meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association opened to-day.

Traffic on the Sixth and Amsterdam Avenue, Columbus Avenue, and the Fifty-ninth Street Crosstown car lines was delayed for more than an hour last evening by the catching of a fender on a Sixth Avenue car at Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue. In some unknown manner the fender became caught in the slot, and before the car could be brought to a stand-still, had been twisted under the car.

Eugene Higgins's steam yacht Varuna, with her owner and guests aboard, arrived in port at noon yesterday after a European cruise of nearly twelve-months. Mr. Higgins's guests were Mr. and Mrs. E. Rollins Morse, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Alan Arthur, Miss Arthur, and Dr. Mitchell. The Varuna anchored off Stapleton, S. I., yesterday afternoon, where the party disembarked.

Peter Masterson, a Deputy Clerk at Police Headquarters since 1876, who was once a prominent contractor and a member of the Legislature in, 1859 and 1860, and an Alder man of the Thirteenth District from 1863 to 1867, died yesterday at 169 West Sixty-first Street in his seventy-fifth year. Mr. Masterson was one of the best known members of the Volunteer Fire Department, and as a "Vamp" he had an active and honorable career.

A man believed by the police to be Peter Burke killed himself by jumping from the central arch of High Bridge into the Harlem River yesterday. He was rescued from the water and taken ashore by two men who happened to be passing under the bridge in a skiff. He was alive, but bleeding from the mouth and ears, and with great difficulty managed to say that his name was Peter Burke.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt was accorded a magnificent demonstration this afternoon by the citizens of Lincoln. Nothing equal to it has yet been seen during the progress of the Governor's journey through the West. Along the line of march from the station to Capitol House Square the streets, windows, and balconies were filled with cheering people.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 2. -- The parade and mass meeting of the striking miners in this city to-day was the greatest labor demonstration ever held in North-eastern Pennsylvania. The sun shone brightly all day, and the weather was more like June than October.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

The successful effort of the French vintners to have certain American wines excluded from competition for prizes at the exposition, on the ground that they are fraudulently sold under names they are not entitled to use, applies especially to the California champagnes and burgundies.
BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The following is the text of the Chinese Emperor's message to Emperor William of Germany:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 2. -- A direct request was received to-day by the Pittsburg Coal Company for a price on coal for export, to be loaded at the seaboard, either at New York, Boston, or Philadelphia, and the amount was said to range from 200,000 to 1,000,000 tons.

After several weeks of legal sparring Gengiana G. F. Wendel was yesterday personally examined as to her sanity before the Commissioners and Sheriff's jury. Her appearance on the witness stand was unexpected and caused a sensation. It had been charged that her brother and sister were detaining her at their country home at Irvington-on-the-Hudson, and that they were trying to get possession of her property.

John Garrabrant, nineteen years old, who on May 5 lured Henry Maass, fifteen years, to the cellar of 182 Eighteenth Street, Jersey City, and killed him for the purpose of securing $3, was yesterday placed on trial for murder, in the Hudson County Oyer and Terminer Court, before Supreme Court Justice Collins and Judge Blair.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- An official of the French Foreign Office to-day formally confirmed the accuracy of the details of France's, note to the powers on the Chinese question as telegraphed from Vienna. Explaining the causes actuating the French Minister of Foreign Affairs in issuing the note, the official said:

A suicide, deliberately planned and carried out with a care for details which made its consummation almost an absolute certainty, was revealed yesterday morning in the finding of the body of Robert McCurdy Lord of Bayonne, N. J., in a vacant house in Mount Vernon. He had leased the house and paid a month's rent in advance.
Cable dispatches from London yesterday indicate an expectation there that the Bank of England's discount rate will be advanced to-morrow. Such forecasts are chiefly the merest matter of guesswork.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. --The War Department to-day made public some more captured Filipino correspondence. The letters are important, for they are the first that show the Filipinos to be holding out solely in the hope of Bryan's election. The other Filipino papers showed that the insurgents hoped for Bryan's victory, but did not state that they would yield in case of his defeat.

The Morris Park Fall meeting, with the $25,000 Matron Stakes as the chief event, opened yesterday with delightful weather, a fast and good track, and an excellent attendance. The racing was quite in keeping with the other conditions, though in the results there were numerous disappointments, greatest of which was the defeat of the hitherto unbeaten colt Commando by S. C. Hildreth's Beau Gallant for the Matron Stakes.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night "Tannhauser" was performed in English. The performance was this second in the series of representations offered by Messrs, Grau and Savage, and was an extremely ambitious undertaking for so young an organization. The audience was not nearly so large as that of the previous night, nor was its applause of so unmistakably friendly a nature.
