The Court of Appeals yesterday handed down a decision which establishes the jurisdiction of the municipal courts of New York in cases against non-residents and foreign corporations. The decision is of importance as upholding the constitutionality of the provision of the charter of Greater New York in regard to the municipal courts, and as affecting hundreds of cases of a similar nature to that upon which the action in the case decided was brought.

Although the new rule forbidding special students from representing the university in athletic competitions, until they have been a year in college, which was announced by the Faculty Athletic Committee of Columbia University on Monday, created no small degree of consternation when it first was made known, a careful consideration of the situation tends to give a more hopeful view.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It matters not what your individual politics are, THE NEW YORK TIMES is, without doubt, one of the most impartial newspapers in Greater New York. The publication in to-day's issue of Mr. Cockran's speech at Chicago and Mr. Coler's speech at Buffalo is sufficient evidence that the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be kept fully posted on the present campaign.

President York of the Police Board came to the City Hall yesterday ready for an argument with Mayor Van Wyck. The crowd at the meeting of the Board of Estimate when the police budget was under consideration heard a short but lively debate. The amount allowed for police purposes in 1900 was $11,992,503, and President York asks now $12,520,306.
Threatening weather yesterday afternoon depressed the attendance on the Speedway, but good sport was witnessed by those that were out.

The attendance at Morris Park yesterday was vastly better than the promise of the programme justified. The racing was only commonplace, in spite of the fact that two minor stakes were down for decision, and the only incident of the afternoon that was out of the ordinary occurred in the fourth race, which Pierre Lorillard's filly Servilia got through the disqualification of Boiling Beer for a foul.

Just before the adjournment of Congress a heated controversy arose between the Senate and the House on the question of armor plate for vessels of the navy partly completed and projected. The Senate had adopted the position, which it adhered to very tenaciously, that the Secretary of the Navy should not pay more than $445 a ton for the best modern armor plate.

It may be one of nature's Fall combinations, the cardinal flower and the purple aster, but when it comes to gowns it certainly looks odd enough. Red and heliotrope or purple. But there it is in the cloth gowns by first-class makers red frocks with purple revers and collars.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Brooklyn took both games to-day from Boston. Lewis was wild and Ineffective in the first game, while Yeaser held the Bostons to five hits. Superior base running by the Brooklyns enabled them to win the second came. Both Tenney and Dahlen were put out of the game for kicking in the second inning of the second game.
The shortage in the water supply of Brooklyn caused a very bitter discussion before the officials of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday.

The Sugar Trust treated Wall Street to another "surprise" yesterday. It is only a few weeks since official announcements were proclaiming that not only had the sugar trade war ended, but that higher prices for sugar had been agreed upon and would be maintained by the trust and all the refineries formerly independent or in opposition.

The thirty-ninth annual meeting of the Peabody Educational Fund was held yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Chief Justice Melville W. Fuller was named First Vice Chairman and presided at the meeting. The Right Rev. Henry B. Whippie, Bishop of Minnesota, was elected Second Vice Chairman.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The results of yesterday's polling in the Parliamentary general election showed less surprises than those of Tuesday. The Conservative majorities still show increases in numerous contests, but in a less marked degree. On the other hand, the Liberals have gained additional seats.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3. -- Capt. and Mrs. French E. Chadwick have closed The Nutshell.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 3. -- Brig. Gen. H.C. Merriam, United States Army, last evening made a sensational speech at the Loyal Legion banquet, in which he asserted that the recent riot at Victor was due entirely to Coeur d'Alene miners. He said: "We have heard of Gen. Irving Hale's experience with Roosevelt in Victor, when things were thrown his way.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- On Monday a United States warrant was issued for the arrest of Isaac A. Sweigard, lately General Superintendent of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company, charging him with discriminating against and discharging employes of the Heading Road because they were members of the brotherhood.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- At the first day's racing of the Leicester October meeting today "Johnnie" Reiff, the American jockey, rode the winning horse in the three following races:

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- For the first time this campaign the Democrats have broken the rule they had established and have given out an estimate upon the election by States. Vice Chairman J.G. Johnson of the Democratic National Executive Committee reached Chicago this morning, and he at once proceeded to figure out a table showing how he thinks Bryan will get 326 electoral votes, McKinley only 88, and the doubtful list will number 33.
Richard Croker gave out an interview last evening replying to attacks made on him by Senator Hanna.

WAUKESHA, Wis., Oct. 3. -- Mr. Bryan to-day made only five speeches and traveled by easy stages from Portage City to this place, speaking only at Portage, Columbus, Watertown, Oconomowoc, and Waukesha. He said to-night he would give the 8th and 9th of the month to Illinois, the 10th and 11th to Michigan, and the 12th, 13th, and 15th to Ohio.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- A scant victory and still less glory fell to the lot of the Columbia University football team in its first game of the season, played here to-day, against the Rutgers College eleven.

The Union League Club and Robert F. Bixby, as trustee under the will of his father, John M. Bixby, have arranged to have the lease of the land on which the clubhouse stands renewed for another term of twenty-one years. Formal, proceedings to carry out this agreement have been begun in the Supreme Court, and papers have been served on the interested parties.

While the season for horse, sales is still a month or more away, the few that are now held in the evenings, serve to attract so much attention that, they are sure to become a feature of the evening life of the town this Winter. Women will make them so. The character of these sales has been changed entirely within year or so.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- The British steamer Amana, Capt. Carr, from Samarang, Java, via St. Michaels, arrived this afternoon, having on board the Captain, Llewellyn Cook, First Officer John Jackson, Second Officer Carl Hensen, and thirteen of the crew of the Liverpool ship Ellerslie, which was abandoned at sea, dismasted and waterlogged.

A fire occurred yesterday morning in the power house of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company at Third Avenue and Second Street. In an instant thousands of wheels ceased turning and stagnation came upon the street car traffic of a great district. For an hour not a wheel turned on more than a dozen lines.

"I have had successes at the Fourteenth. Street Theatre in the past; such successes that I became ambitious and went up Broadway as far as Wallack's. They kicked me out up there. This seems to be my size, so I'm glad to get back home and am rejoiced that you are apparently glad to see me back once more."
BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- Marshal Leonhard von Blumenthal, the last surviving prominent General of the Franco-Prussian war, is dangerously ill.

The trade war between the American Sugar Refining Company on the one hand and the National and the Arbuckles on the other broke out in earnest yesterday, and the aggregate reduction in the price of sugar from 6.15 cents to 5.75 cents in one day is said to be the heaviest ever made in the history of the sugar trade.

A. De Witt Cochrane of the Ardsley Club, who held the golf championship of both the St. Andrew's and Ardsley Clubs one year ago, won the President's Cup yesterday in the opening round of the annual open tournament of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, near Chauncey, Westchester County.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- Senor Don Luis F. Corea, the Nicaraguan Minister to Washington, arrived in this city to-night. Minister Corea has been in Nicaragua for five months, and will return to Washington without delay. He declined to discuss his instructions relative to the canal project until after he reaches Washington.

TIEN-TSIN, Sept. 5, via San Francisco, Oct. 3. -- A terrible narrative of the massacres in Shan-Si Province has reached here through a native Christian teacher who ecaped, and, after a remarkable journey through the country by foot and boat, has just arrived. This man is a graduate from the North China College, speaking English fluently, and absolute confidence is placed in his statements by the American missionary officials here.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 3. -- Although most of the big companies have offered to the mine workers a 10 per cent, net increase in wages, not a move has yet been made by any of the strikers toward a resumption of work. The way the men have thus far stood together without showing arty weakness in any part of the ranks is considered remarkable.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3. -- At to-day's session of the annual meeting of the American Bankers' Association, Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer of the United States, gave an address on "The Treasury and the Money Market."
SYRACUSE, Oct. 3. -- Senator Depew, discussing imperialism to-night before a large Republican meeting, said:

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- At a meeting of the Drainage Board to-day the bid of the New York Security and Trust Company, by W. J. McDonald Co., agents, of $27,850 premium and accrued interest for the $2,500,000 4 per cent. bonds, known as the 1-20 bonds, was accepted by a unanimous vote. The best bid a week ago was for only $2,500 premium.

James Oliver West of 61 West Forty-ninth Street, a well-known holder of and operator in real estate, who had a fortune of not less than $250,000 and perhaps as much as $300,000, was found dead yesterday in the unoccupied house 2,012 Fifth Avenue, which he owned. The circumstances suggested an end like that of Robert McCurdy Lord, who on Monday suffocated himself with gas at 348 Summit Avenue, Mount Vernon.
Maclay Davies have sold for Aymar Embury the two five-story apartment houses, known as the Peerless and the Paragon, 115 and 117 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, on a plot 50 by 100.11.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The newspapers here unanimously applaud Emperor William's "championship of the combined interests of civilization and Christianity," as contained in his reply to the message of the Emperor of China.

-- Boston, naturally enough, is more interested in SIXTO LOPEZ than New York was, and, instead of treating him and his secretary, Mr. THOMAS T. PATTERSON of Brisbane, Australia, with an indifference mitigated only by a little mild amusement, is making apparently serious efforts to find out for just what purpose and at whose summons -- and expense -- the curiously assorted pair came here at this particular time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Princeton's footballers surprised everybody to-day by their strength. They defeated Stevens by the score of 40 to 0, Erratic practice of the past few days had prepared the students for a poor showing of the 'Varsity eleven, but they were very pleasantly disappointed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 3. -- The City of Indianapolis to-night presented a scene of Democratic festivity. From the various buildings in the business portion American flags and streamers of bunting were flung to the evening breeze, while prominent among the decorations, portraits of distinguished leaders of the Democracy, framed in electric bulbs, were displayed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The University of Pennsylvania's football game with Franklin and Marshall to-day was in the nature of a hard practice for the home team, the visitors being defeated by the score of 47 to 0. Since the Saturday game with Lehigh, when the latter succeeded in scoring six points on Pennsylvania, the players of the latter team have been carefully coached and groomed to prevent a repetition of that disastrous happening.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The Census Bureau to-day published the returns for the State of Arkansas, giving the population by counties, townships, and all incorporated towns.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3. -- The first number of The Harvard Democrat, edited by student voters of the university, will appear Saturday. It will be an eight-page weekly paper and it will be printed throughout the college year. George Marsh, Secretary of the Harvard Democratic Club, will be its first editor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Yale's football team won from Amherst this afternoon by the score of 27 to 0. Yale's heavy rush line worked up into something like condition for the first time this season, plowed through the heavy Amherst line at will, and the backs plunged through the line for gains in every play.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- War in the courts was begun this afternoon against the Chicago Gas Trust, and the battle over rates, which for weeks back has been "scattering," is now enlivened by firing all along the line.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Postmaster General Smith returned from his recent stumping tour in Indiana very much displeased with his treatment, and has not hesitated to express his opinion of the methods of the Republican State Committee.

The highest gross and net earnings reported by the Louisville and Nashville Railroad are shown in the annual report of that company, which was issued yesterday. With an average of 3,007.35 miles operated, the gross earnings show an increase of $3,982,093 over the figures for 1899. The net earnings increased $1,111,079, while the expenses showed an increase of $2,872,818.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The wedding of Miss Loretta Darby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Darby of Alton, N.J., and Edgar Felton Sheppard of Central Avenue, Plainfield, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C.E. Herring, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Plainfield.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- There was a moderate degree of activity in the market to-day. New York sold Sugar and bought railroad stocks. Price changes were few in the home specialties. The improved inquiry for bonds, noted yesterday, was sustained, twelve issues being represented in the morning's transactions.

Mrs. Grace Thacer Putnam, widow of Bayard Putnam, died suddenly yesterday at Jamestown, R.I. The cause of her death was heart trouble, from which she had been suffering since last Spring. Mrs. Putnam was the daughter of Thomas Thacher, who was a prominent merchant in New York a number of years ago.
READING, Penn., Oct. 3. -- Coal shipments on the Reading Railway have nearly ceased. There being no more coal to haul, navigation has stopped on the Schuylkill Canal.

The Republicans of the Eighth Congress District had a mass meeting last night at the Germania Assembly Rooms, 293 Bowery. The big hall was packed, and there was much enthusiasm. The meeting had been advertised as the opening of the campaign of Richard Van Cott, the Republican candidate for Congress in the district, and there was an outpouring of the members of the Republican organizations.

Roekaway won the Staten Island Cups yesterday in the polo competition which marked the annual tournament of the Staten Island Polo Club. It was one of the most closely contested games of the season, the result being in doubt until the very close of the game, when the Rockaway men rode off the field as victors by the narrow lead of three-quarters of a goal.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3. -- An interesting card drew a large crowd to the second day's races held under the auspices of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association. The weather was exceptionally fine and the track fast. The Futurity, for two-year-olds, purse $5,000, was won by L.V. Harkness's Walnut Hall.

With business so light that brokers on the curb were idle most of the day, changes of any importance in the outside market were not to be looked for. Yesterday's total was the smallest of the week thus far, and the number of issues the trading in which attracted any attention was very small indeed.

The Tammany Hall Congressional Conventions for the nomination of candidates were held last evening. There were no surprises and the slate prepared by the leaders went through without a break. The following were nominated:

The meeting of the City Club last night was devoted almost entirely to an arraignment of the Police Department. The particular subjects considered in this connection were the conduct of the police in the August riots and the failure of the department to check "the continued and flagrant manifestations of vice in various parts of the city."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The police of this city yesterday arrested a young woman who gave her name as Elenore Howell, and who said she lived in New York, but at what address the police refuse to tell. The police, in fact, refuse all information in regard to the case.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 63 1/2@65. There were no sales.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- The State Tax Commissioners to-day made public the final valuations of special franchises in every county of the State for 1900, as fixed under the franchise tax law. The total is $266,163,059, of which amount Greater New York last year's local valuations of $143,458,326, will pay on $219,679,351, an increase over.

When the trial of John Garrabrant, Jersey City's boy murderer, was resumed yesterday before Justice Collins and Judge Blair, Alexander Simpson, counsel for the defense, said that the atrocity of the crime was positive evidence that the defendant was a moral degenerate of the most pronounced type and totally irresponsible for his acts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Officials in Washington are convinced that a rapprochement among the powers on the China question is near at hand.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Harvard defeated Williams on Soldiers' Field this afternoon by 12 to 0. Last year Williams was the first team played, and then Harvard rolled up 29 points against it. From the Harvard standpoint to-day's game was disappointing. Harvard's two scores were made in the first half.

Magistrate Mott, in the Centre Street Police Court, lectured Capt. Stephenson of the Mulberry Street Station yesterday on the way in which the unregenerate, as the Magistrate said, are allowed to run things in his territory.
Julius Levy Co. have sold, for about $26,000, the six-story tenement 244 East Thirtieth Street, 25 by 100.

CHICAGO, Oct, 4. -- Mayor Harrison is making arrangements for a coup whereby the Chicago Gas Trust may be deprived of the big income derived by the lighting of the streets and the public given better service.

The trial of Foreman James D. Clifford of the Attorney Street Hook and Ladder Company No. 18, on charges based on results of his activity as President of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association was yesterday continued before Commissioner Scannell at Fire Headquarters. Charles Blandy of the Law Department appeared for Chief Croker, Clifford's accuser, and J. Van Vechten Olcott and John P. Everett for the defendant.

Philadelphos Council of the Royal Arcanum won two victories in the bowling tournament of the Brooklyn councils of that organization last night, defeating De Witt Clinton and Pro Patria Councils, while De Witt Clinton defeated Pro Patria. The scores, were:

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 4. -- Never before in the history of Westehester County was such a mysterious prisoner locked up in the County Jail at White Plains as Gregory Carter, known as the "gentleman burglar." That the prisoner has friends of means was demonstrated to-day when Lawyer Emanuel Friend appeared in the Mount Vernon City Court to defend him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A Post Office in Gilmer County, Ga., was to-day named after Theodore Roosevelt at the request of the inhabitants. Another in Braxton County, West Va., is evidently located among persons of a scientific turn, and is named after Nikola Tesla.

Dr. William Webb Browning died Wednesday night from a stroke of apoplexy, at his home at 155 Reid Avenue, in the Borough of Brooklyn. Dr. Browning had been in good health up to Wednesday afternoon, when he was stricken while riding along the Eastern Parkway with his daughter in an automobile.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The workman's side in the question of trade arbitration was presented before the Industrial Commission to-day by A. M. Hammett of Pittsburg, one of the officers of the Window Glass Cutters' Union, which is perhaps the most strongly organized union in the country, and at the same time maintains about the closest and most friendly relations with the manufacturers.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The Hongkong correspondent of The Times, wiring Wednesday, says:

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The continued weakness of foreign exchanges shows fears of gold withdrawals from the Bank of England, and the ready available supplies in the open market are being bought up for the Continent. So, though money is fairly plentiful, a great deal of caution is evident in the discount market, and there is an indisposition to do business on three months' paper below 4 per cent.

MONROE, Ga., Oct. 4. -- On the record of a sixteen-year-old boy Walton County challenges the world for cotton picking. On his last birthday, a few days ago, Warner Hale, of Goodhope was sixteen years old. He decided to celebrate his birthday by beating the world's record in cotton picking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In interest of the truth I am compelled to send you a few lines to contradict the statement given in your issue this morning of Herr von Brandt " that the missionaries caused the anti-foreign uprising by persisting in mingling in political affairs and seeking to gain political influence."

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The feature of to-day's work with the Cornell elevens was the line-up between the first and second 'Varsity teams in which, by rapid, work and close end interference, the regulars twice crossed their opponent's goal line.
Changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical Department:

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- With the open golf championship of the United States half over at the links of the Chicago Golf Club at Wheaton, Harry Vardon, former champion of Great Britain, leads his greatest rival, Champion J. H. Taylor, by one stroke. Vardon negotiated the 36 holes in 157 strokes.

All the Tenderloin knows of Walter Beverley Crane and his volume of "Odd Tales," and last night each policeman, as he came in from post, instead of going immediately to bed or holding converse and more or less acrimonious discussion upon the higher criticism, dug down under his pillow and produced a copy of the "Odd Tales," in which was inscribed: "To my very good friend, the police force, from the author."
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The loss of a sheep is causing the family of Nicholas Chiralla of Storm King, a small station near Cold Spring, a great deal of unhappiness.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The Democrats of Syracuse had their first political rally of the campaign to-day. Bird S. Coler; J.B. Stanchfield, and William J. Stone spoke at the Onondaga County Fair this afternoon to 3,000 persons, and at the Opera House in the evening to about 1,500, a crowd which about half filled the house.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 4. -- An important sale of real estate in the heart of the Summer colony was announced to-day by John Whipple, who sold for Mrs. Catherine. L. Kernochan her estate known as The Cloisters, on the cliffs, to James T. Woodward of New York.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The "khaki" boom has swept the country. Yesterday's pollings are a tale of increased Ministerialist and diminished Liberal majorities. The returns from the rural districts to-day (Friday) and to-morrow may do something to rehabilitate the Liberals, but the results thus far have fully justified Mr. Chamberlain and the party organizers who are backing the Government in their choice of the moment to dissolve Parliament.

Richard Croker is planning to end the campaign for Mr. Bryan here in a blaze of fireworks and oratory. The arrangements are being conducted quietly, and, while on the surface it would appear that the Tammany leader is not working very hard at this time, he is completing a comprehensive political scheme.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Only one of the seven boroughs of Birmingham was contested, but the Liberals organized an aggressive campaign to take one seat in Mr. Chamberlain's city.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 4. -- Tufts second eleven sprung a surprise on the 'Varsity at the game on Tufts Oval this afternoon, by defeating it by a score of 6 to 0.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- W. Bourke Cockran, who was to speak at St. Louis next Saturday under the direction of the Anti-Imperialistic League, has canceled the engagement owing to the league's inability to procure a hall.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 4. -- Three thousand strikers, headed by a band and 300 boy slate pickers, the latter carrying small American flags, left Mount Carmel at 6 o'clock this evening to march to Trevorton, sixteen miles distant, in Northumberland County, to compel the workmen of the North Franklin colliery to remain at home to-morrow.

We have the best authority for saying that there is not the slightest foundation in fact for the story recently circulated that Justice PATTERSON has come to an understanding with Mr. CROKER and Mr. WHALEN, by which the Justice is to refrain from seeking a renomination in order that Mr. WHALEN may be named for the Supreme Court this year, and a nomination may go to the Justice next year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has often occurred to me that the party platforms are based upon an assumption having very little substance, and I have often wondered at the credulity of the public with regard to it. It reminds me of the old problem as to why a bowl of water containing a live fish weighs no more than it would without it.

For the first time in a number of days the market for outside securities yesterday displayed some life, and the monotony of the market was broken by sharp advances in a number of prominent issues. The whole list showed signs of new strength, and the demand for stocks seemed broader than it had been in some days.
W.A. Fee Co. of Milwaukee have been appointed Wisconsin State agents of the North American Accident Insurance Company of Chicago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Active hostilities in the existing gas war to-day put some of the tenants of the Cleveland Plats, Fullerton and Cleveland Avenues, in a state of terror. Solicitors of the Municipal Gas Company are reported to have used threats and violence in their endeavors to take out the meters of the Ogden Company.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- Germany has issued a second note to the powers regarding the method of securing punishment for those guilty of the outrages in China. This note is issued as a result of the edict of the Emperor of China beginning proceedings against Prince Tuan and others. The text of the note is as follows:

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 4. -- Not the slightest notice has been taken by the striking miners of the 10 per cent increase offered to the employes by several of the larger coal companies. As far as is definitely known, not one striking miner has accepted the advance, but, on the other hand, more men have quit their places, notably in the Schuylkill region, where three additional collieries of the Reading Company were shut down.

On an improvised portion of the old Guttenberg horse racing course -- hard, dead, and sloping upward for the first 300 yards -- Maxwell TV. Long of the New ruin Athletic Club yesterday created three new world's records for 350, 400, and 440 yards, making them in 0:362-5, 0:421-5, and 0:47 respectively, and demonstrated beyond the shadow of a doubt that he is the fastest sprinter of the age.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- In view of the coal crisis in Europe resulting from the falling off of the English coal product, with the consequently enhanced prices. Chief Emery of the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the State Department recently addressed instructions to United States Consuls at some of the more important ports abroad, requesting them to indicate the prospects at their posts of the introduction of American coal.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4. -- The American Bankers' Association closed its annual meeting this afternoon. The association elected the following as its officers:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Notwithstanding the fact that Stevens played here yesterday, a fast practice game was played to-day between the 'Varsity and scrub teams. A long preliminary practice on signals and plays took the stiffness, resultant from yesterday's game, out of the men and made them eager-for work.

Louis Stern, one of the members of the New York Commission to the Paris Exposition, returned home on the Teutonic on Wednesday night. He was at his desk yesterday looking bronzed and hearty from his five months' sojourn abroad.
BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- The Republicans of Massachusetts met in the Boston Theatre to-day to hold their State Convention, and the following ticket was nominated:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4. -- Interest in the third day's programme of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeding Association Fall meeting was centred on the Transylvania 2:13 class trotting, purse $5,000. Boralma, winner of last year's Futurity, from Lawson's Boston stables, was the favorite at 2 to 3, and at this figure was played heavily, about $38,000 being placed on him.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 4. -- The Middlesex Republican County Convention this afternoon nominated Theodore Strong of this city for State Senator. The three present Assemblymen were renominated. They are Adrian Lyons of Perth Amboy, H. R. Groves of New Brunswick, and J. E. Montgomery of South Amboy. Dr. F. C. Henry of Perth Amboy was named for Coroner.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has received a communication from the Rev. Dr. William Alexander Parsons Martin, the aged President of the New Imperial University of China, reciting the story of the siege and fall of Peking as he saw it.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Oct. 4. -- Lying at the Morgue in this city, with a bullet through his heart, is a man powerfully built, black hair and mustache, about six feet tall, and aged apparently forty-five years. He was one of two men who, as stated yesterday, held up the Kansas City passenger train on the Burlington Road, three miles south of this city, at midnight.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler, for thirty years pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, according to his custom for over a decade, last night addressed his friends and neighbors on the issues of the National campaign. The meeting was held in the assembly room of the Republican Club, at 104 South Oxford Street, and was under the auspices of the Eleventh and Twelfth Election Districts Associations of the Twentieth Ward.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 4. -- The Democratic Congressional Convention of Dutchess, Ulster, and Putnam Counties, comprising the Eighteenth District, was held here this afternoon, but no candidate could be found to run against Gen. John H. Ketcham, the veteran Republican Congressman, and he was renominated.

The schedules of assets and liabilities of the insolvent banking and brokerage firm of Hatch Foote were filed in the New York Supreme Court yesterday by Daniel B. Hatch, the surviving partner. They show liabilities of $1,910,120, nominal assets of $1,897,069, and actual assets of $1,567,713.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4. -- The Yale team was put through some extremely hard practice this afternoon, the weak points in the team yesterday being given the closest attention to-day. Ward was substituted for Gould at left end, Bloomer kept his place at tackle, Hamlin took Sheldon's place at guard, and Chadwick went into the back field.

SALEM, N. J., Oct. 4. -- Isaac Boyer, sixty years old, shot and mortally wounded his wife to-day in a fit of anger. The woman is still alive. But for the intervention of neighbors the woman would have been beaten to death with the stock of the musket after receiving two charges of buckshot in her body.

The decision of the Court of Appeals this week that Thomas J. Percival, a dockmaster, who sued to be reinstated after having been removed, was properly removed, or, at least, that the department had the power to remove him without charges, has dealt a blow at the White civil service law, which has for some time been expected by its supporters, especially the Civil Service Reform Association.

HONOLULU, Sept. 26, via Victoria, B.C., Oct. 4. -- Republicans and Democrats each held their conventions on the 24th. Each party named a native Hawaiian for delegate to Washington. The Independents are sure to put up Robert W. Wilcox.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- Howard Fetterly of Euclid, N.Y., aged twenty years, a guest at the Otter Lake Hotel, in the Adirondacks, was mistaken this afternoon by John App for a deer, shot through the heart, and instantly killed.

The Republicans of this State have practically completed their list of nominations for the State Senate. In a very few districts where heavy normal Democratic majorities prevail no candidates have been named, but it is possible that selections may be made before next Friday, when all certificates of regular nominees must be on file.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 4. -- In a political speech here to-day Lieut. Gov. Woodruff devoted his time to an examination, and criticism of the speech made here yesterday by Senator Mackey. He ridiculed the assertion made by the latter that the question of imperialism had been fought out long ago between Thomas Jefferson, representing the anti-imperialists, and Alexander Hamilton, the representative of imperialism.

Magistrate Mott's criticism of Capt. Stephenson of the Mulberry Street Police Station for allowing Bowery dives to run unmolested, and saying that he believed that the police know all about and are interested in those places, caused much talk yesterday among the merchants in the vicinity of "Paris by Gaslight," against which it is charged that it is simply a "fake" show conducted as a blind for a dishonest "pin" game.

OMAHA, Oct. 4. -- Gov. Roosevelt received a most enthusiastic greeting from the citizens of Omaha, before whom he discussed the campaign issues this evening. He was met at the train by the Reception Committee and, after a parade through the streets, was conveyed to a tent where an enormous audience had assembled.

The prompt adhesion of our Government, to-day announced, to the modified proposal of Germany, gives good hope of maintaining the concert of the powers in China until all the grievances of the Western world have been redressed. It offers a promise of that "indemnity for the past and security for the future" upon which we have all along insisted.

The feature of the meeting of the Board Of Estimate yesterday was a dispute between Mayor Van Wyck and President Holahan of the Board of Public Improvements. Mayor Van Wyck made charges against President Hotahan, who replied:

Two or three weeks ago a sudden, violent attack was made on the Stock Exchange upon an important iron and steel security -- the stock of the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company -- along with emphatic assertions that the company's business had become so bad that dividends would have to be suspended.
BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 4. -- All records for attendance at the famous Brockton Fair went to smash this afternoon, with 50,000 people on the grounds, a toal of 90,000 for three days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Part of the Washington street-car system was tied up to-day by a little girl's hoop. Late this afternoon she was rolling the hoop along C Street Northeast, when it rolled on the tracks of the electric railroad. Just as a car came along the hoop fell into the slot between the tracks.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 4. -- A man who gives the name of D. R. Knight was arrested this afternoon on suspicion. He came in on a train from Pacific Junction, Iowa. There is no evidence against him, except his alleged suspicious actions.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., Oct. 4. -- It was learned to-day through reliable sources in railroad circles that the Vandalia system, which terminates at South Bend, Ind., has leased the Milwaukee, Benton Harbor, and Columbus Railroad, which operates between Benton Harbor and Buchanan, Mich.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 4. -- The hall in which was assembled the National Association of Democratic Clubs was thronged this afternoon, probably 5,000 persons being present, but as the hour approached for the advent of Mr. Bryan at 4 o'clock the aisles were filled and the hall became crowded almost to suffocation.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Miss Mamie Hand, daughter of a banker of Millville, was married last night to Maurice Wriggins, also of that place. The bride is about sixteen years of age, and the bridegroom two years older. The wedding, although taking place in the home of the trifle's father, was the outcome or an elopement.

PEKING, Sept. 30. -- The withdrawal of the United States force from Peking will begin on Oct. 3. The marines, Major William P. Biddle commanding, will march to Tien-Tsin, and the Fourteenth Infantry regiment will follow them closely.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 4. -- It is probable that the departure of President and Mrs. McKinley for Washington next Monday will end their Summer vacation in Canton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Propositions of a far-reaching character concerning China are being presented in rapid succession to this Government. The State Department had no sooner disposed of one of these propositions to-day by delivering a response to the German Government than it was confronted by an even more important proposition submitted by the French Government, and within half an hour formally seconded by the Russian Government.

Albert T. Patrick, the attorney, and Charles F. Jones, the secretary, of the late millionaire, William Marsh Rice, were arrested last night and taken to Police Headquarters, charged with forgery. They are accused of having forged signatures to checks and assignments drawn by Mr. Rice.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Dull, threatening weather greeted the contestants in the intercollegiate lawn tennis championship tournament when play was resumed on the courts of the Merlon Cricket Club at Haverford to-day. The balls played heavily owing to the dampness of the ground, and notwithstanding the attention given them by the ground keepers, the courts were rough and uncertain.
The intercollegiate Gun Club shoot will be held at Princeton Nov. 17, the morning of the Yale-Princeton football game. Pennsylvania, Yale, and Harvard will send teams.

We have received a certain number of inquiries, some of which we have published from time to time, as to how the election of Mr. BRYAN would affect the business interests of the country. The number of such inquiries is not nearly so great as it was four years ago, and it is evident that the true character of Mr. BRYAN'S policy and ideas is more clearly understood than at that time.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 5. -- The belief prevalent here that the anthracite coal strike is approaching an end is considerably strengthened to-day by the action of the individual operators in following the lead of the big coal-carrying and coal-mining railroads by offering a net increase of 10 per cent. in wages.

It was with considerable hesitation that Myrtle Reed's second volume of a musician's love letters was taken up, a natural inference being that Miss Reed could scarcely hope to repeat her first success. Yet that she has equaled, if not surpassed, the interest of her earlier letters is soon apparent.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage. The amount of the mortgage plus 1,000 times the value of the revenue stamps on the conveyances should therefore show the true consideration.

On an October morning, just before daybreak, THE SATURDAY REVIEW four years ago was born. There were eight pages in that birthling. To-day it has grown to sixteen pages for ordinary Saturdays and to forty for some other Saturdays of the year. Eight goes into sixteen twice, and into forty five times.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 5. -- Albert T. Patrick of New York City, whose arrest in New York on the charge of forgery occurred yesterday, is a son of Capt. H.D. Patrick of Austin. Capt. Patrick is local freight agent of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad, and his family are highly esteemed.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 5. -- In a letter to The Ledger, which will be published in that paper to-morrow, Wayne MacVeagh, who was Ambassador to Italy under President Cleveland's Administration, in giving his reasons for supporting Mr. McKinley, says in part:

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 5. -- Eight Italians employed on the night shift of the Calvin Pardee Co. colliery at Lattimer were attacked on the public road leading from that place to Hollywood early this morning by twenty-five women, who had marched from Milnesvllle. The women were mostly Hungarians and Italians.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Before the largest gallery that ever witnessed a golf championship in America, Harry Vardon, former champion of Great Britain, won the United States Golf Association open championship from Great Britain's premier golfer, J.H. Taylor, by the narrow margin of two strokes, on the Chicago Golf Club links, at Wheaton, this afternoon.

The football situation at Columbia University was considerably clarified yesterday afternoon as the result of a joint conference between the Faculty Committee on Athletics and the football managers. While the Faculty Committee held firmly to the eligibility rules previously announced, assurance was given, that their provisions would not be interpreted in a hostile or unreasonable spirit.

Below will be found a chronological list of the American poems and plays to the McKee collection, printed before the year 1800. As already announced In THE SATURDAY REVIEW the McKee collection, a very remarkable collection, is to be sold this season by John Anderson, Jr. This will form only a small portion of that division of the library devoted to poems and plays.

The Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-first District was held in a hall at One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue last evening. Its feature was a riot In which many delegates, many more of their partisans, a number of city officials, and fifty or more police armed with clubs and revolvers, participated.

Advances recorded on Thursday were well maintained yesterday and some further gains were made. The outside securities market at present is strong, but little activity develops. Some or the largest of the day's gains were accompanied by transactions in only a few hundred shares, and the improvement that showed in closing quotations was due not to any large buying, but to the scarcity of stocks.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The Institute of Journalists is a very respectable body, and it is earnestly desirous of improving the profession which it represents. At its last meeting it decided that the time had come for the examination, of persona wishing to enter the profession of journalism, and accordingly its Council is to draw up a scheme for such an examination.

The sixty-million-dollar American Ice Company has for several days been the subject of gossip in Wall Street because of stories that it is to be reorganized. One of the most persistent of the stories was that the most active of its Vice Presidents, J.D. Schoonmaker, is to succeed President C.W. Morse, who created the company and dictated, up to last May, its policy.

The distinguished English gentlemen of the literary vocation who would place a medallion portrait of John Ruskin in Westminster Abbey may not be aware that their scheme has already been condemned by Ruskin himself. They should brighten up their knowledge of his autobiography. Ruskin had no patience with the way the monuments were "tossed into the Abbey."

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- At the first day's racing of the Kempton Park Autumn meeting to-day the Imperial Produce Stakes, of 3,000 sovereigns, was won by H. Chaplin's bay filly, by Gapolin, out of Queen Adelaide, ridden by "Danny" Maher. Second place was captured by Mr. Theobold's brown colt Volodyoyski, by Florizel II.-La Reine, Lester Reiff having the mount, and Santa Linda came in third.

Joseph Arthur, the playwright and author of the melodrama "Lost River," has decided for the future to abandon writing or staging any more plays. Mr. Arthur feels that it would be impossible for him to stand the strain of undergoing the production of any more new plays, and therefore feels, with what he has already done for dramatic art, that he has accomplished enough.

Felix Bonpre, the venerable and saintly "Cardinal-Archbishop of a certain small, half-forgotten but once historically famed cathedral town or France," visits Rouen, and lodges opposite the cathedral. In the silence of the night he hears a wailing cry, and going out into the moonlit square he finds a desolate boy leaning against the cathedral door.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5. -- Dr. William T. Bull has returned from New York.

Here is a highly moral tale which will make good reading for both old and young. It is a valuable illustration of the text "The way of the transgressor is hard." It is a story of a woman and an umbrella. It is apparent that the umbrella has been the cause of the fall from strict honesty of many otherwise irreproachable individuals.

The columns of to-day's issue at THE SATURDAY REVIEW will sufficiently excuse this article. A friend, after saying many kindly things about us recently, closed his praise with this paradoxical assertion:
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 5. -- The crisis in the coal miners' strike seems to be approaching. Both sides are playing a waiting game, and each imagines that it has the winning card up its sleeve.

How are the mighty fallen! There was a time within the memory of living men when Andrew Lang was regarded as a sort of Sainte-Beuve, or a lesser Taine, or a Matthew Arnold. But the fate of the pitcher that goes too often to the well is notorious. This merry Andrew could not content himself with writing criticism when his convictions called upon him to do so.

The Brooklyn police yesterday arrested three alleged confidence men, who, they claim, they balked in an effort to swindle Capt. John C. Trecartin, a wealthy retired mariner, who lives at 189 Gates Avenue. It is believed by the police that at least one of the men under arrest was of the gang which swindled the late ex-Alderman John French of Brooklyn out of $5,000 about a year ago.

Charles Campbell Goffe, head of the stock brokerage house of C.C. Goffe Co., died early yesterday morning at his home, 174 West Seventy-fifth Street. His death was caused by a malignant carbuncle which developed about ten days ago.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5. -- The track was fast to-day, and same Charlie Herr broke the track record for a race by going the second heat in the 2:08 trot in 2:07 flat, which is a new record also for the little bulldos trotter. He won the race in straight heats and was loudly applauded when the race was over. The summaries:

Max Marx has bought, through David Stewart, from William C. Baker of Grand Rapids, Mich., the plot having frontages of 157.10 feet on Eleventh Avenue, 162 feet on Audubon Avenue, and 350 feet on One Hundred and Eighty-sixth Street.

The fast steppers met in brushes so frequently on the Speeaway yesterday afternoon that there was almost a continuous procession of speed contests. From 3:30 o'clock until 6 there was something going on nearly every minute, and a splendid day's sport was the result. The brushes were as spirited as they were numerous.

There was a sudden change yesterday in the plan to nominate Corporation Counsel Whalen for the Supreme Court bench in place of Justice Edward Patterson. The news leaked out from the inner circle of politicians who surround Richard Croker. It was accepted as settled by many politicians at a late hour last evening that Corporation Counsel Whalen had stepped aside and that Justice Patterson would be renominated on the Democratic ticket.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I am moved by your felicitous reference to "jesting Pilate" on the editorial page of THE REVIEW of to-day to seek light on a matter that has for long Interested and perplexed me. "'What is truth?' said jestin Pilate, and he waited not for an answer."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Board of Visitors to West Point for 1900 has submitted its report to the Secretary of War. The board considers it unfortunate that so much time during the first year is of necessity devoted to the study of elementary subjects, and for the purpose of obviating this necessity recommend that the standard of admission be raised.

Commissioner William Dalton of the Water Supply Department said yesterday that effective measures have been taken to temporarily remove the danger of a water famine in the Bronx District. Late last night the work of laying water mains from the old aqueduct in Jerome Park, connecting with the Bronx mains at Sedgwick Avenue, was completed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- By defeating the sophomore class to-day in the fourth of the series of interclass baseball games, the juniors won the class championship. The score was 3 to 0. The most interesting game of the series will be played to-morrow, when the sophomore and freshman nines will contest.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Shorts in October pork received an unexpected shaking up to-day by the price jumping $2 per barrel, part of it at the rate of 50 cents between trades. The price went from $13 to $15, and closed at $14.50, a net gain of $1.40 for the day. Within thirty days there has been an advance of $3.20.

President Wagar of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange announced from the rostrum of the Exchange that John Zeeman and Harry L. Williamson of 52 Broadway had been expelled from membership by the Board of Directors for alleged "obvious fraud" and "false pretenses."
BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The following dispatch from St. Petersburg has been semi-officially issued here:

Albert T. Patrick, who was the attorney for William Marsh Rice, the millionaire who died suddenly on Sept. 23 last, and Charles F. Jones, who was Rice's private secretary, were arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court before Magistrate Mott yesterday afternoon and held in $10,000 bail each for examination on Monday morning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Harvard will play Bowdoin College on Soldiers' Field to-morrow. Bowdoin has shown considerable strength this Fall, and its supporters think it may threaten Harvard's goal line.

Mrs. Sarah Grand has indignantly denied the insinuation of Dr. Price of Birmingham, England, that she wears ''pantaloons" when she goes sketching in France. As details of ladies' costumes are always topics of interest to the French press, this denial is sure to be widely republished, and yet we trust that the French scribe will be careful in translating it.
PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The following official note was issued here this afternoon:

Notwithstanding that the requirements for admission to the Union Theological Seminary are this year more rigid than ever before, there is a considerable increase in the number of students enrolled over last year. The changes in the requirements for admission affect principally non-collegiate students.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Capt. Beverly W. Dunn of the Ordnance Bureau has returned from Europe, where he spent several months in the study of ordnance matters in England, Germany, France, Belgium, and Switzerland. He was able to secure much valuable information regarding the manufacture of ordnance, and found the army officers of the European Governments very accommodating in giving their methods and views.

Capt. William B. Gordon, Ordnance Department, will make one visit each week for ten weeks from Water-town Arsenal to the C.H. Cowdrey Machine Works, Fitchburg, Mass., on official business pertaining to the inspection of projectiles.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A serious fire has occurred at Welbeck Abbey, Worksop, Nottinghamshire, the famous seat of the Dukes of Portland. The Oxford wing was gutted, but the priceless pictures and furniture were saved. The damage was about u25,000. The Duke and Duchess of Portland are at present absent from home.

Sixty thousand pounds of paper have just been received at Harper Brothers' to be employed in the one volume edition of "Eleanor." The paper if placed one sheet upon another would make a tower 530 feet high. If these sheets were placed end to end in a straight line they would extend for about 1,000 miles. In all about 5,000,000 square feet of paper will be printed over.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 5. -- According to the statement of President T.H. Watkins of the committee which went to New York to demand better tolls for the individual operators, the latter will to-morrow join with the big companies in posting notices of the 10 per cent. offer, by which it is hoped to end the strike.

Accused of no criminal offense, Jean Cazielles, a Frenchman employed as a waiter in a saloon at 123 West Twentysixth Street, arrested for alleged violation of the excise law, remained in the Tombs, prison from July 21 until yesterday, awaiting trial on a charge long since dismissed by the Grand Jury.

PHILADELPHIA, oct. 5. -- Great strength continued to pervade the stock market today. Indicating that bullish sentiment was steadily growing. The more important features in point of activity and strength were Union Traction, United Gas, and the Choctaws, all of which responded more or less sharply to covering by the short interest, increased commission house buying, and support of an inside character.

Four stake events in a programme of six races made an ambitious card at the Morris Park track yesterday, and save such promise of sport as to draw an unusually large attendance. The weather was warm, and the track good. The racing was spirited from first to last, though foul and reckless riding somewhat marred the sport.

The Board of Estimate yesterday considered the amount of money which, will be allowed for the Departments of Water Supply, Public Buildings, Lighting and Supplies, and Bridges for 1901. A surprise came at the end of the meeting, when Mayor Van Wyck paid a compliment to Controller Coler.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I am not going to enter into the discussion as to whether the characters in "David Harum" are drawn from life or from imagination. I don't know: I don't care. Sufficient it is that I have read the book, and liked it so much that I bought a copy for the "shelf."
In view of the fact that the Erie Railroad is one of the lines involved in the present anthracite coal strike, its annual report, issued yesterday, attracted more than ordinary attention.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 5. -- Gov. Pingree has called a special session of the Legislature for next Wednesday noon. It will be called upon to pass a resolution submitting to the people a Constitutional amendment for the ad valorem taxation upon cash value of the property of railroads and other corporations, the same as individual property is taxed.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 5. -- The Yale Republican Club was organized this evening at a mass meeting attended by some 700 of the undergraduates. James R. Sheffield, Yale, '87, of New York City, addressed the college men, and an enthusiastic meeting was held.

One part of the annual address of the President of Columbia University ought to attract general notice. It is that which sets forth the assimilation of the various requirements of the colleges in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania, and the holding of entrance examinations by an intercollegiate examining board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn has been advised that a short time ago a young man called at a house in Augusta, Me., and presented a card on which was printed: "Committee on Distribution Official Records, Washington, D.C. Represented by Arthur J. Chalmers."

Slipshod Honor Endicott -- that is to say, the woman is mentally slipshod! What a strange and incomprehensible heroine Eden Phillpotts has drawn! Honor is indeed a woman to try a man's patience. She never could have had that loyalty which is the grand quality of the woman. She never did know her own mind.

The developments in the week in business circles have not been important. While the general tone is favorable, the situation at present may fairly be termed a waiting one. Where activity appears it is for the most part in the line of actual necessaries. Where orders can be withheld -- where, in other words, wants are not pressing-there orders are withheld.

The annual Horse Show at Goshen will be the notable social event of to-day. A large society delegation will go up from Tuxedo, many of whom are to exhibit horses and to participate as riders or drivers in the show. There will toe a meet of the Meadow Brook Hounds at Meadow Brook, which will be preceded by a breakfast.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The International Peace Congress epitomized its work in an appeal to the nations, adopted this afternoon, in which it says the congress condemned the refusal of the British Government to agree to arbitration or mediation in South Africa and expresses keen regret that the majority of the Governments which might have offered mediation abstained from so doing, in spite of their pacific declarations at The Hague.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- James H. Eckels, ex-Controller of the Treasury, spoke in the Auditorium to-night to an audience that packed the great hall, hundreds of people being turned away.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Thirty-two contests took place yesterday in the Parliamentary general election. Most of them were in rural districts, and the results have not yet been announced.

The play taken from "David Harum" has now been produced with a sufficient measure of success to indicate that the publishers of the novel, who, with the copyright, hold also the property rights in the play, will make still more money within the year or two out of their wise investment in Westcott's story, and that the heirs of the dead author will have their royalties handsomely increased.

The unanimous decision rendered by the Supreme Court of Michigan declaring un-constitutional the law allowing the beet sugar manufacturers of that State 1 cent a pound in bounty has aroused much interest among those engaged in the beet sugar industry in New York, because of the influence the decision may have In this State

The student of Hawthorne and his work cannot escape the sense, of disagreement between the outward events of the author's life and that which one instinctively feels to have been the needs of one side of his nature. There were within him two personalities -- the recluse and the man of action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The British Government has followed in the footsteps of the United States in the Chinese negotiations. It has authorized Sir Claude MacDonald, the British Minister at Peking, to enter into relations with the Chinese officials, just as our Government did in the case, of Mr. Conger.
Not enough attention has been paid to one aspect of Mr. ODELL'S canvass for the Governorship, which nevertheless is of considerable public importance.

Mary Conlon, the wife of an architect and the mother of his twelve children, has brought injunction proceedings to restrain her husband from entering his own home. Mr. Conlon surprised Justice Lawrence and many lawyers in Part I. of the Supreme Court yesterday by pleading his own cause.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The adjournment late last night of the anniversary meeting of the New Shaven Baptist Association was preceded by a lively debate occasioned by a sensational attack on the Newton Theological Seminary, near Boston, and the University of Chicago.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Speaking here this evening before a large and enthusiastic Republican meeting, Senator Depew said:

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5. -- The Port Chalmette Terminal, equipped for handling, compressing, and loading cotton by the newest and cheapest methods and also for handling grain, and which is considered the finest terminal of the kind in the world, will be offered for sale at auction by order of the courts at noon to-morrow, at an upset price of $1,500,000.

It is much to be hoped that nothing will occur to check the flow of CROKER'S new-found loquacity. His deliverances upon National and State politics may be merely diverting; but next year, when the character of his rule over this city comes up for investigation, his remarks upon municipal politics may be serious enough to turn many votes.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 5. -- The Executive Committee of the National Democratic Committee issued the following address to-night:
The art schools are now opening their doors for another year of work and study.

Carl Schurz has decided to resign the Presidency of the National Civil Service Reform Association. Mr. Schurz, who is still at Lake George, has written a letter to the Executive Committee, in which it is understood he treats of questions affecting his proposed resignation.

HOCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 3. -- Gov. Roosevelt, who spoke in this city and Davenport, Iowa, to-night, thus closing another day of hard campaigning, is beginning to feel the effects of the arduous work undertaken by him at the request of the Republican campaign managers. Since he began his itinerary through the Northwestern States he has been speaking from ten to twenty times each day, closing the day's labors usually with a night meeting.

Politics has thus far brought nothing but unmixed and bitter woe to the Rev. Daniel W. Wisher, colored, late pastor of the Mount Olivet Baptist Church, in West Fifty-third Street, and still later pastor of the Baptist Temple, in West Forty-sixth Street. It was during the campaign two years ago that the Rev. Mr. Wisher, from the Mount Olivet pulpit, indorsed Tammany Hall as the rock on which the colored citizen should stand.

You hint, and quite justly, that the list of ten books to take along when you are cast away for life on a desert Island is more or less conventional. I have sprung the question on halt a dozen groups, and the Bible has always headed every list. Yet I would swear that not one out of ten of those who made the lists ever thinks of reading the Bible for pleasure, or ever will.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Democratic Congressional Committee is much exercised over what it asserts is a Republican scheme to make Senator Pettigrew's speeches convert doubtful voters to McKinley. The committee recently sent out through the public document room a large number of Mr. Pettigrew's most powerful and convincing efforts.

MORRIS ROSS of The Indianapolis News writes regarding Goss's The Redemption of David Corson": "There is a historic anecdote that his Majesty once received the announcement from a writer ambitious of attention that his Apology for the Bible' would soon be completed, and that he would have the pleasure of presenting it to his Majesty.

W.B. DARRACH. Ambler, Penu.: "Can any of your readers inform me who is the author of a short poem, entitled 'How Doth Death Speak of Our Beloved?' It is a short poem I copied some years ago from an English magazine, I think. The refrain Is:

Although nature presents comparatively little evidence that October Is here once more, the leaves being still almost as dense as in midsummer, with no brilliant coloring to be seen, there are other signs which point to Autumn's presence, such as the announcement of the Winter concert seasons, the Kneisel, the Philharmonic, or the Boston Symphony, and the opening of the various theatres for a supplementary If not for the regular season.

The alleged inadequacy of service, mismanagement, and total disregard of the comfort of the traveling public on the part of the Brooklyn Rapid. Transit Company was the topic of discussion at last night's meeting of the Committee of Fifty of the Manufacturers' Association at its head-quarters in Montague Street.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- 4:15 A.M. -- It is reported in St. Petersburg, according to the correspondent of The Times at the Russian capital, that the Chinese fleet in Formosa Strait attempted to engage the Russian armored cruiser Rurik, but the latter's speed frustrated the plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- On behalf of the Universal Peace Union, Alfred H. Love, its President, has issued an offer to the mine operators, miners, and others interested in the anthracite strike to arbitrate the differences. An alternative suggestion is that delegates be appointed by the miners and operators to confer on the questions under dispute.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 5. -- Weather and turf were favorable for good golf today, except for a shower of short duration during luncheon. There have been no real surprises to-day for the men who were looked upon as promising for the final meet to-morrow. These are Jack Forrest of Philadelphia and Dr. Harban of Washington.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- As is the Tigers' custom before a game, no line-up between the 'Varsity and scrub teams took place to-day, but, in preparation for tomorrow's game with Lehigh, lively signal and play practice consumed, the allotted time.

Mrs. Lillian Smith, thirty-three years old, wife of Walter Smith, who is employed in a Broadway dry goods store, yesterday afternoon killed herself, her six-year-old son Andrew, and her four-year-old daughter Mabel. She used a revolver and carbolic acid, and she also shot her daughter Ethel, twelve years old, twice in the breast.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 6. -- Sheriff Harvey came to Wilkesbarre from Hazleton this afternoon. His story of the Lattimer affair this morning is as follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The game between Pennsylvania State College and the cadets ended to-day with the score nothing for either side. The weather was extremely hot and both sides suffered from its effects. The cadets' playing was greatly improved since the game with Tufts, Bettis, Farnsworth, Smith, and Casad did some good work for the cadets.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Yale won from Tufts this afternoon by the score of 30 to 0, in what was one of the fiercest football games ever seen at the Yale Field in early season. Tufts played a strong and aggressive game, and while they were unable to score, held Yale's tremendous line plunges in good shape and made the Yale backs very wary of trying end runs.

There was cheer among Columbia students over the showing of their football team in the game with Wesleyan University eleven on Columbia Field yesterday afternoon. The total score rolled up against the visitors was only 12 to 0, but the play of the local team, in spite of the depressingly warm and humid air, had in it the nerve, dash, and determination that has all along been lacking.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- Boston's good market in the mining stocks continued. Old Dominion, Centennial, Utah, and United States Oil were conspicuous for activity. Montana rose 3, to 325, closing at 324. Old Dominion was at 211 1/4, closing at 211. Centennial rose 1 5/8, to 17 5/8, closing at 16 3/4.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The supply of loanable capital is exceedingly large, and advances for a day are obtainable at 2 per cent, and even less. Discount, however, is fairly maintained, in view of the unsatfactory condition of the New York and Continental exchanges, although the market is placing some hope in the shipment of half a million in gold from India.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tammany Hall should remember the wellknown and oft-repeated saying of Abraham Lincoln, "You can fool the people once; you might twice; but you cannot fool the people all the time."

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- All hope of a Liberal victory was abandoned from the first, if anybody, indeed, ever entertained it. After the result of the boroughs' pollings was declared yesterday morning all talk of a reduction of the present majority has also ceased. The Liberal Party may think itself fortunate if it escapes a worse fate than befell it in 1895.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The National campaign was opened here to-night, when President Jacob G. Schurman of Cornell University delivered an address before the university Republican Club, in Alexander Hall.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 6. -- H.M. Forrest of the Philadelphia Country Club won the Virginia Cup in the Hot Springs tournament this afternoon by defeating L.L. Harban of Columbia Club, Washington. It was the closest match that has ever been played on the links here, and the excitement was high.
The Louisiana Republicans have chosen the elephant as their party emblem on the official ballot, preferring it to the American flag.
CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 6. -- The Carlisle Indians defeated Gettysburg College in their annual game here to-day by the onesided score of 45 to 0. The line-up:

Modern ingenuity, which has provided us with innumerable conveniences unsuspected by our forbears, has also afflicted us with a number and variety and inconsistency of penalties for the excessive, wrong, hurtful, or untimely use of these conveniences that is bewildering when one comes to contemplate them as they are presented in one book.

There is a general impression about Chinese animals, as about the Chinese people, that they are quaint, ineffectual, and of no particular use except to Chinamen. Whether the Chinese pug dogs, their hollow-backed pigs, or dwarfed trees, or the absence of almost any good books on sport in the Forbidden Empire have given rise to this idea, it is a very mistaken one.

In the multitude of hastily recorded impressions of the work of any great actor, when that work is still new, the personality of the artist is found to count for more than his art. That was the case with a large proportion of the contemporary criticisms of Macready, Forrest, and Edwin Booth.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- With a snap promising better results Harvard defeated Bowdoin on Soldiers' Field 12 to 0 this afternoon. A safety and the loss of a goal from touch-down would have duplicated last year's record. The Harvard eleven played in better form than before this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Division of Customs and Insular Affairs of the War Department' made public to-day the following summary of its regular monthly bulletin, giving the commerce of the Island of Cuba for the seven months ended Jan. 31, 1900.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The State Department learned to-day that the Chinese Emperor contemplates establishing his capital at Singan, in the Province of Shen-si, instead of returning to Peking.

Nearly five hundred golfers of both sexes kept the public links at Van Cortlandt Park in a state of lively animation yesterday, and to the usual Saturday interest that never lags at Van Cortlandt were added the misfortunes of an accident, and the final competition for the Morosini Cup. The victim of the accident was Mrs. Franklin P. Duryea of 32 West Sixty-eighth Street, who was playing in a foursome competition with her husband.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 6. -- W.J. Bryan to-day concluded his tour of the State of Indiana, arriving here about 8:30 o'clock to-night, an hour and a half late.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 6. -- One of the fiercest tornadoes that ever visited Northern Minnesota struck the edge of the Mesaba Range town of Biwabik at 4:10 this afternoon, killing two persons, injuring eight, and doing damage variously estimated at from $300,000 to $500,000.

MANILA, July 21. -- If civil government for the Philippines is ready before the Filipinos are ready for civil government, no one here in a position to know the state of the islands will be surprised. Doubtless a great majority of the people would prefer quiet to disorder and peace to confusion, and it probably matters little to them what their flag may be, if under it they may go about their affairs undisturbed.

Some lessons may be drawn from the first week's work of the Metropolian English Grand Opera Company. The first of these may be crystalized into the text "Rome was not built in a day." Mr. Savage's newly launched craft is laboring severely under the disadvantage of being manned by a partly inexperienced crew.

Looking at the family as the unit of political life, Confucius holds that organizations of all political bodies can be built up with these units, and that if children have once learned to discharge their duties to their parents, they will have learned how to treat their superiors in larger political associations, and to show proper respect to their rulers in church-and State.

The C.C. Shayne Fur Company, with a capital of $1,000,000, is to be incorporated shortly after Jan. 1 next. The company will take over the business of Mr. Shayne in Forty-second Street, and he will invest $500,000 in the concern, capitalists furnishing a like amount. It is the intention of the company to do an importing, exporting, manufacturing, wholesale, and retail fur business.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- The flight of the Cambodian Prince Inkanthor to Brussels is furnishing the Parisians with much interesting reading, and is giving the foreigners a glimpse of French colonial officialdom.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The only results of yesterday's polling in the Parliamentary general election received last night were those from the Flint and Carnarvon districts, both of which elect Liberals, and from the Shipley Division of Yorkshire, West Riding, which returns a Unionist. These do not alter the gains of the respective parties.

It was announced at Democratic Headquarters in Brooklyn last night that Dr. Andrew M. Gillen had been slated by the organization leaders for the Senatorial nomination in the Fifth District, which has long beep represented at Albany by Senator Michael J. Coffey. The local machine believes that because of its defeat of Coffey in the recent primaries it will be in a position to dictate the nomination of a candidate in the Fifth Senatorial District.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Orange County Horse Show, a training school for the big exhibition at Madison Square Garden, came off successfully in the presence of nearly ten thousand people at Goshen this afternoon. The Tuxedo contingent arrived by special train at an early hour and scattered over the grounds, establishing reception tents in different parts of the grounds.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Oct. 6. -- President Mitchell announced at the mass meeting which followed the strikers' parade here to-day that a convention of miners is to be called. In the course of his address he said:...

Nearly a hundred alumni of the University of Pennsylvania gathered at 44 West Forty-fourth Street last night for the formal opening of the quarters selected by the local alumni club representing that institution. Provost Charles Curtis Harrison was the guest of honor. William B. Boulton, President of the club, presided and made a short address of welcome.

Francis Roe, Assistant Paymaster of her Majesty's ship Hermes, which is now stationed at the Bermudas, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Alexander yesterday, on a charge of embezzlement. He waived examination and was held to await a warrant of extradition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I once heard a Baltimore man describe New York people as a lot of "mugs." By that, I presume, he meant to convey the idea that they are people who easily allow themselves to be imposed upon. To judge by my experience the other evening I come to the conclusion that there is a lot of truth in his remarks.

CREEDMOOR, L,I., Oct. 6. -- The regular supplementary practice day of the season was held here to-day for the marks men and sharpshooter classes. The weather was very warm, a light 4 o'clock wind blowing throughout the day. The attendance was large. Shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Col. N.B. Thurston.

Albert T. Patrick and Charles F. Jones, the attorney and secretary of William Marsh Eice, the aged millionaire who died suddenly at 500 Madison Avenue Sept. 23, will pass to-day in the Tombs prison, not having secured $10,000 bail each for their appearance to-morrow for examination on charges of forgery.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6. -- Albert C. Bostwick of New York has embarked in the trotting horse business. He came here in company with Thomas W. Lawson, ana seeing the success which has crowned the efforts of Mr. Lawson and L.V. Harkness, announced that he will breed and race trotters.

The October Cup shoot of the Crescent Athletic Club was decided yesterday afternoon at the Bay Ridge traps, and was won by O'Brien, with a handicap of four targets at the expert trap and three at the Margenthaler trap, his total score being 46. Banks and Kenyon tied for second place, with scores of 44 each.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Republican Party never loses an opportunity to pose as the upholder of all law and everything that is right and truly good. Just now in every part of the city we may see evidence of the evasion of a law and the degradation of the National flag on the part of the Republican Party, and doubtless it is the same in all other cities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Surely the public owes a vote of thanks to President Haffen and Commissioner Nagle. These gentlemen have done much to restore the dignity and importance of fisticuffs. Much modern pugilism is a compound of effeminacy and fraud. The pugs "fight" with an eye single to box office receipts and to royalties on moving pictures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having been a commuter on the New York Central and Hudson River Railway for many years, your timely editorial on "The Breath of a Locomotive," in your issue of Oct. 3, interests me. All that you state regarding the horrors of the passage through the Harlem tunnel is the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.
Conventions were held in the thirty-five Assembly Districts of Manhattan and the Bronx last night to place in nomination candidates of the Democratic Party for the Assembly.

The letter of Carl Schurz, containing his resignation of the Presidencies of the National Civil Service Reform League and the Civil Service Reform Association of New York, was given out for publication yesterday by George McAneny, Secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- A dispatch received from Lord Roberts, dated Oct. 5, says:

From The Cornhill. The kraal is only a couple of hundred yards from the river, and there is a funnel-shaped inclosure extending from the north gate to the ford. Into this the animals are slowly led, for they must now be kept very quiet. One leader and then another passes through the narrow gateway, followed by some confiding friends.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 6. -- Despite the cold weather to-day, several bathers were seen in the surf at Bailey's and Easton's Beaches.
