CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Congressman C.H. Grosvenor of Ohio spoke at a Republican meeting in Evanston, Ill., to-night in defense of President McKinley's action regarding the so-called slavery treaty with the Sultan of Jolo, Gen. Grosvenor said:

CHICAGO, Oct 6. -- At a mass meeting of the students and Faculty of Lake Forest University to-day football was declared off for the season. It was decided that the death of Lawrence Pierson, half back, resulting from injuries received in the game of Sept. 26, has cast such gloom over the sport at Lake Forest that all games for this season should be canceled.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6 -- Brown defeated Holy Cross to-day on the home grounds 18 to 0. The Brown team was weak in interference and made several costly fumbles. Holy Cross went through the Brown line for good gains and outpunted her, making big gains every time the pigskin was kicked.

Another spectacular pier fire took place last night. Almost the whole of the Atlantic Transport Line's pier at the foot of Clarkson Street was destroyed, and Chief Croker roughly estimated the damages at $100,000.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 6. -- An easterly storm, which passed away in a few hours, swept along the New England coast last night, but while it lasted it caused considerable damage to shipping.

With but a month remaining before election, Wall Street naturally becomes more interested in the political situation. At no time during the campaign has there been doubt in the vicinity of the Stock Exchange as to what the November result will be; and only through transparent betting devices on the curb has there been any suggestion even that the financial centre was giving even slight attention to the claims of Mr. Bryan's managers.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Bucknell University eleven put up a strong game against Cornell to-day, and the home team was able to make but one touch-down and goal, and that in the latter half of the game, after playing on the defensive most of the time. The score was 6 to 0 in favor of Cornell.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Concluding the programme of a busy day of campaigning, embracing a dozen speeches, Gov. Roosevelt to-night addressed two Chicago audiences which crowded both the Coliseum and the First Regiment Armory, yet he had to disappoint several thousand persons on whom the doors were closed after the big buildings were filled.

Cornelius Vanderbilt, owner of the 70foot racing yacht Rainbow, one of the four one-design Herreshoff sloops that furnished such excellent sport during the past Summer by their contests off Newport and in neighboring waters, has written to the Regatta Committee of the various yacht clubs and associations under whose auspices he raced, declining the prizes won by Rainbow.

A certificate of the incorporation of the Exchange Telegraph Company, with a capital stock of $5,000,000, was filed yesterday with the Secretary of State at Trenton, N. J., and with the County Clerk of Hudson County, N.J.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- When Gov. Roosevelt arrived in Chicago to-night he had been on a campaign tour thirty-two days, and the number of miles traveled will far outstrip any record ever made by a Vice Presidential candidate in a canvass for office. In the thirty-two days out he will have covered 12,651 miles, and made other interesting records, as the following will show:

The delegates to the Tammany Hall Senatorial Convention in the Twenty-first District from the Thirty-fifth Assembly District, which is controlled by Louis F. Haffen, President of the Borough of the Bronx, met last night at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventieth Street and nominated Joseph P. Hennessy for State Senator.

From The Cornhill. Early in his career at the bar O'Connell was counsel at the Kerry Assizes in an action against a relative named Mr. Siggerson, and, having occasion to refer to that person in somewhat strong terms in his speech to the jury, Siggerson jumped up in court and called him "a purse-proud blockhead."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Navy Department to-day finally accepted the tornedo boat Craven, built at the Bath, Me., yards.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- A telegram from the United States Consul at Tien-Tsin conveys the information that the Baroness von Ketteler left for Yokohama Sept. 30.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Lehigh was defeated here to-day in a game poorly played by both sides. The work of the Princeton team after the game of last Wednesday and the practice of the week was a great disappointment to the coaches and will result in a general stirring up next week in the ranks of the 'Varsity.

This is the time of the year when the toy and game trade is at its busiest. Dealers in that line say that the general prosperity (or lack of it) over the country "cuts no figure." Folks must have Christmas toys for their youngsters, be the times good or bad.

In spite of the fact that a few days before the British general election the Liberals seemed to be presenting an unexpectedly united front on questions of internal policy and on the alleged repudiated promises of the Conservatives, yet in general the struggle at the polls has been fought out on the question of imperial expansion and colonial government as maintained by Lord SALISBURY'S Ministry for the last five years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Officers have not yet been selected for the new Exchange Telegraph Company. The committee which has in charge the organization of the company consists of W.S. Warren, President of the Chicago Board of Trade; A.O. Slaughter, Charles Counselman, P.B. Weare, P.A. Valentine, John F. Harris, end John R. Walsh.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Centre Street Opera House, the largest auditorium in this city, was filled to over-flowing to-night, on the occasion of the visit to this city of John B. Stanchfield and Bird S. Coler. On their arrival they were met by a deputation of prominent Democrats, who conducted them to their hotel, where they shook hands with hundreds of persons.

SHARON, Penn., Oct. 6. -- A deal was closed yesterday whereby the Valley Railroad, rolling stock, and other properties passed into the possession of Townsend, Reed Co. of Chicago. They also purchased the franchises of the Sharon and Wheatland electric line and certain rights in the proposed Sharon and Youngstown Road.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE TIMES I saw in editorial on the anthracite miners' strike which said: "The miner has been paying too much for the powder that is indispensable in his work, that costs the operator $1 or less and is sold to the miner for $1.50 to $2.75.

Mrs. W.J. Le Moyne will begin her first engagement in New York as a star at Wallack's Theatre to-morrow night in a play by Beatrice de Mille and Harriet Ford, called "The Greatest Thing in the World." The scene is laid in New York in the present day, and Mrs. Le Moyne will impersonate a wealthy widow, whose two sons are saved from disaster, moral and pecuniary, by her devotion and influence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- To-day's University of Pennsylvania-Haverford football game, which the Red and Blue won in rather easy fashion by the score of 38 to 0, demonstrated that Pennsylvania is not particularly strong on the ends, and that one if not both positions at the end of the line are positively weak.

SIMLA, Sept. 6. -- The outlook throughout the majority of the famine districts continues of a hopeful character. The rains have been on the whole copious and general, and though some parts of the country are calling out for more, others profess to have already had too much.
Richard Croker was asked yesterday if a decision had been reached as to judicial nominations. He said:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6. -- Mayor James K. McGuire, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, delivered a speech here to-night before an audience which filled the assembly hall in the City Hall. He dwelt exhaustively upon trusts and imperialism, and toward its close he pitched into the local Republican machine for its opposition to his administration of city affairs.

Sandalwood fans are much prettier than they were when they were brought home to our grandmothers by their sea Captain uncles. The sticks are heavily carved with flowers which stand out naturally, and the fan part is of satin, with Chinese or Japanese embroidery in colors. Boxes and many other pretty things are also made of sandalwood.

"Where do the fillers-in at the continuous performances come from?" was the query put to the manager of one of the agencies that supplies this sort of people to the vaudeville managers all over the country. The performers referred to are the light weights at the shows who "do a turn" while the afternoon audience is disappearing and the evening audience is beginning to trickle into the house.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- It is claimed that Timothy M. Healy has split the Irish Party to almost as great a degree as did the late Charles Stewart Parnell, and that the bitterness injected into the present fight equals that of the historic division. The Freeman's Journal declares that any one voting for Mr. Healy's candidates is "without an atom of self-respect," and describes his campaign, as one of "secret calumny and villification."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- One of the most furious rushes in the history of Princeton University took place to-day after the freshman-sophomore baseball game. The first-year men won the game, and to celebrate the victory endeavored to parade the streets of Princeton under the protection of the junior class.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- As a big Conservative majority daily becomes more and more assured, speculation as to the personnel of the next Cabinet grows rife, and all sorts of guesses are published. None of these, however, seems inspired. All take it for granted that sweeping changes will be made, but this conclusion, it is learned, is unjustified.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 6. -- The naval cadets played the first game of the season this afternoon with the Baltimore Medical College. The Navy kicked off in the first half. The Medical College could not make many gains through the cadets' lines nor around the ends. When the Navy men received the ball, with heavy line bucking and long end runs, they succeeded in making a touch-down.

Very early in life he acquires a thirst for strong drink that is destined to keep him down and drag him lower, and to cut the thread of life when he ought to be in the prune and full strength of manhood.
Mr. Croker had a good deal to say at the Democratic Club last night.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- A large crowd witnesses the much-talked-of match to-day on the cycling track at the Pare des Princes between the French, Dutch, and American cycling champions -- Jacquelin, Meyers, and "Tom." Cooper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Developments of any consequence in the Chinese situation are not looked for until after the return of President McKinley to the capital. He is expected on Tuesday morning, and on the afternoon of that day a Cabinet meeting will probably be held, when the question presented by the French note will be gone over in an informal way.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Stephen Van Rensselaer, John L. Young, and Eugene Crane, three members of the crack Essex Troop of Newark, all of whom are well known in society circles in Essex County, were fined $20 each in the East Orange Police Court last night for disorderly conduct.

Much strength appeared in the market for outside securities last week, and closing quotations showed advances which in many cases amounted to as much as 2 or even 3 points. In only a few instances, however, were these changes in prices accompanied by any considerable activity.

A new face was last night given the events leading up to the declination by Cornelius Vanderbilt of all the prizes won by his yacht Rainbow in the races this season between the four Herreshoff seventy-footers by a formal statement from Herman B. Duryea, joint owner with Harry Payne Whitney of the Rainbow's sister yacht Yankee.

Aboard the Old Dominion Line steamship Hamilton, which arrived here yesterday from Norfolk, Va., was the crew of a schooner that the big steamship had run into and sunk off Cape May, Within less than fifteen minutes after the accident happened the schooner, which was the A. A. Shaw of Philadelphia, went down with all her sails set.

The damp-laden mist that saturated the atmosphere in the Harlem Valley, among other localities, yesterday, was not a sufficient drawback to local road drivers to prevent an hour or more of first-class sport on the Speedway. The footing was fairly good, notwithstanding the wet, and there was a surprisingly large number of spectators considering the disagreeable day.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Stephen Jones, a convict, occupying a cell on the sixth tier of the State Prison here, set fire to his bedding last night, either intentionally or by accident. The smoke was dense and created excitement in the prison.

The English tongue is certainly among the least phonetic of languages. This observation particularly applies to many prominent British family names, some of which are so interesting that we propose giving a few examples.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Sehurz began his long plea against What he terms "imperialism" last Friday with, the following statement:

MANILA, Oct. 7. -- Four troops of cavalry and two companies of infantry have recently reinforced Gen. Young in Northern Luzon, where the insurgents are concentrating in the mountains of North and South Ilocos Provinces under the leadership of Aglipsy, the excommunicated priest and renegade.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 7. -- It is learned to-night that Sheriff Harvey has reached the limit of his patience in regard to the marching of large bodies of men, and that the strikers must obey his request to remain within the pale of the law or take the consequences. He feels he has been as lenient with the crowds as he could possibly be.

The British, steamship Knight Templar, Capt. Finis, which arrived in Quarantine last night from North Shields, reports that on Oct. 1, in latitude 42.38 north, longitude 44.25 west, it sighted a ship in distress with the ensign flying jack down. The vessel proved to be the British ship Nonpareil of London, which left New York on Sept. 10 for Sourabaya, Java, and was abandoned on Sept. 22.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- The Reading Company to-night made public in advance its annual report, which will be submitted to the coming annual meeting of stockholders. The report covers not only the affairs of the Reading Company, but also those of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company and the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, of which corporations substantially all the stock is owned by the Reading Company.

The following is a list of bonds which do not appear in their proper alphabetical order in the "Complete Bond Quotation List" on Pages 4 and 5, but are here so arranged. Opposite each is placed the name of the system under which they are given in the table referred to:

TOLEDO. Oct. 7. -- A meeting of men prominently identified with the five great railroad organizations and women officials of auxiliaries convened here to-day. P.M. Arthur, F.P. Sargent, E.E. Clark, and many others made addresses this afternoon and evening. An executive session was held late to-night. Several objects are in view.

After two weeks of practice at South Field more than twenty-five football candidates are still retained on Columbia's 'Varsity squad, and are housed at the training quarters in West One Hundred and Seventeenth Street. In addition to this number a scrub contingent varying in its personnel but numbering from twelve to fifteen daily is still being instructed by Coach Sanford.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- The Minister of War is considering the question of modifying the regulations relating to the marriage of French officers, particularly in regard to the question of dower demanded. At present an officer may not marry unless the lady is in possession of an independent income of at least 1,230f., or about $250, per year.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Influenced by the latest diplomatic events in China and by the remarkable ease of the money market, the Boerse last week had the best experience it has had for months. The fact that foreign powers regarded the China situation as more favorable had a great weight with operators.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union the first business, done was the reading, of a letter from A.A. Adee, Acting Secretary of State, in reply to a letter from Secretary Bohm, complaining that under the present. Administration everything was going wrong in Porto Rico and that Attorney General Russell had ordered wholesale arrests of labor leaders on the island.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -- In yachting circles here to-day the report that Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-footer Rainbow had carried extra ballast in her races gave room for plenty of gossip. The belief is general that Mr. Vanderbilt was wholly ignorant of the placing of the extra ballast on board his yacht.

The engagement is announced of Mrs. P.F. Baring of this city and Baron F. Ortmans de Senechal of Paris. The ceremony will be performed on Oct. 15 by Mayor Van Wyck at the City Hall. Two days later the bridal couple will sail on the steamship St. Paul for Paris, where they will make their home.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tues day:

PEKING, Oct. 3. -- By an imperial decree issued at Tai-yuen-Foo, capital of the Province of Shan-Si, dated Sept. 25, Emperor Kwang-Su denounces the Boxer movement and designates for punishment nine ringleaders. He acknowledges his own fault and rebukes himself, but he places the chief blame upon the Princes and nobles who participated in the movement and protracted it.

Bank surplus reserves continue to fall. From a total of over $28,000,000 four weeks ago they have been reduced to little more than $6,000,000, and the end does not seem in sight. Money is going to the South and the West in much greater volume than had been anticipated; and advices are that while the Southern demand has been fairly well satisfied, the West still needs no inconsiderable sum.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7. -- Exchange on New York has fallen from 110 to 92@95. Bankers do not anticipate a steady rise in silver. The demand for Mexican dollars for China continues. There is some talk in cotton manufacturing circles of asking the Government to remove the duty of 7 cents per kilogram on imported cotton, but this relief would not help the situation much.

The young woman who is getting something that is up-to-date for the young man gets him handkerchiefs with a hemstitched edge and woven lines forming a border, and in some instances nearly covering the handkerchief.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 7. -- "The worst team Harvard has had in years," is the opinion of all who saw the eleven play last week. The inefficiency of the team was not alone displayed in the line. Reports of Harvard's inability to secure heavy guards and tackles had been in circulation, and a weak line was expected.

John McCullagh, State Superintendent of Elections for the metropolitan district, yesterday sent a letter to Chief of Police William S. Devery, calling his attention to certain facts affecting the registration of voters for the general election to be held on Nov. 6. The first days of registration will fall upon Friday and Saturday, Oct. 12 and 13, and the last two days of registration on Oct. 19 and 20.

On Sept. 26 Mr. W.J. BRYAN, a citizen of Nebraska, who was then whirling about in search of trusts and trouble near his own home, made a speech at Nebraska City, in which he pounced upon the Argo Starch Factory in that place as a fearful example of the ruinous effect of trusts.

The campaign has scarcely begun, but the free and unlimited coinage of political aphorisms has already commenced. The editors and spellbinders have set their dies in operation. Much of the mintage is inferior in substance or form -- like the freesilver dollars of only half value -- but there is an occasional coin with the true ring.

It was probably a surprise to most of our readers to learn yesterday morning that Mr. CROKER had announced his conversion to the principle of a single head for the Police Department. It is not consistent with his previous course nor with his apparent interest as the chief manager of the business of Tammany.

Exhorting his hearers to be loyal to the leaders in the crusade against vice, the Rev. Robert L. Paddock, at the Pro-Cathedral, yesterday morning, prophesied better and happier conditions for the east side. He took for his text, "Seek ye the kingdom of God" and His righteousness and all other things shall be added unto you." He said, in part:

Albert T. Patrick, the attorney, and Charles F. Jones, private secretary and valet of William Marsh Rice, the aged millionaire who died suddenly at his home, 500 Madison Avenue, on Sept. 23, who were arrested last Thursday night charged with forgery, will be arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court this afternoon for examination.

Sir Ernest Mason Satow, K.C.M.G., whose appointment as successor to Sir Claude MacDonald in the difficult and laborious post of British Minister at Peking is announced, has a very large and varied experience of the East and its ways. He has been more than thirty-nine years in the diplomatic service, and the greater portion of his time has been spent in the Orient.

Lord Strathcona, High Commissioner in London for Canada, who last Spring organized and equipped the regiment of Canadian rough riders known as Strathcona's Horse, for service in South Africa, was a passenger on the Cunard liner Etruria, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday.

The trouble that has existed among the members of Gloucester Naval Command No. 17, Spanish War Veterans, ever since the election of Col. Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, N.G.N.Y., as a member of the command about three months ago reached a climax Saturday night when about every bluejacket in the organization resigned.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 7. -- Miss Clara Barton, President of the National Red Cross Society, has issued the following statement to the manufacturers and business men of the country, in which she appeals to them for aid in the way of material to be used in the building of homes for those who lost their all in the recent storm:

Edward K. Jones and Marshall J. Gasquet, both lawyers, with offices respectlively at 45 Cedar Street and 31 Nassau Street, had John Felton of 137 Ninth Avenue arrested yesterday afternoon on the charge of cruelty to animals.

John D. Crimmins, for many years one of the most influential members of Tammany Hall, is an active worker this year in the interest of the McKinley and Roosevelt ticket. He says he has made it his business during the past few weeks to exchange views with many master builders and foremen in the building and other trades.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 7. -- Although Mayor McGuire will return to New York to-morrow, his friends here declare that he is in no condition to resume work. He however, says that his sudden illness last night, which necessitated his retirement from the platform while delivering a speech, amounted to nothing and that he will be all right to-morrow.

The City of New York has been treated with peculiar contempt by Mr. CROKER in the matter of its representative in Congress from the Thirteenth District, who in the present Congress is Mr. JEFFERSON M. LEVY.

Those famous childen, "Helen's Babies," are more interesting in books than out of them. There is a worthy carpenter of Brooklyn, a poor but honest man, who has a veritable Budge and Toddie in his family, and their bright and interesting ways have cost him an amount of money quite out of proportion to their sizes.

SALEM, Ill., Oct. 7. -- William J. Bryan to-day rested in the city of his birth, and spent the day with relatives. He arrived here about noon, and dined at the residence of Mrs. Mollie Webster, his cousin. Thirty of his relatives gathered at the residence and partook of the dinner.

Every day there appear in the newspapers strikingly similar sets of foreign dispatches. One set is dated "Pretoria" and signed "ROBERTS." The other set is dated "Manila" and signed "MACARTHUR." In each case, they describe certain small operations which can be called military only by courtesy, and which, in settled regions, would be the operations of the police.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 7. -- A man, supposed to be Richard W. Sprague, committed suicide by jumping from the steamer George Dingley during the trip from Boston Saturday night. When the steamer was off Baker's Island the man went to the stern and removed his overcoat. This action attracted no special attention, but the passengers were horrified a moment later to see him step upon the rail and plunge overboard.

Only 78 per cent, of Britons who are entitled to a share in the election of members of Parliament take the trouble to cast their votes. Yet the cost to the candidates who stood in 1895 for the present House of Commons was u773,333 3d., out of a maximum allowed by the Corrupt Practices act of u1,025,207.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Senator Hanna, accompanied by Senator Frye of Maine, will go to South Dakota and Nebraska next week. They expect to leave Chicago on Monday morning, Oct. 15, and speak at Waukesha in the afternoon and Madison in the evening. They will then run across to Winona, Minn., and from that point make a daylight run to St. Paul, making short stops for speeches at Rochester, Mankato, and New Ulm.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 7. -- The mystery of the killing of George Thompson, whose body was found on the Johnson farm in South Somerset yesterday afternoon with a gaping wound in the head, was cleared up this afternoon by a story told by Ruel Jackson, son of ex-Mayor Jackson, who was his companion on the fatal hunting trip.

"Let no man think when he fights for the Westminster Confession of Faith that he is fighting for the essence of Presbyterianism, or that when he has set aside the Westminster Confession he has set aside Presbyterianism."
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Fire destroyed Gilroy's Hotel at Garwood, N.J., on the line of the Central Railroad, at 12 o'clock this morning. The origin of the fire is not known.

The body of the woman who killed herself by taking carbolic acid in the Grand Hotel on Saturday evening was identified late last night as that of Mathilda Nelson, who won some notoriety several years ago on account of her suit against the estate of Austin Corbin, late President of the Long Island Railroad.

-- Presence of mind at once admirable and amusing, and a really delightful determination to look on the bright side of things, are shown by The Liverpool Mercury in some comments it makes on the purchase by the British Admiralty of 20,000 tons of American coal for warship use.
Senator Platt was in great good humor yesterday. Asked about the outlook in this State from a Republican standpoint, he said:

The whole connection of M. MILLERAND, the Socialist, with the Waldeck-Rousseau Ministry should serve as an object lesson to those other European Governments which attempt to stem the slowly rising yet presently inexorable tide of popular discontent by restrictions placed upon speech and press.

The large double residence on the north side of Sixty-second Street, 225 feet east of Fifth Avenue, was transferred yesterday by Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard as a gift to her daughter, Mrs. Ernesto G. Fabbri.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- The stockholders of the Reading Company, which company was the result of the reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company and the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company three years ago, held an adjourned annual meeting to-day, at which the annual report, made public yesterday, was approved.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Oct. 8. -- I.B. Hanna, cousin of Hark Hanna and Superintendent of Forest Reserves for Arizona and New Mexico; A.F. Herman, brother of Land Commissioner Binger Herman, and W.H. Pierce, guide, had a thrilling experience and almost lost their lives on the desert between the Grand Canon of the Colorado and the Utah State line.

At its monthly meeting last night in the Marlborough, the Phi Delta Phi Law Club, the local alumni association of a legal fraternity, passed unanimously a resolution calling upon the electors to renominate and re-elect without regard to party, Edward Patterson as a Justice of the Supreme Court.

In spite of the steady rain yesterday afernbon Coach Sanford gave the Columbia football squad two hours of hard practice on South Field. Condidates enough were out to make up three elevens, and, although the players were soaked to the skin and the leather spheres were treacherously slippery, some of the snappiest work of the season was exhibited.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. E.J. Knowlton has closed Idle Hour and returned to New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8. -- One touchdown, a safety, and a goal from field by Sawin from the thirty-yard line tells the story of the Harvard 'Varsity practice today. With a firmer and more aggressive line, the beginnings of interference among the backs, and a snap dash looked for in vain before this season, the 'Varsity pushed the second eleven down the field four times in a practice half lasting about thirty minutes.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The somewhat optimistic view of the Chinese situation which prevailed in Germany last week has been unfavorably affected by the reports that the Chinese Court has resolved to settle permanently at Simgan-Foo. This the Berliner Tageblatt regards as "indisputable evidence that the Chinese Court is as anti-foreign as ever."

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 8. -- President Mitchell to-day issued a call for a convention of mine workers of the three districts comprising the anthracite fields, to mee in Scranton on Friday next. The text of the convention, call is as follows:

Another chapter was last night added to the story of the wrangle among the Tammany Hall braves in the Twenty-first Senatorial District over the selection of a candidate for State Senator. The delegates from the Thirty-fourth Assembly District, controlled by Street Cleaning Commissioner Percival E. Nagle and Park Commissioner August Moebus, met at Morrisania Hall, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventieth Street, and nominated Richard H. Mitchell, the present representative of the district.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 8. -- The excellently equipped Whitin Observatory, the gift of Mrs. John C. Whitin of Whitinsville to Wellesley College, was dedicated this afternoon with appropriate ceremonies in the presence of three hundred guests. The chapel procession was headed by Mrs. Whitin, the donor, and President Hazard.

The Republican mass meeting in the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, last night furnished a series of surprises. Gen. Horatio C. King, a Gold Democrat, presided. J. Sloat Fassett of Elmira, a former Republican candidate for Governor, defended trusts and Abraham Gruber recited some of his political poems.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- While the Methodist Episcopal Conference to-day was considering the report of the Committee on Temperance, and particularly that portion relating to the army canteen, Bishop McCabe took the floor in defense of the President. He said it was not always policy to denounce those high in authority.

-- New Yorkers have been wont to think, with a sort of pride, that the sufferings, annoyances, and irritations experienced by themselves while, traveling up and down their island and through the region contiguous to it are greater and more numerous than those of the inhabitants of any other city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposition of " Poitrinaire, M. D.," is an admirable one, and no doubt much good would be done by the establishment, of sanitaria for consumptives, but it appears to me that the plan is defective in chat it does not go far enough. It deals with the dread disease itself, but not with the cause.

Secretary Willis Holly of the Park Board answered yesterday for Commissioner Clausen a complaint made Sunday at the meeting of the Central Federated Union. During the meeting a delegate from the Belvidere Council of Park Laborers asserted that when the reformers were in office there was more work, though the ap- propriations were smaller; that the reformers gave out no contract jobs, whereas now every little job is given out to contractors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The principal development in the Chinese situation to-day was the definite announcement that the Emperor and Empress Dowager had actually started for the new Chinese capital, Singan, in the mountain region of Shen-Si Province.

The very clear and instructive letter of our special correspondent in Manila. Mr. FREDERICK W. EDDY, published on Sunday, gave an impression of the situation in the islands at the close of the Summer more interesting than flattering. Up to that time the efforts of the authorities to extend peace and order through the organization of local governments in which natives take part had been practically futile.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8. -- There was great activity in North and Middle Comstocks to-day, Ophir selling to 88 and Gould Curry to 65. Twenty-one thousand shares were sold in the morning and about 10,000 in the afternoon. Closing quotations to-day and Saturday were as follows:

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- The race for the Great Autumn Handicap Prix du Conseil Municipal, at Longchamps yesterday, was won by "Tod" Sloan, the American jockey, who had the mount on M. Ephrussi's three-year-old bay colt Codoman. Melina finished second, and Delvino, ridden by Rigby, another American jockey, was third.
Much interest was manifested yesterday at Police Headquarters in the letter sent to Chief Devery by Superintendent of Elections John MeCullagh, who has charge of the metropolitan district.

The members of the New York modish world who are now, for the most part, in the suburbs, and, as a result of the continued warm weather, at Newport and Lenox, had a dull time yesterday, as the heavy showers which in some places were almost continuous throughout the day put an effectual quietus on all outdoor enjoyment.

The one question which Mr. JOHN McCULLAGH'S elaborate communication to Chief DEVERY is likely to raise in the minds of those familiar with the history of elections in this city is, What will he do if his warning is disregarded?

Several hundred thousand rain coats were put into commission for the Fall and Winter season yesterday afternoon, and myriads of umbrellas that had been idle for many weeks were brought forth to protect pedestrians from one off the most copious rainfalls of the year.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Only five results out of the twenty-one constituencies polled yesterday in the Parliamentary general election have been thus far announced. These show that the Liberals have gained two seats, one in Carmarthenshire and the other, strangely enough, in the Radcliffe-cum-Farnworth Division of Southeast Lancashire, which had hitherto gone strongly Conservative.

Frederick S. Gibson, a lawyer living at 27 Waverley Place, was instantly killed last night by a New York and Putnam express train at Morris Heights Station while on his way to attend a meeting of his college fraternity society, Psi Upsilon, in the New York University, University Heights.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The tobacco question again occupied the Rock River Conference of the Methodist Church to-day when it resumed its deliberations at the Garfield Park Church.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew addressed a large audience of Republicans to-night, his speech being delivered under the auspices of the Marquette Club.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- Several thousand persons who attended the Democratic mass meeting at Music Hall to-night were greatly disappointed when they learned that ex-Senator Gorman would not address them. They listened, instead, to the reading of a letter from Mr. Gorman, in which he said:
"All the powers should unite in forcing the punishment of those implicated in the anti-foreign movement in China."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The United States Supreme Court convened to-day. All the members of the court were present except Mr. Justice Gray and Mr. Justice McKenna, who are absent at Virginia Springs. Attorney General Griggs, Solicitor General Richards, ex-Attorney General Wayne MacVeagh, and a number of other distinguished lawyers were present to witness the formal opening of the court.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Bloodshed followed in the wake of Senator Depew and his three-mile escort of North Side Republican marching clubs to-night. Just as the last company in line turned the corner of Sedgwick Street and Chicago Avenue it was charged upon by an organized gang of men, who had concealed themselves in the dark recesses of an unlighted alley.

Before the end of the week the aerial campaign planned by Richard Croker to aid the cause of Mr. Bryan in New York will be in full swing. New methods are being thought out, and features which will, it is believed, drive apathy away are being perfected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Ex-Senator Arthur P. Gorman of Maryland to-day authorized an absolute denial of published reports that he had resigned from the Democratic National Committee and from the other political committees of which he is a member.

Rumors which have been current for several days regarding a large deal in the Washington Heights section were revived yesterday. The property involved, it is said, includes the greater part of the holdings of Jacob D. Butler in that neighborhood. These, according to the report, will shortly pass into the hands of a syndicate headed by ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant.

SALEM, Ill., Oct. 8. -- William J. Bryan began his week's work with a speech early to-day in this city, his former home, Friends, many of whom had known Mr. Bryan from boyhood, gave him a cordial reception. Since yesterday visitors had been coming in from surrounding towns.

We were remarking the other day upon one aspect of the political campaign in this State which is, so far as we know or believe, unprecedented. It is that one man is at the same time the candidate for the Governorship of his party and the Chairman of the State Committee of the same party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- With insurance upon her life amounting to $12,000, Marie Defenbach, aged twenty-three, died on Aug. 25 in a boarding house in La Salle Avenue under conditions which the police believe indicate a plot to swindle an insurance company and two insurance societies, if they do not point to murder.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Thomas J. Mangan, four years ago Chairman of the Become County Democratic Committee, presided this evening at a Republican mass meeting at the Stone Opera House, where he was one of the principal speakers. Mr. Mangan made an address, in the course of which he said:

The examination in the cases of Albert T. Patrick and Charles F. Joncs on an accusation of forgery growing out of their acts as attorney and secretary of the late William Marsh Rice, was yesterday adjourned at the Centre Street Court by City Magistrate Brann, who succeeds Magistrate Mott, to 10 A.M., Oct. 15.
The German Emperor does not really read newspapers or reviews, except on very rare and important occasions, when his interest is especially excited. He has no time.

Sarah Cowell Le Moyne, making her debut in New York as a star actress at Wallack's Theatre last night, was received by a house full of friends. Her reception, when she emerged into view in the first act of a four-act play called "The Greatest Thing in the World" was so violently effusive that it made her hysterical.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 8. -- The new fifth furnace of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company at Ensley, just completed, was fired up to-night and will make its first run to-morrow. The furnace bas a capacity of 250 tons per day, and with the other four will constitute a plant with a total daily capacity of 1,200 tons of pig iron.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- The Yale eleven was put through another hard two halves this afternoon in spite of the muggy atmosphere. Mike Murphy, instead of letting up on the men these past hot days, has worked them harder, and there is an indication with some of them that they may be overtrained and go stale.

ALTON, Ill., Oct. 8. -- That particular portion of Illinois known as Egypt, was pretty thoroughly canvassed by Mr. Bryan to-day. The principal cities of eleven of the southern counties of the State and three of the Congressional districts were visited, and large audiences addressed at the various stopping places.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Oct. 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-night concluded his campaign tour of Illinois, speaking in this city to the largest audience assembled here since the McKinley-Bryan campaign of four years ago.

A novel feature of the racing at Morris Park yesterday was that the entire programme was run over the circular tracks, the Eclipse course for the first day in the history of Morris Park falling into disuse. The change was welcomed by the spectators, regardless of what the horse owners thought of it.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Senator William P. Frye of Maine addressed a Republican mass meeting here to-night, presided over by Senator Sewell of New Jersey.
PEKING, Oct. 3. -- Gen. Yamaguchi will retain 10,000 Japanese troops, 2,000 of them at Peking and the others at Taku, and along the line of communications.

Some activity appeared in a few outside securities yesterday, but the list as a whole was extremely dull and developed nothing of special Interest. Prices continued to be easily affected, and, as it happened, most of the changes were on the side of gains. It is true, however, that of late prices have moved downward just as easily as they have in some cases been advanced.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The expected "waking up" of the 'Varsity after the shaking up by Lehigh Saturday has not materialized, judging from to-day's practice. The teams played very poor football. No life was manifested in the first team's work. The backs started slowly, hit the line without force or direction, and frequently fumbled.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Romeike has sent me a clipping from your paper of Sept. 9, in which you quote my sentence of condemnation from The Engineerings News and defend the Consular Corps from its unjust conclusions. Please accept my sincere thanks. I am afraid The Engineering News man is a person who has become, befuddled by too much learning.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- A bitter factional fight among Baltimore Democrats, which Mr. German and the State party managers have tried to keep quiet until after the Presidential election, may blast the hopes the organization has entertained of carrying the State for Bryan.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Ambassador Andrew D. White, First President of Cornell University, delivered an address to the students at noon to-day. President Schurman introduced the speaker, who was given a most hearty welcome. Mr. White spoke briefly on the past and present of the university, and highly eulogized Ezra Cornell, with whom he had worked during the infancy of the institution.

For many years it has been the duty and the practice of the Marine Hospital Service of the United States to protect us against the coming of contagious diseases, and particularly such pests as yellow fever, toy an outer line of defense, established in notorious ports of infection and strengthened by the assistance of our Consular officers.

Capt. Moses Walton, Jr., Assistant Quartermaster United States Volunteers, will transfer his accountability on the transport Sedgwick to the General Superintendent of the Army Transport Service, New York City, and will report to that officer for appointment to duty as Quartermaster and acting Commissary of Subsistence on the transport Buford, to relieve Major William J. White, Quartermaster, United States Volunteers.

George R. Blanchard, at one time Vice President of the Erie Railroad and one of the most prominent railroad men in this country, died early yesterday morning at his home, I Washington Square North, in this city, after a protracted illness brought on by overwork during the early part of the Summer.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night Bizet's "Carmen" was brought forward by the Metropolitan English Grand Opera Company, English on this occasion surely signifying only the text that was employed and "grand" the surroundings rather than the technical classification of the charming product of the Opera Comique.

Mayor Van Wyck and the other members of the Board of Estimate grappled yesterday with the problem of now much money should be spent on the public school system in 1901. In public and private meetings the matter was discussed with much animation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Richard S. Emmet, descendant of Thomas Addis Emmet and related to the Irish martyr Robert Emmet, is confined to his home, on Pelham Road, with a fractured hip. He was sitting on a chair in his home last night, when he slipped and fell to the floor, the fall resulting in the injury.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- In the contest that has just been held for the University golf championship Abram Poole, Jr., 1904, defeated Percy E. Pyne, 2d, 1903, the Intercollegiate champion and holder of the Pyne Cup during the past year. The play was over thirty-six holes and was won by Poole, with a score of 7 up and 6 to play.

Philip H. Wagner, a Justice of the Peace of Jersey City, and a collector for the William Peters brewery, at Union Hill, who disappeared on Tuesday last under circumstances that led his wife to believe he had met with foul play, has been heard from. He is in Savannah, Ga., awaiting funds to bring him home.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8. -- Up to a week ago there was a general belief that Bryan might carry this State, although there was little hope that Beckham, for Governor, would defeat Yerkes. The registration in cities and towns last week has, however, brought consternation into the Democratic camp.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 8. -- John McDermott, a section foreman of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, has had a striking illustration of the ability of tramps to make trouble for any one for whom they may have a dislike. McDermott is responsible for the section of the track from the east end of the Raritari River Bridge to the signal bridge, east of Stelton, a distance of about three miles.

Russell Sage was quoted on Saturday as saying that the Second and Ninth Avenue lines of the Manhattan system would in all probability be equipped with electrical motive power before the middle of November. This statement was declared to be rather premature by officials of the operating department of the road yesterday.

"There is one thing which makes a man feel at home in New York the first time he comes here, after he has knocked about a few weeks, no matter from what part of the United States he hails," said a merchant now in business in Mexico.
Memorial services for Supreme Court Justice Frederick Smyth, who died in August last, were held yesterday in Trial Term, Part IX., of the Supreme Court, in the County Court House.

It is more like a jewel casket this year, and the buttons that the woman will wear on her best gowns are in beauty and quality quite in keeping with the magnificent materials which go into her frocks.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew is made the defendant in a suit brought Monday by S.G. Brabook of Chicago against The Unique Magazine, formerly The Penny Magazine, of 489 Fifth Avenue, of which the Senator was supposed to be the owner. The papers in the suit, the action being to recover $200 for a guessing prize offered by, the magazine, were served on Mr. Depew personally.

To the Editor of The New York Times. I read in this morning's issue the statement of Col. Gardiner in regard to the Rice case, and I protest against the giving out of such statements by the District Attorney in New York to be published in the news-papers for the purpose of prejudicing the community against a person accused of a crime.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Acting Secretary Meiklejohn of the War Department has sent the following letter to W.J. Bryan:

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold for Max Marx to Alexander Walker the block front on the west side of Auduboh Avenue, between One Hundred and Eighty-fifth and One Hundred, and Eighty-sixth Streets, 160.2 by 100, Mr. Walker giving in part payment the two five-story flats 71 and 73 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 60 by 100.11.
LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Marquis of Bute died this morning at Dumfries House, his seat in Ayrshire, from paralysis.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9. -- This was a livelier day on the Mining Stocks Exchange than yesterday. Prices advanced at the outset; then came a reaction and drop, and then heavy purchasing orders from Virginia City, which sent Gould and Curry to the highest price it has touched in years. The most active stocks were Gould and Curry, Best and Belcher, Ophir, Mexican, Crown Point, and Sierra Nevada.

William J. Bryan will make a speech-making tour through New York State, starting at Madison Square Garden, New York, on Oct. 16, and ending in Buffalo on Oct. 20. He will make in all fifty-five speeches, according to the programme given out by the Democratic National Committee.
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 9. -- Mr. Bryan took occasion to-day to answer the charge that he is being paid for his speeches. He said:

Albert T. Patrick and Charles F. Jones. the lawyer and the secretary of the late William Marsh Rice, who were arrested on suspicion that they conspired to get the millionaire's property and that they forged checks in his name for large amounts, have not yet offered bail. Their counsel Bays that they are not cast down by confinement.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Oct. 9. -- The affairs of the Central Vermont Railway Company are prosperous, according to its annual report for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1900, submitted at the annual meeting, held here today.

The recent decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of Dockmaster Percival does not-give the fight to Tammany heads of departments to make wholesale discharges of clerks and other employes. The first interpretation put on the decision by the city officials was that it did, and preparations were being made for the removal of many Republicans who now hold office under the protection of the Civil Service laws.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2. -- President Charles F. Thwing of "Western Reserve University has collected reports from between one and two hundred of the representative colleges of the United States relative to their finances and investments.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 9. -- P.H. Gilhooly, counsel for the Elizabethport Banking Company, to-day announced that William Schrieber, the missing clerk of the bank, was a defaulter to the amount of $50,000, and that the bank Directors had made good the amount of the shortage.

The announcement of the engagement of Mrs. Pauline F. Baring of 110 East Thirty-fifth Street and Baron F. Ortmans de Senechal of Paris, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Monday morning has created something of a sensation among the members of the Calumet Club, where the Baron has been received as a guest for several months past.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- The life insurance swindle which cost Marie Defenbach her life and which resulted in the arrest of Dr. Unger, F. Wayland Brown, and F.H. Smiley, the last two detectives, had some sensational developments to-day. It transpired that a written confession was made by Mr. Smiley last week, and it is now in the hands of the authorities.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 9. -- Justice Nash, in the Supreme Court, has rendered a decision on a novel point, touching upon the question whether a person committing suicide does so while insane or in his right mind.

To-morrow the men and women of the social world who are interested in fine horses will journey to Morristown, N.J., where the annual horse show will open under the auspices of the Morristown Field Club, and will continue through Friday and Saturday. The large number of entries, 300, as well as the high quality of these entries, assures the success of the show.

Wherever yachtsmen met yesterday the action of Cornelius Vanderbilt in refusing to accept the prizes won by Rainbow, and the accusation of Herman B. Duryea against Capt. Parker continued the sole topic of conversation. With the lapse of time partisanship has had a chance to grow, and opinion yesterday varied much more than on any day since the letters of Mr. Vanderbilt and Mr. Duryea were made public.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The most dramatic scene which has ever marked a financial meeting in London occurred this afternoon, when the shareholders of the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada assembled to hear the half-yearly report of the Directors. A large number of persons were present, the assemblage consisting chiefly of city financiers and clergymen, with a sprinkling of country investors and women.

HAVANA, Oct. 9. -- Governor General Wood says that Cuba now offers great opportunities to Americans who will come here and settle. Land is cheap or can be rented on a small royalty of production. Returns would be quick. He recommends the cultivation by immigrants of tobacco and fruit and the raising of cattle.

For nearly five hours yesterday the whole cable-car system on Broadway from the Battery to Thirty-sixth Street was completely tied up. The blockade, which was one of the longest that has ever occurred on Broadway, was made the more aggravating for the thousands of people who were on their way home from their places of business at the time by a heavy downpour of rain.

For the account of London and Berlin large volumes of American stocks nave been marketed here. These stocks were not bought recently; they have been held on the other side for a long time. Conspicuous in the list is Northern Pacific common and preferred, acquired about two years ago.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 9. -- The wedding of Miss Aimy Belle Cole, daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Hickson W. Cole of Rowayton, and Henry Leach of Brooklyn took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 9. -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, who came here to-day to take part in a labor demonstration, was welcomed in a most enthusiastic manner by the thousands of striking mine workers in this section of the Schuylkill Valley. The city was profusely decorated, and all the stores and other business houses in the vicinity closed at noon.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- A train from Boston loaded with passengers for Chicago and Western points had a hair-raising escape from a runaway freight train to-day, and for a few moments the passengers expected to be hurled into eternity.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Oct. 9. -- One of the most remarkable scenes ever enacted in a Kentucky court occurred to-night in the trial of Henry E. Youtsey, charged with being a principal in the shooting of Gov. Goebol, the defendant himself being the chief participant. The courtroom was crowded at the time and the excitement was intense.

Democratic conventions for the nomination of candidates for the State Senate were held in the seven Senate districts of Kings County last night. As in the case of the candidates for Congress named on Monday night, the Willoughby Street organization proved its absolute supremacy in local Democratic politics by having, all of its candidates placed in nomination.

The Bowery Bank, now situated at the southwest corner of the Bowery and Canal Street, will erect a six-story bank and office building on the lot, 24.11 by 100.1, at the northwest corner of the Bowery and Grand Street. The building now on the latter site was occupied for many years by the National Butchers and Drovers' Bank, which institution sold the property to the Bowery Bank about a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley, accompanied by Secretary Cortelyu and the family servants arrived here at 7:45 this morning from Canton.

The end of a long litigation following upon the failure of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn was reached yesterday in the Supreme Court, that borough, when two suits brought by William N. Dykman, as receiver for the bank, against seven of the Directors were settled. Receiver Dykman sought to recover from each of the bank Directors $4,320, with interest from 1893.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 9. -- Mr. Bryan concluded the last speech of the day here tonight at a few minutes before 11 o'clock. He began at 6:30 o'clock, this morning, and made sixteen addresses during the day. The audiences, were generally large, but those at Peoria, Quincy, and Joliet were especially so.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- It is urged in the annual report or Major Gen. John R. Brooke, commanding the Department of the East, at New York, which was made public to-day, that a pressing necessity exists for the reorganization of the army on modern lines.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 9. -- Interviews with prominent operators here to-day elicited a uniform declaration that no further concessions or modifications of the present offer will be made, and that the miners must take it or leave it just as it stands.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Although Harvard's football team scored 41 points against Amherst this time last year, and Yale 27 against this year's team last week. Harvard was not only unable to score more than 18 points against them in the game on Soldiers' field this afternoon, but barely escaped being scored on by a blocked punt.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 10. -- In a rough game, replete with slugging in its various forms, the Manhattan College football team of New York City went down to defeat here to-day at the hands of Lafayette by the score of 11 to 0. All the scoring took place in the first half. The first touch-down was followed by a goal.
Reduction of half a cent posted rates for sterling exchange, making a decline of 1 cent this week.

If the election were held to-day there is no doubt that we would have a majority in the Electoral College and in the popular vote. But the Republican managers are now collecting from the monopolies a large campaign fund. They will buy every vote that can be bought. They will coerce every vote that can be coerced.

One favored spot on Long Island offers in opportunity for a real estate specu- lation which, so far as the facts at hand enable us to Judge, should be of the most gigantic and profitable character. A powerful syndicate should at once be organized to buy it, lay it out with tanbark roads, and found the City of Sleep, with a brushwood pile on its outskirts and other suitable and appropriate accessories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- It is now practically certain that nothing will be done in the way of awarding armor plate contracts until after election. The armor plate representatives had a conference with Secretary Long to-day, and will have another next week, but they made no new proposition to him and stood on the original bids.

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- United States Oil continued heavy to-day under free selling, reaching 12 1/4, a loss of 1/2; Parrott, Montana, and Utah were fairly active and steady; Massachusetts and Trimountain held prior gains well; Butte lost 3, to 60; British Columbia was up 7/3, at 12 5/3; other coppers generally were firm.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Oct. 10. -- Henry E. Youtsey has remained in a comatose condition all day; whether that is due to the opiates administered to Quiet him last night cannot be ascertained. He has answered no questions addressed to him by his nearest relatives and physicians, but once or twice during the day he held up his hands and exclaimed: "There is no blood on my hands-there is no man's blood on my hands."

The record of yesterday's market for out side securities is a repetition of that of the earlier days of the week, and in the special movements of prices there was little of much interest. All told, the day brought about some improvement in quotations, not on account of any large buying, but because of the small amount of stock that is now offered for sale.

CAPE TOWN, Oct 10. -- The Right Hon. Cecil J. Rhodes received an ovation to-day when he assumed the Presidency of the Congress of the South African League. In the course of his address he attributed the South African war to the "Mugwumps," and said that but for them Mr. Kruger would never have dared to send an ultimatum to Great Britain.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 10. -- A special policeman, was instantly killed another was wounded in the head, a striker was probably fatally shot, and, ten non-union men were more or less seriously, wounded at the Oneida colliery of Coxe Brothers Co. in a clash between the officers and 500 strikers this morning.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Three thousand persons listened to Mr. Stanchfleld, ex-Senator Hill, and Charles N. Bulger at a big Democratic rally here to-night. The latter paid his respects to B.B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor amid the greatest enthusiasm. Among other things he said:

The inquest into the death of Kathryn Saharn, who was found murdered early in the morning of Aug. 19 in her flat at 674 Second Avenue, was begun yesterday at 11 A. M. in the Coroner's Court in the Criminal Court Building before Coroner Bausch.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The work of Princeton in to-day's football game against Pennsylvania State College, in which the former scored 26 points to the latter's 0, stands out in strong contrast with the work of the Tigers during the past week.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 10. --The weather for the first day of Mr. Bryan's tour of the State of Michigan was all that could be asked. He made sixteen addresses from first to last, and all but one of the meetings were held in the open air. The country traversed was varied in character, including the famous Michigan celery belt, the scarcely less famous peach country, as well as much furniture manufacturing territory.

By the fall of an elevator in the Consumers' Brewing Company building, at Fifty-fourth Street and Avenue A, yesterday, five men were more or less injured and are now in the Flower Hospital with the prospect of being kept there for some time as a result of their injuries. The accident was caused by the sudden buckling of two steel tubes, which held the wheel on which the cable ran that supported the elevator.
It was announced yesterday that the engagement of u50,000 in gold in London on Tuesday for New York was consigned to the Bank of British North America.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 10. -- Brown defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology this afternoon in football -- 32 to 0. The Brown 'Varsity played a strong game for the first half and scored 17. In the second half a new substitute line, who were shivering from standing in the rain, were put in, and were just getting in some good work when the whistle blew.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- In his speech here to-night Lieut. Gov. Woodruff said he had a particularly good opportunity to lay bare the falsity of statements of Mr. Bryan in his efforts to array the employed against their employers. Holding in his hand an extract from a London trade paper, he read the following:

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Roland Reed has canceled his future dates and will leave for New York when he finishes his engagement here next Saturday night. He does this on the advice of Dr. Nicholas Senn, under whose care he has been ever since he came here two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Assustant Secretary of War Meiklejohn left here this evening for Nebraska, where he expects to take an active part in the campaign. Mr. Meiklejohn will be a candidate for United States Senator if the Republicans control the Nebraska Legislature.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The marriage of the Rev. Stephen Van Rensselaer of New Lenox to Miss Mary Thorn Carpenter of New York took place this afternoon in Trinity Church, at Lenox.

The average New Yorker, accustomed as he is to an almost limitless supply of fresh water both for use and for waste, would be amazed to observe the more than rigid economy with which the precious fluid is doled out on board ships making long voyages. In the case of a large ocean liner which crosses from port to port in a week less there is no crying need for stint in this particular.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The Yale Demoeratic Club held its first rally of the campaign to-night, with ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois as the principal speaker. The affair was a great success, as Music Hall, with a capacity of 2,500, was taxed to its utmost and hundreds were un able to gain admission.

The Judges of the Court of Appeals have, according to Assistant District Attorney Le Barbier, done an unprecedented thing in requesting that all of the original exhibits in the case of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, the dentist, convicted of murdering "Dolly" Reynolds, be sent to them in order to aid them in making their decision on the motion for a new trial, which was argued last week.

With the warm and damp weather of the early part of the week, the Japanese quince bushes used for hedges here and there about the city where a hedge, is to be found, have budded and blossomed. This is a shrub which is noted for its early Spring blossoms, but it is seldom that it gets so much ahead of the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The reply of the United States Government to the latest note from France offering suggestions as to the settlement of the troubles in China was completed late to-day and delivered to M. Thiebaut, Charge d'Affaires of the French Embassy. By him it was forwarded immediately to his Government.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 10. -- The Republicans in Kentucky are making bold claims that they will carry the Third, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, Ninth, and Eleventh Congressional Districts. It has been learned that in the office of Chairman Babcock of the Republican National Congressional Committee in Washington is the following confidential report sent from Kentucky by Chairman Leslie Coombs of the Republican State Campaign Committee:

NEWCASTLE, Del., Oct. 10. -- The naphtha launch Ocean City, which left Atlantic City on Monday for Philadelphia, put in here this morning with the three men on board safe and well. She had a rather rough experience with the storm, and one of her engines is somewhat damaged, but otherWise the little craft is all right.

BUCYRUS, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- George Fenner, who raised the American flag over the City of Mexico when it fell, dropped dead on the street here yesterday. Mr. Fenner was a resident of this community for half a century. He was born in Pennsylvania, and served through the Mexican War.

Names that are to appear in the Hall of Fame were considered yesterday, the Senate of New York University meeting for the first counting of votes in the conference hall of the university, Washington Square East. Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken acted as Chairman, and Edward, R. Shaw, Dean of the School of Pedagogy, and Clarence D. Amnley, Dean of the Law School, were the Secretaries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Cardinal Gibbons, the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic University, of America, presided at the annual meeting of that body in McMahon Hall to-day. Others present were Archbishop Williams of Boston, Vice Chairman of the board; Bishop Maes of Covington, Ky., Secretary; Thomas E. Waggaman of this city, Treasurer; Archbishops Corrigan of New York, Keane of Dubuque, Christie of Portland, Oregon; Ryan of Philadelphia, Elder of Cincinnati, Bishops.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 10. -- In an address to-night, one of three he made here, Mr. Roosevelt made a reply to the speech of Mr. Bryan yesterday at Macomb, Ill. When the Governor was introduced the crowd rose and gave him three cheers and a tiger. He said in part:

Gen. Benjamin Harrison, ex-President of the United States, who has been in the city for several days, last night expressed his views on the political situation in a talk with reporters at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 10. -- No damage is anticipated to the White Star Line's Oceanic, which touched off the coast of Ireland on her way from New York to this port, though an examination will possibly show that her fore foot is injured.
The Tammany County Convention for the purpose of nominating two Justices of the Supreme Court and one Judge of the City Court was held last evening.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Following is the monthly crop report issued by the Department of Agriculture:

Wall Street Interest rates stiffened yesterday, higher quotations, especially for call funds, being recorded. This was construed as lending some emphasis to the recitations of bear speculators who for some time past have been vehemently declaring that we must suffer from a money market squeeze.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Chairman Jones of the National Democratic Committee said today:

Many of the recent theatrical productions have been more than commonly noteworthy in a pictorial sense. Shabby scenery is rarely exhibited on the New York stage in these days. If the acting was always as good in its way as the scenery, dramatic art would indeed be in flourishing condition.

As a result of the peculations of William Schreiber, for eleven years a clerk in the banking house of the Elizabethport Banking Company of Elizabethport, N.J., who, through a consummate mastery of the art of juggling figures, was able to steal at will, the officers of that institution were compelled to admit yesterday that practically the entire capital and surplus of the bank had been swept away.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- At the second day's racing of the Newmarket second October meeting to-day, the Czarewitch Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, at two miles, two furlong's, and thirty-five yards, was won by L. Neumann's Clarehaven. Second place was captured by J. Moffat's Saturday, (late Midsummer,) and E.Corrigan's Sardonic II., with C. Jenkin in the saddle, came in third.

The new building of the Army Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association on Governors Island was dedicated yesterday. It is the gift of William E. Dodge, whose son, Cleveland H. Dodge, is the President of the Young Men's Christian Association of this city. The building, is a neat frame structure, built in the Colonial style, and is situated on the water front near Castle Williams.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The significance of the action taken yesterday by the Army Fortifications Board in regard to disappearing guns is that it practically puts an end to the future of this weapon throughout the whole world. It is one of the most far-reaching decisions ever given in military matters, and practically explodes a bubble which has been blown up for many years by all the nations of the world.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- Yale's football team defeated Bates at the Yale Field this afternoon by the sweeping score of 50 to 0. The weakness of Bates and the fast play of Yale tells the whole story. Seven of the Bates men had not played before, and Yale used virtually her whole picked team.

Surrogate Thomas yesterday signed an order appointing Waldorf Astor an executor of the estate of John Jacob Astor, to act in conjunction with his father, William Waldorf Astor and Charles A. Peabody, Jr., the surviving executors under the will of John Jacob Astor. In Signing the order Surrogate Thomas practically decides the status of Waldorf Astor as an American citizen, the question having been made a part of the moving papers by the other executors.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Shortly after the acquirement of the Long Island Rail road, in May last, the Pennsylvania Board of Directors determined on a change of certain departments to New York, and the first step in that direction was taken today in the stock transfer department of the Treasurer's, office.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The Liberals have been doing far better, in the counties in the Parliamentary general election than they did in the boroughs. Yesterday they gained two more seats, Cardiff and the Otley Division of Yorkshire, thus equalizing the party gains. The Ministerialists and the Opposition have now gained twenty-seven seats each.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Athletic authorities at the University of Pennsylvania will support warmly the recommendations for a new set of rules to govern the eligibility of college students to participate in intercollegiate athletics, which were drawn up by a special committee representing the Faculty Committees on Athletics of the various universities.

The probability that the new British Parliament will assemble at an early date and the prospect that the ToryUnionist majority may even exceed the majority of 152 returned for Lord SALISBURY five years ago, together with the shattered condition of the rank and file of the Liberals, and the dissensions among their leaders, arouse some curiosity in regard to the nature of the obstructions that will be placed in the way of Ministerial legislation.

Eugene Kinnaird McEnroe, who, besides being secretary and confidential clerk to City Clerk Sohmer, is a relative by mar riage of Richard Croker and a son of Deputy Tax Commissioner Eugene McEnroe, has brought an action against his wife. Mae E. McEnroe, for absolute divorce, and the defendant yesterday made an application in the Supreme Court to be allowed $750 counsel fees and $25 a week alimony pending the decision of the suit.

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- "A Stronger Public Spirit in Our Political Life" was the subject of an address given by Bird S. Coler, Controller of New York City, before the Twentieth Century Club this evening. Mr. Coler said in part:

President Grout of the Borough of Brooklyn and Commissioner Dalton of the Water Supply Department had a serious dispute yesterday after the meeting of the Board of Public Improvements. Commissioner Dalton had reported against the contract proposed by President Grout with the Queens County Water Company for a temporary supply for Brooklyn.

Except for one flitting glimpse of the sun, gloom 'hung' over the Morris Park race track yesterday and the light crowd in attendance shivered even in wraps. The track was at its worst after the rain, and the heavy and holding, going caused numerous withdrawals. The only stake event on the programme, the McGrathiana, selling, at seven furlongs, for fillies three years old, brought out a field of four, with Miss Hanover the favorite.
BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- Great Britain's answer to Germany's second note was received this morning. It is an unreserved and unconditional acceptance of the German position.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 10. -- W.J. Bryan to-day took cognizance of the letter to him by Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn, which was given out yesterday, and prepared a reply to it. The reply says:

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Laura Carroll is named as another victim of the insurance conspiracy syndicate, said to be headed by Dr. August M. Unger. The physician used her, it is said, as a subject on whom to take out policies in a game similar to that which was attempted with Marie Defenbach.

The Kings County Democrats have done themselves credit in four of their nominations for Congress. In renominating FITZGERALD in the Second, DRIGGS in the Third, CLAYTON in the Fourth, and WILSON in the Fifth District they have won respect for sense and courage if they have shown indifference to political consistency.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 10. -- Mrs. William Pita Hugh Whitehouse will make extensive improvements in her Newport villa during the Winter, among other things changing the entrance. The present entrance is too small in comparison with the size of the house, and it is proposed to make another on the north side of the structure, the music room and library being thrown into one apartment to form a hall.

The New York Board of Trade and Transportation held Its first regular meeting after the Summer season yesterday. President William H. Parsons presided. A resolution authorizing the appointment of a committee to work for the repeal of the internal revenue stamp tax was adopted. A report of the special committee on second class mail matter went over to the next meeting for action.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- The British general election is exciting a good deal of interest and comment in Continental Europe. The opinion is universal that it is a personal triumph for Mr. Chamberlain, and that if he becomes predominant in the British Government an era of aggression and jingoism will be inaugurated which will seriously threaten the peace of Europe.

In the following list "rats" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The War revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate or 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
CITY ISLAND, N.U., Oct. 10. -- The naphtha yacht Fearless, owned by a New York yachtsman, has been hauled out at the Jacob yard, to be laid up for the Winter months.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 10. -- The Venezuelan Government has issued a decree providing for the free navigation of the Pedernales and Macareo Canals in the delta of the Orinoco previously the monopoly of a British company.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- A suit to recover insurance on the life of his wife, whom he killed Dec. 31, 1893, has been commenced in this city by Prof. Swithin C. Shortlidge, who is now residing at Kennett Square, in Chester County. The suit, which is to recover the sum of $7,022 from the Provident Life and Trust Company, is one of the most remarkable in the history of life insurance.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The Will of Miss Eleanor Roome of North Plainfield, daughter of the late Judge Roome of New York, was admitted to probate to-day in the Somerset County Surrogate's office at Somerville. There are bequests to public charities and religious institutions, as follows: American Tract Society, $1,000; Educational Fund of Presbyterian Church, $2,000; Board of Foreign Missions of Presbyterian Church $1,000; Board of Domestic Missions.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Sir Thomas Lipton to-day informed a representative of The Associated Press that a challenge from him for the America's Cup is on board the White Star Line steamer Germanic, due at New York Thursday. When questioned as to the details of his challenge he said he preferred that all information as to its contents be first given out by the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The newly arrived Sisters of Perpetual Adoration, who reached this city yesterday morning from Antwerp, Belgium, took charge of their convent and chapel here to-day. The structure is a memorial built by Mrs. T. F. Ryan of New York, in honor of her deceased husband, and its valuation approximates $100,000.

GLASGOW, Oct. 11. -- It can be said that the design of George L. Watson for Sir Thomas Lipton's America's Cup challenger, while embodying several novelties, follows more closely the lines of the American yachts than any previous cup challenger.

It was on one of the Fourth Avenue cars. A young Irishman biibbling over with good humor and a considerable quantity of whisky, boarded the car near the Brooklyn ridge terminal. A. pleasant-faced Deaconess of the Episcopal sisterhood, dressed in the garb of her order, was seated near the centre of the car.
