CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Outpunted, outrushed, outtackled, the Harvard Varsity eleven barely escaped being scored upon by the second in a hard practice game lasting fully twenty-five minutes. As it was, they were forced to the fiveyard line, and forced to punt, but Ellis's kick was a semi-fluke, and the second began hammering away again at the 'Varsity line, with the goal posts within arm's reach.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday afternoon a resolution offered by President York was passed, calling upon Chief Devery to make an investigation of the alleged disorderly houses and Raines law hotels that were named as centres of colonization of voters in the letter from Superintendent of Elections McCullagh to Chief Devery, published Monday morning.

MANILA, Oct. 11. -- The west coast of the Island of Leyte is in a, state of turmoil, the rebel ladrones are actively plundering, the disturbers raiding and attacking and then returning to the garrisoned towns, while the Americans pursue in the mountains.

The committee of the Senate of New York University yesterday added twelve names to the list of those already selected for a place in the Hall of Fame. Those who received the required majority of fifty-one votes were:

The adjourned session of the Republican County Convention nominated at Murray Hill Lyceum last night candidates for the judiciary. Justices Edward Patterson and James A. Blanchard were chosen as the nominees for the Supreme Court Bench and Robert C. Morris for the City Court.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11. -- The Republican State Convention held here today nominated the following Presidential Electors: Frank F. Olney, Providence; Alexander G. Crumb, Westerley; Robert B. Treat, Warwick; George H. Norman, Newport.

There are unmistakable signs that the opening of the New York Winter season, is near at hand Despite the Morristown Horse Show and other suburban attractions, there were many well-known people driving and walking yesterday on the Avenue, and the smart restaurants were also well, filled at the luncheon and dinner hours with familiar faces.

Bedford Council of the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum won both, its matches in the tournament of the Brooklyn Councils of that organization last night, defeating Welcome and Washington Irvlngr Councils. Washington Irving defeated Welcome, which lost both its matches. The scores:

MANILA, Oct. 6 (via Hongkong Oct. 11.) -- The administration of Manila's civil courts by Filipino magistrates, which has long been scandalous, is now attracting public attention more than ever and has been brought to the Taft commission's attention with requests for rectification.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 11 -- F.O. Affeld of New York, the delegate of the National Board of Fire Underwriters to the twenty-eighth annual convention of Chiefs of Fire Departments, which is now in session in this city, delivered an address today on " The Ounce of Prevention," in the course of which he said:

HOMBURG, Oct. 11. -- The laying of the foundation stone of the Imperial Museum to be erected at Saalburg, on the site of the old Roman fortress there, occurred this morning, with considerable ceremony, in the presence of the Emperor and Empress of Germany.

Sir Thomas Lipton's challenge, owing to the delay in the arrival of the White Star Line steamer Germanic, did not reach here yesterday. The town house of the New York Yacht Club, in Madison Avenue, was more than usually filled with club members yesterday in anticipation of the arrival of the document, and Secretary J.V. S. Oddie remained at the clubhouse in readiness for its reception until late last night.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

LONDON. Oct. 11. -- At the third day's racing of the Newmarket second October meeting to-day, the Lowther Stakes was won by Lord William Beresford's bay gelding. Jolly Tar, by The Sailor Prince, out of Joy, ridden by " Johnnie " Reiff.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Clerk and Judges are besieged by crowds of foreigners, prospective citizens, eager to renounce allegiance to foreign princes and potentates. The rush grows greater every day. About 275 aliens a day, on an average, have applied for the big, red-sealed certificates since the rush began on Oct. 1.
ST. JOHN, N.B., Oct. 11. -- The Province of New Brunswick has just been visited by a rainstorm which lasted 108 hours, and which in amount equals ten inches.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Miss Harriet Alexandria Fiero, daughter of J. Newton Fiero of this city, was married this afternoon to Charles Lambert Rothenstein of England at the country residence of Mr. Fiero at Altamont. The ceremony took place in the library, the young couple standing under a canopy of chrysanthemums, with a background of hemlock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The reply of the State Department to the French note relative to the bases of Chinese negotiations was made public late to-day. It reads as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- The new 6,200-ton steamship Sierra, built by the Cramps for the Oceanic Steamship Company, to ply between the Pacific Coast and Australia, sailed from the yard for San Francisco at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

Notices were sent out to the Tammany district leaders yesterday that their requests for speakers could not be filled by the Tammany Hall Speakers' Bureau until after the Bryan demonstration on Oct. 16. The campaign in the districts will be allowed to lag until after the big Bryan meetings, and then it will be Tesumed with vigor.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 11. -- An interesting drag hunt was held to-day by the members of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club. Mrs. Adolph Ladenburg, who rode Juggler; Mrs. James L. Kernochan, on her famous hunter Retribution; William Portman, Master of the Warrenton Hunt Club of Virginia, on Foxhall Keene's steeplechaser Sandegras: Samuel Willets, on Gimcrack, and Ernest C. Hayes, on Virginia Dare, carried away the principal honors of the chase.

We have been disposed to look upon Mr. ADLAI E. STEVENSON, the candidate for Vice President on the ticket with Mr. BRYAN, as a man of serious mind, not too free from political vagaries, but in the main normal, so that it is with great regret that we learn that he has been led into a ridiculous performance by designing or ignorant persons.

It is an economic event of more than passing consequence that, in the building of one bridge, effects a saving close to a million dollars. That is what is represented in the contract awarded yesterday for the new East River structure approaches. Four months ago bids were passed upon that called for $3,321,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- As officially announced by the Census Bureau to-day, the population of the State of Connecticut in 1900 is 908,355, as compared with a population in 1890 of 746,258, showing an increase since 1890 of 162,097, or 21.7 per cent. This is a little higher rate of increase than that of the decade from 1880 to 1890, when it was 19.8 per cent.

As a result of a list of forty-seven questions sent out on June 15 last by the Tenement House Commission, the commission has now at hand, collated in two huge typewritten volumes, what it considers the most remarkable collection of suggestions from all kinds of interested persons that has ever been gathered on the subject of tenement house building.

Prof. Homer B. Sprague, Yale, 52, made the principal address before the College Men's Democratic Club of the City of New York at the meeting held last night in the ballroom of the Savoy Hotel; Prof, Sprague in some of his remarks made a direct attack on President McKinley. Among other things he said:

Whatever may be the object of the expedition to Pao-ting-Foo, which is to usher in the military career of Field Marshall the Count VON WALDERSEE in the Far East, it is quite evident that it is not an expedition of rescue. The French are getting up a little expedition of their own for that purpose, for the rescue of some French priests who are beleaguered sixty miles to the south of Tien-Tsin.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11. -- Grover Cleveland has replied to a letter written by John S. Green of this city inquiring if the former President has changed his views on the financial question as expressed in his letter to Chicago business men on April 13, 1895. Mr. Cleveland's letter to Mr. Green was as follows:

-- An entirely commendable inclination is shown by the officers and Directors of the Elizabethport Banking Company to take upon themselves some moral, as well as all pecuniary, responsibility for the innumerable, and long-continued robberies of young SCHREIBER.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Senator Mason of Illinois, who was at the White House to-day, made this reply to Mr. Bryan's recent utterance on the subject of slavery in the Sulu Islands and under the American flag:
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- In the pollings in the Parliamentary general election yesterday the Ministerialists gained two seats, making their total gains thirty, as against twenty-nine for the Opposition.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11. -- Philip Stillman, '95S., who was for three years centre on the 'Varsity football team, Joined the Yale squad of coachers to-day. Chamberlain, Captain of the '98 team, and McBride of the '99 team, went into the game to-day themselves. Chamberlain playing tackle and McBride full back.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The Morristown Field Club Horse Show began this afternoon. There was a large attendance. Many out-of-town society people occupied boxes. The weather was perfect.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Warden Addison Johnson of the State prison here denies absolutely the charges which the special committee of the Prison Association is said, to be about to make relative to prison management. He said:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 11 -- At the second day's session of the ninety-first annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions to-day much interest was shown in the discussion of mission work in China. After devotional exercises, the Rev. Dr. Judson Smith, Foreign Secretary of the American Board, read a paper on " China': The Situation and Outlook."

The inquest into the death of Kathryn Scharn, who was found murdered early in the morning of Aug. 19 in her rooms at 674 Secend Avenue, was continued yesterday morning before Coroner Bausch and a jury. No evidence was produced that would tend a incriminate Fred Scharn, the girl's brother, who was the first to find her body and on whom the police are trying to fix tie crime.

The annual report of the Central of Georgia shows that the total mileage of the system operated last year was 1,560 miles, with a total funded debt outstanding of $45,941,000. The revenue passengers carried over the lines of the system were 1,789,565 an increase of 13 per cent., and the tons of revenue freight carried were 2,457,977, an increase of nearly 12 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- There was no line-up of Princeton's first team to-day, but the signal practice was sufficiently hard to make the players imagine that a foe confronted them. The coaches goaded the men and kept them right at the work, but were in a good humor and did little scolding.

MARION, Ind., Oct. 11. -- Gov. Roosevelt's train was side-tracked four miles, from this city during the night, after its run from Fort Wayne, and the Republican Vice Presidential candidate skept peacefully until 7 o'clock. After the train left Fort Wayne the stone-throwing incident in the streets of that city was the chief topic of conversation.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Further information regarding Sir Thomas Lipton's new challenger for the America's Cup confirms the statement that the boat will be named Shamrock and will be selected by a series of contests between the yacht Watson is designing and the old Shamrock, after the latter has undergone the improvements proposed by Fife, though both yachts will be kept fully manned by Sir Thomas Lioton and may cross the water, together.

The renomination of Justice PATTERSON by the Democratic Convention has been followed by his nomination at the hands of the Republicans -- adding one more to the precedents constantly becoming more numerous and consistent of sinking party preferences in cases of distinguished merit.

The properties belonging to the estate of the late Bradish Johnson were sold at auction in the Trinity Building Salesroom yesterday for a total of $4,796,100. As had been generally anticipated, there was no competition except for one or two of the smaller parcels, and even in these instances a few bids were sufficient to show that the heirs had no intention of allowing any of the property to pass out of their hands.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 11. -- The woman's golf tournament commenced to-day with a qualification round, eighteen holes. Miss P. Robinson of New York won the prize by turning in a score of 102. The next best was 104, by Miss Hinckle of Bar Harbor. The greens were a trifle damp from the heavy dew, which made the sixth, in particular, very fast, but the sun dried these up before the second round was begun.

Dr. Franklin Smith, seventy-six years old, died at his home, 366 Broome Street, on Tuesday night, after a short illness. He was born in this State, and for over a quarter of a century had been a resident of this city.

B.B. Odell, Jr., Republican candidate for Governor, made a speech last night to the members of the Republican Editorial Association of the State of New York. The annual meeting of the organization took place in this city yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has lately been called to two editorials in the daily newspapers and to one in a prominent medical Journal in this city in which the action of the Trustees of the New York State Hospital for Consumptives has been criticised because they selected a site for their hospital on Lake Clear, in the Adlrondacks.
PARIS, Oct. 11. -- A financial statement issued to-day shows a very satisfactory state of affairs for the exposition year.

Only a few outside stocks yesterday manifested any increase in activity but the developments of the day showed a little more interest than was taken in the trading on the earlier days of the week. In one or two issues trading was quite large, while in some others price movements attracted some attention.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- A series of fetes intended to inject much-needed gayety into The closing days of the exposition was opened this afternoon with a parade and ballet on the River Seine, along the front of the exposition.

William E. Paine, manager of the Carroll Box and Lumber Company, has taken great umbrage at the charges made by Capt. F. Norton Goddard, Republican leader of the Twentieth Assembly District, that the former had discharged William Whitaker from the employ of the company because he had accepted the Republican nomination for State Senator in the Fourteenth District.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Republican managers took Indiana out of the doubtful column to-day and anchored it in the McKinley row. They say the "thirty-day poll" which has just been completed in the Hoosier State shows that Indiana will give a larger Republican majority in November than it did in 1896, when McKinley carried the State by more than 18,000.

Three attacks, apparently preconcerted, were made last night on open-air Republican meetings. Boughs and hoodlums, after falling to interrupt the meetings by yells and shouts, hurled stones and sticks and other missiles. In one case the speaker was struck in the head by a stone, and, with the stone held aloft and blood running from his wound, continued to address the meeting on the privilege of free speech until he had won his audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Col. Humphrey, Quartermaster in China, has sent a cablegram, under to-day's date, to the Quartermaster General, announcing the first departure of United States troops from China. The dispatch is as follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- John White of Kingston and his alleged wife, who is his senior by forty-seven years, were given a serenade last night, to which White replied with a shotgun. Two of the serenaders were seriously wounded, and several slightly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Quartermaster General Ludington has completed arrangements to send two transports from New York to Manila by way of the Mediterranean Sea with a large number of recruits for regiments in the Philippines which are short of their complement by reason of death or discharge.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 11. -- Gen. Edward S. Bragg, a life-long Democrat, who served several terms in Congress and was Minister to Mexico under President Cleveland, to-night addressed a distinguished audience that filled the Pabst Theatre. He spoke in response to a call signed by a number of Gold Democrats.

The arrival of Sir THOMAS LIPTON'S challenge for the America's Cup will increase the general satisfaction at the complete and honorable clearing up of the scandal of the Rainbow's extra ballast during the faces of the seventy-footers last Summer. The real point, the larger, vital aspect of that affair has been hardly considered at all in the discussion it has evoked.

The residence, 29 West Seventy-fifth Street, of Jose M. Andreinl, a merchant at 15 Wall Street, was robbed yesterday, of jewelry'to the value of $500. After some detective work on the part of a conscience-stricken mason, who had left the door open, the thief was landed in the Tenderloin police station with all of the property on his person.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Oct. 11. -- There was great rejoicing here to-night when the official figures were given out showing that the big battleship Wisconsin had averaged 17.25 knots in her thirty-mile trial trip, thus beating the record and making her the fastest ship of her class in the world.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 11 -- The convention of the anthracite miners now on strike throughout the entire hard coal fields in Pennsylvania will convene in this city to-morrow morning for the purpose of considering the 10 per cent, net increase in wages proffered them by nearly all the mine operators in the region.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Some hunters and harness horses from Hollo way's Farm, New Rochelle, N.Y., were sold at auction here to-day and fetched 2,400 guineas. Ben Bolt was sold for 310 guineas, Hereford for 200 guineas, and The Dude for 160 guineas.

Before the Committee on Law of the Board of Aldermen there is now a resolution which, if it should be passed by the Municipal Assembly and receive the sanction of Mayor Van Wyck, would confer upon a private corporation the right to use the streets of this city for advertising purposes for twenty years to come.

New determination after Wednesday's scoreless game with Williams was evident in the Columbia football squad yesterday afternoon. The practice on South Field, which was prolonged until dusk, was the most encouraging as well as the most severe of the season. Vim and dash characterized the individual work of the candidates, while the team play of both 'Varsity and scrub showed immense improvement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The War Department to-day made public the annual report of Brig. Gen. George W. Davis, commanding the Department of Porto Rico. It states that, when the organization of the civil government shall have been completed and the civil machinery is working well, there will be no necessity to retain in the island so large a force as at present.

With the return of pleasant weather, both the attendance and the racing at Morris Park yesterday showed great improvement, and close and well-contested finishes rewarded the crowd for the visit, though the results were not altogether satisfactory to the betting element. The circular tracks were still dead and slow, but the Eclipse course had dried out so well that the opening race was run in time very close to the track record.

The fact that the scholarly London Spectator was lately fooled into printing as an original French poem one of jovial Francis Mahony's translations of famous English verse into French so pure and fluent that many people who knew much about literature were misled by them in Mahony's day, has occasioned a revival of interest in "Father Prout," his literary jokes and fancies and his life.
Mrs. Hugh T. Dickey died suddenly yesterday at Tuxedo Park.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Dr. Morrison cabling to The Times from Peking under date of Oct. 11, says:
From The Evening Post of Tuesday. An instance of the fine forgotten things that Mr. Stedtnan's "Anthology" brings to light again is the following poem of Charles Henry Luders:

The topic of higher education for women was discussed with true Gallic passion at the recent conference of students in France. Women were not admitted to the sessions, but the men voted without hesitation and with what the political reporters call a "hurrah" for the opening of all branches of higher and secondary education to women.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The will of Richard P. Gormully, the bicycle manufacturer who died some weeks ago, was admitted to record in the Probate Court to-day without contest of any kind.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Rear Admiral Silas Casey, at present commandant of the League Island Navy Yard, Penn., has been selected to succeed Rear Admiral Albert Kautz as commander of the Pacific Station upon the latter's retirement in the near future.

Mayor Van Wyck, Controller Coler, and the other members of the Board of Estimate came to an understanding yesterday regarding the consolidation of all the libraries of the Greater New York under the New York Public Library.

The election in the Hall of Fame contest was concluded yesterday afternoon, when the Senate of the New York University assembled and passed upon the list submitted to that body by the committee which for the last three days has been busily counting the votes.

The Continental Casualty Company, which was recently formed by the amalgamation of the Metropolitan Accident Company of Chicago, the Continental Assurance Company of Detroit, and the North-western Benevolent Society of Duluth, has completed negotiations as a result of which it will take over the business of the People's Accident Association of Des Moines, reinsuring its membership, which consists of about 500 policyholders.

Engagements amounting to $3,500,000 of gold in Europe for import to New York were announced yesterday, making the total imports so far announced this week $4,200,000. Further announcements are looked for to-day in foreign exchange banking circles.
KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 12 -- Ex-Fire Chief B.F.H. Bowers, Deputy Sheriff, jailer, and a prominent politician, is in jail for killing Mrs. Charlotte Knowles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Admiral Remey to-day cabled the Navy Department the announcement of his departure from Chinese waters. He goes on his flagship, the Brooklyn, from Taku to Che-Foo, thence to Nagasaki, Japan.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 12 -- P. Louter Wessels, Special Commissioner of the South African republics to the United States, yesterday received a letter from Secretary De Bruyn of the Boer envoys, now in Holland, containing the first reliable and definite, information of the plans of Mr. kruger that has been made public.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Only a very few contests remain in the Parliamentary general election. There were about forty not decided yesterday morning, and polling took place in twenty-nine of these constituencies yesterday. There will be eight contests to-day.

Because of a technicality, the hearing yesterday before the State Board of Railroad Commissioners in the Brooklyn Borough Hall on the petition of residents of the Twenty-sixth Ward with regard to the alleged poor transportation service furnished that district by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, was adjourned.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 12 -- Eight hundred and fifty-seven miners, who hold in their hands the power to end or continue the anthracite coal miners' strike, which has been in progress for more than three weeks, met in convention here to-day for the purpose of considering the 10 per cent. net advance in wages offered by the operators, and adjourned until to-morrow without taking any action on their employers' proposition.

The hitherto unbeaten Corinthian bowlers, with a record of eleven consecutive victories, met their Waterloo in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night, losing two out of three matches with the Spartan team. In the first game the Spartan team made a score of 987, which is the highest yet made on the alleys in this tournament.

The second session of the Christian Endeavor Union Convention, at the Bergen Baptist Church, Jersey City, was devoted to religious exercises, department reports, and addresses. The devotional services were conducted by Bishop Alexander Walters of the Afro-American Methodist Church, after which came a discussion of the best method of winning new members.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Messrs, Sampson Low Co. have just published six volumes of sea stories at the price of a guinea for the set. The list comprises Marryat's "Midshipman Easy," Michael Scott's "Tom Cringle's Log," Cooper's ''Two Admirals," Clark Russell's "Wreck of the Grosvenor," Cupples's "Green Hand," and Melville's "Moby Dick."

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- "Is F. Wayland Brown, who, with Dr. Unger and Detective Smiley, was arrested for conspiracy to defraud insurance companies in connection with Marie A. Defenbach's death, playing a sleuth's part in the case?"

"A sound mind in a sound body is a necessity," says theory. "Parkman," rejoins actuality, and theory retires to the gymnasiums, possibly to mislead some youngster to such endeavors to crush down his physical weaknesses as doubled the historian's sufficiently heavy burden of physical troubles.
The result of the first day's registration in Greater New York was not clearly indicated by the few figures received from official sources up to 3 A.M. to-day.

ARTHUR LUMLEY. New York, referring to Mr. Gregory's "honeymoon joke," writes: "In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 29 'Veritas' states that he is reluctant to contradict a gentleman of Mr. Arthur Lumley's veracity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12 -- The Harvard Republican, fruit of countless vigils by the student members of the Harvard Republican Club, appeared late this afternoon. Its edition of 5,000 copies was quickly distributed among the students and townspeople. It has pictures of McKinley and Roosevelt on the first page and contains generous contributions from Harvard graduates on the issues of the campaign.

Quite the literary event at the month in London is the appearance of the first number of Mr. Murray's Monthly Review. The periodical includes 200 pages of text prlnted in large type with broad margin. The policy of The Review is explained in three editorial articles, and the first installment of Anthony Hope's new story, " Tristram of Blent," is presented.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- George D. Meiklejohn, Assistant Secretary of War, has mailed the following letter to William J. Bryan:

The Governors of the New York Stock Exchange have directed their Law Committee to take up charges against the stock brokerage firm of Carr Peters, at 18 Wall Street, next week. The charges have been preferred upon the ground that that rule of the Exchange has been infracted which provides that there can be no firm relationships detrimental to the good name of the Stock Exchange.

Apropos of an article which appeared in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 4 on the bibliography in the Congressional Library on two of the three "issues" of the present campaign, attention is called to the work of the Department of Labor in its recent Bulletin (No. 29, July, 1900,) on the trust question.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Oct. 12 -- Mr. Bryan concluded the first day of his Ohio campaign in this city to-night. He was met at the station by a torchlight procession, consisting of men both on foot and on horseback, and escorted to a square in the centre of the city, where he spoke from a platform in the open air.

In these days every fairly educated person of either sex is likely to read a foreign language with considerable ease and to write or speak it with some degree of fluency. It is a fascinating study for those who really feel its spell, and throws on one's own language some of that dry, white light of "contemporary posterity" that the sage attributed to foreign travel.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 12 -- The greatest political contest that this State has seen in recent years is close at hand, in the election of a United States Senator to fill the unexpired term of the late Senator Justin S. Morrill, now held by Jonathan Ross, by appointment.

The present history of Westchester County differs from the previous histories that have covered similar ground, notably those of Bolton and Scharf, in that it is particularly intended for popular reading. Something more than a collection of local chronicles or historical facts has been arrived at, and with such an inspiration it must be said that the result has been the formulation of a narrative at once continuous, orderly, discreet, and comprehensive.

No American returning from a sojourn abroad has ever received a heartier welcome than that which awaits "Mark Twain." As an author he has long lived down the invidious reputation of a mere maker of jokes, which never should have attached to him, since, even in his earlier, though perhaps not in his earliest, works there were, to the observant, the signs of serious powers.

The activity which showed on Thursday was not continued yesterday, and trading in the market for outside securities was very light. There was very little trading in even the few issues that were prominent on the previous day, and only a few of the changes in price were of enough importance to attract any interest.

Hardly a business thoroughfare in the city changes its character more slowly than the Bowery, and building operations there are sufficiently rare to attract notice from even the casual passer by. Now an almost unprecedented condition of timings exists, for work for new buildings is in progress at both ends of the famous street at the same time.
MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, addressed a crowded house here to-night. In discussing State issues Mr. Stanchfield said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The official report of the trial trip of the battleship Wisconsir off Lower California is contained in the following brief telegram received by Secretary Long from Admiral Kautz, commanding the Pacific station, at Santa Barbara :

To The New York Times Saturday Review: If the subject of this letter be of sufficient interest, please answer through the columns of THE SATURDAY REVIEW. What was the religious belief of William Morris? I have never known positively from any recognized authority, and I have never been able to form an opinion from any works of his which I have read.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12 -- To-day was the closing of the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association. The 2:22 trot for a purse of $1,000 proved to be an easy thing for the New England mare, Dolly Bid-well, who clearly outclassed her field and won in straight heats from Free Silver and Tell Tale.
CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Speaking at a Republican mass meeting here to-night, Senator Hoar said:

Little change has appeared this week in general business conditions, though what there is is undoubtedly toward betterment. The waiting mood is still on, and it grows clearer that until election uncertainties are out of the way a hand-to-mouth policy will be pursued in many lines of trade.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 12 -- There were 2,500 persons at the second day's session of the Morristown Field Club's Horse Show. Although the weather was threatening, the rain held off, and the show was run off in good shape. The turnout of drags and brakes was large, and there were many coaching parties from, distant points.

Mrs. Kate T. Reilly, formerly Postmistress at Glenamaddy, County Galway. Ireland, and her husband, Thomas Reilly, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Alexander yesterday on a complaint made by Sir Percy Sanderson, British Consul General. He charged them with embezzlement, and asked for their extradition.

Georgiana G.R. Wendel has been adjudged insane by thirteen out of fifteen members of a Sheriff's jury. It took the jury one hour and forty-five minutes last night to reach this verdict. The jury added a "rider" to the verdict, in which it recommended that Miss Wendel be placed in charge of some person or persons not of her immediate family, and that her property be cared for by some disinterested person.

Between 30,000 and 35,000 Italians of this city yesterday joined in a parade in commemoration of the four hundred and eighth anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus. The celebration was held under the auspices of the United Italian Societies of New York, and consisted of two parades, and was followed up at night by a picnic in Sulzer's Harlem River Park.

Two wills executed by the late William M. Rice were made public yesterday. The first will, dated Sept. 26, 1896, was filed for probate at 3:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the office of the Surrogate. No petition was filed with the will, but later in the afternoon a petition was filed by ex-Judge John D. Bartine.

Edwin E. Hooper is one of those who have a strong growth of beard, and who has to wait long hours in barbers' shops, only to have the latest tonsorial scandal poured into his ears. Yet he must be shaved, and as science had invented no substitute, he bore his troubles with becoming meekness.

Every voter presenting himself for registration this year in this city or in any other of more than 5,000 inhabitants will have an opportunity to enroll himself with the party with which he is in sympathy, and thus secure the legal right to take part in its primaries and in the general management of its course.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 12 -- All previous records were broken by the September shipments of pig iron, steel, and cast-iron pipe from the South for European points.

The Ernst-Marx-Nathan Company has sold the seven-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, 75.8 by 85. It is understood that the transaction is partly a trade. The sellers took the Lenox Avenue property, as plaintiffs in foreclose ure proceedings, about a month ago.

One of the most dramatic scenes ever enacted in a Coroner's court took place yesterday during the Scharn inquest, when, in the last moment of the proceedings, a young girl, not hitherto connected with the case, volunteered testimony which resulted in the exonerating of Fred Scnarn, the murdered girl's young brother, on whom the police tried to fix the crime.

Thomas Bates Musgrave, who up to the time of his failure in 1889 was head of the banking firm of Musgrave Co., in Wall Street, is now confined in a private sanitarium in West Thirty-ninth Street. "A writ of habeas corpus has been obtained by his sister and brother-in-law, who allege that Mr. Musgrave's wife and son have had him confined in the sanitarium in order to keep him from public view.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- From reports of incoming sea Captains it is learned that not for many years have there been so many menaces to navigation as prevail on the North Atlantic Ocean at present, and it is understood that the shipping interests of Philadelphia are about to unite in a petition that the Vesuvius be assigned to the work of blowing up the numerous derelicts scattered about the ocean.

NEWPORT, Oct. 12 -- Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador, is taling his first vacation in many weeks. He and Lady Pauncefote left this morning for New York, thence they go to Ophir Farm, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, whose guests they will be for a few days.

Reports to Dun's in respect to Canadian trade say that Halifax reports conditions unchanged. The grocery movement is brisk and there is a better demand for heavy metals, except pig iron, at Montreal, while the cooler weather has helped dry goods sales. Collections are fair to good, and after hardening early in the week money became plentiful at 5 per cent.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 12 -- While there are rumors that the whereabouts of Schreiber are practically known, there is nothing here to confirm such reports. The belief is general that he is somewhere near by and has not gone to Europe, as has been reported.

Another afternoon of excellent racing was seen at the Parkway Driving Club half-mile track yesterday. As on the previous day, there were numerous close finishes, which were the culmination of heats that were hard fought from wire to wire. The attendance again was of respectable proportions, and the track fast.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "P.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been hold to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
Volume III. (1654-1656) of Prof. Samuel Rawson Gardiner's "History of the Commonwealth and the Protectorates" is now ready from the press of Longmans, Green Co.

This is the first of two monographs issued by the Kansas house as part of their clever serial issues into which they are gathering and presenting a remarkable local State and regional history. It is evidently the ambition of the Cranes to become publishers of historical repute in connection with the vast New West, or at least the central portion and communities thereof.

It has been the privilege of THE SATURDAY REVIEW on several occasions to call attention to the fact that the art of music for some strange reason is not regarded by the average literary man as standing in the same relation to general culture as the other arts. It has been noted that literary men display an ignorance of the tone art which they would be ashamed to show in regard to sculpture or architecture.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- This was the quietest day for a week in the Boston market, but prices held well and gained in one or two directions. The revival in the copper shares slept temporarily, only two members of the group showing any animation. Old Dominion was bid up by interests heretofore prominent in its rejuvenescence, rising from 20 to 21 1/2, whence it reacted to 20 1/2.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- For the first time since 1897 the annual class crew races were held at Cornell to-day. Three class crews and the Francis Club crew entered and rowed a mile race on Lake Cayuga.
A reviewer, speaking of J.M. Barrie's sequel to "Sentimental Tommy," says: "Like all Mr. Barrie's work, this new tale is written with a deft, smooth touch that carries a charm in its every word."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Harvard's practice to-day, the last before the Columbia same, was light. In a fifteen-minute game the 'Varsity was able to score on the second eleven but once, and that by reason of Ellis's terrific plunges. Kendall and Sawin did not play, however, which accounts for less end gains.

Several rumors were afloat yesterday afternoon that William Schreiber, the defaulting Elizabethport bank clerk, had been captured in the upper part of the city, but upon investigation they proved to be unfounded. One story was that Schreiber had been located in a house near West One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, had left an upper story window by means of a rope, and was captured after a short chase.

The first regular meeting of the New York Library Club for the current season was held last Thursday afternoon at the rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. The general subject of the meeting was "The Relations of the Libraries of New York City to its Educational Department."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 12 -- The Government has, annulled the concession of the Orinoco Company, alleging non-execution of contract. To the company, which has headquarters at Faribault, Minn., and which is capitalized at $30,000,000, was granted in 1883 a concession or 10,000,000 acres of land situated in the Orinoco district.

We trust that every reader of THE TIMES who is interested in the welfare of the millions of Greater New York read the compilation made in these columns yesterday of the answers made by more or less expert witnesses to the questions put to them by the Tenement House Commission.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 12 -- Gov. Roosevelt concluded his Indiana tour to-night, making two speeches in this city to large audiences. Arriving here at 4:30, the Governor dined in his private car, remaining there until shortly before 8 o'clock, at which time he was escorted to the St. George Hotel, where he reviewed a parade given in his honor.

Ere this the Minnehaha may have poked her nose into her New York dock, and the doyen of American letters, Mark Twain, been landed, together with his baggage, with which, according to a letter he recently wrote to Secretary Gage, the steamer "would be loaded."

The following circular has been sent to the retail trade by the American Publishers' Association, an organization formed last Summer to correct certain evils in the Look trade. This letter has been sent out in the hope that a full consensus of opinion from all persons interested may be obtained upon the questions confronting the committee that was appointed last Summer to draft articles and propose measures for consideration by the association:

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 12 -- O'Brien Sheehan, contractors for the construction of the Rutland-Canadian Railroad, and all having authority to give orders under them, were served with an injunction today, issued by Chief Judge Russell Smith Taft of the Supreme Court, prohibiting them from doing further work upon the road.

The town was quite gay yesterday, and numbers of parties were lunching at the fashionable restaurants. In the afternoon the social, movement was all toward the railway stations and ferry landings, and a contingent of well-known men and women left the city for a week-end stay in the country, or a longer tarry at Lenox, Southampton, or Newport.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 12 -- Twenty-five hundred people at Union Park this afternoon saw the team of the Baltimore Medical College nearly score against the Princeton team. It was a very narrow escape for the Tigers. Toward the close of the first half the "Meds" had worked the ball down to the eight-yard mark of Princeton on the second down, and had made such continuous gains through the line that they seemed likely to score.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 12 -- Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury, addressed a large Republican meeting in this city this evening. It had been announced that he would make the meeting the occasion of a reply to the latest critcism of President McKinley's Administration by Carl Schurz, but he confined himself almost wholly to a discussion of the Currency bill passed last March and made no reference to Mr. Schurz.

HAVANA, Oct. 12 -- At this evening's session of the Ayuntamiento, the Dady sewering and paying contract was under consideration. The modifications suggested by the Military Government were accepted, and a resolution to have the further proceedings under the Spanish law was adopted.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 13. -- The anthracite coal miners now on strike, after two days' convention, decided late this afternoon to accept the 10 per cent, net increase in wages offered by the mine owners, providing they will continue the payment of the advance until next April, and will abolish the sliding scale.

Fred D. Yuengling, whose actions have irequently brought him into public notice during the last ten years, is a prisoner in Ludlow Street Jail on a charge of embezzling $387.85 from the agency of the Lion Brewing Company at Rossland, Kootenay District, British Columbia, of which he was the manager.

Major Gen. Wesley Merritt and Mrs. Merritt were pasesngers on the Lucania, which arrived in port yesterday. Gen, Merritt and his wife have spent several months abroad, visiting the German watering places, the Paris Exposition, the Isle of Wight, and Tunbridge Wells. The General appeared to be in perfect health as he stepped ashore.

GENESEO, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The annual horse show and steeplechase of the Geneseo Valley Hunt Club was held on the home farm to-day, and was one of the most successful in the history of the club. Prominent people from all sections of the State were in attendance, and the crowd was the largest since the inaugural meet.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 13. -- A singular series of accidents occurred in the Mersey to-day. The Norwegian steamer Veritas collided with the Leyland Line steamer Devonia, from Boston Oct. 3. Unsuccessful efforts were made to beach the Veritas on the Cheshire shore, after which she was towed over to the Liverpool side, where the cable parted and she collieded with the steamer Earl of Powys, causing the latter to break from her moorings.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The able arguments of Mr. I. Polack in to-day's issue of THE TIMES are not quite correct.

Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury, paid a flying visit to this city yesterday on his way to Washington from Bridgeport, Conn., where he spoke Friday night at a Republican meeting, and while here, as is his custom, made a short call at the Sub-Treasury, where he looked at the plan for the new vaults there and talked over currency matters with Deputy Assistant Treasurer Muhleman.

"The man who shoots birds with a gun lestroys; he brings back nothing new, he adds nothing to our knowledge. But the man who shoots birds with a camera places us in closer relation with their habits and he brings results that add greatly to general knowledge. It's all very well to say that the man with the gun brings jack specimens but the various species are pretty generally known as to plumage and structure.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- No words can express too strongly the irritation of the British Foreign Office over the latest developments in the Chinese negotiations, and its hopelessness of any working arrangement being arrived at within the near future exceeds, if anything, its irritation, the chief cause of which, to quote an official, is "the extraordinary and unreasonable publicity given to diplomatic communications even before they are officially communicated to the other powers."
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 13. -- The following statement over the signature of J. A. Edgerton, the Secretary, was given out to-night by the People's Party National Committee:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The annual horse show of the Morristown Field Club ended here to-day. Despite the bad weather of the past three days, the exhibition, according to the official was more successful than any held by the club since its organization. The threatening weather did not affect the attendance to-day, and the largest crowd of the show was on hand when the afternoon classes were judged.

Mr. Bryan is to be in New York this week, Wall Street has had the date fixed for a long while, and speculative commitments in variety represent Stock Exchange expectations apropos of the Tammany ovation which seems scheduled. Wall Street has no doubt that extraordinary audiences will greet Mr. Bryan, but as the approach of his appearance comes closer less apprehension is discernible.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- The mosquito fleet of five small gunboats belonging to the United States Navy left Cramps' shipyards to-day for Cuba, with Felix H. Hunicke, Chief of the Revenue Cutter Service, in command. The little warships are numbered from 7 to 11, inclusive. No. 7, the largest, is 70 feet long, 10 feet beam, and has a draught of 30 inches.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 13. -- Princeton beat the Naval Cadets to-day, 5 to 0. The Tigers started at the navy line right off, going steadily through for short gains, with an occasional run around the right end. On the five-yard line the navy made its supreme effort. Three downs and the Tigers were within one yard of the cadets' goal line; there was a rush, a scrimmage, and a tangle of legs and arms.

"I wonder how many people appreciate the value and the cost of one little exhibit at your American. Museum of Natural History," speculated George Church of Chicago while chatting at the Holland House yesterday. "As a lover of the sort of thing one sees there, I spent yesterday taking in some of the beauties of that marvelous collection.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. To carry in one's hand a newly caught snake is unpleasant, because in its fright it emits an effluvium which would disgust any but ardent naturalists, and would, I venture to say, have left Tobit, had he lived among English meadows, at no loss for a means just as efficient as those he used to scare away the evil spirit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The music department of the Congressional Library is now flooded with British war songs. All music copyrighted in this, country goes to this music room, which, therefore, has the most up-to-date collection of music of any library in the world. British songs, being subject to international copyright, are included.

The man who orders buckwheat cakes for breakfast, although aware that that article of diet has seen long and faithful service, will probably be surprised to learn just how far back the cultivation of buckwheat on Manhattan Island dates.

BRISTOL, R. I., Oct. 13. -- The announcement of Sir Thomas Lipton's second challenge for the America's Cup has made this, place take on a livelier aspect than it has had for months past. The proverb about the calm before the storm is now frequently applied to the quiet here for several weeks preceding the announcement of the challenge.

ORANGE, Oct. 13. -- A match game of golf came off on the Essex County Country Club links this afternoon between the Essex County and the Princeton teams. The two team's tied last year. The Princeton team is considered one of the strongest in the State. The score was close, Essex County winning by one point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Russian suggestion that the International Court of Arbitration of The Hague have jurisdiction over divergencies of views arising on the question of Chinese indemnities was submitted to Secretary Hay by M. de Wollant, the Russian Charge d'Affaires, in a note on Oct. 3.

The Protective Association of Professional Baseball Players has drawn up a list of the demands, or requests, as the case may be, of the changes it desires in the ball player's lot. Some radical departures from existing conditions are asked for, such as Sections 1, 3, 5, and 6 of the subjoined propositions.

President Robert Ellis Jones of Hobart College delivered an address at the dinner of the Schoolmasters' Club, held last night at the St. Denis Hotel, upon "The Alleged Impracticability of the College Graduate,' during which he criticised what he termed the "parasitic luxury" and manifest tendencies toward the lavish expenditure of money on the part of American college undergraduates.

Good racing weather, a moderate, attendance, and some excellent finishes marked the final day's racing of the October meeting at the Parkway Driving Club, Brooklyn, yesterday. The special feature of the day was an exhibition by the famous pacing stallion Joe Patchen, in which the Parkway track record was lowered from 2:07 1/4 to 2:06 1/2.

THE CLOSING FETES OF THE PARIS EXPOSITION. -- As cabled to this country last Thursday, 15,000,000 tickets of admission to the grounds of the Paris Exposition remain unused. These are now being sold in the shops of Paris at 20 centimes, or 4 cents apiece. According to the latest mail advices, the daily attendance now averages 480,000 paying visitors.

The usual Saturday dullness prevailed on the curb yesterday and trading in outside stocks was extremely limited. Only three or four issues attracted any attention whatever, and the only events of any interest were further advances in several issues which for the past few days have been the most prominent in the list.

General the Marquis de Lafayette's visit to America upon invitation of Congress in 1824, his reception by the City of New York and subsequent entertainment, are vividly recalled by Mrs. Elizabeth Riker Spring, who celebrated her ninetieth birthday Oct. 8, at her home, 121 East Thirty-sixth Street, and is the sole surviving daughter of Recorder Richard.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13. -- In order as far as possible to show what the feeling is in the western part of the State one of the Bridgeport papers this week polled 156 indiscriminate voters of the city, and ascertained their leanings in the coming campaign. Out of the 156 votes McKinley received 80 votes and Bryan 70.

Deaf children as a class are generally believed to be especially cruel to their mates and to the lower animals. Prof. G. Stanley Hall suggests in a recent article that this apparent cruelty may be in part accounted for by the fact that they cannot hear the cries of pain, and hence do not really understand the amount of suffering which they are causing.

Senator HOAR has complimented Senator TILLMAN, in The North American Review, as "an honest, manly, and able statesman," and some surprise has been expressed at such an estimate from one who is frequently diametrically opposed to Mr. TILLMAN on public questions and party policies.

-- Just beneath the surface of the controversy in which the manager of the Carroll Box and Lumber Company and the Republican leader of the Twentieth Assembly District are now engaged there lies a question of much more public importance than that whether Mr. WHITAKER left the company's employ of his own accord or under compulsion.

"When the Deutschland, Oceanic, or Kaiser Wilhelm come up the bay it is a sight worth seeing," said a marine engineer, "and I don't wonder that people strain their eyes to get a better look at their great hulls. They make one proud of man's achievement, and I could spend weeks strolling through them studying the complicated machinery and mechanism that have been stowed away behind their graceful hulls.

Capt. Richard P. Leary, who as Governor of the Island of Guam, America's diminutive mid-Pacific possession, was brought prominently before the public through his unique administration of affairs on the island, arrived in this city yesterday on the American Line steamship St. Paul, after an absence of eighteen months.

The University of Pennsylvania football leads in number at points scored this season, with Tale next. Princeton has the fewest points of the "Big Four," while Harvard and Yale have yet to be scored against. West Point, also, still has a clean slate Lafayette has accumulated a goodly number of points against its opponents.

A project that at its inception a quarter of a century ago was regarded with suspicion and condemned as visionary has been consummated by the City of Newark, N.J., which is now the absolute owner of a water supply ample for all the needs of the city for half a century to come, and capable of still further enlargement at comparatively small cost.
OMAHA, Oct. 13. -- One man has found the pot of gold at the foot of the rainbow, just as the fairy tale told us it could be found.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- The Russian suggestion to submit the Chinese question to The Hague Arbitration Court is ridiculed by the press, with the exception of The Vorwaerts (Socialist), which indorses the plan and says:

Charles E. Mather, broker of precious stones, disappeared from his office, at 65 Nassau Street, last Monday, and it is charged that he had panned jewels worth about $25,000, which he had obtained recently from the firms of Alfred H. Smith Co. of 182 Broadway and Frederick W. Lewis Co. of 1 Maiden Lane.

Col. BRYAN has promised, in a recent speech, to provide a more satisfactory Commissioner of Pensions than H. CLAY EVANS if the people will give him the chance to make the appointment. Just what sort of Commissioner BRIAN has in mind to please everybody we do not intend to conjecture, but we are willing in advance to extend to him the assurances of our sympathy in his attempt to accomplish a highly undesirable object.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario, Oct. 13. -- Rapid progress is being made by the Algoma Central Company in its railway line through the untrodden wilderness of the north toward Hudson Bay.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Harvard defeated Columbia on Soldiers' Field this afternoon 24 to 0 in the first game these colleges have played since 1891. The afternoon was cloudy, a slight wind blowing from the east.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The abundance of money has not lessened, and borrowers are able to obtain funds at practically their own terms. Discounts are firm. The announcement of a further shipment of half a million in gold to-day from India was counteracted by American inquiries. Business transactions were small, operators being chary of taking bills at any price in the present uncertain condition of the market.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Oct. 13. -- Some interesting bicycle races were held this afternoon on the track of the Lynbrook Driving Association. The principal events were two and five mite handicaps. Carroll F. Hutcheson of Hempstead succeeded in winning both events, winning two very handsome diamonds. The summary is as follows:

From The Geographical Journal. Here and there in the course of the day clusters of huts broke the desolate lines of forest. They were primitive enough, these huts, encircled by stockades. The people are very poor -- sordidly poor -- eking, out their living much as the pigs do, upon, wild fruits, which they are too idle and too improvident to cultivate.

A few days ago two of the fastest trotters on the Speedway -- A. B. Gwathmey'a chestnut mare Louise Mac (2:09 1/4) and A. E. Perren's brown mare Zembia (2:11 1/4) -- met in a three-heat brush on the Speedway, and Louise Mac won two out of three heats. Yesterday these two fine animals had another three-heat tussle, and this time Zembia carried off the honors.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 13. -- A large and enthusiastic crowd greeted Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for Vice President, to-night at the Opera House in this city, where he made a speech in support of the candidates of the party represented by him.

VIENNA, Sept. 27. -- The Shah has been received by the Emperor as a royal sovereign, of equal rank. He and his suite are being entertained at the Hofburg, and a grand State dinner has been given at Schonbrunn, on which occasion the beautiful grounds were most elaborately illuminated.

Those logical foes of the dread spirit of "Imperialism" -- it demands the largest of capitals to emphasize their conception of its importance -- who predicted that our course in China would show that spirit in still worse degree than our course in the Philippines, must feel that Mr. McKINLEY and Mr. HAY and Gen. CHAFFEE and the Administration generally are very disappointing.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Pennsylvania defeated Brown by the score of only 12 to 0 at Franklin Field this afternoon, due to the splendid defense of the Providence collegians. The Red and Blue many times had the ball near the Brown goal, but after the first two scores were made could not carry it over, so strong, so stubborn was the resistance offered by Brown.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- In spite of gloomy forebodings, the theatrical season has profited rather than otherwise during the election weeks. Comedy prevails to the utter exclusion of classic productions, except "Julius Caesar" at Her Majesty's. The popularity of the light order of things may, perhaps, be ascribed to the general want of an antithesis after months of mourning over the war casualty lists.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- Trading to-day was dull. In all only 700 shares of Sugar sold in Boston to-day, but at that it was the most active stock. The selling of Montana from New York continued, and the stock is scarce, with offers to borrow it flat reported. The price eased 1, to 322, a net loss of 2 for the week.

NORTHPORT, L. I., Oct. 13. -- Thomas B. Faherty, manager of the branch office of the American Express Company at this place, has not been in the office since Monday last, and his friends and business associates are anxious to learn his where-abouts.

"People wonder," says the proprietor of the up-to-date second-hand book shop, "where we get all the late navels practically new which we can sell at low prices. Where is, no secret about it; it is a result of the great influx of popular novels.

John R. Dos Passos, the lawyer, has prepared a reply to the charges of anti-imperialists against the Administration of Mr. McKinley in its conduct of affairs in the Philippines, selecting Carl Schurz as a typical spokesman of the faction.

Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-foot sloop Rainbow has been disqualified by the Regatta Committees of the New York and Atlantic Yacht Clubs as the result of Mr. Vanderbilt's letter of Oct. 5 declining the prizes won by his yacht.

Ex-Senator David B. Hill addressed a Democratic mass meeting in St. Mary's Hall, in Hoboken, last evening. Preliminary speeches were made by Corporation Attorney James F. Minturn and Allan L., McDermott, the Democratic candidate for Congress in the Seventh District. Controller Bird S. Coler followed Mr. Hill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to protest against the spirit of the editorial which appeared in yesterday's TIMES, entitled "China and the Missionaries." Its bitter criticism of the missionaries in China surely is not justified by the action of the Peking missionaries in joining in what you call "the very large order that the American missionaries in China have given to their own Government."

TIEN-TSIN, Sept. 7. -- Lured by the prospect of rich bargains and loot, large numbers of buyers are reaching Peking and Tien-Tsin from Shanghai and other cities in the south. Most of them are acting under cable instructions from dealers in America and Europe, the most exaggerated reports having been spread of the value of the plunder taken in the sacking of these two North of China cities.

CREEDMOOR, Oct. 13, 1900. -- The regular supplementary practice of the season was held here to-day for the marksmen and sharpshooter classes. The weather was cloudy and damp. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Col. N. B. Thurston, Ordnance Officer, N. G. N. Y.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of Oct. 4 on the general Philippine situation is a most conservative and masterly argument in favor of the course of the present Administration.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. Most of the dwellers in our own old village were simple "cottiers," holding an acre or half acre, for which they paid rent in kind or in service to the lord of the manor. These payments vary infinitely in afferent manors, but in no case were the demands unreasonable or excessive.
From The London Express. Time, we all know, is precious -- even to the convicted felon in Dartmoor.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 13. -- Crop experts have made estimates on the wheat crop of 1900, running all the way from 100,000,000 bushels to a third more than that. Newspapers of the Northwest have carefully refrained from giving much publicity to the lower estimates, and have in many cases ridiculed them.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 13. -- Chancellor Magie granted a temporary injunction this morning restraining August Belmont, John N. Cadwalader, ana Alvin W. Keech of New York, T. Jefferson Coolidge of Boston, and William F. Harrity of Philadelphia from voting on their stock at the annual meeting of the Distilling Company of America, which will take place on Wednesday.

The following conclusions have been reached after reading a few newspapers which have come under my notice in this and other countries during the past few months:

From The London Chronicle. It was his long finger nail that stuck in me first -- figuratively speaking, I mean. It curved inward across the palm of his hand, and was showing an inclination to go around the wrist in time.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13. -- Louisville to-night save Gov. Roosevelt an enthusiastic reception, the programme concluding with the crowded meeting at the Auditorium. This was in marked contrast to the greeting offered at Elizabethtown, the last stop before the special reached this city.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 63 3/4@64. There were no sales.
To the Editor of The New York Times: 1. If the currency question is paramount, may I ask what section of the United States Constitution gives Congress the power to debase the coinage?

If a man were to stand in front of the Dewey Arch and shout: "Hurrah for Woolley, and Metcalfel" few people who heard him would be able to tell who the men were for whom he was cheering. Nine out of ten Democratic and Republican politicians around the Fifth Avenue Hotel and Hoffman House would be as much mystified as the ordinary citizen who takes no active part in politics.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Yale defeated Dartmouth 17 to 0 this afternoon, at Newton Centre, in a hard-fought contest. The game was witnessed by nearly 4,000 persons. Dartmouth played a pretty game, and contested every point. The Hanover men were by far the lighter team, and Yale was able to leap through their line time and again.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- A trustworthy cable dispatch from Shanghai says Gen. Liu, the chief of the " Black Flags," has left Canton at the head of a considerable force; that he will traverse the Province of Hu-Nan, try to cross the Yang-tse at Oua, and then, traversing the Province of Ho-Nan, join the Empress at Sian-Foo, capital of the Province of Shen-Si, for the purpose of acting as her bodyguard.
BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- This is Thomas W. Lawson's unique method of presenting to a local charity the winnings of his trotter Boralma at Louisville two weeks ago: ...

From The London Express. During the next debating society season one question is bound to be popular: "What is the most remarkable feature of the closing century?" And the best answer to the inquiry will be this: "The victory of the English language over its Continental rivals."

Richard Croker and ex-Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., have taken charge of the Democratic State campaign. David B. Hill's friends have been crowded to the wall. The few powers which are now left to Mayor James K. McGuire, as Chairman of the Democratic Campaign Committee, are gradually being taken away.
OTTAWA, Oct. 12. -- Lord Minto, Canada's Governor General, and Lady Minto, recently paid a visit to the Mormon settlement in Southern Alberta.

On Friday, Aug. 31, 1900, the Sultan of Turkey commenced the twenty-fifth year of his reign. In many respects his rule has been marked by great advances in civilization and education, while in other ways it can be criticised in severe terms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So much loose talk about trusts, especially by lawyers of acknowledged learning in the law, has a tendency to confuse even the more intelligent voters and actually deceive the general public into the impression, and in some cases into the belief, that "trusts" are pirates and brigands, subject to no law, and limited in their operations only by their opportunities.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The French newspapers are highly indignant with the Turkish press, which is doing its utmost -- for political reasons, of course -- to represent the Shah as a potentate greatly inferior to the Sultan in dignity. It even invents the statement that the Shah kissed the Sultan's hand in token of obedience, and addressed him by the title "Caliph."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The attention of the public has been called to the wide spread of consumption, which is prevailing not only in the city, but throughout the entire world, and the interest shown by the public writers is the best indication that the time has arrived when the hygienic question can be freely discussed by the physician without running the risk of adverse criticism.

John Hanley of 50 Jordan Avenue, Jersey City, committed suicide with poison yesterday on the grave of his first wife in the Holy Name Cemetery on West Side Avenue, where he was found at 6 o'clock in the morning.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 13. -- The barge Edith Howes, towed from this port by the tug Abram Minis, loaded with 380,000 feet of yellow pine lumber, has gone to pieces, and the entire cargo of lumber is floating in the ocean near Fryingpan Shoals. The lumber is strewn for a distance of ten miles along the beach near where the bargre was lost.

From The London Chronicle. After nearly 20,000 miles in Russia -- hot and cold, river and mountain, wheat field and gotten field, desert and steppe, empty country and crowded town -- what is the upshot of it all, what are the dominant impressions left upon one's mind?

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- Great Britain's attitude in the Boer war came up for lively discussion at the Peace Congress which is in progress this week in Paris. The Congress had scarcely convened before the English representatives introduced a resolution bitterly denouncing their home Government for its war on the Transvaal.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Oct. 13. -- Judge Jay A. Hubbell, Circuit Judge or the Twelfth Judicial Circuit of Michigan, and who was chairman of the National Republican Congressional campaign committee in the Garfield campaign and for five terms Congressman from this district, died to-day, aged 71.

From The London Express. In certain parts of Australia cannibal trees flourish -- trees which can hold a man's body in the centre, and devour it as readily as our insectivorous wild flowers trap the insects on which they partly subsist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Blackmailing American firms by stealing their trade marks and holding them for a price has become a lucrative business in certain European countries, particularly Germany, where there are people who make a regular business of registering trade marks used by American firms for the purpose of subsequently blackmailing the victims.

From The London Chronicle. It was in August, 1875, that Capt. Matthew Webb performed his memorable feat of swimming the English Channel from shore to shore, and in the quarter of a century that has elapsed, though, a good many attempts have been made at this record, it has never been equaled.

From The London Express. Every election produces its crop of amusing yarns, and that of 1895, the last general election held in Great Britain and Ireland, was no exception to this merry rule. Here are a few carefully selected episodes, showing the funny side of the contest:
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 13. -- State Detective Edward B. Kelly was in Newark this afternoon. He said he was on the trail of Schreiber and that he expected to arrest him in the course of a day or two.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the editorial in your issue of the 10th inst. on "China and the Missionaries."

The woman who buys her patent leather slippers with red heels can, if she intends, to be a continuous symphony in red, buy her boots with uppers of bright red cloth. These, with brass buttons, are military in appearance and carry out the effect of the other parts of her gold braid trimmed frocks and jackets.

President Max Danziger of the New York Plate Glass Insurance Company returned from Chicago last night, where he has been attending a meeting of the Presidents of plate glass insurance companies doing business in that city, called for the purpose of securing higher rates.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
