From Longman's. The history of monarchy presents one illustration, among many, of the dangers of political prophecy. "I think it impossible," said Rousseau about 150 years ago, "that the great monarchies of Europe have still long to last"; an opinion that was very confidently held by many thinkers in the revolutionary age in the throes of which the eighteenth century ended.

ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 13. -- Because the object of his affections refused any longer to accept his attentions, William Boole, a young man of East Orange, cut his throat in the young woman's presence last Wednesday night. The weapon used was a penknife, but to the fact the blade was unusually dull the lovesick youth owes his life.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 13. -- There was a thirty-six-hole handicap on the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club, at Noroton, this afternoon, for prizes offered by Mrs. John T. Williams. The leading sixteen scores were:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The battleship Wisconsin, which had her initial trip on Thursday last, probably will not be complete and ready for commission before Dec. 15.

AKRON, Ohio, 13. -- A memorable day in the Bryan campaign in Ohio closed here to-night with a monster meeting, but, large as it was, it fell considerably behind the meeting at Mansfield, which was the most important stopping place before reaching this place.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Cornell defeated the eleven from Washington and Jefferson this afternoon by the score of 16 to 5. Washington and Jefferson played a fast, plucky game from start to finish and made the Ithacans work hard for every gain, but they were outclassed at almost every point.

From The Contemporary Review. Volleys require control: control means men kept together. Now I have shot big game in America and in the Himalayas, and consequently appreciate the difficulty of shooting straight when excited or tired with an ardous climb, even though I selected my own instant for pressing the trigger.

A determined effort is being made by the residents of Inwood, Marble Hill, and King's Bridge to have Broadway from Dyckman Street to King's Bridge either macadamized or asphalted. They say that this improvement is absolutely necessary, as this is the only road leading to the west end of Manhattan Island, and in its present condition it is almost impassable, it being little more than a mud hole.

An autopsy performed yesterday oil the body of George Reimherr, who died in the insane pavilion of Bellevue Hospital on Wednesday, showed that the man's insanity had been caused by two revolver bullets which were lodged in his head. Reimherr, who was sixty-five years old and lived in poverty at 34S Rodney Street, Brooklyn, was once a wealthy furniture manufacturer.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The cadets defeated Trinity by a score of 28 to 0 on the parade grounds this afternoon. The soldiers were winners from the start, and on this account Trinity lost heart early in the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has now become a question among Americans why Japan has approved the German proposition, which demands the surrender of the ringleaders of the Boxers' trouble to the powers.

Copyright, 1900. LONDON, Oct. 13. -- At last our general election is about over. It will be the end of the month before the new House of Commons is finally complete, because the Orkney and Shetland Islands do not express their mind and will until the 26th inst.

About a year ago an English writer for The North American Review interested a great many readers of that magazine with an account of "The Decline of British Commerce." After a very liberal interval another Englishman has made reply to what was a rather gloomy outlook for British trade.

From The Fortnightly Review. The Irish countryman certainly believes that a spiritual nee lives all about him, having horses and cattle, and living much the same life that he does, and that this race snatches out of our life whatever horse or cow or man or woman it sets its heart on; and this belief, harmonized with Christianity by certain ingenious doctrines, lives side by side with Christianity, and has its own priesthood.

The people who go to the theatres frequently were not startled or stimulated by any epoch-making expositions of dramatic art in the new plays of last week. But there was some good acting. Mrs. Le Moyne in "The Greatest Thing in the World," at Wallack's, contributed one of the most polished and interesting new portrayals of the week in a play that was by no means the best of the lot.

In a splendid race, run in time that established a new world's record for the distance, one mile and three-quarters, Perry Belmont's great colt Ethelbert, at Morris Park yesterday, won the Municipal Handicap, and retrieved his reputation as champion of the turf. The race made a magnificent spectacle, and one of the largest crowds of the Fall meeting cheered the victory and felt repaid by the contest for the journey to the big Westchester course.

From The Spectator. The Indo-Chinese are not soldiers, and as a rule have not the soldierly instincts, but the Burmese "dacoits," that is, "klephts," half patriots, half brigands, who so grievously worried us during the first four years of the conquest, constantly died like heroes, while the Roman Catholic converts of Annam accepted martyrdom in thousands with the tranquil constancy of the early Christians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Division of Customs and Insular Affairs of the War Department made public to-day a bulletin upon the trade of the Philippine Islands. The statement covers a period of nine months ending March 31, 1900, and sets forth that during that time merchandise to the value of $15,102,879 was imported into the Philippines, and goods to the value of $12,928,464 went out of the islands to foreign ports.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, addressed a crowded meeting in Plattsburg Theatre here to-night. The Chairman of the meeting was Thomas F. Conway of this village, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, who introduced Mr. Stanchfield.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The mental attitude of many of the independents in the social, political, and religious life of our country is apt to recall forcibly to mind a story current in Scotch clerical circles. On one occasion several elderly members of the clerical profession in Scotland were gathered together to examine candidates for ordination.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Everything did not pass off with absolute smoothness in the deliberations of the feminist Congress, which have just been brought to an end. Two parties were represented -- one Republican, and Dreyfusard, composed of Mme. Severine, Mme. Pognon, Mme. Marguerite Durand, and all the staff of the feminist paper, La Fronde, the other violently Nationalist, with Mme. Venerre and Mme. Morissot at its head.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 13 -- At the opening of the polo play at the Georgian Court grounds between the Philadelphia Freebooters and Lakewood to-day, the few spectators who braved a steadily falling rain looked out upon a discomforting melee of men and ponies, flying clods of turf, and an ensemble which seemed far from real sport.

All party nominations made in this city of candidates to be voted for at the election on Tuesday, Nov. 6, have been filed with the Bureau of Elections. The time for the filing of party nominations expired at midnight on Friday. The nominations by the Republican and Democratic organizations as filed in the office of the Bureau of Elections are as follows:

Naval officers had not ceased to praise the excellence of construction of the cruiser San Francisco before their admiration was challenged by the production of the Oregon battleship, completed just in time to win great popularity and solid reputation for her builders by her altogether wonderful trip from the Pacific to the Atlantic to recruit the North Atlantic Squadron during the war with Spain.

From The Detroit (Mich.) Free Press, (Anti-Bryan Dem.) It is hardly worth while to discuss the mental processes by which the Hon. Daniel J. Campau reaches the conclusion that the State of Michigan will be carried for Mr. Bryan. It is sufficient to know that he has reached such a conclusion, and is courageous enough to place his signature upon the completed whole.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Bernard Nicholls, the Boston professional who achieved the distinction in Florida last Winter of defeating Harry Vardon, to-day duplicated the feat on the Brae Burn course in Newton. The winner's victory in this thirty-six-hole match was by 1 up. A very large gallery was in attendance and the exhibition was probably the best ever given in this vicinity.

A new fire headquarters has been established in the Borough of the Bronx entirely Separate and distinct from fire headquarters in East Sixty-seventh Street. Advocates of home rule say that this is one more step toward making the Bronx a city, dependent in no way upon Manhattan Island, and they highly commend Fire Chief Croker, who has not only greatly improved the service, but who has given the cause a lift in the right direction.

From Pearson's. It is an established fact that the United States now holds the record for rapid development of fruit industries, such as the growing of oranges and lemons, peaches, and grapes. As a Nation we eat more fruit than any other and grow considerably more than we eat. Eighty millions of dollars a year is the figure for strawberries alone.

From The Cornhill. If we consider for a moment the dally movements of migrating mackerel, traversing in dense shoals and at great speed many miles of tidal water, we shall see the impossibility, save under exceptionally auspicious circumstances, of the travelers waiting to pick up odd launce or "brit," which, as all fishermen know, they will, at the right season, take as bait.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Baron Speck von Sternburg, the German Charge d'Affaires, will sail next Tuesday on the steamer Deutschland for Germany, whence he goes to his new post as Consul General at Calcutta, one of the four important stations of the German foreign service, combining both diplomatic and Consular functions.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The only returns received to-night in the Parliamentary general election are those from Crewe and Inverness-shire. Both show Liberal gains. The Ministerialists have thus far elected 398 of their candidates, while the Opposition have elected 258.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The political situation in Illinois bears a striking resemblance to the old Illinois fence which Lincoln described as being so crooked that every time the hogs went through it they came out on the same side from which they started.

The sale of Newton Bennington's stout and consistent colt Bellario to Senator P. H. McCarren, for Richard Croker, said to have been made on Saturday, was followed promptly by the report that Bellario is to be sent to England, and that Beau Gallant and King Bramble, also bought for Mr. Croker, are to go with him.

Copyright, 1900, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Could you not oblige us by diverting your demands for gold upon the Bank of France? That powerful institution has within the last twelve months added nearly u155,000,000 to its stock and now holds nearly u915,000,000. Surely it might let u10,000,000 of this out without raising the discount rate in France higher than it is here now.

Mr. Bryan will arrive at the Grand Central Station at 2:45 o'clock to-morrow afternoon and will be met by a Reception Committee composed of Mayor Van Wyck, Richard Croker, William R. Hearst, Randolph Guggenheimer, C.C. Hughes, Antonio Zucca, William F. Grell, Dr. J.H. Girdner, William Hoge, Lewis Nixon, Hugh McLaughlin, Nicholas Muller, James Shevlin, Cord Meyer, J.H. Sutphen, J.J. Coogan, F. Bowley, L.F. Haffen, and Julius Newman.

Politicians in this city devoted much of their time yesterday to a study of the registration figures. The returns show that the registration for the first two days of this year in Manhattan, the Bronx, and Brooklyn is over 43,000 in excess of the registration for the first two days of 1896.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tusday:

Wall Street is less fearful of tight money than it was a week ago. Gold is coming not alone from Alaska and Australia, but from Europe; pension payments by the Government will for the next few weeks be on a fairly extensive scale; while the bank statement of Saturday showed a much better condition of the banks than generally had been expected.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Last week the Boerse had a severe setback, which wiped out the advance made the week before. There were numerous factors exerting unfavorable influences upon speculation. The Chinese situation was considered unfavorable. The rise in New York exchange and the unsatisfactory reports of the condition of the iron and coal trades depressed values generally.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 14. -- In response to a request for a statement as to his views on the answer of the United Mine Workers to the operators' proposition, L.H. Watkins, President of the Temple Iron Company, which company is largely interested in coal mining, to-night gave out a statement in which he says, in part:

"As in 1896, this has been eminently a business men's campaign," remarked Cornelius N. Bliss, ex-Secretary of the Interior and Treasurer of the Republican National Committee, to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

Seventy-five American District Telegraph messenger boys and six men formed in line in front of the Knickerbocker Theatre early yesterday morning in order to be on hand at 9 o'clock this morning when the sale of seats begins for the appearance of Maude Adams next Monday night in Rostand's play, "L'Aiglon."

There is a strong movement among business men to promote the election of Gen. JAMES R. O'BEIRNE for Congress in the Seventh District. It ought to be successful, and the General ought to be sent to Washington rather than the Democratic candidate, Mr. NICHOLAS MULLER.

The bowling season has begun in real earnest, and is every alley in the city the roll of the balls and the crash of the falling pins is to be heard on six nights out of the seven in every week. A half dozen of the principal tournaments are already under way, and as many more clubs are arranging schedules and making other preparations for an early start.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- At Longchamps to-day the American jockeys made a good showing. The Prix St. Cyr, 5,000f., over a course of 2,500 meters, was won by M.E. Veil-Pieard's Quartier Latin, ridden by "Willie" Sims. Kiss, also owned by M. Veil-Plcard, and ridden by "Patsy" Freeman, was second.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Chicago gamblers have erected a large building just south of Richton, on the main line of the Illinois Central Railroad, and on Nov. 7 a gambling enterprise which will be a veritable Monte Carlo will be opened.

The rainfall in the past forty-eight hours in New York has been the heaviest known in some time. The precipitation from 8 o'clock Saturday morning until 7 o'clock last evening was 2.14 inches. On last Monday there was a precipitation of 1.15 inches, and on Tuesday .62 inch. This makes the total rainfall for the week 3.91 inches.

Sergt. Fitzpatrick of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station was probably the most astonished man in Harlem yesterday morning when he saw Policeman Smith drive up to the station house with a twelve-foot yawl boat in a big double truck.

From The Rochester Evening Times. Nelson O. Tiffany spoke in Buffalo last week before the Buffalo Society of Natural Sciences on the subject of pound nets. Mr. Tiffany denounced the granting of permits to set pound nets in the waters of the great lakes. He said the nets would destroy the fishing to the detriment of every one, poor fishermen especially.

PEKING, Sept. 7. -- Prince Ching, who visited the foreign Ministers yesterday, did not receive that cordial reception he seemed to expect. At the British Legation, the first one he visited, the demeanor of Sir Claude M. MacDonald was chilly in the extreme, and the visit occupied no longer than five minutes.
An incident that marred the usual placidity of Grace Church occurred just before the 11 o'clock service yesterday morning.
There were three destructive fires in the Wllliamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning, causing much damage to property, injury to firemen, and the death of several horses.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- Mr. Bryan spent the day very quietly. He was the guest of Judge Grant, and aside from going out to church in the forenoon he remained indoors all day. He attended the West Congregational Church and heard a sermon preached by the Rev. J.L. Davis.

The Rev. Albert B. Simpson, President of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, yesterday preached his annual missionary sermon at the Gospel Tabernacle, in Eighth Avenue, near Forty-fourth Street, and as a result over $50,000 in cash, pledges, and property was realized for the support of the missions and work of the alliance for 1901.

TIEN-TSIN, China, Sept. 17. -- With the general belief that this city is to be the military centre and base for the Winter, all the powers are now engaged in a general scramble for buildings. Anything that has a roof is now valuable, and every building in the foreign concession which the bombardment left worth repairing is being put in shape for either barracks or Storerooms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Carroll D. Wright, Commissioner of Labor, has issued a bulletin giving a summary of data in a previous publication on "Trusts and Industrial Combinations," showing the rate of wages in various occupations for a period extending back in most cases from the present year to 1891.

Factory Inspector John Williams, who has been accused from time, to time by delegates to the Central Federated Union of failing to enforce the labor laws, was formally accused before that body yesterday on these charges. Before he appeared a letter was read from him stating that he would be on hand to answer the charges, and while it was toeing read he came into the hall, accompanied by Deputy Factory Inspector Ashe.

Secretary Gage has prepared a statement in which he reviews the National banking system of the United States, with the object, as he says, of dispelling some very prevalent financial misconceptions. The popular belief that the National Bank act was conceived by the banks and for the banks, he says, is erroneous and very much to be deprecated.

St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Eighty-third Street and Twenty-first Avenue, Bensonhurat, which was completed on Saturday, was dedicated yesterday by one of the happiest congregations ever assembled, and congratulations were showered upon its pastor, the Rev. H.E.H. Benedict, for his activity in getting a congregation together and collecting funds for a permanent place of worship.

The search for William Schrelber, the missing Elizabethport bank clerk, was kept up yesterday, but the detectives apparently obtained no new clue, and seemed as far as ever from finding him. Detective Dougherty of the Pinkerton Agency was in New Jersey yesterday conferring with the local detectives.

With pistol, rope, and gas Henry Wilkens, a saloon keeper at 104 Nassau Street, set about ending his life yesterday afternoon. The pistol shot killed him. Wilkens made the most elaborate preparations for death. He was thirty-nine years of age, and for fourteen years had been conducting a prosperous liquor business at the address given, which is at Nassau and Ann Streets.

About a week ago, after he had rested a Sunday at his birthplace in Illinois, Col. W.J. BRYAN made a speech to his old friends and neighbors. Some altogether creditable and kindly feelings, perhaps, or possibly a mere dramatic impulse, moved him to refer with veneration to his parents and to the precepts he had received at Salem and which he had tried to follow.

They were talking about the value of secret society membership in business at a mid-day luncheon the other day. Masonry, Odd Fellowship, Knights of Pythias, Royal Arcanum, B'nal B'rith, and even the Tammany Society had been touched upon, as well as college fraternities and graduate associations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- From ocean to ocean and from the great lakes to the Gulf, in every city, town, and village of the country, it is planned to hold Democratic meetings Oct. 27, which will be addressed by the ablest speakers that the scope of the gigantic plan will permit.

August Belmont, owner of the seventy-footer Mineola, which finished second to Cornelius Vanderbilt's Rainbow in each of the races won during the past season by the latter yacht, will decline the prizes lost to Rainbow through her disqualification by the New York and Atlantic Yacht Clubs.

PEARSON, Ga., Oct. 14. -- Mayor Henry Corbett to-day attempted suicide under sensational circumstances. His wife alone was the cause of his failure. He isolated himself in a distant part of the house and fired two shots at himself. So nervous was be that his hand swerved and both bullets missed him.

There were many fast steppers on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, but the course had not dried out thoroughly, and the drivers did not brush as frequently as is their wont. Dr. H.D. Gill was prominent in the speed bouts with the fleet gelding Rockdale Boy. Rockdale Boy has not been on the Speedway long, but he has kept them all guessing since his advent there.

When the Columbia football Squad lined up for the daily practice game on South Field yesterday afternoon spectators had hard work to tell which was the 'Varsity and which the scrub, or "college," team. The 'Varsity backs had been fitted to the usual scrub line, while scrub backs carried the ball for the 'Varsity forwards.

Further strength developed in the stock market yesterday, and the advance in prices begun in the latter part of last week progressed. The buying, as has lately been the case, was largely professional, but it was apparent that the sustained higher figures were proving a temptation too hard for some few, at least, of the outside public to resist.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 15. -- Committees of United Mine Workers have been calling on miners this afternoon and evening to warn them not to pay attention to petitions being circulated by agents of several coal-carrying companies asking miners to return to work pending a settlement between the operators, coal-carrying companies and miners.

The irritation ascribed, in a press dispatch which has every mark of "semi-official" sanction, to the British Government concerning the negotiations with China, is highly intelligible and perfectly excusable. We do not make out, however, why our own Government should be classed among the offenders.

Thomas B. Musgrave, the Union League Club member and ex-banker, the story of whose confinement in a West Thirty-ninth Street sanitarium has been told, was released yesterday by Justice Freedman in the Supreme Court after a most dramatic hearing.
HAVANA, Oct. 15. -- Gen. Wood will sail for the United States to-morrow by the Ward liner Yucatan, returning via Tampa Oct. 25.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 15. -- Senator Hanna accompanied by Senator Frye began his speechmaking tour of the Northwest today by making six addresses in Wisconsin, two of them of some length. The principal addresses of the day were made at Waukesha, Wis., where the special train carrying Senators Hanna and Frye and other Repulican leaders was held for over an hour, and at Madison.

Robinson -- Falconer. The wedding of Alonzo Clark Robinson, son of James Almore Robinson, and Miss Elisabeth de Haas Falconer, elder daughter of William H. Falconer, was celebrated yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock at the residence of the bride's parents, 8 East Sixty-second Street.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 15. -- Maude Adams appeared at the Academy of Music in this city to-night in Rostand's drama, "L'Aiglon." The play is in five acts, and the production one of great magnitude, each act requiring a heavy scenic set, with a remarkable measure of detail as to properties and effects. The costuming is also rich.

We have received from the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Anti-Imperialist Clubs a request to consent to have our name proposed as an "honorary member" of that association. We have no inclination to board that galley, and we cannot pretend to be especially gratified at the invitation.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 15. -- George V. Hankins is one of the most famous green-cloth speculators in the West. At one time he was noted as the king gambler of Chicago. His old "Dinner Pall " gambling house, at 134 Clarke Street, was one of the finest equipped establishments in the country. From 1890 to 1892 he made thousands of dollars in this resort.

Golf is and will be the story or the week in the social world. If the day be fair there will be a notable gathering this morning on the beautiful course of the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N. J., when the first round in the annual Autumn women's golf championship tournament will be played.
W.G. Oswald has resigned as Cleveland agent of the Northwestern National Insurance Company.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Bernard Katz of Katz Brothers, the brewers of this city, announced this afternoon that the Rogers Locomotive Works had been sold by Jacob Rogers to a syndicate of New York capitalists and a number of Paterson's most wealthy residents. The papers, he says, were signed in New York this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The American share of the loot at Tien-Tsin is larger than at first reported. It has been understood that all the Americans took after the capture of Tien-Tsin was gold amounting in value to $278,000. This report arose from the fact that Li-Hung-Chang asked Gen. Chaffee to restore that sum to the Chinese Government.

-- A correspondent of The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier expressed disapproval of a recent lynching in Alabama, on the grounds the burning alive of criminals has a demoralizing influence on the communities permitting or participating in such acts, and excites harsh criticism elsewhere.

Although Mrs. Effle S. Hankins keeps a boarding house at 218 West Forty-sixth Street, she filed yesterday a bankruptcy petition that placed her liabilities at $598,118.49. Nominal assets, amounting to $823 worth of mortgaged furniture, were given in the schedules.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62 3/4@63 3/4. There were no sales.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 15. -- Raymond C. Bowman, aged fourteen years, son of Charles A. Bowman, a prominent and retired hardware dealer of this city, died at Bradford, N.Y., early this morning from internal hemorrhages, caused by the accidental discharge of a 22-calibre revolver, which he was examining.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 15. -- In a polo game which showed dash and good hitting, plenty of goal scoring, and hard work all through, sometimes at the expense of alignment and formation, Somerset County defeated Great Neck by 13 3/4 to 5 in the first game of the Ocean County Cup series today.

If some one should ask Mr. BRYAN in the course of his speech to-night what would become of the bondholders if his free-silver theories should be enacted into law, he would probably reply that the bondholders, as the leading spirits in the great money trust, have too long bent the back of labor under the cruel weight of their cross of gold.

It was stated at the National City Bank yesterday that that institution has engaged, $2,500,000 in gold in South Africa, it being said that this shipment, which may arrive here within fifteen days, is the first made from the Transvaal district for thirteen months.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The cash drawer in the office of the Newark Athletic Clubhouse, at Clinton and Beaver Streets, was robbed of $500 some time on Sunday night. Arthur E. Wickes, the cashier, has been placed under arrest. He was not locked up, however, being allowed to remain to assist an expert who is examining the accounts.

Upon the whole, it was a very enjoyable performance of "Aida" that was given at the Opera House last evening. One does not go to this opera to see stars, nor even to hear them sing together, or if he does he is commonly doomed to disappointment. Fairly negotiable principals, and a good ensemble, is all that can properly be expected, and this is without doubt achieved in this presentation.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 15. -- There was no conference to-day of operators at the Temple Iron Company's office, as expected, or if there was one the operators declare they know nothing of it. Mr. Watkins, President of the Temple Iron Company, declared that no conference had taken place, and that none was to take place.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The 'Varsity practice this afternoon was short and fierce, but one half being played and the 'Varsity smashing through for two touch-downs, against some very fast play on the part of the second eleven. It took four minutes to get the first touch-down and fifteen to get the second one, and better football has not been seen before on Yale Field this year.

The bazaar for the benefit of the homeless orphans of Galveston, organized by William R. Hearst, was opened last night in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles. There Was a large attendance of well-known persons, including officers of the army and navy who are stationed in or about New York.

The new four-act play by Joseph I.C. Clarke, called "Her Majesty," produced at the Manhattan Theatre last night, in spite of its strong reminders of other recent plays -- "The Prisoner of Zenda," "The Little Minister," "A Royal Family," and even "The Conquerors " -- seems to have originality and vitality enough to fill several profitable weeks in town, and to last through the season on the road.

Mr. Bryan will open his New York campaign to-day. He will dine with Richard Croker and twenty-four other Democrats at the Hoffman House, will make four speeches, eat a late supper as a guest of the Democratic State Committee, and after sleeping in the Hoffman House, will start up through the State on a special train at 9 A.M., to-morrow morning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A special handicap match to-day on the links of the New Brunswick Golf Club for loving cups was won by Irving Howell, with a net score of 83. His handicap was 19 and his gross score 102. The ladies' handicap resulted in a tie between Miss Mignon Shannon and Mrs. John P. Street.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- W.J. Bryan spoke twice here to-day. The longer speech was at the Opera House, at which place the majority of the audience consisted of women. To them, after some general remarks, the candidate addressed himself, saying:

NEWPORT, Oct. 15. -- It was announced to-day that Alfred G. Vanderbilt had rented for next season Chastellux, the charming Summer residence of Lorillard Spencer, on Chastellux Avenue. This means that Chastellux will be the scene of much gayety next Summer, the first season which Mr. Vanderbilt and his bride, who is at present Miss Elsie French, will pass here after their marriage.

The unexpected, always in evidence in horse racing, had an unusual prominence in the sport at Morris Park yesterday. On this occasion the unexpected consisted in the best horses winning straight through on the flat, in spite of the fact that a very heavy track prepared the crowd for surprises and reverses of form.

New York City is facing a budget of $100,000,000 for the expenses of government in 1901. A hundred-million-dollar budget has been a bugaboo to Mayor Van Wyck ever since he took office, and many are the ways and means employed by city officials to keep it from soaring to that mark.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The new Symphony Hall, at Massachusetts and Huntington Avenues, was opened to-night with a special concert, preceding the regular Winter series of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The musical programme consisted of a chorale by Bach and Beethoven's Solemn Mass in D.
Mark Twain returned to America yesterday on the Atlantic Transport Line steamship Minnehaha.
HONGKONG, Oct. 15. -- Sun-Yat-Sen, according to reports from Canton, has taken the town of Kiu-Shan, on East River, and is now investing the prefectoral city of Hui-Chou.

BRYN MAWR, Penn., Oct. 15.--A picturesque entertainment was given at Bryn Mawr College on Friday evening, in the shape of an Italian carnival procession. The members of the junior class were the hosts, the freshmen the guests, and the rest of the college community onlookers. It was a dark night, the better setting forth the gayeties of the fete.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- Miss Hunnewell, the Longwood Club tennis champion, won the ladies' singles at the Longwood tournament to-day, defeating Miss McAter, the National champion, 2 -- 6, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2. The match closed the woman's branch of the tournament. Miss McAter had the match virtually in her hands, standing with the score two sets to one and five games to two in the fourth.

COVENGTON, Ky., Oct. 15. -- Gov. Roosevelt closed his campaign in Kentucky tonight by addressing one of the largest crowds that ever assembled in this city, to listen to a candidate for public office. Long before the Governor's arrival here Court House Square, in which the speaker's stand, had been erected, was congested with men and women anxious to hear him.

Bids for $4,500,000 of New York City bonds were opened yesterday in the office of Controller Coler. A crowd of Wall Street men gathered to hear the bids read, and there was great interest taken in the sale by city officials because of the coming election.

Reflecting the improved conditions on the Stock Exchange, the market for outside securities yesterday displayed much strength and the day's trading attracted more attention than had been given to curb transactions in some time. Not only were many advances recorded, some of which were large, but a number of stock showed activity beyond recent averages.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day granted a rule directing the Distilling Company of America to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed and why the annual meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, should not be indefinitely postponed. The rule is returnable at 4 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.

The statement that the Secretary of the Treasury makes in regard to the present position of the National banks and their relation to the currency and the credit of the country is a perfectly sound one. It ought to have some weight with the thoughtless class who are prejudiced against the banks by the appeals of demagogues, and whose prejudice springs from lack of information.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 15. -- Theodore Marburg, the well-Known tobacco manufacturer and ardent Republican, whose extensive works are now in the American Tobacco Company or Trust, made a political speech to the McKinley Commercial Travelers' Club of Baltimore to-day, in the course of which he said:

The police and residents of Larchmont and New Rochelle are up in arms and the villages have been placarded with reward notices offering money for information lending to the arrest of an Unknown misereant who for the past three weeks has succeeded in killing a dozen or more valuable thoroughbred dogs.

PERSONAL INJURY DECISION. -- Conrad Wolf, while unloading his truck on March 25, 1895, on Spruce Street, near the corner of Nassau Street, was struck on the head and seriously injured by a brick which fell from the American Tract Society Building, then in process of construction.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Oct. 15.--The yacht Myrtle, from this port, capsized early yesterday evening off Great Beds Light, at the head of Raritan Bay. Four men were thrown into the water. They were Charles Hughes, the owner of the yacht; Ira Coddington, Conrad Vogtman, and a Swede, whose name is not known.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Mr. Bryan made a speech here to-day during a five minute stop. Canton was on the itinerary only conditionally, and when Mr. Bryan was told that he could have a brief stop here if he so desired, he replied that whether he should speak or not must depend upon whether there was any crowd at the station.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Though a million and a half was drawn off the market in connection with calls for Exchequer bonds, County Council stock, and various dividends, it had no appreciable effect on the price of short loans. Discounts were easier, owing to the character of the New York banks' statement and the diversion of a portion of America's demand fop gold to the Bank of France.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Mr. Chamberlain having served the purpose of the Unionists in securing a big majority in the Parliamentary General Election, which is admitted on all sides to be chiefly due to him, there seems a disposition on their part, manifested in the Unionist press, to put a stop to the Colonial Secretary's further ambitions.
The first annual report of the Wisconsin Central since its reorganization was published yesterday.

Richard Harper Laimbeer. Richard Harper Laimbeer, who died at his home, 9 First Place, Brooklyn, on Sunday, of apoplexy, was born in England in 1825. He had lived in this country since 1830, and in Brooklyn since 1849. His father, William Laimbeer, was one of the pioneers in business at the Atlantic Docks, Brooklyn, and built the North Pier there.
The Singer Manufacturing Company has bought, through William A. White Sons, from Lydia Fox, the four-story building 88 Prince Street, south side, 100 feet west of Broadway, 37.6 by 100.
In a study of the expansion of railway capitalization, close attention must of course be given to the extension of mileage. The mileage comparisons of 1890 and 1900 are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day granted the motion of the Government to advance the Neely cases and assigned them for hearing on Nov. 12. The cases came up from the Federal Court of New York on, the decision of Judge Wallace denying a writ of habeas corpus.

Racegoers at the Morris Park track yesterday experiences weather in every variety, from Summer sunshine when the crowd gathered, to a Winter storm at the close of the afternoon's sport. A whirlwind filled the grand stand with dust after the fourth race, and a downpour of rain shut off the view of the fith race.
GREENWICH DEPOT, Conn., Oct. 17 -- The wedding of Miss Emma Constant Holly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Holly, to Elmer Livingston MacRae, took place to-night at the home of the bride at Coscob.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 -- Not once since the great Blaine demonstration in 1884. has this city been so crowded with visitors as it is to-night, the occasion of the appearance here of Gov. Roosevelt.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16 -- A surprise was sprung on Harvard students at the football practice to-day. Burnett, last year's centre, who kicked several goals from field in important games, appeared in football clothes. He has passed the condition which has been hanging over him, and is again eligible to play.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The Galveston Relief Fund benefit performance packed the Drury Lane Theatre to the utmost this afternoon. Sir Henry Irving, who was greeted with loud applause, recited the "Dream of Eugene Aram." Then followed acts from "The Price of Peace,". "The Debt of Honor," "English Nell," "Julius Caesar," and "Waterloo."

If William Jennings Bryan patted himself on the back last night when he went to a well-earned rest in his bed at the Hoffman House and said, "William Jennings Bryan, the people are with you," he would have been only human. He would have been something less than that had he failed to feel flattered and elated.

NEWPORT, Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Duncan Elliot is away from her cottage for a few days on a visit to New York. She will return late in the week with her sister, Mrs. George B. De Forest, who has also gone to the city with Mr. De Forest.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Discounts showed an easier tendency to-day, owing to the abundance of money, notwithstanding the fact that there still were fears entertained of the shipment of gold to the United States, though there were indications of less pressure here than had been anticipated.

In trying to recover his hat William H. Matthews of 235 Steuben Street, Brooklyn, was crushed to death early last evening under the truck of a motor car on the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad. The accident happened on the Fifth Avenue line, at the Third Street station, and was witnessed by a score of persons standing on the station platform.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- It was another hard day's work for the Tale 'Varsity football team this afternoon. Benjamin, '98; Butterworth, '95; Heffelfinger, '91; McBride, '99; "Mike" Murphy, Cutten, '99, and Adee, '87, were on hand to do the coaching, and they made things hum for the big fellows.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- A secret conference was held to-day in the office of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company between representatives of various coal-carrying railroads and a number of individual operators.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Oct. 16 -- The exploration party which went north on the steamer Corwin has returned and reports the discovery of en immense field of coal near Cape Sabine, on the arctic coast of Alaska.

Goldman, Sachs Co. announced yesterday an additional engagement of $2,000,000 in gold for import. This gold is said to have been purchased in the open market in different parts of the world, some of it coming from Japan.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 16 -- The Meadow Brook Hunt Club's most exciting drag hunt of the season took place to-day from the Bull's Head Hotel, about a mile east of Roslyn. All the club members and many of the ladies of the club drove to the meet with parties of friends.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Oct. 16 -- Henry E. Youtsey, on trial charged with being a principal in the shooting of Gov. Goebel, was still unable to enter the courtroom to-day. Lying on his bed, he was drawn to the door of the jury room, in plain view of those in the courtroom, and the trial proceeded.
WATERTOWN, S.D, Oct. 16 -- Senator Hanna's train stopped at fourteen towns in Minnesota, and South Dakota during the day, with Watertown for the principal stopping place.

We have awaited with some interest and more curiosity the appearance of Mr. BRYAN before the people of New York, for we have felt that here, if anywhere, he would seize the opportunity to present his claims to the highest office in the gift of the people in a manner to secure respectful attention.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Boston had a broad market, 29,619 shares and $57,000 bonds selling in the first half of the day. Sugar furnished two-fifths of the total, but Montana, Tamarack, American Telephone, Old Dominion, Union Pacific, Atchison, and the general mining list were prominent. Tamarack rose 18 more, to 263, a rise of 28 in two days.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Police Marshal William D. Flood of Bradley Beach was assaulted by Halstead Poland and badly hurt last night. In the course of the affair James Poland, son of Burdett Poland, and James Riddle, Jr., were also cut and bruised. The trouble occurred late in the evening.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Thomas F. Lane, son-in-law of ex-Senator Blackburn, committed suicide at his home here last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- John D. Long, Secretary of the Navy, has written a letter for publication in The Harvard Republican, the organ of the Republican students at Harvard University, in which he discusses at length some of the political questions now pending before the American people.

President HADLEY of Yale has discovered the bacillus of imperialism. In a little speech to Yale students explaining that he should vote for McKINLEY because he believed that if we must have imperialism the McKinley sort was safer than the Bryan sort he illuminated the paramount issue by this observation:

An extraordinary specimen of what may be called theatrical ellipsis is the version of the old Dennery romantic drama "Don Caesar de Bazan," in which George Clarke is acting this week at Keith's Union Square Theatre. Placed in the "continuous" programme between two acrobatic "turns," it occupies a scant fifteen minutes in the performance, and in one of its two scenes ninety minutes are supposed to speed away in considerably fewer than nine.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamp. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Nothing has come as yet of the conference held on Monday between State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh and District Attorney Gardiner, in which the former said he would submit evidence regarding many violations of law in the city, and the latter said he would, proceed on the evidence and obtain warrants before a Magistrate.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- The Clerk of the Court of Appeals is now making up the new calendar which was directed by the court to be taken up at the session commencing at the Capitol in this city Jan. 7, 1901. The call of the present calendar was begun April 17, 1899. It originally contained 890 causes, and during its consideration by the court it has grown until the total is 1,128.

I stand for the unconditional repeal of the so-called Ramapo legislation. I have never suggested anything in the line of remedial statutes. I regard the entire measure as inimical to the interests of the people of the State. -- JOHN B. STANCHFIELD.

LONDON, Oct. 17--4 A.M.--The evidence of Prince. Tuan's continuance in power causes anxiety. According to the Shanghai correspondent of The Morning Post it has produced a serious depression in trade there. Two Chinese banks have failed, others are expected to close, and it is reported that the Russo-Chlnese Bank is in difficulties, owing to the removal of the Chinese Court to the Province of Shen-Si.
BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- The monument to the late Prince Bismarck recently erected at Breslau was unveiled to-day.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- The Island Park races scheduled for to-day were stopped by rain after two heats in the 2:18 pace had been decided. Bretonne, the favorite, took both heats in this event, beating Bogie at the wire in the second by a nose. Summary:

MONTPELIER Vt., Oct. 16 -- In the contest for the United States Senatorship, to succeed the late Senator Morrill, one ballot was taken to-day without result, ex-Gov. Dillingham leading with 18 in the Senate and 88 in the House.

The opening games in the tournament of the Bank Clerks' Inter-Club Bowling League were rolled last night at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, Manhattan. Six teams competed in two series of three games each. The scores were low, as might be expected on an opening night.

The protest of the minority stockholders of the St. Louis Southwestern against the present management of the road by Gould interests has been revived. Jacob Newman of Chicago has expressed his intention of contesting the election of Edwin Gould as President of the company on the ground that Mr. Gould is ineligible under Missouri laws, because he is interested in other companies doing business with the St. Louis Southwestern.

The results of the British elections leave no doubt upon two points. One is that the Conservatives return to power with their majority not substantially impaired, either by the blunders of the South African war or by the blunders of the "new diplomacy" that forced it on. The other is that the unquestioned leader of the majority is Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN.

A terrific and sudden windstorm swept Over New York and the territory surrounding it yesterday afternoon, causing much damage to property, the loss of three lives, and serious injury to many persons. At 4 o'clock a hurricane which sprang up in five minutes was Mowing, and it was about then that most of the damage was done.
Mr. Bryan, upon being introduced at Madison Square Garden, spoke as follows:

Edward C. Alphonse. Edward C. Alphonse, one of the most interesting residents of East Orange, N.J., died Monday at his home, 29 Mulford Street. He had been in ill-health for some time. Mr. Alphonse was one of the best known citizens of East Orange, and was prominent in Grand Army of the Republic circles.

Fire broke out at 9:25 o'clock last night in the storeroom of the Hardware Club, in the Postal Telegraph Building, Broadwas and Murray Street, causing $15,000 damage and the suspension of 630 telegraph wires that were busy sending Bryan's speech and his reception by the Tammany organization. The origin of the fire is not known.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The State Board of Health, through its Secretary, Dr. C.A. Lindsley of this city, has officially stamped with approval the short skirt for women, and has placed under the ban the skirts which trail. In his monthly report. Issued to-day, Dr. Lindsley says:

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- The Court of Appeals, by a decision handed down to-day in the McShane case, practically decides that employes of a State institution cannot register from that Institution Frank A. McShane, an inmate at Bellevue Hospital, New York City, was arrested Nov. 16 last for Illegally voting in the Fourth Election District of the Twentieth Assembly District.

BERNARDSVILLB, N.J, Oct. 16 -- Diamond jewelry to the reported value of $20,000 was stolen last night from the residence of Charles Pfizer, two miles from this place. The butler, David Bichards, is missing. The authorities in all cities have been notified to look out for the man. Mr. and Mrs, Pfizer have been in New York for the last two days.

-- Inquiries addressed to the college Presidents of New England by The Boston. Journal have revealed the interesting, if not particularly momentous, fact that probably all, and certainly a large majority of those eminently estimable individuals are supporters of the present Administration.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 16 -- Pittsburg put up a miserable exhibition of ball playing in the second day's game for the world's championship, and presented the game to Brooklyn on errors. Leever's base on balls, followed by a wild throw, was responsible for Brooklyn's first run. After that Leever pitched a fine game, but Williams's wild throws and O'Connor's drop of Ely's good throw were responsible for the other runs.

When Webster Davis arrived at the Hoffman House yesterday morning he was mistaken by some of the loungers for Mr. Bryan. The ex-Assistant Secretary of the interior, who resigned and espoused the cause of Democracy because he did not like the attitude of the Administration toward the Boers; whose special champion in America he is, has had his mustache shaved off, and this has revealed a cast of countenance decidedly Bryanesque.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Under mixed weather conditions Lakewood defeated Rockaway in the final polo match for the Lakewood Cups to-day, winning these handsome trophies by the score of 9 1/2 to 3 goals. The attendance was large and promise of a close game by two teams evenly handicapped, one of which was the home guard, kept up the enthusiasm from first to last.
Mr. Bryan arrived in this city in his special car, the Rambler, at the Grand Central Station at 2:55 o'clock yesterday afternoon. His car was attached to the Lake" Shore Limited train.

The buoyancy which recently has been manipulated into the market was less assertive yesterday. Many stocks advanced, but those which most went up were not the ones which have recently been chiefly conspicuous or which even yesterday were most active. It is a fact that can hardly benefit by disguise that much of the new cheerfulness which Wall Street is enjoying can be traced readily to the work of clever market riggers.

"I don't care so much about the fact that the man fooled me in regard to his yacht, but I do want to stop a seemingly endless procession of liquor dealers who have been bothering me about a monkey or a parrot."

PITTSBURG, Oct. 16 -- Thomas M. King, receiver of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company, filed a petition in the United Stales Court yesterday asking leave to resign. Judge Joseph Buffington granted the petition and in turn appointed John K. Cowen, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, receiver of the road to succeed him when his final account is confirmed by Special Master William R. Blair.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Some innovations were introduced in the practice of the Tigers this afternoon on the University field. Instead of dispensing altogether with the line-up on account of to-morrow's game with Syracuse University team, the scrub and 'Varsity lined up and played a game without scrimmages.

Yesterday's trading in the market for outside securities was more active than on any day for several weeks past, and this activity was accompanied by even greater strength than appeared on Monday. Some losses made on that day were recovered, and further advances were noted in many stocks.

NEWARK, N.J, Oct. 16 -- Nine men, employed by Contractor John F. Day, were engaged in tearing down and removing the scaffolding in the newly built brick factory of the Mairn Linoleum Works, at Passaic and Pomeroy Avenues, this afternoon, when a hurricane struck the ctiy and wrecked the building, burying the men in the ruins.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 -- A vigorous protest has been made by Baltimore Insurance, casualty, and bonding companies against, the policy pursued by the insurance departments of several Western States. Examiners have been sent on from these States to make examinations of the affairs in the Maryland compaales.

Vice Chairman John T. Oakley hastily adjourned the regrular meeting of the Council yesterday without the formality of a motion to adjourn having been made and in-the face of the protests of several Councilmen who wanted the business of the session continued.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Secretary Long to-day received a telegram from Gov. Jones of Arkansas designating the latter's daughter, Miss Bobby Newton Jones, as sponsor for the monitor Arkansas, which is to be launched at Newport News in the near future.

The seven-story apartment house, known as the Victor Hugo, at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 99.11 by 100, has been sold by Hugo F. Hoefler to J.W. Haaren. The consideration is reported at $335,000.

Dr. John H. Haaren, Associate Superintendent of Public Schools in Brooklyn, who was one of the delegates from the Board of Education of this city to look after the educational exhibit at the Paris Exposition, has prepared a paper on the effect of the exhibit at the French capital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On looking at the names of candidates submitted for enrollment in the projected Hall of Fame, one is led to think that existing impressions and popular repute have been largely relied on, rather than a careful examination made for the occasion. Allow me to present some thoughts that have occurred to me.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The unrevised retuins of the general registration in Chicago and the township of Cicero, which is in Cook County, for 1900 show a total of 405,408, against 380,245 four years ago.

Golf at Baltusrol, where the second round of play for the Baltusrol and Consolation Cups took place; polo at Lakewood, and riding to hounds at Meadow Brook and elsewhere, formed the social story of yesterday. The same story will be repeated today, for with the advent of typical Autumn weather outdoor sports are again to the fore.

The adventures of Kate McEnery, in search of a legacy, probably have caused more legal complications than any dozen ordinary cases. She began the trouble by insisting on going to Ireland to collect a small legacy due her there. She got, to Ireland all right and obtained the money. It was on her return trip that the real trouble began.

Walter O. Wetherbee spent two hours on the witness stand yesterday in the examination before Magistrate Brann, in the Centre Street Police Court, of Albert T. Patrick and Charles F. Jones, charged with forging the late W.M. Rice's name to a check for $25,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Bright and cheering weather favored Mr. Bryan's departure from New York. The sun shone out of a cloudless sky and the air was keen and bracing. Flags and campaign banners flapped gayly in the breeze over the candidate's head as he made his way to the Grand Central Station.

The upward movement in curb stocks which has been so marked since the beginning of the Week was extended yesterday to some issues which theretofore had not been prominent. There was no considerable increase in activity, though the average of the several preceding days was maintained, and trading was probably broader than it has been recently.

Charles R. Flint was seen yesterday afternoon by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES and asked about the truth of the report that he was at the head of a syndicate of New York capitalists which had bought the Rogers Locomotive Works, at Paterson, N.J. Mr. Flint said that he had no statement to make at this time regarding the reports in circulation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 17 -- E. Rollins Morse, who purchased the Rhua House property and the adjoining site known as the Cole estate last year, will shortly have the two houses torn down and on their site will be erected a large and handsome villa of Colonial architecture. The villa will be completed in time for next Summer.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 17 -- New Orleans's registration, just closed, shows the following: Total voters registered, 41,403; white, 39,936; colored, 1,467.
FRIEDRICHSHAFFEN, Wurtemburg, Oct. 17 -- Count Zeppelin's airship ascended this afternoon, was steered against the wind, and was put successfully through various tacks and manoeuvres.
OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 17 -- The supervisors of registration in the Eighth Ward of Omaha will be confronted by a curious difficulty to-morrow, and they are puzzled to know how to act.

The Detective Bureau yesterday morning arrested Harry Howard Stewart, twenty-six years old, of Cleveland, Ohio, on a charge of murdering his two-months-old daughter. He was arrested on receipt of a telegram from the police of Cleveland.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 17 -- For two hours and a quarter to-night W. Bourke Cockran of New York discussed "Imperialism" before an enthusiastic audience of 5,000 persons in the Light Guard Armory. When the cheers which greeted Mr, Cockran's appearance had subsided, he picked up copies of two of the Detroit papers and proceeded to answer questions asked him in their editorial columns.

In the course of an address delivered last night at the banquet of the New York State Medical Association Prof. Felix Adler called attention to moral conditions existing in this city and pointed out to the physicians present what they could do toward blotting out the evil that is menacing the younger generation.

The latest Chicago gas war ends, so bulletins issued in Wall Street announce, coincident with Stock Exchange performances. The People's Gas Company of Chicago -- what Wall Street with grim humor calls "the trust" -- has capitulated once more. An opposition company, upon which $1,000,000 may have been spent or contracted to be spent, ceases to compete, and the Gas Trust is assessed from $3,000,000 to $5,000,000.

Miss Beatrix Hoyt, America's once three years' golf champion, and Miss Frances C. Griscom, the present holder, won their competitions yesterday in the Baltusrol Club tournament, near Short Hills, N.J., by comfortable margins. The luck of the draw brings these two masters, or mistresses, of the game together to-day in the second round for the chief trophy.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Harry Howard Stewart, who is under arrest in New York, is charged with murder in the first degree, and was indicted on that count by the Grand Jury this afternoon. He is accused of having accomplished the death of his two-months-old babe. Yesterday the body of the little one was found by some boys on the shore of Lake Erie, near " Suicide Pier," in front of Lake View Park.

What has become of the "White Wings," those street cleaners who in Col. Waring's day used to keep our streets in such condition that there was good reason for calling our streets the cleanest of any in the world? Have they all gone in so heavily for electioneering that they cannot be spared to attend to the duties for which they are well paid by the city?

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 17 -- Pittsburg played baseball in old-time form to-day and Brooklyn did not have a chance at any stage of the game. Philippe did excellent work in the box and was given gilt-edge support, the only error or misplay being Williams's low throw to first base in the ninth inning.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Six touchdowns and a goal from a place kick by Kendall enabled Harvard to roll up 41 points against Bates this afternoon on Soldiers' Field.

Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul was a passenger on the Majestic yesterday. The Archbishop has been abroad for four months, and his trip appears to have benefited him. He looked the picture of health as he came down the gangplank and shook hands with the Rev. L.J. Evers of St. Andrew's Church, who was waiting to receive him.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- The twenty-ninth annual meeting of the shareholders of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was held at the general office building of the company in this city to-day. The Proceedings, ordinarily of the simplest routine character, were enlivened somewhat by a speech by Clarence Deming of New Haven, a journalist, who was present in his capacity as a stockholder.

Sir Thomas Lipton's challenge for the America's Cup was formally laid before the members of the New York Yacht Club at a special meeting held for that purpose last night in the clubhouse at 07 Madison Avenue. Without a dissenting voice the challenge was voted a hearty acceptance by the hundred or more members that thronged the famous model room, where the meeting was held.

Both the Republican and Democratic Parties were severely criticised at Cooper Union, last night, at a mass meeting of the Prohibitionists of this city, held for the purpose of ratifying the nominations of the Prohibition Party for President and Vice President, and for Governor of the State.

The probability that Lord CROMER will assume the Portfolio of War in Lord SALISBURY'S Cabinet quite naturally irouses some curiosity in regard to the qualifications that he may possess for such a post which, at present and for some time to come, must be the most mportant in the Ministry.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 17.--The news from Philadelphia to-day that the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, after a conference with officials of other mining companies, had agreed to the anthracite miners' demands brought forth many expressions of surprise that it should come so soon after the convention.

The fire in the Postal Telegraph Building has again had the happy result of vindicating the construction of the skyscraper. This is by no means the most severe test to which the new construction has been exposed. That was undoubtedly the fire by which the upper stories of the Home Life Building were burned out, and this very Postal Telegraph Building, which adjoins it, was somewhat injured.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: My attention is called to an editorial that appeared in your issue of Sept. 2, entitled: "The American Awards at Paris." At the beginning of the second paragraph you make use of an expression that it seems proper, for the information and satisfaction of the American people, should be corrected.
BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Prince Hohenlohe has tendered his resignation as Imperial Chancellor, and it has been accepted.

Mrs. Dora Blake of 208 Buttermilk Street, Syracuse, N.Y., is in Hoboken, awaiting the arrival of some goods, while a constable is also waiting with a warrant issued by Justice Seymour for the arrest of Hugo Bender, to whom the goods are consigned. They were shipped from Syracuse a week ago, according to Mrs. Blake's statement, and had not arrived up to last nignt.

Columbia's substitutes were given a chance to show their mettle in the game against the Stevens Institute eleven on Columbia Field yesterday afternoon, and they played with a snap and go that swept the opposing team off its feet. In the two twenty and fifteen minute halves eight touch-downs were made by Columbia, while the visitors never had the ball beyond Columbia's forty-yard line.

At last night's meeting of the School Board for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx a resolution was passed unanimously requesting the Board of Education to begin legal proceedings against the municipal authorities to compel them to issue bonds to pay for the construction of the Wadleigh High School.
BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- The American Passenger and Ticket Agents, at their meeting here to-day, elected officers as follows:

The eighteenth annual meeting of the Council of Superintendents of New York State and the fifth annual meeting of the New York State Association of School Boards were begun yesterday in the Board of Education Building, in Fifty-ninth Street. The sessions will last three days. The Council opened in the morning and the School Boards in the afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The results of the second day's racing of the Gatwick October meeting, to-day, are not calculated to lessen the British irritation at the supremacy of the American Jockeys on the English turf, as evidenced by the severe attack rriade on American jockeys by Lord Durham at a recent meeting of the Jockey Club.

Police Commissioner A. Lankering of Hoboken, who recently went to Indianapolis to attend the convention of Democratic clubs and afterward visited Chicago, reached home yesterday. He said he had not been an hour in Chicago when his watch was taken from his pocket. The theft was committed on a street car.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- The great strike of the anthracite mine workers of Pennsylvania, which began Sept. 17, practically ended to-day, when the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company and the Lehigh Valley Coal Company agreed to abolish the sliding scale in their respective regions and to grant an advance in wages of 10 per cent. net, the advance to remain in operation until April 1, 1901, and thereafter till further notice.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 17 -- The letter notifying William J. Bryan of his nomination for President has been in Mr. Bryan's possession for some time. It is understood that Mr. Bryan will publish his answer this week.

The contest between President Haffen of the Bronx and Commissioner Nagle of the Street Cleaning Department for the control of the nomination for the State Senate in the Twenty-first Senate District came up yesterday afternoon before the Police Commissioners upon the cross-protests of Joseph P. Hennessy and Richard H. Mitchell, each against the nomination of the other as the Democratic candidate for the Senate in that district.

--In 1896, as was noted at the time, Mr. BRYAN evidently came here with a hope amounting to an expectation that he could duplicate LINCOLN'S achievement of I860 and win the respect and admiration of the East by proving to it that the man supposed to be merely an uncouth product of the uncivilized West was in reality a statesman, thinker, and orator more than able to stand comparison with the highest standards.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 17 -- The United States torpedo boat destroyers Dahlgren and Craven were in collision off Castle Hill Tuesday night, the former being slightly damaged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The French Charge d'Affaires, M. Thiebaut, called at the State Department to-day and had a conference with Secretary Hay. It is understood that he presented a memorandum proposing that the peace negotiations with China begin immediately, in accordance with the favorable action of the powers on the recent note of the French Government.

In order to provide a reply to Mr. Bryan's issue of militarism and a large standing army, the Republican National Committee requested Senator Scott, when he was in Washington some days ago, to have prepared a plain statement of facts showing by the official records what has been done by Congress in regard to the army and why it was done.

Eight persons were burned to death by the fire at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the three-story frame house at 45-45 1/2 Hester Street, which was entirely extinguished within a half hour. The entire structure would reach scarcely higher than the second floor of the ordinary modern house.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Discounts were easier to-day on the recovery in American exchange, less acute apprehensions of gold exports, and New York getting supplies from centres outside of London. But the decline will hardly go far, seeing that with the slight easiness the Continental exchanges were weaker.
David Bispham, the opera singer, arrived on the White Star liner Majestic yesterday. He has been in England all the past Summer enjoying, he said, a well-earned vacation.
Announcement was made yesterday that after many delays and postponements the new union waiting room at the Grand Central Station would be opened to the public to-day.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- The announcement of Queen Wilhelmina's betrothal has been sympathetically received by the whole German press, although nearly all the papers point out that the event is devoid of political significance. Attention, however, is called to the fact that her choice cannot fail to strengthen the ties of friendship between the two countries.

HURON, S.D., Oct. 17 -- The special train bearing Senator Hanna and Senator Frye traveled up and down through the counties of central South Dakota to-day, in the districts where the vote as a rule is close and where farmers compose the greater part of the population. Fourteen stops were made during the day, Senator Hanna making speeches ut Redfield, Northville, Groton, Andover, Bristol, Bradley, Elrod, Bryant, Lake Preston, Desmet, Iroquois, Huron, Aberdeen, and Webster.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Oct. 17 -- The heavy northerly gale which has been sweeping over this section all night badly damaged a large fleet of vessels which left the harbor at Vineyard Haven yesterday. Several coasting schooners are ashore, likely to be a total loss. No loss of life has been reported.

Mr. BRYAN strives to set class against class and provoke social tumult. His speeches, therefore, read like the utterances of a dangerous disturber, yet BRYAN AN is not dangerous because his insincerity is plainly revealed even to his least intelligent audiences, and the American people, instinctively judging him to be an unsafe man, overwhelmingly reject his appeal and are resolved not to take the terrible risk of intrusting power to his unsteady hands.
Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for Jeremiah C. Lyons, to Clinton Gilbert, the new five-story American basement dwelling, with extension, 48 East Fiftieth Street, 19 by 63 by 100.5.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17 -- John D. Creighton of Omaha has offered $25,000 for Charley Herr, (2:07,) the famous Kentucky trotting stallion. David Cahill, a poor dairyman. who bought the horse and two others for $25, wants $50,000 for him.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 17 -- William L. Wilson, President of Washington and Lee University and ex-Postmaster General, died suddenly at 9:20 o'clock this morning from congestion of the lungs. He had been failing ever since his return from Arizona. His son, Dr. Arthur Wilson of Lynchburg, visited him on Sunday and left here Monday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 -- This has been a day of triumph for Gov. Roosevelt in Ohio. To-night the City of Cleveland gave him a reception rivaling any similar demonstration ever made here. There was an immense parade, consisting of hall a score of brass bands, dozens of political organizations, including many which had come hither from other places to do honor to the candidate for Vice President.

Five bags of registered mail, inclosed in one large pouch, were stolen from Station H, at the corner of Lexington Avenue and East Forty-fourth Street, on Monday night last, and so far the Post Office Inspectors have been unable to locate the thief, although suspicion has fallen on one man.

Nothing could be better adapted to impress, upon the serious part of the American public, the decay of the Democratic Party than the death of WILLIAM L. WILSON, coming as it does in the midst of the manifestations of the cheapness and shallowness of the demagogue whom an ironical fate has permitted to put himself forward as the representative and organ of that historic organization.

A contest over the estate of John Delmar, who was for many years the Democratic leader of the Eighth Ward, Brooklyn, was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court, that borough, when there was filed a lispendens and the summons and complaint in the suit of Mary Delmar and Delia Delmar, sisters of John Delmar, against Eliza Jane Delmar, his widow and executrix of his will.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- There was standing room only to-night at the first performance of "Foxy Quiller," the new comic opera by Reginald De Koven and Harry B. Smith. The piece scored a great success and the encores were many. The music contains numerous catchy airs and choruses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue shows that the receipts from all sources during September amounted to $23,433,814, a decrease as compared with September, 1899, of $1,067,071.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Princeton's football team defeated Syracuse University this afternoon in a one-sided game, in which the work of the Princeton eleven outclassed that of the visitors in every respect. The final score was 43 to 0 in Princeton's favor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Minister Wu called upon the President this morning and was received in the Blue Parlor.

Edward I. Johnson, a bank examiner of New Orleans, was the only witness called before Commissioner Shields yesterday in the proceedings for the removal of John F., E.H., and W.T. Gaynor, and B.D. Greene to the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Georgia.
It was not necessary to urge Mr. Croker to talk last night. When he met a group of reporters at the Democratic Club he did not wait for them to ask a question, but said:

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Young women who sit at the feet of Prof. Oliver J. Thatcher at the University of Chicago in order to absorb information concerning the history of times mediaeval declare that the professor taints the classroom atmosphere by using a patois which ill clothes descriptions of the momentous events of the period.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- Judge Carter, in the Superior Court, to-day handed down his opinion in the suit by the State of Indiana to recover nearly $3,000,000 from the Vandalia Railroad. He holds that the State is entitled to recover $745,154.65. The action was based on the provisions of a division of profits under a special charter granted the company which built the Vandalia Road from Terre Haute to Indianapolis.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pullman Company was held to-day. Over two-thirds of the capital stock was represented. Directors for the ensuing year were elected as follows:

For visitors to the Morris Park race track yesterday there was more excitement and sensation crowded into the one afternoon than a week usually provides. The weather was pleasant, the track good, and a large crowd was in attendance, confident of good racing and hopeful of profit, as the attractive programme called out a very good class of horses.

"Few men know when to dispose of a good thing," remarked one of the Speedway drivers while resting at one of the road houses after his spin yesterday. "But the old man Hamlin of Buffalo doesn't belong in that class, I can tell you. This year his string of trotters and pacers have done the very best in their history.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- At the first day's racing of the Sandown Park Autumn meeting to-day the Sandown Foal Stakes for three-year-olds was won by Sir R. Afflek's bay colt, Admiral Dewey. Lord Rosebery's colt Cateran Lad and Mr. Fairie's colt Mahdi were secend and third, respectively.

Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, granted a temporary injunction to Wertheimer Co., glove manufacturers, against Samuel Gans, manager of the Western Salvage Wrecking Company, and Field, Chapman Co., auctioneers, restraining them from carrying on a public sale which had been advertised to take place at 10 o'clock this morning, unless the defendants make certain announcements specified by the court.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 18 -- The agony is over. Brooklyn's team is champion of the world at baseball, the owner of the beautiful five-hundred-dollar Chronicle-Telegraph trophy cup, and carries away one-half the gate receipts of the four games necessary to decide their supremacy over Pittsburg.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Oct. 18 -- Gov. Roosevelt entered at noon upon his West Virginia itinerary, making his first speech at Wheeling to a large crowd at the fair grounds. On the platform were 100 men who voted for Fremont in 1856.

Because the certificate of death of Thomas Sylvester Clarke, a retired grocer, which was filed with the Department of Health in June last, had the middle initial of his name "A." instead of "S.," a lively contest will commence to-morrow in the Surrogate's Court over the right to administer his estate, valued at about $75,000.

The large pouch of registered mail matter, containing five smaller pounches, sent to Station H from a number of other branch Post Offices for transmission to the General Post Office, has not been found, although Chief Post Office Inspector King and two of his ablest men, Inspectors James and Jacobs, are at work on the case.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 18 -- Walton H. Holmes of Kansas City was to-day elected President of the American Street Railway Association and New York City was selected for the next annual convention. H. H. Vreeland, New York, and N.H. Heft, Meriden, Conn., were elected First and Second Vice Presidents respectively.

Vice Chancellor Pitney yesterday advised Chancellor Magie to sign a decree setting aside the will of Louis Foth, who died at Carlstadt, N.J., a year ago, and vest the property in Herman Foth, the heir-at-law. Louis Foth was seventy-eight years old. He owned two houses valued at $6,000. He had covenanted with his son, Herman Foth, to will the property to him at his death.

"There is still something of the old Puritan conscience left," said Dr. FELIX ADLER in his stirring little speech at the dinner of the New York Medical Association on Wednesday night. He had been appealing to the medical men to lend their help in the movement, which everybody sees is coming, to cleanse portions of this city of some of their worst pollutions.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The Havas agency has received the following dispatch from Peking:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- To-day's practice at the Yale Field was very ragged. The 'Varsity made a touch-down on a fumble in 1 minute 1 second, after a prolonged fumbling and end runs on both sides.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Pension Commissioner H. Clay Evans, who has been making a campaign tour of his State, Tennessee, visited the White House to-day to report his observations. After leaving the President he said:
