LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Misapprehension having arisen over the wording of Sir Thomas Lipton's challenge. Sir Thomas asks The Associated Press to say the challenge provides for five completed races and not three, as might be inferred from the wording. In fact, it is exactly the same as the conditions of last year, unless, as was the case last year, the result can be achieved in three races.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- An application was made here before Vice Chancellor Pitney for a receiver for the town of Lincoln, in this county, which was boomed into prominence by Silas Dewey Drake and his Common Council of women. The receivership is asked for the New Jersey Realty Company of Bound Brook, which owns Lincoln.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- State Factory Inspector Williams stated to-day that he had received reports from some of his Deputy Inspectors in New York to the effect that Degnon McLean, sub-contractors for Sections 1 and 2 of the rapid transit system, are employing aliens as laborers on the contract.

The audience which assembled in the Academy of Music in Brooklyn last night to hear J.G. Schurman, President of Cornell University and Chairman of the first commission sent to the Philippines, expound the issues of the campaign was composed almost exclusively of well-dressed men and women.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Senator Depew was given a rousing reception in Canandaigrua to-night. There were bonfires, fireworks, and parade. The Grand Opera House was crowded to its greatest capacity, but not one-fourth the people who desired to hear could gain admittance. Justice William H. Adams of the Appellate Court presided.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Census Bureau to-day made public the population for the Territory of Arizona.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 18 -- Lispenard Stewart and Dr. T. Madison Taylor have returned from their hunting trip to Canada, being compelled to bring their hunting to a sudden ending owing to the continual heavy rains. Mr. Stewart has gone to New York for a short visit and will keep White Lodge open until the middle of next month.

William and Henry Fagen of 979 Eighth Avenue and Henry Helmke, who with a boatman named Williams were fishing in the sailboat Hope in the lower bay last Tuesday when they were caught in the hurricane, returned to their homes at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Their experience is regarded as one of the most thrilling that ever fell to the lot of local boatmen.

The trial of Foreman James D. Clifford of the Attorney Street Hook and Ladder Company, No. 18, on charges of insubordination and violation of rules growing out of his activity as a member and President of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association, was continued at Fire Headquarters yesterday, before Commissioner John J. Scannell.

-- Every night in the year every passenger who, between the hours of 4:30 and 6:30 o'clock, sets foot on the platform of the Third Avenue elevated road station at City Hall, either coming from or going to a train, is in imminent danger of death in its most frightful form. The number of persons thus imperiled each day is certainly 30,000, and it is probably considerably more.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The smart rally in New York exchange rates and the knowledge that the United States was obtaining gold elsewhere weakened discount rates here to-day. Another factor in this direction was the buying of bills here on Continental account.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 18 -- The first day of registration brought an unusual number of citizens to the polls. The Republicans were the early birds, their proportion against all other parties varying from ten to one down to two to one.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 18 -- Gov. Roosevelt was welcomed in the President's home town to-day by the Republican organizations. He was escorted to the Tabernacle, where a large crowd listened to his speech, during which he said:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18 -- United States Senator William Lindsay, in an interview to-day, announced himself for Yerkes and McKinley, scored Bryan and Beckham, and declared the Democrats are planning to steal the coming election in Kentucky, if possible.

The strike of the miners in the anthracite coal region seems well advanced toward a settlement, though there are still some elements of uncertainty on both sides. On the one hand the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's miners have received no word that their employers will grant the concessions made by the Reading and the Lehigh, and some of the individual operators have not yet come into the new arrangement.

Chemical Engine No. 4 of Jersey City was called out at 6 o'clock A.M. yesterday by a pot of fat that boiled over and took fire in Guahap's restaurant, at 89 York Street. The horses, known, respectively, as Joe and Ben, were anxious to get away, and as soon as the floors of the engine house were open made a dash for the street without waiting for the driver, Michael Noonan.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Albany's interest in Col. Bryan was so exhausted by last night's parade and two meetings that there was not enough left to-day to give him a farewell demonstration on his departure for the Mohawk Valley. At the station his ear arrived ten minutes late, when "Len" Wager promptly gave the word for the train to move.
WASHINGTON, Oct 18 -- Minister Conger to-day communicated by cable the substance of certain propositions advanced by Prince Ching and Li-Hung-Chang for a settlement of the Chinese trouble.

False alarms of fire, political meetings, and parades do not make a good combination. This was fully demonstrated last night at Camp McKinley, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, where for the space of fifteen minutes the wildest excitement prevailed. The meeting in the big tent was in charge of the colored Republicans of Harlem and the Bronx.

Miss Griscom won the pivotal match in the women's golf tournament of the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N. J., which was played yesterday. The present National champion was pitted against a foe worthy of her finest golf. Miss Beatrix Hoyt, the once three-year champion of America.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 18 -- An important election in Kentucky this Fall that is not attracting the attention it deserves is that for a Judge of the Court of Appeals in the Seventh Appellate District. As at present constituted, the Court of Appeals contains three Republicans and four Democrats. The term of the Chief Justice, James H. Hazelrigg, a Democrat, expires Dec. 30.

Oscar Hammerstein has decided to build another theatre in this city, which will be located on a plot of ground measuring 125 feet by 200, located on Thirty-fourth Street, 120 feet west of Eighth Avenue, running through to Thirty-fifth Street, and to cost when completed in the neighborhood of $600,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey this morning, after a lively debate, defeated by a decisive vote the resolution, submitted by the Committee on Temperance through its Chairman, Dr. J.D. Hart of Belvidere, condemning the National Administration for retaining the canteen in the army.
BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The retirement of Prince Hohenlohe is the principal theme of discussion here.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Pietermarltzburg correspondent of The Daily Mail wires as follows:

Catharine Wilson has bought, through Charles B. Schuyler Co. and Francis B. Robert, the plot at the northeast corner of Broadway and Ninety-seventh Street, 100 feet on the former by 149.7 on the latter by 105 on the northerly line. The price paid for the property is reported at $170,000. A seven-story apartment house will be erected on the site at once, probably from plans by Janes Leo.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Trading was quiet to-day, and showed little feature. Montana, was off 5, to 332, later rallying to 336; Tamarack touched 260, later 256; Old Dominion eased 3/8, to 20 3/4; Utah lost 1/2, to 30 1/2, later 30 7/8; Parrot held at 43 5/8; Isle Royale gained 3/4, to 31 3/4; Osceola was off 1/4, at 70 1/4; Bingham sold up 3/8, to 12 3/8: Baltic brought 22.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- "The Young Men of America" was the subject of an address delivered last night By Senator Albert J. Beveridge of Indiana at a Republican mass meeting in Tomlinson Hall. The speaker announced that he concerned himself less with the question of how young men should vote in the present campaign than with the question of their party allegiance in the future.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's issue of your paper appears an article on "Tenement House Keform." After its perusal I could not but heartily indorse the article, especially having had a similar experience. People who live in another sphere do not know or understand that class which inhabit "tenement houses."

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 18 -- Senator Hanna's itinerary for his second day's speechmaking in South Dakota included stops at half a dozen towns in the eastern and southern counties and wound up with a meeting to-night at Sioux Falls.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18 -- A motor vehicle assisted a newly married couple in East Orange to turn the joke upon a number of fun-loving friends and guests at a wedding reception last night. The wedding was that of Miss Florence Adeline Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Pope of Prospect Street, East Orange, to George Austin Beardsley, Jr., of Newark.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 6. -- The Society for the Moral and Physical Improvement of Young Men, an organization similar to the Young Men's Christian Association, was successfully launched in this city this afternoon in a building specially fitted up for the purpose.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 18 -- The Midland Ironmasters are inquiring in official quarters about the reported intention to prefer American manufacturers to British in awarding contracts for the extensive railway and bridge construction contemplated in South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary Long to-day received a remarkable letter from a Georgia man named F.R. Brown. It begins by saying that the Secretary will probably not remember the writer, never having seen him, but the writer remembers the Secretary well, having often seen him when Mr. Long was Governor of Massachusetts.

CREEDMOOR, Oct. 18 -- The range was occupied here to-day by the Seventh Regiment Veteran Association in their annual competition for the marksmen and sharpshooter decoration, also the H.W.T. Mali match, for which match a trophy was shot for at 200 and 300 yards, presented by ex-Col. Henry W.T. Mali, to be held by the winner until the next competition.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 18 -- At Lake Charles, La., to-day R.H. Nason, a wellknown, lumber and rice man, bet $20,000 to $10,000, put up by Michael Kelly, the prominent business man of that place, that McKinley would be elected. Mr. Kelly has just returned from the East, and backed Bryan on the strength of the Democratic sentiment he found in New York.

Mrs. Mary A.B. Farley, wife of Philip H. Farley, Superintendent of Agencies for the Mutual Life Insurance Company, was killed yesterday by falling from a third-floor window of the extension in the rear of the house at 168 West Eighty-seventh Street to the yard. She was sick and had gone to the room, it is believed, to get some air and fell out in a fit of weakness.

Mr. RICHARD CROKER has done a good deal this Summer and Autumn toward enlarging his "sphere." No impartial observer will dispute that he has beaten DAVID B. HILL at DAVID'S own game, which is New York State politics. Upon this occasion GOLIATH went up against DAVID, armed only with a sling, an equipment which does injustice to both their habits, and a smooth stone, labeled "Unquestionable Regularity."

For the purpose of considering what could be done to improve the situation on west-bound rates to Mississippi and Missouri River points, the traffic managers of the various trunk lines held a protracted meeting yesterday at the offices of the Trunk Line Association. It will be remembered that about four weeks ago a similar meeting was held, at which the Western connections were requested not to interfere with rates out of trunk line territory.

The utmost secrecy is being maintained on the action of the daughter of Thomas B. Clarke, the art collector, for an annulment of her marriage with Harry Wakeield Bates of Boston. None of the parties interested will say anything about the oaee, which is shortly to come up for trial in Westchester County.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Somerset County, 8 1/2; Westchester, 8. That was the polo story told on the grounds at Georgian Court this afternoon to the largest crowd of the season, who cheered with delightful impartiality and earnestness the good points of play on both teams. The game was the second in the series for the Ocean County Cups.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was more active, and was accompanied by sharper advances than on any day since the present upward movement began. The bulk of the day's business was supplied by three or four stocks which were the most prominent, but lighter trading occurred in many other issues.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Joseph Jefferson addressed the pupils of the Chicago Musical College to-day, taking for his subject "Acting and Oratory." He said in part:

C.J. Field, Chairman of the Technical Committee of the Automobile Club of America, has just announced the programme of track tests for automobiles during the coming automobile show in Madison Square Garden, from Nov. 3 to 10. All of the events, except those for Friday, Nov. 9, will be open only to the vehicles in the exhibit.

Wall Street views become rosy, quotations are marked upward on account of circulating reports that "the Vanderbilts" are about to make announcement of a new big deal through which the New York Central system is to be much extended. A variety of auxiliary properties, according to the rumors current, are to be absorbed on the basis of control through acquiring a majority of stock or by interest and dividend guarantees.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Attorney General Davies, owing to the large number of inquiries for his opinion on "voting residence" and qualifications of voters, has prepared a general letter to the public at large, it being impossible to answer each letter separately.

Marguerite Gast, the young German woman who for the past twelve days has been riding a bicycle 200 miles a day over the Long Island roads in the vicinity of Valley Stream, finished her twenty-fifth century (100 miles) at 11:15 yesterday morning, and immediately announced her intention of riding another thousand miles before she would stop.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 18. -- A deed to the Capitol Hotel property was to-day filed by the trustees of the William M. Rice estate, to be situated at Houston. The deed was executed June 20, 1892, by William M. Rice and his wife, Elizabeth Baldwin Rice, as a donation to the endowment fund of the William M. Rice Institute for the Advancement of Literature, Science and Art.
The weights for the two handicaps to be run on the opening of the Empire City Club's meeting next Monday have been announced as follows:

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 18 -- Representatives of nearly all the big coal companies of the region conferred here to-day and made an agreement to amend the notices already posted by attaching the following:
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Senator J.K. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to-day made the following statement:

Chief of Police Murphy of Jersey City is investigating a story told by Mrs. John Hume of 53 Jewett Avenue. She says that when she went to her room at 5 o'clock P.M. on Wednesday a closet door was thrown open and a colored man stepped out. As she turned in affright she was confronted by a white man.

Mr. Arthur J. Evans of the Asmolcan Museum, Oxford, son of the celebrated antiquary Sir John Evans, road an interesting paper on writing in prehistoric Greece and the origin of the alphabet at a British Association meeting at Bradford recently which threw much fresh light upon those subjects.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If our metropolitan pastors would use more of their time in the spirit of Christ's tolerance, in communion with the people they condemn, they would have less time for the composition of their rounded periods of vilification of this city, to which they, or most of them, have immigrated for their livings, and their hearers would less frequently feel like exclaiming: "Verily thou tirest me!"

ROCHESTER, Oct. 19 -- Col. Bryan resumed his tour through the Empire State with more auspicious weather to favor him than that of yesterday. Syracuse was looking its brightest, and there was a nipping, frosty, touch in the breeze. The puddles of last night were drying up and the local Democratic managers were waking up when Mr. Bryan was breakfasting at his hotel preparatory to an early start.

Because their sister, Mrs. Lizzie Murphy, refused to loan them 25 cents, Thomas J. Walsh, twenty-two years old, and his brother, Daniel, who have just returned from the Philippines, where they served in the United States Army, kicked in the door of their sister's flat on the second floor of 121 East One Hundred and Tenth Street yesterday evening, and then chased everybody in the house, which is occupied by ten families, into the street.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Our little house situated upon a hilltop overlooking the river, and looking down upon the stone works at the water side, and round about on the neighboring hills, recalls to my mind yet another hilltop or "brae," and I think of Thrums, "a toon o' braes," of which I have been reading of late in a Canadian magazine.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 19 -- Regarding the statement made in a recent speech by Gov. Roosevelt that he was glad to see such men as Gen. Wheeler supporting President McKinley in the present campaign, Gen. Wheeler said to-day:

HOLYOKE, Mass., Oct. 19 -- The fourth day's racing at Springdale Park was again marked by a number of accidents that assumed threatening aspects at first, but the usual horseman luck prevailed and nothing very serious resulted. In the third heat of the 2:21 pacing class a smashup occurred that involved three drivers, horses and sulkies, and it was nothing short of a miracle that all lives were saved.

On Tuesday night, Oct. 16, at John Anderson, Jr.'s, auction rooms in West Thirtieth Street, a copy of "Engravings from the Works of Sir Joshua Reynolds," containing 300 mezzotint plates. London, 1834, three volumes, was bought by James Stillman for $97.50. It was published at u34. Among other interesting items in the same sale was Mrs. Browning's "Sonnets from the Portuguese."
BUFFALO, Oct. 19 -- The following letter accepting the nomination of the Silver Lincoln Republicans was mailed to-day by Mr. Bryan:

Dr. Anna L. White of 151 West Fortysixth Street obtained a verdict for $467.35 in the City Court yesterday against David Belasco, the playwright. The amount was to recover for medical attendance upon Frederick Lyster, who, according to the papers, when Belasco was a poor boy in San Francisco, launched him in theatrical life by employing him in the theatre of which he was manager.

Archbishop Ireland, in conversation yesterday touching the sentiment at Rome toward the Catholic Church in the Philippines and in Cuba, remarked that he felt quite willing to repeat what was recently said to him in Rome on this subject. He said he did so the more readily that the eminent personages with whom he conversed on the matter showed themselves to be in no way unwilling to have the statements made by them become public.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- The vote of the Presbyteries on the question of the revision of the Confession of Faith, as thus far reported, is as follows:

John B. McDonald, contractor for the rapid transit tunnel, will take immediate action on the complaint made by State Factory Inspector Williams that the DegnonMcLean Construction Company, sub-contractors for Sections 1 and 2, are employing aliens as laborers. In a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES, printed yesterday morning, it was stated that Deputy Inspectors had found quite a number of men employed who had not even declared their intentions of becoming citizens.

A thought-condenser who has road the new London book, "How to Write for the Magazines," says that if it were possible to sum up the author's advice in one sentence, it would be: "Give the editor of the magazine what he wants!"

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 -- The magnificent library building of the State Historical Society, which has been under construction for the past three years, was formally dedicated this afternoon in the presence of a large and distinguished assemblage.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 19 -- The local market only partially responded to the boom in New York. Prices generally strengthened, but improvement in most cases was limited to fractions. The exceptions were: National Asphalt, 5 to 7; the preferred, 20 to 21; 5 per cents., 50 to 52 1/2; American Asphalt 5s, 67 3/4 to 70 to 69 1/2; common stock, 8 3/8 to 9 1/2.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Presidential Candidate Woolley of the Prohibition Party stopped at the Pennsylvania station here to-day on a special train, expecting to address a big temperance gathering. After the candidate's car had been side tracked Mr. Woolley discovered that not one Prohibitionist was there to receive him.

The message of the Chinese Peace Commissioners is semi-officially described from Washington as being satisfactory so far as it goes. That seems to us a much more accurate description than that which is unofficially given in London, that the proposal is a piece of "impudence."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 19 -- Commander Wainwright, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, issued the following order today:

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The King of Belgium gave proof of his friendship for the United States to-day by attending a luncheon given by Commissioner General Peck to Thomas P. Walsh, National Commissioner from Colorado, who leaves Paris to-morrow.

THE PREVAILING RATE OP WAGES LAW -- William J. Rogers, to whom $2,863 was due under his contract with the city for regulating the grade of One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street at Madison Avenue, but payment of which was refused because he had not paid his, employes the prevailing rate of wages, sought a writ of mandamus to compel payment of his claim by controller Coler.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Statistician of the Department of Agriculture has completed his investigation of the agricultural situation in those counties in Texas that were visited by the West Indian hurricane of Sept. 8. Reports have been received from the department's regular correspondents and from many other prominent citizens identified with the agricultural and commercial interests of Southern Texas.

Marguerite Gast's continuous cycle riding performance over the roads in the vicinity of Valley Stream, L.I. was abruptly terminated Thursday night by the action of the authorities of Nassau County. Miss Gast had just finished 2,582 miles when Deputy Sheriff Abraham Furman appeared and informed her that he had been instructed by District Attorney Nieman of Nassau County to prevent her from continuing her ride.

Linseed oil was quoted at 71 cents per gallon yesterday. The day before it had Jumped from 63 to 70 cents, which was a greater advance than had been known in the price of the product for ten or twelve years.

-- Indignation among the thousands of people whose lives are endangered daily at the City Hall station of the Third Avenue elevated railway ought to gain added fierceness because of the fact that the outrageous conditions existing there are at least as much the result of official incompetency or carelessness as they are of corporate stinginess.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The Field, in the course of a judicious article commenting upon the recent meeting of the Jockey Club, at which Lord Durham made his attack upon American trainers and jockeys, says:

Developments of consequence in trade circles during the week now ending have been few. Dullness incident to a Presidential year rules, and the hand-tomouth policy referred to last week continues. Perhaps the most interesting feature reported is the placing of orders with a proviso allowing for cancellation should the election result unfavorably.

John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, spoke at two meetings in Brooklyn last night. Before an audience that filled the Academy of Music he spoke for over an hour on State and National issues.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- The Maryland Steel Company has been awarded a contract to build two immense seagoing cargo carriers. In dimensions the proposed vessels will surpass the two freighters which the company is now constructing for the Boston Steamship Company. They will carry about 12,000 tons dead weight, and will be the largest steamers ever build in an American, shipyard to fly the Stars and Stripes.

The citing of an example of Paul Jones's French by Mr. Buell in last week's TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW has called forth a number of inquiries concerning John Paul's ability to write that language, one correspondents even going so far as to lay his faults of syntax at our door. As the passage stood in our columns Mr. Buell had so written it, and he undoubtedly made a faithful transcription of it.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 19 -- W.J. Bryan, at the end of the third day of his trip through New York State has covered in about fifteen hours of travel an almost circular area in the heart of New York, has made long and short speeches at ten places, and goes to bed impressed with the belief that he has a chance to get the Electoral vote of the State.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- To over 200,000 workingmen in all branches of trades unions the Executive Committee of the State Workingmen's Federation issues an appeal today, calling upon them to work against the members of the last Legislature, who proved themselves enemies of organized labor.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The liner New York, which sails to-day from Southampton for New York, will have on board as passengers Maurice Grau, Edouard De Reszke, Mme. Nordica, Mme. Bauermeister, and seventy other operatic artists.

The five hundredth anniversary of the death of Chaucer, Oct. 25, has been appropriately celebrated in this city by the Grolier Club and in London by the British Museum by exhibitions of various editions of the works of the poet, portraits, manuscripts, engravings, and other objects relating to him.
William S. Grace, ex-Mayor of New York, being asked yesterday for a statement of his ideas on the political situation, said:

CAROLINE WILLIAMS, Columbus, Ohio, writes: I am always Interested in discussions touching the subject of best books for children, and was therefore rejoiced to find this topic cropping up again in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 15 under the heading "Books for Very Small Boys."

One of the chief objects of the banking provisions of the act of March 14 last was to encourage the establishment of small banks under the National banking system in communities that had previously been without satisfactory local facilities. The object has been attained thus far with a degree of success that proves the wisdom of the act in this regard.

Unusually light practice was given the Columbia football squad yesterday afternoon in view of to-day's hard game against the University of Pennsylvania eleven. Coach Sanford took the candidates, nearly thirty in all, out on Columbia Field at 4 o'clock, and for nearly half an hour the squad was kept at work catching and following punts.

MACAULAY-- BORN OCT. 25, 1800. Macaulay was born on Oct. 25, 1800. (one hundred years ago next Thursday, and exactly five hundred years after Chaucer died.) and died on Dec. 28, 1859. He was a man of imperial mind and he lived a happy life. He had the felicity of winning fame which was contemporaneous with him. Best of all he deserved this fame and success, and he was worthy of his friends.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial in your paper published a few days ago I was rather surprised to note an implied approval of the statement to the Tenement House Commission, credited to Mr. Gibson, that model tenements were occupied by others than the class for whom they were intended.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- The body of Jennie Bosschieter was found lying a short distance from the Wagaran bridge, on the Bergen side of the Paterson River at 5:30 o'clock this morning. The discovery was made by two milkmen. The head of the girl rested upon a jagged rock, and there was a fracture of the skull near the base of the brain.

SOUTHAMPTON, Oct. 19 -- A clergyman of Aquebogue presented a curious appeal to his congregation a Sunday or two ago. It was in the form or a letter sent to him from Washington, asking information concerning an old tombstone. The stone is wanted for a date upon it, which will form a much-desired link in a genealogical chain.

Because she was unable to keep up in her studies at the Morris High School, Imogene White, the fourteen-year-old daughter of William White, Chairman of the Board of Registry of the Thirty-seventh Election District of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District, attempted suicide last evening by taking carbolic acid.
After an absence of five years Mr. S.L. Clemens (Mark Twain) returns to his home from "a tour around the world to pay his debts." He is accompanied by his wife and family.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 19 -- The report that Alfred G. Vanderbilt and his future bridge would occupy the Lorillard Spencer cottage after their marriage is without foundation, as the rental of the cottage does not begin until June next, and then but for four months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was present on Wednesday when Mr. BRYAN made his speech at Yonkers. He fired off an impassioned sentence about what the Republican Party had done in the way of stopping factories and neglecting schools to an audience proud of its public school system and its thriving factories.
A letter alleged to have been written by B.B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, was made public last night by Mayor James K. McGuire, who has charge of the Democratic State campaign.

Dr. Wylie Street Jones, a young West Virginian, taking a post-graduate course at a medical college in this city, and living for the time at 229 West Forty-third Street, was attacked by two men Thursday morning at Seventh Avenue and Twentysixth Street. After the assault he was drugged and robbed of $85 and his gold watch.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 10 -- Senator Hanna spoke here to-night to big audiences. At one of the three meetings he addressed he referred to the charges which he said had been recently made by Mr. Bryan that the Republican campaign managers had entered upon an extensive system of bribery in order to secure the election of the Republlcan ticket.

John Lott Nostrand. John Lott Nostrand, one of the oldest civil engineers in Brooklyn, died on Thursday at his home, 25 Palmetto Street, from pneumonia. Mr. Nostrand was one of the original City Surveyors of Brooklyn, and to him was due to a large extent the improvement of Brooklyn by means of the rapid transit.

On a catafalque draped in the National colors and surmounted by an American eagle clutching in its bronze talons the Red, White and Blue, the bodies of the six soldiers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment who died in camp during the Spanish-American war rested yesterday in the drill room of the armory, at Third Avenue and Seventh Street.

One would have thought a matinee race meet was in progress by the number of well-known trotters and pacers on the Speedway yesterday afternoon. Several favorites made their first-appearance this Fall on the road in prime condition and ready for all comers, and the consequence was a series of well contested and exciting brushes.

"Jackie" Haggerty, a character of the old Fourth Ward and the pride of Cherry Hill since the time he jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge to win a pint of beer, died at his home in Cherry Street early yesterday morning from pneumonia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with a great deal of pleasure that I read the article by E.J. Junior in this morning's NEW YORK TIMES, and I can corroborate his statements of the deplorable conditions existing in the tenements. Much has been advocated and something done toward remedying the evil, but no substantial work has as yet been accomplished.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Armed with two big revolvers, Simeon I. Morris, a contractor, was arrested, to-day in the corridor outside the American Wire and Steel Company's offices, charged with trying to attempt the lives of John W. Gates and W. G. Brimson, the latter being General Manager of the Kansas City and Southern Railway.

A.W. HARRINGTON, Flushing, L.I., writes: "In two novels published by two different publishing houses and issued on or almost the same date, there are two paragraphs which are not only in meaning but in phraseology and in reference almost precisely identical. In Miss Hallie Rives's 'A Furnace of Earth' occurs this paragraph:

DENVEE, Col., Oct. 19 -- As a result of the charges and countercharges of fraudulent registration in Denver, trouble is Imminent between United States Marshal Dewey C. Bailey, on one hand, and the city, county, and State officers on the other.

Eduard Strauss, the Viennese conductor and composer, accompanied by his orchestra of fifty-two musicians, arrived in this city yesterday morning on the North German Lloyd liner Aller. They were received by Rudolph Aronson, who will conduct the tour of the orchestra through this country, and a number of friends and musicians.

What has been said in these columns in the editorial articles on "A Professor of Books" recalls an old and rather whimsical idea of the writer, namely, that it would be delightful to have in every circulating library a specialist who could fit books to people, as hats are fitted to faces. This official would need to combine much learning and wide reading with quick perceptions and a rare knowledge of human nature.

ITHACA, Oct. 19 -- Not since his visit to Ann Arbor and his running controversy with the boisterous opposition students has Mr. Bryan encountered similar interruption until to-day when he faced an Ithaca audience of some 6,000 or 7,000 persons, including a very considerable body of Cornell students, probably 400 of them, some for Bryan and others for McKinley.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Although exports of gold in the direction of Paris are causing some uneasiness the demand is not regarded seriously. Far more importance is attached to the recovery of New York exchange. Discounts were easy and improved the tone of the Stock Exchange, partly owing to the enhanced hope that money would be cheaper during the coming months than anticipated.

Yesterday was the third day of registration, the polling places opening at 7 A.M. and closing at 10 P.M. The enrollment of voters was without incident other than half a dozen arrests for illegal registration.

Miss Griscom continued her triumphant career yesterday in the women's tournament at the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N.J. She defeated. In the semifinal round for the Baltusrol Cup, Miss Margaret E. Curtis, the Essex County golfer from Boston, by 2 up and 1 to play.

Rumor mongers on Wall Street were busy yesterday with the affairs of the Chicago Union Traction Company, and one story had it that Gen. Samuel Thomas intended to apply for a receiver for the property. Some of the stories came from Chicago, which prompted Gen. Thomas to send to that city the following explicit denial of the receivership rumor:

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- An audience of 5,000 crowded the Second Regiment Armory to-night to listen to an address by ex-Senator David B. Hill of New York. A great number of people were unable to get into the armory, and for their benefit, several outdoor speeches were made by local orators.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Union Traction this morning recovered practically all the ground lost in the last two days. The common opened at 10 1/2 and closed at 12 1/4; the preferred advanced from 47 at the opening to 49 1/4 at the close. The scare occasioned by the report that receivership proceedings were pending has died out, and traders who went short of the stock on that story, proceeded to take in their lines.

There was a time, of course, when the primacy of Boston as the greatest letter-writing city, per capita, in the Union, would have been accepted as evidence of the higher culture of her people and the greater elegance of her civilization. That time, we suppose, must have been more than a hundred years ago, possibly two hundred.

Not since last year has the outside market had a day as active or as interesting as yesterday. Not only were a number of substantial advances recorded, giving evidence of the much-spoken-of strength of the market, but throughout the whole list transactions were on a scale much beyond any recent record.

John B. McMaster, author of." A History of the People of the United States," will begin in the November Century a series of papers on Daniel Webster. The opening installment, profusely illustrated with portraits, drawings, , will cover the "Thirty Years of Preparation" of this, perhaps, most typical American statesman of the nineteenth century.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 19 -- The principal theme of Gov. Roosevelt's speech here to-day was the Bryan meeting in New York last Tuesday night. He spoke as follows:
I.M. Bernstein has bought, through A. Rothmulle, from Clinton Ogilvie the plot on the south side of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 100 feet east of Lenox Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 19 -- Did H.J. Vandegrift, now a resident of Chicago, disguise himself by a process of facial surgery in order to deceive his wife and get an opportunity to kidnap their child? That is the question that is bothering the police of Omaha to-night.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- I am most sincerely sorry for Mr. Morley Roberts. Like most men who are familiar with his writings, I greatly admired their virile force and their wonderfully vivid descriptive passages, and anticipated a brilliant future for him as a novelist. But alas! Mr. Roberts has contracted the mauntain-climbing habit, and we all know what that means.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The message of the Chinese Emperor to the President urging early negotiations for a settlement, and the President's reply thereto, were made public to-day as follows:

It is getting to be almost a trite saying that the world is shrinking with the rapidity of communication and the exploration and occupation of the places formerly unknown and savage, and various are the speculations as to the effect thereof on the mind and the destiny of man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Gen. Fitzhugh Lee visited the White House to-day to talk over Cuban matters with the President. In speaking of the yellow fever epidemic, Gen. Lee said it was the worst in his experience.

The new St. Adelbert's Roman Catholic Church, on East One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, near Elton Avenue, in the Bronx, will be dedicated to-morrow by Bishop Farley. A high mass will be celebrated at 11 o'clock. The dedication sermon will be preached by the Rev. James Dougherty of the mission of the Immaculate Conception.

The American Ice Company, known as the Ice Trust, was attacked at a meeting of the Dock Board yesterday. The Tammany officials who are stockholders in the company also came in for severe criticism from James Jackson, President of the Manhattan Ice Company.

The popularity of the free lectures to the people given under the auspices of the Department of Education of this city was long ago demonstrated. Begun as they were experimentally as long ago as 1888, when the lectures were given in only six places, they have been gradually extended until last year the lecture centres numbered fiftyone, and the attendance reached the enormous total of 538,084.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- This evening the Right Rev. Bishop Fowler of Buffalo spoke to a great assemblage in the Auditorium, under the auspices of the Marquette Club, on "Lincoln and McKinley." The Bishop spoke for two hours, holding the close attention of his hearers. At times the applause was tremendous.
DUNKIRK, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Lieut Gov. Woodruff addressed a crowd of 5,000 persons at the double barbecue in Fredonia this afternoon.

Wall Street has been witnessing some exceptionally sensational manipulation. Net changes for the week make a long list of increases, and some of the advances have been substantial. Practically every group of securities on the Stock Exchange has been made to look strong, and representatives of every group have risen in price.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Cornell had difficulty in defeating Union to-day, and in two twenty-minute halves scored but 11 points. The game was loosely played throughout, and many costly fumbles were made by Cornell. It was essentially a kicking game. Paige was fully equal to Coffin, who did the punting for Cornell, Cornell scored in the first just after Coffin had kicked the ball, which went to Union's five-yard line.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The newly organized Hunt Club, which has located at Goshen, and of which John R. Townsend and E.H. Harriman are the leading spirits, will hold its first meet on Wednesday, Oct. 24, at the Kennels, Richardson Farm, one mile from Goshen, Orange County. The Monmouth County Hounds will ride with the Goshen followers of the hunt.

The life of Thomas Conroy, a Norwich (Conn.) man, was saved at Bellevue Hospital yesterday by the quick wit of Dr. Christian of the surgical staff, who, with a penknife, cut the throat of the patient, suffocating from a piece of meat that was pressing on the trachea, and relieved him. Dr. Christian has shown his skill in surgery on a number of occasions by saving life with impromptu surgical instruments.

Dr. Henry Moreton, for nearly three-quarters of a century a resident of the old Fourteenth Ward of this city, was found dead in his drug store, 233 Centre Street, late yesterday afternoon. Dr. Moreton was ninety-three years old, and was a familiar figure in that, part of the city in which he lived.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The official mail from Manila contains records of cases of murder and other crimes committed by natives of the Philippines and tried before military commissions. A majority of the prisoners were sentenced to be hanged, but with one exception the reviewing authorities, either Gen. MacArthur or Gen. Bates, commuted tie sentences to a long imprisonment at hard labor varying from ten years to imprisonment for life.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Chicago University is in mourning to-night. Eleven football men from Providence, battling for the honor of Brown University, showed Stagg's Maroons that revenge is a sweet morsel and trounced them by a score of 11 to 6.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Col. W.J. Bryan finished his four days' tour of New York at Buffalo to-night. In those four days he has traveled, through twenty-five counties and made sixty-four speeches. At the close of the trip he is in as good physical condition as when he started, and, so far from being fatigued is he, that he looks forward with eagerness to a resumption on Monday of his quest for votes.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- Murder is the charge on which Charles R. Eastman, instructor of zoology at Harvard University, was arrested at the Parker House to-night. This action was ordered by the Middlesex County Grand Jury, which to-day finished its Fall sitting. An indictment bill was returned against Prof. Eastman, whereupon capias was issued for his arrest.

The most attractive cover made for a punchbowl stand is of heavy gray Russian crash, edged with heavy lace, and with a pattern of grapes and leaves upon it. There is a delicate scallop around the edge embroidered in a light-green silk, and a simple pattern of the grape is in each corner.

Major Gen. Leonard Wood, Governor General of Cuba, arrived yesterday on the Ward Line steamship Yucatan, from Havana. He left this city for Washington at 1 o'clock P.M., and will return to Cuba by way of Florida some time this week.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The General Passenger Agents are preparing to drive ticket brokers out of business in Chicago without the aid of the much-desired national anti-scalping law.

The football games of the past week made some decided changes in the relative standing of the principal college teams. Pennsylvania, which had the highest aggregate score the week before, gives place to Yale, whose sturdy players managed to add 68 points to their score during the week, raising the total to 214, with a clean sheet on the debit side.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill addressed more than 4,000 people at Music Hall to-night. Judge H.D. Peck presided. When ex-Senator Hill was introduced he received a welcome of cheers that continued several minutes.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- With the competition of two races at the old Saugus track this afternoon, the regular season's racing in the New England Trotting Circuit was brought to a close. The summaries:
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- "I believe," said Emperor William recently, "that it is to Germany's advantage for Great Britain to have the Boer Republics."

The wool of the pure native Shetland sheep is generally compared to merino on account of its fine texture. Like the Shetland pony, the pure Shetland sheep is a small and very active creature, often to be seen moving with the swiftness and agility of a goat or chamois among the cliffs and crags of the shore.
A California paper says that the men who live on the ranges are notable for their remarkably retentive memories.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Chairman J.K. Jones of the Democratic National Committee, has issued a statement replying to the references by Gov. Roosevelt and others to the American Cotton Company, of which Senator. Jones is an officer, and which, it is charged, is a trust.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 20 -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers practically admitted to-day that even if every operator in the region were to post notices similar to those that are now being tacked up by some of the mine owners, it is probable that this action would not in itself end the strike.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Linseed was in big demand on the local Exchange to-day. The common opened at 10 1/2, sold to 11 3/8, and closed at 11 1/8. The preferred opened at 52 1/2 and closed at 53 1/4. The general market was quiet but firm. Biscuit common opened and closed at 34 1/8, but sold down to 34, and there was some demand for Union Traction common at 12.
Treaevant Cochran of Dallas, Texas, have been appointed general agents of the Pennsylvania Fire Insurance Company for Arkansas and Texas.
Uriah H. Painter died yesterday at West End, N.J.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 20 -- Gov. Sayers has issued a statement of all moneys received and expended by him for the benefit of the sufferers from the storm on the Texas coast, up to and including Sept. 30. He is to issue a supplemental statement showing the cash received since that date, with an itemized report of expenditures.

Indoor rifle shooting in the National Guard this season will no doubt excite more interest than ever before, and in every organization equipped with a range, armory marksmanship is to be developed in every possible manner. This applies not only to the crack shots, but to the new recruits and less skilled members.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- The commemoration day exercises of the one hundred and fifty-fourth year of the founding of Princeton University were held in Alexander Hall this morning. The Board of Trustees and Faculty, led by President Patton, Secretary of State John Hay, and Bishop Henry Yates Satterlee of Washington, marched in a body to the hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The State Department has received a dispatch from the Consul at Che-Foo, under date of Sept. 9, transmitting an account, based on apparently trustworthy information from a Chinese source, of the massacres of missionaries in Shan-Si Province.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Money, throughout the week, has been abundant, and it was difficult some days to find day-to-day borrowers at 1 1/2 per cent. With floating money worth less than in New York, Paris, and Berlin, with the open market rate of discount below New York and Berlin, and with New York not appreciably higher than Paris, further gold shipments, The Statist thinks, are probable.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Harvard defeated the cadets by a score of 20 to 0 in two twenty-minute halves this afternoon. It was thought the soldiers would make a better showing against the Crimson team, and the disappointment here to-night is great. Harvard was the cadets' superior in weight and strength.

The United Real Estate Owners' Association, which is composed of various taxpayers' and property owners' associations throughout the city, has adopted resolutions embodying recommendations to be made to the Charter Revision Commission.

On the top floor of a squalid tenement at 8 Caroline Street, in a dingy room containing a stove, a table, and two careless little rays of sunshine in the shape "of a little boy and a tiny blue-eyed girl, a young woman was found yesterday pondering over her case of desertion and starvation. She was Margaret Murphy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The omission of Alexander Hamilton's name from the list of Americans worthy to be enrolled in the Hall of Fame is a strange thing even stranger than the feeling which is indicated by placing Thomas Jefferson below Daniel Webster in the list of votes cast.

Louis Alguis, an Italian who was wanted for passing counterfeit bills, as alleged, and who made a sensational escape two years ago, was arrested Friday night by Secret Service Agents Henry and Burke, acting under the instructions of Chief Hazen of the Secret Service Department here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days when we hear so much flippant talk about the bimetallic or double standard of money, it is quite natural and commendable for conscientious inquirers to look into the merits of the issue and, incidentally, to find out, if they can, the roal meaning of the term standard.

A large collection of succulent plants were shipped from Paris yesterday to the New York Botanical Garden as the first results of the trip abroad of Dr. N.L., Britton, Director in Chief of the garden. Dr. Britton has been abroad for some time, being a representative of the garden at the International Botanical Congress in Paris, as well as an accredited delegate from the United States.

The enrollment of voters in New York City was completed yesterday, the fourth day of registration, and the figures returned from the election districts in the five boroughs show a large increase in the number of voters who have qualified, as compared with the elections of 1896, 1897, 1898, and 1899.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 20. -- There was a lively fight here to-day, when Charles B. Jones attempted to register. Treadwell B. Kellum, a Democratic Inspector, challenged Jones. It is alleged that John A. Cormack, a New York business man, interfered and attacked the Inspector. Kellum defended himself, and, with the assistance of a man named Weeks, pushed Cormack and Jones into the street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The latest of the innumerable complications that have come up in the last weeks of the campaign is the attitude of the Quakers in Indiana.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- Judge Harmon, who supported Palmer and Buckner four years ago, declared himself to-day for Bryan.

From The Century. Dr. Crawford, my amiable Baptist host, who, with his wife, has been residing in China for nearly half a century, explained to me why missionaries were compelled to abandon our Western dress. When he first came to China to preach the Gospel he considered it hardly compatible with the dignity of an American citizen to wear a pigtail and felt slippers.

"Speaking of snakes," said a mining engineer, "I do not think there is a spot on the face of this earth to equal Dutch Guiana in that respect. There they have large snakes and small snakes, red snakes and green snakes, amber-colored snakes and golden snakes, snakes harmless and snakes deadly, round-headed snakes and flat-headed snakes, and snakes ranging through the entire list of colors from mud gray to striped orange and red.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct 20 -- Gov. Roosevelt spoke here to-night to as many people as could get within the range of his voice. He addressed two meetings, one outside, the other inside of Music Hall, the largest auditorium in the city, and everything he Bald met with enthusiastic applause.

James Jackson, President of the Manhattan Ice Company, said yesterday that his lawyers had already begun preparations to institute mandamus proceedings against the Dock Board in order to make the board show cause why it has not granted to the company certain dock privileges which have been applied for.

Ten candidates for President and Vice President will be voted for Nov. 6. Ballots will not be cast for all of them in all the States, but the ten parties will be represented at the polls in most of them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the various letters on the "Prevention of Consumption" published in your columns. While it is extremely gratifying to notice the interest displayed in the prevention and elimination of this dreadful scourge, yet I would like to raise a warning voice against some of the measures advocated.

CREEDMOOR, Oct. 20 -- The regular supplementary practice of the season was held here to-day for the marksmen and sharpshooter classes. The attendance was large, as it was the last day this season for the marksmen and sharpshooters. Next Saturday will be for experts only. A light 6 o'clock wind was blowing.

All sorts of pretty, funny, and odd ornaments are ready for the tables of the Fall and Winter feast givers, and beginning with Halloween there will be something appropriate for each season until Lent closes the Winter's dissipation. It is not the woman who has the most money, but the one who can make her guests "take notice," who is the most attractive hostess.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Census Bureau has made public the return of population in Alabama.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Wesleyan was simply outplayed in to-day's football game and Yale won by the score of 38 to 0. The game gave Yale her first real scare of the season, as the Wesleyan boys planted the ball on Yale's ten-yard line, it being the first time that any team has pushed the ball back of the thirty-yard mark.
"Well, I'm blarsted! " exclaimed Cap'n Billy, as the skipper ended his yarn. "Bless me, if that ain't a good 'un."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Sept. 26 is a letter from the pen of Abram S. Hewitt to Mr. Schnitzer on the free-coinage issue. Any opinion from Mr. Hewitt on economic problems comes over to us with much authority, but I think economists on this side of the sea would be inclined to rub their eyes over the recrudescence of the "fifty-cent-dollar" theory.

B.B. Odell, Jr. the Republican candidate for Governor, came down from Newburg yesterday and denounced as a "base and clumsy forgery" the letter given out by Chairman McGuire of the Democratic State Committee, and purporting to have been written by Mr, Odell to a Republican in the State, whom he thought he could trust.

That agreement between Germany and Great Britain has an international interest, of course. But it may be questioned whether it has any great international importance. On the face of it, it is a "self-denying ordinance," ostensibly aimed at Russia. But Russia has already disclaimed her intention of acquiring Chinese territory.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Oct. 20 -- A large and enthusiastic audience packed the Opera House to-night to listen to the address delivered by George Fred Williams of Massachusetts. J.D. Sullivan acted as Chairman of the meeting, and, after speeches by local orators, introduced Mr. Williams, who held the attention of the audience until a late hour.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Charles Dudley Warner died suddenly this afternoon. He had a very severe attack of pneumonia two years ago while in New Orleans, and had never fully recovered from it. Last Spring he contracted pneumonia again while at his home, and this weakened his heart.

The Boers seem not to know or to like to tell the truth, for they lie to one another, are lied to by their leaders, and are all but fattened with lies by their newspaper organs. It is a condition so extraordinary that I cannot comprehend it, though every one of us in South Africa knows it to be true.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- Count von Bulow will retain the Foreign Office portfolio as well as hold the Chancellorship, like the late Prince Bismarck.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The latest and most important project on foot in England is the construction of a canal from Southampton to London. The surmise as to the farreaching consequences such a step would entail is scarcely less interesting than the fact that, if it is accomplished, it is likely to be through the instrumentality of American capital.

HAVANA, Oct. 20 -- The yellow fever situation is improving, Senor Gorgas said to-day there was no attempt to suppress information regarding the fever and that all American cases were reported for reasons of personal safety, as the best treatment was given at the hospital.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- The German Government thinks the Anglo-German agreement contains nothing to which the United States cannot subscribe, since the United States has steadily favored the "open door," the territorial integrity of China, and equal advantages to all the powers there.

From The Contemporary Review. While King Ferdinand II. was reviewing his troops at Naples on the 8th of December, 1856, one of the soldiers, a Neapolitan, named Agesilao Milano, darted from the ranks and inflicted a wound on his sovereign with a bayonet thrust. A few days after the attempt its author was sentenced to death, and executed.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Germany and Great Britain have formed an alliance to maintain the territorial integrity of China and to keep the ports open.

BANGOR, Me., Oct. 20 -- The second fatal shooting accident of the game season in the Maine woods occurred at Nahmakanta Lake Thursday, when W.L. Pond of Torringford, Conn., was instantly killed by his companion, Willey M. Latimer of Torringford, who mistook him for a deer. He died almost instantly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The argument in your editorial article of Saturday entitled "Tenement House Reform," advocating restrictions upon the building of houses for occupancy by more than one family, was answered by Herbert Spencer many years ago. In "The Man versus the State," (Page 342 of Appleton's edition "Social Statics,") Mr. Spencer says:

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 20 -- Senator Hanna concluded his six days' speaking tour of Minnesota, South Dakota, and Nebraska in Omaha to-night, winding up his itinerary by making four speeches, three in South Omaha, and one at Omaha.

From Ainslie's. About two years ago a party of three women and two men were crossing North Park in a wagon in the month of February. The air was bitterly cold, but dry as a bone and motionless. The sun shone with almost startling brilliancy. As the five people drove along over the crisp snow they did not experience the least cold, but really felt most comfortable, and rather enjoyed the trip.

The word "dude," as applied to a fop or exquisite, came suddenly into use about 1882-3, and all that we learn from the dictionaries is that its actual origin is not recorded. The Century Dictionary says that it "perhaps originated in London, England," while the New English Dictionary expresses the more general belief that it came into vogue in New York about the beginning of 1883.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The last month in the Presidential campaign opened with a few people left indoubt as to how to cast their ballot. Being one of the few in such a dilemma, I beg to state my reasons for at last deciding why I will support William McKinley at the polls on election day.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Samuel Untermyer, President Guggenheimer's law partner, who resides at Greystone, the former residence of Samuel J. Tilden, drives to the station every day behind a pair of fast horses.

DISTRIBUTION OF MONEYS RECOVERED FOR DEATH CAUSED BY WRONGFUL ACT. -- Ada May Snedeker, as administratrix of her husband, Charles Snedeker, recovered judgment against George Malcom for $5,771,95 for his death, which was caused by Malcom's negligence. The dead man having left no children, his father, Thomas H. Snedeker, instituted proceedings in the Surrogate's Court of Kings County to compel the widow as administratrix to pay over to him one-half of the judgment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Prof. Oscar Lovell Triggs of the University of Chicago, who made the startling comparison that the genius of Rockefeller was equal to the genius of Shakespeare, has found himself snowed under by a storm of protests from Shakespearean clubs and admirers over all the country.

Twenty-six American race horses yesterday sailed on the Atlantic transport liner Minnehaha for England, where they will campaign until the millionaire owners of twenty-five of them decide to recall them to the United States. The equine voyagers were first-cabin passengers in every sense of the term, so far as the choice of accommodations on a big cattle ship is concerned.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- The Faculty of Yale College this morning announced the list of men in the junior class who have maintained a Phi Beta Kappa rank throughout the first two years of the curriculum. The class has thirty men in the two divisions -- fifteen in the highest attainable grade, the philosophical oration group, and fifteen in the high oration group, as the divisions are known.

The pawnbroker was in a loquacious mood. Usually the man who does business under the sign of the three balls is frigidly cola and as uncommunicative as a clam. But this one, a quaint old fellow, was different, and he talked doubtless because he knew the customer who tarried to chat, by virtue of the young man having pawned the same watch at exactly two months intervals for the past three years.

Major William B. Schofield, additional Paymaster United States Volunteers, will proceed to Peking as soon after Nov. 1 as the Chief Paymaster, Division of the Philippines, can supply him with funds, and report to the commanding General of the United States forces in China, for duty.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Most of the morning, papers fail to comment upon the Anglo-German agreement, but two or three which refer to the matter editorially express unbounded satisfaction with it. The Sunday Special, under the heading "Good Tidings of Great Joy," says:

From The Spectator. Li-Hung-Chang says, "Prohibit missionaries," and a great many statesmen in Europe, as well as a large number of Anglo-Chinese, are ready to accept his advice. It is, however, utterly unreasonable advice if every other kind of business and teaching is to be admitted into China, and it will never be adopted.

"It seems to have been a case pf better late than never with the Sheriff over on Long Island, who has finally put a stop to that outrageous exhibition being given by a woman, who was apparently being spurred on to see just how far she could ride a bicycle before falling exhausted from her wheel," said a bicycle manufacturer, head of one of the largest firms in the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly allow me to publicly testify to my constantly growing regard and respect for the late William H. Vanderbilt, for his thoroughly frank and honest independence, in his expression of opinion in regard to the citizens of this great Commonwealth -- "The public be -- " -- well, every one knows it.
PARTS, Oct. 9 -- The return to Europe of the last remnants of the ill-fated Voulet-Chanoine African mission will recall public attention to the "drama of Linder," as it is called in France.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 20 -- The past season of the Newport Casino corporation has been the most prosperous financially in its history. The Governors have voted to retire two second mortgage bonds valued at $1,000 each. During the past Summer they have expended $1,000 for electric lighting and $2,000 for other improvements and repairs and still they are able to retire these two bonds.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The first Democratic mass meeting of the campaign in this place was held in the Opera House this evening. The speaker was John B. Stanchfield, Democratic nominee for Governor, The house was filled to overflowing.

BUFFALO, Oct. 20. -- Mr. Bryan awoke in his private car this morning, the morning of the last day of his campaign tour in the State, on a siding at Elmira. A hoar frost whitened the face of nature; the touch of Fall was keener than it had yet been. Early-morning Elmirans stood at the sidewalk edge, opposite the Rambler, as if expecting to see Mr. Bryan.

There are twenty-five Republican politicians who yearly sacrifice themselves as candidates for Assembly without hope of election or reward. These men are named to run against Democratic candidates in districts in which the Tammany vote is overwhelming. They accept these nominations from Republican conventions with all seriousness.

Both roses as well as lilies were great favorites in the Middle Ages. They figure together in the accounts of the Royal Garden at Westminster in 1276. The annual rendering of a rose was one of the well recognized forms of quit rent in the olden times. They were also the commonest of all flowers for weaving into wreaths and garlands.

For the last day of the Morris Park Fall races, which ended yesterday, the largest crowd of the meeting turned out, in anticipation of a second contest between Ethelbert and the great old mare Imp. The disappointment was correspondingly great when early in the day Imp's name appeared on the notice board as among the nonstarters.

EASTON, Oct. 20 -- Princeton expected a hard game with Lafayette to-day, but the most skeptical Princetonian felt sure that his team would win by more than five points, but it was not to be, and the final score stood Princeton, 5; Lafayette, 0.

Ten days have passed since word was first cabled from England that Sir Thomas Lipton had once more challenged for the America's Cup, and yachtsmen, even members of the New York Yacht Club, are still asking one another the question: "Who is going to own the new defender?"

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Hillis, discussing "Vice in New York," says that conditions in our metropolis remind him of imperial Rome. It seems to me that no student of history can fail to be similarly reminded, and that no real patriot can escape alarm at some tendencies in American "progress." This morning's TIMES tells the tale so that he who runs may read it.

Antranig Azhderim, an Armenian, the author of several books on life in Armenia and a lecturer on Armenian subjects in the public schools of this city, who was arrested for mutilating a book in the Lenox Library on Friday, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday before Magistrate Deuel.

Considerable excitement was caused among the passengers on the Lexington Avenue line of the elevated railroad, at Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, by the blowing out of a motor box of Car 272 of the line. The self-possession of a brakeman prevented more serious results.

Higher prices again ruled on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The professional operators working for the rise continued their efforts in that direction, and, aided by some outside buying, induced by the continuing strength of the market, had little difficulty in lifting quotations. Generally, all the developments of the day were on the side of betterment.

Edward N. Gibbs, Treasurer of the New York Life Insurance Company and prominent in financial circles in the East, died at his residence, at 277 Madison Avenue, yesterday from heart trouble.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Society folk in Westchester County were out in full force to-night to attend the housewarming given by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Harriman, Jr., at their new residence, Ophir Cott, between White Plains and Purchase. The affair took the form of a dinner dance.

WATERLOO, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- To-morrow afternoon the F tenor bell of the new St. Mary's Church will be blessed with public ceremony. In the absence of Bishop McQuade, who is now in Europe, the ceremonies will be conducted by the Rev. Thomas S. Hickey of Rochester, Vicar General of this diocese.

THH POLITICAL, OUTLOOK IN ROUMANIA. -- Since the combined strenuous efforts of Austria and Russia have caused the withdrawal at Bulgarian troops from the Bulgarian-Roumanian frontier, the Government in Sofia has set out to reorganise the infantry arm of the service, while that in Bucharest is concerning itself with the economic questions which will come before the Chamber, convoked for an extraordinary session this week.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- There was an interesting team match on the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club at Noroton this afternoon between the home club and the Fox Hills Golf Club of Staten Island. The visitors won by the score of 16 to 10. Following are the scores:

Miss Frances C. Griscom, Miss Elsa, Hurlbut, and Miss Marie J. Bryce were the winners yesterday of the three trophies of the Baltusrol Golf Club's open tournament for women. The final rounds of this most successful tournament in the history of the club drew a large and early morning gallery to the links near Short Hills, N.J., and the visitors were rewarded by some excellent and exciting golf.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- New motorpaced records for the hour, for forty miles, and from four to forty miles inclusive, with the exception of the twenty-sixth, twenty-seventh, twenty-eighth, twenty-ninth, and thirtieth miles, were created by William Stinson of Cambridge on the Shoe City Oval this afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- The report of the special Commissioner of citizens appointed to investigate the condition of the elm trees of the city has just been handed in.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Money was plentiful to-day, but there was a small demand. Discounts were weak in spite of the gold withdrawals for France. It is suggested the gold is intended to meet America's requirements in Paris, but the renewed weakness in New York exchange checked dealings in three months' bills at recent rates.

Peter Kiernan, a cabman employed by the New York Cab Company, was engaged Friday evening to drive a middle-aged woman from the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry slip to the Holland House. As he turned the corner from Fifth Avenue to drive to the side entrance of the hotel, he met ''Toie" Hart of 167 East Thirty-third Street, driving toward Fifth Avenue, with a light runabout, to which was hitched a trotter.

Mrs. Annie Walsh and her two young children were dragged from East Chester Creek in an unconscious condition yesterday. The children had fallen into the creek, which is little better than an open sewer, leading from Mount Vernon to Long Island Sound, and the mother had plunged into the muddy waters in a frantic effort to save them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Perhaps the apathy which characterized this campaign until a few days ago is accountable for the fact that this is the poorest year for campaign songs since the civil war. Whatever the reason, it is the fact. Every campaign song which has been published is at the music department of the Congressional Library, and 1900 makes a very slim showing.

On the other hand, the Bryan students are furious, and swear all kinds of vengeance.

In the course of that defense, he exclaimed: "We draw the line between honest wealth and predatory."

A fire which might have been disastrous had it not been for automatic sprinklers and the quick work of an elevator man started yesterday morning in the six-story building at 62-64 Elizabeth Street and 146-150 Hester Street. The building is an old, ramshackle structure, and has narrow stairs and small windows.

Dr. William T. Jenkins of the Board of Health was among the passengers who arrived on the Cunard liner Umbria Saturday night. He has been in Great Britain since the latter part of August investigating the sanitary systems of that country. Among other cities, he visited Glasgow during the prevalence of the bubonic plague there.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Oct. 21 -- The private car Rambler, in which the Democratic Presidential candidate is making his tow of the country, arrived here at 8 o'clock to-night, but Mr. Bryan was not a passenger. It brought only the newspaper correspondents, who usually accompany Mr. Bryan.

MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The ninety-third annual meeting of the New York State Baptist Missionary Convention will be held in the First Baptist Church here on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday next. The President of the convention, the Rev. John B. Calvert, will preside.

Francis Le Baron Mayhew died yesterday in South Orange, N.J., after a long illness. He was born seventy-nine years ago in Mattapoisett, Mass. He received a collegiate education in his native place, and, coming to New York when a young man, engaged in the oil business, in which he continued until the time of his death.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 -- The three days' celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of Vanderbilt University began this morning with a sermon by Bishop E.R. Hendrix of Kansas City, Mo. In the afternoon Bishop R.K. Hargrove of this city delivered a memorial address.

A sensation was caused at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union by a statement made by James P. Archibald of the Paperhangers' Union to the effect that three paperhangers, including himself, who were earning $7 a day on an up-town building, were discharged on the threat of a strike in order that men might take their places who worked for $3 a day.

The parade of the Sixty-ninth Regiment yesterday in honor of their comrades who died in the Southern camps during the war with Spain attracted a big crowd to the vicinity of the armory, where the six bodies had been lying in state since Friday, and an even greater assemblage in and about St. Patrick's Cathedral, where the funeral services were held.

MANILA, Oct. 21 -- The Philippine Commission has passed a bill appropriating $475,000 gold for the payment of expenses incurred for the benefit of the insular government during October. The bill goes carefully into detail regarding the items of expenditure throughout the archipelago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bryan's speeches have convinced a good many old Democrats that they ought to vote for McKinley. This Populist, who has succeeded in obtaining the Democratic nomination, seems to be ignorant of the true principles of American freedom. "Liberty protected by law" is the American motto.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- The first game of the season in the Ohio Collegiate Football League was played yesterday. Kenyon College defeated Case School of Applied Science by the score of 10 to 6. The game was stubbornly contested, and contained a number of sensational plays.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The American anti-imperialist League issued an address tonight to "All Independent Voters in the United States", asking them to support William J. Bryan for President. The address is as follows:

To those persons who cherish the memory of BLAJNE as one of their most sacred recollections we apologize for directing attention, at what seems to be an appropriate time, to some, resemblances between BLAINE and BRYAN. BLAINE, like BRYAN, was an orator, and, like BRIAN, he fully appreciated his own power over multitudes of his fellow-citizens.

Curiosity and the desire to hear the old Strauss waltzes, interpreted by a Strauss filled the Metropolitan Opera House last evening to the lobbies. Large as the audience was, it received with a toleration that was far from enthusiastic the Nicolai, Mascagni, and Grieg numbers of the programme, which was as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- All the morning papers dilate upon the high importance of the Anglo-German agreement. The Daily Telegraph, which describes it as "the most remarkable success scored by British diplomacy since the Berlin treaty," says:

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- After working all day to discover the person responsible for the death of Jennie Besseheiter whose body was found beside the River Road in Bergen County on Friday, Detectives Taylor and Titus, it was said, may possibly make an arrest to-day. The name of the man they suspect could not be learned.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Word was received here to-day of the arrival in Paris of the young African explorer and engineer, William Stamps Cherry of Chicago. He comes direct from the Congo Free State.

Gov. Theodore Roosevelt arrived in Jersey City at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. He remained in his car until nearly 7 o'clock, When, with W. Curtis Guild of Boston, he boarded a Pennsylvania Railroad ferryboat and disembarked at West Twenty-third Street. There the Governor and Mr. Guild entered a carriage and were driven to the Union League Club, where they were soon joind by Gen. Francis V. Greene, President of the Republican County Committee.

The minority of white persons who have undertaken to govern the Territory of Hawaii as they are convinced it should be governed are unquestionably deeply concerned over the prospect that the native Hawaiian shall "come to his own" and possibly prove his aptitude for political development under Republican protection by electing a native Legislature and sending a Delegate to Congress who is at least preferred by the natives if he be not a pure Hawaiian.

Prof. Adler yesterday delivered his first lecture this season before the Society of Ethical Culture at Carnegie Hall. He announced as his subject, "The Conflict Between Moral and Immoral Forces at the End of the Nineteenth Century," and, taking as object lessons the conduct of the Western powers in China, he severely condemned the ethical standards which permitted of such a course of procedure on the part of the "standard bearers of modern civilization."

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Jose Mercandino has returned here from Italy, and tells the story of the disappearance of Luigi Grannotti, who was Treasurer of La Questtone Sociale, the anarchist organ in this city, and who is charged with being an accomplice of Bresci, in the plot to murder King Humbert.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 21 -- As a result of a fire which broke out in the slaughtering pen of A.V. Hinman Co.'s packing house, at the Minnesota Transfer shortly after midnight last night, five firemen are dead and several others injured and property to the amount of about $450,000 destroyed.

"Of course the order of the Superintendent of the Naval Academy prohibiting hazing is a good and a sensible order, and one that all men will approve of. I am glad it was not issued before I went to the academy, however," remarked one of the officers of the navy, who is stopping at the Grand Hotel.

The following is a list of bonds which do not appear in their proper alphabetical order in the "Complete Bond Quotation List" on Pages 4 and 5, but are here so arranged. Opposite each is placed the name of the system under which they are given in the table referred to:
