NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- An escape which was one of the most daring in the history of jail breaking in New York State occurred at the Matteawan State Hospital for Criminal Insane this evening, when a force of twenty desperate criminals made an attack upon eight keepers of that institution, and after taking away their keys overcame all resistance and reached the yard which surrounds the asylum.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 21 -- Almost every locality in which fine horses exist has sent a contingent of high steppers to the sixth annual horse show that will begin here to-morrow and continue for a week. There will be over 300 thoroughbred animals, accompanied by some, of the best-known horsemen in the country.

-- Either because he has forgotten the storm which burst upon him when, in the course of the Spanish war, he criticised the food with which our soldiers were supplied, or else -- and this is more likely -- because storms have few terrors for him. Dr. Louis L. SEAMAN has contributed to The Medical Record an article in which he repeats, amplifies, and emphasizes all of his former accusations against the American Army ration.

Golf will be continued in the metropolitan district during the coming week with unabated activity. The women of the Morris County Club will have one of their busiest weeks of the season. The semi-annual championship will begin to-day on the club links, near Morristown, N.J., with an 18-hole qualifying round, and the eight players making the lowest scores will continue at match play, the final round coming Thursday.

Copyright, 1900, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The essential circumstances have not altered much in the money markets since I last wrote. We live in a very mixed atmosphere, where hope and fear alternately sway the mind. When your exchange threatened us with large exports of gold to New York we were all down in the dumps and saw a 5 per cent, rate immediately ahead.

New York City's electors, over 600,000 in number, are enrolled for the coming election. The registry books were closed at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, and the party managers are studying the returns. The increase in Manhattan and the Bronx and in Brooklyn over the registration of 1898 amounts to 60,782, and in the Boroughs of Queens and Richmond there is a substantial increase over the figures of 1898.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- A poll of the Faculty of Princeton University, made by The Newark Sunday Call, shows that there is not a professor, instructor, or other university officer who will express himself as willing to vote the Democratic ticket this Fall.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- There are indications that the demonstration here tomorrow in honor of the visit of Gov. Roosevelt, Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., and others, will be the occasion of the greatest turnout of Republicans seen on the Hudson River since the campaign of Garfield.
HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 21 -- When President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers was asked to-night what he had to say in regard to a settlement of the anthracite coal miners' strike, he said:

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Senators Hanna and Frye arrives here this afternoon from Omaha, Neb., where last night the concluding meetings were held of their week's touring of Minnesota, South Dakota, and Nebraska. Senator Hanna will devote most of the coming week to speechmaking in Chicago, with Joliet, Ill., and Milwaukee, Wis., also on his itinerary.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 21 -- Gov. Roosevelt spent to-day quietly, resting after his trip through the West. He received no visitors. His private secretary, William J. Youngs, had a conference with the Governor in the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The condition of ex-Secretary John Sherman showed a decided change for the worse yesterday, and it was not believed he would survive the night.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 21 -- The Commercial Gazette to-morrow will say:

Since Sir Thomas Lipton's challenge has given assurance that the year 1901 will witness another series of races for the America's Cup yachtsmen have resumed with new warmth discussion as to the advisability of abandoning the historic course off Sandy Hook for the more breezy neighborhood of Newport.

The full text of the decision of the Court of Appeals of this State in the case of MICHAEL J. COFFEY vs. The Democratic General Committee of Kings County is valuable for the clear and strong statement of the real intent of the body of laws governing primary elections.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Oct. 20, total transactions included 3,006,400 shares of stock, $12,100,400 bonds, including $11,500 Government and $18,900 State bonds.
"You had to make a choice between King Jesus and the Constitution of the United States, and you chose King Jesus."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- President William H. Baldwin, Jr., of the Long Island Railroad Company announced to-day, in referring to the intention of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to build two or three tunnel roads under New York Harbor and the East River, that the plans for these improvements have been completed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Capt. Chester's report on the reasons why the battleship Kentucky turned back to Tompkinsville yesterday has been made to the Ordnance Department, the only trouble having been with one of the guns. An ordnance officer, Lieut. Fenton, was sent by Admiral O'Neil, Chief of the Ordnance Bureau, to New York to look into the matter.

The Sound steamboat City of Lowell, which plies between here and New London, Conn., arrived in port yesterday morning with police signals flying, and when the vessel reached her pier, at the foot of Spring Street, three patrol wagonloads of negro passengers were taken from her to the Macdougal Street Station, charged with rioting during the passage from New London.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 21 -- The general belief here is that the coming week will see the wind up of the strike. The strikers do not admit this openly, but it is the feeling that the lock-out cannot be continued much longer. Both sides are expected to make concessions.

Bishop McFAUL of Trenton, whose article in The North American Review for September on "Catholics and American Citizenship" we noted at the time and regarded as extremely unfortunate, is answered in the October number by a clergyman of his own faith in a most forcible manner.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, who returned to Chicago yesterday from his campaigning trip through the Eastern States, in an interview to-day spoke enthusiastically of the Democratic activity in the States through which he had passed.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- In spite of very bad weather a large crowd assembled at the bicycle track in the Pare des Princes today to witness the match, over a course of twenty miles, between Floyd MacFarland, the American rider, and Jacquelin, in which the French rider was to make a most important attempt as a long-distance racer.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Louis Bailey of Poughkeepsie cut thirty-five minutes off the bicycle record between New York City and Albany to-day by making the distance in 11:10:00. The former record was 11:46:00, held by A.H. Achorn of the Century Bicycle Club of New York, and was only made recently.

Goodwill's Turf Guide, No. 13, containing indexed form tables and all turf records to the close of last week, has just been Issued. The latest volume includes all the dates that former issues of the useful volume embraced, and carries turf affairs in the East almost to the close of the Morris Park meeting.

The failure of the British third-class cruiser Psyche to fire the customary salute of twenty-one guns, that as a mark of international courtesy are fired by all foreign men-of-war when passing Governors Island, on entering New York Harbor, was the cause of much adverse criticism in army circles yesterday.

While a big out-door Tammany meeting was being held at First Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street last evening, the speaker was interrupted by the wild shrieks of pain and rage of a man who had just been stabbed by a jealous rival. The wounded man was Michael Carpiella, thirty-two years old, of Bridgeport, Conn., and his assailant was Louis Phillepele of 2,242 First Avenue.

Bitterly fought was the legal battle yesterday between State Senator Richard H. Mttchell, who is backed by Street Cleaning Commissioner Percival E. Nagle, and Joseph P. Hennessy, who has the support of Louis P. Haffen, as to who is entitled to the regular Democratic nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-first District, which is composed of the Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Assembly Districts.

When the Grand Central Station was opened, thirty years ago, there was a great deal of adulatory nonsense written and talked about it. And yet it was, for that time or any other, architecturally disgracefully bad, while as the engineering solution of a problem of traffic it was evidently a makeshift.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The police of this city are to-night as far as ever from clearing up the mystery surrounding the murder of Jennie Bosscheiter, the seventeen-year-old girl who met her death in a lonely road near the Passaic River late on Thursday night or early on Friday morning.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 22 -- Col. Alfred Waddell, candidate for the United States Senate to succeed Marion Butler, this morning announced his withdrawal from the race on account of illness in his family. The race is now between Democratic State Chairman Simmons and Gen. Julian S. Carr of Durham.

"All safe." Flashed under the sea from a West Indian port, this message came yesterday afternoon to gladden the hearts of three anxious families in Brooklyn. It told of the safety of four men, thought to have gone down to death in a cockle shell of a craft in a gale-lashed sea somewhere off the Jersey coast last Tuesday.

In the squad of thirty or more players that Coach Sanford of the Columbia, footbair team led out on Columbia Field for the daily practice yesterday afternoon, there was no trace of discouragement over Saturday's severe defeat at Philadelphia. Enthusiasm in prospect of the game which will be played against Yale next Saturday was as keen as though Pennsylvania had been the beaten team.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The Chicago Telephone Company announced to-day its decision to reduce from 10 to 5 cents the rate of service for pay station telephones. The work of installing the new five-cent slot telephones was also begun, and will be pushed to completion. The cut in the rate means an aggregate saving to patrons of $500,000, a year.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 22 -- Four of the insane convicts who escaped last night from the Matteawan Asylum were captured to-day and returned to the institution. This leaves three of the convicts still at large.

William T. Brown, Secretary-Treasurer of A.G. Spalding Brothers, and Frank Eveland, Secretary,-Treasurer of the Spalding -Bidwell Company, made a motor vehicle record of 152 miles in sixteen hours and ten minutes, riding from Springfield, Mass., to West Forty-second Street, New York.

An important move against Tammany men for illegal registration was made yesterday by Superintendent McCullagh in the arrest of five men charged with being colonizers. These men made confessions, and Mr. McCullagh applied for a warrant in the Centre Street Police Court for the arrest of Henry C. Honeck, Tammany candidate for Assembly in the Twentieth District, and the proprietor of a Raines law hotel at 244 East Twenty-eighth Street.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 22. -- Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn arrived in Omaha this morning in an exhausted condition as a result of five hours' frightful experience in a cloudburst. Mr. Meiklejohn narrowly escaped with his life, and lost all the personal effects which he carried with him at the time.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 22 -- President Mitchell in an interview to-night practically admitted that the anthracite coal miners' strike would end as soon as all the operators posted a notice guaranteeing the payment of a 10 per cent. advance in wages until April 1. President Mitchell said:

In response to an order of the Court of Appeals, the Democratic General Committee of Kings County met in the Jefferson Building, in Court Square, last night and reinstated Senator Michael J. Coffey as a member of that body. About two minutes after his reinstatement the Red Hook leader, through his friend, Warden Patrick Hayes, sprung a surprise upon the committee by resigning as a member.

One young lad of a party of four had a good, practical lesson on Sunday as to the advisability of behaving himself when on the public streets. The four were strolling along Arthur Avenue, in Bronx Borough, looking for a vent for that spirit of malicious mischief that possesses so many boys just getting into or approaching their teens.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- On the first day of his campaign tour in this Etate Gov. Roosevelt visited six places in Rockland, Orange, and Ulster Counties, and made nine short and long speeches, three of them at Kingston, where he rests for the night.

The anti-Tammany campaign for the election of a Mayor of the City of New York to succeed Robert A. Van Wyck is under way. Far-reaching preparations have already been made for the overthrow of Tammany Hall and Richard Croker. The work has progressed with the utmost secrecy, and the aim of the citizens interested in the movement has been to keep all news out of the public prints until after the election.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Gov. Roosevelt's arrival in Kingston was celebrated by a great throng, one of the largest that Kingston remembers. It was after dark, and the red-fire illuminations and the torches borne by clubs were displayed to the best advantage. A screaming crowd surrounded the Governor's car while he was still at dinner, and peered in at him with loud demands for him to appear.

The funeral of Frieda Cragle of 212 West Sixty-fifth Street, which was to have taken place yesterday morning from the Morgue, was stopped by the police under orders from Coroner's Physician Williams, who decided, after an autopsy, that in all probability a murder had been committed.

HINTON, West Va., Oct. 22 -- The line the Chesapeake Railroad traversing the picturesque vaileys of the Big Kanawha and New Rivers was the scene of Mr. Bryan's campaign to-day. Speeches were made at Huntington, Hurricane, St. Albans, Charleston, Brownston, East Bank, Montgomery, Sewell, Thurmond, and Hinton.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Chairman Jones of the Democratic National Committee said to-day:

POTTSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 22 -- John Wanamaker to-night made his first political address in two years. His speech here was the beginning of a brief tour in the interest of the candidates for the State Legislature who are opposed to the Quay wing of the Republican Party in this State.

The published results of this year's registration in the city were only slightly changed yesterday by tabulations made in Chief Devery's office at Police Headquarters. The figures received there are in no sense official, like those of Gen. Rodenbough, Superintendent of the Bureau of Elections, which will not tie in shape for publication for several days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The State Department to-day made public the correspondence which has taken place between itself and the French Government since receiving the original French note on China, which laid down the terms suggested by France as a basis of negotiation for a settlement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Don M. Dickinson of Michigan, who was Postmaster General in the Cabinet of President Cleveland, and who is still one of Mr. Cleveland's closest personal and political friends, has written the following letter to a gentleman in this city:

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- "With a view of retaining as much gold as possible in the country," says the Moscow correspondent of The Standard, "the Russian Government has relaxed the law in the direction of permitting free traffic in uncoined gold, a privilege formerly limited to registered mine owners.

All things favored the opening of the new Empire City race track to running horses yesterday, and a crowd that comfortably filled the grand stand was in attendance. Race-goers were immensely pleased with the new track when they reached it.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22. -- Exercises in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of Vanderbilt University were held to-day. Chancellor J.H. Kirkland delivered an address of welcome to the delegates from other colleges and universities and Chancellor R.B. Fulton of the University of Mississippi responded.

The Irish-American Union held a political mass meeting at Cooper Union last night. The meeting was in the interests of the Democratic National ticket. President McKinley, Gov. Roosevelt, and Queen Victoria came in for equal shares of hisses. Enthusiasm for Mr. Bryan whenever his name was mentioned reached fever heat.

The City of New York can now borrow money at 3.2 per cent. The City of Hamburg offers to pay 4.11 per cent, for the money it has to borrow. The Controller of New York has just borrowed $4,500,000 in this market. Bankers representing the City of Hamburg advertise here bonds of that city to the amount of 40,000,000 marks, equal to $9,520,000.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- This city, the home of Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, made a holiday occasion of the visit to-day of Gov. Roosevelt, the candidate for Vice President on the Republican National ticket. Col. Bryan had enjoyed a taste of Orange County hospitality last Wednesday.
No currency transfers through the United States Sub-Treasury in this city to Southern and Western points were made either yesterday or Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The public press announces a congress to assemble soon in Madrid of representatives of the Iberian race, and speculates on its objects, without definite conclusions.

The Meadowbrook Hunt will have its usual Tuesday meet and run on the Hempstead Plains to-day, and the Westchester hounds will meet on the grounds of Mrs. Jules Reynal, who is now at the Virginia Hot Springs. Mrs. Paul G. Thebaud, Mrs. Reynal's daughter, will give a hunt breakfast at her mother's house preceding the run.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- "Theodora," the Sardou play made famous by Bernhardt, was presented in English at the Boston Theatre to-night and introduced a new Theodora to the public, in the person of Mrs. Clarence M. Brune, who received a cordial reception.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 22 - John B. Stanchfield, Democratic candidate for Governor, has received the following telegram:

The market for outside securities yesterday opened strong and active, and throughout the day trading was on a large scale. The upward movement of prices that became marked on Friday was continued and many issues showed further net gains. But the market was not so uniformly strong as at the close of last week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- On the Exchange to-day Linseed again attracted the greatest attention. The common opened at 11 3/8, advanced to 11 5/8, and closed at 11 1/4; the preferred opened at 53 7/8, sold to 54, and closed at 53 3/4, after touching 53 1/2. There was, however, considerable profit taking on the way up, and at times this resulted in small set-backs.

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- The papers continue to discuss the question to-night. While most of them approve the agreement, the Russophile press, which means the Anglophobe section, expresses a fear that the coolness between Germany and Russia which arose recently, as evidenced by several incidents relating to Count von Waldersee, will be intensified by the agreement.
PANAMA, Colombia, Oct. 22 -- A dispatch to The Star and Herald from Guayaquil says the Ecuadorian Congress has made arrangements by which the country will pay its entire foreign debt.

A board of survey, to consist or Major Charles Shaler, Ordnance Department, is appointed to meet at Indianapolis Arsenal, Oct. 24, for the purpose of investigating, reporting upon, and fixing the responsibility for certain ordnance and ordnance stores for which Major Charles H. Noble, Twenty-fifth Infantry, is responsible.
The Episcopalians of the Milwaukee (Wis.) diocese favor strongly the appointment of a Coadjutor Bishop, as assistant to Bishop Isaac L. Nicholson.

EASTPORT, Me., Oct. 22 -- Three survivors, of the schooner Delma, which struck Muir Ledge, off Grand Manan Island, last Wednesday and went to pieces, reached here to-day, bringing news of the disaster and of the loss of one of the crew, John Carver, the cook.

The Kings County Grand Jury has taken up the matter of the epidemic of typhoid fever which has broken out in the Boys' Disciplinary Training School, at Parkville, Brooklyn. One of the young inmates of the institution has died from the fever, and there are now nine other cases of the disease in the school.
MADRID, Oct. 22 -- Gen. Azcarraga has succeeded in forming a Cabinet, with the following distribution of portfolios:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- John Hall, the famous '98 Yale end, arrives this afternoon and will remain for the week with the team. His coming was unexpected and was very welcome, as thus far no Yale end has returned to help the candidates, and the need of systematic and good coaching at the position is evident.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- It was authoritatively stated to-night that the United States Government views with distinct favor the principles enunciated in the Anglo-German agreement relating to China, and that a formal response to that effect will be made at an early date to the invitation extended to this Government to accept the principles of the agreement.

Frank J. Gould, who is now erecting a stable and riding ring on a plot extending through from Fifty-seventh to Fifty-eighth Street, just east of Broadway, has added another small parcel to his realty holdings at that point.

Col. BRYAN continues to repeat, in his recent speeches, the assaults upon the army calmly written into his letter of acceptance. A very brief examination of some easily ascertained particulars about the army, for the purpose of testing Col. BRYAN'S right to be considered honest in this matter, compels the conclusion that he is either woefully ignorant or willfully untruthful.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Gov. Roosevelt had his first reception and made his first speech to-day at West Nyack station. The reception was cordial, the crowd of 500 persons giving repeated cheers, while a cannon saluted and a lot of Rough Riders in khaki uniforms waved flags. Several men in uniform and on horseback were particularly enthusiastic at the back of the crowd.

About 15,000 miles were added from 1890 to 1900 to the trackage of the score of railways whose statistical comparisons have been recently presented in these columns. The incidental increase in capitalization has been tremendous -- ranging from about $15,000 to approximately $450,000 for each added mile.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 22 -- Robert Neal, President of the Waggoner National Bank of Vernon, has been succeeded in that position by Thomas Waggoner, who was elected several days ago. Mr. Neal's sudden departure from Vernon has been followed by a number of rumors.

It became known yesterday that the State Civil Service Board, through Chief Examiner Briscoe, is investigating the action of the Police Commissioners in what is termed by the board an evasion of the civil service laws by placing men in the Police Department in an acting capacity and keeping them there for years instead of promoting the men to the full possession of any office.

Despite a recommendation for industrious work from President Leo Schlesinger of the Mechanics and Traders' Bank, Philip Mayers, yesterday, in General Sessions, was found guilty of assault and had added to the sentences for burglary of nineteen and a half years he had previously served four years' imprisonment in Sing Sing for cutting Rose Bland on the arm a few weeks ago, slightly injuring her.

COLOMBA, Ceylon, Oct. 22 -- The statement that the Government of the United States has intervened with the view of the transferral of American Transvaal prisoners to a more salubrious climate has astounded Ceylon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Payne Thompson will close their cottage Nov. 1, and Mr. Thompson, who is in the West shooting, and Mrs. Thompson, who is now in Baltimore, will join each other at Westbury, L.I., where they will remain until late in the Fall, and then go to New York for the Winter.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The Tigers were put through a long, hard practice game with the scrub team this afternoon, during which the second team managed to score a touch-down and a goal from field before time was called, while the first team, either through stiffness resulting from the hard game with Lafayette on Saturday or a general "blue Monday" slump, could hardly make the necessary five yards in order to retain the ball.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Senator George F. Hoar, in The Worcester Gazette this afternoon, says this of John Sherman:

Henry. C. Honeck, the Assemblyman from the Twentieth District, who is a candidate for re-election, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday before Magistrate Deuel, charged with perjury, and with having aided and abetted in false registration. He gave $1,000 bail for examination on the perjury charge and was paroled in custody of his counsel, Stephen O'Hare, on the other charge.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Vice Chancellor Stevens gave a hearing to-day on an application made by John A. Effray to enjoin Mrs. Melanie Effray, his wife, from disposing of certain securities which he conveyed to her and now seeks to get back. Suit has been brought to recover these securities.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- With the Government disbursing much money from the Bank of England, there is no indication of a diminution of the floating supply thereby. The present abundance of money is considered artificial, necessitating caution, and, considering also the condition of foreign exchanges, it tends to check a rapid fall in rates.

When the British cruiser Psyche sailed away from here on Monday afternoon she left behind her a wave of indignation. Major Myer, Commandant on Governors Island, as was told in yesterday's TIMES, was upset because the cruiser disregarded all the rules of international etiquette by not firing a salute in passing his post. Dr. Doty and Dr. L'Hommedieu, Quarantine officials, were equally disgusted.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., was born in Syracuse and belongs to a family of bankers. His father was Cornelius L. Alvord, Sr., brother of the late Thomas F. Alvord, formerly Lieutenant Governor of the State.

"Speaking about hauling 'dead' locomotives across the country," said a Western railroad man, after reading the paragraph about them in this column on Monday," recalls to me a story about one of them that happened several years ago, when I was young in this business. A big engine was being hauled across the country for the Denver and Rio Grande Company from the Danforth works, in Paterson.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 23 -- The first hearing in the contest over the will of Edgar E. Duryea, the former head of the starch works at Glen Cove, was held before Surrogate Seaman here to-day. The will provides for legacies of $50,000 each to two of his daughters, Mrs. Marcia Spriggs and Mrs. Grace Spriggs, and $75,000 to another daughter, Mrs. Eva Thalberg.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 23 -- John W. Gates of Chicago and other holders of securities in the Guardian Trust Company made application in the Federal Court to-day for a receiver for the company and for an injunction to prevent a meeting of the stock-holders called for to-morrow to elect a new Board of Directors.

Plans and specifications for the new armory to be erected for the First Battery on the south side of Sixty-sixth Street, just east of Columbus Avenue, were submitted to the Building Department yesterday by Architects Horgan Slattery. The structure will be built of brick and granite and will cover a plot 175 by 100.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The mystery surrounding the murder of Jennie Bosscheiter, the seventeen-year-old girl who was found lying dead with a fractured skull In a lonely lane last Friday morning, was practically cleared up last night and to-day, the police investigations bringing to light one of the most revolting crimes ever committed in this State.

Henry D. Oliver of Buffalo, manager in that city of the International Paper Company, died suddenly in a north-bound Madison Avenue car at Forty-eighth Street last evening. According to Henry Leseler, the conductor, the man boarded the car at Forty-second Street. When the car was between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets the man fell from his seat to the floor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23. -- At military headquarters here it is stated that the first installment of the volunteer army now in the Philippines will leave Manila Nov. 1. From that time until next June the transports will bring home about 25,000 men at the rate of from 4,000 to 5,000 a month.

Control of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company changes. E.H. Harriman succeeds Collis P. Huntingdon. Mr. Harriman and his colleagues have taken over a majority of Pacific Mail capital stock. Identified with Mr. Harriman in this new big deal -- one of international significance -- is William K. Vanderbilt.

NORWICH, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- On the second day of his State tour, Gov. Roosevelt traveled in the Counties of Ulster, Delaware, Otsego, and Chenango, beginning at Kingston, in the first county, and ending at Norwich, in Chenango. In fourteen towns he made as many speeches. Most of these were delivered from the rear platform of his private car, and were brief.
NEWPORT, Oct. 23 -- Master Louis De Forest has returned to New York to resume his studies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23. -- In preparation for the Pennsylvania football game a week from Saturday Coach W.H. Lewis has begun to train the second eleven on the Pennsylvania guards' back formation. To-day Hallowell took an active part in the play for the first time since his injuries some weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- The new Russian battleship Retvizan was launched at Cramps' ship yard at 1:33 this afternoon. No wine was used at the naming, the Russian ceremony being observed. The Rev. Father Alexander A. Hotovisky, rector of the Russian Orthodox Church, of New York, officiated, assisted by two other priests Clad in the vestments of the Church.

The Democratic campaign managers conceived a plan a few flays ago to get Grover Cleveland to declare his political views in the present campaign. Mayor James K. McGuire of Syracuse, who is in charge of the Democratic State campaign, journeyed to Princeton on Monday on an affair of importance.

-- In the discussion, already bitter and tending inevitably to become more so, that has been excited by the selection of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE'S name for a place in the "Hall of Fame," among the very greatest of the Nation's heroes and benefactors, there is to be seen one of the many unfortunate results that not a few of us have anticipated ever since the curious scheme took definite shape.

It was announced at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon that the First National Bank, at the corner of Broadway and Wall Street, had been rotated to the extent of about $700,000 through the operations of a trusted employe.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- A high official of the German Foreign Office asserted this evening that Austria-Hungary and Italy have expressed their formal adherence to the Anglo-German agreement, but that France, Russia, and the United States have not defined their positions.

That was a significant complaint that the British Foreign Office "gave out" the other day, touching the mischief that was done in international affairs by premature publicity. Upon the surface it was quite just. One can readily understand how regularly trained diplomatists must look upon the irregular manner in which international affairs are allowed to be discussed, all over the world, "in town meeting."
Isaac Untermyer has sold the plot on the south side of One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 200 feet west of Lenox Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

Columbia's football substitutes were in fine fettle yesterday afternoon, and in a forty-minute practice game on Columbia Field scored by straight play against the 'Varsity eleven for the first time this season. Huffaker, the old Central University end, carried the ball over the 'Varsity goal line for the second eleven.
A cab containing three men drove up to the Hudson Street Hospital yesterday afternoon. One of the men, ran into the hospital and called to the clerk at the desk:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 -- The greeting extended to Mr. Bryan on his arrival here this evening and during the meetings held inside and outside of Music Hall was limited in numbers only by the capacity of the places in which the people gathered and in enthusiasm only by the ability of the immense crowds to give expression to it.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- There was little feature in the Boston market. Leading copper stocks yielded fractionally with the volume of business decreased an evidence of the strong undertone and prevailing bullishness of the market, activity only accompanying the upward movement. Sales were absorbed well to-day and confidence in further advances seemed to be widespread.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- In two sharp halves this afternoon the 'Varsity was able to score on the scrub team but once. It was very hard practice work, and the players were thoroughly tired out. Chadwick made the touch-down by a brilliant plunge through centre.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 23 -- Of recent years the education of the naval apprentice of the United States Navy has improved considerably. Heretofore an apprentice joined a receiving ship, and later was sent to the training station at Newport, where he received training fitting him for regular duty, and by the time he was twenty-one years old he was a full-fledged seaman apprentice and ready for the seaman gunner's class.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The polo tournament for the Lakewood and Ocean County Cups presented by George J. Gould was finished this afternoon, and Mr. Gould's team was the winner in both series. Somerset County, after winning from Great Neck and the Westchester County, came up to-day against Lakewood, and were beaten by the score of 14 1/2 to 10 goals.

Six games in the Bank Clerks' League tournament were bowled last night on Reid's alleys, Church Street, in which the teams of the bank of the Manhattan Company and the National Bank of the Republic carried off the honors, each winning both their matches. McNeil of the Manhattan Company team rolled two perfect games without a missed spare.

It is probable that the Brooklyn Disciplinary Training School for Boys at Parkville, which is in a dilapidated and unsanitary condition, and in which an epidemic of typhoid fever has broken out, will be abandoned by the city. Controller Bird S. Coler, who visited the school yesterday afternoon, told a NEW YORK TIMES reporter last night that he found the condition of the building about as bad as it could be.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The American jockeys opened the day at the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day in lively fashion, being placed five times in the first two races, the winner in each event being piloted by an American rider.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 23 -- Ex-President Harrison to-night addressed the convention of the American Public Health Association as follows:

Dr. Alfred Meyer read a paper before the Section of Medicine of the New York Academy, of Medicine last night on "The City and Its Consumptive Poor: A Plea for a Municipal Sanitarium Outside of the Corporate Limits."

At Wallack's Theatre last night, after the performance of "The Greatest Thing in the World," a queer dramatic composition by Mr. Israel Zangwill was presented by Mrs. Le Moyne and her company. This was cheerfully entitled "The Moment of Death," and was divided in three short episodes requiring altogether one-half hour in the performance.
The dance hall at 315 and 317 West Fifty-ninth Street, on which "Billy" McGrory, better known as McGlory, is said to be interested, was opened last night by the The Joe Burke Association.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew left Weehawken on a special train at 10 o'clock this morning on a speechmaking tour, which will last until Saturday. Accompanying the Senator are Seward A. Simonds of Buffalo, E.R. Gunby of Florida, and William A. Prendergast of Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was one of the speakers on "Democratic Day," 3d inst., at the Elmira Fair. Referring to Philippine matters, I mentioned two or three of the admitted cases of barbarity which had been committed by our troops, and expressly charged upon the Administration responsibility, not merely for the fact, but also for the character of the war waged against a weak people struggling to be free.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 23 -- The mystery surrounding the manner in which the outside brokers and commission men were able to secure quotations of the Chicago Board of Trade from Aug. 1 to Oct. 10 was dispelled to-day when the testimony of Chicago electricians and telegraph operators was filed in the United States court.
After the meeting of the Municipal Assembly yesterday President Guggenheimer said he was disgusted and that he would be glad when his term of office expired.

There is little going on in the social world of New York and its suburbs to-day, and there seems to be a lull in the suburban life which has been so lively of late. The Oceanic, due this morning, will be greeted by a number of well-known people, as she is to bring quite a contingent of prominent New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Senator Jones's charge puts in concrete form a story which has been hinted at a number of times. There have been many Democratic insinuations which led to a belief that some such story would be sprung shortly before election, but no one was prepared for the charge that Mr. Jones had himself raised the issue in a letter to the President, and that the latter had taken no notice of it.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 23 -- No attempt was made this morning to resume work at the Stanton washery of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, which was closed yesterday, following an attack on the men by a crowd of women and boys.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Opinions of Chicago bankers on the New York defalcation are as follows:

George W. Baylis, a lifelong resident of Huntington, L.I., died Monday afternoon at the residence of his brother, H.V. Baylis. Mr. Baylis was born in Sweet Hollow, near Millville, Aug. 31, 1831. He was married in 1875 to Elizabeth Sammis. Mrs. Baylis died in 1888. After her death Mr. Baylis lived a retired life, residing with his brother.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 23 -- Exercises in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of Vanderbilt University were continued to-day. In the morning members of the Faculty and Board of Trusts, students, and graduates of the university formed in procession on the grounds and proceeded to Gospel Tabernacle.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Harry Vardon defeated A.H. Findlay in a 36-hole match on the Hawthorn links to-day, 7 up. Vardon's score was 146, Findlay's 155.

NEWPORT, Oct. 23 -- The Republicans held their city convention this evening in the old State House, and nominated Frederick P. Garrettson, one of Newport's most prominent citizens, for Mayor. There was no opposition to the choice. Mr. Garrettson was until this year a Cleveland Democrat, but recently allied himelf with the Republican Party.

Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-footer, Rainbow, and August Belmont's Mineola may resail next season their race for the special cup offered by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, and lost to Rainbow by her recent disqualification as a result of Mr. Vanderbilt's statement that he had unwittingly violated the racing rules in taking additional ballast aboard his yacht.

The plot 60 by 100.5 on the south side of Fifty-second Stret, 180 feet east of Fifth Avenue, purchased last January from the Barney-Sheldon syndicate by Henry G. Trevor and George R. Schieffelin, has been resold by the latter to Flake Dowling. Mr. Dowling said yesterday that the plot would be improved with two, or possibly three, handsome dwellings.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The annual report of the United States Commissioner of Education for the fiscal year ended June 30 last gives the figures for the fiscal year 1898-99.

At the meeting of the Metaphysical League last night in the concert hall in Madison Square Garden, Bolton Hall caused a shock to go through the audience by declaring that some were using mental science as a means of lightening their consciences. "There is a wide discrepancy," he said, "between the cost of production and the price it brings, and we who have every luxury are living on that difference.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- John B. Stanchfield addressed a large meeting this evening in this city, the home of his rival, Mr. Odell. Among other things he said:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- It is reported that an explosion occurred at the Indian Head Proving Grounds about 11 o'clock to-night.

New Directors are to be elected by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Railway Company. Among these new Directors will be financiers representing two financial institutions in Brooklyn, an important New York trust company, and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company. In the Board of Directors of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company at present there are "dummy" Directors, who will make way for representatives of the company's new controllers.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 24 -- While no definite developments have taken place there are indications that baseball men are preparing for a possible renewal of the war threatened last year before the proposed new baseball association went into eclipse. Washington will be one of the strategic points should a fight occur.

A vote is an opinion and also a means to make that opinion effective. The right to vote is conferred by law upon certain persons or classes of persons who will be likely, in the judgment of the lawmakers, to exercise it for the public good. It is withheld from the great majority of citizens, minors and women, for instance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The population of the State of California was announced by the Census Bureau to-day.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 24 -- The Government has built a fifty-thousand-dollar schoolhouse for the Nett Lake Indians, but the latter refuse to allow their children to attend it because it was not built on their reservation. Major S.W. Campbell, the agent in charge of the Nett Lakers, returned to-day from a visit to the band, whom he tried to induce to withdraw their boycott, but without success.

ROME, Oct. 24 -- Prince Chigi, who was prosecuted by the Italian Government for selling a painting by Botticelli, which is now in London, was to-day ordered to pay, as a fine for violating the law against selling valuable works of art for exportation, the sum of 315,000 lire, ($63,000.) which is believed to have been the price paid for the picture.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 24 -- Harry Miller this afternoon bet H.T. Waters $2,500 even that McKinley carries Wisconsin by 75,000.

Another hearing in the case of Foreman James D. Clifford of the Attorney Street Hook and Ladder Company, No. 18, was had at Fire Headquarters yesterday. The charges, which were preferred by Chief Croker, grew out of Clifford's activity as a member and officer of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association.
Mr. ALVORD of the First National Bank was not only a nimble thief but a quick traveler.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The King of the Belgians, while riding in an auto-car yesterday in the Bois de Bologne, was pulled up by the police for exceeding the regulation speed. He was going at the rate of 50 kilometers an hour.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- John Sorrensen, a young Swede, was shot and killed last night by one of the sentinels on guard duty at Fort Hancock. Sorrensen was walking along the beach near the fort and was taken for a private who had escaped from the barracks while under arrest.

Contrary to general expectation, Attorney Frederick B. House offered no defense in the preliminary hearing of Albert T. Patrick and Charles F. Jones yesterday, charged with forging the late William Marsh Rice's signature to a twenty-five-thousand-dollar check.

It is announced that the French Chambers will convene Nov. 6. No more emphatic confirmation of the popular success of the exposition, no more significant sign of the strength of the Government and of confidence in itself, could be given than having the legislators assemble on the day after the great fair has been brought to a close.

Charles James Welch of San Francisco and Miss Elizabeth Kilsyth Livingston were married at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the private chapel of Archbishop Corrigan's residence, adjoining St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride had no attendants. She entered the chapel on the arm of her uncle, Van Brugh Livingston, who gave her away.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Copies have been received here of the British Blue Book on the uprising in China.
The $690,000 loss sustained by the First National Bank through its defaulting note teller, Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., was almost the sole topic of discussion in banking circles in this city yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- It seems likely, from negotiations which have been taking place in Paris, that France, Germany, and Austria will abolish the sugar bounties if other countries will abolish the import taxes.

Plans for the seven-story factory building, to be erected by Browning, King Co. at 376 to 386 Bowery, were filed at the Building Department yesterday by Architect John E. Nitchie. The cost of the structure has been estimated at $275,000. Richard Deeves Son, general contractors for the building, have removed the old structures on the site and are now preparing the new foundations.
MADRID, Oct. 24 -- The gold quotation to-day was 32.20.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- The disclosures made by the police of this city yesterday, following the arrest of Walter C. McAlister, George J. Kerr, William A. Death, and Andrew Campbell, who were lodged in jail charged with murdering Jennie Bosscheiter, were supplemented by other evidence to-day, furnishing details even more hideous than at first made public.

There is now being erected an the northwest corner of Tenth Avenue and Fiftieth Street a five-story building which will represent when completed and put to the, purposes for which it is intended, the first important step in philanthrophy of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., son of the Standard Oil capitalist, and himself a millionaire in his own right.
Therese N. Bowie received permission, in the Supreme Court yesterday to serve papers in her divorce proceedings against her husband, Hunter D. Bowie, by publication.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 -- An interesting feature of Mr. Bryan's campaign work to-day was his consideration at a meeting here to-night of a series of questions proposed by John P. Nields of this ctty. Mr. Nields had proposed a joint debate, but this Mr. Bryan would not agree to. The questions proposed by Mr. Nields were as follows:
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- At the second day of the Newmarket Houghton meeting, to-day, the race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes was won by J.C. Sullivan's four-year-old horse Berrill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Gen. Lieber, Judge Advocate General of the army, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, says there were 6,680 trials by general courts martial during the past fiscal year, of which number 35 were commissioned officers, (11 regulars and 24 volunteers,) 4 cadets, 6,618 enlisted men, (5,424 regulars and 1,194 volunteers,) and 23 civilians serving with the army.

Yesterday's market for outside securities showed a good deal of irregularity, but trading continued large and the day's total was probahly in excess of that of the first days of the week. Business was not, however, as well distributed as it was a few days ago, and by far the largest totals were recorded in the Chicago and Alton securities, all of which were very active.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Princeton supporters to-night are happier over the showing of the 'Varsity in practice to-day than they have been for a long time. In the absence of a scheduled game it was decided that the 'Varsity and a scrub should line up against each other as for a regular championship game.

Advancing quotations were the order on the stock market yesterday until shortly before the close, when profit-taking on rather a heavy scale brought about a reaction. This, however, was not material enough to offset, in a majority of cases, the earlier gains made; and hence it is that for the most part net advances appear in the general list.
The novelty of racing on the new Empire City track continued to be a good drawing card yesterday, and a crowd that comfortably filled the grand stand was in attendance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- T.P. Kane, the Acting Controller of file Currency, to-day gave out the following statement regarding the defalcation in the, First National Bank of New York:

The annual report of the Santa Fe, Prescott and Phoenix Railway shows that the year ending June 30, 1900, was the best in the road's history. President Murphy expresses satisfaction with the results, adding that the growth of new industries will prove of great benefit to the road. The construction of various branch lines is being seriously considered as a result of the present outlook.

Columbia's 'Varsity eleven played the best football seen on Columbia Field this season in the practice game against the substitutes yesterday afternoon. In less than twenty-five minutes of actual play four touchdowns were scored, and the ball was not in all that time rushed more than an aggregate of 15 yards by the second team.

ONEIDA, Oct. 24 -- Attorney General Davies, who joined the Roosevelt party here, says that the statement that Mayor Van Wyck in his answer on the alleged Ice Trust matter arraigns Republicans for being co-stockholders is absolutely without foundation.

Public improvements in every part of the city are being delayed because of the failure of the Municipal Assembly to approve bond Issues. Commissioner of Water Supply Dalton complains that ordinances for laying water mains have been held up in the Municipal Assembly in many instances over a year.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- At a large meeting held here to-night, Secretary Root delivered an extended address, dealing exhaustively with the campaign issues. He gave especial attention to the Philippine problem and to the charge of militarism, making public for the first time an order from Aguinaldo, dated last June, showing that his hope now is in Democratic success at the elections next month, and other documents not heretofore published.

John H. Cook was confronted yesterday morning in Capt. McClusky's office by twenty-five men and women who charged that he had swindled them. Later in the lay Cook was held in the Yorkville Court in $500 bail for examination. Cook was arrested on Monday night at the Hotel Jefferson in East Fifteenth Street by Detectives Kane and Byrne on a description sent out in a general alarm by the Central Office.

The arrival of the Oceanic, which brought over perhaps the longest and most notable list of passengers of any Atlantic liner this Autumn, was really the event of yesterday in town. Out of town the first meet and run of the newly organized Goshen hunt at Goshen, which was attended by the majority of the members of the Tuxedo colony, was the principal event.
Preparations for a political coup were made last evening at the Democratic Club. Richard Croker had charge of the arrangements.
SALISBURY, Md., Oct. 24 -- While Mr. Bryan was speaking to-day at Preston, one of the seven Maryland towns to which he devoted his forenoon, somebody in his audience shouted:

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 24 -- "Will" Stinson of Cambridge, the bicycle rider, is at the Shoe City Oval this week, going against paced records, under sanction of the National Cyclers' Association. Yesterday he broke the existing records of three to ten miles, inclusive, and to-day was informed that they would be accepted as official trials.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The demand for money in connection with the settlement was slight. Discounts were weak on French bill buying, with a plethora of money counteracting the influences of falling exchanges, and the brisk demand for gold in the open market.

The scenery in "L'Aiglon" at the Knickerbocker Theatre is not only appropriate to the epoch and the places represented and well painted. It is also uncommonly well set. Illusion-destroying borders and sky sinks are dispensed with and unsightly rigging is not permitted to show, as it has shown lately in some costly stage productions.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- A special edition of the Berliner Correspondenz, the official organ of the Ministry of the Interior, publishes a statement to-day admitting that Director von Woedtke of the Imperial Department of the Interior, induced Secretary Bueck of the Central Association of Manufacturers to devote 12,000 marks to the purpose of printing official Reichstag material and other documents showing arguments in favor of passing the Anti-Strike bill.
HONGKONG, Oct. 25. -- Advices from LienChow, on North River, say that American mission property there is threatened with destruction by Boxers, who have posted the following proclamation:

Imp, first from the fall of the flag to the winning post, galloped in winner by two lengths and a half for the Mahopac Handicap, at the Empire City race track yesterday, and though the result was exactly what nine out of every ten spectators had anticipated confidently, the cheering and applause that greeted the old black mare from Ohio were as spontaneous and genuine as if she had really achieved a great success.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The annual report of Rear Admiral O'Neil contains an interesting summary of the important developments of the year in the matter of naval ordnance, armor, and powder. The estimates for the next year, which aggregate $7,457,855, include a single item of $4,000,000 under the head of increase of the navy, armor, and armament.
HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 25. -- The following statement was given out for publication to-night by President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, at the conclusion of the conference of union officials:

The latest European mail brings us the diary, kept during the siege of the legations in Peking, of the correspondent of The London Times. The impression a careful perusal of this diary makes is extraordinary. The whole diary cannot be reproduced, since it is printed in The London Times in two installments, each of two of that journal's ample pages.
OGDENSBURG, Oct. 25. -- Senator Depew made some political speeches to-day, the last before an audience that filled the Ogdensburg Opera House to its utmost capacity.

READING, Penn., Oct. 25. -- Shortly before midnight last night John Dwight, a prisoner in the Berks County Jail, serving a five years' sentence for arson, set fire to himself with suicidal intent. After intense suffering he died this morning. Prison Watchman Baker discovered the fire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent "E.O." agrees with "D.B." that Gen. Lee's name is out of place in the Hall of Fame, though he graciously admits that "he was probably a good officer." This of the man who organized and led to victorious combat the Army of Northern Virginia, of which Gen. Joseph Hooker said.

Abraham Gruber, lawyer and political leader, is to-day richer by $40,000, having come out victorious in the contest of the will of Louisa N. Page, who died last Winter at the Hotel Endicott and bequeathed to him the amount stated.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- Boston had a good market. Montana and Isle Royale led the mining group. The steady selling of Montana, noted for a week or two past, continued. The price ran off at first, 3, to 320, at which 620 Shares came out -- 500 shares in one lot -- but quick recovery and advance were made, to 325.

ANNULMENT OF MARRIAGE. -- Louis F. Ruel, after living with Mary Ruel for over eighteen years as his wife, recently brought suit in the Supreme Court to annul the marriage upon the ground that when she married him she had a former husband living, her marriage to whom was then in force.

Mr. Bryan had a day of excitement yesterday. The enthusiasm which greeted him in Philadelphia and the positive frenzy which marked his tour in New Jersey did much to dispel from his mind, and from the minds of the friends who accompany him, the cool reception which he met in Delaware.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 25. -- The annual tournament of the Baltimore Shooting Association closed to-day, the final contest being a handicap at twenty live birds, $20 entrance, $50 added to high guns, six moneys. Smith, Martin, and Postons divided the first three moneys, while the other three went to Hallowell, Panning, and Welch.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The details surrounding the death of Jennie Bosscheiter, the seventeen-year-old mill girl, who was poisoned in the hack room of a saloon in Paterson by four young men of this city last Thursday night, and while in a dying condition was inhumanely treated on a lonely road, and later thrown from a carriage, still furnish the absorbing topic in this city.

Two features of the remarkable defalcation in the First National Bank have, we think, made a very strong impression on the mind of the business community. One is the possession by one employs of such large opportunities for stealing with relatively no check through the systematic inspection of others to prevent him from using those opportunities.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 25. -- The Census Bureau, in a bulletin issued to-day, summarizes the returns of population of cities having 25,000 inhabitants or more in 1900, the individual census of each of these cities having been officially announced heretofore. There are 159 of these, and the bulletin shows that the percentage of increase in their population from 1890 to 1900 was 32.5, as against 49.5 for the same cities in the previous decade.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -- The new vaudeville farce, "The Star and Garter," opened here to-night for its first run of the season. The farce has many unique effects and new songs, but the audience seemed to think it dull. The Agoust family, from France, famous as comedy and pantomime actors, were introduced in the second act and much applauded.

Columbia's football practice was yesterday again of the most encouraging kind. For forty-five minutes Coach Sanford kept the 'Varsity eleven in play against one of the strongest scrub teams that has lined up this year, and at the end of that time five touch-downs had been scored.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- United States Consul Fleming, at Edinburgh, informs the State Department of a critical depression in the Scotch tweed trade. Firms are going out of business, factories stand idle, and the manufactories still operating find it wellnigh impossible to do a profitable business.

The stock market yesterday acted much after the manner of the market of the day previous. Strength developed in the early trading and was well sustained until toward the close, when, profit taking appearing, a reaction followed, though not in any sense of the word material.

The passengers on the Hamburg-American Line steamship Kaiser Friedrich, which Bailed yesterday for Cherbourg and Hamburg, witnessed an exciting scene just after the steamer had put out from her dock. A woman with a maid had hired Stateroom No. 120 on the vessel, and they were on board when she sailed this forenoon.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Oct. 25. -- There was the usual large attendance of society people at the opening of the Orange Biding and Driving Club annual horse show, in the big clubhouse in Halsted Street, East Orange, to-night. The boxes were filled with fashionably dressed people, and the programme showed an unusual number of exhibitors who were new to the Orange show.

Valentine -- Harper. Langdon Barrett Valentine and Miss May Harper were married yesterday afternoon at the city residence of the bride's parents, 269 Madison Avenue. Mr. Valentine is the only son of Henry C. Valentine of 13 East Thirty-sixth Street, and his mother was Miss Grace C. Barrett.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 25. -- Miss B. Grace Keyes of the Concord Golf Club won the championship of the Boston Women's Golf Association on the Oakley Country Club links, at Watertown, to-day, defeating Miss Harriet S. Curtis of Oakley in the finals by a score of 5 up and 3 to play. Fifteen holes decided the match, Miss Keyes making 53 for her out score, equaling bogy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- There are signs of a renewal of the insinuations made against Admiral and Mrs. Dewey last year with regard to the purchase of the famous gift house on Rhode Island Avenue.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1\4@65 1\2. There were no sales.
Paul Mayer has sold for Smith Roffler to an investor, for about $240,000, the sevenstory apartment house at the southwest corner of Broadway and One Hundred and First Street, 69 by 100.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25. -- The Yale Bi-centennial Committee has organized finally for the great celebration which la to take place here next year, and has divided the plans among a number of sub-committees. The celebration will be held on Oct. 20-23 of next year.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 25. -- According to a dispatch to The Tribune from Ann Arbor, Regent Dean of the University of Michigan has received a letter from Dean C. Worcester, a member of the United States Commission in the Philippines, which is in part as follows:

The Chamber of Commerce has sent to the Charter Revision Commission suggestions for "changes in the charter of the city." The letter was signed by Charles Stewart Smith, J. Kennedy Tod, and George Foster Peabody, a sub-committee of the Executive Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- C.D. Snapp, confidential agent for Caldwell Smith, cotton brokers, of Memphis, Tenn., was arrested here to-day, charged with the embezzlement of $32,000. Later in the day he was turned over to Deputy J.F. Alexander of Memphis, who, with Bolton Smith, a member of the firm, had come to Chicago to effect the arrest, and started for Memphis.

-- Papers now arriving from the South contain fuller reports of Lieut. HOBSON'S speech at Selma, Ala., than were given in the first dispatches, and we are forced regretfully to record that these reports, instead of mitigating the young officer's offense, take away the last vestiges of a belief in his good taste and discretion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The latest movement to uplift the colored race dates from this city. Its plan is to induce negroes to go into business and the skilled trades. The persons who are engineering the movement are all colored, and they have formed themselves into an organization called the Union League.

Mayor Van Wyck received yesterday for his signature a resolution over which there has been a ten months' contest in the Municipal Assembly. The fight has been for the transfer of $144,649 from one set of accounts of the Street Cleaning Department to another set. The money is to be taken from the accounts of the Boroughs of Richmond and Queens to be spent for equipment in the Borough of Manhattan.
Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt has addressed the following letter to Marcus Schnitzer, the editor of The Auetro-Hungarian Gazette of this city:

Henry C. Ripley was examined yesterday in the proceedings before United States Commissioner Shields for the removal to the jurisdiction of the Federal Courts in Georgia of John F., William T., and Edward H. Gaynor and B.D. Greene, who are charged with conspiring with O.M. Carter to defraud the United States Government on the work done on Cumberland Sound and Savannah Harbor.

The sincere and enthusiastic applause which greeted "Der Probekandidat" ("The Probationer") at the Irving Place Theatre last evening gave promise that the play will be a success. It is a short play in four acts by Max Dreyer, and was well received in Germany. It is what the Germans call a comedy, but that would not be an American definition.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Partisan interest and spirit have been tested here twice in a week, on Thursday last by the visit of Col. Bryan and to-day by the coming of Gov. Roosevelt. Syracuse was very much crowded last Thursday night about the neighborhood of Clinton Square.

Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., the defaulting note teller of the First National Bank, who in five years managed to steal $690,000 from that institution, may be in the hands of the police. Two residents of Mount Vernon, who are well acquainted with him, declared last night that they had seen him, in company with three men, in a carriage that was being driven rapidly in the direction of this city.

Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down a decision, which, reverses the action of the Board of Police Commissioners in the Haffen-Nagle trouble in the Twenty-first Senatorial District. The Police Commissioners decided that Senator Richard H. Mitchell, the candidate of the Nagle faction, was the regular Democratic nominee for State Senator from the Twenty-first District, and ordered his name placed on the ballots.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- At 8 o'clock this morning Admiral O'Nell, Chief of the Ordnance Department, Navy Department, received a telephone message from the proving grounds at Indian Head, reporting that last night a fire and several explosions occurred in one of the storehouses and a magazine.

Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Frank A. Vanderlip was in town yesterday, and had a short talk with Assistant Treasurer Jordan at the Sub-Treasury. He said that the plan adopted recently to relieve the pressure for small notes had proved fairly satisfactory and that the demand had by this time been almost satisfied.

None of the eminent spokesmen of anti-imperialism, we fear, will rise from the reading of Secretary ROOT'S speech with a humbled and recanting mind, but we should be sorry to believe that there are not some among them who will redden with shame when they see these clear proofs of the errors into which they have been led by ignorance and a perverse refusal to see the light of truth.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Sims Reeves, the veteran English singer, died to-day at Worthing, Sussex.
OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill addressed a large audience at the Academy of Music this evening. At one period a voice called: "Where did you stand in 1896?"

The cable dispatch from St. Thomas, Danish West Indies, stating that much adverse feeling has been caused there by the revival of the report that Denmark intended to sell her islands to the United States, caused much surprise yesterday among Danes and Americans who claim to be posted on public opinion there.

Gov. Roosevelt will arrive in this city at 5.30 o'clock this afternoon. At 4:45 o'clock an escort of police and three carriages, containing a committee to receive him, will leave the Republican County Headquarters, at 1 Madison Avenue, and proceed to the Grand Central Station.
The Vanderbilts have obtained control of the Southern Pacific system.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -- The Yale team is working in these last few days in preparing for the Columbia game in New York on Saturday. Yale's defeat of last year still remains a stinging memory, and this year the Yale men intend to win and to pile up a big score also.
Army. Capt. John B. Bennet, Sixteenth Infantry, is relieved from duty as acting judge advocate, Department of the Colorado, and will join his regiment.

HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- John B. Stanchfield arrived in Hudson this afternoon, and, after being driven about the city by a committee of the local Democracy, was greeted at the Opera House this evening by a large and enthusiastic audience. During the course of his address Mr. Stanchfield said:

Julian Arnold, son of Sir Edwin Arnold, the author of "The Light of Asia," arrived in this city yesterday with two Scotland Yard detectives, who will accompany him to London, where he will be tried on charges of embezzling u140,000.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25. -- A. sixpounder cannon, which reached the shores of Greenwich nearly a century ago as ballast on a ship, and which was left on the grounds which now form E.C. Benedict's estate at Indian Harbor, in exchange for a cargo of wheat, is buried somewhere in a five-acre lot in Greenwich, and efforts are now being made to find it.

The right of the city authorities to interfere with the Brooklyn Disciplinary Training School was questioned, at a meeting of the Board of Managers, held at Borough Hall yesterday afternoon. The Health Department has condemned the building as a nuisance, and the meeting yesterday was called to consider its abandonment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Princeton's scrub team played the 'Varsity practically to a standstill this afternoon on University Field. The 'Varsity scored but one touchdown, and this was due to a fluke on the part of Hale, the scrub centre. He made a bad pass of the ball to Underhill for a punt, the pigskin flying clear out of the latter's reach.

BORDEAUX, Oct. 25. -- An immense crowd gave an enthusiastic welcome to-day to the officers and a number of the men of the Foureau-Lamy expedition, which returned from West Africa on board the Ville de Pernambuco, after accomplishing for the first time in French colonial history a journey across the Sahara from Algeria to the French Congo.

Plans have been filed at the Building Department for the new schoolhouse to be erected at One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Street, Jackson Avenue, and the Boston Bead. The building will stand on a plot 307 by 171, and, according to the estimates of Architect C.B.J. Snyder, will cost $400,000
SYRACUSE, Oct. 25. -- Elial T., driven by Jack Cahill, defeated Joe Martin's Bentigo in a five-mile trotting race here to-day. Time -- 13:45 1/2.

Mrs. Mabel Hanson, twenty-three years old, who lived with her mother and two older sisters on the top floor of an apartment house at 22 West Sixty-first Street, died at her home yesterday afternoon from the effects of a dose of carbolic acid. The family declared that she took the acid by mistake.

A Tale graduate was one of a party that went up to the South Field to see Coach Sanford put the football men through their paces. In a big vacant lot not a pistol shot from what little there is of a campus at Columbia a half dozen scrawny and bony horses were wandering about nibbling at the grass.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- Eugene V. Debs, candidate for the Presidency on the Social Democratic ticket, was the principal speaker at a mass meeting held to-night in the Academy of Music under the auspices of the Social Democrats of this city. Mr. Debs said in part:

Six men, constituting, the police believe, a gang of counterfeiters and moonshiners who have long victimized liquor dealers of the city, were captured yesterday by Private Detective Miller and Detectives Cuff and McNaught of the District Attorney's office, on bench warrants issued by Magistrate Brann at the request of Assistant District Attorney Hennessy, to whom George Gordon Battle, representing two large brandy manufacturing concerns, had presented the evidence worked up by the firms' detectives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- In diplomatic quarters there is felt to be some significance in the fact that France, Russia, and Japan, as well as the United States, have not yet accepted the invitation to accept the principles of the Anglo-German alliance.

It is a misfortune that the average reader of our time has but limited opportunity for the examination of the well-printed books made a hundred years ago. Not only the books but the names of their printers, who contributed much to the improvement of typography, are unknown or have been forgotten.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The Chinese Minister has received a dispatch stating that Kang- Yi, a member of the Cabinet with Yung-Lu and one of the intense antiforeign leaders, whose punishment was demanded by the powers, died of illness on the 18th inst.; also that Yu-Hslen, the late Governor of Shan-Si, who is said to have been responsible for the death of many missionaries, has committed suicide by swallowing gold leaf.

Conditions in the Dominion, according to reports received by Dun's, are rather more satisfactory, notwithstanding interruption to sales of Winter goods by unseasonably warm weather. St. John reports good trade in dry goods, groceries, and shoes, but in hardware and drugs only fair, while collections are hardly up to the average.

What subtle attraction or psychological quality it is that makes an inferior or commonplace book sell, and the lack of which consigns a work of exceptional merit to that dark and spacious limbo where the unpurchased books go, no one has at any time been able to discover. Speculation about it has been rife and recurrent for many years now, and preceded our modern generation.

A sense of the mistake in morals committed by Europe in its assumptions of rights over the Eastern World, based on its superior intelligence, is rapidly coming over the general mind. Were it not for trade, that is, that we want things that China has, this mistake would be speedily admitted, and rectified.

The centre of social interest for this "week-end" shifted yesterday from Hempstead and Westchester to Tuxedo, where the annual Autumn ball took place last evening. Most of those who went to Tuxedo yesterday for the ball, the story of which is told in another column, will remain over Sunday, and the resort will be gay in consequence until Monday at least.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Considerable correspondence is appearing in the papers on the subject of the South African contracts, the writers expressing indignation at the evidence that large orders have gone to the United States. Some, however, contend that the colonists are entitled to go to whatever market they choose, and are not bound to add to their already large losses by buying in the dearest British market.

This lesson is a continuation of that of last week. All of the attending circumstances are the same. Then our Lord Jesus Christ was surrounded by a mixed multitude, consisting of "publicans and sinners," and "Pharisees and Scribes," with many who called themselves "His disciples."
The demonstration in honor of Gov. Roosevelt in New York yesterday was a remarkable one in all respects, brimming over with enthusiasm and culminating in a great meeting in Madison Square Garden.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20. -- C.L. Stone, for many years General Passenger Agent of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad, has been appointed General Passenger Agent of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, the appointment to be effective Nov. 1.

It might seem that one of the great tests of an author's success, and especially of a writer of stories, is whether his characters are sufficiently well differentiated and clearly enough drawn to become stock allusions, to form part of familiar conversation; his people being so widely known and loved that the slightest reference to them is at once understood.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- Boston had a comparatively quiet market. There was little sign of selling pressure, and recessions were confined to fractions. Trading was active in Sugar and National Tube and fair in volume in a few mining stocks, but most of the copper group were dull and fluctuated slightly.

"A CONSTANT READER" writes from Philadelphia "I have just read in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 6 a note from Mrs. Atherton in answer to your editorial criticism of the previous week. I wish to take exception to the statement that 'all men and women of unusual brain power are sensual.'

Helen Hay, the author of R.H. Russell's new volume, which is called "The Little Boy Book," is the daughter of Col. John Hay, Secretary of State. The volume contains verses about the little boy of reality, and has full-page illustrations in color by Frank Verbeck. By an error of type the name was printed in an advertisement in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of two weeks ago "Helen May," instead of Helen Hay.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The annual Autumn ball, one of the most important events of the year in the Tuxedo colony, took place to-night in the circular ballroom adjoining the clubhouse.

We have not yet had in this country precisely the kind of "labor trouble" which they are having in Canada. It is quite true that the "furious Frank and fiery Hun" employed in the anthracite mines of Pennsylvania have considerably complicated the problem presented by the recurring strikes in that region, particularly the unintelligible behavior of the fiery Hun.

The cheers that greeted Jockey Winfield Scott Hancock O'Connor when he returned to the judges' stand after landing C.F. Dwyer's colt Trumpet winner of the Tuckahoe Stakes at the Empire City track yesterday left no doubt as to the opinion of the crowd at that moment, though, as a matter of fact, O'Connor rode a wretchedly stupid race, and barely squeezed Trumpet home by a head.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- In spite of the game with Columbia to-morrow the Yale football team went through a stiff practice this afternoon. During the thirty minutes of play the 'Varsity scored twice on the scrub team, both times after the fiercest kind of centre and tackle smashing. Sharpe was used regularly for end runs with some success, as he covered several yards in one run before he was downed.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 26. -- Application was made to-day to Judge Brinkerhoff to admit to probate the last will and testament of ex-Secretary of State John Sherman. The will was brought into court by Col. M.M. Parker of Washington, D.C., and Congressman W.S. Kerr of Mansfield, Hearing on the application was set for Nov. 15 at 10 A.M.

Should Japan care at all to be understood by Western barbarians, she must feel that she owes a large debt of gratitude to Mr. Lafcadio Hearn, and if the Anglo-Saxon mind can measure the value to itself of the grace of humility. it, too, has reason to thank Mr. Hearn for his unfolding of a civilization that was hoary in wisdom and ripe in charm when our own was in its cradle.

For polo snap and energy the palm for this season's work must be awarded to the Squadron A Polo Club, which has yet to celebrate its first birthday. Eight members of the club, with a referee, appeared at 6 o'clock yesterday morning on the polo field of the Country Club of Westchester and played the final match in the intertroop series for the officers' cup.

No thorough student of the history of jurisprudence can be unfamiliar with the admirable device of the jurors in the famous case of "The King versus the Knave of Hearts," reported in Carroll, 1, 174. It was deemed of some importance to fix accurately, in this case, the date at which the Hatter began his tea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Imports into the United States from Porto Rico have trebled and exports to that island from the United States nave quadrupled in the five months since the enactment of the new Porto Rican tariff, as compared with those of the corresponding months of 1896 and 1897, when Porto Rico was under the Spanish flag.

In all the glory of a beautiful vellum binding, gold-lettered, comes a sumptuous edition of "The Confessions, of St. Augustine." which must make an equally strong appeal both to lovers of that book as well as to lovers of fine editions generally.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- Gov.
