Roosevelt finshed at Schenectady the fifth day of his up-State campaign, covering 866 miles, with a speech addressed to many who had within the week listened to the beguiling accents of the Democratic candidate for President. He met with a reception larger and more spontaneous in its appearance than that which greeted his predecessor.

Closely following Mrs. Meynell's biographical sketch of John Ruskin, comes one from the pen of K. Edward Pengelly. Doubtless, in spite of the non possumus set up by Ruskin's literary executors, there will be many more. Mr. Pengelly's work appears to be a clever pot-pourri of extracts from Collingwood's "Life" and from "Fors Clavigera" and "Praeterita," together with some interesting extracts from unpublished letters.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Harvard's 'Varsity Fall handicap field games were held on Soldiers' Field this afternoon. No records were broken. The games began so late that the pole vault and broad jump had to be postponed on account of darkness. The summary:

The various issues in the Haddon Hall Library Series are always especially noteworthy for the perfection of all the mechanical details which go to make up a beautiful volume; while in the present instance the illustrations, whlch are from actual photographs supplied by the owners or managers of fine estates, and especially the beautiful photogravure frontispiece, "Old Forest Oaks," add very materially to the success of the volume.

Ruth Hall's "The Black Gown" is a romance of the early Colonial period. In the Albany of 130 years ago live the principal characters. There is Conelis Sleight, commonly known as Neal. His first love is for the pretty and somewhat weak live Verbeck. In Albany there is in the garrison Cecil Loveland, who is an officer.

No other occasional performance of an artistic dramatic work before a special and exclusive audience in this town has ever been quite so successful from every point of view as the fine representation of Robert Browning's dramatic poem, "In a Balcony," at Wallack's yesterday afternoon. The house was crowded to the doors, and perhaps there was the usual proportion of idlers and curiosity seekers in the crowd.

One of the reflections aroused by the death of Charles Dudley Warner, which is lamented by an unusually wide circle of friends, is how easy, in this country, it still is to attain literary distinction if one has personal distinction. "A pleasant essayist." That is what any critical reader could fairly say of Mr. Warner as a writer.

Mr. Bryan from 8:30 A.M. yesterday until nearly midnight was whirling from place to place in New Jersey, and making speeches, sometimes from the rear platform of his special train, and sometimes at immense open-air meetings.

A diamond pin worth $200, lost by Anna Paltz, the nineteen-year-old governess of a family named Weiss, living in handsome apartments at 1,129 Fulton Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, caused Walter Hartman, five years old, of the same address, to be held for several hours in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Money was firmer today and in better demand, partly in consequence of the settlement requirements. Discounts were harder. Little business was transacted, as the feeling of nervousness and uncertainty is becoming daily more pronounced. It is feared unfavorable developments may occur at any moment in the form of heavy withdrawals of gold for foreign countries.

Generally, the tone in trade circles has improved during the week. More activity is reported, and all the signs point to substantial betterment in the immediate future should the election result in the success of the Republican Party. A significant development has been the abandonment in some special trades of the "waiting" policy -- of the policy, that is, of pursuing a hand-to-mouth course until after election.

When asked yesterday in regard to the announcement from Philadelphia that the Philadelphia and Reading Company had broken away from the coat syndicate and would hereafter run all its mines to their full capacity, which is said to be 16,000,000 tons a year, the company's officers here smiled.

Mr. HEWITT'S examination of BRYAN'S trust argument, like Secretary ROOT'S speech in reply to the anti-imperialists, is not a defense, not at all an apology -- quite the contrary in both cases -- but a destructive exposure of error and a candid justification of the thing attacked. The friends of the Administration have no occasion to apologize for what has been done in the Philippines.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Senator Depew spoke here to-night in the open air. His platform faced a plaza in which more than 5,000 persons, men and women, stood for over an hour. In the course of his address he said:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Princeton football players, after a hasty toilet and breakfast, took the 9 o'clock train this morning for New York, en route to Providence, where they meet Brown University to-morrow. A large crowd cheered the team off at the station. The men all needed cheering up a little, for they are far from being confident of defeating Brown.

Henry Daily, Jr., one of the best-known old-school lawyers of this city, died Thursday afternoon. The immediate cause of death was shock, due to an operation, made in Dr. Carpenter's sanitarium, as a last hope to relieve Mr. Daily of a fatal kidney trouble.

Much surprise was expressed in military circles last night when it became known that Gloucester Command, No. 17, Spanish War Veterans, which admitted Lieut. Col. Clinton H. Smith to membership, after taking his side in the controversy over the charges of cowardice at the battle of San Juan Hill, preferred against him, has finally decided to request his resignation from the organization.

On Columbia Field to-day a determined football team from Yale will line up against eleven, equally earnest wearers of Columbia's white and blue in the first big football game that New Yorkers have had opportunity to witness on home grounds this season. From several points of view, also, it will be the most interesting game that the Columbia eleven has to play.

George W. Gardanier, first assistant to A.S. Brown, electrical engineer of the Western Union Telegraph Company, and a prominent member of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, committed suicide by opening the arteries of his left wrist and neck at his home, 221 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday morning.

It was learned in Mount Vernon last night that Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., the defaulting note teller of the First National Bank, was at his house in that city on Tuesday morning. This is the day that the bank gave out the statement that the man was a defaulter, and four days after his defalcation was known to the bank officials.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- That the mosquito serves as the "intermediate host" for the parasite of yellow fever, and that it is highly probable that the disease is only propagated through the bite of this insect, is the conclusion reached by a board of medical officers who went to Cuba in the Summer of the present year to make a study of the dread disease.

The writer of popular biography is not always able to steer a safe course between inaccurate prolixity and barren statement of fact Mr. Perkins succeeds in keeping this course through his enviable gift of the historical temper of mind. His volume on Richelieu is an admirable example of the way in which a writer so endowed may pack within narrow limits a history of extraordinary scope.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Charles Perry, the second of the three negroes charged with the murder of Prof. Roy Wilson White, the young law instructor of the University of Pennsylvania, was to-night convicted of murder in the first degree. Henry Ivory was found guilty two days ago.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Scotch steelmakers, owing to the importation of American steel plates, have reduced their prices 5s., making 15s. reduction in a fortnight.

Charles M. Hays, heretofore General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railway, has been selected for the position of President of the Southern Pacific Company by the committee consisting of James Speyer, Charles H. Tweed, and D.O. Mills, which for some weeks past has been considering various names for that position.

HELENA, Mon., Oct. 26. -- Deputy United States Marshal Samuel Jackson fell from the first floor in the Capitol Building to the basement last night and received injuries from which he died three hours later. Jackson was the best-known officer in Montana. He was a pioneer of the Black Hills, and had spent his whole life in the West.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Oliver Husted of Schultzville, this county, accom- panied by Mrs. Lizzie Sherow, for whom he had traded his wife and given $10 to boot, were brought into the police station here to-night by Chief of Police McCabe, who had just arrived with his prisoners from Holly, Mich., where they had been arrested On the charges of grand larceny and kidnapping.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The Auditorium was filled to-night with an immense audience, which assembled to hear Senators Hanna of Ohio and Burrows of Michigan. The meeting was under the auspices of the Republican railroad employes of Chicago. The audience was, to a large extent, composed of railroad men, and the Chairman was Lot Brown, local agent of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The War Department to-day received a dispatch from Gen. MacArthur giving an account of a fight in which a small detachment of the American troops attacked a much superior force of Filipinos. The dispatch follows:

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Oct. 26. -- The marriage of Lieut. George W. Logan, United States Navy, aide de camp to Gov. Allen, to Miss Bertha Allen, daughter of the Governor of Porto Rico, took place last evening in the Throne Room of the palace here, which was magnificently decorated with royal palms, potted plants, and pink flowers, pink being the prevailing color.

Gov. Roosevelt faced a cheering, roaring throng last evening in Madison Square Garden. His face was set, his lips close pressed, and his eyes twinkling back of the pebble lenses of his eye-glasses. As he entered the Garden the buzzing sound of many voices gradually became a roar of cheers and the 14,000 people who packed the Garden yelled with all their might as they waved small and large American flags.

Undoubtedly the capture of Peking has made an impression upon the governing people in China. They are in flight or in hiding. They have learned that the whole indignant modern world cannot be defied. It seems that they have also learned that it cannot be hoodwinked by those devices which they at first thought might be sufficient.

The Summer home of Jacob Hays at the head of Round Island, Clayton, N.Y., has been sold to Mrs. W.J. Burns of Pittsburg, Penn. Mr. Hays was formerly owner of the Frontenac Hotel, and his cottage is one of the handsomest on the St. Lawrence River.

One of the charms of the admirable biography of Commodore Jones by Mr. Buell lies in the glimpses it gives from time to time, and all too seldom, of the literary style of this gifted and singular man. It must be remembered that Jones was of the humblest birth, the son of Scottish peasants with whom the struggle for bare existence was bitter and constant.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- At the last day of the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day the representatives of the American turf here had another good day. Mr. Whitney's Spectrum took the Old Cambridgeshire Handicap, piloted by "Danny" Maher; A. Bailey's Mount Prospect, with L. Reiff up, ran second, and Aquascutum, the property of Sir. J. Blundell Maple, was third.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the judgment in James W. Corcoran against the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company. The defendant corporation appealed from the affirmance of a judgment awarding the plaintiff $168.36 damages and costs for the refusal of a conductor to accept a mileage book for fare on its railroad.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- John W. Gates will be the President of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company.

Trading in the market for outside securities was much lighter yesterday than on the earlier days of the week, and even more irregularity in prices showed than on Thursday. Transactions in the Chicago and Alton issues were still on a fairly large scale, but in other parts of the list orders had considerably diminished.

At St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Fifth Avenue, a triduum, or three days of solemn services, will be held on Nov. 13, 14, and 15 in honor of the newest Catholic saint, St. John Baptist de la Saile, founder of the order of Christian Brothers, whose members teach in the Catholic schools of this city.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Frank McGreavey, twenty years of age, is in jail trying to decide which of two girls he will marry. If he marries one of them he will still have to remain in jail because of the other one. Each girl demands that he marry her. He was arrested on complaint of Anna Schaffer, nineteen years old.

Mr. Ida Cassner, the divorced wife of William Cassner, a builder, living at 100 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, took her two children away from the school-in Jamaica which they have been attending at noon yesterday. The abduction was quietly carried out, and the children were gone almost an hour before the police were notified.

From The Sewanee Review. To many of our children the pleasures of reading are locked and sealed by the attempt to force books upon them at an age unfit for their reading. Why should the young be compelled to associate books which would be a source of pleasure with the memory of hours spent in weary study?

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Harry Elkes broke all bicycle records from twelve to twenty-five miles, inclusive, this after-noon, his time for twenty-five miles being 37:02 2-5, which beats the previous record made by Stinson by 17 1-5 seconds. Elkes was trying to make a new hour record, but in the twenty-sixth mile his motor became overheated, spoiling the pace.

Sorrow is in the eye of a little green snake in the Reptile House in Bronx Park, for she has lost her little friend and admirer, Toady, of whom she had grown very fond. Toady, when last seen by a keeper, was on an exploration into the interior of a homely old snake in the glass box alongside, and he has not come back since to admire his pretty friend.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The following quotation from an article in a morning paper of a few days since voices the sentiments of many persons with reference to the recent action of the "one hundred judges," upon whose decisions, whether correct or otherwise, rested the selection of names to be inscribed, upon the tablets of the "Hall of Fame."

A good many reports have appeared within the last few days with regard to the famous Botticelli "Madonna," which was sold by Prince Chigi of Rome, on account of which transaction he has been condemned by the Italian Government to pay a fine of $63,000.

John Jaques, twenty-eight years old, of 136 Sussex Street, Jersey City, was instantly killed yesterday by the falling of a mammoth chimney at Essex and Greene Streets. Philip Hlnken, thirty years old, of 18 Park Street, was slightly injured. John Kinney, who was working on top of that part of the chimney which was-left standing, escaped unhurt.

Nothing that occurred yesterday in the market for outside securities brought about any change in the general conditions prevalling in that market, and little interest attached to the day's trading. Prices were irregular and trading was on a much smaller scale than at the beginning of the week, but nothing unusual appeared in this diminution of business.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $50O of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 27. -- Brown's football team was defeated by the score of 17 to 5 by Princeton to-day. Notwithstanding the defeat the supporters of Brown are thoroughly satisfied with the showingmade by the team. The game was by far the fiercest ever seen in this city, and the Brown players state that Princeton put up a much better game than did Pennsylvania.

Mary Smith, which is admitted to be her assumed name, the woman who is said to have attempted suicide on Tuesday afternoon at the Hotel Earlington by taking carbolic acid, was driven in a closed carriage yesterday forenoon to Jefferson Market Police Court and arraigned before Magistrate Mott in the private examination room.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Oct. 27. -- With to-night's judging of a number of local and open classes and a parade of prize winners the fifth annual Horse Show of the Orange Riding and Driving Club came to a close. In attendance, enthusiasm, excellence, and number of entries the show was in many ways the most successful ever held by the club.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- William J. Bryan reached New Haven from New York at 11 o'clock, and was driven immediately to the Second Regiment Armory. He was greeted as he entered the hall with a generous and general cheer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me, in view of the recent Paterson tragedy, to ask a few questions?

From The Contemporary Review. Lions infest the whole of the Beira route to this day. Ten years ago, when the line was being surveyed for, they crawled everywhere. The usual idea of these carnivora is that they are the kings of beasts; that lions prance and lash their tails, step after a lordly fashion, and are both noble looking and noble in their habits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Never before in a National election have the indications just prior to election day been more pronounced in favor of one of the parties than at this time. Election wagers and everything else point to the success of the Republican ticket by an enormous majority.

Looking over the large and varied collection of snapshot portraits of gentlemen actively engaged in enlightening the American people as to their duty in the present campaign, we think that the President of the United States may thank his stars that the dignity of his office and the conservative instincts of his old-fashioned nature prevent him from exposing himself in flagrante oratione to the deadly tube of the camera.

The averages of the Amateur Baseball League for the past season have just been issued by the Secretary, W. Parsons Todd of the Morristown Field Club. The league is composed of the New York Athletic Club, the Crescent Athletic Club, the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, the Morristown Field Club, the Montclair Athletic Club, and the Englewood Field Club.

If there were such a thing as a Victoria Cross within the gift of the Republican campaign managers of Brooklyn, ex-Sheriff William J. Buttling, it is believed, would have been decorated with it last night.

Politics in the Eighth Assembly District, known to politicians far and wide as "de Ate," are seething this year. In fact, it is to be doubted it there is another district in the State where the interest in the result of a campaign is so pronounced as in this famous east side bailiwick, the battle ground of many a hard-fought fight in past years.

There was little life to yesterday's stock market. Dealings were on a smaller scale than in recent days, total transactions for the two hours amounting to 230,000 shares. Profit-taking over Sunday was in evidence and the favorable bank statement was taken advantage of to sell; while not a little selling by room traders also appeared, the theory being that, after the sustained rise, a reaction was due.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 27. -- The Supreme Court of the State to-day reversed the ruling of the District Court and ordered the nominees of the Thomas J. Maloney faction of the Democratic Party to be placed on the official ballot as the Democratic ticket.

CREEDMOOR, Oct. 27. -- The regular supplementary practice of the season was held here to-day for the expert class at 700 and 800 yards. The attendance was fair, and weather anything but favorable for long-distance shooting. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Col. N.B. Thurston, Ordnance Officer, N.G.N.Y.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Harvard defeated the Carlisle Indians in this afternoon's football game by the score of 17 to 5. The five points which the Indians made are the first scored on Harvard this season.

From Cassier's Magazine. All the water used by this city of over 75,000 inhabitants is now either distilled from the sea water, brought in tank cars from the distant rivers, or borne in casks on the backs of horses or camels from very carefully preserved wells in the vicinity and fed by not too frequent rains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am informed that certain game dealers in this city intend to continue the importation and sale of European game, under the impression that the Lacey law does not apply to such traffic. In fact, an attorney representing one of these importers called on me and asked me to agree not to interfere with his client in this trade.

To The Editor of The New York Times: One of these days it will occur to stockholders, and also the public at large, that it is about time to try and ascertain the reason the systems in these large banks are such, as to allow clerks therein to continue for several years to help themselves to the funds in their care without being detected, except, as in most cases, by "pure accident."

The private chapel of Archbishop Corrigan, in which Miss Elizabeth K. Livingston, a niece of Van Brugh Livingston, was married to Charles James Welch of San Francisco on Wednesday last, is less used than the majority of the private chapels of the dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church. Many Bishops use their chapels for daily mass, but this is not the custom of the Archbishop.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct 27. -- The Jury summoned by Coroner Vroom of Ridgewood to investigate the death of Jennie Bosscheiter, the murdered mill girl, met to-day at Alyea's icehouse, near which the girl's body was found, on the Bergen side of the Passaic River.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The Chronicle says: "The bills which, the Municipal Street Railway Commission proposes to introduce at the coming session of the State Legislature as the result of several months' exhaustive study of the traction situation, are practically completed. Their phraseology may be amended by the city's legal experts before they are introduced, but the essential details have been decided upon by the commission.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct 27. -- On the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club, at Noroton, this afternoon the first round in the annual club championship tournament was played. An uncommonly long list of prizes had been offered, and this added great interest to the competition, besides stimulating golfers to enter into the contest.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I was surprised at finding that J. Fenimore Cooper, one of the first and best story writers in the English world, was not deemed worthy of a place in the Hall of Fame.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- West Point defeated Williams by a score of 6 to 0 in the football game here this afternoon. The same was the hardest played here this season. The soldiers made a touch-down at the end of the second half, which gave them victory. Little improvement was Shown in the cadets' work since the Harvard game.

-- Extreme dissatisfaction with American rule, or perhaps it would be more nearly accurate to say with American rulers, is expressed by a native resident of Ponce in a letter published by The Hartford Times. The writer declares that Porto Rico, having lost the Spanish and English markets, which were better than those of America for all of the island's products except sugar and molasses, is now commercially worse off than it was before annexation.

BOSTON, Oct. 27. -- "Some perils in the public schools" was the theme discussed at the Massachusetts Schoolmasters' Club this afternoon by President W.H.P. Faunce of Brown University, Prof. Edward Cummings of Harvard and associate pastor at Edward Everett Hale's church, and by President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $3,084,125. The banks now hold a surplus of $6,031,825 above the legal requirements.

From Notes and Queries. The increase of drunkenness in many parts of the United States led to the formation or societies intended to counteract this evil, and, as American intemperance was mainly the result of dram drinking, a pledge against the use of spirits was adopted. The movement spread to this country, and the British and Foreign Temperance Society was formed on that basis, and many local societies came into existence in 1829 and 1830.

Readers of magazines will not have forgotten the tribute that was paid in Scribner's, two years ago, by Capt. LEE, R.A., to "The Regulars at El Caney." The author of this panegyric upon the American soldier followed it up afterward by a speech at a public dinner in which he invoked the admiration of his hearers for our regulars as fighting men.

Activity has been showing in the stock market. Quotations have been strong. Generally the sentiment of Wall Street -- the professional sentiment, at least -- has been and continues optimistic. Net changes for the week were largely, on the side of increases, some of the gains being notable.

Charles Bell Gibson Gaillard and Miss Adele Erben, daughter of Rear Admiral Henry Erben, were married at noon yesterday in the Church of the Epiphany by the Rev. Mr. Kimber, assistant rector of that church. The bride entered the church on the arm of her father, who gave her away.

"A man who is willing to pay enough for it can get a portrait from any book in any library in the world," they say at the Astor Library, speaking apropos of the case of book-cutting which occurred at the Lenox Library last week. "There are people who make a special business of this sort of thing.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas, H. Howard will close Roughpoint next week and return to New York for the Winter.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- John G. Woolley, Prohibition candidate for President, spoke to an enthusiastic crowd of over 1,200 persons at the City Hall here to-night. The Prohibition special arrived here shortly before 7 o'clock, and was met at the station by a committee of local Prohibitionists. A street parade, with fireworks, preceded the speaking at the hall.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The international horse race, a match between L. Neumann's English horse Eager, ridden by Mornington Cannon, most famous of the English jockeys, and John A. Drake's American horse Royal Flush, with the noted Yankee rider, Lester Reiff, up, was run to-day over the Hurst Park Turf Club's course, and was won by the representative of England, Eager cantering in first by three lengths.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I read your paper every day because it has a certain regard for honest dealing which is refreshing. That I am not in thorough accord with its editor, I need offer no further evidence than this:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The detailed tables of the imports and exports for the month of September have been completed by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics. They show the imports and exports of the month by great classes, compared with September, 1899, as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Interested persons of the Democratic Party are using as a campaign document a print bearing two faces, called George Washington and William Jennings Bryan. By radically changing the true photograph of each these two illustrious men are made to strikingly resemble each other in features.

"This murder of the Bosscheiter girl in Paterson, which is now making so much of a sensation in our neighboring State, reminds me forcibly of the murder of Jennie Cramer in New Haven, Conn., nineteen years ago," remarked a newspaper writer who had been in the investigation of the mystery of the earlier case for the paper with which he was then connected.
SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Edward F. Phelan, one of the wealthiest residents of Summit, committed suicide at his home, on De Forest Avenue, this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bryan's admitted skill in repartee and apt retort seems, in the present campaign, to be directed almost entirely to the evasion of issues. When asked as to something dubious, deficient, or inconsistent in his own professions, his reply is almost invariably an arraignment of his opponents for similar offenses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I must confess to a sensation of surprise at reading Everett P. "Wheeler's declaration in to-day's TIMES, to the effect that "domestic strife should be silent when its only effect is to encourage the enemies of our country." This is the pith of a letter which he has extended over two-thirds of a column, and if it is unsound, the whole argument falls with it.

A second view of the beautiful production of Rostand's "L'Aiglon" in English at the Knickerbocker Theatre is worth while. The fine play is all the more enjoyable without the clamor, often factitious and insincere, of a "first night." It is a noble work, even in its English dress, which is not, however, the translation of a poet by a poet, because nature did not endow Louis N. Parker with the poet's gift.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am an officer of the navy, and am therefore supposed to have no interest in politics. Sailors are thought to feel contempt for the land and to pay little attention to its government. This may be partly true, but many navy men know the history of their country and have decided beliefs, and live the artificial life of the sea mainly from devotion.

An alarm of fire was sent in at 6 o'clock yesterday morning from Signal No. 339, corner of Sixteenth Street and Fifth Avenue. The signal corresponds to duplicate boxes on Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth and Sixteenth Street, respectively, and within a minute the avenue was alive and the neighborhood awake with the clattering of fire engines and trucks detailed to that well-guarded district.

LANDLORD AND TENANT. -- The defense interposed by William R. Coe to an action brought against him in the Municipal Court by D. Willis James to recover rent under a written lease for the Curtis apartment house, at 176 West Eighty-seventh Street, was that prior to the date when the rent sued for accrued, there had been a surrender of the premises by him which had been accepted by Mr. James.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 16. -- Two figures of gold were discovered this morning by the workmen engaged in digging the great ditches for the sewers being laid in this city. Numerous objects of great archaeological interest, have been found during the progress of the work, but none of the pieces have been of intrinsic value up to this time.

First Sergt. Ross I. Barton, recently discharged from Company G, Forty-seventh Volunteer Infantry, for physical disability while serving in the Philippines, was visiting old friends in Company C, Twenty-second Regiment, last Monday night, and had some very interesting stories to relate about military life in the Philippines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the papers are devoting so much space to the Alvord defalcation, no one has yet suggested the idea that it should be the duty of any institution to familiarize itself with the habits and mode of living of its employes, particularly those occupying positions of trust.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- W.J. Chalmers of Chicago has just completed an extensive tour of European manufacturing centres. The fact that his firm has plants both in England and Chicago makes him specially qualified to discuss the question of the manufacturing capabilities of both countries Impartially.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 27. -- The Russian press is displaying considerable interest in the coming election in the United States. Several organs have reached the conclusion that both parties occupy virtually the same position.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have been taking but little interest in the discussion now in progress concerning the list of names of famous men of this country to be enrolled in the proposed Hall of Fame. They were necessary to our fame, not we to theirs, as has been said, and the scheme does not, therefore, appeal to me as especially deserving of commendation.

Van Courtlandt did not lack for golfers yesterday on its public links, for despite the threatening nature of the weather fully 400 golfers, including a comfortable sprinkling of fair devotees, turned out to pay allegiance to the royal and ancient game. Noticeable among the golfing fraternity in the afternoon were John B. McDonald, who is building the underground rapid-transit tunnel;

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- On the Stock Exchange to-day business was inactive, and there was a light attendance of operators. The latter, having anticipated a practical holiday, were not inclined to undertake new business. The only feature was a sharp fall in Grand Trunks, on Charles M. Hay's transfer from general manager of the Grand Trunk to the Presidency of the Southern Pacific.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- President Ban Johnson of the American League has returned from the East, where he has been doing some prospecting for the coming season. He has been looking over the situation in Washington and Baltimore, and it is now certain, if is said, that American League teams will be placed in those cities.

President James McKeen of the Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, and Rear Admiral Norman H. Farquhar, commander of the North Atlantic Squadron, have suggested that a monument to Rear Admiral John W. Philip be erected in Brooklyn, where he was for some time the commandant of the navy yard.

Formal orders governing the great Sound Money Parade to be held Nov. 3 under the auspices of the Business Men's Republican and Sound Money Association were issued yesterday from the headquarters of Gen. Anson G. McCook, the Grand Marshal, at 296 Broadway, and cover every point necessary to be understood by citizens intending to march.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Through, the misty vapors of the present campaign there looms up the frightful figure of panic as the mathematically certain result of Bryan's possible success.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 27. -- The political campaign in Canada is getting hotter as the day of polling, Nov. 7, becomes nearer. It is a rather peculiar coincidence that general elections in Canada and Great Britain and a Presidential contest in the United States should take place almost contemporaneously.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27. -- Work was begun this week on the new Yale Administration Building, which is to be erected before the bi-centennial celebration next October. The new hall will be known as Woodbridge Hall, and is the gift to the University of the Misses Stokes of New York City, aunts of Anson Phelps Stokes, Jr., the Secretary of the Yale Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of the great army of men who will not vote next election day. I could never subscribe to the doctrine that the citizen should choose between two evils. Highway robbery might be termed a lesser evil than arson, but a law-abiding man cannot see any moral difference between the two crimes.

The Associate Alumnae Association of the Normal College, which is a working organization with 1,600 members, held its annual Fall reunion in the college chapel yesterday afternoon. Dr. Elizabeth Jarrett, the President of the association, spoke of the work of the coming year. President Hunter of the college spoke of the value to the college of the outside work of the association.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27. -- The New York State Assembly of Mothers will hold its fourth annual meeting in this city on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday of this week at the rooms of the Women's Educational and Industrial Union, 86 Delaware Avenue. There will be three sessions a day, morning, afternoon, and evening, with representative speakers upon different lines of thought relating to the American home.

A pale, yellow dog, which was no larger than a collie, bit two men yesterday and was shot by Policeman Putz after a chase from Battery Park through South Street to Maiden Lane. A pack of small boys, excited by the spectacle of a running policeman with a drawn revolver, joined in the pursuit and sent up an irregular ringing cheer, when the policeman's bullet ended the chase and the dog's career.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bryan and Mr. Croker abandon, in the East, the paramount issue of the Kansas City Convention and the campaign in the West, "Free Silver," and in the great industrial centres take up "Imperialism," the "Trusts," and the "Opportunity" for young men under the "Trust."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- "Do you call this the Navy Department?" said a visitor to Washington who was being shown through the executive departments. "Why it's a city."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of ex-Secretary Carlisle's recent announcement of his intention to refrain from voting at the coming Presidential election, and of your editorial remarks on Oct. 25, upon "The Right Not to Vote," it would be interesting to me, at least, to have Mr. Carlisle's views upon the following suggestions:

Prof. Rudolph A. Witthaus, the chemical expert, to whom were submitted the vital organs of William Marsh Rice, the octogenarian millionaire, who died Sept. 23 under circumstances sufficiently peculiar to warrant the stoppage of the funeral and intended cremation, yesterday submitted his report to Coroner Hart.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- The Exposition exhibitors are in an unpleasant position in not knowing whether the Exposition will close on the date originally set, Monday, Nov. 5, or whether the announcement, made on Wednesday, that it would be prolonged till Nov. 11, is correct.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Dr. Francis W. Shepardson of the University of Chicago has made a particular study of mobs and manias as manias affect the masses, and he has promulgated the theory that the fickleness and unrest of the American people are inherited from the Revolution. He says:

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The Cunard liner Aurania, now being used by the British Government as a transport, which has on board the City of London Imperial Volunteers, returning from South Africa, arrived at Southampton at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps your readers may be interested in what a commercial traveler finds "on the road" politically. It may be taken for granted that partisans will vote for the nominees. The average Republican will vote for any one properly nominated in convention.

From The Fortnightly Review. Recent investigations have shown that while the white emigration to Siberia has been considerable, it has been neither permanent nor beneficial. In 1899, according to a recent Consular report, it amounted to 223,981 souls, but in the first six months of the same year over 59,000 returned penniless to Russia, having failed to find a livelihood.

From The Geographical Journal. I found myself marching toward Tigre with the King? and a following of something between 50,000 and 100,000 strong. Undoubtedly the most picturesque group in this mighty host was Queen Taitu herself, who was seated on a mule and surrounded by her lady attendants, likewise mounted, each of whom carried a bright and different colored sunshade.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Adjt. Gen. William S. Stryker is seriously ill at his home, on West State Street, and the physicians in attendance upon him entertain but meagre hope of his recovery.
Mr. Bryan came to the city from New Haven at 3:20 P.M. yesterday on a special train. He was received with a Yale yell, three hundred college students waving flags of blue and shouting:

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- The Orange County Hunt Club followed the hounds today favored by one of the fairest afternoons of all the Autumn, although the threatening weather of the morning kept many huntsmen away. A half oval course had been laid out northward from the kennels toward the old Stony Ford stud, made famous in the days of the late Charles Backman.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- Mme. Sembrich's performances this week have been most successful. She has been greeted by crowded audiences more enthusiastic than any for years, especially about her and the tenor Bonci, whose voice is pronounced to be phenomenal.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 27. -- The University of Georgia football team was defeated here by the team from the University of the South, at Sewanee, Tenn., by a score of 21 to 6. The Tennesseeans won the game by their superiority in every way. They outclassed the Georgians in weight, endurance, and team work.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The following general order by Gen. Chaffee has been made public at the War Department:

The University of Chicago is undoubtedly a great educational foundation, with large potentialities of usefulness. To a greater or less extent it is already useful; but, if we may venture a suggestion to the Trustees, it would be that the tendency of its Faculty to promulgate "fads," if indulged too far, may be found inconsistent with the highest development of the institution.

Justice, as obtained in the Chinese courts, is a farce. A case occurred while the writer was in China in which a Chinese Judge, sitting with an English magistrate, declared that he was obliged to give judgment against the evidence, or he should lose his appointment!

The throng and display of enthusiasm within the Madison Square Garden last night exceeded even the efforts of the Democrats at the reception tendered to Mr. Bryan on Oct. 16. The edifice could never have held a larger crowd, for every available inch of space within its walls was occupied, boxes, seats, standing room, and all.

Mrs. Daniel Manning of the American Board of Commissioners to the Paris Exposition was among the arrivals on the American Liner New York yesterday. At the pier Mrs. Manning was welcomed by a delegation from the Martha Washington Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 27. -- G.B. Markle Co., operating four collieries, and Coxe Brothers Co., owners of six collieries, to-day granted the demands of the anthracite miners as set forth in the Scranton Convention resolution. This leaves only the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, in the Hazleton region, which has not conceded all that the miners have asked.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1/2@65 3/4. There were no sales.
W.J. Bryan, as the guest of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, had a most enthusiastic and vociferous welcome in this city yesterday afternoon, and last evening.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 27. -- W.J. Bryan will be forced to swear in his vote on election day if he votes at all. He has not registered up to the present time, and only one more day remains in which he can do so -- Friday, Nov. 2. As he will not be in the State on that day, it will be impossible for him to register.

To The Editor of The New York Times: A writer on musical matters in your issue of the 18th is singularly astray in discussing the subject of temperament as related to modern music. He appears to have deceived himself by the use of the word scientific as applied to the natural scale.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The football team of the University of Chicago was this afternoon buried under a score of 41 to 0 at Franklin Field, to the delight of 15,000 Pennsylvanians, who gave vent to their j joy at the close of the game by parading around The field headed by the Red and Blue Band.
SYDNEY, N.S.W., Oct. 27. -- The bill enabling New South Wales to join with, the other colonies of Great Britain in the construction of the Pacific cable has passed all stages without opposition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- There is to be a consolidation of Armour Co. of Chicago and the Armour Packing Company of Kansas City, and an increase in the capital of the Chicago corporation from $20,000,000 to $35,000,000. The plan will be carried out within a week.

LORENZO MARQUES, Sept. 10. -- A trip northward along the East Coast of Africa offers some novelty of scene and a glimpse at places which civilization has yet barely touched, although Central Africa has great prospects of speedy development. Two new lines of steamers are to ply regularly from Europe, with Lorenzo Marques as their furthermost port of call.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- The French Government is not at all pleased at the insight into its colonizing methods that the complaint of Prince Iukanthor, heir to the throne of Cambodia, has given Europe. The Prince still remains in Brussels, and is said to contemplate pawning the crown jewels to pay his hotel bills, since he is unable to obtain any money from his father.

From The Academy. Our Siyott guide, weeks out of his reckoning, had thrown up the sponge. Saddlebags had shrunk like our camels' humps. Our small stock of water looked but a few pints as it swung in the flabby rubber bag from my camel's neck.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The able letter of that sound Democrat Mr. Everelt P. Wheeler, in your issue of the 22d inst., may without offense be somewhat enlarged, for the benefit of Democrats at the coming election.

From The Contemporary Review. I have found that the addition of a pound of fair quality of moist brown sugar to a horse feed of chaff and corn doubles its work-producing power, and that, therefore, the ordinary feed may with this aid be greatly reduced in weight without proportionally reducing the efficiency of the animal getting it.

WASHINGTON, Oct 27. -- There has been considerable talk lately among Cubans and Americans about the early withdrawal of American troops from the island. There will be no complete evacuation for nearly two years, and perhaps longer. This is not because of any intention on the Government's part to permanently retain the island, but is because of the length of time which it will take to get a stable government in operation.

To the Editor The New York Times: The cry of imperialism that the Democrats are so fond of quoting and talking about sounds ridiculous to Republican ears and insults their common sense. It seems to be a mere bluff to lead the unwary astray. Now look at Croker, who bosses the whole Democratic Party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- A deplorable incident concerning the gallant defense of the American Legation at Peking has just come to light. Minister Conger has made serious charges, involving cowardice, insubordination, and neglect of duty, against Capt. Newt H. Hall, who, after Capt. John T. Myers was disabled, was the commander of the little force of American marines.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- While Gov. Roosevelt sat in his private car the other morning chatting with members of his party, the special train which carried him through the Catskills crossed the great Beaverkill swamp at the foot of Wittenberg Mountain and roused a large baldheaded eagle.

What with a greater variety and an increased volume, the business of the last week has been in the highest degree encouraging, and those who look for a really active market a month or six weeks hence regard the dealing of the last few days, accomplished under ante-election conditions, as a thoroughly favorable sign.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of last Thursday there is an article purporting to give a description of a "Settlement House," to be erected on the corner of Fiftieth Street and Tenth Avenue. The neighborhood is characterized by the writer of the article as "Hell's Kitchen."

Nathan Day, who had been a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1876, died Friday night at his home, 19 Park Avenue. He was over seventy years of age, and had been retired for many days. He was formerly a member of the dry goods firm of Nathan Day Co., which afterward became a banking house.

The death of Sims Reeves removes from the British concert stage a personage which had become a tradition. Mr. Reeves was never a great singer in the wide sense of the term. He was a charming interpreter of music of the ballad school, and at one time stood high as an oratorio tenor.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -- One of the most bitterly contested football games ever seen on the Orange Oval was that played this afternoon between the Orange Athletic Club and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club Of New York. In two twenty-minute halves neither team succeeded in scoring, and no time during the game was the ball nearer either goal than the fifteen-yard line.

He was formerly a member of the dry goods firm of Nathan Day Co., which afterward became a banking house.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -- One of the most bitterly contested football games ever seen on the Orange Oval was that played this afternoon between the Orange Athletic Club and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club Of New York. In two twenty-minute halves neither team succeeded in scoring, and no time during the game was the ball nearer either goal than the fifteen-yard line.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- After his trying experience of last night in New York, Gov. Roosevelt has traveled from Jersey City to Binghamton, touching at fourteen places, and making seventeen speeches, long and short, four of them being delivered in this city in as many different halls.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- This has been a colorless week. We suffer from a reaction after the excitement of Parliamentary elections, and also from a certain measure of disgust. Events are not going quite as we should like to see them in any part of the world or the empire.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 27. -- In the stock market here to-day Montana sold down 2, to 320, and rallied to 322 again, with the 320 price made on the sale of another 500-share lot. Isle Royale lost 1/4, to 36 1/4. Old Dominion was at 21 1/2, Amalgamated at 91 1/4, Parrot at 45 1/2, Utah at 33, and Wolverine at 42 1/2.

MUNICH, Oct. 4. -- I have had it on my mind ever since we came back from OberAmmergau to try to write down an account of that most interesting trip. I think the five days we spent there will always be to me one of the most interesting of remembrances. We left Munich early Friday morning, and got to the little village at about 2 o'clock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question before us, the paramount question, is the same one that confronted us in 1896, paramount until it is dead and laid in its grave forever. It is the question that gave Mr. Bryan his first nomination, and that has given him notoriety if not fame throughout the world.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Lord Rosebery's reappearance before the public and his enunciation of a new definition of imperialism cause much comment. Speaking yesterday before a meeting of the Christian Social Union, this versatile and brilliant figure in British politics struck a note which meets with universal approval from all sections of the Liberals, even those who were most bitterly opposed to the former leader.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The urgency of the political situation must be my excuse for intruding upon you again with arguments deprecating Mr. Bryan's course and criticising his utterances during his stumping tour in the present Presidential campaign.

Justice Lawrence, in the New York Supreme Court, yesterday issued a writ of attachment for $700,000 against the property of Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., in favor of the First National Bank on the application of its counsel, Peabody, Baker Peabody.

The specifications for the new British submarine cables in the Pacific have just been published. They call for the construction of more than 8,000 miles of cable to connect the British colonies of Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The issues of the pending conflict between the two great political organizations will determine whether the policy of this Nation is to be one of political isolation or the opposite. Both positions have much to be said in their favor and yet both involve grave consequences.

The Grand Jury of New York County, having dismissed the charges against the officers of the insolvent Traders' Fire Insurance Company of New York, Theodore Sutro, who was the Secretary of the company, has prepared a statement of his connection with and position in the company.

A crowd fully equal to the attendance on the opening day gathered on the Empire City racetrack yesterday to enjoy the half holiday's sport. The track was somewhat muddy from the rain of the night before, but the weather had cleared, and, with conditions favorable for good racing and a very good card, which included two stake events, the contests were thoroughly interesting, and the finishes, as a rule, were close and exciting.

LESE-MAJESTE PROSECUTIONS MULTIPLYING IN GERMANY. -- Newspaper comments upon the various speeches made by the Kaiser in regard to the situation in China and the dispatch of German troops thither have produced no less than five prosecutions on the ground of lese majeste. One case in particular, has called for criticism even from the moderate press, the consensus of opinion being that the Government is going "too far."

From The Nineteenth Century. The British officer is made out of the best materials to be found in all Christendom. He is usually of gentle birth and of sound physique, fortified by the athletic exercises and animated by the honorable traditions of English public schools, brave, courteous, self-respecting, careful of his men, willing to share their hardships, and ready at a pinch to bear their burdens.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27. -- At Franklin Field, Philadelphia, on Dec. 1, for the sixth time, the West Point and Annapolis cadets will meet on the gridiron. In the last contest the navy received an unexpected defeat that quite took the conceit out of the sailors, who, with their friends and adherents, had Relieved there could be but one result.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Senator Depew's tour of the State, which began last Tuesday morning, was finished here tonight in a big tent The speech delivered to-night is the thirty-seventh since he started.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- One of the largest out-door political mass meetings ever organized in Chicago was held to-night in the half mile of State Street known as the "Court of Honor." The great thoroughfare, nearly twice the width of any other street in Chicago, was thronged from Van Buren to Randolph-Street with a cheering, jostling, perspiring mass of people.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- P.M. Helfer and E.A. Holmes, Syracuse University students, discovered a cave near Jamesville, this county, Friday. They crawled into it, and finding a passage leading downward, they entered that also, and soon were in a second cave.

A couple of weeks ago the Mayor's private secretary, Alfred M. Downes, applied to the Corporation Counsel's office for assistance in securing an appointment for a friend of his on one of the commissions for street opening. Downes vouched for the party, as being a good Tammany man. Then the matter dropped for a week.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- October is drawing to a close amid conditions of increasing ease in the money market. The rate for the prolongation of money has fallen to 3 7/8, and there are instances of loans of 3 3/8. Many months have passed since a monthly settlement proved so favorable for the bulls.

Dorothy Pierce, seventeen years old, was overcome by smoke in a fire at 1 o'clock this morning. In her parents' home, at 492 Grand Street, and Capt. George Clifford of Truck No. 18, and Lieut. Reinhardt, were slightly scorched in rescuing her. The girl was taken to Gouverneur Hospital, where it was said she might die.

Thomas Callan escaped from the River Crest Sanitarium, at Long Island City, on Sunday evening, Oct. 21. He had been insane for several years, and his sister, who resides in this city, and friends believe that he is either wandering about in the woods or that he has committed suicide, as he had frequently threatened to do when, in his rational moments, he found he was deprived of his liberty.

The rather unusual expedient of tunneling in sewer building is being adopted by James Pilkington, who has the contract for changing the flow of the large Canal Street sewer east of Centre Street, made necessary by the underground railroad.

"Patriotism: Its Grounds, Obligations, and Duties" formed the subject of an address delivered last night by the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, before the Young Men's Club of that church.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- "Tired but happy" was the appearance of the Tiger football players when they arrived in Princeton this morning after their hard game with Brown and a tiresome journey. All hands, from Captain and coaches down, seem in good spirits over the results of the game.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- M. Waldeck-Rousseau yesterday (Sunday) delivered at Toulouse the anxiously awaited speech outlining the policy and programme of the Government in anticipation of the reassembling of Parliament. The occasion was the laying of the cornerstone of the new barracks there.

PATERSON, Oct. 28. -- A statement was given out to-day by Dr. Townsend in connection with the Bosscheiter murder case. Many people visited the house and the spot where the body was found. Others walked to the jail where Kerr, McAlister, Death, and Campbell are confined. Now and again a voice was heard condemning the four men in angry tones.

Money market conditions continue steadily to improve. The turn in the tide has come, and it is reasonable to expect from this time forward continued betterment. Surplus bank reserves no longer diminish. The unfavorable exhibit of Oct. 20, when reserves were decreased to $2,947,700, marked the low figure, and is probably the last of the kind for some time to come.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 28. -- A total of $20,166,387 worth of gold dust and bullion has bean received at the Seattle Assay Office during the present year. Following are official figures showing, the amount of gold dust and bullion received between Jan. 1 and Oct. 4, 1900: Number of deposits, 6,028; ounces of gold and bullion, 1,243,163.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 28. -- Harvard has sent a letter of inquiry to Pennsylvania regarding McCracken's eligibility, which was causing much discussion in football circles yesterday and last night. The Quaker authorities do not consider the matter as very serious, since they do not think that Harvard will insist upon such a fine technicality as the one which would bar McCracken from playing against the Crimson next Saturday.

PATERSON, Oct. 28. -- Many of the ministers of the different denominations referred in their sermons at the morning and evening services to the tragedy of the death of Jennie Bosscheiter that has caused such indignation in this community. In all the churches where the murder was commented upon swift justice for the four men who are held responsible for her death was demanded.
A mass meeting under the auspices of the Democratic Club of College Men of New York City was held last night at Hammerstein's Victoria Theatre, at Forty-second Street and Seventh Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is the sincere hope of myself and other regular readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES in this vicinity, that THE TIMES will cease its unsuccessful efforts to convince its usually admiring readers that Mr. Stanchfield is independent and will continue to be independent of Croker, and that Mr. Odell is and will continue to be the tool of Platt, even after he is elected Governor.''

The semi-official statement that Lord SALISBURY will retain the double office of Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary, while Mr. CHAMBERLAIN will still guard the Colonial portfolio, will, of course, be interpreted in short-sighted quarters as showing that the majority received by the Government in the recent elections was by its conservative character a rebuke to Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S supposed ambition.

The venerable RUSSELL SAGE has discovered and given to the public a plan for safeguarding the funds of banks and other financial institutions which, like the panacea in medicine, fills a long-felt want. The method is not original, since it is derived from the scheme of rotation followed in progressive euchre, but the application is distinctly so.

The Rev. Jephtha Barcroft, one of the pioneer colored preachers of Westchester County, and a man who spent almost Weentire lifetime in planning and working for the betterment of his race, died on Saturday at his home in Mamaroneck. For more than twenty years he went about Westchester, Putnam, and Rockland Counties, on foot and on horseback, establishing missions and preaching.

From The London Mail. The London representative of one of the largest pork-packing establishments of Chicago was seen by a Daily Mail representative yesterday, and under a pledge that his name should not be published volunteered to give the actual facts of the situation as conveyed to him by reliable advices from the city of pork packers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- "McKinley and Roosevelt," said Vice Chairman Payne of the Republican National Committee yesterday, "will carry every State north of the Potomac River, including Maryland, West Virginia, and Kentucky; every State east of the Missouri River, including Kansas, Nebraska, and both Dakotas; the three Pacific Coast States, and Wyoming.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Nervousness increases in the city, not without reason. We lost u630,000 in gold last week by export, and both the French exchange and yours threaten us with further withdrawals. Our discount brokers have screwed up their rates of three months' bank paper to about 3 3/4, and are struggling to make it 4 per cent.

The Republican State Committee gave out last night two letters which they said were in the nature of official correspondence and would speak for themselves. The first of these letters was addressed to Gov. John R. Tanner of Illinois from James R. B. Van Cleave, Insurance Superintendent of Illinois.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Daily Express claims to have authority for the statement that, when peace is restored, Russia will hand back to its owners the railway from Tong-Ku to Niu-Chwang.

HONOLULU, Oct. 20. -- The heaviest rainstorm which has occurred here within two years began at 7 o'clock on Tuesday night. For half an hour the rain fell in torrents, and within a short time the streets were impassable. The rainfall in Nuuanu Valley, about two miles from Honolulu, was 8.15 inches.
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The Right Hon. Friedrich Max Muller, Corpus Professor of Comparative Philology at Oxford University, died at Oxford to-day at 12:35 P.M. His disease was an affection of the liver.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Gov. Roosevelt has had a day of needed and complete rest. Early in the morning he and Mrs. Roosevelt were driven out into the country about fourteen miles to Lily Lake, spending the day in the woods. Tonight he and Mrs. Roosevelt slipped unobserved out of the Hotel Bennett and into Christ Church immediately opposite.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 28. -- George F. Grassle, a reporter on the staff of one of the Milwaukee daily newspapers, occupied the pulpit of Plymouth Congregational Church to-day and discussed "The Ethical Side of the Newspaper Business; or, The Philosophy of the Press." Mr. Grassie's address was in reply to one delivered by the regular pastor of the church, the Rev, Judson Titsworth, on "What a Preacher Thinks of a Newspaper."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 28. -- A part of the large plant of the Chapot Chamois Company, owned by C. Chapot Son, was completely destroyed by fire this afternoon. The flames, it is believed, were started by rats getting into a box of matches and igniting them. The loss is estimated at $75,000; insurance, $60,000.

At the Calvary Baptist Church last evening the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur, pastor of the church, delivered a sermon in which he called attention to the duties of the patriotic American citizen at the ballot box. Dr. MacArthur chose for his theme that of "Earthly and Heavenly Citizenship and Their Related Duties."

We are a little ashamed of ex-Senator HILL. We have frequently had occasion of late years to recognize his possession of an amount of political wisdom much greater than that of other Democratic leaders in this State, and in the period preceding the actual opening of the Presidential campaign he made vigorous though not very successful efforts to guide his party in ways not absolutely ruinous.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- President Eliot stated to-night that his intention throughout the campaign has been to vote the Republican ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Isaac N. Seligman of this city recently caused to be published a letter written by him in which he takes exception, among other things, to the personnel of the Sound Currency Committee of the Reform Club.
Senator William P. Frye of Maine has addressed an open letter to Candidate Bryan in which he says:

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Complete returns from the Republican canvass indicate a plurality for McKinley in Illinois, outside of Cook County, aggregating 81,770. This would be a clear gain over the vote cast for him four years ago of 9,096. Everybody at State Headquarters firmly believes these figures will not vary materially from the final result.

A special committee of the Social Reform Club has canvassed the Republican and Democratic candidates for Senate and Assembly in Greater New York as to their positions on the Ramapo question. The following questions were submitted to each candidate:

In accordance with a time-honored custom of the politicians the last week before election, especially a Presidential election, is given up largely to the task of arousing enthusiasm and getting out the vote. The processes previously adopted for convincing the minds of voters are for the most part abandoned, and even the chief laborers in that field are apt to devote themselves more to exhortation than to argument.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The question of English versus American methods in the racing world continues to agitate the sporting writers for the London press. The Daily Telegraph again protests against the idea that the supporters of Lord Durham are animated by feeling of Jealousy and points to instances of warm welcome extended to American owners and jockeys.

To the yachting man, and "all who plow the waters" near or about New York, there is given one unfailing sign of the approach of Winter. This is an almost simultaneous disappearance of the countless fleet of pleasure craft that from early May until late October adds picturesque movement to the natural beauty of Long Island Sound and the Hudson.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- For several days past the corridors of Vassar College have been hung with campaign posters announcing that a Republican mass meeting would be held in Phil Hall last night. The posters were enormous affairs, bearing such devices as "The Full Dinner Pail" and the Republican elephant.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Experimental excavations at various points along the route of the Charing Cross, Euston and Hampstead Railway, whose franchise was recently acquired by Charles T. Yerkes, will be begun to-morrow, and the work will then be continued without interruption.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The Republican and Democratic State Committees are doing closer figuring on Maryland than ever before in a Presidential contest. The Democrats, on reports from every district in the State and the wards in Baltimore, predict from 3,000 to 5,000 plurality for Bryan.

MANILA, Oct. 28. -- A private launch towing a barge loaded with merchandise near Arayat was attacked by a force of 150 insurgents under David Fagin, a deserter from the Twenty-fourth Infantry. The American troops, en hearing the firing, turned out in force before the boat could be looted and recaptured it.
Money on call daring the week loaned at 2@6 per cent., closing on Saturday at 3 per cent.

We have expressed the nope that our correspondent in Peking may be to some extent misinformed as to the particular excesses of the German troops in Northern China. We may as well add that the hope partakes more of the character of desire than expectation. Our correspondent is a man of unusually clear judgment, impartial in temperament, careful and experienced.

In the suit incident to the coffee war between the Arbuckle and Havemeyer interests which has been going on for the past four years a decision involving several points was rendered in Toledo, Ohio, on Saturday by Judge Pugsley of the Circuit Court as already told in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WHAT THE KAISER REALLY SAID AT SAALBURG. -- On Oct. 11, Wilhelm II. of Germany laid the cornerstone, as reported by cable, of the Imperial Museum, at Saalburg, near Homburg, on the site of which was an old Roman castellum, which is being restored under the direction of some German antiquarians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has just come to hand the report of the proceedings of the Association of Chambers of Commerce of the United Kingdom, held in Paris on Sept. 5-8 ult. At the time this gathering of English merchants in the French capital was favorably commented upon, but nowhere have I seen any notice of the remarks, made at this meeting's banquets, on the subject of commercial education.

F.D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banks, at the instance of the Non-Partisan Sound Money, Industrial, and Commercial League, has prepared an article on the statistics of savings banks as an index and proof of National prosperity or the reverse. In part the article is as follows:

Such information as was forthcoming in Mount Vernon yesterday in the Alvord case was of a negative character. Chief Foley said there were absolutely no developments. He also said that he had received no advices from New York in the nature of circulars offering a reward, or of any other kind.

WHAT THE KAISER REALLY SAID AT SAALBURG. -- On Oct. 11, Wilhelm II. of Germany laid the cornerstone, as reported by cable, of the Imperial Museum, at Saalburg, near Homburg, on the site of which was an old Roman castellum, which is being restored under the direction of some German antiquarians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has just come to hand the report of the proceedings of the Association of Chambers of Commerce of the United Kingdom, held in Paris on Sept. 5-8 ult. At the time this gathering of English merchants in the French capital was favorably commented upon, but nowhere have I seen any notice of the remarks, made at this meeting's banquets, on the subject of commercial education.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The formality of holding an inquest in the Bosscheiter case was gone through to-night. The testimony taken Drought out nothing new, and the jury found a verdict in accordance with the known facts, holding the four men now in prison responsible for her death.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Oct. 24. -- Among the people of Porto Rico the all-absorbing interest just now is in politics. Planters and peons alike are swelling with importance over the prospect of taking part in an election in which the sovereign will of the people will be expressed -- for the first time, possibly, in these latitudes.

PEKING, Oct. 28. -- Prince Su, who accompanied the Chinese Court in the flight to Tai-Yuen-Foo, and afterward returned here disheartened by the anarchy existing among those composing the immediate advisers of the throne, gave, in the course of an interview to-day, an interesting account of his journey.

DAMAGES TO EASEMENTS OF ABUTTING OWNERS. -- The question of damages to abutting owners on Park Avenue, because of the elevated structures erected there by the New York and Harlem Railroad Company, under the legislative sanctions granted in 1872 and 1892, was passed upon in one of its phases by Justice Freedman, at Special Term of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Supreme Court to-day, on motion of John G. Carlisle, advanced and assigned for argument on Jan. 7 next the case of Elias S.A. De Lima et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. George R. Bidwell, Collector of Customs at the Port of New York.

How the disaster had its origin may never be known. The persons responsible for it, if responsibility there be outside of causes beyond control, may be lying dead under tons of wreckage that are piled high on the site of the Tarrant Building. What has been established is that Policeman Greec of the Church Street Station saw a thin stream of smoke issuing from the ''third-story windows of the Tarrant Building at 12:15 o'clock.
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- A dispatch received here from Pretoria announces the death from enteric fever of Prince Christian Victor of Schleswig-Holstein.

Many persons who were near the scene of the fire and explosions had narrow escapes from death. Many were injured, seriously or otherwise; all were thoroughly terror stricken, and in their talks later with reporters for THE NEW YORK TIMES declare that the scene after the most disastrous explosion, was indescribable.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 29. -- Dr. and Mrs. William T. Bull have closed their Newport season and gone to New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- After the Tigers had been put through a sprinting exercise by Trainer "Jim" Robinson, the 'Varsity team was put through fast signal practice, including formations for end runs, centre plays, and drop kicking. Then the scrub team and the freshman eleven were lined up for a lively game.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Oct. 29. -- Octavio Mena, formerly a clerk in the office of the Captain of the Port, was to-day found guilty of the murder, about a month ago, of Col. Pavon of the Cuban Army, whom he killed in a drunken row.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The City Imperial Volunteers reached here to-day, and received a tumultuous greeting from enormous crowds. The day was, however, marred by a large number of casualties among the onlookers, the crowds becoming Utterly unmanageable in the narrow streets.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 29. -- Josiah White, a farmer, visited the home of his nephews, Joseph, James, and Everett White, at Sweet Valley to-day. There was trouble between the uncle and nephews over the ownership of some property. They had gone to law about the matter, and it worried the uncle.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 29. -- James B. Ferguson to-day decided to sell his entire stud of thoroughbred horses, including St. George, Prince Royal, and twenty-five brood mares, including Marie Janzen, the dam of Black Fox.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- An order was issued to-day by direction of the President, discontinuing the Division of Cuba and the Eastern and Western Departments of that division and establishing the Department of Cuba. Gen. Leonard Wood is placed in command of the new department.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Five hundred men undertook to break up Senator Depew's meeting here this afternoon, and partially succeeded. The Town Committee undertook to restore order and failed. Mr. Bryan had spoken here in the morning at the fair grounds. The town was full of people from the surrounding country.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Margaret Shepard, who has been delivering anti-Catholic lectures in this city for about a week, was this afternoon ordered to discontinue her addresses, on the ground that they were immoral and unfit for any one to hear.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- There was little life to the trading in the stock market to-day. Commission houses sold Marsden down to 8; Railways Company General, 2 1/2; Smokeless Powder, 10 5/8; Electric Company of America, 9 3/4; United Gas Improvement, 115 1/2; Union Traction, 33 3/4; Cement, 8; American Asphalt os, from 70 1/4 to 69.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., the absconding note teller of the First National Bank in New York City, who is charged with stealing $700,000 from the bank, was arrested here this afternoon by Chief Inspector William B. Watts of this city and Detective Armstrong of New York in an ordinary lodging house at the corner of West Newton Street and Huntington Avenue.

What is to be the opening of New York's fashionable season? That is one of the topics one constantly hears discussed at the fashionable resorts and at the theatres nowadays. Heretofore the Horse Show and the opera which followed immediately after set the date. Now comes the vogue of the automobile with all the fashionable set interested in the new fad, and with a show of those machines right at hand.

Mr. BRYAN'S proposition to put the product of every trust on the free list is a perfectly sound one economically, but it is not original with him, as he appears to think that it is; and it is totally inadequate to effect the abolition of the trusts, assuming that they are the horrid things which he describes.

The stampeding of the voters of a State is an undertaking of much more serious moment than the stampeding of the delegates in a convention hall: and a sudden change in the political intentions of a large group of States would be so astonishing as to fall altogether outside the field of calculable campaign events.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- To-day witnessed an almost general resumption of work in the anthracite coal region, where for six weeks the mine workers have been on strike for an advance in wages, a reduction in the price of powder, and in several districts, the abolition of the sliding scale of wages.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 29. -- Over 5,000 mine employes in the Lackawanna Valley refused to return to work this morning because the companies for which they had mined coal failed to comply with the terms of the Scranton miners' convention. The companies affected were the Ontario and Western Railroad Company, the Forest Mining Company, the Green Ridge Coal Company, and the Clark Tunnel Coal Company.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- The long and bitterly discussed question of sophomore societies in Yale College was settled to-day, and the following official announcement was made:

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Gov. Roosevelt began the last week of his State campaign tour with visits to-day to Cortland, Ithaca, and Elmira, places recently visited by Mr. Bryan. He made five principal speeches at these places, and two brief speeches at towns not scheduled for stops.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The Times-Herald will print to-morrow the following New York dispatch from its special correspondent, Walter Wellman:

Mr. Bryan's speechmaking in this city and Brooklyn last night followed a hard day's work in the interior of the State. He made an address at 9 o'clock in the morning at Bainbridge, Chenango County, and after that spoke in succession at Sidney. Unadilla, Oneonta, Otego, Schenevus, Cobbleskill, Voorheesville, Delanson, Ravena, Coxsackie, Catskill, Saugerties, Kingston, Highlands, Marlborough, Cornwall, Highland Falls, Haverstraw, West Nyack, and Little Ferry.

In the face of it the resumption of work throughout the anthracite coal fields of Pennsylvania is not merely a victory for the miners. It is a confession, on the part of the operators, that they have been coerced into allowing to their workmen a share in the profits of their industry to which the miners were entitled, but to which the operators would not have admitted them without coercion.
