MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- About the time her husband was arrested in Boston Mrs. Alvord went to New York. After she departed Sheriff Molloy arrived from White Plains armed with papers directing him to attach the property of the Alvords. He was accompanied by three deputies. Accompanying the Sheriff were Deputies Frank Jarvis, James, and Stafford. The Sheriff took immediate charge.

Aggressive selling for short account and some resulting liquidation by weak or timid holders were the features of the stock market yesterday, with quotations quite generally declining as a consequence. There was no unfavorable news influencing to the lower range of prices; but professionals proceeded on the theory that after the recent sustained rise a reaction was in order.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Harvard's last week of practice before the game with the University of Pennsylvania began, today with a game between the 'Varsity and the scrub, in which the former scored, three touch-downs.

During a slight fire in the four-story brick building at 947 Eighth Avenue last night at midnight, three women who had fainted were carried from the building. Several citizens who were in the neighborhood claim to have, made the rescues and their claim is disputed by some policemen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Trustees of the Sanitary District to-day took preliminary steps toward setting on foot the stupendous scheme for a giant harbor at Chicago by connecting the Chicago and Calumet Rivers with a navigable channel. They repudiated the contract with the State Canal Commission to maintain navigation in the old Illinois and Michigan channel, and notice will be served upon the Commissioners that the Bridgeport Pumping Works will be abandoned Nov. 15.

The American Bible Society has received from the Rev. John R. Hykes, D.D., of Shanghai, its agent in China, a report dated Shanghai Sept. 13, in which he states that the total number of Protestants known to have been massacred as the result of the anti-foreign movement in China, and concerning whose death there cannot be a reasonable doubt, is 93.
ALLIANCE, Ohio, Oct. 20. -- At the Republican mass-meeting held here to-night the following letter from President McKinley was read:
"Without a doubt, Dick Croker must be losing his head."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- With 1,500 barrels of sperm oil and 3,000 pounds of whalebone, the whaling bark Charles W. Morgan arrived to-day from the South Seas and Japanese coast. The Morgan is owned by William R. Wing of New Bedford, Mass., who also owns the whalers California and Alice Knowies, both returning from long cruises off the coast of Japan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I passed down Fifth Avenue yesterday morning I beheld on the board fence between Fortieth and Forty-second Streets, where the Public Library is being built, an illustrated summary of the various trusts which Messrs. Bryan, Croker, Van Wyck, "et hoc genus omne " are inviting their friends and fellow-citizens to vote against.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The report of Brig. Gen. Heywood, commanding the United States Marine Corps, made public by the Navy Department to-day, contains the following account of the seizure of bullion in Tien-Tsin:

William Jennings Bryan, the Democratic candidate for the Presidency, made a flying trip last evening across Manhattan Island. He delivered one speech in this borough, and was hurried over to Brooklyn where he made several other speeches.

The brighter weather of yesterday was a relief from the gloomy skies and mists of Saturday and Sunday, and made a marked change in the appearance of the fashionable streets and avenues up town. Many of those who went to Tuxedo for the ball of Friday night and who remained there over Sunday returned to town yesterday, and in consequence there were many familiar faces at the favored restaurants at the luncheon and dinner hours.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A sermon defending the army canteen was preached yesterday by the Rev. George Buckley of the New York Avenue Methodist Church.

Firemen of Hook and Ladder Company No. 9, stationed in Elizabeth Street, and a gang of fifteen "beer-canners" engaged in a lively scrimmage in the company's quarters yesterday, in which the firemen came off victorious.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Thanksgiving Day proclamation has been issued. The State Department to-day gave out the following:

The greater part of two business blocks was wiped out of existence yesterday, and under the ruins this morning it is probable lie the bodies of forty or more unfortunate victims of fire and explosion. Fire was the first cause of the disaster that bids fair to rank with the many that have in late years visited New York.
MADRID, Oct. 29. -- A conflict between twenty-four armed Carlists and a detachment of gendarmes occurred yesterday near Eadalona, a town six miles northeast of Barcelona.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Mme. Yvette Guilbert, the French music hall artiste, is in Berlin to undergo a dangerous surgical operation for the relief of a throat affection. The operation will be performed by Prof. Israel.
DUNKIRK, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Mr. Bryan wound up his campaign work in New York State with a speech to-night in this city. His address here was the sixteenth in the course of the day.
The Directors of the Atlantic Trust Company and the Bankers' Trust Company have under consideration a plan for the possible consolidation of the two companies.

ROCHESTER, N.Y.,Oct. 30. -- Gov. Roosevelt ended the second day of the second week of his State tour in Rochester to-night. It was a most laborious day, wet and forbidding to outdoor audiences and uncomfortable to the Governor and the speakers who accompany him. Beginning at Elmira, his journey took him to Corning, Bath, Wayland, Livonia, Avon, Geneseo, Canandalgua, Geneva, Penn Yan, and Rochester, requiring a wide circuit in the heart of the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The announcement of the population of the United States, made to-day by the Census Bureau, at once started speculation about the effect on the apportionment for members of Congress. The general opinion is that it will cause the biggest increase in the number of people required to constitute a Congressional district that has ever been known in the history of the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Princeton's 'Varsity eleven contested with the scrub team on University Field this afternoon for the space of nearly an hour. It was the longest game that Princeton's players have thus far taken part in, and was as hard-fought as it was long. From the start the second team made ground gaining difficult for the university team, disputing almost every yard of turf.

An appreciable contribution to the interest of the Paris Exposition, to the pleasure and comfort of American visitors there, and to the growth of mutual understanding and friendship between the world's two greatest Republics has been made, we think, by the publication of the Paris Exposition Edition of THE TIMES, of which the last issue will appear to-day.

Reinforced by big Neyzer, the old Indiana University guard, Columbia's 'Varsity football team ran the scrub eleven off its feet in a short practice game on Columbia Field yesterday afternoon. In less than fifteen minutes of actual play three touch-downs were scored by the 'Varsity. More could have been made if Coach Sanford had permitted the 'Varsity to play a solely offensive game.
Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., the defaulting note teller of the first National Bank, who was arrested in Boston on Monday, was twice arraigned yesterday in the Centre Street Police Court.

The campaign of the little professional market raiders who lately have been industrious short sellers of stocks on the Stock Exchange was nipped rather ingloriously in the bud yesterday afternoon when, on some substantial buying orders being placed in the market by a number of large interests, it developed that the floating supply of stock was limited.

The budget, which represents the estimated cost of the Government of the City of New York for 1901, was passed yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Mayor Van Wyck and the other city officials tried to keep the budget under $100,000,000, and they succeeded by a small margin.

Max Lichtwitz, a personal friend of State Senator Timothy D. Sullivan, and an assistant manager of the Dewey Theatre, may become the sole heir to his deceased wife's estate, although he left her one year after their marriage.

The performance of Shakespeare's love tragedy, which is on view, twice daily, at the Murray Hill Theatre this week, is meritorious in many respects, and the highest price asked for a seat to see it is half a dollar. At the matinees every seat in the house is sold for 25 cents. This is certainly bringing Shakespeare within reach of the masses.

Senator FRYE, in his singularly clear and cogent statement of Mr. BRYAN'S misrepresentations, which we published Monday morning, put forward one contrast between the truth and Mr. BRYAN's idea of it that will appeal with especial force to the class among whom the latter hopes to find the largest number of supporters.

The second will of William M. Rice, in which Albert T. Patrick is made the principal beneficiary, is now sealed up and deposited in the safe of Samuel Untermyer of the law firm of Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall, and will be offered for probate within the next ten days.

William Watson Niles, who was the chief promoter of the beautiful park system in the Borough of the Bronx, died at his residence, Woodlawn Road, Bedford Park, yesterday morning. Mr. Niles was in his seventy-ninth year. He was really the father of the park system above the Harlem River.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 30. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day at this place heard testimony as to the application of Edward S. Campbell, receiver of the Middlesex County Bank, to compel the Directors of that bank to make good $201,747.82, the amount of the shortage caused by the speculations of George M. Valentine, and other losses alleged to have been occasioned by the neglect of the officers of the bank.
The following correspondence between Carl Schurz and Charles Francis Adams was made public yesterday:

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Biscuit common opened at 35 1/4, advanced to 35 3/8, and closed there. The preferred sold up from 89 to 90 1/4 at the close. Street railway stocks were steady at 99 3/4 to par for West Chicago, 89 for Union Loop, and 250 for City Railway. Metropolitan Elevated common brought 31 5/8@32.

After nearly thirty-six hours of work on the ruins of the buildings burned or destroyed in the fire and explosion which had its origin in the Tarrant Building at Warren and Greenwich Streets at noon on Monday, the workmen have brought out the remnants of what are believed to be two bodies. They have been sent to the Morgue and labeled "Body No. 1" and "Body No. 2."

BATH, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- The first stop of the day of the Roosevelt train was made at Corning, the home of the club which was assaulted last night during the parade in Elmira. In his speech Gov. Roosevelt said in part:

RACINE, Wis., Oct. 30. -- The Horlick Food Company of this city, manufacturers of malted milk, lost between $25,000 and $30,000 worth of their goods in the Tarrant Co.'s building, which was destroyed by fire in New York yesterday. The Horlick stock in the Tarrant Building was insured for about $10,000.

The explosion of Monday in a drug warehouse had consequences that make it not only memorable but unique in our annals of disaster. The ruin was so complete that even now it is uncertain whether the loss of life was great or small. The storing of drugs and "chemicals" in a crowded city is looked upon by the law as an "extra hazardous" business calling for precaution and regulation.
OWENSBOROUGH, Ky., Oct. 30. -- Official announcement of the wedding of Gov. Beckham and Miss Jean Rachael Fuqua was made to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- E. H. Harriman has bought the control of the Kansas City Southern Railway Instead of selling out to the persons represented by John W. Gates. The new arrangement was made on Friday, up to which time the plan was that the Gates people should buy the Harriman holdings.
The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has reversed the decision of Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court in the Haffen-Nagle fight in the Twenty-first Senatorial District.

There were several good brushes on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, but the rain caused a postponement of the majority of the heats that had been arranged for until Friday afternoon, when some excellent sport is looked forward to. The footing was fairly good yesterday, and the upper stretch was chosen by the drivers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30. -- The Post to-day prints an affidavit of Finley B. Anderson, a telegraph operator, who testified against Caleb Powers, who was convicted of complicity in the murder of Gov. Goebel, in which Anderson denies certain important statements that he made on the witness stand in the Powers trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct., 30. -- Smallpox has broken out on a number of Indian reservations in the West, and it is feared that when the cold weather sets in the epidemic will become more widespread and assume a more malignant form. Every possible effort is being made to stay the progress of the disease, and the Indian Bureau is forwarding vaccine virus to the various agencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- John W. Yerkes, the Republican candidate for Governor of Kentucky, is in Washington. He has resigned as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Eighth Kentucky District, to take effect Nov. 1. Mr. Yerkes said to-day:

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 30. -- President John K. Cowen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company refuted with convincing proofs the charge of coercing employes made against him by The Baltimore Sun and reiterated by Chairman Jones and Mr. Bryan.

Considerable excitement was created among the diners at Sherry's last evening when a well-dressed young man ran through the dining room followed by a policeman and several citizens. The man ran out into the hall-way and into the barber shop, where he was arrested. He was taken to the East Fifty-first Street Station, where he described himself as Nate Homer, a waiter, living at 259 West Twenty-ninth Street.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30. -- The Maryland Steeplechase Association began to-day a three days' racing season for cross-country horses at Pimlico. There was a large attendance of society as well as horsemen. Both track and turf were in fine condition, and excellent racing was the order. Betting was spirited and the three bookmakers had their hands full to accommodate the speculatively inclined.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Senator Depew wound up a day of hard campaigning with an address here to-night to an audience of 4,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 30. -- Even to-day Harvard's athletic Faculty refused to make any statements regarding McCracken's ineligibility. It is thought they are waiting for Pennsylvania to receive Harvard's ultimatum and make its contents public before they state their position officially. McCracken may not be the only Pennsylvania player to be protested, for it is rumored that Harvard has also sent a note to Pennsylvania asking about the standing of Quarterback Graves.

The bureau of information established by Chief Devery at the Leonard Street Police Station received a number of inquiries for persons who failed to return home Monday night, and it is feared that a number of these are buried in the ruins.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30. -- A report is published here to the effect that the Carnegie Steel Company intends to invade the sheet steel business by manufacturing this product at their Duquesne works.

The figures of the twelfth decennial census of the United States of America are now at last given out. Or, more properly, that one figure on which most of the others depend is given out, the figure of the total population. There is no suspicion of any tampering with the facts on the part of anybody concerned, as there has been in some past censuses.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 30. -- An important arrest was made by customs officials here to-day. The prisoner, August Mason, a hunchback, is said to be one of the most expert and successful smugglers in this country. He was caught with goods in his possession upon which no duty had been paid.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The report that Graves, the speedy little quarter back of the Pennsylvania football eleven, may be protested by Harvard is too ridiculous for consideration, said a prominent Pennsylvanian to-night. Graves is a graduate of Germantown Academy, is a regularly enrolled student, and is well within the lines of the Red and Blue eligibility.

A 100 live bird match at thirty yards, between T. W. Morfey and John J. Hallowell of the New Utrecht Gun Club, for $100 a side, was shot yesterday afternoon at Inter-State Park, and was won by Hallowell, Who killed 97 birds, to Morfey's 93.

To-day, in the language of the Church, is the vigil of the Feast of All Saints, one of the most beautiful in its sentiment of the feasts of the Christian year. This evening is consequently All Hallowe'en. At most of the country clubs, particularly at Tuxedo, and in many of the country houses in the suburbs now open and filled with guests, the old-time anniversary will be celebrated with appropriate and time-honored games and frolics.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 30. -- The second day of the National Beagle Club's trials finished up, Class AA for fifteen-inch bitches. George F. Reed's True and Somerset Beagle's Flossie were first put down and ran a long race. Both showed good, but Flossie proved best. The next brace down was Rockbridge Kennels' Treble and Summers's Bess.
Bryan L. Kennelly Co. have sold for Alice Larken to Mrs. L.B. Leaycraft the five-story brick tenement, with stores, 439 West Twenty-sixth Street, 27.6 by 98.9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The official announcement of the total population of the United States for 1900 is 76,295,220, of which 74,627,907 are contained in the forty-five States representing approximately the population to be used for apportionment purposes. There is a total of 134,158 Indians not taxed.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 30. -- The wedding of Walter Schuyler Kemeys and Miss Emma Dorrance Stone, daughter of the late George F. Stone, was celebrated at Morristown, N. J., yesterday. The ceremony was performed in the South Street Presbyterian Church at 12:30 o'clock, the Rev. Maltby Babcock of the Brick Church of this city officiating.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Mayor Frank H. Flood called a special meeting of the Police Commissioners at 2 o'clock this afternoon to take action on the mob violence of last evening and the assault on Gov. Roosevelt during the Republican parade. A large turnip, an old shoe, and a club taken from the Roosevelt carriage are on exhibition to-day at Republican Headquarters as the missiles that struck Roosevelt.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- John Mitchell, a laborer, aged forty, having a wife and three children living at Wappinger's Falls, was killed in front of a chicken coop on the farm of W.V. Brown, that village, last night.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Money was firmer to-day, in view of the demands in connection with the month end, the more potent influence of the Bank of England's takings from the market, and the expectation of further considerable withdrawals at the coming consol settlement. The condition of foreign exchanges caused discounts to harden.

A young woman who registered at the Grand Union Hotel, Forty-second Street and Park Avenue, Monday evening as Miss A. Cram, Greenfield, Mass., was found unconscious in her bed yesterday morning, her condition being due to the inhalation of gas.

The new lecture hall of the American Museum of Natural History was opened yesterday afternoon with appropriate ceremonies. A large number of friends and patrons were present, and a reception was held. The halls of the new west wing were visited.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The Republican Ciub of Princeton University met a telegram to W.J. Bryan the day a was to speak at Princeton Junction, restliig him to answer two Questions f-9Sn lie shout . the students. To the surprise ;i.. 'di-appointment of the St|Qk Mr. Bryan tailed to answer the periess in his spech. and they supposed that he decided to ignore them.

The long-expected promotions in the Police Department are coming soon if the Police Board and the Civil Service Board can agree as to the proper ratings for merit of the candidates for the several ranks. The Police Commissioners, after a delay of months, got together yesterday afternoon and worked till a late hour last night, getting the ratings together.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has changed its late steel rail contract from 150,000 to 144,000 tons at $20 a ton and makes its final awards as follows :

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The old sloop Wacondah, which has been a landmark of the old Piepgrass yard for the past five or six years, has been sold by Henry Doscher of New York to A. Ebenspacker, owner of the sloop Bonny Kate. The ballast was taken out and the boat was launched from the Jacob yard and placed in the marine basin until the opened seams swell and close.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The Civil Tribunal has appointed George J. Gould trustee for the Countess Boni de Castellane, his sister.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The State Department to-day made public the British-German agreement respecting the maintenance of the "open door" and territorial integrity of China, with the answer of the United States Government, sent in duplicate to each of the principals to the agreement.

Deary, wintry weather and the promised uncertainties of a heavy track greatly reduced the attendance at the Empire City race track yesterday, and few except the regular racegoers made the trip to Yonkeis." The card, however, was a fairly attractive one, with about the best class horses of the late Fall campaign in at least two of the events.

To the Editor of The New York Times. Never before in the history of the United States have we had issues of more paramount importance to engage our intelligent consideration than those that confront us at this moment and are to be settled at the ballot box in November.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Dr. von Siemens, President of the Deutsche Bank, is in Paris completing negotiations for financing the Swiss railroads. The transaction, it is said, involves a loan of 800,000,000f. at 4 per cent., which will be raised principally by American banks, assisted by English, French, German, and Swiss financiers.

John Evans, Leonard Watson, and Ferdinand Gardner were committed to the Tombs yesterday by Magistrate Flammer in default of $2,000 ball each, charged with blackmailing Charles W. Morgan, a Consolidated Stock Exchange broker of 71 Broadway. The attorney for Evans, John Harold Warner, later deposited cash bail with the City Chamberlain, and Evans was released.

In the Greater New York tournament on Thum Ehler's Palace Alleys, Brooklyn, last night, a score of 278 -- the highest of the season so far -- was rolled by Dixon of the Palace Bowling Club. It included nine successive strikes. All three clubs in this tournament last night broke even, each wining one game and losing one, The scores:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 - W.J. Bryan tonight made his first speech here during the present campaign He arrived on a special train at o'clock to-night and went direct to Music Hall, where he talked for an hour, Lodon Harmon, Attorney General under resident Cleveland, presided at the meeting and there were many other leading Democrsts present.

Three trucks filled with speakers started out from the Republican headquarters at 800 Eighth Avenue early last evening to be used in carrying on meetings in the Thirteenth Congressional District in support of the party candidate, William R. Willcox.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest Mr. Ernest H. Crosby's answar to ray letter in reference to the conduct of the present administration in the Philippines.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Sheriff Jacob L. Van Buskirk of Bergen County and a number of his deputies are aiding the New York officers to search for Flannigan, the negro, who murdered Keeper Hugh McGovern of the Seventh District Court Prison in New York. Flannigan has been traced to Bergen County, and was seen at Englewood and Hackensack on Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The Marquis of Lansdowne's elevation to the Foreign Secretaryship, announced in The Daily Telegraph yesterday morning, has, figuratively speaking, taken the country's breath away. It was as unexpected as it is unwelcome. Even the stanchest Ministerial mouthpieces among the newspapers openly condemn it.

Isaac Devoe, ill and eighty-three years of age; is imprisoned for debt in Ludlow Street Jail. Once Mr. Devoe was wealthy, said to have been worth a quarter of a million dollars, but now he stands a fair prospect of remaining in jail, unless some one liquidates for him a debt of $614.77.

Inactivity such as that which prevailed in midsummer ruled in the stock market yesterday. Barely 230,000 shares were traded in, with much of the dealing limited to a few specialties. In the early trading what few transactions there were gave indication of the substantial strength of the support.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Stephen Phillips's historical drama "Herod" was produced last evening at Her Majesty's Theatre by Beerbohm Tree. It is a splendid spectacle, but contains scarcely enough dramatic action to make a great success.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- By a decree of Emperor Nicholas the adoption by Count Cassini of Mlle. Marguerite Cassini, the grandniece of the Russian Ambassador, has been officially recognized, and she will henceforth have the title of Countess and the full right and title of a daughter in the Ambassador's household, whether in St. Petersburg, Paris, or Washington.

Ex-President CLEVELANDS abhors Bryanism, he detests the destructive doctrines which that agitator has taught in the past and continues to teach. Nobody but a person devoid of sense would be capable of supposing that he would vote for BRYAN. Nobody but a shameless prevaricator would have the hardihood to assert that he is going to vote for BRYAN.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 31 -- There was a heavy rainfall all over Texas last night and to-night, and much damage has been done to open cotton. Property was also damaged to some extent in different places by wind and lightning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Senator Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, speaking of Croker's recent suggestion that "Democratic voters congregate about the polling places on the evening of election day, count noses, and then, if the election returns for Bryan do not tally with their count, go into the polling places and throw those fellows in charge of the returns into the street," said:

Capt, and Mrs. Herman Townsend celebrated the sixty-second anniversary of their wedding yesterday. They are the parents of Mrs. William Le Baron G. Alien, who is Known as a playwright and verse writer under the pseudonym of Townsend Alien, She gave a reception from 4 to 6 o'clock in their honor at her residence, on Boulevard Lafayette and Fort Washington Park.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- On University field this afternoon, the 'Varsity, team struggled against the second team for forty or fifty minutes before any scoring was done, and then in the last few minutes of play scored four touchdowns under sensational circumstances. During the entire first half and the greater part of the second neither side could break through the other's defense for large gains.

To the Editor of The NEw York Times: Referring to your editorial in to-day's issue, beaded "The Safeguarding of Banks." which contained a reference to Mr. Russell Sage's plan for preventing defalcations by shifting clerks from one position to another, and also contained your criticism of Mr. Russell Sage's plan.

"If shooting at pigeons from traps is a Jegitimate and a gentleman's sport," observed a gentleman at one of the clubs yesterday, "why is it that so many of our men shoot under assumed names? Are they ashamed of the game or is it because they do not want the fact known when they are beaten? Neither reason is very sportsman-like.

Fortunately for Great Britain, for the United States, and for mankind, we are not yet called upon to write the political obituary of Lord SALISBURY. Neither are we required to sum up, as a thing concluded, the history of his foreign policy. It is plain that he is to remain the Prime Minister of Great Britain.

For several years isolated, experiments in the hospitals have encouraged the hope that we were, on the eve of the discovery that a working combination of hypnotism and surgery was entirely practicable. From time to time we have been favored with accounts, on fairly credible lay authority, of wonderfull exhibitions by French surgeons who have performed critical operations upon patients so effectually hypnotixed that all their recollections of the experience were agreeable.

NAYACK, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- There was launched to-day at the Ayer's ship yards, this place, what will probably be the fastest vessel afloat. The craft is the fastest vessel afloat. The craft is the steam yacht Arrow, designed by C.D. Mosher for Charls R. Fliny of New York City.

ROSLYN, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- A large crowd witnessed to-day's Beagle trials, when two classes were concluded and the Derby class staited. The first run off was Class A, for 15 inch dogs. Ichabod repeated his victory of last year. He and Dorsey's Woodman were first, put down, and Ichabod did most of the work.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 31 -- Senator Hanna has been making campaign speeches in Indiana to-day, traveling about the State in a special train. His first address was made at South Bend to an audience composed largely of workingmen. Most of the factories in the city were closed from 11:30 to 2 o'clock to enable the employes to hear Mr. Hanna.

Frederick D. Yuenling the scn of the well know brewer had a hearing before United States Commissoner Alexander yesteirday afternoon on the complaint made by the British Consul General charging him with embezzlement in Rossland B.C., and asking for his extradition.
A young man of somewhat shabby exterior strolled into the Victoria Hotel yesterday afternoon.

The first official investigation of the Tarrant Building disaster was begun at Fire Headquarters yesterday morning by Fire Marshal Peter Seery. Associated with him was Assistant District Attorney James J. Walsh. The investigation was private, the excuse being that there was no accommodation in the Marshal's little office for the public.

EDINBURGH, Oct. 31. -- The formal union of the Free and United Presbyterian Churches, decided upon yesterday at the joint meeting here of the Free Church Assembly and the United Presbyterian Synod, was consummated this morning. The ministers marched from their respective halls to the Royal Institution, then proceeded to Waverley Market, and held the first meeting of the United Free Church of Scotland. Large crowds witnessed the procession.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Post have closed their cottage and are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster for a few days. They intend to leave for New York Saturday.

OREEDMOOR, Oct. 31. -- The last supplementary practice for the season of 1900 was held here to-day for the expert class at 700 and 800 yards. The attendance was fair and the weather cold and cloudy, with a moderate wind blowing across the target. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Business in mining stocks fell off to-day to very small proportions, and, barring Amalgamated, was flat in the extreme. Amalgamated sold between 90 1/2 and 91 1/2. Montana eased 6 1/2 to 315, at which price 1,000 shares sold in one lot; later the price rallied. A transfer of a large interest in the stock evidently is making through the Stock Exchange, but what it represents is veiled in mystery.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Senator Depew made nine political addresses to-day, including two in this city. His talks, in the main, were repetitions of previous speeches delivered in the course of his tour of the State. Several of them, however, were enlivened by witty thrusts at the Democrats and their Presidential candidate.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The total registration of voters in this city reported to-day to the City Clerk is 5,725, as against 4,876 in 1896.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The University of Pennsylvania football teain left here to-night for Auburndale, Mass, where the players, will put on the finishing touches for the annual game with Harvard on Saturday. The men will remain at Auburndale until Saturday morning, when they will go direct to Cambridge.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Judge Dixon this afternoon summoned the Grand Jury before him and delivered a special charge to it regarding the accusation against Walter McAlister, George Kerr, Andrew Campbell, and William Death, now in jail, charged with the murder of Jennie Bosscheither. It was the first official action of the upper court in the matter.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 -- Gov. Roosevelt concluded his day's tour here to-night with three speeches, making ten addresses since he left Rochester this morning. But few attempts were made to interrupt him, and these were merely questions put to him by persons in the audience. At this place the crowds were large, and much enthusiasm was shown.

Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., former note teller for the First National Bank, who defaulted with $690,000 of the bank's funds, will be turned over to the United States authorities by District Attorney Gardiner to-day. This decision was arrived at after a prolonged conference between Col. Gardiner and United States District Attorney Burnett yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 31. -- Mrs. T. Shaw Safe will have to pay a large bill for repairs to her automobile, which ran away this afternoon.

Philip Sterano, twenty-five years old, an Italian laborer, who says he came from Boston, Mass., fired five shots at Policeman Martin Mannix of the Elizabeth Street Police Station while the latter was patrolling his post at Mulberry and Bayard Streets yesterday afternoon. One of the shots struck the policeman on the left hip, and after penetrating his heavy Winter clothing, was stopped by his revolver, striking it on the handle.

NAPOLEON, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- The following letter from Attorney General Griggs to J.R. Linthicum, Chairman of the Republican Committee of Henry County, relative to certain statements made by ex-Attorney General Frank S. Monnett in a speech delivered here on Oct. 21, was made public today:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 31 -- The Republican State Committee to-day made a final estimate on Minnesota, giving McKinley 60,000 majority, the Republican candidate for Governor 10.000. and claiming the reelection of all the Congressmen. The Democratic Committee estimates the State for Bryan by a small majority, and the Governor by 22,000, with two Congressmen.

After innumerable headings of objections and protestations of merchants and shippers against the advances in rates made by the classification of the Southern Classification Committee, which went into, effect in February test, the committee has at last issued another, classification which is to be known as Classification No. 28.

Charles F. Jones, the valet now in the Tombs with Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, charged with forging the signature of William M. Rice, who died under suspicious circumstances Sept 23, and in whose stomach traces of mercury were found by Prof. Witthaus, to two checks for $90,000, was twice in close conference yesterday with Capt. McClusky of the Detective Bureau and Assistant District Attorney Osborne, who has charge of the case.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The final number of The Paris Exposition Edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES was issued to-day.

The dullness and irregularity of the Stock Exchange market yesterday was reflected in the curb market by similar conditions there, and the course of the day's trading showed very little of interest. Some few advances were recorded, showing that there is still a disposition to purchase stlock, and such declines as occurred in parts of the list were hardly sufficiently market to call prices weak.

About 500 depositors in the Bowery Savings Bank, the Union Bank Savings Institution, the Greenwich Saving Bank, and the Emigrant Industrial Saving Bank addressed the following petition to the Presidents of these banks:

MANILA, Philippine Islands, Sept. 20. -- The enactment yesterday by the Civil Commission of "An Act for the Establishment and Maintenance of an Efficient and Honest Civil Service in the Philippine Islands," as prepared by President Taft, has pleased the Filipino people and has tended to displease the army.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The Fall track games open to the university were held at the Yale Field this afternoon. In spite of bad weather the entries were unusually numerous and the records made were good for thus early in the year. A new star appeared in the person of J.S. Spraker, a law school freshman, whose jumping was the sensation of the day.

-- Grieved by the vehemence of language that has marked some of the letters sent to this paper by people who think that the name of Gen. ROBERT B. LEE does not deserve a place among those of the Nation's heroes and benefactors. The Richmond (Va.) Times advises that the effort thus to honor the Southern leader be immediately and permanently abandoned.
MADRID, Oct. 31. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 73.10. Gold was quoted at 32.77.

The Chamber of Commerce at its regular monthly meeting yesterday passed a resolution presented by John Harsen Rhoades which was in the nature of an appeal to the business interests of the country to uphold the gold standard. It read as follows:

BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- There was more dullness in Boston than heretofore this week, more narrowness, and less feature. Changes in prices were few and generally were unimportant. The market was steady. Parrot improved 1/2, to 45. Montana rose 2 1/2, to 318, fell to 317, at which price 1,100 shares were sold, rose again to 318, at which price 1,000 shares were sold, and later hardened to 320.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not see how we arrive at any necessity for proving that President Bryan could actually throw us down to the silver basis. A catastrophe which everybody should dread would occur immediately upon the announcement of his election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The alignment of the powers on the British-German agreement is now complete. Aside from Italy and Austria, whose adherence to the agreement was expected, owing to their political relations with Germany, Japan is the only power which has given unconditional assent to the agreement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- In a letter to Capt. John S. Miller of this city, Senator Jones, the Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, says:

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1. -- An effort is being made all over the State to get out a large and representative vote at the forthcoming election, and the indications are that it will be successful. The combination of a Presidential, Congressional, and Constitutional amendment election all in one will doubtless be sufficient to produce this effect.

To an American in Paris, who was praising the French people because the sentiment of equality was with them a real and efficient political and social force, an Englishman rejoined that the facts were quite the other way, and that the British aristocracy was really far more "liberal" than the French.

Dullness again ruled in the stock market yesterday. Total transactions fell below 230,000 shares, and of this aggregate one stock alone, Pennsylvania, contributed one-fifth. The movement of prices was irregular, heaviness following early strength and being in its turn succeeded, toward the close, by improvement.

ROME, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill addressed a meeting in the Opera House here this evening. The crowd completely filled the house, and overflow meetings were held outside. Mr. Hill presented the usual arguments of the campaign and added this regarding the manifesto of the savings bank presidents of New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- It is announoced that Langdon Mitchell's play, "The Adventures of Francois," will be soon withdrawn from the stage of the Park Theatre, and will not be seen again unless Mr. Mitchell consents that the play shall be completely revised by some other playwright.

The construction of several new gas tanks over in Brooklyn to supply the outlying districts with illuminating gas has called into requisition a class of workmen whose labors are peculiarly interesting. Not even the work of the "ground hog," who burrows his way through the tunnel under the river in huge compressed-air chambers, surpasses in gruesomeness the labor required of the men who finish the inside of a gas tank.

The wedding of Henry D. Batterman of Brooklyn and Miss Edith Whitney, daughter of Charles Sumner Whitney, took place at 4 o'clock yesterday at the Church of the Transfiguration, the rector of the church, the Rev. Dr. George C. Houghton, officiating. The bride, who entered the church on her father's arm, was gowned in white panne velvet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Gen. MacArthur, at Manila, notified the War Department to-day that Major John G. Davis, United States Volunteers, died at Manila this morning of chronic Bright's disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.-- A negro was arrested in Washington last night and locked up over night in jail for expressing the opinion that the law was not impartially enforced against negroes and white men. The evidence in the case showed that last night there was some disorder near the Hotel Grafton.

Humbled to the dust is the pride of Democratic Cat Hollow, down under the Navy Yard wall in Brooklyn. Erstwhile an impregnable stronghold of the local Democracy, it has suffered invasion by the Republican enemy and is mocked by the banners of the foe swung from its inmost walls.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Willis L. Monre, Chief of the Weather Bureau, has issued the following statement on the weather for November:

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Four eggs were thrown at William J. Bryan to-night just as he left the Central Turner Hall, Milwaukee Avenue, where he had concluded his address. The eggs were thrown by three or four young men, one of whom, John R. Myers, a sign painter, was placed under arrest. The other men escaped.

Julius Jacob, a shoemaker of 2.640 Eighth Avenue, was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court before Magistrtate Crane yesterday morning. He was arrested on complaint of Mrs. A.B. Gillette of 2,407 Seventh Avenue. Mrs. Gillette has devised many nooks and corners for her jewels. Yesterday she placed in the toe of a shoe a seven-stone diamond ring, valued at $500.

By papers filed in two actions brought by "Joseph A. Stoll of 132 Nassau Street against Charles E. Wellborn, an interesting story of real estate transfers for liquor certificates is disclosed. One of the actions is in New Jersey and the other in the Supreme Court of New York County.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Gov. Roosevelt finished the next to the last day of his New York State tour in this city tonight, after having traveled through five counties, making fifteen speeches during the day. The principal stops were at Dunkirk and Jamestown, both in Chautauqua County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your paper has won the admiration and made warm friends of hosts of Republicans, by the earnestness and sincerity with which its columns have sustained the two important and vital issues of the present campaign, the only issues, in fact, before the people of America to-day, the upholding of the honor of the Nation as to our currency at home and our flag abroad.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1. -- If a Dakota divorce apppears regular and is so recognized by both interested parties, the courts of New Jersey will not only uphold it, hut enforce its provisions. Such, in effect, was the decision rendered by Vice Chancellor Pitney here to-day.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 1. -- The laborers at the Conyngham Mine of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company went on strike to-day. The miners refused to pay the laborers 10 per cent. increase in wages, claiming that the company had only advanced them 10 per cent., and that they would not pay the laborers the whole increase.

aMr. BRYAN has no monopoly of mendacity in this campaign. His habit of working overtime and his superior facilities for distributing his product have made the Bryan braird of crooked speech better known in the market than any other, but he has formidable rivals in the business, and on the Republican side.
TIEN-TSIN, Oct. 31. -- The Fourteenth United States Infantry Regiment has started for Manila.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- The Court of Appeals heard arguments to-day in the action brought by Joseph P. Hennessy against Richard H. Mitchell, candidates for Senator in the Twenty-first District, nominated by rival conventions. The Police Commissioners decided in favor of Mitchell. Justice Lawrence reversed this finding, and the Appellate Division affirmed the Police Commissioners.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- In his speech here to-night Senator Depew read from a paper the statement of Chairman Jones of the Democratic National Committee as to what Democrats should do on election night. Senator Depew thought he saw in this statement a menace against the rights of the ballot. He said:

PITTSBURG, Nov. 1. -- The fifth founders' day of Carnegie Institute was celebrated to-day. In and around the beautiful building at Schenley Park entrance more than 5,000 persons thronged in their desire to express their appreciation to Andrew Carnegie, their homage to the distinguished guest of the day, Minister Wu Ting Fang, and their regard for the treasures of art, science, and literature.

The Executive Committee of the sound-money parade met last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to take final action with regard to the arrangements for the great demonstration to-morrow. Reports from all the various organizations which will participate were read, and they were such as to convince the committee that this year's demonstration will excel in every respect the demonstration in 1896.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 1. -- The freakish election bettor has at last made his appearance in Colorado, and some of his wagers are decidedly novel.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 1. -- George Washington Freeman Horner Green, a former negro slave, died in the almshouse yesterday at the reputed age of one hundred and twenty-three years. Green is said to have been born on a farm near Elizabethport, N.J., on Jan. 1, 1777. He was sold to a Virginia planter named Horner, by whom, it is said, he was sold to Gen, Washington.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- Further details regarding the appointment of George J. Gould as trustee for his sister, the Countess of Castellane, show the indebtedness of Count Boni and his wife to be about 23,500,000f. Of this sum there was expended on real estate in connection with the Charity Bazaar and their private home, in the Avenue Malakoff, 3,702,000f.; mortgages, 6,585,260f.; loans, notes, and tradesmen's bills; 4,293,155f., and on art and bric-a-brac, 9,100,000f.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 1. -- When Ira B. Terry awoke this morning and looked out of his window he saw a sight that astonished him. Tombstones were to be seen in every direction. He called his wife, and when she saw what appeared to be a graveyard outside of the house she gave a cry of alarm.

The Democratic papers teem with cheerful prophecy. Our picturesque and imaginative contemporary The Journal of this city irradiates hope from every page. Even the usually saturnine Mr. CROKER, abandoning the dignified reserve he formerly practiced in local politics when it was his own particular field, follows the example of the National shouters and echoes the assertion of Chairman JUNES: "We have won the fight."

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The Stewards of the Jockey Club have issued a significant notice, that in view of the large number of horses now in training at Newmarket, they are not prepared to entertain any fresh applications for licenses to train there.

The football practice on Columbia Field yesterday afternoon still further increased the confidence of supporters of the "White and Blue in the ability of their team to defeat Princeton in the election day game. In spite of the absence of Morley and Berrien behind the line the Varsity eleven played with such energy and dash in a thirty-minute practice game against the substitutes that at its conclusion Coach Sanford complimented the men warmly.
At a meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall, held yesterday afternoon, Richard Croker made an address. He said in part:

SYRACUSE, Nov. 1. -- Supreme Court Justice Hiscook to-day dismissed a writ of certiorari obtained by the Syracuse Rapid Transit Railway against the State Board of Tax Commissioners for a review of its franchise assessment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- "from reports which have come to me and from my own observation. I am satisfied that Indians is as safety Democratic as is Missouri." Thus William J. Bryan, the democratic Presidental candidate, as he alighted from the train at the dearborn street station this afternoon at 8 o'clock.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Queen Victoria has approved the appointment of Lord Salisbury as Premier and Lord Privy Seal, the Marquis of Lansdowne as Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, William St. John Brodrick as Secretary of State for War, the Earl of Selborne as First Lord of the Admiralty A and C.T. Ritchie as Secretary of State for Home Affairs.
DOVER, Del., Nov. 1. -- The Castle Square Opera Company of New York was incorporated here to-day, with a capital of $20,000.

Benjamin Moorehouse, the shipping and receiving clerk of Tarrant Co., is believed by the District Attorney's office to be alive, instead of under the ruins of the firm's building, as at first supposed. This announcement was made yesterday afternoon by Assistant District Attorney James J. Walsh, who represents the people in the investigation into the cause of and the responsibility for the fire and explosions now being conducted by Fire Marshal Peter Seery.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1. -- Yale astronomers are preparing to photograph what leonids appear in the heavens this Fall. Last year at this time the most extensive preparations were made to photograph the meteoric display, but the cloudy skies and the fact that but few leonids appeared threw the astronomers into a state of great perplexity.

The Fire Underwriters and the London and Liverpool, and Globe teams carried off the honors in the Fire Insurance League tournament on Reid's alleys last night, each winning two matches. The Lancashire and Norwich Union teams broke even, each winning one game and losing one, and the Caledonian and Northern teams lost both their matches.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The Yachting World to-day prints the text of letters from Cornelius Vanderbilt to Capt. Parker of the former's seventy-footer Rainbow, dated Oct. 12, and from Mr. Vanderbilt to Herman B. Duryea, dated Oct. 5. In the former Mr. Vanderbilt writes:

Gallantly struggling under the top weight, and fighting for first place from flag fall to finish in going that was ail against her, the stout old black mare from Ohio, Imp, was beaten, but not disgraced, on the Empire City race course yesterday. The race was the last on the card and the real feature of the afternoon's sport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Croker's suggestion to Democrats to gather in full numbers around the polls and to show their full strength after the polls have been closed is an appeal to the rowdy element to commit acts of violence and bloodshed. This sentiment has the Croker ring; the mask has fallen and he is now seen in his true character.

In an editorial article published yesterday The Evening Post calls attention to its valuable and generally fair "Voters' Directory," which it has prepared this year in pursuance of its annual custom, and makes this declaration: "Our aim has been to make the sketches of candidates impartial."

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Somerset Beagle's Flossy captured the Derby at the National beagle trials to-day on William C. Whitney's Westbury estate. In the morning the scent was very poor, but it improved in the afternoon, when a steady drizzle fell. The Derby Class C was the only class finished to-day, but it is expected that to-morrow will wind up the remainder of the programme.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad today declared the usual semi-annual-dividend of 2 1/2 per cent. and an extra dividend of 1 per cent. upon the capital stock of the company, payable on and after Nov. 30, 1900, to the stockholders as registered on the company's book at the close of business yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- It is said tonight that the Grand Jury, acting upon the lines laid down yesterday for their guidance by Judge Dixon, this afternoon found a true bill of indictment for assault and homicide against Walter C. McAllister, Andrew Campbell, William A. Death, and George J. Kerr, in connection with the death of Jennie Bosscheiter, which occurred two weeks ago to-night.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 1. -- Sixty miners of the Hillside Coal and Iron Company's various mines in and around Forest City will leave Scranton Friday night for New York, where they will participate in the mammoth sound-money parade to be held Saturday. These men will appear in the parade as representatives of the Coal Trade Sound-Money Club No. 1, and will carry a white satin banner which cost $300.

Mr. O.H.P. BELMONT is a candidate for Congress in the Thirteenth District. This district extends from Fortieth Street to Fifty-ninth Street, and from river to river, with the exception of a few blocks in the northwest corner. It includes in the residential portion the homes of a large number of business men; it also includes large manufacturing establishments and the homes of numerous operatives employed therein.
It has been decided by the Executive Committee of the New York Road Drivers' Association to hold prearranged brushes on the Speedway every Tuesday and Friday afternoons, weather permitting.
The Kansas City (Mo.) Star prints a letter from Thomas P. Fenlon, an old leader of the Democracy in Kansas, to a fellow-Democrat, in which he says:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 1. -- Husbands do not have to account to their wives for keeping late hours, according to the ruling of Judge Cabaniss of the Police Court. This is the second time that a San Francisco Judge has so ruled. It is held that a man has a right to stay away from home all night and is not bound to give his spouse any explanation.

That was a singular and interesting meeting which DEBS addressed the other evening. Under whose auspices it was gotten up we are not quite clear. It might have been the Republicans, who were anxious to show a practical Bryanite. It might have been the Bryanites, who were anxious to show that not all the disturbers of the public peace were in favor of BRYAN.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Oct. 31. the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,104,402,320, a decrease as compared with last month of $1,754,331. The debt is recapitulated as follows:

The Republican National Committee was worked up yesterday over the reported indorsement given by Senator Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to the suggestion of Richard Croker. that Democrats gather around the polls next Tuesday to see that no frauds on the ballot boxes are attempted.

Great preparations are being made at the country clubs and in the country houses throughout the suburbs for the holiday of election day, now so near at hand. A number of people left town yesterday for Southampton, Lenox, Newport, and Lakewood, to remain over until Wednesday next, and there will be a larger exodus to the nearer suburbs after the parade tomorrow.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Richard Ganzer, alias Rudolph Meyer, a noted counterfeiter, for whom the Secret Service people were on the lookout for eleven years, was put on trial to-day on a charge of having in his possession upward of $7,000 in bogus bills when arrested in Rutherford recently. The case came to a sudden end at noon by the accused withdrawing his plea of not guilty and substituting one of guilty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Division of Customs and Insular Affairs, War Department, made public to-day a summary of its regular monthly bulletin, showing the commerce of the Island of Cuba, for the ten months ended April 30, 1900. The statement shows that the value of all merchandise imported during this period was $39,925,339, and of gold and silver, $5.105,287, giving a total importation of $63,030,626.

Justice E.L. Fursman. sitting in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, upon motion of District Attorney Gardiner, yesterday directed the re-submission of the case of the Directors and officers of the wrecked Traders' Fire Insurance Company, charged with a misdemeanor, to the Grand Jury.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- There was ragged practice in a drizzling rain at the Yale Field this afternoon. Sheldon, Brown, Olcott, Hamlin, Sharpe, and Hale were out of the game again. Stillman, who has been laid up with a bad eye for a week, was out for the first time. He was hurt in the Columbia same and ruptured a blood vessel in his eye.

Not much activity appeared in the market for outside securities yesterday. With the exception of one or two stocks, no issues seemed to have the support of the buying orders which were recently in the market, and in general the curb seemed to be left to itself, the present opinion seeming to be that it is wiser to put off further market commitments until after election day.

The shawl is an article of wearing apparel of which not much has been heard for a good many years, but which is gradually asserting its right to popularity. This is not as a street wrap, but for a general range of purposes for which nothing else will take its place. For a time after the shawl was given up by the average woman as an out-door garment it sank into oblivion.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Congressional Library at Washington I observed that the name of our great American scientist, Matthew Fontaine Maury, had been barred admission.

If Mr. McKinley should be elected by anything like a close vote the Democratic campaign managers will surely raise the cry of fraud. Vice Chairman Stone of the Democratic National Committee and Chairman Richardson of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in a formal statement issued yesterday paved the way for such action.

The City of New York, in June, 1896, entered into a contract with the New York Sanitary Utilization Company for the disposition of garbage by what is known as the Arnold Utilization System, for a term of five years, on Barren Island, in Jamaica Bay, for a fixed compensation, which was $125,000 move than the lowest bidder.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- W.J. Bryan's programme in Chicago to-day comprised twelve speeches. The crowds that greeted him were greater than those of yesterday and last night. The candidate began his itinerary at Handel Hall, in the down-town business district, going from there to the Public Library, where he spoke to an outdoor gathering of workingmen.

The first of the series of Tuesday and Friday afternoon brushes arranged by the New York Road Drivers' Association drew almost a holiday crowd to the Speedway yesterday, and from the interest evinced by the spectators, there is every reason to believe that these events will soon become very popular, and attract widespread attention.

David Woods, a man who is reputed to be wealthy, lies in Bellevue Hospital ill from neglect and lack of food. Mary Connors, a woman who claims to be an artist's model and Woods's wife, is locked up in Yorkville Station charged with larceny of bank books, representing deposits of $30,000 belonging to Woods, and a watch and chain belonging to him valued at $250.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Yesterday was pay day at the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company of this city, the largest concern of its kind in this part of Connecticut. The pay roll was the largest in the history of the concern. in commenting on this fact, the Superintendent of the company, Schuyler Merritt, who was until 1896 a prominent Democrat, said this afternoon:

Resolutions censuring the Police Department for falling to present to the October Grand Jury proper and sufficient evidence upon which indictments and convictions might be had in certain poolroom and excise cases, were yesterday handed up to Judge Newburger, sitting in General Sessions, by Charles W. French, foreman.

Much to the surprise of those members of the congregation of the Spring Street Presbyterian Church who urged his call, the Rev. H. Roswell Bates has announced that he will not accept. This leaves the question of pastorate in practically the same state as it has been ever since the Rev. Dr. A. Woodruff Halsey resigned his pastorate over a year ago to become one of the Secretaries of the Board of Foreign Missions.

Walter J. Travis, the National amateur champion, met his Waterloo yesterday upon the links of the Westchester Golf Club. Travis was beaten by 4 up and 2 to play by W.L. Thompson, one of the younger members of the Baltusrol Golf Club, but who has been pushing himself gradually to the front this season, and he is already regarded as a golfer with whom no chances can be taken in a tournament.

John Kendrick Bangs has written a new volume of humorous adventure which will first make its appearance as a serial in Harper's Weekly after the completion of "The Cardinal's Rose." It will be called "The Olympian Nights," and deals with the adventures of an American newspapers correspondent stranded on Mount Olympus, where he meets the old Greek gods and goddesses.
The attempted suicide in the Tombs, following an alleged confession, by Charles F. Jones, the valet and confidential clerk of the late William M. Rice, led to further developments yesterday.

The recent death of Prof. F. Max Muller, the eminent scholar, makes pertinent at this moment some inquiry into his real services to science. St. John Chrysostom, in speaking of Zoroaster, says, "Why is it that people know nothing of him but his name? " This is far from being the case with Mas Muller.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2. --W.J. Bryan, Democratic Presidential candidate, to-night gave out the following; statement in the form of an interview:

WINSTED, Conn., Nov. 2. -- George Austin, who was reputed to be one of the most skilled passenger engineers in the employ of the Central New England Railroad Company, was stricken with apoplexy while running the train which left Hartford at 4:24 this afternoon.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- The Court of Appeals by a decision handed down to-day replaced the name of Joseph P. Hennessy on the official ballot for Senator in the Twenty-first Senatorial District in place of his opponent, Richard H. Mltchell, whose name was ordered on the ballot by the Appellate Division.

One of the most picturesque demonstrations of the present campaign was that of the Social-Democratic Party, which was held last night. It was the first time in the memory of some of the oldest policemen that a Socialistic meeting had been held in Madison Square. A parade in which over 5,000 men and women marched was preliminary to the big meeting.

CORNING, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Senator Depew wound up his day's campaigning with addresses to two large meetings in this city. He previously had spoken at Wolcott, Penn Yan, Newark, Stanley, Wallington, and Watkins.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Permit me to offer you my personal thanks for your editorial article in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 20 touching the rejection of the name of Fenimore Cooper from the Hall of Fame.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 2. -- Friedhelm, the Summer home of Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer, has been rented to Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones for next season. Mr. and Mrs. Jones occupied The Cloisters two seasons ago. and many brilliant social affairs were given there.

The death of ex-Mayor STRONG causes sincere and general sorrow which without exaggeration may be called affectionate. Although his part in public life was assumed quite late in his career -- he was sixty-seven when he was elected Mayor -- its duties were discharged with marked energy and in a spirit that inspired not merely confidence but a certain warm regard.

Mr. Theodore L. De Vinne's article in THE REVIEW is of great interest. Opinions such as these are of the utmost value to all who wish to know the best in the printer's art. It is most natural that he protests, and strongly, too, against the host of wretched imitators of William Morris and the style he chose to work.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- News of the death of ex-Mayor Strong was received with great sorrow at the McKinley home. Col. Strong was esteemed as a personal friend by the President, who has sent a telegram of condolence to the bereaved family.

William L. Strong, last Mayor of the old City of New York, died shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning in his home, at 12 West Fifty-seventh Street. A few hours later Mayor Robert A. Van Wyck, head of the present City Government, ordered the flag on the City Hall to be lowered to half mast in honor of his Republican predecessor.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- A striking series of living pictures was given at the Tuxedo Club this evening, many of the most beautiful women of Tuxedo's colony, taking part.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one feature of Mr. Bryan's advocacy of the Federal control of industrial enterprises that clashes violently with what is conceded to be a fundamental rule that all consistent Democrats must have imbibed with the pap of their political teachings, and which traverses most completely the very groundwork of the Democratic idea of the proper functions of the Federal Government.

The amazing JONES pauses in his incitement of riot at the polls to utter a cautious prophecy, much more guarded than those he spread broadcast in 1896. He says of the prospect in Illinois: "Much depends on the City of Chicago. If we carry this city by such a majority as we carried it in 1892 the Republicans cannot hold the State."

The Countess Potocka, the author of the present memoirs, was the great niece of the last of the Polish Kings, Stanislaus Augustus Poniatowski, and the great-grand-daughter of the greater Stanislaus, who was the agent of Charles XII., King of Sweden. She was also the daughter of Louis Tyszkiewicz, and was intended to become the wife of her uncle, Prince Stanislaus, but at twenty-six she married Count Potocki, thus becoming in Polish fashion the Countess Potocka.

The town referred to in the article following is St. Joseph, Mo., now a city, according to the census of 1900, of over 102,000 inhabitants, a growth of nearly 98 per cent. in the last decade, a showing exceeding that of any other city so far as the returns have been made, with the possible exception of Memphis, Tenn.

HONOLULU, Oct. 25. -- United States District Judge Estee has rendered a decision in a case involving the status of the Hawaiian laws at the time the islands were annexed by the United States. The question rose in an important libel case that has been in the courts here for some time.

We have had historic romances written in the style of the antiquarian and histories that better deserve the name of romances. From Mr. Lang we get the happy and very unusual combination of careful history written with all the charm of romance. In his preface to "Pickle the Spy" he says: "Resisting the temptation to use Pickle as the villain of fiction, I have tried to tell his story with fidelity."

Students of linguistics who round themselves smiling in much amusement ten years ago over Max Muller's unchanging adherence to his fantastic theories of thirty years earlier will be moved by his death to attempt a candid estimate of his place and rank in linguistic and philological scholarship.

It is a very interesting and, on the whole, a very attractive picture of Cambridge society in the late sixties that Mr. Howells has presented to us in his two articles in Harper's and in the Scribner article on Lowell.

On the whole, business in the Dominion moves along briskly, although, according to Dun's Review, they are suffering just as we are to some extent through interruption by elections and unseasonably warm weather. St. John reports fair trade in groceries and provisions, but in other lines orders come in slowly, as pending elections have diverted attention from business in country districts, and bills are not so well provided for.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Albert S. Jenks and F.T. Davis, the appraisers appointed to make an inventory of the contents of the house of Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., under the attachment of the First National Bank of the City of New York, have completed their work, and, after enumerating all the articles therein found, appraise the value of them at $5,438.90.

Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., the defaulting note teller of the First National Bank, who got away with $690,000 of the bank's funds, was a free man yesterday for the short space of time it took him to walk from the prisoner's bar, in the Centre Street Police Court, to the door of the courtroom.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Daily Express publishes sensational statements that the Boer revival is more serious than has hitherto been believed, and that, in consequence. Lord Roberts's return is likely to be still further postponed. It says also that no considerable party of troops will return home before January or February, while the regimental drafts from England will continue, and 5,000 horses will be sent out.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- The Horse Show has surpassed the most sanguine expectations. To-night standing room was at a premium, and boxes and galleries were alike filled. The crowd numbered over 8,500 persons. The New York and Boston winners follow:

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The trials of the National Beagle Club were about finished to-day. All that remains for the judges to do to-morrow will be to render their decision in the special stake run to-day, in which twelve beagles worked at once. Most of the members will participate in a jack-rabbit hunt on the Hempstead Plains to-morrow morning.

The week preceding election has been characterized by no important developments in trade circles. Generally a very hopeful tone has prevailed, but there has been displayed a continuing disposition in many lines of business to make no new commitments until the votes have been cast and the result determined.

At the investigation yesterday at Fire Headquarters into the cause of and the responsibility for, the Warren Street fire and explosion of last Monday Vernon M. Davis appeared in the interest of McKesson Robbins, who had goods stored in the Tarrant Building. J.J. Allen appeared for W. C. Allen, Secretary and Treasurer of Tarrant Co.

Magistrate Meade in the West Side Court yesterday morning had arraigned before him four prisoners, three women and a man, whom he declared were the most disgusting objects that he had ever seen. The prisoners were Bella Wilson, Mora Garrigan, Della Adams, and William Williams. They all claimed to live at 237 West Fortieth Street.

OWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Theodore Roosevelt, Republican candidate for Vice President, completed to-night at this point one of the most remarkable campaigns ever made by a candidate of any party on the United States. In eight weeks he has visited twenty-four States of the Union, made 673 speeches, traveled 21,209 miles, visited 507 towns and cities, and talked to what is estimated to be 3,000,000 people.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The following statement was issued to-day by the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Nov. 2. -- To-morrow afternoon Soldiers Field will see her hardest-fought football battle of the season, in which Harvard will meet Pennsylvania. The Varsity devoted the afternoon practice to punting, kicking, and running through signals. Barnard again appeared at right guard and Eaton remained at left tackle.

The showing made by the Union Pacific system in its annual report for the year ended June 30, 1900, issued yesterday, is an excellent one. While gross earnings increased 11.56 per cent., operating expenses increased only 9.72 per cent. The increase in net earnings from operation amounted to 14.40 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- The Yale 'Varsity football team omitted its regular daily practice this afternoon on account of the game with West Point to-morrow. Instead, the men were put through an hour and a half of signal work, Murphy taking the second team and Rhodes, McBride, and Cross, the 'Varsity.
BOSTON. Nov. 2. -- George S. Boutwell, President of the Anti-Imperialist League, has made public the following formal address to the public:
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 2. -- Official notices were posted to-day of the inauguration of a pension system for the employes of the Pennsylvania lines. The new system will go into effect Jan. 1, 1901.
BALTIMORE, NOV. 2. -- Edward E. Orth, an Englishman, was arrested here to-day and the police consider that they have made an important capture.

The deer shooting season opened yesterday on Long Island. The forest, fish, and game law of the State provides in general terms that deer shall not be taken at any other time than between daylight and sunset on the first two Wednesdays and the first two Saturdays of November, but, as explained in a recent issue of THE TIMES, the law was interpreted this year so as to make the first Friday an open day.

If you want to know what Dr. Henry Van Dyke is like In his charming out-of-door writings, if you want in black and white an account of the temper and temperament which he puts at your service when he joins you, turn over the leaves of his "Fisherman's Luck" till you come to the chapter called "Talkabillty" and read there a study on a newly defined social virtue, especially desirable in fishermen and in wives.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 2. -- A.O. Bacon will be returned to the United States Senate by the unanimous vote of the Georgia Legislature on Tuesday, Nov. 6. It is an unusual and, to some of the legislators, a disappointing coincidence that the date for the election of a Senator is identical with that of the National election.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The Kanaweola Cycle Club football eleven defeated the University of Buffalo team on the Maple Avenue gridiron this afternoon. Score -- 15 to 0.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Money was in fair demand and plentiful to-day on the disbursement of dividends. The position of the Bank of England does not justify the slightest expectation of easier money in the near future, but rather the reverse. The bullion reserve is a million below that of a year ago, and there is little prospect of its augmentation.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- There was heavy trading to-day in Montana; 15,773 shares sold in the first half of the day, of which 15,585 shares sold at 315, including one lot of 4,000 shares. This latter transaction, involving $1,260,000, is believed to be the largest single cash transaction of record in the Boston market.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 2. -- Everybody was laughing at some ludicrous testimony in the Court of General Sessions here today, and even the court officers joined in the merriment while they were rapping for order. Without a moment's warning and while the merriment was at its height. Judge Barkalow said to a prisoner just convicted of assault:

The Evening Post had a very good and Suggestive article the other day about the extent to which our men of letters who might be supposed to be purely men of letters identified themselves with social movements. They have, not preserved the aloofness which is supposed to mark the purely literary man.

The act of the man who tore leaves out of valuable books in the Lenox Library excited the anger of all lovers of reading. It was a piece of vandalism of a Kind that affects the most sensitive of men, those who have learned to value the silent friendship of the friend who never deceives.

Six speakers of the Socialist-Labor Party who insisted on talking to an enormous crowd at Seventh Street and Avenue C last night were arrested. A good deal of clubbing was done by the officers, who numbered over thirty. The scene about the corner for several hours was wildly exciting, and the police dispersed the crowd several times.

All who have read Dr. Josiah Strong's previous books on social conditions and possibilities in this country will expect to find many interesting and pertinent ideas in his new work on "Expansion," and they will find that expectation fully realized.

In the Long Island League tournament on the Elephant Club alleys last night, the Reinecke team rolled a total of 979 in their match with the Pin Knights, which is the high score of the tournament so far. The Reineckes won both their matches. The scores:
To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been drawn to a statement in your paper charging me with saying the murderers of Miss Jennie Bosscheiter only "went out on a little amusement."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- A colored man, about twenty-one years old, who answers to the description of one of the two men who recently killed the keeper of the West Side Court Prison in New York, was arrested here late to-day.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I see it announced that Longmans, Green Co. are about to publish a book called "St. Kilda," by Norman Heathcote, and from the style of the announcement one might imagine that the author had discovered and described a veritable Terra incognita for the reading public.

If the Weather Bureau keeps its promise to the Executive Committee of the Business Men's Republican and Sound Money Association, the parade to-day will be one of the largest in the history of this country. This is the statement made yesterday at the headquarters of the various organizations that are to be in line.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 2. -- The Grand Jury at 2:50 this afternoon handed up twenty-four bills of indictment, among them those of Walter C. McAlister,George J. Kerr, William A. Death, and Andrew Campbell, who are charged with the murder of Jennie Bosscheiter, who was drugged to death on Oct. 18.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: With the close of the published correspondence through the columns of THE SATURDAY REVIEW between Mr. William L. Stone and myself regarding the character and fair fame of Mr. Fenimore Cooper, I had hoped that these posthumous attacks would cease.
WELLSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt was notified at Cuba of the death of ex-Mayor Strong of New York. The Governor was greatly shocked, and, referring to the ex-Mayor, said:

H. Archibald Pell received the individual attention of the "Sugar crowd" on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for a number of minutes, with the result that, while he would not admit that he was hors de combat, he felt it best to retire hurriedly to the washroom until a hatter, a haberdasher, and a tailor came to his rescue.

Mr. BRYAN'S aptitude at sinking has been needlessly reinforced by the many millstones his campaign managers have hung about his neck.
