If he had been a statesman of shining eminence and the idol of the people he would have had need of all his strength to breast the current and keep his head above water with CHOKER, JONES, STONE, and RICHARDSON industriously weighting him down with their blunders.

The author of "The Monitor and the Navy Under Steam "follows out the history of steam propulsion for ships, and his work is of decided interest. Beginning with Fulton and his Demologos, the first of our armed floating batteries, Lieut. Bennett shows how Ericsson was the true creator of the present iron-clad.

Football practice at Columbia yesterday afternoon lacked the sharpness that has characterized the work of the squad since the Yale game. There was just a trace of staleness in the play of many of the candidates, and the fear that Coach Sanford has been working the men too hard was expressed by onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The annual report of W. S. Shallenburger, Second Assistant Postmaster General, was made public to-day. It shows that on June 30 last the annual rate of expenditure for inland mail service was $55,146,060, for foreign service $2,014,538, total expenditures $57,160,598.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- Miss Jessie Augusta Gary, sixth daughter of ex-Postmaster General and Mrs. James A. Gary, was maried to Van Lear Black at noon to-day at Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock of New York officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Timothy Stone, pastor of the church.

DENVER, Nov. 3 -- With the election three days off, the manners of both parties are claiming Colorado by various pluralities, none of which is taken seriously. Owing to the developments of the past ten days the consensus of opinion is that Bryan will carry the State with a plurality of from 15,000 to 18,000, as against 134,000 four years ago.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 20 -- However anxiously the world in general and society in Holland in particular have been awaiting some announcement of Queen Wilhelmina's engagement, never until Oct. 17 have the newspapers of Holland even detlinitely suggested a suitor for her hand. Yet several times have I read in the American "dailies" long accounts of a positive alliance with this, and with that royal personage with our Queen.

Friday evening's trains took from town the first batch of electors bound for far Western homes whither they went to cast their votes. There will be room and to spare at all of the hotels from now until the latter end of the coming week, when, in case of the election of McKinley, hotel men talk of a big influx of business men to make supplemental purchases for the Winter trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of the many deplorable letters which have recently appeared in your columns in connection with the use of Gen. Lee's name in the Hall of Fame, it was reserved for this morning's issue of THE TIMES to produce one surpassing the others in misstatement of fact and ebullition of personal rancor.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 3. -- The Board of Directors of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company was organized at a special meeting of the officers of the company in this city to-day. Five of the old Directors were dropped from the board and five newones elected, including George J. and Edwin Gould.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to:

Among the great loaders that may be classed as of the liberal (though not properly the Reform Party) is the only Chinaman whose reputation is world-wide -- LiHung-Chang. He is a man of the measure of Bismarck as a statesman. With but one exception, he stands head and shoulders above any of his countrymen.

Wall Street's waiting market has had few interesting features during the past week. Quotations have varied slightly. No development of any noteworthy character has marked the week's events. The last business week preceding the Presidential election has been characterized by a calmness much in contrast with what in past years has been the rule.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 -- Pennsylvania's football team was defeated on Soldiers' Field this afternoon by Harvard, who won from the Quakers 17 to 5, scoring three touch-downs from two of which goals were kicked. Pennsylvania secured but one touch-down, by J. Gardiner.

In the window of a Broadway store there have just been placed on view a number of pictures of the recent operations in China -- those operations which the various Chancelleries are so careful to say were not really war. The pictures come from Japan, and are large colored prints of the kind issued in that country during its war with China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The report of the Auditor for the Post Office Department covering the fiscal year ended June 30, 1900, shows that the total revenues for the department for that period were $102,354,579 and the expenditures $107,249,298, leaving a deficit of $4,894,718. The amount of stamps, stamped envelopes, newspaper wrappers, and postal cards sold during the year was $94,013,699.
An address to Democrats has been issued by a number of prominent men of the party. Among them are ex-Mayor Hewitt, Wheeler H. Peckham, Charles S. Fairchild, and Charles R. Flint. The address follows:

It was announced at the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters last night that few pickpockets had been arrested during the day along the line of the parade, only four being reported. The small number is said to be due to the fact that, owing to the inclemency of the weather, persons had their coats buttoned up tight, which precluded the possibility of being robbed of their valuables.

Although the planetary attractions of the November evening sky will be scanty, its stellar glories will be abundant and brilliant enough to compensate for this loss. At about 8 o'clock in the evening, if we face the north, we may see the Great Dipper, or, as our English cousins prefer to call it, the Plow, barely above the horizon, directly beneath the pole star.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has just been enriched by a costly and rare collection of ancient Greek ornaments presented by J. Pierpont Morgan. Their value is roughly estimated at $150,000. Gen. Di Cesnola, Director of the museum, said yesterday that this gift, together with the Garland collection of ceramics, places the museum ahead of any other museum in this country.

Charles F. Jones, valet of the late William Marsh Rice, who attempted to kill himself by cutting his throat in the Tombs, after making a confession implicating Patrick in Rice's death and in a plot to obtain his millions by forged checks, wills, and assignments, is recovering in Bellevue Hospital.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 3 -- Western bandits who prey upon the express treasure and passengers carried by the railroads have been so active of late that the managers of properties in this section are making extra efforts to outwit the robbers. The success of Messenger Baxter in killing a road agent on the Burlington, near Omaha, a few weeks ago has put new life into the railroad people.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The Horse Show has held the city in its sway to the exclusion of almost everything else during the past week. With the purpose in view that this is to be an annual feature in Chicago's society events, the management set about to give an initial exhibit which should equal, if not excel, anything of its kind here or elsewhere.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Henry C. Payne, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Republican Committee, gave out to-night the following statement, giving the outlook from the Republican standpoint:
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The latest betting here to-night on the election was 2 1/2, 3, and 3 1/2 against Bryan as to the general result.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Oct. 29 -- The political situation here is interesting and not easy to grasp. Almost within a fortnight of election day it becomes known that the Federal Party, which carried the Island at the election of less than a year ago by a majority of over 6,500, has withdrawn from the electoral contest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to further intrude upon your columns to complete my letter published in last Sunday's TIMES on the question of "Opportunity" for young men, and the labor forces under corporate combination, in reply to the arguments of Messrs. Bryan and Croker.

To the Editor of The York Times: Mr. Bryan is reported as saying: "My greatest objection to the trust is that the trust is closing the door of opportunity against our young men and condemning the boys of our country to perpetual clerkships."

A young man, whom the Brooklyn police believe, from letters found on him, to be W.H. Feeney of Troy, N.Y., was arrested at the Hotel Margaret, on Columbia Heights, last night, by Detective Neil Ruddy of the Adams Street Station, charged with passing forged checks on several Brooklyn storekeepers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the waning days of this "distressing campaign," as Mr. Cleveland so aptly terms it, will you permit me to say a final word concerning some of the vital issues presented, in the hope of turning the vote of this or that doubting or undecided Democrat in what I conceive to be the right direction?

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 3. -- Close observers believe this State is likely to be close. Tuesday's vote will be the largest in the history of the State, probably reaching 105,000. Four years ago it was 92,000, and 74,000 two years ago. This falling off was apparently divided about equally between the two parties, though the Democrats claim that their side sustained the heaviest loss.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it the supporters of McKinley and Roosevelt are making so many bad breaks? Omitting Senator Scott's, is it not surprising that Mr. Root was not acquaint- ed with the fifty-fifth and last clause of the Stamp act, as passed by Parliament, which says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Division of Biological Survey of the Agricultural Department is making a compilation of the various State laws relating to the sale and transportation of game, with tables showing close seasons, species prohibited from sale and transportation and requirements in regard to non-resident licenses.

Fire Marshal Peter Seery received yesterday from President Michael C. Murphy of the Health Department Chemist Lederle's report on analyses and tests of the samples taken from five of seven drums which rolled out of the ruins of the Tarrant Building. They were stored in it by the Schoellkopf, Hartford Hanna Company of 100 William Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be hoped that the cause of the recent explosion in Warren Street will be more fully and more intelligently investigated, and that the guilty parties -- if any there be -- more sternly dealt with than were those responsible for the great loss of life which attended the explosion in Hague Street, in this city, fifty years ago.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 3. -- The best political judgment of the leaders of the parties in Nebraska to-night is that the result will be exceedingly close. Neither party claims the State by a large majority, and more bets are being made on the proposition that there will not be 3,000 votes difference in the vote on Governor than on anything else, and representatives of all parties are gambling on both sides of this proposition.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The Orange County Hunt Club did some hard and last riding this afternoon, following the hounds at a killing pace for five miles across country before a check was had. In the field of riders were P. Fenelon Collier, F. Gray Griswold, Gordon Paddock, Dr. J.O. Green, John R. Townsend, J.V. Vale of Ramapo, Mr. Morgan of England, Miss Ethel Money, and Miss Mary Harriman.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 3 -- The basket ball team of Barnard College, New York, was to-day burled under a score of 20 to 0 by the Quaker maidens of Bryn Mawr College in the latter's gymnasium. Judging from the cheers of the undergraduates, for no outsider was admitted, and all men were rigidly excluded, the contest was an exciting one despite the one-sided score.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- When William J. Bryan stepped down to-night from the reviewing stand at the intersection of Plymouth Place and Jackson Boulevard, from which he had watched to-night's Democratic parade, and left for his home in Lincoln, the Democratic campaign in Chicago, Cook County, and the State of Illinois was practically over.
Fairmount Park, Philadelphia, is to have a fifteen-thousand-dollar statue of Robert Morris, signer of the Declaration of Independence and the great American financier of the Revolutionary period.

The Sound Money Parade of yesterday was one of the most remarkable political demonstrations ever seen in this country. For seven hours the flower of the business and professional interests of New York marched in a steady downpour of rain through streets slippery with mud, braving discomfort and even illness to salute New York's Governor as a representative of the gold standard principle.

Some odd contrasts marked the mass meeting of the Hungarian-American Democratic Clubs at Cooper Union last night, and a spirit of more than ordinary sympathy between audience and speaker was apparent in at least one instance. As a result the speaker frequently found it unnecessary to answer questions that he put in the course of his remarks, for the audience did it for him with emphasis.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 3 -- Though the Republican plurality at the June election in Oregon was over 10,000, at next Tuesday's election it is not expected to be more than 10,000, and it may be less. Bets are being made even on 12,000 plurality, and that not five counties in the State will give pluralities for Bryan.

Sentiment on the floor of the Stock Exchange was much improved yesterday, and advancing quotations followed as a consequence. Undoubtedly, the sight of the marching sound money hosts, going steadily forward without regard to the rain, had an inspiriting effect, while the growing confidence of the success of the Republican cause was further manifested.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- In finishing his tour of the State here to-night Senator Depew made the following statement to an Associated Press reporter:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 -- The St. Louis Republican Committee has adopted a novel method to poll all of its votes on election morning in one of the close wards. It has been arranged to fire off bombs to arouse the voters early and then ring the door bell of each club member until he responds and announces that he will go at once and vote.

Archbishop Corrigan celebrated the benediction of the blessed sacrament at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the presentation to the hospital of a portrait in oil of the late Dr. J. McCreery, who for years was the visiting physician of the hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- In his annual report the Auditor of the Post Office Department says concerning the postal frauds in Cuba:

Except for a sharp advance in Standard Oil, which carried that stock to a new high price, and a material gain in Amalgamated Copper, yesterday's market for outside securities was practically without events of interest. Trading was extremely limited, but some slight indication was given of the general feeling in regard to the future of the market by a few advances, which were not, however, except in the cases noted, of much importance.

Now that another lawn tennis season has passed into history, all attention among the tournament players is centred on the forthcoming report of the official ranking committee. President James Dwight of Boston trill appoint the usual committee of five prominent players, who will hold their meeting some time this month in Boston and classify the leading experts for the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a confession of possessing inferior abilities or an inability to attain a position in the front ranks of men of affairs, chargeable to pure and simple malice or jealousy, when politicians having no just claim to patriotic tendencies attempt to array one body of our citizens, whether North, South, East, or West, against each other.

Last night was Tammany night, and all the district headquarters from the Battery to the Bronx were ablaze with fireworks, while speakers talked or the issues of the campaign. At each district meeting the district leader acted as Chairman, and many of the speakers came from the district organizations.

Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee, commenting on the great demonstration, said: " When I arose this morning and contemplated the appearance of things outdoors I believed the number of paraders would be greatly below the estimate, and I thought this might be construed as meaning that Greater New York was not so much in favor of McKinley as it was four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Present conditions point to fair weather with moderate temperature on Tuesday, Nov. 6, over all districts east of the Mississippi River. From the Mississippi to the Pacific Coast present indications are also favorable for fair weather, except on the Middle and North Pacific Coasts, where there may be rain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of to-day's issue under the caption, "No Room for Debs," you profess ignorance as to the auspices under which the Debs meeting in Cooper Union last Tuesday was arranged. Would it not have been just as well for your editorial oracle to have found out this information before attempting to dispense his political wisdom to the multitude?

Copyright, 1900. LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Cabinet making must be an amusing business to those not actually engaged in it. Certainly the explosions, mostly paper balloonish, induced so far by the efforts of Lord Salisbury in this line have been in the main diverting. First of all he incurred the unbounded wrath of his own chosen and leading newspaper, at least the paper that poses as such.

Eighteen members and coaches of the Columbia football team witnessed the Princeton-Cornell game at Princeton yesterday afternoon. The squad left New York at noon, after light practice on South Field earlier in the morning, and returned to the city last night. The men were greatly impressed by the swiftness of the Tiger backs, and were inclined to attribute Cornell's victory to superior weight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its editorial of the 13th ult., entitled "Tricks and Evasions," THE TIMES called attention to Mr. Bryan's "false pleadings and habit of trickery in discussing public questions," and commented on the fact that his opponents nevertheless generally went out of their way to express the opinion that he was honest and sincere in his utterances.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Socialistic labor orators raised the red flag in State Street last night, and were driven off the thoroughfare by the police, who were compelled to interfere to stop a riot. It was Socialistic Labor night and the Debs speakers used half a dozen wagons to speak from along the street.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 -- Republican Chairman Hernly said to-night: "Indiana is safely and surely Republican, and it looks like a landslide. Conditions are the same as in 1894, when we carried the State by 45,000. We will carry the nine Congressional districts that are Republican now and will gain two more.

One of the gloomiest places in all New York yesterday was the Weather Bureau, where it was found early in the day that something had gone wrong. Everything had been working smoothly enough in the weather office when the observers went home on Friday afternoon. After plotting all the weather conditions on the map Forecaster Emery had been led to give out the following reassuring bulletin:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- Senator Louis E. McComas, who spoke at the closing demonstration of the Republican campaign in Music Hall to-night, took occasion to deny certain statements made by Senator Wellington in his Cumberland speech earlier in the canvass. In this connection the junior Senator said:

Yesterday's sound-money parade was even more impressive than that of four years ago, after which it was named. And that for several reasons. In the first place the weather for the procession of 1896 was delightful, while the sharp shower of yesterday morning suf- ficed to deter anybody who was not really in earnest about marching in order to "show his colors."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Mr. Everett P. Wheeler's letter published in THE TIMES of Oct. 22 I notice the following extraordinary statement: "When Jackson suppressed the nullifiers of South Carolina he was doing precisely what McKinley is doing in the Philippines.''

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 3 -- The cadets defeated the football team of Washington and Jefferson College this afternoon by a score of 18 to 0. The game to-day had been looked for with considerable interest for several reasons. It was the first time that these institutions had met and Capt. Phillips and several other players on the visitors' team were members of the Tenth Pennsylvania and had seen service in the Philippine Islands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if Jones, Croker and Company imagine for a moment that any one worthy of the name of an American is likely to be deterred from going to the polls and casting his vote as his conscience dictates because of any covert or expressed threats of violence on the part of any members of the above concern?

From The Spectator. English shipping is exposing itself to a graver danger than it knows in allowing another country to take the lead in the speed of its ships. Life is becoming so fast that a saving of an hour or two on the Atlantic passage is bound to draw the custom of the keenest and most successful -- therefore the wealthiest -- men, whom others follow as sheep the bell wether.
Mme. Evta Kileski, soprano, has been en- gaged by Mr. Gericke to sing with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Providence Nov. 17.

BANGOR, Nov. 3 -- S.C. Pirie of New York, accompanied by his brother, William Pirie, arrived here Friday on their return from a hunting trip to Newfoundland, where they had fine sport with the caribou, which animals abound there. They brought to Bangor fourteen heads, twelve being of bulls and two of cows, and a Bangor taxidermist will mount them all.

From The Review of Reviews. The agricultural features of Jamaica cannot be disposed of without due reference to the part played by the mongoos. Some years ago, the cane fields became infested with snakes and rats to such an extent that drastic measures had to be employed in order to rid the country of the pests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing along Broadway the banners inscribed, " They may make you parade today, but they cannot make you vote against Bryan," recalled to my mind very forcibly the methods adopted by the Croker ringleaders in their respective Assembly districts threatening and browbeating the unfortunate class of men who are under their tyrannical rule because they are City Government employes.

Chief of Police DEVERY, in an effort to account for something he did not under- stand, lately made an admission which the citizen interested in police methods will find extremely instructive. He said: "Sometimes, you know, when we are watching anything, things will happen right behind our backs."

The bowling games of the past week made a number of changes in the relative rank of the clubs in most of the local tournaments. In the Columbia League the Royal Arcanum dropped from first to fourth place, the Bank Clerks, who are the only team with no games lost, coming to the top.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 3 -- The campaign just closing has been the most bitter as well as spectacular in the history of Montana, not even excepting the famous capital contest between Anaconda and Helena. As usual, the two copper kings, W.A. Clark and Marcus Daly, are at war within the Democratic ranks, and therein lies the only hope of Republican success for the State ticket.

W.L. Thompson of the Baltusrol Golf Club and Charles F. Watson. Jr., of the Essex County Club, Orange, N.J., carried off the prizes yesterday in the closing events of the Westchester Golf Club's open tournament. The former is the young golfer who suddenly found fame thrust upon him by his defeat of the amateur champion, Walter J. Travis, on the previous day.
SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 3 -- E.H. Callister, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, gave out the following statement to-night:
George W. Bergen. George W. Bergen, a member of the wholesale grocery firm of Valentine, Bergen Co. of Brooklyn, died at his residence at Freeport, L.I., yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Champion Harry Vardon to-day entered the golf links of Chevy Chase, a suburb of Washington, in a contest with Messrs. Tucker and Ball, local professionals. Owing to a steady rain only about fifty persons witnessed the game. The game up to the fifteenth link was characterized by pretty drives and strokes, with honors equally divided.

From The Fortnightly Review. Whom would Socialists rob of their property? The rich simply? Employers, capitalists, landowners? By no means. They would rob the working man as remorselessly as his employer. They would steal houses, property, and the interests and profits of capital, just as eagerly as they would steal rent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The population of the State of Vermont, as announced today by the Census Bureau, is 343,641, against 332,422 in 1890. This is an increase of 11,219, or 3.3 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the opening of the present cam- paign I have made it a point to be pres- ent at every political meeting of impor- tance held in this city, and, like many others, have noticed with regret the gen- erally mediocre and commonplace quality of the speeches that have been made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some idea of the possible effects of a business panic, such as, it is claimed, would be likely to follow the election of Bryan, may be realized by a recital of the condition of affairs which followed the accession of Vice President John Tyler to the Presidential chair after the death of President Harrison in 1841.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- Upon the Independent and Sound Money Democratic vote depends the result of the election in Maryland. The close of the campaign finds this State rather doubtful from a non-partisan, unbiased point of view, but the Republicans, so far, have the better of the fight, and their chances for carrying the State are decidedly better than those of the Democrats.

Secretary Wilmerding of the Philadelphia Fire Underwriters' Association has issued a circular letter to proprietors of dyeing establishments, urging the employment of every precaution in the use of chlorate of soda and chlorate of potash.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me tell you something of what I know of Crokerism from my own experi- ence in the last two years. In 1898 I took rooms in then a very respectable part of the city, within a stone's throw of a police station. I do not want at present to name the place, but would gladly give it out to some legal authority, if required.

The new Empire City Jockey Club's first Fall meeting ended yesterday under conditions that were fittingly dismal. The card offered was one of uncommon promise, and the racing was above the ordinary, but the results were disappointing and a damp, dejected crowd, on the home coming, found the one real cause for sat- isfaction in the fact that the meeting was over.
Commissioner Dalton of the Department of Water Supply yesterday opened bids for the laying of water mains in the Borough of Brooklyn and in the Borough of the Bronx.

PHILIPPI, West Va., Nov. 3. -- At 1:30 o'clock this morning a terrific explosion occurred at one of the Southern Coal and Transportation Company's mines at Berrysburg. Twelve bodies have already been taken from the mine. The explosion was plainly heard in Philippi.

When the element of prognosticating scores on comparative results of football games is eliminated from the sport much of the love for the game will go, too. It seems positively fascinating for the average football enthusiast to dwell on his particular team's chances in the future games, and at once he is plunged into a maze of figures in which his pride tallies well to the fore on the right side of the table.

The entry list for this year's Horse Show, to be held in the Madison Square Garden the week of Nov. 19, is the largest in the history of the organization. Against something less than 1,300 entries last year there are nearly 1,500 this season, and the number of exhibitors has increased from 244 to 300.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The distranchisement of the negroes in the South, by various methods, and finally by force of legislation, is defended by the white people of the South on the ground that, as they claim, the negroes are unfit for the proper exercise of the rights of suffrage.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3 -- The three alternate days' racing of the Maryland Steeplechase Association, at Pimlico, closed to-day after a successful meeting. Five favorites won the events on to-day's card almost as they pleased, and the bookmakers were hit hard. Both track and turf were soaked with water to-day from incessant rain since early morning, and the speed of the horses was materially affected.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Money is fairly plentiful and discounts are steady. It is expected that little of the India gold will be retained here.

PEKING, Sept. 5. -- If large bodies or troops are to remain in China through the Winter, the work of provisioning them will present no small difficulties. So far it has been possible to get rations here in abundance by road and water, and to supplement the regular issues with native farm products, poultry, beef, and mutton, oo that fare has been varied and almost sumptuous for camp life.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In war and in peace, in business life and in domestic life, in matters physical, intellectual, or material, it is a rule without exception that no person, no Government, no organization can be required or expected to do what is impossible. This appears like a truism, and such it virtually is, yet its statement is occasionally made necessary by the fact that it is ignored.

A fire in the three-story brick tenement at 687 East One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street Friday night did $75 damage to the flat of Adolph Hoffman and Mrs. Hoffman and $75 damage to the building. Firemen notified Fire Marshal Clark that there was a strong odor of kerosene oil, and Detective Maher of the Alexander Avenue Station was placed on the case.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus Reserve of $81,425. The banks now hold a surplus of $5,950,400 above the legal requirements.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Yale won by a score of 18 to 0 on the Cadet gridiron this afternoon. From start to finish the game was brilliant and interesting. Both sides put forth their mightiest efforts. Yale strength carried the day. Cadet pluck never showed to better advantage than this afternoon.

From Forest and Stream. For a few days in each year, and always in the month of September, the South Sea people have a treat in the way of fish -- a small stream runner smaller than the Thames whitebait and better flavored.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- The close of the campaign to-night finds Chairman Franklin Murphy of the Republican State Committee and Chairman William B. Gourley of the Democratic Committee both claiming the State for their party's Presidential candidate. Mr. Gourley claims the Democrats will make gains in the Congressional representation and in the State Legislature.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- John P. Grover, fifty years old, a member of the firm of Grover Brothers, publishers and stationers at 764 Broad Street, dropped dead in the First Precinct Station House tonight. Mr. Grover was making a complaint of shoplifting against George Logan and Edward Morgan at the time.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 3 -- The Republicans of Wyoming have probably given the State a more thorough canvass this campaign than in any other previous Presidential year. In the work which has been done the National Committee has been shoulder to shoulder with the workers, and no stone has been left unturned to insure success for the party and bring Wyoming back into the Republican column.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Chairman George Stone of the Republican State Central Committee said to-day:

BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- A band of masked men blew open the safe of the Farmers and Merchants' Bank, at Jackson Centre, early to-day. It is stated that they secured nearly $6,000. The bank building was wrecked and timbers were blown through the windows of the buildings opposite.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A special dispatch from San Francisco says: "Further details of the drowning of A.A. Bashor of Salem. Oregon, state that he was returning from Alaska a few days ago with a fortune after five years spent in search for gold, when he was washed from a vessel's deck during a storm and drowned.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 3 -- Two thousand spectators were out in a drizzling rain to-day to see the old-time rivals, Lafayette and Lehigh, on the sridiron, and, though the Eastonians rolled up a score of 34 to 0 against the Bethlehemites, the game was full of interest and excitement from beginning to end.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Chairman Jones of the National Democratic Committee tonight furnished the following statement covering the outlook from his standpoint:

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3. -- According to a percentage poll of representative voters taken in various parts of the State, irrespective of politics, the result of next Tuesday's election in Indiana may depend on the action of eighteen "silent" voters in each thousand of the possible 700,000 who will go into the election booths.

At the November meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which will be held Thursday evening at the Yachtsmen's Club, in West Forty-third Street, many important amendments to the present racing rules will be brought up for consideration. Chief among the suggested changes, and one of far-reaching effect upon the sport is the proposed abolition of time allowances except in the first classes of schooners, sloops, and yawls.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Nov. 3. -- The political situation in South Dakota is a standoff, so far as the Electoral and State tickets are concerned. Both side are claiming victory in advance and neither can tell within 5,000 votes what will be the result. There is a large silent element which refuses to be polled by partisans on either side on anything but the legislative ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur in Monday's TIMES is reported as saying: "The man who cannot put his religion in his politics must have very bad politics or very poor religion."
To the Editor of The New York Times: Such was the heading of an article that appeared in your issue of Wednesday last.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Cornell won out against Princeton this afternoon by superior defensive play, superior offensive tactics, and superior handling of the ball, the final score standing: Cornell, 12; Princeton, 0. It was a magnificent football contest, waged under trying conditions. For two hours the brawny warriors of the two universities slid and floundered and rolled over the miry gridiron soaked by an all-day rain, which did not stop even between halves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The report of Quartermaster Gen. Ludington for the year ended June 30, 1900, shows a total expenditure of $83,078,025, and a balance on hand unexpended from various appropriations of $35,962,893. Of the amount given in the expenditures a large proportion is in transfer warrants, and sums remitted to disbursing officers for the payment of accruing obligations.

Andrew Carnegie was among the passengers on board the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, which arrived from Hamburg and Cherbourg early last night. He appeared to be in excellent health, and said that he was glad to get back to America again.

The extreme measures taken by the Spanish authorities to eradicate Carlism do not necessarily indicate that the Carl- ist pretender has once more become a serious menace to the dynasty, but rath- er that the opportunities for rebellion of- fered by his agents to long-suffering, distracted communities may, if allowed to develop unchecked, produce a state of affairs far more dangerous than that of the typical Carlist rising.
David Woods, whom Mary Cummings, or Connors, was last week accused of robbing, died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday from general debility.
Mr. BRYAN'S canvass has failed to win for him the respect of the American people. Not respecting him, they cannot trust him, and not trusting him, they will not have him for their President.

Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon and last evening put the finishing touches to the work of this campaign by holding mass meeting in eight theatres in the city. Several orators were scheduled to speak at each of these meetings, and at each there was a band or orchstra. At all of them the proceedings began by the reading of the Declaration of Independence.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "TRIVIAL CAUSE FOR SHOOTING." May I take exception to the above heading to the account of the deplorable encounter between Elkins and Sweet on Friday afternoon?

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Francis B. Delehanty, who is slated for a City Judgeship in New York City, has been well taken care of by his brother-inlaw, ex-Senator Edward Murphy, Jr. The new berth into which he is to be placed by Richard Croker is the second of its kind that has either been prepared for him, or which he has enjoyed through Murphy's influence.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- President McKinley's last Sunday in Canton for some time to come was very similar to other Sundays of the vacation spent here. He took Mrs. McKinley for her usual morning drive, and then went to the First Methodist Church, where he usually worships. During the afternoon they took another drive.

This ticket was nominated last night by the Tammany County Convention, after one of the bitterest contests Richard Croker ever has been called upon to settle. Each nomination was made unanimously, and on the surface there was no indication of the desperate efforts made by many district leaders to have the slate changed. These efforts did not cease until it was nearly time for the convention to assemble.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- We have escaped a 5 per cent. rate in October, but are no easier in our minds. The truth is, we ought to have had dearer money before the latter half of the month, but as I have more than once explained, it could not be made dear by any usual process available to the Bank or the market.
The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church in West Fifty-seventh Street, preached last night on "Essentials to National Perpetuity and Spiritual Prosperity." He said in part:

An elevated railroad train crushed a man to death by grinding him against the station platform at One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street and Third Avenue shortly after 9 o'clock last night. The victim's name was Joseph Zolenski, thirty-seven years old, a Polish cigarmaker of 545 Baltic Street, Brooklyn.

An explosion and fire yesterday afternoon completely wrecked the five-story building at 498 Broome Street, partly occupied by Alfred Bieyer Co., wholesale dealers in paper and twine. The origin of the fire is unknown, and mystery was attached to the explosion. The police and firemen advanced a theory that the explosion had been caused by the hot air from the fire, which found no means of egress from the building, which was closed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No paper meets with a warmer welcome In our home than THE TIMES. I have always admired your style of not berating persons religiously or politically, but I must say I was not only surprised but shocked that you would publish an article addressed to the editor of such a character as the one headed, "Will Not Vote at All."

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- The morning papers give prominence to the telegram from Emperor Nicholas to M. Loubet. Le Soleil and Le Petit Parisien attach great importance to it in view of the fact that it was sent so soon after the publication of the AngloGerman agreement. It is characterized as "a consecration of the foreign policy of France and a proof that the two nations are still in accord."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 4. -- The condition of Senator Cushman K. Davis is reported as decidedly worse to-night, and grave fears are entertained that if his life is saved it will be at the cost of his foot, or possibly his right leg.

Notwithstanding the small decrease in surplus reserves, as shown in the bank statement of Saturday last, money market conditions continue steadily to improve. The statement, at best misleading because of the "average" system under which it is made, was especially so on Saturday -- though why, authorities are not prepared to explain.

Six cycling races, three for amateur riders and three for professionals, were decided at the Vailsburg board track, Newark, N.J., yesterday, and the 2,000 or more spectators saw some excellent racing as well as an exciting episode not down on the programme. In the two-mile professional handicap race, a portion of the track on the backstretch gave way just after the leading rider had passed over it in the third lap.

It had been generally believed that the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst would define his political views as to the present election in his sermon yesterday, and the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was crowded to its utmost capacity by those who had come to hear him.

The Republican National Committee yesterday issued a statement claiming as certain for McKinley and Roosevelt 294 votes in the Electoral College. The table of the committee of the expected vote by States is the same as the table printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. Commenting upon its claim the Committee says in part:

Croker's determination to nominate Francis B. Delehanty, brother-in-law of ex-Senator Murphy, and until recently a resident of Albany, for the City Court bench may cause some trouble at the County Convention which Tammany has called for to-morrow night. The convention will nominate Supreme Court Justices Dugro and Patterson to succeed themselves.

Copies of the following communication were sent last night by State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh to the Board of Police, the Chief of Police, the Deputy Chiefs of Police, the Inspectors of Police, and to the Mayor:

BUFFALO, Nov. 4. -- Prof. Jacob Gould Schurman, who passed through this city this afternoon en route from the West to Ithaca, made the following public reply to an open letter addressed to him by Sixto Lopez. Prof. Schurman contends that Mr. Lopez's letter is a gratifying proof of the correctness of the report of the Philippine Commission regarding the condition of the Filipinos, and continues:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Gov. Roosevelt spent a quiet day here to-day. This morning he attended services at the Episcopal Church. He was accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt. After dinner he and the children took a long walk through the woods, reaching home again about 6 o'clock. There were no callers during the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Following a recent decision by Judge Beitler that all lists of those voting at elections must hereafter be placed in the Prothonotary's office subject to public inspection at any time, instead of being placed within the sealed ballot boxes when the polls close, John Wanamaker to-day forwarded to a number of organizations interesting themselves in the legislative and county contests of Tuesday a communication bearing on the subject.

Charles F. Jones, the valet of the late William M. Rice, who attempted suicide by cutting his throat after making an alleged confession to Assistant District Attorney Osborne, in which he described how the aged millionaire was killed byLawyer Albert T. Patrick, will be returned to the Tombs to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Brig. Gen. George M. Randall, commanding the Department of Alaska, in his annual report, presented under date of Sept. 20, devotes considerable space to the natives of Alaska and says that the Eskimo has been unnoticed by those he has befriended and has been allowed to die for the lack of proper care and food.

"In the case of the United States the country is young and the people old, whereas in the case of Japan the country is old and the people young." This is the striking statement with which Count OKUMA, the late Prime Minister of Japan, sums up the differences between his country and ours, which make the protective policy of the latter unsuited to the former.

Miss Olga Nethersole was among the arrivals on the American liner St. Paul yesterday. Since her last visit she has spent the time in relaxation from work, her only appearance in public having been at the recent benefit held in Paris, in aid of the Galveston sufferers.
Friends of Joseph I. Green are greatly exercised over a report that Francis B. Delehanty. instead of Mr. Green, will be nominated by Tammany Hall for Judge of the City Court.
Richard Croker last night Issued the following statement:

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- Last week on the Boerse was the best it had known since the downward movement in prices began about the middle of April. Several factors exerted a bullish influence upon the market. The decision of the association of great Berlin banks to rescind the action forbidding members to execute orders for future delivery for unregistered firms gave a new impetus to speculation.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Both sides seem confident of victory Tuesday, but the betting, which has heretofore been strongly in favor of McKinley, has veered sharply toward Bryan, the odds having risen to 8 and 9 on Bryan against 10 on McKinley, while a few days ago 2 to 1 that McKinley would carry the State found few takers.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 4. -- John G. Woolley, Prohibition nominee for President, this evening issued the following statement:...

The Central Federated Union found itself again in a whirl of politics at yesterday's meeting. The politics was first brought in by Patrick J. Daly, one of the three men involved in the charges of receiving bribes from the Republican State Committee, which their accusers failed to prove last Sunday.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 4. -- Col. W.J. Bryan and Mrs, Bryan arrived at their home in this city at 6 o'clock this evening, coming direct from Chicago. They were driven to their residence, where Mr. Bryan will remain until to-morrow morning, when he will start upon a flying trip through Nebraska, devoting the last day of the campaign to his own State.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The defeat by Cornell yesterday was like a thunderbolt out of a clear sky to Princetonians, for the practice work of the football team for several days previous had been admirable and generally satisfactory. Coaches, players, and everybody expected a comparatively easy victory.

If every Democrat in the State of New York should vote for Mr. STANCHFIELD to-morrow, he would be elected Governor, and that would be a very good thing for the State. The best result of the voting would be the choice of Mr. STANCHFIELD for Governor, accompanied by an imposing majority for McKINLEY and ROOSEVELT.

There was a large crowd of spectators on the Speedway yesterday morning, but very little to amuse them as far as brushing was concerned, as the footing was not only heavy, but dangerous, and careful drivers took no chances with their fast steppers, and simply jogged them. Several of the more enthusiastic ones found a stretch of fairly good footing above Dyckerman Street on the macadam.

"This year will go down as 'the pyrotechnic year' in our political history.'' said one of the Park Place fireworks dealers on Saturday afternoon as he was figuring up the profits for his house for the month of October. "Never in any political campaign in this city has there been such a demand for fireworks of all kinds, but particularly for the costlier sorts, as in the one now coming to a close.
