Impressive as was Saturday's parade because of the number and enthusiasm of its participants, the feature of the day that will remain longest in memory was supplied by the strips of cloth, bearing insults to the marching thousands, which had been stretched across their pathway in so many places.

LYONS, Nov. 4. -- No disorders marred the ceremony of unveiling the monument to the late President Carnot here to-day, or the luncheon tendered President Loubet by the Chamber of Commerce, which followed the unveiling, although the Socialist Committee had posted bills calling upon their followers to make the demonstration in protest against the Chamber of Commerce, which is regarded by them as clerical and reactionary.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- A lively incident occurred at the Auteuil races yesterday afternoon over the entry in the Military Steeplechase of Capt. Coblentz, a Jew, whose recent treatment by brother officers at the Military School in Fontainebleau led to a severe disciplinary measure on the part of Gen. Andre, Minister of War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The disturbances in China have struck a severe blow to the silk industry in Europe, and according to Consul Hughes, at Coburg, in a communication to the State Department on this subject, this industry is suffering greatly in Germany, Italy, France, and Switzerland.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Statements were issued to-night from both Republican and Democratic Headquarters. The Republican statement is as follows:

We are exporting goods of American manufacture to the value of more than a million dollars a day -- $338,478,247 for the first nine months of the calendar year. That is proof that we have the capital, the skill, and the industry to manufacture goods that the world wants and will take.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- At Bow Street Police Court to-day Julian Arnold, son of Sir Edwin Arnold, who had been extradited from California, was remanded on the charge of misappropriating trust funds. He denied the charges.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- With a capital stock of $2,500,000, the Westchester Lighting Company of Port Chester was incorporated today with the Secretary of State. It will manufacture and supply gas and electrieity for lighting the streets and public and private buildings of cities, villages, and towns in the State.

Columbia's football team will line up against the Princeton Tigers on Columbia Field this afternoon in what promises to be, both from a sporting and social standpoint, the most interesting game of the year to New Yorkers. The comparative ability of the two teams is such that many even bets have been made.

There is only one guiding principle for us to suggest to our readers this morning in the selection of candidates for the House of Representatives in this city: Vote to strengthen the cause of the gold standard. That we consider to be the most important thing in this canvass.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 -- Suit was filed in the United States court here to-day by M.F. Loughlin of New York and F.J. Virgin and C.L. Loop of Tennessee against the Wells-Fargo and Southern Express Companies for an accounting of the affairs of the Texas Express Company and for $500,000 damages.

When Richard Croker was asked yesterday what comment he had to make on the communication sent by Superintendent of Elections McCullagh to Chief Devery asking the assistance of the police in preventing illegal voting, he replied:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 5 -- Gov. Roosevelt wound up the National campaign here in his home town to-night before what was the largest gathering of any kind ever held here. Prior to the meeting in the Tucker lot there was a parade, of which Harry Hayward was Grand Marshal. His aides were Frederick Sammis, Elisha N. Hutchinson, Frank Spicer, and Frederick Hamsfeld.

In yesterday's market for outside securities active trading was confined to a very few issues, while most stocks, although strong, were dull. The general course of the market seemed to be due to a feeling that after election day an upward movement of prices would be inaugurated which could be expected to bring quotations to a level considerably above the present ones.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 5 -- Late this afternoon $250,000, the largest subscription yet made to the World's Fair local fund of $5,000,000, was handed to William H. Thompson, Chairman of the Finance Committee. It came from the St. Louis Transit Company and the Suburban Railroad, the two companies controlling the street railways of St. Louis.

Roland Reed, who was compelled to abandon his tour while the company was playing in Chicago and return to New York so he might place himself under the personal care of his family physician at St. Luke's Hospital, has arrived at the conclusion that it will be impossible to continue his tour further the present season, and has therefore disbanded the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Yesterday and to-day a regular exodus of officeholders from Washington has been in progress. All the trains leaving the National capital are crowded with voters going to their respective homes to cast their ballots tomorrow. From the Government Printing Office alone almost 1,500 employes have gone to their homes, and the ratio is almost as heavy from the other Government bureaus.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 5 -- The presence at the polls to-morrow of Deputy United States Marshals presages a conflict between the State and Federal authorities. The State authorities claim to be advised that thers is no law permitting the presence of Federal Marshals, and in many of the circuit judicial districts instructions have been given to arrest the deputies if they attempt to take any part in the election.
According to the Shanghai correspondent of The London Times, "confusion, disorganization, and absence of security are the chief characteristics of the allied occupation."
BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- Regarding the present status of affairs in Peking an official of the German Foreign Office made the following statement this afternoon:

Joseph Spencer Kennard, an American Commissioner to the Paris Exposition, was among the arrivals on the French Line steamer La Touraine yesterday. He was most enthusiastic over the showing this country made at the exposition, saying:

HAVANA, Nov. 5 -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention met in the Marti Theatre this afternoon at 2 o'clock. Long before that hour the theatre was crowded. Many thousands were unable to gain admittance, and the streets in the neighborhood were blocked with people.

"Society has a Gordian knot that is causing all sorts of guesses as to how the snarl is to be untangled," remarked a clubman who keeps in touch with all the social squabbles that seem so important to the parties immediately interested, and are the source of so much fun to those who do not take Harry Lehr and his followers very seriously.

-- As everybody knows -- from novels or otherwise -- the Englishman fortunate enough to possess landed property is wont to keep that fact in modest but constant evidence by making the name of his estate, if not exactly a part of his own personal name, at least so frequent an addition to it as to amount to much the same thing.

William S. Devery, Chief of Police, was yesterday indicted by the Grand Jury. He is charged with a felony in having violated Section 7, Chapter 676, of the Laws of 1898, in that he interfered with John McCullagh, the State Superintendent of Elections, and also commanded the members of the police force to interfere to the end of preventing Superintendent McCullagh from performing his duties under the law.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Charles A. Richter of this city has applied for a divorce from her husband because he insists on shooting glass balls from her head with his rifle.

The wedding of Lieut. Israel Putnam, United States Army, son of the late Mrs. R. Putnam of Saratoga, N.Y., and a nephew of M.M. Shoemaker, the traveler and author, and Miss Louise Carleton, daughter of George W. Carleton, was celebrated very quietly yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's parents, 27 West Thirty-seventh Street.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 5 -- In the course of a Quarrel over factional politics at the rooms of a negro Republican club to-day Ottery Dampson was shot three times by his brother Charles, one shot penetrating to the base of the brain. He is dying and Charles is under arrest. Ottery is a janitor at the Post Office.

The Degnon-MeLean Construction Company, which has the contract for the construction of pipe galleries in Elm Street, in addition to the building of the main underground rapid transit line from City Hall Park to Great Jones Street, has about 1,500 feet of excavation opened for the galleries from Prince to Great Jones Street, about half of which is excavated and some of it leveled off to grade.

Representative New Yorkers of almost every walk of life gathered in great numbers at St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, at the funeral of ex-Mayor William L. Strong yesterday. Before the coffin was brought in there was hardly a vacant seat in the church, and a crowd of respectful citizens lined both sides of the avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Census Bureau to-day issued the official figures of the population of the States of Indiana and Florida. The returns show that Indiana has a total population of 2,516,462, as against 2,192,404 in 1890. These figures show an increase since 1890 of 324,058, or 14.7 per cent.

The experiment of building an operetta around a character which made a hit in a previous entertainment has been tried by Messrs. Smith and De Koven, who for a number of years have been the two most prolific providers of this sort of performance. The new work is called "Foxy Quiller," and it was made known last night at the Broadway Theatre.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 5 -- Benjamin B. Odell, Republican candidate for Governor, addressed a mass meeting in the Opera House here to-night. About 1,500 persons heard his speech. John I. Platt, editor of The Eagle, delivered an address. Mr. Odell said:

Fire Marshal Seery several days ago submitted samples of chemicals taken from the Tarrant explosion ruins to Ernest J. Lederle, the Health Department's chemist, for analysis, and that official yesterday sent him his report. There were five samples in all submitted. Each was taken from a steel drum and each was a dark red fluid, of an oily appearance.

Charles B. Sehuyler Co. have sold for Norcross Brothers to a Mr. Hoffman, for about $45,000, a plot of three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Sixth Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway.

The legal fight over the estate of the late Gouverneur Kortright was ended yesterday by the withdrawal of the contest made by Mrs. E. Theresa Kortrignt, the widow of the testator, to the admission of the last will of Mr. Kortright. By the first will he left all his property to his wife and made her sole executrix.

Compared with "the night before election" in previous Presidential years, last night was a tame affair around the hotels in the Tenderloin district, and the crowd of sightseers who flocked to the Fifth Avenue Hotel and to the Hoffman House to witness the final betting on the result of to-day's battle of the ballots, went home much disappointed and wondering what it meant.

In all seriousness it is not a pleasant spectacle that is afforded to the people of this city by the Chief of Police and by the State Superintendent of Elections for the Metropolitan Elections District. Both Mr. DEVERY and Mr. McCULLAGH give the impression that they are playing politics, and politics of no very high order at that.

Throughout the canvass the President of the United States has been mindful of the dignity of his great office and has upheld it. He has gone calmly about the public business before him, exhibiting no unseemly eagerness concerning the election, and taking only such part in the strife of politics as custom exacts and propriety sanctions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- On the application of G. Harry Davis and Frank A. Hartranft, candidates of the Democratic and Municipal League Parties for City Treasurer and Register of Wills respectively, Judge Audenried to-day granted an order restraining the County Commissioners of Philadelphia from issuing a new set of ballots for this city with the circle at the top of the Municipal League column omitted.

The disabled American liner St. Paul, which arrived in port Sunday with her starboard machinery seriously injured, will sail, it is expected, the latter part of this week for Philadelphia, where she will go into dry dock at the Cramp shipyards for repairs.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Money is wanted in connection with the consol settlement and the payment of nearly a million of India and other loans. Discounts are tolerably firm in view of the continued weakness of New York and Continental Exchanges. Another call on the war loan must be met Thursday.

Superintendent McCullagh late last night announced that he had unearthed a big scheme to bring repeaters into Manhattan to-day from Jersey City, and that one of the alleged parties to the fraud, Peter Friend, a saloon keeper at Gregory and Henderson Streets, Jersey City, was arrested at 10 o'clock last night and was held at Police Headquarters, Jersey City, in default of $1,000 bail.

PARK RIDGE, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The "Angel Dancers" have taken another step down from the high position they once assumed relative to all things earthly. Not so long ago they would have scorned to meddle in politics and would have been shocked at the very suggestion that they should withdraw their minds from celestial matters long enough to vote.

OMAHA, Nov. 5 -- Mr. Bryan made twenty-one speeches in Nebraska to-day, nine of which were delivered here to-night. He left Lincoln by special train while it was still dark, and began speaking at 7 o'clock at Exeter. He had made eleven addresses when he returned to Lincoln at 6 o'clock at night.

The Rev. George Duryea Hulst, Ph. D., pastor of the South Bushwick Reformed Church, Bushwick Avenue and Himrod Street, Brooklyn, for more than thirty-one years, died suddenly of apoplexy yesterday in the parsonage adjoining the church at 15 Himrod Street. He was in his fifty-fourth year, and was born in Williamsburg.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- Boston had a broad and buoyant market, Montana ran up 8, to 329. Trading in it was active, but without sensational features. Amalgamated rose 1 5/8, to 93 7/8; American Telephone, on active trading, rose 2 1/2, to 150, with 1 per cent. bid early to call it at 150 till Wednesday night; Isle Royale rose 1 3/4, to 39; Old Dominion 1, to 23, and Parrot 1, to 47.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners will give a public hearing in the matter of the complaints made against the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company by the residents of the Twenty-sixth Ward. L.C. Ruch and Israel F. Fischer will appear on Thursday, Nov. 15, at 10 A.M., in the old Common Council chamber in Borough Hall, Brooklyn.
By what arguments can any opponent of CROKER persuade himself that he ought to vote for ODELL?

If the promised fine weather materializes to-day will be devoted by society to outdoor sports of all kinds in the suburbs. The principal meeting place for the members of the gay world of New York will be the Meadow Brook Club house, near Hempstead, L.I., where the annual steeplechases held under the auspices of that club will this year take place.

Madison Square Garden resounded all the afternoon and evening yesterday to the uninterrupted whirr of horseless vehicles in great variety, while at frequent intervals were mingled the operatic and martial strains of a well-tuned band. The second day of the Automobile Show closed, if anything, under even wore successful auspices than the most sanguine exhibitors and managers had hoped for.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- After the terrible downfall of the Tiger team at the hands of the Cornell giants, it is with varied emotions and many misgivings that Princetonians will flock to Columbia Field to-morrow to witness the struggle between their favorite team and the sturdy men of Columbia University.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- On the night before election the leaders of both political parties profess to be confident of victory at to-morrow's balloting, and both sides claim the State by pronounced majorities.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- The first week of the final stretch of the football season began at Tale Field to-day. The Indian game on Saturday to be followed by the Princeton and Harvard games will tax the Yale players to the utmost of their strength. It will also tax Yale's coachers, as Yale will have to prepare to meet in Harvard football play of the finest sort.

Ten families which occupy one of the apartment houses overlooking Central Park West stand in a fair way of being dispossessed to-morrow. It is not because they are too poor to pay their rent, for, on the contrary, they are all well to do. The real reason is that there are complications over the ownership of the property.
The result of the election in Kings County, peculiar as it may at first appear, was disappointing alike to the Democratic and Republican leaders.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The weakness of American securities on the Stock Exchange yesterday was a reflection of the strong interest taken here in the American elections and a recognition of the fact that, although the success of Mr. McKinley was regarded as almost certain, the contest presented all kinds of possibilities, owing to the complexity of the issues before the American public.

Mr. Bryan carried the City of New York by a plurality of about 31,000 over Mr. McKinley. The total vote cast for the Presidential candidates in the five boroughs of New York was about 600,000. The total registration was 642,034.

Voting in most of the Assembly districts on the lower east side was rapid and quiet. With the exception of the Eighth, in which Martin Engel is the Tammany leader, there were no disturbances of importance and but few arrests for illegal voting.

This will be reaction day, or "the morning after the ball," in the social world, and every one who can will wish to rest after the excitement and suspense of yesterday, and especially of last nigh't. There were many men who will feel compelled to be at their offices early this morning who did not retire at all.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 6. -- Brown defeated Tufts to-day, 26 to 5. The first half was a contest for blood, and every inch of ground was well earned. Brown clearly outplayed her opponent in the first part of the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Estimates from one-half of the counties in Pennsylvania indicate a plurality for McKinley of over 200,000. In this city the fusion of the Democrats with the Municipal League cut down the Republican county ticket, but J. Hampton Moore, for City Treasurer, and Jacob Singer for Register of Wills, are elected by more than 50,000 plurality.

Selling class horses had a practical monopoly of the racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday, the few horses of even ordinary merit that appeared on the programme seeming very much out of place. The quality of the racing had absolutely no effect on the attendance, however, as the tiny and inconvenient grand stand was filled to overflowing and the betting ring was so densely crowded that it was almost impossible to move about.

That large and exclusive circle of fashionable society comprising what is known as the "hunting set" gathered at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., yesterday afternoon to witness the annual steeplechases and pony races of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association.

Whether I am elected or not, I think my experience will be of some service to the country, for I have shown that a young man, without a single corporation behind him, can amount to something. -- Mr. BRYAN at Lincoln, Nov. 5.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 6. -- President McKinley has carried Michigan beyond doubt. Conservative estimates place his majority at 65,000. His majority in 1896 was 41,542. The Evening News says that if McKinley's ratio of majority in the 110 districts heard from is maintained throughout the State his majority will be 90,000.

From The Atlanta (Ga.) Constitution. Col. W.N. Cave of Barnwell, S.C., who is now in Atlanta on business, is in possession of a unique relic in the shape of a diamond pin which was at one time the property of Abraham Lincoln, and which is the only piece of jewelry of the kind that President Lincoln ever wore.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 6. -- Returns now in from Indiana indicate the State for McKinley by 30,000, while Republican Chairman Hernley claims from 40,000 to 50,000, Democratic Chairman Martin will make no statement. Senator Beveridge claims 40,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The jubilation here over President McKinley's re-election broke all bounds. Never, except at inauguration times, did such crowds surge up and down Pennsylvania Avenue, cheering, singing, and blowing horns.

John McCullagh, State Superintendent of Elections for the Metropolitan District, declared yesterday afternoon that the election had passed off quietly, and that there had been no reports of trouble between his deputies and the police. He added that no disorder at the polls had been reported to him.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 6. -- The returns at midnight show a complete sweep of Maryland by the Republicans, a landslide like that of 1896, including all six Congressional districts. Even Congressman Denny, Gold Democrat, in the Fourth District, included in Baltimore City, is defeated by Charles R. Schirm.

No man within or without this Union will soon again venture to raise the question whether the American people are sane and honest. Mr. BRYAN upon two occasions has audaciously challenged both propositions, and the people have with great emphasis twice demonstrated to him the error of his view of the matter.
County say President McKinley's majority in this county will be about 15,000, but that Alschuler, the Democratic candidate for Governor, will carry the State.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 6. -- Private advices from Opelika state that Governorelect William J. Samford is very ill.
John Sabine Smith, Treasurer of the Republican County Committee and a lawyer and politician of note, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 1,425 Broadway.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The Senate reopened its sessions at 2 o'clock this afternoon. M. Fallieres, President of the Senate, who presided, pronounced eulogies of the Senators who died during the Summer vacation. The House then proceeded to formal business.

Richard Croker heard the election returns at Tammany Hall. He was not happy when the first figures began to tick in over the wire placed in the executive chamber of the Wigwarn. His face was tense and he showed the mental strain under which he was suffering.

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 6. -- Society turned out in force to-day for the first of the season's hunts by the Flushing Hunt Club, organized recently by wealthy members of the Flushing Driving Club who are going in for cross-country sport. The meet was on the old Bowne Farm lands. H.G. Murray was Master of the Hounds, and William R. Wallace was the whip.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 6. -- William J. Bryan returned to Lincoln at 10:30 A.M. to-day, after spending the night in Omaha. His first act after arriving here was to swear in his vote and then cast it. He voted the straight Democratic ticket, National, State, and Congressional.

The annual lawn tennis tournament of the Knickerbocker Field Club of Flatbush, L.I., was concluded yesterday morning on the club courts, at Avenue A and Eighteenth Street, with some of the best tennis ever witnessed in Kings County. The surprise of the tourney was sprung in the singles, in the final rounds of which Winchester Noyes defeated W.D.A. Rose after an exciting set of games.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 6. -- Two men dead and four seriously wounded, one of whom will probably die, was the result of a clash which occurred early to-day between members of the police force and a posse of Deputy Sheriffs at a polling place at Twenty-second and Larimer Streets, in the down-town district.
The Fifty-seventh Congress will be Republican in both branches.

Extraordinary changes have taken place in market values during the past four years. Practically every security quoted on the New York Stock Exchange commands now much advanced price. The hard times prior to 1896 found reflection in quotations up to the defeat, of Mr. Bryan four years ago.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 7. -- At midnight Canton was in a frenzy of enthusiasm which knew no bounds. The crowds which had been burning red fire down town marched en masse to the McKinley residence with bands playing, rockets sending lurid streaks across the sky, and tumultuous cheers mingling with the din of horns and steam whistles.

Brooklyn voted early and voted quietly yesterday. The day was devoid of unusual incident, and although many arrests for illegal registration and similar offenses were made, there were no disturbances at the polls reported. The election in the borough was a record breaker as to the rapidity and smoothness with which the big vote was cast.

From The New Orleans Picayune. One of the scientific puzzles of the State of Mississippi is the "Brandywine Stone "Wall." It has long been a problem that is yet unsolved. Some time ago Mr. Thomas Watson of Hazlehurst sent Gov. Longino a pencil drawing of an immense pile of stone in the southeastern portion of Claiborne County, suggesting that the atone might be utilized in building the new Capitol.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6. -- Bryan's plurality in Virginia is fully 25,000. Except in the Second, Ninth, and Tenth Congressional Districts, where the Republicans were conceded a fighting chance from the first, there were big Democratic victories. Although the weather was good, the voters of neither party went to the polls in full force.

Unusual preparations were made in the Supreme Court for the handling of election cases yesterday. Justices Barrett, Bischoff, Truax, and Fitzgerald were in attendance from 9:30 o'clock A.M. until the polls closed, and the other Justices had arranged to be ready to come to the court if necessary.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 6. -- Chairman Dawson of the State Republican Committee claims for McKinley a plurality of 17,000. The Republicans also claim a plurality of 18,000 for A.B. White, their candidate for Governor. There will be a safe Republican majority in the Legislature.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 6. -- A large crowd of members and guests assembled today on the links of the Fairfield County Golf Club to witness the thirty-six-hole match between Harry Vardon and the former American amateur champion, Findlay S. Douglas. The latter did not come quite up to his game, and was beaten by 10 up and 8 to play.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 6. -- The Constitution estimates Bryan's plurality at 40,000. All the Democratic nominees are elected. The Congressmen are R.E. Lester, First District; James M. Griggs, Second; E.B. Lewis, Third; W.C. Adamson, Fourth; L. F. Livingston, Fifth; C.L. Bartlett, Sixth; John W. Maddox, Seventh; William M. Howard, Eighth; F.C. Tate, Ninth; William H. Fleming, Tenth, and William G. Brantley, Eleventh.
The expected has happened. The Republican Presidential ticket has swept the country.

Miss Louise Hilcher. Miss Louise Hilcher, who was well known in this country and abroad as a teacher and lecturer, died suddenly in Dresden on Oct. 14. She was born in Leipzig, and for many years pursued her profession in her native city. At the solicitation of her friends in this country she came here some years ago, and at once arrested the attention of the lecture-going public of New York.

From The London Times. This device provides a means by which electric glow-lamps may be mounted in any desired position without the use of lampholders, sockets, Ordinary incandescent lamps are used, but their terminals, instead of being of the usual form, consist of two sharp spikes about half an inch long and nearly the same distance apart.

The successor of Gov. ROOSEVELT will enter on his office with great opportunities, and with some obvious obstacles in his path. He will do extremely well if he can maintain the standard set up by his predecessor. He will have greater difficulties to contend with of much the same sort, and the public will be gratefully surprised if he is as well prepared to overcome them.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 6. -- The returns from the State are coming in very slowly, but the Republicans are showing gains on an average of ten to a precinct. There are 1,250 precincts in the State. At this rate the State will give a Republican majority for the electoral ticket of at least 10,000.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 6. -- Mr. Bryan's friends practically concede McKinley's reelection, but none of them will make a statement.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6. -- The indications here are that McKinley has carried the State by a large plurality and that the Republican State ticket is elected. Very few returns have been received from the rural districts, and no estimate can be reliably made on the composition of the Legislature.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- A perfect day had the effect of bringing out a full vote in the President's State. Owing to the fact that a long ticket was in the field and that several Congressional districts were decidedly close only an approximation of the result is obtainable. There are 3,109 voting precincts in the States, and the returns are compared with the returns of 1896, when McKinley carried the State by 51,109.

The ever-thrilling story of the Nation's battle of the ballots, as flashed upon the screens along Newspaper Row last night was read in ragged scraps fresh from the telegraph wires by a gathering fully as large, just as variegated, just as interesting, and just as noisy as ever thronged that section on election night.
The headquarters of the Republican National Committee, at 1 Madison Avenue, were tilled with happy men at an early hour last night. Admission was by card.

The ever-thrilling story of the Nation's battle of the ballots, as flashed upon the screens along Newspaper Row last night was read in ragged scraps fresh from the telegraph wires by a gathering fully as large, just as variegated, just as interesting, and just as noisy as ever thronged that section on election night.

QUEENS, L.I., Nov. 6. -- Good shooting was done here to-day at the open trap shooting tournament of the Medicus Gun Club held on the Inter-State Park Grounds. Dr. Ashley A. Webber of Brooklyn, A. Woods, Martin, and other cracks divided most of the events. All the scores were close and some rare sport was enjoyed from start to finish of an admirably arranged and conducted programme.

Some clever shooting and excellent scores marked the trap shooting tournament of the Crescent Athletic Club at the country clubhouse grounds at Owl's Head, L.I., yesterday. C. Kenyon, Jr., won the first trophies and one second, while exceptionally good work was done by Banks, Kryn, McDermott, Rhett, and Keyes.

McKinley and Roosevelt swept New Jersey yesterday, and while the result was no unexpected, the magnitude of the victors surprised even the Republican managers. Early this morning it was estimated that the Republican plurality would reach 60,000.

A small fare at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the large double-decker tenement at 115 and 11. Essex Street caused a panic among the 432 persons living there. The house is said 10 be one of the most densely populated in the world, and it is claimed by the census authorities that no.similar space of ground is known that is occupied by more people.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 6. -- Gov. Roosevelt, surrounded by his family, to-night received the returns at his home on Sagamore Hill. The Governor at no time during the evening seemed anxious about the result. He did not make any special arrangements to receive the news, and depended on messages to be brought from the telegraph office in the railroad station, nearly three miles away.

JAMAICA, L. I., Nov. 6. -- Splendid contests and close finishes marked the annual championship club road races of the Peconic Cyclers of New York, held here today on the Hoffman Boulevard at the lower end. The course was a two and a half mile stretch of the famous roadway. William H. Clark carried off most of the honors, taking the one, three, and five mile championships in fast time for the course.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 6. -- George A. Miller, a New York lawyer, living at Montclair, caused a warrant to issue this morning before Recorder Yost of Montclair for the arrest of George Inness, Jr., the artist. Mr. Miller alleged that the artist voted illegally in the Second District of the First Ward of Montclair.

Election day in New York was all that the most captious critic could desire. There was a sting in the fresh November air early in the morning that made even the usual late sleepers willing to bestir themselves when by so doing they could avoid a long wait at the polls and be able to exercise the highest duty of the citizen.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 6. -- A one-sided game of football was played this morning on the Orange Oval between the Orange Athletic Club and a team from the Fifth United States Artillery, stationed at Fort Hamilton, the local players winning by a score of 31 to 0. At no time did the soldiers secure the ball until within three minutes of the close of the second half, when the Orange team presented them with it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- The whalers California, Andrew Hlcks, and Alexander have reached this port, the two former from Okhotsk Sea and the Alexander from the Arctic. Capt. Smith of the California reports a catch of fifty sperm and eight right whales, producing 1,680 barrels of oil, valued at over $21,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6. -- Returns from the State have been coming in very slowly, but there seems to be little doubt that Bryan has carried the State by from 5,000 to 10,000 plurality. Beckham for Governor has probably gone below Bryan, but will probably be elected by a large plurality.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 7 -- President McKinley's trip from Canton toward the National capital to-day has been one continuous ovation to the twice-elected head of the Nation. At every stop there have been great outpourings of the people, business has been suspended, and many factories along the line have added their thousands of workers -- men and women -- to those who have joined in enthusiastic greetings.

"It is better to be sure than sorry." There is no thoroughfare in the world where that wise saw is more laid to heart than in Wall Street, or more profusely illustrated with modern instances. Most people said, two days ago, that the defeat of Bryanism had already been "discounted" in the Street, and that the election of McKINLEY would have a very trifling result.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Queen has approved the following appointments in the new Ministry:
Edward M. Shepard, who opposed the election of William J. Bryan in 1896 and supported his candidacy this year, in commenting yesterday on the result of the election, said:

The special underwriters adjustment committee appointed last week by the fire insurance companies involved in the recent Greenwich Street losses, where explosions occurred in the building occupied by Tarrant Co., reported at a meeting yesterday that its counsel had given an opinion to the effect that the companies were not liable for damages, if it was shown that the law regarding the storage of explosives within the city limits had been violated.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Gov. Roosevelt, although he did not retire until after midnight, was up in good season this morning, and after breakfast looked over his mail and dispatches of congratulation received from prominent persons in different parts of the country. The Governor, who was in the best of spirits, received a few callers during the morning.

Chief of the day's developments as to the election is the transferring of Nebraska from the list of doubtful States to the long list of those States whose voters pronounced in favor of McKinley and Roosevelt. Advices up to the hour of going to press indicate that the Republicans have control of the Legislature by three or four votes on joint ballot.
"Ladies and gentlemen, seeing that Bryan is sure to be elected and the country is going to ruin, I might as well put an end to it now."
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Many of the leaders of the real Democracy are in favor of reorganizing the party on old lines. James H. Eckles says:
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 7 -- At 10 o'clock tonight it is settled without possible dispute that the Republicans have swept Nebraska and have elected the entire State ticket and the Presidential Electors.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- The Maryland Steel Company, at Sparrows Point, began laying keels to-day for the two largest steel passenger and freight steamers ever constructed in the United States. The vessels are for the Atlantic Transport Company, and will run between New York and London.
If I am buried, the Democrats will have to do the burying -- RICHARD CROKER.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 7 -- It is estimated that 60,000 Republicans voted at the election yesterday for Commissioner to Congress and members of the House of Delegates. Not more than 200 Federals voted. The election was exceedingly orderly. There are no reports of disturbances, but communication with the interior is slow.

Howard Gould is defending an action brought against him in the Supreme Court by his former valet, Frank D. Mowbray, to recover $25,000 on an alleged breach of contract. He proved anything but an easy witness for the plaintiffs counsel to deal with on the cross-examination, which took up the entire afternoon session yesterday and was not completed when court adjourned.

Pier 22, Brooklyn, was the scene of an enthusiastic, yet affecting, demonstration yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the sailing of the United States military transport Buford, with nearly a thousand men aboard, officers and recruits of the Regular Army, for the Philippines. Two o'clock was the hour set for the vessel to sail, but it was after 4 when she was pulled clear of her dock by the Government tugs, and headed down the bay.

Society again smiled upon the Automobile Show in the Madison Square Garden last night. Not only was there an excellent attendance, but many fashionable folk were observed in the boxes watching the endless procession in swift moving vehicles or in the arena listening to the explanations of the exhibitors as they lectured on the superior merits of their respective wares.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was glad to note the terse but very true statement in your editorial page of this morning's TIMES, that "we can no longer put up with that man," (Croker.) I am heart and hand with you there! To my idea there never has been so great a menace to personal and National liberty as confronts us in "that man."

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Because his wife accepted a wedding gift of a house and lot, which subsequently doubled in value, Thomas J. Ahern, a young Greenwich lawyer, has been made defendant in a suit now pending before the Superior Court in Bridgeport charging him with fraud.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Miss Grace Carr of Louisville, Ky., was married to-day to Lord Newborough in Savoy Chapel. United States Ambassador Choate gave the bride away.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 -- Ex-United States Senator David B. Hill received several hundred telegrams to-day from prominent Democrats in various parts of the United States asking that he suggest a plan whereby the Democratic Party might be reorganized. To Mr. Hill this leading question was put by THE TIMES correspondent:

Tuesday being practically a holiday, and the sort of a day that tempted every one out of doors, the bridle paths in the parks and on Riverside Drive were crowded with horseback riders as they have not been any day this year. The proprietor of one of the riding establishments said he could easily have let a hundred more horses had he owned them to people who wished to ride in the parks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the Presidential election is over and our minds are freed from the weighty questions of State involved in the late campaign, we, of this city, ought to take immediate steps to clear this city of the corrupting influences by which it is at present surrounded.

President Mellen of the Northern Pacific Railway arrived in this city yesterday. He was greatly pleased with the result of the election and said he expected a great inciease in the business of his road would follow as a result. "I would be disappointed," said Mr. Mellen, "If my expectations in this respect should not be realized.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Returns received from the State at large during this evening do not materially alter the political complexion of the next State Legislature. The probability is that the Republicans will have a majority of about twenty-two on joint ballot in the State Legislature, which means a Republican successor to Senator Cullom.

Complete returns of the State give William McKinley for President a plurality of 145,243 over William Jennings Bryan for President. Mr. Bryan's gains, as shown by the comparative table, were made in no one section, but covered the entire State.
The latest returns on the Congressional election make few changes in the list published by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- A trolley car was run into by a freight train at the Perry Street crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad in this city, and John Haggerty, conductor of the trolley car, was killed and several of the passengers were injured, one of them receiving a broken arm. The freight train was drilling.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The attention of the Stock Exchange was centred almost entirely on Americans. The excitement continued during the greater part of the day. The initial advance was well maintained, with intervals of slight relapses on profit taking, in some cases with further advances, closing quieter and below the best prices.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- There was no effort in Paris last night to await the American election returns, the difference in time practically eliminating the possibility of obtaining definite information.

Yesterday the voters of the Dominion of Canada held their general election. For the last two months the Conservative campaign, under the leadership of Sir CHARLES TUPPER, has been carried on with considerable vigor against the Premier, Sir WILFRID LAURIER, and the Liberal Government, without, however, exciting much comment in Great Britain or attracting much attention in the United States.

How long will the Democrats of the solid South insist on being saved by the North and West from the consequences of their blind, stupid folly? They have just voted, as they voted four years ago, for the ruin of their industries, the loss of their foreign markets, and the deadening of the new industrial impulse that promises the transformation and enrichment of their part of the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Chicago financiers, brokers, and bankers lost no time to-day in taking advantage of the boom they thought they knew was coming on the opening of the stock market as the result of McKinleys' re-election and Bryan's defeat. Opinions are optimistic.

Joseph E. Freitag shot and killed his wife in her rooms, at 460 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, and then shot himself twice. At first it was thought that he would die, but the surgeons at the Eastern District Hospital decided last night that his chances of recovery were good.
The Arbuckles and the independents made a cut of 15 points in the price of refined sugars yesterday, which was followed by the American Sugar Refining Company.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The announcement is made that J. Forbes-Robertson, the actor and manager, will shortly marry Miss Gertrude Elliott, the American actress.

MOTHER AND SON -- A somewhat remarkable controversy between a mother and her son recently received final decision in the Court of Appeals, after many years of litigation. Benjamin G. Disbrow, in his lifetime, about ten years ago, and his wife. Sarah M. Disbrow, had intended to cut off two of their sons, Charles and Robert, from any share in their property.
BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- German Government circles are all delighted at President McKinley's re-election. The United States Embassy to-day received a number of expressions of satisfaction.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 7 -- Senator Hanna this evening gave out the following signed statement on the result of yesterday's election:

"A woman's chief glory is her hair," and its becoming and fashionable arrangement has always proved an important item of the toilet. In past seasons there has been a sufficient diversity of style to allow every taste to be satisfied, but now one particular mode alone is to predominate and find favor as the "correct thing."

A complimentary dinner was given to Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., at the Republican Club last night. When Mr. Odell reached the clubhouse he held a reception before being escorted to the banquet hall by Louis Stern.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed against Hatch Foote, stock brokers, of 3 Nassau Street, yesterday by the following creditors: Theodore H. Babcock, $2,748; Joseph N.T. Levick, $2,177, and Frederick A. Baker, $779.

No wonder foreign critics comment on the perfect good nature of the election in this country as the most striking feature of it. To them it is, but we ourselves are so used to taking victory and defeat good naturedly that we really do not understand what a feat it is in civilization, what an object lesson in democracy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- The air of despondency cast over the undergraduate body by the defeats at the hands of Cornell and Columbia was not much in evidence at University Field this afternoon. The team seemed in excellent spirits and went through the preliminary catching of punts and falling on the ball with a vim and energy which characterized the work of every Princeton team when driven to the last extremity.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Most of the morning papers, in their comments upon the American election, take the line followed by The Daily News, which says:

With officially reported transactions on the Stock Exchange of a million and a half shares, and with official estimates that the total really was beyond two millions, yesterday gave to Wall Street a record transcending anything ever in the past approximated.
J.A.R. Dunning and Pease Elliman have sold for the estate of Eliza T. Bryson the four-story dwelling 26 East Thirty-eighth Street, 18.9 by 98.9.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 7 -- The results of to-day's elections show that the Government has been sustained by a majority of from fifty to sixty members, on the basis of the returns received up to midnight, with five constituencies yet to be heard from. To-day's elections were in 208 of the 213 constituencies of the Dominion, and the remaining five will hold their elections at later dates.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- In a hard-fought football game on the parade grounds this afternoon, Rutgers succumbed to the superior football tactics of the cadets. The score, 23 to 0, showed how one-sided the play was. From the beginning West Point had the upper hand, and it was only a question of how large a score the soldiers wanted to pile up.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "A Right Beginning of the City Campaign" will be appreciated and its sentiment subscribed to by all thoughtful readers of your paper, but an exception will be taken to the conclusion you arrive at -- that "Croker is the enemy."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Probably the most important golf fixture of the Autumn season in this city will be the women's match between teams representing all Philadelphia and all New York, which will take place to-morrow over the course of the Philadelphia Country Club. Clement A. Griscom, the father of the National and local woman golf champion.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 7 -- "I predict the formation of a new party, based on he protests of the outraged people against Republicanism, as taught by Mark Hanna," declared United States Senator Pettigrew this morning. He had just left his home, to which he withdrew last night when the first considerable batch of telegrams arrived from South Dakota.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- In the stock market to-day, Isle Royale rose 2, to 41, later falling back to 39 again, with dealings of 4,000 shares in the morning. Old Dominion was up 2, at 25; later, 23 1/2. Montana was quiet, gaining 5, to 330; later, 325. Butte also was dull, rising 2, to 71; later 69 1/2. Parrot rose 2 1/2 to 49 1/4; later, 48 1/4.

Fame is a very uncertain jade, as she herself must know by this time, for she is always being told so by her victims. The product of the cycle tax in France now amounts to u173,532, the number of machines taxed being 838,856.
"I was very much surprised and disappointed at the way the election turned out," said Mr. Croker yesterday. "I did expect Mr. Bryan to be elected President of the United States."
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Dally Mail this morning makes the following announcement:

About 200 members of the rank and file of the Republican army of campaign orators met last night in one of the dining rooms of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and enjoyed the first fruits of the full dinner pail argument. The occasion was the first annual banquet of the Republican Speakers' League of the United States.

Plans for the Mayoralty campaign are already forming, and many of the men who will be in the forefront of the battle in the municipal fight are discussing issues. There was talk yesterday or the organizations of many associations having for their object the ousting of Richard Croker from power both in Tammany Hall and also from the control of the City Government.

The annual meeting of the Association of Collegiate Alumnae opened in this city yesterday and will close to-morrow. To-day the members will visit Columbia University and Barnard College. The New York branch will also give a breakfast to the association at Claremont, Riverside Drive.

The announced intention of Senator Thomas C. Platt and other Republican leaders to urge the passage by the incoming Legislature of a State constabulary bill, which will take the control of the police of Greater New York away from the local authorities, has stirred up opposition among leading Democrats, and the proposed effort, if persisted in, may seriously complicate the campaign against Tammany which is to be waged next year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The election is believed to be over by all, except a certain Mr. Jones, too sleepy to talk, and the Warwick of "State leaders" too busy with his packing to understand or to explain. But all others know that the election was held, and that the voters have declared themselves just as it was well known they would do the day after the State Convention.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 8 -- William J. Bryan, though overwhelmingly defeated, is still esteemed as of yore by some Colorado Democrats. He has been invited to become a citizen of Denver and a salary of $10,000 a year is held out as the inducement to remove from unappreciative Lincoln. The editors of a local afternoon paper today wired Mr. Bryan as follows:

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A great demonstration was held here to-night, the home of Gov. elect Odell, in honor of the Republican victory generally and or Mr. Odell's success particularly. First, there was a parade of the Republican clubs of Newburg and vicinity, the column being reviewed by Mr. Odell at his home.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 8 -- The official returns of Tuesday's election are nearly all at hand from the various' parts of the island. They show, as was anticipated and forecasted, the election by the Republicans of the entire House of Delegates and of Senor Federico Degetau as Commissioner to Congress.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- At the close of a long session yesterday, culminating in several exciting divisions, the Chamber of Deputies adopted a resolution of confidence in the Waldeck-Rousseau Government.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Three hundred studies and lectures will constitute the course for the first session of the Bible Teachers' College to be held in Montclair from January until June, 1901. Ten studies in the Gospel by John and ten studies in Hebrews will be given by Dr. Marcus Dods of Edinburgh, Scotland.

Bishop Potter has very nearly completed his investigation, which the Diocesan Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church on Sept. 27 instructed him to make in regard to the indignities alleged to have been offered to the clergy of the Pro-Cathedral in Stanton Street by the police authorities of the district.
A tempting covey of post-election delusions was flushed by our neighbor The Sun yesterday morning, and as this is the open season for that game, the killing may begin at once.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Broken in health by reason of the hardships and privations of the fearful famine in India, Bishop J.M. Thoburn of Bombay, representative of the Methodist Episcopal Church in India and Oceania, has returned to this country after forty-one years of active service in the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The population of the State of Massachusetts was officially announced to-day by the Census Bureau. The population of Massachusetts in 1900 is 2,805,346, as compared with a population in 1890 of 2,238,943, showing an increase of 566,403, or 25.2 per cent. For the preceding decade it was 25.5 per cent.

The question to ask of every decent citizen is not, Are you a Republican or a Democrat? but, Are you anti-Croker? No other issue should be allowed to enter the contest.

There was talk yesterday or the organizations of many associations having for their object the ousting of Richard Croker from power both in Tammany Hall and also from the control of the City Government.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- The first cargo of steel to be shipped via the lakes and the Welland Canal to Europe has just left Conneaut Harbor, the northern terminal of the Carnegie railroad. The vessel carrying this first cargo is the steamer Monkhaven, and the Captain is W.E. Zealand.

HAVANA, Nov. 8 -- The Committee on Rules of the Cuban Constitutional Convention is discussing the advisability of holding secret sessions after the permanent organization has been effected, which will probably take place at the reopening of the convention next Monday. Senors Capote, Tamayo and Kivera are the most prominent candidates for the Presidency of the convention. La Lucha says:

PETTIGREW.

Justice Marean, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday ordered the discharge of Miss Georgianna Wendel of Irvington from the Long Island Home at Amityville, where she was sent as an insane person. Justice Marean ordered Miss Wendel's release on the ground that the proceedings under which she was committed were illegal and void and in violation of the Constitution.

The annual meeting of the Association of Collegiate Alumnae opened in this city yesterday and will close to-morrow. To-day the members will visit Columbia University and Barnard College. The New York branch will also give a breakfast to the association at Claremont, Riverside Drive.

About 200 members of the rank and file of the Republican army of campaign orators met last night in one of the dining rooms of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and enjoyed the first fruits of the full dinner pail argument. The occasion was the first annual banquet of the Republican Speakers' League of the United States.

The income account in the annual report for the fiscal year of the Pacific Coast Company, issued yesterday, shows a surplus of $437,178. The report says that on account of the rapid development of the Pacific Coast country and in order to meet the growing demand for the transportation of passengers and freight, it has become necessary for the company to provide additional modern ships.

BUTTE, Mont., Nov. 8 -- The election in Montana has resulted in a sweeping victory for the Fusion Democrats under the leadership of ex-Senator W.A. Clark, and in Silver Bow County, the seat of the fight, the Fusionists received a majority of 1,200 over the Republicans and the Daly Democrats combined, both of which had tickets in the field.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- The three equity suits which were brought in the Suffolk Superior Court against A.H. Chamberlyn of the Columbia Theatre, asking for a receiver for the properties of "The Cadet Girl," were refused by Judge Braley to-day. Mr. Proctor, counsel for Mr. Chamberlyn, pointed out to the Judge that Mr. Chamberlyn claims, in the case of Ludwig Englander, that he does not owe the money.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Paul Schubert, nineteen years of age, an expert electrician employed by the Westinghouse Electric Apparatus Manufacturing Company, on Orange Street, was instantly killed by 1,000 volts of electricity this morning. He was assigned to the testing of meters. He is said to have had one habit from which he could not be broken, although warned many times.

Gen. Oliver Oils Howard was seventy years old yesterday, and last night in celebration of the event over two hundred of his friends gathered at dinner in the large ballroom of the Waldorf-Astorla. NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- George J. Isbistor of Ghent, N.Y., was married last night to Miss Lizzie Voorhees Schenck, daughter of the Rev. I.S. Schenck of Paterson Street, this city. A number of the bride's friends had congregated outside of the house after the ceremony intending to give the wedding party a serenade.

MAHA, Neb., Nov. 8 -- Final doubts on Nebraska's political complexion were removed to-night. The only possible doubt remaining touches the head of the State ticket, and even the Fusion managers admit that with the twenty obscure counties to hear from on Governor the Fusionists must make gains over four years ago to offset the Republican majority of 2,000.

Cochran, who have been among the most active of the political leaders in opposition to the return of ex-Senator Quay to the Senate, met in this city today and discussed plans for a continuation of the fight against Mr. Quay in the Legislature, which will meet in January.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 8 -- With returns from all but 30 out of 1,886 precincts in Kentucky, The Courier Journal puts Bryan's plurality at 8,000 and Beckham's at 5,000. The missing precincts have been taken into account in this result. The Republicans now claim that pluralities will be shown for McKinley and Yerkes when the returning board canvasses the vote at Frankfort, which it will do three weeks from election day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Bishop Henry C. Potter of New York testified to-day before the Industrial Commission. The commission held its first session of the month, and Bishop Potter was the first of a large number of important witnesses who will appear during November. He spoke on sweatshops, arbitration, and other questions.

WINSTED, Conn., Nov. 9. -- All kinds of weather have prevailed throughout the extreme northwestern portion of Connecticut to-day, and a small blizzard, which shows no sign of abating, is raging tonight. The wind is blowing at a velocity of fifty miles an hour. Many of the streets in towns of this section are literally covered with branches of trees blown off by the high wind.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 9. -- William E. Chandler, who desires to be re-elected United States Senator by the Legislature chosen at the recent election, replied tonight to the criticisms of his Senatorial record recently made by Railroad Commissioner Henry M Putney. The most important criticism made by Mr. Putney relates to Mr. Chandler's persistent advocacy of bimetallism.

The Irving Place Theatre echoed again and again last evening to the Columbia University cheers. Herr Conrled had invited the Columbia boys to be present as his guests and receive an illustrated lesson in the German classics. They cheered their approval in both German and English. It was one of the popular classical evenings of the theatre, a Schiller-Feier.

Many architectural novelties are to be introduced in the Manhattan Congregational Church about to be erected at Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street. "Pete," otherwise known as the "brick dog," is dead. He was owned by Henry G. Hermann of 60 Greenville Avenue, Jersey City. "Pete" was as familiar a figure throughout the Greenville district as was his master. He was a little dog, and his pedigree was hazy, but he was a great favorite, especially with children, who were content to take "Pete" as they found him, without regard to his ancestry.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9. -- The suggestion of an early meeting in New York to consider the question of reorganizing the Democratic Party does not meet with approval among the leaders here. Senator John W. Daniel, who has expressed himself on this subject, said: "Let the fires die out first, and in due season we can rekindle them on a common ground, about which all Democrats can gather."

What the Justices of the Supreme Court and the District Attorney call a most remarkable and widespread conspiracy to defeat the ends of justice by giving and procuring "fake" testimony in divorce cases has just been unearthed through an investigation set on foot by Justices Lawrence and Scott of the Supreme Court which has resulted in the arrest of two persons implicated, and the detention of one as a witness.

MAHANOY CITY, Penn., Nov. 9 -- One man was killed, five others probably fatally injured, and twenty others more or less seriously injured in an explosion of gas at the Buck Mountain Colliery to-day, about two miles from here. The dead man was James Griffith, a former School Director.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Lord Mayor's Show was witnessed to-day by large crowds. Although the latter were unusually dense, they were easily handled by the large police force on duty, in striking contrast to the recent parade of the City Imperial Volunteers. In the vicinity of Ludgate Circus ambulance wagons were held in readiness, but there was no serious crush.

We note with satisfaction that the public is wearying of the cheerful idiots who make grotesque election wagers and that the extremely silly performances which the losers are required to undertake are meeting with small encouragement. The right of a man to make a fool of himself is probably inalienable.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 9 -- It now appears that Dr. Leopold Kann is the only member of his party of arctic scientific explorers who arrived at Dundee yesterday on the whaler Eclipse from Davis's Strait. Dr. Robert Stein of the United States Geological Survey, decided at the eleventh hour not to come to Scotland, but to await the first opportunity of being landed on the American side.

The calling of a special session of the Congress elected at the same time with a President has become almost a fixed rule of political procedure. When a President, as is Mr. McKINLEY'S good fortune, is not only chosen to succeed himself, but has had a Congress in sympathy with him during the second half of his first term, there cannot commonly be any good reason for a special session of the new Congress.

What the Justices of the Supreme Court and the District Attorney call a most remarkable and widespread conspiracy to defeat the ends of justice by giving and procuring "fake" testimony in divorce cases has just been unearthed through an investigation set on foot by Justices Lawrence and Scott of the Supreme Court which has resulted in the arrest of two persons implicated, and the detention of one as a witness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Frank W. Funk, the murderer of William H. Brooks, was hanged to-day in the District jail. The case was a notable one in Washington, and Funk's interesting personality, as well as the circumstances of the crime, attracted much attention. Funk was a self-confessed criminal.

WINSTED, Conn., Nov. 9. -- All kinds of weather have prevailed throughout the extreme northwestern portion of Connecticut to-day, and a small blizzard, which shows no sign of abating, is raging tonight. The wind is blowing at a velocity of fifty miles an hour. Many of the streets in towns of this section are literally covered with branches of trees blown off by the high wind.

LINCOLN. Neb., Nov. 9. -- Returns on eighty-one of the counties in Nebraska give McKinley a majority of 9,498. The nine missing counties in 1896 gave Bryan a majority of 1,500. It is believed his majority in these counties will be much less this year than four years ago. Returns so far Received indicate the election of Charles H. Dietrich for Governor by a plurality of less than 2,000.

"Pete," otherwise known as the "brick dog," is dead. He was owned by Henry G. Hermann of 60 Greenville Avenue, Jersey City. "Pete" was as familiar a figure throughout the Greenville district as was his master. He was a little dog, and his pedigree was hazy, but he was a great favorite, especially with children, who were content to take "Pete" as they found him, without regard to his ancestry.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Lord Mayor's Show was witnessed to-day by large crowds. Although the latter were unusually dense, they were easily handled by the large police force on duty, in striking contrast to the recent parade of the City Imperial Volunteers. In the vicinity of Ludgate Circus ambulance wagons were held in readiness, but there was no serious crush.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 9 -- It now appears that Dr. Leopold Kann is the only member of his party of arctic scientific explorers who arrived at Dundee yesterday on the whaler Eclipse from Davis's Strait. Dr. Robert Stein of the United States Geological Survey, decided at the eleventh hour not to come to Scotland, but to await the first opportunity of being landed on the American side.

The answer of the Mayor to the formal charges made to the Governor in the matter of the Ice Trust has been made public, together with the report of the Attorney General thereon. The judgment of the Attorney General is that the answer, in the absence of other evidence, does not require or justify further action by the Governor.

The most Important testimony given yesterday in the examination before United States Commissioner Shields of Cornelius L. Alvord. Jr., the accused note teller of the First National Bank, tended to show with what ease and dexterity the prisoner succeeded in hoodwinking the Bank Examiners when the department's experts visited the bank on Oct. 15 last.

-- Nothing done by their political opponents in the recent campaign had quite so abrasive an effect upon the temper of Mr. BRYAN and his lieutenants as did the occasional announcement by this or that business man or corporation official that he had received certain orders for work or material, the execution of which depended upon the re-election of President McKINLEY.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- The wreck of the Grand Musical Festival last night has caused consternation among the high-class vocal talent which had been engaged, and the big purses which tempted them hither have turned to ashes when almost within their grasp.

That is a disquieting rumor which comes from China that LI-HUNG-CHANG has declared he had no hope of a peaceable solution of the difficulty. It is true that the dispatch comes from Shanghai, and through a not entirely trustworthy channel. It has perhaps not much more support than its intrinsic probability.

We note with satisfaction that the public is wearying of the cheerful idiots who make grotesque election wagers and that the extremely silly performances which the losers are required to undertake are meeting with small encouragement. The right of a man to make a fool of himself is probably inalienable.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Patrick Charles Bryce, uncle of ex-United States Senator James Smith, died this morning at the home of his son, James E. Bryce, 342 Clifton Avenue. Death was due to apoplexy and old age. Mr. Bryce was ill a week. Mr. Bryce was eighty-three years old, and leaves two sons, P. Lyndon Bryce and James E. Bryce.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon made a brief statement relative to the Ice Trust and the telegram which is said to have been sent to him relative to Mayor Van Wyck's answer by Governor-elect Odell. The statement is as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- The course of American Linseed preferred stock, which has fallen five points on the Exchange in the last two days, when every other issue has had an election-boom rise, led to reports that members of the management are at outs that the company is wrong in its position on the flaxseed market, and that the next dividend would be passed.

The "brisk northwesterly wind" forecast for New York City and vicinity Thursday by the Weather Bureau began to blow early yesterday morning. The term "brisk" was soon inadequate, however, and by noon a gale was blowing which in a short time developed into nothing less than a hurricane.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- The course of American Linseed preferred stock, which has fallen five points on the Exchange in the last two days, when every other issue has had an election-boom rise, led to reports that members of the management are at outs that the company is wrong in its position on the flaxseed market, and that the next dividend would be passed.

Racing under the conditions attending the sport at Aqueduct appealed only to those who were hardened regular racegoers, and these made but a modest showing in the grand stand yesterday. A gale howled over the race course, which was ankle deep in mud and slush. The wind was strong enough to aid appreciably in checking the pace of the horses as they splashed through the mud.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Bishop Henry C. Potter of New York testified to-day before the Industrial Commission. The commission held its first session of the month, and Bishop Potter was the first of a large number of important witnesses who will appear during November. He spoke on sweatshops, arbitration, and other questions.

The most Important testimony given yesterday in the examination before United States Commissioner Shields of Cornelius L. Alvord. Jr., the accused note teller of the First National Bank, tended to show with what ease and dexterity the prisoner succeeded in hoodwinking the Bank Examiners when the department's experts visited the bank on Oct. 15 last.

The Hon. THOMAS CLENDINEN CATCHINGS of the Vicksburg District, Mississippi, is a man of considerable originality. In the chorus of voices uttering more or less emphatic commonplaces on the future of the Democratic Party it is refreshing to hear these cool, definite expressions from him:

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- At the third day's racing of the Liverpool Autumn meeting to-day the Liverpool Autumn Cup was won by J.D. Warden's Fabulist. Lord Farquhar's Japonica came in second and A.F. Basset's Good Luck was third. Eighteen horses ran.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Frank W. Funk, the murderer of William H. Brooks, was hanged to-day in the District jail. The case was a notable one in Washington, and Funk's interesting personality, as well as the circumstances of the crime, attracted much attention. Funk was a self-confessed criminal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The active and vigorous campaign which Secretary Root has ordered Gen. MacArthur to prosecute is about to begin. The plan of campaign is being carefully guarded, because the Philippine Juntas supply Aguinaldo's officers with information concerning everything which it is advantageous for him to know.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9. -- The suggestion of an early meeting in New York to consider the question of reorganizing the Democratic Party does not meet with approval among the leaders here. Senator John W. Daniel, who has expressed himself on this subject, said: "Let the fires die out first, and in due season we can rekindle them on a common ground, about which all Democrats can gather."

The calling of a special session of the Congress elected at the same time with a President has become almost a fixed rule of political procedure. When a President, as is Mr. McKINLEY'S good fortune, is not only chosen to succeed himself, but has had a Congress in sympathy with him during the second half of his first term, there cannot commonly be any good reason for a special session of the new Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- The wreck of the Grand Musical Festival last night has caused consternation among the high-class vocal talent which had been engaged, and the big purses which tempted them hither have turned to ashes when almost within their grasp.

A panic resulted from a fire which started at 10 o'clock last night in the dry goods and notion store of David Dobrowsky, in the five-story double tenement at 15 Moore Street, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The firemen extinguished the flames after the lower part of the house had been burned out.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Oct. 10. -- The site of the Federal capital has been practically determined. The commission appointed to ascertain the most suitable locality has decided, as generally anticipated, in favor of the Monaro district, in the southeast portion of this colony. It is a lovely country, possessing many picturesque features and having a most delightful climate.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 10 -- Thomas F. Fitzpatrick, aged twenty-seven years, representing himself as a nephew of exMayor John Fitzpatrick of New Orleans, was shot through the heart and instantly killed in the Peerless saloon, a fashionable cafe here, at 3:30 this morning.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Oct. 10. -- The action of New Zealand in seeking the annexation of Fiji and other Pacific islands is being vigorously resisted by the federating Australian colonies, and already a strongly worded protest against the annexation of the Cook Islands is on its way to Mr. Chamberlain.

Floyd McFarland, "Tom" Cooper, and nine foreign cyclists, who will take part in the six days' cycle races at the Madison Square Garden next month, arrived yesterday on the American liner St. Louis. The foreigners comprise three French riders, Jean Gougoltz, Carl Simal, and E. Auchotrier; three Germans, K. Kiser, J. Fischer, and F. Ryser, and R. Moeller and M. Fredricks, who represent Italy and Norway, respectively.

Old Brooklynites, who have always taken great pride in the reputation of the erst-while City of Churches for sedateness and general goodness, were deeply shocked yesterday to learn that even Paterson, N.J., was a "slow" place compared to Brooklyn.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 10 -- Gov. Roosevelt was asked to-day if he had anything to add to his statement of yesterday relative to the Ice Trust. He replied that he would say no more on the subject until he had had a conference with Attorney General Davies. That would probably be, he said, on Monday or Tuesday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Harvard was scored against for the third time this season, by Brown on Soldiers Field this afternoon, the final score, 11 to 6, representing two touch-downs End one goal for Harvard and a touch-down on a double pass and twenty-five-yard run with goal for Brown.

Society devotees of the motor vehicle and mere sightseers gathered in force at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and last night to bid farewell to the first show of the Automobile Club of America, which has held forth with progressive popularity during the past eight days. It is estimated that more than 12,000 persons visited the Garden during the afternoon and evening yesterday, a record considerably in excess of any previous day of the exhibition.

"I see some of the papers have published a story to the effect that Clark's victory in Montana cost him $5,000,000," remarked a Neyadan, who is also in the mining line, and who was chatting after a luncheon at the Hoffman House yesterday. "Those may seem big figures here in the East, but no well-informed man from the far West doubts it.

PRINCETON. N.J., Nov. 10. -- The Tiger cubs were too much for the Yale freshmen this afternoon, and the final score was: Princeton freshmen, 17; Yale freshmen, 6. In the first half the young Princetonians outplayed Yale in almost every part of the game. Good luck was also on the side of Princeton and covered up many shortcomings in the way of fumbling and general carelessness.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 10. -- When Mayorelect Garrettson returned from New York to-day he found on his desk more than 200 telegrams and letters of congratulation from all parts of the country, both from public men and cottagers.

Plans are being laid for the formation of a National union of mortuary trades, such as those of grave diggers, coffin makers, embalmers, and shroud makers, with special rules regarding the rights of the workers and their relations to their employers and the public. Unions of undertakers' assistants are in existence in some of the New Jersey cities, and up to recently there was a strong organization of funeral coach drivers in Jersey City.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 10 -- After spending nearly two months in relief work among the sufferers at Galveston and other places on the Texas coast, Miss Clara Barton feels that there is no longer a necessity for her to remain in the field.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Formal steps were taken to-day to gridiron the northern part of Westchester County and Connecticut when the Peekskill Lighting and Railroad Company filed a mortgage for $750,000 in the Register's office at White Plains. The mortgage is made in favor of the New York Security and Trust Company for the purpose of enabling the company to carry on the construction of extensions to its trolley system.

Austin, Texas, Nov. 10 -- Another conflict is imminent between the authorities and the contending factions at Anderson, where, as already reported, fatal rioting caused by the local elections, occurred last Wednesday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Cornell had no difficulty in defeating Oberlin by the score of 29 to 0 to-day and the abbreviation of the second half was the only reason the score was not larger. Time was called just as Cornell was about to go over the line for a sixth touch-down. Oberlin could not gain through Cornell's line and lost materially on an exchange of punts with Starbuck.

Anarchists of this city and its vicinity registered another mark of hatred against the police last night and vowed, when out of hearing, to pay the score with interest at some future date, the time not being specified.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 10. -- By the decisive score of 28 to 5 the University of Iowa defeated the University of Michigan at Bennett Park this afternoon. Michigan's five was the result of a place kick by Sweeley from the thirty-five-yard line just before the end of the second half.
