To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you allow me space in your paper, not being an astronomer, only from childhood a "star grazer" and a most Interested spectator of all visible celestial phenomena, to give my humble opinion as to the cause of the non-appearance of the expected meteoric shower in November, 1899?

Those who expected that the real estate market would enter upon an era of phenomenal activity beginning last Wednesday morning had only disappointment in store for themselves. This market does not lend itself to outside influences as readily as Wall Street does, but the result, if more gradual, is at the same time more permanent and satisfactory.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- It was learned here to-day through parties interested in the great project that the combination of ocean steamship companies now in course of formation will be worldwide in its interests and will include Pacific as well as Atlantic Ocean lines.

The Schoolmasters' Association at New York and vicinity yesterday held its 100th meeting, and the affair was turned into a celebration of the work already accomplished and a symposium on that which is yet to be done.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 10 -- Senator William V. Allen stopped off in Omaha several hours to-night, en route to his home in Madison. "No," said Senator Allen, in answer to a question as to the significance as to the result, "Tuesday's election cannot be regarded as an indorsement of McKinley's policy, although I have no doubt he will so construe it."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Sadie Gardner of this city who procured a divorce through the New York divorce mill, exhibits a receipt signed Maison Co., for $125, stating that it was full payment for procuring her divorce.

Philadelphia sent its best golf team into this territory yesterday and found that the players whose game is a product of metropolitan links were stronger in team competition by 27 holes. The match, which was the second held under the joint auspices of the Metropolitan and Philadelphia Golf Associations, was played on the St. Andrew's Club links, near Chauncey, Westchester County.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- It has frequently been said that people in this town found It easy enough to make money, but difficult to spend it without going away. In other words, Chicago still remains more commercial than fashionable. The man with $20,000 finds this an excellent city in which to live.

MONDAY, NOV. 12. -- By William M. Ryan, foreclosure sale. Edward Jacobs, referee, 467 West Thirty-fourth Steet, north side. 20.10 feet east of Tenth Avenue, 20.10 by 74.1, four-story brick dwelling, with store. Due on judgment, $15.09).

BRISTOL, Nov. 10 -- Although there is yet practically nothing in evidence in the Bristol boat shops that gives the impression that the work of beginning the cup defender will be soon begun, there are evidences enough in other ways that the designer is busy enough in formulating plans for the work to be carried on during the Winter.

The League for Political Education will open its season this month, and a long programme is announced for the Winter. In six talks on ethics John Graham Brooks will give "A Study of the Social Unrest" every Saturday morning, beginning Jan. 5 and ending Feb. 9. The first Saturday morning talks will be upon the city departments, given by different city officials.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 10 -- The worst marine disaster in the long list of steamers wrecked among the rocks and shoals at the entrance to the Bay of Fundy occurred this morning when the side-wheeled steamer City of Monticello, bound from St. John for Yarmouth, was overwhelmed by the mountainous seas only four miles from her destination and engulfed with thirty-one persons.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Eleven to nothing was the score the cadets rolled up against Hamilton in a hard-fought football tussle this afternoon. Hamilton had the heaviest team, but was outplayed at every point. The soldiers were handicapped by the absence of Smith and Bettison, who are in the hospital.

WEDNESDAY, NOV. 14. -- By William M. Ryan, executor's sale, 242 to 252 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, south side, 100 feet west of Second Avenue, 66.4 by 100, lease-hold, four-story factory building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- H.W. Steinbiss of St. Louis, President of the National Building Trades Council, to-day testified before the Industrial Commission concerning labor organizations, arbitration, strikes, and other matters. He said that in 1894 he had framed a paragraph in the constitution of the National Council declaring that experience showed that strikes were failures, but he had since changed his view, and the constitution accordingly had been changed.

Philadelphia sent its best golf team into this territory yesterday and found that the players whose game is a product of metropolitan links were stronger in team competition by 27 holes. The match, which was the second held under the joint auspices of the Metropolitan and Philadelphia Golf Associations, was played on the St. Andrew's Club links, near Chauncey, Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- An agent of the War Department has come into possession of what he asserts are accurate plans for the new French field gun, and these he offers to place at the disposition of the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications, if he is permitted to undertake the construction of a sample gun from the plans at the cost of the Government.

The end-of-the-week games furnished their usual surprises yesterday, but nothing particularly disastrous happened to any of the big college teams, with the possible exception of Harvard, who expected to beat Brown easier and more decisively Instead the lads from Providence proved a worthy foe and held the Crimson score down.

Her manner was tender and caressing, her smile angelic, her mouth the exact size of mine, and her eye softness itself. NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Nov. 10. -- The monitor Arkansas was launched at the shipyard this forenoon. The event was very successful, and the ship rode out on the James River without leaning to starboard or port. Miss Bobbie Newton Jones, daughter of Gov. Jones of Arkansas, christened the monitor as it started down the ways.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Trinity defeated New York University readily to-day at Trinity Field by the score of 22 to 0. The visitors' play was loose, and fumbling was frequent. Both teams were crippled by the absence of regular players, New York being the greater sufferer in this respect.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 10. -- Pennsylvania could only defeat the crippled Lafayette team 12 to 5 this afternoon, and the exhibition of fumbling and generally sleepy play of the Quakers was anything but pleasant to the 10,000 spectators. Lafayette started out with a rush and soon had the Pennsylvanians going, scoring in less than seven minutes of play on a bad fumble by Wallace after Cure had failed on a goal from placement.
A cable dispatch sent from Vienna last Monday evening announced that the Archduchess Maria Raineria had been married In great state to Duke Robert of Wurtemburg.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 10. -- The greatest mining project now being carried out in the West is a tunnel which is being driven into Palmer Mountain 8,400 feet, through 1,400 acres of mineral-bearing ground. The tunnel has progressed nearly 4,000 feet as a result of five years' continuous work.
The Charter Revision Commission has completed the first draft of recommendations to the Legislature as to the changes which should be made in the municipal government of New York.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- It was learned here to-day through parties interested in the great project that the combination of ocean steamship companies now in course of formation will be worldwide in its interests and will include Pacific as well as Atlantic Ocean lines.

The newspapers of New York showed unusual enterprise on election night in displaying election returns. The crowds that witnessed the displays were larger than ever before in the history of New York. At Park Row there were throngs throughout the evening. The largest crowds, however, assembled at Twenty-third Street and Madison Square, a location peculiarly suited for effective bulletin displays.

Venezuela, and not Colombia, may secure Jay Gould's old steam yacht Atalanta, according to a report persistently circulated during the last few days, but in regard to which the only persons competent to speak maintain a silence that in itself indicates that there may be some truth in the story.

Oscar Wincke, until last Monday Cashier of the glass-manufacturing firm of Whitall, Tatum Co., at 46 Barclay Street, has disappeared. He is said to have embezzled many thousands of dollars from his employers. The reticence of members of the firm has thus far made it impossible to learn what was the exact amount of the absconder's peculations.

Burglars, who are suspected of using chloroform in some of their operations, have been working rather extensively during the past week in the neighborhood of Hoyt and Third Streets, South Brooklyn. Within the week there have been three successful burglaries and many attempted robberies in the neighborhood mentioned.

From Our Animal Friends. Horses boarding in well-ordered city stables are usually well cared for, but many who care for their own horses, especially the farming portion, neglect the daily equine toilet. Men who would not think of going out without having their hair combed and their clothes brushed, never think of combing the horse's mane and tail or brushing his coat.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 10 -- Senator William V. Allen stopped off in Omaha several hours to-night, en route to his home in Madison. "No," said Senator Allen, in answer to a question as to the significance as to the result, "Tuesday's election cannot be regarded as an indorsement of McKinley's policy, although I have no doubt he will so construe it."

Burglars, who are suspected of using chloroform in some of their operations, have been working rather extensively during the past week in the neighborhood of Hoyt and Third Streets, South Brooklyn. Within the week there have been three successful burglaries and many attempted robberies in the neighborhood mentioned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Major Gen. Arthur MacArthur, commanding the army in the Philippines and Military Governor of the islands since May 5, 1900, has submitted his report to the War Department.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- The Boston and Albany Railway was formally transferred today to the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad system. President William Bliss of the Boston and Albany Road, acting as the agent of the New York Central Company. All officers and heads of departments will retain their present offices.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 10 -- Gov. Roosevelt was asked to-day if he had anything to add to his statement of yesterday relative to the Ice Trust. He replied that he would say no more on the subject until he had had a conference with Attorney General Davies. That would probably be, he said, on Monday or Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- One of the most interesting house parties of the week was that of Lady Fermer-Hesketh, (formerly Miss Florence Sharon of San Francisco,) who entertained, among others, Lord and Lady William Beresford.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Columbia football players had It much their own way at Athletic Field this afternoon, when they defeated the University of Buffalo learn by a score of 17 to 0. The New York men were too heavy for the Buffalos. The field was slippery, and Capt. Morley resorted to a kicking game, which accounts for the smallness of the score.

TUESDAY, NOV. 13. -- By William M. Ryan, foreclosure sale, Joseph McElroy Jr. referee, 26 West Houston Street, north side, 50 feet west of Mereer Street, 25 by 105, five-story iron-front building. Due on judgment, $52,366.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Columbia football players had It much their own way at Athletic Field this afternoon, when they defeated the University of Buffalo learn by a score of 17 to 0. The New York men were too heavy for the Buffalos. The field was slippery, and Capt. Morley resorted to a kicking game, which accounts for the smallness of the score.

Those who expected that the real estate market would enter upon an era of phenomenal activity beginning last Wednesday morning had only disappointment in store for themselves. This market does not lend itself to outside influences as readily as Wall Street does, but the result, if more gradual, is at the same time more permanent and satisfactory.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 10. -- When Mayorelect Garrettson returned from New York to-day he found on his desk more than 200 telegrams and letters of congratulation from all parts of the country, both from public men and cottagers.

Venezuela, and not Colombia, may secure Jay Gould's old steam yacht Atalanta, according to a report persistently circulated during the last few days, but in regard to which the only persons competent to speak maintain a silence that in itself indicates that there may be some truth in the story.

BRISTOL, Nov. 10 -- Although there is yet practically nothing in evidence in the Bristol boat shops that gives the impression that the work of beginning the cup defender will be soon begun, there are evidences enough in other ways that the designer is busy enough in formulating plans for the work to be carried on during the Winter.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- South Africa threatens once more to absorb public attention in Great Britain. Lord Salisbury, in his speech at the inaugural banquet of the Lord Mayor In the Guildhall last evening, held out little hope of immediate pacification, and the return of Lord Roberts is still problematical, and is certainly a matter of weeks, and perhaps months

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 10. -- A new boathouse, costing almost $40,000, will become the possession of Harvard oarsmen next Tuesday, when the Harvard Club of New York City will formally turn over to the university the large, well-arranged structure which has been building on the river bank next to Soldiers' Field since early last Spring.

PEKING, Sept. 6. -- When it was written that he who controlietn his own spirit is greater than he who conquereth a city, an experience having some of the features of the present campaign was doubtless in contemplation. It is not specially hard to be a warrior. A man needs more courage to run away in an engagement than to go forward or stay still.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 10. -- J.B. Ferguson, the famous breeder and starter, died to-night at 10 o'clock. He had been In ill-health for months as the result of an old bullet wound. He submitted to the X-ray process and had the bullet removed. It eased his pain, but sapped his strength. His death had been hourly expected for several days.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- The most Interesting astronomical Question just now is whether the great meteoric shower, known as the Leonids, from the position of their central point in the constellation of Leo, which was due in November of last year, but which did not then appear, is to be given up as lost or has been delayed, and will take place in its full glory next week.

Floyd McFarland, "Tom" Cooper, and nine foreign cyclists, who will take part in the six days' cycle races at the Madison Square Garden next month, arrived yesterday on the American liner St. Louis. The foreigners comprise three French riders, Jean Gougoltz, Carl Simal, and E. Auchotrier; three Germans, K. Kiser, J. Fischer, and F. Ryser, and R. Moeller and M. Fredricks, who represent Italy and Norway, respectively.
A cable dispatch sent from Vienna last Monday evening announced that the Archduchess Maria Raineria had been married In great state to Duke Robert of Wurtemburg.

From Our Animal Friends. Horses boarding in well-ordered city stables are usually well cared for, but many who care for their own horses, especially the farming portion, neglect the daily equine toilet. Men who would not think of going out without having their hair combed and their clothes brushed, never think of combing the horse's mane and tail or brushing his coat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The startling statement is made In the report of Admiral Crowningshield, Chief of the Navigation Bureau, that the present personnel of the navy would form barely one-fourth of the establishment necessary to fight a first-class European power. It hardly sufficed for the Spanish-American war, and no longer can be considered, the report says, as an effective nucleus about which a larger establishment could be formed in case of war.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- William J. Lee, who was employed for twenty-three years as a bridge estimator for the New Jersey Steel and Iron Company, has been dismissed. He has placed an advertisement in the local newspapers to the effect that he is a victim of the "American Bridge Company Trust, with a capital of $70,000,000, combining twenty-eight separate plants."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- The American Baseball League representatives, President Johnson, Charles Comiskey of Chicago, Connie Mack of Milwaukee, and G. W. Somers of Cleveland, are in Philadelphia looking over the local situation with the idea of placing a club here next season. They came here last night from Baltimore and will remain in Philadelphia a couple of days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The startling statement is made In the report of Admiral Crowningshield, Chief of the Navigation Bureau, that the present personnel of the navy would form barely one-fourth of the establishment necessary to fight a first-class European power. It hardly sufficed for the Spanish-American war, and no longer can be considered, the report says, as an effective nucleus about which a larger establishment could be formed in case of war.
The portion of Gen. MACARTHUR'S report on affairs in the Philippines which has been made public cannot be called highly encouraging.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Peter Gilfoyle of this city had a narrow escape from death by drowning in the Sound last evening, and Thomas Murphy and Thomas Condon, also of this city, suffered considerably from exposure out on Huckleberry Island yesterday afternoon and last night, and all three are now in bed suffering from heavy colds.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 11. -- Col. Whitside received to-day orders from the War Department fixing Nov. 15 as the date for closing the Department of Santiago de Cuba. This date is a fortnight earlier than that assigned in the general expectation of the army people here, and there is considerable uneasiness among the officers, who are not certain how the change will affect them personally.

Charles Corgeo, a shoemaker, of 307 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, was in a hilarious mood last night, and paraded through the upper east side shouting and singing. When in front of 204 East One Hundred and Eighth Street he saw Katie Laio, fifteen years old, who lives there, and her cousin, James Grant, sixteen years old, standing in the doorway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The total expenditure by the Government on account of the Indian service from March 4, 1789, up to and including July 30, 1900, has been $368,358,217, according to the annual report of Commissioner of Indian Affairs William A. Jones. The expenditures for the fiscal year ended last July amounted to $10,175,107.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- William J. Lee, who was employed for twenty-three years as a bridge estimator for the New Jersey Steel and Iron Company, has been dismissed. He has placed an advertisement in the local newspapers to the effect that he is a victim of the "American Bridge Company Trust, with a capital of $70,000,000, combining twenty-eight separate plants."

The gas meter, however well established in the confidence of the gas engineer, has nowhere succeeded in outliving its popular reputation for habitual mendacity. Indeed, "to lie like a gas meter" has been held by those given to speaking in metaphor to be a form of words establishing a superlative standard of comparison to which only the accomplished and experienced manipulator of fiction could conform.

It may be admitted that there are two objects which the State Government may properly seek in the exercise of its police power and through agencies mainly of its own. One is the provision of adequate police service for the parts of the State which cannot be expected to provide it at local expense or to administer it efficiently, and which, nevertheless, need such service very much.

The cream of New York's trotting and pacing stock turned out in full force yesterday morning to do battle on the Speedway, and until the rain, which began to fall about noon caused the majority of the drivers and spectators to scamper for shelter, brush followed brush in such rapid succession that they were hard to keep track of.

Jones. The expenditures for the fiscal year ended last July amounted to $10,175,107.

The Central Federated Union was thrown into an extraordinary state of indignation yesterday by the complaint of a waiter that he was prevented from working because he did not belong to Waiters' Union No. 1, which is controlled by Germans, and that the latter would not admit him to membership because he did not understand German.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Many predictions have been made about changes in the Cabinet. The most promising one was about Secretary Gage's retirement in favor of Controller Charles G. Dawes, but that has been withered by a positive declaration from Mr. Gage that he was going to remain until March 4, and did not know what he was going to do after that.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- The American Baseball League representatives, President Johnson, Charles Comiskey of Chicago, Connie Mack of Milwaukee, and G. W. Somers of Cleveland, are in Philadelphia looking over the local situation with the idea of placing a club here next season. They came here last night from Baltimore and will remain in Philadelphia a couple of days.

Rumors to the effect that Prince GEORGE of Greece, High Commissioner of the powers in Crete, will shortly memorialize the Chancelleries interested concerning a definite settlement of the Cretan question have provoked considerable speculation in the European press. It is quite evident that the condition of the islanders has developed about as far as it is possible for it to develop under the present makeshift administration.

Indeed, "to lie like a gas meter" has been held by those given to speaking in metaphor to be a form of words establishing a superlative standard of comparison to which only the accomplished and experienced manipulator of fiction could conform.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 11 -- James Murray and James Lyle, or Ryan, were brought to the Middlesex Jail this morning on the charge of burglary. They were arrested at a tramps' resort near Lincoln. They had, it is alleged, broken into a railroad station there, and, failing to find much of value, set the building on fire.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Escorted by a dozen young women carrying American flags. Miss Mary Gilchrist of this city rode in a baby carriage propelled by Miss Kathryn Shields of Montrose through aristocratic Montrose last night. Her novel ride was the result of an election bet which Miss Shields lost.

The more the authorities investigate the Maison-Zeimer divorce mill the more they are astounded at the boldness and extent of the frauds perpetrated. It was developed yesterday that the field of operation of the conspirators has not been confined to New York City. The police have evidence that they furnished false witnesses in divorce cases before the courts in Buffalo and Syracuse.

-- In resigning the Presidency of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, Mr. ELBRIDGE T. GERRY has marked the completion of a quarter of a century of effort, not only nobly intentioned, tireless, disinterested, and self-sacrificing, but eminently, greatly, and truly successful.

Pedestrians on Park Row yesterday afternoon stopped to gaze at a tall, athletic-looking man who strode along that thoroughfare dressed in the full uniform of a British soldier. The man swung along with the faintest unsteadiness in his gait, but held himself erect and straight as an arrow, and, with a "ship-me-somewhere-east-of-Suez" air, appeared rather to enjoy the universal interest he attracted.
The portion of Gen. MACARTHUR'S report on affairs in the Philippines which has been made public cannot be called highly encouraging.

Harry Luxemberg of 61 East Broadway, who declared yesterday in the West Side Police Court in emphatic tones that he was "the best and most careful driver in New York City," was held for trial in Special Sessions in bail of $200 because he abused his horses and was fined $5 because he used profane and abusive language to the Rev. Richard M. Sherman, rector of Trinity Chapel. 131 West Ninety-first Street.

A new bowling tournament this week is that of the New York Archdiocesan Union, in which the opening games will be rolled this evening at Thumann's Colonial Hall alleys. One Hundred and First Street and Columbus Avenue. The schedule for the week in the principal local leagues follows:

It was developed yesterday that the field of operation of the conspirators has not been confined to New York City. The police have evidence that they furnished false witnesses in divorce cases before the courts in Buffalo and Syracuse.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The Bronxville Dutch Reformed Church, the congregation of which is made up largely of business and professional men and the colony of authors and artists who live in Lawrence Park, began celebrating its golden jubilee to-day. The services were conducted by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. W.S. Webster.

It is quite evident that the condition of the islanders has developed about as far as it is possible for it to develop under the present makeshift administration.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The Union Railway Company outwitted the property owners on Fourth Avenue to-day by laying its tracks through that thorough-fare and connecting its main line with the Bronxville and Tuckahoe line. The work was begun at midnight by a gang of 1,000 Italians, who proceeded to rip up the street.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 11. -- Col. Whitside received to-day orders from the War Department fixing Nov. 15 as the date for closing the Department of Santiago de Cuba. This date is a fortnight earlier than that assigned in the general expectation of the army people here, and there is considerable uneasiness among the officers, who are not certain how the change will affect them personally.

Harry Luxemberg of 61 East Broadway, who declared yesterday in the West Side Police Court in emphatic tones that he was "the best and most careful driver in New York City," was held for trial in Special Sessions in bail of $200 because he abused his horses and was fined $5 because he used profane and abusive language to the Rev. Richard M. Sherman, rector of Trinity Chapel. 131 West Ninety-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Senator Proctor of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, has suggested to the President the advisability of making the regular army 60,000 strong. Mr. Proctor's idea is to have the Army bill fix this as the minimum strength of the army, and provide that the President can increase it to 100,000 if he thinks it advisable.

The plier of the jimmy and his fellow, the gentle sandbag wielder, are holding high carnival these days in Brooklyn. To, a long list of recent robberies was added yesterday what is regarded as one of the boldest committed in the borough in a long time.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- It required just fifteen minutes for a crowd of men and boys to dismantle a row of flats in West Polk Street to-day. Some of the men in the mob had not worked for years, yet they toiled during those fifteen minutes as though their lives were at stake.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The commendation that you have already received for your editorial of the 7th inst. on the prospective municipal campaign of 1901 and its needs, would seem to make superfluous any additional praise from your readers. It shows, to use a homely phrase, that THE TIMES allows no grass to grow under its feet.

It shows, to use a homely phrase, that THE TIMES allows no grass to grow under its feet.
The burlesque at the New York Theatre, "Nell-Go-In," was omitted at last night's performance owing to Joseph Ott's illness.

The attendance at the Aqueduct race track yesterday was made up almost exclusively of regular race-goers and professional backers, and it naturally followed as favorites were beaten in five of the six races, that the crowd had a decidedly unpleasant time of it. The weather was cool, but clear and pleasant, and the track was at about the best that it has been since the present meeting opened.
"That telegram was a fake, an absolute fake, and I will make the Western Union Telegraph Company prove it a fake."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "P.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the puchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
The New York Herald of yesterday contained the following interview with the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst upon the subject of an ideal newspaper:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Germany is now passing through a period of reflection, self-examination, and a somewhat vague uncertainty as to her future, according to United States Consul General Mason, who has transmitted to the State Department a comprehensive review of the conditions which have been productive of a threatening crisis in many branches of German Industry.

POPLAR BLUFF, Mo., Nov. 12 -- Fire today destroyed the Gifford House, one of the oldest hostelries in Southeastern Missouri. Four bodies have been removed from the ruins. One man is missing, two persons were fatally injured, seven severely, and twelve slightly. It is feared that many more lives were lost than is now apparent.

A polite and friendly greeting was given to John Hare and his London troupe of actors, including Irene Vanbrugh, at the Criterion Theatre last evening, and the first performance in this country of Pinero's polished and cynical comedy called "The Gay Lord Quex" was followed with the closest attention.

Deputy Attorney General Job E. Hedges, who was instrumental in moving for the indictment of Chief of Police William S. Devery on Nov. 5, alleging that the Chief was guilty of a felony in the issuance of an order to the police force to countenance no intimidation of voters by Superintendent McCullagh's deputies on election day, yesterday moved before Recorder Goff the dismissal of the indictment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The French Government, through President Loubet, and also through the Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, has forwarded cordial congratulations to President McKinley on his re-election. The message from the Minister of Foreign Affairs came through M. Thiebaut, the French Charge d'Affaires here, who conveyed it to Secretary Hay with an expression of his own congratulations.

Another high-water mark was established in the stock market yesterday, when recorded transactions reached the enormous total of 1,671,225 shares, with actual trading running, conservative estimates put it, somewhere beyond 2,300,000 shares. The tape, which on Wednesday and Friday last had been quite unable to keep pace with the transactions then, left customers in even worse plight yesterday, purchases or sales, as the case might be, being reported long after the transactions had been concluded.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 12 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day gave out orders for 2,400 freight cars, which makes 5,400 cars contracted for within a week. To-day's orders were distributed as follows:

The Grand Jury yesterday, at a session lasting until nearly 6 o'clock in the evening, ordered indictments against W. Waldo Maison, Henry Zeimer, and Frank Wilson for conspiracy, perjury, and subornation of perjury. These indictments will be drawn by Assistant District Attorney Unger, and, after they have been signed by the Grand Jury, will be filed with Recorder Goff, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions.

The navy of the United States is so "popular," and it has so thoroughly deserved the affectionate pride and admiration that its achievements have won for it that the public will confidently rely upon the Fifty-sixth Congress to give a sympathetic answer to the appeal just made by Rear Admiral CROWNINSHIELD for legislation essential to the maintenance of the personal as well as material adequacy and efficiency of the service.

Three speeches were made by Mark Twain at the reception that the New York Press Club tendered him last night. Among the other speakers were Joseph I.C. Clarke, the playwright; John W. Keller, Commissioner of Charities, and Col. Abraham Gruber.

NEWBURG, Nov. 12 -- The divorce suit of Dr. Alfred Kayne of New York City against his wife, Attalie Claire Kayne, was to-day decided in favor of the plaintiff by a jury in the Supreme Court, presided over by Judge Dickey. The defendant, in her answer to the charge of infidelity, Abraham H. Kaffenberg being named as corespondent, made counter charges against Dr. Kayne, and demanded a jury trial.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The following order was made public at the War Department to-day:

Capt. Lawrence M. Murray, who commanded the famous Confederate cruiser Nashville, is dead at his borne in Maiden, N.Y. After the war he commanded steamers plying between New York and South American ports. Subsequently he served in the Revenue Service at Savannah, Ga. His son, Major Cunliffe Murray of the Fourth Cavalry, was military secretary to Gen. Otis.
The annual report of the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments was made public yesterday by President Feitner.

We reproduce this morning from The Herald an interview with the Rev. Dr. PARKHURST giving at length the qualities the doctor thinks essential to an ideal newspaper. The statement will he found interesting, as Dr. PARKHURST'S utterances are apt to be, and it may well give rise to a profitable discussion.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- The Lokal Anzeiger publishes the following from its Shanghai correspondent:

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 12 -- William Lynde Harrison of New York and Miss Grace Clergue of this city were married this evening at the residence of the bride's father, Joseph H. Clergue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George D. Lindsay of the Methodist Church of Waterville.

The City Central Committee of the Citizens' Union held a very largely attended meeting at the headquarters, 42 East Twenty-third Street, last night to formulate preliminary arrangements for the Mayoralty campaign next year. Every borough was represented. R. Fulton Cutting presided, and Thomas A. Fulton acted as Secretary.

A thirty-three-carat diamond, pronounced by the Custom House officials the largest gem of its kind ever brought into this country, and which is said to have once glittered in the crown of the ill-fated Maximilian, Emperor of Mexico, was found yesterday in the possession of two Mexicans. They were arrested at Broadway and Seventeenth Street by Special Treasury Agent William Theobald on a charge of smuggling.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Fourteen store buildings were partly wrecked, a portion of North Gay Street torn up, and a panic caused in that thickly populated section of the city by a series of six terrific explosions of gas to-day in the city's new subway, under North Gay Street. The entire northeastern part of the city was shaken as if by an earthquake.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Linseed broke sharply to-day from 12 3/8 to 10 1/8, closing there. The trading, especially in the preferred, was on an enormous scale. Sales of the preferred aggregated 14,994 shares, and the price broke from 52 3/4 to 46, closing at that price. It is said the break was manipulated against certain Directors who had decided to unload their shares.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 12 -- Miss Elsie French, accompanied by Alfred G. Vanderbilt, has gone to New York to meet Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Miss Gladys Vanderbilt, who return from Europe Wednesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Tale today began to get into shape for the game with Princeton, which will come next Saturday. The work was hard and fast, and to-morrow and Wednesday it will be the same. Thursday will be light. Friday there will be no line-up, as the team will go to Princeton in the evening.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The great exposition of 1900 closed in a blaze of illumination, the final evening being celebrated by a night fete. The booming of a cannon from the first story of the Eiffel Tower announced that the exposition had ceased to exist.

Several rescues were made at a fire which occurred yesterday afternoon shortly after 5 o'clock in the five-story double tenement house at 501 West Forty-eighth Street, and which is known as 710 Tenth Avenue. The first floor, where the fire started, is occupied as a clothing store by George W. Prager Co., and is known as the Boston Clothing Company.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 12 -- The Missouri Supreme Court ruled to-day that divorce does not carry with it the right for the wile to divulge the husband's secrets at any subsequent legal action. The decision is in effect, that separation by law does not also free wives' tongues.

One might imagine, trom the reports of Mr. PLATT'S recent utterances on the policy of the Legislature, that he was himself that body, that, indeed, he, like the Great Monarch of France, was the State itself. He is not content to announce what he thinks ought to he done, or what he expects to be done.

Throughout the whole list of outside stocks yesterday there was greater activity than any that has shown since the Spring of 1899, when the curb experienced such a tremendous volume of business. In yesterday's trading there was much of the enthusiasm which marked the most active days of last year.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Morrison, wiring to The Times from Peking Sunday, says:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 12 -- It has been definitely settled that the new Palatine Insurance Company of London, organized by the Commercial Union Assurance Association to succeed the Palatine of Manchester, which was purchased outright by the Commercial Union, will enter the United States Jan. 1, when the business will be transferred.

According to a report current yesterday, negotiations are in an advanced stage for the sale of the Morse Building, at the northeast corner of Massau and Beekman Streets by the Washington Life Insurance Company. Officers of that corporation declined to discuss the rumors yesterday afternoon.

HAVANA, Nov. 12 -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention met at the Marti Theatre at 2 o'clock this afternoon, after adjournment from the second day's session. Seats for the delegates had been arranged in a smaller area nearer the platform, the curtain of the stage had been lowered, and the windows hung with heavy draperies, thus shutting out the noise of the street and making it possible for the delegates to speak in ordinary voice.

After a long contest, the will of Robert Bonner has been admitted to probate. Surrogate Fitzgerald, in a decision handed down yesterday, dismissed the contest which had been instituted by Mrs. Andrew Alien Bonner the widow of the testator's son, in behalf of her two children, Robert A. and Lawrence Kip Bonner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- It is understood that the Chinese authorities at Peking have been profoundly aroused by some of the executions of Chinese officials which have occurred of late, and that they have made known in an official way their surprise and regret that this should occur while the peace negotiations are going on.

There was some fast work done by the regulars on the Speedway yesterday afternoon. Monday is usually a dull day, owing to the fact that drivers give their fast steppers enough work Sundays to last them a couple of days, but yesterday was an exception to the rule and many brushes, between closely matched animals, were hotly contested from start to finish.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES does not make the ridiculous assertion that another newspaper does, that "if you see it in its columns it's so," meaning by "it" the news presumably, and THE TIMES could make the assertion with far more truth than its neighbor. Now, when a good newspaper makes a statement we like to think it is so.

Fire Chief Croker yesterday made a statement accusing the police of negligence and shirking of duty, thereby imperiling life and property throughout the city. The Walker Street fire of early yesterday morn- ing, Mr. Croker says, was allowed to gain much headway before an alarm was sent in, and all because the policeman in that district could not have been on post.

Ever since the cable mentioned that Sir ROBERT HART had an article in The Fortnightly Review on the Chinese situation, the full test of it has been awaited with eagerness by all students of the Chinese situation. They were already aware that nothing that has been done or unanimously proposed by the powers in China gave any promise of a permanent settlement or deserved to be called a proposal for permanent settlement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The annual report of the Treasurer of the United States, Bills H. Roberts, on the operations and condition of the Treasury, was submitted to Secretary Gage to-day. Mr. Roberts says the growth and prosperity of the country and the general activity of business are reflected in the transactions of his office.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 12 -- The condition of Senator C.K. Davis took a decided turn for the worse to-day, new complications developing. Dr. Murphy, the eminent Chicago surgeon, has again been telegraphed for and will reach here to-morrow morning. Dr. A.J. Stone, the surgeon in charge of the Senator's case, to-night issued the following bulletin:

With a majority of one, the vote of the Moderator, the New York Presbytery at its regular November meeting yesterday afternoon decided that the Westminster Confession should remain as the creed of the Presbyterian Church of to-day. The meeting was held in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church at Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Honey is not abundant, and is much wanted in connection with tenders for Treasury bills and the Stock Exchange settlement. Discounts have been strengthened thereby, and owing to the character of the New York bank return, which excites discussion as to the prospect of the United States withdrawing gold from London, and whether the recent improvement in exchange is only temporary.
Marcus Daly, one of the copper kings of the Far West, died at the Hotel Netherland yesterday of Bright's disease and heart trouble after a lingering illness.

NEWBURG, Nov. 12. -- Commodore Harry C. Higginson of the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Club has had a new model ice yacht constructed from designs by H. Percy Ashley of New York, who is at the lake superintending the putting of the frame together. The craft will be known as the Aurora. It will be of the first class, and carry 613.20 square feet of canvas.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Henry Villard, the financier, died shortly after midnight last night at his home, Thorwood Park, about a mile east of the village. The cause of death was apoplexy, from which le had been a sufferer for several weeks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The Tribune tomorrow will say:

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- Gov. Roosevelt this morning notified Wheeler H. Peckham and J.S. Hayes, attorneys for The New York World in the charges against Mayor Van Wyck in the Ice Trust matter, that they must present their answer to the Attorney General's findings by Thursday of this week with their evidence or he would decide the case on its merits as it now stands.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Perry Hale was in the 'Varsity line again to-day after an absence of ten days on the hospital list. McBride called him into the line-up, and the thousand or more, students present cheered him wildly. Hale was used very lightly, however, and was plunged into the line only once or twice. On a fair catch by Wear on the thirty-five-yard line, Hale kicked a goal.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- The Harvard Varsity eleven went through probably the hardest practice of the season today. Defensive play made up most of the work, so that in its forty-minute half the Varsity secured but three touch-downs, one by Putnam and two by Stillmau. On offense some improvement was made, but the defense was lamentably weak.
Speaking editorially of the personnel of its staff, the Paris edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES said in its last number:

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Exposition Edition: Learning that your incomparable newspaper had accomplished its mission and will print its last Paris number on Oct. 31, I cannot resist telling you how much I have enjoyed it from its first publication in May last.
BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Thirteen persons were killed and nineteen others injured seriously in a fire-damp explosion in the Pluto coal mine at Wiosa, near Brux.

In the Bank Clerk League bowling tournament, which was continued last night on Reid's Church Street alleys, Manhattan, the teams of the American Exchange National Bank and Kountz'e Bros, teams carried off the honors, each winning two games. The Importers and Traders' Bank and Seaboard National Bank teams broke even, and the Plaza Bank and Hudson River Bank fives lost two matches apiece.

The Van Cortlandt Golf Club is going to close its season of activity with a concert to-morrow night in Carnegie Hall. J.H. McKinley, the well-known tenor, and one of the Governors of the club, has charge of the concert, and he has arranged a musical programme that promises to make an enjoyable social evening for the members.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- President McKinley to-day announced clearly and forcefully to the members of his Cabinet his desire that they should all remain with him during the four years of his coming Administration. His wishes were made known in an extended speech at the Cabinet meeting in the White House to-day.

The dry goods commission house of William L. Strong Co. of 75 and 77 Worth Street has suspended. Edward B. Treat of the firm of Treat Converse, which is in similar business next door, has been appointed as the receiver. The extent of the failure will not be known for several days, as the receiver has not yet had an opportunity to examine the books.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 13. -- The arrest and releasing on bail of Denniston M. Bell, son of Dr. C.M. Bell, for setting fire to the bathing pavilion at Bailey's Beach Sunday has created a great sensation here, owing to the standing of the young man. Dr. Bell, father of the young man, is a prominent physician in New York, and owns a house there in Fifth Avenue.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- In order to prevent the intrusion of her former husband, James H. Mersereau, who desired to serve a legal paper on her, Mrs. Clara Mersereau, the daughter of a wealthy New York had to call on the police of New Rochelle to-day for protection.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Sir Michael HicksBeach, Chancellor of the Exchequer, speaking this evening in Bristol, said it would not be his privilege in the next budget to relieve the taxpayers. He wished he could say that he was not about to increase the budget, but the Government's expenditure had been enormous, especially in China and South Africa.

Richard Croker was so busy last evening preparing for his departure from this country for England that he could not talk politics. It was announced that the Tammany leader had engaged a cabin on the Lucania, which sails on Saturday next.
To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Exposition Edition: Mon cher confrere:

Dr. Henry Drury Noyes of this city died at Mount Washington, Mass., Monday. His body has been brought home, and his funeral will take place Thursday, at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. Dr. Noyes was bornin in this city in 1832. He was graduated from the New York University, and became an eye, ear, and throat specialist.

Pinero's dainty, fanciful, half-satirical, half-sentimental comedy called "The Princess and the Butterfly" is this week's play at the Murray Hill Theatre, and yesterday afternoon the house was nearly filled by well-dressed and otherwise well-appearing persons, who had paid only 25 cents apiece for their seats in that perfectly appointed and modern playhouse, and seemed to enjoy the performance exceedingly.

About all the newspaper accounts of the political division of the Senate of the United States in the second session of the Fifty-sixth Congress have agreed in putting the Republican vote at 51 and the opposition at 35. This statement was evidently based upon the Congressional Directory list, wherein each Senator appears classified according to his own personal description, communicated to the committee publishing the book.

Thomas J. Brady, President of the Department of Buildings, is to resign his seven-thousand-dollar place within a week. This announcement was made by friends of President Brady at the City Hall yesterday. The story was also carried to the Democratic Club last evening and caused talk among the politicians.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- A special dispatch from Madrid to the Frankfurter Zeitung says a representative of Herr Krupp is there negotiating with the Bilbao capitalist Martinez Rivas and other Spanish capitalists for the organization of a company in Spain to build ironclads and manufacture cannon.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 13. -- Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador to Great Britain, this evening delivered the inaugural lecture at the Philosophical Institution of Edinburgh, taking as his theme "The Career and Character of Abraham Lincoln."
The Stock Exchange brokerage house of Grant Brothers of 45 Broadway made an assignment without preference for the benefit of creditors yesterday to Ernest G. Stedman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- S.I. Kimball, General Superintendent of the Life Saving Service, in his annual report to Secretary Gage, says that at the close of the fiscal year the establishment embraced 269 stations, 194 being on the Atlantic, 58 on the lakes, 16 on the Pacific, and 1 at the Falls of the Ohio, at Louisville, Ky.

The officials of the Charities Department are worried over an order sent out by Commissioner John W. Keller. The order directs all heads of bureaus to give a list of the employes and their salaries, so that large reductions could be made in the force of the department.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Dr. Morrison, wiring to The Times, expresses the opinion that China will readily accede to all the terms of the conjoint note except the execution of the Princes and officials, which it will be impossible to fulfill while the Court is in the hands of these very officials."

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was on a much smaller scale than on Monday, and still greater irregularity in prices appeared. The sharp advance of nearly all stocks since the beginning of last week has been followed, naturally, by a good deal of profit taking, and for the almost uninterrupted advance of prices there has been substituted irregular movements, resulting from the more complicated position of the market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before every important election it is usually thrown out broadcast that Tammany is going to pieces through dissensions in the organization. Such reports I am charitable enough to believe are given out by the organization itself in order to hoodwink the opposition. Those who put faith in such reports know very little of Tammany methods.

While our own authorities have every reason to congratulate themselves that we have not been concerned in any of the recent European outrages in China, they cannot blind themselves to the fact that those outrages are very seriously embarrassing the course of the negotiations with the Chinese Government.

Now that the Paris Exposition is a thing of the past those of the French restaurateurs of this city who were unable to get back temporarily to the gay city of their fatherland and take a hand in the merry struggle for the foreigner's coin are reaping a little harvest of their own as a direct result of the big fair.

An indictment against Mrs. Byrde G. Herrick, alleging collusion with W. Waldo Maison, Frank Wilson, and Henry Zeimer in procuring divorces by means of false testimony, has been ordered by the Grand Jury, and will be handed up with the indictments against the principals and directors of the "fake" divorce mill probably to-day.

Columbia's football squad had its first scrimmage practice since last Thursday on Columbia Field yesterday afternoon, and the wisdom of the training policy that allowed the players light work after their hard series of games ending with the defeat of the Tigers on election day, was apparent.

Room traders hammered the market all day long yesterday, on the theory that after the sustained rise of the past week a reaction was due. Their efforts, and further profit-taking by holders of stocks bought at lower figures, resulted in a decline which affected nearly all stocks on the list.

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Exposition Edition: It is with regret I learn that your Paris Edition is to come to an end on the 31st inst., for speaking as a journalist, it has been a great treat daily to read the news of the world in your paper presented with all the smartness and promptitude so characteristic of American journalism.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The World of this city says a judicial separation between Prince and Princess Aribert of Anhalt is an accomplished fact. The paper adds that the deeds were signed and the other for realities completed during the stay in Berlin of Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, father of the Princess.
The Freedman's Aid and Southern Educational Society met at Newark, N.J., yesterday, with Bishop Edward G. Andrews presiding. The following appropriations for academies for colored people were made:

DECISION IN SUIT BROUGHT AGAINST CHESTER A. ARTHUR. -- When the late Chester A. Arthur was Collector of the Port of New York there was exacted, in 1873, under his administration, and collected upon goods imported by the late firm of Reese, Williamson Co., quite a large sum in excess of the duties placed on them by law.

The Dewey Arch will be pulled down in a short time. At the meeting of the Municipal Assembly yesterday a resolution was passed unanimously by both houses authorizing Commissioner Keating of the Department of Streets and Highways to spend the money appropriated for repairing the structure to tear it down.

That the Presbytery of New York had gone upon record as opposing any revision of the Presbyterian creed would be in any case an interesting piece of intelligence. The decision cannot be said to have been unexpected. It is some years since Dr. BRIGGS left the communion of the Presbyterian Church, upon being, either formally or virtually, deprived of his ministry therein, upon the ground that his teachings were heretical.

HAZLETON, Penn., Nov. 13. -- A report is current here to-night that negotiations are on for the sale of all the collieries and washeries of the region owned by individual operators and that the Lehigh Valley and Pennsylvania Railroad Companies are the prospective purchasers.

To-day brings the wedding of Amos R.E. Pinchot, son of James W. Pinchot, whose mother was Miss Mary Eno, and Miss Gertrude Minturn, eldest daughter of Mrs. Robert B. Minturn, who was Miss Shaw. The wedding will be celebrated at 12 o'clock, in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

IRVINE DEPOT, ky., Nov. 13. -- The seventh annual meet of the National Fox Hunters' Association began here to-day. Sportsmen to the number of two hundred participated. The event to-day was the Derby lace for hounds, eighteen months old and under. The twenty-six entries included dogs from all parts of the country.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 13. -- A rare example of human gratitude came to light in Omaha to-day when Major T.S. Clarkson and Harry M. Turner received each $10,000 in crisp Treasury notes from an old army comrade whom they befriended a couple of years ago. Robert Majors of Huntsville, Ala., was the donor, and an interesting story is told, of which the chapter to-day is the last.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 13. -- John K. Van Sickle of Grant Brothers lives at 357 South Broad Street, this city. He has a wife, a daughter sixteen years of age, and an infant child. His house is on what is locally known as "Quality Hill." It is a building which cost $20,000, but passed to the New York Life Insurance Company by foreclosure of a mortgage.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Nov. 13. -- Capt. Gaynor of the sloop Pearsall of Norwalk, which was blown across the Sound in the recent gale and wrecked near here, arrived yesterday in pursuit of the vessel. He described the escape of Austin A. Gaynor, his son, and Fred Gregory, the two boys who constituted the crew of the sloop.

According to dispatches from Washington, Secretary LONG seems to have avoided for the present the experiment of erecting a Government armor plant by accepting the proposition of the Carnegie and Bethlehem Companies to provide armor for $475 a ton, on contracts calling for a supply of about 37,000 tons, to be used in the completion of fourteen battleships and armored cruisers authorized to be added to the naval flotilla.

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Exposition Edition: The American in Paris, whether life-long resident or bird of passage, will regret the disappearance of the Paris Exposition edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The longfelt want which it satisfied will not cease with the exposition.

WHITESBURG, Ky., Nov. 13. -- One of the most cowardly murders in the long list that has disgraced the mountain county of Letcher took place last midnight at Baker, where Mrs. Minnie Hall, widow of Alien Hall, was murdered by unknown men and her twenty-year-old son mortally wounded.
Sale on the Stock Exchange of fifty shares of Bank of Commerce stock at 262@ 261.

There is one point in the newspaper which Dr. PARKHURST has pictured in his mind as ideal which will strike most who are familiar with the business as fanciful to the verge of absurdity. The supreme requirement in the doctor's estimation is independence -- subsidized independence.

The last number of the Paris Exposition Edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, published Oct. 31, gave, under the caption, "Kind Words of Farewell," many communications of congratulation. Those which are appended are only a part of those received from many sources. The text of those printed follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13. -- William Haywood, United States Collector of Internal Revenue of Honolulu, who arrived here on the steamer China, has wired his resignation to Washington. It is said he will represent Hawaiian business interests at the National capital.

The mystery surrounding the jewels taken from the Mexicans, Valino Preza and Alejandro Marcecci, who were arrested on Monday by Special Treasury Agent William Theobald, charged with being smugglers, has not yet been solved. The two prisoners remain in Ludlow Street Jail.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The Globe this afternoon publishes a letter from a Belgian gentleman who has been traveling to Peking via the Trans-Siberian Railroad. He describes, under date of Sept. 6, what he saw in the Amur River. His account surpasses in horror those previously published.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- To-day's sales aggregated about 56,000 shares, against 90,000 yesterday. The market as a whole moved irregularly. Some prices advanced, others declined. Fluctuations were, as a rule, narrow -- less than 1 per cent. United Gas declined 2 1/4, to 123 3/4; Pennsylvania Steel, 1 3/4, to 62 1/4; Electric Storage Battery, 1, to 80.

James J. Corcoran, an octogenarian truckman, who from 1850 to 1880 was regarded as the champion of the Irish immigrant class in the Kip's Bay district, which is about Fortieth Street and First Avenue, lay dead yesterday at 317 East Fortieth Street, shrived and regretted. He was known to his legion of acquaintances as "Jimmy" Corcoran of "Corcoran's Roost."

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a most excellent sign that the citizens of Greater New York are so soon planning for the next municipal campaign. The interest now awakened must, however, be kept alive and not permitted to lag; the enthusiasm of every individual must be increased as time goes on to the day of election.

The Government finished its case against Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., defaulting note teller of the First National Bank, on his preliminary hearing before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday afternoon. Alvord was brought before the Commissioner at 2 o'clock. The first witness, Clarence E. Bacon, a proof clerk in the Clearing House, was shown the Clearing House sheet for Oct. 4.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Princeton's players, on whom such great hopes and fears hang breathless, appear to be improving slightly under the careful, determined coaching of the numerous coaches.

Two detected chorus girls, the Misses May Florence and Ethel York, arrived yesterday on the steamship Minnehaha from London. They had been asked to sing and dance in a concert aboard the ship, but three ministers, who were passengers, objected to making the concert a vaudeville performance, and the ministers succeeded in having the girls' acts cut out of the programme.

The deal by which the Washington Life Insurance Company will dispose of the Morse Building, at the northeast corner of Nassau and Beekman Streets, is a trade which also involves the twelve-story Hamilton Storage Warehouse, at the northeast corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Park Avenue, 100 by 100.

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Exposition Edition: Ca nous est ane veritable tristesse de voir partir LE NEW YORK TIMES Edition de Paris, la tristesse proforde du depart d'un ami. II nous elan active avec le printemps, les roses et les esperances. et nous avions ete si heureux de lul faire fete, car, des les premiers jours il s'etait montre lui-meme si accueillant et si ouvcrt.

A revival of interest in the Indian problem is provoked by the report of WILLIAM A. JONES, the United States Commissioner of Indian Affairs. It is altogether too common for occupants of that office to dwell upon the substantial advancement toward civilization of our Indian wards and to be fertile in suggestion of new and expensive methods of material relief.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- Arrangements are now being perfected for the annual tour of the Yale Hockey Club this Winter. The prospects thus far this year are bright. Last year Yale won the championship, defeating Harvard 5 to 4 in New York, and as many of the old piayers returned to college this Fall there is again a good chance of victory this year.

"I am the masterpiece of all reality," said D.H. Jenkins, negro, a so-called doctor, to Magistrate Brann in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning. He had summoned to court a negress, Edith Lee, whom he accused of swindling him by selling him a spurious madstone.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The Presbytery of Newark this afternoon at the First Church on Broad Street received the report of the committee appointed to consider the four questions submitted by the General Assembly relative to the creed. The Rev. Samuel S. Farrand, the Chairman, reported against revision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Surgeon General of the Army, and Mrs. Sternberg, gave the first of a series of dinner parties this evening. Their guests included the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Fuller. Justice and Mrs. Brown, Mr and Mrs. John W. Foster, Mrs. Somers, and Prof. S.P. Langley.
BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The Reichstag reassembled to-day. The speech from the Throne dwelt at considerable length on the events in China. It was in part as follows:

The American Protestant Episcopal Church has taken the first step towards prohibiting the re-marriage of divorced persons by Episcopal clergymen, and preventing the participation of such persons in the communion of the Church when they have been re-married outside of it.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The funeral of Henry Villard took place this afternoon at 3:15 o'clock at his home, Thorwood, a short distance from this village, and there was a large attendance. The body, in an elegant mahogany casket, rested in front of the mantel in the large library.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- J.T. Stewart, a member of a prominent Council Bluffs (Iowa) wholesale grocery house, left this city to-day en route for Council Bluffs by locomobile. Mr. Stewart has been stopping here at the residence of David Bonner, a New York publisher. He will proceed to New York and thence directly to Council Bluffs.

At the meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday afternoon in The Mail and Express Building, at which President W.H. Parsons presided, a resolution favoring the entire separation of the Police Board and the Elections Bureau was offered by the Committee on City Affairs. The resolution was commented upon but slightly, and was finally referred back to the committee from which it came, in joint session with the Executive Committee of the board.

SULLIVAN, Ind., Nov. 14. -- An extraordinary incident has occurred on the farm of Charles Seliechter, in Gill Township, three miles south of New Lebanon. Thomas McPheeters of Palestine, Ill., was engaged in digging a well on Monday and when he reached a depth of thirty feet the sand and curbing above caved in suddenly, covering him above the shoulders, his head alone remaining above the sand.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission, at its session in the General Post Office Building yesterday, took up the complaint made by the Palmer's Dock and the Hay Produce Board of Trade against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, charging that the latter, four months ago, decided that it would not again deliver hay at its North Fourth Street depot, in Brooklyn, and that since it has held at Jersey City carloads consigned to the New York Hay Company.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- At the Jacob yard, this place, a sample of the one special racing and cruising class has been completed for the approval of the Manhasset Yacht Club for next season. The boat is of the modern fin-keel type and fitted with raceabout rig, making the craft suitable for cruising or racing.

Joseph W. Frost was awarded a verdict for $5,000 yesterday in the Supreme Court in his action against Robert A. Pinkerton and the Brooklyn Jockey Club. Frost sued to recover $30,000 for assault and false arrest at the Gravesend track in September, 1891. His wife has an action for a similar amount now pending against the defendants.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Because his son was disobedient in school, B.A. Maryon, a whisky salesman, of 154 North Grove Street, East Orange, undertook yesterday to administer corporal punishment, and during the whipping the boy's right eye was so badly injured that the doctors removed the eye to-day.

One of the questions with which the Senate is likely to be confronted at a comparatively early stage of its coming session is the question of Mr. W.A. CLARK, of Montana. The question of CLARK was acute last session. Now it threatens to become chronic, like the case of ADDICKS, of which a recrudescence is also threatened.

Prices in the market for outside securities yesterday showed more irregularity than on any day since activity was recently resumed. In the first few days following the outburst of enthusiasm which was called forth by the result of the recent election there was a general effort to secure stocks, and few if any thought of profiting by the early advances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The criticisms in the English press upon the attitude of the United States Government relative to the Chinese complications have attracted a good deal of attention here. In an authoritative quarter it was said to-day:

The principal development in the failure it Grant Brothers, Stock Exchange brokers, of 45 Broadway, who suspended on Tuesday, was a statement by Frank Bergen of 421 North Broad Street, Elizabeth, N.J., attorney for John K. Van Sickle, one of the partners of the firm. Mr. Bergen's statement was:

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- The National Civic Federation has issued the following announcement, calling a National conference to consider the best means to secure conciliation and arbitration in the settlement of industrial disputes:
ALGIERS, Nov. 14. -- The United States battleship Kentucky, Capt. Chester commanding, will leave this port to-morrow for Naples, where she will await orders.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The stewards of the Jockey Club have been hearing evidence, yesterday and to-day, at the Weatherbys' office, (Old Burlington Street,) in regard to the allegations made by Lord Durham against the running of Richard Croker's The Scotchman II. at Doncaster, when, with L. Reiff up, the horse was badly beaten by Lord Durham's Gerolstein.

The names of three men were brought into prominence yesterday as probable candidates for Mayor. Edward M. Shepard has of late received the favorable consideration of Richard Croker, who is now said to be not averse to taking a Brooklyn man recommended by the organization for the first place on the city ticket next year.

McVickar Co. have sold for Juliet M. Livingston to T.J. Maguire, for improvement, the plot of about forty-two lots in the block bounded by Teller and Clay Avenues. One Hundred and Sixty-eighth and One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Streets. The property includes the entire block with the exception of a plot 80 by 125 at the south-east corner of Teller Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street.

NEWPORT, Nov. 14. -- The annual exhibition of the Newport Horticultural Society, which is made up of the gardeners of the cottagers and prominent citizens of Newport, is open and drawing large crowds.

The wonder semi-officially expressed in Washington yesterday concerning the statements of the British press upon American policy in China must have been unofficially entertained and expressed by every American reader who has studied and followed the Chinese situation from the beginning.

The event of social Interest to-day will be the wedding in St. George's Church at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon of Herbert Livingston Satterlee and Miss Louisa Plerpont Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Plerpont Morgan. Mr. Satterlee is the son of George B. Satterlee. His mother was Miss Sarah Satterlee, a cousin of her husband.

The apparent disposition on the part of Chile to grant Bolivia a coast line on the Pacific, as explained in a Washington dispatch yesterday, could hardly have been brought about by Chile's unselfish desire to rehabilitate the little interior republic. More evidently is it owing to the fact that the cause of the latter, espoused by Argentina, has threatened the establishment of an anti-Chilean alliance among the other powers of South America.

List of Plans Filed for New Structures and Alterations. No. 23 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, for a five-story brick stable, 25 by 96; Fanny Weill of 151 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, owner; Jobst Hoffmann of 20 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, architect; cost, $20,000.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 14. -- Tuesday forenoon an attempt was made to poison Mrs. Melvina Prunier of this city. Mrs. Prunier is the young woman who obtained a few months ago damages of $15,000 in New York courts in a case for alienation of affections brought against Lillian Ash, or Campbell, of Fishkill-on-the-Hudson.

"Divorce Day" has been applied to Wednesday by lawyers in the Supreme Court. One of the Justices always sits in Part III., Special Term, on Wednesdays and hears testimony in all uncontested actions for divorce. The recent exposure of the Maison-Zeimer frauds gave the impression that the Justice assigned to hear such cases yesterday would be unusually careful.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The game between West Point and University of Maryland this afternoon was canceled by the cadets. The soldiers are crippled so badly that the coaches decided to call the game off. Several of West Point's best players are in the hospital suffering from sprains that may take months to heal.

W.E. Sebree, a commission broker of 44 Broadway, said yesterday that he had decided to go out of the commission business and enter the "put and call" market. He made this announcement in reply to a question as to dissatisfaction on the part of his customers.

All the lesser traders on the floor of the Stock Exchange went down to Wall Street yesterday expecting and prepared to work for a further and more decided slump in the stock market. Nothing hut bearish talk was heard; the market was top heavy; it had had too violent a rise; the stronger interests were out, and so on, ad infinitum.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Hale, Fincke, and Cook made up the back field in to-day's practice at the field, and the work of the team was very fast and strong. Ferguson and Rafferty went in at ends, and Bloomer, Brown, Olcott, Sheldon, Stillman and Wear played in their regular positions. The scrubs made one touch-down against the 'Varsity, and were scored against four times in the hour and ten minutes of play.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- The second day's session of the State Federation of Women's Clubs was devoted to the reading of several interesting papers and to the report of the Nominating Committee for Officers for 1900-1902. The election will take place tomorrow. Following are the nominations:

On Aug. 25 last John Doerflinger, a stereotyper employed on one of the New York dailies, going home early in the morning, saw a small fox terrier in a perilous position on the elevated railroad structure at Manhattan Junction, East New York. The dog was in danger of being either cut to pieces by a passing train or killed by coming in contact with the third rail.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Census Bureau recently completed the enumeration of the District of Alaska. The schedules have been received at the office and are now in process of tabulation.

The old reservoir in Bryant Park, at Fifth Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, which is being demolished to make room for the new public library building, was yesterday the receptacle for several million gallons of water set free by a break in the forty-eight-inch cross-town main on Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Washington residence of Commander B.F. Tilley, United States Navy, 1,913 N Street, was at noon to-day the scene of one of the prettiest home wedding's of the Autumn, the bride being his daughter. Miss Caroline Williamson Tilley, and the bridegroom Alfred Randolph IIyett, a prominent young business man of Baltimore.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Princeton's football men had a final battle on the university gridiron to-day, before the game with Yale. The players on both the 'Varsity and scrub put more "ginger" into their work than has been their custom lately, and made the students on the side lines think of what might happen if Princeton had a week or two more to practice.

The Very Rev. John E. Barry of Concord, N.H., Roman Catholic Vicar General of the Diocese of Manchester, N.H., was knocked down and instantly killed by a cable car on Broadway directly opposite the Astor House at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The body was wedged under the front end of the car, and it was necessary to jack it up to extricate the dead man.

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- The Appellate Division. Third Department, to-day handed down a decision in proceedings instituted by the New York and Queens County Railway Company against the State Board of Tax Commissioners which attacks the validity of the Franchise Tax act, relative to the filing of reports.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The size of the crowd which had gathered to watch the performance led to the failure of an election bet to go through here last evening, much to the disappointment of the would-be spectators. The principals in the bet were Henry L. Eckhard and William Berges, clothiers, and Arthur Lovatt and Julius Scherer.

Three games only were rolled in the Life Insurance League tournament on Ehler's Alleys last night, as the John Hancock team failed to appear. The other three teams broke even, each winning one game and losing one. In the second game. Soreson of the Mutual Life team rolled 220, with six strikes, three spares, and one break, which is the high individual score of the tournament.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 14. -- Alexander Cort, Philip Ketcham, and Clarence Dour, prominent business men of Farmingdale, are at home to-night, although for the last few days their relatives and friends had given them up for lost. It was believed they had been blown to sea in the gale of last Friday and Friday night, and had been drowned.

The wedding of Amos R. Eno Pinchot and Miss Gertrude Minturn was celebrated at noon yesterday in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, by the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, rector of the church. The bride, who entered the church on the arm of her brother, Robert Shaw Minturn, who afterward gave her away, wore a gown of cream-white satin, severely plain in style and trimmed only with drapery of point lace on the bodice.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- It leaked out to-day that an attempt was made yesterday to bunko a wealthy and well-known resident of Yonkers. The intended victim was J.S. Van Court, a retired banker, who lives in a handsome residence at 147 Stevens Avenue. Mr. Van Court is seventy-four years old, and is a prominent church member.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 14. -- Prof. G. Fred Wright of Oberlin College and his son, Fred Bennet Wright, have arrived here after a five months' journey in Siberia and Central Asia. They sailed from San Francisco on the same steamer that carried Mrs. Conger, wife of the United States Minister to China, and Mrs. Villard, spending a month in Japan and reaching Peking about the end of last April.

Proceedings for the removal to the District of New Jersey of Miss Elizabeth Shanahan, a dressmaker of 11 East Forty-sixth Street, who was arrested on Sept. 7 on her arrival from Europe on the steamship Auguste Victoria, charged with smuggling, were resumed yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields in the Federal Building.

A verdict of $12,300 and an award of $500 extra allowance was given yesterday by a jury in the Supreme Court in favor of John Fullerton, a seven-year-old boy, against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

The Columbia football squad continued its good work in practice yesterday afternoon. Coach Sanford was absent, but under the whip of equally sharp coaching by Capt. Morley and Smythe both the 'Varsity and scrub teams in a thirty-five-minute practice game played as hard, snappy football as has been seen on Columbia Field this season.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- Trading to-day again reached large proportions, and the list as a whole showed an upward tendency. The coppers all strengthened materially.
