Montana, up at one time to 328, fell to 323, but closed at 325 3/4. Amalgamated lifted to 95, Parrot to 45 7/8, Old Dominion to 28, Isle Royale to 40, Copper Range to 25 1/2, and Baltic to 27 1/4.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- More sensations are being sprung in connection with the Loonie case, so prolific of sensations from the start.

The American Ice Company has reduced the price of ice for all except "family trade" to 17 1/2 cents a hundred pounds, or $3.50 a ton. It Is said that it makes a concession cut under this rate for trade which it covets or to customers who might be induced to patronize independent dealers. In fact, ice is going a begging just now, and there is plenty of it, both natural and artificial.

W.E.D. Stokes, the principal stockholder in the Onward Construction Company, which is erecting the magnificent twelve-story stone structure now going up on Broadway, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth Streets, said yesterday that the structure was to be opened as a first-class apartment house.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 2. -- It is reported that the police of Kieff have taken the theatres of that city in hand. They have not found it necessary to measure the length of the skirts of the members of the ballet. The evils which they desire to correct, and no doubt have already satisfactorily corrected, are of another character.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Joseph Jefferson lectured this afternoon in Alexander Hall before 1,500 students and townspeople. Ex-President Cleveland accompanied Mr. Jefferson to the hall, and occupied a seat on the rostrum. Mr. Jefferson said in part:

ROME, Nov. 15. -- A rumor is current in Rome that the illness of the Czar is due to poisoning, and it is asserted that cipher telegrams have been received at the Vatican saying that an attempt was made to poison both the Emperor and Empress, but that the latter was not affected.

Announcement was made yesterday concerning the embarrassments of W.L. Strong Co. that Col. Strong indorsed over a million dollars of paper for F.H. Stott, which is still outstanding. Cornelius N. Bliss and John Claflin of the advisory committee held a conference with Receiver Treat early in the day, and shortly after noon issued the following statement, as authorized by them:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15. -- Harvard's Fall rowing season closed to-day with a regatta between the Weld and Newell Clubs, the former winning three of the four events. The weather was unfavorable. A cold wind roughened the water and snow fell at intervals. The graded eights race was the only interesting contest, and was won by the Newell crew by four feet in the slow time of 10:40. Summary:

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 15. -- A mob of several hundred International Union Cigarmakers fired on the factory of Gonzales Mora Co. this morning. The house was occupied by several hundred men, women, and children, belonging to Resistencia Union, at work. A demand was made by the International that these persons leave the factory.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 15 -- "Mogy" Bernstein, "King of the Newsboys" of Omaha, was married this afternoon in the parlors of the Coates House by Rabbi Mayer of this city. "Mogy's" bride is Miss Blanche Sunfeld of Perry, Oklahoma.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The paramount issues in the coming Mayoralty contest will be Respectability vs. Crokerism, and on the success of either will depend the welfare of New York City and its people for the next four years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Minister from Nicaragua, Seftor Don Luis Corea, arrived in Washington this morning after an absence of four months in Nicaragua, during which time he conferred with President Zelaya and the members of the Cabinet concerning Nicaragua canal affairs, and other subjects of interest to the two countries.

Francis M. Jencks has sold to J. Axelrod the plot. 100 by 100, on the south side of Ninety-fourth Street, beginning 110 feet west of West End Avenue. The westerly 62 feet of this frontage has been resold by Mr. Axelrod to A. Nathan Brown. Mr. Brown will erect a seven-story apartment house on his purchase, while on the 128-foot frontage which remains Mr. Axelrod will build two similar structures.

HELENA, Mont., Nov. 15. -- Memorial services for Marcus Daly, whose funeral took place in New York to-day, were held in nearly all the churches throughout this State and business of all descriptions was suspended, including the operations of all the mines, smelters, and mills of the Amalgamated Copper Company.

Almost all the roads interested in the official classification have sent in their votes on the recommendations suggested by the Classification Committee at its last meeting, and it is expected that the result may be announced by the middle of next week. It may be stated in advance that there have been made no general advances in rates by the committee.

Six American scouts and forty-four Irish cavalrymen of the Boer army arrived in this country on the Hamburg-American liner Furst Bismarck last night. The Americans return because, they say their citizenship has not been renounced, while the Irishmen intimate that their coming was due to the fact that since Ireland is "nominally" British territory, their welcome in that country might not be as enthusiastic as they should wish.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Actual work began this week on the laying of the keels of the mammoth iron steamships to be built at the works of the Eastern Ship Building Company, Groton, opposite New London, and from this date the work of putting together the hulls of the ships will go rapidly on.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 15. -- A shocking termination had the annual cane rush in which the sophomores and freshmen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology engaged this afternoon on the Boston baseball grounds.

George W. Wanmaker presided last night at the meeting of the Republican County Committee, held at Murray Hill Lyceum, on Thirty-fourth Street. Charles K. Lexow. presented resolutions commemorative of the recent Republican victory, which were unanimously adopted.

A special meeting of the Legal Aid Society was held yesterday afternoon in the meeting rooms of the Chamber of Commerce for the purpose of discussing the importance of the seamen's branch of the society and what the society is doing for the protection of American seamen.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Catherine Loonie was taken to Auburn Prison this afternoon to serve her sentence of four years and nine months for offering forged deeds for record.

Miss Edith Collins, who was the sole representative from St. Louis to the women's championship tournament at Shinnecock, has recenly won the women's championship of the St. Louis Country Club. She beat Mrs. Scudder in the final round by 5 up and 3 to play.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 15. -- The preliminary estimate of the average yield per acre of corn to 1900, as published in the forthcoming monthly report of the statistician of the Department of Agriculture, is 25.3 bushels, as compared with an average yield or 25.31 bushels in 1899, of 24.76 bushels in 1898, and a ten-year average of 24.1 bushels.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Clifford Brokaw's British-built cutter Queen Mab, now lying up for the Winter at the Jacob yard, has been sold to L.H. Smith of New York. The Queen Mab was built in England in 1894 from designs of Mr. Watson's for Percy Chubb. Her dimensions are 80 feet over all, 60 feet water line, 16 feet beam, and 11 feet draft.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- Trading was rather quiet to-day, the only active issues being the arbitrage stocks, which were bought for the New York account. The demand included Pennsylvania Railroad, Lehigh Valley, and the Readings, and was due to rumors of coming deals in these properties.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 15. -- A cablegram to Fitz Hugh Whitehouse, Jr., announces the birth in London of a son to Mrs. Charles John Coventry, wife of Capt. the Hon. Charles John Coventry, second son of the ninth Earl and brother of the present Earl of Coventry. Mrs. Coventry was Miss Lily Whitehouse, daughter of William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse, who is a brother of Fitz Hugh Whitehouse, Jr.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Nov. 15. -- A remarkable election story is told by Mrs. Lida Montgomery, who returned yesterday from a trip through the South. She is the wife of Z.J. Montgomery, agent of the Illinois Central.

Justice Blanchard, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down a decision in favor of the plaintiff in the action brought by H. Randolph Whitman against the Holmes Publishing Company, an Illinois corporation, and the Directors of the corporattion, Henry Brandenburg, Josiah Brandenburg, and Frank Byers, and Charles Austin Bates, who was, it is claimed, the recipient of a fraudulent and collusive transfer of the assets of the corporation.

The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, Chairman of the special committee appointed by the Episcopal Convention of 1898 to consider and report upon the subject of divorce, was seen yesterday at St. Paul's Vestry and asked what he thought the prospects were of the Church adopting the three new canons agreed upon by the committee.

Richard Croker instituted a crusade yesterday under the auspices of Tammany Hall against vice on the east side. He made a speech, in which the movement was started at a meeting of the Executive Committee held in the Wigwam on Fourteenth Street.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- At St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church this evening the wedding of Miss Florence Anne Hyde and Warren Southard Jordan took place in the presence of a large gathering The Rev. George Rissell Warder of Hartford, Conn., an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William Fisher Lewis, rector of St. Peter's Church.

Still further diminution occurred yesterday in the trading in the market for outside securities, but from the point of view of prices the market was probably more favorable than on Wednesday. It is true that in some parts of the list further reaction showed, but a number of stocks advanced fractionally above the closing figures of the previous day, and in some few cases substantial gains were made.

The German-American Fire Insurance Company team was the only one of six to win two matches in the Fire Insurance League tournament on Reid's alleys, Church Street, Manhattan, last night. The Caledonian, Greenwich, Norwich Union, and Lloyds Plate Glass Insurance teams broke even, each winning one game and losing one, and the Northern Fire lost both their matches.

There is some doubt, after all, the gossips say, about the production of Stephen Phillips's new tragedy, "Herod," in New York this season. It is said that Mr. Mansfield contracted to produce the play this Winter, with the understanding that the manuscript was to be delivered to him in August.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn to-night wires as follows:

It is the opinion of Mr. FRANK H. PLATT, the son of Senator PLATT, that it will be no easy task to defeat CROKER at the election next Fall. As we have repeatedly said, the task will be very difficult indeed, unless there is a cordial and energetic union of all the opponents of CROKER.

The eighth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers was begun yesterday at the society's rooms, 12 West Thirty-first Street. President Clement A. Griscom presided. Among the society's distinguished guests were: Lieut. Commander De Faranaud of the French Navy, Lieut. Commander Von Rebeur Paschwitz of the German Navy, Capt. Stohensnovitch, Imperial Russian Navy; Capt. Beher, Imperial Kussian Navy, and Naval Constructors Tehernigvosky and Makedonsky, Imperial Russian Navy.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Nov. 15 -- Dr. Edward Ross, head professor in the Department of Economics and Sociology at Stanford University, has resigned. The resignation caused quite a sensation in university circles, where Dr. Ross was extremely popular.

Substantial strength again appeared in the stock market yesterday under the leadership of the standard railway stocks, in which the buying was accounted of the best. As on the previous day, some of the lesser room traders undertook to keep quotations down, and to this end started a bear crusade, first against one stock and then against another.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 15. -- At a dinner given to-night by W.N. Frew, President of the Board of Directors of the Carnegie Institute, to Andrew Carnegie. Mayor W.J. Diehl, and other prominent citizens Mr. Carnegie made an offer to the City of Pittsburg to build a technical school in connection with the Carnegie Institute and endow it with $1,000,000.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The Reiff and Wishard case was keenly discussed on the racecourse at Derby. It transpires that further inquiries on the subject were conducted there this afternoon, and it is said the matter will be thrashed out in the courts as well as in the Jockey Club, lawyers having been instructed to commence an action for libel against Lord Durham, no matter what the decision of the Jockey Club may be.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The long controversy over armor plate prices is ended. The terms of the agreement were made public to-day, and it became known that Secretary Long had scored a victory. The agreement clearly shows that all the estimates of the probable price which have been made during the last month are pure guesswork.
HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- The mountains south of this village are on fire and considerable alarm is felt lest the flames should come nearer.

Coach Sanford gave the Columbia football squad an hour and a half of hard work yesterday afternoon, as it was the last opportunity the team will have for practice before the game with the Cadets at Annapolis to-morrow.

After yesterday's fashionable wedding and a number of small affairs, the members of New York's gay world will rest to-day, which has little of incident on its calendar. The arrivals from out of town for Horse Show week grow larger each succeeding day, and all the favorite and fashionable hotels are already crowded.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 15. -- At the twentieth Church Congress of the Episcopal Church of the United States, which opened here to-day, Ernest H. Crosby of New York spoke on "War from the Christian Point of View" He said, in part:

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 15. -- Boston's market was quiet in comparison with the rate of business for the last ten days, but it was active and broad in comparison with the rate which prevailed for months prior to election day. Mining shares were not over and above active, but Cochiti was prominent and touched 10 3/4, about 3,000 shares changing hands in the morning dealings.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The impression exists in most European capitals that the illness of Emperor Nicholas of Russia is more serious than it is represented to be, but this is probably based upon knowledge that the Czar's constitution is not strong and is little likely to resist a serious attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The report of Gen. Buffington, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, has been made to the Secretary of War. Some of the most interesting portions dealing with disputed points between the Ordnance Bureau and the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications are contained in appendices which have not yet been made public.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- The schooner Mascotte, which has arrived here from the South Seas, brings tales of cannibalism and the massacre of blacks on the Savage Islands. For the past two years the Mascotte has been trading between the Solomon Islands, New Guinea, and New Ireland.

The policy that has been recommended to the Protestant Episcopal Church by the special committee having the question of divorce in charge is that which might logically have been expected to result from the long and careful study and consideration to which the matter has been subjected.
WINONA, Minn., Nov. 15. -- Congressman James A. Tawney of the Ways and Means Committee, speaking of the meeting to be held in Washington on Nov. 30, said today:

DENVER, Col., Nov. 15 -- John Porter, who confessed yesterday that he murdered little Louise Frost, an eleven-year-old schoolgirl of Lemon. Col., will not be taken to Lincoln County at present. Sheriff Freeman of that county declares that he wishes to avoid a lynching if possible, and thinks that when the people have time to cool down they will be willing to allow the law to take its course.

Whoever is responsible for the adoption of fads, fancies, and fashions has evidently decided that pink is to be the color for the Horse Show. There could hardly be any other reason within reach of the masculine mind for the sudden blossoming out in the show windows at ail of the lashionable shops in towns of masses of pink.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 16. -- The Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club will open to-morrow at the Bennings track and continue three weeks. Many of the best handicap horses of the East are already quartered there, and Imp, Seip, and About of the Brosman string arrived to-day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Minister Wu has received from Director General Sheng the following cablegram, which he communicated to Secretary Hay to-day:
Andrew Knox Sons have been appointed Newark agents of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

The papers read yesterday at the last day's session of the eighth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, which was held in the auditorium of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 12 West Thirty-first Street, were of much more general interest than those of the first day and the attendance was much larger.

As large an audience as could gather in the assembly room of the United Charities Building attended the annual meeting of the Charity Organization Society last evening, and after listening to the substance of the eighteenth annual report of the Central Council, read by Secretary Edward T. Devine, was addressed by John W. Keller, Commissioner of Charities, Controller Coler, and Dr. John H. Pryor of Buffalo, Commissioner of the State Hospital for Consumptives.

LIMON, Col., Nov. 16. -- Chained to a railroad rail set firmly in the ground on the exact spot where his fiendish crime was committed, Preston Porter, Jr., or, as he was familiarly known, John Porter, this evening paid a terrible penalty for the murder of Louise Frost, an eleven-year-old schoolgirl.

At the annual meeting of the Charity Organization Society last night, Commissioner John W. Keller took occasion to say in a speech that if the new committee of Tammany Hall appointed through Mr. Croker's agency Thursday night did not "do something" he would refuse to act with it.

The International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association of North America held its annual dinner last night at the Hotel Savoy, with over 300 at table. The speechmaking, under the direction of Dr. L.C. Warner, who presided, was long and interesting. It began at about 8:30 and lasted without interruption, barring that of applause, until near the midnight hour, when half the chairs had been vacated by those who believe in early hours.
"Some papers are opposing it. But any paper that opposes a State constabulary measure is working in the interest of CROKER. But the bill will pass." -- THOMAS C. PLATT.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- As a finishing touch for the big game to-morrow the Princetons spent a few minutes this afternoon in running through the signals. In commenting on the week's routine of work, it may be said that the players have worked with indomitable energy under the instructions of the coaches, and will enter the contest with Yale to-morrow with a desperate determination to win.

The death of Thomas Arnold in Dublin a few days ago, where he had gone with Cardinal Newman a few years since, never returning to England, recalls the fact that his "Passages in a Wandering Life," issued by this old man of seventy-seven, only out a few months ago, gives a very attractive picture of a son of Dr. Arnold of Rugby, who has never been so well-known as his more famous brother, Matthew.

NEWPORT, Nov. 16. -- It can be stated positively that the next international yacht races between the Shamrock II. and the America's Cup defender, which the Herreshoffs have already began work upon, will not occur off this port, and at the same time it can be stated that the Sandy Hook course will be maintained.

In the campaign for the Presidency just closed one of the most noteworthy features was the absence of the usual speeches of the leading men on each side, together with the prevalence of printed argument in the newspapers and in what is known at the headquarters as "literature." The absence of speeches from men in public life was particularly striking.

More seasonable weather has, according to Dun's Review, brought increased activity in many lines throughout most provinces of the Dominion. St. John reports that sorting orders are coming in freely in dry goods, and there is a fair demand for groceries and provisions, while retail trade in general is fairly active.

That was an almost unprecedented success, if not quite, that the President was able to declare the other day, in announcing to the members of his Cabinet his wish that they should all continue to hold their respective places during his second term. Commonly a re-elected President finds that it is desirable to make changes for the prevention of friction.

Joseph Bush and Maurice Shea, both of Brooklyn, are locked up at Police Headquarters, charged with the theft of 600 pounds of opium from the warehouse of Lawrence, Son Gerrish, at 221 to 237 South Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- The new Harvard University boathouse was formally presented to the students this afternoon by representatives of the Harvard Club of New York.

RICHARD CROKER called a meeting of the leaders of Tammany Hall on Thursday evening and plainly and without equivocation admitted his own and their power to stop the immunity that vice and lawnessness enjoy in this city.

Why should not a guide book be good reading -- "literary" reading? There does not seem to be any reason in the nature of things. Travelers for pleasure, "picturesque tourists," are supposed to be reading people. And, moreover, a guide book, in the literary sense, would be useful and attractive, not only to readers actually engaged in touring, but also to readers "who have been there" and to others who "still would go."

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 16. -- A rumor is in circulation to-night in the inner McKinley circles of the State, to the effect that John F. Richards of Ironton, Ohio, is to be appointed Attorney General.

"Songs of Shakespeare," with illustrations by henry Ospovat, is being published by John Lane, Henry Holt Co. have in press for immediate publication an edition of Scidel's "Wintermurchen," with notes and vocabulary by Dr. Corinth L. Cook.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 16. -- Gloucester has reckoned up for the year the cost in loss of life and property of its fishing industry. The season in respect both to losses of life and property has been practically the best in twenty-five years. Although there have been two years when the property loss was slightly less, yet in those years the loss of life was considerably larger.

Football is all the talk of to-day, and the younger and club element at least in New York society will journey to Princeton to witness the great annual struggle on the gridiron between Princeton and Yale. There will be gay and lively scenes on the Pennsylvania ferries, in the Jersey City depot, and in the little New Jersey college town this morning, and again this afternoon.

The Tammany Anti-Vice Committee, appointed Thursday evening at the instigation of Richard Croker to examine into vice as found on the east side, was formally organized yesterday afternoon at the Tammany Headquarters in Fourteenth Street. Despite the intimation of Mr. Croker that all the meetings of the committee would be open to the press and to the public, the session was held behind closed doors.

Now that the first steps toward the arrangement of the plans for the coming season of the Amateur Hockey Club have been taken, the intercollegiate and interscholastic hookey leagues will follow suit and next week meet to determine upon their schedules and membership. Cornell, whose situation in a cold climate renders her well adapted to indulge in the sport of hockey, has applied for membership in the Intercollegiate League.

The bookbindings shown by the Scribners this year are characterized by a greater tendency toward simplicity than was the case twelve months ago. The carved or "embossed" decoration has almost entirely disappeared, and there is less mosaie work than formerly. A novelty in the way of binding material is known as "Niger Calf."

In the future an attempt will be made by the editors of The Critic to have those brief notes of current books, which occupy the closing pages of the periodical and which are critical as well as expository, more than ever distinctive and valuable. A corps of specialists will contribute to these columns unsigned notes which, however brief, very often represent hours of careful reading by men and women of taste, knowledge, and experience.

The Democratic Club was crowded with Tammany men last evening. They gathered to shake hands with Richard Croker before he sails for Europe. Hundreds of politicians, some personal friends and others looking for political preferment, crowded the rooms of the Democratic Club until near midnight.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- Superintendent of Public Works Partridge to-day issued an order closing the State canals for the season Dec. 1 at noon. The order contains the usual provision -- unless sooner closed by ice.

Henry George has already been placed by a majority of the thinking middle class among impracticable reformers. Nevertheless, this life of him will be found an exceedingly interesting book -- a history of a career full of struggle, the story of a unique character in constant contention until past middle life with ill-luck.

In response to a call of a committee of the Medical Society of the County of New York, consisting of Drs. Henry Dwight Chapin, Abraham Jacobi, Joseph E. Winters, and Walter Lester Carr, a meeting was held last night at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, to informally discuss the best method of improving the milk supply of New York.

Mrs. Turnbull has chosen for the setting of her historical romance the Venice of its most brilliant and most interesting period. She has not only a thorough knowledge of her subject, but she is imbued with the spirit of the place and of the time, and her story is filled with the atmosphere of both.

Buoyancy ruled on the stock market yesterday, with quotations ad ng substantially throughout the list on buying by strong financial interests, in which the public joined. In the phraseology of the Street it was a "genuine bull market" -- more real, more natural, and more substantial than on any day since the present upward movement began.
BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The news of the attempt on the Kaiser's life created a great sensation here. It was first received on the Boerse, where the market weakened.

The series called Century Classics which is betas published by the Century Company will appeal particularly to those lovers of books who would have in their library the English classics in a pleasing and useful form -- a form which, in letterpress, paper, and character of binding and of design, is sure to give satisfaction to the bookman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The annual report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for the fiscal year ended June 30. 1900, shows a collection, exceeded but once in the history of the bureau. The receipts were $205,316,107, being $10,316,107 in excess of the estimated amount and $21,831,534 more than during the previous year.

Yale and Princeton football teams will meet this afternoon in their twenty-sixth annual game. The new University Field at Princeton will be the scene of the contest. It will be a struggle of peculiar interest, for on the part of the Tigers the game against their most cherished rivals has many of the characteristics of a forlorn hope.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The John Cudahy Packing and Provision Company was incorporated at Springfield to-day as the first step in organizing a ten-million-dollar corporation, embracing all John Cudahy's packing interests. Almost at the same time the Cudahy Packing Company, which is controlled by Michael Cudahy, gave notice of an increase of capital from $3,500,000 to $7,000,000.

In July last Elias Krams, a grocer at Jane and Spring Streets. West Hoboken, received a letter from his niece, Minnie Krams, whose parents reside in Vienna. Miss Krams told her uncle she was coming to the United States, and would sail on the Potsdam when that vessel made its next trip.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Census Bureau has issued a bulletin announcing the population of Hawaii by islands and districts. It shows, the total population of Hawaii to be 154,001, an increase of 44,981, or 41.2 per cent. over 1898, when the last census was-taken there.

The examination before United States Commissioner Shields of Cornelius L. Alvord, Jr., formerly note teller of the First National Bank, charged with embezzling $690,000 from that institution, ended yesterday afternoon, when the defense declined to submit any evidence.

The art season grows more animated every week and the past seven days have brought a number of interesting incidents and events. There have been several small exhibitions opened, notably one at the Keppel Galleries of paintings by Andreas Andersen and of drawings and sculpture by Hendrick Christian Andersen.

Ex-Justice William N. Cohen of the Supreme Court is preparing a police bill to be introduced in the next Legislature. The report is that, in view of the great opposition that has developed up the State against a State constabulary measure, the Cohen bill will provide for a metropolitan police act very much on the same lines as that of 1857.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Money was in good request to-day, with no present promise of being easier this year. Recently operators have been able to borrow on their own terms. Now they have to go to the Bank of England and pay 4 1/2 per cent. After November the requirements will, be the usual heavy cash drain toward the provinces during December, besides the possibilities in connection with the Government's temporary requirements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The feature of the anuual report of Lieut. Gen. Miles, commanding the army, is a chapter dealing with the need for a general reorganization of the military service. In regard to this question he says:

The Tenement House Commission of the State of New York, appointed by the Legislature to investigate the tenementhouse problem in New York, held its first public hearing yesterday afternoon in the Assembly Hall of the Charities Building, at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Transactions in the market for outside securities yesterday showed a much larger total than on Thursday, and much more life appeared in the trading. The copper stocks were the most active, but in other parts of the list as well business broadened, and in a number of issues prices responded with sharp advances.

What variety of form hovers around and accompanies in their travels many familiar quotations! Even writers of recognized rank occasionally emit a discordant note by putting the wrong word here and there. S.C. Hall, in his "Memories of Great Men and Women," tells how Wordsworth complained of Scott's having misquoted from his poem, "Yarrow Revisited"; how he took from a bookcase one of the Waverley novels, and read:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Griggs, wife of the Attorney General, returned to Washington to-day, after an absence of five months. Mrs. Griggs will present her step-daughter, Miss Constance Griggs, the third week in December. The debutante is the youngest of an attractive trio, and the daughter of the Attorney General by a former marriage.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Nov. 16. -- Queen's hockey team will make a United States tour for two weeks after New Year's, and will play matches in Buffalo, Cleveland Chicago. St. Louis, Pittsburg, and New York.

Many of those who read "Famous Homes of Great Britain and Their Stories" felt that the work was incomplete, although in it were described what were undoubtedly the more famous homes. The work, however, became popular with just that public which might be expected to be appealed to through a work of literary and photographic art containing a record of famous British dwellings that for many reasons was worthy of preservation.

Foreign exchange bankers yesterday stated that the report of a proposed British loan of not less than $50,000,000 was well founded and that fully that amount would be subscribed here. The full amount of the loan, it is said, is likely to be much larger.

The Republican leaders in Brooklyn were relieved of a burden of worry yesterday by the clearing up of the mystery surrounding the defeat of Jacob Worth for Congress in the Fifth District. Mr. Worth had been looked upon by the Republicans as a sure winner, and his unexpected defeat was followed by all sorts of ugly rumors of treachery against the candidate in his own party.

The first concert of the fifty-ninth season of the Philharmonic Society of New York took place yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, It was called, as all these afternoon concerts are, a public rehearsal, but this name has ceased to have any significance. The afternoon entertainments are in every sense concerts conducted with all the dignity and the same general excellence as the evening offerings.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- It is contrary to the etiquette of the Russian Court to publish bulletins, but, as by marriage Emperor Nicholas is a grandson of Queen Victoria, this etiquette is relaxed.

There was plenty of excitement on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, in fact more than the drivers desired, as there were three runaways on the lower stretch while the brushing was at its height, all of which would probably have resulted seriously had it not been for the prompt and efficient action of the mounted police officers.

HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention, which met this afternoon in the Marti Theatre, discussed the report of the Committee on Credentials regarding the status of the delegates from the Province of Havana.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The New York State Federation at Women's Clubs held its final session to-day. Among the papers read was one by Mrs. George McAneny on "The Reform of the Civil Service: The Interest of Women in the Movement." The paper concluded as follows:

There was plenty of excitement on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, in fact more than the drivers desired, as there were three runaways on the lower stretch while the brushing was at its height, all of which would probably have resulted seriously had it not been for the prompt and efficient action of the mounted police officers.

HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention, which met this afternoon in the Marti Theatre, discussed the report of the Committee on Credentials regarding the status of the delegates from the Province of Havana.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The New York State Federation at Women's Clubs held its final session to-day. Among the papers read was one by Mrs. George McAneny on "The Reform of the Civil Service: The Interest of Women in the Movement." The paper concluded as follows:

GLASGOW, Nov. 16. -- The Earl of Rosebery was installed as Lord Rector of Glasgow University to-day. His rectorial address on the subject of "The British Empire," was a stirring appeal to the British race to realize its responsibilities, and to prepare to fight for its existence.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- On the Boerse to-day funds were quiet, but steady. American securities were strong, favorably Influencing locals. The American attitude toward the Chinese question exerted a good effect on the market. Mine shares were particularly animated owing to encouraging reports in regard to the American iron market
President Fish of the Illinois Central is making a tour of inspection over the Louisville Division of that line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The annual report of the United States Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, George M. Bowers, says the present amount of capital invested in the fisheries of the New England States is $19,637,036, showing a decrease of $437,758 since the commission's last statistical canvass in 1889.

Bishop Potter, in a letter to Mayor Van Wyck, has laid bare nearly every phase of vice and crime on the east side. The letter was sent to the Mayor's office on Nov. 15, and was written by Bishop Potter in accordance with the instructions laid upon him by the Convention of the Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New York.

ELECTRIC POWER HOUSE NUISANCE. -- Mrs. Sarah Bly, as a leaseholder of 33 West Twenty-sixth Street for a boarding house, brought suit two years ago to recover damages she claimed to have sustained by the Edison Electric Illuminating Company so operating its power house at 45 West Twenty-sixth Street as to cause a nuisance to her because of smoke, cinders, incessant vibration, and noise occasioned.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- A dispatch from Shanghai says that Prince Tuan has fled to Kan-Su, and that the whereabouts of Yu-Hsien, Governor of Shan-Si, is unknown.

PRINCETON, Nov. 17 -- Princeton won the toss and took the south end of the field, giving Yale the ball. Hale kicked off for Vale to Meier, who was standing on Princeton's five-yard line. He ran the ball back twenty yards before he was downed. Mattis punted fifty yards to Fincke, who was downed in his tracks.

Louis Charles, a clerk in the Street Cleaning Department and living at 148 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Detectives Knierim and Enright of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station and locked up charged with stealing gas fixtures valued at $700.
St. Peter's Church, in Westchester, will be formally reopened at 7:30 o'clock this morning, with Bishop Potter officiating at the service.

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 17 -- Excellent scores were made at the weekly trapshooting tournament of the Flushing Gun Club, which was decided on the club grounds, midway between Flushing and Jamaica, to-day. Capt. William A. Sands, the noted trapshot of the Emerald, Hell Gate, and other gun clubs, led the field at the conclusion of the day's sport with the largest percentage of kills to his credit.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 17 -- There is an interesting will contest pending before Judge Vreeland, in the Morris County Court. Senator Mahlon Pitney, acting on behalf of Miss Edith Richards, asks to have the will of the brother of his client, Jonathan E. Richards, set aside, alleging incapacity and undue influence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The arrangements, or, rather lack of arrangements, for the comfort of passengers by trolley, transferring at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, have been a disgrace for years both to the managing company and to the city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Wisconsin University's team played the fastest football seen here this season, simply overwhelmed the University of Chicago eleven on Marshall Field this afternoon, defeating them by a score of 30 to 5. Wisconsin's goal line was not crossed, the 5 points scored by the Maroons being the result of overeagerness on the part of the Wisconsin linesmen.

From The Contemporary Review. For more than 2.0OO years not only has it been a political axiom that the ruler is for the people, not the people for the ruler, but the civil official always takes precedence of the military of the same nominal rank. The civil Viceroy is supreme commander of all the forces in his Viceroyalty.

The census of 1900 shows that there are 159 cities in the United States having a population of 25,00O or over. The 159 cities have a combined population of 19,694,625, as compared with a population for the same cities from 1890 to 1900 was 4,839,136, or in 1880. The absolute increase of these cities from 190 to 1900 was 4,839.136, or 82,426 less than the absolute increase from 1880 to 1890, when it was 4,921,302.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The National Sea Power Company of East Orange, with a capital of $500,000 filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State in this city to-day.

Astonishing as it may seem, considering the remarkable advances in the preceding days of the week, yesterday's stock market was the strongest and broadest of any since election, the advancing quotations -- substantial throughout the list -- being brought about by buying by large financial interests which are pronouncedly bullish on the situation.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to -- Mr. and Mrs. William Butler Duncan, (Miss Jane P. Sargent,) Nov. 22, 1803.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is pursuing a policy in reference to the proposed Constabulary bill that appeals not only to the intelligent mind, but also to the practical common sense of all who are familiar with the cosmopolitan character of the body politic in this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If any argument were needed to convince one of the essential, if not absolute, fairness of THE TIMES, it would have been found in the editorial comment in to-day's edition on the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst's definition of "the ideal newspaper." It would have been so very easy to offer as an answer a definition of "the ideal clergyman."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- The Harvard freshman football team easily defeated the Yale freshman eleven in the annual game at Yale Field this afternoon by a score of 18 to 0. Immediately after the kick-off by O'Neill of Yale, the Haryard backs, Pruyn, MacKay, and Meier, carried the ball forward by a series of steady pushes.

PRINCETON, Nov. 17 -- This was a sad day for Princeton. For the second time in her history she was beaten at football on her own grounds. And this was the final game of the season, the twenty-fifth annual contest with Yale. That Princeton would lose was a foregone conclusion, but that did not make the defeat any the easier for the young men, whose athletic prowess is their greatest pride.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Nov. 17. -- Four miners were injured, two fatally, in the falling of a case to-day in the Vigo mine. The cage fell fifty feet, to the bottom of the shaft.

The women folk of the Methodist Church at Oxford recently set out to earn money for certain church purposes, and last Friday a meeting was held at which each woman or girl recited the method by which she had earned her contribution. Some of the recitals were funny enough to convulse the audience, and a few are epitomized as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reported failure of the plan to rebuild the Naval Arch can hardly fall to be a disappointment, not alone to New Yorkers, but to those of our countrymen besides who take delight in achievements which help transform our common country from a howling wilderness to a seat of culture.

Across Africa from south to north, traversing 400 miles of Nile swamp -- a feat hitherto thought by many explorers to be impossible -- is the record of Ewart W. Grogan, a young Cambridge student, who is now staying at the Holland House in this city, and who is going from here to New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club opened at the Bennings race course to-day under favorable auspices. The weather was perfect, the crowd large, and speculation active. There were five races on the flat and one steeplechase. Four favorites, one second choice, and one rank outsider captured the purses.
PARIS, Nov. 17. -- Great consternation was created here to-day by the report that Comte de Cornulier, who is well known in the highest Parisian society, had shot and killed his wife.

Wall Street has gone crazy -- so all the timid folks are saying. Wall Street is merely showing natural confidence -- so says Wall Street itself. Precedents are no longer accounted as of any consequence at all. In its bigness the present market surpasses aught that the New York Stock Exchange has ever before known.

Doubtless many persons have said in the last week of the role of the Marquess of Quex in pinero's play, now on view at the Criterion Theatre. "What a splendid part for Charles Coghlan" But one might is well say What a splendid part for Richard Burbage, or Thomas Betterton, Charles Kenable, or Thomas Apthorpe Cooper They are not deader than Coghlan.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 17 -- In a game which surprised her supporters for the stubborness of the defense, Dartmouth lost to Brown's football team by the score of 12 to 5 this afternoon. It was thought that the boys from Providence would have a walk-over, but Dartmouth fought for every inch of the territory, and was in a fair way to win when the first half closed, 6 to 3 against her.

Since the tunnel diggers began operations preparatory to the 4,000-foot drive through and beyond the high hill at the north end of Central Park, that portion of the Rapid Transit Railroad has become one of the busiest sections on the entire line. A cut low down twenty feet and three or four hundred feet in length divides One Hundred and Tenth Street at the junction of St. Nicholas and Lenox Avenues.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 17 -- "The new manager of the Grand Trunk is G.B. Reeve, our former Traffic Manager," said Vice President Price at the Windsor Hotel this afternoon. "Mr. Reeve will take office as soon as Mr. Hays leaves." It has been understood here that Mr. Reeve had retired to private life in California, and F.K. McGuigan's name was mentioned as Mr. Hays's successor.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 17 -- When a crew of sailors are cast away upon one of the many bleak islands off the coast of Maine the newspapers are filled with stories of their sufferings, but it seldom occurs to any one to sympathize with the helpless flocks of sheep that are left on these islands all the year, with no shelter from the fierce heat of Summer or the awful storms and cold of Winter.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 17 -- The order for the yacht destined to defend the America's Cup was brought to Bristol by the Herreshoff Brothers when they returned from New York on Wednesday. No time has been lost in making preparations for the building of the boat. The plans have long been ready, and the first orders for actual work have been given to the blacksmiths, who have been told to set out certain forgings.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- By a score of 18 to 10 the West Point cadets defeated Bucknell this afternoon. The game was interesting from start to finish. Bucknell ended the first half with victory seemingly perched on her banner. The wind was strongly against Farnsworth when he kicked off for the soldiers.

Richard Croker sailed for Europe on the Lucania yesterday. The propellers of the big steamship began to move at 12:02 o'clock, and she moved slowly out into the stream. Mr. Croker stood about amidship on the saloon deck. He was leaning against the side entrance to the cabin gazing at the crowd on the pier.

Over two hundred members of the Thomas Hunter Association of Grammar School No. 35 celebrated their fourth annual reunion last night with a banquet at the Hotel Savoy. The meeting was really an ovation for Thomas Hunter, who for twenty years was the Principal of No. 35, which in those days, when even the best class of people made use of the public schools, boasted of being the most "bluestocking" school in the city.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 -- A mammoth consolidation of lumber companies will probably be announced within a week or ten days. Fourteen companies at least are to be included in the combination if the plans do not miscarry, and several others, making, perhaps, a total of twenty, are expected to be added.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The fifth intercollegiate trap shoot was held here on Stockton Field to-day. Teams of five men each from Yale, Princeton, Harvard, and the University of Pennsylvania were entered. Tale won by killing 203 out of a possible 250; Princeton was second, with a score of 189; Harvard third, with 163, and Pennsylvania fourth, with 160.

From The International Magazine. Shortly after pairing off the two birds will begin to build a nest, or rather to dig one out of the ground. The male bird rests his breastbone on the ground and kicks the sand out behind him. When one side is sufficiently deep he turns around and operates in like manner until a round hole about four feet in diameter and one foot deep is the result of his exertions.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $3,063,725. The banks now hold a surplus of $7,669,775 above the legal requirements.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 3 -- Three hundred years of continuous yellow fever in Santiago culminated in the terrible epidemic of 1899. In December the last case was cured, and to the everlasting credit of the intelligence, vigor, and fearlessness of the United States Army officers and Sanitary Inspectors a year has passed without a single case.

One of those kind friends Who is always searching for the infinitesimal errors exciting only to minds attuned to littleness has sent to the musical editor of this paper marked clippings of THE NEW YORK TIMES'S comments on the debut of Ossip Gabrilowitsch, and also those of The Sun, written, as perhaps this clever person did not know, by so eminent a commentator as.

In the New York City Hall there is a man who may some day rival that historian of the early Dutch settlers, Diedrich Knickerbocker. Every day finds this man hard at work collecting data. He is Martin Keese, janitor of the City Hall, who has held this position so long that the memory of man runneth not to the contrary.

From The Cornhill. It Is commonly believed that the spotted carriage dogs, once so frequently kept in England, were about the most useless creatures of the dog kind, maintained only for show and fashion. This is a mistake. They were used at a time when a traveling carriage carried, besides its owners, a large amount of valuable property, and the dogs watched the carriage at night when the owners were sleeping at country inns.

The siege train ordered from South Africa to China arrived in Cape Town on July 16, embarked on board the hired transport Antillean of Liverpool on the 18th, and we were employed night and day loading the stores and heavy ammunition until July 21; waited another day for some men coming down country to work the Vicker-Maxims.

In the household of Morris Bergner, at 568 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning all was bright and cheery. In the stove which warmed the apartments a fire crackled merrily and the family cat stretched herself gratefully before it. The members of the family were away on various errands, and for the moment all was quiet in the household.

"Here's another one o them circus ships from Singapore," remarked a weathertanned longshoreman to a comrade at Pier 44 East River yesterday morning. An improvised deckhouse amidships of the British steamship Afridi, which had just arrived from Singapore and Eastern ports, indicated the occasion of the remark.'

Some years ago Elbridge T. Gerry, the distinguished lawyer and the effective head of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, noted in one of his annual reports the injury which cheap and nasty novels, and cheap and nasty stories generally, inflicted upon juvenile minds, for which such stuff was garishly prepared by its writers.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- At the third day's racing of the Derby November meeting today American jockeys were again successful. In the Helper Selling Plate, a selling high-weight handicap at one mile, for three-year-olds and upward, the winner, L. Brassey's Charlton, was ridden by C. Jenkins, while second place went to O. Temple's Weybridge, with Rigby in the saddle, and Sir E. Vincent's Eulogy, guided by Lester Reiff, came in third.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 17 -- Gen. and Mrs. Francis V. Greene of New York were here to-day to witness the breaking of ground for their new villa on Harrison Avenue. It is to cost $100,000.

The State Republican Committee met yesterday at the headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel to choose a successor to Chairman B.B. Odell, the Republican Governor-elect. The honor fell, as was expected, to Col. George W. Dunn of Binghamton by the unanimous vote of the committee. Col. Dunn was Mr. Odell's choice for the place.

Major Haldman D.P. Young, Quartermaster United States Volunteers, will report in person to the Quartermaster General of the Army for conference on official business pertaining to the Quartermaster's Department.

Strange circumstances surround the death of Frank Lengfelt, son of S.H. Lengfelt, a broker, of 516 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, whose body was found lying beside the Long Island Railroad tracks near Collins Avenue, Maspeth, at 7:40 Tuesday morning by Charles Dow, a section foreman on the road, on his way to work.
CORNING, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Charles De Groat is under arrest charged with manslaughter in the second degree in failing to properly care for his wife, who died of typhoid pneumonia.

A good volume of business, some of which marked the successful closing of long pending negotiations, and which indicated in several instances the undertaking of new building operations, has made the last week in real estate more interesting than any of its immediate predecessors.

From The Contemporary Review. Tuberculosis is by far the most prevalent and fatal of all bacterial affections. Attacks increase susceptibility, and if anything is inherited in a consumptive family it is a predisposition, not a power of resistance. Yet the microbe is everywhere; vast numbers of people must be exposed to it every day with impunity.

Effort made yesterday to discover how the Police Commissioners will act on Bishop Potter's appeal to Mayor Van Wyck on New York's defilement by protected vice, and Mayor Van Wyck's curt interpellation of and demand for investigation by the Police Board in his letter to President York, was not rewarded.

The action taken by the National Founders' Association at their convention, held at the Murray Hill Hotel in this city last week, by which they hope to crush out the Strike of the molders at Cleveland, is the most important development of the year in the conflict between labor and capital.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The Low Coutries in the feudal time and under the Hapsburgs were governed by women more than any other part of Europe. When Queen Wilhelmina succeeded to the throne the Dutch had no Salic prejudice based on tradition. She has been from infancy the darling child of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Gen. MacArthur has reported from Manila the death of Lieut. M. Koontz, who was killed in action at Bugason, Panay, Oct. 30. Lieut. Koontz served during the Spanish-American war as First Lieutenant in the Twenty-second Kansas and was appointed a First Lieutenant of the Forty-fourth United States Volunteer Infantry, from the State of Kansas, Aug. 22, 1899.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 11 -- From Peking to Shanghai it is next to impossible to meet a European or an American who has resided any length of time in China but who believes that the real trouble has not really commenced. They bitterly reproach the powers for not being more severe in their measures, particularly for not absolutely destroying the Forbidden City at Peking.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 17 -- The first of the sanity experts called in on the Bell incendiary case arrived here to-day and held a consultation with Bell's counsel, Col. Sheffield. Afterward they both visited tne residence of Dr. Christopher M. Bell, on Bellevue Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator Cullom of Illinois said to-day that no attempt would be made to cut down the Southern representation in Congress at the coming session.

Senator Platt, Gov. Roosevelt, Governorelect Odell, and Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts took dinner together yesterday at the Lawyers' Club. After the dinner and a drive, Senator Platt talked freely on State and city politics.

Chief Devery made a personal tour last night of the so-called "Red Light" District, on the lower east side, and then visited the Eldridge Street Police Station, where he informed Capt. Herlihy that he would be transferred to the Steamboat Squad.

An unusually large number of changes were made among the leaders in the principal local bowling tournaments by the games of the past week. In the Harlem League the Standards dropped from first to third place, the Knickerbockers going to the head. In the Greater New York tournament the Queer Club replaced the Monarchs in first place.
An apartment hotel, that will represent an outlay of $2,500,000, has been projected for Brooklyn. Plans have been drawn and ground will be broken within a week or two at Willow and Clark Streets.

From Scribner's. Col. Wright Quotes the conclusion of Sydney J. Low. an authority on the English census, who makes this prediction: " If the process goes on unchecked, the Englishman of the future will be of the city but not in it. He will be a suburb dweller.

MANILA, Nov. 17 -- Two hundred bolomen, with fifty rifles, attacked Bugason, Island of Panay, Oct. 30. The Americans lost three men killed -- Lieut. H.M. Koontz, Sergt. Kitchen, and Corp. Burns, all of Company F, Forty-fourth Infantry.
Maine is mourning over the prospective loss of one of its four Congressmen under the new apportionment.

TIEN-TSIN, Oct. 24 -- The presence of a large number of troops here, in contiguous camps and with naturally existing national prejudices, is causing considerable friction, and several unpleasant incidents have occurred.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Nov. 17 -- A great legal fight is on in the Monroe County courts between the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, which furnishes power to many corporations in leading cities along the Lehigh Valley, and the large ice companies whose plants are situated in the Pocono Mountains in this county.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The controversy in the United States regarding the proposed change of the America's Cup course from off Sandy Hook to off Newport, R.I., can only be settled in one way, according to Sir Thomas Llpton's idea, and that is by sticking to the old order of things. He said to-day:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your conservative yet independent attitude in the last campaign has led a constant reader to hope that you will publish a few thoughts concerning the public weal which have agitated him until he fain would seek solace in the public print.

A Brooklyn pastor is organizing a bureau to provide work for ministers who have no charges. The Advisory Board of the bureau contains such well-known names as the Rev. David Gregg, D.D., Presbyterian: the Rev. C.L. Wells, D.D., Reformed Dutch, and the Rev. C.W.P. Rhoades, D.D., Baptist.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Nov. 17. -- The Rev. M.M. Fanton, the Trustees, and other officers of the local Methodist church are working to prevent a number of local residents from joining the faith-curist community which the Rev. Frank Sanford has organized near Shiloh, Me., under the title of "The Holy Ghost and Us Society."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In a hard fought game the Georgetown University football team to-day worsted the University of Virginia team by a score of 10 to 0. Virginia put up a strong game, but fumbled twice at critical points. Georgetown won largely through the superb kicking of Devlin.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 17 -- The contest over the will of the late Edgar E. Duryea, the starch manufacturer, came up before Judge Seabury here to-day. J. Campbell Thompson, counsel for the three daughters of Mr. Duryea, the contestants of the will, applied to the Court for the appointment of a temporary administrator for the estate pending the litigation over the will.

From The Spectator. The Shetland pony, the smallest of his race and family, the greatest prize and possession of our childhood, is now becoming quite a personage on his own account, His birthplace and bringing-up, his career and obsequies, are unique in the history of the world's domestic animals.

From The Hartford (Conn.) Times. If you wish to witness the most marvelous exhibition of agility to be seen in the New England woods, I would suggest that you go out and watch a gray squirrel making his way through the tree tops. Often as I have observed this performance. I never see it without a feeling of intense admiration and astonishment.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 17. -- Gov. J. Hoge Tyler to-day issued his official call assembling the Virginia Legislature in extraordinary session on Jan. 23. The object of bringing the General Assembly together is to make arrangements for assembling a Constitutional Convention in accordance with the results of the election of May last.

PEKING, Sept. 20 -- Commissioner Rockhills arrival, Gen. Chaffee's departure, the withdrawal of the Russian troops, continued activity by the Germans in raiding settlements within easy marching distance, the capture of the Pei-tang forts on the coast between Tong-ku and Tien-tsin, and Li-Hung-Chang's movements furnish items of simultaneous comment, although not of connected significance, except as they all bear on the situation.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- Boston had a broad and active market, the busiest of any Saturday within memory. Interest was not centred in any group of stocks, but was extended throughout the list. Investment buying or higher priced shares was notable. Amalgamated and Parrot led the mining stocks, with grains of 1 3/4, to 97 1/4, and 1 1/2, to 51, respectively.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- Pennsylvania this afternoon triumphed over the Carlisle Indians by the score of 16 to 6, but It was not such a victory as carried joy to the 15,000 spectators who had anticipated a more decisive score. At that, the game was stubbornly fought and abounded in showy plays.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The campaign is over and we can take stock of our left-over issues. The silver question is surely dead. Imperialism and militarism are not likely to be of service in another campaign. The trusts, however, are still with us, and the trust problem is no nearer solution.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- When the seventy ships now building in the yards of this country are completed and work is begun on the five new battleships and six armored cruisers for which the contracts will be let next month, the United States will have a navy of no small magnitude. The number of ships building and to be built is greater than that of any other country.

Yesterday's market for outside securities developed much activity, wnich was accompanied by sufficient strength to bring about a number of gains more or less substantial. The trading was larger than on any Saturday within recent months, and the total transactions were probably larger than those of some of the less active days earlier in the week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 17 -- One of the best football games which ever took place in Annapolis was played here to-day between Columbia and the naval cadets, and the former won by a score of 11 to 0. All of Columbia's scoring was done in the first half. Weekes made two touch-downs and Bruce kicked one goal.

From The Ninteenth Century. In China it is freely stated that the principal cause of the widespread dislike to missionaries, especially the Roman Catholic, is their interference in lawsuits and practical coercion of the Yamens on behalf of their converts. But such statements must be received with reserve in a country where such assertions are not easily verified, and missionary jealousies are not unknown.

As an evidence of how far extravagant elegance may be carried, a Chambers Street dealer in builders' hardware displays in his windows doorknobs and knockers heavily plated in gold and elaborately finished with hand carvings. There is no fire-gilt about it, but heavy gold plating. These are said to have been made for a residence now building out on Long Island for one of "the Hempstead set."
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17. -- A violin said to bear every evidence of being a genuine Stradivarius, has been found in Leake County, Miss.

When the sixteenth annual exhibition of the National Horse Show Association opens to-morrow in the Madison Square Garden there will be seen in the stables and upon the tanbark the largest number of finely groomed animals that have ever been brought together in this popular feature of New York's social life.

No view of irrigation can be appreciative which regards it as merely an adjunct to agriculture. It is a social and economic factor in a much larger way. It not only makes a civilization in the midst of desolate wastes; it shapes and colors that civilization after its own peculiar design. It forbids land monopoly, because only the small farm pays when the land must be artificially watered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest the articles and letters I have seen in THE TIMES regarding the overthrow of Tammany. I note particularly a letter this morning from Mr. J.W. Watts. Nobody is more interested than I am in the overthrow and downfall of Tammany and "Dick" Croker.

The annual report of Dean James Harvey Robinson of Barnard College has been put in the hands of the printers and will make its appearance some time next month. In his report Dean Robinson speaks as follows of Barnard's new position in the university system of Columbia:

A great opportunity and a grave responsibility are now presented to the leading citizens of New York. RICHARD CROKER has caused the appointment of a committee from Tammany Hall "to act with any citizens or committee of citizens for the purpose of investigating the moral conditions of the city and for receiving suggestions for the correction of abuses, the committee to have the full power of the organization to act."

Lord Russell always seemed to me to enjoy himself more at a race meeting than anywhere else. He was as keen about racing as he was about everything else to which he turned his mind. Many are the strolls we have taken together on the heath in, the early morning hours. I was often amazed by the store of racing information he had not only picked up but regained in his memory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's issue of your paper I read what many have known for years was surely to befall the poor natives of Alaska. And more than a passing notice, I think, should be given to the article headed "Census Report of Alaska,"

Yiddish and Chinese theatres considered in the balance, American can hardly show a stranger and more picturesque playhouse than this, the dramas of the dolls (for great dolls they are) of Palermo and Naples brought into the heart of New York. The great Italian colonies of the metropolis cause the marionettes to flourish.
Flora McDonald Thompson in The North American Review.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- To New York State must be given the credit for obtaining the original historical documents relating to this section which have for many generations been in the archives of Holland. The acquisition of these records from the Classis of Amsterdam is the State's latest achievement.

Harry Vardon added a large measure of fame yesterday to the public links at Van Cortlandt Park and gave from 2,000 to 2,500 persons an opportunity to witness championship golf of the first quality. If any further justification of the popularity of golf on the public links were needed it was given once and for all yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent failures of W.L. Strong Co. of New York City and C.H. F. H. Stott of Stottville, Columbia County, N.Y., to my mind point to a very serious business moral, to wit, the ratings of business concerns quoted by the various mercantile agencies.

Rear Admiral Crowninshield's report that the desertions from the navy for the year numbered 2,452 has not created much surprise among officers who are familiar with the customs which for many years have obtained in the navy regarding enlistments and desertions.

Judge W.G. Hawkins, in Orphans' Court, handed down an interesting opinion Nov. 5, deciding a point of law raised in a will case. He dismisses the idea that a testator's clause in a will to the effect that a contestant shall be cut off as a legatee by reason of an action in contesting always stands.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Football at secondary schools and academies has received the unqualified and almost unanimous sanction of the Principals and Deans of the affiliated schools of the University of Chicago. At the fourteenth annual educational convention of the schools the question of football in the preparatory institutions was discussed at length by 120 educators from all parts of the country, including the Chicago High Schools.

MR. STEAD AND HIS MANAGER OF THE REVIEW OF REVIEWS. -- A judgment awarded to William C. Gates for over $8,000 on the trial before a referee of his suit to recover damages from William T. Stead for breach of contract to employ him as business manager of The Review of Reviews, has been affirmed by the Appellate Division of the First Department.

The College Entrance Examination Board for the Middle States and Maryland met in the Trustees' Room, at Columbia University, yesterday. The meeting was for the purpose of perfecting a permanent organization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am delighted with the prospect of seeing the "ideal" daily paper which the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst and his rich backers propose to set up in New York. I shall take it if I have to pay $1 a copy for it. If it prove to be the genuine thing, I shall ask the few millionaires whom I know to join me in booming it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In spite of the general rejoicing over Richard Franklin Pettigrew's defeat for the United States Senate, the fact is generally recognized that the Senate will not be so interesting a place when he has packed his grip and gone back to South Dakota. Even the Republican Senators will have to admit that life is shorn of much of its excitement.

The accident on the Southern Railway at Oakman, Ala., was in many respects very singular. An engine with some bridge crew cars was switching at the east end of the main line siding, having come out of the Coal Valley spur. While thus engaged a through freight going west came thundering along and hit it.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- Felix J. Hughes of Keokuk, Iowa, yesterday instituted proceedings before Judge Amos Thayer of the United States Circuit Court, to recover a fee for legal services amounting to $500,000 in connection with the settlement of the estate of William Wood, who owned a third interest in the Spar Mining and Smelting Company of Aspen. Col.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Money was in fair demand to-day, there was less pressure, and the borrowings from the bank eased discounts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the pauperization of Indians, as per Commissioner Jones's report, is a timely one and on a topic of interest sufficient for incisive comment. But the "ration issues," properly criticised by the Indian Commissioner, are not general in character.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 18 -- David Hennessy, sixty years old, a real estate broker, is wanted by the authorities, as they believe that he attempted to kill some members of the family of Rufus Corneill to-day. While Mrs. Lydia Corneill, her daughter Lydia, and Rufus K. Corneill, Jr., her son, were seated in the front room of their residence reading, two shots were fired into the room at close range.

PRETORIA, Nov. 18 -- The Boers are active. It is alleged that Commandant Louis Botha has established a Government at Roosendal, north of Middleburg, and that with the L150,000 which he has available he is paying the fighting burghers a crown per day.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- United States Bank Examiner Tucker to-day took possession of the German National Bank at Newport, Ky., and posted a notice that the bank would remain closed pending an examination. Examiner Tucker also announced, unofficially, that Frank M. Brown, the individual bookkeeper and assistant cashier, was missing, and that a partial investigation showed that Brown was short about $201,000.

Dr. Levy, a Harlem Hospital ambulance surgeon, was transferring two patients from the hospital to Bellevue yesterday afternoon when they set upon him, one looking for a bicycle lamp, which he wanted to attach to himself, believing himself to be a bicycle, and the other looking for pink monkeys.

As overture to the opening to-day of the sixteenth annual Horse Show, in Madison Square Garden, under the auspices of the National Horse Show Association, about 300 guests were entertained at a luncheon in the restaurant of the Garden yesterday afternoon, with the Directors of the National Horse Show Association as hosts.

A preliminary meeting was held yesterday afternoon in Liederkranz Hall to make arrangements for the German charity ball, which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 31. The following officers were elected for 1901:

The American Dramatists' Club held their annual dinner at Sherry's last night. The general purpose of the occasion, "to honor the American drama," was manifest in the speeches, which took on a character of optimism and general rejoicing at the progress that has been made by native dramatists.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The German Boerses began last week with a strong rise in values, which was not wholly maintained later, although the situation remained strong. "The Boerses were almost completely under New York influence," remarks the Frankfurter Zeitung, "and a fear is now frequently expressed in commercial circles that the dependence of Europe upon America in business matters will strongly increase."

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A man strolling down Throgmorton Street, our equivalent to Wall Street, any afternoon last week, ignorant of the city's business ways, might easily have come to the conclusion that the lower end of it had fallen into the possession of a mob of bedlamites let loose.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 18 -- A public mass meeting was called this afternoon to express the horror and indignation of Denver at the burning at the stake of the ne- gro murderer Porter by the Limon mob.

Cross-country running is a comparatively new sport at the colleges, but the popular- ity it has acquired and its importance in the cycle of inter-collegiate athletics will be demonstrated at Morris Park on Saturday, Dec. 1, when teams from all the big colleges will compete in the second annual meet of the Inter-Collegiate Cross-Country Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Within the last week I have seen in your paper two interesting letters advocating the study of Plato's "Republic." Will you allow a third person to suggest a careful comparative study of the "noblest pagan's" ideal republic and Christ's ideal of the earthly kingdom of God?

In reflecting upon the failures and defalcations that are just now or recently have been the subject of much comment in this city, the character of the bookkeeping done for the unfortunate firms and corporations at once impresses itself upon the mind. Now, bookkeeping worthy of the name is a science absolutely exact.

The following is a list of bonds which do not appear in their proper alphabetical order in the "Complete Bond Quotation List" on Pages 4 and 5, but are here so arranged. Opposite each is placed the name of the system under which they are given in the table referred to:

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I trespass on your space with one more word, this time in answer to "An American," who is surprised that I sympathize with the Filipinos, although some of them occasionally commit atrocities. All wars are accompanied by atrocities, nor is this one an exception.

In many pulpits in this city yesterday and at other religious meetings the subject of the wide dissemination of vice and the appeal of Bishop Potter for its repression in one particular section were referred to more or less at length. In some cases the incumbents devoted their sermons to a discussion of means of reform, in others the matter was taken up after the delivery of the Sunday discourse, or in answer to questions.

Both Senator PLATT and Senator CULLOM have announced a part of the programme for the next session of Congress, which will begin two weeks from to-day. Both agree that the Ship Subsidy bill will be passed.

MANILA, Nov. 18 -- Capt. Bowman H. McCalla of the United States cruiser New- ark is undergoing trial by court-martial convened by Admiral Remey. He is charged with "irrational and bad management and lack of discipline" on board the cruiser.

The memorandum which the Governor has made public as to the course taken by him, by the authors of the charges against the Mayor, and by the Mayor, is certainly required in the interest of truth and fair dealing.

Miss Helen Gould's philanthropy is the cause of much annoyance to her in the form of thousands of letters received from persons in all parts of the United States who have schemes, charitable and otherwise, to promote. At first she replied to them, but since the Spanish war the number of letters has been overwhelming.

Following are the returns or foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:
An open letter on the Chinese situation by Dr. W.A.P. Martin, President of the new Imperial University of Peking, has been sent to the newspapers of New York City. This is the letter:

There was just enough rain yesterday morning to put the Speedway in prime condition for what proved to be one of the liveliest mornings on the road this Fall. About every trotter and pacer of note in the city was out, and the consequence was a series of brushes of unusual interest and merit.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Gov. Roosevelt has prepared the following memorandum on the charges against Mayor Van Wyck of New York City in the Ice Trust matter:

In the great work of education that is in progress on the east side, the Educational Alliance, formerly the Hebrew Institute, plays a conspicuous part. In every one of its many ramifications it lives up strictly to its name, the leaders as well as the led recognizing that education is the fountain head from which the salvation of the densely populated centres must inevitably spring.

Conditions in the market for outside securities during the past week were somewhat more complicated than those which governed the course of prices during the preceding week, and in consequence the market moved with more irregularity. The general trend of prices, however, was an upward one, and at the close many substantial advances appeared.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Virginia has handed down a decision which would seem to be an extremely tardy judicial recognition of the obvious fact that a married woman living with her husband may be the head of the family. The appellant, a Mrs. RICHARDSON of Plum Point, Va., was Postmistress of the village and conducted a general store.
