LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 -- The Louisville and Clay City Banks have long since charged off notes of Francis D. Carley for $31,000 as dead assets.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- "It is rumored," wires the P. king correspondent of The Morning Post, "that a Spring expedition to Sian-Foo is already being discussed, as the outcome of the probable failure of the peace negotiations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 18 -- The Russian official world is anxious regarding the condition of Emperor Nicholas, but there is a feeling of confidence that he will recover. A Foreign Office official told a correspondent last evening that the bulletins were regarded as favorable.

OSWAYO, Penn., Nov. 18 -- Four men were burned to death in a fire which to-day destroyed the McGonigal House, a three-story frame building, the hotel barn, and the Opera House. The three buildings were burned to the ground in half an hour from the time the fire started.
Discussing railway conditions and the outlook for the future, Vice President Oppenheim of Chicago Great Western says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Andrew Carnegie has announced that he will build a technical school in connection with the institute at Pittsburg that bears his name and will give it an endowment ot $1,000,000. Further, his tone is taken to imply that he will increase his contribution later to meet the needs of the school.

A material change in the outward appearance of the "Red Light" district of the east side was effected yesterday. The coming of Capt. Titus, who succeeded Capt. Herlihy of the Eldridge Street Police Station, wrought the transformation -- a transformation that will hold at least for a time if the utterances of Capt. Titus bear fruit.

Elaborate and impressive services marked the reopening yesterday of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church in old Westchester Village, which, as recalled in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, was ruined in a mysterious fire on Aug. 16, 1899, and has been restored at a cost of $35,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The report of Commissioner of Navigation Chamberlain, made public to-day, says the past fiscal year has been the most prosperous period known to American shipping for some years. Returns for the current fiscal year promise an even more satisfactory record.

LIMON, Col., Nov. 18 -- After being notified that some fragments of pones of a human being had been found on the prairie near where John Porter was burned at the stake, Coroner Brown, and a jury summoned by him gathered up the "remains" and held an inquest.

The unexpectedly favorable bank statement of Saturday and the continuing ease both in call and in time money are striking proofs of the correctness of the views held by representative bankers, and from time to time quoted in these columns, that fear of a money stringency was not well grounded.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Count Kanitz, Dr. Lieber, and other prominent members of the Reichstag have given notice of a bill to amend the tariff law by empowering a levy, under imperial decree and with the approval of the Bundesrath, of ad valorem duties on dutiable goods from countries where German goods are subjected to similar levies, provided that the terms of existing treaties are not thereby violated.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Local ice dealers believe that by recently securing control of the Knickerbocker Ice Company of this city, the American Ice Company intends to get a monopoly of the ice business in Newark. Thomas S. Hussey, a stockholder in the American Ice Company, has succeeded James P. Ross as manager in the office of the Knickerbocker Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: O, what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withall! If Mr. Croker thinks he is "fooling" any sane or decent person by his farewell address to his bosom friends on the eve of his departure for Carlsbad and Wantage he is mistaken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a healthful sign of the popular feeling to see the interest already developed in the approaching campaign against Tammany, but it is not pleasant to see the determined effort that is being made to inject partisan issues, of which the letter of Mr. J.W. Watts in your issue of the 16th is a striking example.

William Mitchell Bunker, Honorary Commissioner of Foreign Commerce of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, arrived in this city, yesterday morning on the Umbria with his wife. He had made a 35,000-mile trip through Siberia and Europe without the slightest accident, and never missed a connection.

MANILA, Nov. 18 -- (First Uncensored News by Cablegram Since the American Occupation.) -- Last week witnessed a very considerable increase in rebel and American activity in the field. Many skirmishes occurred, and several small engagements in Northern and Southern Luzon. The termination of the rains permits a resumption of operations on both sides.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Francis D. Carley, the well-known Wall Street operator, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy at Trenton, N.J., yesterday. His liabilities were placed at $1,000,000; assets, nothing. The principal creditors named in the schedule are Inman, Swann Co. and J. Kennedy Tod Co. of New York City and Mrs. Carley, his wife; the agrgegate of their claims is about $900,000, of which $509,575 was loaned by Mrs. Carley.

The twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, last night was marked by an address to the clergy on doctrines and duties by St. Clair McKelway, in the course of which he said:

Congressman George W. Ray, Chairman of the House Committee on Judiciary, who was one of the leaders in the fight for the Porto Rican Tariff bill, said yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel that until the test case brought to determine the constitutionality of the Porto Rican tariff was decided by the United States Supreme Court, there would be no legislation by Congress for the Philippines.

The Kentucky and Tennessee Board of Fire Underwriters has rejected the proposition of the Governing Committee of the Western Union to abrogate the fire insurance rates on whisky in bonded warehouses. This step was proposed on the ground that there has been a persistent payment of excess commissions in Covington and Newport.
NEWPORT, Ky., Nov. 19 -- The following notice was posted on the doors of the German National Bank of Newport before the hour for opening this morning:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The senior elections were held at Rutgers this morning. Valentine G. Feind of Newark was made a member of the Self-Governing Board, and was appointed to deliver the annual address to the President on class day. Other appointments were: Master Orator -- D.F. Burnet, Newark; Pipe Orator -- J.C. Garrabrandt, Orange; Tree Orator -- John Fry, Newark; Tree Planter -- William Westfall, Newark.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Morning Post's Peking correspondent, wiring Saturday, says:

Substantial help will be given to the public schools of Galveston, Texas, by the teachers and pupils of the public schools of this city. The storm which desolated Galveston destroyed the schools and school supplies of that city, and an appeal for assistance was made to the public school sys- tems of the various cities throughout the country in order that the schools may be rebuilt and new books and other supplies purchased.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- The will of Ambrose McGregor, who died a few weeks ago at Oriental Point, has been admitted to probate. The value of the estate is placed at $4,500,000. The will was executed at Oriental Point on Jan. 27, 1897, and was witnessed by Alice M. Wheeler and A.H. Wheeler of Mamaroneck and Joshua M. Fiero of New York.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals to-day sustained the decisions of the Chancery Court in all three of the cases of Robert P. Lister and others against William R. Weeks of the Lister Chemical Works, growing out of the sale of that concern to the American Agricultural Chemical Company.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 19 -- The skeleton of a man was found this afternoon in Strong's Swamp, four miles west of Babylon. It is believed to be that of Jesse Muncy, who disappeared on the evening of Dec. 22 last.

A long article published by The Tribune on Sunday detailed with much force and entire accuracy the dangers and discomforts to which, now as for years past, the Manhattan Railway Company willfully subjects every one of the many thousand passengers who traverse during the crowded hours the narrow platform of the City Hall station.

Major Thomas Bell, for many years a leading Republican of Kings County, died on Sunday evening at his home, 151 Berkeley Place, Brooklyn, of cerebral hemorrhage. Major Bell was an Inspector of Customs of this port and was well known in Grand Army circles throughout the State.

After hunting for nearly a year, Detective John McKirdy of the Atlantic Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, yesterday succeeded in running down William Seamon, who is accused of holding up Henry Athing, a clerk in the office of the Prudential Insurance Company, at 85 Borden Avenue, Long Island City, at the point of a revolver, and robbing the office of $800.

Coroner's Physician Hamilton Williams performed an autopsy on the body of "Miss Edith Booth," who died in St. Vincent's Hospital Sunday. He found a very bad fracture of the skull and a laceration of the brain tissue. The young woman's parents are very indignant over the treatment which they alleged she received at the hands of hospital surgeons after she was injured.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The Chamber of Deputies at the afternoon session to-day discussed the alleged decorations scandal, the reactionary press having hinted for several days past at an unpleasant exposure regarding trafficking in decorations. Finally it was said that Jean Decrais, son of the Minister of the Colonies, had received 20,000f, for his influence to secure a Cross of the Legion of Honor for Edward Drumont, proprietor of La Libre Parole.

The freight rate situation in trunk line territory continues in excellent shape. Chairman Goddard of the Trunk Line Association declared yesterday that there was not the slightest cause for complaint, and this was substantiated by the agents of the various trunk lines. Rates out of New England, however, are badly demoralized, as they have been for some time, but they have not so far affected the Trunk Line situation.

Columbia honor men for the academic year 1899-1900 have been announced. The honors assigned are of two sorts, the highest general honors, which are awarded to students whose work in the previous college year entitles them to high academic distinction, and general honors, which are assigned to students of marked excellence who do not receive highest general honors.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 19 -- The Indians returned from the University of Pennsylvania game feeling a little sore, but in good shape to begin a week of hard practice before the Washington and Jefferson game at Pittsburg.

The stock market yesterday had to stand the test of enormous realizing sales in addition to pressure from room traders who, not profiting by recent experiences, worked during the day to bring about a reaction in the hope that they might be able to buy in stocks at a lower level.

If there is anything in a name, people who have political interests can easily suit themselves in chrysanthemums this Fall. At the Central Park Chrysanthemum Show opening there was a white William J. Bryan, which is probably still in blossom, and at a later chrysanthemum show there ere a number of other political chrysanthemums.

Athletic officiate from every part of the country gathered at the Astor House yesterday morning in attendance upon the annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union. The session began at 11 o'clock in the morning and continued until 8 o'clock in the evening, with a recess of an hour at noon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Coal development on ail extensive scale may take an investment of $23,000,000 in this State in the next twelve months. Purchases of coal lands and options, both in the soft and hard coal fields, have been proceeding very briskly since the election. The New York Central, the Pennsylvania, and the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg are the railroads principally interested.
Two stock brokerage houses made assignments yesterday, a Consolidated Exchange firm did not meet its Clearing House obligations, and one suspension was announced on the New York Stock Exchange.

"Esmeralda," an opera in four acts, was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time in the United States. The libretto of this work was arranged by Alberto Randegger, the well-known London singing teacher, and the verses were written and partly adapted from the French by Theodore Marzials.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Money was easy to-day, and supplies increased presumably on Government disbursements of the sum paid up for Exchequer bonds and Treasury bills Thursday. A large amount, estimated at u1,000,000, was repaid to the Bank of England to-day. Discounts were weakened by the easier condition at New York, and the favorable bank return.

A number of residents and property owners of that section of the Borough of Queens culled Union Terrace, which is situated east of Dexter Park, have drawn up and signed a petition and submitted it to the Health Department in Jamaica as follows:

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against David M. Williams, doing business as David M. Williams Co., who has a large department store at the corner of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. The petition was filed by Myers, Goldsmith Bronner for three creditors -- the H.B. Claflin Company, $3,573; Wolfers, Goldberg Co., $78, and Rosa Selonick, $437.

QUESTION OF DEDICATION OF LAND FOR STREETS -- Gouverneur Morris, who owned a large tract of land in the region then known as East Morrisania, in 1853 filed a map or it, upon which the different streets were indicated, among others Uncas and Pontiac Streets. Between 1853 and 1857 Benjamin Whitlock purchased various parcels of this land, and during or prior to 1873 John McConville acquired all the land there previously held by Mr. Whitlock.

NEW ORLEANS Nov. 19 -- The sale of the New Orleans and Western Railroad and its Port Chalmette terminals and warehouses was postponed again to-day on account of no bidders. This is the second postponement, the upset price formerly being $1,600,000. Later it was reduced to $600,000. A further reduction probably will be asked.

There is really little going on in the social world of New York during Horse Show week outside of the Garden, where the show is held, and the fashionable hotels and restaurants, and the rule this year in this regard promises to have no exception. The Waldorf, Sherry's, and Delmonico's were crowded, save for two or three hours in the afternoon, from an early hour in the morning.

Considering its importance as an accumulation of population, thrift, industry, and all the material things that go to help along civilization, the Territory of Oklahoma commands admiration both for its progress and its modesty. The history of this newest of our domestic political organizations has all been made in eleven years.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Kemp have closed their season and returned to New York for the Winter.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 19 -- To-night Steve Brodie of New York arrived in St. Louis. Brodie, accompanied by his family, is on his way to Texas, where he proposes to purchase a ranch and spend the remaining days of his life. He stopped over in St. Louis to see Mrs. Brady, widow of "Ben" Brady, who had long been a warm friend of his.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The prompt action of Katie Stciner, the fifteen-year-old daughter of Philip Steiner, of 243 Hawthorne Avenue, this city, probably saved the lives of her own family and of families in three adjoining houses before daylight this morning.

In annual homage to the horse, smart New York yesterday connected Madison Square Garden to the shrine of the ruling spirit for one week, and made the opening of the sixteenth exhibition of the National Horse Show Association of America so conspicuous a success that the promise of the remaining five days can be mentioned only in superlatives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Aroused by recent interviews with President Young of the National Baseball League, "Ban" Johnson to-day stated for the first time the positive plans of the American League. He admitted his organization had failed to renew allegiance to the National agreement, and stated positively that it neither could nor would until said agreement was changed.

By offering to pay a bonus of $2 a day to every non-union man who will go to work in the Cleveland foundries the National Founders' Association hopes to break the power of the Molders' Union and defeat the men who have gone on strike for an increase of 10 cents per day in their wages.

We printed yesterday a summary of an open letter on China from the Rev. W.A. P. MARTIN, whose long residence in China gives special weight to his opinion. The conclusion of the whole matter is, in Dr. MARTIN'S judgment and in his own words, that "the readiest road to peace and order is the restoration of the young Emperor."

Condemnation of the Roman Catholic Church marked the proceedings of the General Missionary Committee at its forenoon session yesterday at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church. The committee, which is composed of the Bishops and leading ministers of the Methodist Episcopal Church in America, has been in session daily since last Wednesday.
A.L. Mordecai Sons have sold for William Finn to the Central Realty Company 109 to 113 West Forty-fifth Street, a plot 60 by 100, on which the buyers will erect a bachelor apartment house.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Boston has had another great day in the stock market. American Telephone was up 1, at 156 1/2. Arcadian lost 2, to 21, rallied to 21 1/2, and closed at 23. Montana held at 320@323. Butte rose 8, to 84, but closed at 81. Eureka was 3/4 lower, at 26. Centennial receded 1/2, to 21 1/4, and later fell to 20, closing at 20 1/2.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Wallace Van Doorn, a builder, of 48 West Forty-third Street, New York City, is confined to his bed at his home here, and unless an operation to relieve the injury to the optic nerve, which is paralyzed, is successful, he will suffer from impairment of the eyesight, and perhaps be blind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Springlike weather prevailed to-day, bringing out another large crowd to the Bennings race track. There was a well-filled card, although some scratching had taken place from the entries announced Saturday. Track in good condition and the speculation was brisk.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Julius Neumann, a cooper of 34 Elizabeth Street, this city, told a story that sounded like the plot of a novel when he appealed to-day to City Clerk Connelly for aid in securing his rights.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 -- Much speculation was indulged in to-day as to the significance attached to the changes made in the Directorate of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad at its annual meeting to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- E.J. Ratcliffe, leading man of the Imperial Stock Company, will sever his connection with the theatre on Dec. 8. Manager Giffen gave him notice to that effect Sunday night after the performance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The China negotiations have reached a most serious stage. The actions of the powers are making partition almost inevitable. The United States is now face to face with the probability that it will either have to take a slice of China or go without any indemnity.
Transfers in the Tenth Cavalry; Capt. Levi P. Hunt, from Troop H to Troop K; Capt. Robert D. Read, Jr., from Troop K to Troop H.

Tammany tactics are attracting the ridicule and denunciation even of the papers that have been lately co-operating with Tammany. The Journal and The World vie with each other in this direction, the former being for the moment a little the more emphatic and direct. A number of the minor leaders in Tammany itself are openly cynical in their treatment of the movement started by Mr. CROKER.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Red Star Line steamer Friesland, Capt. Nickols, from New York Nov. 7 for Southampton and Antwerp, passed Scilly at 8:40 this morning disabled in tow of the British steamer Cluden, Capt. Trattles, from Newport News, Nov. 1, for Rotterdam. The Friesland's rudder was damaged.

The sixteenth annual Horse Show, which opened yesterday at the Madison Square Garden, from the social viewpoint promises to again be a show place for gowns, furs, and jewels and a school of instruction for milliners and dressmakers from the large cities of the country outside of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it not somewhat Quixotic to speak of an "ideal" newspaper, inasmuch as in this application the use of the word ideal is paradoxical. Ideal, as applied herein, really means, "of such perfection as to be practically unattainable."
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- Eugene Zimmerman, father of the new Duchess of Manchester, said to-night:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Standard this morning, in an editorial reference to yesterday's meeting, which was organized for the purpose of exposing alleged unfair tices said to be indulged in by certain American horseman, says:

When the Joint High Commission having in charge all the questions open between the United States and Canada dropped its work last year it was be- cause there was apparently no possibility of reaching an agreement as to the Alaska boundary. There were several other matters under discussion as to which a conclusion acceptable to both sides might have been attained.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Among the callers on the President to-day was Prof. Albert Bushnell Hart, head of the division of history and political science at Harvard University. He was introduced by Secretary Long, and his purpose was to present plans of a committee which has been organized to obtain and publish the facts relative to the Philippine problem.
Senator Chauncey M. Depew has for several years been elected President of the Republican Club unanimously. The report is that he will not accept a renomination because of unexpected opposition.
BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- In the Reichstag to-day Count von Bulow, the Imperial Chancellor, made an important declaration in regard to Germany's policy in China.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- An inspection of the register of the Marylebone Parish Church shows that the report of the marriage of the Duke of Manchester to Miss Helena Zimmerman of Cincinnati is true.
There were a number of highway robberies in the district of the Oak Street Police Station early yesterday morning.

Trading was very active in a number of outside stocks yesterday, and some substantial advances resulted from the day's transactions. In the general list, however, there was a good deal of irregularity, and, though the market was more active, it very much resembled that of the closing days of last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although I am not a resident of New York City, perhaps you will allow me as an American interested in popular government, to reply in your columns to the letter of Mr. J.W. Watts, published in your issue of Nov. 16.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 19 -- The action brought by heirs of the late Hannah A. Davis of Rocky Point against Allen F. Davis of Port Jefferson, to set aside a deed given by the deceased to Davis a short time before her death for 100 acres of the most valuable part of her farm, came up for a final hearing before Justice Smith on Saturday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 19 -- A chattel deed of trust was filed at the City Hall to-day conveying the property of the American Baseball and Athletic Exhibition Company, commonly known as the St. Louis Baseball Club, to Attorney John N. Edwards, to hold in trust for M. Stanley Robison, Treasurer of the club, in consideration of a loan of $48,500.

Commissioner Dalton of the Department of Water Supply is fearful that in freezing weather the Borough of the Bronx will have a water famine. He wants to spend $80,000 without public bidding, and says that the emergency is so serious that not a day's delay should be allowed by the city. He sent a letter yesterday to the Municipal Assembly on the subject.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House, under the Chairmanship of Mr. PAYNE of this State, is in session at Washington, with the support of the President, preparing a bill to be introduced as soon as Congress meets and to be pressed to passage, reducing " war taxes."

The New York State Conference of Religion held its first public session in New York City last night at the Church of the Holy Communion. Twentieth Street and Sixth Avenue, there being present in the audience representatives of eleven different denominations, including Jew and Gentile.

The General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been in session since last Wednesday in St. Paul's Church in West End Avenue closed its labors yesterday, the Bishops and representatives sitting, with brief recesses for lunch and supper, from 9:30 A.M. until midnight.

The Horse Show, always elusive to the general public, improved a bit on its record yesterday and last night. Again there was a crowd and again there was a flare of light, blaring music, the chatter of many tongues, and the unending circle of promenaders around the show ring, but differing far from the scene of the opening day and night.
Next time Joseph F. Wilson of Commissioner Keating's ofice feels like playing practical jokes on reporters he will consider the consequences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Commander Luclen Young, Captain of the Port of Havana, has called for proposals for removing the wreck of the Maine from the bottom of Havana Harbor. The bids will be opened Dec. 15 next. The contractor will be allowed until April 1 next to remove the material, and must engage to use no explosives in the removal.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20 -- Mrs. C.H. Baldwin closed her villa Snug Harbor to-day and went to New York for the Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Wu-Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister to the United States, who arrived here last night from Washington, delivered an address to-night before the American Academy of Political and Social Science. Mr. Wu, who has made frequent trips to Philadelphia, but had never seen the sights of the city, was taken on a tour of observation to-day by members of the Academy.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The debate on the Government's policy in China was continued in the Reichstag to-day. Herr Bassermann, National Liberal, indorsed the Government's policy and expressed the gratification of his party at the Anglo-German agreement.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The War Office has received the following telegram from Field Marshal Count Von Waldersee:

The Trustees of the Atlantic Trust Company and of the Bankers' Trust Company at separate meeting's yesterday adopted a form of agreement, the effect of which is to consolidate the two companies under the title and charter of the Atlantic Trust Company. The stockholders of the two companies will vote on Dec. 10 on the merger agreement.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against Julius Engel and Bernard Heller, surviving partners of Engel. Heller Co., wholesale liquor merchants, at 20 and 31 First Avenue, corner of Second Street, by the following creditors: Corn Exchange Bank, $4,300; National Broadway Bank.

Representatives of all the prominent newspapers or the United States have gathered in this city ready to attend the annual meeting of the Associated Press, which is to be held to-day at the Assembly Hall in the Presbyterian Building at 156 Fifth Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- While advancing years is given by Dr. Daniel C. Gilman as a reason for the announcement to-day of his determination to resign as President of Johns Hopkins University after a quarter of a century of service in that capacity, the chief cause is believed to be the financial condition of the university.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your dispatch from New Haven, published Nov. 16, states that the important collection of antiquities from Abydos, just received at the Peabody Museum of Yale, was presented by the Connecticut members of the American Archaeological Association.

Is it not true that at the election of Nov. 6 the people sanctioned and approved the Isthmian Canal policy of the Administration as embodied in the Hay-Pauncefote treaty? The candidacy of Mr. BRYAN and the loud voices of anti-imperialism made the security of our financial system and the maintenance of our authority in the Philippines the chief issues of the campaign.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20. -- This afternoon Judge Baker of the District Court granted an application for the committal to the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum of Denniston M. Bell, charged with having set fire to the bathing pavilion at Bailey's Beach.

Chicago has a canal from Lake Michigan to the Illinois River, constructed at an expense of $33,000,000, to carry the waters of the lake back from the point of intake of Chicago's water supply in such volume as to protect that supply from contamination by the sewage that had become so serious a pollution as increasingly to endanger the health of a million and a half of people.

By an instrument filed for record in the Register's office yesterday Simon Dessauer transfers to Howard R. Deacon for a consideration of $5,000 all his title in a legacy of $10,000 from the estate of Gottfeb Dessauer.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 20 -- Secretary Root and Gen. Wood, with the members of their party, took a train at 6 o'clock this morning to Daiqulrl, and returned to this city on horseback, following the route of the army in the Summer of 1898.
The New York Clearing House exchanges yesterday were the largest in the history of the Clearing House, which is forty-seven years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Constabulary bill threatened by Thomas C. Platt, It occurs to me, would be rubbing in bosses up to the last point of endurance. What has Mr. Platt ever done for the citizens of this metropolis to warrant this assumption of power? Is he not as responsible as Tammany for the present immoral conditions of the city? Indeed, he is wholly responsible.

Bishop Potter will not deal with the Police Department in the matter of vicious conditions in the Pro-Cathedral district, or in relation to insults offered last September to the Rev. Robert L. Paddock of the Pro-Cathedral, and another clergyman by Inspector Cross and Capt. Herlihy. He will deal solely with the Mayor of New York.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The decision of the Court of Errors and Appeals affirming the judgment in the case of Van Mater versus Lucas, filed yesterday at Trenton, disposes of a long case, involving only the ownership of two cows, worth at most $100, but which has been carried through every tribunal in New Jersey except the Court of Chancery.

Sarah Bernhardt and M. Constant Coqueuin arrived in this city yesterday morning on the French steamer L'Aquitaine. With them as part of their company were some sixty persons, fifty-two of whom were declared to be artists. Mme. Bernhardt was taken immediately upon landing to the Savoy Hotel, where quarters had been prepared for her several day's ago.
ALBANY. Nov. 20. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision granting a new trial to Dr. Samuel F. Kennedy, the New York City dentist, convicted of the murder of Emeline C. Reynolds.

Buoyancy ruled in the stock market yesterday, with advancing quotations, some of them substantial, appearing very generally in the list. In the early morning room traders undertook to renew their bear campaign of the day previous, but their efforts were without avail, the buying orders for investment and commission house account being so enormous that all the stocks offered, including the usual profit-taking sales, were readily absorbed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee met to-day to consider a measure for the reduction of the war revenue tax. The most important action taken was a decision not to remove the tax of 10 cents a pound on tea. The committee will not take up or disturb the tariff on imports, as, the members say, it would open up the whole subject of tariff revision.

William Ficklen, a contractor, who lives at the Hotel Vendome, and is now setting a portion of the curb on Broadway, following the asphalt paving, borrowed $100 from "The People's Storage Company." 244 West Twenty-ninth Street. At the end of two months a demand of $204 was made for the return of the security deposited.

Members of the Chamber of Commerce and their guests to the number of nearly 400 attended the banquet at Delmonico's last night to celebrate the one hundred and thirty-second annual dinner of the Chamber.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 20 -- Three squash racquet courts were opened to-night by the Merion Cricket Club at Haverford with a match between Eustice H. Miles of England, the amateur court tennis champion of the world, and Robert Moore, professional, of the Tuxedo Club, New York. The court in which the match was played is 18 feet wide, 30 feet long, and 18 feet in height, and in consequence necessitated rapid play.

Activity in the market for outside securities yesterday was fairly well distributed througn the list, and some issues not usually active took prominent part in the day's trading. Not only was the market broad, but much strength showed, and some of the best prices seen in the present movement were recorded.

MARSEILLES, Nov. 20 -- Former President Kruger will probably land here on Thursday, instead of to-morrow. Bad weather is reported in the Mediterranean, and the Dutch cruiser Gelderland, on which he is a passenger, may hug the coast of the Gulf of Genoa in preference to heading directly for Marseilles, so as to avoid the cross seas.

-- A few cynical observers of passingevents have been inclined to find cause for irreverent amusement in the fact that New York's vice crusade, so called, was started, not by some particularly atrocious display of wickedness on the part of the city's criminals or their protectors, but by the utterance of a few insolent words addressed to two amiable clergymen.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 20 -- It now looks as it the season of French opera, at the beginning of December, will be the last in this city. Dissension among the stockholders is at the root of the trouble. One faction pleads for art for art's sake; the other wants to realize on its money investment.

Miss Lucy W. Kellen, a dressmaker, has brought an action to recover $60,000 damages from Dr. Morris Manges and Dr. Julius Rosenberg for administering chloroform to her and then operating on her against her will. The defendants have entered a general denial.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 20. -- A number of residents of this place had a perilous experience shortly after midnight last night while on their way home after having attended a theatrical performance in Elizabeth. They were in a trolley car of the Elizabeth and Westfleld Railway Company, and were crossing the bridge over the Cranford River at Cranford, when the car jumped the track and climbed up on the iron girder of the trestle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A card of six races, with some interesting finishes, entertained another good-sized crowd at the Bennings track to-day. Jockeys McCue and Burns divided honors, each landing three mounts under the wire first. In the second race, Sentry, the favorite, won by a neck, while Colonel Ballentine, a strongly backed second choice, failed to get a place.

Charged with stealing several thousand dollars worth of electric light from the Edison Electric Illuminating Company nine of the merchants and restaurant keepers of Chinatown were haled to the Centre Street Court yesterday. When arraigned before Magistrate Zeller, the courtroom, crowded with scared Celestials in multicolored costumes, resembled a fete day in Mott and Doyers Streets.
Army. Second Lieut. Robert D. Russell, Twenty-eighth Infantry, United States Volunteers, is honorably discharged, to take effect Nov. 30.
The Actors' Church Alliance gave a musical and dramatic performance last night in the Squirrel Inn Free Reading Room, at 131 Bowery, established recently by Bishop Henry C. Potter.

J.P. Hassan, according to his own statement, is the inventor of an article the possession of which is the one thing that is needed to make the home completely happy. He lays claim to the invention of a lampwick that will not burn. The inventor of "The Fire-Proof Safety Wick," in a circular explains the uses to which such a wick may be put.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Japanese Legation has received from the Foreign Office at Tokio the text of the Chinese imperial edict, dated the 13th inst., on the punishment of the anti-foreign officials. It is to the following effect:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -- The Harvard 'Varsity eleven held its last secret practice before the Yale game on Soldiers Field this afternoon. All the regular 'Varsity players were in the line-up, and all eave Ellis showed an improvement in play, Ellis took a decided slump, and was replaced early by Putnam.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Pere Marquette common was strong to-day at 30, and the preferred, which fell to 62 1/2 yesterday, was up to 65. Fort Scott common sold at 33, the 6s rose 1/4, to 112 1/4. Birmingham 4s held at 98. There was a good business in bonds, $109,000 par value selling in the forenoon. In mining stocks, Massachusetts rose 1 more, to 13 1/2.

Some peculiar circumstances came to light in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with the death in that borough on Sunday of Albert Rivington Edey, a Manhattan broker. Mr. Edey boarded at the residence of John Seymour, 121 Lincoln Place. He was found dead in his room there on Sunday afternoon.

Lawyer Alfred E. Sander yesterday applied to Justice Wilmot M. Smith, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to have the question as to the mental condition of Miss Victoria Berger passed upon by a jury, and to permit the jury to inquire into the conditions that have surrounded Miss Berger for the last four years.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration " has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Without doubt, the main importance of the speech of Count VON BUELOW, which we printed yesterday, lies in the fact that it contains the first official, or for that matter, unofficial, statement of the conditions upon which alone the world is ready to forgive the Chinese Government the barbarous treatment of foreigners to which that Government has committed itself.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Many distinguished persons who are connected with public and private charitable and correctional work in New York State, and those who take an active interest in these institutions and in charitable work generally, gathered in the Senate Chamber to-night at the first New York State Conference of Charities and Corrections.

E.A. Cruikshank Co., in conjunction with J.N. Kalley Son, have sold for Hoffman Brothers to an investor the five-story store and loft building 118 Warren Street, 23 by 90.11 by 23.2 by 90.9. The present lease of the property has until 1905 to run.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Mme. Sembrich gave a farewell performance here last night and received a great ovation. She will reorganize her company, omitting Bonci and Tavecchia, for the American tour.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 20 -- Joseph Manley, for sixteen years Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Maine Republican State Committee, to-day sent his resignation as a member of the State Committee to Byron Boyd, the Secretary, to take effect in the new year, when the incoming committee is organized.

A pathetic scene was enacted yesterday morning when Lizzie Strange, sixteen years old, pleaded with her obdurate father to take her home and to let her beg the forgiveness of her dying mother, instead of pressing his complaint, in Jefferson Market Police Court, which would result in a commitment to the House of the Good Shepherd.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Anson Phelps Stokes's new sloop, now under construction at B.F. Wood's yard, this place, from designs of Tams, Lemoine Crane, has been set in frame. The joiner work for the interior fittings is being rapidly pushed toward completion, and the launching of the yacht is looked forward to at an early date.

The unfortunate weather conditions unCoubtedly had much to do with the falling off of the fashionable element at the Garden yesterday. The hotels and restauranls, however, made up in liveliness for the comparative dullness of the show, and the theatres that suffered on Monday night from the attraction at the Garden were crowded last evening.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- The Yale 'Varsity football team went through a hard practice this afternoon, the last ten minutes of which was open to the undergraduates. The team has recovered most of its dash, and the coachers say that the men are rapidly coming to their finest condition of the year.

VICTOR, Col., Nov. 20 -- John Hays Hammond arrived here this morning and began his examination of Stratton's Independence Mine. He remained underground until noon. When asked if he admitted that the mine had been gutted, he replied:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 20 -- Delegates representing thirty-seven commercial and industrial organizations. National and local, called together to take action looking to the passage of Senate bill No. 1,439, better known as the Cullom bill, to amend the inter-State Commerce law, to-day adopted a memorial to Congress which is in part as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bishop Goodsell's raid against the Roman Catholics is entirely uncalled for Keep your own door clean before you interfere with your neighbor. How long have the Roman Catholics been in existence? How long the Episcopalians? How long the Baptists? How long the Methodists? How long the Dutch Reformed? How long the Lutheran? How long the Jewish religion?

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 20 -- The Ministers have been intrusted with the conduct of current business during the present phase of the Czar's illness, each of them carrying on his department according to his personal judgment, decisions on important matters being postponed for the time being.

In connection with the American Bowling Congress, to be held at Chicago Jan. 8 to 12 inclusive, there will be held the United States championship bowling tournament, in which representative teams from all over the country will meet in competition for the National championship. Five of the leading bowling clubs of this city have already decided to enter teams, and local bowlers are confident that the National championship will come to New York.

Columbia's 'Varsity and substitute elevens fought a sensational practice game on the muddy gridiron at Columbia Field yesterday afternoon. During the first half of the game the strong second team, drilled by Coach Sanford in the formations used by the Carlisle Indians, proved almost too much for the 'Varsity.

PAUL GRAY died at his home, at 34 Clendenny Avenue, Jersey City, on Tuesday from apoplexy. He was born in Jersey City in 1835. He was active all his life in church work, first devoting himself to the welfare of Trinity Methodist Church and afterward to that of Hedding Methodist Church, an outgrowth of Trinity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- It is asserted positively at the State Department that notwithstanding Count von Bulow's assertion to the contrary, Mr. Conger, the United States Minister, has not committed this country to the alleged demands of the powers. This is not based on any report to that effect from Mr. Conger, but on the fact that his instructions absolutely pre- clude him from taking any such step.

After six weeks of secret planning for the defense of the America's Cup against Sir Thomas Lipton's second challenge, the principal details of the defense, namely those regarding the ownership and management of the new defending yacht, were yesterday made public by officers of the New York Yacht Club The new defender is to be owned by a syndicate of five club members.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 21. -- The following is the text of the official decree under which the Colombian Government directed the seizure of the British steamer Taboga, which was used to carry troops. ammunition, and provisions to Buenaventura, then besieged by the insurgents:

In his speech at the Chamber of Commerce dinner Senator DEPEW spoke up like a man for the purification of the city. "The people who stand for order, for decency, for the family, and the home," he said, "will find a way to unite, will find a pathway of reform, will purify and will redeem this great metropolis, and will brook no opposition to its will."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- The Harvard 'Varsity eleven held its last practice in Cambridge this afternoon, and will leave Harvard Square to-morrow morning at 8:20 for Meriden, via Springfield. At Meriden the eleven and substitutes will hold secret practice Thursday afternoon and Friday morning and afternoon.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 21 -- The most destructive storm in years passed over this State last night, resulting in large loss of life and property and injury and death to many persons. The places at which the fatalities and property damage were greatest were near Columbia, in Maury County; Nolensville, and West Harpeth, in Williamson County; Lavergne, in Rutherford County, and Lagrange, in Fayette County.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Ex-Mayor Hopkins and his friends declared to-day they are absolutely certain of organizing the Democratic State Committee and electing one of their own number Chairman as against the selection of the Harrison-Burke machine. The Hopkins following claim 23 of the 31 votes in the State Committee, and declare they have seven and possibly eight of the eleven Cook County members.
BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Poultney Bigelow made considerable fun of the Germans at the Reform Club to-night. He was speaking of "Modern Colonial Systems."

Down-town business men, brokers, clerks, and messengers in the Wall Street district were greatly excited yesterday morning by an attempted murder followed by a suicide in one of the big office buildings. John Daly, a fifteen-year-old office boy, employed in the Western Union Telegraph offices, at 16 and 18 Broad Street, was shot three times by Joseph E. Neaman, twenty-two years old, a bartender, of 41G Greenwich Street.

If the Fifty-sixth Congress is to be governed in disposing of the task of reapportioning the membership of the House of Representatives by a sense of duty similar to that which controlled the Fifty-second Congress, it will make short and simple work of the preparation and passage of a bill to adjust representation to the increased population shown by the twelfth census.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- At the Jacob yard, this place, the one class cruising raceabouts are in great demand. One of the craft has been finished as a sample model for the approval of the Manhassett Yacht Club from designs of Mr. Jacob. Guy Standing and Andrew Mack, Stephen Roach, the shipbuilder, and George Cory have orders in for these boats.

The sixth annual dinner of the New York Society of Mayflower descendants took place in the main ballroom at Delmonico's last night. Covers were laid for nearly 200 members and invited guests. The hall was superbly decorated with American and foreign flags, and with small blue banners, each bearing the name of a State.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The village of Port Elizabeth is excited over the kidnapping of Samuel Garrison, ten years old, from the public school. A well-dressed woman arrived on the morning train yesterday, and after she had held a short conversation with the lad, they disappeared. It has been learned since that they boarded a train for Philadelphia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 21. -- A severe storm prevailed during the night over northern California. Telegraphic communication was interrupted. On the east seven feet of snow was reported at Summit, but traffic has not been interrupted.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 21 -- Bagriardi, an Italian Anarchist, recently arrested in Sweden and transported to the Italian frontier, where he was delivered to the Italian police, turns out to have been at one time intimate with Bresci, the assassin of King Humbert.

The second day's session of the State Conference of Religion was well attended throughout, but the largest audience of the day was that present at All Souls' Church in the evening. The meeting began at 8 o'clock. Among those present were many of the Rev. Thomas R. Slicer's congregation and a liberal sprinkling of men and women from other denominations of the city.

The attitude of the Police Board in regard to vicious conditions in the Pro-Cathedral district and elsewhere was not changed yesterday by any action taken at Police Headquarters. President York and Commissioners Abell and Sexton were in the building in the afternoon, and a meeting of the board could have been held.

The rise and fall in the fortunes of Adolph L. Roeder were told yesterday in testimony filed in the City Court as a result of his examination in supplementary proceedings. His brother, A.B. Roeder, is married to a daughter of John E. Searles of the Sugar Trust. Adolph, according to his testimony, had an income of $250,000 a year; now his only possessions are two suits of clothes and eight shirts.

The wedding of Arthur Jarvis Slade of this city and Miss Jessica Hildreth Halsey of Newark was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Trinity Church, Newark. The bride entered the church on the arm of her father, Silas Condit Halsey, and was given away by him. Her gown was of white satin, with yoke and sleeves of Duchesse point, and a panel of the same lace ornamented the skirt.

MARSEILLES, Nov. 21 -- The Gelderland, with ex-President Kruger on board, signalled Cape Cepot, off Toulon, at 2 P.M. to-day, and continued her voyage to this port. She reported that she was delayed by a slight accident to her machinery.

The Horse Show claimed its own last night, and Madison Square Garden, blazing with light and redolent of the stable, again held the notable, handsome, and well-dressed gathering that more than the horses has been the feature of the exhibition for many years. The boxes made a gallant showing, and if all the people who occupied them were not ultra-fashionable, the brilliance of the spectacle did not suffer in the least from that cause.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 21 -- The Pennsylvania football team defeated the Naval Cadets this afternoon by a score of 28 to 6. Belknap kicked off for the Navy, and Smith ran the ball back eight yards. By a series of line plunges Wallace made the first touch-down. Hare missed an easy goal.

Wheeler H. Peckham and the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst will discuss the question of vice in this city at a public meeting to be held at Cooper Union Dec. 11. This will be the first appearance of Dr. Parkhurst on the platform since the campaign of 1894, when the late William L. Strong was elected Mayor.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- "The overthrow of Marquis Ito's Cabinet is threatened," says the Yokohama correspondent of The Daily Mail, adding:
OWENSBOROUGH, Ky., Nov. 21. -- Gov. J.W.C. Beckham of Kentucky and Miss Jean Raphael Fuqua of this city were married to-night at the First Presbyterian Church.

Senator Thomas C. Platt was conversing with Senator O.H. Platt of Connecticut and Senator N.W. Aldrich of Rhode Island at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday when a reporter called his attention to a statement that State Senator Armstrong of Monroe had said that the people of Rochester were opposed to a State constabulary measure.

The White Star liner Oceanic, which arrived from Liverpool last night, reported an exceedingly rough and squally voyage. Northwest gales, rough seas, and adverse winds were encountered throughout the entire passage. Though compelled to slow down on several occasions, the big ship reached her dock only a few hours behind her scheduled time, 6 days 8 hours and 42 minutes being the time of passage from port to port.

CONTROVERSY ABOUT GRANITE FOR THE ARMORY BUILDING. -- A recovery by Patrick Gallagher in his suit against Matthew Baird, founded upon the breach of a contract to furnish granite for the erection of the armory building at Fourth avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, in this city, was recently affirmed on defendant's appeal to the Appellate Division.

Perhaps the largest auction sale of high bred harness horses ever held will be the "Old Glory" sale which will follow the Horse Show at Madison Square Garden next week. The total number of consignments received by the Fasig-Tipton Company for this sale will number more than 800 head, and among the animals that will go under the hammer are some of the most famous trotters of the American turf.

The filing of a transfer of the title on Tuesday to a legacy of $10,000 from Simon Dessauer to Howard R. Deacon of Philadelphia brings to light some of the schemes of a wayward young man who is in prison in London, England, for swindling. Dessauer is the son of Hannah and the late Gottlieb Dessauer, who was a merchant in this city and died in October, 1893.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While every one was greeted this morning with, "This is another horrible day; how are we going to stand it?" , I wended my way to Central Park to hear what my feathered friends would have to say. I knew that in Summer this would be an ideal day for them, for they dote on muggy weather, and are always joyous and sing with a will.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- At the opening of the morning session of the New York State Charities and Correction Conference, President Letchworth announced a number of committees. The report of the Committee on the Care and Relief of Needy Families in Their Own Homes was presented by Chairman Frederic Almy, who said in part:
The stock brokerage firm of Sullivan Sullivan of 20 Broad Street made an assignment to Nathaniel M. Halligan, without preference, just before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Perry Belmont yesterday resigned from the Board of Governors of the Democratic Club. His reason, stated in a letter to President Keller, was that without authority "Perry Belmont" had been inscribed on a ribbon attached to a basket of flowers sent to Richard Croker when he sailed for Europe.

The Prudential team was the only one of four to win all three of their matches in the Life Insurance League tournament on Ehler's alleys last night. The Equitable team won two games and lost one, the Fidelity and Casualty won one and lost two games, and the Germania five lost three games. The scores:

The slightly cooler weather that the rain squall of yesterday afternoon brought had a marked effect upon the society attendance at the Horse Show. The public, too, was quick to respond, and for the first time since the show opened the crowd on the promenade recalled that of the Horse Shows of some years ago.

Since the manifesto of the Citizens' Union for a non-partisan movement in the Mayoralty campaign was published a week ago, the following have signed their approval of the address, and expressed their hearty concurrence in the plans outlined:

There is a pleasurable suggestion of old times for the old playgoer in the present performance of the Fechter version of "Monte Cristo" at the Academy, except that such uncommonly beautiful scenic pictures as the Forest of Fontainebleau by Homer Emens and Ernest Albert's conservatory and ballroom of the Hotel de Morcerf belong peculiarly to the present era of magnificent settings.

The foreclosure sale of the property known as Cedar Knolls, in the town of Bronxville, consisting of 183 separate building lots and four large parcels of acreage realized about $100,000. The sale was conducted on the premises on Tuesday by Auctioneer Philip A. Smyth.

Actually recorded transactions in the stock market yesterday ran beyond the 1,600,000 mark, while total dealings, according to conservative estimates, must have amounted to at least two million shares -- approaching to the high-water mark. It was a day of immense realizing.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Jerome O. Read, receiver for the Pioneer Silk Company, assumed charge of the business this morning. He will continue to manage it until all the material in process of manufacture is ready for the market. The Ryle brothers, the receiver, and Eugene Stevenson, counsel for the company, held a long conference to-day at the office of Mr. Stevenson and discussed the financial affairs of the company.

Our smooth and smiling friend WU TING FANG made an address in Philadelphia, on Tuesday evening, the substance of which has been already spread over the continent. In this respect our conditions evidently differ from those of China, where it is always a matter of speculation what the Chinese public knows of matters which are elsewhere of common notoriety.
Rusher Babeock have sold for Flora Douglas to a client for occupancy the three-story and basement dwelling, 325 West Eighty-seventh Street, 20 by 55 by 100.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- The Yale Varsity football team was to-day put through its last heavy day of the week in preparing for the Harvard game. Only one half was played, but it was stiff football and of a variety that made the coachers show evident signs of cheerfulness. Gould and Coy took the ends until the last five minutes of the one half, and were then replaced by substitutes.

NEWARK, Nov. 21 -- Master in Chancery Otto Crouse has advised a divorce in the suit brought by Mrs. Martha S. Gielaw, now of Brooklyn, N.Y., against her husband, Henry J. Gielaw, a marine architect, with an income of $6,000 a year. He now lives in Jersey City. The grounds for the suit were desertion and non-support.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- There were two big surprises at the Bennings track to-day. In the second race Robert Waddell, a 15 to 1 shot, won out by the narrow margin of half a length from McAdie, the favorite, and in the fourth Charles Estes, against whom the bookmakers offered odds of 25 to 1, came under the wire first, Buffoon, the favorite, at prohibitive odds of 1 to 8, finishing third.

MANILA, Nov. 21 -- Gen. MacArthur was asked to-day whether the result of the Presidential election in the United States was in any way responsible for the orders to push operations against the Filipinos. He replied that the result of the election was merely coincident with other features of the situation.

It is no impropriety for a Bishop to seek information about the topics on which he makes public speeches. Even when he comes from the enlightened State of Massachusetts to address so benighted and illiterate a body as the New York Chamber of Commerce he is not constrained by Scripture or statute to keep to the low level of the campaign orator's conventional generalities.

The first annual meeting of The Associated Press since the reorganization under the New York charter was held yesterday in the assembly room of the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue. The membership of the association is nearly 700. The meeting yesterday was the largest in the history of the association, and the spirit which prevailed presaged for the reorganized association a most successful career.

State Auditor GUS W. COULTER of Kentucky, a Democrat and said to be largely responsible for such victory as his party recently won in the State, has been talking like a man who had felt conviction and was bound to declare it in an "experience meeting." He believes that Kentucky has been too long cultivating a prejudice against capital, wealth, enterprise, education, advancement, and that the time has come to diversify her crops.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage to-day issued the following circular discontinuing the refunding Dperations:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The population of the State of New York as officially announced to-day is 7,268,012, as against 5,997,853 in 1890, an increase of 1,270,159, or 21.1 per cent.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Boston had another great day in the stock market. The declaration of a five-dollar dividend by the Butte and Boston Company caused a rise of 12 1/2 points, to 92 1/2; the close after heavy dealings was 90. Other mines had one of the strongest days yet, and the general list was broad and buoyant.

Count Ademar de Castellane, a cousin of Count Boni de Castellane, who married Miss Anna Gould, is at the Hotel Martin. The Count arrived here on Tuesday on the French Line steamship L'Aquitaine. On the passenger list of the steamship his name appears as "Comte de Novante." No one knew him on board, and it was not until he arrived at the hotel that he used his well-known name and title.

The market for outside securities yesterday was strong and broad, and many issues shared in the day's grains. Many stocks were traded in to a very large extent, and in some the transactions were as large as any recorded since election day. There was evidence of increasing interest in the market, and to all appearances outside buying instead of falling off seemed to be growing in volume.

The first official trial of the electric motive power to be used on the lines of the Manhattan Elevated Railway will be made to-day in presence of a number of invited guests on the Third Avenue branch of the system between Ninety-second and Sixty-seventh Streets.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- With the realization of probable conviction on one of six indictments, and with no prospect of leniency on the part of the Court, Will- iam Hamm dug through three feet of solid masonry, and succeeded in escaping from the Ulster County Jail early this morning.

Nathaniel M. Halligan, assignee of the stock brokerage firm of Sullivan Sullivan of 20 Broad Street, which failed on Wednesday, posted a notice on the doors of the offices yesterday stating that all open transactions would be closed out at the opening prices of the day and statements rendered accordingly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Trinity College, the newly founded Catholic institution for the higher education of women, was dedicated to-day with imposing ceremonies. Cardinal Gibbons, Mgr. Martinelli, the Papal Delegate, and other high dignitaries of the Church conducted the service in the presence of a large assemblage, including prominent officials, many members of the Diplomatic Corps, and representative educators from various parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The State Department so far has heard nothing from Mr. Conger respecting the "impasse" reported to have been reached by the foreign Ministers at Peking. In fact, save a brief expression respecting the insufficiency of the punishments proposed by the Chinese Government to be inflicted upon the responsible leaders of the Boxer movement, Mr. Conger has not communicated with the department for more than a week.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Gov. Roosevelt, in addressing the conference at Albany, alluded to the mob murders as a kind of law-lynch-law, and said that it "flourishes most rankly in States where there is a constant miscarriage of justice, where there is a disregard of consequences, where murderers are likely to escape, where the law, or officers of the law, fail to punish crime with proper legal severity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A promising card with delightful weather attracted the largest crowd of the meeting to the Bennings track to-day. There was liberal betting, and the talent picked four winners. The most Interesting event of the day was the Hunters' Steeplechase, with six starters.
Schrag Richtberg have sold for Julius Metzler to Theodore C. Camp the four-story business building 500 Sixth Avenue, between Thirtieth and Thirty-first Streets.

The attendance at the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden reached the highwater mark last night. The indications early were that a great crowd would . be present, but the realization greatly exceeded expectation. The great hall filled slowly, and it was not until after 9 o'clock that the crowd had assembled in all the impressive splendor of a typical fashionable night.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Edward E. Pratt, who died at his home, 24 Chestnut Street, yesterday, at the age of seventy, was a well-known Bostonian. He was graduated at Harvard College in 1852, married Miss Minna Choate, a daughter of Rufus Choate, the famous lawyer, and practiced law with S. Lothrop Thorndike. under the firm name of Thorndike Pratt, occupying a room in the offices of Rufus Choate, at 42 Court Street.

The down-trodden victims of New York's nighthawk Jehus can exult to-day in a triumph gained yesterday by Mark Twain. A "cabby" was haled before Mayor's Marshal Roche and his license to overcharge and insult his customers was suspended.

By permission of a Senate that was not as decisively Republican as that due to meet in December, and notoriously at the dictation of Mr. GORMAN of Maryland, since retired, the army of the United States may consist of 100,000 men until July, 1901, and must then, in the absence of contrary legislation, be reduced to about 27,000 men.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The Rev. Dr. Anthony Schuyler died from heart failure at Grace Church Rectory, Orange, N.J., early yesterday morning-, in his eighty-fifth year. He had been a man of much activity and of many and varied interests, and old age sat lightly upon him until the last. He preached last Sunday and attended a lecture the evening preceding his death.
Edwards, E.W., Sons, Syracuse, N.Y.; Miss A. M. Smith, notions, Jewelry, millinery, ladies and infants' wear; Miss M. Powers, laces and embroideries; Hotel Cadillac.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Money is in good demand and is growing scarce, and it is believed the Bank of England has arranged to further reduce the floating supply considerably. Discounts are sympathetically firm, and it is considered that they have been as low as they are likely to be before Christmas.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Gen. Sir Redvers Buller, the former commander of the British troops in Natal, in the course of a speech to-day at Exeter on the occasion of the presentation to him of a sword of honor, said he had received a quantity of old iron, sent by German critics, while trying to relieve Ladysmith. He added:

Football practice at Columbia was not of the usually encouraging character yesterday afternoon. The 'Varsity fumbled miserably, and played with less spirit than has been shown in several weeks. In the first half of a forty-minute practice game only one touch-down was scored against the second eleven, and this was in spite of unusually ragged play by the substitutes.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Booker T. Washington said to-night regarding the recent lynching of a negro in Colorado that the same class of people who begin to break the law by lynching a negro will soon learn to break the law by lynching a white man.

Robort Low Pierrepont and Miss Kathryn Isabel Reed, daughter of the late Josiah Reed of Weymouth, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon in Grace Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Chauncey Brewster of Connecticut, assisted by the Rev. Frederick Burgess, rector of Grace Church.

MARSEILLES, Nov. 22 -- To-day proved a triumph for former President Kruger of the South African Republic, who arrived on the Gelderland this morning, such as even the Boer delegates and Mr. Kruger's most ardent admirers failed to anticipate. The delirium of enthusiasm which marked every step of his progress from the time he landed until the hotel was reached, was a revelation even to the people of Marseilles themselves.

Owing to large customs receipts on imports and larger receipts from internal revenue taxation, both together exceeding current demands upon the Government, the surplus of receipts for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1900, exceeded $78,000,000, or just double the surplus anticipated in the annual report of Secretary GAGE in December last.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 22 -- United States Senator James K. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, spent the day in Little Rock and left tonight for Washington, D.C. Before leaving he said in an interview:

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The rumor of the Czar's death appears to be unfounded. Nothing to confirm it has been received at the Russian embassies in Berlin and Paris. The embassy here has received no news since the bulletin of yesterday, (Thursday.)

A private dinner was given last night at the Arena by Alfred and Charles Steckler to representatives of about thirty of the leading labor organizations in this municipality. The avowed object of the meet- ing was to form the nucleus of a working- man's revolt against Tammany Hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Christmas tree for eight dogs at the residence of A.F. Diegley, 3,030 Vernon Avenue, will be an innovation of the holiday season. Mr. Diegley's dogs have a taste for candy, and he believes they will fully appreciate any trouble it may occasion him to supply them their Christmas sweets from a tree.

NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- The Morris and Essex League, the most important bowling organization in New Jersey, organized today with these clubs: Roseville Athletic Association, Riverside Athletic Club, Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark, Montclair Athletic Club. Montclair; Field Battery, East Orange, and Union Athletic Club, Rutherford.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- A project was put on foot here to-night, which, it is hoped by its promoters, will result in the founding of a great model industrial town near this city. The scheme was made public to-night at a dinner given by Joseph J. Byers, formerly of New York, but now a financier of this city.

Arthur Seymour Sullivan was born in London May 13, 1842. He was the son of an Irish bandmaster and clarinet player. He began his own musical career as one of the children of the royal chapel, where he was distinguished for his sweet voice and his sympathetic style of singing. There, too, he began his work as a composer, publishing through Novello, Ewer Co., in 1856. "O Israel," a sacred song.

John W. Keller, Commissioner of Charities; Francis J. Lantry, Commissioner of Corrections, and Henry Kearny, Commissioner of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies, were before the Grand Jury yesterday and the day before to answer questions of that body concerning their departments and the conduct thereof.

-- When the new waiting room in the Grand Central Station was opened the other day the multitudinous commuters were so impressed by its size and beauty, as compared with the dingy and malodorous little vault it replaced, that they overlooked its almost grotesque inadequacy as the metropolitan terminus of two great railways, and their habitual rage against corporations to the revenues of which they contribute so much was appreciably mitigated.

An action now on trial in the Supreme Court against the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company promises to furnish some excitement to-day in the part of the court presided over by Justice MacLean. The case is that of Anton Bernas, a Hungarian, who does not speak English, who seeks to recover $30,000 damages for injuries received while trying to get on a Columbus Avenue car on June 4, 1898.

The actual contamination of the water supply of New York City would constitute a public danger. False and sensational reports of its contamination are a public nuisance, an incitement to needless alarm and a real injury to the city.

An employe in the offices of the stock brokerage house of A.C. Hooper Co., which failed on Monday, involving several hundred persons who speculated through that firm, said yesterday that the liabilities of the firm are not likely to exceed $150,000.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 22 Daylight revealed a tangled mass wreckage in the streets of this city. The gale, which sprang up yesterday afternoon, reached a velocity of eighty-five miles an hour. At midnight it had subsided to fifty miles; but, in the business section dozens of roofs lay in the streets; hundreds of telegraph and telephone poles protruded from the debris, while thousands of wires were hopelessly tangled.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The new third rail electric railway between Albany and Hudson was officially opened to-day. Prominent railway officials from New York City arrived in Hudson on a special train and boarded two electric cars at the station. The start was made at 11:40 this morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- The third day's session of the conference on charities and correction opened this morning in the Senate Chamber with a report of the Committee on Mentally Defective presented by William P. Spratling, M.D., Medical Superintendent of Craig Colony for Epileptics. He said, in part:

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Business on the Bourse to-day opened hesitating, but with a more favorable disposition. Internationals were quiet, except Spanish fours. Rio Tintos were in good demand. Toward the close there were large repurchases by option sellers of industrials and banks, especially Credit Lyonnaise and Banque de Paris, which improved considerably, and closed firm.
BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Speakers in the Reichstag to-day, except those of the People's Party and Social Democrats, declared themselves to be in general agreement with the Chinese policy of the Government.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 22 -- The greatest throng of students that has witnessed a practice match this season to-day cheered the Yale football team in its final practice before the great game with Harvard on Saturday. There were ten coachers on the field during the secret practice, which lasted about forty minutes.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Col. D.C. Robinson of this city, who was arrested in New York City last night in an action brought by Mary L. Meinell to recover $4.000, arrived home to-day. He says the case is one of blackmail and that he will at the proper time easily prove this as well as his innocence of wrongdoing.

NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- The individual championship of the East Jersey Golf Association, composed of the Newark Athletic Club, Glen Ridge Golf Club, East Orange Field Club, Hillside Tennis and Golf Club, Madison Golf Club, Elizabeth Town and Country Club, and the Forest Hill Field Club, will be held on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club Nov. 30 and Dec. 1.
The attention of Senator Platt was called last evening to a published report that as a result of his dinner with ex-Gov. Black at the Holland House the State police measure would be "called off."

The Presidents of the Western lines, it was reported yesterday, held a meeting in Chicago a few days ago, at which it was decided to suspend their agreement until Jan. 1, 1900. Accordingly, instructions were issued to their traffic managers to use their discretion in securing business until that date.

Tammany has one manifest advantage in the game it is now playing to baffle the forces of decency in their pursuit of vice. No keeper of an unlawful resort would be fool enough to give testimony against corrupt Police Captains or blackmailing district leaders before any committee whose sessions or records were open to the representatives of RICHARD CROKER.

A step in the direction of municipal ownership and control will be taken by the Charter Revision Commission in its report, which will be handed to Gov. Roosevelt a week from to-morrow. The commission will recommend that the city own and operate its own printing plant instead of having its printing done by contract as now is the case.

The most interesting feature at the Gardent yesterday was an undress rehearsal for the quickest change of teams in a road coach, which will be a regular event this afternoon. The rehearsal took place after the close of the programme yesterday afternoon before a small but enthusiastic audience.

Prominent criminal lawyers who have read the opinion of the Court of Appeals granting a new trial to Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, convicted of the murder of Dollie Reynolds, believe that it establishes a precedent which, if observed, will nullify rules of evidence followed for centuries.

Charged with defrauding Major Gen. Daniel E. Sickles out of $8,000 on the 24th of September last, J. Fletcher Shera, the New York Stock Exchange broker of 6 Wall Street, whose failure was announced Monday, was yesterday arrested with his bookkeeper, Lemuel W. Baxter of 702 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, by Detective McConville.

In the early trading yesterday the stock market was subjected to the severest test yet brought to bear upon it since election. Very large realizing sales appeared shortly after the opening and were succeeded by many others, while at the same time the room traders joined forces to bring about a general reaction, in the hope of picking up stocks at lower prices.

It is no secret to those who have had occasion to follow the details in the extension of the navy that for a disagreeably long period there has existed in the Navy Department, and particularly in that committee of it known as the Construction Board, something very like hostility to Rear Admiral HICHBORN, Chief Constructor, in charge of the Bureau of Construction and Repair.

Last day but one of the Horse Show. From indications last night there will be a goodly attendance all day at the Garden, for Saturday has too many out-of-town attractions, and there is too much social interest in the great football game at New Haven between Yale and Harvard to permit of much fashionable showing at the Garden.

The first steps have been taken at Columbia University to secure the ground now known as "South Field," situated opposite the library, as an athletic field. The matter will be brought before the Trustees of the university, and it is probable that something definite will be done in the near future.

Mr. HENRY LOOMIS NELSON gives in The Evening Post an interview with Mr. CARLISLE in regard to the reorganization, or "renaissance," of the Democratic Party, which is chiefly interesting at this time as showing how little real preparation for such an operation there is in the minds of those who most earnestly and sincerely desire it.

The Merchants' Association made public a document yesterday which purports to show a discrepancy in the water revenues of the city from 1890 to 1894 of $4,107,372. The investigation of this subject was made by Frederick De Berard for the Merchants' Association, and his report was "accepted " by the Board of Directors and publication followed.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- A bull broke loose from a herd of cattle that was being unloaded from Pennsylvania Railroad cars at the Belmont Avenue station, Newark, and began a trip of exploration through the town.
