It made straight for the china shop of John Goeren Sons, at 287 Fifteenth Avenue, where it proceeded to have fun in its own playful little way.

Jacob J. Haffner of 440 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, who has a record of serving two terms in the prisons of this State, has within the past few months produced wills which will cause endless complications among heirs to estates, amounting to thousands of dollars.

Dr. Robert Acton, thirty-five years old, of 163 East Seventy-ninth Street, died yesterday morning in the Presbyterian Hospital from morphine poisoning. He was taken to the hospital from his home at 2 o'clock A.M., in answer to a special hurry call for an ambulance.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 22 -- The talk which has been current during the past three months regarding a direct railway connection between this city and Los Angeles took final shape to-day in the agreement for the incorporation of the Los Angeles and Salt Lake Railway Company. Senator W.A. Clark and his associates interested in the enterprise met here yesterday and held a conference, which lasted until 2 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The Times-Herald says: "John J. McGraw of Baltimore became a full-fledged baseball magnate last evening. In a League conference at the Grand Pacific Hotel, of which McGraw was the central figure, were President B. D. Johnson, James Manning, pledged to Washington; James D. Burns of Detroit, Matt Killilea of Milwaukee, and Comiskey of Chicago.

D.C. Robinson, ex-Mayor of Elmira, N.Y., and the only son of the late Lucius Robinson, who was at one time Governor of the State, was arrested at the Imperial Hotel Wednesday afternoon on an order issued by Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court. Matters were so arranged that Mr. Robinson gave the $2,500 bail required, and was at once released without even having to go to the Sheriffs office.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Thomas Benton Brooks died at his home in New Windsor to-day, aged sixty-four. He was born in Monroe, N.Y., and was graduated from Union College in 1858 as a civil engineer.

The Conference of Religion closed in the evening at the Brick Presbyterian Church. Controller Coler opened the meeting with a paper on "The Unused Power of the Churches in Politics," and was followed by the Rev. A.W. Wishart of Trenton on the same subject. Mr. Coler said in part:

The annual meeting of the Public Education Association, held yesterday in the Berkeley Lyceum, on West Forty-fourth Street brought out the largest attendance that has been present at these meetings in several years. Every seat in the hall was taken by women interested in auxiliary educational work in the city, while the standing room in the aisles was largely taken up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The annual report of Gov. John G. Brady of Alaska, to the Secretary of the Interior, urges Congressional legislation on the extension of the general land laws to Alaska, giving the natives the same legal status as the whites, and the representation of Alaska by a delegate in Congress.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- A dispatch to Reuter's News Agency from Peking, dated Nov. 22, says:

In a north-bound Broadway cable car last night about 11 o'clock were seated four persons. The conductor was leaning against the railing of the rear platform, humming quietly to himself. A tired-eyed, middle-aged woman, with a bundle of clothing in her lap, sat motionless at the front of the car.

Chester B. Lawrence, Jr., a Consolidated Stock Exchange broker, with a suite of offices at 32 Broadway and five up-town branch offices, was arrested late yesterday afternoon by Capt. McClusky of the Detective Bureau on a charge of grand larceny. Edward B. Underhill, who acted as manager for Lawrence, and George H. Wolbert, employed as cashier and book-keeper, were also arrested on the same charge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Mail advices from Manila give in considerable detail the story of the rescue of Capt. Shields and fifty men of the Twenty-ninth Infantry, after their capture by the insurgents in Marinduique. The fight that Capt. Shields and his party put up against an overwhelming force is declared to have been one of the most brilliant incidents in the history of bush fighting in the archipelago.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 23 -- In the United States District Court here to-day, before Judges Amos, Thayer, and Hook, hearing was begun in the habeas corpus proceedings brought by attorneys for Oberlin M. Carter, ex-Captain. United States Army, who was dismissed from the army, fined, and sentenced to a term of years in the Federal prison at Leavenworth, on the charge of complicity in alleged attempted frauds in the Government harbor contracts at Savannah, Ga.

It is proper, and perhaps desirable, to say here that the following article comes from the office of one of the best-known periodicals in this country. The writer has had, wide experience and he is in active service.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Treasury has given notice of the issue of $3,000,000 3 per cent. exchequer bonds, payable in 1905.

Men prominent in literary, dramatic, and musical circles will gather this evening after theatre hours at the Players in Gramercy Park as the guests of Richard Mansfield, who will give a supper in honor of M. Coquelin, the French comedian. The French actor attended Mr. Mansfield's performance of Henry V. last Wednesday evening, visited him during the entr'acte when the two famous "Cyranos" held a long and interesting conversation in French.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A twelve-foot fence of pine board has been erected between the residence of William N.G. Clark, at 114 South First Avenue, and a new house which has been erected by D. W. Whitmore of West Second Street. It is to remain, according to Mr. Clark, if Mr. Whitmore sells or leases the house. If Mr. Whitmore occupies the house himself it will come down.

Under the influence of aggressive short selling, which in its turn induced not a little realizing by timid holders, with more or less enforced liquidation, prices on the stock market declined yesterday, the recessions in a number of instances being sharp and material. The room traders continued their operations of the previous day, joining forces to bring about a reaction and offering stocks down all around the room.

Prof. Edward Arber, the well-known bibliographer and Fellow of King's College, London, whose address is 73 Shepherd Bush Road, West Kensington, London, has lately issued a beautiful folio prospectus, including a fac simile reprint of a term catalogue -- eight pages -- for Michaeimas Term, 1686, showing the matter and method of a most important new bibliography which he hopes to be able to issue.

The Horse Show crowd attained the limit of Horse Show possibilities last night, when it crowded the topmost gallery in Madison Square Garden. The people who succeeded in reaching that point were among the least satisfied of the thousands present, for they could see nothing but the horses, and could not by any possibility be seen by any except persons equally unfortunate, which cut out much of the enjoyment of the occasion.

There was some rare sport on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, when several new-comers on the road put in an appearance and led the way home in a number of fast brushes. Among the strangers was a handsome black team hooked to a light rig, which the driver, who was a trifle mysterious about the names and marks of the pair, said had just arrived in this city from Toledo.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 23 -- In the Court of Appeals to-day the case of Caleb Powers vs. the Commonwealth was submitted without argument with leave to file briefs on Dec. 1. Powers is under life sentence as an accessory to the killing of Goebel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Secretary of State has addressed an identical note to the powers interested in the Chinese situation setting out tersely and afresh the object of the United States Government as to China, and pointing out how such objects as are common to the powers can best be secured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If your readers could step into the famine orphanages I have recently visited in Gujarat and some parts of the Deccan, two things would follow, first, their eyes would be filled with tears, and their hearts ache with pain at the sight of little children slowly dying from causes due to starvation.

Dr. H.G. Patterson of St. Joseph, Mo., a veterinary surgeon, who for the past two years has been in the service of the British Government, has arrived home from South Africa. He has made many trips from New Orleans to Cape Town in charge of shipments of horses and mules that had been purchased by agents of the British Government in this country.

This record of the Haynford Parish birds is chiefly a record of "Imaginary Conversations." The author is one of those bird-lovers to whom -- as is the case with most baby-lovers -- inarticulate noises represent well-defined sentiments and are capable of accurate translation into the human vernacular.

This large and handsome volume will have particular interest. All the world loves a teller of stories, and readers will surely take approvingly to the man who gives them so much of entertaining reading as is found in Major Pond's 640 pages of bright personal description. There are 100 and more good portraits.

Last day of the Horse Show and flay of the great annual football game between Yale and Harvard. The absence of many of the more prominent belles and young society women, as well as men, last evening from the Garden was due to the desire to make an early start this morning for New Haven, while a number went on yesterday to the City of Elms.

Our Consul at Aix-la-Chapelle, Mr. BRUNDAGE, enlivens the files of the State Department with a report which, if not intended to be humorous, is none the less calculated to afford our manufacturers and merchants looking for suggestions relative to the upbuilding of our exports much wholesome amusement.

The appointment of GEORGE W. ALDRIDGE to an office of trust and emolument would be accepted as a Platt-Odell allocution to the people of the State of like import to the Croker-Van Wyck allocution of January, 1898. Tammany then came into power, and all the scaly, creeping, hideous things began to come out of their holes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Horrible conditions existing among the Chinese aboard vessels in the Alaskan salmon canning industry are portrayed in a report Assistant Surgeon L.L. Lumsden, at Angels Island, Cal., has just made to the Marine Hospital Service.

LONDON Nov. 15 -- To most people Mr. Morley's "Oliver Cromwell" will seem the most important book of the last fortnight. The selection of an agnostic like Mr. Morley, the man who formerly made a point of writing "God" with a small "g" inorder to emphasize his disbelief in the existence of the Deity -- as the biographer of a religious fanatic, does not, at first glance, seem to be an appropriate one.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- To-day's debate in the Reichstag, which ended at a late hour this evening, was the culmination of a series of sensational attacks upon Emperor William and the Government over the China bill. It was an oratorical contest between Herr Bebel, the Socialist leader, and Count von Buelow, the Imperial Chancellor, assisted by Gen. Von Gossler, Minister of War, who, although somewhat clumsy, is no mean antagonist.

I shall here speak up for the young writers as against the veterans, for the new thing against the old, just as I would speak up for the nimble pullet against the aged rooster, the sunrise against the moonlight, the sapling against the withered tree, the imagination against tradition, the coming age against the stale ages, or the rosebud against the world.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision affirming an order of the lower court denying a motion made in the case of John H. Parks against John W. Gates. The plaintiff sued for a share of the profits which he alleged were due him under an agreement made to bring about the formation of a certain corporation and the purchase of various factories.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 23 -- Norman W. Hayward and Miss Ethel Robinson are among the best known and most popular young people in this city. Miss Robinson is the daughter of J.H. Robinson, formerly President of the Vermont Life Insurance Company, and at present holding an important position with an insurance company having headquarters in New York.

Bishop Potter delivered an address on "God and the City" at the noonday Litany services yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel. The wickedness which existed in Jerusalem during Christ's life was vividly pictured. New York's licentiousness and the depravity of modern material life were boldly painted in the Bishop's address.

ARLINGTON, N.J., Nov. 23 -- A bill is being drafted for introduction in the coming session of the Legislature to have the Arlington section of the town of Kearny into an independent borough. There is a proposition on foot to incorporate Kearny, Harrison, and East Newark into a city, and Arlington people do not want to be included in the larger municipality.

In the recent death of J. Alsop King the New York Historical Society has lost one of its oldest and most faithful members. He had been President of the society since 1887, and although eighty-three years old at the time of his death, he was seldom missing from the President's chair at the regular monthly meeting's in the old-fashioned hall on Second Avenue and Eleventh Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- "Willie" Campbell, who for years has been one of the most interesting figures on American golf links, is ill at his home in Dorchester with a complication of diseases which have affected his heart, and his physician has given up hope of recover.

DIJON, Department of Coted Or, France, Nov. 23 -- Mr. Kruger has become, for a moment, at least, the popular idol of the French. His triumphant progress northward through the country from Marseilles to Dijon to-day has placed this beyond doubt. He met with a tremendous reception in each town along the route where the train stopped, culminating in scenes of frenzied enthusiasm here this evening.

The first portion of the library of Thomas J. McKee was sold by John Anderson, Jr., at his auction rooms in West Thirteenth Street, Thursday and Friday of this week, a large attendance and large prices evincing the marked interest now taken in American prose and poetry and American plays.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- A sentence of eight years in the penitentiary was to-day imposed upon Rink, a wealthy merchant and at one time Mayor of Stade, who was convicted of having committed thirty-two forgeries. Rink, who fled to the United States, was extradited.

HAVANA, Nov. 23 -- The question whether the future relations of Cuba and the United States are to be considered simultaneously with the drawing up of the Constitution led to a spirited argument between Gualberto Gomez and Gen. Sanguily at to-day's session of the Cuban Constitutional Convention.

The first bound volume to issue from the Palmetto Press is a very attractive edition of Mrs. Browning's "Sonnets from the Portuguese," printed in Bradford old-style type, with French quotation marks, and pratty Latin ornaments inserted where otherwise the line would have to be widely spaced.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was not on quite as large a scale as on the previous day, but the market remained broad, and a number of issues showed fairly large totals. Prices were more irregular, and, in place of the general advance of the previous day, a certain number of declines occurred, which in some cases carried quotations to considerably lower figures than those of the previous day's close.

PRINCETON, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The members of the Princeton University football team who played in the Yale game on Saturday will attend the Yale-Harvard game at New Haven to-morrow. Several of the players left for New Haven to-night, and the others will go up in the morning. The expenses of the trip, including admission to the game, will be defrayed by the football management.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The jury in the Krist murder trial at Owego brought in a verdict of murder in the first degree at 8:35 o'clock to-night. Krist was charged with the murder of Katle Tobin, and his defense was insanity. He heard his doom pronounced with a smile of the atmost indifference.
WAVERLY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Arthur Kinney, aged twenty-three years, committed suicide this afternoon by blowing off the side of his head with a shotgun.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 23 -- This was one of the liveliest days on the Mining Exchange in months, over 5,000 shares of Consolidated Virginia changing hands. This stock, which was $1.05 last week, started to-day at $1.35, and sold up to $1.50. The advance was due to reports of rich ore struck near Ophir line.

The Pulpit Committee of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church is having difficulty in finding a pastor to fill the place made vacant when the former pastor, the Rev. Dr. Faunce, resigned to become the President of Brown University. It is said that the committee lately offered the pastorate to the Rev. Dr. C.P. Gifford of Buffalo, with an annual salary of $7,500, and the offer was flatly refused.

Where so much of the mediocre work of the great English and Dutch masters finds its way to this country. It is worth while to mention a collection of canvases superior to those usually shown. One acquires one's connoisseurship by snatches. Frequently cargoes of foreign art consignments importune one to admire what might be passed without loss; but rarely does one hear of a work for which the proudest spirit might court admission to view.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Some 5,000 shares of Amalgamated changed hands in Boston in the morning dealings between 99 and 100 1/2, and Butte, Sugar, Centennial, and Federal Steel also were active, with fair trading in Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Montana, and American Telephone. The general list was narrower than early in the week and the prevailing tone was softer, although few marked losses were recorded.

Max Marx has sold to McCaul Soles the two unfinished seven-story apartment houses, occupying the entire block front on the east, side of Manhattan Avenue, between One Hundred and Seventeenth and One Hundred and Eighteenth Streets. The buyers will complete the structures immediately.

NEWARK, Nov. 23 -- A grave and unusual municipal problem confronts the Town of Harrison, across the Passaic River from this city. It is a problem that keeps the town Councilmen awake at night trying to reach a solution. It involves the protection of the police.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 23 -- Chairman Hull of the House Committee on Military Affairs to-day called a meeting of the committee for next Tuesday. He hopes that a quorum will be present, and that the committee can go to work immediately upon the outlines of a new army bill.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 23 -- Everything is now in readiness for the Yale-Harvard game to-morrow. It will be the greatest game in five years in this city, and the fact that there is considerable doubt as to the outcome makes the situation the most interesting in recent football history. The city and the campus are agog with enthusiasm over the prospect of to-morrow's contest.

Recent English papers announce under big headlines that Queen Victoria has pronounced against the fashion of docking the tails of her horses, and has ordered that hereafter they shall carry their tails as Nature intended they should. It is further stated that the Queen has induced the Prince of Wales to abandon the cruel practice of docking and that the future King will hereafter ride and drive only horses with long flowing tails.

Some officials of the Street Cleaning Department think there is a combine among the Brooklyn contractors to mulct the city out of a large sum of money for the removal of snow during the Winter. They claim to be unable to thwart the plans of they combine and are calmly waiting for the contractors to collect large sums from the city for work done at what is declared to be an exorbitant price.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Ideal racing weather, a well-balanced card, and a desire to see the mare Imp run, drew another large crowd to the Bennings race track to-day. The track was in perfect condition. There were some surprises in the results, and the talent had only indifferent success in picking the winners.

It is a distressing or a comforting truth, according as you view it, that in this broad country of ours there is a possible market for everything written, no matter what it is about. The question of merit does not and need not come in. You have made an article which you wish to sell. Somewhere there is some one who will print it.

In reading of American diplomacy and diplomatists one is frequently and irresistibly reminded of the young gentleman, who, being at Windsor with his father, a man of world-wide reputation, insisted upon dining at the Queen's own table, and carried his point because it was found impossible to make him see the impropriety of his conduct.

Charles G. Horton, who has of late been doing business under the name of the Consolidated Lumber Company, was arrested yesterday by Post Office Inspector John E. Ashe. He was taken before United States Commissioner Shields and charged with having used the mails for fraudulent purposes, the charge being based on an intercepted circular that he had sent to a man in Canajoharie.

When Dr. Mitchell's first novel appeared -- not very many years ago -- the world held up its hands in amazement. How could a busy specialist, eminent and sought in two continents, his days and nights fringed out by countless and urgent interruptions, find either the time or the needful mental attitude for the production of fiction? Dr. Mitehell has educated us in his possibilities.

United States Senator Thomas C. Platt was a witness in the Supreme Court yesterday in an action brought by Gen. Charles H.T. Collis to recover $250,000 damages from The Press Publishing Company for an alleged libel. Senator Platt's testimony was all stricken from the records, as it was not given at the proper time.

Authorship with art has rarely, if ever, had a more opulent heritage than that illustrated by the Rossetti family in England. The pungent genius which, was the endowment of each member of it was manifest in Nicola Rossetti, the grandfather of Dante Gabriel and Christina. His children also were all distinguished, and his son Gabriele, "the most so," brought to England that branch of the descending line which we know best.

For the first time in several years two colleges of the "big four" will meet to-day for the undisputed championship in intercollegiate football. Harvard, the victor over Pennsylvania, and Yale, fresh from her crushing defeat of Princeton, will lineup against each other on Yale Field, at New Haven.

There seems to be no doubt that Stephen phillips second drama, "Herod," which, unlike its predecessor, "Paolo and Franccsca," has been acted, lacks vitality as a play, and the excuse made for the author that he is too young to comprehend the mysteries of stagecraft will net hold. Too indolent he may be to study theatrical technique, but the great dramatists, it seems, did not have to study that.

JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 23 -- Important changes affecting the operation of the Illinois Steel Company's plant here are practically matured. It is asserted that the plans for a huge wire mill have been completed, and that the work of construction will start soon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Legation of Uruguay established here last Summer promises to take a more conspicuous place in the gayety of nations as seen in the course of a Washington season than might be expected from its importance and recent entrance into the diplomatic body.

CHARLESTOWN, N.H., Nov. 23 -- The funeral of Charles H. Hoyt, the playwright, was held in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. From 9 o'clock A.M. until the hour of the service the body lay in state in the church, and a continuous line of people passed through to view the body of their widely known and universally loved friend and fellow-citizen.

The season is at length at hand when all sorts of publishers' announcements are eagerly scanned to see what new Intellectual feasts the coming Winter is to offer us. The announcement pages of the magazines will be found as tempting as are those of the booksellers and book publishers.

The Tenement House Commission continued its hearings at the hall of the United Charities Building yesterday afternoon. Robert W. De Forest presided, and the subject under discussion was "The Existing Evils of the Tenement House System."

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Charles R. Flint of New York and President Francis L. Patton of Princeton University discussed the advantages and necessity of a college education for a business man before the Outlook Club of this place this evening. Mr. Flint was the first speaker.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The United States Department of Agriculture has issued a pamphlet in which is discussed the "Spot Disease of the Violet."
BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Congressman John P. Fitzgerald has appointed Charles Daly, Captain of the Harvard football team, to the vacancy now existing at West Point, from the Ninth Congressional District.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Some recent allusions to Adah Isaacs Menken -- as she latterly called herself -- and her singular volume, "Infelicia," have recalled some peculiarities of that book which may be interesting, Adah Menken died in the Summer of 1868 in Paris. The year before a collection of her "poems," under the title given, had been published in Philadelphia.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Secretary North of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers states that the total wool clip of the United States for 1900 is 288,636,621 pounds, washed and unwashed, or 118,223,- 120 pounds scoured.

MERIDEN, Conn., Nov. 23 -- At the close of the final practice of the Harvard eleven this afternoon Coach Dibblee said: "The team is in great form. Every man knows his position down to the ground and fits perfectly into the team tactics. They will play a heady, gritty game."

"Hunting antique furniture is a 'graft,' as you men call it," said a lady who has her home filled with all kinds of rare and beautiful "antiques," which she has, as she expressed it, "picked up for a song."

M.K.W., Now York, writes regarding the magazines: "When one considers their cheapness, many of them 10 cents a copy, the reader would be churlish to complain of the bulk, of advertisements included, often outnumbering the pages of reading matter, since in some way the expense of publication must be met.
The charter revisers, it is reported, will recommend that the city establish a municipal printing office. That would be an economic mistake, a political blunder, and an act of industrial usurpation.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Attorney General Davies has denied the application of James R. Maclay and others to bring an action to remove Frederick A. Burnham as President of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association. In his opinion the Attorney General says:

The new asphalt pavement in Broadway, between Fourteenth and Forty-second Streets, begun on Sept. 30, will be completed within the next week, and is what the Highway Department officials term one of the quickest and most satisfactory "jobs" that has been done under their supervision.

Though the trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was on a much smaller scale than on the earlier days of the week, prices were fairly well maintained, and in some few instances substantial gains were recorded. The general list shared the dullness of the Stock Exchange market, and except in a few issues the day's transactions attracted little attention.

When the Dewey Arch Committee meets again it will have some forty propositions to consider, ranging from the "easiest way to get the money needed," as suggested by a number of persons, to the more comprehensive question of "whether the whole thing had not better be dropped as a bad job."

To the Editor of The New York Times: We shall fail woefully in our attempt to Americanize the Philippines or Porto Rico, or any other of our recently acquired possessions that were formerly Spanish territory, if we set out by regarding the long-established Catholic faith of the people as an element hostile to the fullest measure of freedom possible under our Constitution and our laws.

Contrary to general expectations, the stock market yesterday, instead of developing a further reactionary tendency, showed strength, with closing quotations in many instances showing net gains. The opening was somewhat irregular, but very shortly under the influence of continued investment demand, which has been so striking a feature of the market ever since election, quotations began to advance, the standard railway stocks leading.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24. -- Yale crushed Harvard on Yale Field this afternoon in a football game whose memories will be handed down by present Yale undergraduates to their great-grandchildren. The score was 28 to 0. This tells the tale of steady, determined, and irresistible battering by the great football machine which the Yale coaches have turned out this season.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The Foreign Office officials this evening informed a correspondent that the collective note adopted by the foreign Ministers at Peking having been submitted to the home Governments, it was soon to be unanimously accepted.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- It was officially announced to-day that the new City Hall will be located on the east side of Broad Street, one block south of the present City Hall. For several months it has been believed that the site selected would be in Military Park, and the choice of the lower Broad Street site has caused considerable surprise.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 24. -- It took three hours in a downpour of rain for Lafayette and Lehigh to play two thirty-minute halves here to-day, resulting in a victory for Lafayette of 18 to 0. The rain began early in the morning and did not cease throughout the day, causing the field to be in anything but good condition.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The last person to board the American Line train for Southampton at Waterloo Station this morning was the Duke of Manchester, who had a great deal of baggage to attend to, and was just in time to jump into his compartment as the train moved out of the station.

The offenses of apothecaries in the Middle Ages were numerous, and the punishment in some cases a whipping. The worst was the improper sale of poisons -- that is to say, except when not duly prescribed by a known physician of reputation, and even then not to put down in a register the name of the doctor and person to whom such prescription containing poison was delivered, was punishable likewise.

The security market has had a sharp reaction. Some of the industrial stocks have fluctuated nervously, and the iron and steel group has been especially disturbed. That a reaction should come was not astonishing. That it did not come sooner, that it has not been greater, must be the chief warrant for surprise.

THE FRENCH BUDGET FOR 1901. -- The report on the French budget for 1901 has just been issued in Paris by M. Guillain, the official rapporteur for the committee, who, in 1898, was Colonial Minister in the Dupuy Cabinet. Several points of the report, besides revealing an unstable condition in France, are said to have considerable foreign interest.

Commander Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army has just succeeded in dealing a heavy blow at the commercial spirit which some time ago entered the army and which, when it became known, stirred the placid precincts of the Fourteenth Street barracks as they have never been stirred since Ballington Booth's withdrawal from the organization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to correct a statement made in your paper on Nov. 17 to the effect that, with the exception of a little enterprise among negroes in Philadelphia, a co-operative store which is being operated in Chicago was about the only business of the kind among negroes in the North.

Cutler's protest against De La Salle, which gave her another chance to win the interscholastic championship by contesting with Columbia Grammar, availed her nothing in the end, for yesterday, battered and twisted until her line was helpless and unresisting, she went down to defeat before Columbia Grammar School by a score of 18 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Cornell defeated Pennsylvania in the annual freshmen's football match on Fianklin Field this afternoon by the score of 16 to 11. When the Ithaca team appeared on the field it was quite evident that they outweighed their opponents, and all through the game this advantage was in evidence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Language is paradoxical, if the saying is true, that "language was given to man to conceal his thoughts"; so the converse shows that language was given to man to unfold his thoughts, and were it not so the marvelous tomes of literature, which today increases, enlarges, and intensifies our knowledge, would not and could not exist.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 24. -- The succession question is believed to have occupied the Ministry and the Imperial Council, and it is thought that if the Czar's illness should terminate fatally. Grand Duke Michael would assume the Regency until after the accouchement of the Empress.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Secretary Hay's note appealing to the powers to devise measures to bring about an amicable and satisfactory settlement of the Chinese crisis has been received at the Foreign Office, through Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador at Washington, but it has not yet been answered.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 24. -- One of the features of the big white fair for the benefit of the Orange Memorial Hospital, which closed to-night in the old building of the Orange Athletic Club, was a birthday calendar compiled and printed for the occasion, and of which a limited, edition found a ready sale.

A crippled urchin of seven or eight years was upset in Columbus Avenue near the Ninety-third Street station of the elevated railroad. Having been, bereft of one of his feet, and being incapable of plying either or his legs, he was hopping along upon a pair of crutches at nightfall, his back bent, and his eyes looking straight ahead.
LONDON, Nov. 24. -- John Lawson Johnston of Kingswood, Kent, the noted dietetic expert, died to-day at Cannes, France, on board the steam yacht White Ladye. Syncope was the cause of death.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to:

St. Lawrence became the patron saint of the lazy and indolent because when, under the fifth persecution of Valerian, he was tortured to death for his unswerving adherence to the new religion by being broiled alive on an enormous gridiron, he mocked his tormentors by saying. "It is now roasted; turn me and eat."

If the newspaper office were surrounded by an invading army, or fiercely bombarded, the autocrat of the composing room would insist on the locking-up of the forms and the stereotyping of the pages as usual. There is no limit to his devotion to duty. One night, for instance, in a provincial newspaper office, the composing room was suddenly enveloped in smoke, and there was the cry of "Fire!"

MANILA, Nov. 24. -- The fortress of the insugent chief Geronimo, at Pinaurau, which the insurgents boasted was impregnable, was taken and destroyed Thursday afternoon by a picked force of the Forty-second and Twenty-seventh Infantry and Troop G of the Fourth Cavalry, under Col. Thompson.

The death of Sir Arthur Sullivan removes one who has contributed greatly to the gayety of nations. He was the originator of an operetta style and the founder of a school. He was an acknowledged leader, and in his particular field he was a genius. Curiously enough, however, he was incomplete without Gilbert.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24. -- President McKinley and all the members of his Cabinet except Secretary of War Root were the guests of honor at the marriage to-day of Miss Lillian Gary, eldest daughter of exPostmaster General James A. Gary, to Robert Coleman Taylor of New York. The distinguished guests from Washington came on a special train.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The Appellate Division of the Second Department of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision that has been awaited with considerable interest.

The committee of labor leaders which accompanied the Factory Inspectors through the east side sweatshops last week will make a tour of the Italian colony, where the finishing of garments is done by women. A preliminary visit was made by the committee last week to the Italians in Mulberry, Mott, Elizabeth, and adjacent streets, where for blocks the tenements are full of workrooms for the finishing of garments.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -- The Harvard and Yale football game to-day left about $40,0OO to be divided between the treasuries of the athletic associations of the two universities, after paying such extra expenses as the printing of tickets and the construction of the special seats used only for this game.

Vincent Cody, old, gray-haired, and stooping, for thirty-three years a convict in Sing Sing, under life sentence for murder, yesterday received from Gov. Roosevelt the commutation of sentence anxiously expected for nearly a quarter of a century, and left the prison he had known for years as home a free man.
Discussing the foreign exchange situation, C. Schumacher Co., in their weekly review, say:
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 24. -- Syracuse treated Brown to something of a surprise to-day, the annual football game ending in a tie -- 6 to 6.

BRISTOL, Nov. 24. -- Matters in relation to the new Bristol cup defender are daily coming to the surface in and about the boat shops. The work is carried on silently and no questions are asked. There being little or none of the metal material for the hull in the shops, the work now going on for the most part is in the matter of preparations.

A very vigorous and generally ill-natured discussion has been excited in England, and may reach this country before it subsides, by the recommendation of Lord ROBERTS that the returning veterans of the South African war be welcomed with gifts of tobacco by those moved to find some tangible expression of their gratitude to the home-coming-volunteers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: New York City is to be congratulated on having in it one citizen with pluck and energy enough to go to the trouble of having a dishonest cab driver punished.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- President McKinley was to-night the guest of honor at the "Founders' Day" banquet of the Union League, one of the oldest and most influential Republican organizations in the country.

A young woman with a three-year-old child was found asleep in the hallway of a tenement house at Box Street and Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, early yesterday morning and taken to the Greenpoint Avenue Police Station, where she said her name was Mrs. Claudia Staple, and that the child was her three-year-old daughter.

Perhaps oftener than any other one question asked of Press Agent Sawyer at the Horse Show was this one. "Is Sarah Bernhardt here ?" Very many visitors seemed to expect that she would be on show at the Garden along with the horses. So there was general disappointment that she was not.

Writing of these Lolos of Chinese Turkestan, the Rev. W.M. Upcraft says: "The men wear a loose blouse and wide, short trousers made of blue cotton cloth, over which a stout plaited felt cloak is thrown, which reaches from the neck to the knees, and is useful by day in cold or wet weather, and at night forms an ample covering."
To the Editor of The New York Times: To proclaim that the proposed State constabulary law is the violation of the policy of home rule is not in and by itself a sufficient argument against it.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 24. -- Rain poured on the Indians and Washington and Jefferson football players in to-day's game, but 15,000 persons were present at the game nevertheless. Capt. Rogers said his team was not strong, although he had twenty-five Indians with him, who were unable to do better than finish with a tie score of 5 to 5.
BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- At the Anti-Imperialist Convention held here to-day a resolution was presented by Dr. T.E. Abbott of Cambridge, which read as follows:

The first of the three concerts to be given by the American Symphony Orchestra, Sam Franko, conductor, will take place on Tuesday at 3:30, at the Lyceum Theatre. The advance sale so far has been most gratifying, and Mr. Franko's intention to render his music in the spirit intended by the composers is well conceived.

A new and improved style of moving stairway or escalator, as it is called, was put in operation yesterday by the Manhattan Elevated Railway at its up-town station of the Sixth Avenue line at Twenty-third Street. There are thirty-two steps constantly moving upward at a rate of seventy-two feet a minute, which will carry about 4,500 persons an hour.

The New York Clearing House exchanges of the banks for the week ending yesterday established a new high record, as they were the largest in the history of the Clearing House, which is forty-seven years old.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 24. -- Wes- leyan for the second time won the cham- pionship in the tri-collegiate football series by defeating Amherst on Andrus Field this afternoon 17 to 0. About 1,000 people wit- nessed the game, including the Amherst band and about 200 supporters of the latter college.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- All sorts of rumors are current about the Jockey Club investigation into Lord Durham's charges against Lester Reiff, among which is the allegation that a well-known sportsman bribed jockeys with large amounts during the past season, with large profits.

James Carr of 1,553 Broadway drives a spirited little mare that is quite new to the requirements of his hansom cab. Late yesterday afternoon the mare became startled in front of the New York Theatre. Down Broadway she tore, narrowly missing the crowded cable cars carrying their part of the tip-town rush.

ABULUG, Luzon, P.I., Oct. 3. -- First Lieut. I.W. Molony, Battalion Adjutant of the Forty-ninth Infantry, United States Volunteers, has lately made several important captures, and on his captives were found some interesting letters, one of which is supposed to have been written by Aguinaldo under the assumed name of Salvadore Felipe.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 24. -- Mrs. F.O. French has nearly completed the arrangements for the wedding of her daughter. Miss Elsie French, to Alfred G. Vanderbilt, which will take place at Trinity Church on Jan. 14 next.

Or a barren island in that part of the East River lying off One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street 200 men are dally at work, year in, year out, preparing a site for a new home which they hope they will never enjoy and which in about ten years from now will prove the abode of many a hopeful young heart as yet unsuspicious of the impending fall.

The Police Department and District Attorney's office will unite in closing up houses in the financial district who, like C.B. Lawrence Co., A.C. Hooper Co., and Sullivan Sullivan, fail to make returns for money intrusted to them by confiding customers.
Senator Platt yesterday took credit for forcing Tammany into a show of activity against vice. He said Croker had been scared by the agitation for a State constabulary bill.

The Twenty-second. N.G.N.Y., will visit Brooklyn on Saturday evening, Dec. 1. as the guests of the Thirteenth Regiment. The Twenty-second will assemble at its armory at 6:30 o'clock that evening, wearing its full dress uniform, with overcoat. The red coats of the dress uniform of the Twenty-second Regiment will make a striking contrast to the darker uniforms ot the Thirteenth, with red trimmings.

The Building Committee of the proposed Stony Wolde Sanitarium has received twenty calls for help within the past six weeks from workingwomen who are suffering from tuberculosis and need immediate assistance. Four of the calls have come through physicians.

The show of horses and equipages and of their owners and admirers that closed last evening is regarded by its managers as one of the most successful and one of the most brilliant of the series. So far as success is shown by attendance and by popular interest it was certainly attained in superlative measure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- European reports to the Department of Agriculture show that the condition of Fall-sown wheat, spelt, and rye in Germany, as officially reported by the German Statistical Office, is considerably above medium. The preliminary official estimates of French cereal crops for 1900 show the production of 43,612,498 bushels of barley and 232,877,918 bushels of oats.

It did not take the audience at Wallack's Theatre last night long to learn that Mme. Bernhardt was the occupant of one of the stage boxes. Immediately after the curtain went up on the first act of "Sapho" the report that she was present traveled quickly through the theatre, and for a time more attention was devoted to discovering which box the French actress was in than to the performance.

Continuing along somewhat conventional lines and with few extraordinary features, the business of the last week might be regarded in a rather discouraging light. In point of volume, however, the showing has been a creditable one, while reports of pending negotiations and the air of activity in many brokers' offices augur well of the future.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24. -- A Duluth dis- patch recently stated that ocean vessels were to be built there by the large shipbuilding company formed in that city, and brought through the canals to be joined together at Montreal. It appears, however, that the work of uniting the sections of the vessels is to be done at Quebec, where there are a large dry dock and shipbuilding yards, and not at Montreal.

The football game at New Haven took so many people out of town, especially of the younger element, that the effect was plain upon the attendance yesterday at the Horse Show. The closing day of the show is never considered a good one from the society standpoint, and yesterday was no exception to the rule.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $4,608,500. The banks now hold a surplus of $12,278,275 above the legal requirements.

Ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott of Black, OIcott. Gruber Bonynge will, alone, prosecute Inspector Cross and Capt. Herlihy on charges based on vicious conditions existing openly in the Pro-Cathedral district, and set forth in Bishop Potter's letter of Nov. 15 to Mayor Van Wyck. Mr. OIcott will have a free hand.

A daughter was born to Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt. Jr., formerly Miss Virginia Fair, at the residence of Mr. Vanderbilt's mother-in-law, 677 Fifth Avenue, late on Friday night. This residence has been placed at the disposal of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt for the Winter.

The reasons given by Gov. ROOSEVELT for declining to proceed further in the case of the charges submitted by The World against Mayor VAN WYCK were practically anticipated in the report of the Attorney General recently published, and by the Governor's statement of last week.

It would be blindness to omit in any estimate of the position of Buddhism as a living force -- it is not at all improbable that it may turn out, eventually, to be the most important point of all -- the quiet but irresistible way in which Buddhism is making its influence felt, quite apart from any religious propaganda, in the thought of the West.

PEKING, Oct. 1. -- Diplomatic opinion of the means by which the penalty to be exacted of China for the anti-foreign movement shall be paid is already taking crude shape. The Ministers have comparatively little to do just now except listen to military and civilian views upon the subject, and unwittingly they commit themselves regarding various suggestions, and thus informal discussion among them naturally results.

In traveling through a strange country for one's own pleasure one naturally tries to think the best of the people; and most of the people (except the Mashonas and Matabele) among whom I have traveled I have formed some attachment to. But between me and the Chinamen there always seemed a great gulf fixed which could never be overcome.

Two more of the big college football teams wound up their seasons yesterday, as a result of the great contest at New Haven. Yale won a highly creditable and decisive victory, while Harvard suffered a defeat of such magnitude never known to her football teams.

QUEBEC, Nov. 24. -- News reached here early this afternoon that the steamer St. Olaf, which has been coasting between this port and Esquimeaux Point, in the Lower St. Lawrence, for the last two years, had become a total wreck off Seven Islands, and that, her passengers and crew had been lost.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's TIMES a letter signed by " J. H.T., a Baptist of fifty years' standing," unjustly criticises Bishop Goodsell of the Methodist Church, and if you will kindly grant space in your valuable paper, would like to state that such criticism is misleading.

On one of my visits I found Leigh Hunt trying to puzzle out the abstruse question of how he should deduct some such sum as 13s. 9d. from a sovereign. On another occasion I had to pay him a sum of money, u100 or u200, and I wrote him a check for the amount. "Well," he said, "what am I to do with this little bit of paper?"

The people living in the neighborhood of Sixth Avenue and Minetta Street were much excited last night over a trick that somebody played on the children of that vicinity. The trick was to give the little ones a lot of whisky to drink, and as a result one boy is lying in a stupor at Bellevue, another is very ill at the Gerry society, and a four-year-old girl lies dangerously ill in her home.

I may observe the pursuit of bacterial antidotes seems to be stimulated by a circumstance which has had rather an unfortunate influence upon the dignity and fair fame of medical science. I mean the fact that when successful they possess a high commercial value, which redounds to the advantage of those who discover and prepare them.

Henry W. Phillips, who says he is the first Minister to the United States from the new South American Republic of Acre, is on his way to Washington to seek official recognition of the new republic. Mr. Phillips landed in San Francisco several days ago and was in Denver yesterday. In an interview he said the Republic of Acre was proclaimed about twelve months ago, and the capital established at Arieopolis.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- In a fashion our political parties are getting ready for the fray which I still think will be a warm one. Apparently the Government supporters are of the same opinion, for they have been entertaining us all the week by their disinterested efforts to find a new leader for the Opposition, or rather to refurbish an old one and set him up for their own delectation.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Money was in good demand to-day, and hardened on the announcement of an offer of Exchequer bonds Nov. 30. This is a sure cause of disturbance, coming as it will at the month end. Operators, therefore, were more cautious than ever. Discounts were very firm. Three months' were below 4 per cent.

SYDNEY, New South Wales, Oct. 24. -- Like most of his predecessors in Sydney, Col. George W. Bell, while holding the position of American Consul, continued to make himself an immense favorite with the citizens and colonists generally, and no public function was regarded as complete without his presence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bishop Goodsell's ambition to "wipe out a system which has created out of the former man of empire a cringing beggar with a monkey and grind organ" is very laudable in its purpose; but, when he blames the Catholic Church for this condition he evinces a lack of information on the subject.

Walter J. Travis added another championship trophy yesterday to the long list of golf laurels which he has won in recent years, culminating this season with his grand victories of both the metropolitan and National championships. A few days ago he won the Oakland Club championship, on whose links, near Bayside, L.I., he became proficient in the game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Turkish authorities having refused to grant an exequatur to Dr. Norton to act as United States Consul at Harpoot, the indications point to some retaliatory measures on the part of the United States Government in the near future.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It does indeed seem that the Democratic Party must have slumbered when a thought leader with a following like that of Dr. Abbott can call his people together to give them a lesson on "The Principles of Dem- ocracy" and talk to them for an evening without once touching his subject.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fierce diatribes against "Rome" uttered by the good Methodist Bishops at the General Missionary Conference strike a very discordant note in the general harmony that prevails among Christian bodies. It savors little of the spirit of charity to compare the good and great Leo XIII., whom all the world honors and reveres, to a "cringing beggar with a monkey and a grind organ."

Of the six teams which met in the Wholesale Drug Trade Association tournament on Reid's alleys, Church Street, Manhattan, last night, the Colgate Co. quintet were the only ones to win both their matches. The Lanman Kemp, National Lead Company, Johnson Johnson, and Seabury Johnson bowlers each won one game and lost one, while the Church, Dwight Co. team lost both its matches.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Swarthmore defeated Haverford in a sensational football struggle on Whittier Field, at Swarthmore, this afternoon, in the annual match between these Quaker institutions, by the score of 17 to 10. At the end of the first half the score was 10 to 0 in favor of Haverford, the home eleven apparently being outclassed.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The financial doings of the Gallant Brothers, the bankrupt silk firm, were brought to light at the examination of Walter M., Fred, and George W. Gallant before Referee in Bankruptcy John W. Harding yesterday. Letters found by Trustee A.R. Krause, who was recently appointed to wind up the affairs of the firm, disclosed the methods adopted to float the sinking concern, and caused a sensation.

PELHAM, N. Y., Nov. 25. -- A decision has been handed down by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, which, it is believed, will permanently settle the boundary line between New Rochelle and this town, which has been in dispute for nearly a hundred years. The decision confirms Pelham's right to fifty acres of land upon which New Rochelle has for years levied taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Dispatches from Madrid received in official diplomatic quarters here make the first anouncement that in the debates before the Latin-American Congress, whose sessions have just been concluded, the principle of compulsory arbitration urged by the Peruvian delegates was approved by almost unanimous vote, Chile alone holding out and protesting against the action taken.

An appeal for some knowledge of his parents is made by a young man who called at the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. For years he has been seeking to establish his identity. "I am known as John Marian," he said," which was the name given me in the Foundling Hospital, at Sixty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, twenty-two years ago.

A NEW PHASE OF THE MOROCCAN CASE. -- When it transpired a fortnight or so ago that the American Ambassador to Paris, Mr. Porter, intended to visit Morocco, considerable stir was created in European diplomatic circles as to the cause of his visit. (It was announced by cable yesterday that he had arrived in Tangier.)

The weekly statement or the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $4,608,500. The banks now hold a surplus of $12,278,275 above the legal requirement. The changes in averages show an increase in loans of $4,874,000, an increase in specie of $5,890,00, an increase in legal tenders of $1,648,800 an increase in deposits of $11,721,200, and an increase in circulation of $10,700.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Joseph L. Bristow in his annual report recommands an amendment to the Inter-State commerce law prohibiting telegraph and express companies of their employes from aiding or abetting in green-goods and lottery swindles, and other schemes carried on partly by mail and partly by common carriers in violation of tha postal laws.

-- It was not the Intention, in some remarks on bookkeeping which appeared in this column the other day, to place responsibility for the badly devised or badly executed systems of accounts which cause so much loss and make possible so much crime in business circles upon the men who do the actual writing in the books.

Tenants of apartments, and especially lawyers of the class designated by one of their own learned and honorable profession as "ambulance chasers," will be interested in a suit now on the calendar of the Supreme Court of Cook County, Illinois, known as MORDUE against ROSENTHAL, in which a tenant of an apartment house in Ingleside Avenue, Chicago, sues the owner for damages.
The private Secretary of the late Marcus Daly has telegraphed to Montana, in response to inquiries, that no information will be given to the public concerning Mr. Daly's will or estate.

It records the unquestioned indorsement of the gold standard, industrial independence, broader markets, commercial expansion, reciprocal trade, the open door in China, the inviolability of public faith, the independence and authority of the judiciary, and peace and beneficent government under American sovereignty in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- In view of the probable call upon the War Department to make a sudden increase in the enlisted strength of the army, after the present regular force has been discharged, it is a matter of considerable interest to see what may be done by the various recruiting offices toward building up the new regiments, when the number and strength of these is detertnined by the passage of the Army Reorganization bill.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The annual report of Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, for the year ended Oct. 31, 19OO, has been prepared for transmission to Congress.
Senator Thomas C. Platt passed through the rotunda of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon, and noticing a group of reporters, said with a smile, "Looking for innocent blood?"
James D. Clifford, formerly a Captain in the Fire Department, who was dismissed by Commissioner Scannell, addressed the Central Federated Union yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- E.C. Brandenburg, in charge of bankruptcy matters, has made a report to the Attorney General on the operation of the Bankruptcy act of July 1, 1898. The report says with reference to voluntary cases that advantage is being taken of the law by men of all classes and in all walks of life, and in every section of the country.

Continuing ease rules in the money market and all the indications, all the predictions, are that this agreeable state of affairs will remain for some time. The return flow of money from the interior has begun, to which fact are due in some measure the largely increased cash, holdings of the banks, as disclosed by the bank statement published on Saturday.

Policeman Converse of the West Thirtieth Street Station found a woman with her eighteen-months-old girl baby on Broadway at Thirty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon. Both were starving and their clothing was saturated by the rain. The woman, Claudia Staple of Omaha, came here in search of her husband, who, she says, has deserted her.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- Mr. Kruger pased Sunday with his family at the Hotel Scribe, observing the Sabbath in accordance with the customs of his fatherland. His apartments were closed to visitors and he remained within them. Although the boulevards were alive to a late hour last night with merrymakers, the Hotel Scribe was cordoned, and the revelers did not disturb his rest.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- William E. Duffy, who conducted an alleged boarding school for boys at Tuckahoe, was arrested there to-day, and brought before Judge Kellogg upon charges made by Dr. G.B. Balch of the New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children. It was alleged that the treatment of the boys at the place endangered their lives and morals.

Club Championships, Handicaps, and Tournaments Scheduled for the Day. With mild and clear weather Thanksgiving Day will witness one of the largest outpourings of golfers on the links that has ever been seen upon that time-honored holiday. While every local club has made provision for interesting sport, and in most cases the fair competitors have been well considered in the list of contests, the big field of crack golfers will be seen at Lakewood.

The reception of Mr. KRUEGER by the French Government has so far been marked on their part by every evidence of consummate tact, but in no less a degree by good taste. No official note from Downing Street formally announcing the annexation of the Boer republics has intervened to prevent the last President of the Transvaal from being received otherwise than according to his pretensions.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25. -- Marshal Oliver, Professor of Mathematics, United States Naval Academy, died here suddenly this afternoon from a stroke of apoplexy. The deceased was walking in the Naval Academy, where he lived, apparently in perfect health at noon. He ate a hearty dinner, and an hour afterward was taken sick.

Gen. "Joe" Wheeler and Lieut. Richmond Pearson Hobson were the chief attractions at the "mass meeting for men" yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The meeting was under the auspices of the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

Almost unheralded to the general sportloving public there has been developed an indoor Winter game during the past few years that gives every promise of obtaining a top-notch position in the annual cycle of sport. This game is indoor baseball. Like many another sport, and not a few of the more serious institutions of civilized life, the game owes its origin to chance.
On Tuesday last we remarked at the conclusion of an article pointing out the peculiar situation created by the tactics of Tammany in regard to the exposure of vice in certain quarters of the city:
BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- "Willie" Campbell, the well-known golf player of Scotland, died in Dorchester at 1:08 this morning of a complication of diseases. He was thirty-eight years of age.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

QUEBEC, Nov. 25. -- The searching party which left Seven Islands on Saturday afternoon to rescue any of the passengers or crew of the wrecked steamer St. Olaf who might have reached land returned this evening. They report having found only one body, that of Miss Page, buried in the snow and Ice.

Herbert L. Bridgman, Secretary of the Peary Arctic Club, at his home, 604 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, gave out some information concerning Lieut. Peary received in letters from the explorer. The letters, Mr. Bridgman said, were sent by Lieut. Peary to his wife in Washington. Mrs. Peary's family had forwarded the letters to Mr. Bridgman.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The Daily Mail, indorsing an article in its columns this morning from the pen of Frederick Greenwood, founder and first editor of The Pall Mall Gazette, advocates meeting the war budget by a tax of from 5 to 10 per cent. on foreign manufactured imports.

There is trouble ahead for the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company in Tremont, where the residents and property owners have declared open war upon the attempt of the company to bridge One Hundred and Eightieth Street, where a roundhouse and yards are being built to be used in connection with the extension now in course of construction from One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street to Fordham.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 25. -- 12 M. -- The following bulletin was issued this morning at Livadia:

Compelled to stand by and witness a public examination of his baggage, and finally to submit to a private examination, V.L. Tissera, an importer of Ceylon tea, was an object of much sympathy on the Cunard pier yesterday morning. He was among the arrivals on the Campania, having been abroad for several months investigating in behalf of several American firms engaged in the Ceylon trade the business conditions of that island.

The first competition of the season for the Haistead Trophy, which is shot for four times a year, was decided on the Seventh Regiment Armory ranges on Saturday night and was won by Company E, which beat Company C by the narrow margin of three points. Company E's score in detail was as follows:

The greatest horse sale of the year, the Fasig-Tipton Company's "Old Glory" offering of trotting bred stock, consigned by more than 200 owners to the New York market, was begun a short time before 11 o'clock yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden and continued into the evening, with a recess at 6 o'clock for dinner.

The meeting at the Chamber of Commerce at 3 o'clock this afternoon to suggest ways and means for the suppression and regulation of vice promises to fill the large assembly room of the Chamber to overflowing. So far as could be ascertained yesterday, no regular programme has been mapped out by the ten signers of the call for the meeting, but if such has been outlined it was carefully guarded.

The police of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station arrested yesterday a man who they say has for more than a year been victimizing physicians and surgeons throughout the Eastern States. The man describes himself as William A. Ferguson, living at the Capitol Hotel, Bowery and Houston Street.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- At the opening of to-day's session of the Cuban Constitutional Convention in the Marti Theatre, Senor de Quesada moved the rejection of the resolution introduced Saturday by Senores Rivero, Cisneros, and Villundas, expressing the sorrow of the convention at the departure of Gen. Fitzhugh Lee.

Commissioner Dalton of the Department of Water Supply had a long conference with Mayor Van Wyck yesterday. The talk was held after Commissioner Dalton had been before the Grand Jury, and this gave rise to many rumors that there would be a presentment in reference to water matters.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to moan only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Speaker S. Fred Nixon of the Assembly was in the city yesterday and had a long talk with Senator Platt and Chairman Dunn of the Republican State Committee regarding the chairmanships of the various Assembly committees in the next Legislature. Mr. Nixon had expected to see Gov-elect Odell, but that gentleman telegraphed from Newburg that he would not be in New York until to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- An answer was filed in the Court of Chancery this afternoon by the defendants in the suit of Henry I. Dittman and Kalman Haas against the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company, the Distillery Company of America, the Spirits Distributing Company, and others.
BUFFALO, Nov. 26 -- The Star Theatre was filled with a large and fashionable audience to-night, when Ada Rehan presented for the first time "Sweet Nell of Old Drury."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Four favorites and two long shots took first money at the Bennings racetrack to-day. In the fourth race Jockey Slack, who rode San Luis, claimed that Quite Right's rider had fouled him, but the claim was disallowed. In the handicap Carbuncle easily won over a small field. Summaries:

The North German Lloyd Steamship Company, having decided to rebuild their property recently destroyed by fire, in Hoboken, have had drawn plans for the construction of new piers and terminals which will give the company docking facilities superior to those of any transatlantic line touching this port, and unsurpassed in any part of the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reading public owes THE TIMES many thanks for its prompt and full report of Mr. Choate's address at Edinburgh on Mr. Lincoln's life work. It is a masterpiece among English classics, and a model to young men who are looking for a fine example of finished oratory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Treasury Department to-day decided to admit the lacemakers and their families, who were brought to this country by Dr. J.A. Dowle, the "Divine Healer" and the founder of Zion City, Ill., to teach others the art of lacemaking.

John Warren Mack. John Warren Mack, an insurance Journalist and Secretary of The Underwriter Printing and Publishing Company, died at his residence, 471 Lenox Avenue, Sunday morning. He was born at Bath, Steuben County, N.Y., in 1848, and was graduated from Cornell University in the class of '72.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Interest in the tradins to-day was largely in Montana and Butte. Both were active and strong. Montana rose 11, to 331, with another 5,000-share lot changing hands at 320, the closing being at 330. Some 7,000 shares were traded in during the morning. Butte sold between 96 and 94.

The death of John R. Heart at 5,127 Wabash Avenue on Sunday illustrates a point that has been dwelt upon for years by physicians and surgeons. Mr. Beart in August last had a struggle with a bulldog, and was bitten in three places. The struggle in itself was of a character to produce nervous exhaustion, to say nothing of the mutilation by the dog.

Sarah Bernhardt and Constant Coquelin, the leaders of the French stage, began their engagement at the Garden Theatre last evening with a memorably eloquent and moving performance of " L'Aiglon," by Edmond Rostand, one of the finest works of dramatic literature produced in any language within a century or more, and one that needs to be seen in the original, performed by French actors, to be thoroughly appreciated.

A new apartment hotel will be erected in the near future on the large plot at the southwest corner of Broadway and Sixty-seventh Street, as the result of negotiations closed yesterday by Broker John N. Golding for the sale of that property by the Flanagan estate to Franklin Pettit. The plot, which adjoins the Hotel Marie Antoinette, has frontages of 112.10 feet on Broadway.

Three men, believed by secret service officers and the police to be members of a gang of counterfeiters who have recently been operating extensively in Harlem and the upper part of the city, were captured last night after an exciting chase by Policemen O'Neill, Brueck, and Neuschaefer of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Pension Commissioner Evans has discovered that a "speak easy" has been running for some time in the Pension Bureau. It was a cooperative "speak easy." The employes of the bureau who were engaged in it entered a pool, and each took his turn acting as bartender and bringing in the liquor, the expense being borne by all.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am glad to see that some prominent members of the Chamber of Commerce are about to take action with a view of devising some plan to put an end to the corruption and vice which have been infesting our city. I hope that these gentlemen will endeavor to ascertain the cause of the trouble and not be satisfied to stir up matters on the surface.

Justice Bischoff, in the New York Supreme Court, yesterday denied the application of Moses Tanenbaum of the insurance brokerage firm of I. Tanenbaum, Son Co. for an injunction pending the trial of a suit to enjoin the New York Fire Insurance Exchange and other defendants from denying or refusing to Mr. Tanenbaum or his firm brokerage or commission on business, unless he obtains a license from the Exchange.

The Thanksgiving exodus from town will begin to-day, and the men and women of leisure who have not yet come to town for the Winter will again repair to country clubs and houses, which they left a week ago for the city and the Horse Show. The up-town fashionable districts seemed almost deserted yesterday, after the life and movement of last week.

Ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott, who is to prosecute Inspector Cross and Capt. Herlihy on charges based on the condition of the Pro-Cathedral district, which Bishop Potter set forth in his letter of Nov. 15 to Mayor Van Wyck, was at Police Headquarters yesterday, and for nearly two hours discussed the action he is to take with President York and Commissioner Sexton.
The objective of every intelligent movement for the purification of the city must be the police.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- David R. Snover, an Orange lawyer, was sentenced to six months' imprisonment in the county penitentiary by Judge Skinner, in the Court of Special Sessions, to-day, for embezzling money with the handling of which he had been intrusted by a client. The amount involved was $1,575, and Snover is said to have lost the money in stock speculations.

MARYSVILLE, Iowa, Nov. 26 -- Dr. H.A. Hamilton, a prominent physician of this place, was shot dead to-day. Alfred Alin, who had accused the doctor of causing the separation of Alin and his wife, is under arrest on the charge of firing the fatal shot. No one saw the shot fired, and the physician died without making any statement.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Thank you so much for your sane and timely leader upon the subject of an independent paper to be projected by certain altruistic gentlemen and Dr. Parkhurst.

Since the so-called war taxes are to be reduced at the coming session of Congress, if the Republican leaders carry out their announced intention, there is one tax that they can abolish altogether with propriety. This is the tax on bequests for educational institutions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A dispatch from Mr. Conger was received at the State Department to-day, giving details of the agreement reached by the foreign Ministers at Peking, but nothing regarding it was given out for publication. As soon as Secretary Hav had digested the contents, he went over to the White House and spent some time there.

During the last week or two much has been written about Czar NICHOLAS II. of Russia, and prayers for his recovery have doubtless been widespread and sincere. But in all that we have seen or heard expressed there has been a curious misconception of the imperial attributes of the Emperor and of the ways in which he may exercise them.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Aesthetic Boston received a severe shock to-day when Curator Robinson of the Museum of Fine Arts sorrowfully announced that one of the most prized collections in the museum -- the Appleton Tanagra figures -- are rank fakes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The air in most of the churches of Chicago will send people who are bound that way to heaven quicker than any of the preaching they listen to."

There was a meeting of the Executive Committee of the New York University yesterday at the office of William P. Havemeyer, 32 Nassau Street. J. Shirley Eaton, the statistician of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, was appointed to fill the chair of Domestic Commerce and Transportation.

It is human and natural that civilization should demand the stern punishment of the Chinese officials who were responsible for the attack upon the legations and for the murders committed during the months when the Boxers were rampant and government authority in eclipse throughout the empire.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- November corn touched 50 cents to-day. It made an advance of 5 cents a bushel for the day, of 10 cents for the week, and of almost 1 cents, within four weeks. Young George H. Phillips sold what corn changed hands at 50 cents. Shorts did the buying that advanced the market to that quotation.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 26 -- The battered hulk of what was the St. John schooner Advance was washed ashore on Wallis Sands this afternoon, with no signs of life aboard. Whether her crew of four or five men have been taken off by a passing vessel or have found a watery grave can only be conjectured.

The report of the special commission to revise the New York city charter, which has been sent to Gov. Roosevelt, will be made public next Monday. George L. Rives, Chairman of the commission, stated last night that he had an understanding with Gov. Roosevelt whereby he (Mr. Rives) was to make public the report of the commission.

Airshafts were the one evil concerning which all witnesses agreed, in testifying before the public hearing of the Tenement House Commission of the State of New York at the Charities Building last night. About a dozen witnesses were examined, and nearly all of them are or have been tenement dwellers.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Reports showing that during the past year the organization has given assistance to more than 4,000 people were presented at the ninety-seventh annual meeting of the Newark Female Charitable Society to-day. The society is at present giving assistance to 177 families by means of sewing, laundry work, or money.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 26 -- A special dispatch to The Commercial-Tribune from Charleston, West Va., says:

Advancing quotations were the order on the stock market yesterday, and this though the bears worked hard to bringabout a further reaction, offering many stocks down. The buying, however, was much better than the selling, support coming from interests too substantial to be frightened or affected by the tactics of the small traders on the bear side.
BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- From a high Court official it is ascertained that Empress Augusta Victoria has greatly aged of late, her hair being now entirely gray and thin, and her forehead furrowed.

The contract for the removal of snow from the streets of the Borough of Brooklyn was returned to the Street Cleaning Department yesterday by Controller Coler. The formal signing of the contract by the city officials and the contractors has not taken place, and if the objections urged by some of the members of the Board of Estimate are heard there will be a searching investigation before the contract is signed.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Bowery waiter, who turns out to be an English nobleman in cheap fiction, has turned up in real life in the person of Percy Vernon, who recently succeeded to the title and estates of his uncle, Fitzpatrick Henry Vernon, Baron Lyveden, with a town house in Belgrave Place and a country seat with 4,200 acres in Northamptonshire.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- The entire German press refers editorially this evening to a report that United States Ambassador White on Saturday handed the new American note regarding the Chinese settlement to Baron von Richthofen, Secretary for Foreign Affairs, all the papers declaring that Germany refuted to comply with the demands therein formulated.
