Creditors of Count Boni de Castellane and the Countess de Castellane, formerly Anna Gould, have decided to ignore the action of the French courts in appointing George Gould as the guardian of the Countess, and have arranged to bring actions in this State with the view of preventing the Countess obtaining all of the income due her from the Gould estate until her debts, which amount to several million dollars, have been paid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- In making up the Republican caucus list of the Senate the name of Senator Wellington of Maryland has been omitted at his own request. He has, however, chosen a seat on the Republican side.

With only two days remaining for hard work before the Thanksgiving Day game against the Carlisle Indians, Coach Sanford save the Columbia football squad yesterday afternoon an hour of the most relentless practice. It was the first severe work that the squad had had since Friday. At the outset of the practice game there was a trace of raggedness and a backsliding tendency to fumble on the part of both the Varsity and substitutes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The Times-Herald says three Chicago yachtsmen have formed a pool to build a defender for the Canada's Cup, and will strive to produce a craft worthy to represent the Chicago Yacht Club in the race with the Canadian representative. George M. Pynchon, Benjamin Carpenter, and Morrill Dunn, all noted lake yachtsmen, are the members of the syndicate.

Total transactions in the market for outside securities yesterday were much smaller than the average of last week, but in point of view of prices the day was a favorable one. Some reactions took place, but in the majority of stocks prices were well maintained, and in a number net gains resulted from the day's trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of the Navy Long has submitted his report for the past year to the President. He opens by reviewing the operations in the Far East, commnding the prudence and efficiency of Rear Admirals Remey and Kempff, and proceeds by outlining the movements of vessels at the various stations.

Recorder Goff yesterday denied the motion of Abraham Levy, counsel for twenty-three persons accused of violations of the elections law, to dismiss the indictments against his clients, on the ground that the McCullagh election law is unconstitutional. Recorder Goff held that the amendment to the elections law gave to the Attorney General authority to prosecute election cases in person or through his deputies.

The first Boer lighting men ever seen in this country arrived here yesterday on the steamship Statendam from Rotterdam, having less than two months ago crossed the border of their native land and sailed away for the New World to seek new homes for their people. They are Samuel Pearson, who was Commissary General of the Boer Army throughout the war; Commandants W. Snyman and A. Leibenberg.

The will of Charles Hale Hoyt, the playwright, was filed in the Surrogates' office, this city, yesterday. A certified copy was filed at the same time in Charlestown, N. H. Among his friends Mr. Hoyt was supposed to have no relatives, but after his death several cousins appeared. The will, which is dated Oct. 15, 1898, has the following to say about relatives:

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Ralph Hoagland, the well-known Princeton football player, holds the record for accepting a long-distance assignment to officiate at a football game. Mr. Hoagland left De Kalb to-night for San Francisco, where he will umpire the annual championship same between California and Leland Stanford Universities Thanksgiving Day.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Cabinet meeting to-day was occupied mainly with a discussion of Chinese affairs, and the reading of portions of the President's forthcoming message to Congress.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- With all the pomp and circumstance which might have attended the obsequies of a member of the royal family, the body of Sir Arthur Sullivan, who died here last Thursday, was buried in St. Paul's Cathedral this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The racing at Bennings to-day was without special feature. The weather was cool, track, heavy, and attendance good. Four favorites and two long shots won out. In the handicap, KinniKinnic, the favorite, landed the money, Speedmas, who has won several times during this meeting, finishing last. Summaries:

"The New York and Paris Dry Goods Store," an establishment which has been running at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Eighth Avenue for the last two months, disappeared some time between the hours of 2 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning, and at present the creditors of Milton Uhler, who ran the store, are searching high and low for him.
The Fidelia bowlers, the leaders in the National League tournament won three straight games from the Berkeley five on Starr's alleys last night, passing the 900 mark twice. The scores:

Chief Rodenbough of the Bureau of Elections yesterday afternoon sent information to the Police Board and asked for the assistance of the Detective Bureau in regard to an attempt at wholesale fraud in connection with the cashing of the pay certificates of Inspectors of Elections.

The stock market yesterday had not only to absorb a good deal of long stock offered by London and home holders desirous of taking profits, but it also had to stand concerted pressure brought to bear upon it by the room traders, who still continue to fight the upward movement of prices -- though not because they do not believe in it, but because they have been left out of it.

J.M. Horton has bought the tract belonging to the estate of David Dudley Field, bounded by Amsterdam Avenue and the Speedway and the centre lines of One Hundred and Eighty-sixth and One Hundred and Eighty-eighth Streets. The property has a frontage of 573 feet on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue, and has an average width of about 525 feet.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Money is in good demand and scarce, and the Bank of England entirely controls the market. Discounts are very firm. A large number of bills were taken to-day by the Bank of England. Business is so brisk that the bank is adhering to a more rigid rule and is not discounting after 2 o'clock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would seem to all broad-minded people that Bishop Goodsell's attack on the Pope and Roman Catholic Church was in extremely bad taste from an ethical standpoint, aside from the un-Christlike spirit shown toward an opposite religious organization.

-- New York has had experiences of her own that enable her to appreciate just how Boston feels over the discovery that certain terra cotta figurines long treasured in the Museum of Fine Arts as "from Tanagra" are in part out and out forgeries, and in part adroit conglomerations of ancient but unrelated fragments.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Richard Croker goes to Carlsbad in a few days for three months. He had a long farewell talk this evening with the Reiffs, who sail for New York on the Deutschland Friday. Mr. Croker has engaged both the Reiffs and his trainer, Wishard, for next season.

A question of law involving the validity of a will, by which a wife bequeathed all her property unconditionally to her husband, and after the execution of which a child was born to the testatrix, is to be settled in a suit brought by Harrie Jaynes Stokum of Brooklyn against the Kiashema Inn Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in your editorial comment in THE TIMES of Saturday last upon the report of our Consul at Aix-laChapelle. That Consul Brundage should seriously notice in an official report the work of circus bill posters and showmen as calculated to inspire respect for American workmen and American methods, does seem rather odd.

"It is amusing to see the entire Republican press of New York organized in an attempt to strengthen the Democratic Party in New York, the greatest Democratic stronghold in America," was Mr. Croker's first comment.

The history of draw poker has been enriched by a decision handed down yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court, which holds that a winner in a poker game cannot collect from a loser even if the debt is acknowledged, Justice O'Gorman wrote the opinion, in which Justices Giegerich and Beekman concurred.
Senator HALE of Maine, with the experience of years to guide him, utters a prompt cry of warning to his party to "go slow" in the use of the power conferred on it in the recent elections.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27. -- It is stated here that there is a possibility that the New York Central will acquire the Ottawa and New York Railway, and in that way gain an entrance to the Dominion capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The House Committee on Military Affairs to-day met for the purpose of considering the new Army bill. The business was mostly of a preliminary character, the discussion being quite general on army affairs. The Republican members of the committee apparently are in favor of giving the President such an army as he may require.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday afternoon at the Chase National Bank. The following officers were re-elected: President -- D. Willis James; Vice President -- C.E. Whitehead; Treasurer -- A.B. Hepburn; Secretary -- C.L. Brace. The five Trustees re-elected are William Church Osborn, Charles E. Whitehead, J. Kennedy Tod, James R. Roosevelt, and Arthur C. James.

In the now aged farce called "Gloriana," an adaptation by James Mortimer of a French piece called "Le Truc d'Arthur," the abilities of the members of the company at the Murray Hill Theatre are not too severely tested this week. The plot is of the most conventional type and the personages are all long familiar creatures of farce, the like of whose idiosyncrasies it would be hard to find in real life.

Gov.-elect B. B. Odell. Jr., came down from Newburg yesterday and spent several hours at State Headquarters. When Mr. Odell reached the Fifth Avenue Hotel, shortly after noon, he was greeted by Col. George W. Dunn, the new Chairman of the State Committee; S. Fred Nixon, Speaker of the Assembly; Jotham P. Allds, the majority leader of the Assembly; Francis Hendricks, Superintendent of Insurance; Senator Krum of Schoharie, Assemblyman De Graw of Brooklyn, and others.
She came out with a bundle of War Crys in her hands; then stopped suddenly, her eyes fixed on the billboard in front of Salvation Army headquarters in Fourteenth Street.

Albert Bart Roeder, son-in-law of John E. Searles, former President of the Amercan Sugar Refining Company, filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States District Court yesterday afternoon, with liabilities of $345,255 and no assets. Among his liabilities are accounts due Mrs. Theresa Lynch, the diamond dealer, for $1,357; the New York Cab Company, $354 for cab hire, and James W. Bell, Son Co., tailors, $460 for clothes.

The Citizens' Union was formally launched in Brooklyn by forty-five citizens hitherto representing different political faiths at a meeting in the Art Association rooms at 174 Montague Street last evening. Ludwig Nissen was appointed Chairman of the meeting, and Robert Baker, who was sent over from the Manhattan organization, was made Secretary.

It is necessary only to turn back over a very few pages of French history to see that, whether or not the Municipal Councilors of Paris vote for an arbitration in the South African business, the result can have no possible effect upon the attitude of the French Government. That body will continue its attitude of respectful observance of the temperament of Downing Street and of patient toleration of the presence of Mr. KRUEGER.

Golfers and pigeon shots have much in common, and it is becoming no unusual thing to see one who is well known in either of these sports acquire a fair degree of prominence and fame in the other. "Joe" Knapp's victory of the 36-hole handicap at Garden City last week was a case in point.

NEWARK, Nov. 27. -- John Leltenberger, a young baker, of Newark, who is in love with Mamie Betz of 161 Court Street, had an experience with Mamie's father last night that rather dashed his ardor. For three years he had been courting the girl sub rosa, having met with the opposition of her father, Henry Betz, at the outset.
In the course of an address last Sunday in advocacy of Catholic schools, Father LAVELLE, the esteemed rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, said:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- The police of this city to-night arrested a woman who goes by the name of Mme. Nicholson Brown, and whose business is fortune telling. Mme. Brown had advertised extensively in the newspapers as one who could read the future, explain the secret of happy marriage, and do other things not in the ken of ordinary mortals.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Mr. C.W. Mullin states in your Sunday issue that he writes "from the standpoint of a member of the Established Church of England, and one who in this country is strictly non-sectarian."
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on "Mr. Kruger's Mission," you write:

We have just had an instance of the fate of monopolies which undertake to be too greedy. It would be very interesting to compare the expectations with which Mr. CHARLES W. MORSE of the American Ice Company started out this present year of grace with the realizations with which he finds himself confronted at the end of it.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- When the attention of Dr. Leyds was called this afternoon to the statement attributed to Samuel Pearson, former Commissary General of the Transvaal Army, and cabled from New York that Mr. Kruger would probably soon proceed to the United States, he replied: "The rumor is without foundation.
A Committee of Fifteen will be appointed "to prevent and eradicate vice in every form" in this city as the result of a meeting held yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce.

Fifth in the line of prisoners before Magistrate Pool in Yorkville Court yesterday morning was a little mite of a boy. His shoes had been blackened until they mirrored his face, which, too, had been painfully shined. His hair was parted and brushed into an unnatural gloss. It was obvious that the prisoner had been prepared to impress the Court as a good boy who was out of his native element.

Six cases of smallpox were reported to the Board of Health during the twentyfour hours ended at noon yesterday, marking the first appearance of the disease in this city since August, save for an isolated case in Brooklyn a few days ago. Four of these cases have been traced directly to a colored woman, for whom the Inspectors of the Health Department are searching.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Does not your editorial against granting the city permission to do its own printing take a somewhat belated view of the functions of a municipality?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- George W. Wilson, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, died this forenoon in his apartments at the Riggs House of Bright's disease, complicated with asthma. He had been dangerously ill for several days past. There were with him at the time of his death Mrs. Wilson, his daughter, Mrs. Pardonner, and several of his associates of the Treasury Department.

Daniel Crain, whose form of insanity is religious mania, managed to stir up several neighborhoods between his home, 2,354 Southern Boulevard, and Bellevue Hospital last night, and incidentally gave the physicians of Fordham and Harlem Hospitals no end of trouble in the transfer. Hallucinations that the people in the flathouse in which he lived ought to die flitted through Crain's imagination about the time the tenants were getting up from supper.

The opening of an electric line from Hudson to Albany, paralleling and in a manner necessarily challenging the Hudson River Road, is an event of almost or quite unique importance. It is so for the reason that this is the first venture of the kind which aspires to do the general business of a railroad, in freight as well as in passengers.

The Fasig-Tipton Company's "Old Glory" sale of light harness horses in Madison Square Garden drew another large crowd of trotting horsemen yesterday for the second day and night of the great offering, and from 10 o'clock in the morning until 10 at night, except for short recess for dinner, the auction was in progress.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- New York Will be well represented at the second annual exhibition of the Philadelphia Dog Show, which will open at Horticultural Hall to-morrow, and will continue during the remainder of the week. A large proportion of the 1,500 entries are from metropolitan kennels, and a majority of the judges are New York fanciers.

MANILA, Nov. 28. -- A detachment of the Third United States Infantry was ambushed Saturday near Mallolos. The Ladrones fired a volley at the Americans, killing two privates of Company F and wounding three. The insurgents escaped into a swamp.

The Board of County Canvassers met at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and announced the official vote cast in New York County (Borough of Manhattan and the Bronx) for all offices. The vote for President and Governor as officially certified was as follows:

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Mr. Kruger began a busy day this morning by making an official call on the Premier. Before 9 o'clock he departed from the Hotel Scribe, driving in a landau surrounded by Republican guards and bicycle policemen, to visit M. Waldeck-Rousseau. He was accompanied by Dr. Leyds, Dr. Van Hammel, and Mr. Fischer.

Martin A. Repp, a saloon keeper, of 3,454 Fifth Avenue, early yesterday morning heard a burglar in his apartments, on the fifth floor of the building in which he lives. He chased the man out of the window on to the fire-escape, where, clad only in his nightshirt and without anything on his feet, he followed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- In his annual report, just issued, Superintendent Talcott of the State Homeopathic Hospital here assigns intemperance as the cause of the greatest number of cases of insanity among the men in that institution, and mental strain and worry the cause of the greatest number among the women.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27. -- Pretty girls of the Woman's College sat beside a grinning skeleton, which had the seat of honor at a unique entertainment last night in Bennett Hall of the college. The affair was called a "laboratory supper." Young women students from all parts of the country gathered about the board.

Weary with fighting off death for nearly two days, the crew of the three-masted schooner Hattie V. Kelsie, Capt. Rulon, were towed into the harbor yesterday afternoon on their weather beaten vessel. Until they were taken in tow by the wrecking tug L.J. Merritt early in the morning, none of them had had an hour's rest or a taste of food for more than thirty-six hours.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 27. -- Ex-Senator W.D. Washburn is likely to succeed Senator Davis. Gov. Lind will make the appointment within a few days, as a blow to the Republican leaders and candidates. It so happens that Gov. Lind's term of office will not expire until Jan. 1. He is a Democrat, or Fusionist.

"Let us throw off this detestable yoke," said Dr. FELIX ADLER at the meeting held in the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. That is the aim of the purification movement, to put an end to the detestable subjugation of this city to a political organization corruptly in league with vice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Senator Hale of Maine, in an interview to-day, indicated that he intends to place himself in opposition to some of the measures recently proposed. He said: "The Republican Party should now go slow. We have had a great and deserved victory. The people have expressed their faith in the Administration, and have committed the entire Government to the Republican Party for at least another Congress.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Young Prince von Hohenlohe-Oehringen, youngest brother of Herzog von Ujest, has entered the service of a large Berlin bank, which is a very unusual proceeding for a member of the German nobility.

"Never in all my experience have I seen such an infamous transaction where a lawyer and a son combined to defraud an old father," exclaimed Magistrate Pool, indignantly, in the Yorkville Court yesterday during the examination of Louts Poirier of 20 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, charged with having conspired to defraud his father, John D. Poirier, and whose counsel was Joseph Hlavac, Jr., of 93 Nassau Street.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 27. -- The relations between the United States Government and the Porte are becoming acute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley will give the first of a series of dinner parties Thursday, Dec. 6, when they will entertain the sixteen American Commissioners to the Paris Exposition. Mrs. Root and Miss Root, wife and daughter of the Secretary of War, returned today.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 27. -- The annual football contest between the Orange and Newark Athletic Clubs, which will be played on Orange Oval Thursday morning for the Eastern athletic championship and the Weidemayer Cup, is the main topic among football enthusiasts in Jersey. Both organizations have strengthened their possible weak points and each thinks it has the winning team.

Robert E.A. Dorr, editor and publisher of The Mail and Express, died early yesterday morning at his residence, 685 West End Avenue. For some months Mr. Dorr had been a sufferer from a complication of intestinal troubles, and his death was not unexpected. During the past ten days he had failed greatly.

Amos D. Smith, Third. Amos D. Smith, Third, who for many years was the general agent of the Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, and who was State Commissioner in the State of Rhode Island, as well as a Colonel attached to the staff of the Governor of the State throughout the civil war, died yesterday at his residence, at 9 East Ninth Street.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 27. -- United States Senator Cushman Kellogg Davis, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate, died at his home in this city at 9 o'clock this evening after an illness of two months. He had suffered greatly during his sickness, and gradually sank away, being unconscious for several hours before death, and, so far as known, suffered no pain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Frantic efforts are being made by shorts caught in the Phillips corn corner to swamp him with grain on the last day of the option. The way in which they hope to down him and get themselves out of a tight place is by reinspection of this week's receipts, which have been graded No. 3, one grade too low to pass on contract.
Activity and strength of the Seaboard Air Line stocks on the Baltimore Stock Exchange beyond all records of that institution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The future of the Democratic Party is an interesting subject, especially so just now, in view of the chaotic condition of that great party. I have read with interest Mr. Carlisle's suggestion in The Evening Post that the reorganization movement, if begun at all, must begin with the South, as it is now the only Democratic part of the country.

Contracts will be signed shortly for the sale of the four lots on the north side of Ninety-eighth Street, beginning 100 feet west of West End Avenue, by the Metropolitan Improvement Company, to E.L. Smith, for $70,000. The buyer will erect on the entire pict a seven-story apartment house, arranged to accommodate five families on a floor.

An innovation in produce stakes is announced by the Westchester Racing Association in the conditions for the Matron, open now to mares whose entry will make eligible to the race their foals, two years old in 1903. The new feature of the event is a division of the stakes into two parts, one for a race exclusively for fillies, and the other for colts and geldings, a plan adopted to equalize the chances of owners.

We have received a copy of the address given by EUGENE SMITH, Esq., of this city before the National Prison Association at its recent annual meeting, on "The Cost of Crime." It is a singularly interesting paper, careful in its statements, moderate in its conclusions, and written with great clearness.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 28. -- Never before in Newport's history have there been so many of the cottagers here for Thanksgiving dinner as will be the case to-morrow.

Michael Healy, forty years old, a stone mason, living in Mechanic Street, New Rochelle, N.Y., jumped from a fourth-story window of a flat occupied by his step-brother. John Farrelly, 311 West Sixty-ninth Street, last night, and will die. The building is known as "All Nations Block."

Very little more need be said, from a critical point of view, of the new "modern play" at Daly's Theatre. "The Man of forty." Its reckless use of coincidence, its unsophisticated construction, its lack of the desirable theatrical quality called "sympathy" are not to be disputed. Yet its merit is considerable, and it "acts" surprisingly well.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The conversation which Mr. Kruger had with the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, yesterday, was confined to the former sounding the latter as to the probable attitude of France in certain eventualities. Mr. Kruger did not press for a definite statement.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The trolley lines in Elizabeth, Rahway, and Plainfield, with the exception of the North Jersey Street Railway Company's system in Elizabeth, have been consolidated, and will be known as the Elizabeth, Plainfield and Central Jersey Railway. The new company has a capital stock of $3,000,000, and is authorized to issue bonds to the amount of $2,500,000.

BEAVER, Penn., Nov. 28. -- The Cleveland night express, leaving Pittsburg at midnight, on the Cleveland and Pittsburg Road, ran into a washout half a mile west of Beaver, Penn., at 1 o'clock this morning, and the locomotive, mail, baggage, and express cars jumped from the tracks and plunged into the Ohio River.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The second annual bench show of the Philadelphia Dog Show Association opened to-day in Horti-cultural Hall, and will continue throughout this week. The exhibition is second only to the New York show, and the bulldog classes have never been equaled in this country.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 28. -- In a letter addressed to the Bryan Home Guards to-day, W.J. Bryan says: "The contest between Democracy and plutocracy will go on, and those who believe in the Declaration of Independence and the doctrine of equal rights before the law must still defend human rights from the encroachments of greed."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Some interesting and vigorous correspondence has taken place between the Interior Department and Gov. C.S. Thomas of Colorado, and Indian Agent Myton of the Uintah and Ouray Agency, in Utah, as the result of reports of incursions of Indians on Colorado lands in quest of game.

The Manhattan Elevated Railway Company's project to bridge East One Hundred and Eightieth Street struck a snag yesterday afternoon, when about a hundred property owners attended the hearing before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen and opposed the scheme. The hearing lasted three hours.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- The list was extremely dull all day, and the trading was narrow. Amalgamated was the only feature, and under the same mysterious selling that had been in evidence for several days past, sold off to 93 1/2, but closed stronger at 95 1/2. New York certificates of small lots were offered in delivery to-day.

QUEENS, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Splendid birds, some of the best shooting ever done on the famous Inter-State Park grounds near here, coupled with an attendance of several hundred enthusiastic lovers of trap shooting, marked the third renewal of the Inter-State handicap to-day.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- John J. Vetter, fifty years old, an incurable invalid, committed suicide at his home, 418 South Sixth Street, late this afternoon by drinking carbolic acid. He was despondent.

A young German woman, with three bullet wounds in her head, supposed to have been inflicted by her sweetheart, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning from her apartment, at 212 East Twenty-fifth Street. She gave her name as Gertie Beier, her age as twenty-three years. In the flathouse where she lived she was known as Mrs. G. Wolfram.

It must be particularly gratifying to Secretary. HAY to observe that all Europe seems to be coming round to his way of thinking about the Chinese question. For the present attitude of the Powers seems to show that they are beginning to see what he long ago foresaw.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to say in reply to the remarks of ex-Capt. Clifford, quoted in THE TIMES of the 26th inst. as having been uttered at a meeting of the Central Federated Union on the 23th Inst.:

The Board of Health at its meeting yesterday morning received a report, preliminary in its nature, from the chemists who were given samples of the Croton water to analyze. The report was dated Nov. 28, 1900, and is as follows:
R. Fulton Cutting, President of the Citizens' Union, gave out yesterday a statement of his views as to the way the coming municipal campaign should be conducted. He said:

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 28. -- Halcyon Skinner, the man who revolutionized the carpet making industry, was killed to-day by being struck by a train on the New York Central Railroad in this city. Mr. Skinner was wealthy, and lived in a house which backed upon the river. It was his habit to pass out of his rear gate and walk up the railroad tracks, which skirt the river, to his boathouse.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The semi-official Berliner Post, in the course of an evidently inspired article, replying to the suggestions of more lenient punishment of the guilty officials in China made by the United States Government, says:

Judge William W. Cohen, Senator Platt's legal adviser, announced yesterday that he was drawing up three police bills, each of which differs from the others. Senator Platt has heard so much talk about the probable unconstitutionality of a State Police bill that he is evidently determined to take no chances.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Elmer Robinson, a member of the Seach's Inlet lifesaving crew, hovered for hours this morning between life and death and is still far from being out of danger as a result of a fearful experience he had last night. During all the cold night he floated about the Great South Bay half submerged and soaking wet.

John Stovel of New Rochelle is relating with much gusto to his fellow-Westchester County farmers to-day how "he seen the sight, down in N'York t'other day." and how after many thrilling experiences, he arrived home safely with his money in his right boot leg, thanks to the good offices of the police, who saved not only his wealth, but his life.

Postmaster Van Cott returned yesterday from Washington, where he has been conferring with the Post Office authorities regarding the appropriation bill for a new Post Office in this city. In speaking of the matter Mr. Van Cott said he thought the prospects for the passage of the bill brighter than ever before.

It is not likely that the venerable President of the ex-Transvaal Republic entertained any illusions about his reception in Europe. Oom PAUL was not born yesterday. His retreat to Europe, as an alternative to expulsion to St. Helena, was perfectly explicable. But it was none the less a clear confession of defeat, a throwing up of the sponge.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- A letter to The Standard from its correspondent with the Twenty-sixth Infantry in the Philippines gives a detailed account of the death of Second Lieut. Max Wagner of that regiment, who was killed on the evening of Oct. 2 while en route to Santa Barbara from Jaro with Private Lamoreux, his orderly.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 28. -- At a meeting of the leaders of the Democratic Party of this State to inquire into the cause of the defeat of the party at the recent election, it was unanimously decided that the Democratic Party in this State should disband.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 28. -- It was the general belief here that the Keel of the new cup defender will not be run for four weeks yet. The working force at the boatshops has been doubled, but the work on hand is that of repairing the seventyfooter Rainbow, and every effort is being made to get her out of the way.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28. -- A committee representing the M. A. Hanna Republican Club of this city, which recently passed a resolution indorsing Mr. Hanna as a candidate for the Presidency in 1904, called upon the Senator to-day at his office to present the resolution. President Gallagher of the club acted as spokesman.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day granted the application of the Jamestown, Chautauqua and Lake Erie Railroad for permission to construct a road, about sixteen miles in length, which will connect the Jamestown and Chautauqua Road with the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad at Westford.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Navy Department knows absolutely nothing of the reported loss of the Yosemite. Secretary Long said to-night that he had heard nothing of it except what he had been told by reporters, whose only information was based upon press dispatches.

Despite the fact that yesterday's stock market was under pressure practically all day from three different sources, not only were there no material recessions, but in not a few instances closing figures showed net gains for the day. In the early trading London was a large seller of stocks, the sales from that source running up to 75,000 shares, distributed throughout the international list.

G.C. Howe, who succeeded Charles E. Leland as proprietor of the Hotel Kensington, at Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, has received a new lease of the property for a term of five years at an aggregate rental of $73,000. Negotiations were conducted through Broker Matthew J. Ward.
William Faversham, leading man of the Empire Theatre Stock Company, is lying critically ill at his home, 260 West Fiftysecond Street, where on Tuesday afternoon he was operated upon for appendicitis.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The fires were drawn this afternoon from the Cohansey Company's window glass tank. Five hundred men and boys are thrown out of work. The blowers struck because of "dockage" on "market money" last week. The men demanded more and that the company pay the scale.

The police authorities yesterday were silent as to any phase of vicious conditions and their repression or control. President York and Commissioners Sexton and Abell were at Police Headquarters, but did not meet. Chief Devery and Mr. York's colleagues, however, had a conference.

Thanksgiving day of late years has not been one of much social incident in town. Since the Faculties of Yale, Princeton, and Harvard prohibited the football teams of those universities from playing in New York City the annual football contest between Yale and Princeton, which was formerly the event of the holiday in town, has ceased to mark the day.

Five people were more or less seriously burned in a fire that almost demolished the third floor of the six-story tenement at 115-117 Essex Street early yesterday morning. The injured were Joseph Savetzky, thirty-six years old; Morris Savetzlcy, ten years old; Samuel Savetzky, five years old; Gussie Kartgener, twenty-two years old, and Ray Nathan, seventeen years old.

A movement has begun in St. Louis to induce the Board of Health of that city to embody in its Sanitary Code a clause declaring whistling in street cars and other public conveyances a nuisance, and forbidding the same under such moderate penalties as it is permitted to impose.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to compliment you on the admirable sense of neutrality you have displayed in publishing the melodramatic effusion to be found under the heading, "A Plea for Oom Paul," in your issue of today.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 28. -- W.E. McCormack, Dartmouth, 1897, has been engaged for Dartmouth's football coach next year. Dartmouth has been trying to secure his services for several years, but he has been retained by Exeter, where he has turned out a winning team for three out of four years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The State Department has cabled to Minister Conger to forward the text of the agreement reached by the foreign Ministers at Peking. Meanwhile Mr. Conger will withhold his signature until the President has had an opportunity to satisfy himself as to this important document and to make such changes as will bring it in accord with the Administration's policy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If it were to be determined ab initio what measure of local self-government should be granted to municipalities in some State to be organized, or if the discussion were merely academic, the arguments of your correspondents in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES in favor of a State constabulary bill would seem to be of much force.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Finding themselves unable to produce enough contract No. 2 corn to fill sales made to George H. Phillips for November delivery, the shorts, including several leading elevator firms, it was announced to-day on the Board of Trade, had agreed to settle their shortage at 50 cents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Consul General Mason, at Berlin, has submitted his annual report for 1900 to the Department of State, in which he combines a comprehensive review of commercial and industrial conditions in Germany during the past year with an earnest injunction for an amicable adjustment of the many vexed questions of trade existing between the empire and the United States.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 28. -- Among the yachts at this port is the steamer Wacouta, belonging to J.J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railroad. The Wacouta was formerly the Eleanor, built at Bath, Me., for W.A. Slater of Norwich, Conn. The Wacouta will go into commission about Feb. 15, when, it is said, her owner contemplates a European cruise.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 28. -- Changes in Louisville of great interest in connection with the American and Continental Tobacco Companies will, it is announced, go into effect Dec. 1.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew to-day presented to the State an oil painting of himself made when he was twenty-nine years of age, and which will replace the one recently painted that hung in the Secretary of State's office together with other portraits of former Secretaries. The picture was painted by A. Muller Ury, who also painted the one taken down.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Owing to the near approach of the convening of Congress, many Senators and Representatives cannot attend the funeral of Senator Davis. The members of the Ways and Means Committee will meet on Saturday, probably, to act on the war revenue reduction measure, so they cannot attend.

Charles D. Hughes and Ira D. Godfrey, stock brokers, who were arrested Tuesday by Capt. McClusky's detectives at their offices, 20 Broad Street, on a charge of grand larceny, preferred by Prosecuting Attorney James T. Aimsber of Defiance, Ohio, were both committed to the Tombs in default of $1,500 bail by Magistrate Zeller, sitting in the Centre Street Court, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- A financial coup, to evade the franchise-extension question entirely, at least for a term of years, is said to be under consideration by leading officials of the traction companies. It involves a reorganization of all the existing traction corporations and their merger into a new parent corporation, whose ultimate capitalization will be little less than $50,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Three years ago the German Government awarded a gold medal and a money prize to a sailor whose courage and daring had saved from death the crew of a German bark. The gifts were placed in the hands of the German Consul General at New York, but active search failed to find the man for whom they were intended.

We must co-operate, even if one of the conferrees be Mr. PLATT. He must be impressed with our idea of what is good for the city, and the way to impress Mr. PLATT is to have strength behind you. When you have that you will find Mr. PLATT very affable. -- President CUTTING of the Citizens' Union.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "Catholics and School Money" again brings to the forum of public discussion the question why should our Catholic fellow citizens burden themselves with a separate system of schools? The reason they allege is that the public schools are godless, i.e., they do not teach theoiogy.

A cable dispatch published yesterday contained a prescription for consumption of Prof. Hoff, who was said to be a scientist of high standing in Vienna. Prof. Hoff, according to his own account, has found the prescription efficacious, and now freely offers it to the world. This is the prescription:

The Tenement House Commission, appointed by the Legislature to investigate the tenement house problem in New York, held a public hearing yesterday in the assembly hall of the United Charities Building on the subject of vice in tenements.

-- Seeing queer cases by the dozen every day, of course the Police Magistrate loses appreciation of queerness, as such, since to him it becomes the commonplace. Still it does seem as though Magistrate ZELLER might have given a little more attention than he did to the misadventures of Mr. JOHN STOVEL, who was found floating in the water off the Battery yesterday just after daybreak.

Sports of every description will be in order to-day and the lovers of muscle, brawn and speed will find plenty of entertainment, no matter what their favorite sport may be. In local circles football and golf clearly have the ascendancy, and while thousands of men and women will play the latter game there will be equally as large a number watching the Columbia boys struggle with the Carlisle Indians in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The talent again picked four winners at the Bennings track to-day, the eighth time this has occurred during the ten days of the meeting To-day's events were without special interest. Perfect Autumn weather prevailed and the crowd was large. In the hurdle handicap, with only five starters, the favorite, Perion, won easily by a length and a half.

President Miles M. O'Brien of the Board of Education last night presented formal charges of neglect of duty and violations of the civil service laws against Secretary A. Emerson Palmer. They had been filed by John Wallace, formerly chief clerk of the board, who was dismissed several months ago on charges of neglect of duty and irregularities.

With the Carlisle Indians for opponents the Columbia football team will play at Columbia Field this afternoon its closing game of the season of 1900. Comparative records of the two elevens justify the belief that the contest will be one of the closest and hardest fought that the Blue and White has yet had.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28. -- The announcement was made this afternoon that George T. Oliver, who represents a syndicate made up of himself and a few friends, had purchased a controlling interest in the capital stock of The Pittsburg Chronicle-Telegraph.

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners at a meeting held yesterday passed a resolution which is regarded as a practical abandonment of the plan to construct pipe galleries in Elm Street along the route of the rapid transit railroad. Work on the pipe galleries was stopped on Thursday, Nov. 8, because of a controversy between the Rapid Transit Commissioners and the city officials.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 28. -- The case of Miss Anna Stringer against Bert Brower, who, she claims, has promised to marry her and has postponed the wedding time and again, was called before Judge William M. Hawkins this morning. The case went over until next Wednesday. The case has attracted much attention here, owing to the fact that Miss Stringer effected the capture of Brower herself, with the aid of a shotgun.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A large crowd, probably the greatest ever gathered there, assembled at the Bennings race track today. It was representative of the National capital, official, social, and business circles being represented. Speculation was lively, but the talent succeeded in picking only two winners.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The Directors of the model factory town of Belle Meade, ten miles from here, have elected the Rev. Dr. David J. Burrell of the Marble Collegiate Church, New York, a member of the board. The company was organized last April, with a capital stock of $350,000.

MANILA, Nov. 29. -- The typhoon which caused the wreck of the Yosemite was of unprecedented violence, and did great damage on the Inland of Guam. Many are reported to have been killed or injured. At Agana three were killed and ten died of exposure.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The Second Battery, National Guard of New York. Brevet Major David Wilson commanding, held its twenty-third annual Thanksgiving Day shoot and outing at the State rifle ranges and practice ground here to-day. The principal event of the day was the battery match, in which the conditions called for seven shots at 200 yards and seven at 300 yards.
VALPARAISO, Nov. 29 -- It is reported here that the Bolivian Congress in secret session yesterday rejected the Chilean proposals.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 29 -- The scene on Lafayette Field here this afternoon, when with but a fraction of a minute to play, Cure kicked a goal from the field, winning the same by a score of 10 to 6, was the most exciting demonstration seen here in years.

Miss Clara Louise Richardson, the daughter of the Rev. Samuel Richardson, pastor of the North Fifth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Williamsburg, was buried yesterday in Greenwood Cemetery. Miss Richardson died on Sunday night in the parsonage, 182 North Fifth Street, of typhold fever.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Thanksgiving Day was a memorable one at Tuxedo among the society colony. During the day many notable events took place. Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Alexander gave a musicale in the afternoon at their cottage to 100 invited guests, and at night a vaudeville performance at the clubhouse was given by the Tuxedo Club.

A smallpox scare, which first came to the public notice Wednesday, has spread with alarming rapidity, until at a late hour last night there were twenty-four known cases. When the first two cases were discovered Dr. Benedict and Dr. Somerset of the Bureau of Contagious Diseases began a most thorough investigation of the district in which the first cases were found.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of the 20th ult. on "The Infant Ship Industry," comparative prices of three classes of iron and steel were given showing relative Quotations in Great Britain and in the United States. None of the classes included steel ship plates, one of the most important materials in modern shipbuilding.

With the playing of the Thanksgiving Day games the football season for 1900 practically ended, only one other important game being left to play, that between West Point and Annapolis to-morrow at Philadelphia. Pennsylvania and Columbia finished their seasons with victories over Cornell and the Carlisle Indians respectively, Columbia, having particular cause for elation, as the overwhelming defeat sustained at the hands of the Indians last year has been partly atoned for.

Delays continue to be the rule at the Grand Central Station, and the exasperation of the travelers who are daily forced to lose there both time and temper grows steadily stronger, because of their realization that the trouble is due to no temporary cause which the railway officials are doing their best to remove.

The story of yesterday's social doings can perhaps be best read in the sporting col- umns this morning, for the modish world devoted itself to country and to golf, riding, driving, hunting, and other outdoor diversions. It was a gray misty day, with now and then spurts of rain, but fortunately no downpour to keep people housed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- How little Americans know of the events in the great continent south of us, in comparison to our full knowledge of European, and even Asiatic and African, affairs, is curiously illustrated by the history of the Republic of Acre. This republic was declared, a revolution was inaugurated, and for more than eight months there was an organized rebellion against the Government of Bolivia.

The Columbia football team closed its successful season yesterday afternoon by defeating the strong team of the Carlisle Indian School on Columbia Field by a score of 17 to 6. The Columbia men would perhaps have been happier of they had beaten Harvard's score, and still happier if the wild men of the West had not scored at all.

There was a rare morning's sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday, when an aggregation of trotters and pacers such as was never before seen on the famous speeding ground made things very lively for several hours, and brush followed brush with such rapidity that they were hard to keep track of.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As Richard, Duke of Gloster, remarked, so echoes the Republican Party: "Now, are our brows bound with victorious wreaths." The question arises. Shall Congress allow a particular element of the Republican Party (who, likened to Gloster, are drunk with the fruits of victory,) to pass the Ship Subsidy bill?

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The Horse Show held by the Union County Hunt Club on the club's new track and show grounds here to-day was attended by a large crowd, and was a pronounced success. After the ring exhibition and the judging of a number of classes for horses kept for riding, driving, and hunting, the guests were entertained at luncheon in the clubhouse adjoining the track.

Field Marshal the Count VON WALDERSEE, it appears, has the honor and satisfaction to report to the Berlin War Office that the "numerous expeditions carried out by the allied forces appear to be gradually bringing about the desired pacification of the country." As an educated German, it seems that the Field Marshal must have learned Latin in his youth.

The trap shooters of the Crescent Athletic Club had a busy day at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday. The principal event of the day was the Thanksgiving Cup at fifty birds -- twenty-five at the expert trap and twenty-five at the Magau trap, which, resulted in a tie between E. Banks, H. Brigham, and W. Marshall, with a score of 45 each, Banks winning in the shoot-off.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Burglars took advantage of the absence of families from their homos this evening to ransack three houses on the East Side, the fashlonable quarter. They were the residences of ex-Sheriff Hopper, who lives at 87 Auburn Street; Dr. James Crooks, 263 Sumner Street, and Benjamin East wood, at 162 Hamilton Avenue.

There has been no change of sentiment or opinion in Wall Street in respect to the future of the stock market, unless, indeed, it be that, because of the reaction -- the reckless and overspeculative element having been shaken out -- confidence has grown greater. On all sides, and in all things, conditions favor advancing prices.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- A detachment of 260 men, consisting of Companies A, B, and 1 of the Royal Canadian Regiment, Col. Otter commanding which has just reached England from South Africa by the Hawarden Castle, arrived in London to-day and proceeded to Kensington Barracks.

The Catholic Club last night tendered a reception to Archbishop Corrigan. The affair was an elaborate one, and was attended by the most prominent Catholics of New York, members of the club, and by many guests, among whom were included prominent persons of other denominations.

What the people demand is, not retrenchment, but growth; not reform, but progress. Discarding our negative issues, the anti-imperial, anti-silver, anti-trust, yes, even anti-boss, we must adopt a great positive programme, "pro bono publico."

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 29 -- Notwithstanding many of the students had gone home to spend their Thanksgiving holidays, a good sized crowd saw Lehigh defeat Swarthmore by the score of 17 to 0 in the closing football game of the season. Both teams showed the good effects of the cool, tracing weather, and played a dashing game from start to finish.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 29 -- Advices from Tora, a small Mexican habitation on the Sinaloa Canal, nearly 200 miles south of Guaymas, declare there was trouble recently between Mexicans and the Yaqui Indians at a small pueblo near that place. Five Americans escaped public execution only because the Yaquis went to their assistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The promoters of the ex-slave pension scheme are now trying a more daring method than ever before. They are bombarding the President with letters and petitions asking him to recommend the plan in his annual message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- James Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture, in his report to the President for the year ended June 30 last, devotes much attention to the importation of plants and animals for the general benefit. Since 1862 this work has been developed along scientific lines, and the bureau and division staffs are now in touch with producers throughout the United States.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Cochery, the Acting President of that body, announced that Denys Cochin, Conservative, representing a district of the Seine, had presented an interpellation as to the intentions of the Government regarding arbitration in favor of the Boers.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 -- The accounts of George R. Griffiths, who was clerk of the Hoard of Education here for thirteen years previous to his death, which occurred Oct. 1. 1900, are short at least $100,000, and it is thought that when the exact amount of the stealings becomes known they will be found to be nearer double that sum.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 29. -- Floyd T. James, owner of the Orawaupum Hotel livery stables, was killed last night by a trolley car near Mamaroneck. He and Superintendent Chaderton of the New York Telegraph, Telephone, and Cable Company were in a wagon when run down by a car.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Division of Insular Affairs of the War Department has made public a summary of that portion of the annual report of the Department of Licenses and Municipal Revenues of Manila, which relates to the liquor traffic in that city.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- More than 400 Americans were present at the Hotel Cecil this evening at the Thanksgiving dinner given under the auspices of the American Society in London. F.C. Van Duser, President of the society, was in the chair, and the guests included Baron Alverstone, Lord Chief Justice of England; William court Gully.

Dr. Frederick Rose, the British Consul at Stuttgart, in his report on the trade, agriculture, and finances of Wurtemberg for the year 1899 and part of 1900, which forms one of the diplomatic and Consular reports just issued by the Foreign Office, makes special reference to the acetylene industry.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- Nearly 400 persons attended the Thanksgiving Day banquet of the American colony in Berlin at the Kaiserhof this evening. The company included Prof. Bisbeo of Dartmouth College, Prof. MacMillan of Princeton University, and the following United States Consuls: Charles E. Barnes, Cologne; Dr. H. Pitcairn, Hamburg; J.F. Monaghan, Chemnitz, and Frank W. Mahin, Reichenberg, Austria.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 29 -- A desperate fight between striking telephone linemen and non-union linemen under police protection at noon to-day resulted in two deaths and the wounding of several men. The dead are Will Lacey, policeman, shot through the heart while making arrests, and O.D. Blanton, lineman, shot near the heart while looking on.

The public announcement that the Educational Alliance needs $90,000 to carry on its work on the east side ought before this to have secured the required sum and more. And this not because of any appeals that could be made on the score of charity, and by responding to which the givers should have the satisfaction only of relieving distress which did not touch them.

Lakewood's usual big field of golfers turned out yesterday for the Thanksgiving Day open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club. The contest will be continued to-day and to-morrow, the match yesterday being an eighteen-hole medal play round to reduce the competitors to their class level for the match play rounds.

The White Star liner Teutonic, which was duo in port Wednesday, arrived at her dock at noon yesterday. The strong westerly gales and high head seas encountered on the passage were responsible for the delay. The bad weather lasted practically from port to port, but was most severe from the 24th to the 26th and on the 28th.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 29 -- Over 21,000 people crowded Franklin Field this afternoon to witness the annual Thanksgiving Day football game between the Universities of Cornell and Pennsylvania, the latter winning by the score of 27 to 0. Cornell could do little with Pennsylvania's line, all her gains being made around the ends.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- A stage loaded with women and driven by a man rolled down the embankment along which New Street, in West Paterson, runs, this afternoon, and all of the occupants were more or less injured. One of the women may be seriously hurt. New Street, where the accident occurred, runs alongside the mountain and has a sharp descent.

The resignation of the venerable and much respected President of one of our great educational foundations, because he finds himself unfitted by taste and training and unequal in strength for the management of its business and financial affairs, is calculated to set the friends of education thinking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The House Committee on Military Affairs to-night made public a letter received from Secretary Root, under date of the 28th inst, transmitting a draft of a bill prepared by the War Department for the reorganization of the army. The letter says, in part:

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Flushing society people turned out to-day in greater numbers than ever before to participate in the fox hunt arranged by the Flushing Driving Club. A field of nearly fifty riders of both sexes participated in the event, making the largest turn-out of cross-country riders ever seen about Flushing.

In hospitals, prisons, and charitable institutions throughout the city yesterday, the day was truly one of thanksgiving, for it brought a little cheer, and peradventure, a little encouragement born thereof, to many sufferers from the unkindness of fate or from their own shortcomings, in the shape of tangible and succulent evidence that they were not altogether objects of indifference to the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The second day of the dog show drew an even larger crowd in attendance than the opening day. Much interest was manifested in the various classes of animals, and the judges always had a crowd around them as they selected the dogs which they thought were entitled to prizes.

Ex-Superintendent of Police William Murray last evening gave out a statement regarding the speech of ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt at the Chamber of Commerce meeting to devise means for the repression of vice. The ex-Superintendent denies the truth of the allegation of ex-Mayor Hewitt that he talked with Mr. Murray about police corruption while serving as Chief Executive of the city.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The most interesting action at the International Seamen's Union Convention to-day was the adoption of a report bearing unon the inducements, or rather lack of inducements, offered to American boys to so to sea. The report says in part:

At Police Headquarters last night it was learned that the police are thoroughly investigating the alleged drugging, kidnapping, and robbery of Mrs. Mary Taylor, the clairvoyant who mysteriously disappeared from her home, 274 State Street, Brooklyn, about three weeks ago, and a few days later was found wandering about the west side in this borough.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The new grounds at the Hempstead Gun Club were opened here to-day with a live bird trap shooting tournament. The new grounds are situated on the old race course, near the reservoir road. The birds, as a rule, were a capital lot of fliers, and provided keen sport.

Prof. B.A. HINSDALE of the University of Michigan died at Atlanta, Ga., yesterday. He went South, with his wife, several weeks ago for the benefit of his health. He was suffering from a nervous collapse. Prof. Hinsdale was a prominent educator, and was the author of a number of historical and educational works.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 29 -- With the assistance of a quartet of selected players from the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York, the Newark Athletic Club won the football game with the Orange Athletic Club, on the Orange Oval, this morning by the score of 6 to 0. Poor coaching, overtraining, and a lack of knowledge of a new code of signals adopted a few days ago, had much to do with Orange's defeat.

The largest day crowd of the week attended the "Old Glory" sale of light-harness horses by the Fasig-Tipton Company, in Madison Square Garden yesterday. The prices were low until late in the afternoon, when a number of choice lots brought the average up to that of the earlier part of the great offering.

Fifty delegates, representing 1,100,000 Roman Catholics, decided yesterday to form a federation of the Roman Catholics in the United States. Preliminary steps toward organization were taken at a secret meeting held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

Disclosures as to the connection of Albert T. Patrick with the estate of the late William Marsh Rice are promised for to-day in the Supreme Court. Patrick is now in the Tombs on the charge of forgery in connection with certain checks supposed to have been issued by Rice just before his death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Thirteen persons were killed and fully eighty badly injured by the collapse of the roof of the Pacific Glass Works, on Fifteenth Street, to-day, while it was crowded with men and boys watching a football game between Stanford and California Universities on the field adjoining.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Spectator, in a striking article dealing with the Chinese crisis, expresses the opinion that the most recent developments at Peking foreshadow a Chinese victory over the allies.

The Episcopal Parish of the Incarnation will take steps at once to rebuild its mission in Thirty-first Street, near First Avenue. The mission consists of a small stone chapel and three dwellings, two on the west side of the chapel and one on the east side. It is purposed to replace these buildings with modern ones, fitted in every way for aggressive east side work.

Edmund J. Bell, a boy of nineteen years, living at 508 West One Hundred and Sixty-second Street, was arraigned late yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Alexander, charged with having robbed the mails of $2,000. The young man made a complete confession. He said:

Ralph Henry Barbour, who wrote that rattling good book about American school life, and particularly about football, "The Half-Back," is now having published through D. Appleton Co. another tale of school life and interscholastic sport entitled "For the Honor of the School," with illustrations by C.M. Relyea.

The first part of the Thomas J. McKee collection sale come to a close Friday night, Nov. 23, in the auction rooms of John Andersen, Jr., in West Thirtieth Street, the 1,282 lots having fetched over $15,000. The interest taken in the sale was marked, and the offering of the various rarities for public competition brought together buyers from many parts of the United States.

Nine trunks filled with dutiable goods, mostly table and bed linen, were seized at the Brevoort House last night by a Deputy United States Inspector armed with a search warrant issued late yesterday afternoon from United States District Attorney Burnett's office.
BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The semi-official statement that Mr. Kruger is coming here is discussed cautiously. It is regarded as premature to predict that Emperor William will receive him.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30. -- Judge Amos Thayer in the United States District Court has appointed F.M. Slack of Kansas City receiver of the Guardian Trust Company, of which A.E. Stilwell is President.
AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 30 -- A dispatch from Monterey, Mexico, says:

Advanced theories of municipal government were discussed by ex-Mayor Josiah Quincy of Boston in the great hall of Cooper Union last evening at a meeting held under the auspices of the People's Institute.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the caption of "A Plea for Oom Paul," in your issue of 28th inst., "A Constant Reader" writes: "Every reader of Mr. Kruger's speech, of course, (excepting the editor of THE TIMES,) was aware that the old statesman was not referring to the war as carried on in the beginning, (when these Frenchmen were present,")
MADRID, Nov. 30 -- The gold quotation to-day was 33.65.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The President and Speaker Henderson had an extended private conference this morning. They took a long drive together, at which, it is understood, the programme for the coming session of Congress was discussed.

The lamest crowd that ever attended a horse sale in New York filled Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon when the sensational race horse and champion trotter. The Abbot, was offered at auction in the "Old Glory" sale by the FasigTipton Company.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- I presume as a matter of course that Mr. Conrad's "Lord Jim" has already appeared in America. I only hope that the mania for changing the titles of books republished in America has not led to the conversion of "Lord Jim" into "Senator Dick," or some other improved title.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Trading was quiet today. Cochiti hardened 1/3 more, to 10 1/2, and British Columbia 1/2, to 20 3/4. Only one sale each was made in Utah and Parrot in the morning, and only odd lots of Butte changed hands at 89 1/2 ex dividend, 95 cash. Massachusetts was up 1 1/4, at 14 1/4. Franklin gained 1/2, to 16, later selling at 15 1/2.

In a decision handed down yesterday afternoon by Justice Burr Mattice, in the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, Frank A. Barnaby, a well-known local real estate broker, was declared to have committed fraud in a real estate transaction involving property on Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. The case in which the decision was rendered was that of James B. Healy, a Montague Street tailor, against Barnaby, W. Clarence Martin, C. Grayson Martin, and James W. Golden.

Ossip Gabrilowitsch, the young Russian pianis gave his second recital yesterday afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall. His programme consisted of the following numbers: Mendelssohn's prelude and fugue in E minor, Opus 35, Schumann's C major fantasy, Opus 17; Chopin's A flat ballade, D flat prelude, and B minor scherzo, Opus 20; Leschetitzky's "Melodie a la Mazurka, Tschaikowsky's barcarolle in G minor, and the Schubert-Tausig "Marche Militaire."

In this little book the heroes and heroines are less important than the stage setting, which is fortunate as, to use an Hibernicism, they are more than ordinarily ordinary. The descriptions of Old Washington are adroitly introduced by means of their adventures and love affairs, however, and the reader is thus nourished with a moderate supply of historical meat smothered in a sauce of romance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Details of Secretary Root's Army bill, now in the hands of the House Committee on Military Affairs, were made public to-day. The measure provides for a Lieutenant General, six Major Generals, and fifteen Brigadier Generals. The number of Captains, First Lieutenants, and Second Lieutenants of the cavalry and infantry is increased from twelve to fifteen for each regiment.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Money is much wanted in connection with the month-end requirements, but, owing to the large borrowings recently from the Bank of England, the pressure is less than had been anticipated. Discounts arc casier.

A few years ago Prince Chang Chih Tung, now one of the Chinese Commissioners who is to negotiate peace in settlement of the pending disputes in China, wrote a took which dealt with needed reforms in China. in the light of foreign influences. The present Emperor, who is said to be Kindly disposed toward foreigners, ordered the book to have the widest distribution possible in his empire.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 30 -- Mrs. Root, wife of the Secretary of War, will go to Philadelphia to-morrow morning, accompanied by a party of friends, to attend the football game between West Point and Annapolis.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The police of this city to-night arrested a man named John W. Hogan at his boarding house, 58 Clinton Street. Hogan is wanted in New York by Chief McClusky on charges of fraud and grand larceny.

These two volumes --" William Shakeepeare: Poet, Dramatist, and Man," by Mr. Mabie. and "Guglielmo Shakespeare: II Poeta e I'Uomo," by Signor Garlanda -- represent from curiously different points of view an epitome or about all the scholarship and culture that the Avon poet has inspired.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The largest stock of gold coin and bullion ever held in the United States is now accumulated in the Treasury and its branches. The total has been rising steadily during the whole of the present year, and is now $474,108,366, or about $76,000,000 greater than at the close of 1899.

When Andrew the Stimulator bids us leave off reading newspapers and magazines, the advice is doubtless intended for our good. In the kindness of his heart he imagines we will at once devote the time gained to the perusal of books and to our eternal profit. But would we? Candidly, no.

The Onlooker of London prints a story from its Paris correspondent, "Adrienne," of Marie Bashkirtseff. Apparently the writer knew the young Russian and admired her beauty and wit, but she has no scruples in saying that Marie was "an impertinent minx." "Adrienne" writes:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- At a meeting of the creditors of Francis D. Carley, the New York broker who filed a petition in bankruptcy two weeks ago in this State, Frederick H. Wisner was to-day elected as trustee to represent the interests of the thirty persons and concerns who hold judgments and claims against Carley, to the amount of $1,000,000.

The resumption of business yesterday in the market for outside securities brought no gerenal increase in activity, and the day was a relatively quiet one on the curb. Prices were somewhat irregular, buying movements and profit taking ones alternately causing advances and declines. The copper stocks were less prominent than they were a short while since, and to a certain extent their former position was assumed by the industrials, several of which were quite active.

A few weeks ago we were discussing the disinterested pursuit of reforms, in which Lowell, Curtis, and Warner, three literary men highly representative of American culture, engaged. It suggests the question of whether or not the single-minded direction or thought to one aim or its diffusion to many has been characteristic of men of letters.

The Book of Book Plates, edited by Joseph W. Simpson and published quarterly by Messrs. Williams Norgate of Edinburgh, in an edition limited to 500 copies, at 5s. per annum, is so thoroughly artistic in spirit and treatment and its articles so charming, that its pages will be found of great interest even to those to whom the subject of book plates does not make special appeal.

Charles Miegel, who boards at 22 Mercer Street, Jersey City, is employed as a boxmaker at Isaac Vanderbeek Sons' lumber yard and factory at Greene and Steuben Streets. Miegel, who is twenty-five years old, is an amateur entomologist. Some time ago he found a tarantula among some Southern pine received at the yard.

The publishers have chosen for the second issue in a series of reprints intended for book lovers, of which the first volume, Richard do Bury's "Philobiblon," was issued some time ago, a little known work, "Bibliomania in the Middle Ages," by F. Somner Merryweather, which originally appeared in London in 1849.

Peter Piernot was fined $2 yesterday in the Magistrate's Court in Long Island City. He asserted he saw the ghost of Gilliam Guldensuppe, the man murdered and cut up by Mrs. Nack and Martin Thorn. He lives with the family which now occupies the house on Fifth Street, Woodside, in which Guldensuppe was done to death.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- In the Reichstag to-day, during the debate on the loan bills, Dr. von Thielmann, Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, Was asked why the loan for 80,000,000 marks was placed in America.

The Committee of Fifteen to undertake the work of the repression of vice was made known yesterday by Charles Stewart Smith, upon whom devolved the task at the meeting of citizens at the Chamber of Commerce last Tuesday of making the selections. The committee comprises:

A fiscal policy that remits the tax on bank checks and retains the duty on the hides from which the boots and shoes of the people are made cannot be successfully defended before any representative audience. Yet this is only one of a multitude of criticisms which the proponents of a reduction of $30,000,000 in the internal revenue taxes must meet before they can reach a safe point of justification.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The fourteenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland began here to-day. An interesting discussion took place in this afternoon's session as to the duties of colleges with reference to the preparation of young men for the administrative and diplomatic service of the Government.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 30 -- Alexander Jackson of Camden, one of the best-known old men of Kent County, recently decided that if he lived until Thanksgiving Day he would distribute part of his fortune. He has no children and few immediate relatives. He is going to give away $100,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks to-day announced a merger of the "Northern Insurance Company of New York" with the "Eastern Insurance Company of New York," under the title of the Northern Insurance Company of New York, with a capital stock of $250,000.

The quarto volume whose title is given below contains an avowed attempt to show the leading from a certain art of the Roman world, strictly Roman in character and developed after the reign of Augustus was fully established, into that which we call Christian art. It was written for a prefatory article to a work of unquestioned Christian origin, as will be stated below.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- M. Hutin, President of the Panama Canal Company, called upon Secretary Hay to-day and had a long talk with him touching the prospects of the Panama Canal as affected by the probable legislation at the approaching Congress.

The case of H. Victor Newcomb, the exrailroad President, came up in the Supreme Court, before Justice Fitzgerald, again yesterday on the application of his wife to have a commission appointed to inquire into his mental condition. De Lancey Nicoil, who represented Mr. Newcomb, opposed the motion.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 30. -- William H. Osborne, twenty-eight years of age, a clerk in the employ of the French Cable Company at 44 Bread Street, New York, committed suicide in the Nelson House, in this city, this evening by shooting himself in the right temple.

By arrangements made with Gov. Roosevelt the Charter Rivision Commission will give out to-day the report of the changes which it thinks should be made in the government of the city. It has also been decided that the public shall be informed of the recommendations of the commission on Monday morning.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Oscar Wilde died at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the Maison du Perier, Due des Beaux Arts, in the Latin Quarter. It is a small, obscure hotel, at which Wilde had been living for several months under the name of Manmoth.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: If any book is laid away with me in my casket, as "Shakespeare" was in Tennyson's, let it be the precious worn and torn little copy of John Milton's poems, complete, which I carried in a saddlebag during three years spent in the war for the preservation of the Union, and which has since been to me what it was then, a solace and delight.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30 -- J. Caldwell Meyer was arrested this morning on a charge by John McLaren, who claims that the accused obtained a promissory note from him for a life insurance policy under false pretenses.

Two men who were boys "when Lincoln broke the quorum" sat on a bench in the old State House yard at Vandalia and compared recollections of that event. An old settlers' reunion brought the Rev. Ben McMahon and Uncle John McConnell together. And when the comparison of recollections got fairly under way it carried the pair back to the thirties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 -- Four persons injured in the disaster that befel the crowd of men and boys watching the football game yesterday from the roof of the glass works, died this mornings 'making the total number of dead seventeen. Several more of the injured will die.

Frederick Bergner, well known as a musician in and teacher, one of New York's pioneer instructors on the cello and an original director of the Philharmonic Society, completed fifty years of labor in this city on Nov. 23, and a company of his friends and pupils gathered at the residence of Mrs. Isaac N. Seligman, 36 West Fifty-fourth Street, to congratulate him upon the occasion.

Quite apart from its great bibliographical value, one's first feeling on taking up Mr. Arnold Wood's list of original editions and reprints of "The Complete Angler," from the first edition, in 1653, down to and including those of the year 1900, is one of unmitigated satisfaction in regard to its typography, paper, binding, illustrations, down to even the most unimportant detail of its making.

Alter many months of litigation over the possession of the Casino between George W. Lederer and the Sire Brothers, both interests came together yesterday and the differences were amicably adjusted. The theatre was turned over to Mr. Sire last night by Mr. Lederer, who voluntarily vacated the premises.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 30 -- With the arrival here of the football teams of the United States Naval Academy and the West Point Military Academy, substitutes, coaches, and enthusiastic rooters, Philadelphia began to take on its holiday appearance in anticipation of to-morrow's great contest on Franklin Field between the two branches of Uncle Sam's service -- the army and the navy.

Snappy and energetic golf, which is always the case when good men meet as opponents in the big Lakewood tournaments, was the feature yesterday on the Lakewood Club links, when two matchplay rounds for the three cups were played. The qualifying sixteen in each set were reduced to four, and they will meet this morning in the semi-final round.
NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 30 -- Mrs. David King and her daughter, Miss King, will close their Newport season to-morrow and go to New York for the Winter.
