To the Editor of The New York Times: The Hawaiian feeling toward the "haole," or stranger, is this: The Hawaiian has been cheated, deprived of his country and his rights, and he knows it. In 1805 a few misguided men tried to regain their liberty by force, and they failed, very naturally: their friends had told hem how hopeless the undertaking would be, but they did not realize this.

It is a significant fact that the two best known expounders and describers of the literary art of Russia. Onleguine and Chtchoukine, have for several years made their home in Paris. To their names may be added that of Waliszewski, who is the author of "A History of Russian Literature."
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The Senate to-day unanimously adopted a resolution of sympathy with Mr. Kruger in the same terms as the resolution of yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies.

Over two thousand city employes have lost their jobs during the past week, and there has been much walling in the Tammany camps of several politicians. All the leaders have been asking questions as to why this sudden descent should be made on office holders so soon after election, and why 2,000 of the faithful should be dismissed to spend a very cold and cheerless Winter.
ORVILLE A. CRANDALL, Sr., one of the leading canal forwarders of Buffalo, died yesterday morning. He was born in Westmoreland, Oneida, County, in 1841.
The committee named by Chairman CHARLES STEWART SMITH to carry on the work begun at the Chamber of Commerce meeting is as follows:
There is no contract for the removal of snow, and in case of a severe storm Commissioner Nagle of the Street Cleaning Department would be placed in a dilemma. He said yesterday:

There are two kinds of readers, those that confine their attention to popular books of the day and that other class which looks upon all contemporary literature as being "copious terrestrial dross that welters chaotically." There is, of course, another brand which divides its interest between the old-time writings -- the classics -- and the best modern books.

If it be true, as announced in a dispatch from Valparaiso yesterday, that the Bolivian Congress in secret session has rejected the Chilean proposals for a definite settlement of the contingencies growing out of the Peruvian-Chilean-Bolivian wars, then it rests with Chile to rupture the armistice now existing, and, after twelve months, to renew hostilities.

"William J. Ferguson," who was arrested on Tuesday last on the complaint of Dr. Jarman of 54 West Seventy-fifth Street, who alleges that "Ferguson" swindled him out of a small sum of money by representing himself to be a physician from Galveston who had been ruined by the flood, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields and held in $1,000 bail.
No charges of any character have been lodged at Washington against Collector George R. Bldwell. He will serve out his term and probably be reappointed.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The Business Men's Association of the City of Newburg gave a complimentary dinner to their fellow-member Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., at the Palatine Hotel this evening. There were 150 guests present, among them being Governor-elect Odell, his secretary, James G. Graham; his stenographer, J.C. McKnight: Judge William D. Dickey of the Supreme Court, Mayor J.D. Wilson, and ex-Mayor Benjamin B. Odell, father of the Governor-elect.

The northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, a plot 60 by 100. part of the Stewart mansion site, has been resold by the Barney-Sheldon syndicate. Mr. Barney would say nothing yesterday regarding the identity of the buyer or the price paid for the property. The syndicate has held the plot at $650,000, and the figure in the present sale is undoubtedly in that neighborhood.

The question of how far it may be possible to enlist Filipinos for police and y service in the islands is an intensely interesting and important one. An article in The North American Review for December by Major L.L. SEAMAN, M.D., late Surgeon of the First United States Volunteer Engineers, treats of the subject, but not so conclusively as we could wish.

More than 450 loyal sons of the land of the heather gathered about the banqueting board in Delmonico's last night to celebrate the one hundred and forty-fourth anniversary of the St. Andrew's Society. The dinner was one of the largest that has over been held in the history of the organization, and much of its success was due to the efforts of its President, Andrew Carnegie, who presided.

Our esteemed contemporary, The Evening Post, recently discussed at some length the inability of women to write the genuinely romantic novel, the novel of incident. The fact that certain women writers of to-day had succeeded in attracting public attention to their works in this line did not appear to our contemporary to be a matter of permanent significance, and in this we agree with it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- In a special report to the Navy Department Lieut. Commander W.H. Southerland, the officer in charge of the Naval Militia, sets forth facts to make obvious the necessity of a National naval reserve, in addition to the present militia organizations, calling particular attention to the fact that this proposed innovation is not suggested with any view whatever of displacing the present Naval Militia.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Stamford's first annual dog show was a great success. The armory was thronged with spectators throughout the day.

May not a timely and needed word be Written here of women's clubs in the light of the sixth annual convention of the New York State Federation, which closed its session in Albany on Nov. 16? Officers and delegates went to their homes fully satisfied with the results of the convention.
Congratulations may be offered this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to-

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Andrew Radel, Vice President of the Middlesex and Somerset Traction Company, has purchased the Akron and Cuyahoga Falls Rapid Transit Electric Railroad of Ohio and took possession of the property to-day. No figures are given, but it is understood that the price is well up in the hundred thousands.

The stock market yesterday was quiet and, until toward the close, strong and steady. At that time, following the publication of the bank statement, a bear drive was made, with the result that, together with some profit-taking, prices were forced somewhat lower.

Acting under orders from the Governors of the Stock Exchange, Manager Drew of the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company on Friday evening, after the close of the day's business, removed the Stock Exchange tickers from the offices of a number of Consolidated Exchange houses. Among the firms from whose offices the tickers were removed are J.L. McLean Co., 60 Broadway; Lewis A. May Co., 31 Broadway, and C.W. Morgan Co., 71 Broadway.

BUFFALO, Dec. 1 -- The Captains and precinct specials were summoned before the Police Commissioners to-day and directed to enforce rigidly every law, and especially the law against gambling. In an interview subsequently, Police Commissioner Cooper said the Commissioners had been made the scapegoats of inefficient or conniving subordinates, and that they will not stand it.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- At the old homestead of the Post family, near Pine Island, Orange County, to-morrow Mr. and Mrs. David Post will celebrate the seventieth anniversary of their wedding day.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1. -- The Westchester Lighting Company is the name of a new gas and electric light trust, which has been formed in Westchester County, and which it is said proposes to absorb all the other gas and electric light companies in the county. Simultaneously to-day certificates of increase of capital stock of the company from $2,500,000 to $12,500,000 were filed in Albany and in the White Plains Clerk's office.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- There is a noticeable incursion of Filipinos into London and Paris. The report, subsequently denied, that Agoncillo, Aguinaldo's agent in Europe, was contemplating going to Hongkong to reorganize there the Filipino transport and re-supply the Filipinos with munitions of war has given rise to the belief that the Filipinos in Europe are contemplating a new campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The second annual exhibition of the Philadelphia Dog Show Association closed to-night after a successful season of four days. Announcement was made of the following additional prizes:

In substantial majority the net changes of the past week have been advances. From a news standpoint Wall Street had little to interest it and much less to influence it. Daily bulletins from abroad have announced the Czar's death, with involved war complications for practically all of the nations of the earth; but otherwise not much out of the ordinary has been disclosed.

The attendance and the prices at the Fasig-Tipton Company's "Old Glory" auction sale of light harness horses in Madison Square Garden fell off together yesterday. In the forenoon only a few buyers wore present, and the lack of competition resulted in the dealers present securing many bargains.

George Gissing in The Fortnightly Review. Even when I had grown accustomed to the place, its singular appearance of incompleteness kept exciting my attention. I had never seen a town so ragged at the edges. If there had recently been a great concagration and almost all the whole city was being rebuilt, it would have looked much as it did at the time of my visit.

Otto Kempner, who at the Democratic State Convention at Saratoga defied the Kings County leaders and made a vigorous stand for the nomination of Controller Coler for Governor, last night announced that he had tendered his resignation as a member of the Democratic General Committee of Kings County from the Twentieth Assembly District.

The conviction that the police force must be reformed before any serious results can be obtained in the repression of vice in this city is by no means confined to the men who want to see the work done. In a remarkable interview with a reporter of The Evening Post, MARTIN ENGEL, the leader of Tammany in the Eighth District, made these significant remarks:

Carl G. Rasmus was the winner of the first weekly handicap shoot for the December Cup at the Crescent Athletic Club traps yesterday afternoon. His handicap was 6 at the expert trap and 5 at the Magau trap, and he killed 22 at the former and 21 at the latter, making, with his handicaps, the maximum score at each and the maximum total of 50.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Miss Pierson of Ramapo, while driving through the park to-day, just escaped a serious accident. Two strangers in an automobile were racing through the park, when Miss Pierson encountered them at Alexander's Corner, on the lake. Her horse became frightened and ran away, throwing her out as well as a woman friend who was driving with her.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- A representative of the Foreign Office here stated to-day that Germany has not indicated a disposition to modify her demands for the punishment of guilty Chinese officials, since she does not yet know what the different powers want.

CONSTRUCTION OF WILL -- The Court of Appeals a few days ago decided against the determination of the Appellate Division, that Robert E. Dunham was entitled to an annuity of $300 from the estate of his father-in-law, John F.J. De Raismes. Justice Russell, about a year ago, in Dunham's suit against John A. De Raismes and others, to enforce payment of the annuity, gave judgment in his favor.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of to-day, headed "Cooperation with Mr. Platt," you quote President Cutting's remark as to how to make Mr. Platt "affable."

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The first step in the punishment of the police civil service frauds as been reached in the indictment of three men by the Grand Jury. These are the two nembers of the "Chicago Credit Comany" and an attorney. It was expected hat the jury might also include in its indictment some city officials, but such was not the case, although it is thought that he next jury may do so.

From The Contemporary Review. But of all the wrongs in regard to natives and their labor in the Transvaal none come near to the scandals of the liquor trade. The laws restraining it are excellent on paper, but their administration is infamous. They prohibit the sale to natives; but they are broken wholesale.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 23 -- The Government of Mexico has decided upon strong measures to check the growing and, to some extent, risky, scarcity of ready money at its command. Immense exportations of silver dollars have taken place during the past few months, and these are the more worthy of note as the production of the white metal diminished during the fiscal year ended June 80 last.

The Duke of Manchester arrived yesterday evening on the American Line steamship St. Louis with his bride, who was Miss Helen Zimmerman, daughter of Millionaire Eugene Zimmerman of Cincinnati, whom he married about two weeks ago in England.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The first live bird shoot of the season was the attraction at the Country Club this afternoon, and a quartet of wins shots, K.P. Thomas, Lakewood; R.W. Houghton, Milwaukee; Howard A. Colby of Orange, and Harry Suydam of Brooklyn, put in a lively afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- The body of Col. Liscum, who fell at the head of the American troops before the walls of Tien-Tsin, arrived here this afternoon on the transport Thomas. The body will lie on the Thomas until Monday afternoon or Tuesday morning, when it will be taken under military escort to the train, which will carry it to the National Cemetery at Arlington, Va., for interment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Dinners and receptions to ex-President and Mrs. Benjamin Harrison will be leading social events the coming week. Contrary to the prevail- ing impression, they will not attend the banquet to be given at the White House Thursday night. They had accepted the invitation of Senator and Mrs. Elkins, who have invited a large company to dine on that evening in honor of the former Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Fine weather drew a big crowd at Bennings to-day, and the racing was the best of the meeting. Three of the finishes were of the hair-raising sort. Three favorites won. McMeekin, William Barrick's high-class three-year-old, made his first appearance at Bennings in the last race.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- West Point was first on the field, but the middies soon followed the soldiers. Annapolis won the toss, and chose the west goal with the wind in her favor. Farnsworth kicked off to the Navy's 10-yard line, where Smith fumbled and Goodspeed fell on the ball. Casad skirted left end for three yards, but West Point lost the ball on downs.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 1 -- William Butler Duncan, Jr., who recently accepted the management of the new cup defender to be built here, visited Bristol last evening for the first time since he actually became the leading yachtsman in charge of the craft that is to sail for the cup against the British challenger next August.

From Good Words. With regard to the ordinary heathen burial, it was the Basuto custom to bury their dead in a sitting posture, and generally in their kraals, but this practice is becoming less common. They are indifferent regarding the graves of their dead, which are left unprotected by wall or fence.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A gang of expert forgers, whom the Scotland Yard police believe to be Americans, have been making some big hauls among the London banks, though, as the institutions that have suffered refuse, quite naturally, to make the amount of their losses known, the sum total of the plunder can only be guessed at.

The "pom-pom" is a one-pounder, automatic gun. It uses metallic cartridges similar to those used in small-arms, but of a calibre of 1 1/2 inches, throwing a shell weighing one pound. The cartridges are placed in a looped belt, and this is attached to the gun. By a simple operation, one of the cartridges is inserted in the barrel and is fired by pulling the trigger.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- One of the responsible heads of the departments in the War Office said to-day, in an interview:

William H. Van Nortwick. William H. Van Nortwick, formerly a newspaper editor, died on Thursday at the residence of his son, Robert A. Van Nortwick, 53 Gardner Avenue, Jersey City. The funeral was held yesterday afternoon at the house. Mr. Van Norwick was born in New Brunswick, N.J., Dec. 10, 1821.
On the day before Thanksgiving there were twenty more marriage licenses issued in Baltimore than on any previous day in the history of the city bureau. Prosperity continues to do its effective work.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The week just closed has been one of singular flatness. People seem to have tacitly agreed to rest from their contentions until some kind of a lead has been given by Parliament, which assembles on Monday to vote supplies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The monthly state- ment of the public debt issued to-day shows that at the close of business Nov. 30, 1900, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,101,174,875, a decrease for the month of $3,227,445. The debt is recapitulated as follows:

Lieut. Richmond Pearson Hobson, United States Navy, is lying ill at the Presbyterian Hospital, in this city. Lieut. Hobson's illness is slowly but surely developing into typhoid fever, and, although he was reported as resting easily last night, the physicians who are attending him admit that their efforts to ward off the disease have been unsuccessful.

The necessary sewer changes incident to the construction of the Rapid Transit Railroad are being prosecuted with quite as much activity at present as the work on the tunnel. Freezing weather will cause a necessary stoppage on certain parts of the tunnel work until next Spring, when, quoting the words of one of the division engineers, " the campaign will begin all along the line and will be wide open thenceforth."

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- The announcement that no new students would be received in the Veterinary School of Harvard University has led to much discussion, and an effort is being made to raise sufficient money to continue the work.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 1 -- During the last week the bulletins referring to the Czar's health have not been signed by Baron Freedericksz, the Minister of the Court. The law positively requires the signature of the Minister of the Court in such cases.

From The Nineteenth Century. The oldest picture book in our possession is the midnight sky. We stand out under the stars on some clear moonless night, and, looking upward, though no forms are visible, though it is only here and there that the natural grouping can by the utmost legitimate effort of fancy be made to fit some preconceived shape, yet we still seem to see the whole vast dome covered with mysterious frescoes.

Frank Brainard, first Vice President of the Produce Exchange, was the guest at a complimentary dinner given last night at the Manhattan Hotel by the members of the Produce Exchange Sound Money League. Louis Spence, one of the last speakers, complimented Mr. Brainard for his work as Marshal of the Produce and Maritime Exchange division of the sound money parade.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The PostStandard will say to-morrow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Possibly through the columns of your paper I may arouse the traveling public to the fact that we have some rights, as well as the corporations, who hold such valuable franchises as the Long Island Railroad, Brooklyn Rapid Transit, and Metropolitan Railroad.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Surveying the money position, The Statist says:
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The Times-Herald tomorrow will say:

About 200 members of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association of Greater New York were present yesterday afternoon at a special meeting of the association at Arlington Hall, Brooklyn, and applauded warmly when President Capt. James D. Clifford declared that the fight in the Fire Department would be waged until the men obtained redress for their grievances.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 1 -- The mineral and timber riches of the almost unknown Island of Mindanao, in the Philippines, are outlined here by T.H. Russell, who is one of the first white men to get even a few miles into the interior. Russell went to the islands in June, 1898, with the First Colorado Regiment, and remained with that organization until it was ordered home.

The present rush to the Garden Theatre to see Sarah Bernhardt and Constant Coquelin in "L'Aiglon" is not an indication of a sudden development of fine artistic taste in this neighborhood. Once in a while the multitude rushes to an exhibition of dramatic art in the same spirit as it goes to horse races and football games.

However we may ridicule it, hypnotism is assuming an aspect in its relation to medical jurisprudence which makes it a proposition to be reckoned with. A few days ago, in Red Bud, Ill., a young man deliberately shot and killed another young man. The murder was premeditated, since the murderer had openly declared his intention to kill his victim on sight, and made his promise good on the first occasion which offered.

The sun is the most conspicuous figure in the events of most importance in December. Early on the twenty-second day of the month he reaches the extreme southerly point in his apparent journey to the South, in which trip he has been busy ever since the Summer solstice that occurred away back in June last.

Process servers are finding excitement in connection with the divorce case of May Evangeline Weil against Henry Goodman Weil, but they have served the papers upon the principal witnesses, who will appear when the case comes up for trial before Justice McAdam and a jury in the Supreme Court, on Wednesday.

A long list of proposed new members is one of the first things which greets the visitor's eye at the entrance to the National Arts Club, 37 and 39 West Thirty-fourth Street. The club held its second house warming last Wednesday and opened a second house to accommodate its increasing membership.

Bernard J. York, President of the Police Board, told the League for Political Education something about the Police Department yesterday morning. The women of the league have been hearing about the various city departments in a series of lectures under the general title of "Civic Interests of New York," and Mr. York's address was one of the series.

The commission appointed by Gov. Roosevelt under an act of the Legislature of 1900 to examine into the local government of the city and the effect and workings of the charter, and to suggest advisable legislation made its report yesterday, anil at the same time made public its report. With the report the commission submitted a bill to be transmitted to the Legislature providing for certain amendments to the Greater New York charter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the letter of Maud Nathan in your issue of this date -- Nov. 27 -- during the Parkhurst era a few years ago it was asked of one of the heads of the police force at that time what could be considered the chief causes of prostitution, and in answer one of the greatest reasons given was -- miserable wages paid by employers.

Arthur Griffiths in The Forum. There is, as a rule, no reluctance to help the military attache. Foreign nations know the importance of reciprocity. They keep attaches in London who are always eager to learn. These are, as a rule, courteously treated, made free at the military clubs, are welcome guests at military messes, are invited to be present at professional functions, manoeuvres, experiments, and trials with new weapons.

A National organization of amateur reinsmen, the pet project of a number of wealthy patrons of the light-harness horse in New York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Chicago, which has been under consideration for the past three months, was practically perfected yesterday after two meetings held at the Hoffman House.

Mr. ODELL, made a little speech to his friends and neighbors gathered to do him honor the other night, which indicates that he has his eyes wide open to certain things which have not lately attracted the attention of Republican leaders of the "organization." He announced his faith in Newburg as the site for a great shipbuilding plant, and said he was willing to back his faith with an investment in the project.

Portuguese guardas civiles watch almost every corner with sword and pistol, and there is no admixture of the "Lokung" or Hongkong police, where they would be eminently useful, among a population concerning whom my China "boy" warns me, "Take care pocket. Macao man plenty tief, plenty pirate, plenty murder."

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Trading was quiet today. Old Dominion was fairly active and got up to 31 1/2, but it fell back to 30 3/4 at the close. Cochiti held its gain, at 10 1/2, and Baltic and British Columbia were strong features, rising to 29 1/2 and 21 1/4 respectively. Pullman's Palace Car crossed 200 today, touching 200 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The State Department to-day sent instructions to United States Consul Gummere, at Tangiers, Morocco, to proceed to the capital of that country, as far as possible, on a United States man-of-war, to again present the claim of the United States for indemnity on account of the murder of Marcus Ezagui, a naturalized American citizen, who was killed in June, 1900.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Albert Thaband, the fourteen-year-old son of Dr. W.H. Thaband, formerly a dentist of this place, claims to have been kidnapped yesterday and taken to Manhattan by two men, who subsequently released him and gave him his fare to return home. The boy is a clerk in a real estate office here.

CHILE DIVIDED AS TO THE AGGRESSIVE ATTITUDE OF HER GOVERNMENT TOWARD BOLIVIA. -- Mail advices from Valparaiso are that there is considerable opposition to what is called "the unconciliatory and grasping foreign policy" of the Chilean Government as recently illustrated in its ultimatum to Bolivia.
THEODORE D BARNUM, a prominent business man of Buffalo, died Friday night. He was born at Utica in April, 1842.

Intercollegiate cross-country run championships were divided yesterday in the second annual meeting at Morris Park of the five colleges composing the Cross-Country Athletic Association. Alexander Grant, the crack long-distance runner of the University of Pennsylvania, carried off the individual honors, while Cornell won the team contest.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Prices were firm on the Boerse here to-day, the feature being the buoyancy of Argentines. Chinese were higher. Locals were fairly active on some bear covering. Hamburg-Americans rose in consequence of a rumor that they had been introduced on the New York Stock Exchange.

The hockey championship series of games will begin on Dec. 20 in New York, when the teams representing the New York Athletic Club and the Hockey Club of New York will line up on the ice in the St. Nicholas Ring for the initial contest. After this first game there will be a period of rest extending over the Christmas holidays until Jan. 3.

That was a curious announcement in Friday's papers of the formation of a "Roman Catholic Federation" throughout the United States. To any reflective reader it must have seemed mainly curious because so superficially superfluous. The Roman Catholic Church -- and we use the prefatory adjective simply because there are other organizations that arrogate to themselves the word "Catholic" -- seems already to amount to a Federation.

Controller Coler gave out yesterday statistics prepared by his experts on the amount of money spent by the Police Department during the past ten years. In 1890 the cost of the police forces of what is now Greater New York was $6,267,337.97. The cost for next year is estimated at $11,162,325.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Ex-President Kruger spent this morning in conferences with members of his party, only receiving three or four persons outside his followers Just before leaving his apartments he walked out upon the balcony. His appearance was the signal for warm cheering and the repetition of the cries that havegreeted him wherever he has gone this week.

The optimism of the charter revisers is not less confident, but is more cautious and better justified than that of the charter authors. If they listen with credulity to the whispers of fancy and pursue with eagerness the phantoms of hope it is in a learned and experienced way.

As an aftermath of the yachting controversy precipitated by charges made by Herman B. Duryea against Capt. George Parker, the sailing master of Cornelius Vanderbilt's seventy-foot racing sloop Rainbow, the Newport Yacht Racing Association yesterday made public its action in disqualifying the Rainbow in the series of races sailed under its auspices off Newport during last July and August.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Federal Judge Swayne to-day issued an injunction against State Controller Reynolds and the Sheriff of Leon County, restraining them from selling at auction next Monday, the Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad for back taxes alleged to amount to nearly $100,000.

They have an artist at work in the entomological department of the Natural History Museum this year assisting in the preparation for exhibition of last Summer's collection of insects. When these are ready the collection will be in better condition for the observation of the visitors than ever before.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club closed today, and Walter J. Travis carried off the honors by defeating Findlay S. Douglas by 3 up and 2 to play.

Among the arrivals on the American liner St. Louis last night was Mme. Marcella Sembrich, the prima donna. She was accompanied by her husband. Prof. Wilhelm Stengel, and comes to America to inaugurate her season under the management of C.L. Graff.

MlLFORD, N.H., Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Mary A. Lull, widow of Col. Lull of this town, left for Corsicana, Texas, to-day on her errand to deliver to the United Daughters of the Confederacy a flag, the distinguishing mark only of which is a lone star, captured in the charge of the Eighth New Hampshire Volunteers on Fort Hudson, La., May 27, 1863.

The Rev. Roland Allen in The Cornhill. I remember two years ago, when the legations called for guards and the city was disturbed, a wild story going about that the Empress was resolved to invite the Foreign Ministers to an audience, have them all slaughtered before her, let loose the troops upon the foreigners in the city, and to commit suicide.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 1. -- Gen. R. A. Alger, ex-Secretary of War, passed through the city to-day. He was accompanied by Col. Hecker, Frederick M. Alger, and John Millen of Duluth, Minn. They will inspect lumber lands and other property belonging to Gen. Alger's farm. Gen. Alger, in an interview, discussed the business of the next session of Congress, the restoration of Gen. Eagan, and other things.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Canada, Dec. 1. -- The man must be awake day and night who can keep track of the numerous enterprises that Francis H. Clergue is inaugurating here at the Sault, and can follow the operations of the great Eastern syndicate that has backed Mr. Clergue with its faith and millions.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The members of the Royal Canadian contingent of troops were received at the Mansion House to-day by the Lord Mayor and Corporation. His Lordship expressed the high honor he felt at entertaining a regiment "whose services to the Empire were so great that they had been acknowledged by the Queen's own lips, the highest honor which could be bestowed on returning troops."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Considerable money has changed hands in connection with the calls upon new issues of capital amounting to u900,000 and the distribution of various dividends and interests aggregating u1,500,000. The accession of supplies from the Bank of England eased the market. Discounts sympathized, much less going to the Bank of England.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 -- Those who claim to know say that only a beginning has been made in the exploitation of the mineral wealth of British Columbia, and especially the southern portion of it, known as the Kootenay region.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "C.B.D.," in his letter of the 26th inst., flourished the good old-fashioned weapons of "heresy and schism" against the sects of this country. It may be remarked here that several of these sects of Christians, so-called, are much larger than the Church he represents.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The trade in American meats is more and more restricted throughout Germany. A striking case is at Gera, where a large business firm, that of Beyer, has been ruined by the authorities of the principality of Reuss forbidding the official examination of his American meat. Beyer is unable to sell it without a certificate of inspection.

According to the will of R.G. Dun, the petition for the probate of which was filed yesterday, the business of the Dun Mercantile Agency will be continued by Trustees during the life of the testator's widow, Mary B. Dun. Those who are to derive the benefits of the business for this time are Mrs. Dun, the children of Mr. Dun's deceased sister, Elizabeth Douglass; his living sister, Mrs. James, and, after her death, her children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Secretary Hay this morning, for the Government of the United States, and Senor Correa, the Nicaraguan Minister, for his own Government, signed a treaty whereby the latter Government concedes to the Government of the United States the necessary rights and privileges within her bestowal for the construction of the Nicaraguan Canal.

What Wall Street hears of improved business conditions and increased confidence throughout the country finds corroboration in specific statements made by foremost brokers and banking authorities doing business at practically every important point. Some representative opinions will be found herewith:

From Ainslee's Magazine. "It is this sea-borne traffic that is most difficult to suppress. Just now, (in December,) when the southwest monsoon sweeps the Indian Ocean, it is active. The lean dhows from Muscat steal along the coast, and concealed in many a creek and river mouth, wait for their agents inland to bring them a cargo.

The occurrence of Thanksgiving Day during the week caused a considerable falling off of activity on the part of the local bowlers, as the games in most of the tournaments were suspended on Wednesday, while on Thursday there were no matches at all. In consequence fewer changes in the standing of the clubs resulted.

As the regrular season of music advances music lovers fall into moods more and more thoughtful, and the mail of the musical editor is laden with letters of inquiry, complaint, and objungation. No music critic has yet been discovered who can think the thoughts of a hundred thousand readers. And if such a being existed, his writings would be full of irreconcilable contradictions.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Beginning on Tuesday evening a series of games for the bowling championship of the Borough of Manhattan will be rolled between picked teams of five men each, representing the four principal bowling leagues of the borough. Two of these leagues -- the Harlem and the American National -- represent the upper and lower east side respectively, and the other two -- the Columbia and National -- represent the upper and lower west side respectively.

There was excitement on a Fifty-ninth Street east-bound electric car just before last midnight, and before it was over James Ward, who says he is a cabinet maker living at 148 East Sixteenth Street, was locked up charged with being a pickpocket.

The possibility of selling American coal at the Black Sea ports at a fair, if not large, profit is suggested in a report that Consul Heenan sends from Odessa, under date of Oct. 16, inclosing a letter from the Mayor of that town asking about the properties and prices of American coal. The towns of Nicolaiev and Sebastopol, as well as Odessa, are largely dependent upon foreign coal.

"No system of checks can prevent a dishonest employe from stealing," said a veteran business man and bank Director of this city," and the best deterrent I know of is an occasional overhauling of accounts by an outside actuary. If all hands feel that this is liable to happen at any moment, they are very apt to keep straight.

The Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers, preaching last evening in the Baptist Temple, Brooklyn, on "The Gospel of the Marriage Altar," declared that although the east side had its sin, Fifth Avenue had its share, and that clubs for both men and women had their relations to the home and marriage altar "as well as the saloon and other homes of vice."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Beyond the probable reading of the President's message no business of importance will be done in Congress Monday, both houses adjourning out of respect to the memory of Senators Gear and Davis, and Representatives Daly and Hoffecker, whose deaths will be announced.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Dec. 2 -- News reached here to-day of a triple killing at Parkdale, Ark. The two Killian brothers, merchants of the place, having had a previous falling out with Station Agent Phillips about railroad business, last night at 11 o'clock went to the station, smashed every window, and then went in search of Phillips, who was at his boarding house.

Trouble has arisen in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The full significance of the strained relations existing between the Rev. William A. Wasson, the rector, and several members of the vestry, was only yesterday made manifest to the congregation.

Ex-Judge Ernest Hall, one of the best-known citizens in the Borough of the Bronx, was asked by a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES what he thought of the proposed amendments to the charter. "The Borough of the Bronx has practically got everything it has asked for in the amendments," he said," and much credit is due James L. Wells, the Bronx Borough member of the committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Three little regimental mascots were involuntarily passengers from Manila on the transport Thomas. They were Fred Seagelstell, aged thirteen years, from Cleveland, who went out with the Thirteenth Infantry; John Wolfling, aged nine years, of Buffalo, and Sam Carter, a colored boy, who claims the South as his home.

One would have thought the Speedway Reason was at its height by the number of light-harness horsemen on the stretch yesterday morning. They turned out with one accord bright and early, to enjoy what was probably the last ideal day of the year for brushing. Many old scores between fast steppers were finally settled, and the coming week will see many of the favorites retired until next Spring.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Some of the bondholders of the International Packing Company are seeking through their attorney, Jacob Newman, an investigation into the affairs of the company. A letter was sent to Alfred S. Austrian, attorney for the packing company, yesterday, making an inquiry as to where all the money had gone.
Delegate Carrahan of the United Masters and Pilots' Association explained to the Central Federated Union yesterday his scheme to reverse the conditions of the Millionaires and the workingmen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the matter of Healy versus Martin I am very sorry that the Court should exhibit so much ignorance of the case as to characterize my conduct as a broker, which is the only position I ever occupied in the matter, as I did not receive any proceeds or profits of the exchange beyond the usual legal commissions.

Data gathered and compiled for the 1900 report of the United States Geological Survey show that, while still a factor of local importance in a few industries, and a domestic convenience wherever available, natural gas is giving out. The amount utilized in 1899 is estimated at about 108,000,000,000 cubic feet.

NEWARK, Dec. 2 -- Thomas T. Kinney, for many years one of Newark's most prominent residents, died this morning at his home, 1,062 Broad Street, of a complication of diseases. The funeral will be held Wednesday morning at Grace Church, this city.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, Signer Rubini, Minister of the Treasury and ad-interim Minister of Finance, announced in his budget statement that the budget of 1900-1901 at present showed a deficit of 10,000,000 lire, of which 13,000,000 lire must be charged up to the expenses of the China expedition.
Seven hundred fishermen fished the three miles of river between Richmond and Teddington yesterday. Far as the eye could pierce the mist, the towpath bristled with fishing rods.

The decrease in surplus reserve reported by the banks on Saturday is significant of nothing more than the preparations always made at this time of year for dividend and interest payments due on or about the 1st of December. Even with the decrease reported, surplus reserves are still more than two million dollars in excess of the figures at this time a year ago.

The police of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station are mystified over the drowning of Policeman Patrick McGloin of that station, whose dead body was found shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning floating in the East River at the foot of East Ninety-fifth Street.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Mrs. M.B. Loveridge, a widow, who lives with her daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. L. B. Patton, at 45 Linden Place, this city, was awakened at 2 o'clock this morning by some one grasping her, and opened her eyes to find a man standing beside the bed, with one hand upon her shoulder and one clasping her throat.

Associate Rabbi Samuel Schulman of the Temple Beth-El at Seventy-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue, preached a sermon yesterday on "The Ideal City," in which he gave considerable attention to the present conditions on the east side, and outlined the principles on which any reform movement, in his opinion, must be founded to insure success.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 2 -- Secure from the prying eyes of the public, and in the most isolated place in the big boat shops in Bristol, the job of laying down the new cup defender that is to meet Sir Thomas Lipton's Shamrock II. next August on the Sandy Hook course is being prosecuted with dispatch.

THE ASSEMBLING OF THE BRITISH PARLIAMENT -- According to London cable advices the new Parliament will assemble to-day for a brief session, the business of which, following the announcement of the chief Ministerial Whip, should be confined exclusively to the question of the supplementary vote required to meet the expenses of the war in South Africa.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Quick vengeance was taken upon a murderer here to-night, and it is probable that he will follow his victim to the grave within a day or two, if not within a few hours. Meanwhile four men and two witnesses are detained pending further investigation, and the four may have to stand trial for the murder of the murderer.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 2 -- The recent suicide of Miss Laura Hamilton, one of the heirs at law to the estate of the late Miss Catherine Ann Suydam, caused a troublesome search to learn who are the heirs at law of the estate. Miss Suydam died early in November. She was eighty-eight years old.

Frederic Degetau, first Commissioner to the American Congress elected by the people of Porto Rico, is at the Hotel Imperial. While an accomplished linguist, Mr. Degetau speaks English with less fluency than some other tongrues. Born at Ponce he has traveled extensively, and has an intimate knowledge of different forms of government.

With the close of the Thanksgiving events the golf season on Northern links comes to a sudden stop in activity, and the list of fixtures for the coming week presents the smallest number that has appeared since the formal opening of all the courses early in the Spring. As a general rule the competitive season on local links closes with the 1st of December.

In discussing the benefits to follow the substitution of electricity for steam as the motive power on the elevated railways of this city. The Electrical Review prophesies that even the excellent equipment now in course of installation will prove entirely inadequate before the underground road is completed.

Miss Georgia Cayvan, the actress, who for many years was one ot the city's most popular players, has been ill for several weeks in the Sanford Hall Sanitarium of Flushing, L.I. She is suffering from nervous prostration. It is said she is on the verge of mental and physical wreck, having become almost totally blind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Archbishop Martinelli. the Apostolic Delegate, will participate at the services to be held at St. Patrick's Church in this city at midnight Dec. 31 to consecrate the new century to God. The ceremony, like that of a year ago, is expected to be an unusually brilliant one, and most of the Bishops throughout the country probably will hold similar services.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The new Monte Carlo, near Richton, was opened for business yesterday by the gambling trust. "Tom" McGinnis entered a stockade surrounding the big pool room near the Illinois Central Railroad tracks and chained up a half dozen vicious dogs. Harry Perry and James O'Leary lugged a forty-five-thousand-dollar bank roll into the building.
I am indebted to a gastronomic correspondent for the following monograph on the subject of "sauce," which strikes me as at once true and humorous:

The Bureau of immigration will be transferred from the present quarters to the new station on Ellis Island the 15th of this month. The transition from the cramped and badly arranged quarters which the bureau has occupied since the fire that destroyed the old station on the island in 1897 will be marked.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 2.-- Excellent mining reports continue to come from Alaska. The richest quartz ledge, ever found in the Atlin district has been uncovered in the Gleaner group, on Taku Arm. David Von Cramer has reached Skagway with samples of the ore in which free gold is very plentiful.

Now that Mr. KRUEGER has passed from French territory, and the relations between the Qual d'Orsay and Downing Street have apparently undergone no change, and the French Government morally and physically is stronger than at any time during the Loubet administration, the remarkable demonstrations inspired by the venerable burgher appear something in the light of a paradox.

The cornerstone of the new Catholic Church of the Guardian Angel, on the Boulevard at Coney Island, was laid yesterday afternoon in the presence of 2,000 spectators. The parish was organized seven years ago by the Rev. James Cullen, its present head. Father Cullen, in his efforts to raise funds for the new edifice has in the past seven years held sixty entertainments of various kinds, and, with subscriptions, has succeeded in raising $24,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- About five hundred delegates are in Washington to attend the twenty-seventh Annual Convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, whose regular business sessions begin in this city at the Lafayette Square Theatre to-morrow.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The body of George Annis of this city who, it was reported, committed suicide by jumping into the canal in Syracuse last Thursday, was brought to Jamestown and this morning an autopsy was conducted. It showed conclusively that the young man was suffering from a deranged condition of the mental faculties, and that this condition resulted from a recent blow on the head.

Probably no part of the plan of the Charter Revision Commission will have to face more determined opposition than that relating to the changes in the school system, but there is none more important and, on the whole, more sound and practical.

The Belgian steamship Olbers, Capt. Brathwaite, which arrived from Brazilian ports yesterday, brought into port the shipwrecked crew of the Norwegian bark Bolivia -- sixteen men, among them Capt. Olaf Haakonsen, the commander of the illfated craft. They bad been rescued about 200 miles northeast of Bermuda early Thanksgiving morning.

A decree of the Department of Industry and Public Works of Chile issued recently gives notice that Chile will be among the exhibitors at the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo. An appropriation of 500,000 pesos, equal to about $185,000, will be provided to pay the expenses of the exhibition. It has been decided to hold a national exhibition in Chile in order to make a collection of the representative Chilean products.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- In an address to a large class which he confirmed at Grace Episcopal Church here to-day Bishop Potter declared that "all great reforms, political, social, and moral, have originated with the Christian Church."

William F. Farmer of 332 East Eighty-fourth Street, has the East Eighty-eighth Street Station detectives at work investigating the robbery of $3,000 in cash and $3,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry, from his home some time Saturday night or yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The monthly settlement passed off under unusually easy money conditions. Private discount advanced temporarily to 4 1/4 per cent., but fell back 1/8. The market expects easier rates. From Reichsbank officials it is ascertained that the bank now looks forward to entering upon the new year with the existing rate.

Gov. Stanley made more than one hundred speeches during the recent campaign, and he says he was interrupted only once by a questioner. "This man," says the Governor, "fired a long question at me, which was greatly involved. I answered it seriatim, but he was not satisfied and began to grumble about something.
O.B. WYMAN, Judge of the Sixth Judicial Circuit of Wisconsin, died of cancer yesterday at Buffalo, N.Y., where he had been under treatment.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of Senator Davis should serve as a warning to the public concerning the danger there is in the careless use of the knife in trimming corns on the feet.
MANILA, Dec. 3 -- One thousand more Bolomen have surrendered to Capt. Green of the Thirty-third United States Infantry at Vigan, Island of Luzon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- There are few indications here to-day that the Congress is to reassemble to-morrow. At the hotels there is scarcely more than the usual number of familiar faces, and only at the Normandie, where Speaker Henderson lives, and where he has been called upon by many of the Republican members who have reached the city, has there been anything like a considerable flocking of statesmen and politicians.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- A special meeting of the National Polo League was held at Hotel Garde, in this city, this afternoon, one of the objects being to take action on the failure of the Meriden management to strengthen its team. On account of other engagements, President Murnane and Secretary Morse of Boston were not prestnt, and Thomas Cotter of Hartford presided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is, I believe, unquestionable that in this city there is a sufficiently large number of respectable and law-abiding citizens honestly desirous of a radical change in the now feloniously inspired Municipal Government, and Police Department who by their votes one year hence can effect this result.

It is a curious evidence of the grip that selfish interests have on political parties that the first thing the Republicans will try to do in the session that opens to-day at Washington is to push aside the bill of Senator SPOONER regulating civil government in the Philippines and replace it by the Frye ship-subsidy bill.

Thomas Lynch, a resident of Brown's Point, a settlement midway between Matawan and Keyport, died last night under circumstances that led to an investigation by the Coroner, who has ordered an autopsy. Last evening Lynch staggered into a saloon at Brown's point and sat at a table. It was seen that he was sick, and he was carried to his home, where he died a few hours later.

The Rev. Dr. Abbott E. Kittredge preached to a large congregation last evening in the Madison Avenue Reformed Church, Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue, on the topic, "The Duty of Citizens of New York at This Time." The text was a clause reading: "A citizen of no mean city," taken from the thirty-ninth verse of the twenty-first chapter of Acts, which related to the birthplace of St. Paul.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- American securities declined early last week under the pressure of realizations, but more than recovered the loss under renewed buying for Continental and New York accounts. More notice was taken as the week advanced of the lower-priced securities, like Erie, Missouri, Kansas and Texas, and Reading, while a prominent feature was the buying of Southern Railroad shares, which closed from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 points higher.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeal has rendered a decision upholding that of a Divisional Court in the suit of the Attorney General vs. the Jewish Colonization Association. The Crown claimed estate and succession duty upon the death of Baron Maurice de Hirsch.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Five railroad employes were instantly killed and twelve persons injured by the explosion of a boiler in the power house of the Chicago and North-western Road this evening. Among the injured is John Butterworth, chief electrician of the power house. He is so badly hurt that it is believed he will die.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Time does not diminish popular interest in the opening of Congress. To-day, as heretofore, the Capitol was thronged with people who were drawn by curiosity, pride, or friendship, to see the members of the two houses resume their places and begin the business of making laws for the Nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Time does not diminish popular interest in the opening of Congress. To-day, as heretofore, the Capitol was thronged with people who were drawn by curiosity, pride, or friendship, to see the members of the two houses resume their places and begin the business of making laws for the Nation.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Mrs. Edward Valentine, nee Voice, who until she obtained a divorce in North Dakota was Mrs. Charles Hollister, has again figured in the courts. Mrs. Valentine, who is a granddaughter of Alfred H. Duncomb, a millionaire of East Chester, inherited, it is understood, $500.000 from her grandfather's estate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- There are ten new members of the Fifty-sixth Congress elected to fill vacancies caused by death or resignation, two of the vacancies occurring in the State of Iowa.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Col. Albert L. Mills, Superintendent of the Military Academy, made the following statement to-day:

The presence in a great and crowded city of enough cases of a highly contagious disease like smallpox to constitute an incipient epidemic is a matter of grave public concern. To exaggerate the danger to be apprehended from it would be a crime against the public interest; scarcely less so is it to underrate these dangers or deny their existence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The annual report of Secretary of War Root is of more than usual interest, owing to its wide scope and the fact that it treats of subjects of such importance as the Philippine insurrection, the Chinese campaign, the developments in Cuba and Porto Rico, and, finally, with the subject of army reorganization.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Following the visit of the New York Central Railroad officials, in the course of their tour of inspection of the Boston and Albany Road, came the announcement to-day that the New York Central in the near future will expend fully $2,500,000 in the development of its extensive harbor property here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The War Department to-day received the following dispatch from Gen. MacArthur, telling of the voluntary surrender of a large number of insurrectos to Gen. Young at Santa Maria. The omission in the telegram comes of faulty transmission or an inability to plausibly decipher the missing words:

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Emperor William's telegram to Mr. Kruger refusing to receive him continues to be the chief subject of comment in the French press. The afternoon newspapers strike a note of sadness. They see in his Majesty's action the shattering of his reputation for chivalry. Le Temps and Le Journal des Debats explain Emperor William's message by the AngloGerman understanding on African questions.

A Municipal Assembly device to legalize the squatting on the public street by the portico of-the Pabst Hotel, in Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, has -- for the present -- been thwarted by Alderman Joseph Oatman of the Twenty-seventh District.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Since last Autumn, when John McCullagh, State Superintendent of Elections, made his first bid for the Haight property in this village, until the present time negotiations have been pending, and are now practically completed. The deal will be closed on Dec. 6.
To the Senate and House of Representatives:

Judge Warren W. Foster, in charging the November Grand Jury, sworn in by him "yesterday, called the attention of that body in General Sessions to its powers in connection with the vicious resorts and disorderly places that "it is rumored and suggested and stated exist in the city," and whose existence "is owing, perhaps, in large measure to official corruption."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Attorney General Griggs this afternoon sent his annual report to Congress. It opens with a statement of the conditions of the work of the United States Supreme Court, which shows that 370 appellate cases were docketed and 371 were disposed of, leaving 303 cases still pending.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Owing to a misdirected hammer blow by one of a number of men working near the keel of L'Aquitaine at Havre yesterday, the liner sprang a leak, and the water entered her machine rooms, causing her to heel over. Her moorings broke, and the stage connecting the quay with the vessel fell, precipitating three men into the water.

Lieutenant Commander Reynold T. Hall, Assistant Engineer of the Steam Engineering Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, who served under Admiral Dewey through the Asiatic campaign as Chief Engineer of the gunboat Petrel, is lying in the Brooklyn Naval Hospital, on Flushing Avenue, with a fractured skull, having been struck by a falling scantling yesterday while inspecting the new engineering hall in course of erection near the Marine Barracks.

"Professor Morlarty" has come to life in the east side, and there is no Sherlock Holmes to cope with him. Maybe the professor is a myth, but to the inhabitants of the quarter around Rivington and Attorney Streets he is as real as he is mysterious, having at his beck and call a score or more of henchmen equally as wicked as himself.

Maybe the professor is a myth, but to the inhabitants of the quarter around Rivington and Attorney Streets he is as real as he is mysterious, having at his beck and call a score or more of henchmen equally as wicked as himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Republican Senatorial Committee on Order of Business to-day decided that the Ship Subsidy bill should displace the Spooner Philippine bill as the unfinished business. It also considered at the same time the disposition of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, and decided that that question should receive alternate attention with the shipping bill.

Ettle Humphreys, a rather pleasing looking young woman, was a dressmaker who had a voice and considerable musical talent. Her ambition was to go on the stage, but in her own opinion there was one obstacle in the Way. This was a little too much prominence of the tip of her nose. Miss Humphreys visited Woodbury's dermatological institute and had an operation performed.

The Philippine policy of the President, restated in his message, was made known to the people during the campaign. In his letter of acceptance Mr. McKINLEY embodied a large part of his instructions to the Taft Commission, and in that way and by further formal declarations he communicated to the electorate a knowledge of his views and his intentions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The annual report of Secretary of War Root is of more than usual interest, owing to its wide scope and the fact that it treats of subjects of such importance as the Philippine insurrection, the Chinese campaign, the developments in Cuba and Porto Rico, and, finally, with the subject of army reorganization.

The President does not err in devoting the first and largest division of his message to the Chinese question. It is at the moment the most burning question in the whole round of our foreign, including our colonial, relations. And it is very much the most extensively misunderstood.

The Philippine policy of the President, restated in his message, was made known to the people during the campaign. In his letter of acceptance Mr. McKINLEY embodied a large part of his instructions to the Taft Commission, and in that way and by further formal declarations he communicated to the electorate a knowledge of his views and his intentions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Attorney General Griggs this afternoon sent his annual report to Congress. It opens with a statement of the conditions of the work of the United States Supreme Court, which shows that 370 appellate cases were docketed and 371 were disposed of, leaving 303 cases still pending.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- The Government's curt and decisive intimation that Emperor William will not be able to receive Mr. Kruger has created a profound impression throughout Germany. What may be called the anti-British section of the press does not conceal its annoyance, and the moderate Anglophobe organs with difficulty repress utterances of disappointment.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Emperor William's telegram to Mr. Kruger refusing to receive him continues to be the chief subject of comment in the French press. The afternoon newspapers strike a note of sadness. They see in his Majesty's action the shattering of his reputation for chivalry. Le Temps and Le Journal des Debats explain Emperor William's message by the AngloGerman understanding on African questions.

Ettle Humphreys, a rather pleasing looking young woman, was a dressmaker who had a voice and considerable musical talent. Her ambition was to go on the stage, but in her own opinion there was one obstacle in the Way. This was a little too much prominence of the tip of her nose. Miss Humphreys visited Woodbury's dermatological institute and had an operation performed.

Lieutenant Commander Reynold T. Hall, Assistant Engineer of the Steam Engineering Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, who served under Admiral Dewey through the Asiatic campaign as Chief Engineer of the gunboat Petrel, is lying in the Brooklyn Naval Hospital, on Flushing Avenue, with a fractured skull, having been struck by a falling scantling yesterday while inspecting the new engineering hall in course of erection near the Marine Barracks.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- "Punchinello," a play in four acts, by Elwyn A. Barron, was given its first performance on any stage at the Tremont Theatre this evening by E.S, Williard and his company. The play was well, but not overenthusiastically, received, possibly owing to its being first night and the edges just a bit ragged.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- There are ten new members of the Fifty-sixth Congress elected to fill vacancies caused by death or resignation, two of the vacancies occurring in the State of Iowa.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Following the visit of the New York Central Railroad officials, in the course of their tour of inspection of the Boston and Albany Road, came the announcement to-day that the New York Central in the near future will expend fully $2,500,000 in the development of its extensive harbor property here.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeal has rendered a decision upholding that of a Divisional Court in the suit of the Attorney General vs. the Jewish Colonization Association. The Crown claimed estate and succession duty upon the death of Baron Maurice de Hirsch.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Col. Albert L. Mills, Superintendent of the Military Academy, made the following statement to-day:

A Municipal Assembly device to legalize the squatting on the public street by the portico of-the Pabst Hotel, in Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, has -- for the present -- been thwarted by Alderman Joseph Oatman of the Twenty-seventh District.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Since last Autumn, when John McCullagh, State Superintendent of Elections, made his first bid for the Haight property in this village, until the present time negotiations have been pending, and are now practically completed. The deal will be closed on Dec. 6.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- "Punchinello," a play in four acts, by Elwyn A. Barron, was given its first performance on any stage at the Tremont Theatre this evening by E.S, Williard and his company. The play was well, but not overenthusiastically, received, possibly owing to its being first night and the edges just a bit ragged.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- The Government's curt and decisive intimation that Emperor William will not be able to receive Mr. Kruger has created a profound impression throughout Germany. What may be called the anti-British section of the press does not conceal its annoyance, and the moderate Anglophobe organs with difficulty repress utterances of disappointment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Wilfred Grover, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, who lives with his parents at Cranbury, and has a mania for letter writing, has taken to the woods, and several Constables up Cranbury way are looking for him. He is wanted on a charge of threatening the life of Constable Jacob Gordon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The War Department to-day received the following dispatch from Gen. MacArthur, telling of the voluntary surrender of a large number of insurrectos to Gen. Young at Santa Maria. The omission in the telegram comes of faulty transmission or an inability to plausibly decipher the missing words:

The President does not err in devoting the first and largest division of his message to the Chinese question. It is at the moment the most burning question in the whole round of our foreign, including our colonial, relations. And it is very much the most extensively misunderstood.

Judge Warren W. Foster, in charging the November Grand Jury, sworn in by him "yesterday, called the attention of that body in General Sessions to its powers in connection with the vicious resorts and disorderly places that "it is rumored and suggested and stated exist in the city," and whose existence "is owing, perhaps, in large measure to official corruption."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES's editorial in protest against the bad policy of retaining the tax on hides must meet the approval of any fairminded American who has followed recent tariff experiments and attempts at taxation adjustment. The tariff on hides was never demanded by any one except a few political leaders hostile to the interests of the New Bngland manufacturers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Wilfred Grover, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, who lives with his parents at Cranbury, and has a mania for letter writing, has taken to the woods, and several Constables up Cranbury way are looking for him. He is wanted on a charge of threatening the life of Constable Jacob Gordon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Five railroad employes were instantly killed and twelve persons injured by the explosion of a boiler in the power house of the Chicago and North-western Road this evening. Among the injured is John Butterworth, chief electrician of the power house. He is so badly hurt that it is believed he will die.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- It is expected that next week the new calendar for the Court of Appeals, which goes into effect at the January term, will be ready for publication. The period during which attorneys were allowed to file cases for a place on that calendar expired on Saturday last. There will be 610 cases on the calendar, of which 180 will be preferred and 430 general causes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Republican Senatorial Committee on Order of Business to-day decided that the Ship Subsidy bill should displace the Spooner Philippine bill as the unfinished business. It also considered at the same time the disposition of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, and decided that that question should receive alternate attention with the shipping bill.
To the Senate and House of Representatives:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Mrs. Edward Valentine, nee Voice, who until she obtained a divorce in North Dakota was Mrs. Charles Hollister, has again figured in the courts. Mrs. Valentine, who is a granddaughter of Alfred H. Duncomb, a millionaire of East Chester, inherited, it is understood, $500.000 from her grandfather's estate.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- It is expected that next week the new calendar for the Court of Appeals, which goes into effect at the January term, will be ready for publication. The period during which attorneys were allowed to file cases for a place on that calendar expired on Saturday last. There will be 610 cases on the calendar, of which 180 will be preferred and 430 general causes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- All conjectures about the surplus for the fiscal year ending next June seem to have been too conservative, according to the report of Secretary Gage. Hitherto the surplus for the year has been estimated at not more than $40,000,000, but the Secretary finds that it will be quite $80,000,000, or a little more than the surplus for the last fiscal year, which was $79,500,000 in round numbers.

Open war has been declared upon ex-Police Justice Patrick Divver, Tammany leader in the Second Assembly District, by Councilman Thomas F. Foley and Representative Daniel J. Riordan, who will fight Divver in the next primaries to depose him from the leadership. There has been trouble in the district ever since Riordan was refused a renomination for Congress by orders from Richard Croker and Thomas J. Creamer named.

MANILA, Dec. 4. -- Two members of the crew of the United States auxiliary cruiser Yosemite, which recently, foundered during a typhoon off the Island of Guam, have arrived at Cavite on board the United States transport Alava, which left Guam Nov. 26 with seventy-five marines who had been transferred to Cavite from Guam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Quartermaster General Ludington has received a cable message from Gen. Humphrey, Quartermaster, with the troops in China, saying that the transport California sailed from Taku, China, on the 30th ult. for San Francisco with the remains of seventy-four soldiers and marines who died either of wounds or disease during the recent military operations in China.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Dr. Thomas Bassett Keyes, President of the American Psychological Medical and Surgical Society, sent out a call to-day for a "Congress on Cancer and Its Modern Treatment." The subject is to be taken up at the regular meeting in Chicago the first Tuesday in May, 1901.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The committee of clergymen and laymen appointed by the last General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church to make a recommendation to the next General Assembly, which meets in May, on the question whether there shall be a revision of the Confession of Faith, assembled here to-night and will continue in session to-morrow until their work is completed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the question of municipal ownership of franchises, which you characterize as a fad, have you forgotten the vote of the people on the seven questions submitted to them in November, 1894, the only chance which they have had in recent times of expressing their views on public questions?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Commissioner General Ferdinand W. Peck, who is to dine at the White House to-morrow night, is likely to have his enjoyment disturbed by considerations of what his enemies in Congress are about to do. The Democrats made a number of attacks on Mr. Peck at the last session, and some of them asked questions about his expenses as Commissioner General to the Paris Exposition.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The Times, referring to President McKinley's allusions to the Nicaragua Canal, says:

The fourth quarterly conference of the Presidents of Western railroads will be held in the Equitable Building to-day. A large attendance is expected. There was considerable speculation among the representatives of the various roads yesterday as to whether or not the Great Northern and Northern Pacific would be represented at to-day's meeting.

-- Some of the Philadelphia papers have been thrown into a state of amusing excitement by a speech made in that city on Sunday by Dr. STANTON COIT. This individual, it seems, is a native of the United States, and he lived here long enough to be graduated from Amherst, but after that he went over to England, where he has remained for the last fifteen years.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- The German Foreign Office and a section of the press will reserve a final expression of opinion upon President McKinley's message to Congress until the full text is at hand. Many of the papers believe they detect a cooler tone toward Germany than toward Great Britain and France.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- James G. Stowe, the United States Consul General at Cape Town, landed at Southampton to-day, wearing the identical coat which he wore when the Boers attacked his train while he was on his way to Pretoria on a special mission. A bullet hole in the collar of his coat testified to the narrowness of his escape.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The committee appointed to revise the statutes relating to patents, trade marks, , to-day submitted a report of its conclusions to Congress. The commission consists of Francis Forbes, Peter S. Grosseup, and Arthur P. Greeley. The changes which they recommend are embodied in three proposed bills, drafts of which they submit with the report.

Humphrey, Quartermaster, with the troops in China, saying that the transport California sailed from Taku, China, on the 30th ult. for San Francisco with the remains of seventy-four soldiers and marines who died either of wounds or disease during the recent military operations in China.

Residents of West One Hundred and Twelfth Street who own valuable dogs have been heavy losers of late by a system of poisoning which some one in the neighborhood is practicing. Among the most valuable dogs that have been poisoned is Friar, the mother of the Great Dane prize-winner Major McKinley, who was sold for $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The report of the Isthmian Canal Commission, submitted by the President to Congress to-day, gives as the unanimous conclusion of that body that "the most practicable and feasible route for an isthmian canal, under the control, management, and ownership of the United States, is that known as the Nicaragua route."

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 4. -- Gov. Pingree at 10 to-night announced that he had pardoned both Gen. W.L. White, ex-Quartermaster General, and Gen. A.F. Marsh, ex-Inspector General of the Michigan National Guard, who were convicted of complicity in the State military clothing frauds, upon the payment of $5,000 fine by each.

Visitors to Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, for several months past have found it easiest to enter the jail by way of the saloon of J.J. Atkinson, corner of Lafayette and Raymond Streets. Atkinson made it a point to keep on hand a bunch of jail passes. How he got the passes is not known.

CHADWICK, N.J., Dec. 4. -- The Oliver Schofield, a three-masted schooner, is pounding to pieces on the coast south of this place, near Lavalette City. She drove ashore about 3 o'clock this afternoon, and her crew were saved by members of Life-Saving Station No. 13, who employed the breeches buoy in effecting the rescue.

There are 110,000 Democratic voters in Brooklyn, twice as many, almost, as in the whole State of Connecticut. There are only twenty-two States in the Union that have a larger Democratic vote than Brooklyn.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 4. -- Banking and Insurance Commissioner Bettle filed his annual report with the Governor to-day. It shows there are 360 building and loan associations in the State. This is an increase of two over last year. All but one of the 360 associations made reports. The accounts of the association not reporting were kept by the Secretary, who died during the year, and were not figured out in time to be included.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- The Record to-morrow will say:

Police Commissioner Jacob Hess lies dangerously ill sit his home, 68 West Sixty-eighth Street. He is suffering from pneumonia and chronic nephritis. While he rallied somewhat yesterday and was slightly better at midnight, his friends are very apprehensive that the end is near.

The first bowling games in the local championship series were rolled last night on Thrum Kahlsdorf's Harlem Palace Alleys, between two picked teams from the Harlem League and the American National League, representing, respectively, the upper and the lower east side clubs. The lower east siders won two of the three matches, thus scoring two points to the upper east siders' one.

HAVANA, Dec. 4. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention resumed its sittings today with an air of business. The first thing done was to defeat overwhelmingly the motion of Senor Gualberto Gomez to discuss Gen. Wood's address at the opening of the convention. This action will probably close the incident.

"Existing Conditions in New York -- What Are We Going to do About Them?" was the subject of discussion at last night's meeting of the Social Reform Club. The speakers were the Rev. Robert L. Paddock of the Pro-Cathedral, the Rev. F.J. C. Moran, the Rev. W.D.P. Bliss, and Edward King.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The report of Gen. J.C. Breckinridge, Inspector General of the army, earnestly recommends that the benefits of the law of March 3, 1899 providing for the retirement of officers of the navy, under certain conditions, with the rank and pay of the next higher grade, be extended to include officers of the army.

Traffic on many of the Brooklyn trolley lines was suspended yesterday evening by a fire which destroyed the Ridgewood power house of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, at Myrtle Avenue, Wyckoff and Woodbine Streets. The fire started at 3:45 o'clock, and within ten minutes the entire building was in flames.

The project of connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans by a canal across the isthmus has always had its enemies, open or secret. They have been active at Washington, influential and quite successful in preventing favorable action. These influences are still at work.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- John Armstrong Chanler, a cousin of Col. John Jacob Astor and divorced husband of Amelie Rives, the novelist, has escaped from the Bloomingdale Asylum here, and, although it is a week since he disappeared, Dr. Lyon, the Superintendent, this evening said that he had no knowledge as to his whereabouts, and was very anxious to find him.

Marsh, ex-Inspector General of the Michigan National Guard, who were convicted of complicity in the State military clothing frauds, upon the payment of $5,000 fine by each.
