WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- An amusing feature of the Subsidy bill debate to-day was the way in which Senator Hanna appeared as the real "Senator in charge" of the bill. Mr. Frye was "in charge," but Mr. Hanna was the guiding spirit of the whole thing, and he demonstrated it in rather unusual ways.

Wall Street was treated to a surprise yesterday, when shortly after noon it was announced that a meeting of the Directors of the American Sugar Refining Company -- commonly known as the trust -- had been held at the residence of President H.O. Havemeyer, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, and a quarterly dividend of 1 8/4 per cent, had been declared on the common stock of the company.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Burglars early this morning used dynamite on the safe in the general store of Charles Wellins at Mullica Hill. The door was blown out and across the room. Eight hundred dollars were stolen from the safe.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Plans for the electrical equipment of the Metropolitan District Railway are now rapidly nearing completion. They are attracting much attention on the part of electrical companies all over the world, and particularly in the United States. Lemuel Bannister, who is a Director In both the British and American Westinghouse Companies, said this evening:

Negotiations have been concluded by which the entire block bounded by First Avenue, Avenue A, Fourth, and Fifth, Streets, owned by John Jacob Astor and leased by him to various tenants, will be sold to these tenants. Title to the properties will pass on Dec. 10.

AMEN. For the benefit of all concerned it is made known that the "Amen Corner" was so named because it if the gathering spot in the Fifth Avenue Hotel corridor of those who talK politics, music, religion, poetry, art, political economy statesmanship, office seeking foreign and domestic finance, international law, constitutional law, police court law, civil district law, the quality of cigars, the quality and effect of stimulants, club life, the idiosyncrasies of the Mugwump.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Jennie Cello, an Italian girl of nineteen, told a story today in the Recorder's Court of the annoyance to which she has been subjected by Narcelze Pecci, an Italian barber, who is infatuated with her. Jennie lives at 132 Vine Street, this city, and the barber is her next-door neighbor.

The Rev. Felix Marion Lepore of the Italian. Catholic Church of Denver has come East to enlist capital for a number of inventions which he has made. Father Lepore says he is not a genius, and that his inventions are the result of visions.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The records of the Department of Health of this city contain an entry which shows that on July 12, 1899, William L. Beadleston was married to Emma P. Humphrey in this city by Alderman John H. Southwick. The bride's age is given as twenty-seven and that of the bridegroom as twenty-six.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- Chief Inspector watts to-day disclosed a mysterious case of awakened conscience, in which he has been acting for nearly a month past. On Nov. 33 an express team brought two large cases addressed to Chief "Watts to headquarters. There were no marks to tell where they came from.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Joe De Barthe, formerly of Baker City, Oregon, made an interesting witness in the United States District Court this morning in the case of James and Thomas Armstrong, charged with using the mails to fraudulently dispose of medical diplomas which were worthless. De Barthe had been attorney and lecturer for the Independent Medical College, which was conducted by the Armstrong Brothers until it was raided by Post Office Inspectors.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Burglars early this morning used dynamite on the safe in the general store of Charles Wellins at Mullica Hill. The door was blown out and across the room. Eight hundred dollars were stolen from the safe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Senator Frye (Rep., Me.,) at to-day's session of the Senate concluded his speech upon the Ship Subsidy bill. He devoted his attention principally to a technical explanation of the various provisions of the measure, explaining with especial care that provision Which would admit to American registry foreign-built ships.

Counselor Thomas F. Nolan, known as "the Irish Barrister" of Tammany Hall, filed yesterday at the St. Francis Hospital. The funeral services will be held in the Church of the Holy Redeemer, in Third Street, this morning. Five weeks ago Mr. Nolan was stricken with paralysis. He was taken to the hospital, where his nephew.

A peculiar case, in which an unrelenting mother figured, came before Magistrate Steers in the Grant Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. Two boys were arraigned on a charge of larceny, the complainant being their mother. The peculiar feature of the case was that the mother was not the person who had suffered the loss.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Wheeling has loft Vancouver for Bremerton.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- This morning a well-dressed elderly man called upon the Rev. T.F. Kelly, pastor of St. Joachim's Church at Matteawan. He said he was M.A. Flannery, Surgeon General of the United States Army, and that he had called on a very pleasant mission. Some months ago a young soldier was stricken with illness in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Debate on the Army Reorganization bill opened in the House to-day. After routine matters had been disposed of Mr. Daizell, (Rep., Penn.,) from the Committee on Rules, presented the following special order for the consideration of the army bill:

WASHINGTON. Dec. 5 -- The executive session of the Senate to-day was devoted chiefly to the consideration of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty. The agreement and the amendment to it suggested by the Committee on Foreign Relations were read at the instance of Senator Lodge, who took charge of the treaty on behalf of the committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Dr. G. Clinton Blakelock of 13 North Grove Street, East Orange, has taken advantage of the Federal bankruptcy law to stay a foreclosure of a mortgage. The sale of the doctor's household effects, under a mortgage held by James K. Wakefleld of 44 James Street, was fixed for Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Wheeling has loft Vancouver for Bremerton.

The members of the City Club had one of the largest meetings in its history last night at 19 West Thirty-fourth Street. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day sent to Congress the annual estimates of the expenses of the Government for the coming year. They aggregate $626,741,762, a slight decrease from the total estimates of last year. The appropriations for the present year are $586,655,302.

"Civic Righteousness" was the subject of discussion last night at the monthly meeting of the New York Local Assembly of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, held in the lecture room of the Pro-Cathedral, in Stanton Street. The meeting was presided over by Charles Comfort Tiffany, Archdeacon of New York, who introduced Bishop Potter as the first speaker.

The Rev. Felix Marion Lepore of the Italian. Catholic Church of Denver has come East to enlist capital for a number of inventions which he has made. Father Lepore says he is not a genius, and that his inventions are the result of visions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day sent to Congress the annual estimates of the expenses of the Government for the coming year. They aggregate $626,741,762, a slight decrease from the total estimates of last year. The appropriations for the present year are $586,655,302.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 5 -- The Jones Valley Iron Company has banked the Williamson blast furnace in this city, operated by it under lease, on account of an accident to the plant and because of embarrassments attending failure of prompt payment of the employes' wages. The employes claim that their wages are overdue and unpaid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Panama Canal Company does not appear to have given up the idea of attracting the attention and capital of the United States to the completion of the French route across the isthmus. To the Panama opposition to the Nicaragua route is attributed the report heard here to-day that Nicaragua demands $20,000,000 as the price of the concession sought by the United States from that nation.
Deputy Chief John MacKellar, the second in command of the Brooklyn police, was found unconscious in the street near his home shortly before midnight last night. He died a few minutes later.

"Civic Righteousness" was the subject of discussion last night at the monthly meeting of the New York Local Assembly of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, held in the lecture room of the Pro-Cathedral, in Stanton Street. The meeting was presided over by Charles Comfort Tiffany, Archdeacon of New York, who introduced Bishop Potter as the first speaker.

C.W. Morgan, trading as C.W. Morgan Co., stock brokers, 71 Broadway, and Michael Hart, his bookkeeper, were arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of conspiracy and grand larceny following an investigation made by Assistant District Attorney Byrne. The men were arrested by three of Capt. McClusky's detectives and locked up in Police Headquarters and later admitted to ball.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Jennie Cello, an Italian girl of nineteen, told a story today in the Recorder's Court of the annoyance to which she has been subjected by Narcelze Pecci, an Italian barber, who is infatuated with her. Jennie lives at 132 Vine Street, this city, and the barber is her next-door neighbor.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 5 -- A genuine boar hunt furnished Danbury with more excitement yesterday than it has undergone for many a year. The animal, which was a black one, weighing nearly 700 pounds and displaying a set of tusks that protruded from its mouth two inches or more, had been shipped from Ridgefield to Waterbury in a cage which was not half strong enough to restrain it in its efforts to escape.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Joe De Barthe, formerly of Baker City, Oregon, made an interesting witness in the United States District Court this morning in the case of James and Thomas Armstrong, charged with using the mails to fraudulently dispose of medical diplomas which were worthless. De Barthe had been attorney and lecturer for the Independent Medical College, which was conducted by the Armstrong Brothers until it was raided by Post Office Inspectors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Chairman Hull is confident that he will be able to get his Army Reorganization bill through the House in its amended shape, and he talks hopefully about its chances in the Senate, but at the War Department this confidence is not shared. It is also a matter of grave doubt whether the Senate will pass a Reorganization bill, even one dealing so considerately with the staff as the modified House bill.

Counselor Thomas F. Nolan, known as "the Irish Barrister" of Tammany Hall, filed yesterday at the St. Francis Hospital. The funeral services will be held in the Church of the Holy Redeemer, in Third Street, this morning. Five weeks ago Mr. Nolan was stricken with paralysis. He was taken to the hospital, where his nephew.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- Reports that Vickers' Sons Maxim, Limited, the great English steel firm, had offered $7,500,000 for the Mid vale Steel Works, and had practically concluded negotiations for the purchase of the Cramp Ship Yards of this city were definitely denied to-day by the highest representatives of both the Philadelphia firms.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 5 -- Thirty-two men employed at the Nayaug Colliery, in Dunmore, were entombed by a cave-in this morning, but, thanks to a fortunate circumstance, a terrible disaster was avoided. The men were at work about 1,000 feet from the bottom of the slope and 400 feet below the surface.

WOODBINE, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The big frame factory building owned by the Woodbine Land and Improvement Company, and leased by Daniel Blumenthal as a clothing manufactory, was burned this morning. This village was founded with a portion of the Baron de Hirsch Fund. The land company is a side company of the Baron's fund for the betterment of the people of his race.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Justice Lawrence heard the case of Miss Annie Castka, nineteen years old. who sued to have her marriage to Frank Castka annulled because it was entered into under Curess. Annie is the daughter of Emil F, Corsari, who is in business in Beekman Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Panama Canal Company does not appear to have given up the idea of attracting the attention and capital of the United States to the completion of the French route across the isthmus. To the Panama opposition to the Nicaragua route is attributed the report heard here to-day that Nicaragua demands $20,000,000 as the price of the concession sought by the United States from that nation.

HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- The Havana Municipal Council held a special meeting this evening to discuss the sewer project. The Sewer Commission, consisting of one member appointed by the municipality, one by Michael J. Dady, and Senor Villalon, selected by the other two, made its report, recommending the payment to Mr. Dady of $564,000 for being the owner of the project and for expenses entailed since submitting his planss to the old municipality in 1895.
Deputy Chief John MacKellar, the second in command of the Brooklyn police, was found unconscious in the street near his home shortly before midnight last night. He died a few minutes later.

HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- The Havana Municipal Council held a special meeting this evening to discuss the sewer project. The Sewer Commission, consisting of one member appointed by the municipality, one by Michael J. Dady, and Senor Villalon, selected by the other two, made its report, recommending the payment to Mr. Dady of $564,000 for being the owner of the project and for expenses entailed since submitting his planss to the old municipality in 1895.

It is also a matter of grave doubt whether the Senate will pass a Reorganization bill, even one dealing so considerately with the staff as the modified House bill.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Plans for the electrical equipment of the Metropolitan District Railway are now rapidly nearing completion. They are attracting much attention on the part of electrical companies all over the world, and particularly in the United States. Lemuel Bannister, who is a Director In both the British and American Westinghouse Companies, said this evening:

The animal, which was a black one, weighing nearly 700 pounds and displaying a set of tusks that protruded from its mouth two inches or more, had been shipped from Ridgefield to Waterbury in a cage which was not half strong enough to restrain it in its efforts to escape.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Debate on the Army Reorganization bill opened in the House to-day. After routine matters had been disposed of Mr. Daizell, (Rep., Penn.,) from the Committee on Rules, presented the following special order for the consideration of the army bill:

A peculiar case, in which an unrelenting mother figured, came before Magistrate Steers in the Grant Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. Two boys were arraigned on a charge of larceny, the complainant being their mother. The peculiar feature of the case was that the mother was not the person who had suffered the loss.

A peculiar case, in which an unrelenting mother figured, came before Magistrate Steers in the Grant Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. Two boys were arraigned on a charge of larceny, the complainant being their mother. The peculiar feature of the case was that the mother was not the person who had suffered the loss.

WILLIAMSON, West Va., Dec. 5 -- This afternoon S. Davis Stokes shot and killed the Rev. John W. Wohl in a street duel hero, Mr. Stokes being also dangerously wounded To-night the whole town and even the country districts are greatly excited.

Gregorio de Quesada, the father of Gonzalo and Dr. Gregorio de Quesada, a prominent Cuban resident of this city, dropped dead in the Bank of the Manhattan Company, at 40 Wall Street, yesterday afternoon. Mr. de Quesada, who had been feeble, for some time, was a depositor in the bank and went there to draw some money.

C.W. Morgan, trading as C.W. Morgan Co., stock brokers, 71 Broadway, and Michael Hart, his bookkeeper, were arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of conspiracy and grand larceny following an investigation made by Assistant District Attorney Byrne. The men were arrested by three of Capt. McClusky's detectives and locked up in Police Headquarters and later admitted to ball.

Application was made yesterday before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court for the appointment of a receiver for the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association of New York. The application was made by three of the stockholders of the association -- James N. Carpenter. Martin P. Carter, and Pulaski P. Carter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- John Armstrong Chanler is still missing from the Bloomingdale Asylum. Added credence was given to the belief that Mr. Chanler went direct to New York when it was learned to-day that a man answering his description was seen to board a Harlem express train at White Plains at 4 P.M. on that day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Senator Frye (Rep., Me.,) at to-day's session of the Senate concluded his speech upon the Ship Subsidy bill. He devoted his attention principally to a technical explanation of the various provisions of the measure, explaining with especial care that provision Which would admit to American registry foreign-built ships.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The records of the Department of Health of this city contain an entry which shows that on July 12, 1899, William L. Beadleston was married to Emma P. Humphrey in this city by Alderman John H. Southwick. The bride's age is given as twenty-seven and that of the bridegroom as twenty-six.

WOODBINE, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The big frame factory building owned by the Woodbine Land and Improvement Company, and leased by Daniel Blumenthal as a clothing manufactory, was burned this morning. This village was founded with a portion of the Baron de Hirsch Fund. The land company is a side company of the Baron's fund for the betterment of the people of his race.

Negotiations have been concluded by which the entire block bounded by First Avenue, Avenue A, Fourth, and Fifth, Streets, owned by John Jacob Astor and leased by him to various tenants, will be sold to these tenants. Title to the properties will pass on Dec. 10.

The members of the City Club had one of the largest meetings in its history last night at 19 West Thirty-fourth Street. The Committee on Co-operatlon and Affiliated Clubs has arranged the following programme for four of the regular Friday evening meetings held under the auspices of the People's Institute in the large hall of Cooper Union:

AMEN. For the benefit of all concerned it is made known that the "Amen Corner" was so named because it if the gathering spot in the Fifth Avenue Hotel corridor of those who talK politics, music, religion, poetry, art, political economy statesmanship, office seeking foreign and domestic finance, international law, constitutional law, police court law, civil district law, the quality of cigars, the quality and effect of stimulants, club life, the idiosyncrasies of the Mugwump.

WILLIAMSON, West Va., Dec. 5 -- This afternoon S. Davis Stokes shot and killed the Rev. John W. Wohl in a street duel hero, Mr. Stokes being also dangerously wounded To-night the whole town and even the country districts are greatly excited.

We can readily believe that, as the Washington dispatches have reported, there was rejoicing in the State Department over the announcement that all the Powers represented in China had come to our terms respecting the treatment of that country. Most Chinese news is so doubtful that it is prudent to wait for a few days to have the first announcements confirmed, but there seems to be no reason to distrust the authenticity of this announcement.

Mayor Van Wyck was urged yesterday by a delegation of residents of East Fifty-fourth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, to sign an ordinance repealing one passed about a year ago ordering the Commissioner of Highways to renumber East Fifty-fourth Street, between the two avenues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce held its first meeting of the session to-day. The meeting was devoted mainly to the consideration of the ship subsidy bill and to amendments suggested by Chairman Frye. The most important of these amendments was one providing that all ships shall take 50 per cent. of their cargo capacity when leaving a port of the United States for a foreign port.

The officers and Directors of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association will appear before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day to make answer to the complaint of several of their stockholders, who ask for a receiver, on the ground that, as the complaint alleges, the affairs of the association have been grossly mismanaged and that actual fraud has been committed.

Frank Du Bois, the insurance brokers of 47 William Street, whose office manager, William W. Gates, is a defaulter to the amount of about $20,000, yesterday issued a statement concerning the affair. Gates is still a fugitive and it is not likely that the firm he defrauded will take any steps to apprehend him.

The officers and Directors of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association will appear before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day to make answer to the complaint of several of their stockholders, who ask for a receiver, on the ground that, as the complaint alleges, the affairs of the association have been grossly mismanaged and that actual fraud has been committed.
VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The Landis will contest began its course in the Cumberland County Orphans' Court here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The War Department to-day sent to Congress reports on a number of important river and harbor projects, including that for connecting the Mississippi River with Lake Michigan by means of the Illinois River and the Chicago Sanitary Canal, and also for extensive improvements of the Sault Ste. Marie River, connecting Lakes Superior and Huron.
BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- The annual meeting of the New England Trotting Horse Breeders' Association was held in the American House to-day. These Directors were elected:

Naval officers are looking forward to the voyage to Manila that has been ordered by the Navy Department for the little tug Wampatuck, which has been doing service in the Brooklyn Navy Yard for some time. The order came as a surprise to the officers in the yard. If she completes the long trip it will be the first time on record that so small a tug has been able to do so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Judiciary Committee of the House has a very curious and interesting bill before it. It is a proposition to amend the Constitution introduced by Representative Sibley of Pennsylvania. It proposes that the President of the United States shall be elected for a term of six years, instead of four, and that he shall be ineligible for re-election for a second term.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- An exciting runaway enlivened proceedings at a funeral in Fairmount Cemetery, Newark, this afternoon.

The sale of the collection of the Japanese and other art objects which belonged to the late Joseph W. Sprague of Louisville, Ky., was continued at the galleries of the American Art Association yesterday afternoon. The objects disposed of consisted of Oriental silverware, Japanese sword guards, arms, and ivories, and miscellaneous specimens, mostly of cabinet size. A large collection of photographs was disposed of at the close of the sale.

Frank Du Bois, the insurance brokers of 47 William Street, whose office manager, William W. Gates, is a defaulter to the amount of about $20,000, yesterday issued a statement concerning the affair. Gates is still a fugitive and it is not likely that the firm he defrauded will take any steps to apprehend him.
VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The Landis will contest began its course in the Cumberland County Orphans' Court here to-day.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 6. -- It was learned positively to-day that the new cup defender is to be plated with Tobin bronze. The material was found so satisfactory on Columbia that there was scarcely a question of the use of any other. The announcement to this effect has not, of course, been made by the Bristol designers, but comes from an authoritative source.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 6. -- The strike which was declared by the cutters at the Milltown India Rubber Works yesterday was concluded this afternoon, when the cutters returned to work. The strikers held a meeting this morning and later a delegation visited John C. Evans, the Superintendent of the factory, and found him ready to debate any question with them excepting the question of who shall be employed there.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- The Northern New York championship football game between the Ogdensburg and Watertown elevens was played at Glen Park this afternoon and was won by Watertown by the score of 23 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The War Department to-day sent to Congress reports on a number of important river and harbor projects, including that for connecting the Mississippi River with Lake Michigan by means of the Illinois River and the Chicago Sanitary Canal, and also for extensive improvements of the Sault Ste. Marie River, connecting Lakes Superior and Huron.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The House of Representatives to-day, at the end of a long sitting, passed the Army Reorganization bill by a vote of 166 to 133. Three Democrats, Messrs. Hall of Pennsylvania, and Underbill and Clayton of New York, voted with the Republicans for the bill, and Mr. McCall, Republican, of Massachusetts, with the Democrats against it. Otherwise It was a strict party vote.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 6. -- Mr. Kruger arrived here to-day and was greeted at the station by the burgomaster and Councilors. A choir of 600 men and girls chanted Psalm 72, Verses 6, 7, and 11, Mr. Krtiger and his suite then repaired to the royal waiting room, where the Burgomaster warmly welcomed them in a brief speech.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- An attachment for the benefit of local creditors upon the deposit of the Philadelphia branch of C.W. Morgan Co. was issued this afternoon. The funds of the branch were kept in the Tradesmen's National Bank, in the Drexel Building. The attachment also covers the handsome office furnishings of the Rooms 921 and 924 Drexel Building, where the firm was located.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6. -- Plans for the combination of the independent telephone companies of the United States are rapidly nearing completion and details will be announced shortly. An agreement has been practically reached. Alexander Brown of this city is a leader in the movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The House of Representatives to-day, at the end of a long sitting, passed the Army Reorganization bill by a vote of 166 to 133. Three Democrats, Messrs. Hall of Pennsylvania, and Underbill and Clayton of New York, voted with the Republicans for the bill, and Mr. McCall, Republican, of Massachusetts, with the Democrats against it. Otherwise It was a strict party vote.

David B. Hill came to town yesterday on "legal business." Politicians by the dozen made efforts all day to see Mr. Hill, for the word had gone forth that he had come from Albany to organize a hunt for the Tammany tiger. Some of the politicians went so far as to claim that David B. Hill was here as a vice crusader.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 6. -- The strike which was declared by the cutters at the Milltown India Rubber Works yesterday was concluded this afternoon, when the cutters returned to work. The strikers held a meeting this morning and later a delegation visited John C. Evans, the Superintendent of the factory, and found him ready to debate any question with them excepting the question of who shall be employed there.

Charles W. Morgan, the stockbroker, of 71 Broadway, who was arrested at his office in the Empire Building on Wednesday on charges of grand larceny and conspiracy to defraud, was busy yesterday. His first care was to file in the County Clerk's office, through his lawyers, Niles Johnson, an assignment -- without preferences, except as to this week's salaries of employes -- to Bert Hanson of Ritch, Woodford, Bovee Wallace.

Albert T. Patrick, the lawyer who is a prisoner in the Tombs, has at last disclosed his line of attack on the first will of William Marsh Rice. Patrick in his affidavit filed yesterday practically makes a charge of forgery against witnesses to the will. He directly declares that the names of the witnesses to the will were written by one and the same person.

Mayor Van Wyck was urged yesterday by a delegation of residents of East Fifty-fourth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, to sign an ordinance repealing one passed about a year ago ordering the Commissioner of Highways to renumber East Fifty-fourth Street, between the two avenues.

In the second act of the new piece called "Madge Smith, Attorney," which had a trial performance at the Bijou Theatre yesterday afternoon, a general simulation of light-hearted mirth on the stage proved contagious in the audience and some new songs sung with spirit by gleesome May Irwin, Ignacio Martinetti, and Joseph Sparks, turned out to be uncommonly effective.

It is possible that Commander Freeman, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, may be permanently retired, as a result of a physical break-down. Some time ago Commander Freeman showed signs of nervous prostration. He was sent to the Naval Hospital, where after careful nursing he apparently recovered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has frequently espoused the cause of the overworked, underpaid postal clerks of this city. In obtruding upon your valuable space, I hope it will be clear to the Postmaster that some measure ought to be taken to relieve their present hard lot.

Louis J.J. Otto, who is a broker at 149 Broadway, has just gone through an experience with a process server which has caused him to decide to appeal to the court. A dainty note, supposed to be from a young woman, was the inducement that led Mr. Otto to the house, when he was served with the papers in a case growing out of a dispute over a tailor's bill.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6. -- Plans for the combination of the independent telephone companies of the United States are rapidly nearing completion and details will be announced shortly. An agreement has been practically reached. Alexander Brown of this city is a leader in the movement.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The Racing Calendar to-day announces that Lester Reiff, the American jockey, has been exonerated of the charge of pulling Richard Croker's horse. The Scotchman II., at Doncaster.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The Racing Calendar to-day announces that Lester Reiff, the American jockey, has been exonerated of the charge of pulling Richard Croker's horse. The Scotchman II., at Doncaster.

It is possible that Commander Freeman, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, may be permanently retired, as a result of a physical break-down. Some time ago Commander Freeman showed signs of nervous prostration. He was sent to the Naval Hospital, where after careful nursing he apparently recovered.

Mrs. Alice F. Coutant of 44 West Twenty-sixth Street, Borough President Grout's stenographer, who is charged by State Senator-elect Samuel S. Slater with attempting to sell information to his political enemies, detrimental to the Senator's character, was not arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

The movement which has for its stated object the ousting of John W. Gates from the active management of the American Steel and Wire Company is gaining force and headway. Welles, Herrick Hicks, who at the request of certain stockholders instituted the proceedings, advertising for proxies to enable them to vote at the annual meeting for an "honest and efficient management," stated yesterday that their request was meeting with entirely satisfactory and gratifying results.

Sixty-seven talesmen, constituting the jury panel for the December term of court in Part II., General Sessions, were yesterday discharged for the term by Recorder Goff, to whom, it is said, have come rumors of dissensions, bickerings, and accusations among the jurymen, rendering impartial verdicts an impossibility.

Louis J.J. Otto, who is a broker at 149 Broadway, has just gone through an experience with a process server which has caused him to decide to appeal to the court. A dainty note, supposed to be from a young woman, was the inducement that led Mr. Otto to the house, when he was served with the papers in a case growing out of a dispute over a tailor's bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A card of seven races, in four of which the fields were of generous proportions, furnished the sport at the Benning track to-day. Favorites took the money in four of the events, and two outsiders passed under the wire first. Federalist, the favorite, took the first easily by six lengths.
There will be a conference of Republican leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-night and something definite will probably be done with regard to proposed police legislation.

In reply to the questions of Senator LINDSAY, Senator LODGE explained during the executive session on Wednesday that the Davis amendment to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty was substantially in the language of Article 10 of the Constantinople treaty, guaranteeing the neutrality of the Suez Canal, and might be expected to serve the purposes intended to be served by that article in respect to the Suez waterway.

Governor-elect Odell yesterday gave notice that he will oppose the creation of additional offices and that his concern as Chief Magistrate of the State will be to reduce, not to increase, the expenses of the Government. He made the statement in response to an application for a large increase in the number of Deputy State Factory Inspectors.

The movement which has for its stated object the ousting of John W. Gates from the active management of the American Steel and Wire Company is gaining force and headway. Welles, Herrick Hicks, who at the request of certain stockholders instituted the proceedings, advertising for proxies to enable them to vote at the annual meeting for an "honest and efficient management," stated yesterday that their request was meeting with entirely satisfactory and gratifying results.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Senate was in executive session for more than four hours to-day, the entire time being devoted to the discussion by Senator Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty for the abrogation of the portion of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty which relates to the Nicaraguan Canal.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 6. -- Amos Ruscoe of New Fairfield wants a divorce from his wife on the plea of cruelty, and the wife has brought a counter suit against her husband on the same grounds. The case was heard to-day in the Superior Court, and some interesting testimony was brought out.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- An exciting runaway enlivened proceedings at a funeral in Fairmount Cemetery, Newark, this afternoon.

There was in President MCKINLEY'S message one statement of principle as to taxation so sound, so pertinent to the actual situation in many industries, and so full of wise and pointed suggestion to Congress, that it should be written above the chair of the presiding officer of each house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- When the House met an arrangement was agreed to by which the consideration of the Grout Oleo-margarine bill, which was to have come up to-day under a special order made at the last session, was postponed until to-morrow, and the House proceeded with, the consideration of the Army Reorganization bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Judiciary Committee of the House has a very curious and interesting bill before it. It is a proposition to amend the Constitution introduced by Representative Sibley of Pennsylvania. It proposes that the President of the United States shall be elected for a term of six years, instead of four, and that he shall be ineligible for re-election for a second term.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your suggestion in this morning's edition as to the so-called "Dewey Arch" should be acted upon. The arch was a triumph of city decoration, and commemorated a National victory. New York, with its many private architectural monuments, has all too few public memorials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- When the House met an arrangement was agreed to by which the consideration of the Grout Oleo-margarine bill, which was to have come up to-day under a special order made at the last session, was postponed until to-morrow, and the House proceeded with, the consideration of the Army Reorganization bill.

He directly declares that the names of the witnesses to the will were written by one and the same person.

A full representation of the membership of the St. Nicholas Society assembled for the sixty-sixth annual banquet, held last night at Delmonico's. The function was attended by all the quaint Old World glitter and pomp that has characterized the banquets of the society in the past, and upward of 300 members and guests in song and oratory honored the traditions of their ancestry of Holland.

CHICAGO, Dec, 6. -- In a sweeping order directed to Chief of Police Kipley, Mayor Harrison to-day revoked the licenses of seven of the most notorious resorts, and informed the keepers of other dens that unless they close their doors to the demimonde their privileges will likewise he withdrawn.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- No trace has been found of John Armstrong Chanler, who escaped from Bloomingdale Asylum on Nov. 28. There is a belief that Chanler may have committed suicide, or else is wandering aimlessly about New York. Dr. Lyon, Superintendent of Bloomingdale Asylum, said to-night:

Most Chinese news is so doubtful that it is prudent to wait for a few days to have the first announcements confirmed, but there seems to be no reason to distrust the authenticity of this announcement.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The fifteenth Parliament of the reign of Queen Victoria opened yesterday. Before the lights went out in the ancient chambers almost every leading politician had spoken. Such fierce, personal animosity and such bitter invective had scarcely ever before marked proceedings at Westminster.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- A new cruising raceabouf is under construction at the Jacob yard, this place, for E.H. Weatherbee, designed by Messrs. A. Gary Smith and Henry G. Barbey. The dimensions are 42 feet 3 inches over all, 28 feet water line, 11 feet beam, and 4 feet draught, fitted with a centreboard and a knockabout rig.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Henry Russell, the well-known song writer, died yesterday.

Some of the politicians went so far as to claim that David B. Hill was here as a vice crusader.
