The funds of the branch were kept in the Tradesmen's National Bank, in the Drexel Building. The attachment also covers the handsome office furnishings of the Rooms 921 and 924 Drexel Building, where the firm was located.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The fifteenth Parliament of the reign of Queen Victoria opened yesterday. Before the lights went out in the ancient chambers almost every leading politician had spoken. Such fierce, personal animosity and such bitter invective had scarcely ever before marked proceedings at Westminster.

Governor-elect Odell yesterday gave notice that he will oppose the creation of additional offices and that his concern as Chief Magistrate of the State will be to reduce, not to increase, the expenses of the Government. He made the statement in response to an application for a large increase in the number of Deputy State Factory Inspectors.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- No trace has been found of John Armstrong Chanler, who escaped from Bloomingdale Asylum on Nov. 28. There is a belief that Chanler may have committed suicide, or else is wandering aimlessly about New York. Dr. Lyon, Superintendent of Bloomingdale Asylum, said to-night:

Gossip among local yachtsmen regarding the forthcoming international races for the America's Cup was given a new lease of life yesterday by the announcement that Thomas W. Lawson, either independently or as the head of a Boston syndicate, had under consideration the building of a yacht which would be offered as a competitor of the New York Yacht Club syndicate's Herresboff boat for the privilege of defending the cup.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce held its first meeting of the session to-day. The meeting was devoted mainly to the consideration of the ship subsidy bill and to amendments suggested by Chairman Frye. The most important of these amendments was one providing that all ships shall take 50 per cent. of their cargo capacity when leaving a port of the United States for a foreign port.

CHICAGO, Dec, 6. -- In a sweeping order directed to Chief of Police Kipley, Mayor Harrison to-day revoked the licenses of seven of the most notorious resorts, and informed the keepers of other dens that unless they close their doors to the demimonde their privileges will likewise he withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

-- Active work has now begun on both of the little ships, or big boats, upon the relative merits of which depends the settlement of the momentous question whether the America's Cup is to remain for the present comfortably where it is, or whether it is soon to add a chapter to its very short record as an ocean traveler.
A report from St. Luke's Hospital last night said that physicians had performed an operation upon Roland Reed, and that his condition was very critical.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Amalgamated Mining continued active and heavy to-day, losing from 93 1/4 to 90 3/3, with a point rally. Butte softened 3, to 78, and Arcadian 1/2, to 21. There was little change in other mining stocks. Massachusetts Electric shares continued in good request at 24 7/8@24 1/2 for common and 81@80 1/2 for preferred.

Alice O'Donnell, a nurse in the employ or Mr. and Mrs. James Jones, who live in the apartment house at 127 Palmetto Street, Brooklyn, killed their only child, a boy of eighteen months, last night by cutting his throat with a razor. The murder was committed in the kitchen of the apartment while Mrs. Jones was singing for her husband in the parlor.

M.A.W. of Albany N.Y., quoting from Dr. Johnson, "Teach a boy to have entertainment out of books," continues to say, "and, to the teacher and the parent," that may be put down as the first and greatest of educational rules. Dr. Johnson further expresses his belief that it did not much matter what kind of books the boy derived his first entertainment from, for he would 'get better ones by and by.'

The stock market yesterday appeared to be influenced by the reported large loss in cash by the banks during the week and by the talk in certain quarters of the probability of higher money rates, if not of an actual stringency. At the same time the reports of the trouble between Portugal and the Netherlands led to some selling in the fear that a war between those countries might involve other powers.

Negotiations are pending for the sale of the property 34 to 38 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, running through to 29 and 31 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, owned by Henry M. Denton. Beyond saying that the deal would probably be successfully concluded, interested parties declined to discuss it yesterday afternoon.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The Peking correspondent of the Deutsche Zeitung writes that several German marine officers discovered Sir Claude M. MacDonald, ex-British Minister at Peking and Lady MacDonald personally superintending coolies who were carrying off treasures from the Chinese Imperial Palace to the British Legation buildings.

John B. Cauldwell, Director of Fine Arts for the United States at the Paris Exposition, was among the arrivals on the Hamburg-American Line steamship Deutschland yesterday. Concerning the American exhibit, Mr. Cauldwell said:

Four American jockeys who have been conspicuous on the English turf in the latter part of the racing season of 1900 were passengers on the ocean liner Deutschland, which arrived in port yesterday, twentyfour hours late. The jockeys were the brothers Lester and "Johnny" Reiff, and Daniel Maher and "Clem" Jenkins.

A number of clever and difficult feats of horsemanship were performed by some of the most dashing riders in Squadron A last night, in the armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. The exhibitions of various phases of rough riding were incidents in a series of inter-troop contests for a cup offered by Franklin B. Morse of Troop I.

LISBON, Dec. 7. -- The Minister from the Netherlands to Portugal and the Portuguese Minister at The Hague have left their respective posts. It is believed that a difference has arisen on the subject of the exequatur to the Dutch Consul at Lorenzo Marques, which the Portuguese Government has withdrawn.

On Nov. 12 and 13 Bangs Co. sold an interesting collection of books relating to America, including many items of considerable scarcity, Romans's " Florida," New York, 1776, bringing $90, George D. Smith securing it. La Salle's "Journal," London, 1714, an uncut copy, sold for $36 to Dodd, Mead Co.

Some remarkably fine books were disposed of at a sale held by Bangs Co. on Nov. 26-28, among them being nearly complete sets of the Kelmscott Press and Groller Club publications, Shelley's "Poetical Works," printed by Morris in 1894-5, in three volumes, brought $246, while John Keats's "Poems," 1894, went for $175.

Two men, supposed to be brothers and thought to be George and William Miller of Marlborough, Ulster County, N.Y., were found asphyxiated by gas in a small room on the second floor of the Boston and Fall River Hotel, 210 West Street, yesterday morning. Both men were well dressed, had money, and seemed to be countrymen.

There will be shown to-morrow for the first time, in the Marble Collegiate Church, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, a new memorial window given by Mrs. Sarah A. Sandham in memory of her son, George Augustus Sandham. The new window has for its subject the battle of the hosts of Israel with the armies of the five Kings of the Amorites, as recorded in the tenth chapter of the Book of Joshua.

Postal clerks in this city have been informed to be on their guard against a new counterfeit five-dollar silver certificate, it is on the new issue, bearing the portrait of the Indian Onepapa. The counterfeit Is a photo-lithographic note of fair workmanship and good paper, containing distributed silk fibre.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- The gutter poets, or whom it is the profession to perpetrate doggerel records of passing events, have, of course, been inspired by the coming of Mr. Kruger. At the Montmartre Fair, which is in full swing on the other boulevards, I purchased on Saturday evening a baker's dozen of Kruger songs, which were being squeaked to considerable audiences by wheezy itinerant minstrels.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Dec. 7. -- A report that the Smith estate, at Smith's Point, has been sold to H.O. Havemeyer was denied by E.T. Smith to-day. The reported price offered was $400,000. The Smith heirs claim that the value of their property has been greatly enhanced by the Supreme Court's decision confirming the title of the estate to nearly half of Great South Bay.

Two correspondents, who cherish a respect for this noble tongue of ours, have written to us expressing a desire that we say something more about the misuse of common English words. One of them calls attention to the persistent use of "balance" for "remainder" and the other rightly objects to the employment of "lurid" to signify "brilliant" or "highly colored."

A most interesting addition has been made to the contents of the mummy room at the British Museum in the form of a body which is believed to be the oldest extant, and of especial value as throwing some light on the doubtful origin of the ancient Egyptians. Some archaeologists have contended that the Egyptians originally inhabited mid-Africa, and were therefore negroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The usual run of luck by the talent which has been characteristic of the Fall meeting of The Jockey Club at the Bennings track was repeated to-day, when four favorites won. The sport was good, though the finishes generally were by wide margins of three and four lengths.

Brentano's have arranged for the exclusive right to publish in the United States, in French, Edmond Rostand's play "L'Aigion." The work is now in preparation, and it is expected to be ready about Dec. 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- In relation to the lynching in La Salle County, Texas, Oct. 5, 1895, of Florentino Suaste, a Mexican citizen, the President, in a special message sent to the Senate to-day, recommends that the Mexican Government be paid 2,000 for the heirs of the victim.

The ninth annual exhibition of fine bindings and rare books at the Bonaventure Galleries was opened on Wednesday, Dec. 5, and will continue for one week. Some 300 volumes were on view, of which 85 are figured and described in a neat catalogue. A number of the books come here direct from the Paris Exposition, where Mr. Bonaventure received a medal for his display of bindings.

A tall, dignified, well-dressed man called upon Chief Devery, at Police Headquarters, yesterday and, after introducing himself as William Horsman of 230 East Twenty-second Street, threw a paper down on the Chief's desk. On the paper was written:

Louis Stichof died last Monday at his home, 415 Seventh Avenue, and although on two separate occasions friends and relatives have gathered at his funeral, his body still lies at his home while rival undertakers are engaged in a legal squabble as to who shall dispose of it.
I said to my cowboy friend, "Do you know this Bear?"

For some persons the harrowing scenes depicted in John R. Spears's "American Slaver Trade" will prove unpalatable reading. Looking back fifty years it seems scarcely possible that men possessing a single grain or humanity or honor would engage in such an atrocious and degrading traffic as the author here describes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Senator Platt of Connecticut, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba, to-day made public the statement prepared by the Auditing Division of the War Department showing the expenditures made by E.G. Rathbone, late Director of the Department of Posts for Cuba.

The Bureau of Incumbrances yesterday made its regular quarterly swoop on the stores in the Astor House and carted away a double truckload of trunks, barber's poles, signs, and showcases, to the elation of several hundred small boys and bigger idlers. Whenever the Astor House stores are raided, there is a semi-holiday in the neighborhood.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- A meeting of persons interested in Stratton's Independence Mine to-day attracted a large attendance of shareholders, who passed a vote of no confidence in the Board of Directors, after one of the stormiest city meetings on record. The whole meeting was disorderly. The Directors were hissed and hooted, and the words "scandalous" and "disgraceful" and accusations of fraud were hurled broadcast.

According to Dagonet, in The Referee, the term Hooligan owes its origin to the indistinctness of a witness and the misapprehension of a police court reporter. The name arose in this way: In a well-known and busy centre of South London there has been for many years a family of flower sellers. One day some years ago pretty Polly L -- was, in the language of the fraternity, "Coppered by the Bozzer," for willful damage.

The Strollers came to the Waldorf-Astoria last night and brought in their train a number of society people and others to see "the first performance on any stage" of a musical comedy called "The Cruise of the Summer Girl."

"Lessons in Love" is a happy title for Mrs. Trask's group of short stories. Each is characterized by its author's well-known deftness and delicacy of touch, and epigrammatic flashes of insight. Each is read with a sense of aroused, perhaps of questioning, thought, with the desire to "talk it over" with the writer, rather than with that feeling of finality with which one usually lays aside the narrative of a romantic situation.

The scattering in many directions of the natural forces that are in every one accounts largely for the mediocre achievements of most people in what they undertake. "The one prudence in life is concentration." There are few that can say of what they are engaged in, "This one thing I do."

Some weeks since we were considering the apparent injustice of making the price of a book depend upon the material ingredients of its manufacture -- on the paper, covers, -- instead of on the volume's usefulness and helpfulness, on the intellect or inspiration that is in it, or the thought and research that have gone to its creation.

In the preface to his study of Milton Mr. Raleigh disarms such of his readers as might consider his theme outworn by accepting Bacon's verdict that criticism of great writers must be classed as a "science of conceit," at the same time urging that an attempt at appreciation of Shakespeare or Milton made for love of the subject is not conceited by necessity.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange unanimously adopted yesterday the plans for their new building as drawn by Architect George B. Post, and previously submitted to the Building Committee. The committee has been at work on the matter for many months, and they believe that the plans now decided upon will in every way answer the requirements.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- The chill which settled upon the New York list was responded, to in the Philadelphia market today, but the volume of business was too meagre to permit of more than scant variations. It was a spotty market, with Reading first preferred and the Choctaws dominating the list in the way of activity.

The Late Charles Dudley Warner in The Century. Perhaps the most curious and interesting phrase ever put into a public document is "the pursuit of happiness." It is declared to be an inalienable right. It cannot be sold. It cannot be given away. It is doubt- ful if it could be left by will.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Mr. Chamberlain still fills the political stage. An unexpected but adroit announcement by him in the House of Commons yesterday that civil government would be given to the two Boer countries, coupled with his promise to limit farm burning and other severe military measures so far as possible, took the bottom out of the chief amendment of the Opposition to the address, and it was withdrawn.

Matteo Bove, who, it was claimed, was wanted for the alleged murder of Gaetano Casa in Salerno, Italy, was yesterday discharged from custody by Magistrate Brenner, in Brooklyn. Bove's case was a peculiar one, no one apparently being willing to assume the responsibility of keeping him in custody.
After a session lasting for three days, the Quarterly Conference of Western Railroad Presidents adjourned yesterday afternoon, to meet again in this city on the first Wednesday of March, 1901.

General business conditions continue favorable, and all the reports in respect to the outlook are encouraging. A feature of the week has been the ease with which collections have been made -- in marked contrast with the difficulty experienced some weeks ago.

To The New-York Times Saturday Review: In reading with great interest the account in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 17 of the dinner given by the Lotos Club to Mark Twain, and of all the clever and amusing things said thereat, I was particularly struck by a remark of ex-Speaker Reed's:

PEKING, Dec. 6. -- Mr. Conger, the United States Minister, and the other foreign envoys received to-day a letter signed by Kang-Yu-Wei, the well-known Cantonese reformer, who was formerly an adviser of Emperor Kwang-Su, and who has always been favorable to foreigners.

There were forty-six boobies at the big progressive euchre party of the American Army and Navy Aid Society at Sherry's yesterday afternoon. It was one of the biggest progressive euchre parties on record, and the only women in the company who did not wear an expression of green-eyed jealousy on their faces when they looked at the happy forty-six were the five who preceded them and won the first prizes.
C.W. Morgan of the firm of C.W. Morgan Co., who made an assignment after his arrest on complaint of customers, gave out the following statement last night:
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The second supplementary estimate of u10.000,000 issued yesterday makes the total army estimates for the year u92,309,153.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The complete report of the Deep Waterways Commission was sent to the House of Representatives to-day by Secretary Root. The project before the commission is one of vast magnitude, for a deep waterway and routes between the great lakes and Atlantic tidewater.

TOLEDO, Dec. 7. -- A motion in an important case was heard and overruled by Judge Ricks of the United States court yesterday afternoon. The litigation will interest union men, as the plaintiff, August A. Hickerson, one of the American Railway Union strikers, seeks damages from Messrs. Cowan and Murray, formerly receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railway for alleged blacklisting.

Six colored women, graduates of the Colored Home and Hospital Training School for Nurses, received their diplomas last night in the lecture hall of the Academy of Medicine, at 17 West Forty-third Street. Never before in the Northern States has there been regularly graduated a class of colored nurses, the care of the sick of that race having hitherto been intrusted to white attendants.

The Forest Preserve Board met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, Commissioner Charles H. Babcock, State Engineer E.A. Bond, and Assemblyman Merton E. Lewis were present. The first matter discussed was the claim of George R. Finch of Glens Falls to 11,000 acres of land in Hamilton County.

The qualifying round of the National Class B billiard tourney, now in progress under the sanction of the Amateur Athletic Union, at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, was yesterday brought to a close by two games, in which William Paige of Boston and Frank Billiter of Minneapolis were the victors.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 7. -- William Seaton, aged twenty-two years, formerly of Decatur, Ill., to-day attempted to exterminate an entire family, his relatives, at South Park, nine miles from Seattle. With an axe he smashed in the heads of four persons, leaving them for dead; then shot one man in the back and attempted to kill a Deputy Sheriff.

The Court of Louis XIV., even at the end of the seventeenth century, was already a synonym for that delicate epigrammatic cleverness essentially French. "Wit was the mode, the supreme mode among the wittiest people in the world and in an age which was pre-eminently the Age of Good Talk -- and bad deeds.

When Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court called up yesterday the matter of the application for a receiver for the Anglo-American Mutual Savings Association, Charles A. Deshon, the attorney for the company, requested a postponement for a reasonable time in order that he might prepare a plea against the Court's jurisdiction.

The portion of the collection of Oriental art objects which belonged to the late Joseph W. Sprague of Louisville, sold yesterday at the galleries of the American Art Association, consisted entirely of specimens of lacquer ware. In these the Sprague collection was remarkably rich, a number of objects, such as the Daimio trunks, being of a character hardly ever seen at sales either in this country or Europe.

J. Lawrence Van Alen, who is to marry Miss Daisy Post on Monday next, will give his farewell bachelor dinner at Sherry's this evening. Mr. Van Alen's attendants at his wedding and who will be his guests at this dinner are to be M. Orme Wilson, who is to be best man, and Frank W. Andrews, Jr., Robert L. Gerry, Lawrence R.L. Gillespie, and George Griswold, 2d, who are to be the ushers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent issue of your SATURDAY REVIEW contained a list of Raiph Waldo Emerson's contributions to the four volumes of The Dial, Boston, 1841-3. Permit me to add to that incomplete catalogue the following. marked by Mr. Emerson with his initials as written by him, in my copy of The Dial, now in the Library of Congress:

One of the most elegant books of the season will, unfortunately, not be presented until January. It is entitled. "A Descriptive and Historical Catalogue of the Collection of Pictures and Sculpture at Apsley House, London," which, as everybody knows, was a residence of the Duke of Wellington. It will be Illustrated by 52 photo engravings, especially exevuted by Braun, Clement Co. of Paris, and will be presented in two volumes, royal quarto in size.

The second public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday aftarnoon at Carnegie Hall with the customary surroundings of gentle women and music students in search of light upon their art. The programme consisted of the following numbers: Beethoven's overture to "Egmont," Bruch's G minor violin concerto, Richard Strauss's tone poem, "Ein Heldenleben," ("A Hero's Life"); Tartini's "Devil's Trill," and Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries."

An amazing exhibition of human weakless and folly was given at the Herald Square Theatre yesterday afternoon, when a so-called play entitled "Sold and Paid For" was performed in a slipshod and slovenly fashion before a scant audience largely composed of friends of the author and professional theatregoers.

There was plenty of life and activity on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon. The warm, bright weather brought the road drivers and their fast steppers out in full force, and for several hours before dusk there were many interesting contests.

E.B. PATTERSON, Brooklyn, N.Y., writes: "Apropos of Howard Pyle's decoration of Edwin Markham's 'Man with the Hoe, and Other Poems.' some one writing in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 10 has a severe indictment of the poor for alleged pessimism. I know that this dismal charge has sometimes been laid at Mr. Markham's door, but I am one who cannot read despair in his message.

Members of the Harlem Republican Club with their friends to the number of about 1,200, gathered in the new home of the organization, 23 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, last evening at a reception given in honor of Governor-elect Benjamin B. Odell and other leaders of the winning State ticket at the last election.

In his "Ode to the Comic Spirit," Mr. George Meredith, if we read his puzzling phrases and paragraphs aright, appeals to humor as "the sword of common sense" -- a weapon to set much store by by those who exploit a fervid imagination, or who embody "warm emotion and loving fancies in rhythm and rhyme. Of it he says:
MANILA, Dec. 7. -- More activity is shown in the operations in Northern and Southern Luzon. The reports from the former district come in more quickly and telegraphic interruptions are fewer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Senator and Mrs. Fairbanks gave a large dinner party this evening in honor of ex-President and Mrs. Harrison. Those present to meet them were the Chief Justice and Mrs. Fuller, the Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hitchcock, Justice and Mrs. Harlan, Senator and Mrs. Frye, the Speaker of the House and Mrs. Henderson.
Governor-elect Odell intimated yesterday that he would send a special message to the Legislature early in the session on the question of canal improvement.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Dec. 7. -- Admiral Kautz received orders this afternoon to sail without delay to "South America," and in accordance with these instructions preparations are now being hurriedly made for both the Iowa and Philadelphia to leave this port to-morrow.

Kate Bowen, sister of William P. Bowen, Foreman of Engine Company No. 59, at One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, was found dead yesterday morning in a small room behind the restaurant of Ernest Dausand at 616 Hudson Street. The room was full of gas that had escaped from a radiator.

DENVER, Dec. 7. -- Harry Vardon, the English golf player, made his initial appearance at the Overland Park Club links this morning in a game with Walter Fairbanks, amateur champion of the club. Fairbanks played with a handicap of one-half to a hole and won out with a score of four up to three to go.

Nearly the entire list of active outside securities developed new strength yesterday, and closing prices showed in many cases substantial gains for the day. In some cases the advances were the result of favorable news, but in many others the course of prices was attributable to nothing more specific than an increased demand.

There is danger that the fame of the late Sir Arthur Sullivan, (1842-1900,) who died in London, Nov. 22, with a smile on his countenance, will be connected with comic operas, to the exclusion of due recognition of the fact that he was a great composer of sacred music, inclusive of fifty hymn tunes.

At the dinner of the Reform Club on Thursday evening where speakers considered the condition of the city and how it could be improved, the most suggestive and immediately practical speech was that of Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD.

The week that closes to-day has been a remarkably busy one in New York art circles for this time of the year. In addition to a number of small exhibitions at the dealers' galleries, there have been displays at the Salmagundi Club -- the annual Autumn one of water colors by members -- and the annual one of the Black and White Club at the Durand-Ruel galleries.

LONDON, NoV. - The success of Miss Cholmondeley's clever story, "Jezebel," has been very marked. The in order to revenge himself on her mother. Precisely how this vengeance was to be accomplished is not very clear, unless the vengeful father imagined that the child would neceessarily live up to her name. If so, ho was disappointed, for Jezebel turned out to be a most admirable girl.

The singular acrimony and vindictiveness with which Mr. CHAMBERLAIN was attacked in the House of Commons, in the first debate of the session, were more marked by reason of the cheerful unanimity with which he was not defended. The situation is rare, if not unique.
Our Council, Royal Arcanum, won two of their three matches with the Spartan bowlers in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

Robbins Avenue, northeast corner of One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, for a one-story frame shed, 44 by 50: Thomas Graham, Stamford, Conn., owner; Ernest Iden of 490 Courtlandt Avenue, architect; cost, $95.

"I'm monarch of all I survey." This was the defiant challenge hurled over the transom by the cook in the Alfred G. Sonn family of 371 West Sixteenth Street yesterday when the family walked into the dining room for breakfast.

Eggs, love, and lucre figured prominently in the romantic recital of the past history of "Gus" Hart, alias Steinhart, of Missouri and New York, convicted yesterday in General Sessions of appropriating to his own use $1,161.36 of his prospective fatherin-law's money. This sum represented the proceeds of a sale of 382 cases of fresh eggs consigned to Hart for disposal in the New York market by A. Loewenstein of Chillicothe, Mo.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Money was in increased demand to-day, the tone was harder, and the supply was fairly large. Discounts were firm. The joint stock banks were not keen to deal in bills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- President Homer of the Baltimore Clearing House and thirty other prominent business men representing the Clearing House, the savings banks, and the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association of Baltimore, called in a body at the Treasury Department to-day and urged Secretary Gage to accept the invitation of the President to remain at the head of the Treasury Department for another four years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Representative Hull, Chairman of the House Committee on Military Affairs, is doomed to disappointment in his hope that the Senate would send the Army Reorganization bill direct to a conference committee instead of subjecting it to further discussion in the Senate.

Near the close of his "Cromwell" Mr. John Morley has written a sentence that is a product either of gross ignorance -- and Mr. Morley is not an ignorant man -- or of a deliberate intention to blacken the memory of a man as little inferior in honor as he was in courage to the best and bravest England ever brought forth.

John S. Silver was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday charged by Howard J. Barlow of 27 West Ninetyeighth Street with the larceny of $580.84. Barlow alleges that he gave at various times to Silver more than $500 to be invested by the latter in Atchison stock. Demands for a statement of his account or a return for his money, he claims, were unavailing.

Several pedestrians passing the saloon at Forsyth Street early yesterday morning were startled by the sound of woman's screams coming from the hall within. Rushing in they found a woman rolling about on the floor with her clothing in flames. The burning clothing was torn from the woman's body, and she was taken, unconscious, to Gouverneur Hospital, where it was said that she would die.

He was a true book-lover, this stalwart woodsman and Swiss mountaineer who lived in a rude chalet in our Connecticut forest where he sometimes met scarcely a mate from one week's end to another. In clearing woods it is the fashion to build temporary shelters for the workmen, who provision and "find" themselves and sleep as work-folk did in the middle ages with a round log for a bolster, and lead hardy and resolute lives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- After a hard fight by the opposition and the minority of the Committee on Agriculture, the Grout Oleomargaine bill was passed by the House to-day by a vote of 196 to 92. The bill makes all articles known as olemargarine, butterine, imitation butter, or imitation cheese transported into any State or Territory subject to the police powers of such State or Territory.

A writer who signs himself or herself S.D. McCormick has been contributing to The Bookman a series of articles entitled "Survivals in American Educated." We do not know how persons born and educated to the various parts of this country may regart his deductions, but certainly it seems that the educated people of Boston whose "survivals" are described in the November number have cause for remonstrance.

VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 7. -- The taking of testimony in the contest of the will of Founder Landis, who founded this place. Sea Isle City, and numerous other places in South Jersey, was completed this evening. The counsel will sum up on Monday, and the case will rest with the Court by adjournment on Monday evening.

Joel Chandler Harris in The World's Work. It's lots too late in the day to try to hamper the politicians will too much principles. Forty-odd year ago it sounded all right to hear that kind of talk. In them days folks hadn't nigh reached the'r present state of progress an' civilization. They was ruther underdone as compared to what our town editor calls the th'obbin' present.

The Directors of the United States Rubber Company, who had held several conferences duping the week, met again yesterday, but what they did is a matter of mystery. Immediately after the meeting Charles R. Flint went out of town, while the other Directors refused to discuss the meeting or what was done at it.
The Republican organization has decided on a Police bill for New York City. It will give the Governor power to remove the Commissioner without charges at any time.

The present average quality of gas in New York is quite as good as we need expect, and even better than is likely to be maintained. There are several reasons for this. One is that the lower the candle power of water gas the cheaper it is to make and the larger the quantity used to maintain a given standard of illumination.

The contact of the flame from a plumber's candle with the fumes from benzine caused an explosion yesterday in the basement of a newly completed apartment house at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The two steam fitters, John and Edward Stevenson of 389 Willis Avenue, who were at work in the basement at the time, were seriously burned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Ex-Representative William D. Bynum is having a hard time trying to set into office. He was nominated during the last session of Congress to be a member of the Board of General Appraisers, and the Democrats of the Senate refused to accept him as a person fully answering to the requirement of the law that a certain proportion of the board shall be of the minority party.

Unlike many other holidays, Christmas has no merely local or national signification. Nor is its celebration a modern custom, for which reason the literature of many lands, for a period of time covering centuries, will be found to be full of references to it, its celebration, and the many quaint customs centring around its observance.

The bill authorizing the appointment of Representative Boutelle of Maine as a Captain on the retired list of the navy, upon his resignation from Congress, has been reported favorably by the House Committee on Naval Affairs, over which Mr. Boutelle presided until his present affliction.
Denials by officials of the Illinois, Indiana and Iowa Railway Company of the story that the Atchison Railway will absorb their road.

Prank G. Carpenter, who is well known to the reading public through his newspaper work and books of travel, some of which are used in their schools as reading books, has prepared another interesting volume, the outcome of a 25,000-mile journalistic expedition to South America, in search of information for the American business man and general reader.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- "Mr. Kruger has abandoned all the proposed journeys to other capitals," says the Brussels correspondent of The Standard, "and all further diplomatic efforts to secure arbitration will await at The Hague the development of events at the seat of war."
Horace J. Hayden, Second Vice President of the New York Central Railroad, was instantly killed last evening at his residence, 337 West Seventy-sixth Street, by falling from a third-story window.

It was a very unusual incident in the career of a Cabinet officer that occurred yesterday to Secretary GAGE, when a delegation of some thirty bankers and business men of Baltimore called on him and urged him to accept the invitation of the President to remain for another four years in the Treasury.

In the discussion that is now going on among the laymen about the ideal newspaper a moment's consideration might be given to the ethical rating to be accorded to a newspaper that notifies its advertising patrons that beyond a certain predetermined amount of space it cannot accept their advertisements.

To every careful reader of the Scriptures the names of the blind son of Timeus, and of the rich publican Zaccheus, are almost as closely identified with the City of Jericho as the name of Joshua, who destroyed it, (Joshua, vi., 21-26.) or that of Hiel, who rebuilt it. (First Kings, xvi., 34.) The one was a beggar -- the other, rolling in wealth -- but there, both became "the sons of God."

H.C. Davis of the brokerage firm of A. A. Housman Co., who has been in London representing the Yerkes syndicate, which is to build the new underground railway in that city, returned on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland yesterday. Concerning the proposed road Mr. Davis said:

John Williams, State Factory Inspector, came from Albany yesterday to testify before a conference called by the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor, held yesterday afternoon in the phurch Mission House, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue. The conference was called to consider the best methods of enforcing the Factory law in the east side shops.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 8 -- This city will have another strike of considerable magnitude on its hands, beginning Monday. A big mass meeting of weavers of the Acushnet and Hathaway mills was held this afternoon, about 400 weavers being present. It was voted to strike. At the outset four persons, who it was claimed were present for the purpose of spying upon the actions of the weavers, were excluded from the meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 8 -- Charles McCaul, one of the most prominent builders in this country, died at his home, here, to-day, of pneumonia, aged about fifty-five years. Mr. McCaul was born in Londonderry, Ireland, and was engaged in the building line from earliest boyhood. Mr. McCaul's attention was occupied most closely by the new United States Mint building, which he was pushing rapidly toward completion, and by preparations to erect the new Wanamaker building.

Gov. Roosevelt spent a busy day yesterday. During the morning he received a large number of callers at the Union League Club, After he had lunched with Henry C. Payne, National Conimitteeman from Wisconsin, and they had indulged in campaign reminiscences, the Governor made a call upon Chairman George L. Rives of the Charter Revision Commission and discussed with him the commission's report.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 8 -- The officials of the Santa Fe here take the situation very coplly. In speaking of the situation, General Manager Mudge said to-night: "About 75 per cent, of the operators have quit work. This means that about 600 men have walked out. We anticipate no special trouble in the operation of trains, as most of them are running on timetable schedules.

James J. Reid, forty-two years old, was locked up in the Butler Street Police Station, Brooklyn, last night, charged with shooting his wife, Elizabeth, and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Mary Reid. The two women are in the Long Island College Hospital, and the wife, it is feared, may die as a result of the shooting.
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 8 -- J.A. Newman, General Chairman of the Santa Fe Division of the Order of Railroad Telegraphers, including the entire Santa Fe system, refering to the strike, said:

Battery E won for the second year last night the inter-company athletic championship of the Thirteenth Regiment Heavy Artillery, at the Fall regimental games held in the big armory at the corner of Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn. An unusually large crowd of spectators turned out to witness the tussle of the military athletes for supremacy in a dozen or more events.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 8 -- The Duke and Duchess of Manchester, who arrived here from New York last night, were not at home to their friends during the greater part of to-day. They arose late, and the Duke was afterward seen amusing himself on the lawn of Mr. Zimmerman's house with his newly acquired Boston terriers.

Over 3,000 men, women, and children, witnessing an amateur circus performance at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon, saw Joseph C. Starck, a professional bicycle rider, dive to his death from an incline thirty feet high into a tank of water. Starck's head struck the side of the tank.

Having summoned the members of his family from their homes outside the city, and after having informed his New York friends that his last week on earth ended with Saturday, Philip S. Sondheim, a young lawyer living at the Criterion Hotel, Broadway and Forty-first Street, last night killed himself with a revolver.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The marriage of Miss Johanna Hayes Shepard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus D. Shepard of The Gables, just east of this city, to Osborne Wyckoff Bright of New York took place this afternoon at 3 o'clock in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

BANGOR, Dec. 8 -- The Christmas tree industry is now at its height in Maine, many carloads and even vessel loads going forward, every week to the large cities. Only a few years ago the fir tree was looked upon as a nuisance in Maine, because it grew as rankly as the burdock and crowded out better growths, while being of no value itself except as it might be considered an ornament to the landscape.

BERKELEY, Cal., Dec. 8 -- D.O. Mills of New York, at the request of President Benjamin Ide Wheeler, has promised the University of California to defray the expenses, about $24,000, of a two years' astronomical expedition from the Lick Observatory to South America or Australia. The object of the expedition is to study the movement of stars in the line of sight.

Through good detective work Capt. Schmittberger of the West One Hundredth Street Station and Detective Walsh have recovered nearly $5,000 worth of furs belonging to many wealthy residents of the upper west side, which were stolen two weeks ago from Samuel Kramer, a furrier, at 612 Columbus Avenue, who had them for repair and storage.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. E.C. Richards of Bridgeport, Conn., were arrested at Coytesville last night on instructions from the Bridgeport authorities, but without specific charges. They had in their possession eight vehicles and fourteen horses, which were found in a livery stable.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 -- The tin can manufacturers' combination, which will include several of the largest Baltimore plants, and also plants in Philadelphia and Delaware, and which was expected to be completed by the end of this year, has been postponed.

Owing to the firm alarm box at the corner of Barclay and Greenwich Streets being; out of order, a policeman last night had to turn in a "still alarm," and by the time the engines appeared a fire that had broken put in the three-story brick building at 241 Greenwich Street had gained strong headway, and three buildings were gutted before the flames were got under control.

The Aqueduct Commissioners announced yesterday the dismissal of John R. Soper, Superintendent of Dam Construction. On Oct. 29 last Superintendent Soper was ordered, according to the records of the Aqueduct Commissioners, to take charge of another part of inspection work than the masonry work to which he had been assigned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Get-away day was one of the most notable of the Washington Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Bennings. Despite the inclement weather -- a raw wind and a threatening sky -- the attendance was one of the largest of the meeting. Speculation was unusually brisk and heavy, and as three favorites and two strongly backed second choices won the talent had a good day.

Having summoned the members of his family from their homes outside the city, and after having informed his New York friends that his last week on earth ended with Saturday, Philip S. Sondheim, a young lawyer living at the Criterion Hotel, Broadway and Forty-first Street, last night killed himself with a revolver.

Golf on Northern links for 1900 is at an end. There will, of course, be more or less desultory playing during the Winter, but the championships and club tournaments are over. Only one more big tournament remains to be played in which local golfers will take a prominent part, and that is the Atlantic City Country Club open tournament, which will take place on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday of this coming week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Over 600 telegraph operators on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad left their desks this afternoon and lalked out on a Strike. Advices late to-night from points along 5,000 miles of track in the system indicate that the freight traffic is practically tied up, and that passenger trains are running slowly with no further destination than the next division terminal.

From The Chicago Tribune. Chicago's smoke and grime and soot and dirt as the specific cause of malformations to the lungs of every person who has breathed its atmosphere for any considerable period may be a revelation to most people outside of the medical profession. Yet there are thousands of men and women in Chicago's down-town streets whose lung tissues are as black from coal soot as soot trill make them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The text of the agreement reached between the foreign envoys at Peking has been received at the State Department, and is now in process of translation from the cipher code.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 8 -- The lead for the new cup defender's keel, which, went astray in transit, has been located. There was a deal of worry here about the delay while the search for the missing cars was being made, and there is great relief now that the lead can be forwarded.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. E.C. Richards of Bridgeport, Conn., were arrested at Coytesville last night on instructions from the Bridgeport authorities, but without specific charges. They had in their possession eight vehicles and fourteen horses, which were found in a livery stable.

Yet there are thousands of men and women in Chicago's down-town streets whose lung tissues are as black from coal soot as soot trill make them.

Battery E won for the second year last night the inter-company athletic championship of the Thirteenth Regiment Heavy Artillery, at the Fall regimental games held in the big armory at the corner of Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn. An unusually large crowd of spectators turned out to witness the tussle of the military athletes for supremacy in a dozen or more events.

The indoor cycling racing season under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association was opened last night in the Madison Square Garden. The track on which the races were run is with one exception the steepest that has even been used in this country, and as a consequence there were a number of spills, although none of the riders was hurt.

Golf on Northern links for 1900 is at an end. There will, of course, be more or less desultory playing during the Winter, but the championships and club tournaments are over. Only one more big tournament remains to be played in which local golfers will take a prominent part, and that is the Atlantic City Country Club open tournament, which will take place on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday of this coming week.

NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- Judge Kirkpatrick of the United States Circuit Court to-day appointed Henry C. Kelsey of Trenton receiver of the Bay State Gas Company of New Jersey. The appointment was made on the application of Chauncey G. Parker of this city, acting for Patrick J. Brady of New York, the holder of $10,000 worth of second mortgage bonds of the company.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- Two burglars were surprised by Dr. J.F. Detwiler in his home early to-day. The doctor seized a rifle and fired at the men repeatedly as they escaped through a window. A trail of blood showed that one of the shots took effect. As the men reached the street they fired back, but failed to hit any one.

Attorney General Griggs now has under consideration the rights of the United States Government in the shoals off Governors Island. If he decides that the cession of the island by the State to the Government included the shoals, the project for the extension of the island which has seen fully matured by the War Department will be begun in the near future.

The official returns of rifle practice in the New York National Guard for the present year, completed yesterday by Col. W.B. Thurston, Inspector of Small Arms Practice, show a great advance in marksmanship over the year 1899. The State has this year 9,559 trained riflemen, against 8,184 in 1899, a gain of 1,375.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke, who is a member of the Committee on Revision of the Presbyterian creed, made a statement to-day in which he said that revision must surely come.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 -- The tin can manufacturers' combination, which will include several of the largest Baltimore plants, and also plants in Philadelphia and Delaware, and which was expected to be completed by the end of this year, has been postponed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 8 -- At to-day's session of the American Federation of Labor Convention an appeal was read from the Federation of Labor of Porto Rico for "freedom of speech, assembly, and press," and that a committee be sent to the island for the purpose of completing organization.

The Rev. Father William Everett, the oldest Roman Catholic priest in the Archdiocese of New York and for more than a generation rector of the Church of the Nativity in Second Avenue, near Third Street, died at his residence, adorning the church, at 10:10 o'clock Friday evening. He also enjoyed the distinction of being one of the oldest practicing physicians in the city.

For twelve years Abraham Rosenthal of 53 Stanton Street has mourned the loss of his eldest daughter, who was kidnapped when she was only five years of age from his home, in Russian Poland. In vain he searched for her after her disappearance, saving the greater part of his meagre wages and living in want to pursue his quest.

G.B.D. Hasbrouck, the legal representative of the State Controller, announces that the personalty of the estate of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt had beer appraised at $52,500,000. The real estate left by the great financier, the lawyer said had been appraised at $20,000,000, thus fixing the total valuation at $72,500,000.

BANGOR, Dec. 8 -- Pitiful scenes have been enacted this week in the little town of Otis, in Hancock County, where the personal property of the people is being seized by the Sheriff to satisfy judgments against the town. Otis is one of those poverty-stricken little Maine communities where everybody gets a living, or tries to do so, from rocky and worn-out farms.

The sale at the galleries of the American Art Association of the collection of art objects which belonged to the late Joseph W. Sprague of Louisville was concluded yesterday afternoon, when the most elaborate and costly objects in the collection were disposed of. These consisted of the wonderful carved furniture which was made for Mr. Sprague in Japan by the greatest masters of woodcarving in that country.

One of the features of rapid transit tunnel work which the public hears little of, is the photographs taken at each stage of the work and filed for future reference, one in the office of the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company and the other in the office of the Rapid Transit Commissioners.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 27 -- On an island in the Neva, nearly opposite the Winter palace, rise the sombre walls of the Citadel of St. Peter and St. Paul. In the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul, as any guidebook will inform the visitor, are buried the earthly remains of all the Czars of all the Russias, from Peter the Great down, with one exception.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The marriage of Miss Johanna Hayes Shepard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus D. Shepard of The Gables, just east of this city, to Osborne Wyckoff Bright of New York took place this afternoon at 3 o'clock in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The text of the agreement reached between the foreign envoys at Peking has been received at the State Department, and is now in process of translation from the cipher code.

Manager William Brock Shoemaker of the Columbia University football team completed an approximate report of the finances of the team yesterday. The report shows that the receipts from all sources for the year were about $40,800, while the expenses amount to $38,000. About $2,500 is still due the association, while there are unpaid bills to the amount of $4,000.

In quarters separated from the commoner live stock on the ocean transport Patricia, which sailed from New York for Hamburg yesterday morning, were about fifty head of carefully selected and high-bred American trotting horses, the property of half a dozen owners, several of whom accompanied the horses on the voyage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day continued its hearing upon the anti-canteen provision of the Military bill, hearing in addition to a number of short speeches in advocacy of the provision a protest against it from the Rev. Mr. Miller, who served fourteen months as an army Chaplain in the Philippines.

A trail of blood showed that one of the shots took effect. As the men reached the street they fired back, but failed to hit any one.

Bernard J. York, President of the Board of Police Commissioners, who conducted the investigation made by the Police Board into the charges made against policemen in connection with the negro troubles on the west side last August, made public yesterday a report on his investigation. The report fails to fix the blame for the clubbings on any policeman.

The Committee of Fifteen appointed by Charles Stewart Smith in accordance with a resolution passed at a meeting of citizens at the Chamber of Commerce Nov. 27, when vicious conditions in the city were considered, will hold its first meeting to-morrow afternoon in one of the offices of George Foster Peabody.

The conference was called to consider the best methods of enforcing the Factory law in the east side shops.

The Rev. Father William Everett, the oldest Roman Catholic priest in the Archdiocese of New York and for more than a generation rector of the Church of the Nativity in Second Avenue, near Third Street, died at his residence, adorning the church, at 10:10 o'clock Friday evening. He also enjoyed the distinction of being one of the oldest practicing physicians in the city.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8 -- A golfing party of fifteen competitors enjoyed the day at the Country Club of Lakewood in the first men's open handicap of the season on those links, and Clarence H. Robbins won the prizes offered for both actual and net scores. Summary:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Mrs. Mary Woolsey, daughter of the late Zacharlah Freer, is compelled to fight for a claim of $900 against Mr. Freer's estate, as her brothers refuse to pay it. Mrs. Woolsey, who is the wife of John E. Woolsey, claims that her father induced her to abandon her intentions to leave home, promising her that he would amply reward her after his death.

NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- E.M. Heaton of 35 Williams Street, this city, made complaint to-day before the Newark Overseer of the Poor against Francis Carlyle and Miss Jessie Busley, members of the "Hearts Are Trumps" company, now playing at the Newark Theatre. Heaton charges that the couple left a child with him and his wife ten years ago, and had since failed to support it.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 8 -- The Duke and Duchess of Manchester, who arrived here from New York last night, were not at home to their friends during the greater part of to-day. They arose late, and the Duke was afterward seen amusing himself on the lawn of Mr. Zimmerman's house with his newly acquired Boston terriers.
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 8 -- J.A. Newman, General Chairman of the Santa Fe Division of the Order of Railroad Telegraphers, including the entire Santa Fe system, refering to the strike, said:

Two mechanics' liens, aggregating ,$24,997, were filed yesterday at the County Cleric's office against the apartment house property of Builder Alonzo B. Kight by Jackson Sharp for materials and labor furnished. One of the claims, for $23,360, affects the apartment house at the southwest corner of Central Park "West and Seventy-first Street; and the other, for $1,637, is against the property on the west side of Central Park-West, 50-feet north of Sixty-ninth Street.

Attorney General Griggs now has under consideration the rights of the United States Government in the shoals off Governors Island. If he decides that the cession of the island by the State to the Government included the shoals, the project for the extension of the island which has seen fully matured by the War Department will be begun in the near future.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Though the trouble between Holland and Portugal can scarcely result in war, it is far more serious and interesting than is generally supposed. Great Britain is concerned in the affair more deeply than appears on the surface, for it is now learned that it is due to a British protest to Portugal that the exequatur of Mynheer Pott, the Dutch Consul at Lorenzo Marques, was withdrawn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8 -- Four artists are living in a haunted house at North Mianus, within sight of Henry O. Havemeyer's mansion, defying ghosts which are said to appear nightly. They are Louis Loeb and Albert Sterner, illustrators; Ernest Benson, water colorist, and W.G. Schneider, miniaturist.

Heaton charges that the couple left a child with him and his wife ten years ago, and had since failed to support it.

While in a fit of melancholia, it is believed, resulting from continued ill-health, Uriah C. Burnap, sixty-six years old, general manager of the wholesale dry goods firm of Faulkner, Page Co. of 58 and 60 Worth Street, Manhattan, said to have been a close friend of the late ex-Mayor William L. Strong, committed suicide yesterday at his home, 116 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.

Thurston, Inspector of Small Arms Practice, show a great advance in marksmanship over the year 1899. The State has this year 9,559 trained riflemen, against 8,184 in 1899, a gain of 1,375.

They are Louis Loeb and Albert Sterner, illustrators; Ernest Benson, water colorist, and W.G. Schneider, miniaturist.

PEKING, Dec. 6 -- Capts. Wingate and Ryder, who accompanied the expedition to Kalgan, returned to-day. They visited several places to which the Germans did not go, but they encountered no opposition. They learned that some twelve Europeans, mostly Swedish and Norwegian missionaries, besides Capt. Watts-Jones, were massacred at Kwei-hua-Cheng by orders of the Taotai, and that 100 native Christians had also been put to death.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Though the trouble between Holland and Portugal can scarcely result in war, it is far more serious and interesting than is generally supposed. Great Britain is concerned in the affair more deeply than appears on the surface, for it is now learned that it is due to a British protest to Portugal that the exequatur of Mynheer Pott, the Dutch Consul at Lorenzo Marques, was withdrawn.

PEKING, Dec. 9. -- The removal of Gen. Tung-Fu-Hsiang from the command of the Chinese forces surrounding the Court is considered by the foreign envoys to be a very important step, as showing the real desire of the Government to come to terms. His banishment indicates that the Court recognizes the expediency of obeying the demands of the powers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- A list of the crippled has been taken at the University of Chicago and at Northwestern. During the brief session twelve men were injured seriously or painfully at the University of Chicago, while at Northwestern ten athletes received hurts which put them temporarily out of the game.

To fold arms or not, is the burning question in the Ninth Regiment these days, all because of a paragraph in the report of Col. William Gary Sangrer, Gen. Roe's inspecting officer, who recently reviewed the Ninth and reported:
Hugh O. Pentecost spoke yesterday before Unity Congregation in Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue, on the subject of the vice crusade.
Hugh O. Pentecost spoke yesterday before Unity Congregation in Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue, on the subject of the vice crusade.

Constitutional government aims at and attains about the same results in England and the United States, but the details of its workings are in many respects curiously different. The contrast in length between the average "Queen's speech" at the opening of Parliament and the average "President's message" at the opening of a Congressional session illustrates a divergence in custom which, if not of any great importance, is still characteristic and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Archbishop Ireland in a sermon preached at St. Patrick's Church to-day, reviewed the question of the independence of the Pope, and prophesied that at no remote day the "Italian people and Christendom at large would give back to the papacy its wonted dignity and liberty."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Supreme Court to-morrow morning will hear argument in the case of Neeley vs. Henkel, involving the right of the United States to extradite Neeley for trial in Havana for the alleged embezzlement of the Cuban postal funds. The Court has specially assigned it for argument, and it is at the head of the call.

Evidently the Boer General DE WET, with his gallant little band, is in a position to extricate himself from which calls for superlative strategic genius. He has been in precarious positions before, has almost been surrounded, but has always managed to escape between some unconnected links in the British lines.

There was an excellent morning's sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday, despite the wind squall and shower which made everybody scatter for cover and kept the horses under the sheds for half an hour. When the clouas broke away it was found that the rain had laid the dust and put the roadbed in better condition than it was before, and the brushing commenced again with unabated interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Supreme Court to-morrow morning will hear argument in the case of Neeley vs. Henkel, involving the right of the United States to extradite Neeley for trial in Havana for the alleged embezzlement of the Cuban postal funds. The Court has specially assigned it for argument, and it is at the head of the call.

There are signs that the entente extra-cordiale assumed to exist between Mr. ODELL, the candidate for the Governorship, and Senator PLATT has been somewhat impaired, and that the relations between the Senator and the actual Governor may turn out to be consistent with the self-respect of the latter and unsatisfactory to the former.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- A dispatch from Johannesburg says the town has been fenced round with barbed wire to prevent the inhabitants getting food to the Boers.

GREENPORT, L.I., Dec. 9. -- The schooner' yacht Rosina is aground off Rocky Point, and will probably go to pieces. She is pounding hard on the rocks, and, as the wind holds high, it is thought she cannot be saved. Her crew was taken off today by the life savers from the Rocky Point Station.

At a meeting of the Society for Ethical Culture, held in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, Wu-Ting-Fang, Chinese Minister to the United States, lectured to an immense audience on the "Teachings of Confucius." He compared the teachings of the great prophet and founder of the Chinese religion, with those of Christ Christianity, he said, the doctrine of reward and fire and brimstone, was gradually giving way to the teachings of Confucius.

Its spectacular features multiplied and the exactions of the long struggle increased, the annual six days' bicycle race by relay teams of two was begun at 12:05 o'clock this morning, in Madison Square Garden, in the presence of a crowd of 5,000 people, who cheered and applauded the competitors with an earnestness that left no doubt as to the popularity of that form of contest.

The annual meeting of the St. Vincent de Paul Society was held last night in the Cathedral School Hall, 111 East Fiftieth Street. Archbishop Corrigan presided. The meeting was opened by Jeremiah Fitzpatrick, President of the Superior Council of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, who called the new members of the society to the front of the platform, and then made them an address upon their duties as members of the society.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 9. -- During one of the most bitter gales that ever swept Lake Erie, the iron ore barge Charles Foster, in tow of the Iron Duke, went to the bottom at 4 o'clock this morning, ten miles off Erie, and eight persons, the entire crew, were drowned.

The decision handed down by the New York Court of Appeals recognizing the responsibility of an electric railroad company for compensatory damages to a woman injured by being thrown down by the jerk of a car in starting is likely to deprive passengers fortunate enough to get seats and wise enough to hold them of one of their principal diversions.

The East Indian python, 27 feet 6 inches long, the biggest captive snake in the world, was fed at the Zoological Gardens of the Bronx last Friday after a hard fight. The snake, a female, has refused to eat voluntarily. In the den with her are two other pythons, one 26 feet 4 inches, and the other 23 feet 6 inches long.

Constitutional government aims at and attains about the same results in England and the United States, but the details of its workings are in many respects curiously different. The contrast in length between the average "Queen's speech" at the opening of Parliament and the average "President's message" at the opening of a Congressional session illustrates a divergence in custom which, if not of any great importance, is still characteristic and interesting.

Atlantic City will be the Mecca this coming week of the golfing fraternity that enjoys the competitive excitement of open tournaments. The second big tournament given by the Atlantic City Country Club will be held there on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, and the indications are that there will be a good turn out of Metropolitan and Philadelphia golfers.

John McAuliffe, an artist, seventy years of age, was instantly killed yesterday morning by falling from a window of his apartment, at 405 West Twenty-second Street. McAuliffe had been a sufferer from nervous prostration lately, and was not very strong, although he was able to be about and had been out to a barber's shop on Saturday.

The controversy which has arisen between two neighboring churches in Brooklyn over the fact that one has, a chime of bells which it causes to be rung while the congregation of the other church is at worship will probably be settled by such a change of hours for service as will prevent further annoyance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The lake route for the transportation of grain from the West to the East and the seaboard resumed its old-time pre-eminence during the season of navigation now closing.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- It is generally understood here to-night that the negotiations that are pending for the sale of the Rogers Locomotive Works to a syndicate headed by the Katz Brothers, the heads of the Paterson Brewing and Malting Company, are so far advanced that it is almost certain the deal will be closed this week.

A meeting of the delegates who will represent the New York bowling club's at the American Bowling Congress in Chicago next month was held at Thum Kahlsdorf's Harlem Palace alleys last night to receive the reports of the sub-committees in charge of the arrangements for the trip.

"The Folly of Overambition and the Struggle for Precedence in American Society" was the subject of a sermon preached last evening in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, Dr. Hillis said in part:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- G.A. Adams of Hancock, N.H., has been elected manager, and H.J. Costello of Syracuse, Captain of the Syracuse University baseball team. The football team, it was announced at the athletic council meeting, lost $2,500 this season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A mass meeting was held here to-day under the auspices of the Women's Interdenominational Union in the interests of the proposed Constitutional amendment prohibiting polygamy in the United States and in all territory under its jurisdiction. Dr. Josiah Strong, President of the Social League of New York City, presided.

Evidently the Boer General DE WET, with his gallant little band, is in a position to extricate himself from which calls for superlative strategic genius. He has been in precarious positions before, has almost been surrounded, but has always managed to escape between some unconnected links in the British lines.
LISBON, Dec. 9. -- King Carlos has received from Queen Victoria the following telegram in response to the one sent by his Majesty yesterday:

Elder, niece of Archbishop Elder of Cincinnati, a well-known writer on Catholic Church subjects, has stirred up a discussion in the religious press and among the laity by her recent public criticisms of the Catholics in the United States. Catholics here, she holds, are far behind the Protestants in the enlistment of lay activity in the enterprises of the Church.

The annual memorial service of Ascension Memorial Church, in West Forty-third Street, west of Broadway, was held last night. The services were conducted by the Rev. John F. Steen, the rector, and the musical programme was under the direction of Henry E. Duncan, organist of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- From a social standpoint, the legislative session of 1901 bids fair to be an unusually brilliant one. During the past week numerous Senators and Assemblymen have visited, the capital city with a particular object in view -- that of house hunting. The Sweney residence, on Elk Street, known to legislators as the "House of Lords," will again be occupied by Senators Ellsworth, Stranahan, White, Higgins, and Humphreys.

Barring postponements of ties, the National Class B billiard tournament, which was begun last Monday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club in this city, will be brought to a close this week. Two games of the final round are to be played daily and these will undoubtedly bring out the best play of the tournament.

A clerical critic some time since made the amusing statement that no newspaper in this city was open to the discussion of what he regarded as the plot to secure a division of the school moneys in the interest of the Roman Catholic schools. This gentleman was a Protestant.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 9. -- Harry Vardon defeated three opponents at Overland links yesterday. He played against the best ball of James Russell, the instructor of the Overland Club, Frank L. Woodard, and Walter Fairbanks, winning by a score of 3 up. The game was for thirty-eight holes.

At a meeting of the Society for Ethical Culture, held in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, Wu-Ting-Fang, Chinese Minister to the United States, lectured to an immense audience on the "Teachings of Confucius." He compared the teachings of the great prophet and founder of the Chinese religion, with those of Christ Christianity, he said, the doctrine of reward and fire and brimstone, was gradually giving way to the teachings of Confucius.
Rabbi Emil G. Hirsch of Chicago preached in the Temple Beth-El, at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday morning. His subject was "The Religious Opportunities of Our Day."

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 9. -- The officials of the Santa Fe Road take a decidedly hopeful view of the telegraphers' strike situation. They all say the backbone of the strike is practically broken already, and that the affairs of the road will be in their normal condition inside of two weeks. The officers felt justified to-night, in view of the alleged improvement in conditions, in rescinding the order closing the shops.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Archbishop Ireland in a sermon preached at St. Patrick's Church to-day, reviewed the question of the independence of the Pope, and prophesied that at no remote day the "Italian people and Christendom at large would give back to the papacy its wonted dignity and liberty."

MANILA, Dec. 9. -- While the capture of supplies and the occupation of new points are quite numerous, those involving actual fighting are comparatively few. Apparently the insurgents are falling back at all contested points, sacrificing their possessions in most cases and satisfied to save themselves.

Haddon Chambers, the English dramatist, who arrived here Saturday, will remain but two weeks in this city. He is compelled to leave at the end of that period in order to return to London to begin the rehearsal of his new play. This is to be produced by George Alexander at the St. James Theatre in January.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The Daily Express publishes an interview this morning with F.W. Hawley, Vice President of the Erie Canal Electric Traction Company, who has just made a tour of the principal canal systems in Europe. Mr. Hawley said that he expected to obtain, very shortly, a concession for electric canal traction in Holland, and that he could see a great opening in France and England.

A statement made to a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES by Manager Albert S. Ames of the Criterion Hotel, near which Philip Sondheim shot himself Saturday night, and Capt. McClusky's attitude toward Detective Armstrong shortly after the shooting indicate that charges may be preferred against the detective.

Atlantic City will be the Mecca this coming week of the golfing fraternity that enjoys the competitive excitement of open tournaments. The second big tournament given by the Atlantic City Country Club will be held there on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, and the indications are that there will be a good turn out of Metropolitan and Philadelphia golfers.

An innocent traveler on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was yesterday the cause of a lot of fun for one of the whist parties in the smoking car of an express train. Between hands the members of the party instead of abusing one another for misplays began to talk of hunting.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- At the general offices in this city of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway system, it is claimed tonight that the efforts of the striking telegraph operators to tie up the business of the system are being overcome. PEKING, Dec. 9. -- The removal of Gen. Tung-Fu-Hsiang from the command of the Chinese forces surrounding the Court is considered by the foreign envoys to be a very important step, as showing the real desire of the Government to come to terms. His banishment indicates that the Court recognizes the expediency of obeying the demands of the powers.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- A dispatch from Johannesburg says the town has been fenced round with barbed wire to prevent the inhabitants getting food to the Boers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- A list of the crippled has been taken at the University of Chicago and at Northwestern. During the brief session twelve men were injured seriously or painfully at the University of Chicago, while at Northwestern ten athletes received hurts which put them temporarily out of the game.

At a conference held yesterday at the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, the plan of perfecting an unsectarian organization for the promotion of evangelical work all over this country was discussed. William Phillips Hall, who was associated with the late Dwight L. Moody, was chosen Chairman of the meeting.

There was a hearing before a Sheriff's jury in the Kings County Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, on an application for the appointment of a committee of the person of William D. Ashley of Fishkill, N. Y. Ashley formerly lived in Springfield, Mass. He took the Keeley cure several times and finally went away to Nebraska, his family following him.

The Tenement House Commission appointed by the Legislature to investigate the conditions and surroundings of the New York and Buffalo tenement houses had a session yesterday in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building. Commissioner of Public Buildings Thomas J. Brady and two of the other Commissioners put in an Interesting afternoon under the cross-examination of Chairman Paul D. Cravath.

J. Lawrence Van Alen, only son of J. J. Van Alen, and grandson of Mrs. Astor, and Miss M. Louise ("Daisy") Post, second daughter of the late William Post, and niece of Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, were married yesterday at noon at the residence of the bride's mother, Mrs. William Post, 100 East Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The naval movements to-day record the sailing of the gunboat Bancroft from Colon for Almirante Bay. It is understood that her mission is to look into the advantages offered by the port of Chiriqui as a coaling station. The sum of $400,000 is now available under an appropriation by Congress for securing naval stations.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 10. -- Poor prices prevailed at the Fasig-Tipton sales here to-day, 71 head bringing an average of $103. The consignment of the millionaire breeder, J.B. Haggin, consisting of thirty brood mares, sold for small prices, the owner, at the ringside, seeing the entire lot bring but $2.250. Tenny, D.T. Pulsifer's famous horse, was withdrawn from the sale at the last moment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The first of the great supply bills, the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill, was passed by the House to-day in record time. The bill carries $24,498,408, and has 131 pages, but there was less than ten minutes debate upon it.
