William Phillips Hall, who was associated with the late Dwight L. Moody, was chosen Chairman of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- An idea of the strict discipline exacted of the United States troops in China is indicated by the following general order issued by Gen. Chaffee, commanding the China relief expedition, under date of Oct. 8, a copy of which was received at the War Department to-day:

There was a very small but very select gathering of fast steppers on the upper stretch of the Harlem River Speedway, yesterday afternoon, who for a couple of hours before dusk made things very lively. For so few horses it was by far the best after- noon's sport witnessed this Fall, for without a single exception every horse present had a good mark and was well known to harness horsemen.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -- Cotton prices crumbled rapidly to-day, and the operators on 'Change appeared as if they were going mad. The official session of the "future" market begins at 9 o'clock. New Orleans time, but the doors of the Exchange are opened at 8. At the latter hour members began to pour in, and visitors were also strongly in evidence.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Evening Standard, which has special sources of information, said last evening that a great battle between the British forces under Gen. Knox and the Boers under Gen. De Wet was going on.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Residents of this city and Passaic were surprised yesterday when they learned of new arrangements that had been made by the Jersey City, Hoboken and Paterson Railroad company, whereby Passaic has been deprived of through service to Paterson by way of the Newark line and all transfers north and to the various points in this city.

As the locomotive of a south-bound train on the Sixth Avenue elevated road passed the women's waiting room at the Thirty-third Street station shortly after 9 o'clock last night the employes and passengers were startled by the wild scream of a woman who had been looking out of the window.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Representative Overstreet of Indiana, who took the most prominent part in the House in the last session in getting a gold-standard bill passed, and who hopes to see a measure of amendment to that law passed before long, said to-day that no steps have been taken in the Banking and Currency Committee to strengthen the currency law.

The committee of fifteen appointed to devise means to deal with vice and official corruption held its first meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of George Foster Peabody, 27 Pine Street. At 3 o'clock William H. Baldwin, Jr., President of the Long Island Railroad, walked into Mr. Peabody's office.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York, held last night at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, it was decided to hold two indoor meets at the Eighth Regiment Armory on Jan. 19 and 26. The events of the first night are to include a two-mile handicap race, a one-mile novice, and a five-mile team pursuit race for teams of two men from each of the associated clubs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The story originating in New York that advance information on the Government cotton crop had been offered for sale on Saturday on the Cotton Exchange came to the ears' to-day of John Hyde, statistician of the Department of Agriculture.

Quick work by means of the telephone resulted in the capture of a negro in the house of Simon Frankel, a diamond broker at 117 East Seventy-first Street, yesterday afternoon. The man was detected by Mary Noonan, who, with, another servant and Mrs. Frankel, were the only persons in the house.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10. -- The members of the Yale Varsity football team were guests yesterday at a complimentary banquet given by the University Club in their new dining hall to-night, about 200 undergraduate members of the club and guests being present. Walter Camp spoke, as did Capt. Gordon Brown of the champion team, George Adee, '95; George S. Still- man, and others.

The report indicated a crop of 10,100,000 bales, against the expectations of traders that it would show not over 9,750,000, and within twenty minutes of the receipt of the report prices broke from 40 to 50 points.

Capt. G.D.S. Trasn surprised the Standing Committee of the Marine Society yesterday afternoon by declining to accept the nomination for re-election as President. He did not explain his reasons for the refusal, and the meeting which had been called for the purpose of making the nominations, was hastily adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- It is stated at the Navy Department that Rear Admiral Rodgers is to proceed to his new assignment on the Asiatic Station aboard the New York, which will be his flagship in Eastern waters. That vessel is now undergoing a general overhauling at the New York yard. She is to be ready for sea by Feb. 15, 1901, and Admiral Rodgers is expected to start for his new station soon after.

The "Spirit of the Harlem River" called at Mayor Van Wyek's office yesterday. When the door of Mayor Van Wyck's office was opened the "Spirit" literally blew in. She was fashionably dressed and carried a reticule. In her trail came a swish of cold air. The door was slammed to and then the "Spirit of the Harlem a River" arranged her dress, her small blond curls, and rubbed her cold nose.

John A. Hendrick of this city and Charles G. Schmitt of Chicago were the winners in the two games of the National Class B billlard tournament played yesterday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Mr. Hendrick defeated William Palge of Boston, by a score of 300 to 214 in the afternoon, and Mr. Schraitt won easily from Frank Billiter, the Minneapolis champion.

Thomas C. Bent, bandmaster of the Old Guard, will make his second matrimonial venture to-morrow evening, when he will be married to Mrs. Sarah J. Wyckoff, who is twenty years his senior. The ceremony will take place at the Waldorf-Astoria in the presence of twenty-five friends of the couple.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The story originating in New York that advance information on the Government cotton crop had been offered for sale on Saturday on the Cotton Exchange came to the ears' to-day of John Hyde, statistician of the Department of Agriculture.

Capt. McClusky of the Detective Bureau yesterday turned over to Bert Hanson, assignee of C.W. Morgan Co., brokers at 71 Broadway and elsewhere, the securities and other valuables taken by his men at the time of their descent on the Morgan office, which occurred the day before the assignment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- An idea of the strict discipline exacted of the United States troops in China is indicated by the following general order issued by Gen. Chaffee, commanding the China relief expedition, under date of Oct. 8, a copy of which was received at the War Department to-day:

The Ship Subsidy bill now before Congress contains in its preamble the following curious statement: "Whereas, the profitable employment of the surplus productive power of the farms, factories, mines, forests, and fisheries of the United States imperatively demands the increase of foreign commerce, therefore" the annexed subsidies shall be paid.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10. -- The members of the Yale Varsity football team were guests yesterday at a complimentary banquet given by the University Club in their new dining hall to-night, about 200 undergraduate members of the club and guests being present. Walter Camp spoke, as did Capt. Gordon Brown of the champion team, George Adee, '95; George S. Still- man, and others.

Capt. McClusky of the Detective Bureau yesterday turned over to Bert Hanson, assignee of C.W. Morgan Co., brokers at 71 Broadway and elsewhere, the securities and other valuables taken by his men at the time of their descent on the Morgan office, which occurred the day before the assignment.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -- Cotton prices crumbled rapidly to-day, and the operators on 'Change appeared as if they were going mad. The official session of the "future" market begins at 9 o'clock. New Orleans time, but the doors of the Exchange are opened at 8. At the latter hour members began to pour in, and visitors were also strongly in evidence.

The Ship Subsidy bill now before Congress contains in its preamble the following curious statement: "Whereas, the profitable employment of the surplus productive power of the farms, factories, mines, forests, and fisheries of the United States imperatively demands the increase of foreign commerce, therefore" the annexed subsidies shall be paid.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg space for a few remarks on the amendments to the charter. All honest citizens must admit that the commission has done good work for the city, and the citizens should ask the Legislature to adopt them, and at the same time to add a little to them.

At a conference of the Baptist ministers of Chicago a few days ago a prominent and evidently courageous member made the startling statement that "unless the church becomes a continuous vaudeville it cannot hold its congregation." Chicago experience seems to show that this generalization is warranted by the facts.

John A. Hendrick of this city and Charles G. Schmitt of Chicago were the winners in the two games of the National Class B billlard tournament played yesterday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Mr. Hendrick defeated William Palge of Boston, by a score of 300 to 214 in the afternoon, and Mr. Schraitt won easily from Frank Billiter, the Minneapolis champion.

John A. Hendrick of this city and Charles G. Schmitt of Chicago were the winners in the two games of the National Class B billlard tournament played yesterday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Mr. Hendrick defeated William Palge of Boston, by a score of 300 to 214 in the afternoon, and Mr. Schraitt won easily from Frank Billiter, the Minneapolis champion.

The committee of fifteen appointed to devise means to deal with vice and official corruption held its first meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of George Foster Peabody, 27 Pine Street. At 3 o'clock William H. Baldwin, Jr., President of the Long Island Railroad, walked into Mr. Peabody's office.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York, held last night at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, it was decided to hold two indoor meets at the Eighth Regiment Armory on Jan. 19 and 26. The events of the first night are to include a two-mile handicap race, a one-mile novice, and a five-mile team pursuit race for teams of two men from each of the associated clubs.

There was a very small but very select gathering of fast steppers on the upper stretch of the Harlem River Speedway, yesterday afternoon, who for a couple of hours before dusk made things very lively. For so few horses it was by far the best after- noon's sport witnessed this Fall, for without a single exception every horse present had a good mark and was well known to harness horsemen.

We do not yet know the exact terms of the letter addressed to the Count VON WALDEKSEE by Gen. CHAFEE and returned to him because its language was not considered sufficiently respectful, but as the subject of the letter was the looting of public property for no military purpose, we can imagine that the feelings of the Count may well have been hurt.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Sheriff Sturr to-day drew the panel of seventy petit jurors from among whom the jurors who will try the cases against Kerr, McAllister, Death, and Campbell, the men accused of murdering Jennie Bosschieter, may be tried. Among them are James McAllister and Charles Kerr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The first speech in opposition to the Ship Subsidy bill in the Senate was delivered to-day by Mr. Clay, (Dem., Ga.) He is one of the minority members of the Committee on Commerce, which conducted the hearings on the measure and reported it to the Senate, and is recognized as one of the most vigorous opponents of the bill in the Senate.

The question of the cost of buildings for new schools was brought up at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The Board of Education was blamed for its methods and the Charter Revision Commission was also criticised by Mayor Van Wyck. Bond issues for $201,250 for new school sites at Union and Trenton Avenues, Seventy-sixth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, and Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street were authorized.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- At a special meeting of the shareholders of the Grand Trunk Railroad to-day, the purchase of the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroad was ratified.

With the imperceptible rise in the temperature yesterday came the first snow of the year. There have been flurries on one or two occasions, but they were of such brief duration and the snow was so insignificant in quantity that they were hardly noticed. Yesterday, while the fall was not heavy, there was sufficient to cover the housetops and streets with an apparently substantial yet in reality very thin coating.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Board of Trustees of the American University held its annual meeting here to-day. In the absence of John E. Andrus of New York, President of the board, John F. Robinson of Illinois presided.

Detectives Cells and Schinner of the Morrisania Police Station made an arrest yesterday, which is said to be the quickest piece of work ever done by policemen in this city. They arrested within fifteen minutes after the theft had been reported to Headquarters a man who was trying to get away with a horse and buggy which did not belong to him.

Officers of the Harlem Savings Bank, at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, one of the best-known institutions up town, and which has been in existence for thirty-seven years, have been very much annoyed during the last fortnight by reports concerning the bank which have resulted in quite a serious run upon its deposits.

Commenting on the enterprises on the Canadian territory connected with the water power at Sault Sainte Marie, of which we recently gave an account, the journals of Detroit are discussing very seriously the splendid opportunities open to the trade and industry of the United States, if we have the foresight to enter into liberal arrangements with the Canadian Government.

Miss Alice Brown, the Secretary of the Professional Woman's League, whose clubhouse is at 1,509 Broadway, had an experience with a thief yesterday afternoon that she says she will remember for some time to come. Womanlike she was equal to the emergency while it lasted, but when it was over she admits having come as near to a swoon as she ever came in her life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Senate to-day confirmed the following nominations:
CAPE TOWN, Dec. 11. -- Field Marshal Lord Roberts, with his wife and daughters, sailed for England to-day on the Canada.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Piscatagua has arrived at Hampton Roads, the Farragut at San Diego, the Dupont at New York, the Solace at Cavite, the Foote at Newport, and the Albatross at Sausaleto.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- With all possible expedition the Senate will dispose of the Army Reorganization bill, thus keeping up, if there is no break in the programme, the record of the session for prompt disposition of the measures before it that are regarded as most important.

The schedule of Cornelius Vanderbilt's personal estate, stocks, bonds, cash, insurance, and effects was made public yesterday. It was printed in The New York World, which paper also printed what purported to be the valuations finally fixed upon by the Appraiser for the State, the Deputy Attorney General, and the attorneys for the estate.

A lawsuit of peculiar interest will come up to-day before Judge Beach and a jury in Part III, of the Supreme Court. The New Amsterdam Gas Company is being sued for $25,000 damages for having, it is alleged, caused the death of Alfred Von Mechow in February, 1899, by gas poisoning.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 11. -- Surrogate Seabury, having decided to reopen the case in the matter of the will of the late Edgar E. Duryea, testimony was taken to-day in the Surrogate's Court.

The question of the cost of buildings for new schools was brought up at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The Board of Education was blamed for its methods and the Charter Revision Commission was also criticised by Mayor Van Wyck. Bond issues for $201,250 for new school sites at Union and Trenton Avenues, Seventy-sixth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, and Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street were authorized.

The schedule of the possessions of the late CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, filed yesterday with the Surrogate show that Mr. VANDERBILT was strictly an investor, not at all a speculator. His personal fortune is appraised at $52,999,867. It is almost entirely invested in the bonds and shares of railroads of assured earning power.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 11. -- Replying in the Second Chamber to-day to the interpellation of Count von Bylandt, notice, of which was given yesterday, on the subject of the tension between the Netherlands and Portugal, the Foreign Minister, Dr. W. H. de Beaufort, sketched the history of the misunderstanding, which, he declared, had been exaggerated.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 5. -- Porto Ricans have been greatly impressed with the sound advice given to them in the message of Gov. Allen to the House of Delegates, which was read yesterday. In the course of the message the Governor said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Assistant Attorney General James M. Beck in the Supreme Court to-day replied to the argument of John D. Lindsay in the Neely extradition proceedings. Mr. Lindsay contended yesterday that the United States had no right to maintain a military government in Cuba, and that the presence of troops there was virtually a prosecution of war.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Max Beerbohm's first play. "The-Happy Hypocrit," which was produced last evening at the Royalty Theatre, London, proved to be a charming and clever trifle, with a fantastic motive -- a pure, girl's love changing the countenance as well as the heart of a man who had lived an evil life.
Still the bicycles continue their fast, incessant whirl around the steep, ten-lap track in Madison Square Garden, and still the enthusiasm by day and night continues with unabated ardor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Assistant Attorney General James M. Beck in the Supreme Court to-day replied to the argument of John D. Lindsay in the Neely extradition proceedings. Mr. Lindsay contended yesterday that the United States had no right to maintain a military government in Cuba, and that the presence of troops there was virtually a prosecution of war.
George Shaw, a dry goods merchant, went down stairs into the kitchen of his residence, 140 West Eighty-sixth Street, at midnight Monday night to see if everything was safe for the night.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The Evening Standard yesterday said the battle between Gen. Knox and Gen. De Wet continued, and that the forces were changing ground incessantly. Lack of definite, information on the battle was said to be due to the absence of telegraphic communication with the scene of action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The debate on the war revenue reduction bill opened in the House to-day, but was confined to two speeches -- one by Mr. Payne of New York, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, on behalf of the majority, and one by Mr. Swanson (Dem., Va.,) on behalf of the minority. No arrangement about the length of general debate was made.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Presumably the United States is about to enter upon the important and costly work of constructing a Nicaragua Canal.

Another public meeting was held by the Tenement House Commission yesterday afternoon. Paul D. Cravath again acted as Chairman, and the principal witness was President Michael C. Murphy of the Board of Health.

His personal fortune is appraised at $52,999,867. It is almost entirely invested in the bonds and shares of railroads of assured earning power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Piscatagua has arrived at Hampton Roads, the Farragut at San Diego, the Dupont at New York, the Solace at Cavite, the Foote at Newport, and the Albatross at Sausaleto.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Among the advocates of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty when it shall be amended either by the adoption of the Davis amendment or some other amendment that shall give to the United States the right to protect the canal, the expectation is general that the treaty will be disposed of on Thursday.
George Shaw, a dry goods merchant, went down stairs into the kitchen of his residence, 140 West Eighty-sixth Street, at midnight Monday night to see if everything was safe for the night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Wu-TingFang, Chinese Minister to the United States, who came here to deliver an address to-night before the Contemporary Club, made a statement in regard to his address on Confucius before the Society for Ethical Culture in New York last Sunday, adverse comments upon which have since been printed. He says:

NEWPORT, Dec. 11. -- Since last Saturday the rumor has been repeatedly heard here that Rosecliff, the new Summer house of Mr. and. Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, has been sold, but the records at the City Hall fail to show such a sale. From a reliable source it was learned to-day that a real estate firm in New York had been in negotiation with Mrs. Oelrichs, and that she had been offered $700,000 for the place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The remains of Col. Emerson H. lascum, which have been lying in state in this city since yesterday, were interred in Arlington Cemetery this afternoon. The escort to the cemetery, under command of Col. William A. Rafferty, consisted of a squadron of cavalry, Battery F. Second Artillery, and a battalion of marines.

There is again an abundance of variety on the social programme, for to-day. There are to be two weddings -- one out of town, at Corona, L. I., where John Lawrence Riker, 2d, and Miss Caroline Duncan Leverich are to be married, and one at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the nuptials of Henry Mckean Ferriday and Miss Elsie Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mitchell, (Miss Caroline Woolsey,) will be celebrated.

Sam Small, the Georgia evangelist, who has been serving as Chaplain in the volunteer army in Cuba, arrived in the city on the Ward Line steamship Mexico yesterday. He has a very poor opinion of the inhabitants of Cuba, especially the former insurgents, and considers them, as he says, "immeasurably inferior to the Southern darky."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- At a special meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, Railroad the matter of reorganizing, the financial affairs of the road by issuing refunding bonds that shall bear a lesser rate of interest than the present outstanding securities of the company was discussed.

DUBLIN, Dec. 11. -- Delegates representing County Councils, Borough Corporations, District Councils, branches of the United Irish League, and kindred bodies met today in national convention in the Dublin Rotunda in order to "recreate the Irish Party."

At a little after 6 o'clock on Monday evening, when all the extra cars of the Third Avenue surface line were in requisition and every car crowded to the platform, with passengers, a big furniture van wheeled into Third Avenue at Twentyfirst Street and started up town on the north-bound tracks.

He is one of the minority members of the Committee on Commerce, which conducted the hearings on the measure and reported it to the Senate, and is recognized as one of the most vigorous opponents of the bill in the Senate.

There is more than an excuse, in the case of the man KILLORAN, for repeating the suggestion made recently in this column that the mere fact of having contracted the smallpox should be treated as convicting evidence that the sufferer from the malady has committed a grave misdemeanor, if not felony, to be punished with a severity commensurate with the seriousness of the offense.

NEWARK, Dec. 11. -- Charles A. Carter and Frank Todd, employed by William Provost, a milk dealer at 12 Warren Street, this city, had a narrow escape from death this morning at the Eighth Avenue crossing of the Lackawanna Railroad.

Womanlike she was equal to the emergency while it lasted, but when it was over she admits having come as near to a swoon as she ever came in her life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The remains of Col. Emerson H. lascum, which have been lying in state in this city since yesterday, were interred in Arlington Cemetery this afternoon. The escort to the cemetery, under command of Col. William A. Rafferty, consisted of a squadron of cavalry, Battery F. Second Artillery, and a battalion of marines.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Mrs. Matthew M. English of this city, who died suddenly in New York City to-day, kept a small confectionary store at 546 North Twenty-fourth Street. She was afflicted with heart disease. In the excitement of getting ready to go to New York she had a fainting spell, but recovered sufficiently to go on her trip.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- At a special meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, Railroad the matter of reorganizing, the financial affairs of the road by issuing refunding bonds that shall bear a lesser rate of interest than the present outstanding securities of the company was discussed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- It is not at all certain that W. A. Clark of Montana will secure a place in the Senate, notwithstanding that he is waiting to come in as an appointee of the Lieutenant Governor, and will later apply as the duly elected Senator to succeed Senator Carter.
CAPE TOWN, Dec. 11. -- Field Marshal Lord Roberts, with his wife and daughters, sailed for England to-day on the Canada.

The schedule of Cornelius Vanderbilt's personal estate, stocks, bonds, cash, insurance, and effects was made public yesterday. It was printed in The New York World, which paper also printed what purported to be the valuations finally fixed upon by the Appraiser for the State, the Deputy Attorney General, and the attorneys for the estate.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 12. -- A year ago the Peavey Grain Company commenced the erection here of a giant elevator of a new style. It was to be concrete from floor to roof, without a stick of timber in the entrie structure, and was to be, as well, the largest grain storage structure in the world.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 12 -- Announcement is made to-day that the Republican caucus to agree upon a candidate for United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of M. S. Quay will be called to meet on Tuesday night, Jan. 1, at 8 o'clock. The Legislature meets in biennial session at noon that day.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 12. -- A year ago the Peavey Grain Company commenced the erection here of a giant elevator of a new style. It was to be concrete from floor to roof, without a stick of timber in the entrie structure, and was to be, as well, the largest grain storage structure in the world.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12. -- Dr. W.S. Rainsford of New York talked to the students at Harvard this evening on "The Various Social and Political Problems of the United States." He classed these problems under two heads -- "Discontent" and "Lawlessness." He said the fact that Mr. Bryan received a vote within 5 per cent. of that of Mr. McKinley showed conclusively that a large portion of the country is discontented with the Administration.

The run on the Harlem Savings Bank, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, continued yesterday and increased to almost a panic. Before the bank closed for the day at 3 o'clock more than $150,000 had been withdrawn.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12 -- For the third time in two years the State Legislature convened here to-day in special session called by Gov. Pingree. Consideration of a measure taxing railroads, telephone and telegraph companies, express companies, and other forms of corporate property on the cash value of their property instead of specifically upon their earnings, as under the present law, is the object of the session.

It is plain that Mr. CLARK of Montana is not to be allowed to get into the United States Senate without more trouble than he had expected. The alert and untiring Senator from New Hampshire has in effect given notice that any new application will be considered in the light of the facts brought out in the inquiry into the first election.

A judgment has been entered against the City of New York for $818,074.32, with interest from May 14, 1897, being the amount of damages awarded the trustee of the successor of the assignee of an inventor named KNIEBS, for the use by the city of a device applicable to steam fire engines.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 12. -- Some time ago committees representing the Indianapolis Board of Trade and Commercial Club investigated the natural gas situation thoroughly and reported in favor of meter measurement as the only means of prolonging the life of natural gas as a fuel.

-- Even a great poet, using his powers with the most serious intention, can make himself ridiculous if he chooses an unfortunate subject or expresses an absurd opinion. M. EDMOND ROSTAND -- about whose greatness there is no question -- has just chosen the unfortunate subject, expressed the absurd opinion, and made himself ridiculous.

It is plain that Mr. CLARK of Montana is not to be allowed to get into the United States Senate without more trouble than he had expected. The alert and untiring Senator from New Hampshire has in effect given notice that any new application will be considered in the light of the facts brought out in the inquiry into the first election.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- The State Board of Canvassers has finished the canvass of the State vote in the last elections. The vote shows that but four of the sixty-one counties cast a majority of votes for Bryan. They were New York, Queens, Richmond, and Schoharie. Onondaga County gave the largest plurality for the Republican ticket, 9,633; St. Lawrence, second, 9,595; Chautauqua, third, with 8,660, and Oneida, fourth, with 6,393.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Edward Lloyd, the well-known tenor, gave a farewell concert last evening at the Albert Hall. He was enthusiastically cheered. Mr. Lloyd's voice shows no diminution of power or quality; but he is tired of public life, and is retiring to raise fancy cattle.

The Trustees of the New York public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations; at their monthly meeting, held yesterday in the Astor Building, Lafayette Place, took active steps looking toward consolidating with the New York Free Circulating Library.

The whole theory of the Ship Subsidy bill is that Americans cannot compete with Englishmen or Germans in building and running ships. If any American were told that he was inferior in brains, energy, and business ability to the average Englishman or German, he would resent the statement as an insult or pity its author as a prejudiced and ignorant persons.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Early this morning Mrs. Flora Wickham terminated her unhappy married life of only two years' duration by deliberately shooting herself with a 32-calibre revolver. The dead woman's husband, J. Emmet Wickham, is the owner of a large business block in this village, on the top floor of which he dwelt.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 12 -- The fourth annual convention of the League of American Municipalities met here to-day in the Auditorium. The Mayors were welcomed in addresses by Gov. M.B.M. Sweeney of this State and by Mayor Smyth of Charleston. Response was made by the President of the league, Mayor Henry V. Johnson of Denver.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 12. -- An animated discussion arose in to-day's session of the American Federation of Labor convention over a resolution for a labor portfolio in the Cabinet, upon which, the committee reported adversely. The original resolution provided that the proposed Cabinet officer should be a bona-fide trades unionist.

According to the story told yesterday by friends in this city, a love affair was the cause of the suicide of Sidney Samuel, who until recently was a member and London manager of the firm of Samuel Brothers, exporters, of 54 Broad Street, who was found dead with a bullet in his brain in a hotel in Portland, Me., early on Tuesday morning.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Edward Lloyd, the well-known tenor, gave a farewell concert last evening at the Albert Hall. He was enthusiastically cheered. Mr. Lloyd's voice shows no diminution of power or quality; but he is tired of public life, and is retiring to raise fancy cattle.

From The St. Paul (Minn.) Globe, (Dem.) It appears that on the vote for Governor, at least 15,000 votes were thrown out because the ballots were marked for both Lind and Lucas, the Socialist-Democratic candidate. In Le Sueur County 384 votes were thus thrown out. Of the Congressional candidate Heatwole, (Rep.,) polled 1,973 votes, Schaller, (Dem.,) polled 2,141, and Lowe, (Middle of the Road Pop.,) polled 24.

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- Several complaints have been made within the last few days, to the State Controller in relation to a circular letter issued by a New York lawyer, and which statement appears to have been sent to a large number of corporations doing business in the City of New York The circular letter reads as follows:

Has this city a Mayor? Is he alive, at large, and awake? If we have a Mayor who is alive, at large, and awake, we should like to know whether his attention has at any time been called to the state of public morals in the lower east side of this city and whether he has ever considered his official powers and duties in relation thereto.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Considerable irritation was aroused during yesterday's debate on supply in the House of Commons.

George L. Rives, Chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, yesterday gave a luncheon at his home, 14 West Thirty-eighth Street, to the members of that body and Governor-elect Odell. All attended with the exception of Commissioners John D. Crimmins and C.C. Beaman.

Frances Russell Taintor, daughter of H. F. Taintor, President of the Taintor Manufacturing Company, has commenced an action in the Supreme Court against the Charles Besseler Company to recover $7,500 damages for injuries received in a peculiar way.

An application will be made before Justice Maddox in Brooklyn to-day for the appointment of Col. William J. Youngs of Nassau County, Secretary to the Governor, as receiver of the Anglo-American Loan and Savings Company.

F. Norton Goddard, who was instrumental in introducing into the last Legislature a bill making it a felony for any one to have in his possession paraphernalia used in writing policy, which bill was defeated largely through the opposition of Anthony Comstock, said yesterday, that he had been deceived at the time regarding Mr. Comstock's motives in the matter.

Mary Mannering in her new capacity of "star" actress is in no wise different, artistically or personally, from the former "leading lady" of Daniel Frohman's permanent company. She is always charming, and she rarely fails to secure just the right effect in a scene or passage of a play when the dramatist has fairly met the actor half way.

Sweeney of this State and by Mayor Smyth of Charleston. Response was made by the President of the league, Mayor Henry V. Johnson of Denver.

The whole theory of the Ship Subsidy bill is that Americans cannot compete with Englishmen or Germans in building and running ships. If any American were told that he was inferior in brains, energy, and business ability to the average Englishman or German, he would resent the statement as an insult or pity its author as a prejudiced and ignorant persons.

One scarcely expected to see in St. Petersburg a demonstrative rebuke, implying organized sentiment, to anti-Semitism. Considering the attitude of Russian law and Russian officialdom toward the Jew, the riot occasioned last Thursday by the presentation of an anti-Jewish play in the Russian capital is most remarkable.

The run on the Harlem Savings Bank, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, continued yesterday and increased to almost a panic. Before the bank closed for the day at 3 o'clock more than $150,000 had been withdrawn.

Josephine Noirjean, or Eckhardt, a welldressed young woman, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in the hallway of a tenement house at 48 Greenwich Avenue by taking acid. The woman gained entrance to the hallway by ringing one of the bells at the entrance. She then walked up to the third floor, where she seated herself on the bottom of the stairway leading to the floor above.

The four vacancies in the Committee of Fifteen, which were created by declinations to serve, were not filled yesterday, and the Sub-Committee of Five had not, it was stated on authority, decided on any one in the place of those who failed to qualify. No arrangement had been made last night for the second meeting of the main committee.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 12. -- A telegram has been received by the police from Montagu Samuel of 54 Broad Street, New York, brother of Sidney Samuel, who committed suicide at the West End Hotel yesterday, The message closed: "Kindly wire steps necessary to take charge of remains.''

The property holders of Elm Street, who desire to have the city take over the amount assessed against them for the widening of Elm Street, have brought their case before the Board of Public Improvements. Their share of the cost amounts to about $2,500,000. They object to paying on the ground that they have not received any benefits from the improvements which, they say, will not be completed until the rapid transit tunnel is built.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12 -- For the third time in two years the State Legislature convened here to-day in special session called by Gov. Pingree. Consideration of a measure taxing railroads, telephone and telegraph companies, express companies, and other forms of corporate property on the cash value of their property instead of specifically upon their earnings, as under the present law, is the object of the session.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Considerable irritation was aroused during yesterday's debate on supply in the House of Commons.

Josephine Noirjean, or Eckhardt, a welldressed young woman, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in the hallway of a tenement house at 48 Greenwich Avenue by taking acid. The woman gained entrance to the hallway by ringing one of the bells at the entrance. She then walked up to the third floor, where she seated herself on the bottom of the stairway leading to the floor above.

Has this city a Mayor? Is he alive, at large, and awake? If we have a Mayor who is alive, at large, and awake, we should like to know whether his attention has at any time been called to the state of public morals in the lower east side of this city and whether he has ever considered his official powers and duties in relation thereto.

According to the story told yesterday by friends in this city, a love affair was the cause of the suicide of Sidney Samuel, who until recently was a member and London manager of the firm of Samuel Brothers, exporters, of 54 Broad Street, who was found dead with a bullet in his brain in a hotel in Portland, Me., early on Tuesday morning.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The family of William H. Strickland, 69 Delaware Avenue, Ocean Grove, is sadly afflicted. Yesterday morning, Genevieve, the five-year-old daughter, died of typhoid fever, and the other six children are down with the same disease.

The Trustees of the New York public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations; at their monthly meeting, held yesterday in the Astor Building, Lafayette Place, took active steps looking toward consolidating with the New York Free Circulating Library.

F. Norton Goddard, who was instrumental in introducing into the last Legislature a bill making it a felony for any one to have in his possession paraphernalia used in writing policy, which bill was defeated largely through the opposition of Anthony Comstock, said yesterday, that he had been deceived at the time regarding Mr. Comstock's motives in the matter.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Early this morning Mrs. Flora Wickham terminated her unhappy married life of only two years' duration by deliberately shooting herself with a 32-calibre revolver. The dead woman's husband, J. Emmet Wickham, is the owner of a large business block in this village, on the top floor of which he dwelt.

Nearly 300 loyal sons of Pennsylvania, sat at table at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening for the second annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society of this city. The New Yorkers were reinforced by quite a number of the residents of Philadelphia, who came over to add to the cheer of the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The House of Representatives was decorated with the flags of all nations to-day. Shortly before the centennial exercises were to begin, Representative Walter Reeves of Illinois, Republican, wandered in. He glanced toward the Executive gallery, and was horrified to see the British flag dropping over a corner of it.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 12. -- A telegram has been received by the police from Montagu Samuel of 54 Broad Street, New York, brother of Sidney Samuel, who committed suicide at the West End Hotel yesterday, The message closed: "Kindly wire steps necessary to take charge of remains.''

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- In the Reichstag today the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, referring to the complaints which have arisen on account of Emperor Willlam's failure to receive Mr. Kruger, again went lengthily into the reasons for the non-reception of the Boer statesman, covering new ground in a statement which he made as to the relations between Germany and Great Britain.

A bachelor woman has a perfect fright to remain away from her home until midnight, and if, her landlord refuses to permit her to carry a night key he must, at least, respond to the bell and let her into the house. This was the ruling made yesterday by Justice Andrews in the Supreme Court.

An application will be made before Justice Maddox in Brooklyn to-day for the appointment of Col. William J. Youngs of Nassau County, Secretary to the Governor, as receiver of the Anglo-American Loan and Savings Company.

The Senate killed the arbitration treaty with England, a convention that embodied the intelligent spirit and deep moral conviction of the American people. It holds under advisement, with intent to kill, the reciprocity treaty with France, which would extend our commerce and stimulate our industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- With imposing ceremonies the National capital to-day celebrated the centennial anniversary of the founding of the seat of the Federal Government in Washington. The exercises combined a military parade, a review by the President from the east front of the Capitol and orations in the hall of the House of Representatives, where a brilliant audience was assembled.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12. -- Dr. W.S. Rainsford of New York talked to the students at Harvard this evening on "The Various Social and Political Problems of the United States." He classed these problems under two heads -- "Discontent" and "Lawlessness." He said the fact that Mr. Bryan received a vote within 5 per cent. of that of Mr. McKinley showed conclusively that a large portion of the country is discontented with the Administration.

The Senate killed the arbitration treaty with England, a convention that embodied the intelligent spirit and deep moral conviction of the American people. It holds under advisement, with intent to kill, the reciprocity treaty with France, which would extend our commerce and stimulate our industries.
Winston Spencer Churchill, the war correspondent, told a fashionable audience at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening how he escaped from Pretoria. The grand ballroom was crowded to the doors.

-- Even a great poet, using his powers with the most serious intention, can make himself ridiculous if he chooses an unfortunate subject or expresses an absurd opinion. M. EDMOND ROSTAND -- about whose greatness there is no question -- has just chosen the unfortunate subject, expressed the absurd opinion, and made himself ridiculous.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 12 -- Announcement is made to-day that the Republican caucus to agree upon a candidate for United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of M. S. Quay will be called to meet on Tuesday night, Jan. 1, at 8 o'clock. The Legislature meets in biennial session at noon that day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 12. -- Some time ago committees representing the Indianapolis Board of Trade and Commercial Club investigated the natural gas situation thoroughly and reported in favor of meter measurement as the only means of prolonging the life of natural gas as a fuel.

From The St. Paul (Minn.) Globe, (Dem.) It appears that on the vote for Governor, at least 15,000 votes were thrown out because the ballots were marked for both Lind and Lucas, the Socialist-Democratic candidate. In Le Sueur County 384 votes were thus thrown out. Of the Congressional candidate Heatwole, (Rep.,) polled 1,973 votes, Schaller, (Dem.,) polled 2,141, and Lowe, (Middle of the Road Pop.,) polled 24.

Frances Russell Taintor, daughter of H. F. Taintor, President of the Taintor Manufacturing Company, has commenced an action in the Supreme Court against the Charles Besseler Company to recover $7,500 damages for injuries received in a peculiar way.
Records, began to fall into the background yesterday in the six-day bicycle race at the Madison Square Garden.

Plans for a novel new-century celebration, to be held at the City Hall, were perfected yesterday. President Guggenheimer of the Municipal Council has taken up the matter and is preparing resolutions asking the Municipal Assembly to appropriate $2,000 for the affair.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- The Tribune to-morrow will say that John W. Gates has become interested in the Denver and Rio Grande Railway, and will assist that road in building an extension from Grand Junction, Col., to tap the coal fields of Emory and San Pete Counties, Utah.

It is interesting to know, on the authority of municipal officers in the exchange of views and experiences, that the great City of London has problems of municipal administration which are closely akin to those which have not reached a satisfactory solution in New York.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the first paragraph of the Amnesty bill, which deals with cases arising out of the Dreyfus affair, was Adopted by a vote of 329 against 244. An amendment excluding cases of espionage and treason from the amnesty was adopted by a vote of 296 against 248.

BOSTON. Dec. 13. -- The announcement is made in The Transcript to-night that Mrs. John L. Gardner contemplates giving to the City of Boston for a free public museum the Italian palace which she is building and all its contents. This means that one of the finest private collections of paintings, statuary, bronzes, and metal work in America may be the property of this community.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The latest news from Peking, from official sources, is that Great Britain has signified a willingness to sign the agreement reached by the foreign Ministers, with a slight amendment, which is said to be rather in the nature of a mere change in form rather than an amendment of the scope of the agreement in any material point.
LANSING, Mlch., Dec. 13 -- At 2:45 this afternoon the Senate, by a vote of 17 to 11, adopted a concurrent resolution providing for final adjournment of the special session to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- For nearly three hours to-day Mr. Hanna of Ohio addressed the Senate upon the pending Ship Subsidy bill. While he has spoken heretofore on the floor of the Senate, his effort to-day really was his first formal speech to the body since he became a member of it.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The third semi-annual golf tournament of the Atlantic City Country Club began on the links at Northfield this morning with a high-class list of entries. The morning was an ideal one, and the links could not have been in better condition.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one feature of the report of the Commission on the Revision of the Charter which has not received the discussion which it merits.

The letter of the Directors of the Indianapolis Gas Company to the stockholders explaining why they are not earning dividends is seriously misleading and an insult to the citizens of Indianapolis. It will doubtless have quite the opposite effect from that intended, and instead of creating public opinion in favor of the introduction of meters, it will cause consumers to harden their hearts against the company and oppose every measure it proposes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The University of Pennsylvania won the first annual debating contest with Columbia University at the Academy of Music to-night. The question discussed was, "Resolved, That the United States should establish a system of graded subsidies, based upon mileage traveled by registered American vessels while engaged in foreign trade.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The adoption by the United States Senate of the Davis amendment to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty yesterday is evidently regarded as far too weighty a matter for hurried comment by the London morning journals. Accordingly The Times and most of the other papers will postpone until to-morrow their editorial treatment of the question in its present phase.

Accordingly The Times and most of the other papers will postpone until to-morrow their editorial treatment of the question in its present phase.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The American Institute of Architects began its thirty-fourth annual convention to-day in the banquet room of the Arlington Hotel. About seventy-five members were present, including the President, Robert S. Peabody, and the Secretary, Glenn Brown. Mr. McFarland, President of the Board of Commissioners of the District of Columbia, delivered an address of welcome.

Gardner contemplates giving to the City of Boston for a free public museum the Italian palace which she is building and all its contents. This means that one of the finest private collections of paintings, statuary, bronzes, and metal work in America may be the property of this community.

A young woman, supposed by the police to be Pauline Feste, killed herself at the Grand Union Hotel, Forty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, some time yesterday afternoon by shooting herself in the left breast. Just who the woman is will not be learned until the various letters and will left by her are opened.

SHANESVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 13. -- Four masked men, discovered in the act of dynamiting the vaults of John Doerschuck's private bank early to-day, drove off all who attempted to interfere, and got away with between $3,000 and $4,000.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to make a plea in favor of discrimination with regard to the men and officers of the present police force?

John Hubbard, no home, who had been sentenced to the Island as a vagrant, was the sole occupant of the big prison van which left the Harlem Prison early yesterday morning on its way to the Yorkville Prison gathering up the morning crop of human derelicts for the workhouse. The lone passenger had settled himself comfortably and had dropped into a gentle slumber when he was rudely awakened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- In the Senate Committee on Military Affairs today the hearing on the Army Reorganization bill was continued, and in addition to a number of army officers. Archbishop Ireland and Bishop McGoldrick were heard. The two prelates spoke only on the provision of the bill prohibiting the establishment of canteens or post exchanges.

David Schrenk, a cabinetmaker in the Sohmer piano factory, Astoria, went insane yesterday at noon, and without the slightest warning shot and killed a fellow-workman and seriously wounded another. He then ran at top speed to the East River, snapping his revolver at a policeman who tried to oppose him, and plunged into the water.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Peter Austin was convicted to-night of manslaughter in the second degree for killing a man named Brower-fourteen years ago. The jury went out at 5 o'clock and returned the verdict at 9 o'clock this evening. He was not surprised at the verdict, as he expected to be convicted, and he received the announcement calmly.

Among the arrivals on the White Star liner Majestic last night were two troopers of the famous British fighting organization in South Africa known as Brabant's Horse. They were J. Stonewall Jackson of Centre, Texas, a relative of the Confederate General, and Horace J. Robinson of Brocville, Ontario.
MANILA, Dec. 13. -- The Taft commission has passed an act authorizing Gen. MacArthur to establish police in the cities and towns and appropriating $150,000 for their maintenance.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- In the debate to the House of Commons yesterday on the second reading of the War Loan bill, the Bight Hon. Sir William Vernon Hareourt lengthily criticised the Government's financial makeshifts. He said the Ministers would have strenuous support in making the Transvaal share the cost of the war.

Sir William Vernon Hareourt lengthily criticised the Government's financial makeshifts. He said the Ministers would have strenuous support in making the Transvaal share the cost of the war.

The entry of the judgment for $7,788 against George A. Ballantine, noted in yeserday's NEW YORK TIMES, may result in making a very great legal mixup, as far as Mr. Ballantine's creditors are concerned. They had all entered into an agreement by which they were to receive their money in three annual instalments, the first to be paid next month.

The Christian Science doctrine will be thoroughly explained before the contest over the will of Helen C. Brush is ended. The taking of testimony in the case began yesterday afternoon before Surrogate Fitzgerald. Miss Brush died on July 7 last, leaving about 575,000 worth of property. In a will dated May 24 she gave $10,000 to her sister, Mrs. Almira J. Southard, and $1,000 to her brother, James E. Brush.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The President to-day nominated John W. Yerkes of Kentucky to be Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Mr. Yerkes had previously been nominated to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Eighth District of Kentucky, which nomination wag to-day withdrawn.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Among the ancient Dutch records of Ulster County which have been translated by the official translator of the Holland Society, under the supervision of Judge Clearwater of this city, is one especially interesting, entitled, "The Supplication of the Consistory of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church to the Magistrates at Wildwyck."

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 13. -- The Chicago Limited on the Illinois Central, due to arrive here at 7:15 o'clock to-night, was robbed at Carrollton Avenue, on the out-skirts of the city, by masked men. The mail and express cars were blown open with dynamite and the former was rifled of its contents.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 14 -- The Committee on Resolutions of the American Federation of Labor reported to-day with reference to the dispute between the International Association of Machinists and the International Typographical Union as to trade autonomy. The committee recommended that the Federation of Labor refuse to interfere.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In one of those "Talks at the Mermaid" -- which were never reported -- 'tis said that Ben Jonson asked Shakespeare if, as he said, "all the world's a stage" and "all the men and women players merely," who, then, were the spectators? Shakespeare had his quip ready and answered in an impromptu epigram, the gist of which was that they were "both actors and spectators," too.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- Boston had a good market to-day, with manifestations of renewed life in the mining stocks, most of which were firm and some of which were decidedly strong. The steady buying of Tri-Mountain continued with price up to 19 and a great deal of bullish talk heard up and down the Street.
A "hitherto unpublished letter" from Charles Lamb to his physician appeared recently in The Lawyer of London:

LONDON Dec. 1 -- Nothing is yet known of the date of the appearance of Mr. Kinling's new novel. It will be called "Kim," not, "Kim of the Rishti," and will appear in Cassell's Magazine, presumably some where about the beginning of the new year. Cassell's Magazine has lately been entirely remodeled.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The match play rounds in the Atlantic City golf tournament at Northfield were inausurated to-day under weather conditions that were far from favorable. The gale of wind that greeted the contestants handicapped the players out of all proportions, and the cold penetrated the golfers, so that golfing was not the keenest enjoyment.

Thomas J. Munnock of New York and Connecticut, who described himself to the editor of a sensational newspaper the other day as a reporter and a "good fakir," is in the Bellevne Insane Pavilion, rapidly going crazy in devising means to get out. Incidentally, Mr. Munnock is at present a sane man, twenty-three years old, with a predilection for "yellow" stories, but he says he is now in the worse fix he was ever in.

The editor of this collection does well to lead off with An ton Mauve. None of the other Dutch artists represented has the same delicate distinction and poetic Insight. The score or so of illustrations from his work are sufficient to show his narrow range, his melancholy temperament, his discriminating vision, and his uncertain hand.

Under the leadership of the coal stocks and the standard railway shares the stock market yesterday took on a tone of aggressive, strength -- showed, in fact, stronger than at any time since the few days immediately following the election. Prices advanced throughout the entire list, the gains in some instances being most substantial, with the close buoyant and at the best for the day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff arrived in Washington this afternoon. He has come to attend the dinner which Senator Depew will give to Governor-elect Odell to-morrow night.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 8 there is a correspondent's answer to a request for information about the personal appearance of Jesus. It was without qualification a long ago di ted account, which was never seriously considered.

AMERICAN WOOLEN for the first time in several days showed considerable activity, and both the common and preferred stocks closed with net gains. The latter advanced to 77 8/4 and closed there with a net gain of 2 1/4 points. Over 500 shares were traded in. The common on somewhat larger transactions advanced to 21 3/4 and made a net gain of one-half a point.

GEORGIA CLAY, New York City, thinks Mr. Joseph Jacob, in his article on Mr. E. C. Stedman's "An American Anthology" in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 24, has made some asscrtions, which, she says, "cannot fail to evoke criticism. It is very evident that Mr. Jacobs has not given the 'Anthology' an exhaustive reading, and certainly his spirit, was not in touch with that, which compiled such a work.

The Appellate Division yesterday, by a divided court, reversed the decision made by Justice Leventritt last June, refusing a peremptory writ of mandamus to William J. Rodgers to compel the Controller to deliver to him a warrant on the City Chamberlain for payment of $2,863. This was the amount earned by Mr. Rodgers under his contract for regulating and grading One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street from Amsterdam Avenue to the Boulevard.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Lord Kitchener reports that after severe fighting with Commandant Delarey at Nooitgedacht, Gen. Clements's force was compelled to retire. Delarey had a force of 2,500 men. Four British officers were killed. The other casualties were not reported.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Miss Sara Hammond Palfrey's "King Arthur in Avalen," issued by the W.B. Clarke Company, is divided into three parts, the title poem occupying only the first eighteen pages, and being followed by "The Churchyard," a collection of verses literally memorial, being faithful sketches of the persons whose initials or names head them.

President James J. Coogan's right to bold the office of President of the Borough of Manhattan has been challenged. A lawyer has written to Controller Coler stating that President Coogan voted at the last election at Southampton, L.I., and by this act he forfeited his right to hold his five-thousand-dollar job in the City Hall, Borough of Manhattan.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Literary and social circles were greatly shocked at the announcement of the simultaneous death of M. Edmond Tarbe des Sablons, the wellknown man of letters and playwright, and his wife, which occurred yesterday under unusually dramatic circumstances.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- In regard to the meaning and justification of the so-called Davis amendment to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, H.H. Kohlsaat, editor of The Times-Herald, to-day makes public a private letter he received from the late Senator C.K. Davis. The letter bears date, "Committee of Foreign Relations, United States Senate, Washington, D.C., March 12, 1900," and is in part as follows:

FRANCIS B. HAYES, New York, speaking of the distinguishing features of a Southerner's speech, writes: "There are three especially noticeable -- his soft pronounciation of 'i' and 'ou' in such words as 'vice' and 'house,' the use of 'like' for 'as' and 'do like I do,' for 'do as I do,' and his 'reckoning' where a New Yorker would 'guess,' and a Bostonian 'suppose' or 'think.'

Speedway drivers seem very reluctant to give up their favorite pastime, for they turned out in force yesterday despite the cold weather and spent a very lively afternoon on the stretch behind their fast-steppers. The roan pacer Moth, Millar, 2:07, driven by Dr. Randall, proved himself to be in the very best of condition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The report of the Director at the Mint on the production of gold and silver in the United States during the calendar year 1899 shows only slight variation from the approximate figures given out early to the present year. The final figures are $71,053,400 for gold and $32,858,700 for silver at its average commercial value during the year.

That all men are invited "to eat bread in he kingdom of God" was set forth by our Lord in two parables -- "The Great Supper," (Luke, xiv., 15-34,) and "The Marriage of he King's Son," (Matt., xxii., 1-14.) That all who belong to that kingdom will be rewarded. He also set forth by two parables -- that of "The Pounds" and that of "The Talents," (Matt., xxv., 14-50.)

Local Methodists have organized for a big money campaign. Some trouble has been had in harmonizing all elements, but it has been done. Unlike the plan of American Methodism as a whole, local Methodists will set themselves no stint. They will merely start out and get all they can. Two years will be needed to complete the task.

Ten thousand copies of Ralph Connor's Western story, "Black Rock," were sold by its publishers, the Revells, last week. More than 100,000 of his two books, "Black Rock and "Sky Pilot," have been sold. It has been made known before that Ralph Connor is Rev. Charles W. Gordon of Winnipeg.
The following advertisement, which was published yesterday, caused considerable excitement in the vicinity of University Place and Ninth Street:

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Edward Oswald, of this city, who murdered his wife and child in April, 1899, was to-day sentenced to sixty years at hard labor in the New Jersey State Prison by Supreme Court Justice Garrison. Oswald is thirty-six years of age.

The second day's hearing of the contest over the will or Helen C. Brush before Surrogate Fitzgerald attracted a large audience. Christian Science plays a part in the contest and many members of the First Church of Christ, Scientists, which will benefit to the extent of $50,000 if the will is sustained.

Christmastide is not usually marked by much activity in the New York art world in the way of public or private exhibitions. The dealers are too much occupied in supplying the needs of the purchasers of Christmas gifts, and the public is too busy preparing for the festival and the succeeding holidays to have time to devote to art displays.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Earl of Hardwicke replied to Lord Rosebery's criticism in the House at the reassembling of Parliament on Dec. 7. Lord Rosebery referred to Lord Hardwicke, now Under Secretary of State for India, as being a member of a firm of stockbrokers.

Ought Mr. Hervey White's "Quicksand" to be defined as the wail of human miseries? There are so few gleams of sunshine in the romance. Of all the personages there is barely a single one in the story who has not his or her hours of poignant agony. It is only Hiram Stubbs who is finally fairly happy, and then he has made the sacrifice of his life-long affections.

Gen. Shields.* Gen. James Shields was one of the notable Irishmen who have given their strength and ability to the service of the United Slates. His biography calls him the greatest Irishman who ever trod American soil, yet during his army lifetime and the score of years that have elapsed since his death there has not appeared any biography till now.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 14 -- The hearing in the contest over the will of Edgar E. Duryea, the Glen Cove starch manufacturer, was continued here to-day before Surrogate Seabury.

It is time for the President seriously to consider whether he should not withdraw the Hay-Pauncefote treaty from further consideration by the Senate. He would spare himself a personal humiliation and in our judgment would promote the public welfare by that course.

This volume, which bears the imprint of San Francisco publishers, Messrs. D.P. Elder Morgan Shepard, will be found most attractive by all children who are lovers of animals, and even more so by the children of a larger growth into whose hands the volume may happen to fall.

Love of Alma Mater was the dominating spirit that last night drew about the banqueting board in Delmonico's several hundred of the loyal sons of old Williams, the occasion being the annual dinner of the Williams College Alumni Association of New York.

A large gathering of New York club women were treated to a discussion of their favorite topic, the woman's club, yesterday morning at a meeting of the League for Political Education. The question for debate, as regularly put, was: "That club life offers to woman a desirable opportunity for social and intellectual development."
